column2: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 22 -- Harold C. Field, a former treasurer of Brown University and a leading banker and business man here, was found dead this morning on the beach near his summer home at Sakonnet. His age was 77.

Eight pharmacists accused of selling barbiturates without a prescription were arrested yesterday as city and state officials opened a coordinated drive to halt the illegal, widespread sale of sleeping pills. The "crack-down" was staged by detectives of a newly established sub-section of the Narcotics Squad that since July 6 has been checking intensively on 200 of the 4,000 drug stores here where the violations were reported flourishing.
Fifteen City College students accused of disorderly conduct in connection with a campus strike last April went on trial yesterday before Magistrate William E. Ringel in Upper Manhattan Court.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee approved a bill today which would increase payments to disabled war veterans, and to widows and children of veterans.

Samuel Resnik, through his Silray Corporation, has purchased the five-story forty-two-family apartment house at 25 East Clarke Place, the Bronx, for cash above mortgages of $102,575. The seller was a client of the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, broker in the transaction. The property is assessed at $125,000.

One of the broadest scientific research programs ever undertaken was started here last night by Dr. Clarence C. Little, former president of the universities of Maine and Michigan and now director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory in Bar Harbor, Me.

HONG KONG, Sept. 22 -- The British Navy came in for sharp criticism in the local trading community today over its failure to make any move to protect a British ship intercepted off Shanghai and held twenty-five days by Chinese Nationalist warships.

WARSAW, Sept. 22 -- The Polish Foreign Office is pursuing investigations into the case of Hermann H. Field of Cleveland, Ohio, architect who disappeared on Aug. 17 while bound for Prague, United States Embassay officials reported today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 22 -- An 8 per cent boost in freight rates has been granted to Canadian railway companies by the Board of Transport Commissioners, it was announced today. The railways had asked for a 20 per cent increase.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The fourteenth annual fair and flower show of the Westchester County Horticultural and Agricultural Association opened at the County Center this afternoon with 2,000 exhibits of flowers, vegetables, fruits, shrubbery, rock gardens, arts, crafts, animals and fowl in 448 classes.

Aaron Copland's suite from his score to the motion picture, "The Red Pony," will be performed at the first concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony in Carnegie Hall on Oct. 13, it was announced yesterday. It will be conducted by Leopold Stokowski, who will be on the podium for the first eight weeks of the season.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and prices closed 5 points lower to 2 points higher than on Wednesday after starting 2 to 4 points higher and holding within a 10-point range all day.

The New York Central Railroad, for the first time in its history, has refused a request of the Public Service Commission to rescind plans to cancel scheduled passenger trains until the commission had determined whether the cancellation was justified, it was learned yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 22 -- Leo Durocher mixed up his squad with a flock of displaced persons from the Giants' farm system today in the campaign's farewell to the Reds and had to be content with a split of a twin-bill that attracted the smallest double-header crowd of the season -- 1,494.

Sales of malleable iron castings are now at a rate at least 30 per cent above average levels prevailing in June and July, and further improvement is expected in the fourth quarter, Ralph T. Rycroft, president of Kencroft Malleable, Inc., Buffalo, New York, disclosed here yesterday, following the first showing at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of a Technicolor educational film of malleable foundry activities.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- A New York doctor has proposed self-imposed censorship by the medical profession to curb news on cancer research.

" Operation Survival: America's New Role in World Affairs," an attack on the present United States policy of basing our political as well as our military strategy on the atomic bomb and its long-range carrier, the B-36 "super-bomber," is scheduled for Oct. 17 publication by Prentice-Hall.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 22 -- El Trebol poloists of Argentina were leading Bostwick Field, 5 -- 3, in the semi-final engagement of the annual Monty Waterbury handicap tournament on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today when rain interfered in the third chukker.
The Chase National Bank has been appointed transfer agent of the $4.25 convertible second preferred stock of the El Paso Natural Gas Company.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 22 (AP) -- One small tropical hurricane died today and another lost intensity but still held a threat of high tides along the Louisiana coast.

O. John Rogge, chairman of the National Council of Arts, Sciences and Professions, recently issued this statement concerning Paul Robeson, who was prevented from giving a concert in Peekskill: "Every artist and every democratic institution is threatened.

Yugoslavia split publicly yesterday with the once solid Soviet bloc by deserting Russia's fight against United Nations General Assembly debate on the religious trials and human rights cases in Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Nearly $18,000,000,000 will be spent by American business during 1949 on new plants and equipment, the Government estimated tonight.

Plans for the proposed $12,600,000 connection between the IND in Queens and the Sixtieth Street tunnel of the BMT Queens-Manhattan line were approved yesterday at a special meeting of the Board of Estimate. The Board of Transportation estimated that the connection would be completed three and one-half years after the first contract is let.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 22 -- A small core of families benefit most from health and welfare agencies, which in many instances cross paths in each community, if St. Paul is characteristic of the rest of the nation.

On a brilliant first-period dash of 16 yards by Bosh Pritchard at the end of a water-logged game's single sustained march, the Philadelphia Eagles launched the defense of their National League title with a 7-0 triumph over the New York Bulldogs at the Polo Grounds last night.
Comparatively few cancellations by foreign buyers of orders for United States goods have developed thus far as a result of the wave of currency devaluation, exporters here reported yesterday.

THERE is something about politics which baffles novelists. Perhaps fiction to be successful must confine itself pretty closely to the personal level, to emotions and human relationships and individual problems. Just why this seems to be so is hard to see. Certainly there is nothing much more important than politics, since the lives of millions may be affected for generations by political ideas or even by the decisions of politicians.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- As if things weren't breaking tough enough for the Yankees, a little rain fell into their lives tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, who recently was questioned by a Senate subcommittee investigating the activities of alleged "five-percenters," was having a painful bout with a dentist this afternoon, President Truman said today.

DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 22 -- The Tax Court of the United States in Washington has ruled that Mrs. Nora Payne Hill, Danville high school teacher, is not entitled to a deduction of $239.50 representing the costs of a summer school session at Columbia University.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Sept. 22 -- The Roman Catholic Archbishop of New Orleans said today the remains of St. Peter had "definitely" been found in a tomb in St. Peter's Basilica in Rome.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, answered critics of his proposed budget increases today with a vigorous plea not to amputate the agency just as it was beginning to walk.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The text of President Truman's statement today announcing a recent atomic explosion in the Soviet Union:

Sixty displaced persons, who arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 5:30 P. M. -- just before the beginning of the Rosh ha-Shanah holiday -- underwent an unexpected experience in democracy yesterday.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 23 -- Republican party leaders, from national to "grass roots" levels, appeared convinced today the party must write a definite farm program to win back the farm vote lost last election to President Truman and the Democrats.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Gen. George C. Kenney, one of the Air Force's top experts in strategic bombing, said today positively that Soviet Russia did not have a long-range bomber comparable to our B-36, but did have planes "that could carry an atomic bomb over the ocean."

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Dr. Hugues Gounelle, director of Foch Hospital Research Center and medical adviser on American aid to France, tonight listed under-nutrition as the essential cause of France's exhaustion as that nation came out of World War II.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The fate of air racing in this country will not be known for a while.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that approximately 20,000,000 non-farm families in the United States owned their homes at the beginning of 1949, or an increase of almost 2,000,000 over the home Owners in early 1948.

New wallpapers designed in California and executed by the Kemble Company have been put on display here. For this collection, designs that are whimsical without being forced or fantastic have been screen-printed in strong colors that avoid being bizarre.

Students of navigation will be able to gain valuable practical experience in a novel series of operational navigation cruises, which will be started today by the Hayden Planetarium, according to Gordon A. Atwater, chairman and curator.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 23 -- Carol Paight, 20 years old, was placed under police guard in Stamford Hospital tonight pending investigation of whether she shot her police-sergeant father in pity after learning that he had an inoperable cancer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Senate today postponed action on a pay rise for the armed forces although Senator Virgil Chapman, Democrat, of Kentucky, urged prompt approval of the measure, which he called part of America's "insurance against war."

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 23 -- A wild ride to a hospital in the bed of a railway express truck as an inhalator crew worked over him proved futile here today for a 2-year-old boy who had been found floating face down in a shallow duck pond by his mother.

ROME, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- The Union Free School District 1 sold $1,500,000 of bonds due Dec. 1, 1950 to 1968 to the Chase National Bank, the Bankers Trust Company and the R. D. White Co. at a bid of 100.098 for interest of 1.60 per cent.

The 1950 production program of the RD-DR Corporation (Reader's Digest-deRochemont) has been expanded to include six hour-length "featurettes" in addition to two longer pictures, it was announced yesterday by Louis de Rochemont, the producer.

In announcing the framework of the Communist regime in China Mao Tze-tung and his colleagues have clung to the familiar brand of double talk. It is to be the "people's" government, the "people's" democracy, the "people's" millennium. Just where this fits into Mao's July declaration that China was to have a "democratic dictatorship" is not explained.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- After listening to arguments for ninety minutes today on the constitutionality of the Feinberg Law, Justice Harry Schirick of Supreme Court reserved decision on the Communist party's motion for a permanent injunction restraining the Board of Regents from acting under provisions of the statute.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- United States bombers, including for the first time the long-range B50, will roar over Britain again in joint maneuvers with British, French, Belgian and Dutch air forces during this week-end. The three-day exercise beginning tomorrow will test for the second time in four months the military cooperation between the United States and the powers in the Western Union alliance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said tonight it would make no recommendation as to penalties when Henry M. Blackmer finally faces trial on a twenty-one-year-old tax evasion indictment.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- Dr. Alexei Cepicka Czechoslovak Minister of Justice accused the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church here today of "going over to murder, burglary arson, fraud, sabotage and espionage" and of having sided "for reactionary purposes with subversive and criminal elements."

Maximilian Moss, president of the Board of Education, said yesterday that the board was considering granting salary increases to supervisory and non-teaching personnel and that recommendations for raising teachers' pay probably would be forthcoming next month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Thirteen professors of economics advised Congress today to write into law a policy of low taxes and high Federal expenditures in times of depression and high taxes and reduced expenditures during inflationary periods.

President Truman has shown good judgment in sharing with the American people his information that "within recent weeks an atomic explosion has occurred in the U.S.S.R." It would have been a mistake to attempt to make a state secret of this knowledge. The attempt probably would have failed, and in any case should not have succeeded.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 23 -- The names of seven outstanding chemists who will receive awards administered by the American Chemical Society were announced here today at the closing session of the society's 116th national meeting.

TOKYO, Sept. 23 -- It is gradually becoming clear that the plan of permitting Japanese corporations to revalue their assets in order to give effect to inflation and then taxing the write-up 6 per cent will produce considerable embarrassment.

Officials of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the United Steelworkers, CIO, met for two and a half hours yesterday at company offices, 25 Broadway, and will hold their next negotiation session on Monday.

Two leading Canadian newsprint manufacturers have informed the American Newspaper Publishers Association that no revision of prices to customers in the United States is contemplated as a result of the 10 per cent devaluation of the Canadian dollar earlier this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Yankees' season-long dash for the American League pennant suffered a jarring letdown today as the Bombers, poised to make a twin killing of the tail-end Senators, missed their target with the first barrel.

There'll be a top-quality double-feature bill at Belmont Park today. Eight veterans of the racing wars, including Stymie and Assault, are booked to compete in the mile-and-a-half Manhattan Handicap, and ten 2-year-old fillies, whose reputations still are in the making, are in the six-furlong Matron Stakes.
DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, today reported progress and scheduled a Saturday session. They held day and evening sessions today.

American war veterans who were wounded or stricken with illness in service should receive all the consideration that a grateful country can give them. But ever since 1924 there has been a trend toward caring medically for sick veterans whether or not their disabilities are the result of military service.

"The Author Meets the Critics," the literary discussion program in which a writer defends his work against two critics, will return to the air on the ABC television network on Monday, Oct. 3, from 7:30 to 8 P. M. Last season the program was carried by NBC.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Randy Gumpert pitched a four-hitter for his thirteenth victory as the Chicago White Sox defeated the St. Louis Browns, 4 -- 1, before a ladies' night turnout of 3,497 tonight. Catcher Eddie Malone paced the Chicagoans' twelve-hit assault with four safeties -- a triple, double and two singles.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 -- Industrialists whose plants have been crippled or shut down by the prolonged Missouri Pacific Railroad strike have endorsed the refusal of Guy A. Thompson, trustee in the carrier's reorganization, to negotiate union claims until the men return to work, Mr. Thompson said today.

As retailers prepared to face an impending serious shortage of television receivers because of greater demand arising from the forthcoming world series, Admiral Corporation yesterday placed its metropolitan area dealers on allocation T. J. Hodgins, general manager, Admiral, New York, local factory distributing branch, said his organization has been notified by the factory that it must accept quotas and is passing them on to dealers.

"Artists Row" on Washington Square South, the focal point of the now traditional outdoor art show in Greenwich Village, was somewhat marred by an inartistic wrecker's bridge in the foreground as the thirty-sixth semi-annual exhibit opened yesterday for a run through Oct. 16.

Following is the text of the speech delivered yesterday before the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, as unofficially translated from Russian:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has signed Barbara Stanwyck to appear with Clark Gable in "To Please a Lady," which Clarence Brown will produce and direct in December. Robert Birosh is writing a scenario from a story by Marge Becker and Marre Lyndon about, automobile racing.

BERLIN, Sept. 23 -- The chairmen of the political parties in the Western sectors of Berlin have concurred in a declaration that the city should be incorporated economically and financially into the German Federal Republic, it was reported today by the Western-sponsored news agency, DPA.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Commodity Credit Corporation will help Southern farmers find additional storage space for cottonseed as a step toward assuring wider participation in the Government's price-support program, Ralph S. Trigg, president of the CCC, announced today.

Andrei Y. Vishinsky, the Soviet Foreign Minister, accused the United States and Britain yesterday of planning an atomic war, and introduced a resolution at Flushing Meadow proposing that the United Nations General Assembly request the five Great Powers to conclude "a pact for the strengthening of peace."

DUBLIN, Sept. 23 -- The Government of Ireland was believed tonight to have agreed partly to the united States request that American transatlantic airlines be allowed to use the Dublin Airport instead of Shannon.
Following is a statement by Secretary of State Dean Acheson to a news conference at the United Nations General Assembly yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- High officers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations expressed the view today that the new Communist party line was to split all pro-Communist unions from the CIO and to form a new labor federation. This belief is supported by the following developments:

A tendency to "shade" interest rates on prime loans is reappearing in the more competitive areas of the Second Federal Reserve District, according to a report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The report, covering the three months ended on Aug. 31, was based on data supplied by the bank's representatives after visits to banking institutions in the forty-nine counties of the district.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 23 -- A small group of German scientists who were fully acquainted with advanced atomic investigation in this country went to Russia immediately after the war to aid in Soviet atomic experiments, according to information available here.

A nation-wide campaign in the United States to interest American concerns in bigger imports from Brazil in both traditional and new fields is planned by the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau, with the backing of Brazilian producers and exporters, it was stated yesterday by Jose Garrido-Torres, director.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- With an announcement today that an atomic explosion had occurred in the Soviet Union, the British Government re-emphasized, as did President Truman, the need for "truly effective and enforceable international control of atomic energy." The British Government used many of the same words as the President.

Russian refusal at a meeting of foreign ministers' deputies yesterday to reconsider any of the disputed points forced new adjournment of talks for a Big Four treaty to re-establish Austria's independence.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Stanley J. Marek, president of the Franklin Washington Trust Company here, announced today that the banking institution would absorb the twenty-five-year-old Franklin Mortgage and Title Company under a plan to be voted on next month at special meetings of the stockholders.

A hold-up in which the comely young woman victim appealed so strongly to two of three robbers that they later telephoned to her and offered to give back their share of the loot was described by detectives of the West Fifty-fourth Street police station last night as they questioned two suspects.

Eight neatly dressed women, each of whom admitted to "seventy-plus years," went to the Palace Theatre yesterday afternoon. They sat in reserved boxes, and their laughter was quick, their eyes wide and warm as they beheld the eight-act vaudeville show, brought to a rousing finish with the dancing of 70-year-old Pat Rooney Sr.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Peace talks in the violent 102-day-old Bell Aircraft strike were recessed indefinitely today.

WASHINGTON, Sept 23 -- Swift action on the North Atlantic defense program and closer relations among the United States, Canada and Britain in the field of atomic energy were seen in responsible quarters this evening as possible twin consequences of the reported atomic explosion in Russia.
Five hundred persons attended dedication ceremonies yesterday for the city's new laundry, garage and fire house, which will service six Hospital Department institutions on Welfare Island.

Although arrangement are an integral part of every flower show, linking them to home settings was an appropriate departure of the Garden Club of New Jersey this week. Their annual two-day show was held at the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair on Thursday and yesterday.

Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for the seat he holds by appointment of Governor Dewey, disputed yesterday the contention of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic-Liberal adversary, that he had never wanted or invited Communist support.

An echo of the so-called Park Avenue gambling party for the benefit of charity resounded in Special Sessions yesterday when Max Stark, 45-year-old head of a check cashing concern in New Jersey, was arraigned on a grand jury information accusing him of conspiracy to violate the gambling laws.

Thomas R. Steutel, Commissioner of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service met yesterday in separate sessions with the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the New York Shipping Association, representing shipping lines and employing stevedores.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Following is the calendar of known atomic explosions:
UTICA, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Oneida County's Democratic leader refused today to heed orders from the State Chairman that Democratic candidates repudiate American Labor party endorsement.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 23 -- The plan for the administrative structure of China's new "People's Republic" was released today by the official New China News Agency, indicating how Mao Tze-tung's principle of a "Democratic People's Dictatorship" will be put into practice.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 23 -- Public welfare departments should pay private agencies to provide psychiatric and casework service for persons receiving public assistance, who cannot obtain such service from public institutions, Harry O. Page, Deputy Commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Welfare, declared today.

HONG KONG, Sept 23 -- Gen. Ma Pu-fang, Moslem Nationalist governor of Tsinghai, confirmed here today that he would bow out of the Chinese civil war picture for the time being to make a pilgrimage to Mecca. The General said he would leave in about a week with members of his large family by commercial airliner.

Staff members of the Goldwater Memorial Hospital declared yesterday that a technique of adult education quietly evolved during a seven-year study at the institution may be a significant new approach to the complex medical problem of rehabilitating the chronically ill.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Lorain Journal Company will fight a Government charge that the Lorain, Ohio, newspaper conspired to injure a competing radio station.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- In a great anxiety that passed soon into a positive response -- demands for fresh tries at international control of the atomic bomb -- Congress heard today the news that an atomic explosion had occurred in the Soviet Union.

With the baseball pennant race still running high temperatures in both leagues, college football's entrance today will be greeted with something less than undivided attention. Yet, its arrival will change our lives in many ways for the next few months. For one thing, every week will now trace a crescendo of anticipation that leaves one just about ready to burst at kick off time every Saturday.

The Port of New York Authority as agent for New Jersey is prepared, at the request of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, to enter separate negotiations with the Maritime Commission for the leasing and improvement of Government-owned piers in Hoboken, it was learned yesterday.

A total of 48 per cent of retail paint dealers surveyed in Chicago by Martin-Senour Company, paint manufacturer, credits local advertising for bringing in most of their customers, the company announced yesterday. Thirty-two per cent credited the company's national advertising while another 29 per cent believed the majority came into the store from casual traffic.
Stockholders of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation at a meeting held yesterday in Richmond, Va., elected as directors Charles E. Heinrichs, Edward Ryland and Arthur Ross.

Mrs. Gertrude Hornbostel, who contracted leprosy in a Japanese prison camp, and her husband, Maj. Hans Hornbostel, retired Army engineer who spent the last three years at Carville, La., close to the colony where she was confined until pronounced cured of the disease, have arrived on Long Island to buy a home and live a normal life in peace.

Faced with an acute Puerto Rican problem, the Board of Education has assigned ten special teachers to Spanish-speaking areas and has expanded its in-service teacher training program, it was learned yesterday. The program, which affects Puerto Rican adults as well as pupils and teachers, is designed to enable recent arrivals to understand and acquire American ways and customs and assimilate into the New York community.

LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Governor Dewey said today, at ground-breaking ceremonies for a $1,000,000 public beach project at Lake George, that the development was part of the administration's plan to make the forest preserve as useful as possible in meeting the greatly increased demand for outdoor recreation.

LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Governor Dewey declared today that "we have been deluded into believing that we alone could have the atom bomb." He referred to President Truman's announcement that the United States had evidence of an atomic explosion in Russia.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Rallying for two third-quarter touchdowns, Boston University tonight defeated Syracuse University, 33 -- 21, before 25,000 who sat through a downpour to watch the opening football game for both teams.

WASHINGTON, Sept 23 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended last Saturday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index was 154.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.4 per cent above four weeks ago and 9.1 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

President Truman's announcement that we have evidence of the occurrence of an "atomic explosion" in the Soviet Union within recent weeks ranks only next to his original announcement of the explosion of the first atomic bomb over Hiroshima on Aug. 6, 1945. It marks the end of the first period of the atomic age and the beginning of the second.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23 -- Izvestia predicted today further deepening of Anglo-American economic contradictions as a result of the devaluation of the pound and warned that the dollar itself "is not guaranteed from upheavals."

RUTLAND, Vt., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Three major plans for milk-price formulas for the New York milk-shed were advocated today at a hearing here -- one of nine scheduled by the United States Department of Agriculture.

A nation-wide plan of action by Protestant churches on behalf of migrant workers for the next ten years will be mapped next week at a conference of representatives of national, state and private agencies. The session, under the auspices of the Home Missions Council of North America, will be held at the Young Men's Christian Association Hotel, 826 South Wabash Avenue, Chicago, Tuesday through Thursday.
A man and wife charged with assisting in the manufacture of counterfeit stamps were held in $53,500 bail yesterday when arraigned before United States Commissioner Edward W. McDonald.

LANDOVER, Md., Sept. 23 -- After an hour's delay caused by a rain storm, the second round of the women's United States open medal play championship got under way today at the Prince Georges Golf and Country Club.
We are now regaled with Secretary of Labor Tobin's suddenly developed brainstorm on how to ward off a depression -- increase all unemployment insurance benefits!

The move of securities to higher ground was furthered yesterday by the stock market, but only after a shaky start. Under the leadership of railroad shares, the list on the Stock Exchange again exhibited renewed strength, with considerable assistance from the utilities.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Dutch and Indonesian negotiators have unanimously accepted the main points of a statute setting up a United States of Indonesia under the Dutch Crown.

George Balanchine's "Ballet Imperial" had its first presentation of the season last night by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House, and Mary Ellen Moylan, in its central role, swept everything before her in a breath-taking performance.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The former Hudson River Day Line reported today it would dispose of river-front properties at six communities in an auction Oct. 19 and 20. The total assessed valuation of the properties is more than $700,000, according to Alfred V. S. Olcott, president of the Indian Point Corporation, formerly the Day Line.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23 -- The first hint at the strategy the steel industry may employ to head off a threatened strike of 500,000 steel workers Oct. 1 came today from one of the smallest companies in the industry.

ROME, Sept. 23 -- The collapse of the seamen's strike that has tied up the main Italian ports for two weeks was marked by the sailing today of the liner Vulcania from Genoa bound for New York. The Vulcania was authorized to sail by the seamen's union, but this was generally discounted as a face-saving device as 96 per cent of the crew had voted to sail anyhow, whether the union approved or not.
I should appreciate an opportunity to reply to the letter of Matthew J. Troy which purports to answer a letter of Pete Kavanagh, which I read with much pleasure.

Several thousand persons gathered yesterday about the steps of the Sub-treasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets to witness a celebration marking the 160th anniversary of the enactment of the Bill of Rights. The observance was sponsored by the Bill of Rights Commemorative Society and the Wall Street Post of the American Legion.

The Raytheon Manufacturing Company had a net loss of $547,000 in the quarter ended on Aug. 31, in contrast to the $275,000 profit shown in the similar period a year ago, Charles F. Adams Jr., president, informed shareholders at the annual meeting held yesterday in Boston.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- Governor Dewey, in a proclamation designating the week of Oct. 2 as "Employ the Physically Handicapped Week," said today that the state's employment rate during August "took a spectacular leap" to "a new high point for the entire year."
Reports that the local operating company of the National Dairy Products Corporation would stop delivering milk to homes were called false yesterday by L. A. Van Bomel, president of the corporation.
Emperor Haile Selassie appealed to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday to award Eritrea and Italian Somaliland to Ethiopia.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- The Inter-ordered the closing of its Farmall plant in Rock Island, Ill., because national Harvester Company today of a shortage of castings and forgings, supplied by the company's tractor works in Chicago. These works were struck Tuesday by the United Farm Equipment Workers Union, CIO.

The majority plan for United Nations atomic control was sponsored by the United States in June, 1946, and was adopted in expanded form by the General Assembly on Nov. 4, 1948. The vote was 40 to 6, with the Soviet group in opposition.
MILAN, Italy, Sept. 23 -- Italian manufacturers are already beginning to feel the effects of sterling devaluation.

The defense rested in the nine-month Communist trial yesterday, and the Government waived its right of rebuttal. Federal Judge Harold R. Medina gave counsel until 2 o'clock Tuesday afternoon to submit requests for instructions to be included in his charge to the jury and announced that arguments on closing motions would be heard at 10:30 o'clock Wednesday morning.
The heaviest firing will be to the West and South, as the big guns of collegiate football swing into action on all fronts today.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Retired ministers of the New Jersey Methodist Conference will receive substantially larger pensions during the coming year, according to announcement at the 113th annual session here today.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Sept. 23 (AP) -- One man was killed and three women were injured, one critically, in the collision of two automobiles tonight near the entrance to Bennington College. The dead man was identified as Charles Tilgner Sr., 78 years old, of Brooklyn, N. Y.

It could be that Manager Barney Shotton and his Dodgers have "a reasonable doubt" about winning the National League flag, but there was obviously no doubt about it in the minds of the hundreds of fans who greeted the returning heroes at La Guardia Field yesterday.

TOKYO, Sept. 23 -- Dozens of restrictive rules, all irksome to Allied personnel here and most honored in the breach, were eased today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur. In the future the wall separating the foreign community from Japanese life will not be quite so high.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities indicated today that key Communists in Washington have gone underground and are trying to infiltrate the Government.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Striking members of a Congress of Industrial Organizations union who have halted the operation of the Continental Paper Company here for twelve weeks shut off production in an adjoining subsidiary plant today when they angrily turned away the workers of an American Federation of Labor union who previously had been permitted through the picket lines.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 23 -- Earl E. T. Smith and Robert Knowles of Brookline, Mass., scored 32, 35 -- 67, three strokes under course figures to win the medal during the qualifying round of the Meadow Brook club's invitation best-ball tournament today.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Apart from a few features in copper and gold-mining shares, business activity died down in the stock markets here today and an irregular tendency generally was seen as books were leveled before the week-end.

QUEBEC, Sept. 23 -- Police reported tonight that a drug-dazed woman confessed to carrying a package, believed to have contained dynamite, which was placed aboard an ill-fated Quebec Airways plane that blew up Sept. 9, killing all twenty-three persons aboard.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Measures to stimulate production and exports and to prevent unemployment were ordered today after two long sittings of the Cabinet to examine the whole economic and financial situation resulting from devaluation of the pound and other currencies.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- The County of Broome, challenging the constitutionality of a 1949 law granting more than fifty upstate Supreme Court justices salary increases of $5,000 a year, began legal action today to have the statute nullified.
Willard G. Van Name had the distinction on Sept. 2 of having a letter published in your newspaper relative to what he termed "the imminent destruction of the world's most remarkable pine forest."

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- A proposal that Congress take action to support the cottonseed meal market led to general buying of soybean futures on the Board of Trade today, largely by professional operators, and caused a strong rally in that grain, the close being at the top with gains of 1 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel.

The main body of the Carabineros Chilean team, consisting of three officers, six enlisted men and ten horses, which will compete in the military jumping events at the sixty-first National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 1-8 arrived yesterday morning on the Grace Line's Santa Rita.

Passing up Fifth Avenue and confronted by the scaffolding around the old Church of St. Nicholas, about to be demolished after seventy-seven years of service -- and a membership including the first President Roosevelt -- the lady said she'd miss the dramatic contrast afforded by the brownstone crocketed spire against the pale, plain mass of Rockefeller Center.

letxil sales declined during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Contributing to the decline w. ere a religious holi-j day and some wet weather. Departmerit store sales here were believed to be about 13 per cent below the corresponding week last year.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 23 -- A sprightly little man, his full head of white hair, and a gay Sinatra-like bow tie making it hard to believe that he will celebrate his ninetieth birthday tomorrow, was the honored guest of the Central Railroad of New Jersey today.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Paul Ramadier, French Minister of National Defense, commenting on President Truman's announcement of the atomic explosion in the Soviet Union, said that France had previously registered such explosions.

The primary market for securities continues to be dominated by the rising borrowing by state and local governments and their agencies on tax-exempt bonds. This is especially the case next week, when borrowing on tax-exempt bonds will be highlighted by flotations totaling $154,500,000 in behalf of borrowers on the state or state-agency level.

TOKYO, Sept. 16 -- Publishing circles in Japan are in a panic. The Japan Distributing Company, "Nippai," The great monopoly concern that handles almost every book and magazine sold in Japan, suspended payment on Sept. 15. September payment was to have been 400,000,000 yen.
William Ernest Hocking's letter in THE TIMES of Sept. 17, regarding the present trend of neo-fascism in Germany, seems to be based upon a naive conception of European history since Bismarck.

In an opinion called a precedent in defining the latitude of an arbitration board, Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan dismissed yesterday a motion by the Order of Railroad Telegraphers to impeach the board's findings in its interpretation of clauses in the union's contract with the New York Central Railroad Company.
BOSTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Wool trading, except where mill needs were imperative, stalled this week on announcement of the devaluation of the British pound.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission handed down an opinion today in which it found that Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., of Chicago, an investment-banking firm, had transgressed the anti-manipulation provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 -- With the left wing in full control, the fourteenth international convention of the United Electrical Workers, CIO, was adjourned unexpectedly in mid-afternoon today following the adoption of a statement by the leadership accusing the rightists of being "traitors" who would "convert the UE into a company union."

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Maj. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, retired, wartime atomic bomb chief, issued reassuring statements yesterday in commenting on the announcement that an atomic explosion had occurred recently in Russia.

That lost hour's sleep over which New Yorkers have yawned since April 24 will be restored tonight. The city, the rest of the metropolitan area and most communities where daylight saving time has been observed will revert to standard time.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The Government was reported to have decided to demand a showdown in Parliament next week. It was learned today that the Cabinet has decided after all to ask both Houses for a vote of confidence after the debate on devaluation of the pound.

Magistrate William E. Ringel found thirteen young men and three young women guilty of disorderly conduct in connection with a City College campus strike last April 11 in Upper Manhattan Court yesterday. He suspended sentence on each.

NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Tops of bathing suits fashioned so beautifully that they would be as flattering in the same role on an evening gown were shown by Howard Greer in his first collection of swim wear for Caltex. Viewed in the gardens of his Valles home, the suits drew repeated applause from about 300 buyers and members of the press.

HONG KONG, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Communist reports said today that units of Gen. Chen Yi's Twenty-ninth Army had landed yesterday at the southeast port of Amoy under cover of a heavy artillery barrage. Earlier, the Nationalists reported they had repulsed a previous attempt by shelling a concentration of 200 junks containing Communist assault troops, inflicting 1,000 casualties.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 23 -- The United Nations made public today an exhaustive report on the Haitian economy as a demonstration of how it was prepared to tackle the problem of technical aid to underdeveloped countries.
A net profit of $5,057,949 was reported yesterday by the Timken-Detroit Axle Company for the fiscal year ended with last June, which contrasts with $7,665,102 earned in the previous fiscal year.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP) -- An undisclosed number of solid silver bars have been recovered from a sunken Spanish galleon in the Florida Keys. The Smithsonian Institution in Washington confirmed the find today and announced it had bought one of the ingots weighing seventy pounds.

HARRISON, N. Y., Sept 23 -- Marvin Pierce, president of the McCall Corporation, magazine and fashion publishers, at 230 Park Avenue, New York, was driving to the Rye railroad station this morning when he tried to prevent a cup of coffee from spilling on his wife's clothes. In an accident that followed, his wife, Mrs. Pauline Robinson Pierce, 53 years old, was killed and Mr. Pierce was injured.

It was a birthday party; the celebrant was not at all shy about admitting to 50 years. The twenty-five guests sipped Perrier Jouet champagne and ate steaks sliced thick from the beef filet. The hostess was Junoesque Mina Langerfeld, described by one restaurant writer as a "smart-bobbed Statue of Liberty with a sense of humor."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- Sam H. Husbands, president of the Transamerica Corporation, testified today in the Federal Reserve Board's anti-trust proceeding against the corporation that qualifying shares of the Bank of Sellwood; Sellwood, Ore., were sold to directors of the bank at sums substantially less than Transamerica had paid for them.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was a little easier yesterday and final prices were 6 to 10 points net lower.
Terry Young of the East Side registered an upset victory over Enrique Bolanos, Mexican battler from Los Angeles, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers defeated the Indians tonight, 5 to 0. Virgil Trucks hurled his nineteenth victory and increased Detroit's third-place lead over Cleveland to 2 1/2 games.

As an hors d'oeuvre to the season, the Kraushaar Gallery is showing a choice selection of twentieth century American gouaches, water-colors and pastels. Most of these pleasant and naturalistic sketches have a certain lyrical quality, whether it be in the satire of Demuth and Shinn or in the pastoral note struck by Sidney Raynes and Mahonri Young.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson said yesterday that he assumed the explosion in Russia reported by President Truman had been caused by an actual atomic weapon. He insisted, however, that the news had come as no shock and would not change the United States-sponsored plan for international control of atomic energy.

As an hors d'oeuvre to the season, the Kraushaar Gallery is showing a choice selection of twentieth century American gouaches, water-colors and pastels. Most of these pleasant and naturalistic sketches have a certain lyrical quality, whether it be in the satire of Demuth and Shinn or in the pastoral note struck by Sidney Raynes and Mahonri Young.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Testimony before the Gillette committee investigating price spreads between farmer and consumer today enlarged on the theme that one avenue to lower prices rested in giving up the quart at the door for the pick-up at the grocery store.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- President Truman today nominated Ben Connally and James V. Allred, Houston attorneys, to be Federal District judges for Southern Texas. That they would be confirmed by the Senate with little or no opposition appeared certain, Capitol observers believed.

Numerous taverns here and in the northern part of the state had their licenses suspended or canceled this week for violations of state regulations and the alcoholic beverage control laws, officials of the State Liquor Authority disclosed yesterday.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Wyoming Division of Lehigh Valley Railroad will be eliminated on Jan. 1. Supervision of the presnet Wyoming Division will be shifted to the headquarters of the two remaining divisions -- New York and Buffalo.
The number of polio cases reported to the city Health Department has declined for the fifth successive week, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.

The Jewish people throughout the world crowded synagogues and temples at sundown yesterday to attend services marking the start of Rosh ha-Shanah, the beginning of the New Year, which is 5710 in the Hebrew calendar.

Charged with violating the Multiple Dwelling Laws, eight landlords or building managers were fined a total of $775 in Municipal Term Court yesterday. The heaviest fine was imposed by Magistrate Peter M. Horn on Mathias L. Vorella, 50 years old, of 39 West 105th Street, owner of a building at 28 East 111th Street, who paid $300.

An inquiry on the correctness of a report that "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" had been booked to open at his Ziegfeld Theatre on Dec. 8 drew this reply from Billy Rose yesterday: "It looks very likely, but no contracts have been signed." He conceded, however, that the necessary legal papers had been drawn.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- Mrs. Iva Ikuko Toguri D'Aquino, the Tokyo Rose of a treason trial that began eighty days ago, was described sarcastically as "our little heroine" and denounced as a "female Benedict Arnold" by the prosecution today as it completed its final summation.

"Once More, My Darling," a comedy romance directed by and starring Robert Montgomery, will open this morning at the Globe. Ann Blyth is co-starred and the veteran stage performer Jane Cowl is making her first screen appearance since she tried the movies briefly some thirty-two years ago and found them not to her liking.

Three women were injured in a freakish accident at 1:45 P. M. yesterday when a collision between a bus and a truck at Fifth Avenue and Forty-first Street broke a traffic light post that struck the women as it fell.

One effect of a sensational piece of news, like the terse announcement that an "atomic explosion" has occurred in the Soviet Union, is to obscure and diminish all other events. Already, while only the bare fact is known, and nothing of the type of bomb or Russia's capacity to produce in quantity, it starts a flood of speculation that drowns out the sensations of yesterday.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 23 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican, of South Dakota, said today "it now appears that earlier and prevailing laxity in safeguarding this country against Communist espionage has permitted what were once the secrets of our atomic bomb to fall into the hands of America's only potential enemy."

Two women and a child were overcome and fifty persons fled to safety shortly before 3 P. M. yesterday when a leaking refrigerator sent sulphur dioxide fumes throughout the Baratt Hotel, a five-story furnished rooming house at 342 West Twenty-third Street.

Rubber futures prices on the Commodity Exchange yesterday were mixed at the close of trading. Sales volume continued high, with a turnover of 1,880 long tons. Liquidation selling appeared in the September delivery, and prices dipped to 17 cents a pound, off 25 points on the day.

Irving B. Hirsch had scarcely finished arraying $10,375 on the desk in his check-cashing office at 859 Longwood Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday morning, when two masked and armed men came in, took the money, and escaped.

CANTON, China, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen charged Russia today with open violation of the Sino-Soviet treaty, but said the question whether the issue would be presented formally to the United Nations depended on the United Nations debates between the "democratic and tyrant nations."

The continuance of a "no compromise" attitude on the hiring hall was voted overwhelmingly yesterday by the seventh biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, in its acceptance of the findings of its officers' reports committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Truman announced this morning that an atomic explosion had occurred in Russia within recent weeks. This statement implied that the absolute dominance of the United States in atomic weapons had virtually ended.

ECCENTRIC religious cults have flourished in mystery novels almost as verdantly as in southern California; but Mr. Spicer has hit on a fresh approach in this Red Badge Prize detective tale. His Church of Shining Light figures not as a criminal racket but as a pathetic example of man's fumbling toward peace of soul.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Veterans Administration said today it had paid out almost $21,000,000,000 in benefits for World War II veterans, their dependents and heirs.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 24 -- The United Nations Commission for India and Pakistan expressed the belief today that the two dominions would reach a peaceful solution to the long dispute over the Princely State of Kashmir.

In a noisy session, marked by loud outbursts and general disorder, the convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, sanctioned yesterday the expulsion of five former officers of the union, thus exhausting their final organizational appeal for reinstatement.

With Ellis Kinder of the Red Sox shutting out the Yankees, 3 -- 0, for his twenty-third victory, the Bombers' American League lead over Boston was reduced to one game yesterday. The Dodgers routed the Phils, 8 -- 1, last night to remain half a game behind the National League's leading Cardinals, who won, 3 -- 2, despite a two-run rally by the Cubs in the ninth inning.

The New Jersey State CIO called yesterday for expulsion from the CIO national executive board of all pro-communists and the establishment of new right-wing units as "organizational havens" for those who break away from their left-wing international union leaders.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Harness racing and "acrobatic auto driving" will set the pace for the sixty-second annual New Jersey State Fair, which will open here today on Nottingham Way. The fete will close with auto races next Sunday.
LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The text of the Tass English-language broadcast, as monitored here, follows:

In "Capitol Hobbyists," it is said that the oldest Bible in the collection of Representative Joseph Bryson, "an English one, was printed in 1608, three years after the first publication of the King James text."

The number of polio cases previously reported for last week showed a decrease, according to the Department of Health officials, but twenty new cases and three deaths were recorded for the twenty-four hours ending at 9 A. M. yesterday.

AS the title suggests, here is a "practical" handbook on the use of faith in daily living. The author, a clergyman who has seen the results of the use of faith, is concerned about people's undeveloped inner resources for meeting the issues of life, and he seeks to lead them to an understanding of the nature and function of faith.
The new chaplain at Children's Village, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., has set himself a goal that would be the despair of most parish clergymen.
SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 24 (AP) -- One apparently can swim safely in the blue waters of Bikini lagoon, but the food supply still carries an atomic bomb hangover.

LENHARTSVILLE, Pa. -- Hawk Mountain, near here, is preparing for its annual influx of student and amateur naturalists. This massive promontory, 1,506 feet above sea level, is one of the few places in the world where the seasonal flights of accipiters -- hawks and eagles -- can be observed with scheduled regularity.

Mayor O'Dwyer's "political operations" in the city's school system were criticized yesterday by the Liberal party in a report of its Municipal Affairs Committee, made public by Adolf A. Berle Jr., State Chairman.

THE Self-Employment program of the GI Bill of Rights hit, you might say, the jackpot when it granted Martin Yoseloff the means to employ himself as a writer. For in his second novel, "The Girl in the Spike-Heeled Shoes," Mr. Yoseloff has reaffirmed his earlier talent and produced a work that is something to sing about.

I AM glad to tell you something of my trip to Germany, the country that for so many years has seemed like a nightmare. When we encountered its flag abroad, we averted our eyes with a shudder. To be carried off to Germany would have meant certain death -- a wretched, miserable death.
It is my questionable pleasure to retort to your reader. Matthew B. Morton, who referred in a letter on Cabell Phillips' "Camden, Alabama: a Case History" to the "moral degradation" of the South.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Stanford sounded a stirring challenge to all future football rivals today with a resounding 44-0 victory over a supposedly strong Harvard team, a legend dissipated before some 38,000 fans gathered for the intersectional conflict.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Wheat futures on the Board of Trade firmed in late trading today, with buyers finding offerings scarce. Soybeans showed more action than grains and dipped more than a cent a bushel at times after yesterday's advance.

Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the United Nations General Assembly, said last night in a radio interview that the question of international atomic control "must be faced squarely" at this session as a result of President Truman's announcement that the Soviet Union had succeeded in producing an atomic explosion.

RETAIL prices of quality furniture this year are 10 to 20 per cent lower, on the whole, than the record post-war peaks reached in the summer of 1948. While certain items - notably bedding and colonial-style maple furniture -- have undergone little or no apparent price cuts, important hidden price decreases in the form of greatly improved construction and better design exist in virtually all types of home furnishings.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- The Inland Steel Company has notified the 17,000 employes at its huge Indiana Harbor, Ind., plant that they will be striking for lower pensions and welfare benefits than they now have if they walk out Oct. 1 to force acceptance of an employer-financed social security program based on the recommendations of President Truman's steel fact-finding board.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Princeton opened its eightieth football season with a 26-14 victory over Lafayette before 22,000 spectators at Palmer Stadium today but it was no easy triumph for the Tigers. They did not seal the decision until the final minute of play.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Foremen's Association of America, an independent union with 29,000 Midwestern members, today mapped an anti-Taft-Hartley law stand for the 1950 elections.

WITH the grain fields reaped, the corn shocked, the hay safe in the barn and summer's tide ebbing in lazy warmth from the stubble fields of September, there rises upon air stilled to listen the long, soft autumn hum. This is the chorus made of a thousand stridulent voices that are not voices.

A ceremony in its Jersey City terminal Oct. 3 will mark the start of a new chapter in the annals of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, which this year entered the second century of operation. It will signify the end of a decade of reorganization under the bankruptcy laws and the return of the "Big Little Railroad" to the owners.

CURIOSITY and misty memories contributed their share to a host of encumbrances, such as bad weather for Technicolor cameras and the failure of two generators to function smoothly, which upset the time schedule of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer unit that descended upon this quiet country village two weeks ago to record Owen Johnson's noted stories of life at the Lawrenceville prep school, "You're Only Young Twice."

In the belief that "an engineer cannot tell the whole story with a blueprint and slide rule, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, at Troy, N. Y., will introduce this fall a program to help students "think and write clearly."

LIKE other industries, the motion picture business was hit on several fronts last week by the devaluation of the pound in England and the resultant revaluation of currencies by twenty-three other countries. In a way, the movie makers were, perhaps, hit the hardest, since they do business in all of the affected areas, whereas other industries might not have such far-flung commerce.

Preparations for the first physical steps toward starting the long-heralded Brooklyn Civic Center were taken yesterday when Borough President John Cashmore signed a contract calling for immediate demolition of twenty-four old structures on Adams Street.

EVERY now and then some crackpot informs this department by mail that Broadway is a hotbed of communism and that most Broadway plays are subtly seasoned with communist propaganda. This is part of the current American folklore.

HOMEMAKERS shopping for automatic washers will have a wide variety of makes and models from which to choose this fall. Washer manufacturers, having caught up with back orders accumulated during the war years, are now turning their attention to the innovations being developed in their research laboratories.

Rose Schneiderman, honorary president of the Women's Trade Union League and former secretary of the State Department of Labor, has endorsed the Mayoralty candidacy of Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion nominee, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Fiorella H. La Guardia, co-chairman of the Morris Campaign Committee.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Dr. Frank Dunstone Graham, Walker Professor of International Finance at Princeton University, was killed by a fall from the top of Palmer Stadium at 5:05 o'clock this afternoon, just after the Princeton-Lafayette football game.

DR. BACH has already written two non-fiction books that deal understandingly with the varied religious practices of mankind. Now he has done a novel on the Hutterians, that sect who live "according to the Gospel and not according to the world."

WATCHUNG, N. J., Sept. 24 -- The annual one-man minstrel show of Alexander Clinton Wilmerding, honored yesterday as "New Jersey's No. 1 commuter," went off on schedule at a party tonight to celebrate his ninetieth birthday and won applause from an audience of relatives, friends and neighbors.

ON the campus of the University of Wisconsin are the offices of a unique theatre. It is a theatre whose walls are the boundaries of the State of Wisconsin, whose stage is as large as all the stages in the state put together, whose audiences number in the millions and whose participants are the thousands of actors, directors technicians and playwrights within the boundaries of the state.

RAREST of phenomena in the history of art is the painter's wife who has forged for herself an independent artistic existence. True enough, Angelica Kauffmann "looked with tenderness upon Reynolds," took Nathaniel Dance through Italy on an unofficial honeymoon and finally married a Venetian artist called Zucchi, whose name she never bothered to adopt.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 24 -- A new method of blood transfusion was credited here today with having kept alive a young man seriously injured Thursday night in a home laboratory chemical experiment. Although the youth remains on the critical list of the Englewood Hospital, staff doctors reported today he surely would have died in a few hours after the accident but for the forced transfusions he has been receiving.

A course on "American Values in World Perspective" will be offered this fall by the School of General Studies of Columbia University The course is designed to "furnish the student with information, ideas and interpretations on which he can build a constructive approach to an understanding of the problems of our rapidly changing world."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The immediate concern in Washington is not that the Russians will make atomic war on the West but that they will now launch a new and particularly deceptive peace offensive in the United States and Europe and in the United Nations.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Villanova College's football forces stunned a crowd of 20,000 today by romping to a 27-6 victory over Penn State. It was the first time a Penn State team had tasted defeat on its home grounds in three years.

The middleweight title bout between champion Jake La Motta of the Bronx and Marcel Cerdan of France, scheduled next Wednesday night at the Polo Grounds, was postponed indefinitely yesterday because of an injury to La Motta's right shoulder.

Its origin must be traced; its cause diagnosed, its symptoms catalogued and described. Or is the disease, perhaps, in itself a symptom of some deeper-rooted malady, some unease of the soul that manifests itself in an itch to apply pigment to canvas?

SHANGHAI, Sept. 24 -- The readiness of the Soviet-oriented Turki regime in Sinkiang to remain a part of China under Chinese Communist leadership was reflected today in the disclosure that Seyfuddin, a top-ranking member of the Turki autonomous movement, was head of the Sinkiang delegation to the conference of the Communist-sponsored Chinese People's Consultative Council in Peiping.

CHANDLER, Ariz., Sept. 24 -- The Air Force's aviation cadets training at Williams Air Force Base here to be jet fighter pilots declared today that the new jargon now widely attributed to them is the invention of fiction writers who sit up late writing but have never visited a jet fighter base.

More than $2,330,000 was awarded to 2,670,000 employes last year, according to a survey of suggestion systems covering 312 companies. The survey conclusions were reviewed at a meeting of the directors of the National Association of Suggestion Systems last Friday at the Statler Hotel, according to F. A. Denz, administrator of suggestion plans for Remington Rand, Inc., and past president of the association.

MR. LANCASTER, political cartoonist for The London Daily Express, writer and astute commentator on the contemporary scene, gently lampoons the Middle Ages in this tale of an unwilling hero. First serialized in The Atlantic Monthly, it is now published as a child's book.

ATHENS, Sept. 24 -- A spurt in the demand for gold sovereigns was reported this evening -- following upon Greece's devaluation of the drachma Tuesday -- but the extent of the buying had not been officially ascertained.

WITH the new equipment available today, housewives can take their choice of a home as fragrant as an old-fashioned garden, as fresh as pine woods or (if that's their pleasure) a house with no smell at all.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Ohio State launched its football season today by defeating Missouri's alert and powerful Tigers, 35 to 34, in as wild and woolly an opener as the big Buckeye Stadium ever has witnessed.

CAPTAIN ELLSBERG, famous naval officer, has made an exciting adventure story for older boys out of the harrowing, fatal expedition seeking the North Pole by way of the Bering Sea seventy years ago. His first account of that heroic failure was well received in 1938 under the title, "Hell on Ice"; this book is his own rewrite for juvenile readers.

GENEVA, Sept. 24 -- The wave of currency revaluations that began with Sir Stafford Cripps' dramatic Sunday night announcement and continued most of this week has been both the most extensive and the most orderly readjustment of international currency values the world has ever seen.

The American Civil Liberties Union held yesterday that civil rights in this country were in greater danger than at any time in the last twenty-nine years because of "imagined insecurity" in the face of the cold war with Russia.

BLUE EARTH, Minn., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Senator George D. Aiken Republican, of Vermont, said today that the solving of farm problems was a job for the farmers themselves with a minimum help from the Government.

In full bloom, when May is young, it will take your breath away with its spectacular display in the pristine woods. It looks as though it were covered with a swarm of white butterflies fresh from the cocoon.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 24 -- The seventy-sixth annual Danbury Fair, Connecticut's leading fall agricultural exposition, will open next Saturday for a nine-day program.
