It sets Goya in his epoch, gives a convincing account of the man, and deals exhaustively with his paintings and etchings. The title is taken from Goya's comment beneath one of his more harrowing .etchings of the Disasters of War.

THOMAS MANN, whose chronicle of the life of Joseph runs to more than 1,500 pages, once said that only the exhaustive is truly interesting. Biblical narrative itself would seem to prove him wrong: for centuries the tales of the heroes and heroines of the Old Testament have been compelling in their brevity.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 24 (UP) -- A Birmingham Post reporter charged today that a highway patrolman and a policeman "looked the other way" while part of his camera was being smashed at a Ku Klux Klan rally.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 24 -- President Truman's announcement on Friday of the "atomic explosion" in Russia was received calmly in the South. Newspapers, however, did devote much space to the story and gave it big headlines.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Pitt handed William and Mary College a 13-7 defeat today, but emerged with very little to bolster advance billing that Pitt football is headed back for the big time.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Sept. 24 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that in the two years since the availability of certain radioactive isotopes for foreign distribution was announced by President Truman, 616 shipments had been made to twenty-two countries for use in medical and scientific research.

Agreement in the Dutch-Indonesian round-table conference on the statute of union is good news of major importance. This clearly forecasts the success of the meeting and makes it probable that the deliberations can be concluded within the desired time limit.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- A vote in the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today to extend the agency's activities in Germany sent Polish, Czechoslovakian and Hungarian delegates stalking out of the room in protest.

WHEN a smart woman has taken stenographic dictation from a man for seventeen years, she is in a position to speak with authority on how he thinks, feels, acts, and reacts. Grace Tully, terming herself "merely a secretary to the President and no more," presents, in "F. D. R. -- My Boss," a unique close-up of the man who dominated a decade and a half of the life of this country.

In promotions here last week retailers emphasized fabric-covered cornices, hooked wool rugs, pastel percale sheets and misses' rayon velvet dresses, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc

QUEBEC, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A slim, wavy-haired Quebec jeweler, J. Albert Guay, was formally charged today with having murdered his wife, who died with twenty-two others in an explosion-torn Quebec Airways plane Sept. 9.

A UNIQUE projection system, which uses an elliptical-shaped reflector of rhodium-plated copper instead of the conventional condensers, is incorporated in an overhead projector for 4:5 to 8x10 transparencies. The new Scriber Visualizer, designed primarily for use in visual education, is now in production at the Beverly Hills plant of the Visual Scriber Corporation.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- The Government has outlined a three-point program to strengthen its program to hold prices in line and in many cases to bring them down as a means of removing the serious threat of labor disorders and of preventing another inflationary price-wage spiral.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 24 -- It was the same old juggernaut Notre Dame, plus some frisky new hands, as the Fightin' Irish touched off a bid for a fourth straight unbeaten season with a 49-6 clouting of Indiana's out-manned Hoosiers today. From a modest 16-6 halftime advantage, the Irish rolled up 20 points in a devastating third period and 13 more in the final quarter for their 29th straight game without defeat.

Retail trade was not particularly active here last week, with the sales comparison with a year affected by the approach of the religious holidays. Department store volume was estimated at about 13 per cent under the like week of 1948.

LAST Tuesday brought the return of Milton Berle to NBC in the formal inaugural of the television season, but it was not a particularly enchanting evening. The idol of Channel 4 was in there working as hard as ever with gag, costume change and spectacular sitdown, but the result at best was only so-so vaudeville and not very bountiful Berle.

Since the devaluation of the British pound sterling a week ago, British manufacturers have shown a greater willingness to alter lines to fit the desires of retailers in this country, Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, reported yesterday.

A niche in the record book eluded Bob Elliott of the Braves yesterday when the veteran infielder lined out to short on his fourth trip to the plate against the Giants at the Polo Grounds. Having slammed his fifteenth, sixteenth and seventeenth homers of the season earlier, Elliott was in position to become the fifth man in major-league history to achieve four round-trippers in one game.

WASHINGTON -- Plans for a step-saving U-shaped kitchen, introduced a year and a half ago by the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture, are now being sold in all but five of the forty-eight states.

ANGLE parking is an accident breeder because it puts the motorist in a blind spot when he is backing out into traffic, according to a survey presented by Thomas W. Ryan, New York State safety director.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 9 -- Along with the major tasks of nation - building, undertaken when freedom to joust with a competitive world was granted by the British a year and a half ago, the Ceylonese Government is attempting with determination to uplift the island's ancient and vanishing pariah community, the jungle dwelling Rodiyas.

A SHY, little man with a disarming grin, unknown outside the Orient, today wields more direct influence among millions of Japanese than any human except Gen. Douglas MacArthur and Emperor Hirohito and, except for the Emperor, he is probably the most popular Japanese alive.

LANDOVER, Md., Sept. 24 -- Miss Louise Suggs of Carrolton, Ga., dropped two strokes of her lead as she carded a 77 for the third round in the 72-hole women's United States open golf championship today. Added to her previous rounds of 69, 75, this gave her a total of 221 over the Prince Georges Golf and Country Club course.
Clarence J. Tobin, dean of the Brooklyn Supreme Court stenographers, is retiring on Saturday. He completed forty-eight years' service as a civil service employe on June 1.

I THINK J. Arnold in his letter titled, "Acting or Psychiatry," is typical of many "embryonic thespians." It is unfortunate that many of these people are never able to bring their work to fruition, and too many remain embryonic.

With an eye on the Iron Curtain, the Marshall Plan countries are building a vast network of electric generating facilities that will power their industrial recovery. Attainment of this goal is being hastened through the Economic Cooperation Administration's $300,000,000 program of electric power rehabilitation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 24 -- Premier Marshal Tito handed a note today to Sandor Kerestez, Hungarian Minister in Belgrade, denouncing the Budapest trial of former Hungarian Foreign Minister Laszlo Rajk as "another stage in a campaign and plot against Yugoslavia" that would "only contribute to the creation of a war psychosis in the world and inflict a heavy blow to international cooperation and peace in this part of Europe."

JEAN BLOCH-MICHEL has to his credit an impressive war record: he is a hero of the French Resistance. His first novel, "The Witness," would therefore not seem to be autobiographical in any obvious way. It is presented as the biography of a neurotic, written in the form of a letter addressed to a casual acquaintance by one who has finally resolved on suicide.
LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 24 Nebraska used the breaks and superior power here today to beat South Dakota, 33 -- 6, in the football opener here before 28,000 fans.

OF all the spring-flowering bulbs to be planted this fall, narcissus are perhaps the best garden investment. Once the purchase Is made and the bulbs planted, no further care is necessary. Under almost any weather or soil conditions, they will bloom every spring and produce more flowers each year.

PROBABLY no other home furnishing accessory today is so unsuited to its purpose, esthetically and functionally, as the lamp. We have lamps made like flowers, like swans, like works of art, on the one hand -- or symbols of chromium philosophy, on the other.

OUT of the "dissenter" mind of Anglo - Saxon North America comes new and original music that has split away from its European sources. Out of the "colonizer" mind of South America comes "mildly creative" music that is "not much more than an outcropping of the Old Hispanic World."

Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the United Nations General Assembly, said in a radio speech yesterday that the Western democracies must ally themselves with the movement toward native self-government and independence in Asia or forfeit the entire region to "another power."

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 24 -- First-game jitters almost produced a major reversal in the enlarged stadium of the University of Michigan today as 97,239 persons watched the Wolverines come from behind to score their twenty-fourth consecutive victory by finally prevailing over Michigan State, 7 to 3.
TOO many of our modern architects, interior decorators and lighting engineers have consigned the magic of candlelight to the ignominy of community bonfires and the archives of dead busts.

THIS is the month when geraniums suddenly burst forth in a riot of bloom that far surpasses any display they may have made all summer long. It is also the time when the question arises of housing them in winter quarters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- About 80,000 displaced persons have been admitted to the United States out of a quota of 205,000 authorized by 1948 legislation, the International Refugee Organization said today.

Your pictures of "America's Big Game" showed our ten first American families population-wise as reported by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service census. How much rarer, however, and therefore more interesting is the Woodland Caribou, which the same census tells us has only twenty-five left in the family -- ten in Idaho and fifteen in Montana.

THE British people have gone farther than any other modern industrial nation in making life secure for all. They have also got into a dangerous international squeeze of being unable to pay for the imports their overcrowded island must have to maintain any Western standard of living.

If "Twelve O'Clock High" means "over the target," as you report in the caption of a picture in your layout "World War II on the Screen," the Air Force really must have changed. It used to mean that fighters, flak or something equally disagreeable was straight off the nose and above.

During a series of industrial meetings held here last week, top executives of leading durable goods companies revealed that orders now being booked for deliveries during the fourth quarter are larger than had been expected earlier in the year. In many lines, these executives said, they had not found out what factors had been responsible for the increased rate of buying.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Sept. 24 -- A big turnout and a close vote were seen today as Oklahomans prepared to make a decision Tuesday between legal liquor and their present 42-year-old constitutional prohibition.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 23 -- The governorship contest between Republican incumbent Alfred E. Driscoll and Democratic State Senator Elmer H. Wene, Vineland chicken farmer, remained in its sparring phase this week, with no promise of dramatic action for at least three weeks.

BUYING furniture is often a gamble, but if the shopper is alert to price trends and is familiar with quality, the risk is greatly minimized. Prices this fall are somewhat lower than they were a year ago, but they may still seem high to shoppers working on limited budgets.

IT all began when the Merriweathers inherited a house in Connecticut not far from New York City, where they had always lived. After much debate it was decided that the family -- seven Merriweathers, two servants, and a French poodle -- should move to the country.

The four-month suspension of the important Soviet history journal, Voprosy Istori, was explained yesterday when it became known through the delivery of another issue that nine out of thirteen members of the scholarly publication's editorial board had been removed in the purge of Soviet historians last March and April.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 24 -- Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican, of Indiana, declared here tonight that the virus of "statism" in this country had "reached the point where an American President for the first time is openly espousing programs to change the American form of Government."

Devaluation of the Netherlands currency is likely to bring wage rises to a number of groups in that country, Prof. Barend C. Slotemaker said last week in an interview after a luncheon of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York at the University Club.

Rosh ha-Shanah, marking the start of the New Year 5710 in the Hebrew calendar, was observed yesterday in temples and synagogues. The principal note in sermons was for greater emphasis on spiritual values. The rabbis also reviewed world events of the last year.

JESSE STUART, novelist, short story writer and poet, at 42, has two autobiographical works to his credit, both dealing with his life in the "mountain region of Kentucky" -- that forever picturesque land where force reigns, nightingales sing, school trustees cannot read their names, and pipe-smoking grandmothers dance to fiddle tunes.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Twenty years ago the auto industry, working around the clock most of the time, set a production record; it built 5,385,420 cars and trucks.

" LES NOURRITURES TERRESTRES," first published in 1897 and now for the first time published in English in this excellent translation of Dorothy Bussy, has a strange history. Having sold only 500 copies in the first ten years after its publication, it has become a kind of succes de scandale in the last four decades.

HISTORIC Old Deerfield, Mass., is undergoing the same transformation that turned Williamsburg, Va., into a Colonial landmark, the difference being solely in scale. Old Deerfield is a small village. With the aim of creating a living community that will recall the majesty of New England's frontier days, residents of the one-time northwestern outpost are in the quiet process of restoring their village to approximately its original state.

NOW that the United States is the greatest power in the Western World and a major candidate for global hegemony, Americans are doing some serious thinking about themselves and their nation. As the process goes on, we hear less boasting and less lamentation than we once did.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 24 -- A mother's desire to be near her two seriously ill children and the urge to help other youngsters fight the crippling effects of infantile paralysis have inspired Mrs. Richard Romano, Brooklyn housewife, to spend hours each day for the last month as a volunteer worker at the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Institute for Infantile Paralysis at the Medical Center here.

IN purchasing a television set for the home there are many factors which the prospective owner should consider. The most important undoubtedly is the matter of cost, but there also are the concurrent questions of the size of the screen, indoor and outdoor aerials and, in most cases, the rearrangement of the room to provide comfortable viewing.

THE final novelty of the season of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House will be the premiere of Tatiana Chamie's "Birthday" on Tuesday evening. It is set to an arrangement of Rossini music by Lucien Cailliet, its scenery is by Mstislav Doboujinsky and its costumes by Barbara Karinska.

RONALD COLMAN, who has not made a picture since he won the Academy Award for his 1947 appearance in "A Double Life," went back to work the other day in "Champagne for Caesar," an independent production to be released by United Artists.
ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Cornell opened its sixty-second season of football today with a 27-0 victory over a stubborn Niagara eleven at Schoellkopf Field.
Chile charged yesterday that the Soviet Union's "crusade" against Yugoslavia was a threat to the peace of the world.

As Senator Estes Kefauver pointed out ("What's to Be Done About Congress ?") there is need of change in the archaic rules of Congress, but there is also need for a change in the attitude of the men who operate under those rules.

MURDER on a train, in fiction, usually involves either high suspense melodrama, in the manner of Alfred Hitchcock, or elaborately intricate time-table puzzles, in the vein of Freeman Wills Crofts. But Mr. Bellairs' train is a small and shabby one, hardly suitable to either grand-manner thrills or mental gymnastics.

THE Senator wore a look of despair. He made a sweeping gesture around the office, indicating piles of papers everywhere -- on his desk, on top of filing cabinets, completely covering the sofa, a secretary's desk and a near-by table.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 -- Despite their own confusion, notwithstanding a rousing closing rally by the Cubs, and regardless of Brooklyn's smashing triumph over the Phillies tonight, the Cardinals still are leaders in the National League pennant fight, by the slender margin of half a game.

SCIENTISTS are becoming as dissatisfied with the familiar contours of earth as their inquisitive ancestors were with the Garden of Eden. During the past decade the possibility of flights into the upper atmosphere has passed the science-fiction stage; it is no longer necessary even to preface one's remarks with "it may seem fantastic, but * * *"

* * * It is as foolish to expect poetry to stand still and be content to be limited by the restrictions of archaic verse forms, rhyme schemes, and, if need be, sentence structure, as it is to expect pictorial art to be held in bondage by photographic representations of nudes, pieties and banana peels.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Lieut. John E. Tuchen of the Air Force felt a jolt.

FOR too long a time grandmother's techniques for washing have been passed down from generation to generation. There was nothing wrong with her methods in her day, perhaps, but grandmother did not have to cope with the newer types of textiles and she made hard work of a job that her granddaughter prefers to do with less energy and in less time.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 24 -- To relieve a shortage of anthracite for hospitals and homes, Local 898, United Mine Workers of America, at Nanticoke, today authorized a force of seventy men to report for duty at No. 7 Mine of the Susquehanna Collieries Company Monday morning and run 65,000 tons of coal, now in stockpile, through the breaker so it can be marketed.

Motorists were urged to put secret identification marks on their cars to foil night prowling ear thieves in a city-wide warning yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York. Emphasis was given to surveys indicating that a large percentage of motor vehicles are stolen between 5 P. M. and midnight, particularly during the fall and winter months.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18 -- Evidence is increasing to support the now widely expressed idea that Egypt is starting to turn her back on Arab affairs and seek her associates among nations more of her own class in terms of population and industrial and commercial development.

CANNES -- the year the small seaside places along the Cote d'Azur that stretches from Marseille to the Italian border are back to normalcy. The Waterfront villas and hotels are freshly painted; the beaches full of bathers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board today found one local union of the Structural Iron Workers Union, AFL, guilty of violating the Taft-Hartley act by obtaining the discharge of an employe because he was a member of another local of the same union.

LONDON. THE new Soviet nationalism is more than a joke. Certainly it is funny, and also pathetic, to see the drab, inarticulate millions of Stalin's Russia being told in every article, in every broadcast, in every slogan, that they, the new Soviet man and the new Soviet woman, are immeasurably superior to all other people on earth.

When the defense in our Government's trial of eleven accused Communists rested its case on Friday, the proceedings had been going on over a period of nine months. There had been 158 days in court, of which the defense had used eighty-two. No one can predict, and no American respecting judicial process will predict, what the verdict is to be.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP) -- a hard-driving Georgetown football team wore down wasteful Holy Cross, which 'lost two touchdowns because of penalties, for a 20-13 victory today before 16,000 opening game fans.

WITH the official Communist Liberation Daily remaining silent, other controlled newspapers in Shanghai last week started a concentrated press attack on American motion pictures as alleged vehicles for spreading "imperialist poison" and "doping" the minds of Chinese audiences with "sex and legs."

HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Moving equally well on the ground and through the air, Colgate's eleven opened its 1949 campaign today with an easy 32-0 victory over Buffalo University before 5,300 rain-soaked fans.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Army opened its football campaign with an expected triumph over Davidson at Michie Stadium today. Using their top men in both the offensive and defensive units, the Cadets ran over the Wildcats from North Carolina by the score of 47 to 7, to the complete satisfaction of a crowd of 17,561 spectators.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24 -- The "wall of separation" between church and state cannot be defined logically because some degree of governmental support of religion has been customary for years and continues with public approval, a legal authority declared today in the Harvard Law Review.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 -- Victor Cattan of Panama will celebrate tomorrow his eleventh birthday in the Shriners Hospital for Crippled Children, where ten operations have made it possible for him to walk for the first time in his life.

Current export policies must be re-appraised by American foreign traders to meet the stark fact that United States goods will cost foreign buyers up to 44 per cent more in terms of their own currencies as a result of the wave of devaluation last week.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 -- Boston fishing interests, worried over the effects of sterling currency devaluation, are watching a new trend of Gloucester fishermen for ranging farther at sea in search of new sources of supply.

MR. and Mrs. GI Joe and little Joe are grouped in the middle of a bare living room, together with a loosely massed mountain of furniture, barrels and luggage. This impedimenta has just been deposited by the moving men. Mr. and Mrs. strike an attitude of dejected bewilderment.

THAT old family argument about who'll do the dishes has given way, the jokesters claim, to a spat over who'll turn on the dishwasher. Fractious couples may be deprived of even that bone to pick if this year's trends in work-saving kitchen gadgets and equipment continue.

To defend Robert E. Sherwood as one of this country's major playwrights would certainly seem to me an impertinence. The Parke-Bernet Galleries will hold its first auction sale of the season this week in its temporary quarters, the former Brummer Art Gallery, 110 East Fifty-eighth Street.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 24 -- Virginia, mother of Presidents, is proud of her history, but not of the way history is taught in her schools, a legislative commission indicated today.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser chalked up his eighteenth victory of the season today while the Detroit Tigers were turning back Cleveland, 8 -- 5.

THE several thousand or hundred thousand collectors of buttons have been eagerly awaiting this opulent-looking volume by Mrs. Albert -- one of the most respected authorities on the subject and editor of the National Button Society's Bulletin -- and Miss Kent, who has assisted in preparation of some outstanding books on antiques.

THE restaurant, the cafe, the bar, the hotel lobby, the ship's salon -- these are the public meeting places today, rather than the postoffice, the court house or even the church. These are the rooms in which people gather, linger and talk.

Employment in the nation's privately owned shipyards has decreased since the first of the year at the rate of 1,500 men a month and is now lower than it has been at any time in the past decade, according to a survey by the Shipbuilders Council of America.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- The Literary Gazette, one of the important journals of Soviet opinion, charged today that the United States plan for atomic energy control was designed to establish an international "supertrust" that would assure domination of United States monopolies and militarists in the atomic field.

EUROPE'S summer tourist season was a huge success, even though it failed to measure up to overoptimistic estimates of the Economic Cooperation Administration. It fell short simply for lack of transatlantic ship and plane space.

" MODERN" means "pertaining to the present time," and modern design as a name for contemporary design is generic, not specific. Unlike any of the confined name periods of the past, it offers a hitherto undreamed-of freedom of expression.

SHOPPING for upholstery fabrics on a limited budget will be almost as much fun as shopping with a champagne pocketbook this fall, and the search for exciting materials at reasonable prices will be more rewarding now than ever before.

A new technique for evaluating employe performance which eliminates personal bias of superiors almost entirely is in final stages of development by a leading oil company, an employe relations executive for the concern revealed in an interview last week.

WOR-TV, New York City's newest television station will begin regularly scheduled program operations on Tuesday, Oct. 11. The new telecaster will use Channel 9, the seventh and last frequency assigned to the New York-northern New Jersey area.

IT'S surprising how little American readers really know of the English detective story. A recent issue of that lively and informative periodical, the Crime Book Magazine of London, mentions current books by twenty-four British mystery novelists; of the two dozen, only one is at present appearing regularly in this country, and sixteen have never had a single one of their books published here.

MR. STONE'S fifth biographical novel deals with the life and times of one John Noble, an American painter labeled "the last of the Bohemians" when he died in the mid-Thirties -- a hectic, already half-forgotten figure, whom Mr. Stone now reintroduces as an authentic genius, using much of the same organ music that served him so well with the truly immortal Vincent van Gogh in "Lust for Life."

TODAY, when people are still looking for good furniture at minimum cost, the multiform virtues of knock-down furniture are well worth exploring.

RICHARD STRAUSS' "Der Rosenkavalier" will be the opening-night opera at the Metropolitan on Nov. 21. Thus both the city's leading opera companies will be honoring the composer with a similar gesture, for the New York City Opera opens on Thursday with his "Ariadne auf Naxos."

City College opened its 1949 football campaign yesterday with a 59-0 rout of Susquehanna U. before 2,200 thoroughly surprised fans at Lewisohn Stadium. It was the opening game in the sixtieth year of coaching for Amos Alonso Stagg, but the Grand Old Man's Crusader eleven could do nothing to stop the Beavers' drive.

As a relatively optimistic report of the United Nations Conciliation Commission for Palestine was released yesterday at Flushing Meadow, comments by Arab and Israeli representatives indicated a continued deadlock ahead when the commission meets here next month.

TROY, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada will be the principal speaker at an evening convocation on Friday, Oct. 14, marking the 125th anniversary of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. The Prime Minister's acceptance was announced today by Dr. Livingston W. Houston, president of Rensselaer.

The Big Four foreign ministers probably will meet early this week as the only means of breaking the deadlock in negotiations for a treaty on Austria, informed sources at the General Assembly of the United Nations at Flushing Meadow said yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Photographic techniques are taught solely as a means to creative expression in a three-year course at the California School of Fine Arts here. Under the direction of Minor White, this unique photographic school is affiliated with the University of California, and because of its special approach to teaching photography it has attracted students from all over the country.
The first Trappistine nuns to set up an establishment on American soil are due to arrive here from Ireland next Saturday to form the first institution of their order in the United States.
HONG KONG, Sept. 24 -- A flourishing state of trade between Hong Kong and Communist North China is revealed in official figures on the colony's exports and imports for August released today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 -- John Bronoski hobbled into the area medical office of the United Mine Workers Welfare Fund today. A short, stubby man with a perpetual grin, he has worn an artificial leg since the day five years ago when a cutting machine jolted out of the coal face and sawed off his left leg above the knee.

COLOR is the one aspect of interior design that is legitimately subject to the influence of women's fashions. As clothes fashions change, the mood of the wearer changes. Her new concept of herself consciously or unconsciously changes her ideas of how she should look in her home.

NEW ALBANY, Ind., Sept. 24 -- Frank Haller, letter carrier for the local postoffice, resumed his rounds after his vacation last week and regaled many of the householders on his route with the following account of a fishing trip he said he made to the Blue River in Harrison County.

An avalanche of disconcerting news rocked the stock market last week. After taking devaluation of the pound sterling in its stride on Monday, with moderate declines, prices weakened on Tuesday to show the widest losses of the year. The coal walkout and threats of a steel strike left investors even more apprehensive than did the foreign crisis.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Rutgers crossed the enemy goal line twelve times today as the Scarlet opened its eightieth year of football with a 79-6 triumph over the United States Merchant Marine Academy of Kings Point, L. I.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The Navy will make an all-out effort Monday to show the Pentagon high command that the aircraft carrier is a powerful weapon in atomic warfare.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 24 -- A cargo vessel leased by the Korean Government from the United States Army through the Economic Cooperation Administration disappeared with two Americans aboard off the Korean coast between last Tuesday and this morning, the Korean Government announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 -- Prospects of an increase of wildcat strikes in the steel industry disturbed the recess in negotiations today between the corporations and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO. Both sides are to take up negotiations Monday in the hope of preventing a strike next week-end.

EVERY year dozens of authentic English low-boys, knife boxes, beau brummels and other oddments dating from the days of George III are hauled onto the New York docks. Every year they are fewer, however, therefore more expensive, and although the devaluation of the British pound may have some slight effect on these high prices it will certainly not cause major price reductions.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Southern California's Trojans, looking mid-season sharp, opened their 1949 football season with a 42 to 20 triumph over Navy today.

For the second time in less than a week the Brooklyn police were summoned yesterday to prevent a man from leaping from a tenement roof. The man involved was Vincent Rauert, 24 years old, a war veteran, of 142 North Third Street, Brooklyn.

The announcement on Friday of Russia's atomic explosion dwarfed the activities of the fourth session of the United Nations General Assembly -- which opened on Tuesday at Flushing Meadow. But in its proceedings prior to Friday, the Assembly was the stage for developments that in an ordinary week would have held great interest.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Governor Dewey has accepted the invitation of the Rockland County Republican Committee to be its guest at a dinner in Bear Mountain Inn the evening of Oct. 13, according to Charles W. Hawkins of Spring Valley, chairman of the Republican County Committee.

The outlook for the American economy was shrouded in uncertainty last week. The reason was a wide-ranging conflict between labor and management in three vital areas of the economy -- steel, coal and automobiles.

BREWSTER, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- A new super-highway link between here and Danbury in neighboring Connecticut, discussed pro and con for the last twenty-five years, will become a reality on Nov. 15, the date set for completion of the $988,000 project of the New York State Highway Department.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady and moderately active Saturday. Final prices were 2 to 4 points lower than on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Probably 5,000,000 employes of American business can count on regular checks from private pension funds when they retire.

LONDON, Sept. 24 (Reuters) -- The unbeaten Wolverhampton Wanderers took a four-point lead in the Football Association's first division today with a smashing 7-1 victory over lowly Huddersfield Town. A crowd of 48,000 at the Wolves' stadium saw three goals scored in the first few minutes of play.

When the interest rate paid as a part of the market price of bonds exceeds the rate commanded by bonds of comparable investment merit, the bonds will sell at a premium. For income-tax purposes such premium may be recovered as a tax-free deduction from the income of the bonds. This is called amortization of bond premium.

If "giant" apples and grapes grow on your tree and vines, New York State's Agricultural Experiment Station, Geneva, N, Y., would like to hear from you. Don't send the fruit itself, but mark the tree or vine and mail a postcard that describes the fruit briefly. Giant fruits have long been known, but not until more knowledge was acquired in recent years about genetics could plant-breeders make the most of them.

IN these days when short story writers are more often identified with a particular magazine than with a distinctive quality of their own, it is a rare volume of stories that is both versatile and conveys a unity of impression Helen Eustis, who will be remembered for her successful psycho-thriller.

Walter Behr's letter of Aug. 29 has just come to my attention. Mr. Behr asks how it is that the star and director of the Oberammergau Passion Plays should now be asked to serve on our Theatre Advisory Committee.
" NOBODY can live decently in a one-room apartment," a disgruntled friend of mine once complained, "except an automaton."
LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 25 -- The Moscow radio early today broadcast a statement by Tass, the official Soviet news agency, which said that Russia had had the secret of the atomic bomb since 1947.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Senator Scott W. Lucas, Democrat, of Illinois, says that "blind isolationists" who oppose the Truman Administration's foreign policy are doing more to help Stalin than American Communists are.

Sam Boal's "The Ties That Blind" was as welcome to me as the National League pennant would be to the Philadelphia Phillies. Ever since I've been old enough to button up a shirt collar I've been wondering who thought up the infernal idea of men spending at least half of their lives being strangled to death.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Members of the House, sun-tanned and invigorated by a month's vacation, came back to Washington this week with high hopes of a whirlwind finish of the session's business. With few exceptions, they had what is known here as adjournment fever.
LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Ben Gazelle, 38, of Toronto, overcame a leg cramp today to win the twenty-mile Lake George swimming marathon.

LEON ROTHIER retired from the Metropolitan Opera in 1942 with the expectation that his public career was ended. He was 68, had been with the company for thirty-two years and had sung more than 500 performances of Mephistopheles in "Faust" alone.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 24 -- United Nations relief officials for Palestine Arab refugees are under instructions from Lake Success demanding that the relief rolls be cut by 120,000 persons by Oct. 1 and by 190,000 by Nov. 1.

It looks as if the major contributions to medical progress are now reads not by physicians, but by chemists. This impression is deepened by the many papers of medical importance that were read last week at Atlantic City, N. J, before the American Chemical Society.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The steel-coal-automobile-electrical industries crisis which threatens national economic stability springs from the comparatively rapid growth of monolithic unions to match the power of gigantic industrial units.

RIDGEFIELD PARIS, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Bergen County police prepared today for possible violence Monday morning at the common gate that gives access to the struck Continental Paper Company and the Alford Cartons Company. Workers at the Alford plant, a subsidiary of the struck factory, were prevented from reporting to their jobs yesterday by angered pickets.

SUSSEX, England -- In medical circles in England today a chief topic of conversation everywhere is the National Health Service. The feeling of the vast majority of doctors is the same, "We don't like it, but it is here to stay for a long time at least, and we will make the best of it."

Officers and members of the Teachers Union, CIO, denied here yesterday a report published in THE NEW YORK TIMES that pro-Communists within the union were demanding that it leave the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

ROME, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The semi-official Vatican City newspaper, Osservatore Romano, said today it was "reasonable" to fear the approach of World War III unless the atomic bomb, a "terrible and inhuman" weapon, was outlawed.

One of the candidates next month for the office of Bishop Coadjutor of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will be the Right Rev. Horace William Baden Donegan, Suffragan Bishop of the diocese, it was learned yesterday.
EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Northwestern got off to a driving start in the Big Ten gridiron championship race today by bowling over Purdue, 20 to 6.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Arthur Henderson, Britain Air Secretary, flew in a United States B-50 bomber today during maneuvers designed to test Britain's defenses against enemy bombing attacks.

OF the several unfortunate aspects of a shoddy season such as the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo is giving us at the Metropolitan Opera House this fall, one has received less emphasis than it deserves. To spend an evening at an inferior performance is cause only for personal resentment; to see the naive taste of a new public being exploited where it could just as easily be led toward something substantial is more deeply disturbing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Carl R. Gray, Veterans Administrator, tonight gave World War II veterans another five weeks to enroll in college or training courses under the GI bill.

HONG KONG, Sept. 24 -- Communist troops in Northwest China are estimated here to be less than fifty miles from the Yumen oil fields in Kansu corridor, the most important military objective in the Northwest.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 24 -- W. Kingsland Macy of Islip, Representative in the First New York District and Republican leader of Suffolk County, has instituted a court proceeding to prevent the Independent Efficiency party of Islip Town from using a flying eagle as its emblem on the ballot at the general election on Tuesday, Nov. 8.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24 -- Little Connecticut threw a scare into Yale, to reach the 4-yard line on an opening 56-yard assault and again the 18 after recovering a fumble, but the Elis' launching of their football season had a happy 26 -- 0 ending in the Bowl today.

EASTVIEW, N. Y. -- The historic Hammond House of Revolutionary fame, in which George Washington never slept although he did reputedly jump through a rear window to escape from the British, is entering a new era as a shrine and museum. Crumbling foundations and rotting timbers threatened its life a few months ago, but historians have now corrected the worst defects and rededicated the place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- David E. Lilienthal believes Russia's possession of the atomic bomb means this country must do everything necessary to "establish unquestioned and unmistakable leadership" in an atomic armaments race.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 -- Chrysler Corporation employes in Michigan voted slightly less than eight to one to strike in support of their contract demands, results of a state-conducted election disclosed tonight.

AS part of Nassau County's golden anniversary industrial exposition, beginning Oct. 8 and running through Oct. 12, Roosevelt Field will come into its own again, if only for a few brief days Nassau County has sometimes been referred to as the "cradle of American aviation," and Roosevelt Field has for many years been one of the most historic airfields in the world.

LONDON--The happiest Americans abroad last week were those among the 12,000- 15,000 United States tourists in England who had not yet changed all their dollars into pounds. Devaluation of the pound by 30 per cent meant a 43.92 per cent increase in the value of the dollar in sterling exchange.

The editorial "Germany's President" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 13 and various recent cables of your correspondents in Germany have given your readers a slightly inaccurate picture of the personality of Dr. Theodor Heuss, the new Western German chief of state.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Sept. 24 -- A new and dangerous chapter in the atomic age opened this week and the arms-aid program and Atlantic pact defense measures took on an urgent meaning as President Truman announced that henceforth we would be living in two atomic worlds.

LIKE the steam shovel on a new construction job, a street corner demonstration of a new fix-it gadget has an allure that few men can resist. The variety of such tools now available probably accounts for the growing enthusiasm of countless amateur handymen whose sole accomplishment along these lines used to be replacing burned-out light bulbs.

In Washington last Thursday Vice President Alben W. Barkley told reporters: "There is a longing in the hearts of Congressmen to get back into the hinterland." The House -- which had returned the day before from a month's vacation -- had started a drive for speedy adjournment.

VERACRUZ -- A trip by freighter used to be a low- priced and hardy method of going places. Today, like everything else, it has become more expensive and effete. But ever since the war it has been almost impossible to get accommodations.

EVEN those teen-aged girls who haven't editorial ambitions will enjoy Marjory Hall's latest career novel, for the young people in it are very much a part of the present-day world. Those who do have such ambitions will get some good pointers on magazine work from this crisply written story.

APLATITUDE has come home to me with qai religious force. I was repining at the thought of my slow progress-- how few new ideas I had or picked up--when it occurred to me to think of the total of life and how the greater part was wholly absorbed in living and continuing life---victuals--procreation-rest and eternal terror.

AN increase of two-and-one-half times in ground-glass image brilliance of twin-lens reflex cameras is obtained with the Hartley field lens, just announced in Los Angeles. Made of lucite and selling for $4.95, it can be installed in any twin-lens camera.

The May Department Stores Company and its subsidiaries had consolidated net sales of $180,075,000 in the six months ended on last July 31, and the volume for the twelve months ended on that date was $404,020,000, the company announced yesterday for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico, predicted today that the Senate's new compromise farm program calling for flexible price supports ranging from 75 to 90 per cent of parity would be written into law.

At Goshen the other day the high school opened up a smoking room for students. Set in the basement and with only a long bench along the wall, the room was a long way from the plush dens of the movies or the University Club.

Capt. A. H. McCollum, USN, will begin his new duties today as deputy commander, Military Sea Transport Service (Atlantic) at the Brooklyn Army Base, it was announced over the week-end by Brig. Gen. Paul F. Yount, commanding general of the Port of Embarkation.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 25 -- The Communist radio in North Korea said today that a United States Army cargo ship leased to South Korea, and which "vanished" Wednesday, had arrived at a North Korean port.

MONTREAL, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Jerusalem must be made an international city, and Cardinal Spellman now is interceding with President Truman to have this brought about, the Rev. Raphael Quinn, secretary to the Roman Catholic Custodian of Holy Places, said today.

LANDOVER, Md., Sept. 25 -- Finishing in a blaze of glory with another par shattering round, Miss Louise Suggs, 26-year-old Carrollton, Ga., professional, won the fourth annual 72-hole United States open medal play golf championship today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- National commanders of the two large veterans' organizations, the American Legion and Veterans of Foreign Wars, today pledged "teamwork" in "common objectives."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25 -- The Palestine Arab refugee situation is heading into a serious crisis that will be placed before the United Nations Secretary General and his refugee advisory group this week.

UTICA, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, arrived here tonight on the first leg of a campaign tour that will take him through ten counties of the "North Country" this week.

Spiritual maturity among Christians in the United States is needed to meet the challenge of the spread of knowledge of the use of atomic energy, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

It is probably too early to whistle an optimistic tune about the successful revival of vaudeville -- especially backstage in the dressing room, where it might "jinx" the act. However, the fact remains that since May 19, when Broadway's famed Palace Theatre revived vaudeville with an eight-act four-a-day program, customers have been observed to throng the aisles and line up before the box office.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 25 -- No state in the country can afford "not to have" a modern mental health program, Gov. Luther W. Youngdahl of Minnesota declared today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- Sidney Poitier and H. M. (Dots) Johnson, stage actors who were seen on Broadway in "Anna Lucasta," have been signed by Twentieth Century-Fox for the leading roles in "No Way Out," a story by Lesser Samuels dealing with the problems of a Negro interne in a metropolitan hospital, the studio has announced.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Price rigging by private industry, which is illegal in the United States with its "uncontrolled" economy, is winked at by Britain's Socialist Government. This, with the common practice of restricting markets, is a kind of private socialism practiced by manufacturers to protect the least efficient producers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The atomic explosion inside the Soviet Union is already affecting the political atmosphere here very much as the Communist coup in Czechoslovakia and the Soviet blockade of Berlin affected it in 1948.

Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the United Nations General Assembly, declared yesterday that while the United States and Russia differed radically on the problem of atomic control, they were in "complete agreement" that the problem could be solved only through the United Nations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Browns suffered their 100th loss of the season in dropping a 7-5 decision to the White Sox in the first game of a double-header today but bounced back to win the second game, 6 -- 2. Darkness halted play after six innings in the night-cap.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 25 -- The New Jersey State Fair, annual event here for well over a century, opened today with a record crowd of 65,000 on hand. Parking areas for cars were overloaded and the auto licenses indicated visitors had come from nearly every county of the state and near-by centers in Pennsylvania.

I have read with interest and regret your news items and editorials on the closing of the Good Neighbor Federation's Community Center in East Harlem. We at Union Settlement, only three blocks away, well know the crying need for more community centers, for greater facilities and for funds to carry on our work in the heart of East Harlem.

The herculean task of resurfacing six blocks along the heart of Fifth Avenue, from Fifty-first to Fifty-seventh Street, was carried out yesterday in less than twelve hours as the entire crew of the asphalt plant of the Manhattan Borough President's office was pressed into service.

All is not gloom in Mudville. Sure, the news emanating from Fenway Park was disheartening, and folks in Flatbush are still shuddering from the effects of the debacle at Ebbets Field. But, in the realm of one-day wonders, the Giants made themselves masters of the field yesterday.
S. J. Woodworth has been appointed sales manager of the Wright Hoist division of the American Chain Cable Company, Inc. He succeeds A. R. Haskins, who will resign Oct. 15.

That doughty defender of the Bill of Rights, the American Civil Liberties Union, raises some difficult questions in its current report, made public Saturday. It is critical of our occupation policy in Germany and Japan -- unduly so, one might suggest, in view of recent trends in both countries -- and it thinks it detects a national hysteria exceeding "in its severity, intolerances and fears" anything comparable since 1920.
Marjorie Garrigue, pianist, will give a recital at Town Hall at 8:30 o'clock tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Senate economy advocates talked today of trying to tie a money-saving string to an armed services pay increase bill that is expected to win approval with little opposition.

The recent devaluation of currencies by most European countries may result in an unprecedented fall and winter boom in transatlantic travel, in the opinion of Birger Nordholm, representative in this country of the European Travel Commission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- On the eve of possible final action by the House, former Indian Commissioner John Collier urged today that the Navajo-Hopi Indian rehabilitation bill be discarded.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -- Irish linens and cottons with surface interest took precedence in a resort-into-summer showing held in the Chapman Park Hotel poolside patio and sponsored by California apparel creators.

Former Prince Alexander Hohenlohe, who came to the United States in 1939 and subsequently became a citizen, shot himself in the left chest in his apartment at 206 East Sixty-second Street shortly after 6 o'clock last night.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- A post-war record wheat harvest is in sight for Europe.

A dispute among the officials of the American Merchant Marine Staff Officers Association has led to the formation of an opposition organization and a struggle for the right to represent pursers employed by the major American-flag steamship companies operating from New York, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- An early movement of new-crop corn impends, and brokers expect that inside of two weeks sufficient new grain may be available to start elevators running their drying equipment. Two cars of new corn were received last week from Southern Indiana and tested 17.2 and 20 per cent moisture, which is regarded as low for this early in the fall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- State Department officials said today the Administration would ask Congress to "liberalize" tax laws on income earned in foreign countries to stimulate private investment abroad. A program for that purpose has been prepared by the Administration.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 25 -- The evacuation ship Gen. W. H. Gordon slipped down the Whangpoo River at 4 A. M. today with 1,220 passengers, including 363 Americans.
Cotton price quotations in the domestic market continued to move narrowly last week, but active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 13 to 25 points on the week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Directors of the United States Chamber of Commerce urged American business today to support to the fullest extent possible the recruiting of a civilian reserve for the country's armed forces.

The need to examine merchant marine "requirements and responsibilities" is stressed in a message sent by President Truman to the Propeller Club of the United States, which will hold its twenty-third annual convention next month in connection with the annual American Merchant Marine Conference.

The realism and relevence of the Christian faith today were emphasized in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Shoemaker yesterday morning at Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Devaluation of the British pound and its consequences for the franc and other currencies failed to cause any great disturbance on the Paris Bourse. The market had for a long time expected that the pound would be devalued.

Faustin J. Solon, vice president of Owens-Illinois Glass Company of Toledo, Ohio, has been elected chairman of the Joint Committee on Improvement of Public Understanding of Our Economic System sponsored by the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies, it was announced yesterday.

Six hundred persons took part yesterday in an eight-block parade followed by a memorial service for the war dead at Catholic War Veterans Square, 122d Street and Rockaway Boulevard, Ozone Park, Queens. The event was sponsored by the Queens County Chapter of the Catholic War Veterans.

LONDON, Sept. l7 -- Restitution of war damage still is proving a heavy charge on the budgets of Great Britain and Western Europe. More than four years after the hostilities the equivalent of billions of dollars is being spent annually to compensate for war losses.

The American Zionist Council announced yesterday that the leading rabbinical groups in this country "are solidly united in the determination to resist all attempts to cut off Jerusalem from the State of Israel."

ALBANY, Sept. 25 -- An analysis of recent state elections reveals that a large proportion of voters did not express themselves on referendum issues, although only an insignificant number of ballots were found to be blank or void in the vote for major state officials.

Margaret Truman, the President's daughter, will make her first appearance in New York as a professional singer on Dec. 20, when she sings four or five numbers in a half-hour broadcast that will be sponsored by the American Oil Company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Preston Tucker said yesterday that he will start legal action to block sale of the 480-acre plant he leased from the War Assets Administration to build a new type automobile that never got into full production.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Both British and Israeli diplomats have been astonished at how much and how quickly relations between the two countries have improved since the end of the British mandate in Palestine and especially since Britain and Israel exchanged diplomatic representatives six months ago.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder of La Cresenta, Calif., retained his National amateur hard-court tennis title today with a workmanlike 6-1, 6-3, 6-1 victory over Eric Sturgess of South Africa.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Two members of Congress said today that lax controls and a soft attitude toward communism had opened the way to Communist infiltration and helped Soviet Russia make an atom bomb.
The quadruplets born last May to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Collins of 1972 Clinton Avenue, the Bronx, were baptized yesterday at 4 P. M. in a ceremony at the Concourse Plaza Hotel.

BRNO, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 25 (UP) -- At least seven persons were killed and twenty-five injured today when three racing cars, competing for the Grand Prix of Czechoslovakia, plunged into groups of tightly packed spectators on three different occasions.

The nation's economy is moving steadily toward price stabilization, according to an analysis by the National Association of Manufacturers of recent changes in production, productivity, prices, profits, jobs and wages, released over the week-end.

Birthday greetings are in order today for one of the schools that compose New York University. With the opening of classes this morning the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, one of the oldest collegiate schools of business in the country, will begin celebrating its golden anniversary.

A free show that played to a steady crowd of 400 persons was staged yesterday at the southern tip of Times Square as workmen continued the ear-splitting task of ripping up Forty-second Street, preparatory to its first real repaving in twenty years.
TOKYO, Sept. 25 -- The Japanese Government is contemplating a "second round" of dismissals of public employes, whose numbers are still held to be excessive, political sources said today.
PARAMUS, N. J., Sept. 25 -- This community, a borough of populous Bergen County harboring 4,800 inhabitants, was cited without pride today as being no place to become ill or to have a baby.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Sept. 25 -- An increasing tendency to divert freight from the rails to the highways was predicted at the fall meeting of the Felt Association over the week-end as the result of higher rates and other factors affecting railroad operations.

Whenever there is any let-down in the rate of business activity -- whether it be from a fairly normal level or from the high plateau of an unprecedented boom -- there is one phenomenon that can be depended upon with complete assurance to put in its appearance.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- The Soviet Union's possession of the atomic bomb will rob the North Atlantic Treaty of its efficacy for Europe, Gen. Charles de Gaulle declared in a speech today at Bordeaux.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 26 -- H. Beecher Jackson, 36-year-old pastor of the Thirteenth Avenue Presbyterian Church and one of this city's prominent Negro ministers, was booked for murder tonight in the ice-pick slaying last Friday night of Earl H. Wells, 70, sexton of the church and clerk of its board of trustees.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- The New York State Council of Machinists, representing forty-six lodges and six districts of the International Association of Machinists (Ind.), meeting in semi-annual convention here today, endorsed the candidacy of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for United States Senator on the Democratic ticket in November.

WANTAGH, L. I., Sept. 25 -- Thrown into the swift current of Jones Inlet, west of Jones Beach, today by the capsizing of their rowboat, a man, his wife, and 6-year-old son clung to a swaying buoy until a passing cabin cruiser rescued them.

Borough President Cornelius A. Hall of Richmond, who is running for re-election on the Republican and Democratic tickets, declared today his support for Mayor O'Dwyer as "the best Mayor this city ever had and the best friend Staten Island ever had."

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 25 -- Community leaders and other residents here expressed deep sympathy today for 20-year-old Carol Paight, who is held on a murder charge for the killing of her father, Police Sgt. Carl Paight, after learning that he had an inoperable cancer.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- As one early result of the devaluation of the pound, the price of Malayan tin went down today for United States buyers, but it went up for nearly everybody else, including the British.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Dr. Harold C. Urey, physicist, said today Russia's announcement that she had the atomic bomb secret in 1947 was "a bluff -- a date pulled from a hat."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- In a drifting match with breathless sails most of the time, Corny Shields today won the second International sloop race for the Haebler trophy in the post-season series being held at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Estimating that he would get at least 850,000 votes, enough to elect him, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that neither Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, nor his "Republican colleagues in political hypocrisy" would succeed in their scheme to avoid the real issues of the campaign by a lot of double talk about Labor party endorsements of Democratic and Republican candidates.

Joseph Erlichman of 598 Linwood Street, Brooklyn, was held without bail yesterday by Magistrate John E. Prendergast in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of kidnapping for a hearing in the same court today.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- A tendency was observed among British trade unionists today to ask for increases in the wages of lower paid workers rather than a blanket increase for all workers to compensate them for higher living costs resulting from the devaluation of the pound.

Your editorial of Sept. 16 dealing with Kashmir conveys the impression that whereas Pakistan has blithely agreed to the United Nations' terms of mediation it is India that is blocking a peaceful solution of that serious dispute.

The Yugoslav delegation to the United Nations has informed other delegations that it intends to run against the Soviet Union's candidate for a seat on the Security Council, and the election may be held at this afternoon's session of the General Assembly, it was learned last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Housewives in general will pay somewhat more for milk and dairy products this fall -- but the level will still be below that of a year ago, the Department of Agriculture said today.
TORONTO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- People of many faiths from two countries met today to mourn those who lost their lives in the burning of the steamship Noronic.

In a cash deal for occupancy by the new owner, the four-story store and apartment building on a lot 21.5 by 78 feet at 1554 York Avenue, northeast corner of East Eighty-second Street, has been purchased by Mrs. Lee Hyman through Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., brokers.

The Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig, minister of the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, warned in his morning sermon yesterday against loose moralizing about the fables and foibles of national leadership.

Religion should be used to promote social and economic progress, and particularly to get rid of war, declared John Haynes Holmes, retiring minister of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-Fifth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Soviet obstructionism and the urgent need for outlawing the atomic bomb were stressed last night by Lester B. Pearson, chairman of the United Nations General Assembly's Political Committee and chief of the Canadian delegation, in a broadcast made from here to the people of Canada.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Sept. 17 to 23 are given in the appended tabulation:
BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- A drive to organize every man who teaches in the schools of the state was announced tonight by J. Philip Gallivan of Medford, president of the Schoolmen of Massachusetts.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 25 -- Midwest Republican leaders are determined today to get a definite farm program and make a positive approach to the 1950 Congressional elections in a campaign to recapture the farm vote from the Democrats.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 -- Steel and coal contract negotiations will be resumed this week on a far-flung front amid general belief that they are entering the crucial week. The talks affect more than 1,000,000 workers in the nation's heavy industries.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday that no people in the history of man "have come so far on the road to understanding, citizenship and culture in eighty-five years as has the Negro race."

After long and careful preparation the preliminary steps in President Truman's Point Four program will go to the House of Representatives tomorrow. The President is right in not allowing this measure, already unanimously approved in principle by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, to go over to the next Congressional session and Congress will be right to give it prompt consideration and firm approval.

The first English version of any of the works of Ferdinand Raimund (1790-1836), Austrian playwright and actor, will be published on Oct. 6 by Frederick Unger Publishing Company. "The Spendthrift" (Der Verschwender), described as "a musical fairy tale in three acts," has been translated and adapted by Erwin Tramer.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in its week-end performances at the Metropolitan Opera House gave the season's first presentations of "Pas de Quatre," Ruthanna Boris' delightful little "Cirque de Deux," the divertissements from the last act of "Raymonda" and Fokine's "Igrouchki," which has been out of the repertory for several years.

HONG KONG, Sept. 25 -- Another obstacle was cleared yesterday for Chinese Communist troops on the desert road to Turkestan and the Soviet Union with the turnover of the City of Hami in Eastern Sinkiang to the Communist cause.
In a recent article on the negotiations over the government property at Manhattan Beach THE TIMES reported Park Department spokesmen as saying that the water there was not suitable for bathing.
Members of the Orthodox and Conservative branches of Judaism ended at sundown yesterday their observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, marking the New Year 5710 in the Hebrew calendar.

The following table shows capital expenditures since Jan. 1, 1946, for equipment and improvements of the municipal transit system, including those in progress for which financial commitments have already been made:

Judges are under the same obligations as any other citizen to testify in a criminal case concerning the character of the defendant or any other relevant fact of which they have knowledge, according to an interim report made yesterday to the New York Criminal Courts Bar Association by its committee on the code of ethics for the prosecution and defense of criminal cases.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- "The atomic bomb may well awaken man's ultimate despair because it seems to transfer responsibility for his fate from the hand of God into the hand of presumptuous man," the Rev. Martin J. Neeb told 4,000 Lutherans of the Metropolitan area at Concordia Collegiate Institute here today.

A new plan, aimed at breaking the big-power deadlock over atomic control, is now being drawn up by the Indian delegation for presentation to the United Nations General Assembly, Sir Benegal Rau, chief delegate, disclosed yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 -- Harry Brecheen pitched and batted the Cardinals to a 6-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs today in the finale of the 1949 home campaign before 30,943 fans.

The Quartermaster Corps Research and Development Branch announced over the week-end issuance of a new Textile Series Report, No. 56, "Summary of Specification Requirements for Quartermaster Textiles." Its purpose, it was said, is to assist the textile industry in meeting increased requirements for Army and Air Force textiles.

The West Penn Electric Company's offering of 856,895 shares of new common stock for subscription and exchange is now effective and will continue until Oct. 7. Of the total, 468,621 shares are being offered to common stockholders at 23 5/8 on the basis of one additional share for each five held.

Willis D. Gale has been elected to the new position of chairman of the finance committee, in both the Commonwealth Edison Company, and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois, it was announced yesterday, following meetings of the directors of the companies in Chicago.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The first wild rapture with which the stock market here hailed devaluation of the pound sterling was reminiscent of the abandonment of the gold standard exactly eighteen years earlier. It seemed to suggest that the mere trick of a stroke of the pen altering the exchange rate had produced a cure for all economic ills.

New Yorkers must hope that the projected Westchester County and Connecticut links of the New England Thruway, which eventually will carry high-speed traffic from New York City to New Haven, will soon be advanced to match the work that already is being done in the Bronx on the same improvement.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- United States aid in gifts and grants to foreign countries amounted to $5,169,000,000 in the fiscal year that ended last June 30, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Sharing occupancy of first place in the American League baseball race for the first time since last April 21, a tired but still confident Yankee team came back from Boston at 9:35 o'clock last night to a tumultuous reception in Grand Central Terminal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Prices of grains ranged lower on the Board of Trade last week on selling induced by devaluation of various foreign currencies, which brokers believe will result ultimately in decreasing the demand for American grains despite operations of the Marshall Plan funds.

With many orders canceled because of present unsettled currency valuations, barter transactions, particularly in chemicals, present an immediate and productive means of maintaining volume in international trade. This was declared over the week-end by Frederick W. Richmond, president of the United States Foreign Corporation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Liquidation was on in the lard market on the Board of Trade last week, with January and March deliveries selling at a new low for the year. The break came in the face of purchases of 3,500,000 pounds of cash lard by the Government, and the latter will take about the same amount this week.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Some observers here believed today that the chances far peace had been increased with Moscow's announcement that the Soviet Union had the atomic bomb. They said the United States and Russia could now meet on terms of equality.

The fares and service on the municipal transit lines were brought into sharper focus yesterday as issues in the city campaign. Mayor O'Dwyer made public a letter and report submitted by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, defending the higher rates and declaring that the city system "is in much better condition today and is giving better service than it was on Jan. 1, 1946."
GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears exploded three times in the final 17 minutes today to whip Green Bay, 17 -- 0, in a National Football League ga before 25,571 fans in City Stadium.
Eighty-seven German high school and college students arrived here yesterday for study in this country arranged by the Church of the Brethren. They came aboard the Army Transport Henry Gibbins.

MONTREAL, Sept. 25 (By Canadian Press) -- Despite devaluation of the Canadian dollar, the American publisher pays the same amount in United States funds for newsprint, R. M. Fowler, president of the Newsprint Association of Canada, said Saturday.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills handed the high-riding San Francisco Forty-niners their first defeat of the All-American Football Conference season, 28 -- 17, today before 32,097 spectators in Civic Stadium.

KANDY, Ceylon, Sept. 10 -- Although Colombo, the gay, bustling capital, is the spearpoint of newly free Ceylon's modest effort to edge into the company of larger nations, the heart and soul of the island dominion reposes some seventy miles away, in the cool upland city of Kandy.

The Presidential fact-finding board in the steel dispute has submitted its findings. It is now possible to gauge public reaction to this method of strike discouragement in labor-management-public disputes.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $53,242,416,531. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
RIDGEFIELD PARK, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Peace officers from four nearby communities were alerted today for possible violence tomorrow morning at the struck Continental Paper Company plant here.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The defending champion Cleveland Browns fought off a greatly revived Baltimore Colt eleven today, winning by a 28-20 score to stay unbeaten in the last twenty-eight games.

HONG KONG, Sept. 25 -- The National Government's finances are dwindling rapidly. Bankers here connected with the handling of the National Government's monetary affairs say that at the present rate of expenditure the entire Treasury resources in the gold, silver and foreign currencies that the Nationalists took out of Nanking and Shanghai will be exhausted within the year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A strong belief that the time is ripe for the United States, working through the United Nations to renew its efforts to obtain international atomic control came today in the wake of the knowledge that Russia, too, has the atomic bomb.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Psychologists at Princeton University and the Hanover Institute at Hanover, N. H., demonstrated today experiments in a unique Alice-in-Wonderland laboratory, designed for the study of the processes of perception, which they regard as a basic key to human behavior.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Delegates to the Fifty-sixth triennial convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in America registered today preparatory to opening their two-week meeting tomorrow. More than 10,000 bishops, priests and laymen were in attendance.
With the poet in mind, perhaps this report on the Dodgers and their almost extinct pennant chances should be entitled, "Elegy Written in a Brooklyn Ball Park."
WASHINGTON, Sept 25 -- Approval is expected soon by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development of a $10,000,000 loan to Britain for colonial development, it was learned tonight.
Seven new films, including importations from England, Italy and Sweden, are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Bob Lemon hurled his twenty-first victory today for the Indians, defeating the Tigers, 7 to 1, before a crowd of 33,977 in the team's final home stand. Lemon fanned eleven Tigers for a Cleveland high this season.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 25 -- Devaluation of the guilder is meeting a mixed reception in leading Netherlands banking quarters. The Government's decision to follow sterling threw plans regarding the Indonesian guilder out of gear as it had been the intention to read-just Dutch-Indonesian parities in the ratio of two Indonesian guilders for one Dutch guilder.

The new 16,500-ton Norwegian America liner Oslofjord is nearing completion in an Amsterdam shipyard and will make her trial run from the Netherlands port to Lands End in southern England on Oct. 14, the company announced here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Dick Weik's two-hit pitching gave the Senators a 4-0 second-game victory and an even split of today's double-header with Philadelphia. The nightcap was abbreviated to seven innings because of darkness.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Hannibal, Mo., got off to a fast start in the American Baseball Congress "world series" tonight by taking the opening game from Kalamazoo, Mich., 5 to 1.
CANTON, Monday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists began their long-awaited, large-scale invasion of Kwangtung today.
Last week's foreign exchange market was shaken to depths not plumbed in the international monetary history of this generation.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 25 -- Another week-end "double" went to Mrs. John G. Winant's Scottish terrier Champion Walsing Winning Trick of Edgerstoune today when the importation became best-in-show in the twenty-seventh all-breed event of the Westbury Kennel Association on Phipps Field.

Two hundred delegates to the United Nations General Assembly and members of their staffs attended a solemn pontifical mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning. They were told by Msgr. James H. Griffiths, chancellor of the Military Ordinariate of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, that they represented "the hope of the millions of little people of the world."

BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- The sinewy left arm of Mel Parnell, 27-year-old southpaw from New Orleans, reached out today to collar the faltering and battered Bombers and for the first time since the first two days of the American League pennant race, Casey Stengel's Yanks have been forced to share possession of first place.

From the New England specialty that it was thirty years ago, the doughnut has become a nationwide favorite, its production big business. Proof of this development is a new laboratory just opened by the Doughnut Corporation of America at 42 Stone Street.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, was assailed yesterday by Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic vice chairman of the City Council, as a person who displayed no interest in rent control for the benefit of tenants before becoming a mayoralty candidate.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 25 -- Forty-nine Metropolitan area pros, each playing with two partners, participated in a pro-member tournament at the Innis Arden Golf Club today. With a best-ball score of 32, 29 -- 61, 10 under par, a pair of younger competitors, Lloyd Wadkins, Quaker Ridge assistant, and William J. Kadlec, topped the field.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 25 -- Staging a second-half rush that produced seven goals, Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes, five-time winners of the national open title, captured the twenty-fourth Monty Waterbury Memorial handicap tournament today on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- The Wine Institute has begun a survey to determine effects of foreign currency devaluation on existing markets for California wines, with a view possibly of asking the Tariff Commission for greater protection for the American wine industry, it was disclosed today.
