DUBLIN, Sept. 25 -- Agreement is imminent tonight on the use of Dublin Airport by the transatlantic airlines of the United States. While the field originally was of commercial importance only, observers here now believe the agreement also involves conceptions of great strategic importance, since the revelation that the Soviet Union has the atomic bomb.

Harley - Davidson Motor Company, Milwaukee, manufacturer of motorcycles in the United States, is charged in a Federal Trade Commission complaint with monopolistic use of exclusive - dealing contracts, the commission announced over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Navy opened a week-long celebration today in paying tribute to the 150th birthday of the naval gun factory here, the world's largest naval armament plant.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Prompt aid in returning to civilian jobs the 12,000 reserve officers about to be released from the armed services was pledged today by the Department of Labor.

There are certain fashions that lend themselves admirably to town or country wear. They are for the women who divide their time between city and suburbs as well as for the ones who like to travel. In the styles selected for the home seamstress this week we have chosen a coat, a cape ensemble and a coat dress that will be as smart on the Avenue as they are in the station wagon.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, tonight headed into what was expected to be their last week of bargaining on a new contract that will include a pension plan for 115,000 Ford workers across the country.
Caesar G. Finn, 48-year-old composer-pianist, fell eight floors yesterday in the building where he lived at 135 Central Park West. He died in Roosevelt Hospital.

Municipal issues scheduled for sale this week aggregate $115,413,903, compared with $64,838,800 sold last week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The sharp increase is due principally to two state issues totaling $69,000,000. To date, the weekly average of offerings for the year stands at $66,610,982.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 25 (AP) -Ralph Kiner connected for his fifty-third home run of the season today, establishing a new National League mark and tying another, as the Pirates defeated the Reds in both ends of a twin bill, 7 -- 3 and 5 -- 3.
Caesar G. Finn, 48-year-old composer-pianist, fell eight floors yesterday in the building where he lived at 135 Central Park West. He died in Roosevelt Hospital.

Municipal issues scheduled for sale this week aggregate $115,413,903, compared with $64,838,800 sold last week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The sharp increase is due principally to two state issues totaling $69,000,000. To date, the weekly average of offerings for the year stands at $66,610,982.
LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A leading Yugoslav Communist asserted today that the Communist Information Bureau 'does not exist any more."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, won his second Western Amateur golf championship today, beating Walter Cisco of Louisville, Ky., 5 and 4, in the 36-hole final at Bellerive Country Club.

Buying was active in the wholesale garment market here last week, with demand centering on holiday lines and items for quick delivery, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Suits were in strong demand in the medium and better-price ranges. Owing to a shortage in some ready-to-wear lines, buyers gave a good share of their business to secondary sources, it was said.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- The newspaper Figaro will print in its issue of tomorrow what it presents as a detailed description of Atomgrad, said to be the place where the Soviet Union has produced the atomic bomb.
"People Like Us," the Frank Vosper melodrama co-starring Ann Dvorak and Sidney Blackmer, now is scheduled to open here on Oct. 25, instead of two nights later, as originally planned.
ZURICH, Sept. 25 -- Since the pound sterling was devalued last week, causing an avalanche of like currency moves all over the world, the Swiss franc has been under enormous pressure.

The days when the shelves of the linen closet held piles of dazzling white sheets and towels will soon be a thing of the past if manufacturers of bedroom and bath linens have their way. The pastel sheet and the Turkish towel in couturier colors have been around for years, but a brand-new note is a series of startling dark shades in sheets, blankets, quilts and towels.
LANSFORD, Pa., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Service was normal today on the Lehigh and New England Railroad after a twenty-hour stoppage of 200 conductors, firemen and engineers.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 -- That losing habit, cultivated in five exhibitions, still was with the New York Football Giants today at Forbes Field. This time, however, it really hurt, because the 28-7 defeat at the hands of the Pittsburgh Steelers was an official National League contest, the curtain-raiser for both clubs.

The time required to process and distribute food products is partly the reason why lower farm prices are not reflected immediately in lower retail grocery prices, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, explained yesterday.
The local art season continues to gather speed with nearly a score of shows opening this week. Among them is an exhibition of contemporary sculpture, European and American, at the Buchholz Gallery.

If one could imagine a cosmic scoreboard for the cold war with an umpire from Mars keeping a round-by-round account there is no doubt that he would have chalked up a winning mark for the Russians this past week. That atomic explosion in the Soviet Union was a punch that had been advertised but it would be silly to say that it did not hurt.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 25 -- Nationalist resistance in Ningsia, westernmost province of Inner Mongolia, appeared to be disintegrating today as the Peiping radio claimed the capital city and virtually all towns on the east bank of the Yellow River.

IF the club owners in the National Football League have been suffering from eyestrain for the past few years, it has been caused by their nervous searching for chinks in the All-America Conference armor. They just spotted another one the other day. Things can't be going too well with Baltimore. Cecil Isbell has just quit as the coach of the consistently beaten Colts.

Yugoslavia denounced the Soviet Union in the United Nations yesterday for systematically attempting to destroy her sovereignty. In a speech before the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow. Foreign Minister Edvard Kardelj delivered his country's first open attack in the international organization against a policy that he described as a threat to peace.

ST. LOUIS, Sept 26 -- With the well wishes of hundreds of ardent supporters ringing in their ears, the Cardinals entrained at 6:30 this evening for Pittsburgh quietly confident that they are on their last lap to their tenth National League pennant.

Gary Graffman, 20-year-old New York pianist, who was the runner-up in the Rachmaninoff Fund contest last year, has been declared the winner this year of the annual Edgar M. Leventritt Award, which carries with it a solo appearance with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony in February and engagements with the Cleveland Orchestra and the Buffalo Philharmonic.
Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris said yesterday that the Greek Army was a defensive unit and would not initiate attacks against forces across Greece's borders.

Harry Geiss, who for the last ten years has conducted his own men's pajama and shirt business, has joined the executive staff of Wilker Brothers Company, pajama and sportswear manufacturer of McKenzie, Tenn., with headquarters in the Empire State Building.

The average increase in movie admission prices is less than one-third of the 31.6 per cent rise in the general cost of living since September, 1945, according to figures compiled by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics and reported yesterday by the Motion Picture Association of America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- An examiner recommended today that the Civil Aeronautics Board find Seaboard and Western Airlines, Inc., guilty of violating regulations governing non-scheduled international air transport.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The full $1,314,010,000 Foreign Military Aid Bill passed by the Senate was accepted today by spokesmen for the House, which last month had approved only $869,505,000.

There are 15,000 Science Clubs with 250,000 members who are high school boys and girls. It was a happy thought of Dr. C. C. Little, director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory of Bar Harbor, Me., and of Watson Davis, director of Science Service and organizer of the clubs, to enlist these 250,000 eager students in the scientific campaign that has for its object the conquest of cancer.

This country might not be facing strikes in the steel and other industries if adequate social security benefits had been put into effect, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard told 200 unemployment officials yesterday. He was an opening-day speaker before the Interstate Conference of Employment Security Agencies at the Roosevelt Hotel.

The case for China against the Soviet Union has been completed and will be submitted for the agenda of the General Assembly of the United Nations today, according to well-informed sources at Flushing Meadow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Fullback Pat Harder scored 20 points and Charlie Trippi bolted to two touchdowns in a spectacular running display tonight to lead the Chicago Cardinals to a crushing 38-7 National Football League victory over the Washington Redskins.

MALONE, N, Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The president of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association said today that dairymen would have confidence in a new milk pricing formula only if it contained a cost-of-production index.

The three-story six-family apartment house at 559 Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Michael and Victoria Colavito from Stanley and Joanna Nalewayski. Carlo Colavito was attorney for the buyers and Philip Rosen acted for the sellers.

Young men join the Army and Air Force primarily for career and educational reasons, according to a recent three-day survey of 100 enlistees in the southern New York-New Jersey Recruiting District by military information specialists. A report of the survey was made public yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 26 -- Assurance that there would be no price increase for at least several years has resulted in reinstatement of virtually all of the many sizable orders for Scotch whisky that had been canceled when the British pound was devalued, Harry L. Lourie, Washington, D. C., told the National Alcoholic Beverage Control Association convention here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Six months of field tests should precede approval of color television for general public use, Donald G. Fink, chairman of the Radio Industry's Joint Technical Advisory Committee, told the Federal Communications Commission today as it opened hearings on whether color broadcasting was really ready.

The City Investing Company has purchased eighteen buildings, comprising virtually the entire block bounded by Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues and West Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, from Webb Knapp, Inc. Announcement of the sale was made yesterday by Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, and William Zeckendorf, president of Webb and Knapp.

The report to the Mayor by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, on operations of the New York City Transit System since Mr. O'Dwyer entered City Hall on Jan. 1, 1946, is the most important of the departmental reports issued in the election campaign.

Management must adopt the "individual approach in dealing with personnel despite entrenched strength of "power unions" claiming to represent workers as a bloc, Raymond S. Livingstone, vice president in charge of industrial relations, Thompson Products Company, Cleveland, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Equipped with appetites and notebooks, 110 newspaper food editors gathered here today in the nation's food capital for their sixth annual conference, held this year at the Drake Hotel.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 -- Not by denouncing socialized medicine but by offering a better solution will free enterprise in hospitals and medicine be preserved in this country, Senator Lister Hill, Democrat, of Alabama, warned today.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Britain's powerful shipbuilding industry, beset by rising costs and by an approaching saturation in world demand, is growing increasingly uneasy at United States efforts to let Germany and Japan rebuild their merchant fleets to preswar levels.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 -- A crowd of between 25,000 and 30,000 is expected to turn out for tomorrow night's game between the Cards and Pirates. The fans have a twofold interest: the Cardinals' struggle to incerase their game-and-a-half lead over the second-place Dodgers, and Ralph Kiner's efforts to tie or beat Hack Wilson's National League home-run record of 56.
ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Governor Dewey left by train tonight for Chicago, where on Wednesday he will become a thirty-third-degree Mason.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Polish Government says that it has been unable so far to throw any light on the mysterious disappearance of Hermann H. Field, Cleveland architect, presumably in Warsaw recently, the State Department reported today.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, announced yesterday that it would resume negotiations on Oct. 4 with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and not later than Oct. 12 with the General Electric Company.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 12 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 6 per cent.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 26 -Stocks of coal above ground in Belgium were reported today to have gone beyond 3,000,000 tons, pointing up a saturation in the coal industry that may threaten the life of the new Government, even if it survives Parliament's re-examination of the King Leopold question next month.

WAUREGAN, Conn., Sept. 26 -- For many years, Mr. Atwood conducted his business enterprises from an office in Providence. Until he became ill three weeks ago, he visited Providence weekly for meetings of the board of the Rhode Island Trust Company, of which he had been a member since 1908.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Within the next two days Britain expects to conclude a long-term trade agreement covering the exchange of more than 100,000,000 of goods over the next five years. Timber and timber products from Czechoslovakia and a short-term loan of sterling make up the essential parts of this latest bilateral trade agreement between Britain and one of Russia's satellites.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- The Tokyo Rose treason case went to the jury just before noon today. Eleven and one-half hours later, at 11:15 P. M., the jurors were escorted to a hotel to be locked up for the night. They were to return to their deliberations at 9 A. M. tomorrow.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 26 -- Greater Pittston, with a population of 75,000, was electrified last midnight when the bells of St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church began to toll.
BERLIN, Sept. 26 (AP) -- German scientists are producing for Russia trans-ocean rockets they designed for Hitler just before the war ended, Soviet zone informants said today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 26 -- Police Sgt. Carl Paight was buried this afternoon with military honors and tributes to his service to the community. His widow and son, Carl Jr., attended the services at the First Methodist Church and at the grave.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The British Cabinet met today and drafted a motion of confidence to submit to Parliament tomorrow. It was couched in such terms that only those who are willing to attack the policy of "full employment" openly or challenge the necessity of any devaluation can vote against it -- unless it is amended.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- With Congress still unsure of its adjournment date, President Truman began today to prepare for its next session in January. He asked all Government departments to tell him what problems they wished included in his State of the Union Message.

Pig lead prices were cut 3/8 cent a pound here yesterday by custom smelters but St. Joseph Lead Company held to a 15 1/8-cent price level, officials stated. This was the first reduction in lead since the advance to 15 1/8 cents a pound was posted on Aug. 18, when St. Joseph Lead Company raised prices to meet levels established earlier by custom smelter producers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe criticized delays in the Tucker Corporation's reorganization proceedings today as he deferred action nine days on a plan of the trustees to turn back operation of the company's big plant to the Government.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- Emphasis is upon the bustline in the important swim suit collections presented here. Suits are shown with built-in bras, or are boned, wired, or engineered without boning to provide stay-up security for the strapless suits, which predominate.

Brooklyn teen-agers in the Williamsburg area, who recently formed a group to make their neighborhood a better place to live in, put on display yesterday a series of photographs that document the problems they are trying to solve.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- The Christian church has failed to measure up to the spiritual standards of its early disciples and as a consequence has become little more than a "pale reflection of contemporary society," the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill. Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States of America, declared today.

There are only about 64,000 Navajo and Hopi Indians -- a small drop in this world's sea of troubled minorities. Yet they are Americans of great antiquity, their tribal ways are precious to them and interesting to the rest of us, and it is important that they should not be unjustly treated.

Soviet Russia will need at least ten years to mass-produce atom bombs on the scale now existing in the United States, it was said last night by Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, commanding general of the First Army and former Ambassador to the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -Dr. Hans Kindler, noted orchestra leader who died Aug. 30, recommended his soul "to the god of music" in his will, filed today in District Court.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Failure of the Federal Government to keep United States firemen informed on atomic bomb developments was criticized today by William Fitzgerald, chief of the Seattle Fire Department. He deplored the Government's "lack of foresight" in not inviting fire fighters to current atomic experiments at a New Mexico proving ground.

Excerpts from speeches before the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday by Dr. Edvard Kardelj, Yugoslav Foreign Minister, and Dr. Dmitri Z. Manuilsky, Foreign Minister of the Soviet Ukraine:

EAST PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, speaking here today at the ceremonies dedicating a new Allen B. DuMont television receiver assembly plant, declared that the DuMont plant re-emphasizes New Jersey's pioneering role in industrial research and development.

A luncheon in behalf of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York will be held on Oct. 13 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. John Henry Hammond heads the committee in charge of the arrangements.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26 -- Prison educational systems must be "insisted upon," not merely "tolerated," John C. Burke, warden of the Wisconsin State Prison at Waupun and president of the American Prison Association, asserted today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 26 (AP) -- There was a photo finish and an objection to enliven proceedings in the featured Bellmawr Purse today at the Atlantic City racetrack. Mrs. Edward De Camillis' Blue Fedora was victor in the six-furlong dash by three-quarters of a length.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -Representatives of the Lawyers Guild said after a Justice Department call today they did not believe the department would attempt to disbar attorneys who are Communists or "act like Communists."

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The political commentator for Pravda, official Communist newspaper, accused United States Secretary of State Dean Acheson today of a "monstrous distortion of facts" in blaming Russia for failure of the United Nations to institute atomic controls.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 26 -- The admission last week that South Africa had failed to obtain a dollar loan was followed today by an announcement that, under a new system of import control, raw materials and essential supplies from the United States would be cut by one-half of the present total during the first six months of next year.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin today signed into law a bill appropriating $60,000 for an anti-tuberculosis program which he said would "save the lives of thousands of Puerto Ricans in this generation.''
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly active at times yesterday but prices held within a narrow range and the close was steady, 5 to 17 points net higher.

The religious series entitled "Lamp Unto My Feet" will return to the CBS television network on Sunday from 4:30 to 5 P.M. The program, representing the Roman Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths, seeks to broaden the viewer's understanding of his own and other faiths through the experiences of children engaged in learning basic principles of their various religions.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged last night in a radio broadcast that Mayor O'Dwyer, his Democratic adversary, had "undermined civil service and prostituted the merit system for the benefit of politicians."

Nineteen units that may be combined in innumerable variations to make a sofa of any shape, even including one version that resembles a hairpin curve on a mountain road, may now be examined and experimented with at W. J. Sloane.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- The political ferment in Berlin is on the increase, keeping pace with the growing acuteness of the city's economic difficulties. Both sides of the East-West demarcation line are affected.

After a show of strength in the early dealings, the stock market yesterday turned easier and final prices were moderately lower. Losses, however, were small and only a comparatively few issues showed changes of a point or more.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 26 -- Moshe Piyade of the Yugoslav Politburo revealed today in Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, unpublished records of Yugoslavia's postwar relations with the Soviet Union and Hungary in connection with the recent Budapest spy trial.
SEATTLE, Sept. 26 -- An elaborate aerial defense system was disclosed today to be operating twenty-four hours a day in the Pacific Northwest.

The State of Virginia obtained financing through the sale of revenue bonds yesterday for the first river ferry and bridge improvement of its Highway Commission. It placed $19,000,000 of tax-exempt serial and term bonds maturing over twenty-four years with a group of investment bankers at an interest cost of 2.6553 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 -- Filmakers, Inc., the independent producing company organized by Collier Young, Ida Lupino (Mrs. Young) and Malvin Wald, has signed a deal with RKO for the distribution of three of the company's future pictures, RKO announced today.

Warren Wright's Calumet Farm stable, which hadn't been doing much since its recent arrival from Chicago, cut loose at Belmont Park yesterday and collected all the cash it went after. Four for four was Calumet's remarkable score. The net: $23,685.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A group of cotton men set out today to find out how to prevent any drop in exports of United States cotton as a result of the cut in the value of the British pound.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 26 -- The New Jersey Superior Court ruled today that bonds issued by the State Turnpike Authority would not be considered part of the public debt and that a public referendum to sanction such issues was not required.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Present Congressional attempts to plug the so-called loopholes in the Clayton Anti-Trust Act would empower the Federal Trade Commission "to put the entire national economy in a strait-jacket," Gilbert H. Montague, New York attorney, told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today.

An underwriting syndicate headed by the Stone Webster Securities Corporation and White, Weld Co. will place on the market today new issues of common and preferred stock of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company valued at $22,440,000.

If the original terms of the Social Security Law had been carried out we would not be in the present muddle over pensions for steel workers, because the federal fund by now would be paying adequate benefits.

Close cooperation between the Army Transportation Corps and the National Federation of American Shipping has resulted in the prompt booking of military cargoes on commercial vessels, according to an article to be published this week in The National Defense Transportation Journal.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Czechoslovak, Polish and Hungarian delegates to the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization failed to appear at commission or committee meetings today. It was understood, however, they would attend the plenary session tomorrow.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 11 -- This island still looks to the hurried observer like a British colony, with all that is good and bad in a colonial country. This does not bother the Ceylonese, who are happy to have obtained their political independence with exceptional speed and in a friendly atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Friday's announcement of the Russian atomic explosion has accelerated efforts of the United States Maritime Commission to get prompt passage of a bill permitting the Government to write war risk insurance on the country's merchant ships, it was learned tonight.

TOKYO, Sept. 26 -- Bankers here are protesting vigorously but probably ineffectually over Government plans to cut interest rates on loans. They complained bitterly when the rate was slashed on Sept. 1, from 10.2 to 9.85 per cent. The new proposal, they feel, would pauperize them with a mere 9.5 per cent.

With winter coming on, New York property owners were urged yesterday by William H. Byrne, director of the city's Smoke Control Bureau, to learn all they could about their heating plants and to make certain that the plants were operated as efficiently as possible through the cold weather.

The Yankees' pennant hopes suffered a devastating blow at the Stadium yesterday when the on-rushing Red Sox beat them, 7 to 6. Thus, for the first time this season the New Yorkers were out of first place, with the Boston contingent standing alone at the top of the American League, one full game ahead.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- A clash between the policies of a managed economy and the type of liberalism favored by Premier Henri Queuille broke out in an interministerial conference here tonight, with prospects for a stormy session at tomorrow's Cabinet meeting.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- Two young Americans, Warren Oelsner, 20, of Oyster Bay, N. Y., and Peter Sellers, 18, of Radnor, Pa., who have been held by Russian authorities in the Soviet zone of Germany since July 30, will be released Wednesday, the United States High Commissioner office announced today.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Federal Judge William C. Coleman said today that he will sign an order vacating an injunction which had blocked a stock-trading plan of Eastern States Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The Senate today voted $25,000,000 to patch up the Government's "mothball fleet" of merchant ships.

The announcement by the British Government last Sunday that it planned to end its monopoly in bulk dealings in tin raised the hope of commodity traders yesterday that a free market for tin would be possible here soon. Britain's Ministry of Supply had announced also a reduction of its tin price to 95 cents a pound from the previous pegged price of $1.03.

Rubber futures were up slightly in early trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday but a reaction later in the day deprived the market of gains registered during the morning. The market closed with September unchanged from Friday's close and more distant deliveries down 1 to 15 points.

The atomic explosion in Russia made many of us almost forget for a few days that there was an explosion of atomic proportions in the currencies of the world only a week ago. It was set off by the devaluation of the pound sterling from $4.03 to $2.80. Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, called that tune and today he and his Government are going to pay the piper in Parliament.

The Rev. Martin J. Scott, Jesuit author and educator, commemorated his sixty-fifth year as a member of the Jesuit order, his fiftieth as a priest and his twenty-fifth as a member of the faculty of St. Francis Xavier High School yesterday morning at a solemn high mass at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in his honor.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 26 -- The projected devaluation of the Deutsche mark has been delayed because of French economic security demands, it was reliably reported tonight. This was said to be the basis of discussions between United States High Commissioner McCloy, European Recovery Plan and French officials in Paris today.

Recently in THE TIMES there appeared an article concerning the number of vacancies in the nation's medical schools and the overwhelming number of applicants for these openings. I should like to indicate a relative problem which is a cause of sharp resentment on the part of the thousands of rejected applicants.

A fictionalized biography of Ignaz Philipp Semmelweis, the discoverer of the cause of childbed (puerperal) fever, will be published on Oct. 17 by Doubleday. "The Cry and the Covenant," by Morton Thompson, presents the story of the doctor who was derided and hounded by his contemporaries and about whom Lord Lister said: "Without Semmelweis my achievements would be nothing.
Both the Cardinals, who may have won the pennant, and the Dodgers, who may have blown it Sunday, had little to do yesterday save think about the immediate future, since both teams were idle.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement today on signing an extension of the reciprocal trade program:
Just as they sowed, so did they reap yesterday in the little garden behind Bellevue Hospital on Twenty-eighth Street fronting the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

" THE WITNESS,"* by the French writer Jean Bloch-Michel, is a brief, intense novel that recounts the effect of an act of cowardice on the life of a young man and that assumes the nature of a parable, for the act is revealed as symbolic of the way in which selfishness can get in the way of love and brotherhood.

Repaving of Forty-second Street from Second to Twelfth Avenues is 50 per cent completed and traffic has been maintained although it crawls at a snail's pace most of the time, a survey showed yesterday. The same traffic problem prevails at Columbus Circle, which also is undergoing a face-lifting job for a future speed-up of traffic.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Restrictive practices by labor are reducing potential British productivity just as price rigging by employers' associations is keeping prices at an artificially high level. Both contribute to the costs of production, which have sent wholesale prices up to 217 per cent of the 1938 level despite rationing, price controls and subsidies, compared with a rise of 155 per cent over 1937 in the United States where wartime controls have been abolished.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- About 100 delegates registered here today for the 124th annual New York State convention of Universalists, held at All Souls Universalist Church. More delegates would arrive tomorrow to remain until the final meeting, ending with a luncheon Wednesday noon, it was said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Reclamation Commissioner Michael W. Straus will be called before the Senate Interior Committee Oct. 11 to answer charges of incompetence and "politics" filed against him by Senator Sheridan Downey, Democrat, of California.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Referring to national policy-makers of the Republican party in recent years as "short-sighted little men," 450 leaders and members of the Westchester County Republican Committee adopted unanimously this afternoon a 2,000- word platform that demanded curbs on centralized government, "riotous spending" of the people's money, Federal "invasions" of states' rights and "unbridled meddling" in private business.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Guy G. Gabrielson, Republican National Chairman, today told 140 Cook County (Chicago) party leader that, although Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower could not accept his invitation to attend last week's GOP-sponsored farm conference in Sioux City, Iowa, "he wanted to leave one thought with me" in declining.

PITTSBURGH, Sept, 26 -- Gordon B. Washburn, widely known in the field of art museum administration and an expert on art as it affects civic and educational development, was chosen today to succeed Homer Saint-Gaudens as director of the Fine Arts Department of Carnegie Institute.

E. H. Van Ingen Co., Inc., importers and suppliers of British woolens to high grade merchant tailors and special order houses, have refigured prices on woolens in stock at $1 to $1.50 a yard lower than those prior to devaluation of the pound sterling, it was stated yesterday by Walter F. Sharot, president of the company.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- A leading French atomic physicist asserted today that France was not in position to compete with the Soviet Union and the United States and Britain in an atomic arms race, because of her limited industrial plant.

William N. Margolis, assistant director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, has been ordered to New York to enter stalemated negotiations for a new agreement between the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and Atlantic and Gulf Coast operators, it was announced yesterday.

A substantial decline in construction costs of state-aided public housing was reported yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner. Mr. Stichman said that analysis of bid received on Melrose Houses indicated a drop of 18 per cent in the last ten months.

A compromise proposal by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to help finance a social insurance program and enter into a joint study of pensions was rejected yesterday by the United Steelworkers of America, CIO.
The text of a speech delivered before the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday by British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin:
College training for men and women foremen and supervisors will be available under a new program that opens tonight at New York University's adult unit, the Division of General Education.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- March and May wheat sold at a new seasonal high on the Board of Trade today after the market had broken moderately in the early trading in sympathy with soybeans. There was no pressure on wheat after the initial selling and a strong rally got under way after midday and, with short buying freely, the close was about the top with gains of 3/8 to 1 3/8 cents on the day.

Bids requested on July 2 by the United States Maritime Commission for construction of two 18,000-gross-ton combination passenger and truck-trailer vessels for service on the West Coast were opened in Washington yesterday, the commission's office here reported.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- President Truman has altered the itinerary of his trip to Kansas City this week to include an overnight stop in St. Louis to install the officers of the Missouri Grand Lodge of Masons at mid-day Thursday. He is past Grand Master of the lodge.

PARIS, Sept 26 -- In a series of talks between John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, and French officials here today the problem of devaluation of the German mark was raised to a high political level on a plane of its effects upon European cooperation, and the fixing of the mark's new parity was again postponed.
A slim, sparkling-eyed girl from Flushing, Queens, was chosen yesterday as Eastern queen of the World's Championship Rodeo.

The Ethyl Corporation, manufacturer of gasoline anti-knock compounds, has taken a twenty-year lease of three floors in the thirty-six-story office building under construction at 100 Park Avenue. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., renting agents for the property, were the brokers in the transaction.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Two strikes that threatened to force Britain's car and radio manufacturers to exhibit their wares before foreign buyers without the usual stage setting and props seemed settled tonight. But another labor dispute of peculiar interest to London housewives entered its second week, making it likely that a good many butchers would have to offer their customers rabbits in place of the traditional weekly "joint."

Billy Rose acknowledged yesterday that booking contracts have been signed for the forthcoming musical version of the Anita Loos-John Emerson play, "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," to open at his theatre, the Ziegfeld, during the week of Dec. 5.

Campaign headquarters for former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, nominee of the Democratic and Liberal parties for United States Senator, were formally opened yesterday on the third floor of the office building at 383 Madison Avenue.

Again urging the creation of a transit authority, Paul Windels, former Corporation Counsel, sharply criticised yesterday the report on the operation of municipal transit lines made to Mayor O'Dwyer by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

A sharp increase in the number and total cost of orders placed annually by the Department of Purchase has occurred in the O'Dwyer administration, according to a report on the agency's activities made public yesterday by the Mayor.

Record attendance of more than 1,500 marked opening of the week- long annual Premiums and Advertising Specialties Exposition yesterday at the Seventy-first Regime Armory. The show is said to be the largest yet held. It is not open to the general public.

Israel will ask the United Nations General Assembly to limit international authority in Jerusalem to the actual protection of Holy Places, Aubrey S. Eban, head of the Israeli delegation, told the Assembly in general debate yesterday at Flushing Meadow.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- Today's contract negotiations between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, were delayed seven hours while both sides "reduced to writing" their positions on pensions, insurance and other issues.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 26 -The executive committee of the Syrian Palestine Refugee Organization today submitted in Damascus a new petition to the Syrian Government asking it to reject proposals of the United Nations Economic Survey Committee headed by Gordon R. Clapp.

Under Mayor O'Dwyer the cost of city government to the average New York family has increased by $160 a year, and a disproportionate share of this rise has been saddled on small wage-earners, Paul L. Ross, the American Labor candidate for City Controller, asserted last night in a radio broadcast.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 26 -- The gap between Yugoslavia and the rest of Communist-dominated Eastern Europe widened tonight as Hungary gave ten members of the Yugoslav Legation twenty-four hours to get out of the country.

The resignation of Health Commissioner Mustard after two years in city service is a loss to the city. He has ably administered a large department. He led no headline-snatching crusades, but worked quietly and conscientiously. In a department of more than 4,000 employes, with a budget of almost $14,000,000 a year, an executive of broad and diverse qualifications is required.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- President Truman accepted today the credentials of Ion Mihail Magheru, new Rumanian Minister to the United States, with a pointed reference to the envoy's statement that he came to this country to "foster good relations" between the peoples of Rumania and the United States.

Umpire Bill Grieve said last night he would file a report with Will Harridge, American League president, because of a remark made to the arbiter by Cliff Mapes, Yankee outfielder, during yesterday's 7-6 defeat of the Bombers by the Red Sox.

Britain, the United States and the Netherlands agreed last night to ask the United Nations General Assembly to allow member Governments to immediately sign and ratify the international treaty on news-gathering, completed by the Assembly in 1948.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein granted a motion by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein yesterday to restrain The Jewish Consumptives Relief Society near Denver from soliciting in New York State, the court holding that the society was not legally authorized to do so.

The seventh biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, came to an abrupt end yesterday afternoon with the forces of Joseph Curran, union president, more firmly in control than ever, having scored a final victory over the opposition on the last proposal to reach the convention floor.

The decorating problems faced by homemakers who live in the suburbs will be put before a panel of nine home furnishings authorities in a three-day Home Fashions Forum opening tonight at the J Bergen County Junior College of Teaneck, N. J.
The Manati Sugar Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $854,452 for the fiscal year ended with last June.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Following is the letter President Truman sent to Vice President Barkley today about legislation to increase the pay of Cabinet officers and other top Government officials.

Your editorial of Sept. 17 "Platform for Transit" recognizes that we are confronted with accumulated neglect in the upkeep of the subways. It is the one part of a transit program which may no longer safely be neglected. Twice within a recent week serious accidents were narrowly averted.

Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, announced yesterday that Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier" would be the work performed on the opera's opening night on Nov. 21. It will be the first occasion on which the opera has been used to launch the season.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 -- Guy A. Thompson, trustee for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, accused officers of four striking railway brotherhoods today of trying "to expand the practice of featherbedding already so prevalent in the railroad industry."

Dr. Harry S. Mustard announced yesterday that he would resign as this city's Commissioner of Health by the end of the year to become executive director of the State Charities Aid Association, a private health and welfare agency.

I think your editorial criticizing Mr. Murray, head of the United Steel Workers, on his position in the steel wage negotiations is unfair to a responsible union head. Mr. Murray has dropped his demand for a steel wage increase, although the current profits of the steel industry are such that they could well afford to pay it, but the representatives of the steel companies have made no similar concessions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 26 -- District Court Judge Richard S. Mischlich today returned possession of the fire-ruined Million-Dollar Pier on the Boardwalk to its owners, the Associated Realty Corporation of Philadelphia.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 -- With only four days of negotiation left before the Friday midnight strike deadline, talks between the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, and the country's largest steel companies bogged down anew tonight.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Two hundred and fifty striking Congress of Industrial Organizations workers of the Continental Paper Company here formed mass picket lines this morning at the common entrance to their plant and the adjoining subsidiary, Alford Cartons Company plant, prepared to prevent Continental supervisory employes and Alford American Federation of Labor workers who are not on strike from entering their respective plants.

Prospects are growing brighter for a much better waterfowl season than last year, and the latest report from Ducks Unlimited indicates that Western Canada, the great nesting and breeding grounds, shows a definite increase in duck numbers.

Price spurts, which carried five issues of Brazil's Sao Paulo dollar bonds upward 2 to 13 points yesterday, were linked in foreign bond circles with buying in anticipation of repatriation of bonds for the sinking fund. The City of Sao Paulo 6 1/2s of 1957 moved up 13 points to 66, and the State of Sao Paulo 8s of 1950 rose 4 points to 90.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 26 -- A year ago Brown University enjoyed its best football season since 1932, with a record of seven victories in nine games.

The Democratic party organizations have forwarded to President Truman their recommendations for appointments to the four new Federal District Court judgeships created for the Southern District of New York by Congress, it was learned yesterday.
Dingle-Single likes to take a nip, now and then, of strangers. He tolerates little petting except from Paul Sydell, the actor who trained him to balance like a toe dancer.

John Lasak, star right halfback of City College, was found dead at 7:55 A. M. yesterday in Army Hall, a college dormitory. The 21-year-old Long Island City, Queens, youth had scored three touchdowns in City's 59 to 0 victory over Susquehanna University in Lewisohn Stadium last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company, Rock Island, Ill., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due Oct. 1, 1979, that are to be sold at competitive bidding.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Apart from considerable activity in gold mining shares, most sections of the stock market were quiet here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- By an apparently unanimous voice vote, the Senate passed and sent to conference with the House today the long-contested military pay bill. It would authorize some $300,000,000 of annual increases throughout the armed and affiliated services.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -The Government estimated today that it lost $600,000,000 supporting the prices of farm food and fiber products during the year ending last June 30.

CANTON, China, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A new Communist drive advanced today to within about ninety miles of this uneasy capital. Official dispatches said three Communist armies, possibly numbering 75,000 men, had penetrated Canton's Kwangtung Province on the northeast.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 26 -- The Rev. H. Beecher Jackson, 37-year-old pastor of the Thirteenth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Thirteenth Avenue and Boston Street, who the Newark police said confessed yesterday to the ice-pick slaying of the church's sexton in the minister's study Friday night, today pleaded not guilty to a murder charge in the Fourth Precinct Court here.

ROME, Sept. 26 -- The essential rights of man are so inviolable that against them no reason of state, no pretext of the common welfare can prevail, Pope Pius XII said yesterday in speaking to members of the International Congress of Humanistic Studies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A saving of $1,000,000 a day in New York by reduction of travel congestion within the next three years was forecast today by T. T. Wiley, director of that city's department of traffic engineering. An over-all plan for changing maladjusted traffic flow, parking and loading periods would be presented next month to the New York City Traffic Commission, he added.

DENVER, Sept. 26 -- Henry M. Blackmer, who returned recently from a 25-year European exile to face income tax evasion charges, pleaded guilty to these charges in the Federal District Court here today, but must wait thirty days for disposition of his twenty-two-year-old case.

Paris came to Broadway yesterday. With an amusing twist of the imagination, Macy's transported the atmosphere of the famous old city to three store windows for the opening of its colorful Accessory Bazaar. Here against a background of facades of "Les Boutiques," the little French shops, were exciting displays of original imports and adaptations of French gloves, umbrellas, jewelry, blouses, scarfs, belts, bags and perfume.
Magdalena Berziger, 22-year-old daughter of a prominent Swiss publisher, was taken to Bellevue Hospital in a serious condition after an unexplained suicide attempt early yesterday afternoon.

Marjorie Garrigue, pianist and wife of Fred Smith, director of the Cincinnati College of Music, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. It was her first appearance here since her debut at the same auditorium fourteen years ago.

An anti-cold tablet, in which a new anti-allergy drug is added to aspirin and other compounds generally prescribed for colds, has resulted in "aborting" all symptons within twenty-four hours in 90 percent of the victims taking the tablet within the first hour of onset, according to a report in the United States Naval Medical Bulletin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The disclosure that Russia has atomic weapons has increased the importance of current atomic energy talks with British and Canadian representatives and will probably put the conferences on a "continuing'' basis, James E. Webb, Acting Secretary of State, said today.

It was on a recent trip to Maine that a friend of this column first became aware of the lure of license plates. The assistant driver, who is also Lady of the House at home, suggested, "Let's see how many different state and foreign licenses we can count.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26 -- Although the liquor industry in Continued From Page this eotmtry is a nine billion dollar business from the point of view of capital worth, Vice Adnral F. E. M. Whiting, IISN (Ret.) of New York, president of the Licensed Beverage Industries, said today that the American people do not think of the industry as one of the most vital factors in American industry, which it is.

After bitterly attacking the Soviet Union for refusing to render "any genuine cooperation" with the Western powers since the war, British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin told the General Assembly yesterday that "notwithstanding all our disappointments, the United Nations has performed a great task."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Treasury announced today acceptance of tenders for $901,592,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills, to be dated Sept. 29 and to mature Dec. 29, which were offered on Sept. 23.

Teachers in the city's public schools take special care to explain to their students that the characters in Charles Dickens' "Oliver Twist" and Shakespeare's "The Merchant of Venice" are not "typical'' of any nation or race, it was brought out yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

THE Yankees were great when they had it. In fact, they were just as great and just gallant at the Stadium yesterday when they didn't have it. The "it," of course, is the lead in the American League pennant race. The dispossess notice arrived for that swank penthouse apartment in which they had been residing in unexpected luxury ever since April 19.

A charge of conspiracy to violate the Gold Reserve Act of 1934 was returned yesterday in a Federal Grand Jury indictment against Nicholas Briglia, 45 years old of 121 Primrose Avenue, Mount Vernon, N. Y., and Carl Cappiello, 49, of 39 Essex Street, Brooklyn.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 -- Extra details of state police were rushed into Clearfield County tonight as some nonunion mine operators in Western Pennsylvania announced their intention of attempting to reopen their mines tomorrow. The mines were closed by roving bands of pickets a week ago when the 480,000 members of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers went on strike.

The twenty-first annual survey of advertising course, sponsored by the Advertising Women of New York, Inc., will open, the evening of Oct. 3, at the Astor Hotel. Registration for the course may be made tomorrow between 5:45 and 8:30 P. M. at the Astor; by mail to the Advertising Women's Club, 1233 Sixth Avenue; or on. Oct. 3, immediately preceding the opening of the course.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- Exhibits purporting to show that banks in which Transamerica Corporation holds a majority of stock are primarily service institutions were introduced today by the defense at the Federal Reserve Board hearing in its monopoly case against Transamerica.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Despite a setback in its curtain-raiser of the season last Saturday, Lawrenceville School's football forces entertain high hopes of whipping into shape for the more important battles that lie ahead.

Deep in the catacombs of the Stadium, completely hidden from the eyes and ears of the 66,156 fans, who were on hand for yesterday's pulse-stopping crucial struggle between the Yankees and Red Sox, the Yankees really let loose. In a brief but breezy encounter that was quickly broken up. Plate Umpire Bill Grieve and Cliff Mapes of the losers had to be restrained from ripping into each other immediately after the ball game.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 26 (UP) -- A Mexican airline plane with twenty- three persons aboard, including possibly two United States citizens and a high Mexican Government official, was believed tonight to have crashed into snow-capped Popoctaepetl volcano, forty-five miles southeast of here.

ABOARD THE CARRIER FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT, Sept. 26 -- The Navy took the Army and Air Force out to blue water today, and beyond the fifty-fathom curve off the Virginia capes demonstrated the technique of aircraft carrier operations for the benefit of Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, and all the principal service chiefs.

Frederick Loeser offered its Brooklyn customers a review of fall fashions yesterday afternoon at the Hotel St. George. The show included most of the top style notes of the season, including those from the recent Paris openings.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Declaring himself in favor of both the power and seaway development of the St. Lawrence River, Senator John Foster Dulles charged today that the Democratic Administration in Washington had sidetracked the project for political reasons.

TOKYO, Sept. 26 -- Japanese sources today suggested that the time had now come for a personal meeting between President Truman and Premier Stalin in an attempt to reach a compromise in an international situation that appeared to be headed toward a third world war.

Mutual recriminations between Russia and the Western powers at yesterday's session of the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow re-emphasized the conflict over control of atomic energy, as each side blamed the other for the threat of an atomic arms race.

The Foreign Ministers of the Big Four powers met for more than three hours last night at the Waldorf-Astoria but were unable to break the deadlock over the treaty of Austrian independence. They are expected to meet again tomorrow night, it was announced

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the concert by the United States Army Ground Forces Symphonic Band of Washington, to be given Friday night in Carnegie Hall, for the benefit of the New York City Cancer Committee. Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick heads the committee for the concert.

The Public Service Commission has denied a petition by the New York Central Railroad for a rehearing of the commission's recent order requiring the railroad to continue operation of two passenger trains on its West Shore Division between Albany and Weehawken, N. J.

A thirteen-state police alarm for the arrest of Stanley Ondahl, 26 years old, of 742 Fifty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, was sent out yesterday after the South Brooklyn Savings Bank, 6424 Eighteenth Avenue, found that $10,000 to $11,000 in cash was missing.

New York has two visitors, both originally from the Philippines, who are devoted to a great cause, the getting of a better understanding of Hansen's disease, or leprosy, and the changing of the public attitude toward those who have contracted it. Major Hornbostel and his wife, the latter recently released from the government hospital at Carville, La., have come to the metropolitan area to live.

Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, said last night it would be better to have no control of the atom than an ineffective control that would "set up a Maginot line behind which civilization in the United States would rest in a false security."

Seventeen prize-winning pictures were chosen from the 3,000 works on exhibition in the Thirty-sixth Semi-annual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit, it was announced yesterday. The selections included first, second and third prizes in several categories, and a number of honorable mentions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, designed to harmonize international trade relations in the cause of world peace and prosperity, became law today and President Truman hailed it as a reaffirmation of our live-and-let-live policy.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- In preparation for its first commencement tomorrow night, the experimentally operated New York State Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences here was taking inventory today of its standing as a technological unit of the expanding state institutions of higher education.
Offered as a factor to help relieve traffic and parking congestion in this city, a Crosley taxicab was shown yesterday at Fine Cars, Inc., Crosley car distributor, 429 East Seventy-fourth Street.

Variations of the fretwork motif, cut-out designs of oriental derivation and heavy dull brass hardware in the shape of Chinese symbols are among characteristic adaptations of Far East design to be found on several contemporary translations from the Chinese.

Why should we be so startled at the news that Russia now has the atomic bomb? Scientific achievement is not a monopoly, and it is possible that other countries in addition to Russia have the know-how or soon will have. The only bad thing is the armament race that is going on by both the West and the East, which, if not controlled, may lead to the destruction of civilization.

Former Secretary of State Cordell Hull will be 78 years old next Sunday. He may have felt that yesterday was a sort of pre-birthday celebration as he watched President Truman sign the bill extending the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for another three years. Reciprocity, which used to be a Republican baby, has been a Democratic baby since 1933, and its establishment and continuance have been the crowning achievement of Mr. Hull's career.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 -- The American people should study the British health program "not as a thing to be feared, but as a test-tube experiment, from which they may at least learn what not to do."

Your issue of Sept. 9 contained a report by William M. Blair dealing with the resolution adopted by the American Bar Association on the Genocide Convention. According to that report, the association's House of Delegates disapproved of the Genocide Convention because it involves vital constitutional questions, including "international tribunals, which might supersede American courts and endanger the self-governing power of American states."

A young "two-gun" robber held up a Fifth Avenue sporting equipment store last night one minute before closing time and escaped with five more pistols and a revolver. The day's receipts had been locked up just before his entry.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 27 -- Four veterans of the Confederate Army met here today for the opening session of the fifty-ninth annual reunion of the United Confederate Veterans. The reunion is to be the next to last meeting of the organization.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 -- The Tokyo Rose jury was deadlocked tonight, about thirty-four hours after receiving the treason case in Federal Court, but Judge Michael J. Roche instructed the members, as "reasonable" men and women, to retire for the night and try again tomorrow to reach a verdict.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- James B. Carey, right-wing leader of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, declared today that local unions had begun to repudiate the actions of the union's "Communist-minded misleaders" at last week's international union convention.

State employment security officials, who for years have been trying to get from the Federal Government "more adequate" refunds of locally collected taxes for administrative expenses, received support yesterday from a Federal official.

Stockholders of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, at a meeting yesterday, voted favorably on a proposal to change the beginning of their fiscal year from June 1 to Sept. 1. The reason for the change, directors said, was to enable them to consider a summer dividend on the basis of a full year of operations.
Oscar Tschirky, otherwise Oscar of the Waldorf, will mark his eighty-third birthday quietly today at his Swiss chalet at New Paltz, N. Y.

Advertising, sales and promotion representatives of grocery and tobacco concerns brought registration over the 3,000 mark yesterday afternoon during the second day of the week - long annual Premiums and Advertising Specialties Exposition in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 27 -- Forestry camps are successfully rehabilitating delinquent boys in Los Angeles County (California), John M. Zuck, Los Angeles probation officer, reported today to the American Prison Association's Congress of Correction.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- One of the most important measures yet taken by any country to liberalize trade in post-war Europe became effective in Italy today. The official gazette published a decree abolishing import licenses and all other quantitative restrictions upon important groups of imports from the other Marshall Plan countries.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 27 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said here today that labor had been required to invade the political field because "we had found that we can win strikes but we still have to win political battles."
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 27 -- The General Assembly's Social Committee voted tonight to shelve the United Nations' proposed worldwide treaty on freedom of information.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 (AP) -- S. A. Horvitz, publisher of The Lorain Journal, said today the Government's anti-trust suit against the paper constitutes a "threat to the rights of every newspaper and publication in the United States." He added:

The big tuna seem to have been moving northward in real numbers, but apparently they are pausing a while off Wedgeport, Nova Scotia, for this fishing port has been breaking its own records every day since Thursday.

Two new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Paramount, the attraction is "My Friend Irma," an adaptation of the radio program produced by Hal Wallis and featuring Marie Wilson, in the title role; Diana Lynn, John Lund, Don DeFore and the comedy team of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 27 -- The Yugoslav Government ordered nine officials and employes of the Hungarian legation in Belgrade today to leave Yugoslavia within twenty-four hours.

Employment of Negroes in jobs utilizing their highest skills would add $6,000,000,000 to the buying power of the people of the United States, John E. O'Gara, vice president and general manager, Macy's of New York, declared yesterday. He spoke before second-day sessions of the American Management Association's three-day personnel conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Department of Public Works reached some sort of milestone in its efforts to carry out New York City's vast program for cleaning up the waters of New York Harbor when it opened bids aggregating $6,729,518 for advancing the construction of the new $22,500,000 Owl's Head Sewage Treatment Works on Brooklyn's south shore.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 -- Dr. Glen Shortliffe, a Canadian Socialist, has been barred from entering the United States to accept a post at Washington University here, it was learned today.

Units of the Atlantic Fleet and of the Fleet Marine Force are preparing at Norfolk, Va., and other East Coast ports for cold-weather exercises in October in Davis Strait, between Baffin Island and Greenland, and on the Labrador coast.

The O'Dwyer campaign headquarters at the Commodore Hotel announced yesterday the formation of a Liberal party committee supporting Mayor O'Dwyer and his running-mates, Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri and Controller Lazarus Joseph, for reelection.

There is no way to appraise, or fully appreciate, the United States Navy of modern times without watching the aircraft carrier in action at sea. Secretary of Defense Johnson has now done so, and he took along the Army and the Air Force as part of his "psychological unification" program.

It looks like a peach of a plum crop this year. Latest estimates by the Department of Agriculture for California, producer of 95 per cent of the country's plums, place the 1949 crop two-fifths above last year's and a quarter above the ten-year average. From now till the end of October the Pacific cascade will rise to crescendo.

A 30 per cent reduction in round trip fares on ten United States and foreign-flag airlines flying the Atlantic has been granted by the Civil Aeronautics Board and will go into effect Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday.

It cost the Yankees $500 in fines yesterday for their part in Monday's tempestuous session at the Stadium when Catcher Ralph Houk led a vehement protest against Umpire Bill Grieve's decision calling Johnny Pesky safe at the plate on a squeeze bunt by Bobby Doerr.

Pessimism over Britain's ability to hold the line against inflation was general in financial circles here last night following yesterday's statement by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the House of Commons.

WESTBURY, L. I. Sept. 27 -- Mrs. Arthur K. Atkinson Jr. of The Creek fired a 41, 37 -- 78 to take a one-stroke lead as the fifteenth annual Women's Long Island Golf Association three-day medal play championship opened on the Meadow Brook Club course today.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- British business men who have been told to get out and earn more dollars were astonished today to hear, even before they had started, that any extra profits they might earn would be taken by taxes.

The chairmanship of Manhattan and the Bronx in the Red Cross 1950 Fund campaign has been accepted by William H. Draper Jr., former Under-Secretary of War and vice president of Dillon, Read Co., it was announced yesterday by Colby M. Chester, chairman of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 -- Bernard J. Ridder, editor and publisher of The Journal of Commerce, New York City, said today there was only one real danger in the economic outlook for the next year or so and that was "a serious drop in industry's private capital expenditure."

A construction loan of $1,083,600 has been granted by the Bank of the Manhattan Company to the Grassy Sprain Village, Inc., on the seven two-story apartment structures being built at the southwest corner of Tuckahoe Road and the Catskill Aqueduct, in Yonkers, N. Y. The development will have 124 suites and a garage providing for seventy-four cars. Occupancy of the apartments is expected about Dec. 15.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Migrant farm workers, who make up about one-fifth of the agricultural labor force of the United States, now number almost 900,000, an increase of more than 40 per cent since the end of World War II.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- President Truman, who early this month said that the 1950 campaign started the day after Labor Day, put the stumping spirit into a speech today defending the welfare state. The occasion was the annual celebration of Democratic Women's Day.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 27 -- The United States will vote in favor of Yugoslavia's candidacy for a place on the Security Council, a delegation source disclosed today. Under an informal agreement reached by the great powers in London in January, 1946, when the United Nations was being set up, the place on the Council was allocated to an Eastern European country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Raymond C. Cosgrove, president of the Radio Manufacturer's Association, said today that the nation's set makers eventually hoped to come up with a color television set that would sell for only $49.95.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Four anti-American and anti-British propaganda films produced by the Nazis during the early part of the war have been shown in Soviet movie theatres in Moscow and the provinces throughout the summer, according to reports received at the British Foreign Office tonight.

While opinions may have differed over the desirability of Britain's recent devaluation of the pound, there was almost complete unanimity on one point. It was generally agreed that this bold move would be worse than wasted unless the Labor Government were prepared to take the necessary steps to validate the new exchange rate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Russia's possession of an atomic weapon may require expansion of this country's Atomic Energy program, but the limited supply of uranium ore currently is a major obstacle, it was indicated today.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,629, compared with 2,372 last week and 1,884 in the similar week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 736 arrivals yesterday, against 948 on the preceding Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- By a vote of 332 to 2, the House today granted pay increases, extended vacations, sick leaves and allowances for uniforms to postal employes, that, taken in their sum, will add $180,000,000 a year to the cost of operating the Post Office Department.

Three members of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee returned on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary yesterday convinced that socialized medicine was "not working well in Europe," and reiterated their opposition to President Truman's proposed national health insurance program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today rejected, in the public interest, a proposal for altering its rules on safety for trucks and buses so that amputees might drive such vehicles.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 27 -- The United States Government has rejected a Belgian request to include displaced persons working in this country among the categories of those eligible to emigrate to America.

When Ford Frick, National League president, ordered tomorrow's regularly scheduled game between the Cardinals and Pirates at Pittsburgh to be played today, the move apparently was accepted as a precaution to insure that no important game be washed out in such a tight pennant race

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 27 -- A spokesman for the Israeli delegation to the United Nations emphasized today that it would ask the General Assembly to limit international authority in Jerusalem to the actual protection of the holy places. Holy places outside Jerusalem also should be under the jurisdiction of the international authority, he explained.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- The United States Senior Women's Golf Association opened its twenty-fourth championship with a preliminary Scotch foursome, in which thirty-seven teams competed over the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.

MADRID, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Spanish stockholders in a $200,000,000 international public utilities firm incorporated in Spain voted confidence today in their Government to defend their interests against foreign efforts to dissolve the company.

Conforming to proclamations by President Truman and Governor Dewey, New York will join the rest of the country in observing Fire Prevention Week from Oct. 9 to Oct. 15, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle announced yesterday.

There is nothing like an atomic explosion to open all our eyes to the hard realities of international life. It may be doing Representatives in Congress an injustice to say that they rose to the occasion on the spectacular mushrooming of an atomic release.

Wesley F. French, general statistician for the New York Central Railroad, was asked yesterday by Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright if he thought the people of New York State should be made to defray revenue losses incurred by the Central outside the state.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Federal Trade Commission dismissed without prejudice today thirty-three complaints in which manufacturers of candy and confections were charged separately with practices violating the Robinson-Patman Anti-Discrimination Act.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 -- The Anglican Communion was envisaged here today by the Most Rev. Cyril Forster Garbett, Archbishop of York, as the logical vehicle for the ultimate reunion of all of Christendom.

Accepting the chairmanship of Brotherhood Week, to be observed nationally from Feb. 19 to 26 under the sponsorship of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, former Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan declared yesterday that "the big question today is whether the human spirit will remain free or whether it is to be enslaved by totalitarianism."
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Pending the outcome of the parliamentary debate on devaluation, buyers marked time in the stock market here today.

For home handymen who like to putter, but want to be assured that what their efforts produce will be useful, knockdown furniture appears to be a solution. It comes unassembled, usually with simple directions, and may be easily put together by an amateur.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Irving David Fox, a former atomic researcher, refused to tell Congressional spy hunters today whether he was a Communist when he did wartime work in the University of California's radiation laboratory.

One of the largest single transactions of recent years in a commodity futures market was concluded yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, by the posting of contracts representing 103,000 tons of No. 6 raw sugar against actuals.

By acclamation, John Chapman of The Daily News yesterday was elected to the presidency of the New York Drama Critics Circle. Twenty-one of the Circle's membership of twenty-seven were present at the annual meeting held at the Hotel Algonquin. Other officials, all incumbents, were chosen for another term.
DUBLIN, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Two United States daughters of one of Ireland's fighting patriots. Diarmuid O'Donovan Rossa, are the toast of Dublin tonight.
The purchase of three players from minor league affiliates and the sale of three other players carried on their roster were announced yesterday by the Giants, through Secretary Edward T. Brannick.

NETCONG, N. J., Sept. 27 -- The police here said today that they had seized thirty-two ancient castiron pistols and 204 'live .22 caliber cartridges since last Saturday from elementary school boys in this community.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- United States Air Force observers who had been watching Britain's four-day air maneuvers highly praised today the Royal Air Force fighter defenses and particularly the quality of the fighter pilots. One United States veteran of World War II said the British fighter pilots were "as good as any in the world."

Lives of great men used to remind us that of making statues there was no end -- which was good for the marble cutters and the bronze casters. The fashion has so far fallen out of favor that sculptors engaged in this employment have been hard put to find the jobs that once came easiest.

ATHENS, Sept. 27 -- Constantine Rentis, Minister of Public Order, said today that according to security intelligence the Communists were planning another round in their fight against the Greek state. The new struggle, he said, will find expression in "terrorism as has been the case in Palestine, acts of sabotage and murder."

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 27 -- Dmitri Z. Manuilsky, Ukraine Foreign Minister, charged in the United Nations Security Council today that the United States was deliberately obstructing a settlement of the Indonesian conflict.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 27 -- Prohibition forces tonight won their battle to keep Oklahoma legally dry. Returns from 3,545 out of 3,720 precincts in a special state repeal election gave these totals:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 27 -- In reply to charges reported to emanate from Rev. Brother Raphael Quinn of Montreal, secretary to the Roman Catholic Custodian of Holy Places, that Israeli forces were responsible for bombing and destruction of shrines in Jerusalem, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs tonight issued a categorical denial.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 12 -- Ceylon chooses to remain more closely tied to Britain, which freed the island from colonial rule eighteen months ago, than her powerful neighbors in the British Commonwealth of Nations, India and Pakistan.

PITTSBURGH, Wednesday, Sept. 28 -- The United States Steel Corporation offered late last night to meet the 10-cent pension and welfare "package" recommended by President Truman's steel fact-finding board, but it demanded that its 170,000 workers make an additional contribution from their own pay checks.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 27 -- The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today unanimously elected Prince Wan Waithayakon of Thailand as vice chairman and approved its four-item agenda as submitted by the Assembly.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Government today filed a civil suit designed to restore price competition among wholesalers of plumbing supplies in Northern California. Defendants include the Northern California Plumbing and Heating Wholesalers Association, Inc., and 16 member companies.

C. J. Devine Co. and associates bought yesterday $1,100,000 of bonds of Central School District No. 4, New Castle and Mount Pleasant, N. Y. The bonds will come due Oct. 15, 1950 to 1974. The price paid by the bankers was 100.65 for interest of 2.20 per cent.
Attorneys for The Nation filed three petitions yesterday in an effort to upset the rulings of educational authorties banning the magazine from the libraries of public schools here.

MASSENA, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Senator John Foster Dulles sought today to link his Democratic opponent, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, with the forces that see no danger to the country from Communist tactics.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Britons love a crowd, and today at the opening of the special session of Parliament they came from all over London to throng around the gates and wave and cheer, and sometimes boo politely, at the political personalities entering the precincts of the House of Commons.

Four five-story apartment houses at 166 East 100th Street and 103, 107 and 109 East 102d Street have been sold by the Christian Meyer estate to Samuel Hurwitz, operator, in a deal negotiated by Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers. Each building occupies a lot 25 by 100 feet each and contains four and five-room suites.
