Two of the three trained dogs that were stolen Monday from a parked automobile on West Forty-seventh Street were back yesterday in the possession of their owner Paul Sydell, actor.

I compliment you upon your editorial in which you support the bill presently pending in the City Council to grant tax exemptions to landlords who rehabilitate boarded-up or half-occupied tenements. I would like to add two thoughts to what you said so well.
Included with the new furniture on display this week for Home Fashion Time are two groups of French Provincial furniture for homemakers interested in this period style.

The Club 100, a social organization of Syrians living in the neighborhood, and their friends, has purchased the bungalow and a plot of land at the southeast corner of Ocean Parkway and Avenue K, Brooklyn, from Agnes Scandore.

The Board of Education will consider at its public meeting tomorrow whether to allow the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, Inc., to conduct a fund-raising campaign in the city's schools, it was learned yesterday.

OGDENSBURG, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Elimination of service on the New York Central Railroad's nineteen-mile branch line between this city and De Kalk junction will have an adverse effect on the economic life of this north-country region, witnesses testified here today at a hearing before the Public Service Commission.
There apparently is still some bounce left in the Bombers and they put all of it on display at the Stadium yesterday as they upended the Athletics to keep their pennant hopes alive.

Stock prices were whittled fractions yesterday although the selling pressure in a few instances, particularly as a result of disappointing dividend news, brought values down a point or more. At the close, quotations were a shade above the lowest levels reached in midday.

The Armed Services Pay Bill authorizing about $300,000,000 of annual increases throughout the armed and affiliated services has now reached the White House. We are glad that Congress has at last cleared this needed legislation. It ameliorates an injustice to higher officers which had grown steadily worse for years.

A campaign for a minimum of $500,000 to supplement funds already available for the construction of a 145-bed addition and remodeling of Jamaica Hospital in Queens will start at a dinner tomorrow night at the Pomonok Country Club, Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

DETROIT, Sept. 27. -- The Ford Motor Company has offered a non-contributory pension plan costing 8 3/4 cents an hour to the United Automobile Workers, CIO, Ford confirmed tonight as the two parties approached the final 24 hours before expiration of their extended contract.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- James E. Webb, Acting Secretary of State, received a cool and, at times, hostile reception today as he presented the case for President Truman's Point Four program before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 27 -- The Chinese People's Consultative Council in Peiping today approved, without a dissenting voice. Organization statutes establishing the framework of Communist China's new Government that is expected to be formally proclaimed within the next two weeks.

Mrs. Harold S. Smith heads the executive committee for the bridge and canasta party in behalf of the New York Association of Day Nurseries to be held on Oct. 27 at the Pierre. Serving with her are Mrs. William H. Dunn, Mrs. Wharton Poor, Mrs. Edwin P. Stevens, Miss Anna Eva McLin, Mrs. William B. Groat and Mrs. Arnold Lefkowitz.

Counsel in the Communist trial submitted to Federal Judge Harold R. Medina yesterday their requests for instructions to be included in his charge to the jury. United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey handed in thirty-four requests an hour ahead of the 2 P. M. deadline set by the judge last week.

Since Mayor O'Dwyer took office on Jan. 1, 1946, the city has appropriated $13,115,869 to help pay the expenses of privately operated museums, zoos and botanical gardens, according to a report made public by the Mayor yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 27 -- Regent Abdul Illah of Iraq, returning from London, is scheduled to make a stop-over in Damascus this week. His visit will top off a series of informal trips to Damascus and discussions in Lebanon by political personalities of the two Hashemite kingdoms of Iraq and Jordan.

Urging construction of the proposed South Street elevated highway as a "vitally essential traffic relief measure" and as "a necessary adjunct to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel," Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan announced yesterday that he would press for preliminary authorization of the project before the Board of Estimate tomorrow.

The luxurious fur showing that Bergdorf Goodman held yesterday morning in its second floor fur department got under way on a gay note. Dyed mole showed its colors. There were little jackets in blue, a dark shade with a bit of a sapphire cast, taupe and a full-length coat with diagonal closing in a bright Christmasy red.

Chinese linens that have been accumlating in Shanghai since the Communist regime took over will be shipped out in the next two weeks, according to Max S. Weissman, president of the Linen Trade Association. Coming by fast steamship, the goods will be here in time for the Christmas trade, he said, and there should be sufficient quantities for the balance of the year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A rolling stone will gather no moss, but a ball club that keeps rolling collects handsome dividends. And so it was with the Red Sox tonight at Griffith Stadium, where Joe McCarthy's league-leaders rolled over the Senators and flattened the already well-flattened cellar occupants, 6 -- 4.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Bobby Driscoll, 12-year-old American movie actor taking a leading part in the filming of "Treasure Island" at Denham Studios, was fined 100 $280) by Beaconsfield Magistrates today for obtaining employment in Britain without the consent of the Ministry of Labor and the National Service.
SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 27 (AP) -- A Munitions Board official said today that the requirements of war, not the pressure of business men, will guide the United States in stockpiling strategic materials.

Savings bank earnings are likely to continue sufficient to justify existing dividend rates to depositors, "even though some further gradual decline in interest rates might occur over the period ahead," according to August Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Bank Trust Company.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- As part of a general movement to liberalize trade in Western Europe the British Government was expected today to remove quota restrictions soon on many imports from other Marshall Plan and Commonwealth countries.
BAYONNE, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Military authorities are planning in case of war to minimize the manpower problems of World War II by using selective service exclusively, with no recruiting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A final agreement on every detail of the $1,314,010,000 foreign military aid bill was reached today by spokesmen for the Senate and House and they prepared to seek tomorrow the approval of Congress itself.

Fawcett Publications has leased 150,000 square feet of office space [for twenty-one years in the enlarged Fawcett Building which the Tishman Realty and Construction Company is to build at the northeast corner of Avenue of the Americas and Forty-fourth Street. The James H. Burns Company was the broker.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, took issue yesterday with the contention made in behalf of the O'Dwyer Administration that subway service had been improved since the nickel fare was doubled.
The threat of a paralyzing coast-wide dock strike at midnight Friday has been postponed for thirty days through Federal intervention, it was announced last night.

BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Eight letter men, bolstered by many promising newcomers who have had previous scholastic gridiron experience, form the nucleus of Blair Academy's 1949 football squad. A powerful forward wall and a speedy corps of backs give every promise of making amends for the Blue and White's showing last year, when Blair won only two of its seven games.

Homemakers who have no convictions about color or lack the courage to carry out ideas they do have may be both informed and reassured by looking at coordinated color displays on view this week at Lord Taylor or Bloomingdale's. Further hints may be gathered by watching a Home Fashions show to be presented this afternoon at Abraham Straus.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A registration statement covering 30,000 shares of $20 par value preferred stock and 25,000 shares of $10 par value common stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Maine Public Service Company, Presque Isle.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Scoring one of the lowest rounds of the fast-dwindling season, Jim Turnesa, Briar Hall professional, and his partner, Irving Brodsky of Elmwood, captured the chief honors in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur best-ball handicap tourney today at the Bonnie Briar Country Club with a 63.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Search parties reported tonight that twenty-five persons -- all those aboard -- had been killed in the crash of a Mexican airliner on Popocatepetl Volcano.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, contended yesterday that the official report for the first year's operations of municipal subway lines under a 10-cent fare confirmed his charged that Mayor O'Dwyer was planning a further increase to 15 cents.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- With the statement that Britain's policy already had been made clear, Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee brushed aside a suggestion in the House of Commons today that he and President Truman should have a conference with Premier Joseph Stalin on the atomic bomb.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 27 -- China officially accused the Soviet Union today of threatening Chinese independence, endangering the peace of the Far East and violating the Charter of the United Nations.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 27 -- Russia's latest proposal to prohibit atomic weapons is unacceptable to the United States, an authoritative delegation source said today.

Starting the week of Oct. 10, National Distillers Products Corporation will open a comprehensive campaign for Old Sunny Brook Kentucky Whisky, which is scheduled to run in 475 newspapers as well as in magazines, car card and outdoor posters, it was announced yesterday.

Like a veritable treasure trove, the Fantasia, a new accessory shop that opened yesterday on Lord Taylor's third floor, is filled with carefully culled suggestions gathered with taste from throughout the store. Here one glimpses fabulous jewelry from Italy, gloves from the houses of Dior and Fath, intricately wrought belts from Mexico, superbly chic umbrellas, bags from the top designers of this country, many one of a kind, others original imports.

The autopsy in the sudden death of John Lasak, star right halfback of the City College football team, has not revealed the cause of death and microscopic studies will be made of heart and brain tissues, Dr. Milton Helpern, deputy chief medical examiner in charge of the morgue, said yesterday.

Sales and earnings of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation in the fiscal year ending on Friday will have been the best since consolidation of Nash Motors and Kelvinator Corporation in 1937. George W. Mason, president, told stockholders yesterday.

Jimmy Demaret, Bob Hamilton and Ben Hogan, golf professionals, returned to this country yesterday from England, where the United States team defeated Great Britain's representatives, seven matches to five, in the Ryder Cup competition at Ganton last Sept. 16 and 17. The trio arived on the Queen Mary.

The projected extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike west to the Ohio state boundary was financed yesterday by the sale of $77,500,000 of tax-exempt revenue bonds to investment bankers at an interest cost of 2.986 per cent to the state.

TOKYO, Sept. 27 -- The Finance Ministry has completed and will submit to the Cabinet tomorrow the draft of the national budget for 1950 -- the first since the war to show a decrease in the costs of government.

A fifteen-month campaign to "evangelize America" was started yesterday at a city-wide convocation of ministers representing thirty-seven Protestant and Orthodox denominations organized in a movement known as the United Evangelistic Advance. They met at the Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, Brooklyn.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Claude C. Tanner's Colonel O'F, a good stakes performer last year, won his first race along the comeback trail when he accounted for today's sixth and feature race.

The Erie Railroad's net income this year will approximate the $1 a share currently being paid on the common stock, Paul W. Johnston, recently elected president, said yesterday at a press conference here.

Charging that American high schools are "falling down" on the job, the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell, honorary canon of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Chicago, declared yesterday that public instruction was geared to the child of average and below average intelligence, but that "the child with brains" was being neglected
The wave of currency devaluation will cut American exports by 10 per cent or more, according to the consensus yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Statler Hotel.

Directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway declared yesterday a regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 and an extra of $2 on the common, payable Dec. 1. These are the same disbursements made a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer will visit New York City for three days next week as part of a nation-wide economic survey he is making at President Truman's request.

The youth part of Felony Court heard a bizarre story yesterday of three teen-age high school students who allegedly extorted the weekly lunch money of a 16-year-old fellow pupil by threatening him with bodily harm.

PARIS, Wednesday, Sept. 28 -- A divided French Cabinet, with none of the groups composing it desiring a breakup, wrestled unsuccessfully until 1 A. M. today with the problem of how to keep from granting a wage rise before the first of the year.

The Warren Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $6,965,590 after charges and taxes, equal to $4.10 a share on the outstanding stock. This compares with $8,529,731, or $5.02 a share, a year earlier.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Eighth place in the National League was beckoning the Reds today, but they rallied for two runs in the ninth and a 5-to-4 victory over the Cubs. A Chicago victory would have dropped Cincinnati into a cellar tie with the Cubs.

Through a series of unrelated developments the $144,000,000 Puget Sound Power and Light Company yesterday averted a sharp cut in the book value of its stock, the effect of which is that such value will be about $22 a share at the end of this year, or about the same as it was at the close of 1948.

A $1,000 violin, created 200 years ago by the master Carlo Giuseppe Testore in Milan, Italy, and found last month in a Broadway cafeteria, was restored yesterday to its owner by Frank Leuci, Police property clerk.
An artist and a photographer who on Monday were dispossesed from their Greenwich Village apartment at 55 Grove Street while in California, brought action yesterday to have the eviction set aside.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- In a 5-to-4 vote, reminiscent of Supreme Court splits, the Senate judiciary committee decided today to ask Judge Sherman Minton to appear for questioning in executive session before it acted on his nomination to the Supreme Court of the United States.
CANTON, China, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Fresh Nationalist troops marched into Kukong today to the sound of gunfire outside the Communist-threatened rail city 125 miles north of Canton.
BONN, Germany, Wednesday, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- The Western Allied High Commissioners reached an agreement today on the rate of the devaluation of the Deutsche mark.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- The text of President Truman's broadcast to the women of the country today follows:...

BUFFALO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Federal Judge John Knight today dismissed a $1,626,531 anti-trust suit filed by the Dipson theatres against a group of motion-picture distributors and local Shea Theatre interests.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Joe Gordon's ninth-inning single on relief pitcher Howie Judson's first pitch scored Lou Boudreau with the winning run tonight as the Indians defeated the White Sox, 3--2, before 8,782.

Col. Allan M. Pope, for many years president of the First Boston Corporation and a former president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, has accepted the presidency of the Investors League, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- All deliveries of wheat, except July, sold at a new seasonal high price on the Board of Trade here today as did December and May wheat in Minneapolis and Kansas City. Removal of hedges against flour sales was largely responsible for the upturn, which put December here 1 3/4 cents a bushel above the price prevailing before many countries devalued their currencies.

Golds Express Company has leased the one-story garage-type building at 776 East 139th Street, the Bronx, from Vera Ralston at an aggregate rental of $35,000 in a transaction negotiated by the Joseph G. Platzner Company as broker.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 -- The strike-beset mining area northeast of this coal center took on the look of a military reservation today as thirty-five non-union mines reopened in defiance of roving bands of armed pickets.

The Board of Transportation plans to eliminate the rush-hour "C" express service on the Eighth Avenue IND line between 205th Street, the Bronx, and Fulton and Church Streets, Manhattan, it was learned yesterday.

A vacant irregular tract of land, about 344 by 568 feet, on the westerly side of Laurel Hollow Road, extending through to Cold Spring Harbor, in Oyster Bay, L. I., has been purchased by Christian J. Truelson from the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation.

The consumer (and this includes you and me and all the rest of us) is being sold down the river by spineless or venal politicians who, yielding to the threats or blandishments of pressure groups or lobbyists, enact and administer laws so that the general public is soaked for the profit of a select few.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 -- A little-known rookie hit a grand-slam homer at Forbes Field tonight before 27,283 onlookers and dissipated the Cardinals' chance of lengthening their lead over the Dodgers in the red-hot National League pennant race.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler today issued the list of players eligible to compete in the world series. The list covers the Red Sox and Yankees, fighting it out for the American League pennant, and the Cardinals and the Dodgers, battling for the National League flag.

The local ship repair industry is greatly concerned over the possibility that future repairs of Army vessels might be done in Navy yards in an effort to lessen the impact of recent personnel reductions at these yards, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to return by Dec. 1 thirty small naval vessels lent to it by the United States during the past war, the State Department announced today.

MARTINSVILLE, Va., Sept. 27 -- Warning that poor furniture quality eats up both manufacturers' and retailers' profits, Hall Young Kaighin of the bureau of standards of R. H. Macy Co. declared here today that "a quality-conscious approach to the design, planning and execution of furniture manufacture is the shortest road to business expansion and to profits."
John M. Hughlett, formerly vice president and general manager of Dan River Mills, Inc., has joined J. P. Stevens Co., in an executive capacity. He will assume his duties in November after a vacation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 27 -- Columbia has transferred its projected Margaret Sullavan picture, "No Sad Songs," to the program of Robert Rossen Productions, Inc., an independent company in which Columbia participates financially, and whose pictures Columbia distributes.
Before an assemblage of Jewish scholars and lay leaders, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman was inaugurated yesterday as chairman of the board of overseers of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 -- Henry H. Heimann, of New York, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, said here today there have been many reasons in the last few weeks to believe that the first post-war readjustment period was well on its way.

The final novelty of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo's season at the Metropolitan Opera House proved to be the best. This was Tatiana Chamie's "Birthday," with music by Rossini, decor by Doboujinsky and costumes by Karinska, which had its premiere last night, with Nana Gollner, ballerina of the Ballet Theatre company, as guest star.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The late summer rise in industrial activity resulted in an addition of almost 500,000 employes to the payrolls of nonagricultural establishments, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today for the month ended Aug. 15.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Garry Davis, self-styled world citizen, was brought up for trial here today on a charge of having no foreigner's permit to reside in France. On a defense motion the court agreed to postpone the hearing until Oct. 4 to give Davis' lawyers time to prepare their case.

In addition to her great insistence on femininity, Carrie Munn is a custom designer with a practical side to her nature. She believes a costume should be versatile, giving its wearer the advantage of several changes. To this point, in her collection viewed yesterday at 640 Madison Avenue, she showed her now famous paillette-quilted skirts topped with several changes of blouses.
Mayor O'Dwyer made a strong protest yesterday against continued imposition of a special unloading charge for fruit and vegetables shipped here by water from New Jersey railroad terminals.

Utility investors who worry about public power competition were joined yesterday by executives of power and light companies as they bemoaned the growing importance of power in the Administration's plans for the 1950 Congressional campaign.

Mayor Heracles Retos of Trikkala, Greece, yesterday notified Mayor E. T. Houston of Tucson, Ariz., of an eight-point program that his city had started in gratitude to mark the plan of "community affiliation" that the American city organized. Operation Democracy, Inc., a clearing house of such plans between cities in the United States and Europe, announced the Trikkala project.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- A new tax to offset the profits that British exporters may earn in the dollar markets as a result of the devaluation of the pound was announced today by Sir Stafford Cripps in opening the debate for national support of Labor's financial policy.

PERHAPS it is still too early to concede defeat and toss in the towel for the Yankees. It's a cinch that they are not going to quit at this stage in the proceedings because there just isn't any geezer in them. They'll be in there fighting until they are dragged off by the heels. But it's about time to toss a bouquet in the general direction of Casey Stengel.
Trading in cotton on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and final prices were 1 to 6 points net lower than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Parking meters in such crowded urban areas as mid-Manhattan would add to traffic congestion while providing more space for idle cars, delegates were told today at the annual meeting of the Institute of Traffic Engineers here.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Cyril James Senior, first officer of the lost luxury liner Magdalena, said today a rock ahead had been mistaken for an unlighted ship just before the 17,500-ton vessel had grounded off Rio de Janeiro April 25.

BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- Two violent disturbances were recorded on the local football seismograph during the past week-end, but this town has been in such a lather of pennant fever that they went almost unnoticed. One of them registered the Stanford landslide that buried Harvard at Palo Alto.

A charge that the Federal Government was trying to "regulate a hobby" came to light yesterday in a dispute involving the nation's 80,000 amateur radio operators, popularly known as "hams," and the Federal Communications Commission.

Whether it means roasting its own coffee, blending chemicals to mix its own medicines, or just going out into the open market to buy the best it can find of everything it needs at the most favorable prices, New York Fields to no one in its constant efforts to drive the best bargains it can get, according to Purchase Commissioner John Splain.

A proclamation issued yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer announced New York's participation in the first National Smoke Abatement Week, held Oct. 23 to 29. The event is sponsored by the Smoke Prevention Association of America, Inc.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- Randolfo Pacciardi, Minister of Defense, called today for some "remarkable sacrifices" by Italian taxpayers to carry out a five-year program of naval construction to start when the ban on new warships imposed by the Italian peace treaty expires Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Col. Bernt Balchen, Arctic flier, landed his Air Force C-54 transport here tonight at 11:59 o'clock after a one-stop flight from Norway.

Faraway of the Glen Riddle Farms earned top billing in the Times Square Handicap, the Class C event that served as the feature at Belmont Park yesterday. With Gordon Glisson giving him a sound ride, the 4-year-old son of War Relic made himself the star of the day by scoring a three-quarter-length victory over Mother, running in the colors of C. V. Whitney.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- The reappointment of Leland Olds to the Federal Power Commission met opposition from New York, his home state, today as a Senate Commerce Committee opened hearings on his nomination.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- An Administration "must" bill to increase the salaries of top government executives was picked today as the vehicle for a last-stand and possibly successful effort by the Senate's economy bloc to direct President Truman, in the light of falling Federal income, to cut 5 to 10 per cent from appropriations already made by Congress for the present fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Areas distressed by a high rate of unemployment were now beginning to benefit from the administration's program of favoring them with Government procurement contracts, construction and loans, John R. Steelman, assistant to President Truman, reported today.

IN the twelve years I have been co-editor of "Books of the Times" I do not remember reading a wittier defense of traditional values than Peter Viereck's "Conservatism Revisited -- The Revolt Against Revolt."*

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 -- President Truman landed here tonight for a forty-eight-hour visit in his native state, during which he will officiate at the installation of James Bradford as the new Grand Master of the Missouri Grand Lodge of Masons tomorrow morning. The President also will speak tomorrow night at a big dinner in Kansas City honoring William M. Boyle Jr., the Democratic National Chairman.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept 28 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll charged today that his opponent, State Senator Elmer H. Wene, "is trying to be all things to all persons and fooling no one."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The United States is spreading agricultural knowledge already in the Western Hemisphere with signal success, Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today in urging approval of President Truman's Point Four program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Creation of special banks to finance small business was proposed today by A. D. H. Kaplan, economist of the Brookings Institution.

Beatrice Foods Company reported yesterday a net profit of $2,194,135, equal to $4.10 a common share for the six months ended with August, in contrast to $1,627,690, or $2.98 a share cleared in the corresponding period a year ago.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 28 -- A three-week postponement in the discussion of the Greek question was proposed by Australia today to give a United Nations conciliation committee time to make a new attempt to bring about a settlement of differences between Greece and Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 28 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky today told United Nations delegates that the United States' atomic monopoly had "lapsed."

Eye-filling for the woman who appreciates handsome furs was the Dein-Bacher showing at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. Of particular note for its styling was the opening group, entitled "Black Magic". Here such glossy black furs as Persian lamb, broadtail and velvety seal were handled with fine fashion flare.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Administration leaders in the House have suffered a major setback in efforts to bring the National Science Foundation bill to the floor before adjournment.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 -- Touches borrowed from a court jester on play and sun fashions; white cut-work embroidery and braiding on blue denims; sports dresses in a new nylon knit similar to bagheera; swimsuits with panel front attaching bra and shorts; pique jumper dress over narrow bra; sleeveless pique chemisette will full printed chintz skirt; dinner prints with marquisette peignoir coat or stole.

European nations are afraid that Marshall Plan aid will end before the scheduled date in 1952 and that the United States will again start building an ascending tariff wall, Paul G. Hoffman, Administrator, Economic Cooperation Administration, said last night.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- London critics, who went to Manchester lsat night for the first European performance of Tennessee Williams' "A Streetcar Named Desire," were unanimous in praising Vivien Leigh for her acting.

The grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, which only yesterday afternoon was set "concert style" for the meeting of the American Managers Association, was transformed in twenty minutes last night into a dinner setting for 1,600 members of the National Security Industrial Association.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Two of Britain's biggest exhibitions of export products, the annual motor and radio shows, opened today under as many handicaps as the export drive itself.

Substantial initial losses in revaluing the net foreign currency assets of the American Cable and Radio Corporation were foreseen yesterday by its president, Kenneth E. Stockton, in the wake of foreign currency devaluations.

New York's Forty-niners -- the tens of thousands of young couples migrating this year from furnished rooms and small apartments to suburban homes of their own -- are discovering many new things about living.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28 -- John L. Leban, president of Schenley Distillers, Inc., New York, today urged package store operators to continue their campaign against taxes to prevent "prohibition by taxation."
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The first British productivity team to study United States industrial methods reported today that this country lagged far behind the United States in efficiency and production.

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 28 -- Two months after having shrugged off warnings not to enter the Soviet zone without proper credentials, two United States youths were released today from a Russian jail in Magdeburg, where they had spent the intervening period.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- In the face of steady pressure for wage increases from segments of Britain's powerful trade union movement, the British Government let it be known here today that it had no intention at this time of introducing a national minimum wage.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Heavy profit-taking attracted by the rapid upturn in wheat in the last few days resulted today in a reaction of 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel from the early high on the Board of Trade when December and May sold at new seasonal high prices.

The first full class to receive baccalaureate degrees under the collegiate program instituted in 1946 was graduated from the New York State Maritime College, Fort Schuyler, yesterday. The occasion also marked the seventy-fifth anniversary of the college.

The charge that Senator John Foster Dulles and other leading Republicans had set up a "straw man" named "statism" on which to focus their attack was made yesterday by former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, last evening.

UPTON, L. I., Sept. 29 -- Dr. William Mason Hale has been named head of the bacteriology and virology division and Dr. Sidney C. Madden of the pathology division of the Department of Medicine at Brookhaven National Laboratory, northeastern center for nuclear research, it was announced today.

In a move designed to put extra pressure on Charley Conerly, Coach Charley Ewart yesterday announced that Sam Tamburo and Bob Sponaugle would start at the ends for the New York Bulldogs in their game against the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds tomorrow night.

Out of what is left of the Wild West's howling wilderness and nto Madison Square Garden's hard-dirt arena came 200 cowpokes last night -- and a band of genuine redskins. That flourish opened the twenty-fourth annual world's championship rodeo for $84,000 in prize money.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- David Smith, vice president of the Philco Corporation, urged the Government today not to approve any color television system that would make present sets obsolete. He said some television shows looked better in black and white.

THE world watches with chilled loathing to see what he will do now. Once again it would like him to promise something or other, forgetting how many spectacularly different things he has promised in the past. Yet in this decisive moment of history there are still in guileless quarters the rancid lees of hope.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Making an auspicious start in defense of the title she won on her first attempt last year, Mrs. Betty Meckley of Washington, D. C., scored a fine 39, 42 -- 81, in the first round of the twenty-fourth United States women's senior golf championship at the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- Profit-limiting laws were criticized today by Vincent H. Maloney, partner of Alvord Alvord, New York, as "dangerous because they impose a sort of super-taxation which is enacted into law without any of the careful consideration given to new tax legislative proposals."
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 28 -- State Senator Elmer H. Wene, Democratic candidate for Governor, won today the support of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor.

BOSTON, Sept. 28 -- The weather, rather than the two contenders, lengthened the suspense in the National League pennant race today, so tomorrow the Dodgers will meet the Braves in a doubleheader, with the first game starting at 1 P. M. The Brooks still trail the National League's leading Cardinals by one game with four contests remaining for each contender.

Trading in prime crude soybean oil futures as a major commodity on the New York Produce Exchange was started under a new-type contract yesterday. William C. Schilthuis, president of the Exchange, declared trading in the new contract opened at 11 A. M.

The urgent need for maximum efficiency and economy in the military establishment so that the nation's industrial strength will not be sapped by excessive taxation is recognized fully in the Defense Department, W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, and Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, declared last night.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Mrs. Walter Reynolds and Dr. G. Everett Gaillard of Knollwood carried off the low gross honors in the Westchester County Golf Association's mixed foursome competition at the Sunningdale Club course today with a score of 80.
HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 28 -- Maurice P. (Mickey) Shuman is not disheartened in the least because his Peddie School football team this year is greener and not quite as heavy as that of 1948.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Congress approved today, with heavy majorities, a $1,314,010,000 program to help arm this country's European associates in the North Atlantic defensive alliance and other non-Communist lands.

Supreme Court Justice Murray Hearn in Brooklyn ordered the city's Board of Education yesterday to refrain for the time being from enforcing any of the provisions of the Feinberg Law, which calls for teacher loyalty tests.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, will publish tomorrow an article in which Moshe Piyade of the Politburo asserts that the late Premier Georgi Dimitrov of Bulgaria, who died in Moscow early last July, secretly sympathized with the Yugoslavs in their struggle with Soviet leaders and urged them to remain steadfast.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week were decreased by 69,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total stocks were 103,262,000 barrels, compared with 103,331,000 a week earlier and 90,410,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The State Department indicated today that in spite of President Truman's disclosure of "an atomic explosion" in the Soviet Union amendments to the present Atomic Energy Act were not so urgent as to require attention this year.

The Botany Mills beachwear line for 1950 will be expanded by the introduction of a wide range of swim trunks of non-worsted fabrics, it was announced yesterday by Harry K. Lowe, sales manager of the Products for Men Division. In addition to the virgin wool worsted line, the trunks include combed cotton gabardine, Celanese, rayon, nylon and poplin prints.
THE DALLES, Ore., Sept. 28 -- CIO longshore pickets smashed an attempt to unload Hawaiian pineapple here today in a mass attack that seriously injured two truck drivers.

HAWAII, Sept. 28 -- A motion by the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, in Hawaii for a preliminary injunction against the Territorial Government's operation of piers was denied today as two Federal judges sitting en banc, handed down a split decision.

A three-year contract covering 33,000 workers in eight unions in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx was signed yesterday by the Hotel Association of New York and the New York Hotel Trades Council, AFL.

In a sharp attack on the Board of Education's bureau of plant operation and maintenance, James Marshall, board member from Manhattan and former president, charged yesterday that the bureau's procedure of issuing oral orders for contracts violated the State Education Law.

A gadget that performs such a variety of tasks that it's a valuable addition to even the smallest kitchen is the Shred-O-Mat produced by the Rival Manufacturing Company of Kansas City, Mo. Just being introduced in stores here, this device consists of a base that sits securely on a table or shelf and three interchangeable discs, one for slicing, another for shredding and a third for grating.

There is more than an element of inspiration in the thought of the thrift of 30,944 city, county and state employes -- most of them in low-paid brackets -- who think enough of their homes, their families and their security to save their money, and save it effectively.

The Illinois Bell Telephone Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 95 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 30 to holders of record yesterday. The dividend was 20 cents less than the amount paid in June and compared with $1.50 paid in March. G. K. McCorkle, president, attributed the decrease to a decline in earnings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Senate voted tonight to increase salaries of top-level Government officials far below the scale recommended by President Truman and prescribed that the departments and agencies concerned absorb the estimated $750,000 payroll increase within their regular appropriations.

The State of North Carolina financed yesterday the first step of a long-term program for rehabilitating secondary roads by selling to investment bankers an issue of $50,000,000 of tax-exempt serial obligations maturing from 1951 to 1969 at an interest cost of 1.5768 per cent.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 28 (AP) -- A retired New York economics professor was killed today in a fall from the tenth-story roof of a downtown Miami hotel.
Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin declared last night he was "optimistic" on settlement of the steel industry's labor troubles and on the increasing prosperity of the nation as a whole.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a very narrow range yesterday and closed barely steady, 3 to 6 points net lower than on Tuesday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -- Russ Meyer chalked up his 17th pitching victory of the season for the Phillies today by shutting out the Giants, 2 to 0.

With the Red Sox losing in Washington last night, the Yankees tied them for the American League lead, although for a few harrowing moments at the Stadium yesterday it looked as if the Bombers again would string themselves up higher than the near-by Bronx County Court House.

One of the most antic misconceptions of them all is that these cool days cause a man to wish to work harder. The inference is that, released from the raging inferno of July, he draws himself to his full stature, beats his chest with enthusiasm and then goes out to build a bridge.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Following is the statement of Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, concerning the pension-insurance offer made to the United Steelworkers of America, CIO:

ROME, Sept. 28 -- While many European nations are facing the possibility of price increases as a result of the devaluations, the Italian Cabinet today decreed a general decrease in the price of bread.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Consumers Price Index, formerly called the Cost of Living Index, has started uphill again after its early-summer slide

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28 (UP) -- The Argentine Government informed the United States today that it had only "the greatest goodwill and desire to help" the United States correspondents, newspapers and magazines.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- Fifty-six hours after receiving the Tokyo Rose treason case the deadlocked jury interrupted its deliberations to go to dinner and again be locked up for the night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Pay increases averaging $113.60 annually for 885,000 classified civil service employes were voted today by the House.

The States Marine Corporation, operators of world-wide cargo services, will open a new service between North Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico ports and the Persian Gulf in November, it was made known yesterday by John H. McIntyre, vice president of the steamship company.

The float of undistributed new corporate bonds in the hands of banking syndicates was estimated in underwriting circles yesterday at $35,000,000, with railroad equipment-trust serial certificates accounting for more than half of the total.

Ralph Bellamy will star in a new detective-mystery series entitled "Man Against Crime" over the CBS television network beginning Friday, Oct. 7 from 8:30 to 9 P. M. The actor will play the part of Mike Barnett, a private detective who never carries a gun.

Master mariners and barge captains approaching New York Harbor from the south this coming December may blink their eyes in astonishment when they see two lightships in the area generally covered by Scotland Lightship since 1868.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 28 -- A 98-year-old Confederate Army veteran stood fast to his word of honor today and disrupted plans to have the United Confederate Veterans hold their final reunion in Charleston, S. C., next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- When the shadow of national prohibition was materializing into the dry but porous substance it soon became, the late Representative Swagar Sherley of Kentucky remarked of the House that "whisky has no enemies in the cloakroom and no friends on the floor."

In your issue of Sept. 26 you have a letter from Emmanuel S. Larsen. It may be noted that, according to Mr. Larsen, not only is Pakistan the villain of the piece in the Kashmir story but also the U. N. is its willing accomplice. For, says Mr. Larsen, "the more recent U. N. proposals for arbitration have the appearance of an attempt to conceal Pakistan's act of aggression.

WASHINGTON, Sept 28 -- Manufacturers' sales in the United States advanced sharply in August to a total of $17,200,000,000, the highest volume since March, the Office of Business Economics of the Commerce Department announced today.

One of your editorials, "Veterans' Preference," on Sept. 17, makes a sad case for veterans in government and state civil service. I feel that you have overlooked and sidestepped the core of the problem.
DALMINE, Italy, Sept. 23 -- An industrial revolution is in the making in northern Italy.

For more than twenty years Sidney Sugarman, Bronx attorney and politically an important functionary of the Bronx Democratic organization, has been getting mail intended for Sidney Sugerman, a Westchester resident, politically unattached, who practices law in the Wall street area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Traffice congestion and attendant evils will disintegrate New York and other large cities throughout the country as surely as an atom bomb unless remedies are applied, Wilbur I. Smith, president of the Institute of Traffic Engineers, warned today at the closing session of its annual convention.

The addition of twelve new members to the board of trustees of the Citizens Budget Commission was announced last night by Robert W. Dowling, president of the commission, after the fall meeting of the board at the Astor Hotel.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 28 -- Johnson Johnson, the world's largest manufacturer of surgical dressings, unveiled today its new 207,000-square-foot shipping center designed to cut down the time of handling orders from one week to one day.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Although unable to reach a definite accord upon the price-wage dispute, Premier Henri Queuille's cabinet after a meeting today appeared bent on avoiding a crisis at least until Parliament reconvened in a month's time.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Prof. Ferdinand Hercik of Czechoslovakia told the general conference of the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization tonight that Marxism was the correct answer to the problem of international understanding.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Bob Lemon filled a dual role today as the Indians defeated the White Sox, 4-2. The victory put Cleveland a length and a half behind third-place Detroit.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 -- A syndicate of Hawaiian small-business men today detailed plans for the development of shipping to carry foodstuffs and other freight to the islands during the current longshoremen's strike against the major shipping companies.
Rapid forcing of blood under pressure into the veins and arteries of patients weakened by extreme loss of blood was urged upon doctors yesterday afternoon.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 28 -- Measures to keep down the price of jute and to counteract an expected rise in the cost of raw jute from Pakistan, the principal world supplier, since that Dominion's decision not to devalue her currency, were announced by the Indian Government tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 28 -- An Israeli delegate protested to the General Assembly's Social Committee today that "discriminatory" acts by the Egyptian Government had prevented an Israeli representative from attending a conference of the United Nations World Health Organization scheduled to be held in Alexandria last month.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Government completed plans today for eleventh-hour mediation in the steel dispute which threatens a strike of 500,000 steel workers at 12:01 A. M. Saturday.

President Truman's announcement of last Friday that an "atomic explosion" had occurred in Russia seems to have made little impression upon some of the die-hards on Capitol Hill in Washington, in the Pentagon, and throughout the country.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 28 -- China's charges that Russia is threatening peace in the Far East won a tentative place on the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly today despite Soviet protests that "bankrupt" Chinese militarists were engineering a campaign of "slander" against Moscow.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 28 -- The text of the Australian draft resolution on the Balkan question introduced today before the United Nations Assembly's Political and Security Committee (the First Committee):

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Governor Dewey and eleven other residents of New York State tonight were among 153 candidates who received the Thirty-third Degree in Scottish Rite Masonry at the 137th annual meeting of the Supreme Council for the Northern Masonic Jurisdiction.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 28 -- Mrs. Arthur K. Atkinson of the Creek continued to lead the field by a stroke with 158 after the second round of the fifteenth annual Women's Long Island Golf Association three-day medal play championship at Meadow Brook today.

Extensions of subway service, principally in the IND system, involving new express routes and other shifts expected to change the underground travel habits of thousands of New Yorkers, were announced yesterday by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

Expressing scorn for unobtainable and undesirable "perfect security," Columbia University's president, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, urged 1,000 students yesterday to embrace the opportunities surrounding them in life and at the university.

An interesting preview of beautifully grained woods that may appear on the home-furnishings horizon in the next six months was presented yesterday by the United States Plywood Corporation, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

In anticipation of the November election, the State Attorney General's office has devised a program of close cooperation with the city's Police Department to combat voting frauds, it was announced last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- The National Public Health Service reported today that the number of polio cases reported thus far in 1949 had exceeded those for any other year on record.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 28 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky was in a mood of glorious wrath today. He was mad at the Chinese. He was mad at the British. And when the Soviet Foreign Minister is mad, he swells and blows as does Leo Durocher when he protests an umpire's decision.

WARSAW, Sept. 28 -- The hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland is expected to reach a minimal agreement with the Polish Government on Friday, when the first of a series of negotiations aimed at settling Church-State differences will be concluded, usually reliable sources said today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 -- The private hopsitals of the nation were called on today by Dr. Paul B. Magnuson, Chief Medical Officer of the Veterans Administration, to set up diagnostic clinics staffed with top professional personnel.
DETROIT, Thursday, Sept. 29 -- The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, reached agreement at 2:10 A. M. today on a new contract embodying a non-contributory pension plan.
LAVENHAM, England, Sept. 28 -- Alec Hodsdon advertised his 1901 steam-driven motor-car for sale. His price: 150 [$420].

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28 -- The first football game in history between Yale and Fordham Universities, scheduled here Saturday was canceled tonight by Yale authorities as a precautionary measure to prevent a spread of poliomyelitis.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Sept. 28 -- Officials of Bridgewater Township narrowed down the search for three lost acres of land tonight either to First Mountain or Second Mountain in the Watchung Range -- but would not commit themselves on either one of the two.

" The Innocents," William Archibald's dramatization of the Henry James novel, "The Turn of the Screw," has been added to the list of Broadway openings for the month of November. Until yesterday a state of uncertainty existed about the ultimate fate of the play.

One final effort to reach agreement on a treaty for Austria at this time began last evening when the Big Four Foreign Ministers met in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in a session that was continuing until early this morning.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 28 -- Dartmouth regained its place last year as one of the football powers of the East with one of the finest groups of backs to wear the Green, a rugged line that remained intact throughout the season and a quarterback in John Clayton who had few peers as a passer and engineer of the T-formation attack.

The dispute in the Allied Kommandatura in Berlin over terms of payment for German elevated railway workers was symptomatic of a situation that is rapidly becoming more serious. After the battle of the airlift was won in June and the blockade lifted, the tendency was to heave a sigh of relief and forget about Berlin.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 28 -- Mary Garden, as vivacious and glamorous at 72 as she was when she was the toast of two continents as prima donna of the Chicago Opera Company, arrived here today aboard the Holland-America Line's flagship Nieuw Amsterdam for a three-month lecture tour of this country.

Grants totaling more than $200,000 were presented yesterday by the Masonic Foundation for Medical Research and Human Welfare to seven colleges and research groups to further research into the cause and cure of rheumatic fever and allied diseases.

Credit executives feel that the final quarter of the calendar year should be "quite satisfactory" provided the strike situation does not interfere, it was declared yesterday by the Chicago Association of Credit Men.

Resumption of service by the Italian liners Saturnia and Vulcania, recently tied up by a strike of Italian seamen, was announced yesterday by George C. Gaede, vice president in charge of passenger traffic for the American Export Lines. Simultaneously, Mr. Gaede issued a completely revised 1949-50 schedule for both vessels.

Gen. Omar Bradley, chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, urged American industrialists yesterday to "step forward" and enter government service, because "our Government needs our best men twenty-four hours a day, every day."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 28 -- An issue of the United States Information Service Czech - language news bulletin devoted to the Soviet atomic explosion was confiscated by Czechoslovak postal authorities yesterday, a United States Embassy spokesman announced today, because of a quotation from a NEW YORK TIMES editorial.

Reflecting developments in the progress of negotiations over labor difficulties in the steel industry, the stock market yesterday rebounded fractions to 2 points in the heaviest dealings in a week. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,300,000 shares compared with 1,070,000 on Tuesday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, rejected today an offer by the United States Steel Corporation to grant a pension and social insurance "package" of 10 cents an hour on condition that its 170,000 production employes make a supplementary payment of their own.
A reprieve for the shipping industry in two maritime labor disputes apeared certain yesterday.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 13 -- American private business is being welcomed into partnership by the Ceylon Government as part of the program to convert to industrialization from a classic colonial economy. At present the island is struggling along unwillingly on lines laid down by former foreign rulers, for exclusive development of primary products for export to the mother country.

Oren Root, Republican-City Fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, charged yesterday that the O'Dwyer administration had bought for $1,500,000 one of the best settlement houses on the lower East Side and had since permitted the building to remain idle, depriving the children in the area of its facilities.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Britain's first trade and financial agreement with Communist Czechoslovakia was signed here today. It will help to restore Czechoslovakia's foreign markets and provide her with raw materials for her industry, while giving Britain essential goods and substantial payment on Czechoslovakia's debts to this country.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The first shot was fired today in what is expected to develop into an all-out battle in Syracuse tomorrow over methods of setting producer milk prices in the New York milkshed.

A pre-game football rally scheduled for tomorrow night on the Fordham University campus in the Bronx will be held as originally planned, but its slogan has been changed from "beat Yale" to "beat polio." The shift came after discovery of infantile paralysis cases on the Yale campus had forced cancellation of Saturday's football game.
HONG KONG, Sept. 28 -- The Sinkiang Provincial Government has formally announced Sinkiang's adherence to the Communist Chinese regime.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Big corporations are not monopolizing American business despite the fears of President Truman and members of Congress to the contrary, Dr. Willford I. King, chairman of the Committee for Constitutional Government, told a Senate Judiciary Subcommittee today.
Charles M. Trunz, president of Trunz, Inc., has been elected a trustee of the Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Mediators today invited the Bell Aircraft Corporation management and leaders of Local 501 of the United Auto Workers, CIO, on strike since June 13, to meet with them Friday to resume negotiations. Bell declined the invitation but the local said it would send representatives of the International Union and members of the local bargaining committee.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 -- Gov. Forest Smith of Missouri today asked the Governors of ten other states affected by the strike of 5,200 trainmen on the Missouri Pacific Railroad to meet with him here on Oct. 6 in an attempt to settle the dispute.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 28 (UP) -- Gov. William M. Tuck declared a state of emergency throughout Virginia because of the coal strike today, and United Mine Workers officials said Virginia's 15,000 union miners would return to work for the state.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 28 -- The West German Government speedily and angrily rejected today a formal decision of the Western Allied High Commission on currency devaluation and challenged the right of the commission to revise German coal prices under the Occupation Statute.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A succession of tributes -- from President Truman down -- were paid to the United States Military Government in Germany today for having restored peace and "fearlessly and successfully" resisting the Berlin blockade.

Fire Commissioner Quayle has called attention to the imminence of Fire-Prevention Week, to be observed from Oct. 9 to Oct. 15, and has asked us all to cooperate. There will not be as many "stunts" or special ceremonies this year as there have been in some previous years, but the press, radio and theaters will help to urge upon all the necessity of fire precautions, especially in the home.

In another radio speech addressed directly to Mayor O'Dwyer, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor charged last night that Mr. O'Dwyer had violated a pledge, given to the Labor party four years ago, that he would not raise the subway fare as long as he remained Mayor.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- Dore Schary and Louis B. Mayer, chief production executives at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, have issued blanket orders to studio producers and department heads to dismiss all "unnecessary" personnel, including employes who do not contribute to "the essentials of production," it was disclosed today.

Scheduled to be used for a building development, the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing played host to its last open event yesterday as thirty-three pairs teed off in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day amateur best-ball tournament.
Union Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, and the General Theological Seminary in Chelsea Square, announced yesterday record enrollments of students for the ministry.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 28 -- The Communist party of New Jersey announced today that Lawrence Mahan had withdrawn as its candidate for Governor and that the organization's support would be given to James Imbrie, the Progressive party candidate.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- Rain today forced postponement until tomorrow of the Cardinals' final game with the Pirates. Originally scheduled for tomorrow, the contest had been advanced because of fear it otherwise might be rained out completely.

An eventual "blending" of radio and television, with the former holding listener attention during the day and the latter the viewer at night, was visualized yesterday by Dr. Lawrence E. Deckinger, director of research for the Blow Company.
The city's "failure" to provide itself with a continuing statistical "self-portrait" to help solve its social and economic problems was described yesterday by a social research expert.

TORONTO, Sept. 28 -- Only one of seven doors that could have been used as passenger exits was open when the 6,905-ton Great Lakes cruise steamer Noronic burned at her pier here early on the morning of Sept. 17, a Federal Court of Inquiry was informed at the opening of hearings today.
An exhibition of 125 rare books and documents showing the origin and development of the Book of Common Prayer will open today at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street.

The Russian proposal for dealing with atomic energy calls for "simultaneous" destruction of existing stocks of atomic weapons and the establishment of what Mr. Vishinsky has described as "strict and effective international control." This plan was submitted to the General Assembly of the United Nations a year ago at Paris and has now been put forward again at Flushing Meadow.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Widespread falls among industrial shares was the outstanding feature today on the stock markets, which was overshadowed by the Chancellor's speech. Announcement of a further increase in the tax on distributed profits and Sir Stafford Cripps' warning regarding dividend limitations sent prices down sharply.

Sales of canned meats will reach a record high this year and will continue to grow in 1950, Russell M. Smith, president of the National Meat Canners Association and national manager of all canned meats for Wilson Co., meat packers, predicted yesterday.

The Citizens Budget Commission is not an organization that is likely to sponsor an unconscionable salary grab by city officials. On Aug. 15 this organization, nonpartisan and dedicated to promotion of more efficient government, sent a letter to the Board of Estimate and the City Council proposing that the Mayor's salary be raised to $35,000 a year from the present $25,000 and suggesting pay increases for other high elective officials.

Plans for a $4,000,000 public parking garage -- a revision of a project that was abandoned two years ago -- were announced yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer. Mr. O'Dwyer said the development, which would be built, maintained and operated by private capital on city-owned land under a fifty-year lease, would cost the city's taxpayers nothing.

Anything goes for a centerpiece on a dining table these days if one may judge by a series of table arrangements to be seen in New York department stores this week. Although the simple low silver or crystal bowl filled with flowers is still around and looks fine when it does appear, odd items like pottery animals, crystal figurines and ceramic fruit appear to be competing for the center of the scene.
Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that some parking meters were expected to be in operation in the city on an experimental basis before the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- In their wildest dreams the Yankees couldn't hope for a wilder pitch than the one uncorked tonight by Lefty Mel Parnell at Griffith Stadium. For with this totally unexpected errant toss by the winningest pitcher in baseball, this exciting American League flag chase was tied into a knot that may take a lot of untying.

VIENNA, Sept. 28 -- Willa Stewart, who was recently signed to a year's contract with the Vienna Staatsoper, made an unexpected debut tonight when she pinch-hit on a few hours' notice for Ljuba Welitsch in "Aida."

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Proposing a motion of censure, Winston Churchill, leader of the Opposition, accused the Labor Government today of squandering the national assets and of bringing Britain "to the verge of national and international bankruptcy."

Gerald E. Rosenberger, president of Coro, Inc., fashion jewelry manufacturer, announced yesterday the election of Royal Marcher, formerly secretary and treasurer, to the new post of executive vice president. George Rosenberger, a director, was elected treasurer and Jerome H. Oppenheimer, vice president, was made secretary.

" I had a very fast trip from the head of the stretch," said Jockey Eric Guerin when he slid down from Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Loser Weeper after the running of the $18,175 Vosburgh Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. He certainly had.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Empire District Electric Company, Joplin, Mo., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering 100,000 shares of its $10 par-value common stock.

Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, told the Overseas Press club yesterday that the United Nations offered the best hope for a new world based on the dual factors of morality and friendship among great nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A Congressional conference committee agreed today on a foreign-aid appropriation of $5,809,990,000, including $3,628,380,000 for European recovery in the current fiscal year and an additional $150,000,000 of loans to Marshall Plan countries through the Export-Import Bank.

George S. Counts and Nucia Lodge, both on the staff of Columbia's Teachers College, who collaborated on the translation of "New Russia's Primer," have a new book about Russia on Houghton Mifflin's list set for Oct. 18 publication.

These are the days of "packaged" excursions, for both hunting and fishing, and if the present trend continues we can except to see advertisements for an all-expense, round-trip excursion to Kansas for rabbits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Al Jolson, the "Mammy" singer asked President Truman during a White House visit today if he thought he might run again for the Presidency. Mr. Jolson quoted the President as replying:

We note with much gratification the recent report of Mayor O'Dwyer concerning the Department of Correction of the City of New York. With the benefit of many years of observation of the local correctional picture, we hasten to commend the Mayor and his Commissioner of Correction, Albert Williams, for the many advances made.

THE custom of holding a special "day" for a ball player is fundamentally sound and is a method of expressing the appreciation of the fans for services rendered above and beyond the call of duty. In the old days the hero so honored would shuffle in embarrassment to home plate, receive a traveling bag or some such inconsequential trinket and then stutter his thanks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Gen. Jacob L. Devers recommended today that the atomic bomb be used as "a tactical weapon" to increase efficiency of the Army's ground forces.

In comments from the bench at the Communist trial yesterday, Federal Judge Harold R. Medina stressed the importance of the Government's evidence on secrecy, false names and conspiratorial methods used by Communists in underground activities.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the address of Winston Churchill in the House of Commons today:

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- The Western commanders in Berlin broke off today the talks with their Russian counterpart ordered last June by the four-power Foreign Ministers in an effort to restore divided Berlin to normal life.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y, Sept. 28 -- The campaign technique of the Democratic party is to win the senatorial race in New York this year by default, Senator John Foster Dulles, the Republican nominee, declared today before Franklin County voters here and at Malone.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Philip Murray, president of the CIO-United Steelworkers of America, relative to contract negotiations with United States Steel Corporation:

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- A call to American Protestanism to "wake up" to its responsibilities in providing a haven for Europe's displaced persons was voiced here today by the Right Rev. Norman B. Nash, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Massachusetts.

Mayor O'Dwyer bluntly warned the city's taxicab industry yesterday that he would not permit it to adopt cheaper methods of operation until it proved that such economy was necessary to sustain it, and unless he knew "in advance that the drivers will be fully protected."

Many parties will be given at the dinner dance in behalf of the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue to be held tonight at the reopening for the autumn season of the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza. Several large cocktail parties in the Palm Court of the hotel and in private homes will precede the benefit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Senator Clyde M. Reed, Republican, of Kansas, declared that testimony introduced at a Senate commerce subcommittee hearing today indicated that Leland Olds of the Federal Power Commission "is a full-fleged, first-class Communist."

A single defense force and a common currency for the free Western democracies were urged yesterday by Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, and Owen J. Roberts, former United States Supreme Court Justice, at a luncheon meeting of the New York members of the Atlantic Union Committee in the University Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal change for the week ended Sept. 21:

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- More than fifty men were arrested in Pennsylvania and West Virginia today as armed pickets intensified their efforts to keep non-union coal mines from operating. Two shots were fired at a convoy of coal trucks in Center County, Pa., but no injuries were reported.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had decided not to adopt any amendment to its exemptive rules under section 11 (D) (1) of the Securities Exchange Act. That section generally prohibits any broker-dealer from extending credit on any security that is a part of a new issue in whose distribution he participated within the preceding six months as a member of a selling group or syndicate.
Your editorial of Sept. 27, "An Ancient Minority," is eloquent in calling to public attention the dangers for Navajos and Hopis inherent in provisions of the pending Navajo-Hopi Bill.

Tonight's musical events: "Ariadne auf Naxos," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:30 o'clock; "Hansel and Gretel," and "Down in the Valley," Lemonade Opera, Greenwich Mews Playhouse, 8:40; Queens Symphony Orchestra, Alfred Thieleker, conductor, Gertrude Freeze, soprano, Forest Hills High School, 8:30.

Yesterday was the 100th anniversary of the first steam train operation of the Hudson River Railroad Company between West Thirty-first Street and Peekskill. In those days the Vanderbilts did not like railroads because "the Commodore," whose bronze statue now adorns the front of the Grand Central Terminal, was then the largest owner of Hudson River steamboats.

The downward trend in meat prices continues, with pork and beef lower for the second successive week and several cuts of beef 4 or 5 cents less than they were last Friday. The City Department of Markets, which noted these changes in its weekly survey of retail shops yesterday, also reported that prices of poultry and eggs have dropped.
MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The Soviet-Yugoslav military alliance, signed in Moscow on April 11, 1945, was to have run for twenty years. Under its main provisions the two powers agreed.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 -- Cardinal chances of a tenth National League pennant suffered a damaging jolt on Forbes Field today when the Pirates, on an almost unnoticed rampage, buried the Redbirds, 7 to 2, before 9,573 chilled cash customers.

CANTON, China, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Defense Ministry charged today that the "direct influence of Soviet Russia" was behind a move which appears to have severed remote Sinkiang Province from Nationalist China.

TROY, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Senator John Foster Dulles, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, warned today that unless the trend toward an all-powerful central government were checked, the country eventually would have to fight its way back to liberty and freedom "through revolution."

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- A gradual lowering of construction costs was predicted today by Thomas S. Holden, president of the F. W. Dodge Corporation, and by Raymond M. Foley, Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, Washington, D. C. Both were speakers at the annual fall meeting of the Producers' Council, Inc., in cooperation with the Chicago Building Congress.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 29 -- President Truman pleaded tonight for a $100,000,000,000 expansion of the national income to improve the American standard of living and declared that with his Fair Deal program "we will win in 1950 and we will win in 1952."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The number of new labor disputes that resulted in work stoppages increased during August, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 24, 1949, totaled 661,472 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 81,550 cars, or 11 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 247,120 cars, or 27.2 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 276,482 cars, or 29.5 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of 1947.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan took initial steps today toward rigid marketing quotas for the 1950 cotton crop. Quotas would he designed to hold down the size of the crop and prevent accumulation of a top-heavy surplus.

E. B. McInerney has been appointed to the board of directors of the Royal Bank of Canada, it was announced yesterday. He has been manager of the bank's branch in London, England, since 1929, and will be succeeded in that post by B. Strath, assistant manager since 1948.

Among the newly opened art exhibitions, Lynn Rowan's watercolors of New York street scenes, now on view at the RoKo Gallery, are fine pieces of staging. The visual facts are all accounted for and then taken liberties with through an impetuous manner that gives them the dramatic character that is this artist's particular approach to a subject.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- Something that was unbelievable last Sunday became a thrilling fact today when the indomitable Brooklyn Dodgers took a double-header from the Braves and suddenly found themselves half a game in first place instead of a game and a half behind the Cardinals.
Five prominent English clergymen sailed for home yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after a six-week tour of the United States.

The American League flag race, which plunged into another first-place tie between the Yankees and Red Sox, following the Senators' spectacular ninth-inning victory over Boston in Washington Wednesday night, came to a complete standstill yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The text of the Soviet note abrogating the treaty of friendship with Yugoslavia, as broadcast today from Moscow and distributed by the Soviet Monitor, an affiliate of the Tass news agency:

The recent explosion in Russia has had the effect of breaking a legislative log jam in Washington -- proof enough, perhaps, that the by-products of atomic fission can travel a long way in a short time. The military aid bill went briskly through both houses on Wednesday, carrying an authorization nearly half a billion dollars greater than that which the House was willing to approve in August.

Paraplegics are responding favorably to the essay contest on "How the Veterans of Foreign Wars Can Help Me, a Non-Ambulatory Veteran," sponsored by the Crossroads of the World Post, No. 310, VFW, it was learned yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 29 -- The Ministry of Home Affairs published today a seventy-one-page booklet entitled "Communist Violence in India." It reveals, in detail from captured documents, the Communist party's instructions to its members for armed assaults upon authority through guerrilla bands and "shock brigades" preparatory to a general revolution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 24 were 8 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

Oneida County, N. Y., sold yesterday an issue of $1,100,000 of airport bonds due from Dec. 1, 1949 to 1966 to a banking syndicate headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler and including Reynolds Co. and Ira Haupt Co., at a bid of 100.0899 for an interest coupon of 1.40 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The Radio Corporation of America told the Federal Communications Commission today that the first color television sets it offers the public probably will range in price from $400 to $1,000.

Arbitration of disputed contract terms for 3,300 drivers and maintenance employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation was begun yesterday. Representatives of the two concerns and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, met at the offices of the American Arbitration Association, 9 Rockefeller Plaza, to present their viewpoints.

"Task Force," which arrives at the Strand, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Gary Cooper is starred in the Warner Brothers drama dealing with naval aviation, with Jane Wyatt, Wayne Morris, Walter Brennan, Julie London and Bruce Bennett among the principal players.

A political rally with all the essence of a musical comedy -- songs, dances, jokes -- was held yesterday evening, with Newbold Morris, mayorality candidate on the Republican - Liberal - Fusion ticket, stepping briefly into the role of lead comedian.

Many parties were given at the Wedgwood Ball, the pre-opening dinner dance held last night in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Lighthouse of the New York Association of the Blind. Mrs. Donald S. Stralem and Mrs. Constance Woodworth were co-chairmen of the dinner committee.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Efforts to achieve a compromise in the wage dispute that has split the French Cabinet were renewed today, with the prospect that negotiations would continue through tomorrow. There was progress toward agreement on a price reduction program, but the Socialists remained in disagreement with Finance Minister Maurice Petsche over the question of a bonus to workers in the lower brackets.
