The Whitehead Metal Products Company has sold its building at 205 Frelinghuysen Avenue, corner of Branford Street, in Newark, N. J., to the 535 Realty Company. The F. N. Breidenbach Company was the broker. The Whitehead company has moved its steel warehouse to larger quarters in a portion of the former Crucible Steel building in Harrison.

Small business apparently has lost none of its appeal as the "darling" of legislators, financial spokesmen commented yesterday. After reading Washington reports that the subcommittee of the Joint Congressional Economic Committee had received a proposal for the creation of special banks to service small firms, bankers observed that they'd "heard it all before."

In denouncing the treaty of friendship and alliance with Yugoslavia the Soviet Government is working up to a crescendo in its campaign to overthrow Tito. It bases its latest action on the "evidence" in the treason trial in Budapest that Laszlo Rajk was conspiring with Yugoslav and American agents against the Communist regime in Hungary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Senate, by a vote of 52 to 14, passed this evening a "must" bill of the Administration calling for salary increases, ranging up to $7,500 a year, to more than 200 top-level officials of the executive branch of the Government.

The need for variety performers to provide entertainment for military personnel in Japan, Guam, the Philippines and Okinawa was announced yesterday by the Special Services Division of the Far East Command, through its special representative, Edward Sheffield Stephenson.

An employer-financed, industry-wide welfare program that will benefit 2,500 employes of 131 iron fabricating and structural steel concerns in this city, Westchester and Long Island, and their 6,000 dependents, went into effect yesterday.

Full of praise for the Marshall Plan, 16-year-old Gerhard Hornemann, who lives in the British sector of Berlin, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday for a two-week stay as a guest of the State Department and the Army as a winner of an essay contest on "What the ERP Means to Me."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed irregular, 5 points lower to 17 points higher than on Wednesday.

Donald E. Fellows, actor and singer and a member of the "South Pacific" cast, has purchased the one-family house at 443 Ninth Avenue, Pelham, N. Y., from Heinz H. Biel. Finnerty's Real Estate was the broker in the transaction.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 29 -- Concluding eight days of party debate on his Government policy statement, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer reiterated today German claims on the Saar. However, he warned the Bundestag, or lower house, to refrain from embellishing such a "justified" demand with demands on Sudeten Czechoslovakia and insinuations that Austria, too, ought to be part of a German federation.

STALINGRAD, Russia, Sept. 28 -- United States Ambassador Alan G. Kirk today concluded a three-day unofficial visit to Stalingrad, whose war-time defense, in the words of the late President Roosevelt, "marked the turning point in the war."

An aerial search for two Italian fliers, missing since Sept. 17 in an attempted non-stop flight from the Azores to New York in a light single-engined plane, was ended after several hours of rescue frights over the Atlantic yesterday when the reports from Italy that had instigated the search were branded as a hoax.

American weaving mills are buying imported rayon staple at a landed price 1 and 2 cents under that of comparable American fiber, it was learned yesterday. Initial orders for delivery in October are comparatively small, however, textile men said, to give the weavers opportunity to make their test for uniformity of quality.

The local premiere of "People Like Us" has been advanced a second time. Jot it down now for Wednesday night, Oct. 19, instead of Oct. 25, at the Cort. Producer William L. Taub had expressed a preference for the Mansfield, which the Shuberts are booking during the tenure of the DuMont Television lease from Michael Myerberg, owner of the house, until next August.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Iva Ikuko Toguri D'Aquino, known as Tokyo Rose to Allied troops in the South Pacific, was found guilty tonight of betraying the United States, her native land, by broadcasting morale-damaging statements while in the employ of Radio Tokyo.

TORONTO, Sept. 29 -- A full twenty minutes before the first alarm was turned in to the Toronto Fire Department, from the deck, the Noronic's C deck was ablaze, Earl E. Roettger of Cleveland testified Friday before the Federal inquiry being conducted here.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 -- As expected, business in the Pittsburgh district declined sharply last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. All the drop resulted directly or indirectly from the almost complete shutdown of the coal mines; the volume of trade on a seasonally adjusted basis was up appreciably.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Fire chiefs meeting here hope to cut down on flaming deaths by persuading Hollywood to stop showing scenes of people smoking in bed.

The breach between Benjamin A. Javits, cofounder of the Investors League, Inc., with B. C. Forbes, chairman, widened yesterday when Mr. Javits, who resigned as vice president and general counsel on Aug. 22, obtained an order from the State Supreme Court which gives him immediate access to the membership list.

The committee of eight police officials chosen to weigh the evidence for permitting the smaller taxicab in New York City should have an easy time making up its mind. Mayor O'Dwyer went to Police Headquarters himself and read the verdict even before the jury had begun to hear witnesses.
Complaints that the New York Central System had treated its Putnam division like a stepchild failed yesterday to persuade the system that it should restore two trains cut from its fall schedule.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Ray C. Wakefield, 54 years old, a member of the Federal Communications Commission from 1941 to 1947, died at Emergency Hospital today.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- British industrialists who are being urged to help end the country's dollar famine by tripling their exports to the dollar markets now fear that the continuing high level of taxation will drive their production costs too high and may even frustrate the effect of devaluation as a stimulant to the export drive.

EXETER, N. H., Sept. 29 -- The lot of a prep school football mentor is a lesson in futility. From year to year he labors with his green material and just when his earnest efforts are beginning to pay off, his potential stars are graduated. Thus, the ensuing season finds coaches having to start from scratch.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Federal district Judge Michael L. Igoe, who has been presiding in the Tucker Corporation reorganization case since its start last March, criticized attorneys again today for delays in the proceedings.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- A veteran newspaper photographer was killed and three United States Navy officers seriously wounded at 2:40 o'clock this afternoon when a signal mortar exploded on the beach as 3,000 sailors and marines staged an amphibious landing under simulated combat conditions.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 29 -- The National Cotton Council will open sales promotion offices in New York on Oct. 1, it was announced here today by Ed Lipscomb, director of sales promotion and public relations. Paul M. Jones, who for the last four years has served as sales promotion manager in Memphis, will head the New York offices at 271 Church Street, formerly occupied by the Cotton-Textile Institute.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- The Legal Committee voted today to open and close the annual General Assembly with one minute of silence dedicated to prayer or meditation, leaving it up to each delegate to use that time to pay homage to his God, meditate on the principles of the United Nations, or both.

William L. Laurence, in his article on Sept. 24, placed his finger on a very important point when he suggested that the Soviet development of the atomic bomb might make an agreement with Russia easier, since "bargaining between equals is more likely to produce desirable results than bargaining between two principals, one of which holds a decided advantage over the other."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29 -- A. manifesto of the Syrian National Bloc, the party representing elements most firmly opposed to union with Iraq or Jordan, showed this morning that the party had gone all the way for unity with Iraq.

Newbold Morris, the Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Mayor, predicted the election of himself and his running-mates yesterday by the "comfortable margin" of 100,000 to 150,000 votes. Mr. Morris made his estimate informally at a press conference at his Astor Hotel headquarters when he was asked how large he thought the registration had to be to enable his ticket to win.

The Rego Park View Corporation has purchased a vacant plot, 100 by 120 feet, on the south side of Saunders Street, 100 feet west of Sixty-fifth Road, in Forest Hills, Queens, from Leonard Morgenthaler. The new owner plans to improve the site with a six-story apartment building.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 29 -- The Soviet Government's denunciation of its treaty alliance with Yugoslavia has steered the Belgrade-Moscow struggle into more dangerous channels, according to informed opinion here tonight.

TOKYO, Sept. 29 -- Prices of Japan's export goods are expected to drop perhaps 25 per cent within the next few weeks. Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters now appears about to remove virtually all floor prices which have been making it impossible for Japanese items to compete in world markets.

The first Business Archives Center in New York for the storage and servicing of corporate records is now ready for operations, Emmett J. Leahy, executive director, The National Records Management Council, told more than 150 members of the Records Management Association at its one-day conference at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

VANCOUVER, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The International Woodworkers of America (CIO-CCL) today swung its entire 100,000 members behind the CIO's campaign to raise dollars for Political Action Committees.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A delegation of the Congress of Industrial Organizations that visited Palestine recently recommended today further substantial loans by the United States to the Republic of Israel.

Findings of the first comprehensive economic survey ever made of transatlantic air freight for any considerable period were released here yesterday by Seaboard and Western Airlines, Inc., the only all-freight international carrier in this country.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- Wilson H. Compton, alternate United States representative to the United Nations General Assembly, cautioned the Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee today against attaching "undue significance" to "conflicts of opinion" over proposed legislation to carry out President Truman's Point Four program.
Non-contributory pensions are advocated in your issue of Sept. 27 by Alfred Baker Lewis. However, he confuses rather than clarifies the issues. To do so he distorts some facts and ignores others.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Justice Isadore Bookstein of the Supreme Court tonight granted another temporary stay of enforcement of the Feinberg "anti-subversive" school law. He acted on a suit challenging the constitutionality of the law.

His engagement as an accordionist at Iceland Restaurant, 1680 Broadway, was extended at least one more day yesterday for Anthony Lavelli, Yale basketball star of last season, byt a truce reached last night in a jurisdictional labor dispute.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 29 -- New England's railroad leaders were told bluntly today by one of their important customers that unless they could gear less-than-carload shipments to speeds demanded by industrial sales departments they would face continuingly greater competition from trucking companies.

In answer to John M. Gibson's letter published Sept. 18 challenging the statement of Dean Bernard Berelson of the University of Chicago, in which the latter claims that the test of being well read lies in reading a book a month, I make bold to say that both writers are in error.

An insurance broker who periodically quits New York's financial district for a compass point in the jungle told yesterday of how his] feats of "magic," purchased in a store off Times Square, won over recalcitrant head hunters of the Amazon.
Eight crewmen said the man was dead. But the ninth, 22-year-old William Stillwaggon, looked at the dripping figure on the deck and insisted it still held life.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- The British Government is considering an invitation to the United Nations to hold next year's General Assembly in Edinburgh, Scotland, if any formal move is made to shift the 1950 scene of operations from New York.

Dr. Robert M. W. Kampner of Philadelphia warned Americans not to depend too heavily on the newly constituted Bonn Government in Western Germany as he returned yesterday from four years of service as a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The announcement by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, that dividend taxes will be increased in Great Britain to offset profits exporters may earn in the dollar area as a result of the devaluation of the pound, surprised most participants in the recent Washington monetary conversations and dismayed many of them.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 29 -- This evening the radios of two of the Isbrandtsen Line ships halted by the Nationalists in the Yangtze [the outbound Flying Clipper and Flying Independent were indicated] went off the air after reporting that the ships were being boarded.

A self-admitted state unemployment insurance chiseler escaped a sixty-day workhouse sentence yesterday when his landlord came forward in Municipal Term Court to pay a $672 fine that had been levied as an alternative. The defendant, however, received an additional fifteen-day term that he is now serving.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers agreed with the television industry yesterday to extend to Oct. 15 the poriod for determination of compensation to be paid by video stations for use of the society's music.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 14 -- Indians in Ceylon, who comprise one-eighth of the population and most of the laboring class, are facing a crisis in their status here that has placed the relations of the Governments of Ceylon and India in a delicate balance.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 -- The United Public Workers, arraying itself alongside other left-wing unions threatened with expulsion from the Congress of Industrial Organizations, charged today that "fratricidal suicide" was being committed within the CIO at the expense of the basic principles of trade unionism.

The Continental Shipyard in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, from which the Monitor, famous ironclad, steamed out in 1862 to open a new era of naval warfare in her historic battle with the Merrimac, appears to have reached the closing chapter of an eighty-nine-year career.

Dr. Millicent Carey McIntosh, dean of Barnard College, urged yesterday greater student participation in maintaining the college's emphasis on scholarship free of "adolescent fetters and childish enthusiasms." She congratulated students and faculty on helping to reduce the college's budgeted deficit from more than $100,000 to $77,000.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- Long-range effects of the devaluation of Britain's pound sterling and other foreign currencies will be to lower prices here and create more competitive conditions for American products, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, conceded here today.

Many of this country's major industries watched closely yesterday the progress of steel negotiations in Pittsburgh, mindful that a trike after midnight tonight would critically involve them in a matter of weeks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- The largest single sum of money ever raised by the women of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States was presented today to the church's triennial general convention.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Administration forces ran into opposition today in a drive for House passage without change of a bill to expand and liberalize the social security program.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29 -- The Harvard football team will leave tomorrow morning for New York to play Columbia at Baker Field Saturday in its first appearance in the big city in many years, and Lou Little and the Lions are warned that trouble is brewing for them, regardless of what happened to the Crimson in its opening game with Stanford at Palo Alto.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 -- Dynamiting of two tipples at nonunion mines in Pennsylvania and Kentucky was reported today as an estimated 15,000 miners continued to man strip and deep-mine operations in defiance of the nationwide work stoppage by the United Mine Workers of America.
SEA CLIFF, L. I., Sept. 29 -- Walter I. Wood, who has just returned from participating in a search near the summit of Mount Ararat for Noah's Ark, declared here today that the search had been futile.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 29 -- The texts of two messages from Sinkiang leaders, published here today, announcing a shift of allegiance to the Communists, indicate that the defection was a victory for Gen. Chang Chih-chung and makes possible his plan for Soviet help in developing that vast Central Asian province.

Fifty tons of scenery, costumes and properties came here from England yesterday in the biggest transatlantic haul in theatrical history. The shipment was a full complement of material for the first American engagement of the Sadler's Wells Ballet that opens on Oct. 9 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Original eighteenth and nineteenth century prints are displayed with reproductions in an educational exhibition of French, English and American toiles that opens Monday at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street.
MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A plan for reorganization and refinancing of the Aeronca Aircraft Corporation has been approved by shareholders.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Three United States merchant vessels were intercepted and halted by Chinese Nationalist warships today in Chinese territorial waters off Shanghai.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- A drive to improve the economic and social conditions of the country's 1,500,000 migrant agricultural workers and their families was started today at the National Conference on the Church and Migratory labor.

Homemakers who are nostalgic for the quaint hominess and warm informality of an early American countryside cottage will feel completely at home in a series of three model rooms just installed at Hathaway, 51 West Forty-fifth Street. A living room, bedroom and dining room have been furnished with pine reproductions from the Drexel American Traditional collection, and the Lees Countryside Collection of carpets designed to harmonize with them cover the floors.

Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, was cited last night for "courageous leadership and distinguished service in furthering the ideas of the United Nations" at a testimonial dinner in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel given by the American Association for the United Nations.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The Earl of Harewood, 26-year-old nephew of King George VI, married Austrian-born Marion Stein, 22, this afternoon and 10,000 Londoners and visitors from the provinces took the day off to pack the streets and squares between the church and Buckingham and St. James's Palaces in the hope of catching a glimpse of the celebrities.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- The Yugoslavs are playing a bold, prominent and controversial role in the current session of the United Nations General Assembly.

A newspaper campaign, described as the "most concentrated" yet undertaken to inform the public on year-around dependability and regularity of air transportation, has been scheduled for this fall and winter by United Air Lines. Beginning in October, ads will run in thirty-six newspapers of major cities from coast to coast.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Eastman Kodak Company announced today price reductions affecting 8 mm. home movie film, certain cameras and accessories and color prints.
ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- A Cornell University scientist has installed a battery of geiger counters 2,250 feet under the shore of Cayuga Lake in an effort to find out more about cosmic rays.

RYE, N. Y., Sept 29 -- A former metropolitan district player who now lives in Villanova, Pa., and registers from Merion, Mrs. Robert F. Beard, became the new title-holder today as the twenty-fourth annual United States Women's Senior Golf Championship was concluded over the south course of the Westchester Country Club, Mrs. Beard posted an 81 for a two-round total of 166.
Representatives of the city's taxicab industry said yesterday they could not heed the Mayor's plea for increased commissions for drivers unless a fare increase were granted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A foreign aid appropriation of $5,809,990,000 got final Congressional approval tonight. The measure includes $3,628,380,000 for European recovery in the current fiscal year and $150,000,000 of additional loan authorizations for Marshall Plan countries from the Export-Import Bank.

Leaders of both the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations have decided to make an intensive campaign for the election of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator.

The Board of Estimate gave preliminary authorization for construction of the South Street elevated highway yesterday and Manhattan Borough President Hugo E. Rogers announced the project would go on the drawing boards of his engineers "at once."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- Montgomery Clift, who has been absent from Hollywood since he completed "The Heiress" a year ago, will arrive in town tomorrow in preparation for the start next week of Paramount's new screen version of the Theodore Dreiser novel, "An American Tragedy," which George Stevens will produce and direct, with Clift in the role of Clyde Griffiths.

"Lincoln Finds A General," a two-volume military study of the Civil War by Kenneth P. Williams, will be published on Nov. 1 by Macmillan. Mr. Williams, Professor of Mathematics at Indiana University, appraises the leaders and campaigns of both the Union and the Confederacy during 1861-64 and recounts Lincoln's search for a general capable of winning victory over Lee and Jackson.
TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Enforcement of provisions regulating canners in the new Florida citrus law was ordered held up temporarily today by Federal Judge W. K. Barker.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 29 -- The Chancellory announced this afternoon that the exchange rate of the Deutsche mark in Western Germany was 23.8095 cents, retroactively effective Sept. 19, the day Britain devaluated the pound.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- Britain will lead other colonial powers in a determined fight to kill a special United Nations committee that has passed critical judgment on conditions in dependent areas throughout the world, a high British delegation source disclosed today.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation has received the work of installing additional refrigeration space aboard the six Grace Line C-2 combination passenger cargo vessels regularly employed in the line's run on the West Coast of South America, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Parliament's grand inquest into the causes and consequences of devaluation of the pound was concluded with a 342 to 5 vote of confidence in the Government tonight after a debate in which economic issues were thrust aside by political electioneering.

The youngster, a week in the hospital, smiled weakly from his bed. His left leg was in traction; his right wrist was in a plaster cast, the result of an automobile accident. He told anxious relatives that he was getting along fine although the doctors said he would have to be there for several months.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- At the academic convocation marking the opening of the eighty-fifth year of Vassar College, Dean Marion Tait today stressed that "in education, as in any enterprise, the really important first things are the quality and sincerity of our mutual care and respect for each other as individual human beings."

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- December wheat developed independent weakness on the Board of Trade today, closing 1 1/8 cents a bushel lower, while the deferred months rose 3/8 to 1 1/4 cents, the latter on July. Corn was unchanged to 1/2 cent off; oats, l/4 to 1/2 cent off; rye, 1/2 cent off to 1/4 cent up; soybeans, 1/2 to 1 cent up.

Mrs. Edith Marqusee has been named merchandise manager of the Bonwit Teller branch stores. Anita Cleary becomes-manager of Bonwit Teller, White Plains, and Jean Allen becomes buyer of separates, sweaters, beachwear and play clothes for all stores.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Britain took a long step toward freer international trade today. Import quota restrictions were removed from about half of the goods that private traders buy from soft-currency countries.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Passenger trains on the New York Central Railroad's West Shore division were described here today at a Public Servce Commission hearing as "worse than cattle cars." However, witnesses urged the commission to restore to service four trains eliminated by the railroad last Sunday.
W. C. Stolk, executive vice president of the American Can Company, has been made a director, D. W. Figgis, chairman, announced today. Mr. Stolk succeeds James B. Taylor, who has retired.
Consolidated net earnings of Colonial Mills, Inc., were $2,122,641 for the nine months ended Aug. 31, according to the report yesterday.
Coffee and sugar futures prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange rose yesterday under rather strong demand, but other commodity markets exhibited mixed price trends.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Rumors of an early general election stimulated leading industrial shares to such good purpose in the stock markets today that they more than recouped yesterday's losses which were caused by an increase in the profits tax.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A request for an immediate $70,000,000 fund needed for the first step in a program to accelerate this nation's production of atomic weapons has cleared the White House and will be transmitted to Congress soon, it was learned today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- Following are speeches by Dr. T. F. Tsiang of China and Warren R. Austin of the United States and an unofficial translation of excerpts from a speech in Russian by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky on the Chinese question at a plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly here today:
The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it had endorsed Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, and regarded Mayor O'Dwyer, his Democratic opponent, as qualified.

TOKYO, Sept. 29 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Japanese press tonight that establishment of a two-party system here along lines in the United States would best pave the way for vitally needed foreign investments and the early conclusion of a peace treaty.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Bucky Walters, who failed to develop the Cincinnati Reds into a winning team this year, was released as manager today. Inexperience was cited by Warren Giles, general manager, as the reason for letting the once great right-handed pitcher go.

While insisting that they had largely succeeded in stopping unemployment insurance payments to longshoremen "seeking work" in the Catskill Mountains, and garment workers doing likewise in Miami, state and Federal insurance officials announced yesterday a new for further such plan reducing chiseling.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted unanimously today to set up a new conciliation committee for settlement of differences between Greece and her neighbors -- Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia.
The possibility that New York's railroad supply lines may have to be shortened was raised yesterday at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing in the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

TROY, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley told a Veterans of Foreign Wars meeting here tonight that free speech should be restricted for persons advocating destruction of "the things we believe in."
CHICAGO, Sept 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The problem of having "job customers" just as satisfied as product customers cannot be solved in efforts confined to the four walls of the office or factory, it was de clared last night by Virgil B. Day, assistant manager, employe relations, policy division, General Electric Company.

Response to earlier merchandising of Christmas cards indicates good holiday season sales that should bring 1949 greeting card retail volume to slightly under the 1947 peak of $200,000,000, it was learned yesterday.

A new issue of 10,000 shares of the Southwestern Associated Telephone Company's preferred stock will be placed on the market today by an underwriting syndicate headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, the Stone Webster Securities Corporation and Rauscher, Pierce Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A Federal Housing Administration official said today the agency has made no regulation requiring builders to have mortgage applications filed or processed through FHA. He explained, however, that the FHA has cautioned its field offices by letter that it has neither funds nor staff sufficient to handle large numbers of housing applications which do not result in FHA mortgage insurance.

Complete satisfaction with the contract between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was expressed yesterday by Henry Ford 2d shortly before he sailed for Europe aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Mr. Ford was accompanied by his wife.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 -- The problem of medical indigency is "vastly exaggerated" in New York and the other wealthy states and there seems to be no need for the Federal Goverenment to help those states, Dr. Eli Ginzberg, director of the New York State Hospital Study, declared today.

The New York City Opera Company began its fall season at the redecorated City Center last night with a tribute to the late Richard Strauss in the form of a performance of his "Ariadne auf Naxos." There was nothing gloomy in this tribute, for "Ariadne" is full of bite and laughing poetry.
The City Youth Board that was set up in April, 1948, to combat juvenile delinquency has had encouraging results, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday in a report on its activities.

The keenly awaited debate in Britain's Parliament has come and gone, leaving us all -- including the British people -- as much in the dark as ever. Seldom could so many words have been used to say so little, and that goes for the man whose famous sentence is being paraphrased.

The stock market blew hot and cold yesterday. After extending gains to around the best levels of the year, prices eased in the final hour and closed mixed. Sales topped the million-share mark for the fourteenth consecutive session, expanding to 1,380,000 shares -- due largely to activity in the low-price utility shares -- compared with 1,300,000 shares on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A freakish home run by Third Baseman Bob Kennedy helped the Indians beat the White Sox, 8 -- 3, today as the winners pulled within a game of third-place Detroit in the American League standings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The first of a series of fourteen regional conferences to plan a much- accelerated March of Dimes for January because of the high costs of this year's poliomyelitis epidemic was held here today. Five states were represented.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- During the week ended Sept. 28, member bank reserve balances increased $256,000,000. the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Two five-story buildings, each with fifteen apartments, at 507 and 519 West 1338th Street, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, were sold by the Chase National Bank to Samuel Hurwitz, who bought them for cash over purchase money mortgages of $18,750 on each building.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The Westchester Cancer Committee said today that the county's first cancer detection center would open Wednesday night in New Rochelle Hospital and function every Wednesday night thereafter.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- British diplomatic quarters saw nothing of immediate threat to Yugoslavia in the denunciation today by the Soviet Union of its treaty of friendship with Belgrade. The Kremlin's action did not seem to alter the situation as the treaty already had ceased to have any meaning in the light of the Soviet Union's persistent and virulent hostility toward Yugoslavia.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., has offered four of its subsidiaries an exchange of Federated common stock for their net assets under a plan to simplify the corporate structure of the parent organization, Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated, announced yesterday.

Three members of the Senate Armed Services Committee disclosed yesterday that they had heard testimony in Germany that corroborated charges of American brutality against former SS officers and men tried for participation in the massacre of eighty-three Americans at Malmedy, Belgium.

ROME, Sept. 29 -- Debate in the Chamber of Deputies on the Government's financial and economic policy after the devaluation of the pound began this afternoon and resolved itself into a harsh attack by the Opposition against the United States in general and the Marshall Plan in particular.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Declaring experience had shown that the "hand of monopoly is a dead hand," Crawford H. Greenwalt, president of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., said today that his company's present size and success had not resulted from "stifling competition by absorbing competitors."

Maintaining their upward movement for the fifth successive week, business loans made by banks in this area rose $50,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday. According to the data covering the twenty-four reporting New York City member banks, issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, business loans outstanding now total $4,765,000,000.

The Foreign Ministers of the four great powers failed to make any appreciable headway here in a conference on a treaty for Austria that ran nearly five hours and broke up at an early hour yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Rain prevented the Red Sox from engaging the Senators in the finale of their series today at Griffith Stadium. Locked in a first-place tie with the Yankees, the Bosox were not quite sure whether they welcomed the postponement until they learned that the Yankees, too, were idle.

The Jack Skinner-saddled entry of Trough Hill and American Way, which had made a one, three finish in the 1948 Brook Steeplechase, did even better in yesterday's forty-first running of the Brook at gray, rainy Belmont Park. This time it was a one. two hit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Texans took up the battle today against a third term on the Federal Power Commission for Leland Olds. They charged him with plans to destroy state powers over natural gas and, eventually, oil.

"HAVE you ever heard of Thoreau?" the nature-struck man from the city said to his wife, "Henry David Thoreau?" His wife said no, she had never heard of Thoreau, Henry David Thoreau. They were looking at a house in the country, a picturesque old ruin of a place, one of those perishing rustic disasters with A View.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- Despite a hard-hitting speech by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, who denied Soviet intervention and charged that the successes of the Chinese Communists had resulted from the incapacity of the Chinese Government, the United Nations General Assembly decided today to place China's complaint against the Soviet Union on the agenda of the present session.

The resolution of Andrew G. Clauson Jr., Richmond member of the Board of Education, urging salary increases ranging from $300 to $812 for members of the school staff has been referred to the Committee on Budget and Finance and to Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, "for a joint report within a reasonable time," it was announced yesterday after a public meeting of the board.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- A new opera on the largest scale opened the winter season at the Covent Garden Opera House tonight, "The Olympians," with book by J. B. Priestley and music by Arthur Bliss.

Last Sunday afternoon a shiny convertible car drew off the Wilbur Cross Highway somewhere between Hartford and New Haven. Its top was down to the warm sun, and it had New York City license plates, A young couple left it, stealthily approached a stone wall and from it began to rip great clusters of autumn foliage.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina reserved decision yesterday on defense motions to throw out the whole nine-month Communist trial, but indicated he was inclined to deny them. He did this by agreeing with United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey that the Government's case is stronger today than it was last May when the judge denied similar motions.

The Board of Estimate approved unanimously yesterday the local law amendment giving the City Temporary Housing Rent Commission power to review decisions of the Federal Housing Expediter that increase apartment rentals above the March 1, 1949, level.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Tear gas bombs today ended the more violent of two wild melees that broke out in the turbulent Bell Aircraft strike as non-strikers sought to pass an all-women picket line.

For those who are unable to wait, woodcock will be legal game in the myriad of alder runs in Maine tomorrow, and while none of the reports indicate an abundance of native birds the timber-doodle population is said to be as large as last year.

The tenants of 441 East Ninety-second Street agreed yesterday that man's best friend is the dog and that a tabby on the hearthstone is indeed a heart-warming sight. However, they asserted, it wasn't sufficient reason to ask them to give up their homes to make room for a new dog and cat hospital.

A luxuriously appointed ten-room house of contemporary design that has been furnished and decorated by Lord Taylor will be open for public inspection on Monday at 205 Austen Road, Seven Oaks Park, Orange, N. J. Designed by Emil A. Schmidlin, architect, and Miss Ellis Leigh, designer, the house in Orange has been selected by House Beautiful as its "Pace Setter" house for 1949.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the Combined Locks Paper Company, Combined Locks, Wis., had filed a registration statement covering 50,000 shares of its Class A common stock, $1 par value, that are to be offered for sale by certain of the company's stockholders.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29 -- The Soviet Union announced tonight that it had formally denounced its treaty of friendship, mutual assistance and post-war cooperation with Yugoslavia. The action was taken on the ground that the Yugoslav Government had carried on "hostile and disruptive work" against the Soviet Union at the instigation of "foreign imperialist circles."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 29 -- A new United States-supported plan for freeing European currencies and trade, described by one official as bolder and more ambitious than anything yet blueprinted, is being prepared by experts of France, Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands.

The fourth annual Winter Sports Forum, jointly sponsored by the New York State Winter Sports Council and the New York State Department of Commerce, will take place at Youngs Gap Hotel, Parksville, N. Y., starting this afternoon and continuing through Sunday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- Dr. Edvard Kardelj, Yugoslav Minister of Foreign Affairs, issued a statement tonight declaring that "the fact that the Soviet Government has denounced the treaty of friendship and mutual aid with Yugoslava confirms the correctness of the position taken by Yugoslavia at this Assembly, and more particularly of its appraisal of the Soviet Government's anti-democratic attitude toward Yugoslavia."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 -- With 500,000 steel workers set to strike at midnight tomorrow, virtually all the country's steel mills started cooling off their furnaces today in preparation for a full shutdown.

ROME, Sept. 29 -- The Pope said today that artificial insemination of women was entirely illicit and immoral and therefore should be condemned except when practiced under well-defined circumstances in wedlock and merely as an auxiliary to the performance of the natural act.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club finished with 39, 38 -- 77 today for a 54-hole total of 236 to win the fifteenth Women's Long Island Golf Association three-day medal play championship for the third time at the Meadow Brook Club.
Major league baseball's two sizzling pennant races continued to keep the nation's fans in a turmoil of excitement yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 29 -- A twin-motored Lockheed Lodestar plane owned by Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, crashed early this morning in the fog-shrouded meadows in Elizabeth, south of the airport here, injuring three men, none seriously.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 -- With a precedent established in the contract signed with the Ford Motor Company early today, the United Automobile Workers, CIO, will move quickly to make noncontributory pension plans a pattern for the industry.

IT'S rather distracting to turn one's gaze toward the gridiron at this time of the year and discover that the fellows in the huddle are the Yankees, Red Sox, Dodgers and Cardinals. For each of them it is last down and goal to go. Concentrating on football is indeed a chore. But at least this prophet brings a remarkable record for consistency into the task.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- The six-power talks on atomic control continued in strictest secrecy today as the Western powers waited for the Soviet Union to make a move to break the three-year-old logjam on international harnessing of the power of the atom.

Many of the fashions singled out and described by this writer in reports cabled from the Paris couturier openings were presented in originals and copies by Macy's at the luncheon hour yesterday in the Terrace and Persian Rooms of the Plaza Hotel.

There will be no lowering of dollar prices on French perfume imports as a result of currency devaluation, toiletries trade sources reported yesterday. Some perfumers have already adjusted franc prices upward to match the higher exchange rate, and the action is expected to become general, it was reported.

The United States has about two million civilian employes. Between March 22, 1947, and the end of July, 1949, about 10,000 of these came up on charges or suspicions of disloyalty. Of the 5,450 cases decided, according to the current report of the Loyalty Review Board, "ineligible determinations" were made in 332 cases.

Supreme Court Referee Isidor Wasservogel dismissed yesterday a suit brought against the Seafarers International Union, AFL, Atlantic and Gulf District, by twenty-nine men who alleged they had been illegally expelled.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 29 -- The United States called on the United Nations today to send military observers to Korea to keep on the watch for trouble that might lead to civil war in the country.
New York's two National Football League entries, the transplanted Bulldogs and the long-established Giants, will stage the first of two 1949 meetings at the Polo Grounds tonight.

SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 29 -- The dean of Lackawanna Railroad commuters, 87-year-old Henry Bancroft Twombley, will be honored tomorow by the railroad and officials of this community as he completes sixty years of commuting between here and New York.

Building plans filed yesterday included sketches for a new out-patient building for Beth Israel Hospital at 323-35 East Sixteenth Street through to 332-42 East Seventeenth Street costing $654,000. Charles B. Meyer is the architect.
LITTLE ROCK, Sept. 29 -- Four Confederate veterans closed their fifty-ninth annual reunion today amidst the cheers of more than 20,000 persons along a one-mile parade route.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Legislation to bolster the Clayton Anti-Trust Act was described today by James L. Donnelly, executive vice president of the Illinois Manufacturers' Association, as "an unwarranted attempt by Federal bureaucracy to secure further domination over industry and business."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Ending a year-old mystery, the House Un-American Activities Committee today named a young Midwest university professor as the "Scientist X" it accused of giving war-time atomic secrets to a man it called a Communist spy.

Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, declared yesterday that he had found a "joker" in a housing rehabilitation bill fostered by Mayor O'Dwyer, Robert Moses and Joseph T. Sharkey. But Mr. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, retorted quickly that what Mr. Stichman had "discovered" was not a joker.

In its first change of ownership since it was erected in 1907, the six-story apartment house for thirty-eight families at 508-10 Lenox Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of West 135th Street, has been sold by the McKinley Realty and Construction Company to Samuel Hurwitz, operator, it was announced yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 30 -- The three American merchantmen were still being held off the mouth of the Yangtze under "continuous threat of fire," the Isbrandtsen Company's agent here reported tonight.

In a decorative setting provided by the Astor Gallery and the Jade and Basildon rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the New York Antiques Exposition opened its fifteenth fair yesterday for a run through Tuesday.

With an air pistol and a note nearby, the body of Mrs. Betsy Ross Hansen, 32 years old, widow of Dr. William Webster Hansen, research worker in the fields of radar and nuclear physics, was found yesterday in her apartment at 48 Greenwich Avenue.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- A suggestion that the United States finance a new Marshall aid program for South Asia and build up India as an Asiatic bulwark against communism was made today by the influential Manchester Guardian.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 30 -- The United Rubber Workers, CIO, ended their thirty-five-day strike against the B. F. Goodrich Company today for a "10-cent package" that is to be devoted to improvements on existing pension and insurance plans.

A variety of dishes for autumn menus is suggested by the foods that the United States Department of Agriculture reports will be in abundant supply this month. What's more, the list of "plentifuls," which includes items that are as reasonably priced as they are readily available, is an excellent guide for those who do their grocery shopping on a budget.

The Scandinavian National Travel Commission has authorized an out-of-season advertising campaign to attract serious-minded tourists interested in social welfare, educational advancement, the cooperative system and similar activities, it was announced yesterday.
Gloom, black and foreboding, darkened every nook and cranny of the Yankee dressing room following the victory of the Athletics yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 -- Resort openings here presage the most exciting, wearable and flattering clothes season in years, starting about November for those who travel to warmer climes and extending on into summer for everyone.

Victor Borge, comedian and pianist, became yesterday the first major Hollywood star to resign from the American Guild of Variety Artists as a result of the union's jurisdictional dispute with the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo.

Eleventh-hour efforts by government mediators have failed to resolve the differences between labor and management in the steel industry. As a result the long-threatened strike of 500,000 workers became a fact at one minute past midnight this morning.

In a beam-ceilinged room in The Cloisters high above Fort Tryon Park stands a fourteenth century French statue of the Virgin, without a head. A half-dozen cool corridors and sunlit cloisters away the statue's head lies forlornly in a locked room among dozens of other medieval art "treasures."

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Dr. Luther H. Evans, Librarian of Congress, and five other delegates to the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, were nominated today to fill six vacancies on the agency's executive board of eighteen members.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of the strike call sent out to steel workers tonight by Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers, CIO:
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The following is the text of Hungary's note repudiating the friendship treaty with Yugoslavia:

READING, Pa., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Some elements of the nation's economy are faced with extinction at the hands of an "overcentralized National Government," the Pennsylvania Realtors Association was told today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- International Harvester Company notified officials of unions representing some 65,000 employes of the company's, twenty-one plants today that it is willing to pay an amount equal to ten cents an hour toward the total cost of pension, insurance and welfare plans.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Foreign exchange dealers and competent financial observers here expressed the belief today that Britain had cut down considerably the rate of loss to her gold and dollar reserves since devaluation of the pound. One estimate is that the return of dollars during the last few days has amounted to many millions of pounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Circulation of a proposed report clearing David E. Lilienthal of accusations of "incredible mismanagement" as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission stirred a harsh controversy today in the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

Dr. Robert V. Seliger, author of 'Alcoholics Are Sick People," which was published by the Oakridge Press of Baltimore, is preparing a manuscript for a new book, "Cancer of the Ego," as well as a textbook in psychiatry for medical doctors, medical psychologists and allied workers in the field of human behavior.

Although sales of Armour Co. and domestic subsidiaries rose to $1,379,072,464 for the thirty-nine weeks to July 30, according to the report released yesterday, the report disclosed a net loss of $6,342,055, after allowing for a tax credit of $3,678,543.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 30 (AP) -- The American Cotton Manufacturers Institute, made up of more than a thousand mills, was formed here today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 30 -- The Yugoslav news agency Tanyug issued a statement tonight asserting that the Soviet Government, in denouncing its treaty of alliance with Yugoslavia, had demonstrated that it considered all of its solemn agreements as "scraps of paper."

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Heavy buying of soybean futures based on reports that the Government might allocate $250,000,000 for the purchase of fats and oats, coincident with a strong upturn in cottonseed oil, dominated trading on the Board of Trade today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Saturday, Oct. 1 -- The United States State Department has rejected a request by the Economic Cooperation Administration representatives in Germany to modify the program of reparations deliveries, it became known today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Truman will make no further attempt to intervene in the steel strike, the White House announced late today after the Chief Executive's return from Kansas City. A close associate of Mr. Truman, who would not be identified by name, said:

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 30 -- Harold A. Brand, 1-year-old former auctioneer on Atlantic City's board-walk, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury in connection with what Assistant United States Attorney Grover C. Richman called the greatest swindle scheme in the state's history.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 30 -- Mao Tze-tung, chairman of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party, was elected chairman of the new Central Government of the People's Republic of China today as the Chinese People's Political Consultative Council completed its job of launching the new government of Communist China.

The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday that it has entered into a ten-year charter contract with the Marine Transport Lines, Inc., for use of the 13,000-ton tanker Marine Chemist in the transport of chemicals from Free-port, Tex., to points on the eastern seaboard.

TORONTO, Sept. 30 -- Garth O'Neil, 19-year-old head bellboy on the Noronic, changed his testimony today at the Federal inquiry. He said he had broken a fire alarm box on the ship and notified the wheelsman of the fire before he had fought a blaze in the linen closet on C Deck, not after.

Pockets, pockets everywhere is a fashionable refrain this season. They trim coats, ornament suits, decorate dresses, are the darling of young and old. Originated by famous designers, their popularity has swept through the fashion world.

The New York Giants it is now apparent, had a selfish motive for permitting the Boston Yanks to be transplanted to this city, where they would operate as the New York Bulldogs of the National Football League. This motive was uncovered at the Polo Grounds last night when the Giant operatives scored a 38-to-14 victory over the erstwhile New England eleven, while a crowd of 17,704 looked on.

Spring lines of women's coats and suits will be taken on the road next week by salesmen of New York garment manufacturers. First showings of the lines will be in the South and Southwest and salesmen will work back to the Eastern territories through principal cities in the Midwest.

City Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr., one of the eleven defendants in the Communist conspiracy trial, submitted yesterday a memorandum to Federal Judge Harold R. Medina and made oral argument on his petition to discharge his counsel, Harry Sacher, so he may present his own summing up to the jury.

All this week the Navy has been pacing a round of celebrations for the 150th birthday of the naval gun factory at Washington. By tomorrow every bureau, every element, will have rendered its own salute and depicted its own part in the story of American naval ordnance -- from Revolutionary 32-pound round shot of 100 yards range to modern 3,000-pound shells that wing twenty-five miles or more.
Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement and the most sacred day in the Jewish calendar, will be observed beginning at sundown tomorrow by Jewish people throughout the world.
Allegheny County, Pa., announced yesterday that it will receive bids Oct. 25 on $6,500,000 of bonds dated Oct. 1, 1949 and due Oct. 1, 1950 to 1979.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- The Cardinals went down to defeat before the Cubs on Wrigley Field this afternoon, 6 -- 5, and their pennant chances suffered a terrific jolt.
MOSCOW, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Another "lost" musical work of the composer, Peter Ilich Tchaikovsky has seen restored and presented in Leningrad.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 30 (AP) -- A wild fight in the cab of a speeding Southern Pacific locomotive brought death to a berserk brakeman early today. He died in a Salem hospital this morning, apparently of injuries suffered in the fight to subdue him.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 30 -- The Belgian Ambassador in London has been instructed to ask Britain for an explanation of what Jean Duvieusart, Minister of Economic Affairs, alleged today was discrimination against Belgian goods.

It seemed to most of us that President Truman did his best the other day to keep his announcement of an atomic explosion in Russia out of politics. He deliberately waited until after the Senate had passed the military aid bill. He made the announcement in as unspectacular a manner as he could.

Nineteen 2-year-olds, including seven stakes winners, three fillies and a pair of maidens, are listed to compete in today's sixtieth running of the Futurity at Belmont Park. The six-and-a-half-furlong sprint down the Widener straight- away is the top race of the year for juveniles.

ALBANY, Sept. 30 -- Governor Dewey will open an intensive personal campaign next week for the election of John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for United States Senator. He will leave Albany by automobile Monday morning on an up-state tour that will combine politics with the inspection and dedication of several public works projects.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has led in the commendable fight for the adoption by the United States Congress of the proposed new Displaced Persons Act, already passed by the House but held up in the Senate by Senator Pat McCarran. It seems to me, however, that between the adoption of the new law and the proposal about to be discussed in the U. N. Assembly there is a close relationship.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The stock markets today ended the second week after devaluation of the pound on a firm note. Further gains were made by British Government stocks, leading industrial shares, oils and particularly South African gold-mining issues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Led by higher prices for meat animals, the general level of farm prices increased nearly 2 per cent between mid-August and mid-September, the Department of Agriculture reported today. This was the first upturn in these prices since March.

ROME, Sept. 30 -- The Chamber of Deputies approved the Government's financial and economic policy by a large majority late this evening at the end of a two-day debate on the new situation created by devaluation of the pound sterling.

The proposal of the United States, Australia, the Philippines and China to strengthen the hand of the United Nations Commission on Korea is one of several needed steps to meet a dangerous and delicate situation. That situation has its strongly military phase with the threat of civil war, which the Commission itself has stressed in its reports.

Rafael Sebastia, Spanish pianist, made his Town Hall debut last night. Gifted with nimble fingers and a certain flair in his interpretations, he nevertheless failed to project the musical values in his chosen program.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The delegates of Britain's National Union of Railwaymen, which has 400,000 members, decided here today to seek from the Railway Executive which runs the country's nationalized railways, a standard minimum wage of 5 [$14] a week.

The tenth annual celebration of World Communion Sunday by Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churches will be begun at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow. When the churches of New Zealand. start the observance at that hour it really will be only 6 P. M. today in New York.

NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., Sept. 30 -- Stephen Berrien and Chester Sanok of Upper Montclair teamed well to win the qualifying medal with 34, 36 -- 70 in the seventeenth New Jersey State Best-Ball golf championship over the Green Brook Country Club course today.

Yankee pennant hopes hit the deck with a disheartening thud yesterday when the Bombers, completely baffled by the tantalizing slants of Dick Fowler, went tumbling to defeat in their concluding game of the year with the Athletics. Ferris Fain's three-run homer in the third inning was the decisive blow in the 4-1 triumph.

The Marine Midland Corporation will pay stockholders of the Bank of Yorktown $57.30 a share net under the recent merger agreement, it was announced yesterday in a letter to stockholders signed by George M. Adrian, Yorktown's president.
Hearing of treason charges against John David Provoo, 33-year-old former sergeant, was adjourned yesterday until Oct. 28 to give the Government time to bring twenty witnesses from Japan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Truman returned to the Capital tonight well satisfied with the reaction to his speech in Kansas City last night in which he pleaded for an expanded economy to raise the standard of living.

Retail sales here during the week were again below the corresponding period last year, it was estimated yesterday. Department store sales were down about 8 per cent, according to reports from leading stores. Sales last week were 12 per cent below last year.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 30 -- In a surprise move the Soviet Union proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly grant Libya immediate independence, and that "within three months all foreign troops and all military personnel shall be withdrawn from Libyan territory."

Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie, widow of the 1940 Republican candidate for President, and Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, wartime head of the Office of Strategic Services, called yesterday on Senator John Foster Dulles and pledged their support in his campaign for election to the Senate on the Republican ticket.

A twelve-acre tract in Hasbrouck Heights, N. J., has been purchased by the Bonanno Construction Company, developer of large industrial terminals in North Bergen and Ridgefield. The property is on the easterly side of Route 17, just north of its junction with Route 6, and near the Bendix plant and the Teterboro Airport.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 30 -- Unless something is done to relieve current overcrowding of classes and the underpayment of teachers, the nation will lose a quarter-century of educational gains, Dr. A. N. Jorgenson, president of the University of Connecticut, declared here today at a Rutgers University educational convention.

Prices of industrial materials were generally reported in a strong position as the third quarter closed yesterday. On a broad range of products, manufacturers reported increased demand, firmed prices and plans for active production schedules which will extend through the fourth quarter of the year.

Jack W. Crawford, 59-year-old chef, who last week received a suspended five-day workhouse sentence for keeping monkeys in his apartment at 309 West Forty-second Street, taced the problem of losing his liberty or his pets yesterday when Supreme Court Justice William Hecht Jr. vacated the stay that barred execution of the sentence.

"A week ago I'd have settled for the play-off," declared Manager Barney Shotton of the Dodgers yesterday evening just before taking his happy band of players aboard an 8:30 train for Philadelphia and the two-day battle with the Phils which opens this afternoon at Shibe Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Truman made a special appeal tonight for the United Service Organizations, reactivated at his request, in a nation-wide broadcast opening the $185,000,000 annual Community Chest campaigns in 1,250 cities.
TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 30 -- Counsel for six Trenton Negroes, who face trial for a shopkeeper's murder in January of 1948, found their "missing witness" sitting today in the Mercer County court room.

PITTSBURGH, Saturday, Oct. 1 -- The national steel strike went into effect with none of the violence that has marked the two- week-old coal strike. At most large plants a handful of pickets appeared a few minutes before the strike deadline.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared last night that he was opposed to discrimination of any kind, and that the guarantees of the Bill of Rights and the Constitution of the United States must be made to work for every citizen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -Senator Wayne Morse, Republican, of Oregon, urged the Administration today to invoke emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act in the dispute between Hawaiian longshoremen and employers.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30 -The United Nations economic mission, under the chairmanship of Gordon R. Clapp, is beginning to make progress in getting Arab cooperation for an eventual program of replacing the present system of direct relief by a temporary system of work relief.
DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Joe Gordon's pair of two-run homers gave the Indians a 6-4 decision over the Tigers today and moved them into a tie with Detroit for third place in the American League race.

Increased prices on rough diamonds, due to devaluation of the British pound sterling, were quoted in cables yesterday to diamond importers in the United States from the Diamond Trading Company, London, it was reported yesterday by Albert E. Haase, executive director of the Jewelry Industry Council.

In a speech over radio station WHOM, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, charged last night that both his major party opponents, Mayor O'Dwyer and Newbold Morris, were following the road to a 15-cent transit fare.

Two young American bicyclists, who entered the Soviet zone of Germany July 30 and were beaten and imprisoned in a dungeon before being released last Wednesday, returned here yesterday with no harsh words against Russian guards for the treatment they had received.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it would approve a plan for a compromise settlement of a claim of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, New York, against its subsidiary, the Market Street Railway Company, San Francisco, and for liquidation and dissolution of the latter, provided the plan is modified in certain respects.
Through the combined efforts of three agencies, a young Italian surgeon arrived here by plane yesterday for five months' study of the latest methods of helping disabled children.

Tomorrow is the anniversary of the hanging of Major Andre, who was executed at Tappan, N. Y., on Oct. 2, 1780. Convicted as a spy, it had been he who conferred with Benedict Arnold about the latter's plans to turn over West Point to the British.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Average primary market prices declined 1.1 per cent in the week ended Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index was 152.4 per cent of the 1926 average, the same as four weeks ago and 9.2 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.
John R. L. Johnson Jr., assistant general counsel of the Hercules Powder Company, has been appointed director of the legal department, the company announced yesterday. He succeeds E. Way Highsmith.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 -- Benjamin Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, tonight issued the following statement:

Productivity in France's heavy electrical equipment industry can be raised to a level equal to that in the United States if techniques recommended by a sixteen-man French mission are adopted, the mission reported here yesterday.

GRAND FALLS, Newfoundland, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press) -- The entire Canadian newsprint industry may be on short time next year, E. M. Little, president of Anglo-Newfoundland Development Company, said today.
The State Congress of Industrial Organizations, representing a million union members, made known its plans yesterday for electing former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman to the United States Senate.

New securities marketed here in September were the largest in three months. Bonds totaling $561,072,000, representing sixty-two issues, were publicly offered against $445,722,000 for fifty issues in the preceding month and $297,462,000 for forty-nine issues in September, 1948.

Now that the Greek Army has succeeded in driving all but a few isolated bands of the remaining rebel forces into Albania, the political phase of the battle begins. Before submitting Greek charges against her northern neighbors to the General Assembly, the U. N. Political and Security Committee had voted unanimously to set up a conciliation commission and give it three weeks to try to settle the dispute.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged last night in a speech in Staten Island that Mayor O'Dwyer had broken a pre-1945 election promise to put an end to garbage dumping there and has been treating the borough like a stepchild in the four years he had been in office.

Eleven Army ships, assigned to the fleet of the New York Port of Embarkation, are being prepared for permanent lay-up in reserve fleet anchorages, their services no longer needed because of decreasing traffic.

Occasional tables for the living room are of many kinds of materials and may take any number of shapes if one is to judge by the new examples now being exhibited at the National Home Furnishings Show at Grand Central Palace.

Coffee futures were active and sharply higher in early trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Demand was from trade houses and producing interests. Later in the day profit taking and scattered long liquidation appeared and prices eased off somewhat but final levels were still well above the previous day.

ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 30 -- About a decade and a half ago Steve Sorota did better than all right as a back with famous Fordham elevens tutored by Major Frank Cavanaugh and, later, Sleepy Jim Crowley. Today, Steve is doing equally as well as head football coach at Phillips Academy, Andover.

Important new discoveries concerning the cause and treatment of schizophrenia, the mental illness that occurs most frequently, were reported in the results of a comprehensive research program that became known publicly yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Senator Wayne Morse, Republican, of Oregon, introduced a bill today for the authorization of a special commission to overhaul Federal, state and local tax codes. In addition, the bill would make the following immediate revisions in the Federal tax structure:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Dr. Elmer W. Engstrom, research director for Radio Corporation of America, said today that his company was just as willing to risk its money on color television as it was on black-and-white video.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 30 -- New England railroad men admitted privately today, that the reason for post-war deterioration of freight service was the necessity for awaiting greater tonnage loads to offset a great increase in operating costs.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed co-transfer agent for the Class A common stock of the Liberty Loan Corporation, Chicago. It also has been appointed paying agent for the $350,000 of Albany County, Wyoming, hospital bonds.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 30 -- The Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today the first article of an international covenant binding all member states to punish anyone found guilty of promoting organized prostitution or engaging in the traffic in persons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -Senator Clinton P. Anderson of New Mexico, took the first step today toward clearing the way for the Department of Agriculture to impose marketing quotas on the 1950 corn crop. He introduced several amendments requested by the department which would give it until Feb. 1 to announce corn quotas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Reluctance of the Rules Committee to prohibit amendments from the floor threatened today to upset the plans of Administration leaders for House consideration this session of a bill to liberalize and expand the social security program.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 17 -- Marxism on the beautiful and bounteous island of Ceylon appears to have degenerated since World War II into a small, strident and splintered movement with little to feed upon in a land where everybody eats.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 30 -Representatives Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut and Thurmond Chatham of North Carolina, members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, sailed this afternoon for a four-week survey of western European countries that will benefit by the military aid to Europe bill.

The "lost children" of Italy -war-maimed, orphaned, homeless-are finding new life, new hope, through the "boundless generosity of the American people," Countess Carlo Sforza, wife of the Italian Foreign Minister, said here yesterday.

Joseph Grotto, in a purchase for investment, has acquired from the Eckert Realty Corporation the five-story building at 2337 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, containing three stores and thirty-nine apartments. Snyder Co. were the brokers.

Mrs. Eleanor Louise Patenotre, 80-year-old former owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer and widow of Jules Patenotre, one-time French Ambassador to the United States, pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to a charge of tax evasion and handed over a check for $2,000,000 in civil liability settlement.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Wholesale prices of many important industrial commodities have jumped sharply in Britain on the heels of the Government's devaluation of the pound sterling. This was disclosed today by a survey of prices now quoted on the nation's ex changes compared with those of Sept. 16 -- two days before the pound's dollar value was cut 30.5 per cent from $4.03 to $2.80.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- An agreement to subordinate national military projects to an "integrated defense" program for the North Atlantic area is being asked of North Atlantic treaty nations by the United States as the first condition for receiving American arms and equipment.

At the risk of appearing ungracious, I must point out that the friendly remarks made by H. T. Edwards about me in your issue of Sept. 24 are likely to be misconstrued. No one who read his letter casually could be blamed if he assumed that I held similar views to those expressed by Mr. Edwards.

The North Atlantic pact nations in conference next week in Washington "will try to find the best means of defense in the event of an attack," Albert Deveze, Belgian Defense Minister, said yesterday on his arrival at 9:30 A. M. at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on a Pan American World Airways plane from London.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 30 -- A 2-year-old girl suffering from bronchial pneumonia and whooping cough almost died early today on an emergency airplane flight here when oxygen that was being administered to her ran out before the plane landed.

October's first Saturday presents college football slate of midseason caliber. Experts used to have a simple problem at this stage of the campaign. It was just a matter of picking the big team over the little team, while concentrating on the baseball scores.
The cotton futures market yesterday closed irregular 4 points higher to 7 points lower.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 30 -- The T-formation attack as developed by the Chicago Bears has stood as probably the deadliest modus operandi in football since it exploded upon the Washington Redskins in 1940.

TOKYO, Sept. 30 -- Dumping suddenly has become a vital matter for administrators of the Supreme Commander for the Allies. With various commercial agreements, including the postponed sterling area pact, under consideration, outcries against Japanese dumping are rising in volume.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 30 -- The arrest of twenty-six vicars of the Roman Catholic Church in the Budejovice and Litomerice Dioceses was reported in Prague tonight by sources that generally have proved reliable in the past.

BERLIN, Sept. 30 -- The airlift to Berlin folded its wings here tonight. An epic of the aviation age ended just after nightfall as a C-54 touched down at Tempelhof Airfield and taxied to a terminal in the wake of the usual little yellow Jeep with the big red illuminated sign, "Follow me," on its back.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 30 -- The steering committee of the round-table conference on Indonesia will begin tomorrow a week-end of informal discussions "somewhere in Holland" on economic and financial questions that have brought the conference almost to a standstill.

Capt William M. McGuire, retiring Marine Inspection Officer of the Coast Guard, Third District, was the guest of honor at a luncheon given yesterday by Rear Admiral E. H. Smith, Coast Guard commandant, and other officers assigned to this area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The United States Government turned down today a request for naval aid in freeing the three American merchant ships detained by Chinese Nationalist warships off Shanghai and referred their owner to an earlier warning that the vessels would run the "purported blockade" of Chinese ports at their own risk.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Alleghany Corporation, majority common stockholder in the Missouri Pacific, today told the Interstate Commerce Commission it should modify the plan of reorganization of the Missouri Pacific that it approved Aug. 6 by increasing the capitalization from $611,931,952 to $770,149,688, a rise of $58,217,736.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan, in an address today before the Executives Club of Chicago, predicted chaos and depression for farmers and other segments of the economy unless the nation adopts an agricultural program which would establish farm prices at "levels that will promote agricultural abundance and prosperity."

Steel inventories on hand and orders now being shipped will enable three leading appliance producers to continue current production rates for from two to six weeks despite the steel strike, company officials reported yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Amid expressions of relief at the adoption of the foreign aid bill at figures close to the estimates, experts of the European Marshall Plan organization met today to prepare implementation of the measure's promises for immediate liberalization of trade.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 30 -- New York needs 3,000 additional hospital beds to get "tuberculosis under control," Dr. Howard Snyder, medical consultant to the New York State Hospital Study of Columbia University, said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 -Kirsten Flagstad, whose chances of winning permission to sing in the War Memorial Opera House here looked slim during a heated controversy last summer, appeared tonight in the role of Isolde before a packed house.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 -- Western civilization and Marxian communism are now embroiled in a "bitter contest" for "nothing less than the soul of man," the Most Rev. Cyril Forster Garbett, Archbishop of York, said here today.

BOSTON, Sept. 30 -- A naval court of inquiry investigating the explosion of a smoke signal projector that killed a newspaper photographer and wounded three Navy officers yesterday during amphibious landing exercises at Carson Beach heard testimony today that half-pound blocks of TNT were being fired from the launcher to simulate aerial bursts.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 30 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, declared today that the devaluation of the Deutsche mark and attendant economic conditions initiated with respect to Ruhr coal prices had set the stage for a significant reorientation and improvement of the entire European trading scheme.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Senate today approved in rapid succession two bills to authorize an estimated $211,000,000 in annual pay increases for 1,355,000 classified and postal employes of the Government. About half a million of those slated for rises are in the Post Office Department.

Paul Crouch, a self-described former official of the Communist party, testified yesterday at a deportation hearing against Mrs. Betty Gannett, 42 years old, of 205 West Tenth Street, at the offices of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 70 Columbus Avenue.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- A showdown is expected tomorrow between Premier Henri Queuille and the Socialist members of his Cabinet over the question of wage increases.
