After laborious discussions throughout today there was no prospect of agreement and the chances have grown stronger that the Government will fall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Federal Security Administration would be the "operating agency" for the first phase of President Truman's proposed "bold new program" to develop the poor and backward areas of the world.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 30 -- If Arthur Krock's mythical Soviet diplomat, Comrade Astigmatoff, were to report from here on the present state of American opinion, his dispatch might very well read something like this: To Comrades Stalin, Molotov, Gromyko, Beria:

Longshoremen in ports along the entire Atlantic Coast have voted approval of an extension of their present contract and will continue working another thirty days to permit further negotiations of a wage dispute.

Those planning a trip to North Carolina for the fall channel bass fishing, which is reported to be getting better every day, will have an opportunity to combine their fishing with some shooting, for the season opens today on rail and marsh hens.

"The Blue Lagoon," arriving at the Globe, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The British-made romantic adventure stars Jean Simmons and Donald Houston, and was produced in Technicolor by Sidney Gilliat and Frank Launder. Based on a novel by H. de Vere Stacpoole, the screen play was written by Frank Launder, John Baines and Michael Hogan and directed by Mr. Launder.
DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A classy Villanova College football team won its third straight game as it powered its way to a 34-7 victory over the University of Detroit tonight.

Farm land prices have declined in forty-one states, according to the seventh annual study of the Agricultural Commission of the American Bankers Association, which has just been completed. Despite the decline, however, levels in these states are still slightly higher than the 1920 boom peak.

Few of the inhabitants of Greater New York are directly involved in the Community Chest appeal which President Truman broadcast last night. Only on Staten Island is there a Community Chest within the city limits. In the metropolitan area, however, there are about sixty chests.

Stock prices drifted in a narrow range yesterday on the Stock Exchange and closed mixed in slower trading. Traders were inclined to adopt a cautious attitude as the threatened steel strike drew nearer. A hope still prevailed in financial circles that, if a strike did occur, it would be of short duration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Depending, of course, on week-end developments at the Yankee Stadium, it could be that the Red Sox walked into the pennant today. For while the New Yorkers were bowing to the Athletics, the Bosox made the most of fourteen bases on balls and staggered to an 11 -- 9 victory over the Senators.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 -- Orders for the 80,000 miners in the anthracite fields and for 22,000 in bituminous fields west of the Mississippi River to return to work Monday were issued by officials of the United Mine Workers today, but there was no indication of a break in the deadlocked negotiations with the major soft-coal producers of the country.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 30 -- A mystery blast in the Pensacola area sent tremors almost 100 miles into Alabama today and hours afterward the heavy concussion had not been explained.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -Anne Baxter will play the leading feminine white role in "No Way Out," Twentieth Century-Fox's film about the difficulties facing a Negro interne in a metropolitan American hospital, it was learned today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Hungary renounced today the 1947 treaty of friendship and mutual assistance with Yugoslavia, following Russia in a move expected to set a pattern for other countries of Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Department of Defense announced today the approval by Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, of an Army program to "give greater assurance of quality of treatment and opportunity" to Negro enlisted men.

Brock Pemberton is all set to swing into action with his forthcoming production of Doris Frankel's comedy, "The Time Is Yes," formerly known as 'Rondo in a Flat." Rehearsals will start today and the producer will direct with the assistance of Margaret Perry, daughter of the late Antoinette Perry, who staged many of his plays, the last of which was the redoubtable "Harvey."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner walloped his 54th home run of the season tonight and set a few more records as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Cincinnati Rods, 3 -- 2, before 9,416 fans. Bob Chesnes allowed only four hits, two of them in the ninth when the Reds scored both their runs.

PITTSBURGH, Saturday, Oct. 1 -- The national steel strike began at 12:01 A. M. today. Telegraphic orders from Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, ordered 500,000 workers from their jobs after Federal mediation efforts had collapsed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- John T. Taylor, legislative spokesman for the American Legion, told the Senate today not to bring the Displaced Persons Bill to the floor during the absence in Europe of Chairman Pat McCarran of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange for September was the largest of any month this year and the most active for any corresponding month since 1946, the total of 176.775,404 shares for the first nine months of this year was the smallest since 1942.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Unemployment declined from 3,689,000 in August to 3,351,000 in September, according to the latest Census Bureau figures released today. This was the second successive decline in monthly unemployment figures.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 30 -- The United States will not support India's plan to turn the tangled atomic control controversy over to the United Nations International Law Commission.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Following are the companies ordered struck tonight, together with the number of union employes and plants:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Gen. Jacob L. Devers, chief of Army field forces, reviewed his troops for the last time today and retired to a Virginia cattle farm.

Sharply admonished to stop "going around with a chip on your shoulder," Patrick McParland, bus driver convicted of assault for having pushed a passenger so hard the latter was hospitalized, received a $250 fine and a suspended three-month workhouse sentence when he appeared yesterday in Special Sessions.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Earl L. (Curly) Lambeau stepped down as head coach of the Green Bay Packers of the National Football League today after thirty years at the post.

The progress made in the city administration's school construction program and the promise of further expansion next year were emphasized by city officials who participated yesterday in the dedication of Junior High School 22, College Avenue and 167th Street, the Bronx, which was opened on Sept. 12.
As the major league pennant races enter upon their final two strides to the wire, Brooklyn's dauntless Dodgers today seemed to be sitting right handsomely in the National League ...

A 30-year-old Brooklyn machinist was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court charged with accepting $200 from two veterans o nthe representation that he would obtain for them preference on their applications for apartments in a city housing project.

Issuance of tax-exempt bonds to satisfy the financial needs of local governments continues to be the dominant factor in the market for new securities. Emissions of this type coming up next week are topped by an offering of $8,500,000 of bonds by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania on Tuesday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 -- In an unexpected move Guy A. Thompson, trustee for the strike-bound Missouri Pacific Railroad, made a concession to four railway brotherhoods today in a proposal that may pave the way for settling the three-week-old walkout of 5,200 trainmen.
Ernest Bevin, British Foreign Secretary, held a press conference yesterday in which he put aside questions of politics to talk of the pleasures and benefits of travel in Britain.

ALBANY, Sept. 30 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the Brooklyn Trust Company, Brooklyn, had been authorized to open a branch office at 116-22 and 116-24 Queens Boulevard, Kew Gardens, Queens, and also to operate a personal loan department there.

In a precedent-setting Federal Court decision that may alter the entire power policy of the Government in an eleven-state area of the West, the United States District Court in Boise, Idaho, ruled yesterday that the Department of the Interior could not stop the $80,000,000 Idaho Power Company from building a $3,000,000 power transmission line over Government-owned land in the mountainous state.

Mayor O'Dwyer, addressing 300 probationary patrolmen at promotion and induction ceremonies at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon, called on the new appointees to "pray for guidance to do the right thing and for the courage to do it once the decision is made."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A threatened strike of 1,350 employes of the General Steel Castings Corporation plant at near-by Eddystone was averted last night shortly before the midnight deadline.
MILAN, Italy, Sept. 26 -- More than in most European countries, industry in Northern Italy demonstrates that technology is not the main thing that Europe needs to learn from the United States.

CANTON, China, Sept. 30 -- Robert A. Strong, United States Charge D'Affaires for Nationalist China, has resumed full-time representation of American interests at the seat of the central Government here. Mr. Strong shifted his residence this week from HongKong to Canton.

The Board of Elections upheld yesterday the City Fusion party petition nominating Abe Stark for Brooklyn Borough President; Edmund H. H. Caddy for Kings County District Attorney and Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Giaccone for a full term in the Second Judicial District.

Completion of negotiations for the sale of station WINS to Generoso Pope, publisher of the Italian language newspaper, Il Progresso Italo Americano, was announced here yesterday. The transaction, however, wil have to await the approval of the Federal Communications Commission.

The introduction of social studies at all age levels in Christian educational institutions in India and China was urged yesterday afternoon at a luncheon at 71 West Twenty-third Street, by Dr. Mary Sweeny, a child welfare specialist.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 30 -- China's hope for an early hearing of her charges against the Soviet Union received a setback today when the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly assigned the case fifth place on its agenda.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Prime Minister Attlee went to his country home today and other Members of Parliament went to the hustings after having stirred up a lot of lively speculation on the date of the next general election during a strenuous week of politics in London.

Transactions in exchange-offer dollar bonds of Colombian departments and municipalities on a when-issued basis run the danger of violating the Securities Act of 1933 until prospectuses are available for delivery to purchasers, the Securities and Exchange Commission warned here yesterday.

WARSAW, Sept. 30 -- Poland joined Hungary today in formally denouncing a treaty of mutual aid and friendship with Marshal Tito's Yugoslavia. The two countries acted a day after the Soviet Union had similarly voided its treaty of friendship with Yugoslavia.
Maynard Nichols' "What to Call Weather" should be commended for clarifying the meteorological definitions so often misunderstood by the weather-conscious public.

A great day for a great guy, that's what it was, as his friends in the stands and his rivals on the field paid tribute to Joe DiMaggio yesterday at the Stadium. For a solid hour before the game the Yankee Clipper, wan and weak after his recent siege, heard himself extolled and found himself surrounded by a small mountain of gifts, ranging from 300 quarts of ice cream to a super-special speedboat.
HONOLULU, Oct. 1 -- Late this month the United Shares, as exemplified by a huge Western Task Force, will try to wrest this Hawaiian island of Oahu from an entrenched "agressor" force.

IT IS hardly necessary to say, at this late date, that one expects from Conrad Aiken poetry of craftsmanship and taste. A master of many styles, he has for years been exhibiting a formal distinction that makes several more fashionable poets look almost amateurish.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Grains worked lower on the Board of Trade today, while lard, after a barely steady start, moved upward toward the close. Dealings were not active.

Orderly, rational and matter-of-fact, as if they had just won by 10 -- 0 rather than by 5 -- 4, the Yankees filed into their dressing room immediately after Phil Rizzuto threw out Dom DiMaggio for the game-ending play yesterday. Billy Johnson strode calmly through the door, followed by a smiling Yogi Berra and a grinning Tommy Henrich.

One hundred and fifty reserve officers of the Army and Navy will attend the second annual Economic and Industrial Conference, sponsored by the Commandant of the Third Naval District, Rear Admiral Walter S. DeLany, for two five-day periods beginning on the next two Mondays, it was announced yesterday.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed diamond set 14-karat gold watches, cotton Riviera shirts, Paris inspired belts, and modern bedroom furniture, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

Oswald Garrison Villard, who died in this city yesterday at the age of 77, took with profound seriousness the fact that he was the grandson of William Lloyd Garrison, the Abolitionist leader. To new issues, that of world peace among them, he applied the words of his renowned and pugnacious ancestor: "I am in earnest; I will not equivocate; I will not excuse; I will not retreat a single inch; and I will be heard."

Your Poughkeepsie correspondent, in describing Prof. Maud W. Makemson's valuable discoveries in Maya chronology, mentions one of the most remarkable figures in Spanish-American history, Bishop Landa of Yucatan. It is true that he burned over a score of precious Maya picture MSS. but it is also true that he was an earnest student of their religion and actually learned to read the Maya hieroglyphics.

The wave of currency devaluation constitutes a challenge to American exporters, which should stimulate them to greater selling efforts and new methods in more competitive world markets, according to Louis L. Horch, longtime observer of foreign trade and former regional director of the local office of the Department of Commerce.

The recent devaluation of the pound sterling again has disturbed the historical relationship of that currency to the dollar. With so much of the world trade carried on in these two currencies, economists are of the opinion that the disturbance of their normal relationship eventually will bring about a change in the trend of international trade.

The comeback of the toll turnpike as a major means of transportation -- but under public rather than private auspice -- was underscored last week by significant developments in three major states -Pennsylvania, Ohio and New Jersey.
LONDON (Canadian Press) -- A fruit once thought to grow on trees below the sea has brought new publicity to one of Britain's most obscure colonies.

Representative Vito Marcantonio and Paul L. Ross, respectively American Labor party candidates for Mayor and Controller, attacked yesterday Mayor O'Dwyer's statement that he had no responsibility for barring Negroes from Stuyvesant Town as "brazen" and "dishonest."

Greentree Stable and Jockey Ted Atkinson won their first Futurity at Belmont Park yesterday. Guillotine, a son of the 1939 Futurity winner, Bimelech, did the job for them in the sixtieth edition of the nation's No. 1 race for 2-year-olds.

BALLETS are literally treading on each other's heels these days. Tonight the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo closes at the Metropolitan Opera House, Thursday the Ballets de Paris engagement opens at the Winter Garden, and next Sunday the Sadler's Wells Ballet from Covent Garden, London, begins its first American season at the Metropolitan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- While Central Western sports fans sat on the edge of their chairs before radios and television sets this week rooting for their favorite teams in the major leagues' hot pennant races, industrialists uneasily scanned their diminishing soft-coal stockpiles and wondered whether John L. Lewis would let them replenish their coal bins.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 -- Losses in retail busines activity were prevalent throughout the Twelfth District during the last week. Based on the United States Department of Labor reports for Los Angeles and Seattle, retail prices on the Pacific Coast showed a moderate decline during August.

The annual awards granted by the Allied Artists of America, Inc., to exhibitors in oils, water colors and sculpture, were announced yesterday in connection with the annual exhibition that will open today with a private showing at the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue.

ALTHOUGH many shows returned to the air earlier than usual this fall, this week finds the traditional rush of premieres getting the radio season into full swing. Conspicuously absent from the list this year is the name of Fred Allen, who is taking a sabbatical and plans only occasional guest appearances.

GAINSBOROUGH is an exception to the rule that the artist's work explains the man. For, if the whole spirit of Georgian England seems crystallized in his graceful aristocratic portraits and in his exquisite landscapes, Gainsborough himself was a most un-eighteenth century character, a far stranger and more violent man than these placid works would lead one to believe.

On an average day twenty-eight ships enter New York Harbor carrying $10 million in foreign merchandise for the United States -- scotch whisky from Britain, wool from Australia, perfume from France, jute from India.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -The Wolverhampton Wanderers unbeaten leaders in the English Football Association's first division, held last year's champion Portsmouth team to a 1-1 tie at Fratton Park today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Big Government is moving to meet the challenge of Big Business for career workers; and the increased pay for civil servants, a major consideration, will add $600,000,000 annually to the American tax bill.

THE Second District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State will hold its annual meeting on Monday at the Riviera Beach Club, Brightwaters, Bay Shore, L. I. The business meeting, which begins at 10 A. M., will be followed by a lecture on horticulture by Dr. George S. Avery. Dr. Avery is director of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- The might of Pennsylvania's line humbled Dartmouth for the seventh year in succession today, 21 -- 0, in a ragged opener for both teams that must have set a record for the number of fumbles perpetrated in the second quarter.

Silver of Georgian days and earlier, a collection of Victorians gold, silver and enamel vinaigrettes, porcelains and other decorative objects will be auctioned on Friday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 110 East Fifty-eighth Street.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 1 -- The Government of Israel informed Gordon R. Clapp, head of the United Nations economic survey mission to the Middle East, that it would guarantee the safety of all members of the mission while in this country, it was learned tonight.

BY-PASSING traffic jams, a favorite outdoor sport of the city motorist, is not necessarily limited to the peak travel months of summer. A hyphenated word, "noncontributory," was the stumbling block which precipitated the steel strike at midnight Friday. Clinging to a hope that some settlement would be reached before the deadline, stocks vacillated last week concurrently with bulletins issued by the negotiators.

ANOTHER one of Mrs. Judson's stories about Americans of foreign extraction, is always a delight. She has the gift of creating human, lovable American children who yet manage to retain the flavor and charm of their parents' old-country ways.

In cooperation with the New York Bar Association, the Board of Education last week began a unique in-service course for the city's teachers and supervisors on the function of everyday law practices in a democratic society. The course is believed to be the only one of its kind in the country.

A plastic which cannot be dissolved by any known solvent at ordinary temperatures, and which is unaffected by such potent chemicals as sulfuric, hydrochloric, nitric acids and caustic soda, is manufactured for the United States Atomic Energy Commission by the Carbide and Carbon Chemical Corporation at Oak Ridge.

IN this first novel by a former R. A. F. squadron leader, a group of British fliers finds itself stationed on a remote and sparsely settled island north of Scotland. It is wartime, and into their midst, like a shot in the arm, comes Donnington, a human hypodermic.

ASIDE from their spectacular spring bloom, flowering quinces have the added feature of attractive fall foliage. And even in winter they may be enjoyed, for their branches are among the first to be used for indoor forcing.

A plea to end "racketeering in the city administration, and make City Hall a center of Government rather than a political center," was voiced yesterday by Newbold Morris, Republican, Fusion and Liberal candidate for Mayor.

IF you have drawn an off-season vacation, consider yourself one of the chosen few whether you plan to head for a resort or wander around the country in an automobile. This attitude is based on a 12,000-mile motor trip my 7-year-old daughter and I made across the United States.

With textile prices staging a recovery of approximately 15 per cent since the second quarter of the year, New York suppliers of finished goods have an excellent chance of making up earlier losses and show a good profit for the year, it was pointed out last week.

ROME, Oct. 1 -- Minister of Defense Randolfo Pacciardi and General Efisio Marras, Chief of the Combined General Staffs, left by air for Washington today at the head of a six-man delegation of experts to attend meetings of the Defense Committee of Atlantic powers.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 1 -- Senator Robert A. Taft has covered about one-seventh of his self-imposed 100-day assignment to "report to the people" of Ohio's eighty-eight counties, and newspaper men who have accompanied him believe that he has made some new friends and lost no old friends.

The automobile industry has long had its own variation of the classic chicken-or-the-egg query -- which comes first, an adequate supply of cars or an adequate supply of highways ? There is ample evidence of progress in parallel. In the first place, a new production record for trucks and cars in 1949 is already in sight.

Columbia's young football team revived an old Baker Field custom yesterday, coming up with a touchdown in the last minute of play to win a game. There were just forty seconds to go when Leon Van Bellingham streaked seven yards around end for the score that beat Harvard, 14 to 7.

Order rose bushes and deciduous shrubs for planting late in the fall. . . . If leaves on locust trees are brown and dry, it is probably due to leaf miner.

BIG SPRING, Tex., Oct. 1 -- This robust West Texas plains town played eager host today to a life-term convict who received a six-day "vacation" from the Tennessee State Prison to accept acclaim as a musical composer.

THE pungent odor of burning leaves is already heavy on the autumn air. Many suburbanites do not realize it, but burning these leaves is almost like burning dollar bills. For placed in neat piles (behind the garage or shrubbery), they would decompose to a crumbly stuff costing as much as $3 a bushel if purchased from a dealer.

LUXEMBOURG -- An exhaustive study of problems connected with tourism and the ways by which the industry can be encouraged was made at the annual conference of the International Union of Official Travel Organizations, held here recently with representatives from more than thirty countries participating.

IN his latest novel Walter Havighurst turns again to his favorite Great Lakes region. Much of the story is told through the eyes of Maury Hazard, a young war correspondent who returns to peacetime America at odds with the world and himself. Once back on Hazard Island, Maury finds inner serenity through his brother David, a nurse, and a singer who has lost her voice.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 1 (UP) -- Amherst College defeated the United States Coast Guard Academy, 27 -- 13, today before 3,000 fans in Jones Field.

LEWIS GIBBS, who last year published a brilliant biography of Sheridan ("Sheridan: His Life and His Theatre"), now comes forward with an entertaining study of the elusive Lady Mary Wortley Montagu. As the motives that controlled the main event of Lady Mary's life are shrouded in mystery, her biographer must not only be a writer capable of evoking the age of Queen Anne and the first three Georges but must also be a literary detective.

Teachers in the public rural schools of the United States earn approximately one-half the income of teachers in the urban areas, Dr. Frank W. Cyr, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday in making public a report of the college's sixth annual Work Conference on Administration and Organization of Rural Education.

Advances made in the Kenny treatment for infantile paralysis victims will be discussed at a three-day polio seminar at the Sister Kenny Foundation headquarters in Minneapolis, tomorrow through Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.

OTTAWA, Oct. 1 -- Canada moved another step forward this week to full self-government by adopting the second reading of the Government bill to abolish appeals to the British Privy Council and to make the Supreme Court of Canada the final court of appeal.

THOSE nostalgic literary seedlings sown so profusely in childhood's garden of memories these past years have more than taken root. They are hardy perennials now. This book is another flowering of a remembrance saga set in picturesque Finland around the turn of the century.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 1 -- A lack of interest among drinkers and a religious crusade among conscientious Drys were believed to be the deciding factors in the smashing defeat on Tuesday of the proposal to repeal prohibition in Oklahoma.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Penn State threw a first-half scare into the Army camp today but in the end the team that boasted the greater strength persevered and the cadets went on to register a decisive 42-to-7 triumph over the Nittany Lions.

WHEN Boswell dedicated his garrulous "Life of Johnson" to Sir Joshua Reynolds, he battered that celebrity with implacable compliments. The flagrant and ruthless praise is a perfect example of an antique style that used dedications to gain patrons, prestige or pay.

A general increase over the summer months of about 30 per cent for September frozen food sales is causing wholesale distributors and manufacturers to show renewed interest in acquiring supplies, it was learned here yesterday.

Using the hotel business as a barometer of business conditions in New York City, Frank Andrews, president of the New Yorker Hotel, yesterday predicted a general upswing this fall to continue well into 1950.

FROM spring through fall, yellow flowers are indispensable in the patchwork of garden colors. Marigolds and calendulas rival the brightness of the late summer sun, and yellow chrysanthemums are dominant throughout autumn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The natural reaction of men after an atomic explosion is stay out of the area until the atmosphere clears and the instruments can be safely read. That is what the policy-makers are doing now.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 16 -- The Minister for Immigration, Arthur A. Calwell, has recently welcomed to Australia the 100,000th post-war-assisted immigrant from the United Kingdom and the 50,000th from Continental Europe.

HONG KONG, Oct. 1 -- Gen. Chen Cheng of the National Army, commander in chief of Southeast China Command Headquarters on Formosa, was today investigating charges that an army corps assigned to defend Pingtan Island, off the Fukien Province coast, had had only 1,000 combat troops but 3,000 officers -- with 2,000 dependents accompanying them.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Thousands of Germans surged into the United States and British Zones from Eastern Germany today and thousands of others were trekking toward the border. It was a peaceful mass invasion that had developed when the Russians temporarily had released border controls at several points.

Brooklyn College's need for more teachers and better plant facilities was outlined yesterday by Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college, in his report to the Board of Higher Education for the academic years 1948-49.
An estimated 50,000 Americans of Polish extraction, many of them in native costumes, are expected to march up Fifth Avenue today in the thirteenth annual Pulaski Day parade.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 1 (UP) -Heavily favored Minnesota scored touchdowns on two dazzling passes and two block-buster line plays today to defeat Nebraska, 28 to 6, before 36,000 fans.

WILLIAM GRANT STILL, whose early work, "The Troubled Island," was given in the spring by the New York City Opera, is almost two-thirds of the way through a new opera. It is set in the American Southwest.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 -- It is always difficult for foreign observers in a vast nation like Russia to assess accurately the public reaction to such a major event as the announcement that the Soviet Union does in fact possess the atomic weapon. However, it can be safely reported that the average Soviet citizen is well aware that this is the most important world event since the end of World War H.

The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Archbishop of Boston, returned on the Cunard White Star liner Britannic yesterday with a party of 200 Roman Catholic laity from the New England area which he led in a two-week pilgrimage to Ireland.

Attorneys representing twenty-two member associations of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, with headquarters at 80 West Fortieth Street, will meet on Tuesday night, Oct. 18, to form a Legal Advisory Committee for salesmen. Mitchell M. Shipman, 70 Pine Street, general counsel of the National Council, called the meeting and will preside at a round table discussion at Morgen's Restaurant, 141 West Thirty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Alex Kellner won his twentieth game of the season when he pitched and batted the Athletics to a 7-4 victory over the Senators today. Dick Welteroth made one of his few starts and was no puzzle to the Philadelphia batters.

Howard L. Tiger in his letter published Sept. 18 has lifted a sentence out of Waldemar Kaempffert's review of the July, 1949, issue of the Journal of the American Water Works Association, in which the effort of the association to codify their response to the wave of impressment of fluorine compounds upon entire communities' water supplies was ably and accurately discussed.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 2 (Sunday) (AP) -- The Singer Sewing Machine Company and the United Electrical Workers, CIO, announced at 1 A. M. today that they had "tentatively reached an agreement" that would end a strike that has kept 2,100 Singer employes idle since May 5.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 1 -- Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister, urged the United Nations today to give immediate independence to the former Italian colonies of Libya and Eritrea, and allow Italy to administer Italian Somaliland until it was ready for freedom.

Last week three families sat around the television to watch a theatre program. What we saw was thoroughly nauseating. The play included two gruesome murders, a dope peddler and a hopeless drunk. It was devoid of a single attribute of character one could admire.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 18 -The remnants of the British Army forces that were on this island when Ceylon was headquarters of the Southeast Asia Command in the latter years of World War II are now beginning to be moved out and replaced by the nucleus of a Ceylonese army under British command.

DELL begins life on an Indiana farm, a realistic, hard-driven girl determined to get ahead in the world. She is flattered when the elegant Gerald Thornton sees something in her, but marriage to Gerald is not what she had thought it would be. Gerald is not man enough for her -- and in their cheap Chicago rooms, embittered and feeling cheated, she decides to be the man of the family.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The forty-year dream of Chicagoans and their city officials of establishing a consolidated railroad terminal to house fifteen railroads now terminating on the South Side has apparently faded.

TERMS like footcandle, test area, calibrations, and visibility level were tossed around in scientific profusion at the recent National Technical Conference of the Illuminating Engineering Society at French Lick, Ind. If an uninitiated householder had wandered into one or two of the sessions, he might have been pardoned for not realizing that all this weighty talk was aimed at enhancing the comfort and pleasure of his evenings at home.

With no ceremony or visible change, the fifty-one-year-old Army Transportation Corps quietly became yesterday the Military Sea Transportation Service and will henceforth be part of the Navy's "blue water" operations.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- Philadelphia women's apparel stores last week reported sales were 23 per cent under the same week last year, and were off 14 per cent in the four-week period. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 88,595, as against 139,355 a year ago, a decrease of 36.4 per cent.

In 1898 Andre Debierne, an associate of Madame Curie, discovered the rare radioactive element actinium. Unlike uranium, thorium and radium, actinium was never applied to any scientific or commercial purpose because it was obtainable only in specks.

IN 1632 Margaret Askew, aged 18, married Thomas Fell, the squire of Swarthmoor Hall, in the most isolated and desolate corner of then rural Lancashire. She bore him nine children and ran his house, while he became a local potentate and judge.

GENEVA -- The new international convention on road traffic, signed here recently after several years' work by various agencies of the United Nations, will not make any spectacular changes in international highway travel for the ordinary tourist.

RICHMOND, Oct. 1 -- The Fifth District faces the final 1949 quarter with optimism in spite of coal and steel uncertainties. So far the mine suspension has not been felt by industry other than the coal carrying railroads, while retail purchasing power has been cut only in mining areas in the Virginias.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 -- A few weeks ago a survey of department store executives' opinions of sales for the second half of 1949 revealed an average expectation of a level of business about 5 to 10 per cent below the second half of last year. The record to date has been somewhat better than this, but most merchants believe their earlier estimates will be borne out by fourth-quarter performance.

LOUIS M. LYONS, in his review of Joseph Dineen's "The Purple Shamrock: The Hon. James Michael Curley of Boston" (Book Review, Sept. 11), makes this statement: "Roosevelt paid through the nose for Curley's support."

EDWIN MUELLER has received black die proofs of 40-groschen green, 60g red and 1-schilling blue stamps which Austria will release on Tuesday for the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Universal Postal Union. "Weltpostverein" and the date 1874 and 1949 are inscribed, together with the initials of North, East, South and West. Post-horn, envelope and roses adorn the 40g.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The Cardinals lost whatever chance they had to win the National League pennant in the regular championship campaign by bowing to the Cubs today, 3 -- 1. They were beaten before 20,211 astonished onlookers at Wrigley Field by Bob Chipman, a left-handed pitcher with a record that is something less than impressive.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly heavy yesterday. Closing prices were 2 to 10 points net lower.

A bouquet to John Gould for his elegant Down-East yarn, "Tall Tales About the Pogy." Perhaps Mr. Gould will be interested in knowing that sports fishermen hereabouts often use the pogy as "chum" when trolling for bluefish.

A new course on the "Fundamentals of Housing" will be given this fall by the College of Home Economics of Cornell University. A two-semester unit, the course will begin with a broad survey of housing history and world needs in the housing field. Later it will narrow down to individual family problems.

The best trend in production schedules since last October has appeared, with 50 per cent of the plants reporting increased and only 10 per cent showing declines, according to Robert C. Swanton, chairman of the business survey committee of the National, Association of Purchasing Agents.

Congratulations to Benjamin Fine for "More and More, the IQ Idea Is Questioned." By helping to expose the pigeonhole-every-child theory of education he will perhaps catalyze a long-overdue revolution in our testing program which favors the head and forgets the heart. * * *

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Cornell's team had too much power and deception for a hard-fighting Colgate eleven today, and the result was a 39-27 victory for the Big Red. It was the first real test for both teams and brought 20,000 spectators to Schoellkopf Field.

CLYNDE, one of those remote English villages so dear to the hearts of English mystery writers, is a place where nothing ever happens. In fact, the residents are so used to having nothing happen that even the disappearance of the new rector doesn't stir them.
PARIS, Oct 1 -- France will ask for a Western European conference to prop monetary and economic stability as an aftermath of the recent currency alignments, it was announced officially tonight.

THE devaluation of the British pound and dependent currencies made itself felt last week in Hollywood when Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer, the bellwether of the major studios, announced a new economy drive to meet the anticipated loss in foreign revenue.

WITH the autumn two music seasons open in New York, the one tempestuously publicized and diligently reviewed, the other substantially unnoticed in the press, yet capturing the devotion of a large corps of music enthusiasts.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Mighty Michigan steam-rollered over a willing but outclassed Stanford football team today by a 27-7 count.

THESE two small volumes are perhaps the most important books about the contemporary American scene that we will have this year. This is not to say they are the best books -- and certainly not to say they are the best-written books -- on the subject of American politics, past and present.

THIS department observed recently -- the observation having been driven home during a talk with the author of "A Rage To Live" -- that American writers don't look like writers. Well, this department has seen it all now and it offers an award -- if it had an award -- to Nelson Algren for being the writer who least looks like one.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 1 -Highlighted by an 88-yard touchdown run by Dick Gabriel, Lehigh won by 39 to 7 from Case Institute of Technology today.

BUFFALO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Lawrence D. Bell, president of the Bell Aircraft Corporation asked Governor Dewey tonight to name a fact-finding board to seek a new approach toward settlement of the strike at the plant of his company.
IN New York City a half-pint of heavy cream (eight fluid ounces) averages 35 cents, a tall can of evaporated milk (thirteen fluid ounces) 15 cents. Ounce for ounce, the cream costs more than triple.

DALLAS, Oct. 1 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District during the last week were better than sales for the corresponding period of last year in two of four major cities in the district, but were considerably below sales for the preceding week this year.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 23 -- Two-way traffic through the Iron Curtain has loomed large in the Turkish press this week.

IT takes more than one primula to make a garden and while Primula vulgaris (also known as P. acaulis) and the bunch primrose, P. polyantha, are fine, few growers are satisfied until they have established an unusual one.

POETRY is what you thought about when you were a child, somehow not forgotten in the business of growing up, and discovered to be true, and valuable, and possible, just as you always thought it was. . . . Poetry is the language of a hoped-for country of light, overheard when the road you walk on brings you nearer the unknown border than ever before. . . .
COPENHAGEN, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- What is believed here to be the first real "world school" for children has been opened in Copenhagen.

THE real person of the small, gray tyrant with the withered arm, the heavy Georgian accent, and the maddeningly flat prose-style remains hidden from us still -- from his latest biographer no less than from those who knew him, worked with him, and were finally destroyed by him.

ROUND-TRIP excursion tickets good for sixty days after purchase and costing about 30 per cent less than regular rates went on sale yesterday in the ticket offices of ten United States and foreign-flag airlines flying the Atlantic.

With the enactment by Congress of Title 14 of the United States Code into positive law the Coast Guard as of Nov. 1 will be operating for the first time in its history under a statute prescribing the service's precise duties, responsibilities, organization and jurisdiction, according to the September issue of the Coast Guard Bulletin.

THE first week of autumn brought out in the galleries exhibitions of work ranging from highly traditional to highly modern, with an unaccustomed early season stress on sculpture both in shows and in the news, as will be evident elsewhere on the page.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 1 -- With a formation of jet fighter planes from near-by Mitchel Field roaring overhead, Nassau County's 903-acre park on the outskirts of this community was dedicated as a memorial to the country's war dead this morning.

It has been suggested that any plays enjoying successful runs on Broadway should be duplicated with second or even third companies within the New York theatre district. This would theoretically serve two purposes. First, it would make tickets more readily available to the theatregoing public.

Orders placed by buyers in the wholesale garment market here last week emphasized holiday merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -Capt. John C. Crommelin of the Navy, outspoken critic of armed forces unification, submitted tonight to orders not to discuss relations between the services during a television interview.

THE outlook for economic man was pretty bleak, according to the early classical economists. Adam Smith did not see much future for the "labouring poor." Malthus, one of the world's most eminent pessimists, thought the human species would multiply until, like a horde of grasshoppers, it stripped the earth of sustenance.

WASHINGTON -- Using driver behavior as a guide in determining the adequacy of an existing road or in selecting a new route was suggested here last week by Thomas H. MacDonald, United States Commissioner of Public Roads.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Billy Cox, a slender halfback with the marksmanship of a frontiersman, put on a sensational passing show today to lead Duke to a 21-7 victory over Tennessee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- If American cities were attacked tomorrow the Federal Government would be ready with two civil defense planning organizations totaling about a dozen men who have no authority whatsoever.

MISS HILDEGARDE WITHERS, an irrepressible, middle-aged school teacher, whose headlong dives into amateur detection are well known to inveterate mystery-story readers, is at it again. And, as usual, Inspector Piper of the New York Homicide Bureau acts as a long-suffering friend and scapegoat.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- Except for instances of greater expense and inconvience to industrial and commercial establishments, there has been relatively little effect on the general business situation in the St. Louis metropolitan area so far from the prolonged Missouri-Pacific strike.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L. I., Oct. 1 -- A two-hour air show, featuring 600-mile-an-hour jet fighter craft made in Nassau County, will open the Nassau County Golden Jubilee Industrial Exposition here at 2 P. M., next Saturday.

IN two current one-man exhibitions the renewed vitality of contemporary sculpture is significantly demonstrated. This vitality is all the more remarkably proved in that neither of the two sculptors exhibiting feels compelled to seek strength by casting in his lot with the narrow sect of modernists.

IT is a pleasant thing to have within easy reach an unpretentious and uncomplicated book like "Countryman's Year." The title is modest and understandable, the plan of the book, simple and convincing -- about twelve dozen capsule-sized essays suggesting some of the things the countryman sees and feels through the twelve months' cycle.

Predicting an extremely active Christmas holiday season in costume jewelry, Jack Ruderman, treasurer of Kaufman-Ruderman Company, Inc., one of the leading manufacturers in the field, estimated yesterday ,that total sales of the industry this year will closely approximate the 1948 figure of $220,000,000.

More than one-half of the nation's 900,000 public school teachers do not have tenure and can be dismissed without explanation by local school boards. For many years educators have urged that fair dismissal legislation be enacted in states where such laws do not now exist.

EDWIN CORLE, so well known for his desert writings, relates here the tale of Highway 101, that California route known in tourist folders as El Camino Real. It was trodden by Portola and his handful of soldiers in 1769 when the chain of Franciscan missions was projected from San Diego northward to San Francisco Bay.

Disturbed over an increasing amount of racial tension in the East Harlem area, the Committee for Inter-Cultural Activities, organized recently under the East Harlem District Health Committee, began yesterday the formation of sub-committees to remedy the situation.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 -- A decklevel speed of almost that of sound has been set by the Douglas (D-555-II) Skyrocket, the sweptwing Navy research plane, it was reported today by The Los Angeles Times.

ROME, Oct. 1 -- Cardinal Spellman arrived in Rome by air from Amsterdam tonight to make his "ad limina" visit to the tomb of Apostles Peter and Paul and report to the Pope on the condition of affairs in the Archidiocese of New York.

EVANSTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's snarling Panthers turned from their customary role as punching bag for Big Ten football powers and upset Northwestern's three-touchdown favorite Wildcats 16-7, at Dyche Stadium today.

ONE of the finest and most dependable sources of color in the early fall garden is hardy perennial asters or Michaelmas daisies. Although they announce their presence long before the end of the summer -- in fact, some flower with the annuals -- the wealth of blossoms extends summer into autumn.
THIS book is as confused and irritational as a jigsaw puzzle without a pattern. What Mr. Laski is trying to say is constantly obscured by what he is trying not to say.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 1 (AP) -Archbishop Joseph Francis Rummel said today he had cancelled the annual Roman Catholic observance of holy hour here tomorrow afternoon because city park commissioners insisted on racial segregation.

A LONG comes another of England's post-war novelists to probe the curious Siamese twin relationship between good and evil in men's souls. Graham Greene's investigations are more pretentious, and Elizabeth Bowen writes better, but Mr. Massingham, it seems to me, has sent over a morality tale of considerable merit.

Marking National Employ-thePhysically-Handicapped Week, an exhibit, "The Disabled Are Able," will be opened today at 2 P. M. in the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West, it was announced yesterday. The slow will continue through Oct. 9.

THE pictures on these two pages illustrate a theory that modern art -- which many people reject and find unintelligible when it hangs on the walls of a museum -- has become, willy-nilly, a part of daily life.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Dean Acheson, United States Secretary of State, during the course of the recent financial negotiations in Washington, gave Robert Schuman, Foreign Minister, a formal promise of support for fixing the price of Ruhr coal at a more favorable rate for France, a French official said today.

ROWING down the river in a leaky rowboat, Shad Davis, an earnest 16-year-old with a love for horses and instinctive ability to handle them, hides his old boat and enters the grounds of the county fair. There he gets a job as assistant groom to Cedar's Boy, grandson of the great horse depicted in an earlier book by Mr. Meader, "Red Horse Hill."

A PROGRAM for improving facilities for tourists was proposed at a recent meeting in New Orleans of the National Recreation Congress. The recommendations indicate recognition of the current trend to motor holidays and the resultant need for roadside accommodations and information.
ONE is weary of the leading countries" of Europe, of their ubiquitous, pontificating "leading" musicians who have cornered the market, the power and the forum.

LETS begin by getting the business of the title out of the way, a title which perversely reminds this reviewer of Ferdinand the Bull. The condor, it may be explained, is the great bird of the Andes countries (Mr. Isherwood may be interested in knowing that it has a wing spread of some nine feet), while the cows are symbolic of the pampas and estancias of the Argentine.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 1 -- Mrs. Herbert E. Carnes of Tenafly became today the first woman ever to be president of the Audubon Society of New Jersey. Her election was announced tonight to a meeting of 200 bird lovers in the Public Service Auditorium here.

CARTERSVILLE, Ga., Oct. 1 -Allatoona Dam, the $32,000,000 project designed to provide multipurpose river resources for the rich industrial and agricultural areas of North Georgia, is now 90 per cent completed.
THE other summer-flowering bulbs fall into two categories: Those to be lifted before frost and those that should be left until later. The first group needs attention in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Formation of a new six-state New England Democratic conference to discuss power and labor problems, business prospects and the Administration's farm program was announced today by James H. Vahey, Democratic state chairman from Massachusetts and chairman of the conference.

A POLITE letter from a mild-mannered Yale Professor vacationing in England, saying he's on his way home with over a million dollars' worth of diamonds that have something to do with a foreign power and that he thinks our Government would like to know about it, sends Ed Brakely, State Department intelligence man, up to New Haven to find out what it's all about.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 -- Despite the display of sidearms and the use of dynamite in some coal fields in central Pennsylvania, particularly in Clearfield County, the two week strike of the country's 400,000 soft-coal miners settled today into the stubborn pattern established by the United Mine Workers since the ascendancy of John L. Lewis as president.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 -- The country's steel mills are shut down because labor and management cannot agree on whether employers should pay the whole bill for pensions and social insurance or whether workers should share the cost.

NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., Oct. 1 -- After two rounds in the seventeenth annual New Jersey amateur best-ball championship at the Green Brook Country Club today, the medalists, Steve Berrien and Chet Sanok of Upper Montclair, had reached the semi-finals.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 -- The spectacular battle between the New York Yankees and the Boston Red Sox for the American League baseball pennant and a different kind of battle, involving attempts to unload Hawaiian pineapples on the West Coast despite picket lines and cracked heads, gripped attention of this area this week.
IN a remote sort of way the late Signor Luigi Pirandello deserves an assist in connection with the production by Roger Stevens of "Twelfth Night," scheduled for the Empire Theatre tomorrow evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- Big Ralph Branca and the Dodgers seemed to have the 1949 pennant all wrapped up to ship home as early as the sixth inning here today when four muscle men of the Phils shot away the wrappings and wrecked the delivery truck beyond repair.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -- A bipartisan move to raise the pay of members of Congress to $20,000 or $25,000 a year is rapidly gaining momentum.
ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- Governor Dewey's up-state campaign for John Foster Dulles, the itinerary for which was announced today, will rival in intensity his primary campaign in Oregon a year ago last May.

A 99-year-old Armenian woman, said to be the oldest person to come to this country under the displaced persons program, arrived here yesterday on the Army transport General S. D. Sturgis. The ship brought 854 DP's from twelve nations, docking from Bremerhaven at West Twenty-first Street.
OMAHA, Oct. 1 -- The reported Russian atomic blast continued to hold popular interest in the Midwest this week, but it had some competition, of course.

THE prices of Rolleiflex cameras will be stabilized within the next sixty days at $307.50 for the Zeiss Tessar lens model and $261.50 for the Schneider Xenar lens model following the completion of Fair Trade agreements now under way according to a recent announcement in Los Angeles.
DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians blanked the Detroit Tigers 4 to 0, today to assure themselves of at least a tie for third place in the American League race.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Vern Bickford pitched the Braves to a 3-0 triumph over the Giants today to assure Boston of no worse than a tie for fourth place in the National League.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 1 -Holy Cross' football team, its ranks heavily larded with sophomores, fell before Brown University's winged-T attack today, 28--6.

Details of the Little Orchestra Society's coming season of eight programs in Town Hall, under the direction of Thomas K. Scherman, were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -President Truman went to the Washington's Naval Gun Factory today to help celebrate its 150th anniversary. He received full military honors and then boarded the yacht Williamsburg to watch two hours of marine pageantry.
DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Open opposition to the new Ford pension plan cropped up today for the first time within the United Auto Workers Union, CIO.

A 31-yard touchdown drive at the opening of the fourth quarter ended a tense deadlock and gave Colby College a 20-14 victory over C. C. N. Y. yesterday to the despair of 3,500 Lavender rooters in Lewisohn Stadium.

D.

Suddenly he jabbed with a straight left, his finger pointing excitedly in the direction of the huge scoreboard in back of the bleachers.

The rock-bottom definition is: A form of government under which, subject to considerable restrictions and limitations, the adult population has the right to express its preferences in matters political.
The membership of the American Society of Civil Engineers, the oldest engineering group in the United States, has risen to 26,300, with forty honorary members, the magazine Standardization announces.

Among Labor's leaders there is as clear an understanding as among the Tories and foreign economists of the need to curtail government spending, cut costs and hold wages to the present level.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 1 -- Utahans have been shamefacedly keeping score on the number of escapes from their ancient State Penitentiary. With the count of escapees now standing at 22 for the year, intense interest was aroused by a report from a special investigating committee appointed by Gov. J. Bracken Lee, in which dismissal of Warden Mason W. Hill was recommended "at the earliest possible date."

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Military planning among the British, Norwegian and Danish Governments will begin here almost immediately after the meeting of Atlantic pact Defense Ministers in Washington next week, it is reliably learned.
