WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Army's new plan for improving the opportunities of Negroes in its ranks was condemned today as a "sham" by the Americans for Democratic Action, which called on President Truman to reject it.

As a result of a campaign in seventeen Canadian newspapers, Amm-i-dent toothpowder outsold all other powders and ammoniated dentifrices in Canada by midsummer and was fourth in the entire field, according to Dan Stern, director of Stafford-Miller of Canada, Ltd., Canadian manufacturer of Amm-i-dent by arrangement with Amm-i-dent, Inc., of Jersey City.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 2 -- Skipper Schroeder of Summit and Miss Joanne C. Link of Westwood, a pair of talented 15-year-old youngsters, claimed two titles each today in the wind-up of the three-day Rock Spring Horse Show. Schroeder won the saddle seat horsemanship and hunter's seat horsemanship titles after leading the field in three preliminary events.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 -- The five survivors of the plane crash which took the life of Buddy Clark, radio singer, on Saturday night, were reported "fair" to "fine" today as the Civil Aeronautics Board began an investigation of the accident.

Jean Westbrook, violinist, made her New York debut in a recital given yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Her program consisted of Bach's Concerto in E major, Mozart's Sonata in G major (K. 301), Bartok's Rumanian Folk Dances and two contemporary American works that received their first performances, David Diamond's Chaconne for Violin and Piano and Noel Sokoloff's "Epithalamium."

It never occurs to some people that one man's Tuesday may be another man's Saturday. Most wage-earners think of "days off" in terms of Saturday and Sunday and visualize the five-day week as a work period that begins on Monday morning and ends on Friday afternoon.

A Brooklyn debate about eggs became so scrambled yesterday morning that the police and a magistrate had to intervene. Basically, the argument was about whether a cafeteria should be compelled to cook eggs for six minutes just because it advertises eggs cooked "any style."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- A Congress described as "punchy" by one Senator, edged up to a showdown today on politically loaded farm, immigration and welfare issues.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- The Soviet Army newspaper Red Star, in an article by Ilya Ehrenburg, said today that if the "American beasts of prey" should start a war, the conflict would not be confined to the Old World but would "reach America, too."

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, and Mayor O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for re-election, will have strong support from the Truman administration, it was learned yesterday.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Third-baseman George Kell of the Tigers won the unofficial American League batting crown today. He banged out two hits in three times at bat as Detroit lost by 8 -- 4 to Cleveland.

While merchandise in waterfront stores has become less accessible to British seamen in New York because of the devaluation of the pound, crew members aboard two Furness Line vessels are rejoicing because by the same action, they have received a pay increase of about 30 per cent insofar as money sent home is concerned.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 2 -- It was "Hi! Ho! Come to the Fair" today as throngs from New England, New York and New Jersey streamed through the gates -- from early morning until sundown -- for the second day of the Danbury Fair's seventy-sixth annual edition.
Gift to U. N. by Everyone in World Is Suggested

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 -- Had it not been for preparations in the steel centers last week for the steel strike, the steel ingot rate would have been 84.5 per cent, down 1 1/2 points from the week before. But because of precautionary measures to protect furnaces and material, a general slowdown began early on Friday.

By the end of 1949, New York City will have been host to at least 660 conventions, and its hotels, theatres, stores and other businesses will have taken in $1,000,000,000 from some 13,000,000 out-of-towners, according to Royal M. Ryan, executive vice president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Sept. 24 to 30 are given in the appended tabulation:

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 -- High Federal officials, convinced that a long strike in either steel or coal would be enough to send the national economy into a tailspin, were reported today considering a double-barreled "peace offensive" to restore production in both fields.

MONTREAL, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Indianapolis Indians of the American Association made it two straight against Montreal of the International League in the little world series by winning 5 -- 1 today. Indianapolis won the opening game of the best-of-seven series by the same score last night.
Five new films, including importations from Hungary and Italy, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WRENTHAM, Mass., Oct. 2 -- The town's selectmen, monks from nearby abbeys and hundreds of neighbors turned out here last night to greet fourteen Trappistine nuns who arrived to enter their new St. Mary's Abbey situated on a 500-acre farm here.

When a woman whose size goes to a 20 is thinking of making herself a dress or suit, she must keep in mind that simple lines are the most flattering to the figure. The patterns that we show here are carefully studied to do something for one who likes to be in the fashion swim and yet have a dress of design that suits her type.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 2 - The Dodgers picked up the Pot of Gold today but it took them ten innings and 3 hours 17 minutes to beat the stubborn and fighting Phils, 9-7, and bring about the second Subway Series in three years.

Charging that the present city Administration had been derelict in protecting citizens against public utility rate increases, the Liberal party, through Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman, proposed yesterday establishment of a New York City Public Utilities Bureau to represent the city in cases before the Public Service Commission.
Perhaps it was destined from the very beginning that Casey Stengel and his amazing Yankees were to win this 1949 American League pennant.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Following the disclosure that an atomic explosion had occurred in the Soviet Union, Britain advertised today for young scientists to work in its three atomic research establishments.
BRADDOCK, Pa., Oct. 2 -- Striking steelworkers in this drab mill town are counting on "their friend," Harry S. Truman, to find a quick solution for their strike.

Pessimism over the effects of devaluation on United States exports may be overdone, the National City Bank's October letter, to be issued today, asserts in a survey of the implications of lower foreign currency values in terms of our money.

Britain's decision to devalue its currency reflects the determination of her government to seek a solution to trading problems "in the competitive arena of multilateral trade instead of permanently sheltering an overvalued pound behind the protective barriers of bilateralism," the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its Monthly Review, published today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A quarrel between the chief of the National Guard Bureau and his air branch chief burst into the open today when the Army confirmed that the air officer had been discharged and quickly reinstated.
MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- Russia today recognized the Central People's [Communist] Government of Chin.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal - Fusion candidate for Mayor, will make an all-out attack on the administration of Mayor O'Dwyer, his Democratic opponent, in a radio speech tonight, it was said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -The nation's chiropodists cautioned parents today not to force their infants to stand and walk before they were ready. They said it was a common cause of "pes valgo-planus," or flat feet.
Thousands of Polish Americans marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday under a bright autumn sun and into deepening twilight in the city's thirteenth annual Pulaski Day parade.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- The International Harvester Council of the United Farm Equipment Workers, CIO, has asked Philip Murray, head of the CIO and of the striking Steelworkers Union, to call a conference of all CIO unions now engaged in wage-pension strife to develop a united no-compromise approach."

EVER since "The Dwelling Place" was published in 1943 I have been an ardent admirer of the writing of Anne Goodwin Winslow. Her serene and lovely books have all in their fashion been gentle protests against the current trends of modern literature. They are short. They are gracious and well mannered. They are lucid and thoughtful.
BIG SPRING, Tex., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Frank Grandstaff, a life-term convict, sat in the front row today and listened nervously while twenty-eight men sang his musical history of Big Spring.

There was a wild time in Crabtown Saturday night and even grim old Tecumseh is said to have almost smiled beneath his war paint in approval of Navy's bursting of the iron shackles for its first football victory in sixteen games, going back to early in the 1947 season.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 2 -- The Nationalist Navy today "kidnapped" the two United States merchantmen that were detained as they left Shanghai last Thursday and took them to the naval base in the Chushan Islands, the ships' agent here, A. P. Pattison, said today.

The New York art season really hits its stride this week with some thirty exhibitions in museums and galleries. On Wednesday the Museum of Modern Art will open its twentieth anniversary exhibition entitled "Modern Art in Your Life."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 2 -- Diplomatic observers predicted today the rapid development during October of Czechoslovakia's part in the Communist Information Bureau's campaign against what it regards as its triple headed enemy -- "Titoism," the Vatican and "Anglo-American imperialism."

The Puerto Ricans in New York, whose number is a guess between 160,000 and 600,000, are the displaced persons of the Western Hemisphere. A study of their problems showed yesterday that these refugees from an overpopulated tropical island, where the average wage is $14.28 a week, have more trouble adjusting to this city's life than do the survivors of Europe's concentration camps.
Hearings before the Civil Aeronautics Board on a basic air cargo case that may set the pattern for future international air cargo operations will begin today in Washington.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 2 -- Gordon R. Clapp and his associates of the United Nations economic mission expect to present to the United Nations by early November a program that would provide work and livelihood for physically fit Palestine Arab refugees for a period of two years, it is learned from an official source.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 2 -- The United States Government is studying a plan for spurring private productive investment abroad, particularly in under - developed countries, based on the Federal Housing Authority insurance principle that has proved so effective in promoting private investment in housing in this country.

OKLAO CITY,-Oct.' 2 --J Independent retail food merchants cnot expect to be "legislated tO success by controls over their corn-i petitors,' C. C. Precure'of Britton,I Okla., president of the Nationa Association of Retail Grocers, told the annual convention of the Oklahoma Retail Grocers Association in the Oklahoma City Auditorium this afternoon.

The people of the world are faced with the choice of religion or ruin, the Rev. Wayland Zwayer, secretary for Europe of the Church World Service, Inc., declared yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church at Thirty-first Street.

There are more than thirty species of Viburnum, and one of the most interesting is the Wayfaring Tree, or Hobblebush. It may have been three centuries ago when it acquired its folklore names. Viburnum alnifolium has a way of attracting attention to itself. It's a straggling, irregular type of woodland shrub with branches five to eight feet high.

Possession of the atom bomb does not bestow security upon America, Rabbi Leo Jung declared in a sermon last night at the Jewish Center, 131 West Eighty-sixth Street. The service marked the opening of the observance of Yom Kippur, or Day of Atonement, most sacred day in the Jewish calendar, which ends at sundown today.
ST. JAMES, L. I., Oct 2 -- Two persons were killed and two others were injured critically in automobile accidents in this area early today.

F. Van Wyck Mason, author of four novels about the American Revolution, has begun work on a Civil War tetralogy, Lippincott reports. Emphasizing the naval aspect, the novels will alternate in points of view. The first novel, "Proud New Flags," is written from the Confederate side, beginning with the capture of Norfolk Navy Yard and the burning of the Union fleet.
PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Three notable events occurred here last week from the monetary viewpoint.
Grace Walker, who thinks she is the only woman copper miner in the United States, came back to New York yesterday for a brief visit.

The Rev. Dr. James A. Pike, who preached his first sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, as chaplain of the university, emphasized the contributions that followers of differing reigious faiths might make to one another's spiritual welfare.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Los Angeles' rough riding Rams, scoring when and how they pleased, routed the Green Bay Packers, 48 -- 7, today in a National Football League game before 24,308 fans at City Stadium.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The stock markets here are still in the process of adjustment to the immediate effects of the devaluation of the pound sterling, but they appear to be approaching the stage when consideration of longer term effects will become the predominant factor in the investment outlook.

ROME, Oct. 2 -- Cardinal Spellman was received tonight by the Pope to whom he delivered a report on the Archdiocese of New York. The audience had been fixed for tomorrow morning but Cardinal Spellman went by car to see the Pope at the papal summer residence of Castel Gandolfo at 8 P. M. in response to an urgent summons from Pope Pius.

CARMEL, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Twenty-one women have been nominated by the Democrats and Republicans for various town offices in the six towns of Putnam County. There are fifty-seven offices to be filled in the six towns. The lists of candidates also include seventy-eight men.

After a summer high in the snowy wastes of the greatest group of high mountains on the North American continent, a field party of the Arctic Institute of North America has returned with new data on the vegetation, animal life and climate of the Seward and Malaspina glaciers in Southeast Alaska and Yukon Territory of Canada.

The New York City Opera Company completed the first week of its new season at the City Center yesterday by presenting the two excellent productions it added to its repertoire last fall. In the afternoon it gave Verdi's "Aida" and in the evening Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro."

JACKSON'S MILL, W. Va., Oct. 2 -- Reckless and careless complexes of youthful drivers were emphasized today as the chief factors for the increasing highway accident rate attributed to the teen-age bracket.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The following is the text of a note handed by Russia to the United States Ambassador in Moscow, protesting the formation of the West German Republic. Similar notes were given to the British and French envoys. It was released by the Soviet Monitor here:

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 2 -- The time has arrived to campaign for a shorter standard work day and work week, American Federation of Labor leaders suggested today. The suggestion was made in the Executive Council report that will be ready tomorrow at the opening session of the annual AFL convention.

Patrolman Albert J. Olsen of the Juvenile Aid Bureau has received a scholarship set up by Fordham University's School of Social Service for a member of the bureau on social case work with juvenile delinquents, it was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Oct. 2 -- In words that constituted a review of the occupation's economic policies, Gen. Douglas MacArthur today attacked an article in the current issue of Fortune magazine, declaring that it contained statements "sharply at variance with the facts of record which have been accurately reported by many competent local correspondents."

Asserting that there is a possibility of his election with a large registration, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, called yesterday on the voters of the city to make this possibility a reality and warned them not to be deterred from registering next week by Tammany or Republican "tricks."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Dick Weik and Lloyd Hittle held the Athletics to two hits today as the Senators wound up the season with a 2-0 victory. Lou Brissie went the route for the Mackmen, yielding seven blows.

Those who figured the new public address system at Grand Central Terminal had some bearing on train announcements were mistaken. The new era in station announcing beginning today at the terminal will have no bearing on the arrival or departure of trains.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 2 -- A new East-West struggle in the United Nations is expected to develop from the Soviet Union's recognition of Communist China and its break with the Nationalists, announced today by the Moscow radio.
Excavations on the Aegean island of Samothrace have produced a third marble statue, similar to the celebrated "Victory of Samothrace," Dr. Karl Lehmann of New York University reported yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Pirates closed their 1949 baseball season with an even break against the Reds in a double-header today. Pittsburgh won the first game, 4 -- 2, and dropped the nightcap, 6 -- 5.

Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market continued to hold to a narrow trading range last week. At the close, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 10 to up 6 points from the previous week. Current season contracts showed slight losses and more distant months had small gains.

NEW ORLEANS, Monday, Oct. 3 (UP) -- A hurricane with 90-mile-an-hour winds moved to within 210 miles of the Texas coast early today and weather observers said that if it maintained its present course it would strike between Corpus Christi and Galveston this afternoon.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 2 -- Winners of the 1949 Journalistic Awards of the International Labor Press of America were announced tonight at the banquet of the organization's thirty-eighth annual convention. The Paper Maker, edited by Ed Wall, won five awards.

The Citizens Budget Commission announced yesterday that it had asked the three principal candidates for Mayor to express before Election Day their views on six issues that concern the city's fiscal affairs. Letters were sent by Robert W. Dowling, president of the commission, to Mayor O'Dwyer, Democrat; Newbold Morris, Republican-Fusion-Liberal, and Vito Marcantonio, American Labor.

The winning streak of the Hamilton Polo Club was halted at five games by the Rumson (N. J.) Polo Club yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army reservation. Seven goals by Buddy Combs helped capsize Hamilton by 12 to 5 before 2,200 persons.

The dwelling with two-car garage on plot 30 by 100 feet at 3447 Corlear Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by irs. Julia Franco to a Mrs. Maloney in a transaction negotiated by Vincent Tarangioli, !broker, for cash over a mortgage of $6,000.

The reputation of Joseph P. Kenned is so outstanding one does not cros swords with him lightheartedly. He writes you a letter warning that if the devaluation of the pound does not bring about an "effective readjustment" of Britain's monetary troubles she must not blame America for being forced to take such drastic action.

TOKYO, Sept. 15 -- The Japanese capital is about to lose one of its most picturesque features, its sidewalk stalls, which have been a resource and a comfort to Japanese shoppers for more than fifty years.

A television program for inventors and another in which actors ad lib a dramatic sketch are among five more programs that WOR-TV has announced as regular evening features after its official premiere on Oct. 11.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 -- America's hopes for world leadership are "doomed" unless its people rid themselves of their "lingering contempt" for the Negro race, the Right Rev. William Scarlett, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Missouri, declared here today.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Baltimore Colts scored their first victory of the All-America Football Conference season today by defeating the Buffalo Bills, 35 -- 28, before 25,692 in Civic Stadium. Y. A. Tittle's pass to Billy Stone, spanning 52 yards, decided the issue with 24 seconds remaining.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 2 -- The nation-wide steel strike is creating a new worry for United Nations officials who fear it may delay completion of at least one of the buildings on the permanent site of the world capital in Mid-Manhattan.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The Soviet Government, in notes handed today to the United States, British and French envoys in Moscow, said it considered the formation of the West German state a violation of the Potsdam agreement and of the decisions of last June's meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

The expected yield on farm mortgage loans made by life insurance companies from 1945 to 1947 was 3.20 per cent, according to a study released by the National Bureau of Economic Research. With an allowance of 0.25 per cent for loss, the expected yield after costs would come to 2.95 per cent.

HONOLULU. Oct. 2 -- Talks aimed at ending Hawaii's costly dock strike, now entering its sixth month, began here today amid an air of cautious optimism. Harry Bridges, president of the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union's CIO, and Louis Goldblatt the ILW's secretary-treasurer, flew here from San Francisco for the discussions.

The World Bank is giving a constructive demonstration how funds can be applied to good purposes under sound conditions in its grants to India. On Aug. 18 the Bank made available to India $34,000,000 for railway rehabilitation and construction. On Thursday an additional loan of $10,000,000 was made.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- The most persistent long-term decline in non-farm employment between 1910 and 1948 was in jobs for laborers, according to a study of national employment by industries and occupations announced today by the industrial research department of the University of Pennsylvania.

The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, 14 Wall Street, announced yesterday grants totaling $940,000, the majority payable over five years, to medical colleges and other educational institutions in the eighteen months started with January, 1948.

Another hopeful note for the prospects of cancer research has been struck by press announcements and your editorial of Sept. 27 "Pied Pipers," noting the Jackson Laboratory's appeal to high-school students for aid in trapping mice of thirteen genera not yet maintained among its inbred stocks.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A rookie did what nine seasoned hurlers couldn't do today -- win a ball game for the St. Louis Browns.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- By defeating the Philadelphia Americans; 1 -- 0 today, the Philadelphia Nationals, champions of the American Soccer League, annexed two more points in the championship competition. Tom Oliver kicked the goal.

Mr. !Michaels, manager of the basement division of LaSalle Koch of Toledo, is succeeding Walter T. Stolurow, who has resigned.

SEATTLE, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Four University of Washington backs and one lineman were on the damaged list today after the 27-7 football defeat which was capped by the Notre Dame coach, Frank Leahy, reportedly angrily criticizing the officiating.

Resurfacing of midtown Fifth Avenue was completed yesterday as crews from the asphalt plant of the Manhattan Borough President's office put a new crown on the roadway between Fifty-seventh and Fifty-ninth Streets in four hours and sixteen minutes.

New York University's School of Law announced yesterday that it had taken over the old Lafayette Hotel on a short-term lease to provide living quarters for tenants of the Washington Square South block upon which it plans to build a new law center.

The import of World Communion Sunday was emphasized yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving in his sermon at St. James' Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 (UP) -- With big Marion Motley his old bone-crushing self, the Cleveland Browns finally showed all their vaunted power today as they ripped the Los Angeles Dons, 42 to 7, in an All-America Football Conference game before 30,466 fans.

The eightieth birthday of the late Mahatma Gandhi was celebrated at a memorial service held yesterday at the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, under the auspices of the India League of America.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Decision by the British and the United States Governments on the matter of recognition of the Chinese Communist regime has been made more urgent, in the opinion of London diplomatic observers, by the proclamation of the People's Republic in Peiping and the Soviet Union's move to establish relations with that regime.
HONG KONG, Oct. 2 (UP) -- Text of the statement by Moo Tze-tung, Chairman of the Communist People's Republic of China proclaiming his new regime as broadcast by the Peiping radio:

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 2 -- Dr. Edward Kardelj, Yugoslav Minister of Foreign Affairs, said today that although the Yugoslav Government did not know what was "back of the mind" of the Soviet Government, "it was hard to believe that anyone in the present situation could decide to embark on the adventure of making an armed attack against an independent and sovereign country, a member of the United Nations."

LONDON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- Following are the texts of notes sent by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, to the Foreign Ministry of the Communist People's Republic of China, and to the Chinese Embassy in Moscow, as broadcast today by Tass, official Soviet news agency, and distributed by the Soviet Monitor, an agency of Tass:

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate would consider soon a proposal by a limited dividend housing company for construction of a 948 - family cooperative garden apartment development in the Bayside area of Queens.

Pennsylvania Station sounded last night like Ebbets Field during a sustained Brooklyn rally. Nearly 25,000 Dodger fans milled through the vast station screaming a welcome to the Brooklyn ballplayers on their homecoming.

The greatest demand upon the Christian is to love "totally" with all his heart and mind, Msgr. John S. Middleton, secretary for education of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 2 -- Press reports from Peiping today said that the new Communist People's Republic of China had officially delivered bids for foreign recognition to consulates in the new Communist capital.
It will be the New York Yankees against the Brooklyn Dodgers in the 1949 edition of the world series starting Wednesday at Yankee Stadium.

Since President Truman's Point Four program for making "the benefits of our scientific advances and industrial progress available for the improvement and growth of underdeveloped areas" depends on the cooperation of private capital, the business community's reaction to it is important.

To Shakespeare goes the distinction of supplying Broadway with the first play of the 1949-50-season. Tonight at the Empire, where the curtain is advertised to rise at 8 o'clock, the bard's comedy, "Twelfth Night" or "What You Will," will have its formal opening under the auspices of Roger Stevens, a theatre-minded real estate operator, after three previews.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- An atmosphere of optimism permeated the ranks of exhibitors today at the second annual Television and Electrical Living Show, which opened yesterday at the Coliseum under the sponsorship of the Electrical Association.

Some furniture stores are seek* ing to place advance orders for fast selling bedroom suites in sufficient quantities to take care of anticipated needs for the rest of the year, retailers reported lastI week. They reported some difficulty in finding supply sources Wi11ng to accept orders for delivery before Nov. 15.

CANTON, China, Oct. 2 -- The National Government has become essentially a military coalition, the main components of which are the Kwangsi group of Generals Li Tsung-jen and Pai Chung-hsi and the Formosa group of Chiang Kai-shek.

The fiftieth anniversary of the pounding of the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement will be celebrated with a four-day program of religious rites, beginning tomorrow, at the friars' motherhouse at Graymoor, Garrison, N. Y.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Governor Dewey canceled tonight several speaking engagements scheduled for this week in order to attend the funeral Tuesday of Thomas E. Broderick, former chairman of the Monroe County Republican Committee.

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week exceeded business at the retail level 'as shortages in some ready-to-wer lines moved retailers to place orders through the holiday period, according to reports prepared especialiy for THE NEW YORK TTME. S by leading resident buying o/flees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Senate "five-percenter" inquiry, which reached into the White House staff and also brought about the retirement of an Army major general, probably will not be resumed this year, Senator Clyde R. Hoey, Democrat, of North Carolina, said today. A report on the inquiry may be issued soon.

The former Italian colonies are back in the news and, what is more important, back on the familiar chessboard of power politics. Any situation can be simplified by eliminating cross-currents and contradictory factors and taking a single point of view, but the trouble with the African colonies is that they have been caught up, like so many other post-war developments, in the clash of East and West.
The scene in the Yankees' dressing room immediately after they had clinched the pennant yesterday was precisely what one would expect it to be -- hilariously happy.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Ministers of the Labor Government, in political speeches today, were unmistakably preparing their followers for a general election, but they were careful not to say when the polling would take place.

Britain's Labor Government and its Conservative opponents debated devaluation in Parliament for three days last week. By a strange conjunction of events, however, while the running account of that controversy was being received here, other news stories were coming in from Times correspondents in London which, to the person interested in the basic causes of Britain's difficulties, might well have made not only the debate but the devaluation issue itself seem fantastically unreal.

Italy has abandoned her claim to trusteeship of all her former colonies except Somaliland, the least populous and least important of the lot. This was the gist of the dignified address made on Saturday before the Political and Security Committee of the U. N. General Assembly by Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza.

An investing client of Morris L. Bower, attorney, bought the sixstory apartment house for fortyeight families at 115 West Sixteenth Street. from Shelmore Estates, Inc., in a deal negotiated by Michael Rozental, broker. Isaac Futterman was the attorney for the seller of, the property, which is 100 by 9Z feet and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $198,855 held by the Brooklyn Savings Bank.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 2 -- An agreement ending a twenty-two-week-old strike at the Bridgeport works of the Singer Manufacturing Company was ratified here today at a membership meeting of Local 227, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A Supreme Court, including one new justice, and at least one absent one, will meet at noon tomorrow to begin a new term for the country's highest bench.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 2 -- An pursuance of its policy of bringing the Indian population down to an "irreducible minimum," the Nationalist Government has ordered police action on a wide scale to round up Indians illegally residing in South Africa, who are believed to number several hundred thousand.

A critical analysis of Federal benefits to war veterans, issued yesterday by the Tax Foundation, Inc., asserted that the Veterans Administration insurance program alone had cost the nation's taxpayers $4,000,000,000 since 1942.

The future of the shipbuilding industry in this country is dimmed by the fact that virtually all the tonnage now on order will be completed and delivered by early 1951. Leaders of the industry, along with representatives of labor, are disturbed over the Government's delay in carrying out a long-range construction program.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- In a scathing attack on the present French Government headed by Premier Henri Queuille, Gen. Charles de Gaulle ridiculed today the Cabinet's efforts to solve the nation's economic troubles through further international consultations.

The foreign exchange market was considerably less active than during the previous week. Though a large amount of transactions were reported at the start, as the week wore on the market settled down and only a moderate turnover took place.

Probably because of advertisements pledging that baseball scores would be broadcast over loudspeakers yesterday at the air show at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, attendance at this benefit for the Police Athletic League jumped yesterday, its second and final day, to 10,000, as contrasted with 2,000 the first day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Lard prices averaged higher on the Board of Trade last week despite liquidation at one time by holders of October contracts. Removal of hedges against sales of 7,000,000 pounds of lard to the Government and the announcement that further business would be put through within a day or so, combined with activity in crude vegetable oils, furnished the background for the strength.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- France's procedure in inviting the West European nations to new monetary consultations will take the form of a memorandum to be sent to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, Maurice Petsche, French Minister of Finance, said today.

NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., Oct. 2 -- Scoring a surprise victory, Frank Gervasio and Tony Pacifico of Crestmont won two tough matches by identical scores to capture the seventeenth annual New Jersey State best-ball golf championship over the Green Brook Country Club course today.

New York and Brooklyn must have seemed a bit insane last night, but it was a healthy madness. They were celebrating an almost incredible finish to an incredible baseball pennant race. Not since 1908 has the outcome in both leagues depended upon games played on the last day.

YAKIMA, Wash., Oct. 2 -- Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court was thrown from a horse and injured seriously today while riding on the mile-high Pacific Coast Trail, in a rugged part of the Cascade Mountains, seventy-five miles west of Yakima.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Member companies of the Radio Manufacturers Association produced 185,706 television sets in the five-week period between Aug. 1 and Sept. 2, according to a report issued here today by the RMA. Total industry production, it is estimated, exceeded 200,000 television receivers. August production by member companies of the RMA was the highest since last March, when 183,361 television sets were produced in a five-week period.

A large majority of small business men believe that big business does more good than harm and feel that their most difficult problems are created by government bureaus rather than by large companies. This is revealed in a survey, released today, by Dr. Henry C. Link, vice president of the Psychological Corporation.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- The Cardinals came out of their painful slump before 30,834 onlookers at Wrigley Field, but too late to grab the National League pennant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce endorsed today the objectives of President Truman's Point Four program but urged that the plan to assist underdeveloped nations with American knowledge be started on a modest basis.

A career woman who earns more than $50,000 a year might well be excused for not knowing much about culinary matters. No apologies are needed, though, for Mona Kent, who is the creator and writer of the radio soap opera, "Portia Faces Life," and, in addition, a wonderful cook.
Bernard Nr. Baruch yesterday told a group of blind, legless or otherwise handicapped workers successfully plying the trades of the physically normal, that he was always glad to be among them.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 2 (AP) -- A stubborn fire that spread among 2,000 tons of newsprint was under control but still burning today in The Miami Herald Building. Losses were estimated at about $750,000.

CANTON, China, Oct. 2 (UP) -- The Chinese Nationalists have rushed the Eighth and Eighty-ninth Armies into Yunnan Province on a "bandit-suppression mission," dispatches from Kunming, capital of the province, reported today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (UP) -- The Chicago Bears drew first blood today in their bitter cross-town warfare with the Chicago Cardinals by punching out a 17-to-7 victory before a record 52,867 customers. The crowd was the largest ever to witness a professional football game in Comiskey Park or Chicago.

Italy does not consider the possibility of being abandoned in case of attack from the East, Randolfo Pacciardi, Italian Minister of Defense, said yesterday at La Guardia Airport on his arrival from Rome.
Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday a report on the expansion of services and manpower of the Department of Housing and Buildings since Jan. 1, 1946, when he took office.

MONTREAL, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals got back into the running in the little world series tonight with a 3-1 victory over the Indianapolis Indians, leaving the series standing two to one for the American Association team.

The announcement yesterday that President Truman and his party leaders in Congress have agreed to abandon all efforts to enact a civil rights bill at this session merely confirms a fact which has been evident, if not admitted, for more than half a year. Last March the proponents of civil rights legislation lost a battle to amend the Senate's rules so as to put an effective curb on filibusters.

It was with genuine regret that I read in THE TIMES of the death in Long Beach, Calif., of Charles L. Chappel, the 102-year-old G. A. R. veteran who attended the last G. A. R. encampment at Indianapolis just three weeks ago. Iowa's last Civil War veteran also died on the same day, leaving only about a dozen Union veterans still alive.
ROME, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Vatican informants said today they expected Marshal Tito to release Yugoslavia's Catholic Primate, Archbishop Aloysius Stepinatz, who was imprisoned in 1946.
Contending teams -- New York Yankees, champions of the American League (won 97 games, lost 57) vs. Brooklyn Dodgers, champions of the National League (won 97 games, lost 57).
Bruce Howard, a 9-year-old victim of infantile paralysis, will throw out the first ball to open the world series tomorrow at Yankee Stadium. Bruce will be the guest of Commissioner A. B. Chandler.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- The October Grand Jury of Westchester County was sworn today and Supreme Court Justice James W. Bailey ordered it to conduct a sweeping investigation of the recent outbreaks of violence near Peekskill between left-wing followers of Paul Robeson and anti-Communist residents of the area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A registration statement covering 5,000,000 shares of the 3-cent par value common stock of the Keller Motors Corporation, which expects to manufacture a low-priced station wagon, was permitted to become effective today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3--An outspoken plea for the internationalization of Jerusalem was voiced here today before the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that Miss Gladys M. Dorman, Brooklyn attorney, had been appointed to the Board of Higher Education and that Sean P. Keating, deputy License Commissioner, would become a member of the Board of Standards and Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee closed its hearings on the reappointment of Leland Olds to the Federal Power Commission today after being denied access to a report of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the New Yorker.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Administration's Congressional leaders, with the approval of President Truman, abandoned today any effort to pass the President's civil rights program in this session.

Devaluation of the Argentine peso will touch off a series of similar moves by other Latin-American countries, in the opinion of foreign exchange specialists here. They said yesterday that the action would cause, in South and Central America, the same reactions that the recent devaluation of the British pound had caused on a global scale.

More than 25 per cent of the alarms answered by the Fire Department in the three and a half years ended last June 30 were false or unnecessary, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday in a report on the department's activities during his administration.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Committee on Canons of the Protestant Episcopal Church General Convention here voted today against changes that would have aided the cause of the Rev. John Howard Melish, ousted rector of Holy Trinity Church, Brooklyn, N. Y.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Captain D. R. Lee, master of the 17,500-ton Royal Mail liner Magdalena, which was lost on her maiden voltage off Rio de Janeiro last April, was found guilty today of "grave dereliction of duty."
A. F. Rust has been appointed used car manager of the Hudson Car Company of Detroit.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- British Treasury experts were reported today to be examining proposals by Government departments for reducing their expenditures.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- The Hilton Hotels Corporation, which owns the Stevens Hotel and Palmer House in Chicago and hotels in other cities, is again actively negotiating for the Waldorf-Astoria in New York, it was learned today.

With the world series going on this week, football will have to continue to knuckle to baseball in bidding for public interest, after competing against the hottest double finish in the history of the pennant races. Nevertheless, not all of the madness will be confined to the Bronx ball park and Ebbets Field.

Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer have both pledged their full support to the Independent Citizens Committee seeking ratification of a constitutional amendment that would exempt $150,000,000 for hospital construction from the city's debt limit.

The Amott-Baker realty bond price averages showed a gain in September for the third successive month. Based on the average price of forty issues, the index showed a $1,000 bond selling at $752 on Sept. 30, marking a gain of 1.6 per cent over the $738 on Aug. 31.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- One distilling company came out today against Government proposals to revise the system of labeling whisky, while barrel manufacturers gave partial endorsement. Hearings on the propasal opened before Carroll E. Mealey, Deputy Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The 4,993 operating national banks in the United States and possessions reported net earnings of $378,000,000 for the six months ended June 30, an increase of $23,000,000 over the first half of 1948, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today. There were eleven fewer operating banks than on June 30, 1948.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Senate approval of a conference committee report today completed Congressional action on the Navajo-Hopi Aid Bill. The measure now goes to the White House.

Democratic organizations in the five boroughs, coordinating their efforts with the campaign groups of Mayor O'Dwyer and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, began yesterday a drive to have every Democrat in the city register next week so that he could vote in November.
HOUSTON, Tex., Tuesday, Oct. 4 -- A 100-mile-an-hour hurricane roared out of the Gulf of Mexico toward Houston early today, blacking out several coastal cities in its path.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 3 -- Mexico, one of seven additional nations declaring general approval of the plan of the United Nations Economic and Social Council for technical assistance to economically under-developed areas, warned today that it had standards for foreign investors.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Pat Circelli of Gedney, with each of two amateur partners, Joe Marra of Dunwoodie and Joe Gabbe of Gedney, topped the field in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester PGA today at the Whippoorwill Club with two cards of 32, 33 -- 65, six under par.

Perhaps no world series in recent years has perplexed the so-called experts quite so thoroughly in their efforts to analyze the outcome than the forthcoming clash between Casey Stengel's Yankees and Burt Shotton's Dodgers. And that is understandable enough.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 3 -- Yugoslavia and the Soviet-bloc states in the United Nations have decided to follow Russia in immediate recognition of the Communist People's Republic of China, a generally well informed source said here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Documents secretly given to reporters today pictured the Navy's morale as shot to pieces and the country's security imperiled under the present unified defense setup.

In the refinancing of the Film Center Building at 622-638 Ninth Avenue, the Film Center Building Corporation has obtained a first mortgage loan of $1,500,000 for fifteen years from the Prudential Insurance Company of America. The Samuel Kronsky Company was the broker.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today new price support formulas for hogs and 1949-crop corn.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina denied an application yesterday to let City Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr. dismiss his attorney and sum up for himself in the Communist trial.

Alger Hiss will apply for a change of venue from New York to United States District Court in Vermont when his second trial on a perjury charge comes up Oct. 10, he announced yesterday. It is understood the papers asking a hearing on the application will be served in Federal District Court here today.

In the shadow of the Third Avenue "el" at 462 East 158th Street stands a tiny, decrepit red brick building. Behind the two windows of showcase type are green banners, bearing this message, "Home for Homeless Boys, Non-Sectarian. Welcome."

Action by the Argentine Institute of Trade Promotion (IAPI) in announcing new hide prices, following the week-end devaluation of the peso, was awaited here yesterday by the leather and shoe industries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Senator Brien McMahon, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, declared today he did not expect that Congress would be asked at this session to make any change in the Atomic Energy Act as a result of this nation's conversations with the British and Canadians.

Police escorts operating in relays yesterday from Hoboken to New York guarded the transfer to the Metropolitan Museum of Art of a collection of paintings and drawings by Vincent Van Gogh valued at $3,000,000.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Diplomats in London thought today that the Soviet protest against the establishment of the Western German Government presaged the formation of a Soviet-sponsored government in Eastern Germany that would claim to represent the whole nation.

Inventories of major appliances supplemented by shipments of orders now in manufacturers' hands will enable larger local retailers to meet consumer demand for at least sixty days, no matter how long the steel strike is prolonged, dealers reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter from Federal Judge Sherman Minton to the Senate Judiciary Committee which today approved his nomination to be a justice of the Supreme Court:

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A political candidate can accept a Democratic nomination by write-in vote without losing his right to be considered for the Republican slate, the Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court ruled today.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 (AP) -- That old Washington Redskin reliable, Sammy-Baugh, threw three touchdown passes tonight to lead his team to a 27-14 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers before 30,000 Fans.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Fusion-Liberal candidate for Mayor, asserted last night in a radio broadcast that Frank J. Costello, gambler and ex-convict, was the "real boss of the Democratic machine in New York City." Because of this, he added, "every mobster, every extortionist, every bookmaker" felt safe so long as Mayor O'Dwyer was in City Hall.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 3 -- Sava Kosanovitch, Yugoslav Ambassa dor to the United States, said today that the Yugoslav delegation to the United Nations General Assembly was "not competent" to make any statement regarding Archbishop Stepinatz.
WASHINGTON, Oct, 3 (AP) -- Heavy Marshall Plan purchases of industrial machinery, motor vehicles and petroleum were approved in recovery grants today by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

A doleful and doubtful harmonica rendition of "Hearts and Flowers" echoed across the trading floor of the Stock Exchange yesterday as "pallbearers" circled Post 9 to mourn their loss of Commonwealth Southern Corporation.
Two productions will make their Broadway bows this evening, the British importation, "Yes, M'Lord," and "The Mikado."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 3 -- Despite early Police Department opposition to having "a forty-foot monster in the streets," the 400 fifty-passenger buses operating in every borough of New York have produced "excellent" results, Col. Sidney H. Bingham, Commissioner of the New York City Boards of Transportation, said here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Truman appeared as a man of many faces under the skillful sketching of a group of the country's top cartoonists and comic-strip artists today.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Disclosure that the officials had a pre-game movie brush-up on Notre Dame tactics today re-kindled Irish resentment against officiating of their 27 -- 7, penalty-punctuated triumph over Washington's Huskies at Seattle Saturday.

For forty-one years, Fred Maisch has sat at the recording controls in the laboratory of the Radio Corporation of America or those of the Victor Talking Machine Company. Over those long years as senior engineer, he has put on wax virtually everything from Bach to bop.

TOKYO, Oct. 3 -- The Japanese are awaiting with extreme interest the course other nations will follow as a result of the Soviet Union's recognition of the new Communist regime as the legal Government of China.

A group headed by Harris, Hall Co., Inc., today will offer to the public, subject to the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission, a new issue of $4,500,000 equipment trust certificates of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company.

" Famous Jury Trials," a fictionized version of cases taken from court history, will have its television premiere tomorrow over WABD as a Wednesday evening feature from 9:30 to 10 o'clock. The program was heard for many years as a radio series.

The eight mounts the Irish Army team will use in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden Nov. 1 to 8 arrived yesterday in charge of four enlisted men aboard the United States Lines' American Scout. Sgt. Walter Smyth, in charge, said all the horses were in good condition.

SHAKESPEARE wasn't even thinking of baseball when he wrote that. Lewis Carroll didn't have the diamond sport in mind when he escorted Alice through Wonderland. But this year's twin pennant races were trips into fantasy. The best team in the National League won the championship by the skin of its teeth -- and in the tenth inning, too.

Rosalia Maresca, New York soprano, who has been heard here in operatic productions presented by Alfredo Salmaggi, made her New York recital debut last night at Town Hall. She confined herself entirely to selections in Italian, most of them by nineteenth-century composers who lived well into this century.

The Save the Children Federation announced yesterday the acceptance by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former American Military Governor in Germany, of the chairmanship of a federation committee to sponsor child service work among needy German children.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Maine Chance Farm's Royal Blood zoomed to an easy five-length triumph today in the $10,000 added Princeton Handicap, opening day attraction at Garden State Park.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Main interest in an otherwise quiet but generally firm stock market today was the continuing heavy turnover of South African gold shares, with prices still advancing. British Government securities, too, were in demand, with most of the long or medium-dated issues showing gains of one-eighth to one-quarter point at the close.

CANTON, China, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Nationalist China's note to the Soviet Union said it was clear to the world that the "regime set up in Peiping is Soviet-sponsored" and called it a "puppet regime forced upon the people against their free will."

ALBANY, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The American Legion launched a state-wide campaign against the Mitchell amendment today by charging that the proposed Constitutional amendment to revise civil service preference would "place disabled veterans at the mercy of machine politics."

Alas for the Bronxites, especially those dwellers of Baghdad-on-the Subway, who use the Sixth or Eighth Avenue line. THE TIMES informs us that the Board of Transportation will make half the number of expresses available in the rush hour, though the fares today are double.

Interpretations of contemporary furniture by several outstanding designers have been gathered together and may be compared with one another in the new "Designer's Showcase" at Modernage, 16 East Thirty-fourth Street. Here one may see designs from the drawing boards of such men as Edward Wormley, Isamu Noguchi, Harvey Probber, Charles Eames and George Nelson.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be the special guest at the opening NEW YORK TIMES Youth Forum of the season, which will be held at 9:30 A. M. today before 2,000 high school students in the auditorium of the United Nations General Assembly Building at Flushing Meadow, Queens.

UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Governor Dewey appealed today to both Democrats and Republicans to elect John Foster Dulles as United States Senator, saying that "the only people who don't want him are the Communists and their supporters."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -Following is the text of a letter from Vice Admiral Gerald F. Bogan to Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, concerning Capt. John G. Crommelin, as well as the endorsements by Admirals A. W. Radford and Louis E. Denfeld:

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The plans for an economic grouping of European countries started in Washington during the monetary talks will be discussed here Oct. 11 when the Finance Ministers of France, Belgium, Italy and the Netherlands will meet.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -The Senate Interior Committee tentatively approved today legislation authorizing Hawaii and political subdivisions to sell six bond issues.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 (AP) -Umpire Beans Reardon will retire from the business of "call 'em as you see 'em" when the world series is over.
In his first detailed statement on the "atomic explosion" in the Soviet Union, Bernard M. Baruch urged yesterday that this country:

The Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation announced yesterday that the Department of Justice had consented to its application to the Statutory Court here for a six months extension of time to complete is reorganization plan. Under the terms of the consent decree, which took the company out of the Government's anti - trust suit against movie producer-distributor companies, RKO had agreed to separate its theatre holdings by next month.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- The New York Telephone Company amended its petition for a permanent rate increase today and asked the Public Service Commission to permit charges of ten cents instead of five for local calls from coin telephones, to take effect in the fall of 1950.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- The successful treatment of nine major cases of bulbar poliomyelitis by means of a new respirator that operates on ordinary house current was reported today by two Harvard researchers.

Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., had net sales of $42,554,891 for the fiscal year ended July 31, the second largest in the company's forty-five-year history and exceeded only by the record net sales of $49,707,532 in 1948, Allan A. Ryan, chairman, and Maxwell V. Miller, president, told the stockholders yesterday.
Directors of the General Motors Corporation yesterday elected as vice president Hugh Dean, Carl H. Kindl, Wilbur H. Norton and Elis S. Hoglund.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 -- Six thousand members of Local 6 of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, began heading back to work here today after a warehouse strike that had kept them idle 109 days.
BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Joe McCarthy dropped broad hints today that he intends to stay as manager of the Red Sox.

Oren Root, Republican-City Fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, was endorsed yesterday by the Citizens Union. The organization said he was "forceful, competent, well-informed and progressive" and if elected, would have no difficulty "in giving the Borough President's office the housecleaning it needs."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Ordinarily, if someone says to someone else, "You can't have it both ways," the someone else never ventures to dispute it. But a theory is emerging among the political strategists of the Administration that the adage will not apply to President Truman.
Futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices rose 3 to 10 points.

In a reaction to Argentina's devaluation of the peso, hides futures sold off 30 to 34 points on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday. Trade interests estimated that the devaluation automatically would reduce the price of "frigorifico" steer hides in terms of dollars by 30 1/2 per cent at Buenos Aires, but expressed the fear that a good part of the reduction might be canceled through increases in prices demanded by sellers there.

City officials appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer are forcing civil service employes under their jurisdiction to write letters to friends urging votes for the Mayor's re-election, John A. Wells, manager of the campaign for the Morris-Uviller-Diserio ticket, complained yesterday.

Following by a week Securities and Exchange Commission approval of an increase in the flow of income to the General Public Utilities Corporation from its subsidiary, the Associated Electric Company, GPU directors raised yesterday by 5 cents the quarterly dividend payments on its common stock.

Total assets of the First National Bank of the City of New York on Sept. 30 rose to $804,676,638 from a total of $732,325,014 at the end of June, according to the bank's quarterly condition statement, to be published today. Deposits amounted to $658,646,874 on Sept. 30, compared with $585,181,528 on June 30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration said today that it would not pay the $10,000,000 to $12,500,000 in ocean freight costs on shipments to Europe under the Marshall Plan during the second quarter of 1949.

If you "knew somebody" and wanted to see the World Series, yesterday was the day to have called your friend. Today, it was indicated by a billowing rush of inquiries from fans across the nation, it will be almost impossible to obtain tickets.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 -- A new step in development of the "equity plan" introduced a year ago by Westinghouse Electric Corporation to simplify and safeguard installment buying and encourage local bank financing of electric appliance purchases by dealers and their retail customers was announced today.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 3 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, threw a three-pronged dart at the Congress of Industrial Organizations today as he opened the federation's annual convention.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 3 -- In a political upset, the Republican party took over control of this town's municipal government at the polls today.
Disease, filth and crime are serious problems in Spanish Harlem and those other Manhattan, Brooklyn and Bronx slums where most of this city's estimated 350,000 Puerto Ricans are crowded.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- The grain markets here developed a strong undertone today after a small dip early, and advanced rapidly soon after the opening under the leadership of soybeans, which were up 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 cents a bushel at the close, with commission houses with Easttern connections and processing interests aggressive on the buying side.

JACKSONS MILL, W. Va., Oct. 3 -- Parents indirectly slaughter their own children on the highways when they set bad examples by flouting rules of the road, delegates were told today at the Conference on High School Driver Education here.
LONDON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Home Secretary James Chuter Ede today banned all political parades in London for the next three months.

CHICAGO, Oct, 3 -- A six-week productivity study by a group of French foundrymen in the gray iron foundry industry got under way here today. The study is sponsored by the Economic Cooperation Administration, under its technical assistance program.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The United States asked Russia today to help locate a cargo ship, missing in North Korean waters with two United States officials aboard.

ROME, Oct. 3 -- Speaking to the press at the North American Ecclesiastical College today, Cardinal Spellman said that the conversation during his audience with the Pope yesterday dealt almost exclusively with affairs of the New York Archdiocese.

Ferris Booth, who has suggested that President Truman invoke the power of God to halt a possible atomic war, said yesterday that his idea for a world-wide "spiritual renaissance" had been simmering in his mind for years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 3 -- The Independent Motion Picture Producers Association, headed by I. E. Chadwick and comprising makers of low-budget films, has voted to dissolve as a gesture of protest against the demands of Hollywood labor unions for minimum employment guarantees.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 24 Louis Stark quotes some unnamed high officers of CIO to the effect that "the new Communist party line was to split all pro-Communist unions from the CIO and to form a new labor federation."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 3--Prodded on the possibility of holding the General Assembly in Moscow next year, Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky has suggested 1953 as a good time for Russia to play host to the United Nations, it was learned today.

Organized labor is wholly united in support of Mayor O'Dwyer for re-election and of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for election to the United States Senate, Martin T. Lacey, president of the Central Trades and Labor Council, AFL, and Michael J. Quill, president of the New York City CIO Council, asserted yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 -- Figures ostensibly aimed to show that neither the Giannini Bank of America nor the majority-owned banks of the Giannini Transamerica Corporation were apart from the general pattern of banking in five-state Far Western area were introduced today at a resumption of the Federal Reserve Board's hearing of its monopoly charges against Transamerica.

HONOLULU, Oct. 3 -- Negotiators for the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union and for seven struck Hawaiian stevedoring companies met separately today on the latest move to end the 156-day Hawaiian dock strike.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 3 -- Senator Arthur. H. Vandenberg, Republican architect of the nation's bipartisan foreign policy, was reported to be "doing fine" tonight in the University of Michigan Hospital after undergoing an operation for the removal of one-half for his-left lung.

Scheduled for publication this fall is a new work by Percy MacKaye, author of some sixty volumes of published poems, plays and operas. It is a sequence of foul plays, "The Mystery of Hamlet, King of Denmark, or What We Will," which cover the years before the birth of Prince Hamlet up to his appearance in Shakespeare's play.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A bill introduced by Senator J. Allen Frear Jr., Democrat, of Delaware, to amend the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, is receiving strong public support if the letters, telegrams and telephone calls that have deluged his office are any criterion.

HENRI-RENE-ALBERT-GUY DE MAUPASSANT, a strapping Norman who was once mistaken for a professional wrestler, was literary genius, perhaps the greatest master of the short story the world has known. He was also a psychotic born too soon to benefit from the discoveries of psychiatry. His career is still another proof that neither virtue nor common sense is necessary to distinction in the arts.

ROME, Oct. 3 -- Pope Pius XII made a strong plea for "prompt and responsible community action" in aid of displaced persons and "expellees" yesterday in a speech at his summer residence, Castel Gandolfo, to members of a Congressional committee which, under the leadership of Representative Francis E. Walter of Pennsylvania, is investigating the situation of war refugees in Europe.

Reminiscent of a recent baseball game, the stock market staged a late rally in the final hour yesterday and closed moderately higher, after a session of the slowest trading in a month. Rail, chemical, oil and selected issues set the pace, with the steel group ending stronger.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Twelve grants for mental research, five of them to New York institutions, were announced today by the Public Health Service of the Federal Security Agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The volume of installment plan credit rose to a record high of $9,613,000,000 at the start of September. It increased $282,000,000 in August, the second month after credit controls were dropped.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Oct. 3 -- With the aid of moonlight, the next to last pair to finish in the Metropolitan P. G. A. one-day amateur-pro tourney carried off top honors at the North Hempstead Country Club tonight.

With only 10 per cent of the nation's steelmaking facilities in operation, loss of steel production in this first week of strike is calculated at about 1,400,000 net tons. The American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday that the industry's operating rate for the current week, based on the regular weekly reports from the various companies, would be 8.2 per cent of theoretical capacity, a decline of 76.4 points from last week's rate.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 8 per cent last week, compared with the corresponding period of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 6 per cent.

With both longshoremen and Atlantic Coast shipowners and stevedore employers agreeing last week to extend their present contract for thirty days, the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service moved yesterday for immediate resumption of negotiations for a new agreement.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- United States farmers added 5 per cent to their wealth in the year ended Jan. 1, a government spokesman said today.

Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, Professor of International Relations and director of the European Institute at Columbia University, will succeed Prof. Albert C. Jacobs as the university's provost, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the president, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- British shipping experts predicted today growing unemployment in the country's ship repair yards unless rising costs could be checked. Their fears have been supported by the dismissal over the week-end of 1,000 men at one Tyneside repair yard and reports that several hundred more in the area would soon be laid off.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 3 -- A flood-control conference sponsored by the Mississippi Valley Association criticized Congress today for failing to act promptly on appropriation bills for Federal agencies at work on projects in the Missouri River Valley development.

The first time John Fiorenze ever used a pistol, yesterday afternoon, he shot and fatally wounded a mugger and holdup man, neatly avoiding the mugger's victim. Both were customers in John's Merchandise Exchange at 893 Eighth Avenue, where all the action took place.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 7 per cent during September compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- All political circles in this city experienced a ground swell of speculation today on the probable significance of the Soviet diplomatic note to the Western Powers denouncing the formation of the new German Federal Republic.

A woman major in the International Salvation Army has been imprisoned in her native Yugoslavia, Commissioner John J. Allan, international chief of staff, said yesterday at Salvation Army headquarters, 120 West Fourteenth Street.

The First Guardian Securities Corporation will make today one of the first public offerings in the American market of the securities of an Israeli corporation since the United States formally recognized the new state of Israel last January.

Increased optimism on the immediate outlook for advertising and business has been reported in a new survey taken among members of the Association of National Advertisers, it was learned yesterday. The improved feeling, it was said, exceeds the largely optimistic attitude shown in a previous survey announced in March.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The State Department announced today that it still recognized the Nationalist Government of China and would not recognize the newly announced Chinese Communist authority without first consulting Congress.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that international trade in cotton rose sharply in the 1948-49 marketing year.

A new kind of package for apples has begun to appear in Grand Union and Peter Reeves stores in the last two weeks. It's a transparent pliofilm bag called a "Snap Sack" because of the elastic closure, which makes it possible to remove the contents without damaging the container.

Rates charged by leading New York City banks during the first half of September showed little change from the levels prevailing during the first half of June, according to the quarterly report on commercial loans and rates issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Thanks to Will Shakespeare, the season is having a pleasant beginning. "Twelfth Night" has turned up at the Empire in a light and joyous performance. Since it is a performance and not a production, there are no stars in the crown of this patchwork masquerade.

Now as the poets rhapsodize over golden autumn and nature boys and girls run through the woods with red and yellow leaves in their hair a group of solemn recorders sharpens a fresh batch of pencils and prepares to make anonymous statistics of what are at this moment very much alive people.

With the formal opening on Thursday of their new clubhouse at 111 East Thirty-seventh Street, the 800 New York City branch members of The American Association of University Women will have a headquarters all their own for the first time in the group's sixty-three-year history.

A strong seller's market has replaced the deep recession which prevailed last June, builder's hardware manufacturing executives reported yesterday in interviews prior to the opening today of the first New York national builder's hardware exposition at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Seven justices met today in a brief ceremonious opening of the Supreme Court term. Shortly before, the Senate Judiciary Committee had approved, 9 to 2, the nomination of United States Circuit Judge Sherman Minton of Indiana as an associate justice.

ATLANTA, Oct. 3 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, of the New York Area, Methodist Church, told 500 educators and seminary students today that it was up to the Christian churches to "put an end" to racial segregation and injustices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Senate took up the Anderson long-range farm bill today in an atmosphere of non-partisanship, with the controversial Brannan program relegated to the background.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Holders of 5 1/2 per cent convertible gold bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that it should modify the plan of reorganization of the MOP system, approved last August, by providing for payment of the $73,441,733 claims of these bond owners.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 -- The three-day-old steel strike began to make its pinch felt on the national economy today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 -- From the ranks of the striking coal miners 102,000 went back to work today, assuring heat for homes in the Northeastern and Western States, but their return brought no-relief for fuel-hungry factories, railroads and utility plants.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 27 -- Unemployment, which has been diminishing somewhat recently, places great difficulties in the way of reconstructing the Italian economy entirely apart from its obvious effects as a burden on the productive population and as producing a fertile area for Communist agitation.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 3 -- Britain today dropped her frequently expressed criticisms of United Nations supervision of her rule in the African trust area, and for the first time gave unreserved endorsement to the work of the Trusteeship Council.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- In the face of a 900,000-bed shortage in the nation's hospitals, the House approved today by a one-sided vote a bill doubling the amount of federal assistance to the states for hospital construction.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Halfback Steve Van Buren of the Philadelphia Eagles set a new National Football League lifetime ground gaining record tonight as he smashed over for two fourth-period touchdowns to give the Eagles a 22-24 victory over the Detroit Lions.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 3 -- The Dutch delegation to the round-table conference of Indonesia has withdrawn its proposals for a veto power over the proposed new republic's financial and economic policy.

The signs are that the Soviet Union is at last ready to set up its "German Democratic Republic" in the Eastern Zone. This has been foreshadowed ever since the Americans and British gave up their hopes of achieving the economic unity called for in the Potsdam agreement and created the bizonal area.

" Viewed as a whole, New York is as clean as any of our large cities and it excels them all in sanitation services furnished to the people. The city is certainly cleaner than it was five years ago. * * *" This is the O'Dwyer Administration's report to the people on its Sanitation Department after three and a half years in office.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Joe Kuhel got his walking papers today as manager of the Washington baseball team.

John M Price, a second lieutenant in the Army Signal Corps who was paralyzed from the neck down in a diving accident on Aug. 15, 1943, yesterday answered the telephone himself, at the Veterans Hospital in the Bronx and announced that he was, going home to Stroudsburg, Pa., on Saturday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 3 -- Premier Marshal Tito told 600 officers, including generals, and other guests at a banquet marking the end of last week's big army maneuvers that Yugoslavia was threatened with war, but that Yugoslavs preferred to die honestly in battle rather than submit to slavery, according to the official text released tonight for publication by the Government Press Office.
The text of the statement by Bernard M. Baruch follows:

HONG KONG, Oct. 3 -- Reacting quickly to Soviet recognition of the Chinese Communist regime in Peiping, the Nationalist Government in Canton announced tonight the severance of relations with the Soviet Union and the recall of its diplomatic representative in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Treasury announced today that tenders for $900,328,000 of 91-day Treasury bills to be dated Oct. 6, and to mature on Jan. 5, which were offered on Sept. 30, had been accepted.

Next to last at the far turn with half a mile to go, the Foxcatcher Farms' Gaffery made a beteween-horses run that earned her a nose-tip decision in the seventy-ninth edition of the Ladies Handicap at orchidaceous Belmont Park yesterday.

Production of a nine-passenger, four-door De Soto suburban was announced yesterday by the De Soto division, Chrysler Corporation. The unit, an addition to the line, is scheduled to go on display today at the Chrysler International Auto Salon, 405 Lexington Avenue.

If the big tuna continue to collect in the Soldier's Rip off Wedgeport, Nova Scotia, they will have to begin fishing for them through the ice, and undoubtedly there are a few members of the big game fishing brotherhood who would like nothing better.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The dispute that prompted the chief of the National Guard Bureau last week To dismiss then reinstate, the head Of the guard's air branch is expected to be one of the first matter discussed tomorrow by the new Civilian Component Policy Board.

The two last-ditch pennant winners, the Yankees and the Dodgers, are not the only ones who will hit the jackpot in this third subway world series played by the same teams within the last nine years, which opens tomorrow in the vast Yankee Stadium before more than 70,000 wild-eyed fans.

MARIPOSA, Calif., Oct. 3 -- An atomic scientist today reported the discovery of radioactive ore of unknown, quantities in the heart of the Mother Lode region, where the gold rush in 1849 brought wealth and fame to California.
In the editorial on "Our State University'' in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 1 the question of a low tuition fee is mentioned.

The American Guild of Variety Artists, the American Federation of Labor union covering performers in night clubs and vaudeville, plans to apply today in Supreme Court for an order temporarily restraining James C. Petrillo's American Federation of Musicians from interfering with members of the guild.

OLEAN, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, declared today that labor's right to collective bargaining and its right to strike were being jeopardized by the trend toward an all-powerful central Government.

Explosion and fire virtually wrecked a five-story garage at 148-50 West Twentieth Street yesterday morning and critically injured an attendant there. A fireman and a policeman who rescued him were burned.
