CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Counsel for one of Preston Tucker's indicted associates asked today that editors of two magazines be held in contempt of court for publishing articles about the ill-fated Tucker automobile company.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 3 -- The East-West split dominated proceedings today in the special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, which voted 44 to 6, over Russian opposition, to continue the United Nations Commission for Korea, increase its powers, and instruct it to pay special attention to reporting developments "which might lead to or otherwise involve military conflict in Korea.'
Harold S. Munroe has become a general partner in Hay, Fales Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

The United States Court of Appeals reversed yesterday a District Court decision that bail of $25,000 was reasonable for George Pirinsky, secretary of the American Slav Congress. He is being held on Ellis Island pending deportation.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 3 -- Sir Benegal N. Rau, the Indian representative, proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly grant Libya "almost immediate" independence and that its constitution be drafted by an assembly set up with the help of a United Nations Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 3 -- Argentina announced today the devaluation of her peso by 46 per cent in relation to the dollar. The Government froze price to prevent an inflationary spiral and put a temporary halt to imports.

When the Supreme Court met for the first time yesterday after its summer vacation -- if the life of a Supreme Court Justice in summer can be called a vacation -- everyone must have been reminded of the impermanence of the judges and of the permanence of the judicial institution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, was reported today preparing to speed efforts to write a new contract with the bituminous coal industry and settle the two-week strike of 400,000 mine workers.

Over last week-end, when the reduced winter overseas air travel rates went into effect, a sudden jump of 300 per cent in travel to Northern Europe was noted by Pan American Airways, it was reported yesterday by Willis G. Lipscomb, vice president in charge of traffic and sales.

Price reductions on men's clothing ranging from $2.50 to $5 per suit at retail are being named for spring and summer, 1950, by manufacturers here and in other production centers, a canvass indicated yesterday. The picture for the coming season is still incomplete as many lines are due to open officially next week.

Whether or not the average citizen understands modern art and whether or not he likes it, he stumbles across myriad manifestations of it in the course of a day's existence. That is the theme of the exhibition, "Modern Art in Your Life," which opens today at the Museum of Modern Art.

I see in THE TIMES of Sept. 29 the headline -- "Senator Reed Hits Olds as Communist." Senator Clyde Reed, Republican, of Kansas, said that Leland Olds of the Federal Power Commission is a "full-fledged, first-class Communist"; this statement was proved by the fact that Representative John E. Lyle, Democrat, of Texas had placed on the record the statement that Commissioner Olds, twenty years ago, had advocated public ownership of electric utilities.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Paul P. Gourrich, 59, economist who served as research director of the Securities and Exchange Commission, committed suicide yesterday, the police reported.

PICTON, Ont., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Miss Canada IV, challenger for the world speedboat record, has been granted unlimited extension to try to crack the 141.7 mile-an-hour mark set ten years ago by the late Sir Malcolm Campbell at Lake Coniston, England.
An extension of services to New York's Puerto Rican population was reported yesterday by several municipal departments at the first meeting of Mayor O'Dwyer's Advisory Committee on Puerto Ricans.

The Tito-Stalin controversy continues to offer fascinating back-stage glimpses of what goes on in the Soviet inner circles, but no single statement in this war of documents is as illuminating as the Yugoslav leader's speech at the end of last week's military maneuvers.

WHO do you like? Nor is it any easier in its more grammatical form: Whom do you like? If the real experts and the pseudo experts can't be accurate in calling the turn on a 154-game season where form has a chance to assert itself, they are stabbing in the dark when it comes to a short series.

Chile's manipulations of her currency rates in their application to exports and imports are giving that nation most of the benefits of a monetary devaluation without the necessity of formalizing the move, international exchange specialists said here yesterday.

Trumpet King of the Willorene Farm showed thirteen other 2-year-olds how to run the mile at Belmont Park yesterday. Participating against a number of youngsters whose chances were much more highly regarded, the son of Bolingbroke registered an upset by capturing the Mate Purse in the good time of 1:38.

Three windows in a building occupied by the Metropolitan Electric Protective Center, 152 West Twenty-sixth Street, were broken by rocks yesterday while mass demonstrations took place outside the structure.
On no less an authority than Charles Dillon Stengel, it can be said the Yankees are ready for the World Series which opens today in the Yankee Stadium.

The Committee on Child Care appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer in February, 1946, submitted yesterday a series of recommendations that it said must be followed if all children in need of care away from their homes were to receive prompt and adequate attention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, will call to order tomorrow the first session ever held of the Defense Committee set up by the signatories of the North Atlantic Pact. The committee consists of the Defense Minister of each the twelve nations, or their representatives.

Peacetime military procurement is being planned on a long-term basis to ease slack periods for industries supplying goods to the armed forces, according to Maj. Gen. Herman Feldman, Quartermaster General. A prime objective of the department, he said, is to obtain deliveries when production for civilian channels is at its lowest point.
The 43-year-old wife of an opera singer was raped yesterday morning by a burglar she caught ransacking her two-room apartment at 166 East Fifty-sixth Street.
MEDINA, N. Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement today by Sector John Foster Dulles calling for a new national labor relations law:

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 4 -- The Soviet proposal for the immediate independence of Libya, together with the withdrawal of foreign troops within three months, was endorsed today by Faris el-Khouri, the Syrian representative on the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

Discounting strikes in two of the nation's basic industries -- steel and coal -- the stock market rolled ahead yesterday and extended gains to the best levels of the year. All divisions of the list shared in the advance and, although at the close some issues were a shade below the best levels of the day, gains ranged from fractions to 2 points.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- President Truman's Point Four program is not another "give-away" plan, but a logical extension of the good-neighbor policy, Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.

At the first of this season's youth forums of THE NEW YORK TIMES, held yesterday at Flushing Meadow, more than 2,000 high school students heard a teen-age panel and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt discuss human rights as the key to world peace.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 4 -- The United States today submitted to the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly a resolution asking the International Court of Justice for strict legal clarification of the alleged suppression of human rights by Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Criticism was made today on over-employment in Government jobs and under-production in Britain's important cotton industry.

A "clinic" or board of review for business - sponsored films, will be set up during the anuual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers in the Waldorf - Astoria Hotel, Oct. 10-12, it was announced yesterday. The organization's films committee will examine and develop constructive criticism of such films that are submitted to them during the meeting.

Bridge players from the South, with heavy aid from the West and Midwest, seemed yesterday to have excluded Negroes from membership in the American Contract Bridge League and from tournaments under its sponsorship.

In about a month CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe) will begin sending food and textile packages to Yugoslavia and Jordan, Paul Comly French, CARE executive director, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Representative Alvin F. Weichel, Republican, of Ohio, said today that companies that wrote wartime shipping insurance had kept $140,000,000 in "Government money" and made another $15,000,000 by investing it.

The baker's trick of using a rolling pin to shape bread dough has been borrowed for a new method devised to make this task easier for housewives. It seems to answer a problem that has troubled beginners in bread-making who find it difficult to fashion a loaf that is presentable and free from air bubbles.

TORONTO, Oct. 4 -- Capt. William Taylor, 66-year-old master of the ill-fated steamship Noronic, testified at the Federal inquiry today that no instructions so far as he knew had been issued either to the crew or passengers as to where to go in case of fire.

Higher quality of performance in serving the public was urged yesterday as essential to business success in the fields of television, public relations and the graphic arts. Reiteration of this need ran through panel discussions on the diverse subjects at opening of the two-day annual Eastern conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in the Roosevelt Hotel.

Lee Savold, heavyweight challenger whose postponed fight with Bruce Woodcock, British titleholder, would have been recognized in some quarters as for the world championship, returned from England yesterday on the Queen Elizabeth.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Following are the texts of letters exchanged by President Truman and Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, and chairman of the Commerce Committee, on the renomination of Leland Olds for a third term on the Federal Power Commission:
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A leading maker of men's clothing said today you can expect lower prices in woolens next fall as a result of British devaluation of the pound.
PRAGUE, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Czechoslovak Cabinet's actions included a decision to demand of all clergymen an oath of loyalty to the Government.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Frankie Parker, third ranking United States star, and two other American aces advanced to the fourth round of the singles in the Pan-American tennis tourney today.

With the retirement of Gen. Jacob Loucks Devers the Army is losing an officer whose enthusiasm, energy and devotion to the service have marked all of his forty-four years in the uniform of his country. One of the planners of the European invasion, General Devers commanded the American forces in Europe before the advent of General Eisenhower.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 4 -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, called on the American Federation of Labor today to go out and sell its story to the American people. In doing so, he made a few gingerly passes at the hazardous topic of labor unity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Common stockholders of the Missouri Pacific system urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to modify the plan for Mopac reorganization that it approved in August and to adopt the recommendations of its dissenting members.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Winston Churchill, Anthony Eden and other ranking members of the Conservative Opposition, will meet Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee and his chief defense advisers after Parliament reassembles Oct. 18, it was reported here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- United States imports increased from $455,600,000 in July to $490,600,000 in August, a gain of $35,000,000, the Census Bureau reported today.

A score of mothers, employing baby carriages as barriers and carrying placards, halted traffic on West Twenty-sixth Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues from 8:30 A. M. to 9:40 A. M. yesterday in protest against lack of traffic supervision while children go to and from school.

Governor Dewey was accused yesterday of resorting to "shocking" and "un-American" campaign tactics in urging a "holy crusade" for the election of Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican, to his present seat. The charge was made by Edward C. Maguire, campaign manager for former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Senator Dulles' adversary on the Democratic and Liberal tickets.
The Duplan Corporation and its consolidated Canadian subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $464,731, on net sales of $8,469,594, in the three months ended on Aug. 31.

CANTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The long-smoldering front north of Canton burst into flame today. Attacking Communists menaced two key cities -- Hengyang, Nationalist base 265 miles north, and the key rail city of Kukong, 125 miles north.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 4 -- Mrs. Saul Weinsier of the Fresh Meadow Club shot a 78 -- 8 -- 70 to win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one - day medal - play handicap tournament held over the Piping Rock Club course today. Six over women's par, Mrs. Weinsier scored a 40 going out and a 38 coming back to take the first net prize.

TORONTO, Oct. 4 -- The first jet-propelled airliner ever built in the Western Hemisphere, a sleek, clean craft that will cruise at better than 420 miles an hour, was flown and shown publicly here today for the first time.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Leading over virtually every step of the way, Windsor Farm's Loriot galloped to a two-length victory in the featured Westmont Purse at Garden State Park today.

Paul van Zeeland, Foreign Minister of Belgium, declared yesterday that the announcement of the atomic explosion in Russia would not lead to a change in direction toward a united Europe but would accelerate the pace to achieve the union.

New facilities in Manhattan for parking any considerable number of automobiles are rare enough to call for comment. The agreement between the city and the New York Life Insurance Company which revives the project at East Sixty-fifth Street and Second Avenue seems to be of benefit to all parties concerned.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- All United States military medical patients throughout the world, except those physically unable to fly, are now being transported by airplane, it was announced today by Maj. Gen. Laurence S. Kuter, commander of the Military Air Transport Service, which operates the evacuation airplanes.

The subway-circuit World Series between the New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Dodgers is scheduled to start at 1 o'clock this afternoon before 72,000 to 74,000 fans in Yankee Stadium. Manager Casey Stengel announced yesterday that Allie Reynolds would be the Yanks' starting pitcher. Manager Burt Shotton of the Dodgers was not quite so certain about his choice.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Barker Fairley, a professor at the University of Toronto, has been barred from the United States by immigration officials, Dr. Katharine E. McBride, president of Bryn Mawr College, said today.
Following is the of Mayor O'Dwyer's opening campaign speech last night:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 4 -- Tel Aviv and the abutting seaport of Jaffa, which had been granted to the Arabs in the original United Nations partition plan, were amalgamated today by decision of the Israeli Cabinet. The combined city will be called Jaffa-Tel Aviv.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 4 -- The friendships that bind President Truman to the Kansas City political scene may be the most important issue in the 1950 Congressional elections.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 4 -- The Czechoslovak Cabinet approved today one bill for the control off all churches and another creating a special office headed by a Cabinet Minister to carry out the Government's will in church matters.

The sale of $8,500,000 of sewer bonds scheduled for today by Tampa, Fla., is intended to finance abatement of water pollution which has made waters of the Gulf of Mexico touching the city unfit for bathing and has forced the city's residents to become tourists if they want to go swimming.

BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- An official announcement was made here tonight that the Soviet zone People's Council would meet Friday. The formation of a new "government for all Germany" is thus expected to be announced this week-end.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The assets of all banks in the United States and possessions on June 30 totaled $172,000,000,000, or $4,000,000,000 below the level of Jan. 1, Maple T. Harl, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, announced today.

Columbia began preparing in earnest yesterday for Saturday's game with Yale at Baker Field. The Lions held a brisk three hours of heavy contact, the latter half under lights. They sharpened their offense and then worked out their defense against Eli plays.
The latest development in the unending "Battle of Washington" has both an opera bouffe and an E. Phillips Oppenheim quality.

Miss Charlotte Van Bomel heads a group of debutantes of this season who are aiding in the plans for the Young World Friendship fashion show and luncheon to be held on Oct. 12 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre in cooperation with the Save the Children Federation.

A resolution introduced in the City Council yesterday afternoon for an investigation of the fitness of Councilman Stanley Isaacs, Manhattan Republican, to sit in that body was beaten by a vote of 15 to 1 after it was assailed by Democrats and members of the minority groups.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Garry Davis, "world citizen" since September, 1948, when he renounced his United States citizenship, was sentenced to eight days in jail today by a magistrate's court for not having a foreigner's residence permit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Congressional leaders consulted today in worried indecision over the latest assertion from high naval officers that their service was being enfeebled by the policies of the unified military command.

Although tenants in the forty or more old buildings in the block bounded by Hudson, Christopher, Barrow and Greenwich Streets were notified several years ago that they should look for new quarters, many of them still are living there on a month-to-month basis.

The Department of Commerce, created by Mayor O'Dwyer in January, 1948, has succeeded in persuading a number of business enterprises that planned to transfer their activities elsewhere to remain in the city, the Mayor said yesterday in a report on the agency's work.

MEDINA, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for election to the United States Senate seat from which former Senator Robert F. Wagner resigned, called today for a new national labor law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Senate and House Democratic leaders put all their efforts in concert today to bring the first session of the Eighty-first Congress to a close by three weeks hence, or sooner.

Nancy Oakes de Marigny, daughter and heir of the late Sir Harry Oakes of Nassau, Bahamas, received an annulment of her marriage to Count Alfred de Marigny yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Aaron Steuer on the ground that jurisdictional requirements were not met when the count was divorced from his first wife.

Coffee futures were irregular in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Prices reacted shortly after the opening as a result of profit-taking. Demand from producer interests again rallied the market, however, and it closed out only slightly lower than on Monday.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Socialist Ministers were under pressure of their rank and file and from labor organizations today as Premier Henri Queuille prepared to air the wage question in a broadcast tomorrow.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 4 -- In a succession of terse phrases at a news conference this morning and later in a luncheon speech, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin of Britain painted a picture of the world situation that his audiences found unusually encouraging.

Raymond Massey is a handy actor to have in any play and producers are well aware of his versatility. Besides co-starring with Mady Christians in the Richard W. Krakeur-Robert L. Joseph production of "The Father," Mr. Massey also will stage the Strindberg revival.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- It is pleasant to report today that at least one aspect of life in Britain is virtually perfect -- the weather, of all things.

The formation of a Committee of Citizens Against the Feinberg Law, including educators, religious leaders and attorneys, was announced yesterday by State Senator Fred G. Moritt, Democrat, of Brooklyn, its chairman. The forty-eight-member committee, described as nonpartisan, will undertake to lead the campaign for repeal of the law, which bars "subversive" persons from public school jobs.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 4 -- Jack Riley, in his fifteenth year as head coach of the Hill School football team, is not one to go out on a limb. But this year's Blue and Grey eleven, which opened its season last Saturday by defeating Williamson Trade, is, in the words of Riley, a hustling team.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- Ground was broken this afternoon in near-by Springfield Township. Delaware County, for a $135,000 building to house a five to ten-million-volt DeGraaf generator described as one of the three largest atom-smashing machines in the world.

Now let's not have any bad feeling between nations, or any of that sort of rot. But the fact seems to be that London has sent us a trifling comedy that probably seems even more trifling in New York. It is W. Douglas Home's "Yes, M' Lord," which was put on at the refurbished Booth last evening.

In the three months since the city's Smoke Control Bureau has been operating as an independent unit 3,830 persons have made complaints of smoke nuisances at 1,799 locations, William H. Byrne, director of the bureau, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Federal intervention in the soft coal strike of 400,000 miners within forty-eight hours was regarded here today as a distinct possibility.

A volume that might become the literary bible for the thousands of detective story writers will be published on Oct. 18 by Macmillan. The book, "An Introduction to Criminalistics," presents detailed information on the various modern scientific instruments and methods of analysis that provide potent means of apprehending the guilty and of proving guilt or establishing innocence in the court room.

Carl Furillo, the iron-armed outfielder, whose .431 hitting pace during the hot September drive did more to bring the Dodgers the pennant than any other single factor, will be in Manager Burt Shotton's line-up today despite the groin injury that had him moving with difficulty in yesterday's workout.

As a part of its twentieth-anniversary program, the Museum of Modern Art will open to the public today an exhibition entitled "Modern Art in Your Life." It is less an art exhibition than a demonstration of a thesis which should not need demonstration, but which apparently does need to be reiterated at intervals -- that modern art is not an orphan stepchild of the life of our time, nor a product of spontaneous combustion.

Night time and glitter gave Walter Florell the theme for his midseason showing of hats yesterday in his showroom, 29 East Fifty-third Street. Tiny hats he called "two on the aisle," large brims he characterized as "ringside table."

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 4 -- United States personnel in Germany must do their utmost to halt "a renewal of Nazism and anti-Semitism" and deal with the hardening attitude toward the occupation, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, declared today.

The New York City Rent Advisory Board, headed by Joseph D. McGoldrick, rejected yesterday by a vote of thirteen to three a proposal for an all-around 15 per cent increase of home rentals in the New York area.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 -- One non-union mine was put out of commission today and another was rocked by a dynamite blast as the strike of 380,000 soft-coal miners went through its sixteenth day.

Contracts will be advertised late this week for two vehicular overpasses, costing $1,500,000, one at East Forty-second Street and the other at East Forty-eighth Street, over Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan announced yesterday.
Contending teams -- New York Yankees, champions of the American League (won 97 games, lost 57), vs. Brooklyn Dodgers, champions of the National League (won 97 games, lost 57).

The General Council of the Trades Union Congress in Britain has not yet given its endorsement to the Government's devaluation of the pound, with the implication it carries for a possible reduction in real wages. The price for its support, according to London news reports, is likely to take the form of some wage relief in the lower brackets, plus further restrictions on the profits of business.

Repeating his charge that gambling is rampant in New York, Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusian candidate for Mayor, asserted yesterday that he had the names and locations of 1,080 bookmakers that had been given to him voluntarily.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 4 -- Roger Garreau, veteran French colonial authority and president of the United Nations Trusteeship Council, retorted sharply today to critics of French administration in the African trust territories of Togoland and the Cameroons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4 -- Bette Davis has signed with Jack Skirball and Bruce Manning to star in "This Day Is Ours," which Skirball and Manning will produce in November for RKO release, the distributing company announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 -- The Government considered imposing controls on the export of steel today as the four-day-old steel strike put electric refrigerators, stoves, washing machines and other household appliances on an allocation basis reminiscent of the period immediately following the war.
The Communist trial probably will go to the jury a week from tomorrow, a few days short of nine months since its opening on Jan. 17.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Despite an appeal from President Truman for confirmation of Leland Olds of New York for a third term as a member of the Federal Power Commission, a Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce subcommittee today voted 7-to-0 to reject the nomination.

Alger Hiss, through his attorney, Edward C. McLean, formally filed in Federal Court late yesterday a motion for transfer of his second trial on a perjury charge from New York to United States District Court in Vermont.

Paul Dullzell, president of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, made it clear last night that the union of vaudeville performers would not heed the demand of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, that it withdraw its court action against the American Federation of Musicians.

The disclosure that the Rockefeller Foundation granted $110,000 more than a year ago to Cornell University, for use by a group of professors of government and lawyers in studying the facts concerning the Government's investigations of subversive was made yesterday in a roundabout way.

" THE King and his Ministers forgot that revolutions are hatched by one or two men in a back room. There must be a grievance to begin with -- a stamp tax or a question of electoral reform -- but the men who are set on changing the whole structure of government, a Samuel Adams in 1776 or a Lamartine in 1848, will never be satisfied with the mere elimi nationof the grievance."
BUFFALO, Oct. 4 (UP) -- President Truman's "bold new program" for developing natural resources is not nearly bold enough, James P. Warburg said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Post Office Department reported today it has halted mail deliveries to thirteen men and eleven firms in Toronto, Canada, who were offering mine stock in this country.

ARCOLA, N. J., Oct. 4 -- James Oleska, cross-handed player from Shoreview, won the last Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament when he carded an even par 39, 32 -- 71 over the Arcola Country Club course today.

Nick Scollard and Bill Chipley will start at end for the New York Bulldogs against the Green Bay Packers at the Polo Grounds Friday night, it was announced yesterday by Coach Charley Ewart. The veteran wingmen replace Bob Sponaugle and Sam Tamburo, the rookies who received the call against the Giants.

A drive to raise $25,000 with which to finance operations of the Gold Standard League for the State of New York, was opened yesterday at a luncheon in the University Club. The luncheon, attended by 200 business leaders of the city, was given by Philip Le Boutillier, president of Best Co., and chairman of the league in this state.

JACKSONS MILL, W. Va., Oct. 4 -- "Back seat" influence in curbing excesses of teen-age motorists was cited today as an outstanding potential factor for reducing accidents on the highways, at the National Conference on High School Driver Education here.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The storm blown by four whistle-tooters in the Notre Dame-Washington football game Saturday faded to a gentle breeze today.

Whisky inventories now being held in distillers' warehouses have reached an all-time high level of approximately 507,000,000 gallons, spokesmen for distillers disclosed here yesterday. This has resulted in a leveling off of production to the current rate of about half of that during 1948, it was explained.
The probable line-up and batting order, with final batting, fielding averages and pitching records, for the first game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium today follow:

An "international identity card" describing her as a "world citizen" enabled Miss Virginia Faith Davis, sister of "Citizen of the World" Garry Davis, to cross the borders of Switzerland, France, Italy and Germany, she related here yesterday.

" Under the Sun of Rome," an Italian-made topical drama, which arrives at the Avenue Playhouse, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Renato Castellani directed the importation, which is the first foreign-language picture to be released by United Artists. Oscar Blando, Francesco Golisano and Liliana Mancini head the cast of the offering.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 -- Attorneys for Harry R. Bridges today began a courtroom battle aimed at winning dismissal of perjury and conspiracy indictments against the Australia-born West Coast longshore leader and forestalling his trial, which has been set tentatively to open on Nov. 14.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Senate confirmed tonight, 48 to 16, the nomination of Federal Judge Sherman Minton to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.

Prospects for a good duck season improve with every report that flows in from the Canadian openings and, although the majority of visiting hunters on New Brunswick rivers held out for black duck limits, teal, scaup and whistlers were reported to be unusually plentiful.

The International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, reduced its original set of demands yesterday to six "indispensable" proposals. The union acted at the urging of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, which is making a determined effort to bring about a settlement of the contract dispute with the New York Shipping Association.

Dramatic illustration of the fact that "the disabled are able" is afforded by the exhibit this week of physically handicapped persons at work in the Education Hall of the American Museum of Natural History. There one can see the deaf, the blind and the crippled performing with great efficiency such skilled operations as assembling radios, splicing and winding films, grinding lenses, typing, drafting and weaving.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Five free balloons, investigating cosmic radiation, traveled twenty-six miles up to the thinnest part of the earth's atmosphere today to set a new altitude record for balloons carrying instruments, the National Geographic Society announced.
Chief Justice Laurance M. Hyde of the Missouri Supreme Court reported yesterday that "the Missouri plan" for selecting judges had proved extremely successful.

The moves against Marshal Tito are coming with such speed and from so many directions that they are getting hard to follow and assess. Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia have now denounced their treaties of alliance with Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, in asking for the recall of the Yugoslav Ambassador goes one short step further than the other satellites and their Mother Country Russia, although Prague is doubtless responding to orders from Moscow.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 4 -- Delegates of the major powers were called in for the first time today to meet in closed session with the newly-formed United Nations Balkan Conciliation Committee.

Russia's apparent possession of the atomic bomb some three years before American scientific opinion believed it possible can be attributed to loose administration in Washington, in the opinion of Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination last year and president of the University of Pennsylvania.

A positive and sound pension system now exists via the machinery of the Federal Old Age Security System. Amendments which would raise payments now made by employer and employe plus provision for the inclusion of individuals now left out would cover a maximum of individuals with decent payment benefits for the future.

After four months of secret negotiations, Lever Brothers Company has completed plans to erect a twenty-story headquarters building of striking design in the block-front on the west side of Park Avenue between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets, it became known last night.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Last night's hurricane from off the Gulf of Mexico lost much of its intensity today after passing over this city of 500,000 in the early hours. But the winds and rain dealt a heavy blow at the coastal crops, with rice, cotton and vegetables suffering the most.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 4 -- Airborne immigration to Israel from an unspecified country at the rate of 1,000 daily, which began two weeks ago, is completely disrupting Israel's immigrant absorption program. Officials declined to discuss the new immigration wave for "security" reasons.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The trial of Preston T. Tucker Sr. and seven others associated with him in his post-war venture to produce a rear-engine automobile, on charges of violation of the Mail Fraud Statute and the Securities Act, began here today with the selection of eight jurors.
Michigan, Notre Dame and Oklahoma ran 1-2-3 in the season's first Associated Press poll to pick the top ten college football teams from coast to coast.

Manhattan College's 1949 - 50 basketball team will play a twenty-six-game schedule, beginning on Nov. 19, and ending on March 2, Kenneth A. Norton, director of athletics and head coach of basketball, announced today.

The American Friends of France, Inc., have taken over the performance of Les Ballets de Paris on the night of Oct. 20 at the Winter Garden to raise funds for the organization. Miss Maude A. K. Wetmore heads the benefit committee.

ROME, Oct. 4 -- The Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano published today the first of a series of articles by its editor, Count Giuseppe Dalla Torre on the situation of the church in countries behind the Iron Curtain.

It will be Allie Reynolds, 31-year-old part Cherokee Oklahoman, against (maybe) Don Newcombe, strapping Negro right-hander, on the firing line when the curtain rises on the 1949 world series at the Yankee Stadium today.

A dramatic treatment of real-life events provoking a major crisis in the life of a selected person will be the basis of a new television series entitled "Crisis," beginning tonight over the National Broadcasting Company at 8 o'clock.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 4 -- The Boyce Motor Lines, Inc., whose cargo of carbon bisulphide caused a fire and explosion in the Holland Tunnel last May 13, was indicted by the Federal grand jury today. The true bill, presented to Judge Thomas F. Meaney, accused the corporation in six counts of unlawfully transporting a dangerous chemical through the tunnel in violation of Interstate Commerce Commission regulations.

GARRISON, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement was celebrated at Graymoor, mother house of the order, here today. The occasion also marked the departure of four missionaries for Japan.

A civil suit asking combined damages and indebtedness cancellation of about $64,000,000 was filed in Federal Court yesterday by an informal stockholders committee of the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis Omaha Railway Company against the road's parent company, the Chicago North Western Railway Company.
The Daily Worker, organ of the Communist party, reported yesterday in a statutory circulation statement that its average sales over the last twelve months were 23,400 copies.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- In the twelve days of September that followed Britain's devaluation of her currency, about u20,000,000 was added to this country's fast diminishing reserves, thus slowing the rate of the drain. This was announced by the Treasury and by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in a speech tonight at the Lord Mayor's dinner to the bankers and merchants of London.
ALBANY, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Governor Dewey described Italy today as "a bulwark against Communist aggression in the cold war."

BELGRADE Yugoslavia, Oct. 14 -- The Czechoslovak Government, moving with precision to carry out the Soviet Government's well organized maneuver against Yugoslavia went one step further than other satellites by requesting the recall of the Yugoslav Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Senate returned the Anderson long-range farm bill to committee tonight after striking down the measure's basic principle, flexible price supports, by voting to continue indefinitely the high rigid props on the so-called basic commodities that were originally enacted to meet wartime conditions.

World series tickets could be fairly easily obtained yesterday -- at speculators' prices. Any one who knew the ropes at all could lay hands on a block of tickets to the four games scheduled to be played at the Yankee Stadium during a possible seven-game series.

How can you explain the ways of public taste? Colomon, the English pianist, returned to New York last season after an absence of ten years and was hailed as one of the great artists of our day. You would think that for his first recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night there would be a huge throng.

The Refrigerated Steamship Line, which has been inactive in the last two years because of up-profitable operating conditions, will resume its coastwise fruit service this fall and will transport a limited number of passengers and pleasure automobiles between New York and Florida.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Government decreed tonight a state of siege to combat what it said were activities intended to re-establish a regime of "despotism and terrorism" in Paraguay.

Added inducements to clock watchers to keep tabs on the time were offered yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel by the Semca Clock Company in a preview of twenty-three new timepieces. Rhinestones, simulated rubies and sapphires, leather -- both real and imitation -- and simple brass were used to make decorative cases.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France have agreed in principle that it would be a good thing to bring the West German Government into various international governmental organizations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, asked the Federal Communications Commission today to adopt the color television system evolved by CBS to speed up the "inevitable" switch from the current black-and-white telecasting.
BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- Brooklyn owes Boston a favor. Brooklynites plan to square things Oct. 22.

When the steel companies were presenting their arguments against a "fourth round" before the President's fact-finding board this summer they were inclined, generally speaking, to deal rather sketchily with the issue of the union's pension demands. There were exceptions to the rule, such as that provided by Enders M. Voorhees, finance committee chairman of United States Steel.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The British Government is quietly confident that it can hold out against an Argentine effort to raise the price of meat to Britain by about 49 per cent because of the sterling devaluation. Argentine meat provides about 40 per cent of Britain's scanty ration, so the dispute is a matter of urgency to the Labor Government.

Mayor O'Dwyer formally opened his campaign for re-election last night with a recapitulation of the achievements of his first administration in improving city services and finances and making New York a better place in which to live.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 4 -- Following the Communist Information Bureau's pattern, Czechoslovakia denounced today her treaty of friendship and mutual aid with the Government of Yugoslavia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade here today, reacting in the late trading after July wheat and March and May corn had sold at a new seasonal high. Uncertainty regarding the outcome of the farm support bill now in debate in the Senate led to considerable evening up in all pits.
During the great struggle in which the prediction was commonly made that England would succumb to the ruthless Hitler there were still others who proclaimed, "There will always be an England."

The two six-story buildings at 2985-2995 Botanical Square, the Bronx, operated as a single unit and containing 185 apartments, have been sold by Milton Gettinger to the Ralic Realty Corporation. The property, assessed at $620,000, occupied an irregular plot about 300 by 140 by 242 feet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Following is the roll call vote by which the Senate tonight sent the farm bill back to the Agriculture Committee with instructions to bring a revised bill back in forty-eight hours:

Coal exports to Japan have increased more than 1,100,000 tons during the first seven months of this year compared with the same period last year. These orders partly replace cutbacks in demand during 1949 by European buyers, F. F. Estes, executive secretary of the Coal Exporters Association, told more than 125 members at the annual meeting of the trade organization yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 915, against 1,629 last week and 743 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 331 arrivals yesterday compared with 736 last Tuesday.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Eastern European delegations to the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization were defeated here today in an attempt to keep the agency out of Western Germany.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Charles De Witt, Browns' vice president, announced today the signing of Burke McLaughlin, 19 - year - old pitcher just discharged from the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee ordered an investigation today of the recent agreement allowing Great Britain to use $175,000,000 in Marshall Plan funds to buy Canadian wheat.

Court-martial proceedings against Pvt. Anthony V. Martino began yesterday on Governors Island with the prosecution contending that he deserted the Army in France in 1944 and stowed away on a merchant ship to spend the rest of the war in the United States.

Two major works will be introduced to this country by the Philharmonic-Symphony under the baton of Leopold Stokowski, it was announced yesterday. They are Prokofieff's Sixth Symphony and Messaien's "Trois petites Liturgies de la Presence Divine."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The nonpartisan League of Women Voters of the United States today opened a two-day meeting to launch a new national campaign to get women into the two political parties as active workers.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., Oct. 4 -- The Navy, quarreling with the Air Force over their respective roles, was mildly reproved while the Army was complimented by President Truman today as he witnessed a magnificent review and then combat exercises by the Eighty-second Airborne (All-American) Division.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 -- Efforts to bring the celebrated "Melish case" to the floor of the fifty-sixth triennial General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church came to an abrupt end today when the convention's House of Deputies failed to debate the issues involved.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Administration scored a clean-cut initial victory today in its effort to legislate greatly expanded Social Security coverage and benefits by getting a rule through the House under which amendments by Representatives will be barred during consideration of the bill.
With no end of good-will and a cast likewise endowed, S. M. Chartock last night launched at the Mark Hellinger what he hopes will be a permanent Gilbert and Sullivan company.
In his letter in your issue of Sept. 27 former Corporation Counsel Paul Windels presses his contention that his self-supporting Transit Authority is the answer to New York's transit problem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Chinese Communist request for recognition of the newly proclaimed People's Republic of China has now been received here, the State Department disclosed today. The department indicated that it was in no hurry to act.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 4 -- In a vehement attack on President Truman's Point Four program, Dr. Juliusz Katz-Suchy of Poland charged today before the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee that it was an attempt to use the United Nations as a disguise for the penetration of American "monopoly capital" into the colonial territories of Western European countries.

The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania sold yesterday $8,500,000 of general obligation Series L bonds due from Oct. 1, 1950 to 1961, to a banking syndicate headed by Chase National Bank at a bid of 100.041 for interest of 1.10 per cent, a net cost to the issuer of slightly more than 1.09 per cent.

Plans for converting an East Side home into a cultural center were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the residence formerly occupied by the late Darwin P. Kingsley at 50 East Sixty-eighth Street to the House of Iran, Inc., a non-profit membership organization planning to use it as a clubhouse for Iranians.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today, with little change, the rate-making practices of the Western railroads.

Total deposits of the National City Bank of New York on Sept. 30 amounted to $4,526,158,895 and total resources were $4,897,643,284, according to the quarterly statement of condition published today. The figures compare, respectively, with $4,579,501,332 and $4,945,372,474 on June 30 and $4,567,484,131 and $4,912,440,813 at the end of September a year ago.

There is no proper place in the American democratic process for the kind of rowdyism that was displayed when Representative Vito Marcantonio spoke from a sound truck to a crowd at Ninety-fifth Street and Broadway as the American Labor party candidate for Mayor.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today, with little change, the rate-making practices of the Western railroads.

Total deposits of the National City Bank of New York on Sept. 30 amounted to $4,526,158,895 and total resources were $4,897,643,284, according to the quarterly statement of condition published today. The figures compare, respectively, with $4,579,501,332 and $4,945,372,474 on June 30 and $4,567,484,131 and $4,912,440,813 at the end of September a year ago.

There is no proper place in the American democratic process for the kind of rowdyism that was displayed when Representative Vito Marcantonio spoke from a sound truck to a crowd at Ninety-fifth Street and Broadway as the American Labor party candidate for Mayor.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- School books that were anathema last week to 11-year-old Glenn Schmidt glistened with allurement today -- all because of a note from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on the presidential letterhead of Columbia University.

WARSAW, Oct. 4 -- Despite the existence of treaties of friendship and mutual assistance with the "people's democracies," the Soviet Union guards its borders with these countries as rigidly as with non-members of the Soviet bloc, the Polish Journal of Laws indicated today.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Activity in South African gold-mining shares and a continued demand for British Government stocks were features of the stock markets here today.

George Whitney, president of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., was elected yesterday to succeed Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, as president of the New York Clearing House Association. S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, was also named, at the association's ninety-sixth annual meeting, to serve as chairman of the Clearing House Committee, succeeding Mr. Whitney.

AUBURN, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Governor Dewey denounced the Brannan farm plan here tonight as "a slick scheme" that would add the Government as a new and expensive middleman between the farm producer and the urban consumer.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was firm yesterday and final prices were 12 to 18 points net higher.

In a sunny corner of the Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center three 3-year-olds sat in a circle clapping their hands in rhythm to the music of a record. Two mothers sat watching. On the floor sat the third mother with a therapist, Mrs. Eric Pollack, clapping their hands in unison with the children.

A record attendance of more than 3,000 was set yesterday by registrations during the second day of the first New York exposition and convention of the National Contract Hardware Association, officials revealed at the Statler Hotel.

Tampa, Fla., financed yesterday the construction of new sewage collection and treatment facilities by the sale of $8,000,000 of revenue bonds to a syndicate of investment bankers at an interest cost of 3.239 per cent.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Mexico's famous Vega brothers, Armando and Rolando, tripped a United States tandem of Frank Parker and Art Larsen, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, today in a quarterfinal doubles match in the Pan American tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Veterans Administration canceled today its month-old restrictions on the educational rights of war veterans. It installed a more liberal set of rules, but called on Congress to pass legislation to "prevent grave abuses" of the benefits granted in the GI Bill of Rights.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- John Foster Dulles is unquestionably the best man to further a strong and firm policy against the threat of Russian aggression, Governor Dewey told an audience of 300 tonight.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- France's most stable and enduring post-war Cabinet collapsed today with the prospects of grave difficulties in discovering any political combination to replace it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of an amendment to its rules to provide that upon the merger of two Stock Exchanges the surviving exchange might continue unlisted trading privileges in securities admitted to such privileges on the absorbed exchange.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 4 -- Counter-charges of widespread racial and religious discrimination in the United States were made here today by Jan Drohojowski of Poland. He spoke on behalf of Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania, who are accused of violating their peace treaties in the suppression of fundamental liberties and human rights.

A banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and Kidder, Peabody Co. put on the market yesterday afternoon a new issue of $18,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds of the Gas Service Company, a natural gas distributing subsidiary of Cities Service Company, at a yield to investors of about 2.825 per cent.

A noticeable letdown has developed in several lines during the last two weeks as a result of the steel and coal stoppages, although the general business situation continues "very good," Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer said yesterday.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 5 (AP) -- The twentieth annual meeting of the Independent Petroleum Association of America unanimously adopted yesterday a program to combat improper use of power by American and foreign companies importing oil into the United States to increase such imports to the detriment of the domestic oil industry.

A luxurious group of expensive brocaded silks woven in Lyons, and a collection of sprightly Provincial prints on unglazed chintz at lower prices were among the newly imported French fabrics introduced yesterday by Brunschwig Fils, 509 Madison Avenue.
The Triangle Litho Print Company, floor in 47-49 West St and 80 Washington St -- Raymond E. Ryan, Inc, broker.

Mr. and Mrs. Clyde K. Harris, who arrived Tuesday on the Queen Elizabeth, are at the Pierre before going to Amarillo, Tex., where they will make their home. Mrs. Harris is the former Princess Cecille, daughter of Crown Prince Wilhelm of Prussia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Four loads of Iowa beef steers sold at the highest price of the year today, $35.50 a hundred pounds. Two loads were from Cascade, Iowa, and a string of thirty-five head amounting to two loads came from Miles, Iowa.

BATAVIA, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- The decision of the Czechoslovak cabinet to create a special office of cabinet rank to control religious affairs was cited today by Senator John Foster Dulles as "an ominous warning "to those attempting to increase the power of the Government in Washington.

Pvt. Anthony V. Martino, presumed dead by the Army after he disappeared in 1944 from his infantry unit in France, but who showed up in May as a Staten Island taxi driver, was found guilty of desertion yesterday and sentenced to dishonorable discharge and ten years at hard labor.

Most of the Puerto Ricans who come to New York seeking a better life find their job opportunities here limited to dishwashing, day labor, unskilled factory work and other tasks on a low economic level. Despite the small earnings in such jobs, 90 per cent of the Puerto Rican families in this city are self- supporting.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee approved today a bill providing a long-range program for building up the United States merchant marine.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The League of Women Voters, opening a new drive to get women into the two political parties, mapped a wide strategy today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr. moved a step further toward becoming the Billy Mitchell of the Navy today when he acknowledged that he was the "culprit" who had distributed to the press copies of a confidential letter blasting current defense policies.

A resolution urging the Office of International Trade to free from export license requirements shipments of goods to Europe which are in free supply here and have no strategic importance was adopted yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Statler Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Federal Government today stepped into the fight between coal mine operators and John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers.
DETROIT, Oct. 5 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, will demand more of the Chrysler Corporation this year than the pension plan won from the Ford Motor Company last week, it was learned tonight.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 5 -- Several months ago, a 10-year-old Brooklyn boy sent a letter to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Unless more "Little Boy Blues" start watching the sheep, Americans may go to the butcher shop one of these days and find there is no such thing any more as lamb chops and mutton.

The application of Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., for an operating differential subsidy for its three "Good Neighbor" passenger vessels was unopposed yesterday at a one-day hearing in Washington, the Maritime Commission's offices here reported.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Republicans on the Senate's "five percenter" subcommittee today demanded an early meeting to push its investigation of the Capital's "influence industry."

In a leading West Side transaction reported yesterday, Don Allen Midtown Chevrolet, Inc., occupant of the four-story industrial building at 227-43 West Sixty-first Street, bought the property from I. J. Fox, Inc., furriers. It is one of two industrial parcels remaining in the blocks occupied by Amsterdam Houses, a New York City Housing Authority development, and was sold through Adams Co., Real Estate, Inc.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- An insurance executive said today that insurance men must sell "the dangers of high taxation" to the public. He was W. E. Bixby, president of the Kansas City Life Insurance Company. He said to 1,000 other senior insurance executives at the forty-fourth annual meeting of the American Life Convention:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The United States, Great Britain and Canada are considering an informal "partnership" for the development of atomic energy, the State Department revealed today.

BUFFALO, Oct. 5 -- This is the most important time in our history to be a parent or teacher, Mrs. John E. Hayes of Twin Falls, Idaho, president of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, told the fifty-second annual convention of the state congress today.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 5 -- The applause for Leonard Bernstein, composer and conductor, had barely died out, after his response to the bestowal of the Griffith Music Foundation's 1949 Honor Award at a luncheon in the Essex House this afternoon when the solemnity of the occasion was broken by a special announcement.

ALBANY, Oct. 5-- Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said today that Benjamin P. Whitaker, Professor of Economics at Union College, would take a sabbatical leave to serve as secretary of the committee. Charles L. Locke, secretary for seventeen years, died recently.

Because of currency devaluations, xporters should start now to weigh the factors in favor of increasing their foreign advertising, according to a study on advertising problems abroad, released yesterday by the research Institute of America.

D. A. Schulte, Inc., a chain of approximately 200 cigar stores extending to the Middle West, will soon stock numerous lines of women's accessories, it was learned here yesterday. H. Cornell Smith, president of the chain, predicted that current planning will result in about 80 per cent of the chain's total sales consisting of soft lines within three years.
NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 5 -- Business in industrial New Britain and the teachers in its educational system have "drifted too far apart," and an effort was made today to get them back together.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The "low morale" among Navy officers, which was the subject of the confidential memorandum of the admirals to Secretary Matthews that didn't stay confidential, bears at least a direct chronological relation to the cancellation by the Secretary of Defense of construction of the supercarrier "U.S.S. United States."

Strato Freight, Inc., an irregular air carrier which lost one of its planes near Puerto Rico on June 7 with a toll of fifty-three lives, refused to enter a defense plea to a charge of negligence yesterday at a Civil Aeronautics Board hearing.
BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- The Moscow order to create an "all German government" was nearer execution today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Joe Louis, retired heavyweight boxing champion, tonight received the annual Brith Sholom National Sports Award in recognition of his outstanding contribution to American youth.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The United States has ordered about $81,000,000 in Japanese gold turned over to France and Thailand in payment for purchases by the Japanese Government during the last war, the State Department announced today.

The secrecy surrounding the development of the atomic bomb has "spread like a fog" over all sorts of unrelated subjects, with the result "that many developments are kept secret that might have led to major advances elsewhere in American industry," according to Prof. Robert F. Bacher, former scientific member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.
OTTAWA, Oct. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Houses are going to be scarce in Canada for some time to come and rents are likely to increase, a cross-country survey by the Canadian Press indicates.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- United States Attorney Otto Kerner Jr. opened the prosecution of Preston T. Tucker Sr. and seven co-defendants in Federal Court here today by declaring that the Government would show that the eight defendants had devised a scheme to defraud, had used the mails in carrying it out, had made untrue statements as to material facts in obtaining money or property and had conspired together in these acts.
The Eastern Area Sister Kenny Institute may be forced to close because "returns have been very small" in its drive for $572,000, Rex G. Williams, executive director, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The State Department has no plans to send Ambassador John Leighton Stuart back to his post in China in view of uncertain conditions in that country, it was learned tonight.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 5 -- Making his first political speech in the current campaign for Governor here tonight, former Mayor Frank Hague predicted a sweeping victory for Senator Elmer H. Wene.

One problem that every school system faces is that of dealing with truancy. Educators for many years have wondered what should be done about it. A sensible answer is found in the year-long study made by the Citizens Committee on Children of New York City, in its significant report "Children Absent From School."

The unruly team of four horses that Premier Queuille has been driving for thirteen precarious months has finally proved beyond his strength. The Socialist horse bolted, but it may yet be pulled back into line. However, the crisis is evidence of the existence of difficulties that were postponed but never solved.

WARSAW, Oct. 5 -- Following closely upon the heels of the Soviet Union, the Polish Government tonight delivered a note of protest to the three Western Powers in Germany accusing them of creating in the new West German Republic a chauvinistic state dedicated to planting the seeds of a new war through revisionist propaganda.

Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., announced yesterday that the Appellate Division in New York decided last Monday that stockholders who refused to vote in favor of Paramount's plan of reorganization, splitting its motion picture and theatre activities, were not entitled to have their stock appraised.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 5 -- As renewed messages of desperation were received here from two United States merchant ships being held by Nationalists in the Chu Shan Islands, the American Chamber of Commerce of Shanghai sent a protest to the State Department today over the lack of protection for United States shipping to and from this port.

TORONTO, Oct. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Prof. Barker Fairley of the University of Toronto, who has been barred from entering the United States, said tonight he was not a member of any political party and never had been.

The fourth annual Dance Festival, sponsored by the Spanish Refugee Appeal, was held at Carnegie Hall last night. Though the hall is larger than the Ziegfeld Theatre, where the previous festivals have been held, and the price scale was higher, there was as usual a completely sold out house.

Paris, New York and London joined hands to give fashion tone to the Tailored Woman's fall and winter display which took place in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. An eager audience crowded the handsome room at the luncheon hour to see what the latest from the three fashion capitals is.

WILDWOOD, N. J., Oct. 5 (AP) -- State Senator Elmer H. Wene said tonight that the Republican administration under Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was "a one-man government." The Democratic candidate for Governor made the statement as he wound up a day-long auto tour of sparsely populated, normally Republican Cape May County.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- The same kind of unification of the armed forces that led to victory over the Japanese in the Pacific war in 1945 was stressed by Admiral of the Fleet Chester W. Nimitz in a lecture before the corps of cadets here last night.

The motion - picture stars of Hollywood declared an "open fight" yesterday on the stage, radio and vaudeville performers in the East in a new union dispute over who should have jurisdiction over television.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Alexander B. Hawes, attorney, said today that the International Pressmen's Union has filed claims against the estate of its late president, George Berry, at Rogersville, Tenn.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 5 -- Reliable reports said today that nearly 1,000 Prague citizens were arrested in a big police round-up last night. There was no official confirmation. The estimate of the number seized in the dragnet came from a person close to police sources.

Blame it on the early morning showers. Blame it on the widely-advertised scarcity of tickets. Or blame it on television. But the fact is that any baseball fan desirous of witnessing the opening game of the world series yesterday could have done so with a minimum of trouble and expense.
Maybe the game wasn't the greatest one I ever pitched, but this one was good enough for me. I can't think of one that came at a better time.

Just as the small Viking sailing ships were distinguished from other craft of the period by their unusual and symbolic figureheads, the new Norwegian-America liner Oslofjord will have a distinctive bow decoration setting her apart from other modern liners, according to a report from her Amsterdam, Holland, shipbuilders.

A collection of Edith Sitwell's poems, written between 1917 and 1949, will be published next month by Vanguard Press, entitled "The Canticle of the Rose." Two of Miss Sitwell's best-known books of poetry are "The Song of the Cold" and "Green Song."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- United States, British and French officials are all in agreement that they are now facing another critical period in their relations with the Russians. Yet all are diverted from the urgent tasks of dealing with the developing international crisis by serious problems at home.

A six-story building containing twenty-five apartments and five stores and occupying a plot 45 by 100 feet at 2 and 4 Ridge Street, also known as 258-60 Division Street, was sold by Seymour M. Tannenbaum to an investing client of Max M. Schwartz, attorney, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
Never did so many nurse so few beers for so long as the fans who crowded the bars of New York yesterday to watch the opening of the 1949 World Series on the television screen.

Howard R. Suslak sold the ten-room house on a plot 60 by 100 feet at 50 Dover Street in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn to Ben Libou for cash over a first mortgage of $14,000 with the Greenwich Savings Bank. Eisberg-Lenz, Inc., was the broker.

Because of the general conversion to jet-powered aircraft by the armed services, one of the country's leading plane manufacturers plans to increase its fuel storage and distributing equipment more than eight times in the event of Mobilization Day orders, it was said yesterday at the second annual Economic and Industrial Conference being held at the receiving station of the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 -- The House of Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal Church today adopted a record yearly budget of $5,634,617. This amount will be extended each year for the next three years to support the worldwide work of the church.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 5 -- Benelux countries advanced toward their long sought economic union today by initialing an agreement freeing 30 per cent of all trade among the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg. The agreement will go into effect immediately upon ratification by the three governments and will be retroactive to Oct. 1.

DETROIT, Oct. 5 -- George T. Christopher, president and general manager of Packard Motor Car Company, announced today his resignation effective Dec. 31, to retire to his 750-acre farm in Tipp City, Ohio.
President Truman has accepted the honorary chairmanship of Brotherhood Week next Feb. 19 to 26, under auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 -- The argument that even if Harry R. Bridges did make a false statement during his naturalization proceedings he did not commit perjury was offered today by Irvin Goodman of Portland, Ore., one of his attorneys, while the longshore leader's counsel continued seeking dismissal of perjury and conspiracy indictments.

More and more people are interested in the healthy, outdoor bathing type of beach, like Jones Beach, rather than in the "mechanical gadget" resort like Coney Island, Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday at Jones Beach.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Oct. 5 -- The nation's business is coming through the reconversion period in good shape, it was declared at the conference of the New Jersey Bankers Association that opened in the Berkeley-Carteret Hotel here today.

Pan American Airways announced yesterday it would start Stratocruiser service between New York and Frankfort, Germany, on Nov. 5, bringing the two cities six hours and five minutes closer to each other. The double-decked planes will make the flight in seventeen hours and twenty minutes, making stops at Shannon, Ireland, and Brussels. Belgium.

Arthur Napoletano, 36 years old, of 2915 Gunther Avenue, the Bronx, was held in $50,000 bail by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell yesterday, charged in a grand jury indictment with conspiracy to violate the Federal anti-counterfeiting laws.

Count Carlo Sforza, Italian foreign minister, said yesterday that he believed the Soviet Union's success in producing an atomic explosion was "a blessing in disguise" for the United States because it would prevent the development of a "Maginot Line" mentality.

A raving band of Yankee ball players trooped off the field at the stadium yesterday to go into a war dance in their swank clubhouse as part of one of the wildest scenes ever encountered in the wake of a world series opener.
John L. Bradley has been appointed sales promotion manager of the Crosley Distributing Corporation. He succeeds Charles L. Schafer, who has resigned to return to the West Coast.
Tommy Henrich's ninth-inning home run ended an epic pitching duel and gave the Yankees a 1-to-0 victory over the Dodgers in the opening game of the 1949 world series at the Stadium yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 5 -- The Israeli Government proposes to leave the concession for the development and exploitation of Dead Sea minerals in the hands of present concessionaires, Palestine Potash, Ltd., provided they are able to raise the means to exploit it adequately, Finance Minister Eliezer Kaplan told the parliamentary Finance Committee today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 5 -- The United States recalled for the budget experts of the United Nations today the bright pictures that many delegates have painted of their countries' economic progress in speeches before the General Assembly and then served notice that if these accounts were accurate it was time to reduce the excess quota of United Nations' costs borne by the United States.

Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson announced yesterday that his department would produce a weekly series of radio programs pertaining to national security, which will he broadcast from 10 to 10:30 P. M. by the American Broadcasting Company, beginning Tuesday, Oct. 25.

The New York City Sponsoring Committee for National Employ-the-Physically-Handicapped Week yesterday cited Daniel Lionel, classified advertising manager of The Brooklyn Eagle and teacher of journalism at Brooklyn College, as "New York's Handicapped Man of the Year."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Senate's bi-partisan farm leaders, spurning any possible compromise, prepared today to renew their fight for a long-range price support program geared to peacetime economic conditions.

Higher expenditures for advertising are vital in making consumption balance production, but more realistic advertising will be needed in selling more goods at less cost to both the consumer and the advertiser, speakers declared yesterday at closing sessions of the annual Eastern conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in the Roosevelt Hotel.

When the imposing structures being built near Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, become the 1,000-bed Fort Hamilton Veterans Administration Hospital next spring, the institution will have its own power plant, housing, laundry and even post office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Truman indicated today that he would sign three Federal pay bills, now being ironed out in House-Senate conferences, that would increase the pay of Federal employes, from clerks to Cabinet officers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Edward Manning, a former employe of the Chicago atomic laboratory, testified today that an accused Russian spy had "direct knowledge" of the wartime work in the laboratory.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Although usually attentive to anything that might seem to relate to fiscal policy, business responded in neutral fashion here today to Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Stafford Cripps' remarks about budget expenditure.
ALBANY, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Civil Service Employes Association reaffirmed today its support of the proposed Mitchell amendment on veterans' preference.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -- Negotiations to bring Dolores del Rio back to the American screen in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Ferguson," opposite Cary Grant, have been instituted, it was learned today. According to Arthur Freed, producer of the film, there is "nothing definite" on the deal as yet, but Miss del Rio is wanted for the role.

An increase last week of 633,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Peroleum Institute. Stocks at the week-end were 103,895,000 barrels, compared with 103,262,000 a week earlier and 90,453,000 a year ago.

CANTON, China, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Leonard Clark, 42, explorer, of San Francisco, was charged today with the fatal shooting of two companions at a drinking party, which began as a celebration of a wedding anniversary.

BURT L. STANDISH gained enduring fame as the biographer of the fictional Frank Merriwell, who won games with ninth-inning home runs. The kids loved it. But some sixty-odd thousand adults at the Yankee Stadium yesterday discovered for themselves that this sort of finish was neither kid stuff nor always fictional.

Natural gas and fuel oil sales have made heavy inroads upon industrial markets for coal, officials of the National Coal Association stated yesterday during opening sessions of a three-day annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Grain markets developed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today under the leadership of soybeans. The latter closed at the bottom with losses of 1 1/4 to 2 cents a bushel following a little strength early.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 4 -- This morning's meeting of the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly was taken up mainly with protests by the Soviet bloc regarding executions in Greece, and there were only two speakers on the disposition of the former Italian colonies.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 -- The Westinghouse Electric Company today abandoned its refusal to discuss pensions and social insurance in negotiations covering 90,000 unionized workers, but the company insisted the workers would have to share the cost of any plan agreed upon.

Voluntary welfare organizations must be alert and effective in meeting social needs so that Government will not be required to take on any more of this task than is necessary, Frank L. Weil said yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 5 -- Edward J. Lueders, 77 years old, of Amityville, is a polio patient in the Nassau-Suffolk Hospital in Copiague. He was stricken on Sept. 27 but his case was not reported to the Suffolk County Health Department until today.

The City Fusion party's petition nominating candidates for Bronx Borough President, District Attorney and County Judge will be turned over to District Attorney Samuel J. Foley for possible criminal action after the Board of Elections gets through passing upon its validity, it was announced yesterday at a hearing before the board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Counsel for the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company today told the Interstate Commerce Commission that unless the railroad received an increase of five cents in its interstate fares it would face bankruptcy within three years.

Among 1,272 displaced persons who arrived here yesterday from Bremerhaven on the Army transport Gen. C. C. Ballou was Gen. Povilas Plechavicius, a former Commander in Chief of the Lithuanian Army from 1927 to 1929 and a leader of Lithuanian underground activities against both the Russians and Germans during the war.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 5 -- Despite the doctrinaire attack from the Soviet bloc on the motives of the United States and the United Kingdom in supporting economic development for underdeveloped countries, members of key delegations took satisfaction today in the large measure of support voiced thus far for the technical aid program being considered by the United Nations General Assembly.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 5 -- The Soviet Union told the United Nations today that there could be no Balkan settlement unless Greece stopped executions of anti-government leaders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- After nearly six hours of uninterrupted discussion, the Defense Committee of the North Atlantic Treaty organization agreed today on the basis for a satisfactory integrated plan for the defense of the area by the twelve signatory nations.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 5 -- The Soviet Union made a surprise one-minute announcement today that it was preparing new proposals on disarmament.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 5 (AP) -- It will be a battle of winners here Saturday as Michigan and Army meet in the No. 1 football game of the week-end college card.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Investors Diversified Services, Inc., which recently came under the control of the Alleghany Corporation, will continue as investment manager of three affiliated investment funds companies. The affiliates are Investors Mutual, Inc.; Investors Stock Fund, Inc., and Investors Selective Fund, Inc.

Emerging occasionally from a cloud of smoke of their own making, the muzzle loader enthusiasts volunteer the information that they are getting in trim for the big event, the championship shoot which is scheduled to take place at Shartlesville, Pa., Oct. 15 and 16.
