Ten proposals to the City Planning Commission for the construction of private parking garages have been filed under a revised section of the city's zoning law effective last Aug. 15, Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the commission, announced yesterday.

If the pattern of yesterday is followed -- and there's no reason why it should not be -- the 1949 world series will win acclaim as the most orderly of all the post-season classics. Some 200 patrolmen, mounted police and officers, with acting Chief Inspector Edward C. Moran in charge, had less trouble handling the crowd than they would have had keeping peace at a game between married and single men at Macombs Dam Park.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 5 -- Property in this city controlled by the Port of New York Authority that is not used for public purposes will be assessed for taxes for approximately $15,000,000, City Commissioner Meyer C. Ellenstein announced today.

Mayor O'Dwyer, IVfanhat[an orough President Hugo Rogers and Miss Kate Wollman will speak at gFound breaking ceremonies for the Wollman Memorial Recreation Center in Central Park at 3 P, M. tomorrow, the Department of Parks announced yesterday.
JACKSONS MILL, W. Va., Oct. 5 -- Traffic congestion in New York City was described today as a curb on teaching teen-agers safe driving techniques.

There seems to be considerable misunderstanding as to the meaning and effect of the resolution regarding the genocide convention recently adopted by the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association. A communication published in your issue of Sept. 28 is an illustration of this misunderstanding.

For the time being there is little that the United States can do actively to halt the revolutionary momentum that is now leading to the full-scale military conquest of China by 4,000,000 Communist troops. But as the world's leading economic power, the United States still seems to be in a position to affect future developments in China.

Cesar Brion, 197 1/2, Argentina, stopped Tami Mauriello, 201 1/2, Bronx, in 2:18 of the second of the main bout listed for ten rounds at the opening show of the season at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 3,302 paid $6,670 to see the program.
BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- Undaunted by the poor snow conditions of last season, winter resorts in New England will continue on as large a scale, if not larger, than in the past during the 1949-50 campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A Congressional investigation of the bitter dispute within the armed services, involving particularly the Navy and Air Force, was voted unanimously today by the House Armed Services Committee, and tonight the identity of the naval officer who made public the confidential documents that put the cap sheaf on the controversy was disclosed.

A tract of vacant land in Woodmere, L. I., has been sold by Harry Ginsberg and David K. Schwartz to Woodmere Estates, Inc., which plans to improve wit ith a group of ranch-style houses. The irregular parcel, about 650 by 1,800 feet, is on the north side of Peninsula Boulevard, about 257 feet east of Woodmere Boulevard.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 2 points higher to 9 points net lower.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Oct. 5 -- Mrs. R. M. Torgerson, New York State champion for the last four years, was easily the best in the next-to-last medal play handicap tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

Holdings of United States Government securities by the Chase National Bank of the City of New York on Sept. 30 amonted to $1,760,469,739, compared with $1,723,449,124 on June 30 and $1,545,408,567 at the end of September, last year, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition, to be published today.

TORONTO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Capt. William Taylor emphatically denied before a Federal commission of inquiry today a suggestion he had been under the influence of liquor when his ship, the cruiser-steamer Noronic, had burned at her berth here Sept. 17.

The main coaxial cable of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, television artery connecting Eastern and Midwestern video stations, was cut accidentally yesterday at 3:47 P. M. by workmen digging a trench in Cleveland.

A special drive to bring out a big Republican registration next week when registry books will be open throughout the city was agreed upon yesterday at a conference between Alger B. Chapman, manager of Senator John Foster Dulles' campaign, and the Republican chairmen of the five New York City counties.

Faced with the possibility of a strike by 1,200 clerks, Safeway Food Stores, operator of 155 units in the metropolitan area, halted delivery yesterday of all perishables from warehouse to retail outlets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A bill designed to implement President Truman's Point Four program by authorizing the Export - Import Bank to guarantee United States capital against certain risks of investing in foreign countries was approved today by the House Banking and Currency Committee.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 5 -- American Federation of Labor delegates turned their convention into a political rally this afternoon and heard a sharp attack on Senator John Foster Dulles and high praise for his opponent, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, in the New York Senatorial campaign.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 5 -- The ten-day period of incubation ended today for the Yale football team after a light outbreak of polio, and for the first time since the cancellation of the Fordham game the squad went through a hard scrimmage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The personal papers of former Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York, sponsor of the Wagner Labor Relations Act and New Dealer, have been presented to Georgetown University, the Very Rev. Hunter Guthrie, S. J., president of the university, announced today.

An unusual experiment will begin soon in the field of cancer to demonstrate how the cooperation of municipal and voluntary hospital services may produce the best possible treatment for thousands of patients annually, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Truman's earnest appeal for the confirmation of Leland Olds for a third term as Federal Power Commissioner fell on deaf ears again today when the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee voted, 10 to 2, against the nominee.

The election of James Dalton Cunningham, president of the Republic Flow Meters Company of Chicago, as president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers for 1950 was announced yesterday at the society's headquarters, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 28:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Senate tonight shelved until next year a bill designed to spur construction of moderately priced homes. In place of that measure, a quickly drafted resolution to extend the Federal home loan insurance program was approved by a voice vote.

Maurice Valency's adaptation of Jean Giraudoux's "Intermezzo," now labeled "The Enchanted" in order to avoid confusion with the Ingrid Bergman picture of the same name, is scheduled to make its New York debut in January, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Administration registered a smashing triumph, greatest of the Eighty- first Congress, today as a bill greatly expanding the nation's Social Security program swept through the House by a vote of 333 to 14.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "The Heiress," starring Olivia de Havilland, Montgomery Clift and Sir Ralph Richardson. The Paramount romantic drama was produced and directed by William Wyler from Ruth and Augustus Goetz' adaptation of their play.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 5 -- The Western Allied High Commissioners are expected to approve tomorrow a trade agreement calling for the exchange of approximately 600,000,000 Deutsche marks ($142,860,000) worth of goods between West and East Germany during the next year.

Due to competition, mark-ups on frozen foods have been cut, it was reported here yesterday. Retailers formerly selling at 25 per cent mark-ups are now, for the most part, selling with a 20 per cent mark-up, it was said. Highly competitive stores were said to be making mark-ups of only 15 per cent on most lines.

Last Nov. 10 the Epiphany Branch of the New York Public Library -- located on East Twenty-third Street, between Second and Third Avenues -- placed a sign on its door: Closed for Rehabilitation. That "rehabilitation" has now dragged on for more than ten months, enough time for an entire library structure to be built, let alone "rehabilitated." So far there has been no sign forthcoming as to when the library will open.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Successful relays of color television programs between Washington and New York were reported today by Columbia Broadcasting System, which wants to start colorcasting regularly.

A call on the entire membership of the Zionist Organization of America to assemble in their communities on a given day within the next four weeks to participate in a mass "Biblical oath" to stand by Israel "in its struggle against the attempt to sever Jerusalem from the Jewish state," was made yesterday by Daniel Frisch, president of the organization.

The blue and white United Nations flag, with its olive-branch wreath for world peace, was hoisted yesterday from the highest peak of the thirty-nine-story steel skeleton at Forty-second Street and the East River. Diplomats and other dignitaries were there to celebrate the "topping out" of the United Nations permanent headquarters building.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, expressed amazement last night at the statement by Senator John Foster Dulles, his Republican opponent, that unless the American people checked now the trend toward an all-powerful centralized federal government they might have to fight their way back through "bloody" revolution.

United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., a holding company for various manufacturing and distributing concerns in the textile and allied industries, reported yesterday that net profit declined 48 per cent in the fiscal year ended June 30.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct 5 -- Bituminous coal operators today announced immediate acceptance of Federal mediation in the seventeen-day strike of 400,000 miners, but appeared pessimistic over the outcome.

Kling Factories may advance prices 2 or 3 per cent on selected numbers in their solid mahogany and mahogany veneer bedroom furniture line before the end of the month, George Dudley, general sales manager, reported yesterday. He emphasized that price increases are still in the consideration stage but added higher costs of lumber and thin veneer stock "can no longer be ignored completely."

With reserve funds used up by the record epidemics of recent years and the greatest case-load of polio patients in history, the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis started yesterday a campaign to raise $4,000,000 among leading New York business men.

When a fashion can be worn a number of different ways, women usually love it. J. J. Slater, 624 Madison Avenue, introduced a shoe during luncheon at the Pierre Hotel yesterday which can be worn in twelve ways.

The blockade of a Utica Avenue trolley car at St. Mark's Avenue in Brooklyn by a commandeered automobile resulted yesterday in the capture at 11 A. M. of one of two alleged thieves. The second man escaped during the short chase in which two shots were fired by the thugs.
YUMA, Ariz., Oct. 5 -- Bob Woodhouse and Woody Jongeward, former Navy fliers, set a world record for sustained endurance flying tonight when they passed their 1,008th hour in the air.
Mrs. Fiorello H. La Guardia, widow of the former Mayor, accused Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday of unjustifiably attempting to besmirch her late husband's reputation in opening his campaign for re-election.

Word from Buenos Aires that hide prices there have been advanced 15 to 20 per cent in terms of dollars since the devaluation of the Argentine peso brought frantic trading in hide futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. The price advances wiped out all but 10 to 15 per cent of the 30 1/2 per cent reductions which would have resulted from the devaluation of the peso.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Active consideration is being given by the British Government to the establishment of a national wages tribunal to pass upon claims for higher wages that may be made as a result of the increase in living costs caused by the devaluation of the pound.

Extension of this country's laws to permit the entry of more displaced persons from Europe will aid in the general recovery of Europe, Msgr. Edward E. Swanstrom, executive director of war relief services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, declared yesterday.

Les Ballets de Paris, a company of young dancers under the direction of Roland Petit, will make their first appearance in this country tonight at the Winter Garden. The program features especially Mr. Petit's ballet version of "Carmen," in which Renee Jeanmaire has the title, he himself is Don Jose and Serge Perrault is the Toreador.

Pitching a four-hit shutout for eight innings and losing a world series game on one pitch, as Don Newcombe did at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, is tough to take -- and that's the way the giant Negro right-hander was taking it when reporters crowded around him as he sat in front of his locker after the game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Judge Sherman Minton called at the White House today to thank President Truman for appointing him to the Supreme Court and rendered an expert opinion on the first world series ball game.

Guaranty Trust Company of New York has been appointed paying agent for $3,360,000 of Illinois Central Railroad's 2 1/8 per cent equipment trust certificates, series CC, dated April 1, 1949. The bank has also been appointed co-transfer agent for the common stock, $5 par value of The Southern Company, Wilmington, Del.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The French Government crisis that resulted in Premier Henri Queuille's offer of resignation is generally considered here to have been precipitated, but not caused, by the Washington financial talks in September and the devaluation of the pound that followed.
The famous Fifth Avenue mansion of the late steel financier, Andrew Carnegie, opened yesterday as a school for 800 students devoted to community service.

The city's Division of Labor Relations has intervened in 150 labor disputes and has saved business and employes millions of dollars since its creation in October, 1946, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday in a report on the agency.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 5 -- Weighty issues of international diplomacy were momentarily forgotten today as leading United Nations delegates and Secretariat officials went to Yankee Stadium along with other fans to witness the first game of the 1949 World Series.

Perhaps the happiest man in the Yankee Stadium yesterday, outside the line of actual combat, was Edward Grant Barrow, octagenarian retired business manager of the American League champions, whose genius in appraising baseball material contributed no little to the lofty estate the Yanks have enjoyed for so many years.

Consolidation of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., and J. Friedman Co., two of the largest men's clothing producers in the country, was announced yesterday. Both companies have been in business for more than sixty years and have been competitive, making the same type product and selling to the same price market.

The $23,300 Sysonby Mile at Belmont Park yesterday promised to be a thriller-diller. It was. It resulted in the defeat of Calumet Farm's Coaltown, No. 1 contender for horse-of-the-year honors, by Greentree Stable's 3-year-old Capot, who once again proved himself to be as stout-hearted a runner as there is in the business.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Lack of educational services is as critical as the lack of food and shelter in the present world, Dr. Althea K. Hottel, national president of the American Association of University Women, reported today as the chief conclusion she had drawn from a trip around the world.

Reports on this year's packs of canned fruits and vegetables indicate that corn, green beans, peaches and pears will be plentiful. Already prices of these products are lower than in 1948, with pears down as much as 12 cents a tin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A bipartisan group of forty-four Senators called on the Government today to end its dismantling of Germany's industrial plants, but the State Department soon afterward appeared to have dashed any hopes for a change of policy.

Teen-agers throughout the country may be helped to a better understanding of themselves and others through a dramatic sketch prepared for amateur production in schools, churches and clubs, and now ready for distribution, the New York Committee on Mental Hygiene of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street, announced yesterday.

We hope that New York will never become so large or complacent a city that we lose the small-town pleasure of welcoming with pride a new resident. The city extends a cordial greeting to Lever Brothers Company, which is to build a block-long headquarters structure on Park Avenue between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets.

In commenting on the question of non-contributory pension plans discussed in THE TIMES' editorial of Oct. 1, "The Labor Picture," and in Elisha Friedman's letter which was printed Sept. 30, may I call attention to an existing pension fund?

Carrying through on the optimistic closing note of the previous day, stock prices yesterday extended gains to new high levels for the year to date. Closing quotations were shaded slightly on the heaviest trading in three weeks, as the turnover expanded to 1,470,000 shares; on Tuesday the turnover was 1,310,000 shares.
The play-by-play description of the first game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday follows:

Terminating a family ownership of forty-five years, James E. and Susan M. O'Reilly have sold the three-story three-family apartment house at 897 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, to Alphonse and Paul Cuneo. The sale was negotiated by Anthony V. Moratto as broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Orders from dealers to hardware jobbers are above normal for September and many industry members are now falling behind on deliveries, John H. Mize, president, National Wholesale Hardware Association, declared yesterday. He addressed more than 400 members of the National Contract Hardware Association during the third day of the fifteenth annual convention at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A registration statement covering $5,000,000 of first and general mortgage bonds, Series S, due in 1979, that are to be sold at competitive bidding, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Central Maine Power Company, Augusta, Me.

Money problems are human problems, as THE NEW YORK TIMES points out in its editorial "The Price of Devaluation." We cannot live without money, and we are finding it increasingly difficult to live with it. And if the difficulty is not to become so great that it is beyond peaceful solution, as it was, as THE TIMES points out, at the time of the French Revolution, a moral solution to money problems must be found.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 29 -- If the present rate of technological growth should continue in the industrial regions of Europe it looks as if United States machinery manufacturers would have a permanently larger market in Europe.

Textile production techniques in Great Britain are not more than ten years behind those in the United States and need only the application of effort and money to draw abreast, it was pointed out yesterday by Solomon Barkin, research director, Textile Workers Union, CIO.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 5 -- Premier Hachem al-Atassi and other members of the Syrian Cabinet and dignitaries greeted Abdul Illah, the Regent of Iraq, at the Damascus Airport this morning when he arrived en route from London to Baghdad after long conferences with the British.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 5 (AP) -- The ring career of Enrico Bertola ended in tragedy today. The 27-year-old Italian boxer died of a head injury suffered in a bout last night with Lee Oma. Death came at 1:20 P. M.

Oppenheim Collins introduced new fall millinery at an informal tea for the public in the second floor salon yesterday afternoon. A diversified selection of styles, fabrics and trims was featured for all occasions.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5 -- A judicial inquiry into the issues that caused the strike of 5,200 trainmen on the Missouri Pacific Railroad was ordered today by Judge George H. Moore of the United States District Court.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution will oppose establishment of any world federation "with all their vigor," their president general declared tonight.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 5 -- President Syngman Rhee voiced his Government's assurances today that it would "give the utmost cooperation" to the United Nations Korea Commission in its renewed efforts to unify Korea.
There is proof now that extra added hurdles don't stop Times Square pedestrians.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 5 -- A pledge to "do everything humanly possible to save the people of New Jersey from any new taxes" was made today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, Republican candidate to succeed himself.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 -- Philip Murray's United Steelworkers of America, CIO, made another dent today in the steel industry's solid front of resistance to employer- financed pension and welfare programs.
MADRID, Oct. 5 -- Representative James P. Richards, Democrat, of South Carolina, said here today that he literally lost his pants on a train in Spain last Sunday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 5 -- Gen. Jacob L. Devers, recently retired chief of the Army field forces, tonight termed the present "an age in which the ability to strike first, and swiftly, may mean the difference between a country which lives and a country paralyzed and destroyed."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 5 -- Moshe Piyade of the Yugoslav politburo broadened his offensive against the Soviet Government today by attacking internal political conditions in the Soviet Union.

Both the Federal Landlords Committee and the larger Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee commented regretfully yesterday on the New York City Rent Advisory Board's refusal to support a general 15 per cent rise in residential rents here.

HEMINGWAY used to praise the terse clarity of good cablese. It is, as you know, the dehydrated language used to save cable tolls. When suitably watered, it blooms into pages of rich, nourishing prose. Yet in itself it often tells a story wonderfully well.

In the fifth of his radio speeches addressed to Mayor O'Dwyer, his Democratic opponent, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, disputed Mr. O'Dwyer's claim, made in his speech at the Commodore Hotel on Tuesday night, of improvement in the condition of the streets, schools and subway service during his administration.
MADRID, Oct. 5 -- Representative James P. Richards, Democrat, of South Carolina, said here today that he literally lost his pants on a train in Spain last Sunday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 5 -- Moshe Piyade of the Yugoslav politburo broadened his offensive against the Soviet Government today by attacking internal political conditions in the Soviet Union.

Both the Federal Landlords Committee and the larger Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee commented regretfully yesterday on the New York City Rent Advisory Board's refusal to support a general 15 per cent rise in residential rents here.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The thirty-sixth International Automobile Show opened its doors at the Grand Palais here today to a public eager to inspect current models that for the first time since the war can actually be ordered with some hope of early delivery.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 6 -- United Nations authorities have withdrawn their instruction to reduce by Oct. 1 the number of Palestine refugees on the roles of relief agencies from 940,000 to 820,000. The order had been issued in anticipation of a reduction by Nov. 1 of the relief agency lists to 750,000.

Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss (Retired), member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York that he regarded as "misguided" any "philosophy that may hold that security is no longer warranted" in matters relating to atomic energy, "now that others may possess atomic weapons."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Oct. 1, 1949, totaled 658,128 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,344 cars or 0.5 per cent less than for the preceding week, 250,738 cars or 27.6 per cent less than for the corresponding week last year and 284,327 cars or 30.2 per cent less than in the corresponding week of 1947.

In an interview at his campaign headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic-Liberal candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, declared yesterday that he would go into that office completely independent of Tammany.

The State Department has indicated that it will take no action in respect to recognition of the Chinese Communists until it has consulted Congress. Congress, in turn, is always expected to consult its constituencies and to reflect the judgment of the public. But neither the Congress nor the public can be informed unless it has access to the best possible collection of available facts and available judgments from competent sources.

The six-story apartment house accommodating fifty-seven families at 1085 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Zavan Realty Corporation to the Richibelle Holding Corporation. The property is assessed at $250,000 and was sold for cash above mortgages of $191,503. The brokers were Pearce Mayer, Joseph Ribler and Louis Eisen.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Montreal squared the little world series with Indianapolis with a 7-1 victory on Clarence Podbielan's two-hit pitching job tonight.

Four investment banking syndicates competed yesterday for the underwriting of American Gas and Electric Company's offering of more than $22,000,000 of new common stock to the company's stockholders. The winning syndicate, headed by Union Securities Corporation, got the contract for offering to handle the underwriting for a compensation of $116,000, equal to about 23 cents a share for the 498,081 shares underwritten, or to about one-half of 1 per cent of the total money commitment.

As tight a finish as the last two at the Yankee Stadium was provided in yesterday's main event at Belmont Park. Joe W. Brown's Riverlane scored a nose-tip decision, and the last horse in the field of six was only three lengths out of it at the end of the nine-furlong run.

The United States Department of Commerce is making a survey of the stocks of warehouse steel, but the Government does not plan to extend export controls unless the current strike makes it "absolutely necessary," Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6 -- The Yugoslav-Soviet rift was assured today of airing in the United Nations General Assembly when the Belgrade delegation formally called for an international declaration against any country that provokes civil war and exports terrorism.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Agricultural production in Africa can be tremendously increased if it is preceded by an intensive research program, according to three American experts who have just completed a two-and-a-half-month survey at the request of the British Colonial Office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat, of Iowa, chairman of the subcommittee investigating the spread between farm and retail prices, today asked three Minneapolis milling companies why flour prices dropped only 15 per cent between January and October, 1948, while wheat prices fell 30 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement on the signing of the Mutual Defense Assistance Act of 1949:

George H. Kerner, representing the Kings County Democratic organization, walked out of a Board of Elections hearing yesterday when the Commissioners started to double check the clerks' report on the Kings County petition nominating Newbold Morris and his two running mates on the City Fusion party ticket.
An irate band of pickets pinned two policemen against a wall yesterday on East Fifty-ninth Street and released them only after they were ordered to do so by other police with drawn pistols.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The United States protested with unusual sharpness today against what is described as the Soviet Union's "shocking" treatment of Americans who had wandered "inadvertently and innocently" into the Soviet zone of Germany.

While the recent currency devaluations could lead to a genuine upsurge in world trade, much more needs to be done by all countries concerned if they are to move away from bilateralism and arbitrary trade controls, the National Foreign Trade Council declared yesterday in an analysis of the advantages and drawbacks of the changes.
ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- The State Federation of Labor, through its League for Political Education, made plans at Albany meeting today to further the Senatorial campaign of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Presentation of evidence began today in the trial of Preston T. Tucker Sr. and seven present and former business associates as the first two of an expected seventy-five Government witnesses took the stand in the court of Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis A. Pick, Chief of Army Engineers, declared here today that a definite decision should be made soon on whether it is feasible to build a ship canal across New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A model for a pioneer "anti-atomic" hospital, with three underground levels to serve 5,000 people in an emergency, was displayed here today by two California members of Congress, Representative Clyde Doyle, Democrat, of Long Beach, and Representative Gordon L. McDonough, Republican, of Los Angeles.

Importers, affected by the closing down of the Chinese market, will shift their orders to Madeira, it was predicted yesterday by Arthur M. Klurfeld, executive secretary of the Handkerchief Industry Association. Added pressure for embroidered goods from Madeira, he pointed out, will tend to raise prices there with the result that savings from the 11 per cent devaluation of Portugese currency will be wiped out.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Amid the full-throated cheers of the corps of 2,400 cadets and an artillery salute from a battery of howitzers, an Army football team that was not in the best of shape in the backfield left here tonight for Ann Arbor, Mich., to play the ranking college eleven of the country Saturday before 97,000 spectators.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 -- The administration of Holy Communion by intinction, a perennial subject of debate within the Protestant Episcopal Church, was officially sanctioned for the first time today by action of the body's fifty-sixth triennial General Convention.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 6 -- Nicolaas C. Havenga, Finance Minister, announced in a broadcast tonight that a loan for South Africa of 10,000,000 [$28,000,000] would soon be floated in London and that 6,000,000 [$16,800,000] would be raised from joint United States and Swiss sources. Early next year, he said, a further 10,000,000 loan would be available in London.

" Les Ballets de Paris," Roland Petit's little company which has won a considerable reputation for itself in its home city and in London, made its American bow last night at the Winter Garden in a program consisting of "Carmen," its piece de resistance, and three shorter works.

East Harlem residents rallied to a call of a loudspeaker last night on the steps of the Church of the Saviour, (non - denominational), 111th Street and Lexington Avenue, to sign a letter to Mayor O'Dweyer, calling for early inspection of housing facilities in the area by the Department of Housing and Building.

Britain's action in devaluing the pound sterling without prior consultation with the French and other Western European nations has proved a disservice to the cause of European unity, Robert Bollack, director of the Agence Economique and president of the National Syndicate of the Economic Press of France, asserted here yesterday.

" How d'you think I feel?" yelled the 64-year-old silver-haired Barney Shotton from the midst of a ring of reporters who had hemmed him in just as had happened the day before when the Yankees had beaten the Brooks by the same 1-0 score that brought the Dodgers even yesterday.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The General Electric Company demonstrated today what it said were "the most powerful lightning bolts ever produced by man."

MEN never tire of retelling it: the most moving, tragic and inspiring story in the world, the story of Jesus of Nazareth. It was told first by word of mouth and best in the four Gospels. But the Gospel story is so tantalizingly brief and so filled with mysterious gaps that the temptation to imagine more than is known has been irresistibly alluring to many writers. Some have written learned works of theological speculation.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Britain's health service, which provides free medical care to all citizens, is costing the taxpayer, 300,000,000 [$840,000,000] a year, Aneurin Bevan, Health Minister, disclosed today at a press conference.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Felicisimo Ampon of the Philippines racked up another stunning upset today to oust the United States' sixth-ranking player, Earl Cochell, from the Pan American tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Latin-American customers now may buy United States-made machine tools on the installment plan.
Two events designed to call attention to the fact that today is the 100th anniversary of the death of Edgar Allan Poe took place here yesterday.

Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, informed the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France yesterday that Moscow was prepared to make important concessions to expedite negotiations on a state treaty for Austria.
LONDON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Dr. Edith Summerskill, Parliamentary Under-Secretary to the Minister of Food, said today that bacon and eggs for breakfast were merely fad.

The abundance of reasonably- priced vegetables, poultry and fish this week-end somewhat offsets higher costs of four meat cuts. Encouraging, too, is the decline of 2 cents on medium Grade A eggs, now 73 cents a dozen. And the market reporter for the United States Department of Agriculture recommends that lots of fruits be included in today's marketing plans, for many varieties are especially economical now.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Truman signed without comment today the $5,809,990,000 foreign-aid bill providing $3,628,380,000 for European recovery in the current fiscal year and an additional $150,000,000 in loans to Marshall-Plan countries through the Export-Import Bank.

MOSCOW, Oct. 6 -- The Russian Orthodox Church appealed today to Christians throughout the world to unite in solidarity against a new war and to accept as a basic tenet of global Christian harmony "recognition of the complete possibility of the peaceful coexistence of different political and economic systems without interference in internalaffairs" between nations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles, National Boxing Association champion, would "jump at the chance" to meet Joe Louis if and when the old kingpin of the heavies should decide to emerge from retirement.

When we say this, we have to qualify what we mean by "success." Relatively few of our population can save enough during even the most useful working years to sustain them during the years when they are too old or too feeble to work.

There was a noticeable pick-up in enthusiasm among the spectators at the Stadium yesterday. While the ho-hum attitude of the opening game still was in evidence at the second contest a slight rise in fever could be discerned. The reason: A more exciting ball game, even if the pitching continued to dominate.
A sea-going couple completed yesterday the first leg of a 15,000-mile cruise when their ninety-one foot schooner docked at the Seventy-ninth Street yacht basin, Hudson River.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- An increase in the price of gasoline and Diesel oil on the British domestic market was forecast today by the Government and oil company officials. This increase will be another result of the devaluation of the pound.

Condensed into a twenty-four-page summary, the evaluations of an intensive survey on theatrical conditions, conducted by Edward L. Bernays (an adjunct professor of public relations at New York University) in behalf of the League of New York Theatres, were disclosed by him yesterday at the league's annual meeting in the Hotel Astor.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York announced yesterday an $8,042,000 expansion program, involving the construction of nine community centers, a city-wide resident facility for young adults, eight new extension centers and the modernization of five community centers now in existence.

The merger of Gunther and Jaeckel was signalled publicly yesterday noon in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel by the first fur show of the new concern. The showing was worthy of the two names so famed in the designing and fashioning of fur wraps.

Advertising in the eight major New York City newspapers during September totaled 12,989.475 lines, a gain of 1.58 per cent over the like month of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: Automotive, up 28.22 per cent; general, 9.26 per cent; financial, 2.48 per cent, and retail, 2.29 per cent.

Oil paintings, sculpture, graphic arts and handicraft, created in displaced persons camps in Germany by exiled Lithuanian artists who had fled their country to escape Communism, will go on display at the New York Hall of Science, 1506 Broadway, from Oct. 20 through Nov. 19, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Columbia Broadcasting System demonstrated a sample color television network to the Federal Communications Commission today. Color signals were sent over a 470- mile circuit with little or no loss in quality.

The clothes of forty-three gifted designers were shown last evening at the Plaza Hotel in one test of the American Fashion Competition for 1949 sponsored by The Chicago Tribune and directed by Mrs. Grace Pickering. Three winners were selected by the audience of fashion executives and press. The votes, however, will be pooled with those cast in Chicago at a show to be given soon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- During the week ended Oct. 5, member bank reserve balances increased $368,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- Plans for remaking two notable films were announced today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Paramount. The Metro project, a new version of "Scaramouche," Rafael Sabatini's romantic novel about the French Revolution, was described as a possible vehicle for Gene Kelly.

A conference of scientists in the fields of X-ray crystallography and the nature of solids will be held at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn on Oct. 15 as a welcome to Dr. Paul P. Ewald, pioneer in these fields, who came from Queen's University in Belfast, Ireland, to the Chair of Physics at the Brooklyn institution.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Controversy is developing between the British Government and industry over the question of the dollar export drive, and since the devaluation of the pound took place both sides are becoming more voluble in the laying of blame on one another.
THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 27 quotes Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, speaking of Russia's production of atomic bombs, as follows:

Although a admitting that his "sophomore team" was developing satisfactorily, Coach Lou Little was inclined to go along with those who favored Yale over Columbia in the pre-game speculation at Morningside Heights yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6 -- United Nations delegates today heard a representative of a native Somaliland organization declare his country was not ready for independence and would have to refuse it if the world organization decided to confer it.
MIDDLESEX, N. C., Oct. 6 (AP) -- A big school bus crammed with children ripped into an ice truck today, killing seven youngsters. About twenty were hurt.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6 -- Sir Hartley Shawcross, British Attorney General, led a seven-nation attack today on Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania in the General Assembly's Special Political Committee, which is considering charges that the three Soviet satellites suppressed human rights and fundamental liberties.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A cheaper and quicker method of making mirrors for "reflecting" microscopes -- described as an important aid to cancer and other research -- was announced today.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 6 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today hailed House approval of the liberalized social security benefits as "the outstanding legislative victory for labor during this session of Congress."

Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, referred yesterday to Wednesday night's radio address by former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for the United States Senate, as "the most demagogic and inflammatory talk I have ever heard by any man in public life."

Three persons of the theatre, Walter Hampden, Peggy Wood and Moss Hart, were cited yesterday by Supreme Court Justice George J. Beldock, president of Youth United, for their "outstanding service in-behalf of the legitimate theatre."
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 6 (AP) -- E. B. Stewart's Justice and Jeff-Lin Stable's Northern Deb finished in a dead heat for first in the six-furlong feature at Garden State Park today.

A brisk demand for steel shares sent stock prices higher yesterday in fairly active trading. Gains, however, were mostly fractional except for a few selected industrial issues, which scored advances of a point or more. At the close, quotations were slightly below the day's bet levels.
TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 6 (AP) -- An enthusiastic crowd of some 500 Negroes today applauded a description of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll as "a God - sent blessing to our people."

A concert entitled "Stars for Israel" was given last night at Carnegie Hall, under the sponsorship of the Mizrachi Organization of America and for the benefit of Kiriat Medrashiah, an educational and housing center for Jewish youths to be established at Pardes Hanna, Israel.

DETROIT, Oct. 6 -- Enough steel to build another 600,000 automobiles was now on hand in the motor industry, it was reported today by Automotive News, trade publication, as the first pinch of the steel walkout was felt by two companies.

The residence of the late Judge Patrick Hughes on Hinman Place in the Rye Neck section of Mamaroneck, N. Y., has been purchased by James F. Mathias, who is now occupying the property. Peter C. Doern Jr., Inc., was the broker.
As Told to The United Press Yesterday's game is one that the folks back in Arkansas will talk about for a long time. I know I will,-anyway.

Many tickets have been purchased for the American premiere of the J. Arthur Rank Technicolor film, "Christopher Columbus," on Tuesday night at the Victoria Theatre for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York. Miss Augusta de Peyster is chairman of the patroness committee and Mrs. Clifford D. Mallory Jr. co-chairman.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 6 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin addressed an urgent appeal today to all Democratic and liberal forces in New Jersey to elect State Senator Elmer Wene as the next Governor of the state, citing the Governorship election here, the Senate race in New York and the special Congressional election in San Francisco as "three important tests of national political sentiment."

Six famous "sons and daughters of Brooklyn" have been cited by the Youth United Award Committee for distinguished service in their respective fields and as an example to youth. The awards were announced by Supreme Court Justice George J. Beldock, president of this organization, which is devoted to a constructive program for citizenship.

YONKERS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The appointment as chairman of the finance committee of the Westchester County Democratic Committee of Hugh Grant Straus of Harrison, N. Y., was announced here today by Harold T. Garrity, Westchester County chairman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Section 2 (2) of the Constitution provides that the President has unlimited discretion over whom he shall "nominate" for specified federal offices, but that the "consent" of the Senate is required before he can "appoint" them. At the White House today Mr. Truman sought to confine this right to deny "consent" to those nominations and legislative proposals only which a President does not certify to be a "party matter."

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 6 -- One of the most enthusiastic football fans at Choate School is the Rev. Seymour St. John, headmaster. It is natural, therefore, that the sport plays a pretty important part in a student's life here.

By way of demonstrating that their distinguished adversaries, the Yankees, by no means held exclusive rights to the process, it remained for the Dodgers yesterday to perform the prodigious feat of winning a world series game on one tally.
HONOLULU, Oct. 6 -- Hawaii's costly 159-day longshore strike was settled abruptly here today as the union and the operators finally reached an agreement to return 2,000 striking steve...

Hide futures turned easy after early firmness on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Closing price levels were 10 to 25 points net lower. The volume of transactions dropped to 2,160,000 pounds from the 5,000,000-pound figure established on Wednesday, when prices rose sharply.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 -- The battle over the report of President Truman's steel fact-finding board took a new twist today when the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, disclosed that it had rejected a 10-cent-an-hour "package" offer for 12,000 employes of the Radio Corporation of America.

Although registering their sixth successive weekly rise, business loans made by banks in this area advanced only $18,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday. Figures covering the twenty-four reporting New York City member banks, issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, showed that the latest advance was the smallest in the current series of upturns, but brought the total outstanding to $4,783,000,000.

It is hard to believe that Captain Crommelin took the wise or right course of action in releasing channeled correspondence about the Navy's unification attitudes on his own initiative.
