A plan for the musicians' union to collect royalties on musical films shown by television stations was outlined yesterday by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, to more than eighty representatives of video program producers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee returned its long-range farm bill to the floor today with the controversial high-support provision deleted, thus assuring the renewal tomorrow of a battle to continue the wartime policy of liberal prices for basic commodities.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 6 -- The Government Press Office announced tonight that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs had ordered eight officials of the Polish Embassy and five officials of the Czechoslovak Embassy to leave Yugoslavia in retaliation for the expulsion of Yugoslav diplomatic personnel from Poland and Zzechoslovakia.

The Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital will have as its team captain in the current campaign of the United Hospital Fund Jackson E. Spears, vice president of the National Mallinson Fabrics Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Watson Jr., executive vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation, who is general chairman of the campaign.

Currency devaluation will bring no flood of imports into the United States, nor does it mean a "cataclysm" for American exporters, August Maffry, vice president of the Irving Trust Company, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The first step toward restoration of old Fort Clinton in Battery Park, New York, was taken today when the House approved a $584,000,000 Interior Department appropriation bill after agreement by a conference committee.

A fashion show for the public was presented by the Brooklyn branch of Oppenheim Collins in their second-floor budget department yesterday afternoon. The show was composed of a variety of dresses, all to retail under $18.

The "full support" of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Mayor O'Dwyer and Robert F. Wagner, Jr., was pledged yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and her son, Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt, Jr.

The Russian satellite "German Republic" that is planned for today is a challenge to Western Germany even more than to the United States, Great Britain and France. In effect, the Soviet Union is setting up a competitor for German good-will and support. The Russians are going to bid high, but the West, which created and now supports the Federal Republic of Germany, can feel relatively confident.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 -- A ten-year prison sentence and a fine of $10,000 were imposed today upon Mrs. Iva Ikuko Toguri D'Aquino, "Tokyo Rose," who was found guilty last week of broadcasting treasonable statements to American troops from Radio Tokyo.

The welfare organizations of the country never have enough money to carry out their plans to the full. Each year there is a deficit that must be met by philanthropic contributions which a prosperous and a generous country never fails to make. So it is with the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

TORONTO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Great Lakes pleasure cruiser Noronic, on which more than 100 persons lost their lives in a disastrous fire Sept. 17, had been exempted from regulations requiring that her bulkheads be made fire-resistant, testimony revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation granted a loan of $34,400,000 today to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, Willow Run, Mich., for the purpose of "completing the company's line of cars."
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6 -- The Philippines proposed today that the blue and white flag of the United Nations be flown throughout African and Pacific areas under the international trusteeship system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Under the promise that it might quit soon, Congress broke a long deadlock on $841,918,190 of Federal spending today and moved up other bills providing for additional billions.

DETROIT, Oct. 6 -- Evidence of a revolt that could end in the rejection of the thirty-month pension-plan contract between the United Automobile Workers, CIO, and the Ford Motor Company was seen today after a stormy two-day session of the National Ford Council of the union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee unanimously approved today a bil Ito cut down on "boondoggling" with Federal funds under the veterans educational program.

The Republic of the Philippines has leased the seventh floor of the Crowell-Collier Building nearing completion by Starrett Brothers Eken, Inc., at 640 Fifth Avenue, corner of Fifty-first Street, through Herbert Charles Co., and Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., agents for the building, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Unification, or at least certain phases of it, seemed to have swung full circle today, and to be right back where it started.

Slightly more than $100,000 was offered here yesterday for the village of Passamaquoddy, site of the tidal power and industrial development dream in northeastern Maine on which it was once proposed to spend $100,000,000. A Federal expenditure of $10,000,000 had been authorized when work on the project was stopped by Congress in 1936.

The Electric Bond and Share Company took another major step in its divestment program yesterday with announcement that its entire holdings of 803,229 common shares of Middle South Utilities, Inc., will be offered to its common stockholders for $12 a share on a 1-for-8 basis.
Special subway service to carry fans to and from Ebbets Field during the Dodgers' home games of the world series was announced yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 -- The strike of 500,000 steel workers sapped the country's industrial resources for the sixth day today, with no move by either union or industry leaders to get peace talks started again.

The outwardly normal person, through snobbishness and seeming physical perfection, has succeeded in forcing the obviously handicapped person into a cruel segregation, a speaker declared last night at a symposium devoted to the "good business" of hiring the handicapped.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- After the advance and activity of the last few days, a reaction set in on the stock markets here today. Small declines in gold-mining shares and British bonds and a sharp drop in Brazilian railway securities were the chief features of the set-back.

Richard E. Curcio has purchased the four-story twenty-three-family apartment house at 25-63 Forty-second Street in Long Island City Queens, from Fred Mennella. The property, on a plot about 57 by 97 feet, is assessed at $58,000. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Truman said today that the Army's recent report asserting Negroes were receiving greater equality of treatment and opportunity was to be regarded as a progress report toward the ultimate objective of integration.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N. J., Oct. 6 -- Announcement was made today by lawyers for the Continental Paper Company here that Superior Court Judge John Grimshaw Jr. has granted an injunction restraining Local 299, United Paperworkers Union, CIO, from mass picketing and violence at the plant, which has been closed for fourteen weeks owing to the strike.

The action of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries on Wednesday in favorably reporting to the House on H. R. 5346, which covers amendments to the Merchant Marine Act of 1936, was approved yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America.
George Fries, 54-year-old house painter from Lumberton, N. J., who was arrested last June for a murder committed in Brooklyn in 1921, was a free man yesterday.

Investigation into alleged anti-trust practices in the New York State Medical Society and medical societies of Queens, New York and Nassau counties are being carried out here by the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice, J. Francis Hayden, chief of the division's New York office, made known yesterday.

Net asset value of the capital stock of the Lehman Corporation rose from $43.30 share to $48.82 in the first quarter of the corporation's twenty-first fiscal year, the report as of Sept. 30, issued yesterday, showed. The assets stood at $95,044,100 at the quarter's end.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Pennsylvania Electric Company, Johnstown, Pa., had filed with it a registration statement covering $11,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1979, and 70,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, Series D.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Asserting that it is the executive who carries out economy while others merely talk about it, President Truman today promised some startling figures on economies being effected now.

In your editorial of Sept. 24, "To Salvage Old Housing," you correctly point out that most of the objections to the current program of rehabilitation of boarded-up tenement houses should be waived in view of the existing conditions. I think it important to bear in mind one objection, not to the program itself but to the way it may possibly be administered.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The Paul Baerwald School of Social Work, the first school of its kind in Europe, will officially open its doors in Versailles next week, Dr Joseph J. Schwartz, European director of the American Joint Distribution Committee announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The State Department, in an indictment of almost unprecedented severity, accused the Soviet Union today of having set up an "oppressive police state" in Eastern Germany. It warned the Kremlin that the United States "will not permit" a single power to continue to obstruct "all strivings toward a democratic peace."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- With President Truman's signature today, the long debated project to supply military assistance to foreign countries to the amount of $1,314,010,000 by next June 30 became law. The new statute is called the Mutual Defense Assistance Act of 1949.

E. R. Squibb Sons and wholly owned subsidiaries in the western hemisphere, manufacturing chemists, reported yesterday that consolidated earnings for the fiscal year ended June 30, amounted to $6,883,927, an increase of 86 per cent over the previous fiscal year, when income totaled $3,691,778. The net is equivalent to $3.93 a common share compared with $1.94 a share in the preceding fiscal year.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina denied all pending defense motions yesterday and announced definitely that he would submit the nine-month Communist trial to the jury next Thursday or Friday. At the last previous session of court on Tuesday he had merely said it was "extremely probable" that the case would go to the jury.

State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi invoked a rarely used power of his office yesterday and appointed a five-man fact-finding commission to investigate the sixteen-week-old strike of the Bell Aircraft Corporation in Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Testimony of a securities analyst for a group of public holders of a small amount of common stock of the Philadelphia Company today ended a hearing on a compromise reorganization plan for the Pittsburgh Railways Company.
In five of the new art exhibitions as many painters show work that represents some of the various aspects of contemporary art.
ATHENS, Oct. 6 -- The law providing for automatic suspension of all death sentences, pending review by a Council of Pardons, was passed tonight by the Parliamentary Recess Committee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- In one of its strongest attacks on President Truman's compulsory health insurance proposal, the American Medical Association disclosed today that the AMA and fifteen state and county medical societies, including four New York groups, were under investigation by the Department of Justice.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6 -- Appearance of a "limited recovery" in United States industrial production and a more substantial rise in consumer expenditures was noted today by the United Nations in a survey of recent developments in the world economic situation.

Ronald Colman and his wife, Benita Hume, will be starred in a new radio comedy series, the "Halls of Ivy," over the National Broadcasting Company network. The starting date has not been set, but it probably will be late in this month or early in November on a Tuesday or Saturday night.

British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin, due to sail for home today aboard the Queen Elizabeth, said last night that he was convinced that his five-week visit here had been rewarding and expressed optimism about the future.

Five thousand amateur radio men and as many others who are interested in "ham" operator activities are expected to attend the three-day radio show and convention of the American Radio Relay League, which opens at 4 o'clock this afternoon at the Ninth Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.
Production of a new all-glass rectangular television bulb was announced yesterday in Toledo, Ohio, by the American Structural Products Company, subsidiary of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company.

Federal Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Brooklyn was asked yesterday to decide whether the statute covering assault on the high seas could be used to prosecute a man accused of a similar offense on an airplane in flight.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- The New York National Guard and Air Guard have added 475 new members in the first two weeks of the 1949 fall recruiting campaign, Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commanding general of the Guard, announced today.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The next-to-last one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, held over the green fairways of the Scarsdale course, attracted a field of sixty-seven players today, but the majority found the going difficult and only twenty-four turned in their scores.

Every afternoon except Sundays during the last two weeks cards with numerals nearly three feet high have been flashed at half hour intervals from the attic window of a two-story house at 95-34 238th Street, Bellerose, L. I. Neighbors, who were first curious and then annoyed, told the Nassau County police about it a few days ago.
Five times more pre-school-age children are killed by accidents at home than in the streets, Dr. Samuel M Wishik, director of the Health Department's bureau of child health, declared yesterday.

Many dinner parties were given at the entertainment known as the Two-in-One dinner dance held last night at the formal opening of the Sherry-Netherland's two new rooms, the Carnaval and the Chanteclair, for the benefit of the Soldiers', Sailors' and Airmen's Club.

As the latest addition to the sagebrush saga section of the cinema, "Brimstone," which arrived at the Palace yesterday, deviates from the norm on two counts. This horse opera was photographed in Trucolor, hardly a startling dis tinction in this case, and it features Walter Brennan, veteran of numerous Westerns and a particular credit to this one.

Two of New York's three professional football teams will be in action tonight. The Bulldogs will face the Green Bay Packers at the Polo Grounds in a National League contest, while the Yankees are meeting the Hornets in Chicago in an All-American Conference game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct; 1 were S per cent below sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists I percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

The Federal Reserve Board has created an "uptown area" for the purpose of slashing by $14,000,000 the reserve requirements of a group of commercial banks within its confines, it was announced here yesterday. The action, according to the Federal Reserve ank of New i York, follows the recommendation I made by the bank's board of directors, after approving a request for .a reduction in requirements made by the commercial banks in the area.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 6 -- Long Island potato growers are sharply divided over Uncle Sam's bulging market basket.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Senator John Foster Dulles pleaded for "intelligent economy" in government today as he ended a four-day swing through Western New York as the Republican candidate for election to the United States Senate.

An automobile-looting ring that had been averaging between five and ten vehicles weekly was crushed yesterday, the police announced, with the arrest of six men on charges of grand larceny, Sullivan Law violation and criminally receiving stolen property.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The downfall of the Queuille Government has caused indefinite postponement of a French project to create a special bloc embracing France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg in which freer trade and currency convertibility would be developed.

ROME, Oct. 6 -- Pope Pius XII received Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, in a farewell audience this morning at Castel Gandolfo prior to the Cardinal's departure by air for Paris tomorrow en route to the United States. The Pontiff imparted his apostolic benediction on all the faithful of the New York Archdiocese.

In the interests of conservation, not of wildlife but energy, this might be a good time to confess that we know of no "secret" hunting area, teeming with game, within two hours ride from the city, and if we did happen to know of such a spot wild horses could not drag the information from us.
PARIS, Oct. 6 -- President Vincent Auriol accepted today the resignation of the Cabinet of Henri Queuille who has been Premier for more than a year and started consultations to select his successor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- All that this country needs "is for its salesmen to get busy again, find out what the consumers want and sell it," John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today in a brief visit to Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Civil Service Commission held today that Will Rogers, former member of Congress from Oklahoma, was eligible to continue as a $10,000-a-year hearing examiner for the Department of Agriculture.

A rebuilt and strengthened Germany may become a threat to world peace unless its people learn to understand and accept the United Nations' aims of an international society, Walter H. C. Laves, Deputy Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, declared yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 -- The Matson Navigation Company, chief cargo supplier for the Hawaiian Islands, announced today that with the longshore strike ended it would start loading eight ships in West Coast ports "at the earliest oppor- tunity."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Discussing President Truman's Point Four Program, Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that "in the light of Soviet expansion and aggression" the United States should give first consideration to its own "undeveloped areas."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6 -- High United Nations officials have proposed a "diplomatic bargain" under which the United States would drop support of the Yugoslav candidacy for the Security Council in exchange for Russian concessions in the Balkan controversy, it was reliably reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of the note delivered today to the Soviet Foreign Office by the United States Embassy in Moscow, protesting the treatment of Americans in Eastern Germany:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Truman declared today that no change was contemplated in this country's proposal for international atomic controls, a proposal that he termed the most important in the history of the world.

There is no question but that Europe is returning "awfully quickly" to normal economic conditions, Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney said yesterday on his return from a three-week visit to England, France, Italy and Luxembourg.
A real estate agent with a taste for expensive champagnes and imported liqueurs was among six alleged rent gougers arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 6 -- The Government will face a stone wall tomorrow when it begins its attempt to mediate the strike of 400,000 bituminous coal miners that began on Sept. 19.

The Federal Power Commission has taken action to reduce quantities of natural gas which may be used for steam boiler fuel and is adopting a more favorable general policy toward the coal industry, Tom J. McGrath, general counsel for the Fuels Research Council, Inc., declared yesterday.

After reading the harrowing article about 'teen-age drivers in THE NEW YORK TIMES, I am more convinced than ever that one of the most pressing questions before our liberty-loving America is, What causes reckless driving?
The Citizens Union announced yesterday its endorsement of Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, General Sessions Judge James Garrett Wallace and City Court Justice Frank A. Carlin.

F. M. Linder, president of Jacob Ruppert Brewery, announced yesterday the election of Herman A. Katz, as vice president. Mr. Katz has been sales agent for the Ruppert Company in the New England States fourteen years.

TOKYO, Oct. 1 -- The Communist party has had scant success in holding the Japanese repatriates from Soviet territories who arrived here early this year avowing the Marxist philosophy and expressing as their aim the speedy communization of Japan.

The New York City Opera Company added another impressive achievement to its credit when it gave its first performance of "Der Rosenkavalier" last night. This comic masterpiece by Richard Strauss and Hugo von Hofmannsthal is far from easy to produce, but the brave, young company at the City Center carried it off.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Francis P. Matthews, Seceretary of the Navy, denounced his service's recalcitrant airmen today as faithless, insubordinate and "guilty" men and suspended one of them, Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr., and ordered him confined to this city preparatory to a court-martial.

Most pianists put contemporary music at the end of their programs, but David Stimer reversed the procedure. The majority of his offerings at Town Hall last night was composed by Satie, Poulenc, Stravinsky and Ned Rorem. At the end came a Mozart sonata.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Oct. 6 -- The "basic fallacy" of the Government's planned economy "lies in the assumption that the actions of the public can be predicted and predetermined," W. W. Townsend, member of the business and bank consultant firm of Townsend-Skinner, New York, asserted at the closing session of the twenty-first midyear conference of the New Jersey Bankers Association here today.

In a day of intensive campaigning, Newbold Morris, Republican-Fusion-Liberal candidate for Mayor, declared himself yesterday in favor of the city's purchase of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart as an extension of City College and heard himself described as the only legitimate political heir of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.
With a moderate volume of business, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 2 points higher to 13 points lower.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6 -- The general debate in the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee over the proposed expanded program of technical assistance to under-developed areas drew toward a close today, with the majority of delegates hailing the program and spokesmen for the minority Soviet bloc voicing qualified but substantial approval.

New York headquarters of Press Wireless, which transmits news dispatches, said last night the Chinese Communist Government had ordered correspondents in its territory from countries "without diplomatic relations" with the new Red regime to stop sending dispatches.

To Vermont-born Luke Dalrymple, chief carpenter, building superintendent and handy man at Marlboro College, yesterday was a red-letter day. For, in the company of his college president, he saw New York for the first time. And he also learned that the new science building now being constructed on the Marlboro campus would be known as Dalrymple Hall.

As the result of an investigation in Miami, Fla., into an alleged black market in babies, Irwin Slater, 38 years old, an attorney, was arrested yesterday afternoon in his Manhattan office on a charge of violating the New York Social Welfare Law.

GENEVA, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Governor Dewey defined the issues in the Senatorial race between John Foster Dulles and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman today as he carried his up-state campaign for Mr. Dulles through three central counties.
Persons suffering from tuberculosis do not show any distinct personality patterns, Dr. Allan Hurst, medical director of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver, declared yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6 -- Influential delegates to the United Nations General Assembly are discussing a proposal that is intended to assure the Kremlin that the United States and other Western powers are not planning to launch an atomic war against the Soviet Union, it became known tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Truman candidly acknowledged today that he had directed the Democratic national chairman, William M. Boyle Jr., to put "heat" on Senators to confirm Leland Olds for a third term as a Federal Power Commissioner.

During the twenty-five years that the Municipal Broadcasting System, operator of city station WNYC, has been in existence, the station has highlighted programs designed to widen public knowledge of the operations of city departments, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday in a report.

If the nation's 500,000 steel workers wish to strike, that is their right, and no one can justifiably raise a finger against their doing so. But, by the same token, any worker desiring to remain on the job ought to have equal consideration. He ought to be allowed to stay at his task if he so elects.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6 -- An eight-state Governors' Conference sought today to find a means of settling the strike of 5,200 trainmen against the Missouri Pacific Railroad.
A note of resignation hung over the Yankee clubhouse after yesterday's second game of the world series and the defeat which sank the American League champions into a tie with the Dodgers.

Asserting that Governor Dewey obviously was planning to seek the Republican nomination for President again, Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, charged last night that both Mr. Dewey and Senator John Foster Dulles, his Republican opponent, were appealing to bigotry and class prejudice in an attempt to elect Mr. Dulles.

Among the disappointed fans at yesterday's game at the Yankee Stadium were some 2,000 men, women and school children who failed to get into the bleacher seats before game time. Although 12,000 places were available in this section at $1 each, all were occupied before "Play Ball" was called.

The Foreign Commerce Club of New York intends to play a much more active part in civic affairs than in the past and give much more time to the problems of this port, Paul G. Boise, president said yesterday.

The State of Connecticut sold yesterday $6,480,000 of University of Connecticut tax-exempt building bonds due on Oct. 15, 1950 to 1979, to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 101.3199 for interest of 1 5/8 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.60 per cent to 1.70 per cent.

The Hotel Fourteen, a thirteen-story building at 14 East Sixtieth Street in which the Copacabana Club is located, has been sold by the Barnett Fourteen Operating Corporation, Rubin Barnett, president, to the 14 East Sixtieth Street Corporation, John A. Buckbee, president, it was announced yesterday.

Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer, former Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan and Mayor O'Dwyer joined a gathering of 1,500 persons last night in honoring Bernard F. Gimbel, the merchant, for "distinguished service in the field of human relations."

The Hotel Fourteen, a thirteen-story building at 14 East Sixtieth Street in which the Copacabana Club is located, has been sold by the Barnett Fourteen Operating Corporation, Rubin Barnett, president, to the 14 East Sixtieth Street Corporation, John A. Buckbee, president, it was announced yesterday.

Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer, former Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan and Mayor O'Dwyer joined a gathering of 1,500 persons last night in honoring Bernard F. Gimbel, the merchant, for "distinguished service in the field of human relations."

The Lafayette National Bank of Brooklyn in New York reported as of Sept. 30 total deposits of $38,590,863 and total assets of $41,451,117, compared, respectively, with $38,151,237 and $40,880,962 on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $10,292,869 against $11,201,961; holdings of United States Government securities to $16,567,408 against $15,510,734, and loans and discounts to $12,647,863 against $12,278,364.

Fort Pitt Brewing Company declared a regular dividend of 15 cents, an extra of 10 cents and a 4 per cent stock dividend, all payable on Oct. 28. The stock dividend will be paid out of shares the company purchased on the open market, it was announced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Tactics used by a local of the Longshoremen's Union, CIO, and four of its agents in a jurisdictional dispute were unlawful, a trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board charged today.

As a civilian and graduate of West Point who served in the Regular Army after World War I and in the Navy during World War II, I feel particularly gratified that the publication of Vice Admiral Bogan's letter to the Secretary of the Navy will encourage open discussion of the differences between the services.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday that upward of $18,000,000 will be spent on the expansion and improvement of municipal hospital facilities in Brooklyn if Amendment No. 7 to the State Constitution is ratified by the voters next month.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Wet weather over a large part of the Central West, which stopped harvesting of soybeans and corn, and reintroduction of a farm price-support program in the Senate gave the grain markets a strong undertone on the Board of Trade today.

Although bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday showed a small gain, they continued slightly below the level of a year ago. Total transactions in the twenty-five leading cities amounted to $13,588,784,000, representing a gain of 4 per cent over the $13,070,584,000 of the previous week, but 4 per cent below the 14,150,030,000 volume for the corresponding week a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday that upward of $18,000,000 will be spent on the expansion and improvement of municipal hospital facilities in Brooklyn if Amendment No. 7 to the State Constitution is ratified by the voters next month.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 7 -- Representatives of native organizations in two former Italian colonies came before the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee today to plead for independence for their countries.

MADRID, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Spanish police closed the case of the Congressman's stolen trousers today by arresting a gang of railroad thieves and recovering the missing garment, with $3,800 and a rabbit's foot in one pocket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -The State Department said today that Chinese Nationalist warships had released the two United States flag freighters of the Isbrandtsen Line that had been halted off Shanghai on Sept. 24.

The six-story building at 1956 Crotona Parkway, the Bronx, containing six stores and thirty-three apartments, has been sold by Silver Brothers to the Fed-Cher Realty Corporation. The property, on a plot 109 by 126 feet at the southeast corner of Tremont Avenue, is assessed at $155,000 and was sold for cash above mortgages of $116,000.

Bert W. Gleiehman, representative for leading plumbing manufacturers, has leased the onestory factory and warehouse building at 40-30 Twenty-third Street, Long Island City, Queens, from the Pter Puppet Playthings, Inc., it was announced yesterday by the Roman-Caswell Company, broker.
In your editorial of Sept. 24 "Kashmir Plebiscite" you commend the original proposal of Pandit Nehru for a plebiscite as "the right way to settle the question."
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Oct. 7 -- A concert that could happen only once in a lifetime happened again here tonight, and it has not lost a trace of its first, fine rapture.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Consumers will get milk and dairy products at somewhat lower prices next year, the Agriculture Department predicted today.

A series of some six ads on safety in the home, tied up with merchandise, will be released soon for retailer use by the Advertising Council, it was learned yesterday. The ads are being prepared under supervision of the council's new retail advertising committee.

DETROIT, Oct. 7 -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, reinforced by a loan of $34,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will move into the low-price automobile field next spring, it was learned tonight. The company, which is already producing cars in the medium and higher price ranges, plans a model designed to undercut Ford, Chevrolet and Plymouth.

Low-end and medium-price dress business has slowed perceptibly in the last week, according to manufacturers in the New York market. They attributed the slump to the fact that new resort and spring lines are to be shown next weak, and to renewed buying caution resulting from the steel strike.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- The final Women's Metropolitan Golf Association intersectional team match for the Myra D. Patterson Trophy was won by the Long Island side, which defeated New Jersey on 31 1/2 points and captured 24 from Westchester for a grand total of 55 1/2 over the Wykagyl Country Club course today.
Beginning final arguments yesterday in the nine-month Communist trial, defense counsel asked the jury to acquit because:

Vincent Lyon has purchased a vacant irregular plot, about 160 by 150 feet, occupying the south blockfront on Union Turnpike, between 271st and Langsdale Streets in Bellerose, Queens, from Bergold Homes, Inc., of which B. Berkeley is president.

Radio manufacturers are substantially increasing production to meet demand, a canvass of leading producers revealed yesterday. The consensus is that radio has staged a sales recovery virtually unnoticed because of concentration of trade attention on television and at least two important producers agreed with retail opinion that radio cutbacks earlier in the year were much too drastic.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Noel Havilland Field, whose brother, Hermann, disappeared in Poland about Aug. 22, now also appears to be missing behind the Iron Curtain, the State Department disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Mid-Continent Airline probably will finish its case on Monday in its effort to obtain the nation's largest feeder air system through acquisition of the Parks Air Line. The Civil Aeronautics Board's investigation of the deal is recessed until Monday.

"There is absolutely nothing to the stories and rumors that Jackie Robinson has been sold to the Boston Braves. I have just talked to Branch Rickey and he is very much disturbed that such a story has been printed."

CAMP LEE, Va., Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Defense Department is showing "some leniency" toward the Air Force in its economy cutback, Lieut. Gen. Joseph T. McNarney said tonight.
ROME, Oct. 6 -- The Vatican denied today that a concordat was being negotiated with the Polish Government to regulate relations between the church and the state in Poland.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Business again was on a greatly reduced scale on the stock markets here today, with South African gold-mining shares continuing to dominate the scene.

They took the world series, which some folks had begun to suspect was being played with an invisible ball, to Brooklyn yesterday and for eight innings the oustanding sluggers of the Yankees and Dodgers still were painfully baffled.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Jerry Voorhis, secretary of the Cooperative Health Federation of America, said today that he was "hopeful that the American Medical Association will itself take constructive action to bring an end to any discrimination by state and local medical societies against doctors of unquestioned professional standing who associate themselves with voluntary pre-payment group health plans."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Air Force is about to commit the country to a war plan that would be "a bad gamble with national security" and might be morally indefensible as well, Admiral Arthur W. Radford asserted today.

In fall, most every woman's fancy turns to furs. There is that air of opulence to them tossed casually over the shoulders or wrapped high about the throat that quickens a woman's heart and doubles the chic of every costume, coat, suit or dress.

Raymond Lewenthal, young American pianist, who made his local debut last year at Town Hall, gave his second New York recital last night in the same auditorium. His program comprised Mozart's Rondo in A minor, Schubert's Sonata in B flat major, Antheil's Fourth Sonata, Liszt's "Mephisto Waltz," a Debussy group, and offerings by Ciaja and Rachmaninoff.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 7 -- The Annecy protocol, which would formalize the accession of additional Governments to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, will be opened for signature at a ceremony at United Nations headquarters here next Monday afternoon, it was announced today.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., State Chairman of the Liberal party, charged last night that Democratic politicians, chiefly in Tammany, were now working out "a piece of Grade A treachery" by which they plan to betray former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, in favor of Senator John Foster Dulles, his Repubican opponent.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 7 -- Mrs. Thomas McDarby of the Plainfield Country Club shot a 43, 44 -- 87 to win the low gross honors in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day handicap tournament held ever the Rock Spring Club course today.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7 -- Four striking brotherhoods and the Missouri Pacific Railroad agreed late today to try a plan produced by an eight-state Governors' conference for ending the rail strike.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended Oct. 4, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 152.5 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.3 per cent below four weeks ago, and 8.2 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7 -- The first full week of the strike of some 500,000 members of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, employed in basic steel plants, ended tonight on a deeply pessimistic note.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 7 -- More and more reports of arrests in all sectors of the population and all parts of the country -- up to 10,000 within a week, according to some estimates -- continued to flow into Prague today.

The largest collection of authentic Shaker furniture to be shown in New York in ten years will be included in a two-day exhibition of Shaker Folk Material opening this morning at the Barbizon-Plaza Galleries, 101 West Fifty-eighth Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 7 -- The Rumanian Government notified Secretary General Trygve Lie today that it categorically denied all charges of having violated human rights and refused to participate in the current discussions on the issue in the General Assembly Special Political Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Senator Brien McMahon, chairman of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, declared today that he was "satisfied that, when, as and if the Air Force has to deliver the bomb, it can get to it instantly."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Henry L. Stimson, in his book "On Active Service," refers to that "dim religious world" of the Navy, "in which Neptune was God, Mahan his prophet, and the United States Navy the only true church."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Navy has applied the principle of the echo to detecting and locating gallstones or foreign objects in the soft tissues of the body.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- An Eastern German state was established here today when the Soviet-sponsored People's Council transformed itself into a People's Chamber and declared the constitution adopted by the council some time ago was now in force.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Grain prices ranged lower on the Board of Trade here today with trading at a minimum. Soy beans were under pressure from processing interests which sold heavily and closed with net losses of 1 1/4 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel.
After a long period of indecision, the Russians have recently come to the conclusion that American geographers and cartographers are the most sinister agents of "imperialist warmongers."
VIENNA, Oct. 7 (UP) -- The Russians today returned to the United States zone three American soldiers they had held for 129 days. The men were underweight and suffering from lack of medical care.

Registration for the election on Nov. 8 began yesterday in New York State, except in this city and Westchester County. The up-state registration places were open from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. They will be open today and next Friday the same hours and on Saturday, Oct. 15, the final day, they will be open from 7 A. M. to 10 P. M.

Mrs. Rebecca C. Simonson, president of the Teachers Guild, AFL, revealed yesterday that she had withdrawn from the recently organized Citizens Committee Against the Feinberg Law because "some of the members have not proven themselves to be true defenders of democracy."

The Maritime Commission announced here yesterday that operations would start Monday on the loading of a third group of twelve vessels to be used for the storage of surplus grain for the Department of Agriculture.
Ticket speculators should take out Brooklyn citizenship papers before they work at Ebbets Field. That seemed the gist of yesterday's ruling by Magistrate James A. Blanchfield.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- The woods in this lower corner of the Adirondack area are bright with fall color, and from the scouting around we did yesterday and today it would seem there are several things other than color to attract the hunters this season.

Country fairs and markets in city and suburbs supply fresh ideas this month for flower arrangements. Now, if ever, is the time when fruits and vegetables seem appropriate for the places where flowers are used during the rest of the year.

ROME, Oct. 7 -- The solution to Italy's housing problem was brought measurably nearer today when it was announced that the Economic Cooperation Administration had approved the expenditure of 23,050,000,000 lire (about $36,700,000) out of the European Recovery Program's counterpart lire fund for the repair and reconstruction of war-damaged private dwellings.

The Eagle-Picher Company and consolidated subsidiaries, producers of zinc and fabricators of lead, in their report covering nine months ended with last August, revealed yesterday that net profit, after giving effect to a credit of $4,500,000 presenting transfer from inventory reserve, amounted to $2,631,476.

"THE ART OF LIVING,"* by that slightly immortal caricaturist, Steinberg, who draws cartoons with friendly impartiality for The New Yorker, The Architectural Forum, Harper's Magazine, Harper's Bazaar, Harpo Marx, House and Garden, Vogue, the Museum of Modern Art and the American Export Lines, is a book without words that tells a covey of wildly improbable anecdotes and makes many an eloquent comment on the wayward spirit of man.

This week an enormous, rambling old house at 48 Spruce Street, Asheville, N. C., was opened as a memorial to Thomas Wolfe. It was once Eliza Gant's boarding house and the people who walked through the pages of "Look Homeward, Angel" lived there. So did the author who made the place famous, and he described it in the novel that once made Asheville furious.

Doris Frankel's comedy, "Love Me Long," until recently known, as "The Time Is Yes," has been booked to make its New York debut at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre during the first week in November, it was announced yesterday by Brock Pemberton, producer.

Price of Three Star Hennessy and Three Star Martell, two of the world's leading cognacs, will be reduced nearly 10 per cent at retail here on or before the first of the year, it was learned yesterday.
Eight years of litigation in connection with the sale of radio station WMCA ended yesterday, Philip Handelman, counsel for Donald Flamm, former owner of the station, announced.

In a top personnel shakeup prompted by "the changing era ahead," Niles Trammell yesterday relinquished the presidency of the National Broadcasting Company and became chairman of its board of directors, succeeding Gen. David Sarnoff.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Dr. James Roscoe Miller, 44 years old, formally took over the administration of Northwestern University today with a declaration of faith that human intelligence has greater power than any materialistic force including the atom bomb. He became the university's twelfth president.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Right Fielder Roy Weatherly's tenth-inning double gave the Indianapolis Indians a 5-4 victory over the Montreal Royals tonight. The triumph put the American Association team ahead again in the little world series, three games to two.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The selection of a Socialist leader to attempt to form a government was expected today as soon as President Vincent Auriol concluded late tomorrow his preliminary consultations in the French Cabinet crisis. There appeared to be little chance that this first candidate could succeed, but his experience was expected to assist the President in his effort to find a man who could win a majority in the National Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Representative J. F. Combs, Democrat, of Texas moved today to try to speed up sale of the Orange Navy Shipyard in his state.
BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- The balance of power in the East-West struggle for Germany shifted slightly in favor of the Soviet Union today.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- The little western Pennsylvania coal mining town of Perryopolis is not so sure today that it will have the $1,400,000 it expected to spend on civic improvements.
Local 25, representing 10,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, endorsed yesterday the candidacies of Mayor O'Dwyer to succeed himself and Herbert H. Lehman for the Senate.

Gerald McDonald, a 14-year-old boy in Newfoundland who has never seen a professional baseball game, is pulling with all his feeble strength for a New York Yankee victory in the world series with autographed photographs of all the Yankee players around him.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Villanova College struck from behind for its fourth straight football victory tonight, defeating St. Mary's 28 -- 20, after the Galloping Gaels of California had converted three fumbles into touchdowns within five minutes in the second period. A crowd of 14,632 saw Villanova remain among the nation's unbeaten elevens.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Urging the House Foreign Affairs Committee to approve measures designed to get President Truman's Point Four program under way, J. A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, said today the President's proposal could be the most potent weapon in the world battle for a democratic way of life.

Danny Gardella, the little outfielder who has been pressing Federal court action against organized baseball for $300,000 damages, last night announced that he was withdrawing his suit and would return to the game as a member of the St. Louis Cardinals.

BATAVIA, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- "Rubbish" was the word that Governor Dewey used today to describe the Democratic charge that he had invoked religious prejudice and class distinctions in behalf of the candidacy of John Foster Dulles for the United States Senate.

The need of expanding the foster home program that attracted 500 prospective foster parents to its agencies last year, will be emphasized in the annual campaign of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies beginning Tuesday.

In two radio speeches from station WHOM, one in Italian and one in Spanish, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, issued last night a challenge to Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion Mayoralty candidate, to deny that he would vote for John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for Senator.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Means of stepping up dollar-earning exports, and the feasibility of extending Britain's working week to increase production, were understood to have been discussed today at a meeting of the National Advisory Council of Production, presided over by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

"Unfair practices of buying offices" were listed as most harmful to "not only the salesmen but also the entire economy" in a statement yesterday by Marshall J. Mantler, managing director of the Bureau of Salesmen's National Associations.

Directors of the Eastern Sugar Associates declared yesterday a dividend of $1.25 on the $5 preferred shares of beneficial interest, to be applied to the accumulation account. The dividend will be paid on Nov. 21. Similar amounts were paid in preceding quarters.
The ABC television network, on Tuesday, Oct. 18 at 8 P. M., will introduce a new series of panel discussions designed to "explore the practicality of religion as applied to everyday living."

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Testimony that one official of the Tucker Corporation doubted the honesty of Preston T. Tucker Sr., president of the corporation, was given in Federal District Court today at the trial of eight past and present executives of the corporation on charges of violating the Mail Fraud Statute and the Securities Act.

Johnny Mize's ears were stinging with the jeers of the Brooklyn bench when the Yankee pinch hitter nailed that two-run single in the ninth yesterday to blast open the third world series baseball game.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 7 -- President Truman's hobby is weather forecasting, with a special interest in outguessing the weather man. That is what he revealed this evening after his arrival at the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Woodward, six miles south of here, for a quiet week-end.

Continued nervousness over the possibility of large imports of South American hides affected trading in hide futures on the Commodity Exchange again yesterday. As a result the day's trading, which involved 2,840,000 pounds, saw a wide disparity betweent prices quoted for the December contract and those for the more distant months.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 7 -- Inaugurated as the fifth president of Stanford University, Dr. J. E. Wallace Sterling today warned against letting apprehension over totalitarianism lead Americans into destroying their "ideals of education for free men."

This week-end marks the climax of the celebrations with which our neighbor Nassau is marking the fiftieth anniversary of its establishment as a county. Today inaugurates a five-day series of expositions on industry and business in the county, from aviation to housing and electronics.

The Green Bay Packers, who had been unable to break into the victory column in two previous starts this season, found the New York Bulldogs made right to their order at the Polo Grounds last night. Tallying two touchdowns and as many field goals, the team from Wisconsin literally romped to an easy 19-to-0 decision over the locals.

Three new volumes are scheduled for publication in the next two months by Simon Schuster in the series of volumes which form the Inner Sanctum Library of Living Literature. In November, the concern will issue "Inner Sanctum Edition of Pickwick Papers," by Charles Dickens, with a critical introduction by Clifton Fadiman, and "A Treasury of Great Reporting," edited by Louis L. Snyder and Richard B. Morris, with a foreword by Herbert Bayard Swope.

Twenty-three former United States ambassadors yesterday placed themselves on record as favoring the restoration of full diplomatic representation in Spain. Most of the twenty-three also said they believed in halting the dismantling of the German industrial machine.

HONOLULU, Oct. 7 -- Union and industry negotiating teams began work today to clear up fringe issues, the only ones standing in the way of the return to work of 2,000 striking Hawaii members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 7 -- An American student, Savel Kliachko, 26, of Palo Alto, Calif., reported to the United States Embassy in Prague today that he had been arrested and held incommunicado as a "spy" for five days in Slovakia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved reduced railroad rates on iron or steel articles and on armor plate or shapes from Geneva, Utah, to the Pacific Coast. The report was written by Commissioner Clyde B. Aitchison.

His Boots, best young steeplechaser in the country, gave a superb front-running exhibition at Belmont Park yesterday to win the forty-ninth Grand National, America's top over-the-jumps event, for Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Fast action in rainbow hues today closed the Columbia Broadcasting System's demonstrations of its color television system before Government officials.

DETROIT, Oct. 7 -- In one of the most unusual editorial columns ever to appear in the labor press in Detroit, Thomas W. Thompson, fourth-term president of Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, paid repeated tributes tonight to the chief Ford Motor Company negotiator, while criticizing sharply the work of Walter P. Reuther, international president of the union.

The first national week of prayer for leprosy missions will be the center of attention in 14,000 American Protestant churches starting tomorrow and ending Oct. 16. The missions are those in 125 leprosy colonies in twenty-nine countries on five continents, which are supported by these churches.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 7 -- Australia wants the General Assembly to make a fresh start on the atomic question by establishing a new United Nations agency to take over the work of producing an international control plan, it was learned today.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- A sharp conflict over whether to raise or lower westbound North Atlantic freight rates is reported brewing here between United States and British shipping interests. The situation is expected to be resolved at the North Atlantic westbound freight conference to be held here next Wednesday.
In a series of speeches last night in Manhattan and Queens, New-bold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion Mayoralty candidate, predicted the election of himself and his running mates.

The closed, darkened community center of the Good Neighbor Federation at Park Avenue and 106th Street, unused for two years because of a lack of funds, was recommended for use yesterday in the city's efforts to aid New York's Puerto Rican community.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 1 point higher to 6 points lower.

Pig lead prices were trimmed 1/2 cent a pound yesterday by a leading custom smelter, and producers of lead products reduced their lines by proportionate amounts, varying with the lead content. The new price set for lead, New York basis, was 13 3/4 cents per pound.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Opportunities for the revival of healthy world trade created through the world-wide devaluation of currencies may be lost if governments continue in force trade-stifling controls and barriers which now exist, A. M. Strong, vice president of the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, said here today.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- Charles Munch began today his first season as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra by presenting the same program offered by Wilhelm Gericke at the opening subscription concert in Symphony Hall fifty years ago. It was greeted enthusiastically.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The State Department, commenting on a prohibition of news dispatches by foreign correspondents in Shanghai, charged the Chinese Communists today with a "flagrant disregard" of international standards of treatment of foreigners and accused them of using the "crude effort" of the news gag to force recognition of the recently proclaimed Communist government.

A proclamation designating next Monday as "United Hospital Fund Flag Day" and urging the public to "contribute generously" to the support of eighty-six voluntary institutions which share in United Hospital Funds was issued yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall.
OTTAWA, Oct. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Finance Minister Douglas Abbott announced today that Canada's reserves of gold and United States dollars were $985,000,000 at the end of September.

A Government plan to spend $25,000,000 to bring 134 laid-up merchant ships to ready emergency status has been balked by a conference committee of appropriations members from both houses of Congress, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Senate, reversing itself for the second time in four days, rejected with apparent finality today a proposal to continue indefinitely the rigid, high wartime price supports on basic agricultural commodities.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 7 -- Michigan and Army, currently ranked first and seventh among the college football teams of the country, will renew relations here tomorrow before a gathering of 97,000 persons.

The Government of South Africa has arranged to borrow 100,000,000 from four American commercial banks on a three-year revolving credit, according to an announcement made here yesterday by the investment banking firm of Dillon, Read Co., Inc., which is negotiating the transaction.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- A recommendation by the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government that the Army engineers be relieved of river, harbor and flood-control work was criticized here today by William H. Webb, executive vice president of the National River and Harbors Congress.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Federal Judge William C. Coleman today dismissed a shareholder's suit seeking to block a stock-trading plan by Eastern States Corporation.

TOKYO, Oct. 7 -- Japanese authorities announced today that the Soviet Union had released seventeen Japanese fishing boats seized on charges of poaching in Russian waters off the Kurile Islands, between the Pacific and the Sea of Okhotsk.

Trading in automobile stocks, at an accelerated pace in the final minutes of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, sent prices yesterday higher at the close. The rallying note recouped most of the earlier losses in the remainder of the list.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it regarded former Magistrate Francis X. Giaccone, whom Governor Dewey appointed to the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District, as qualified and preferred over Special Sessions Justice Walter R. Hart, Democratic-Liberal candidate, for Supreme Court Justice.

Around the renomination of Leland Olds to serve a third term as member of the Federal Power Commission there swirls a double-barreled controversy. It threatens to eclipse the really pertinent question: do Mr. Olds' present views and his record as commissioner for the past decade warrant his reappointment?

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Odds-maker James J. Carroll made the Yankees stronger favorites today in the World Series, but picked the Dodgers to win tomorrow's game if Don Newcombe goes against Ed Lopat. In the event that Lopat is opposed by Rex Barney, Carroll rates the Yankees a slight choice in the fourth game.

An employer offer of three cents an hour toward the establishment of a pension fund was rejected yesterday morning by the negotiating committee of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, at a joint meeting of both sides. The offer was made contingent upon the union's willingness to contribute an equal amount.

The Chinese Communists have put a new twist on the recognition question. It seems now that unless and until a country recognizes the Red regime as the government of China its citizens may not send out news. The use of a news embargo as a means of an attempt at diplomatic blackmail is a novelty that does credit to the Communist appraisal of the esteem that free countries put on free reporting.

In its first change of ownership in fifty-six years, the four-story building occupied by Flagg Bros., shoes, at 123 West Forty-second Street, has been sold by the Mary C. Warren Estate to Charles E. Singer for investment. Three years ago, Mr. Singer bought the building occupied by Thom McAn shoes at 129 West Forty-second Street from Charles Benenson.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 7 -- The American Federation of Labor launched a campaign today to recruit at least 1,000,000 new members in 1950.

In its third attempt to sell the village of Passamaquoddy, in northeastern Maine, where it was hoped once to harness the tidal flow for electrical power, the Federal Government accepted yesterday three bids for a total sale price of $131,755.

Mayor O'Dwyer ended a lively public hearing at City Hall yesterday by signing a local law empowering the City Rent Commission to reject, modify or approve any rent rise allowed by the Federal authorities since last March 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The roll-call vote by which the Senate today rejected the amendment by Senators Milton R. Young, Republican, of North Dakota, and Richard B. Russell, Democrat, of Georgia, for mandatory price supports at 90 per cent of parity on basic farm crops, cotton, wheat, corn, tobacco, rice and peanuts, was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Government today recessed preliminary mediation conferences in the strike of 400,000 soft coal miners. Both sides in the wage-welfare dispute agreed to resume collective bargaining next week.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Armando and Rolando Vega of Mexico today upset Earl Cochell, San Francisco, and Felicisimo Ampon of the Philippines, 6 -- 4, 13 -- 11, 6 -- 4, to gain the men's doubles final in the Pan-American tennis tourney.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 7 -- With Israel virtually at the saturation point as far as current immigrants are concerned, the youth of North Africa are being detoured through Europe. France already has received 1,300 and similar preparations are being made in Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Italy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Truman ate $2-a-pound prize Missouri ham at a breakfast with fellow Missourians and a few guests at the Capitol today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 7 -- Supply Minister Bernard Joseph today told Israelis who had been eating less since his austerity program for economic recovery was launched six months ago that they would be able to loosen their belts a notch this month.

Eva Likova, young Czech soprano, made her debut as Violetta in the City Opera Company's "La Traviata" at the City Center last night. She is gifted with good looks that undoubtedly helped her as a motion picture actress in Europe, and a good voice that won her a place on a Lewisohn Stadium program a year ago.

Foreign traders meeting here yesterday with Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer informed him that some cancellations have developed on orders for United States goods as a result of the wave of currency devaluations.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman has encouraged Communists in the belief that, if elected, he would help them achieve two major goals, Senator John Foster Dunes asserted last night at a Republican rally in Queens.
Ground-breaking exercises for the new Wollman Memorial Recreation Center in Central Park were held yesterday. Rain held the attendance down to about 100 persons.

Too early and too late, it rained twice in Flatbush yesterday. This observation was, of course, from Dodger fans. On the other hand, Yankee followers thought the sun shone brightly all day long, despite the darkness and dampness that enveloped Ebbets Field.

Even firm friends of instant coffee may fail to realize it is a shortcut not only in preparing the breakfast cup, but also in making desserts that call for a coffee flavor. One combines the powdered product with the other ingredients, liquid or dry.

This morning's lone newcomer, at the Mayfair, is "Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad," a feature-length Walt Disney animated subject in Technicolor, released by RKO. Bing Crosby narrates the story of Ichabod Crane from Washington Irving's "Legend of Sleepy Hollow," while Basil Rathbone tells that of "Mr. Toad" from Kenneth Grahame's "The Wind in the Willows."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 7 -- Careful cutting of corners and widespread currency devaluations will pare the operating costs of the United Nations next year by $4,000,000, leaving $37,225,012 to be assessed in 1950 at an average rate of two cents annually for each person in the fifty-nine member countries, Secretary General Trygve Lie disclosed today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7 -- Frank Capra's next production at Paramount will be "Roman Holiday," a screen comedy by Ian Hunter, which the studio acquired yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 7 -- The Balkan conciliation talks will enter a new phase early next week when representatives of the United States, Britain and Russia and of four Southeastern European countries -- Greece and Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia -- will meet together for the first time.

Frederick MacCurdy, State Mental Hygiene Commissioner, called on the general hospitals of the state yesterday to set up extensive mental health treatment and prevention programs and promised that the state would implement them when a satisfactory standard had been evolved.
ASHEVILLE, N. C., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Rescuers found nine bodies today amid the burned remains of an Air Force transport plane.
ALBANY, Oct. 7 -- The Health Department estimated today that some 260,000 residents of the state are suffering from diabetes, but that only half of them have been identified thus far.
This was one time I had a real close shave.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Truman nominated James Bruce of Maryland, former Ambassador to Argentina, today to head the $1,314,000,000 foreign military assistance program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, today told the Senate in a cable of more than 300 words that he had found fraud in the workings of the present Displaced Persons Law and said that its proposed liberalization would be a "serious mistake."
PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 7 -- This community, one of the oldest industrial centers in the United States, last June was listed as among the areas hit severely by recession and unemployment.

American monetary aid to Britain is responsible in part for that country's present Socialist form of govenment, in the opinion of James S. Kemper, Chicago insurance executive and treasurer of the Republican National Committee, who returned yesterday on the liner America from a six-week European tour.

In the Dodger clubhouse yesterday afternoon the atmosphere was as dismal as the dark clouds and drizzling rain that had settled down over Ebbets Field just before the Yankees beat the Dodgers to take the commanding lead in the world series, two games to one.

NEW BRUSWICK, N. J., Oct. 7 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, Republican candidate to succeed himself, praised the record of his administration, which he said was the "one over-all issue in this campaign," in a speech tonight before the Women's Republican Club of Middlesex County at the Pines Restaurant, near here.

Three armed thugs, working on a split-second schedule and with minute regard for detail, held up three employes of a concrete company yesterday noon in the heart of the Grand Central area on East Forty-second Street and escaped with a payroll of between $25,000 and $30,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 7 -- Yugoslavia, charging the Soviet Union with imperialistic exploitation of her economic relations with the under-developed countries of the Soviet sphere, lifted the curtain today on operations of Soviet joint companies in Yugoslavia in her attempt to prove the charge.

The blockfront vacant parcel on the north side of Avenue U, between Nostrand Avenue and Haring Street, in Brooklyn has been sold by Realty Associates, Inc., to the Sixty-first Avenue Land Corporation. The plot, fronting 210 feet on Avenue U, contains 42,000 square feet.

The American Jewish Congress announced yesterday that, as a friend of the court, it had filed a brief in State Supreme Court at Kingston, N. Y., supporting the attack upon the constitutionality of the Feinberg law, which would require a loyalty test of teachers in the public schools.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The seven conclusions with which Admiral A. W. Radford wound up his statement to the House Armed Services Committee today follow:

The incidence of polio in this city in the last seven day was "almost normal for this time of the year," Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, said yesterday in reporting that the number of cases had declined for the seventh successive week.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, appealed yesterday to Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan to reverse an earlier decision and to grant New York dairy farmers a hearing on their petition for a temporary increase in the fluid milk price.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Veteran Buddy Young and Rookie Don Panciera swept on the ground and in the air with ease tonight to pace the New York Yankees to a 38-to-24 triumph over the Chicago Hornets in an All-America Football Conference game before 17,098 fans.
CAMDEN, N. J Oct. 7 -- Howard B. Unruh, the 28-year-old war veteran who killed thirteen persons on Sept. 6 along an East Camden street, is insane and will be committed to a mental institution.
HONG KONG, Oct. 7 -- The Nationalist defenses in South China crumbled along a broad front today as Communist troops drove forward in frontal and outflanking advances.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, accused President Truman today of using "totalitarian" tactics in the fight for Senate approval of Leland Olds' reappointment to the Federal Power Commission.

The questions of recognizing the Communist-dominated Peiping regime and dealing with the Nationalist blockade, which has cut off Shanghai from vital sources of raw materials, have become the focus for distinct differences of opinion between the British and Americans on what to do about Red China.
Recently an editorial on the subject of veterans' preference appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES in which a very important phase of the matter is not touched upon.

The National Coal Association yesterday endorsed the reappointment of Leland Olds as a member of the Federal Power Commission. Speaking at closing sessions of the bituminous coal producing industry's thirty-second annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Charles A. Owen, NCA president, said coal producers feel that Commissioner Olds has been "very sound" in his treatment of natural gas matters coming before the commission. "

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Duquesne Light Company, Pittsburgh, received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer for sale at competitive bidding $15,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, series due Oct. 1, 1979.

On a stage hung with the red, black and gold flags of the Weimar and also the Bonn Republic, flanking an enormous white dove of peace, the Soviet-sponsored "People's Council" met yesterday in Hermann Goering's Air Ministry in Berlin and proclaimed the long-heralded "all-German government."

The explosions of the past week in Navy circles have done two things. They have made imperative a public and profound reappraisal of our entire defense strategy and precipitated a full-dress debate on it. Second, they have demonstrated that unification and integration in the armed services are by no means as complete and satisfactory as had been supposed and hoped.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Saunders Mills' Bangaway, a disappointment in the Hambletonian Stake at Goshen, today captured the $59,922 Kentucky Futurity in straight heats. Thus he clinched the 3-year-old trotting championship.

Continuing their home-building activity, but turning their attention in larger measure to higher-priced houses, Levitt Sons announced yesterday the completion of the acquisition of a site of nearly 400 acres in Nassau County for the erection of 700 residences in ranch style, to be priced at $17,500 up.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Striking first through the air and then on the ground, Temple's football team tonight rallied to vanquish Syracuse, 27 -- 14, before 20,000 in Archbold Stadium.

In 1899 a young Ohio musician arrived in New York with a dream of creating a musical organization that would give the people a better understanding and appreciation of music. More important, he was determined to present the best in symphonic music at popular prices.

The President has on his desk, for a signature we hope he will not give, a bill that on the face of it would help the Navajo and Hopi Indians, who certainly need help. The measure seems to provide $88,500,000, over a period of ten years, for road building, health and other good works.

Methods of dealing with Communists at home and abroad were suggested last night at Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street, the Willkie Memorial Building, where the fifth anniversary of the death of Wendell L. Willkie was commemorated.

A 1950 capital budget calling for the expenditure of $238,278,804 in city funds for next year's public improvements was made public yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The allocations totaled a little more than one-third the $607,955,954 sought by the various city departments.
"Tickled? I'll say I'm tickled. Say, it's one of the happiest moments of my life."
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 -- "Religious illiteracy," was singled out today by the Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church as the "basic weakness" of present-day Christianity.

Retail sales here declined during the week due to high interest in the world series which kept many consumers near radio and television sets. Department store sales were estimated to be more than 15 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 8 per cent below last year.

Haarlem, the Netherlands, has extended its "affection" to its namesake in New York, through a letter from its burgomaster to the Rev. Dr. John H. Johnson, rector of St. Martin's Episcopal Church, 122d Street and Lenox Avenue.
The State of Texas announced yesterday that it will receive bids Oct. 26 on an issue of tax-exempt veterans' land bonds dated Oct. 1, 1949 and due April 1 from 1956 to 1979.

The big games in college football today are Michigan against Army, Texas against Oklahoma and Southern California against Ohio State, with special emphasis on the duel between the mighty Wolverines and the spirited Black Knights, out in Ann Arbor.
Medium-sized general hospitals should make more of an effort to rehabilitate disabled patients, Dr. Michael B. Miller, director of rehabilitation at Beth Israel Hospital, said yesterday.

BOSTON -- Ski enthusiasts will find an enlarged and improved winter sports program in New England during the 1949-50 season, it was pointed out by representatives of state development bureaus, resort and hotel operators, travel agencies and affiliated organizations during the day-long winter recreational promotion conference which was held here last week.

HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 8 -Dartmouth's football power exploded against Holy Cross at Memorial Field today and the Indians triumphed, 31 -- 7. Scoring almost at will and in every period, the victors took the lead halfway through the first quarter and were never headed.

THIS year marks the 150th anniversary of Alexander Pushkin's birth, and the Soviet press has displayed a most acrobatic ingenuity in linking, through hand-picked quotations, Russia's greatest poet with the latest Party line.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- The considerable advantage which Western powers have enjoyed in the struggle with the Soviet Union for Germany inevitably will be reduced with the establishment in the Soviet Zone of Occupation of the "Free German Government" managed by German Communists and directed, like the Governments of the other satellite states, from Moscow.

Sound economics and public welfare programs do not readily fuse. But like all beneficent movements, social security is an appealing subject. This accounts largely for the almost unanimous vote of the House of Representatives on the greatly expanded Social Security program, adopted last Wednesday, by a vote of 333 to 14.

They rolled back the time curtain thirty-three years at Ebbets Field yesterday, back to the good old days of 1916 when Brooklyn got its first taste of world series competition, and lost, 4 games to 1, because a fellow named Babe Ruth helped pitch the Boston Red Sox to victory.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The undefeated Philadelphia Eagles, piloted by Tossin' Tommy Thhompon, powered by Steve Van Buren and protected by a hard-charging line, rolled over the Chicago Cardinals tonight, 28-to-3, before a National Football League crowd of 34,596 at Shibe Park.

It would take the pen of a Pushkin or some of the more morbid Muscovite authors to paint the word picture of the frustration in the Brooklyn Dodgers' clubhouse after yesterday's third beating by the Yankees.

ALICE DUER MILLER was somewhat of a phenomenon in her time. She wrote light novels designed primarily for feminine readers. From 1916, when her "Come Out of the Kitchen" became an immediate success, until her fairly recent death, she kept on turning out books of great popularity which got made into plays or movies or musical comedies.

NORTH CHATHAM, N. H. -This is the kind of vacation one often plans but seldom achieves. It is autumn foliage time and I have a front seat to thousands upon thousands of acres of beautiful scenery. It is like theatre-in-the-round with the positions reversed -- the spectator sitting in the middle of the bowl surrounded on all sides by one of the most gorgeous settings that nature unfolds.

NO matter flow sharply American and Soviet diplomats may dispute in the United Nations Council chamber, when they adjourn for cocktails and hors d'oeuvre they agree that Russia has at least one unexcelled good-will export.

The warmest weather since the last week in August -- with temperatures 11 degrees above normal -- moved into the city yesterday to send the mercury up to a high of 77 for the day at 3:10 P. M. The record for the date is 82, set in 1931.

LONDON, Oct. 8 (Reuters) -The Wolverhampton Wanderers, leaders in English soccer, today continued their unbeaten run, defeating Derby County, 2 -- 1. Liverpool, also undefeated, held second place with a 2-0 triumph over Middlesbrough.

WHEN Ferenc Molnar's "The Guardsman" opened twenty-five years ago this Thursday evening at the old Garrick Theatre, Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, playing the leading roles, were making their first appearance together on a Broadway stage.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- After three years of groundwork, right wing leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in California are bringing to a climax their fight to rid the CIO setup in the state of its left wingers accused of following the Communist party line.
