JACKSON'S MILL, W. Va. -Chronic motor vehicle accident repeaters, drivers with tendencies to emotional instability and personal maladjustments, are reported on the increase by Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of the Center for Safety Education at New York University.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 8 -Along the banks of the Severn this warm afternoon the Navy team came back in the last quarter to beat a slightly favored Duke eleven by 28 -- 14.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- "Take an American Senator. You press a button and he's a Republican. The weather changes -- he's a Democrat."

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Oct. 8 -- The project begun here this past summer to salvage one of the state's few remaining seventeenth century houses was shown today to about 1,000 members of the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society of Connecticut as a restoration in the making.

AUTOMOBILE and passenger service to Florida will be resumed early in November by the Refrigerated Steamship Line, which will start operation of its coastwise fruit service this fall after a two-year lapse. The line will run ships twice weekly, leaving New York Monday and Wednesday for Fort Pierce and Jacksonville from November to June.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 8 -- Four separate units of the United Nations are preparing to tackle the atomic control controversy and push it to the front as the world organization's No. 1 problem.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Pitt, fought off its feet for two periods, finally got going in the second half here today and turned back West Virginia's Mountaineers, 20 -- 7.

Russia appeared to be taking the offensive again last week. Pressures were stepped up on various fronts -in Germany, Yugoslavia, the Far East. The startling disclosure of three weeks ago -- that an atomic explosion had taken place inside the U.S.S.R. -seemed almost symbolic of the new Communist drive.
Two sons of Pensive, the 3-year-old Ponder and the 2-year-old Theory, collected $59,450 for Warren Wright's Calumet Farm at Belmont Park yesterday.

IN a few cities -- Boston, Philadelphia and Cleveland -- the orchestras have begun their new seasons. The New York Philharmonic-Symphony gets under way next Thursday, and most of the others in the nation, major and minor, professional, semi-professional and amateur, will be about their business of making music for their communities some time this month or next.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 8 -- The week-end and the world series combined left the United Nations General Assembly in the doldrums today.

Taking full advantage of their rivals' mistakes, Stuyvesant High routed Columbus of the Bronx, 28 -- 0, and Seward Park halted another Bronx foe, Evander Childs, 16 -- 0, in the scholastic double-header at Triborough Stadium yesterday.

The first announcement that the regular administration of cortisone dramatically benefited sufferers from rheumatoid arthritis and rheumatic fever was greeted with a storm of applause. But nothing like a detailed clinical report has so far been published. Dr. P. S. Hench and his colleagues of the Mayo Clinic, where the experiments were conducted, made it plain that they were presenting merely some of the metabolic effects of cortisone.

INGINIAGALA, Ceylon, Sept. 19 -- In common with all the underdeveloped countries of Asia, Ceylon is avid for the application of Western "know how" to her potentialities. The imagination and the ambition of all Ceylon have been fired by a spectacular demonstration of American methods in the building of the new Dominion's first major public works project, a large multi-purpose dam near this jungle village northeast of Colombo.

WHISTLEBLOW, Scotland, is the scene of this book, as it was in Miss Kyle's earlier and far better "Holley Hotel." Once again the story starts in Mollie Maitland's home, Holley Hotel, where a covey of children run down the mystery of the Mirror Room in near-by Castle Doone.

THE publishers call "A Family Matter" a book about a "good" woman -- and the quotes are theirs. It is difficult to imagine what standard of goodness they had in mind, because to the average reader Alice Ireland will seem like a monster of iniquity, so wicked as to be fairly unbelievable.

" OH, I love to talk to young men!" said Mary Garden on being introduced the other day. Whereupon she turned spryly on her heel and left the room, only to reappear with a long rope of pearls. "I thought I had lost my beads," she explained as she draped them about the necklace she already wore.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 8 -- The three-year deadlock on the international control of atomic energy, which had been expected to produce only routine debate at this session of the United Nations General Assembly, has regained outstanding attention as a result of President Truman's announcement that an "atomic explosion" had occurred in the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -Senate Democratic leader Scott W. Lucas of Illinois charged today that some Republicans were playing "gutter politics" with atomic energy.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 8 -- President Truman wrote to the editor of The People's Journal, a newspaper of Dundee, Scotland, about a week ago and requested more information about the tune to "Hail to The Chief," the flourish music played at every public appearance of the President.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 -- A backlog of 534 grievances between the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen and the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company, which four months ago threatened to precipitate a strike, has been completely settled.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Columbia University's president, told 2,500 university alumni and their families yesterday that "nothing can defeat Columbia." He spoke briefly at a picnic luncheon on the baseball diamond of the university's Baker's Field that was a highlight of the second annual fall homecoming of alumni.

EDWARD J. STEICHEN has received the award "for outstanding contributions to photography (over-all)" in the 1949 U. S. Camera Achievement Awards, Tom Maloney, editor-publisher of U. S. Camera Magazine, competition sponsor, announced last week.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 8 Blind Justice with evenly balanced scales in her hand has been discarded as a vestige of capitalism by the "people's democratic" regime of Czechoslovakia. In her place it is putting Marxism-Leninism, whose justice is heavily weighted in favor of "the working class."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 8 -- The Ministry of Foreign Affairs replied today to the Hungarian Government's note of Sept. 29 abrogating the twenty-year treaty of alliance by accusing the Budapest regime of having revived the "fascist" expansionist foreign policy of the pre-war Hungarian state.

Eight hundred persons, including 100 delegates from colleges, universities, and educational associations from all over America, will assemble on the Queens College quadrangle at 3 P. M. on Tuesday, to hear Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, deliver the principal address at the inauguration of Dr. John J. Theobald as the president of Queens College, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Henry W. Raudenbush Jr., chief marshal of Queens College.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Navy went on trial this week under the crystal chandeliers of the House Armed Services Committee room up on Capitol Hill.
TOKYO, Oct. 8 -- Japan has been assured of immediate United States help in rebuilding her war shattered merchant marine, it was announced today by Trade and Commerce Minister Heitaro Inagaki.

AAN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 8 -The longest winning streak compiled by a major college football team in twenty-five years ended today as Michigan, the nation's top-ranking eleven, was toppled by Army, 21 -- 7.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 8 -- The United Nations advisory committee on administrative and budgetary affairs has approved a $4,000,000 increase in the 1950 budgets of specialized agencies attached to the United Nations, it was announced here today, but it urged careful study of the use of the funds.

WHEN plans for fall garden work were made in September, the warm weeks ahead seemed to allow plenty of time for everything. Now, with two week-ends of October already past, the gardener has little margin for completing the several odd jobs that must be done before frost.

HONOLULU, Oct. 8 -- All Hawaii waited impatiently today for the beginning of a hoped-for return of normal seagoing commerce with the mainland of the United States after being isolated for more than five months by a dock strike.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- Sixty thousand West Berliners demonstrated today against the formation of a Soviet-donated Eastern German Government claiming jurisdiction for all Germany. Swarming the plaza in front of the Schoeneberg district town hall, they made it clear that they were disposed to assume the offensive against absorption into what they termed a "Soviet protectorate."

An unusual mishap stopped northbound express traffic on the IRT at the Fourteenth Street station briefly yesterday afternoon when a motorman, telephoning for clearance on a mixed signal from the track level, was struck by a southbound train.

JUST a hundred years ago today, Oct. 9, an unencumbered writing man, wishing to get a better view of the ocean than he had yet had, started for Cape Cod on a visit which produced a celebrated book and a prophecy which we have seen come true in our generation.

IN a book somewhat resembling a silent motion picture, an American newspaper man and a free lance photographer present this bit of fiction from Japan. The story was acted out in the village of Odawara, by a small group of Japanese children and adults.

ANYONE who deals professionally with books, and, more broadly, anyone to whom they mean a great deal, must sometimes ask himself, What is literature? The word itself is one of those which defy precise definition as we try to approach the essential nature of what the word stands for when we use it to designate a superior kind of writing.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 8 -- An underdog Princeton eleven matched Pennsylvania's two touchdowns today, but failure to convert after their initial score cost the Tigers a well-deserved tie, the decision in a tense and bruising battle going to the Quakers by a 14-13 count.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Democratic National Committee's grass roots campaign for Senate confirmation of Leland Olds as a member of the Federal Power Commission was carried today to Democratic Governors and Mayors throughout the country.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Taking the lead at the outset and widening it as his rider pleased, James Cox Brady's Casemate today zoomed to a five-length victory in the second running of the $10,000 added New Jersey Stallion Stakes at Garden State Park.

YONKERS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Two 9-year-old boys trying to cover up the accidental shooting of one by the other sent police on a futile thirty-minute hunt today for a supposed maniac before the hoax was exposed.

How much radiation can a man stand and live? Experts on the subject differ, as a survey of twenty-four leading radiologists and radiological physicists shows. The survey was conducted by Dr. Robert R. Newell of Stanford University's Medical School, who headed a subcommittee of the Radiological Society of North America.

ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- Chairman Benjamin F. Feinberg of the Public Service Commission announced today that improvement in the natural gas supply throughout the state would permit thousands of additional customers to obtain gas for house heating this winter.

HAVANA, Oct. 3 -- In the face of rising public indignation, the Cuban Government is striving to break the power of the revolutionary groups that have been using the streets of Havana for a private battleground during the past several years.

Last week, H. Cornell Smith, president of D. A. Schulte, Inc., predicted that by the end of 1952 that large cigar store chain will be doing about 80 per cent of its total business in men's and women's furnishings. This emphasized the growing trend toward greater diversification in many types of retail outlets.

Modification of the present statutory restrictions in New York State on trust investments is now likely to be sought actively by trust company executives, it was learned yesterday. For nearly three years a special committee has been at work on the project, and its report is scheduled to be published at the end of next week.

RICHMOND, Oct. 8 -- Cautious buyers are giving Fifth District retailers serious concern. Weather and labor unsettlement share the blame for an unexpected slowdown. Lingering warm weather is retarding apparel sales, but the economic uncertainty is reflected sharply in most other lines.
Your captious review (Sept. 23) of the motion picture "That Midnight Kiss" was read with considerable interest by the writer.
Arthur Boecher is one young New York University student who won't have to listen in embarrassed silence when his ex-GI fraternity brothers spin tales of overseas experiences.

The American Friends Service Committee, which on Oct. 1 entered a new fiscal year, plans under a revised budget to give special attention to American community problems in economic, racial and international relations and in slum areas as well as young people's social and industrial problems.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 8 (AP) -- American Federation of Labor political leaders today added four Southern Democratic Senators to the nine Republicans the AFL already had ticketed for defeat in the 1950 elections.

" THE Last Enchantments" is the fifth novel by a young English writer and -- with the exception of "Kind Relations," brought out in 1939 under the imprint of a very small house -- the first to be published here. Solely on the evidence of the present book, and the mature talent it represents, one must wonder what our major publishing houses were thinking of when Mr. Liddell's earlier novels appeared in England.

AS the author of "Street Scene," "Counselor-at-Law," "The Adding Machine" and more than twenty other produced plays, Elmer Rice has earned a considerable reputation. His Hollywood novel, "Imperial City" (1937), was a popular success, too, although the more exacting critics found it less than excellent.

HERE are barnyard comedy and drama based on a real-life incident. The cast includes Goldie, a frustrated, broody hen; Cockleroo, a lordly rooster, and Yellowhammer, as bedraggled an orphan kitten as ever needed a friend.

DEVON, Pa., Oct. 8 -- A Pekingese from England, Champion Dah-Lyn Kaijin of Caversham, went to best in show in the 623dog thirty-seventh all-breeds event of the Devon Dog Show Association as darkness was falling over the horse Show grounds today.
DUNDEE, Scotland, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Dundee's weekly newspaper said today President Truman had asked it to tell him all about the history of the tune "Hail to the Chief."

TIME is running out for many a wild boar, bear and fox that live in the Cherokee National Forest of Tennessee and in the hunting areas of North Carolina. The organized hunts that are an autumn feature of that section of the country will soon be under way.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 8 -Stepping off into the victory column, Fordham turned in a 44-9 football triumph over the United States Merchant Marine Academy today before 6,000 at Tomb Memorial Field.

A thorough revision of New York's program for dealing with truants is recommended in a significant year-long study, "Children Absent From School," which was made public last week by the Citizens' Committee on Children of New York City. The committee proposed a complete overhauling of the Board of Education's Bureau of Attendance to bring its philosophy in line with current educational needs.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 8 -A fortnight ago 850 members of the Rutgers University faculty and administrative staff participated in an all-day "self-evaluation" convention. At twenty-seven committee meetings, the staff investigated and appraised the university's educational philosophy, physical need academic shortcomings, personnel procedures, research programs and student life.
IOWA CITY, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Underdog Illinois, led by Sophomore Johnny Karras upset Iowa, 20 -- 14, today in a Big Ten Conference football game.

On Friday the State of Indiana brought to its climax what had been proclaimed as James Whitcomb Riley Centennial Year. The most beloved of Indiana's poets was born on Oct. 7, 1849, and it was on Oct. 7 that the actual anniversary was celebrated. But Governor Gates had declared that the entire year should be marked by celebrations of tribute and by additional support for the Riley Hospital Cheer Guild.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Indianapolis Indians won the Little World Series tonight by hammering five Montreal pitchers for a 12-2 victory. Tile decision gave the American Association team the series, four games to two.

That Paul Robeson, despite his alleged Communist sympathies and allies, had a right to sing at the Lakeland picnic grounds near Peekskill, Westchester County, N. Y., on Aug. 28 and also in the same area on Sept. 4, all fair-minded persons will readily agree. By the same token, the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars had a right to parade in protest of the concert.

IF it is necessary to take on temporarily some of the techniques of fascism in order to wage a war successfully against totalitarianism, perhaps it is also necessary to abolish the democratic process in bringing to trial those defeated generals who waged war against us.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 8 -- Both the Dutch and the Indonesians are considering new proposals from the United Nations Conciliation Commission to break the impasse in the round table conference.

Mrs. Bess Bernard, 44 years old, of 825 West End Avenue, who is being investigated for her alleged connections with a black market in babies, will be arraigned today in Felony Court on charges of felonious assault, resisting arrest and preventing an officer from performing his duty.

A BOOK of extravagant adventure, "Weeds of Violence" falls into two distinct parts -- one about whaling in the early part of the nineteenth century, the other about life in the South Pacific islands. The whaling episodes are distinctly the better, rousing and realistic.

WARSAW, Oct. 2 -- Polish pedagogues have been cautioned not to overlook any possibility of injecting "political significance" into their spelling and arithmetic classes. While Polish teachers have easily recognized the significance of the political approach in history books, they have failed to learn that every textbook constitutes a "political problem," the newspaper Trybunu Ludu stated recently.

Gilbert Sullivan and the Eagle Pencil Company no longer have a common interest in "The Mikado." For reasons that appeared in demands from hundreds of customers soon after Pearl Harbor, the world's largest pencil company swapped the "k" in Mikado for an "r."

AS a roving contributor to The Reader's Digest, Paul de Kruif has been telling some millions of his readers exciting stories of the triumphs scored in clinical research. In "Life Among the Doctors" he whips the stories into book form.

A 53-year-old housewife told the police last night that two robbers, one armed, had locked her in a linen closet yesterday in her Bronx home, opened a small bedroom safe and then escaped with $8,000 and a quantity of jewelry.

NARCISSUS and tulips are the mainstays of the spring garden. During April and May they supply the bulk of color and seem to relegate all other plants to a secondary role. They are, of course, planted during the fall.

PARKSVILLE, N. Y. -- The New York State Winter Sports Council held what was generally regarded as its most successful convention here at the Youngs Gap Hotel last week-end. Following three days of panels and discussions attended by hundreds of resort operators and hotel keepers, the over-all consensus was that this state is going to make a determined bid to regain the supremacy lost to New England in the winter sports field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Members of the House, responding to pressure back home greater, perhaps, than anything that has been seen in the Eighty-first Congress, voted overwhelmingly this week to expand social security coverage and benefits for millions of American voters.

A "COOLING off" period was the only treatment applied to the steel deadlock which last week shut down 90 per cent of the industry. This prescription may very well mean that the recent business upturn will start to "cool off" too, as large segments of purchasing power are nipped off by the frost of steel shortages.

Each of the twenty-one voluntary hospitals participating today in Brooklyn's first annual Hospital Sunday will demonstrate for visitors a special phase of its work, it was announced yesterday by Emil N. Baar, general chairman of the Brooklyn Division of the United Hospital Fund.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed tweed skirts, misses' coats, umbrellas and Chinese modern furniture, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 8 -- Scoring twice in the second half, the Amherst College football team came from behind to defeat Bowdoin, 14 -- 7, before 5,500 fans at Pratt Field today.
OTTAWA, Oct. 8 -- Both Canadian labor organizations have, during the past weeks, solemnly repudiated the left-wing sympathizers with communism among them and re-elected their old leaders.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- Officials of Western and Eastern German trade organizations signed today an agreement to exchange goods valued at 432,000,000 Deutsche marks ($112,816,000) during the next nine months.

RETURNING to this country after spending fifteen months studying with Pablo Casals in Southern France near the Spanish border and finding such a dearth of information and host of misconceptions concerning this great artist's voluntary exile and retirement, I would like to shed some light on a subject so vital to us all.

Almost nine months have elapsed since eleven top leaders of the Communist party, U.S.A., came to trial before Judge Harold R. Medina in the Federal Courthouse in Foley Square. Twelve were under indictment, but the case of William Z. Foster, party chairman, was severed because he was suffering from a heart ailment.

HENRI RABAUD, composer of "Marouf," died in Paris on Sept. 11 at the age of 75. The dispatches said he had suffered a long illness, but nevertheless he succeeded in completing a new opera before his death. It is based on Marivaux's famous eighteenth century comedy, "Le jeu le l'amour et du hasard," and will be one of the two new operas being premiered this season by the Paris Opera-Comique.

Mayor O'Dwyer charged yesterday that the administration headed by the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia had neglected the city's waterfront facilities and other public works because it allotted so much of the city's capital resources to an "over-emphasized" airport development program.

THE winning team was scoring virtually at will and the coach of the losers in desperation finally sent in his biggest and dumbest line-backer in an attempt to halt the artfully masked T-formation attack of the opposition. The big oaf took his position, stolidly ignored decoys and solidly slapped down the genuine ball-carrier for a five-yard loss.

The brokerage fraternity was called to task last week by one of its own members in Washington when the advertising manager of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane charged that the brokers themselves were to blame for the failure of the public to invest in stocks during the last three years of "bargain levels."

The fight for freedom on economic front in this country will not be won unless women give their support, Arthur H. Motley, president of Parade Publication, Inc., declared yesterday at the opening celebration of National Business Women's Week, which begins today.

The oil and chemical industries using steel shipping containers will be seriously affected by shortages resulting from the steel strike before the end of October. L. B. Keplinger, president of the Steel Shipping Container Institute, Inc., said yesterday that if the strike continues after the end of this month the shortage of containers will be critical, with the supply of new containers expected to be exhausted before the end of November.

Twelve more world series ticket speculators were arrested yesterday as part of the pre-game police activities at Ebbets Field. One of those taken was a woman who allegedly sold a ticket to a plainclothes policeman in the rotunda of the baseball park.

NOW, when the palominos and pintos are in town, local boys and girls of 6 to 9 will be especially interested in this book. Those who have already seen a rodeo in the West will delight in recapturing the heady excitement of that unique American institution.
Your picture in the letters columns of "wonderful looking" Joe DiMaggio would look even more wonderful if it were of him and not of the equally wonderful Tommy Henrich.

AN important expansion in the field of color motion pictures was indicated last week by the disclosure by Karl Herzog, executive vice president of the Cinecolor Corporation, that his company has undertaken to process release prints for three-color, live-action feature films at a price of 5 cents a foot -- which is 1.22 cents below the rate of the Technicolor Company, heretofore the lowest priced three-color laboratory in the industry.

An answer to one of the most challenging questions of post-war finance -- how the nation's public-utility plant is to broaden its equity base for permanently expanded operations -- is unfolding slowly in Wall Street, but in ways that few financiers could have foreseen at the end of the war and that nobody would have imagined two decades ago.

A record installation of new materials handling equipment is now planned for 1950 in the 23,000 offices, sorting stations and transfer depots of the Railway Express Agency, C. C. Peterson, its chief engineer, revealed last week. The new devices are required to improve customer service in handling more than 10,000,000 individual shipments a day throughout these offices.

The weekly recorded concert held at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will not be heard on Columbus Day. The Main Reading Room and Information Desk will be open as usual from 9 A. M. to 10 P. M. Several divisions will close for the day and others for part of the day, but material from them may be reserved in advance and consulted in the Main Reading Room.

A record volume of purchasing of American gas equipment is now scheduled as part of a nation-wide gas-plant modernization program in Italy, Virgil Stark, president, North American Utility and Construction Corporation, 415 Lexington Avenue, revealed here yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 17 -- The United States housing situation is in a "catastrophic" state and United States architecture reflects the "disintegration and rotting of art," according to an article in Izvestia by V. Kusakov, corresponding member of the Academy of Architecture of the U.S.S.R.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 8 (UP) -- Boston University scored three touchdowns through the air and three more on the ground today to outclass Colgate, 40 to 21.
WITH this new novel Sholem Asch completes a trilogy begun in "The Nazarene" and continued in "The Apostle" that represents by far the most distinguished work in the New Testament field

RICHMOND, Oct. 8 -- It was a troubled week in the Upper South. In southwest Virginia, striking coal miners stirred with resentment against the plans of Gov. William M. Tuck to use state highway equipment in strip-mining coal. In Roanoke, steel workers were out. In Tarboro, N. C., violence flared in the five-month-old strike of the Hart Cotton Mills.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 8 -Wesleyan eked out a 12-to-6 victory over a Coast Guard Academy eleven today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- John L. Lewis and the soft-coal operators agreed today to meet next Wednesday for resumption of negotiations on the United Mine Workers' demands for higher wages, a shorter work-week and larger welfare contributions.

Up to the first of October, 33,144 cases of poliomyelitis had been reported this year. Last year there were 27,908, then a record. This year's epidemic is therefore the worst the country has ever known. By the end of the year the number of cases probably will reach 40,000. For the first time since July 30 there have been fewer than 2, 000 new cases a week.

Soviet housing construction is still lagging behind requirements and new construction is at a pace that is still outdistanced by the growth of the urban population in the Soviet Union, according to statements and figures in recent issues of the Soviet press and broadcasts of the Soviet radio.

With registration for the election on Nov. 8 beginning in New York City and Westchester County tomorrow, the organizations of all four legal political parties, Democratic, Republican, Liberal and American Labor, have arranged for special efforts this week to bring out a large registration.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 -- The Truman Administration is trying to extricate the national economy from a double squeeze in which Mr. Truman's enemy, John L. Lewis, is tightening one end of the vise and his friend, Philip Murray, the other.

THIS document on Father Edward Joseph Flanagan, patron saint to the American waif, gives the curious illusion that the subject is seen through restless water. Miniature tide-rips (literary flashbacks, mostly) keep ruffling the image so that it is never clear.

That the duties of a sales manager today encompass a range undreamed of ten or fifteen years ago is demonstrated in the Intensive Sales Development and Management Course which opened for its third term last week at the City College Midtown Center, 430 West Fiftieth Street.

Temporary suspension of Florida's new citrus law by injunction will have little effect on the local market at this time, members of the food industry declared yesterday. The law was aimed at reducing the amount of unripe fruit shipped at the beginning of the season and called for label registration of canned goods to guarantee quality.

Formation of a customs union and export bloc embracing most of Western Europe as well as Western Germany is in the making as a result of the British devaluation of the pound sterling, Robert Bollack, French economist and president of the Syndicate of the Economic Press of France, declared here last week.
Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for that post, will start tomorrow on his fourth up-State trip, Alger B. Chapman, his campaign manager, announced yesterday.
OMAHA, Oct. 8 -- Midwest farmers were engaged in an exciting race with time this week to provide adequate storage space for a bumper corn crop.

A spurt of buying of worsted lines for women's spring apparel has resulted in a sold-up worsted position for major mills for the balance of the year, it was learned last week. Some mills have withdrawn their lines on both men's and women's worsteds while others are taking orders for February delivery at the earliest.

FANNIE COOK'S fifth novel, set against the background of St. Louis during the depression of the Nineteen Thirties is a paean to the masculinity of Tom Carr. Protagonist Carr, a great-fisted, muscular young man nearly as broad as he is tall, delivers his lines in a shout and about as often as not his eyes are black with fury.

IN Princeton's University Library, memorial to Harvey S. Firestone, will open tomorrow a show entitled "Drawn From Life: Original Portraits by S. J. Woolf." It represents three decades of Woolf's activities in catching the celebrities of this generation in the mirror contrived by his pencil and his pen.

The restoration of Atlantic salmon rivers along our northern coast has been a slow and difficult process, but the report of the Atlantic Sea-Run Salmon Commission indicates that real progress has been made in several of the Maine rivers.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 8 -- A bright sun, casting unseasonal warmth on the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains, confirmed President Truman's claim to expertness in weather forecasting and won him a fifty-cent bet from his hostess, Mrs. Stanley Woodward.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Abe Stern, "small-town cop" who was elected president of the New York State Association of Police Chiefs last July, said tonight that he was much affected by being mobbed, even though it occurred in a nice way and not in line of duty.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 8 (UP) -- A Yankee wingback named Fred Sherman led North Carolina to a hard-won 28-to-13 victory over South Carolina today with some help from the fabulous Charley Justice.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UP) -- The Army today announced development of a compact radiation-detecting device for use by both military and civil defense organizations after an atomic bomb blast.

TURIN, Italy, Oct. 4 -- In the all-important struggle to modernize European industry, and modernize it rapidly, while the Marshall Plan lasts, the Italian automotive industry is further ahead than most of its competitors seem to realize.

BELGRADE, Oct. 8 -- The Soviet Government's campaign to overthrow Marshal Tito's regime in Yugoslavia has entered the domain of spectacular and dramatic gestures such as the abrogation of treaties of alliance and mass expulsion of Yugoslav diplomatic personnel from the capitals of the Eastern European bloc.

CHATTANOOGA, Oct. 8 -- A glance at a map of the world reveals that the Tennessee Valley is about as far removed from Russia as any other part of the United States, and that situation gives rise to the belief that this section of the country eventually will become the new arsenal of America.

DETROIT, Oct. 8 -- Activity in Congress toward increasing Federal security benefits is the most important result of the recently negotiated contract between the Ford Motor Company and the CIO United Automobile Workers, in which the workers won a company-financed pension plan, Walter P. Reuther, UAW president, told some 1,000,000 members today.

There was a time when a man could go around armed. Then the community forbade it except by permit. There was a time when you could shout at the top of your voice or through a loudspeaker. Then the community said this is not free speech, but a nuisance.
Before he was tossed into action to save the fourth game of the world series yesterday at Ebbets Field, Allie Reynolds was tossed off the bench in the Yankee dugout.

WHEN Tommy Henrich hit his home run to topple huge Don Newcombe in the opening game of the world series on a dull, gray, threatening afternoon, the Brooklyn Eagle mischievously used the headline, "It Shoulda Rained." Yesterday was the first gloriously bright day the post-season classic has had, but hearts were heavy in Flatbush because only a downpour could have saved their beloved Burns from the extinction to which they seem inevitably heading.

The Continental Oil Company set table during a snowfall yesterday for luncheon guests in its new 55,000-barrel oil tank at Billings, Mont. John W. Bonner, Governor of the Treasure State, addressed several thousand persons who gathered at the dedication of the largest Continental plant in the Rockies.
Author of "The Browning Version," opening Wednesdays, "The Winslow Boy" and other plays.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The alumni association of the Catholic University of America announced the creation today of a Cardinal Gibbons Medal for distinguished and meritorious service to the Roman Catholic Church, to the United States or to the university.

With the help of flawless relief pitching by Allie Reynolds, the Yankees beat the Dodgers, 6 -- 4, at Ebbets Field yesterday and gained a 3-1 lead in games in the world series. They need only one more triumph to win the baseball classic.

Benjamin Feldman, the Brooklyn pharmacist whose two previous first-degree murder convictions were reversed by the State Court of Appeals, will go on trial tomorrow for the third time. He is accused of poisoning his wife, Harriet, with strychnine in 1943.

The most ambitious expansion program in the history of the oil industry is contemplated by the end of 1952 by American, British and Dutch oil companies in areas outside North America and Eastern Europe. According to figures submitted to the Economic Cooperations Administration, these companies plan expenditures in that period of two to three billion dollars.

NOW that Cezanne and Van Gogh, Matisse and Picasso are accepted and fashionable masters of modern art, their work finds plush settings in the homes of nouveau collectors. In one Hollywood mansion, for instance, the paintings hang in rooms with gold-plated (or are they 14-karat?) door handles and one of the best pictures slides back into the wall to allow a movie projector to show the studio's latest offering.

VIENNA, Oct. 8 -- Austria's second general election campaign since the war's end closed tonight with parties of the right and left angling for the pre-war Nazi vote, the conservative People's party denouncing its Socialist opponents as midwives of communism and the Communists predicting ruin from a devaluation of the Austrian schilling on orders of the United States.
The Brooklyn Heights link of the Brooklyn-Queens Connecting Highway "is now virtually completed," Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn announced yesterday.

Ten series of concerts headed by the Boston Symphony under Charles Munch, and five separate recitals will be presented by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences this season, it was announced yesterday. All the events will take place in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

WHILE they are not committed to any one particular film venture, the movie future of Fredric March and Florence Eldridge (Mrs. March) definitely is bright. Last week the pair, looking no more like Columbus and Queen Isabella than Fredric March and Florence Eldridge, pointed out that despite certain hazards encountered during the filming of "Christopher Columbus'" they were seriously contemplating appearing in one or, possibly, two films next year.

While stressing that the physically handicapped were able to hold their own in various phases of employment, Miss Ann Lehman, senior consultant for the handicapped of the New York State Employment Service, emphasized yesterday the need for a greater expansion of recreational facilities for the disabled.

I am a little surprised by a story in your column "Europe Laughs," based on the revenge of an untipped usher in an English theatre. I have known the English theatre for twenty years and never yet have I known an usher to expect a tip. In Paris and Brussels a tip is expected and demanded. Unless London has changed since 1939, one bought a program but sat down without any other tip.

It would he interesting to hear what Casey Jones, the brave locomotive engineer, would have to say about the dictum of the President's panel of experts in the steel wage dispute -- namely, that depreciation in the man in industry is to be regarded "in much the same way" as depreciation in the machine. Casey had a locomotive that was good for thirty years and cost around $100,000.

THE successful fight demonstration last week of the Canadian designed and built Avro Jetliner has sharpened a question American aircraft manufacturers and airline operators have been asking themselves for the last two years: Has the United States delayed too long in entering the field of jet passenger-plane development, and, if so, how long will it take and how much will it cost to catch up with Great Britain and Canada?

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 8 (AP) -- California's bruising Bears powered to three touchdowns on the ground and two more through the air today to whip Wisconsin, 35 -- 20, in an intersectional football game under a blistering sun at Camp Randall Stadium.

In addition to voting for a United States Senator and municipal officials, the electorate next month will pass on eight proposed amendments to the State Constitution and three propositions involving state aid for public housing.
SPRAYING and dusting equipment can soon be cleaned up and put away for the winter with a clear conscience. A few battles, however, still need to be fought with plant pests and diseases.

IT is somewhat unusual to read in a geography textbook for university students about deviationists "foaming at their mouth," about "capitulationists" opposing some industrial project, and about saboteurs "struggling against the introduction of local fuel."
HONG KONG, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Two United States fliers held a year by the Chinese Communists are imprisoned at Tsingtao, officers of the Panamanian merchant ship Eastern Trader said today.

BEING a cowboy entertainer who neither sings nor plays a guitar is one of the major distinctions about Bob Dixon -- known as Sheriff Bob on the "Chuck Wagon" television series on WCBS-TV. Ordinarily, such a fellow might be left tied up like a calf in front of an audience, but not Dixon.

" A DETECTIVE novel," wrote S. S. Van Dine in 1928, "should contain no long descriptive passages, no literary dallying with side-issues, no subtly worked-out character analyses, no 'atmospheric' preoccupations." And Ellery Queen, making his debut the following year, loyally obeyed Van Dine's dictum.

In a hall in the Soviet sector of Berlin last Friday afternoon Wilhelm Pieck, Communist leader, stood on a platform and announced: "The People's Council has proclaimed itself the People's Chamber of Parliament." The 2,000 persons in the hall, some of them Russian army officers in civilian clothes, cheered.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Wheat and corn sold off on the Board of Trade today, although the largest declines were reduced in a rally which started shortly before the close. The July wheat contract showed the most weakness throughout the session, falling more than 2 cents a bushel before making a slight recovery.

The Educational Policies Commission, whose membership includes Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, and James B. Conant, head of Harvard University, declared last night that state laws requiring special loyalty oaths of teachers were a menace to educational freedom.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8 -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad and its striking operating employes will start negotiating their differences Monday morning under a plan which Gov. Forrest Smith of Missouri, one of its sponsors, believes will end the walkout within a week.

FELIPE and his father, the Duke de Torres, were determined to forestall the efforts of Manila's new governor to rob the merchants and people of the city. Sixteen-year-old Felipe discovered the details of the governor's plot, was captured, kidnapped and placed aboard a galleon sailing for New Spain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Development of a new type of portable earth-shock detector -- described as capable of detecting earthquakes and powerful explosions over a world-wide range -was reported today.

WASHINGTON. THERE is new hope among men who know the land that within the lifetime of most of us we can dispel the ubiquitous ghost of Thomas Robert Malthus, the gloomy English clergyman economist who envisaged a world in constant misery and want because it could not produce enough food to match the rate of population growth.

Michael Joseph Phillips has been appointed general manager of the new industrial division of Greer Hydraulics, Inc., of Brooklyn. He was formerly manufacturing vice president of the Universal Business Machine Company and assistant to the president of Jack Heintz Precision Industries, Inc.

THIS is the story of Danny, of Danny's father who loved to hunt but whistled so loudly he scared all of the game away; of Aunt Vanilla and her cookstove; of Henry the hound-dog; Mabel the cross-eyed eat and Bello the mule.

Residents of Harlem suffer disproportionately from inadequate housing, poor sanitation, lower wages, greater unemployment and restricted educational opportunities, speakers stressed yesterday afternoon at a conference for Health Care Without Discrimination in the Theresa Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 125th Street.

On Sept. 29 THE NEW YORK TIMES carried a Washington report that the House Rules Committee had tabled H. R. 4846, a bill to establish a National Science Foundation. The report stated further that action on H. R. 4846 during this session was unlikely.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 8 -- Chinese Communist armies may soon assist North Korean Communist troops in an invasion of South Korea, China's Ambassador to Korea, Shao Yu-lin, declared today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and of the United Steelworkers of America, announced plans tonight to put the steel union's case for company-supported pensions before the public.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 8 -- A modest but important beginning was made this week in translating the dream of Benelux into reality. This phase, known as "pre-union," was inaugurated with the signing of an agreement lifting all controls on more than one-third of the trade between Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

Reflecting the recent upsurge in business activity, employer job requests to private employment agencies for top production and distribution executives have increased appreciably in the last sixty days, Maude Lennox, head of the personnel recruitment organization bearing her name, revealed in an interview last week.

PLANS are completed for the Department of Defense to produce a weekly radio series on national security in cooperation with the ABC network beginning Tuesday, Oct. 25, from 10 to 10:30 P. M. Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson said the program will "give the radio audience an opportunity to learn about the latest developments and accomplishments in the realm of national security."

IN its current exhibition, "Modern Art in Your Life," the Museum of Modern Art, as part of its twentieth anniversary program, is in effect rather elaborately demonstrating a truism. That the life of a given time is necessarily reflected in its art, architecture, industrial design and in the make-up of a thousand things in daily living, it would seem, hardly needs to be said.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Senator Millard E. Tydings, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and a leading Congressional architect of the Atlantic pact, acknowledged here today that the defensive strength of Britain, France, Belgium and the Netherlands was "not as good" as he had hoped it would be.

THE designs of the 10c and 25c airmail stamps to be issued by the United States as its contribution toward observance of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Universal Postal Union were announced last week by Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson.

THIS short novel is readable, in the sense that it moves smoothly and rapidly toward its quite predictable climax. Its protagonist, Hank Sturgis, a drifting, casual he-man who is indifferent to the women he so effortlessly attracts, is definitely a man of parts.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Governor Dewey charged tonight that the Federal Government "robs the state of most" of the money it collects for administration of the unemployment insurance program.

LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Fish swam last night in flooded gutters at Dartmouth, England, from a local cloudburst; but a London reservoir with a capacity of 4,400,000,000 gallons of water is today bone dry.
HAVANA, Oct. 3 -- Cuba, long desirous of creating a national merchant marine, recently granted a six-year tax exemption to any company that would operate vessels under the Cuban flag.

There is nothing static about it, which is one of its more dangerous features.

The Donets Basin, largest single source of Soviet coal, has achieved approximately the pre-war rate of production and is expected to exceed it shortly, according to an issue of Pravda Ukraina that has just reached this country.

THE title of this volume is appropriate, for Sarah Truax not only has played the lead part in nearly one hundred and fifty major stock company tours throughout this country and Canada, but she seems to have done it with unusual modesty and poise.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- Sales reported for last week by women's apparel stores here were 16 per cent les than a year ago. For the four-week period they were off 14 per cent. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled only 83,473, as against 146,584 a year ago, a decrease of 43.1 per cent.

DECORATING the home with dried arrangements is a hobby that is growing by leaps and bounds every year. What is behind this ever-increasing interest in dried materials? Without a doubt, the answer is summed up in one word -- color.

CASTLE ROCK, Wash. -- In a cathedral-like grove of Douglas fir trees one of the West's great recreational areas will be dedicated next weekend to the memory of the first Chief Forester of the United States.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 8 (UP) -- A rejuvenated Penn State team smothered Boston College's passing attack for a 32-to-14 football victory before 16,000 fans today.

WITH two concurrent exhibitions devoted to French nineteenth and twentieth century masters the winter art season may be said to be well under way.

THE old saying that there is no such thing as a bad Western movie may have a new corollary: There is no such thing as a red-blooded one. Producers are facing a disturbing fact: the new economy measures are striking fresh and serious blows at the shootin'-rootin'-tootin' quality of Westerns.

PANDIT JAWAHARLAL NEHRU, Prime Minister of India, arrives in the United States this week and the American public will see for the first time the world's most popular individual -- if a man's popularity can be measured by the spontaneous response of his countrymen. Crowds of a million and more in moderate-sized cities of India are no novelty for him.

Combined effects of the world series, poor weather and adverse psychology generated by strikes cut retail trade volume here last week. Estimates put the decline in department store sales at 15 per cent or more under ast year.

Mrs. Marion Bellard has been head usher at Town Hall -- right in the heart of the Broadway area, at 123 West Forty-third Street -- for twenty-seven years. And over those years she estimates that she has heard 13,500 concerts -- "most of excellent quality and not to overlook a few indifferent ones."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 -- Although the St. Louis metropolitan area is fortunate in having two moderate sized steel companies whose operations are continuing without interruption during the strike, some uneasiness prevails here, inasmuch as this area normally consumes more steel than it produces.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 8 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, announced today a 40 per cent increase in the number of cooperative farms of the Soviet Kolkhoz model between March and the middle of September.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- United States and British officials will begin a new campaign to win French agreement to the inclusion of Western Berlin in the German Federal Republic as a counter-stroke to the establishment of a German Communist Government, authoritative sources said today.

The dismissal of monopoly charges against two North Atlantic steamship freight conferences, recommended last week by a Maritime Commission trial examiner, was described yesterday by Hans J. Isbrandtsen, president of Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., as "far from conclusive."

It should, however, be the gardener's choice, rather than nature's.

Designer Paul Bry has recently demonstrated that some thought to space, furniture arrangement and color can turn an unpretentious cottage into a comfortable -- if miniature -- home in the country.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va. -With summer's heat gone from central Virginia, tourists interested in America's past find two good reasons for visiting in comfort this little city fifty miles south of Washington. HONG KONG, Oct. 8 -- The National Government's Executive Yuan, or Cabinet, meeting in Canton today, passed an order calling for the arrest of Mme. Sun Yatsen, widow of the founder of the Chinese Republic. Along with Mme. Sun, the Canton order called for the arrest of eighty-three top Communists and their collaborators.

The Brooklyn Museum and surrounding property at Eastern Parkway and Washington Avenue would be expanded into a many-sided cultural center for Brooklyn, according to plans now being weighed by city officials and officers of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Employment and payrolls in Chicago showed little change during August. But in individual industries there was a divergence of trends. Industries displaying large gains in employment and payrolls included fruit and vegetable canning, saw and planing mills and the manufacturing of glass and glass products, sheet iron and tin plate, boots and shoes and confectionery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Paul Robeson, Negro baritone and outspoken supporter of the Soviet Union and communism, will appear here Oct. 13 as speaker and singer at a Negro freedom rally, it was announced today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8 -- Cornell survived an uncertain start to move on to its expected victory over the Harvard football team today. Spotting the home forces a touchdown in the early stages of play, the Big Red eleven from Ithaca came back sturdily to register a 33-to-14 triumph over the Cantabs.

MANTOLOKING, N. J. -- This village of less than five hundred people has been the scene of frenzied doings in weeks past. Usually shore towns can look forward to an undisturbed rest after Labor Day. This year the Barnegat country is having a solid influx of visitors in the fall.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Sophomore Halfback Ronald Clark wheeled back the opening kick-off 100 yards as the Nebraska Cornhuskers scored two touchdowns on two electrifying plays to defeat Kansas State's Wildcats, 13 -- 6, in a Big Seven Conference football game today.

Hirsch points out that Theodor Heuss, the new Western German chief of state, was a "loyal disciple and intimate collaborator of the late Friedrich Naumann." A ONE-WEEK exhibit of paintings by Eva Melady will open at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on Thursday, Fall Rose Day. Originals for the illustrations of Dr. Cynthia Westcott's "The Gardener's Bug Book," they will be on display in Room 306 of the Administration Building, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, until Oct. 19.
THE operators of WOR-TV will indulge in a bit of sentimentality in connection with the start of regularly scheduled programs for the new station at 6:55 P. M. on Tuesday.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 8 -Completely outplaying the home side in the second half, Wagner registered its second triumph of the campaign with a 19-to-6 victory over Hofstra today.
NEW price reductions have been announced by three manufacturers. Keystone Manufacturing Company has lowered the price of its 8mm Keystone K-36 camera with f/3.5 Wollensak lens from $54.95 to $49.95.

WARSAW, Oct. 8 -- Poland's citizen militia is undergoing a new purge of "alien and accidental elements," General J. Konarzewski, Commander in Chief of the militia, disclosed today in the Army newspaper Polska Zbroja.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, was among many prelates who took part this afternoon in a solemn ceremony in Notre Dame Cathedral during which the Most Rev. Maurice Feltin was enthroned as Archbishop of Paris.

FLEUR d'AMOUR, a comparative newcomer to florist shops, is now fast achieving popularity with the amateur greenhouse gardener as well. The sturdy plants bear pure white blooms (about the size of a twenty-five-cent piece) which resemble miniature gardenias, if anything.

THE popular, mistaken and lasting legend that dramatic critics hate the theatre and theatregoing is magnificently disproved in Ward Morehouse's gallant salute to the national institution, "Matinee Tomorrow," an affectionate and nostalgic backward glance at the American theatre's career during the past fifty years.

THE author's note at the head of this book is dated July 8, 1949, at which time Chairman Lilienthal of the Atomic Energy Commission was in the midst of an investigation stirred up by Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper of Iowa in the hope that charges of "incredible mismanagement" could be made to stick. They didn't stick, for there was no foundation for them.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange Saturday was featured yesterday by steadiness. Closing prices were 3 points higher to 3 points lower than the day before.
BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- New England transportation men are expressing concern over post-war methods of merchandising as a threat to their region's economy.

JERICHO, Palestine, Oct. 8--King Abdullah of Jordan said today Jerusalem would be internationalized only over his dead body.

For many years educators have been seriously concerned with the question of high school drop-outs. Despite the efforts of school officials, only one-half of the 1,700,000 students who entered high school as freshmen this fall will remain to be graduated four years from now.

FISHERS, N. Y. -- The first section of the New York State Thruway -- which will eventually provide an express highway from one end of the state to the other -- was opened at a point about a mile from this village by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey last week.

With public construction leading the way, 49,000 new dwelling units were started in the New York metropolitan area during the first half of this year, compared with 36,500 units in the similar period of 1948, Robert R. Behlow, director of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, reported yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- The matter of giving diplomatic recognition to Communist China was a leading topic of discussion on the West Coast this week.

SO few good stories have been published here by Australians about their continent -- which is not just an overgrown Pacific island but as large as the United States -- that it is regrettable to read a new Australian book adding so little to its literature.

The twenty-second annual Graduate Fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine, one of the most important medical events of the year, will begin tomorrow at the Academy building, 2 East 103d Street. The subject of this year's Fortnight, which will continue until Oct. 21, is "Advances in Diagnostic Methods."

In the absence of Catherine Mackenzie, this week's column has been written by the director of research at the Caroline Zachry Institute and Mrs. Frank, his collaborator. They are authorities on child care.

The University of Notre Dame will hold its third annual Natural Law institute DDec. 9-10. The two-day program, sponsored by the university's College of Law, will be devoted to an exposition of the current conditions on the natural law philosophy in American jurisprudence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The communique writers in Washington and Moscow, like the sports writers in New York, were leading with their big adjectives this week. In fact, there has seldom been a week since the end of the war in which the "You're another" school of diplomacy has had such a fine, unrestrained run.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Although municipal elections this fall were of immediate concern, voters throughout New England were nevertheless interested in behind-the-scenes maneuvering for position in the 1950 national picture, even at this early date.

SIX or seven years ago, when Helen Sobel was winning every tournament she deigned to enter, and had just become the first woman ever to reach the number-one spot in contract bridge rankings, a publisher suggested (quite mildly, too) that she write a book about the game, and Helen hardly spoke to him for a week.

THE language of the new State of Israel is Ivrit, or modern Hebrew, but by far the most popular language of the bookshops, literary circles and the reading public is -- with hardly a dissenting voice -- English, with an American accent.

BREVARD, N. C., Oct. 8 (AP) -- The thin white strip of paper that jackets the cigarette you're smoking has written a new story in American enterprise. And in doing so, it has transformed a quiet mountain valley in western North Carolina into one of the country's important industrial areas.

DALLAS, Oct. 8 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District last week fell moderately below sales for the corresponding period of last year, but were ahead of sales for the preceding week. The increase was largely seasonal. Over the upper portion of Texas the harvest of a bumper cotton crop continued, still plagued by a shortage of labor.

In spite of a lull in retail volume, business in the wholesale garment market here continued good last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Manufacturers are still asking for longer delivery periods, but this situation will soon be adjusted by sluggish retail activity, which has been aggravated by the coal, steel and other industrial work stoppages.

EVER since the Miss Buncle books D. E. Stevenson has been writing pleasant, light novels about nice English people. She has a warm affection for these not at all extraordinary people, and a happy gift for making the reader share her liking and her interest in their small affairs -- blackberrying with sentimental memories, or sharp words with a self-righteous and irritating neighbor.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 8 -- Two years after the United Nations adopted the plan for partition of Palestine, Jews and Arabs are still glaring at one another across strategically situated No Man's lands and distant conference tables. Disagreement seems to be the order of the day, largely because it is on a five-to-one basis.

APPETIZERS, once just savory trifles to accompany sherry or cocktails before dinner, have gained new importance. Influenced by the French hors d'oeuvre, the Italian antipasto and the Swedish smorgasbord, they are more varied, more elaborate, some of them hearty enough to appear as principal fare for a special luncheon or late-evening buffet.

NO one needs the excuse of an anniversary to make new recordings of Chopin's music. But since the anniversary is on hand, Victor and Columbia are prepared to take advantage of it On Oct. 17 it will be just 100 years since Chopin died, and prominent in the October releases are two new recordings of big Chopin works.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Delayed twenty-four hours by storms, the battered liner Nieuw Amsterdam arrived here today with several persons aboard injured in a rough Atlantic crossing.

JOANNA McINTYRE at 20 is an unbending prudish little red-haired schoolteacher with green eyes and complete faith in the Lord's guidance for her every problem. When her dark, handsome fiance betrays her, God speaks and shows her the way out.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The first session of the Eighty-first Congress is at last, now in October, about to come to the end that it was supposed to reach last July 31.

TULSA, Okla., Oct. 8 -- In 1948, purchases of crude oil and refined oil products in the United States accounted for 11.4 per cent of Canada's expenditures of $2,600,000,000 (U. S.). Oil purchases represented the largest single item of these expenditures.

The Lincoln Galleries, Inc., a new auction house for the dispersal of art and literary property that was opened on Friday in the Lincoln Warehouse building at Sixty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, will hold its first sale on Wednesday and Thursday.

HONG KONG, Oct. 8 -- The Canton Government was reported today to be completing preparations for evacuating to Chungking as Communist troops in north Kwangtung drove down the Canton-Hankow Railway to within 100 miles of the Nationalist refugee capital.

MINNESOTA, Oct. 8 (AP) -Minnesota throttled Northwestern's attack for three periods and took a 21 to 7 decision in the first test of the Gopher's 1949 football team against Big Ten opposition.

MR. HART'S novel, his first, is remarkable among Civil War stories for its brevity and incisiveness. It is also memorable for its main character, an illiterate, salty, courageous woman called Old Pine by the Southern soldiers whom she follows in her wagon and serves as trader, nurse and a sort of grass-roots OWI.

Plans for building Bell Park Terrace, a 300-family extension of Bell Park Manor, limited divided housing cooperative for veterans in Bellrose, Queens, were announced yesterday by State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman. It will be erected on Hillside Avenue opposite the site of Bell Park Manor, a 550-family section announced last month.
BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 8 (AP) -- An early-season storm spread snow a foot deep across much of Idaho today. It temporarily marooned hundreds of deer hunters and caused the death of a North Idaho woman.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 8 -- Manufacturing employment in Minnesota reached a 1949 peak in August of 3/4 per cent above July, the State Employment Service reported this week. Important gains were recorded in the textile industry which showed an upturn for the first time since November, 1948, due to activity in the knitting mills, and in the woodworking industry where output of household furniture was stepped up.

RUTH ST. DENIS and Ted Shawn will dance together for the first time in a number of years on Thursday, when they will open the series of "Around the World With Dance and Song," directed by Hazel Lockwood Muller, at the American Museum of Natural History.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 8 -Notre Dame turned loose its fleet of pony backs with a murderous ground attack today to slaughter Purdue, 35 to 12, before the largest crowd in Boilermaker football history. Some 52,000 fans jammed in newly enlarged Ross-Ade Stadium to watch with an autumn sun sending the temperature to 83 degrees.
HAVANA, Cuba, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A 325-pound sack of sugar fell twelve feet to the floor. The workman who had released it examined the sack, found it unharmed, and grinned broadly.

Holdings of United States Government securities of leading banks here in the third quarter were further increased as the institutions sought to employ profitably the funds released by an additional decline in business loans. This was reported in the condition statements of the fifteen largest commercial banks for Sept. 30.
Each player of the winning world series team will receive at least $5,884.21 for his share and each loser $4,164.59, according to unofficial figures announced last night.
Investment of United States capital in Israel averaged $2,000,000 a month over a six-months period, Gideon Strauss, Israel Consul for Commercial Affairs in New York, said last week.

New York University's eleven, which in recent years has experienced little success on the gridiron, always looks like a champion against Brooklyn College. The Violets maintained this status last night as they subjected the Kingsmen to a 39-to-13 drubbing at the Polo Grounds.

CREDIT Darryl F. Zanuck and his people at Twentieth Century-Fox with doing one brave thing in their "Pinky" which hadn't been done before in the two other memorable screen dramas on racial prejudice that have come along this year. The have barged right into that area of most conspicuous racism, the Deep South, and have mirrored some ugly illustrations of the dark reign of Jim Crow rule down there. '

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- With the exception of San Diego retail business activity in all areas of the Twelfth District suffered moderate to marked declines during the last week. Total retail trade in the mountain area states during August enjoyed favorable increases over a year ago except in Montana.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Britain's admirals, generals and airmen once huffed and puffed at each other as their American counterparts are doing today -- but that was thirty years ago.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- David B. Robertson, president of the Brotherhood of Firemen and Enginemen, said today that the Presidential emergency board's report which turned down the union's demand for an extra fireman on Diesel-electric locomotives used on the country's major railroads "should positively be rejected and in no uncertain terms."

EAST HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8 (UP) -- Fullback Fred Meyers made two 79-yard runs for touchdowns in leading New Haven State Teachers College to a 27-to-6 victory over City College of New York tonight.

May I correct what I am sure was an inadvertent error in your columns of Sept. 18? Your correspondent Thomas Pryor, whose articles we all read and enjoy, stated that all film societies in the United States are now "dealing exclusively in 16mm. films."
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 8 -The Williams' College split T formation moved effectively on the ground and through the air to pile up a 35-0 victory over the University of Rochester today.
PRAGUE, Czechoslavakia, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia is sending to her uranium and coal mines and forced labor camps the thousands snatched up in a week-long roundup, reliable reports said tonight.

TONIGHT the Sadler's Wells Ballet opens its first American engagement with a performance at the Metropolitan Opera House, and everybody seems considerably excited about it. Just why the advance interest has been so intense is difficult to explain, and not even the local impresario himself has any very clear interpretation of it.

HAVANA, Oct. 8 -- With the atomic bomb reportedly in the hands of Russia, it is imperative that the Latin-American countries separately and jointly prepare to defend themselves, according to Minister of National Defense Segundo Curti.

THOUGH designed for popular use, this is an unusually comprehensive and thoughtfully selected collection of folk tales. Examples have been drawn from nineteen different parts of the world, some dating back to Egyptian, Hindu and Greek antiquity, others, like the American tall tale, originating as recently as the last century.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- By the force of circumstance and perhaps an ironical twist of fate Philip Murray, whose talent lies in peaceful compromise, finds himself inexorably caught in the grip of events that compel him to act like a labor war lord.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 8 -Robert S. Fowler, 51 years old, president of Macey Fowler, Inc., 385 Madison Avenue, New York office furniture dealer, was found dead at 6 A. M. today in a field near Winged Foot Drive, one half mile from his home at 5 Dundee Road here.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- French officials said today the new regime established in the Russian zone of Germany had no legal basis such as that of the Western Government resulting from an election. They added that the promise of an election in the Eastern zone in October, 1950, had been exacted by the Liberal and other non-Communist splinter parties the Soviet Union apparently wanted in the regime, but that the election would not be free.

SECAUCUS, N. J., Oct. 9 -Winding up the Northern outboard regatta season with the traditional Hackensack River race meet at Snipes' Beach here this afternoon, the young White Plains housewife, Mrs. Eleanor Shakeshaft, nationally prominent in Class M racing, captured that event in straight heats for a perfect point score of 800.

The "Band of America," radio's oldest commercial network series, will become a simultaneous television production over the National Broadcasting Company chain next Monday from 9:30 to 10 P. M. The band is conducted by Paul Lavalle.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- Parents' associations are playing an increasing role in the Soviet school system, assisting children with studies, improving home conditions and aiding the schools in dozens of different ways, the magazine Family and School reported today.
TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 9 -- Caleb S. Green, 64 years old, president of the Trenton Banking Company, took his life today with a pistol in his downtown hotel room, the police said.

In observance of the thirty-ninth anniversary of the consecration of St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Rev. Edwin B. Broderick of the cathedral staff hailed the structure yesterday at a solemn pontifical mass "as a treasure that becomes priceless with the passing years." Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, cathedral administrator, was the celebrant.

Thirteen-year-old Gerry Gearhart of Boonton, N. J., riding Long View's Lovely Lady, yesterday added four first places and a reserve championship to her first-day total of two firsts at the annual Long Acres horse show at the Long Acres Stables, Willowbrook.

BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- The Russians dismantled various headquarters and control points today that they have occupied in Eastern Berlin since 1945 and at the same time announced the foreign policy to be pursued by the East German puppet state, the German Democratic Republic.

ZURICH, Oct. 9 -- Experiences of practical business men in Switzerland already have raised widespread doubt about the correctness of the assumption that international trade would revive as a result of the general devaluation of currencies in Europe.

Integration of the sales of all products made by the Stamford division of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company into three major sales divisions was announced yesterday in Stamford by Meade Johnson, general sales manager.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 9 -- United Nations delegates are busy with back stage consultations on a possible counter-proposal to the Russian omnibus peace plan, which tries to tie arms reduction, atomic energy control and condemnation of the United States and Great Britain as war mongers, all into one resolution.

Winners of awards in the First National Exhibition of Dinnerware Design, which will be shown at the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts starting Oct. 29, were announced yesterday by Miss Anna Wetherill Olmsted, director of the museum. The contest, jointly sponsored by the museum and Commercial Decal, Inc., of Mount Vernon, N. Y., is intended to bring new artists to the attention of commercial potters in the United States.

Recommended standards for the advertising and selling of men's wear have been issued to all New York City retailers, it was announced over the week-end by the Better Business Bureau of New York City. The standards, result of several months of intensive work by the BBB with a number of retailers, are aimed at improving the quality and accuracy of advertising of men's clothing and furnishings.

Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy has signed a contract with Whittlesey House for the publication next spring of his memoirs, entitled "I Was There." Based on his notes and diaries made at the time, Admiral Leahy tells of the conferences and strategy that brought success to our war efforts.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 9 -- Mrs. C. Douglas Dillon of Far Hills, N. J., turned in one of the best rounds since she has been playing the game, to help Harry Wilmerding of the home club tack another fine 59 to their opening round of 59 for a 118 total and victory in the Meadow Brook Club's annual invitation mixed foursomes handicap golf tournament today.
It would have been nice to be around at the finish, but I have no complaints as long as we won. That's the important thing.

THE Oregon Trail from Independence in Missouri to the Cascade Mountains overlooking the Pacific is the great road of the American past. More than the first sites of English settlements in Virginia and New England, more than the memories of the pioneers who braved the forests of Ohio and Kentucky, it appeals to the national imagination.

There'll be plenty of variety in the racing shows at Belmont Park today and tomorrow. Horses will race on the main track, through the Widener straightaway, over the hurdles and over the steeplechase jumps at the annual meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 9 -- The American Federation of Labor's Committee on International Labor Relations warned today against "any attempts to revive a policy of appeasement of Soviet imperialism at this critical juncture."
Sunday at dusk on the Bowery. An occasional vehicle passes. It's warm and a lot of people are on the sidewalks, but few are moving, for few have any place to go.
The Staten Island Museum at St. George opened its doors to the public yesterday afternoon in beginning its fall season.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 9 -- Mr. Clapp and members of his survey mission arrived at Lydda Airport today from Beirut for talks with the Israeli Government concerning the resettlement of Arab refugees. They met tonight with Government officials at a place that for security reasons has not been disclosed.

There is a strong bond of kinship between the members of the armed forces, fighting for democracy and freedom in wartime, and the policeman, whose duty it is to maintain and perpetuate them in peacetime, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, declared yesterday.

HONG KONG, Oct. 9 -- Troops of Communist Gen. Lin Piao swept unopposed through South Hunan today and reached the new positions held by forces of Nationalist Gen. Pai Chung-hsi along the Kwangsi-Hunan border. Canton reports said fighting between the Communists and General Pai's men had already broken out at Lingling in the extreme south of Hunan along the Hengyang-Luichow railway.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 9 -To help meet the acute need for trained social workers, which surveys show is a serious problem throughout the country, Adelphi College here has just opened its new graduate school of social work.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., Oct. 9 -- Despite the number of beribboned veteran pilots based at Quonset Point Naval Air Station, which has many air duties in addition to being the home port of four aircraft carriers, the name heard most often here is Micky Beavertail.

Robert B. Blaikie, Democratic leader of the Seventh Manhattan Assembly District, who bolted Tammany to lead the successful campaign of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for election as Representative from the Twentieth Congressional District, is in Bellevue Hospital recovering from injuries received when he was hit by a bus, it was learned yesterday.

A fine fresh salad for luncheon has the endorsement of both gourmet and health expert. And now it is receiving new importance from the chic Sherry-Netherland. We like to think of the latter as the "hotel with a view." Situated as it is at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, it overlooks the south end Of Central Park, surely one of the prettiest parts of the city.

A crowd of reporters was circled around Barney Shotton in the clubhouse yesterday after everything was all over, firing questions at the silver-haired Dodger pilot, who was trying his best to answer everybody, when Commissioner Happy Chandler broke through.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- While it strives to bring about quickly the long-awaited adjournment of Congress, the Senate faces a possible stumbling block in the displaced persons bill, a measure certain to start a bitter floor fight.

An endorsement of Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for election to that office, by John W. Davis, Democratic candidate for President in 1924, was made public yesterday by Charles Evans Hughes Jr., chairman of the Independent Citizens Committee for Mr. Dulles.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- State Controller Frank Moore announced today that he will sell $43,365,000 of state housing bonds at noon on Tuesday, Oct. 18. The last sale of state bonds took place last Nov. 30, when $51,450,000 of housing bonds were sold.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- All of the big railroads that serve the far western range states as well as the Corn Belt plan reduced feeder-in-transit rates for livestock moving eastward. The lower rates went into effect on one road last month and others will follow this month, it was learned.
