SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Kaps Al, the veteran campaigner belonging to Mr. and Mrs. Oliver D. Appleton of Scarsdale and ridden by Mrs. Appleton, captured the conformation hunter championship as the seventh annual three-day horse show of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club was concluded tonight.

Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany, denounced yesterday as "arrant nonsense" the charge by Adolf A. Berle Jr., State Chairman of the Liberal party, that Democratic politicians, chiefly in Tammany, were preparing to betray former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, candidate for United States Senator, and divert votes to Senator John Foster Dulles, his Republican opponent, in return for Republican votes for Mayor O'Dwyer.

Howard Hughes' production, "The Outlaw," a Western saga based on the adventures of Billy the Kid and starring Jane Russell and Jack Beutel, has been removed from its "Class C or condemned" category by the National Legion of Decency and placed in the legion's "B" or "morally objectionable in part for all" grouping, it was simultaneously announced by the legion and a representative of the producer.

An attempt to crack the costly bottleneck in one of the world's most important distributing points for perishable food -- Washington Market on the lower West Side -was scheduled to begin before dawn here this morning.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Legislation to prohibit the Rural Electrification Administration from lending money to cooperatives which compete with local merchants in the sale and servicing of electrical appliances was proposed today by Joseph T. Meek, executive secretary of the Illinois Federation of Retail Associations.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 9 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner for Germany, said today he was not in favor of ending dismantling of German industrial plants unless the country could justify such a move by guarantees on considerations of security and reparations.

A new diversified open-end management type investment company, to be known as the Stein, Roe Farnham Fund, Inc., has been set up by the Chicago investment counselor firm of Stein, Roe Farnham, it was announced yesterday.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 9 -Best in show in the fourth annual fixture of the Northwestern Connecticut Dog Club at the Municipal Stadium today was taken by Kinvarra Kennels' Irish setter Ch. Tyrone Farm Malone II. It was the fourth top award for the setter and came at the judgment of the noted animal artist, S. Edwin Megargee Jr.

Although one-third of all students in American colleges and universities this fall are veterans, the end of the GI domination of the classroom and campus is at hand. Fewer than 10 per cent of the new students are ex-servicemen, compared with more than 50 per cent during the last several years.

Walter H. BonDurant has been appointed Northeastern district manager of appliance sales for the General Electric Company. Formerly central region manager for Hotpoint, Inc., he succeeds C. A. Reeves, who has been assigned to other duties.
Although held to a 2-2 tie by the Brookhattan eleven at Sterling Oval yesterday, the New York Americans maintained a one-point lead in the American Soccer League. The score was 1 -- 1 at the half.
ROOSEVELT FIELD, L. I., Oct. 9 -- The Navy flew off with the honors today at the air show that featured the second day of the Nassau County Golden Anniversary Industrial Exposition here.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 9 -- An anchor ten feet long and weighing an estimated two tons, which may have belonged to the ill-fated steamship Portland, was brought into this port today by the fishing dragger Agda. The anchor was brought up in the vessel's drags about nine miles north-northeast of Race Point Light yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 9 -Phil Patton sailing the International sloop Grilse won the Haebler Trophy and Willy Olsen with his Class S Woodcock took the Arthur Godfrey Trophy. That was decided today with the wind-up of racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club for the fall post-season prizes for the summer yachts.

Jacques Bronstein, Russian pianist, appeared as soloist in three concertos with a symphony orchestra conducted by Franco Autori last night at Carnegie Hall. The works presented were Mozart's Concerto in D minor, Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto and Saint-Saens' Concerto in G minor, prefaced by the Overture to Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro."

After a lapse of nearly fifteen years, Goeta Ljungberg, Swedish soprano, returned to give a recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The cordial applause and the bountiful flowers showed that there were many who had not forgotten her in her absence.

Jot down Oct. 29, instead of Oct. 26, as the date for the premiere of "Montserrat" at the Fulton. The setback of Lillian Hellman's adaptation of the Emmanuel Robles play, which she also directed, was made immediately after Saturday night's first performance in Princeton.

MADRID, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Spain today juggled her variable exchange rate system, lowering the dollar value of the peseta so that Spanish exporters will be able to sell more, while importers can buy less for their money.

The twenty-seventh annual celebration of the British Harvest Festival was conducted at vespers yesterday afternoon at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, with 1,000 present, including representatives of several British and British-American societies.

A thirteen-year-old photograph sent here by Cleveland authorities, combined with a week-long search in bars and grills in the Times Square area, resulted early yesterday in the arrest of a man and his woman accomplice accused of taking $4,300 in four tavern holdups in the last two and a half months.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 9 -- J. Mahlon Buck, president of Smith, Kline French, Inc., of Philadelphia, warned today that eventually under a socialized medicine program the government will enter the pharmaceutical manufacturing business to cut down the cost of the national health scheme.

What concrete proposals can be made to meet the situation created by the atomic explosion in the Soviet Union? We are faced with crucial alternatives. To us it seems that in the last analysis the possible courses of action reduce themselves to two: Either an atomic arms race that can only lead to unthinkable disaster, or an effective program for universal disarmament.
LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Aneurin Bevan said tonight that in a "very short time" the British nation would be asked to give its verdict on the Labor Government's stewardship.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Air France, the French national airline, more and more under the control of important French private business interests, is beginning to emerge as the one successful venture in postwar French aviation.

The Rev. John O. Mellin, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, yesterday classed the Roman Catholic Church and communism as two great movements calling upon "spiritual allegiance to gain temporal power." He said that Protestants should not accept every threat from the "Communist hierarchy" against the "Catholic hierarchy" as an attack on all Christendom.

There is much that is praiseworthy in the report of the President's Steel Fact-Finding Board, submitted to the White House last Sept. 10. On the other hand, the longer one studies those sections dealing with the moot issue of pensions, the more one is impressed with what may be described as the "hit-and-run" character of much of the argumentation.
Heading a list of twenty-six new exhibitions this week are several important one-man shows of paintings at New York galleries, as well as group shows at local museums.

Britain's leading dollar-earning industry, tourism, is looking for a 25 per cent increase in visitors from the United States next year as a result of the devaluation of the pound, according to John G. Bridges, director general of the British Travel Association, who is here to address travel groups.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- The leaders of several of France's political parties that might form a future majority will meet tomorrow to pass opinion on a program for economic recovery that will be submitted by Jules Moch, Socialist Minister of the Interior, whom President Vincent Auriol appointed to this task.

Recalling that as Governor of New York he had fought for social security legislation, Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, expressed yesterday his approval of the bill expanding the national social security program, just passed by the House of Representatives.
SANTA FE, N. M., Oct. 9 -- New Mexico's Republicans, for the first time in eighteen years, are encouraged over the chances of winning a state election next year.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The return of Foreign Minister Ernest Bevin from a five-week sojourn in North America is eagerly awaited by his colleagues in the Labor Government as forshadowing a possibility of a break in the deadlock that has been hampering Britain's ability to make the most of the opportunities presented by devaluation.

LONDON, Oct. 9 (Reuters)--British movie theatre workers want Hollywood and the British Government to make available more money for movie making in Britain, because they fear that a film shortage may force many theatres to close.

As the national steel strike enters its second week, some consumers of steel have started to curtail their operations and many others are ready to slow down their production toward the end of this week if no break comes in the stalemate of the nation's No. 1 industry.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- The Insurance Economics Society of America assailed today what it called "police-state methods" by the United States Government in its investigation of the American Medical Association.

Two thousand foster parents who since 1945 have admitted dependent Roman Catholic children to their homes in the Archdiocese of New York attended vespers at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon. It was the fifth annual celebration of vespers especially for them.

Buyers in the wholesale garment market here last week found that deliveries of wanted holiday items have slowed up considerably, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Buying generally was cautious as a result of the steel and coal strikes and a few cancellations of orders were received from industrial areas.

GENEVA, Oct. 9 -- Thirty-one countries representing twenty-eight customs areas released new customs tariff schedules today incorporating the results of the summer-long trade conference held at Annecy, France.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Prices of wheat held close to the highest level of the year on the Chicago Board of Trade last week, and December corn sold at a new high since Feb. 4, while the deferred deliveries of that grain went to a new seasonal high before reacting.

Describing City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs, Republican-Liberal candidate in the Twentieth District, as "an outstanding public servant," the Citizens Union announced yesterday its endorsement of Mr. Isaacs. It declared it regarded his re-election as imperative, particularly as the change in the method of electing Council members is likely to wipe out most of the present Council minority.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- A great drama is being played these days to standee audiences in the old House Office Building up on Capitol Hill.

Shipbuilding rivalry between Germany and Japan on the one hand, and Britain, Norway and Sweden on the other, has created "quite a dilemma" for the United States, which is giving financial aid to all the countries involved, Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, said yesterday on his arrival at La Guardia Airport from Madrid.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 (UP) -Glenn Dobbs dazzled the Buffalo Bills with a magnificent passing exhibition today to give the Los Angeles Dons a 42-to-28 upset victory in an All-America Conference game.

Many boxes and seats have been sold for the all-Chopin recital to be given by Artur Rubinstein, pianist, next Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Chopin Fund and the Chopin Scholarship Fund.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 -- The nation's steel centers, hit both directly and indirectly by the strike of more than 500,000 members of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, were heartened today by increasing signs that a break in the stalemate may be expected soon.
VIENNA, Monday, Oct. 10 -Austria, which decisively rejected communism in its first post-war election in 1945, swung further right in yesterday's second free expression of the public will.

Casey Stengel was so happy in the Yankee clubhouse yesterday after his team had routed the Dodgers by 10 to 6 to win the World Series in five games that he congratulated Commissioner A. B. Chandler for "doing a great job."

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,954,393,531. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct 9 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Oct. 1 to 7 are given in the appended tabulation:

His stage, motion picture, radio, television and concert appearances have won Burl Ives a devoted following, and last night 1,300 were on hand when he gave a program of folk songs at Town Hall. Dipping effortlessly into his repertoire, he sang twenty-five songs, and if the audience had had its way he would have sung many more.
ROME, Oct. 9 -- Three weeks after the devaluation of the pound, Economic Cooperation Administration circles in Rome are impressed by the strength that the lira has shown.

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was a desultory affair last week, and at the close of the market on Saturday active futures contracts there were two points lower to eighteen higher than at the end of the preceding week.

Erna Berger, German lyric-coloratura soprano, whose recordings have made her well known in this country, will sing during the forthcoming season at the Metropolitan Opera. Her name and those of a new conductor and eight new singers engaged for the 1949-50 season were announced yesterday by the Metropolitan's press bureau.

The obligation of Christians "to work for new and improved social conditions" was stressed in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday morning by Canon Thomas A. Sparks, cathedral pastor.

Confident of making a good showing in the international military team competition at the national horse show at Madison Square Garden, which opens Nov. 1, the Irish Army jumping team arrived yesterday at La Guardia Field from Shannon.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The mental strain of grappling with manifold problems presented by devaluation of the pound sterling is proving to be beyond the capacity of many persons, and the stock markets here recently have contented themselves with reflecting the impact of current events rather than developments that may or may not occur.

Last June some of this country's most eminent educators, members of the Educational Policies Commission, issued a report dealing with the problems schools and teachers have to face as a result of the current cold war of ideas. They believed that students should be given an "objective exposure to facts," and this ruled out Communists as teachers.

There are 37,058 Girl Scouts enrolled in Greater New York troops. This figure, added to 10,500 on the waiting list, shows that more than 47,500 girls in this area have proved their eagerness to participate in the Girl Scout program. In response to this eagerness the 1949 Girl Scout Contributors Campaign of Greater New York will seek to raise a goal of $500,000.

An "honor system" by which 2,500 local restaurants are policing themselves has caused a sharp decline in the number of Health Department summonses issued this year for violations of the city's food-handling laws.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 9 -- Criticism of the devaluation of European currencies is more and more gaining ground. From talks in several leading Dutch financial and industrial quarters, the opinion emerged that apart from some increased possibilities of liberalization of European trade and of realization of the aims of Benelux, devaluation would do more harm than good.

The percentage of city employes exempt from civil service is lower in New York than in any other municipality in the United States, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday in a report on the activities of the Municipal Civil Service Commission since he took office in 1946.

Registration for the November election starts in this city and Westchester today. The registration booths are to be open from 5 P. M. to 10:30 P. M. today through Friday, and from 7 A. M. to 10:30 P. M. on Saturday, the last day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Representative John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, warned today that the United States was laying itself open to "an atomic Pearl Harbor" by indifference to civilian defense planning.

The prophets were right who predicted earlier in the year that by now we should be entering the most critical phase of the cold war. The establishment of two rival governments in Germany does not change the basic situation any more than Russia's possession of the atom bomb or the politico-economic tremors disturbing Europe in the wake of the devaluation of the pound.
HONG KONG, Oct, 9 (UP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek said today that World War III had already started with Russia's "direct participation in an aggressive war against China."
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 -- Operators of more than a dozen nonunion strip coal mines at which production has been disrupted by disorders will attempt to resume tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, said today that secret testimony of the Air Force high command supported his charge of "incredible mismanagement'' in the atomic program -- but this was quickly disputed.

Is your hospital equipped with a good blacksmith shop, a blazing forge, an anvil and a blacksmith with brawny arms? In a surprising number of hospitals in New York this is absolutely necessary equipment. For it is in the blacksmith shop that the leg braces and metal and leather supports for other parts of the bodies are made for handicapped patients.

The reappointment of Dudley F. Sicher as justice of the Domestic Relations Court will be greeted with satisfaction by all who are interested in maintaining the highest standards of the local bench. Justice Sicher has proved himself to be a jurist of preeminent abilities in the difficult post he has filled so successfully during the past decade.

Many of the home furnishings fabrics now being brought into this country from Europe have a luxurious old-world quality usually associated with period decor, but a new group of Belgian linens imported by Morley-Fletcher, 357 Fourth Avenue, is an exception.

Scoring in three of the four periods, the Cardinal Hayes football team registered its first victory of the season yesterday at Randalls Island in defeating All Hallows, 20 -- 6, before 5,000 spectators. The winners were originally scheduled to play St. John's Prep but the game was postponed on Friday when a Redman J. V. player came down with polio.

Real atomic security for our cities requires prevention of war. The best way to prevent war appears to remain what it has been, to enlist forces on the side of peace too strong for any aggressor to challenge successfully, Even Hitler would not have chosen war in 1939 if he had been convinced that he could not win.
HAVANA, Oct. 9 -- "Stranger in the Hills" had its first presentation here last night at the Normal School Theatre in the Spanish language.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- At one stage in their National Football League encounter at Griffith Stadium today, the New York Giants and Washington Redskins were tied, 21 -- 21. At another, the New Yorkers soared to a 45-21 spread and at the finish it was 45 -- 35, a really 'good victory" for Steve Owen's charges.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 9 (AP) -- A thunderous ovation that included an eleven-gun salute greeted Army's victorious football squad at the Plains today following its sparkling 21-7 upset triumph over Michigan. Observers believed the rousing welcome was unequaled in the 60-year history of the game at the military academy.

Of 255 recently adopted pension plans, 58.7 per cent are on a joint contributory basis, according to a survey just completed by the National Industrial Conference Board and released for publication today. All pension plans included in the survey have been made effective or were revised since October, 1945.

I agree, as you suggest in your editorial of Oct. 1 commenting on my letter of the previous day, that Russia prohibition of the free movement of people and ideas across her boundaries constitutes a grave obstacle to understanding; nor do I question that the constitutes evidence that her intention are by no means free from evil.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Bob Waterfield's three touchdown passes and a rough Los Angeles line swept the Rams to a 31-16 triumph over the Chicago Bears and into sole leadership of the National Football League's Western Division today.

The United States maritime industry now faces its most critical employment slump in more than a decade with the number of American-flag ships in operation rapidly decreasing and job opportunities dropping proportionately, according to observers.
Gentle southwest breezes nudged October right off the calendar yesterday and gave New Yorkers a day in June.

New recognition of the religious emotions in man has arisen in the field of psychic behavior, said Rabbi Zev Zahavy, in a Succoth sermon yesterday morning for Congregation Ohab Zedek, 118 West Ninety-fifth Street.

The letter of A. J. Muste of the Fellowship of Reconciliation, which appeared in your issue of Sept. 30 and which inspired an editorial the following day, illustrates an attitude toward the Soviet Government which should not go unchallenged.

A DRAMATIC world series, which had moved along with the ponderous and measured pace of a Greek tragedy, wound up at Ebbets Field yesterday like a slap-stick comedy. It had all the sheer magnificence and perfection of the game between the married men and the single men at the annual outing of the Marching and Chowder Club, but it finished just as fate had ordained way back in April -- with a crushing Yankee victory.
BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- Officials of the United States High Commissioner's Office estimate that $250,000,000 is needed to put the three Western sectors of Berlin on their economic feet.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 9 -- Czechoslovakia is preparing a children's version of war games to be staged near Prague on Oct. 23 under the direction of soldiers and police, the Communist party organ Rude Pravo announced today.

Army's stirring upset of Michigan is looked on by old-timers at the Military Academy as the top feat of a West Point team in modern times. Earl Blaik, the coach, rates it as the finest performance of any of his Army elevens since the 1944 victory over Navy.

The American debut of the Sader's Wells Ballet from Covent Garden, London, at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was an occasion in every sense of the word, complete with national anthems, a list of distinguished patrons and flag-draped boxes in which were seated British Ambassador Sir Oliver Franks, Mayor O'Dwyer, Consul General Sir Francis Evans and Lady Evans, Trygve Lie, Sir Alexander Cadogan and other notables from the United Nations.

There is an expression, prevalent to housewives, which can stand a little investigation. No, it is not "Where did you go after work?" Nor is it "You never fixed the screen door." Neither is it "Did you ask about that raise?" These thoughts are spoken legitimately, for it is the acknowledged right of housewives to question and complain.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Britain and the United States face the complex and baffling problem of whether -- or when and how -- to recognize the Communist Government in China and to acquiesce in the Communist occupation of China's seat on the Security Council.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Trading in lard futures on the Board of Trade was unusually light last week and prices held within comparatively narrow limits, averaging slightly lower in sympathy with a rapid decline in the price of hogs.

The Rev. Dr. Harold C. DeWindt, pastor of the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, defended organized religion in his morning sermon yesterday against charges of obsolescence.

Doris Trotman, soprano, gave a recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. She was heard in a group of Elizabethan songs, six infrequently presented lieder of Schumann, Benjamin Britten's set of songs, "On This Island"; French lyrics by Faure, Claire Kessler's "The Man With the Blue Guitar," "Anecdote" and "Cradle Song," which received their first performance, and Negro spirituals arranged by Roland Hayes and William Lawrence.

ANURADHAPURA, Ceylon, Sept. 20 -- After 150 years of desultory digging, archaeologists are still unearthing the remains of a brilliant pre-Christian civilization in this Sacred City of Ceylonese Buddhism, the ancient capital of Lanka, as Ceylon was once called.
The scientists predicted right. Russia has had an atomic explosion, perhaps a bomb, and all the world knows it. For the moment, at least, another wave of fear has swept over mankind.

Twenty-five hundred men are reported to be working around the clock in three shifts to finish work on the new Norwegian liner Oslofjord before her trial run on Friday. The vessel is under construction at the Netherlands Dock and Shipbuilding Company yard at Amsterdam.

The New York State Maritime College, Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, has admitted the largest freshman class in its seventy-five-year history, Vice Admiral H. F. Leary, president of the college, announced yesterday. Admiral Leary said 188 young men had reported to commence the four-year course, and included, in addition to New Yorkers, residents of New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, Washington, Michigan, Rhode Island and the Canal Zone.

TOKYO, Oct. 9 -- The conservative policies of Premier Shigeru Yoshida continue to have the large-scale support of the Japanese people that was demonstrated at the last general election, it was asserted today by Asahi, as a result of a public opinion poll the newspaper conducted in all parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Creation of a Presidential commission to find all the facts pertaining to the controversy within the Defense Department was urged today by the Army and Navy Union, one of the oldest of veterans' organizations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -High schools do not meet the needs of 60 per cent of their students, J. Dan Hull, Assistant Federal Director of Secondary Education, asserted today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 9 (UP) -- A Communist source said privately today that the week-long wave of arrests throughout Czechoslovakia was an attack "against the biggest underground network uncovered since the Communist party came into power."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 9 -Five new television films were completed last week and five more have been scheduled for production this week by Frank Wisbar at the Hal Roach Studio for General Television Enterprises, the distributing company which holds a contract with Procter Gamble.

PUSAN, Korea, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The crew of the United States blockade- runner, Flying Independent, reported on arrival here at midnight that their ship got safely into Shanghai because a Chinese Nationalist warship had surrendered to the Communists.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The San Francisco 49'ers roared to a 56-28 victory today to hand the Cleveland Browns their first All-America Football Conference defeat since 1947.

The twenty-third annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States, which will open at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Oct. 19, is expected to have the largest attendance of the eight consecutive conventions in New York, officials of the club said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Leaders of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen today adopted a resolution "rejecting" the adverse report of a Presidential Emergency Board last month on the union's request for an additional fireman in diesel-electric locomotives.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, announced yesterday that Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President last year, would speak on municipal, issues from WJZ tomorrow night at 7:15 o'clock.

In a radio speech from WNBC at 7:30 o'clock tonight, Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, will reply to Mayor O'Dwyer's "keynote" speech, made at his Commodore Hotel headquarters last Tuesday evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The State Department, hailing results of the trade agreements conference at Annecy, France, stressed tonight the important concessions made by and for the participating countries in the interest of world trade.

Despite the political struggle between Arabs and Jews, cooperation between Israel and its Arab neighbors will be achieved in the near future, Eliahu Elath, Israeli Ambassador to the United States, said last night at the annual meeting of the Institute of Ethnic Affairs.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 9 (UP) -Frankie Parker polished off "possibly" his last amateur tennis tournament today with a spectacular upset of Jaroslav Drobny of Czechoslovakia for the Pan American championship.

Casey Stengel and his Yankees, who took off last spring on a forlorn hope only to wing their way to the American League pennant, brought a year of remarkable achievement to a triumphant close yesterday as they crushed the Dodgers in the fifth and final game of the 1949 world series.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 -Starting in the fall of 1950, the Harvard Law School, for the first time in its 132-year history, will admit qualified women applicants.
Eight new films, including importations from England, France and Italy, are to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 9 -- On the eve of the Norwegian general election to renew the Storting (Parliament) for the next four years, prognosticators here tend to agree on only one thing -- that the Communists will lose heavily in tomorrow's voting.

A city transit authority to operate, improve and extend the municipal transit system would not be practical, according to a report signed by the three members of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and the general manager-secretary of that agency.
NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 9 -- County Federations of Holy Name Societies paraded in various New Jersey communities today.

The New York Yankees, the team that has done it with mirrors all season, finished in approved style yesterday by taking the series final. Much congratulation is in order for a courageous and versatile club and a skillful and inspiring manager. This was not the old-time Yankee powerhouse that overawed its opponents into meek submission.

Darryl F. Zanuck, vice president in charge of production at Twentieth Century-Fox since the merger of the Twentieth Century and Fox film companies in 1935, has been signed to a new contract under which he will retain that post for the next ten years to be followed by another ten years of "exclusive service in an advisory capacity."

The tenth day of the tenth month has been celebrated in China since 1911 as National Emancipation Day. It is the anniversary of the start of the successful revolution against the Manchu dynasty led by Dr. Sun Yat-sen. Its theme has always been liberation from a regime regarded as wrong politically and as essentially alien.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 30 -- Devaluation has proved tragic for Nehemiah Munyama, a Negro carpenter in Durban, Natal. For six years he worked sixteen hours a day, six days a week, to save u1,000 to take him to the United States to study for a degree.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 10 (Reuters) -- Israel has agreed to destroy military posts near the Sea of Galilee, and Syrian troops are to evacuate a demilitarized zone farther north in accordance with the armistice timetable, it was announced tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct 10 -- President Truman has accepted an invitation to come to New York on Oct. 24 to deliver the main address at a cornerstone ceremony on the Manhattan site of the United Nations skyscraper headquarters, Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10 -The Society of Motion Picture Engineers has made television the principal topic of discussion at the sixty-sixth semi-annual convention, which began here today. The meeting will thresh out the question of whether the organization's constitution should be changed to permit inclusion of television engineers as members.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture today estimated this year's cotton crop at 15,446,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, 503,000 bales more than the 14,943,000 forecast a month ago. Last year's crop was 14,868,000 bales and the ten-year (1938-47) average was 11,306,000.

Last-minute efforts yesterday failed to stave off the strike vote of The Herald Tribune unit of the Newspaper Guild of New York, CIO. The vote was scheduled in three sections, one last night, the second this afternoon and the third at 6 P. M. today, all being held in the Newspaper Guild offices, 133 West Forty-fourth Street.

Radioactive nitrogen is being used to study the aging process, giving to medical science for the first time a veritable "hour-glass" for measuring accurately the rate at which the "sands of life" are running out, it was reported last night at the opening session of the twenty-second Graduate Fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine.

Acting in accordance with the Federal Reserve Board's recent reduction of reserve requirements for certain member banks in the "uptown" Manhattan area, the State Banking Board has placed non-member banks similarly situated in the same reserve category, it was learned yesterday.

The Chinese Consul General protested yesterday to city officials the display of Red flags of Communist China in Chinatown as that community celebrated the thirty-eighth anniversary of the Chinese Republic.

Oren Root, he Republican-City Fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, declared yesterday that the campaign being waged by his Democratic-Liberal opponent, Robert F. Wagner Jr., was an "insult to the people of New York."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- This capital has become accustomed and even a little cautious about the arrivals and departures of Prime Ministers and Foreign Ministers in the last two years, but there is nothing casual about the preparations for the arrival tomorrow of India's first Prime Minister, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The direct issue over domestic policy which has taken form in the contest between Herbert H. Lehman and John Foster Dulles for the Senate seat now occupied by Mr. Dulles has given immense political importance to the outcome, and both Republicans and Democrats here recognize it fully.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Officers of the Farm Equipment Workers Union have voted to merge with the United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers Union in defiance of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Mid-Manhattan was gripped yesterday by one of the worst and most prolonged traffic jams in the city's history. The snarls persisted all through the daylight hours and their effects harassed motorists and pedestrians for miles around the core of the paralysis, Forty-second Street from Fifth to Ninth Avenue, where workmen are repaving the famd thoroughfare.

The Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry has invited bids to supply 4,005,000 barrels of crude petroleum to Japan by July 1, 1950, it was announced yesterday by the Foreign Trade New York office of the Supreme Command for the Allied Powers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -Tons of Pennsylvania apples will be purchased for the Federal school lunch program, Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, announced today. He said the Government would buy twenty-one carloads of Pennsylvania apples during the picking season.

Expansion of the New York commercial zone as applied to trucking unrestricted by Federal regulations was urged yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. In a brief filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington it was asserted that present Federal limitations made for shipping inefficiency and delays.
Eduardo Balarezo, 48 years old, of North Great River, L. I., went on trial in Federal Court yesterday charged with being the guiding force of a huge cocaine smuggling ring.

CANTON, China, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Government informed foreign diplomats today, the thirty-eighth anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Republic, that full-scale removal of personnel to Chungking would start tomorrow.

Two hold-up men, one armed with a pistol and the other with a blackjack, held up the Savoy Ballroom, 600 Lenox Avenue, at 9:10 A. M. yesterday and escaped with $5,000 of the $7,000 week-end receipts after tying a woman cashier to a chair and knocking the porter unconscious.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- A counselor of the Chinese Embassy in Paris announced today that the entire Embassy staff except the Charge d'Affaires and a bookkeeper had declared for the Com munist regime of Mao Tze-tung and had called upon Chinese diplomatic personnel throughout the world to follow suit.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The characteristics that mark one nation from another are among the most stubborn facts of history. The aims of a nation may be modified, but are seldom entirely abandoned. Methods may change, but policies tend to persist all the same.
The conviction of a New York bus driver for assaulting a passenger, as repoted in THE TIMES, points up a serious transportation problem.

The report of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority members who called a city transit authority impractical was termed yesterday "a strictly political document" by Paul Windels, advocate of an independent transit agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Displaced Persons Commission, which never had been asked to present its case for liberalization of the DP Act before the Senate Judiciary subcommittee considering that bill, today was finally invited by a group of members of the full Judiciary Committee to submit a report on the bringing of displaced persons from Europe up to the present.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- As the European Marshall Plan Council prepares to tackle this month its greatest single task -- that of insuring freer trade in Europe -- it is handicapped by a widened gap between the British and Continentals, notably the French.

Stiffening competition will cause some advertisers to increase budgets for they coming year, while most will meet tightening conditions, with budgets about the same as this year's, it was indicated yesterday at the opening of the Association of National Advertisers' fortieth annual meeting.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- President Vincent Auriol received tonight a report from Jules Moch on the reception by French party leaders to M. Moch's program for a future Government. The President thanked M. Moch for the manner in which he had fulfilled his official mission but did not designate a candidate for the Premiership.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today that it was sending a four-man general economic and financial mission to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on Saturday.
Heeding the pleas of the candidates, New Yorkers turned to the registration booths in good numbers yesterday to qualify as voters on Election Day, Nov. 8. The total enrolled in the city was 285,447.
ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- Governor Dewey will fly to New York tomorrow morning to inspect several Queens housing projects. While in the city he will register for the November election.

A new television variety show, starring Paul Whiteman, is being planned for presentation over the American Broadcasting Company at an early date not yet determined. The program is expected to be carried on Sunday evenings under the sponsorship of the Good-year Tire and Rubber Company.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 10 -- Dmitri Z. Manuilsky of the Ukraine opened Russia's defense of her satellite Governments in Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania before the United Nations General Assembly's Special Political Committee today by accusing the United States and Britain of "falsity and hypocrisy" in saying those Governments were violating human rights and freedoms.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (UP) -- Lowell (Red) Dawson, the taciturn coach of the Buffalo Bills professional football team, was discharged in a sudden upheaval and Line Coach Clem Crowe immediately was chosen to take his place, the team announced today.

Mayor O'Dwyer laid the cornerstone of the Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island yesterday. The Mayor declared that it was "an expensive hospital,'' but an expense that the people of New York had to bear if they were "going to take care of the needy sick."

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Prices of British Government securities in the stock market here relapsed sharply today and losses up to 3/4 point were recorded at the close of business. The exception was the defense bonds, which closed 1/8 point higher.

Hide futures gained 15 to 32 points in a day of moderate trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. The tone of the market was firm at the close with a total of 2,440,000 pounds in the day's trading.

VIENNA, Oct. 10 -- Final if unofficial results of the Austrian general elections, held yesterday, indicated this evening that not only the Socialists but their senior partners in the late coalition Government, the People's party, had lost ground as a result of the emergence of the Nazi-tinged Independent party of Dr. Herbert Kraus.

Plans for the construction of 130 ranch style homes in Hewlett Harbor, L. I., were revealed yesterday by George Klein, builder, with the announcement of the purchase of a tract of about thirty acres. The property, adjoining the Seawane Country Club is bounded by Waverly Avenue, Thixton Creek and Pepperidge Road.

Rising prices on rayon textiles have been a factor in stocking of goods in sizable quantities by both converters and garment manufacturers, it was pointed out yesterday in the trade. Buying has been speeded up by the urge to cover requirements in a market that has seen prices go up 20 per cent on gray goods and 10 to 15 per cent on finished goods, according to suppliers.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10 -- Atomic power, in itself, is a "feeble agent" compared with the element of hope that science has given to mankind, W. W. Butterworth, Assistant Secretary of State, declared tonight at the opening session of the thirteenth annual Congress of the International Society of Surgery.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India, who is on his way to Washington at the invitation of President Truman, held a series of informal converations with British Ministers today. Neither Pandit Nehru nor his hosts would disclose the subjects of the talks, which were said to have been either "private" or "mainly social."

A statement of policy expressing willingness to cooperate with the Department of Justice in its investigation of alleged efforts by medical societies to monopolize prepaid medical plans was adopted last night by the comitia minora of the Medical Society of the Medical Society of the County of New York.

The influence of politics upon strategy has nowhere been more sharply emphasized than in the Navy-B-36 hearings before the House Armed Services Committee, which were continued in Washington yesterday.

Your news article of Sept. 26 captioned "Voters Apathetic on Referendum" and citing the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey report on the 1947 elections is another instance where the cold figures of statistics when dealing with human reactions add up to a false picture.

Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of Brooklyn, author of the displaced persons bill now locked in the Senate Judiciary Committee, predicted here yesterday that if given an opportunity the Senate would "overwhelmingly" vote its passage.
Notre Dame is the top college football team, the experts have decided in The Associated Press' second nation-wide poll of the season.
MEADE, Kan., Oct. 10 (UP) -- A Los Angeles-to-Chicago Rock Island passenger train plunged through a storm-weakened trestle east of here today, killing at least six persons and injuring seventy-five.

IF a fellow gets rapped repeatedly on the head-by a blunt instrument, he eventually becomes numb and inured to pain. The National League has been humiliated by the American League so often in the world series that the senior circuit should be used to it by now. But no defeat rankled more or cut deeper than the crushing of the Dodgers by the Yankees.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 10 -- J. D. Crump, president of the National Wholesale Druggists Association, charged today that the sovereignty of the state is being destroyed by the Federal Government "in its lust for more and more taxes."

Harry Sacher of defense counsel in the Communist trial charged yesterday that President Truman had ordered the trial for political reasons. He said this in his closing statement to the jury as the trial went into its thirty-ninth week.

Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, is scheduled to arrive in Washington today to begin a visit of about three weeks in the United States. It will be his first trip to this country and there will be a virtually unanimous hope that it will not be the last. We expect to enjoy having him here and we hope that he enjoys to the full being with us.
Benjamin Feldman, 41-year-old Brooklyn druggist, went on trial for the third time yesterday in Kings County Court, accused of the strychnine murder of his pregnant wife, Harriet, in December 1943.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 10 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly introduced a resolution today calling for the independence of Libya in 1952, three years from the adoption of the proposal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The White House issued today a "box score" on the President's legislative program, terming it "a remarkable record of achievement," after Democratic leaders informed President Truman they expected Congress to adjourn on Saturday.

Exerting a beneficial influence on higher education, the more than 2,000,000 veterans who have attended American colleges and universities in the last four years have helped raise standards on the nation's campuses. Almost everywhere they have brought to classrooms maturity and an attitude of serious motivation.

Development of a time-saving chemical method portending increased production of insulin was announced here last night by Dr. James R. Killian Jr., president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "Master of Bankdam," a British-made drama, which will arrive on Saturday at the Embassy Theatre, Park Avenue and Forty-second Street. The drama, presented by J. Arthur Rank and dealing with the development of the Yorkshire woolen mills, features Anne Crawford, Dernnis Price, Tom Walls and Stephen Murray. Walter Forde directed.

The special dispatch from Tel Aviv published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 5 regarding the "amalgamation" of Jaffa with Tel Aviv is a veritable slap in the face of the United Nations. It is a slap by the hand of an arrogant infant in the face of an indulgent and doting parent.
Designs for the new $9,765,000 tuberculosis hospital in the East Bronx, to provide 500 beds, received the Art Commission's preliminary approval yesterday at the October meeting.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Oct. 10 -- The Port of New York Authority today renewed its two-year-old proposal for operation of the Hoboken piers. Mayor Fred M. De Sapio, who rejected the original offer, said he would give an answer within a few weeks.

Four candidates for appointment by President Truman as Federal Judges for the Southern District were approved yesterday by the New York County Lawyers Association, through its board of directors. The association, in the same fashion, passed judgment on candidates for judicial office at next month's elections.

Optimism concerning a possible early settlement of the steel and coal controversies cooled somewhat yesterday and traders on the stock market turned their attention to issues other than the "pivotal" type. Prices fluctuated irregularly and closed mixed in slightly slower dealings.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The New York Central Railroad makes no effort to attract the traveling public to use West Shore railroad trains, and trains are arbitrarily discontinued with no notice to the public or regard to public necessity and convenience, Frederick H. Stang, Ulster County attorney, said this afternoon.

When that much-discussed "fact-finding committee" after considerable deliberation reported its conclusion that increases in wages are not justified at present, it performed a portion of what might have been an outstanding service to the nation -- including each of its varied groups.

Homemakers without set ideas about room arrangement, who would like to be free to move the furniture from place to place, would have a fine time with the four rooms newly decorated by William Pahlmann for Blooming- dale's. The rooms are filled with the easy-to-push-around furniture- on-wheels that Mr. Pahlmann introduced under the name of "Momentum" earlier this year.

Nathan Wilson, operator, has purchased two hotel properties from the Knott Corporation. They are the Hotel Bryant, at the southwest corner of Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street, and the Hotel Collingwood, at 45 West Thirty-fifth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- London butchers who are having to face angry housewives for the fourth week because they are unable to deliver the regular 2s 4d meat rations as the result of the Smithfield market "slowdown" sent a deputation to John Strachey, Minister of Food, today as ask him to intervene in the dispute which has caused them Serious financial loss.

The report of R. H Mary Co., Inc., and subsidiaries, released yesterday for the fiscal year ended on July 31, showed net earnings of $6,834,000, based on the "Lifo" method of inventory keeping, a decrease of 17 per cent from the previous fiscal year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- The trial for fraud of Preston T. Tucker and seven other present and former officials of Tucker Corporation was adjourned abruptly today by Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy after the defense asked for a mistrial. The defense motion, on which a ruling will be made tomorrow morning, was made after a Government witness blurted out the information that one of the defendants has a criminal record.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of Ford Motor Company, confirmed here today that talks between himself, his advisers and Harry Ferguson, British inventor who is suing the Ford company in America for alleged patent infringements, had broken down completely.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic and Liberal candidate for Senator, yesterday urged all persons eligible to vote in this year's elections to register this week so they can cast their ballots on election day.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 10 -With a record-breaking score of 135, Al Brosch of the Cherry Valley Club added the Long Island P. G. A. crown to his list in the 36-hole championship test held at the Garden City Country Club today.

CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 10 -- Limping painfully as the result of a hip injury suffered when thrown from a half-wild pony on a mountain pass in Tibet last month, Lowell Thomas emerged from the wilderness today with an account of growing fear in the Land of the Living Buddha as Chinese Communist armies approached its Lorders.

DAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 10 -Delaney Kiphuth, son of Bob Kiphuth, Yale's famous swimming mentor, is in his first year as head coach of Hotchkiss School's football team, but the new pilot is hoping to continue the family's aquatic interest by helping Coach Bill Stakely with the swimming squad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- President Truman called on Congress today to provide the money before it adjourns to carry out the $1,314,010,000 military assistance program approved late last month to strengthen the defenses of much of the non-communist world.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- A new theory on the origin of the earth and other planets of the solar system was advanced here tonight by Dr. Gerard P. Kuiper, noted Netherlands born astronomer of the University of Chicago.
MILAN, Italy, Oct. 7 -- A consciously progressive managerial and technical middle class gradually emerging in Italy.

First steps have been taken by a leading cutting tool manufacturer to completely eliminate multiple chain discounts in pricing and to substitute a new system of net pricing in industrial sales throughout the country. Carl J. Linxweiler, sales manager of Threadwell Tap Die Company, Greenfield, Mass., revealed yesterday that his company is now introducing a new system to replace old trade customs which were "unwieldly, costly and a source of error."

The thirty-one nations which participated in the four-month-long tariff discussions at Annecy, France, this summer, have just published a list of the concessions agreed upon. Covering many thousands of items, the list comprises a book more than an inch thick.

In the present troubled world Judaism has a message not only for Jews but for all mankind, Rabbi Abram V. Goodman of Temple Emanu-El, Davenport, Ia., said last night at exercises opening the twenty-eighth academic year of the Jewish Institute of Religion, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

Among the brave men of the town, take respectful notice of S. M. Chartock, who is endeavoring to produce Gilbert and Sullivan without the support of an acting organization fifty years old. Having begun with an unsatisfactory "Mikado" last week, he has come up with "The Pirates of Penzance," which is not very satisfactory now but ought to be in crisper form by the end of the week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, the President's military aide, declared today that there were only "two people" he had to please -- Mr. Truman and Mrs. Vaughan -- and indicated that he felt unconcern for his detractors if he could go on helping veterans.

Soviet farm capacity "is far too small to support the present industrial output and the large urban population associated with this," it is indicated by a three-year study of Russian farm statistics in the Food Research Institute of Stanford University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, told Congress tonight that the heat of its investigation of Navy discontent with military policies could "do grave damage to our national security."

The first split season period on waterfowl opened in Maine and New Hampshire over the past week-end, and although the turnout is never large for the early shooting, excellent reports came in from most of the popular gunning spots.

Twenty-eight claimants were eliminated yesterday by Surrogate William T. Collins as heirs to the $4,984,683 estate left by Miss Mary Bullock Powers, 72-year-old recluse, who died July 20, 1948, in her apartment in the Hotel Seymour, 50 West Forty-fifth Street.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 -- Research grants totaling $76,000 from Denmark and Canada to the United States were announced tonight as the New England and American Diabetes Associations opened National Diabetes Week at a public meeting here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A delegation from the National Non-Partisan Committee, including Paul Robeson, one of its co-chairmen, and O. John Rogge, former assistant attorney general, visited the Department of Justice today to ask quashing of the indictments against twelve Communist leaders.

Steel operations in this second week of the sixth major strike in the industry's history are scheduled to rise 1.1 points from last week's rate to 9.3 per cent of theoretical capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 -- The United States can no longer afford many of the obsolete forms of city growth that have accompanied the growth of its urban population, Frederick Clark, director of the Regional Plan Association, Inc., of New York, told the American Society of Planning Officials tonight.

Four new Queens elementary schools, erected at a cost of more than $7,500,000 as part of the Board of Education's post-war building program, were dedicated yesterday, Mayor O'Dwyer, who was to have participated in the four exercises, failed to attend because of the pressure of business.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 10 -Delegation of nine counties today debated the 1950 net budget of $37,225,012 for United Nations' operations, as presented by Secretary General Trygve Lie. The majority pressed for additional savings over and above the $4,000,000 pared by Mr. Lie from his original estimate.

The most complicated and strongly disputed item remaining on the agenda for a state treaty for Austria was tackled yesterday by the Deputy Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union as they resumed negotiations here.

WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 10 -The country's leaders in the fields of flood control and soil conservation heard a plea today for the establishment of a Federal Department of Natural Resources. They had gathered in Wheeling for the start of a bi-state convention of the American Forestry Association, to be highlighted on Wednesday with the dedication of the $45,000,000 Muskingum River Valley project in Southeastern Ohio.
Despite the bearish Government cotton crop estimate, the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 17 points higher than on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Congress was told today that prices generally might have reached the same "period of stabilization on a high plateau" that preceded the financial crash of 1929.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 10 -- In a tripartite statement issued here tonight the Allied High Commissioners formally charged that the new East German Government "is devoid of any legal standing" and predicted that the elections in Eastern Germany would take place only when it was certain that "they shall follow the pattern already set in the other satellite states."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Society of Industrial Realtors announced today that it had selected Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of directors of General Motors Corporation, to receive the society's 1949 industrial award.

This week marks the second annual Fine Food Festival at Macy's. Within the eighth floor grocery department are all the come-ons of the county fair, plus the same amazing array of edibles and potables one views at that rural carnival.

Venerable Harvard graduates tell of a time when any woman crossing the Yard -- even a scrub woman with a pail and mop, bound on her lawful errands -- was greeted with coyotelike howls from every available window. This is not the case today. Women can now take graduate work at Harvard, or, under Harvard professors, at Radcliffe, in the arts and sciences, engineering, medicine, dentistry, public health, architecture, education, public administration and business management.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10 -- The mandamus suit of Miss Esther McCready, Negro, to compel her admission to the School of Nursing, of the University of Maryland, the first of several such cases of widespread interest throughout the South because they question the validity of the Regional Compact on education, was dismissed today after hearing in the Baltimore City Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The United States Embassy in Prague has protested the arrest and five-day detention in solitary confinement of a United States student in Czechoslovakia on a scholarship awarded by that country's Ministry of Education.

Danish gymnasts almost literally mopped up a gym floor with one another yesterday. They were demonstrating a few tricks of balance, suppleness and grace in a two-hour exhibition that had a couple of hundred physical education students from New York University gasping.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 10 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, declared today he was confident that the United States still held the lead in the weapons of war.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10 -- A mass celebration of the discovery of America atop Mexico's famous volcano Popocatepetl cost at least two lives and a number of casualties.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 -- With strong emphasis on the essential need for good international business relations, Government officials and industry leaders opened the twenty-first annual Boston Conference on Distribution here today in the Statler Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 10 -- In the small community of Silvi Marina, 130 Italian war orphans, from 5 to 16 years, old, are waiting hopefully for help from the United States -- for help that will enable them to put a roof on their first permanent home.
Mayor O'Dwyer stressed yesterday the importance of modifying the present building code to facilitate the construction of large theatre buildings that can be operated on a sound economic basis.

It is unusual to be able to order the work of a well-known artist at a budget price and even in a choice of colors, but exactly this may now be done by collectors who like ceramics. The Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, is offering a new collection of ceramic pieces for the home that have been specially designed by the American painters and sculptors associated with that group.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, will leave on his scheduled speaking tour of strike areas, and Federal proposals for discussions with Bethlehem Steel management will not interfere with his program, it was announced here today.

Swift Co. has appointed the Bob White Organization, Chicago, as exclusive agent for the national sale of its Park Lane brand of canned poultry products, it was announced yesterday. Park Lane canned whole chicken is now being introduced in a few select test markets.

A good many things in life are intriguing, at least momentarily. Set down the novel and the movie before the blonde, and perhaps even before the world series. Taste in such things changes and interest passes, and what may have seemed like a very fine book no longer ago than yesterday is, this evening, a very bad Western, in color.

In two proceedings in United States District Court yesterday one Federal judge reserved decision on a motion to transfer the second Alger Hiss perjury trial to Rutland, Vt., while another denied a defense plea for a two-month delay before the retrial began.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- Senator John Foster Dulles asserted today that former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic-Liberal rival in the Senate race, had raised the "bigotry" issue as a defense against the legitimate criticism that the Communists were supporting Mr. Lehman's candidacy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The Democratic party's farm leaders in Congress scheduled a talk with President Truman tomorrow for a showdown on new farm legislation.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 10 -- Archbishop Josef Beran is quoted in a document that reached Western quarters today as declaring to the Roman Catholic clergy of Czechoslovakia that to give public support to the Government's proposed new church law is "treason to the Christian faith and to the holy Church."

Funds authorized to the Board of Water Supply for construction of the Delaware water supply project since Jan. 1, 1946, total $172,760,000 and the cost of all contracts actually awarded since then is more than $125,000,000, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday in a report.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia; Oct. 10 -- The attitude of the United States and the other Western powers toward the Belgrade-Moscow struggle has become a subject of increasing interest as well as concern to more articulate elements among the Yugoslavs who have followed closely the rapid deterioration of relations with the Soviet Union in recent weeks.
An intensified national drive for 30,000 new members was opened yesterday by Hadassah, Women's Zionist Organization of America, at an emergency membership conference at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

OSLO, Norway, Tuesday, Oct. 11 -- A Communist debacle is heralded by the early returns from yesterday's Norwegian parliamentary election. Communist Leader Emil Loevlien appears to have lost his seat and altogether the Communists seem destined to lose five or even six of their eleven seats in the Storting.

Vowing that the Dodgers would come back next year to atone for their crushing world series defeat at the hands of the Yankees, and absolving his manager, Burt Shotton, of any blame for the disaster, Branch Rickey declared yesterday he would bend every effort to put together a team in Brooklyn that will defeat the American League next October.
Escarp, owned by M. Andrew Cushman, was the surprise winner of the New York Turf Writers Cup at the opening of the two-day meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association at Belmont Park yesterday.

Unusual weather conditions over most of the nation resulted yesterday in new heat records for the day in the East and high winds in the West. The wind in the West reached a peak speed of 120 miles an hour in Colorado and blew at a consistent 95 miles an hour over the crop - bearing areas of the Midwest.
A fanciful tale of a $32,000 armed hold-up on an IRT subway train about to pull into Grand Central was unfolded dramatically yesterday by an old salt trying to deceive his young wife.

George Orwell, English author of "Nineteen Eighty-Four," which was recently published here, has won the first annual Partisan Review Award of $1,000 for a significant contribution to literature. It was made "not for a single book, but for a distinguished body of work."

Newbold Morris, the Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, devoted his principal speech yesterday, broadcast over station WNBC, to answering Mayor O'Dwyer's declaration that under the O'Dwyer regime the citizens had achieved a "richer life."

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, Soviet Commander in Chief in Germany, announced tonight that his Government had transferred to the newly created People's Chamber the administrative functions heretofore handled by the Soviet Military Administration.

The State of Iowa announced yesterday that it would offer $8,750,000 of war service compensation bonds on Nov. 2. The offering will mark the second installment of a total authorized borrowing of $35,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Radio Corporation of America showed publicly today its all electronic color television system for the benefit of the Federal Communications Commission.

Charles F. Noyes will be the guest speaker at the first of a series of fall luncheon meetings of the Young Men's Real Estate Association this noon at the Longchamps Restaurant on Fifty-seventh Street near Fifth Avenue.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Trailing far back in the early stages of the event, Woodland Farm's Picture Card, a 38-to-1 shot, turned it on in the charge through the stretch to win the feature Sherwood Purse by a head at Garden State Park today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The net income after taxes of American manufacturing corporations dropped $393,000,000 in the second quarter of 1949 to a total of $2,018,000,000. This was $845,000,000 below the total for the comparable period in 1948.
YUMA, Ariz., Oct. 10 (UP) -- Two weary fliers piloted their little cabin plane back to the ground today after setting a new endurance record.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 14 per cent for the week ended Oct. 8, compared with the same period a year ago, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the four weeks sales were 10 per cent lower.

YAKIMA, Wash., Oct. 10 -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas felt lucky today, the eighth day since his chest was crushed by a horse that reared and fell on him. His doctors informed him that he has fourteen fractured ribs, not an unlucky thirteen.

The wave of arrests in Czechoslovakia of government officials, business and professional men and intellectuals is proving to be one of the most important developments in the post-war history of Eastern Europe. The victims appear to number thousands, which would indicate that a definitive drive is under way to purge the country in Stalinist style.
Children as well as parents have a responsibility for improving their communities, it was agreed yesterday by a panel of six teen-aged youngsters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Interstate Power Company, Dubuque, Iowa, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 300,000 shares of $3.50 par value common stock to be sold at competitive bidding.

Elena Nikolaidi, Greek contralto, appeared without fanfare last January and scored a resounding success in her American debut. If there was any doubt that this first recital of hers had introduced a new artist of importance to this country, Miss Nikolaidi dispelled it in a program at Town Hall last night.

Pennsylvania Station received a new station master yesterday. The third holder of the post since the building opened in 1910, he is Herman Flait, who at the age of 46 has a record of thirty years' service with the Pennsylvania Railroad. He succeeds Thomas L. Hawkes, who is on a leave of absence from the job he had held since 1935, when William H. Egan, first holder of the post, was made general station master.

The United Hospital Fund, which is seeking $3,367,513 to meet the 1948 deficits of its eighty-six member voluntary, non-profit hospitals in the five boroughs of the city, is the oldest federated charity in the United States.
The Cooper Union Forum is embarking this week on its ninetieth aniversary -- and in the same setting that Abraham Lincoln used to deliver the speech that won him his first Presidential nomination.

An audience of 1,900 assembled at Carnegie Hall last night for a program by Yehudi Menuhin. It was the violinist's first recital here for more than a year and a half, for he confined his United States schedule last season to a single appearance on behalf of the United Jewish Appeal.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Weather conditions, which were favorable for giving the new winter wheat crop a good start through widespread rains, led to some selling of that grain today, while high winds that accompanied the storm are reported to have resulted in considerable damage to corn by flattening fields or blowing the ears off the stalks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A discussion of the constitutionality of the bitterly fought non-Communist oath demanded under the Taft-Hartley Labor Law began when the Supreme Court today heard the first arguments of its new term.
The Middle West will again present the top college football attraction this week in the meeting at South Bend, Ind., between Notre Dame and Tulane.

V. C. Jesperson has been appointed sales manager of the electronics and merchandising division of the International General Electric Company, to supervise foreign sales of home appliances, radio receivers, construction materials and chemicals.
Many of the reductions in United States tariffs negotiated during the summer at the trade conference at Annecy, France, range up to 50 per cent of former levels.
A large turnout heard Earl Blaik's power-packed Army eleven lauded by Lieut. Doug Kenna, a former backfield star, at the weekly get-together of the football writers at Toots Shor's yesterday.

TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 10 -- Lieut. Gov. Joe Hanley of New York tonight challenged a review of benefits available to veterans with the comment that "the only things the Spanish War veterans had received in the last twenty years had been promises."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy voted today to conduct public hearings next week in its proposed review of the nation's civilian defenses against possible atomic attack.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The National Industrial Traffic League said today that express rates had reached a peak and it was doubtful that a proposed increase would yield additional revenue to railroads.

A far-reaching plan for the re-organization of the State of Washington Gas and Electric Company has been confirmed as "fair, equitable and feasible," by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe, it was made known yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- Evidence continues to accumulate that the political machine of Georgi M. Malenkov, Deputy Premier in the Soviet Union, is consolidating itself within the Bolshevik party by shoving into limbo all henchmen of the late Andrei A. Zhdanov, whose death already had been preceded by the collapse of his personal influence in the apparatus of the Communist Central Committee.

The contract to build a prototype cargo ship that will serve as a basic model for mass production in an emergency was awarded in Washington yesterday to the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation of Pascagoula, Miss., the New York office of the United States Maritime Commission reported.

Both common and preferred stockholders of West Penn Electric Company overscribed an offering of 856,895 shares of new common stock which had been made available to them under subscription rights and exchange offers that expired last Friday, Earle S. Thompson, president, announced yesterday.
With two victories in Ivy group competition, Pennsylania's team tops Cornell and Yale's surprising eleven, which have one triumph each.

" Horse and buggy facilities for the biggest perishable food market in the world" were deplored yesterday by Representative George McI. Grant, Alabama Democrat and chairman of a House subcommittee investigating markets, after a dawn inspection of Washington Market on the lower West Side.

Department stores and other large-volume purchasers of major appliances will attempt to persuade distributors to fill heavy orders for them at the expense of smaller retailers if current shortages in some items grow more acute, buyers reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -The National Farmers Union urged today that Congress enact legislation to give the Federal Government clear title to submerged coastal lands.

The Sheffield Farms Company announced yesterday reductions in the retail prices of milk. The Borden Company promptly declared that it would meet the cuts, although Francis R. Elliott, the president, said that no economic justification existed for lower quotations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Government today announced early renewal of its mediation efforts in the steel pension dispute that has made idle 500,000 workers since Oct. 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 -- Employers were advised tonight by Robert N. Denham, General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, not to "try to beat" the Taft-Hartley Law nor to "try to use it as a medium for breaking down the union that may be in your shop or that is coming into your shop."

Syndicate termination and sudden price declines in new bond issues not wholly distributed have returned to plague the primary market for new corporate bonds after a long period in which underwriting houses had smooth market sailing, despite the competitive temptation toward overpricing.

METHUEN, Mass., Oct. 10 -- An apparent attempt to wreck the Boston Maine Railroad's Rockingham Racer, carrying hundreds of race track fans to Rockingham Park, N. H., was averted today by an alert policeman.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 10 -- Charges and counter-charges were exchanged today as the Soviet Union and Poland sought to rebut and Yugoslavia attempted to sustain her indictment of Russia's economic relations in the satellite sphere as "imperialistic exploitation."

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Herbert Morrison, Deputy Prime Minister and the Labor party's chief political manager, took the Opposition press severely to task today for what he called "partisan distortion" and "emphasis on trivialities."

A total of 1,968,424 persons traveled between the United States and foreign countries by sea and air transport in the period July 1, 1948, to June 30, 1949, according to the fiscal-year report of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, out yesterday.

A hundred engineers, geologists and Government officers opened the twenty-fourth annual meeting of the American Shore and Beach Preservation Association yesterday at the Astor Hotel with a discussion of public beach development.

" The shorter, the more feminine," describes the newest coiffures created by many of the topflight stylists in the field. "And no shingle" is the experts' next firm stipulation. However their scissors may snip, there seems no danger of styles becoming boyish, for the greatest emphasis placed by all stylists of the short coiffure is on femininity and individuality.

What was formerly dubbed "Double Bill," which embraces two short plays, "The Browning Version" and "A Harlequinade" (both written by Terence Rattigan, author of "The Winslow Boy" and "O Mistress Mine"), is now referred to simply as "The Browning Version."

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- A new practice of periodical consultations among the United States Ambassadors in Europe is expected to grow out of the meeting scheduled to be held in Paris on Oct. 21 of the principal American diplomats in Western Europe.

William Rosen, missing prosecution witness in the first Alger Hiss trial, appeared under subpoena in Federal Court yesterday. He was released from Federal Bureau of Investigation custody only after he promised Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell that he would be on hand to testify at the second trial.

Underwriting the economic stability of Europe at the cost of $5,500,000,000 annually has prevented the "inundation" of the Continent by communism, Vice President Albert W. Barkley, declared yesterday. The worth of guaranteed economic and political freedom in countries friendly to the United States, he said, cannot be measured in terms of dollars.

Iran has become the first foreign country to announce a complete industrial, social and economic development plan to take full advantage of Point Four of President Truman's program of aiding backward nations with American know-how. An increase in Iranian agricultural and industrial output of more than 200 per cent during the next seven years is the goal.
LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The board that controls betting at English race tracks today envisioned a country-wide network of pari-mutuel machines controlled through one central office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- John L. Lewis would refuse to appear before a coal dispute fact-finding board of the type set up by President Truman in the steel industry if the Government officially moved to set up such a board.

Robert M. Kilgore, 25-year-old son of Senator Harley M. Kilgore of West Virginia, was taken yesterday to the psychiatric ward at Kings County Hospital for observation after a disturbance in his apartment at 145 Hicks Street, Brooklyn.

BUFFALO, Oct. 11 -- Senator John Foster Dulles told voters here today that former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic-Liberal rival for the Senate, possessed a blindness toward the danger of communism in this country that should totally disqualify him for high political office.

Six new films, including importations from England, France and Italy, open in first-run theatres this morning.
