Heading the Columbus Day arrivals is "Christopher Columbus," British-made biography starring Fredric March in the title role and Florence Eldridge (Mrs. March), at the Victoria. The J. Arthur Rank presentation, which was filmed in Technicolor and is being released by Universal-International, was directed by David-MacDonald from a screen play by Muriel and Sydney Box and Cyril Roberts.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 11 -- The Norwegian Labor party won a smashing victory in Monday's Parliamentary elections. Final results may show the complete exclusion of the Communists from the Storting [Parliament]. If this is so, it will be the first time this has happened in Western Europe since World War II.
Your editorial of Oct. 7 favoring extension of social security, so emotionally appealing, leaves the reader with one question: How far Can we go without endangering our economy?

Members of the American Shore and Beach Preservation Association attending their twenty-fourth annual convention here ended the two-day meeting yesterday with an automobile tour of some of the major parkways and three public beaches in the metropolitan area.

Activity in rubber futures increased on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, with turnover amounting to 1,210 long tons, compared with 680 on Monday. Prices sagged 10 to 15 points in the early trading because of easier markets at London and Singapore.
LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Dave Sands, Australian triple champion, tonight won a ten-round decision over Pete Mead of Grand Rapids, Mich., before a capacity crowd of 10,000 at Harringay Arena.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- In a note to Moscow published tonight the British Government declared that the Soviet Union's policy for the unification of Germany was to "establish a highly centralized German administration in which the Communist party would have an influence out of all proportion to their strength in the country."

SOUTH CARVER, Mass., Oct. 11 -- Cranberry harvesting is at its peak this week here in the state that grows three-fifths of the world's crop. Though it is not expected that the yield will equal the record of 1948, it will be adequate to provide a supply of the little red berries that will last in canned form until pickin' time comes round again next fall.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 11 -- The Soviet Union, yielding to the will of the majority of the Governments in the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee, withdrew today its objections to a technical assistance conference to finance a United Nations expanded program of technical aid to underdeveloped countries.

ROME, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Vatican sources said today the Lateran Cross had been awarded to William Randolph Hearst, American publisher, by the canons of the Basilica of St. John Lateran in Rome. This is a simple medal and not an award from Pope Pius XII, the sources added.

In 1880, one year after the founding of the United Hospital Fund, which was known then as the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, this city had a population of 1,911,698. It was computed that there was charitable provision in the voluntary hospitals for 1,800 patients.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Navy men in effect appealed today to the country over the heads of the highest military authority to repudiate as "ruthless and barbaric" and militarily unsound the Air Force plan of strategic atom bombing that would mean "the random manslaughter of men, women and children in the enemy country."
Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, asserted yesterday that Federal aid to education was needed to remedy "gross in- equalities" in educational opportunity.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 11 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that the United Nations Security Council adopt a declaration stating that it "deems necessary the submission by member states of information on conventional armaments as well as information on atomic weapons."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder told the sixth annual meeting of correspondent institutions of the Pennsylvania Company for Banking and Trusts today that the national income is currently running $4,000,000,000 a year ahead of last year's rate of $209,000,000,000.
Chain stores in the metropolitan area will cut milk prices up to 1 1/2 cents a quart tomorrow, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Socialist parties of Europe have been receiving so many knocks in the last year or two that the resounding victory of the Norwegian Labor party in Monday's election deserves notice. It is proof that Socialism of a certain type is still popular.

Formation of a new Philadelphia investment firm with the name of Tyson Co., Inc., was announced yesterday by Albert B. Tyson, president. Other officers are Joseph Tyson, vice president; Harold R. Tyson, vice president, and Gilbert Parker, secretary-treasurer.

The Democratic National Committee hopes to raise $250,000 at a $100-a-plate fund-raising dinner in New York on Dec. 2, William M. Boyle, new Democratic National chairman, announced yesterday after a luncheon meeting with leading Democrats from New York and other states.

Each piece up to true connoisseur standards, the showing of furs by Alfred Rainer yesterday at his salon at 17 East Fifty-fifth Street was a pleasure to view for its great fashion sense and superb simplicity.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A young Negro boxer, felled by a smashing head blow in the ring last night, died today with a blood clot on the brain. The death of Talmadge Bussey, 26 years old, was the eighth recorded ring fatality in the world this year.
Crosley Motors, Inc., reported yesterday a net loss of $1,030,309 for the year ended on July 31. A year earlier the company had disclosed a net profit of $1,496,854.
For just a fleeting moment yesterday, fear gripped 7,500 persons watching the performance of the twenty-fourth annual rodeo at Bellevue Hospital's outdoor arena.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- An examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today to the commission that cancellation of pickup and delivery service by two railroads at 57 points in New England and New York was justified.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 11 -- The Government press office announced today that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs had demanded the Albanian Government cease repeated border incidents, which, it is asserted here, were being engineered to provoke Yugoslavia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Brokers on the Board of Trade expressed a belief this afternoon that the Government's estimate on corn, showed too small a drop -- 60,000,000 bushels in September -- to have much effect on the market when it reopens on Thursday. The figures on soybeans, however, were somewhat in excess of trade expectations.

Buyers' Total Higher Out-o'f-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended ,yesterday numbered 2,766, comtapered with 915 last week and 1,469 in the similar week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEV YORK TIME. There were 765 arrivals yesterday against 331 last Tuesday.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Overhauling the front - running Whiffenpoof less than forty yards from home, Mrs. William E. Snell's Penson sped to a thrilling half-length victory in the National Park Purse at Garden State Park today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -After thirty-two years, Cohen, Goldman Co., Inc., a New York clothing manufacturer, will receive from the Government final payment on uniforms made for World War I use.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 11 -- A full-dress attack on the United States and Britain on charges of Using the United Nations to further their "frustrated" ambitions in the Balkans was launched here today by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister.

The United Seamen's Service, which has threatened to close its doors three times since the war owing to a lack of funds, is now not only financially sound but has undertaken an expansion program to bring its services within the reach of more seamen, it was announced yesterday.
United States and Canadian airmen will fly wing to wing in an "attack" on New York, scheduled for Oct. 22, it was announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The first ten days of the national steel strike dropped iron ore shipments from upper Lake ports below the 1948 level for the first time this season. The Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today that ore shipments for the week ending yesterday morning were 553,486 tons, compared with 2,421,678 tons in the similar week of 1948.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- President Truman cautioned Democratic farm leaders of Congress today against lower price supports for basic commodities, approved by the Senate, lest the party lose the farm vote in future elections. That, according to those who attended, was the principal point made by the President at a White House conference with Congressional farm leaders and Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, arrived here by air from London this afternoon and began a three-week-long visit with the expressed hope that the United States Government and his would form a relationship that would result to the "mutual advantage" of both and the "good of humanity."

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11 -- John H. Mize of Atchison, Kan., president of the National Wholesale Hardware Association, said today that while the first nine months of this year produced a decrease in sales volume of about 12 to 14 per cent compared with the same period in 1948, the outlook for the wholesale hardware industry is "optimistic."

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 11 -- After seven arduous weeks' negotiations the round-table conference on Indonesia has ground to a halt and for the first time since the two parties sat down together here the possibility of the conference's failing was being take into account today.

Hopes for a formula to solve both the steel and coal strikes were reborn yesterday and immediately were reflected in higher prices on the stock market. Demand for railroad issues generated a rally that carried prices ahead fractions to 2 points and raised the composite rate to a top unequaled since last Nov. 1. Final quotations were slightly below the day's peaks, with an over-all gain of 0.93 point.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Legislation which "would provide the opening wedge for competition by government-financed Rural Electrification Administration cooperatives with privately owned telephone companies" in rural areas "quite probably" will be passed by Congress before adjournment and "most surely" will be signed by the President, it was predicted today.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a deficit of $5,206,569 from operations in the first eight months of this year. This compared with a loss of $1,458,974 in the same 1948 period.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- Surgical use of nylon membrane for restoring mobility to arthritic joints was publicly demonstrated for the first time today at the Robert Breck Brigham Hospital, where the technique was developed.

Inaugurated yesterday as the second president of Queens College, Dr. John J. Theobald warned that fear of being labeled radical was causing many Americans to give up the fight for good social causes. He declared that this was playing into the hands of extremists.

GENEVA, Oct. 11 -- Marshal Tito's efforts to keep the Yugoslav economy from foundering, in the face of the blockade by Communist Information Bureau states, are threatened with failure because of a lack of freely available foreign exchange, a reliable Western source said here today.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt asserted yesterday in a radio broadcast that former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman's experience and knowledge were needed urgently in the United States Senate.

The New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra's deficit for 1948-49 was $43,975.78, and an even larger deficit is expected next year, Floyd G. Blair, treasurer, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York at Steinway Hall.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- The seventh annual Westchester Better Homes Exposition, sponsored by the White Plains Civic and Business Federation, opened this afternoon in the county center. One hundred fifty exhibitors are displaying an estimated million dollars' worth of gadgets, appliances, foods and furnishings for the home.
The Congress of the United States is just negotiating the act which would enable the displaced persons to emigrate to the United States.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- British Government stocks continued to decline on the stock markets here today as business slowed, but leading industrials advanced.

Newbold Morris, the Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Mayor, said yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer had "no interest in city government, only in politics,'' and he declared that the Mayor was runnig for office now only to keep himself in politics so that he could run for some other office in the near future.

In an article by Will Lissner which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Oct. 5, he states that The Daily Worker circulation is declining. A report which he claims was made by me, as general manager of the newspaper, was supposed to have stated that the circulation had fallen to 19,000 and that as a result of two campaigns for subscriptions the circulation, as reported over the last twelve months, was 23,400.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- The jury hearing the fraud and conspiracy case against Preston T. Tucker and seven other individuals who took part in his automobile promotion was dismissed today by Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy and a new trial was ordered to start next Monday, Oct. 17.

A method by which hidden microphones and wire recorders used to eavesdrop on sales personnel of stores was disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The threat of a possible boycott of Atlantic Coast ports, with a resultant diversion of cargoes to Gulf of Mexico or Canadian harbors, apparently had a sobering effect upon longshoremen and their employers and yesterday's meeting of representatives from both sides was marked by a conciliatory attitude.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 11 -- Yale's long football practice today for the visit of Cornell to the Bowl next Saturday was marked by good humor.

" Not So Long Ago," a new study of America by Lloyd Morris, has been scheduled for Nov. 7 publication by Random House. The volume presents a history of the radio, the automobile and the motion pictures and analyzes their influence on the color and content of American life.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 -- Goose-stepping policemen, battalions of youth in a torchlight parade, floodlights and fireworks featured the strongest upsurge of German nationalism since the Hitler era today as the population of the Soviet zone and the Eastern sector of Berlin acclaimed Wilhelm Pieck's election as President of the new Eastern state.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct., 11 -- A five-minute inquest was conducted here today by Coroner Theodore E. Steiber in the "mercy killing" of Sergt. Carl Paight of the Stamford Police Department on Sept. 23 in Stamford Hospital.

Governor Dewey inspected four cooperative housing sites in Queens yesterday and extolled the virtues of private financing of home construction, which he said was the only way the housing shortage could be solved.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Jim Turnesa, Briar Hall Country Club professional, and his amateur partner, Dr. Ray House of the same club, topped a field of fifty teams with a best-ball of 33, 33 -- 66 to win the final Westchester P. G. A. pro-amateur tournament today at the Metropolis Country Club.
NASHVILLE, Ark., Oct. 11 -- A military prisoner bailed out of an Air Force plane on a dare over southwest Arkansas today. He was caught five hours later walking along a highway.

After a two-hour argument yesterday Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter reserved decision on a motion for a temporary injunction brought by the American Guild of Variety Artists, AFL, to restrain James C. Petrillo and his American Federation of Musicians, also AFL, from interfering with the guild.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Hope for adjournment of Congress Saturday dwindled almost to the vanishing point today as the Democratic leadership of the Senate, striving to speed its schedule, found itself blocked in efforts to advance several important bills.

BUFFALO, Oct. 11 -- A five-man fact-finding board, appointed last week by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, will begin its inquiry here tomorrow into the seventeen-week-old Bell Aircraft strike.

Spurred by the unseasonably warm weather, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's runaway century plant had shot five feet above the roof of the desert greenhouse yesterday. Gardeners were anxiously scanning the weather reports for hope of cooler, less stimulating weather.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on a compromise bill to raise the pay of 253 top Federal officials by $1,000 to $7,500 annually.

ALBANY, Oct. 11 -- Senator Austin W. Erwin, chairman of the State Commission on Agriculture, said today that announcement of milk price reductions in the New York area proved the commission's contention that New York City milk distribution costs could be reduced to benefit consumers.

The Girls Service League will be the beneficiary of the performances of the Terence Rattigan plays "The Browning Version and Harlequinade," with Maurice Evans and Edna Best in the leading roles, on Monday night at the Coronet Theatre.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- Many retailers believe the achievement of greater productivity by employes represents the most urgent problem of retailing today, Delbert J. Duncan, professor of marketing, Cornell University, declared today. He addressed business leaders at the closing session of the two-day conference on distribution held in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The New England Public Service Company, Augusta, Me., received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to extend for another year from this date the maturity of $10,300,000 of promissory notes held by the First National Bank of Boston and four other banks and trust companies.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, gave the first concert of its New York series of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Ormandy was warmly welcomed when he appeared. At the end he and the orchestra were applauded long and loudly.

Top merchandising executives of New York and other large metropolitan stores were among the spectators at showings Of spring and resort dress lines that opened yesterday, according to local manufacturers. Their attendance, it was said, forecasts closer liaison between store management and buyers on the new apparel lines.

Representatives of industry sought to appraise yesterday competitive effects of the Annecy tariff reductions but few immediate major complaints appeared. However, Richard H. Anthony, secretary of the American Tariff League, charged that many of the new reductions have been compounded to 75 per cent of the 1930 tariff rate.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Financial accounts of Britain's three state-owned airlines published here today show that in the fiscal year ended last March 31 aggregate operating deficit was reduced by 12.2 per cent.

WOR-TV, the seventh and final commercial video station authorized for the metropolitan area, made its official debut last night on Channel 9. The first personality to be seen over the station was John Gambling, a WOR radio veteran of twenty-five years.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Construction of a 1,000-car garage by private eneterprise on city-owned property to relieve traffic congestion in mid-Manhattan was proposed today by Charles Schnurmacher, president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The champion Philadelphia Eagles and the Washington Redskins are setting the pace defensively and offensively, respectively, in the National Football League.

Coach Lou Little put Columbia's football Lions through one of the most intensive workouts of the season at Baker Field yesterday. Playing under the lights during the latter half of the practice session, the squad worked on its offense and defense throughout the heavy contact scrimmages.

More than fifty post-war posters from sixteen countries make up an exhibition opening today at the Museum of Modern Art. It will remain on view until Nov. 20, and thereafter will circulate in condensed version throughout the country.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Jules Moch, Socialist Minister of the Interior in the Cabinet that fell on Oct. 6, was nominated as Premier tonight. He accepted, and his candidacy for the task of forming a new French Government will be voted on by the National Assembly on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The State Department announced today the availability of 648 Fulbright exchange fellowships for Americans wishing to teach, do research or undertake graduate study in twelve foreign countries or their colonial dependencies.

If you happen to see a man wandering around the National Hardware Show today with a large fishbowl, in which are swimming a number of vari-colored minnows, each glowing with an unearthly light, it will be Eugene Burns of the Firelure Corporation with his latest idea.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- On a mission of revenge, a Tulane eleven bristling with talent and bitter memories of a record 59-6 trimming when last they met two years ago will challenge mighty Notre Dame Saturday.

Commodity Exchange officials here yesterday told the members I of the subcommittee of the House Committee on Agriculture, inspecting New York markets, that the Government should not interfere in commodity speculation and the limitation of margins.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A bill raising veterans' compensation and disability payments by more than $112,000,000 a year was signed yesterday by President Truman.

John E. Slater, president of the American Export Lines, sailed on the Cunard White Star liner Caronia yesterday for a six-week visit to Italy, where he said he would discuss plans with agents for operation of his company's two new liners scheduled for service in late 1950.

Chicago Park District announced yesterday that it will receive bids Oct. 25 on issues of tax-exempt bonds totaling $15,000,000, and consisting of $3,000,000 due Nov. 1, 1968 and callable from May 1, 1950 to 1968, and $12,000,000 due on Nov. 1, 1969 and callable from May 1, from 1951 to 1969.

Reflecting what leaders in the copper industry described as "a healthy and consistent consumers' demand," stocks of domestic refined copper decreased 23,277 tons last month for the first time this year. In August there was an increase of 4,350 tons.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- John L. Keeshin got back in the trucking business today when he and an associate, David H. Ratner, purchased the Hayes Freight Lines, Inc., for a reported $2,000,000. The 23,756-mile line serves 1,700 cities in Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Kentucky and Tennessee.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11 -- Ray Schumacher, McKesson and Robbins, Inc., executive, San Francisco, reported today that for the first time since the war operating expenses in the wholesale drug industry are increasing faster than sales.

Investment banking syndicates competed yesterday for the awards of $13,000,000 of new senior securities, consisting of $8,700,000 of public utility company bonds and $4,300,000 of railroad - equipment obligations. The awards were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The arrival of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru at the Washington Airport this evening symbolizes the fulfillment of a vision that preoccupied the late Franklin D. Roosevelt in the closing days of his life.

Unit sales of Electrolux vacuum cleaners soon will exceed unit volume of all other vacuum cleaners combined, Walter Dietz, president, predicted yesterday in an address before a meeting of the Sales Executive Club of New York in the Roosevelt Hotel.

The possibility of a pay rise for teachers in the New York City schools, to be either scheduled or carried out before election, loomed strongly yesterday. Reports in education circles were that a rise of $500 a year, costing the city a total of $20,000,000, was in the offing.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 11 -- The New Jersey State Golf Association held its final golf tournament of the season at the Upper Montclair Country Club today and followed it with their annual meeting and dinner at which Stephen Berrien, president of the association, lauded the group's solvent condition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, will confer with representatives of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in New York on Thursday on issues in the current strike of 500,000 steel workers.

I have just read the letter of Donald I. Segerstrom of Sonora, Calif., in your issue of Sept. 24, as an answer to the letter of Willard G. Van Name of the Museum of Natural History, which you published Sept. 2, relative to the imminent destruction of the world's most remarkable pine forest in Tuolumne County.

LYDDA, Israel, Oct. 11 -- After three days of mingled hope and frustration, the United Nations economic survey mission for the Middle East, headed by Gordon R. Clapp, flew back to Beirut today to prepare its report, which is expected at the end of the month.

Sam Jethroe, speedy Negro outfielder recently purchased from Montreal by the Braves, visited General Manager John Quinn of the Boston club here yesterday and signed his 1950 contract. Jethroe came to New York from Indianapolis, where he had played for the Royals in the little world series.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -Herbert John Burgman, 53 years old, former clerk in the American Embassy in Berlin, went on trial for treason today in Federal District Court before a jury of seven men and five women.

Oren Root, Republican - City Fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, was accused yesterday by Nathan Straus, former Federal Housing Authority Administrator, of misrepresenting the record of Robert F. Wagner Jr. with respect to public housing.

The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York opened a drive for $500,000 yesterday afternoon with a tea at the Plaza Hotel attended by 500 campaign volunteers. This year's appeal has a larger goal than any of the annual fund-raising efforts in the agency's thirty-seven years, it was said.

TOKYO, Oct. 11 -- The United States occupation forces in Japan constitute a "stabilizing force for the entire Far East and we intend to keep them here as long as it is necessary to do so," Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Chief of Staff of the Army, asserted today.

SO much pure balderdash was uttered by folks in authority both during and after the world series that a few pearls of wisdom dropped by Branch Rickey Jr. might have been overlooked. Said the Twig, "I hope the Yankees are in the series next year because we'll beat 'em for sure." Kindly notice that his only concern was over the ability of the Yanks to make the October wind-up.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Joe Louis, retired heavyweight champion, has a ten-round exhibition arranged tentatively with Johnny Shkor of Baltimore in the Boston Garden next month, but Massachusetts law may prevent it.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 11 -- A flat notice that 500,000 striking steel workers would stay out as long as was necessary to win employer-financed pensions and social insurance was served on the steel industry today by Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Fifteen-year-old Marlene Bauer of Long Beach, Calif., continued to set the pace today as favorites advanced to the second round of the women's Texas open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Good harvest weather is assuring the nation of its second largest volume of crops in history and a record supply of corn for producing meat, dairy and poultry products.

WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. -- Fresh from its opening-game success over Cranwell of Lenox, Mass., last Saturday, Loomis School's football team has the necessary speed and weight that go toward a successful campaign, barring further injuries.

Qualities manifested by Christopher Columbus on his voyage to the New World are the qualities the world needs today, President Truman said last night in a message read to 2,100 guests at a civic dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Scores of posters entered in a Fire Prevention Week contest for New York firemen went on display yesterday at Engine Company 31, at 87 Lafayette Street.
BERLIN, Oct. 11 -- In the light of flickering torches and to the chant of nationalist slogans, the Communist Government of the East German Democratic Republic was inaugurated this evening.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 11 -- The United States agreed today to fly the United Nations flag over United Nations trust territory under its administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Francis p. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, made public today the report of an investigating board absolving all individuals of blame in the death of James Forrestal last May 22. The former Secretary of Defense leaped to his death from an upper story of the Naval Medical Center at Bethesda, Md.
The Government's close watch of departing foreign liners for subversive agents seeking to slip out of the country is to be tightened up and expanded, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -Two television manufacturers who have been experimenting with color sets estimated today that they could market them at prices ranging from $220 to $304.
Mayor O'Dwyer, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard and other city officials spoke yesterday at ceremonies marking the establishment of the new Harlem Welfare Center.

Pointing out that more than 13,000,000,000 pounds of food are received each year by the markets and wholesale and retail stores of this city, Mayor O'Dwyer described yesterday the work the Department of Markets has done in supervising the food industry since he took office on Jan. 1, 1946.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Political promises sometimes come home to roost.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A Government foreign policy spokesman made it clear today that Continental sensitivities regarding European unity and Britain's part in it would not be permitted to interfere with collaboration among the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada toward solving the dollar-sterling problem.

Testifying on behalf of the Navy in its current controversy with the Army, Commander Eugene Tatom told the House Armed Services Committee that "you could stand in the open at one end of the north-south runway at the Washington National Airport with no more protection than the clothes you now have on, and have an atom bomb explode at the other end of the runway without serious injury to you."

The critical question of what is termed oil "exploration rights" in Austria was tackled yesterday by the Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies at their regular meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where they are negotiating a treaty for Austria.

A 21-year-old City College student was shot at 9:15 o'clock last night as he fought off four men who attempted to molest a classmate with whom he was walking through St. Nicholas Park near West 135th Street.

HONG KONG, Oct. 11 -- Communist vanguards were reported to have pushed almost unopposed to within fifty miles of Canton tonight as a disintegrating Nationalist regime rushed the evacuation of its refugee capital.

A five-man Administrative Committee of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, named by Michael J. Quill, international president, and other members of the International Executive Committee took possession of the offices, books and records of the left-wing Pan American Local 504 in Jackson Heights, Queens, on Monday, it became known yesterday.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 11 (AP) -- William Loeb, publisher of The Burlington Evening News, said the paper's entire force of twenty printers was discharged today for refusal to handle material intended for use in engraved advertisements.

The Board of Elections accepted yesterday the petition nominating three City Fusion party candidates in the Bronx even though the lawyer for the Bronx Democratic organization pleaded that the petition be turned over to the Bronx District Attorney's office because of a large number of alleged forgeries.

The Boston Bruins and the Detroit Red Wings inaugurate the longest season in National Hockey League history tonight when they square off in Detroit in the first game of the 1949-50 campaign. Detroit won the league championship last season, although Toronto captured the Stanley Cup playoff.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Joseph E. Moody, spokesman for the Southern coal producers, declared today that the United Mine Workers' Welfare Fund was "a Tammany Hall organization of handouts."

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Officials of the British Treasury were engaged today on a study of the future role of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation with a view to submitting recommendations to the body's consultative committee at its meeting in Paris late this month..

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 11 -- The round of attacks on the $37,225,012 budget proposed by Secretary General Trygve Lie for the United Nations next year continued today in the Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee. Roland Lebeau of Belgium compared the work of the Information Department to the huckster song in "soap operas."

CLEVELAND, Oct. 11 -- The Federal Housing Act of 1949 was adopted because its supporters achieved an effective political organization through the cooperation of such divergent groups as the United States Conference of Mayors, the American Municipal Association, labor groups, civic associations and religious bodies, Warren J. Vinton, first assistant commissioner of the Public Housing Administration, said today at a meeting of the American Society of planning Officials.

There was a slight drizzle early the other morning, and deep was the despair along the the lower Hudson. A drizzle there could mean drizzle along the Gowanus, with a postponed ball game and the necessity of everyone spending all afternoon just working.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Following is the text of a statement delivered today by Rear Admiral Ralph A. Ofstie to the House Armed Services Commitee in its investigation of the dissatisfaction of some naval officers with high military policy:

Dispelling any doubt regarding his own stand in the matter, President Truman has called on Congress to make good the pledges given in the North Atlantic Treaty and the military assistance program by voting at this session the necessary funds to make both these projects living realities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The twentieth century reconstruction of the White House under its nine-teenth century facade will begin in the middle of November, it was disclosed today, as the White House announced that bids for the work would be opened Oct. 28.

The authority of a hotel to increase by 15 per cent the rentals of permanent guests when the latter comprise less than three-quarters of the hotel's occupants was challenged yesterday in War Emergency Court.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn today sported a fine new Irish shillelagh fit for cracking Democratic heads in the House if the need should arise.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 11 -- As this city sweltered in a spell of uncomfortably hot weather today, plans were being laid for something brand new in fund-raising drives. Starting next Sunday a campaign, sponsored by Mayor John V. Kenny, will get under way to raise $20,000 for the purchase of a snow plow for the Italian hamlet of Capracotta.

The Jonai collection presented yesterday at the luncheon hour in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel offered a large selection of daytime and evening dresses, some suits and town coats. They were custom made and custom order.
BELLMORE, L. I., Oct. 11 -- Maj. Hans Hornbostle and his wife, Gertrude, after spending three years together in a Louisiana leper colony, are starting a new life in their new home here.

A daring sense of humor and a vivid imagination characterize the new designs for wallpaper by Ilonka Karasz that were introduced yesterday at the Katzenbach Warren showroom, 49 East Fifty-third Street. It might take courage to plaster one of Miss

Greatly heartened by their back-to-back victories over the New York Bulldogs and the Washington Redskins, the New York Football Giants yesterday buckled down to work for the home opener of their twenty-fifth season, against the Pittsburgh Steelers at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

WARSAW, Oct. 11 -- Acknowledging that many priests have "strayed" to the Government's side in Poland's church-state struggle, Archbishop Stefan Wyszynski, Roman Catholic Primate, has called upon the rest of the clergy to stand fast and "to fight for every hour of religious teaching that is permitted us."

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 11 -- As this city sweltered in a spell of uncomfortably hot weather today, plans were being laid for something brand new in fund-raising drives. Starting next Sunday a campaign, sponsored by Mayor John V. Kenny, will get under way to raise $20,000 for the purchase of a snow plow for the Italian hamlet of Capracotta.

The Jonai collection presented yesterday at the luncheon hour in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel offered a large selection of daytime and evening dresses, some suits and town coats. They were custom made and custom order.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Having determined that an "emergency" existed in the October egg future, the Board of Governors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced today that, effective at the opening of the market on Thursday, trading in the new contract will be limited to the closing of open commitments.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The Conservatives opened their annual conference today not knowing whether they would have to fight a general election this year or next. Prime Minister Attlee was still keeping them guessing.

The struggle between free American unionism and the Communists seems to be approaching a climax. Whether or not that climax is reached at the forthcoming convention of the CIO, the ultimate conclusion is inevitable: Communist influence in the American labor movement, with perhaps some minor exceptions, is going to be eradicated.
St. Luke's summer -- according to Webster a period of unseasonably warm weather in October -- continued here yesterday with the temperature reaching 85.1 degrees at 2:50 P. M.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 11 -- Mass arrests were resumed on an unprecedented scale in Prague and other parts of the country at dawn today after a two-day let-up. Informed sources believed the total now was approaching 10,000 of which half were in the capital.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 11 -- The American Federation of Labor convention, which closed last night, left no doubt with observers that labor unity is as far from reality as ever.

Henry Obermeyer, formerly director of advertising of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, has resigned to become vice president of Bozell Jacobs, Inc., advertising agency, it was announced yesterday.

A taxpayer's suit aimed at forcing the Board of Education to discontinue using Charles Dickens' novel "Oliver Twist" and Shakespeare's play "The Merchant of Venice" in the city's public schools was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Anthony J. Di Giovanna in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The United States has assigned priority to the rearmament of Western Europe because there is no immediate threat of Communist aggression against the Western Hemisphere, the Inter-American Defense Board heard today from Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

Private philanthropy stimulates the initiative of those who receive its benefits, while "bureaucratic paternalism" tends to an opposite effect, Coverly Fischer said yesterday. He spoke as general fund campaign chairman of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies at a luncheon in the Downtown Athletic Club.

Eugene Dennis, summing up in his own behalf yesterday at the Communist trial, warned that conviction of the Communist leaders would mean outlawing the Communist party, which would mean the organization of new "secret societies." George W. Crockett Jr. of defense counsel also predicted that if the party were outlawed another would take its place.
Two young Argentines turned up yesterday to take a look at Times Square. Unlike most tourists from their native country, they arrived in their own car.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 11 -- Three major operations requiring almost four hours of surgery were televised today from Charity Hospital to a meeting room in a hotel a half-mile away as part of the program of the thirteenth Congress of the International Society of Surgery.
PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Coach Paul Brown angrily threatened today to sell members of his champion Cleveland Browns if they fail to perform better this week-end.
The cotton futures market closed from 6 to 11 points higher yesterday, with a moderate business being done.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11 -- Wall Street and several other New York City locations will provide the background next week for the filming of Robert Montgomery in scenes for "The Witness," which is being produced for the most part in England by David Rose and associates operating under an unusual corporate setup as two separate though related companies, Coronado Productions, Inc., of Hollywood and Coronado Productions England, Ltd., of London.

Two bandits, one armed, robbed a sweater manufacturer, his wife and his brother-in-law last night of $400 and jewelry valued at $2,000 just after the three had finished dinner in the home of the manufacturer in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn.

With no confusion reported, New Yorkers continued yesterday to register in large numbers. A total of 324,752 persons qualified to vote during the day. The total for the two days far surpassed the figure reached for a similar period in 1945, the last Mayoral election year.

Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party nominee for President in 1948, made his first address in the municipal campaign last night. In a 15-minute speech over WJZ under the auspices of the American Labor party, which he called the New York arm of the Progressives, he urged the election of Vito Marcantonio as Mayor.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 -- Maj. Gen. Alexander G. Kotikov, Soviet commandant in Berlin, flatly denied today Western charges that the Russians were creating difficulties on Berlin's railroads. In a letter to the three Western commanders he accused the Western powers of "groundless and artificial charges."
A coordinated program to combat voting frauds in next month's election was put into operation yesterday by the Police Department and the State Attorney General's office.
VIENNA, Oct. 11 -- The Austrian Cabinet presented its resignation to President Karl Renner today but was asked to carry on until a new government could be formed.

Hampton Roads, who hadn't won a steeplechase stake since October of 1947, took horse-of-the-day honors on the second and final afternoon of the United Hunts Racing Association's meeting at Belmont Park yesterday. His strong finish won the Temple Gwathmey Steeplechase and earned jockey-of-the-day honors for Albert Foot.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- Pravda, organ of the Communist party, and Culture and Life, organ of the Communist party Central Committee, today published detailed reviews of a book by Ralph Parker, British newspaper correspondent, charging the British and United States Embassies in Moskow with active preparation of war against the Soviet Union.

Another "name" tennis player deserted the amateur ranks yesterday when the veteran internationalist, Frankie Parker, agreed to turn professional under the direction of Bobby Riggs. Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, United States titleholder in 1948 and 1949, joined the Riggs play-for-pay brigade last month.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 11 -- The job of working out a plan for settling the future of the onetime Italian possessions in Africa was handed today to a special twenty-one nation subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today warned the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers that if its executive board approved the merger arranged with the Farm Equipment and Metal Workers Union "it will be acting directly contrary to a CIO directive."

Two bandits, one armed, robbed a sweater manufacturer, his wife and his brother-in-law last night of $400 and jewelry valued at $2,000 just after the three had finished dinner in the home of the manufacturer in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn.

It was an exciting and provocative evening that the Sadler's Wells Ballet gave us at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, for in the second program of its season it showed us for the first time the work of its own choregraphers. In its first program it had already made its admirable company known to us in an international classic, "The Sleeping Beauty"; here it showed us its creative directions.

Cardinal Spellman denied yesterday the charge by a Soviet representative at the United Nations that he had given $30,000 two years ago to Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty to finance a plot against the Hungarian regime. Cardinal Spellman made his statement on arrival at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from Paris, after his visit to Pope Plus XII in Rome.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Boasts that Russia "governs over one-third of the world and possesses the atom bomb" were made by the prosecution today in an appeal hearing for Laszlo Rajk and five co-defendants.

Columbus Day furniture volume in several department and home furnishings stores exceeded the comparable day last year, buyers reported yesterday. A merchandise manager for a large home furnishings chain said his organization's gain is attributable partly to slow store traffic in 1948 because Columbus Day fell on the eve of an important religious holiday.

Stanley M. Isaacs, Republican-Liberal candidate for re-election to the City Council from the Twentieth District, announced formation of his campaign committee last night at a meeting of the East Side branch of the Americans for Democratic Action at 40 East Fortieth Street.

As a tribute to Abraham Walkowitz on the occasion of his seventieth birthday, the Jewish Museum will open today an exhibition of seventy drawings and paintings by this still-energetic pioneer of the modern movement in America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 5.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 12 -- Soft coal operators and miners went through the motions of bargaining today, as they have been doing here intermittently for nearly four months, and came out with the same answer -- no progress.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- A "serious delay" in efforts to make Europe's Jews self-supporting may be caused by lagging in contributions to the United Jewish Appeal in the United States, Moses A. Leavitt, executive vice chairman of the American Joint Distribution Committee, warned here today at a conference of the committee's officials and program directors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- By the votes of nine Democrats versus six Republicans the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy voted today to absolve David E. Lilienthal and the Atomic Energy Commission of charges of "incredible mismanagement." Two Republican members and one Democratic member did not vote.

HONG KONG, Oct. 12 -- A century of United States trade representation in the big Central China city of Hankow came to an end three weeks ago with the departure of the last American agents of United States business, just one day after the arrival of a Soviet trade mission.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 12 -- Princeton will be ready to throw its full strength against Brown Saturday when the rugged Bruin eleven comes to Palmer Stadium for what shapes up as one of the best football games of the season in the Ivy set.
Nearly 1,000,000 New Yorkers have registered to vote in the first three days of Registration Week, according to an unofficial compilation last night at Police Headquarters.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 12 (AP) -- James Cox Brady's Basis scored an upset triumph in the $7,500 added Quaker City Handicap at Garden State Park today before a crowd of 17,595.

ATHENS, Oct. 12 -- The Greek Government is awaiting a reply from Moscow to a protest, lodged Oct. 7 with the Soviet charge d'affaires here, against the reported deportation under inhuman conditions of about 17,000 Greek subjects in the Soviet Republic of Georgia, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Oct., 12 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson today gave the Senate Foreign Relations Committee a "complete report" on the Far Eastern situation.

The national board of managers of the United Council of Church Women, meeting this week in Los Angeles, voted to join six other national interdenominational bodies in a merger to form a National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, on the second day of his first trip to the United States, placed wreaths on the tombs of George Washington at Mount Vernon and the Unknown Soldier in Arlington Memorial Cemetery. He described the first President of the United States as "one of the really great men of the world."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- With every indication that the action would precipitate a bitter floor fight, the Senate Judiciary Committee today reported out the House-approved bill to liberalize the Displaced Persons Act of 1948.

Department store sales yesterday were reported generally disappointing by retailers here. Although store traffic was extremely heavy in the midtown shopping area particularly, it was estimated that city-wide sales were from 15 to 20 per cent below those made on Columbus Day last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The headline above was not the one used by Secretary of State Acheson today over his report to the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations on the cold war with Russia, particularly in the Far East. Yet the headline summarizes, though bluntly, the point of chief interest to Mr. Acheson and the committee he addressed.

The calm and sociable passage of what was billed in advance as Casey Stengel's "clean-up" press conference at Yankee headquarters yesterday suddenly was enlivened by the interjection of a pointed, and somewhat barbed, query by George Weiss, general manager of the champion Bombers.

New subway cars, buses and trolley coaches ordered by the Board of Transportation in 1946 with the approval of the Board of Estimate will cost the city $44,221,504 instead of the original contract total of $39,393,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- As the European Marshall Plan Council prepares for a new discussion of freer intra-European trade late this month, some Continental members insist that the Council should discuss at the same time the prospects of internal financial stability in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Navy officers pictured the high defense command today as enfeebling the fleet's power to defend the Atlantic pact world and preoccupied with heavy Air Force bombers that could only fight a long "siege" war.

The O'Dwyer campaign will begin in earnest on Monday, and will continue at a fast pace through the following three weeks up to election day, it was said yesterday at the Mayor's headquarters at the Commodore Hotel.

"Holiday in Havana," which opens at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Desi Arnaz and Mary Hatcher are starred in the Columbia comedy with music. Ann Doran, Steven Geray and Minerva Urecal are among the supporting players.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- A great ring career drew to a partial conclusion on a winning note today at the Interstate Kennel Association's dog show. Champion Merry Monarch, 6 1/2-year-old golden brindle boxer from the Claredda Kennels of Glen Head, L. I., went to the top in the 599-dog fixture and immediately afterward Walter C. Foster, his handler, said it was the last all-breed appearance for the great show dog and sire.

OTTAWA, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Canadian newsprint producers have been advised by the Government not to reduce the export price of their product because of the devaluation of the Canadian dollar, it was learned today.

David B. Jarvis, president of Sieling Jarvis, operator of the American-flag tanker Saint Christopher, the crew of which has asked for repatriation after delivering cargoes between Soviet-controlled ports in the Far East, asserted yesterday that the voyage was a "routine commercial operation made with the complete knowledge of the State Department."
DETROIT, Oct. 12 -- A fully automatic torque converter transmission will be available on Mercury and Ford passenger cars next summer, the Ford Motor Company disclosed today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Cooperating to the fullest, breeze and mild fall temperature came through today for the "lay-up" racing off the Larchmont Yacht Club, the final wing-spread of the year for the summer yachts on Long Island Sound.

The quantities of rock salt thrown on the snow and icebound surface of the West Side Highway after the storm of Dec. 26, 1947, have eaten into the pavement and supporting structure to such an extent that a major repair job must be done next year, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan made known last night.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery qualifiedly praised today the Western European Union's tactical military organization at the end of its first year. At the same time he acknowledged that there were deep-rooted faults in the structure that only prompt political decisions from above could cure.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 -- Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshore leader, today lost his legal fight to avoid trial on Nov. 14 on perjury and conspiracy charges.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Senator John Foster Dulles advised members of the First Baptist Church here tonight to "hold fast to the religious view of the nature of man" and to reject Marxist materialism.

Advancing autumn is stripping the leaves from the ailanthus trees and New York's back yards are once more naked to the view of the watcher at the window that looks down on these cloistered relics of the days when most of the city was laid out in hollow squares of private dwellings.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 12 -- His Highness, the Maharaja Jam Saheb of Nawanagar, is working zealously these days trying to cut costs for the United Nations.

Small in silhouette and in tones flattering to wear with furs were the hats featured in Milgrim's showing of holiday millinery yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Grouped in colors, they were presented first in rosy tints of American beauty, then tones of honey beige, snowy white and, lastly, in charming small shapes for after-dark glittering with rhinestones and feathers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Congress today completed passage of the first general health bill of this session, the Hospital Construction Bill that more than doubles current aid to the states.
BUFFALO, Oct. 12 -- Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate in the New York Senatorial race, declared here today that the future of Europe depended primarily upon the development of Africa.

GENEVA, Oct. 12 -- A considerable reduction in dollar expenditures of the sterling area countries other than Britain appears to be a necessary part of any solution of the long-run dollar-sterling problem, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- House investigators charged tonight that the Government's ship subsidy program is shot through with "irregularities" so gross that Congress should consider abolishing the Maritime Commission as an independent agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Edmond M. Hanrahan resigned today as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and President Truman named an employe of the agency and a Washington lawyer to fill two vacancies on the five-man commission.
AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 12 -- The United Rubber Workers, CIO, has notified its local unions not to accept agreements that called for reductions in pay.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Three ancient Hebrew scrolls, judged by experts to be a thousand years older than any previously known Biblical manuscripts, will go on public display "for the first time anywhere in the world" at the Library of Congress beginning Oct. 23.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 13 -- "A Streetcar Named Desire" opened triumphantly at the Aldwych Theatre last night and the audience, some of which had queued for twenty-four hours for gallery seats, gave it a wild reception.
BUFFALO, Oct. 12 -- A state fact-finding board began its inquiry today into the seventeen-week-old Bell Aircraft strike amid indications that the hearing might be long and bitter.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Transamerica Corporation announced today that it intends to sell 1,199,554 shares of stock of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, reducing its holdings to 11.1 per cent of the bank's outstanding stock.

Tom Wallace, editor emeritus of The Louisville (Ky.) Times and president of the Inter-American Press Association, received yesterday the 1949 Americas Award at a luncheon of the Americas Foundation at the University Club, 1 West Fifty-fourth Street.
Lord Boyd Orr was quoted in Associated Press dispatches as saying in Scotland last night, after the Nobel Peace Prize announcement:

Oren Root, Republican-Fusion candidate for borough president of Manhattan, declared last night that the American system would suffer unless something was done promptly to improve public schools. Mr. Root, who spoke at the opening of his downtown headquarters at 177 Avenue A, criticized the O'Dwyer Administration for failure to construct school buildings, particularly on the East Side.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L. I., Oct. 12 -- Nassau golden anniversary's industrial exposition ended here today featuring "Nassau County Government Day." Officials estimated more than 350,000 people visited the exposition during its five-day run.

The presidents of four major Zionist groups in the United States, representing a membership of more than 1,000,000, urged their regional chapters throughout the country yesterday to participate in the United Palestine Appeal's national conference on Israel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today plans for "streamlining and improving" collections from employers of withholding taxes and old-age insurance contributions.
Hundreds of ex-Wacs and Waves are responding to the call to enlist in the Organized Reserve Corps of the Women's Army Corps, it was learned yesterday at First Army headquarters, 90 Church Street.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Sir Stafford Cripps hinted today at a possible revision of the rate of release of sterling balances, those huge sums of blocked sterling piled up largely in India and the Middle East during the war. Those debts have been tempting exporters away from the dollar market.
Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, the Democratic-Liberal party candidate for Senator, urged last night vastly expanded powers for the United Nations as a goal the United States should actively seek.
United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey began his closing statement to the jury yesterday in the Communist trial, arguing for conviction of the defendants as heads of a criminal conspiracy.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 12 -- The United States joined thirty-eight other countries today in calling for a United Nations investigation of all laws and regulations in African and Pacific trust areas that discriminate against the local inhabitants.

BERLIN, Oct. 12 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, told correspondents tonight that inclusion of Western Berlin within the framework of the Western German Federal Republic was being discussed by the Western Allied High Commission.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 12 -- The United States and Britain plan to oppose any effort to incorporate the New City of Jerusalem into the state of Israel, spokesmen for their delegations to the United Nations General Assembly indicated here today.

The arrival of Pandit Nehru in the United States should provide more than the opportunity to express our friendliness for a great contemporary and a great new nation. It offers a reason for the study of one of the biggest and most critical problems in the world today and it may be that the Administration's analysis can lead to action.

The Senate's action yesterday in passing the Anderson "compromise" farm bill, after weeks of bitter argument, is decidedly encouraging. It is all the more reassuring in view of reports on Tuesday that President Truman had given his endorsement to a program of rigid 90 per cent price guarantees.
Two completely different viewpoints on civil defense are likely to be presented before the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy when it opens its hearings on this subject next week.

Following reports that Mayor O'Dwyer was considering a pay increase for teachers, the Teachers Union, CIO, announced yesterday that it was renewing its demand for a $1,200-a-year across the board rise for all teachers. It charged the city had in sight the $54,000,000 in revenue needed to finance such an increase.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 12 -- General debate on the question whether there has been any violation of the peace treaties for Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria through their alleged suppression of fundamental liberties and human rights was concluded here today before the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

A total of more than $5,000,000 has been spent this year to redesign new products shown by more than 550 exhibitors, displaying more than 3,000 lines of hardware at the National Hardware Show which opened at Grand Central Palace yesterday, exhibitors estimated.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 12 -- Mass arrests, apparently designed to break the back of the Czechoslovak middle class, continued today. Those arrested in the campaign, which began Oct. 3, included professional men, former owners or managers of businesses and small tradesmen.

Conrad N. Hilton, who started his hotel career in five rooms of an adobe building in New Mexico more than thirty years ago, announced yesterday that he had added the world-famous Waldorf-Astoria to his growing list of hostelries. With the acquisition of operating control of the Waldorf, he will have thirteen hotels with more than 12,000 rooms.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- A Conservative manifesto calling for tax relief, harder work, longer hours, government retrenchment, the end of nationalization and a revival of competition was delivered today by Anthony Eden before 4,500 delegates to the annual meeting of the Conservative party.
With the biggest Columbus Day parade in the city's history, New Yorkers paid warm tribute to the memory of Christopher Columbus yesterday on the 457th anniversary of his arrival in the New World.

The Workmen's Circle, 175 East Broadway, announced yesterday plans for construction of a million-dollar recreation center, infirmary and home for the aged at Burke, Grace, Ely and Hammersley Avenues, at 222d Street, the Bronx.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 12 -- The United Nations Middle East economic mission has now turned, with the arrival of Royal Tyler of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, and Sydney Sherwood of the Export-Import Bank, to what Gordon R. Clapp, its chairman, and his associates consider their most important and fundamental job.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Oct. 13 -- The Senate early today swept aside the wishes of President Truman and refused to confirm Leland Olds for a third term as a member of the Federal Power Commission by a vote of 53 to 15.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- After eighty-eight years of continuous military service the Fort Slocum establishment of 125 Army buildings here on an eighty-five-acre island in Long Island Sound was being put in mothballs today.

The abnormal physiology of the major types of congenital heart disease "can now be investigated in a way that was heretofore impossible," it was declared last night at the annual Graduate Fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine by Dr. Lewis Dexter, Assistant Professor of Medicine at the Harvard Medical School.

Effective use of standardization can do much toward production of better products at competitive prices, speakers said yesterday at the second day's sessions of the annual meeting of the American Standards Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Senate passed the Anderson long-range farm bill today to give a hard-fought victory, but possibly only a temporary one, to advocates of a sliding-scale system of price supports geared to peacetime economic conditions.

Radio broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera's Saturday matinee performances will be carried again by the American Broadcasting Company, beginning Nov. 26. Each performance will be heard in its entirety from the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House, starting at 2 P. M.
The latest Soviet puppet regime has announced its program in Berlin. This program will scarcely please those Germans who hailed the new regime in the expectation of some dramatic Soviet concession.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The members of the armed forces today were assured of wage increases aggregating $300,000,000 a year when President Truman signed the military pay bill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The move for "life adjustment" education in the high schools, started in 1946 and continued in annual conferences since, has simmered down to "an action program for the education of all," J. Dan Hall, Assistant Director of Secondary Education of the Office of Education, said today.

Many parties will be given at the dinner dance in behalf of the East Side House Settlement to be held tonight at the formal opening for this season of the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Proceeds will further the maintenance and expansion of the beneficiary, located at 540 East Seventy-sixth Street, which provides educational and recreational activities in a crowded district of the city.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 12 -- After this week Miss Theresa Clear won't be manager at the Western Union office here. She is retiring, after forty-six years, to do charitable work and to visit a few of the myriad places that until now have just been points on her telegraph lines.
A new "Flapper Fanny" has made her debut in fashion this season. She has not the 1920 look, but she embodies what was flattering in those days with 1949 revamping.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- By unanimous vote, the Senate instructed its conferees tonight to hold out against funds for a fifty-eight-group Air Force and greater stockpiling activity in the military appropriations bill, subject of bitter disagreement in conference.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 12 -- Even with buoyant markets for stocks and a high level of confidence as to future profits, "it is going to be increasingly difficult to finance the necessary expansion of American business without Government assistance unless we find additional millions of sources of equity capital," Robert P. Boylan, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, declared here tonight.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 12 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, asserted tonight that he would testify before any Congressional committee that the Navy had already been assigned its appropriate role and share of the defense dollar in any war to come.

As a former member of the naval services during World War II, and as a citizen, I wish to express through your columns my indignation at the action of high Navy officials in publicly criticizing the Armed Services Unification Law. That law was adopted after full and complete discussion both by the people and Congress.

ARMONK, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- water shortage that officials described as the worst in memory has left one-third of the homes and estates in central Westchester County with dry wells, watershed engineers reported tonight.

Hearings on the application of Moore-McCormack Lines for resumption of an operating differential subsidy on its three passenger vessels in service between New York and the east coast of South America will be closed in Washington on Tuesday, the Maritime Commission announced esterda The vessels involved are the Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay.

In 1922, after quitting the League of Nations, which their own President had taken the lead in proposing, the United States launched their relentless tariff policy upon a stunned and war-wasted world.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- About a score of Latin-American diplomats assembled with President Truman today for an unusual observance of Columbus Day.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 12 (AP) -- British and Russian delegates to the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East clashed today over treatment of small nations and colonial possessions.
'Twill be a great day for the Irish when, on Oct. 31, Gimbels starts a two-week "Salute to Ireland" in cooperation with American Airlines.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 12 -- The Nobel Peace Prize for 1949 has been awarded to Lord Boyd Orr of Britain, the former Sir John Boyd Orr, nutrition expert and crusader for world government, the Nobel committee of the Norwegian Parliament announced tonight.
GENEVA, Oct. 12 -- Norway has offered permanent homes and care to 200 refugees, including at least fifty totally blind persons, the International Refugee Organization announced today.

The Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) has an annual smelting capacity of 124,900,000 pounds of aluminum remaining idle all or part of the year and which has not been scrapped because of possible defense needs in the future, Irving W. Wilson, senior vice president of Alcoa, testified yesterday.

Being one the theatre's ablest craftsmen, Maurice Evans has taken hold of one effective play and given it an excellent performance. It is "The Browning Version" by Terence Rattigan, author of "The Winslow Boy" and "O Mistress Mine"; and it opened a new season for the Coronet last evening.

"Heywood Broun," a biography of the late columnist and founder of the Newspaper Guild, will be published by A. A. Wyn on Oct. 27. It is the work of Dale Kramer, who has been doing research on the Broun story for ten years. Mr. Kramer represented Yank on the battleship Missouri when the Japanese surrendered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Robert D. Murphy, new United States Ambassador to Belgium, and the late Thomas C. Wasson, who was killed while serving as Consul General at Jerusalem, received the State Department's first "distinguished service" awards today for service "of national or international significance."
RED WING, Minn., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Eugenie Anderson said today she was an "ardent supporter" of the President's foreign policy.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- A selling wave that centered on British Government stocks drove down prices on the stock markets here today. The exception to the trend was provided mainly by South African gold-mining shares.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 12 -- The United States delegation to the General Assembly plans to offer a resolution emphasizing the necessity of complete compliance with the United Nations Charter, and loyal cooperation with the organization, to counter-balance a Soviet omnibus resolution calling for a Big Five nonaggression pact.

Two figures in the annual report of the treasurer of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, published yesterday, must be juxtaposed if their full significance to the musical institutions of America is to be grasped. During the fiscal year ending May 31 the society's total operating deficit was $43,975.77, and it turned over to the Government a sum of $109,420.10 collected as federal admission taxes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- An investigation of taxation of life insurance companies was voted today by the House Ways and Means Committee.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 12 -- Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly opened the way today for giving full independence to all Libya by Jan. 1, 1952.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Eddie Dyer will be back as manager next year, but some player changes are in store for the Cardinals if deals can be arranged.

Earl Wild, pianist, was heard in a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. Works demanding virtuosity formed a conspicuous part of his program, and it was in his ability to cope successfully with these display pieces that his chief strength lay.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Word that Transamerica Corporation would reduce its holdings of stock of Bank of America to 11.1 per cent of the amount outstanding revived speculation here that a Federal Reserve Board's anti-monopoly action against Transamerica may be settled.

Bernhard Weiser is a pianist who can produce music of remarkably clear articulation, when he has his mind on it. He did it last night in Town Hall when he played the agitated first movement of Rachmaninoff's Sonata No. 2. He was often capable of catching the sentiment of more lyrical passages, too.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 12 -- Science must find more methods of preventing and controlling thrombo-embolism, the principal post-operative cause of death, according to a report today to 500 sureons attending a world-wide conference.

Appointment of the Rev. Lawrence A. Walsh, former dean of Fordham College, to the newly created office of provost of the university, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Lansing P. Shield, president of the Grand Union Company, operator of chain grocery stores, said today that the steady increase in population in this country would require 6,000 additional super markets by 1960 to keep Americans well fed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A group including Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today accused the steel industry of acting "in favor of its profits and against the national interest" in the current steel strike.

Pre-packaging of meats goes one step farther in a new product now being offered at the Bohack stores. In one cellophane wrapping it combines cooked dried beef and the seasoned-flour thickening for a quick-to-fix white sauce. Butter and milk (proportions of which are designated) are all that's lacking; total preparation time is five minutes.

In a radio speech from WMCA, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, asserted last night that the newspapers of the city were "protecting" both Mayor O'Dwyer, his Democratic opponent, and New-bold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Senator Clyde R. Hoey, Democrat, of North Carolina, disclosed today that James V. Hunt, Washington "influence" peddler whose activities touched off the Senate's "five-per-center" investigation, is closing up shop.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- No organization "is any better than the men who run it; a neat organization chart is not a panacea for all ills."

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Jules Moch, Premier-designate, spent the greater part of today in preparing the declaration that he will make tomorrow before the French National Assembly, which has been convoked in special session to approve or to reject his candidacy as Premier.

An appeal to advertising men to use their skill in communicating to the American public the need for keeping the American public awake to the necessity of the Marshall Plan was issued last night by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator.
Selling Scranton as a formidable opponent to a football squad that was all steamed up to meet Yale and has a coming date with Army is Coach Ed Danowski's big problem at Fordham right now.

At the Broadhurst Theatre this evening at 8 o'clock, George Abbott will unfold his eighth musical production, "Touch and Go." This is the revue, which under the label of "Thank You, Just Looking," was done at the Catholic University in Washington, last Spring.

As a veteran and Naval Reserve officer (inactive) I am much concerned over the evident inability of the branches of the armed services so to coordinate their activities as to assure to the people of the United States the security to which they are entitled on the basis of the large funds which are now being expended in that direction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Mrs. Eugenie Anderson of Red Wing, Minn., was nominated by President Truman today as Ambassador to Denmark, the first woman in American history to be offered such a diplomatic rank. Senate confirmation of the appointment is required.

HONG KONG, Oct. 12 -- Communist Gen. Chen Keng's main force reportedly was advancing rapidly tonight from Kaihow, thirty-five miles north of Canton, along the motor road, after having been halted in a day-long battle in which Nationalist air supremacy briefly checked the Communists' progress.
The Fifth Avenue Association, in a telegram to Mayor O'Dwyer, protested yesterday against the routing of the Columbus Day parade through the midtown section of Fifth Avenue.

The cost of building new public schools could be cut 40 per cent if the Board of Education would erect one-story structures instead of the present multi-storied buildings, according to the October issue of Architectural Forum, issued yesterday.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 12 -- With the replacements far from plentiful and working with a green line, Taft School's football coach, Bob Adams, is faced with more than a few weighty problems this season.

A new premium sales division has been formed by the Benrus Watch Company, it was announced yesterday by S. Ralph Lazarus, president. Richard A. Youngblood, formerly in charge of premium sales for the American Safety Razor Corporation, has been placed in charge of the new division at Benrus.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation's Erie Basin yard, at Dwight Street, Brooklyn, remained idle yesterday as pickets guarded the plant's three gates. The walkout, resulting from a work classification dispute, started last Thursday afternoon.

Jules Braunschvig, vice president of the Alliance Israelite Universelle, announced here yesterday that he had received word from a representative of the organization in North Africa, of the decision of the French authorities in Morocco to undertake a vast slum clearance program in the Mellah, or Jewish ghetto of Casablanca.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- John L. Lewis, chairman, and Senator Styles Bridges, public trustee of the United Mine Workers of America Welfare and Retirement Fund, filed identical replies today to a suit brought in the Federal District Court demanding an accounting for $14,000,000 alleged to have been expended by the fund since 1946.

Your editorial urging registration for all persons eligible to vote is commendable. Your statistical comparisons between eligible voters and past registrants for past elections is both impressive and disheartening. There is no defense for ignoring local elections, the bulwark of democracy.
TOKYO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The San Francisco Seals arrived today to a thunderous welcome for their "bicycle series" with Japanese and GI baseball teams.
The Fifth Avenue Association, in a telegram to Mayor O'Dwyer, protested yesterday against the routing of the Columbus Day parade through the midtown section of Fifth Avenue.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 12 -- Donald Duck, Pluto, and Mickey Mouse; their hair standing on end and their eyes wide with astonishment and consternation, got involved in the war of propaganda today.
