BERLIN, Oct. 12 -- Strict adherence to the foreign policy of the Soviet Union, promises of better living conditions and a bitter denunciation of the Western powers and Western German Federal Republic featured the first statement of policy from the new Eastern German Democratic Republic today.

Columbia's offense drew most of Coach Lou Little's attention at Baker Field yesterday as the Lions went through another long and heavy practice session for Saturday's game with Pennsylvania at Philadelphia. The attacking unit reversed the procedure of the previous day and stressed passing plays.

The desirability of a standard of mental health for everyone,, comparable to a standard of physical health, was questioned yesterday by Dr. Lyman Bryson, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College. He particularly criticized the, concept of many psychiatrists that the individual should develop all the potentialities of his personality, and declared:

The desirability of a standard of mental health for everyone,, comparable to a standard of physical health, was questioned yesterday by Dr. Lyman Bryson, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College. He particularly criticized the, concept of many psychiatrists that the individual should develop all the potentialities of his personality, and declared:

The warm, if not downright heated discussions which have been in progress between Weimeraner owners and the owners of other hunting dogs at last has reached the "chalk, marbles or money" stage, and from where we sit it would appear that the "other dog" fanciers are going to face the choice of putting up or shutting up.
The answer to one of the most active literary guessing games in years will not be given for at least another several months, it became certain yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Oct. 13 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate early today rejected President Truman's nomination of Leland Olds to the Federal Power Commission:

DETROIT, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Two big goals by Center George Gee counted heavily tonight as the Detroit Red Wings opened defense of their National Hockey League championship with a 2-to-1 victory over Boston before 11,061 fans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A hearing on the communications equipment and manpower needed for safe operations of long over-water airplane flights is scheduled for Oct. 18.
Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate, declared last night that "we will begin digging the Second Avenue subway as soon as I have been sworn in as Mayor."

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Back from the United States, Foreign Secretary Bevin went to 10 Downing Street tonight to discuss with Prime Minister Attlee the date of the next British general election. Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council and the Labor party's campaign manager, also attended the conference.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today reported that it will borrow Stephen McNally from Universal-International to be the third co-star of its forthcoming "No Way Out" with Richard Widmark and Linda Darnell.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Capital Airlines, Inc., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement overing $7,400,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent convertible income debentures; $3,700,000 of 4 per cent debentures, Series A, and $3,700,000 of 4 per cent debentures, Series B.
HONG KONG, Thursday, Oct. 13 (UP) -- The last Nationalist officials abandoned Canton today as thousands of Chinese Communist troops closed in on the refugee capital.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson denounced today the "so-called German Democratic Republic" as an illegal and undemocratic instrument of "Soviet masters."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved an increase in interstate passenger fares of the Long Island Rail Road. It applies only to through tickets purchased at L. I. R. R. stations to points outside New York State served by connecting lines and to the portion of the trip made over L. I. R. R. lines.
The Polish-born wife of a United States Army captain has been held on Ellis Island since Sept. 20, when she returned to this country from a visit to Italy, it was learned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 -- Federal mediators, preparing to make their first attempt to end the twelve-day-old steel strike, received indications from both sides today that their efforts were bound to fail.

Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's Royal Governor, who is getting to be an opening-day specialist, delivered the goods as the $21-for-$2 sixth choice in the six-furlong Interborough Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

Tony Pellone of the West Side outpointed Al (Bozo) Costantino, East Side welterweight, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. In registering the victory, Pellone received the unanimous vote of Referee Ruby Goldstein and Judge Harold Barnes and Bill Recht.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Oct. 12 -- David K. Berninghausen, head librarian at Cooper Union, New York, asserted tonight that most Americans did not realize "how near we are to the complete surrender of the right to form our own opinions."

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 12 -- Having achieved a "pre-union" stage the Benelux Ministers Council will open a three-day conference in Luxembourg tomorrow to prepare for the next and harder stage in bringing about a full economic union among Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.
A meeting arranged by the American Labor party in a Washington Heights public school where several election district registration boards were in session was halted last night soon after it started.

Joseph Roberts, general manager of The Daily Worker and The Worker, in a letter published in THE TIMES of Oct. 12, attempts to convey the impression that he is denying he ever reported the circulation of The Daily Worker to be 19,000 by referring to "a report which he claims was made by me * * *."

In the spring rain has a purpose; roots and the beginnings of stems and leaves are stirring in the earth, and these need the rain. Spring rains wash away winter's grime, black particles of dust and soot captured by snow and left behind in the thaws to form dirty streaks on the pavement.

MADISON, N. J., Oct. 13 -- Robert C. Morris of Madison, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, was elected president of the Drew University board of trustees today. He succeeds Frank E. Baker of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Admiral Louis E. Denfeld, highest active officer of the Navy, asserted today that his service was being dangerously weakened by high command decisions that were uninformed and "arbitrary."

New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $12,200,000 were placed on the market yesterday by underwriting syndicates. In all cases the bonds were acquired by the bankers at competitive sale. The offerings were as follows:

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 13 -- India slammed the door today on virtually all trade with Pakistan as a result of the Moslem dominion's decision not to devalue its rupee. Pakistan has quoted a rate of 144 Pakistan rupees to 100 Indian rupees but India has declined to recognize the departure from parity and inter-dominion commerce has been at a standstill.

Appropriations totaling $6,752,400 for the construction of three new public schools in Brooklyn and one in Queens were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The board also appropriated $1,313,000 for the rehabilitation of schools and for school supplies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Truman saw a gulf today between the word "ethics" and the word "communism." He was unable to bridge it, and he said he knew that Communists have no ethics.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- The annual invitation exhibition "Painting in the United States, 1949," opened this evening at Carnegie Institute with a preview at which prizes and awards were announced. Beginning tomorrow it will be open to the public daily through Dec. 11.
Capt. E. V.. (Eddie) Rickenbacker saluted yesterday as "patriots of the first order" the Navy leaders who are fighting to prevent curtailment of the naval forces.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 13 -- The International Society of Surgery voted unanimously today to readmit to membership the surgeons of Japan and Germany who have been screened and declared eligible by military occupation authorities.

Half of an oversized billiard ball, a miniature model of the Plexiglas nose of an airplane and a child's blond wood building block are among the unusual objects that turn out to be clocks in a new collection designed by George Nelson. The Chronopak electrical timepieces are made by the Howard Miller Clock Company of Zeeland, Mich., and have a handsome futuristic appearance that should make them suitable even in tomorrow's world.

LAKE SUCCESS, Friday, Oct. 14 -- By a tie vote, a special subcommittee of the United Nations General Assembly early this morning defeated a key proposal to set up a commission to supervise Libya's transition to independence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Truman has no plan to seize the coal industry and negotiate an agreement with the United Mine Workers to end the strike of nearly 400,000 soft coal miners. The walkout began on Sept. 19.
The cotton futures market on The New York Cotton Exchange turned barely steady yesterday and closed 9 to 18 points net lower than on Wednesday.

HONG KONG, Friday, Oct. 14 -Communist troops occupied Canton's White Cloud civil airport shortly after 9 o'clock last night without firing a shot and are expected to enter the abandoned Nationalist refugee capital, three miles away, this morning.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The annual conference of the Conservative party voted unanimously today to tighten Britain's empire ties and, with scarcely less warmth, supported closer cooperation with Western Europe and the United States.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 13 -- Short range miniature propaganda war between the United States Information Service and the Czechoslovak Soviet Friendship Society continued unabated today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Department store sales in the Week ended Oct. 8 were 12 per cent below sales in the corresponding Week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

The nation's supply of gasoline declined 1,188,000 barrels last week according to the report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks at the week-end were put at 102,707,000 barrels, compared with 103,895,000 a week earlier and 91,411,000 a year ago.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- As often happens in these all-day Westchester County pro-amateur best ball golf tournaments, the last to arrive in the shades of night turn out to be the winners. So it was today as James Marotta, professional of Maplemoor, teamed with Mike La Medica of Hasty Brook to win top prize with a six-under-par 33, 32 -- 65 over the Siwanoy course.

A new type of dictionary, one dealing with geographical information, is scheduled for Nev. 14 publication by the G. . C. Merriam Company. Entitled "Webster's Geographical Dictionary," it contains information on more than 40,000 names, including all incorporated cities, towns and villages in the United States and Canada with 1,500 or more population.

The price of fashion will be only slightly lower next spring, according to statements made at the meeting of the Fashion Group, Inc., yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel. Formally, the luncheon meeting was for a report on fabrics for the spring.

" This fraud on the people has got to stop," Magistrate Morris Rothenberg asserted yesterday as he handed out a ten-day workhouse term to a man who admitted he had accepted $208 in unemployment insurance as well as undisclosed sums in home relief payments whole holding a job.

For three hours and forty minutes yesterday more than 250 stockholders harangued their way through the forty-fourth, and second longest, annual meeting in the history of the Electric Bond and Share Company.
PRAGUE, Szechoslovakia, Oct. 13 -- New arrests of Roman Catholic priests were reported tonight, while the round-up of members of the "bourgeoisie" continued
Any future war will in all probability find cities throughout America banded together in regional mutual aid pacts to assist each other in minimizing the effects of any kind of disaster.

The Greyhound Lines, national passenger bus system, announced yesterday that it will spend $400,000 by the end of November for a special campaign to promote autumn travel. The campaign marks a 50 per cent increase over the normal amount spent for advertising by the eighteen associated Greyhound companies for the fall months of October and November, it was noted.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 13 -- Randolfo Pacciardi, Defense Minister of Italy, visiting the USS Midway here today, termed the giant flattop "magnificent," but expressed some doubt concerning the ability of aircraft carriers to survive attack in a "small sea" like the Mediterranean.

I have just read Sylvan Waitzfelder's letter to THE TIMES published Oct. 8 on the law on veterans preference, stating that 655,000 were hired to fill the places of veterans ousted in 1948. Mr. Waitzfelder forgets to mention that the 655,000 veterans displaced from government service were almost entirely war-service indefinite employes who were, in fact, replaced for the most part by veterans who had acquired permanent status.
Domestic steel production for September, the third quarter and the first nine months of 1949 was below the figures for last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The Screen Actors Guild and the Screen Extras Guild issued a joint statement last night refuting reports that they might form an "alliance" with James C. Petrillo's American Federation of Musicians. The statement was released both here and in Hollywood.

Ten Democratic members of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy yesterday made public their answer to the charges of "incredible mismanagement" which Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper directed last May against AEC Chairman David E. Lilienthal and his colleagues. They gave the AEC an earned credit for taking "a vast enterprise which was falling apart at the seams and re-shaping it into a formidable deterrent against aggression."

Public-spirited citizens founded the first voluntary, nonprofit hospital in New York more than 175-years ago. Others were organized as the city grew and its needs for medical care increased. These hospitals are operated under the direction of nonsalaried trustees.

TOKYO, Oct. 7 -- Japanese official agencies are quietly purging university professors, school teachers and administrative assistants suspected of being members of the Communist party or of harboring Communist or radical sympathies, it has become apparent here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The most intricately knitted bed jacket of Dowager Queen Mary was flown here for today's opening of a knitting, quilting and children's frocks exhibition of British Women's Industries, Ltd. It is sponsored by Lady Franks, wife of Sir Oliver Shewell Franks, British Ambassador.

Are junior fashions necessarily young fashions? This is always a question to department stores. Gimbles gave its answer by a rearrangement made on the fourth floor where a new department catering to a size rather than an age is being opened to the public today.

HONG KONG, Friday, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The British-owned steamer Fatshan arrived safely in Nationalist-abandoned Canton today on another evacuation run as the British took steps to keep air and rail lines open to the South China metropolis.
The two leading contenders for the Manhattan Borough Presidency staged a friendly campaign debate yesterday at a luncheon of the Women's City Club in the New Weston Hotel.

The possibility of Notre Dame's long stretch of invincibility on the football field coming to an end in the game tomorrow with Tulane at South Bend, as did Michigan's against Army, makes it pertinent to call attention to the remarkable record of the man who has brought the Fighting Irish through thirty-one successive games without defeat.

VIENNA, Oct. 13 -- Transfer of Brig. Gen. Jesmond D. Balmer from his post of United States Deputy High Commissioner for Austria to become assistant commands of the Anti-Aircraft and Guided Missile Center at Fort Bliss, Tex., was announced here today.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- Samuel Titto Williams, 20 years old, of Brooklyn, was re-sentenced to death by the Court of Appeals today after he made an unusual personal claim of innocence before the high court. The court fixed the week of Nov. 14 for his execution.

New York's two leading professional football teams will be playing for high stakes this Sunday. Their game with the Pittsburgh Steelers at the Polo Grounds offers the Giants an opportunity of taking sole possession of second place in the National League's Eastern Division standings.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Notre Dame's "Four Horsemen" team of 1924 will be honored in a twenty-fifth reunion celebration the week-end of the Irish-Southern California game here Nov. 26.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of Interior, today accused Senator Sheridan Downey, Democrat, of California, of "unabashed perjury" in his attacks on Reclamation Bureau officials.

Marked with the individuality of this designer, the Knize collection of coats, suits and furs was joined by the knitwear of Aileen Rice, both of 24 East Fifty-sixth Street, in a showing at the Plaza Hotel yesterday of custom order creations. Distinguished by such detail as contrasting, color piped seams, eyelet-laced insertions and accents of velvet, satin, stitching and braid, the suits were tailored with slim skirts, and jackets frequently flared into rippling back peplums.

GENEVA, Oct. 13 -- Extension of the activities of the International Refugee Organization one year beyond June, 1950, the tentative date for closing down the organization, was proposed today by J. Donald Kingsley, director general.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- The New York State Catholic Welfare Committee said today that the position of the State Health Commissioner and State Department of Education regarding sex education in the common schools is "fundamentally at variance with traditional Christian teaching."

LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 13 -- At its opening session here today, the Benelux Cabinet Ministers' conference went squarely into a crisis that delegates agreed could wreck the carefully planned timetable for the full economic union of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The House Postoffice Committee today recommended an increase of $129,000,000 in the nation's mail bill, with $36,000,000 of it to come from raising the penny, post card rate to 2 cents.
Admiral Richard E. Byrd said last night that he had had been information, from an undisclosed source, that the Russians had been exploring Antarctica by ship and plane, looking for uranium.

Herbert Hoover asked the West Side Association of Commerce last night at its twenty-fifth anniversary dinner at the Statler Hotel, to support the cuts in government expenditures recommended by his commission. He cited the half-billion dollars cut from the armed services budget by Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson, now the subject of bitter controversy before the House Armed Services Committee, as an example of how such economies could be attained.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 13 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee defined in debate today the scope of the authority of the proposed intergovernmental committee on technical assistance, the policy-making body of the United Nations' expanded program of technical aid.

The opening concert of this season by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was given under the baton of Leopold Stokowski last night in Carnegie Hall. The most novel music on the program was the "Children's Suite" of Aaron Copland, heard for the first time in New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A chain food store executive said today that continued Government farm price supports will serve the public interest -- but only if they provide plenty of freedom for farmers.

Damages to the Vernon Avenue bridge over Newtown Creek between Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, and Vernon Avenue, Long Island City, suffered on Sept. 8 when the bridge was rammed by a 10,000-ton collier, have compelled the city to spend $85,000 on a span that must be replaced by a new one in two years, it was learned yesterday.

WINFIELD, N. J., Oct. 13 -- The Federal Government had reduced the asking price for its Winfield Housing development here from $1,450,000 to $1,400,000, less accumulated credits on net profits totaling about $41,000 since April 1, 1945, when the present contract as signed, Delmore Brickman, executive director of the Winfield Mutual Housing Corporation, was advised today by John Taylor Egan, commissioner of the Public Housing Administration in Washington, D. C.

Prime Minister Attlee's decision to carry the Labor Government through to its full five-year term is certainly courageous. It may also prove wise from the political viewpoint. He is taking a chance because this would have been a favorable moment to call a general election, with full employment, generous social services, a good standard of living at a low cost.

Compromise proposals to enable Britain to shed at least a part of the heavy burden of wartime blocked balances of pounds sterling are expected to be made shortly by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, and by the British Treasury, bankers said here yesterday.

MONTREAL, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens blanked the Chicago Black Hawks, 4-0; tonight in the opening game of the National Hockey League season for both teams. Maurice (The Rocket) Richards scored twice and Jerry Plamondon and rookie left winger Gilles Dube once for the Frenchmen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Advocates of eventual world government marshalled their arguments today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, but they differed among themselves on the path by which the common goal was to be reached.

In its weekly check of retail stores yesterday, the consumers' service division of the City Department of Markets found meats, poultry, fish and eggs largely unchanged in cost from last Thursday. It was only in produce that prices had fluctuated, as homemakers will see when they lay in stocks for the week-end.

A property in the garment district occupied largely by coat manufacturers figured in a purchase and quick resale yesterday when the seventeen-story building at 257-61 West Thirty-eighth Street was purchased by the Bizet Realty Corporation and resold to the 257 West Thirty-eighth Street Corporation, represented by Maurice Schur.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- The Western Allied High Commissioners have informed Cabinet Ministers in Bonn that the inclusion of Western Berlin in the Western German Federal Republic is a matter beyond their competence, Jakob Kaiser, Minister for all German affairs in the Western Republic, said at a press conference today.

ONEONTA, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Senator John Foster Dulles declared today that the people were entitled to know whether former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic-Liberal rival in the Senatorial race, would, if elected, be a "mechanical voting machine," with William M. Boyle Jr., the Democratic national chairman, "pushing the lever."

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The announcement that there would be no general election this year reversed the pattern of the last few days on the stock markets here today. British Government securities became the strongest instead of the weakest market, thus ending the decline of the last three days.

DUBLIN, Oct. 13 -- Joseph E. Carrigan, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission here, predicted today that Ireland probably would wipe out her trade deficit and achieve a balance between imports and exports by 1952-53 when Marshall Plan aid ended.

Successful competition between smaller metal producers and the Aluminum Company of America is perfectly possible, D. A. Rhoades, vice president of the Kaiser-owned Permanente Metals Corporation, declared in Federal Court yesterday.

Production at the Eagle Lion studio in Hollywood probably will remain more or less dormant while the company concentrates on building up its distribution arm during the next several months, it was indicated yesterday by N. Peter Rathvon, adviser to Eagle Lion on its special financing fund for independent film production.

Expenditure of approximately $1,000,000 for new construction and improvement of facilities in the New Jersey-New York port district was approved yesterday by the Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority at their monthly meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The French Government has been negotiating with two New York banks for a $75,000,000 refunding loan to replace a like amount outstanding from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Embassy officials here said today.

A consistent, long-range procurement program that would call for a steady though not large production of military aircraft was urged yesterday as the most economical way to provide the nation with airpower.

No man of this generation has been a more energetic worker for world peace or a more disinterested friend of humanity than John Boyd Orr, who has received the Nobel Peace Prize for 1949. The man who was born in a poor Scotch family sixty-nine years ago last month now carries the title of Lord Boyd Orr.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Central and South West Corporation, Welmington, Del., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 725,567 shares of its $5 par value common stock.
The city of Boston announced yesterday that it would receive bids Oct. 26 on bond issues totaling $15,500,000. Dated Nov. 1, 1949, the bonds will come due Nov. 1, 1950 to 1979.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Atomic Energy Commission received Congressional praise today as having attained a working balance between the "security of concealment" and the "security of achievement." The stockpile of atomic bombs it has built was described as a deterrent to any aggressor.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Governor Dewey attacked former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, tonight as an apostle of socialized medicine and quoted from Nicolai Lenin in describing socialized medicine as "the keystone in the arch of the socialized state."

The Goddard Neighborhood Center will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Browning Version," with Maurice Evans and Edna Best, on the night of Oct. 24 at the Coronet Theatre. Mrs. Greenough Townsend is chairman of the committee in charge of the sale of tickets.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 13 -- The wink of an eye, the flick of a finger, or day-to-day temperature changes help fix the price you will pay when you go to market for cauliflower.
LONDON, Friday, Oct. 14 -Prime Minister Attlee's decision not to hold an early general election was badly received by most of the British newspapers today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The Scarsdale Committee of Ten, which has been seeking since June to awaken the community "to the infiltration of subversive influences," said today it would like to obtain from the Board of Education a definite declaration of policy concerning the teaching of Americanism in the schools.

CATALOOCHEE, N. C., Oct 13 -- Although it takes longer to say "Cataloochee" than it does to walk slowly through the place, it is located in the heart of the bear, boar and black powder country, and no sportsman worthy of the name is going to quibble about terms when he is on the fringe of the deep timber.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics today fired veteran coaches Al Simmons and Earle Brucker in the first major decision the club ever has made against the wishes of Connie Mack.
CANTON, Oct. 13 -- Tension increased almost hourly in Canton today as the Communists pressed toward the city from the north and northeast.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- During the week ended Oct. 12, member bank reserve balances decreased $268,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
At least thirteen Persons were injured, none seriously, in a dynamite explosion in an excavation at East Ninety-ninth Street and Madison Avenue at 2:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

The steady stream of New Yorkers to registration booths yesterday indicated that the total enrollment this year will be far ahead of the 2,400,000 estimated by the Board of Elections when registration week began Monday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Harold V Bozell of New York City, president of the General Telephone Corporation, today was elected president of the United States Independent Telephone Association, which represents some 6,000 companies outside the Bell system.

Bargain purchases won the co-features at Jamaica yesterday -- the two divisions of the $4,000 Argosy Purse for 2-year-olds. Miss Degree, who cost Edward M. O'Brien $700 as a yearling, took the first section; Ceara, a $10,000 claim three months ago, scored his third victory in Mrs. Jan Burke's silks in the second division.

The first fatality of the slowly-starting season is "People Like Us." Scheduled to arrive next Wednesday night at the Cort, the melodrama by the late Frank Vosper has been deferred to an indefinite date to allow for mandatory structural changes, it was reported.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Prime Minister Attlee informed the nation today that there would be no general election this year. His unprecedented statement was designed to quiet unrest and uncertainty regarding the Government's intentions, unrest and uncertainty that have been stagnating the Government and hampering business initiative since devaluation of the pound started rumors of an impending dissolution of Parliament.

Attendance yesterday at the National Hardware Show in Grand Central Palace, set an all-time record yesterday of 21,900, according to Frank Yeager, director. Buying was very heavy in both hand and power tools, and many exhibitors were said to be building order backlogs. Prices were said to be "very firm."

A thoroughly attractive performance of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" was given by the New York City Opera Company at City Center last night. Laszlo Halasz, who conducted, paced the opera concisely and it came across with dramatic impact as well as with high spirits.
Alumni of City College Honor Philanthropist, Statesman for Services to New York

More and better films about mental health are "sorely needed" throughout the country to help combat "widespread misunderstanding, superstition and misconceptions about mental health" Dr. Robert H. Felix, director of the National Institute of Mental Health of the United States Public Health Service, declared yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Shirley Temple, who as a golden-haired tot charmed her way into the hearts of millions of movie fans, today filed suit to divorce John Agar, the actor.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 13 -- France intends to counter the Soviet Union's proposal that members of the United Nations give information on atomic weapons. France will issue a reminder that the majority plan for international atomic control, which would ultimately elminiate the use of nuclear fuel for war purposes, was approved overwhelmingly by the United Nations General Assembly last year.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- Responsibility for the thirteen-day-old steel strike was laid at the door of "atheistic capitalism" today by Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, and of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Senate's refusal to confirm Leland Olds for a third term as a member of the Federal Power Commission was described today by President Truman as a bad thing.
The Citizens Union announced yesterday its endorsement of Joseph T. Sharkey, majority leader of the City Council and Democratic-Liberal candidate for reelection in the Eighth District, Brooklyn.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The major baseball leagues will hold their annual draft for new talent here on Nov. 17, Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler announced today.
Scenes, events and personalities of City Hall since it was constructed in 1803 were shown last night at the preview of a special exhibition at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- In an effort to prevent the Congress of Industrial Organizations from canceling its charter, the leftist United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers Union, CIO, will conduct a referendum vote of its 50,000 members next week on whether it should merge with the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union, CIO.

Dr. Paul R. Hawley, chief executive officer of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Commissions, Chicago, listed yesterday as one of the major failures of voluntary health insurance to date the refusal by such insurance plans to enroll self-employed individuals, particularly farmers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13 -- The Yugoslav Ministry of Foreign Affairs replied today to the Bulgarian note of Oct. 1, abrogating the Bulgarian-Yugoslav treaty of alliance, by accusing the Bulgarian Government of having plotted to annex Yugoslav Macedonia.

Refusal of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation to allocate Marshall Plan funds for $6,500,000 of American automotive products to Turkey was strongly protested yesterday by the board of the Overseas Automotive Club. The effect, it was charged, will be to deprive the United States of its traditional market in Turkey for the benefit of European countries.

With the unrestricted flow of pedestrian travel regarded as one of New York's main traffic problems, the City Traffic Commission will analyze effects of the few "Wait" and "Walk" signs installed here, it was learned yesterday. These follow the pattern of those in Washington and many other cities where pedestrian crossing is controlled by law.
Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that the force of public opinion, aroused by his speeches, had "driven Frank Costello out of town."

Education for nursing must procure "quick identification of significant social change" and be geared into the general educational system of the country, Dr. R. Louise McManus, director of the Division of Nursing Education at Columbia University's Teachers College, declared yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, famous husband and wife team of the American theatre, celebrated their twenty-fifth anniversary as stage partners today in a new play which may be a prediction for their own future.

Gasoline and diesel engine production in Great Britain has recovered to a point well above that of the pre-war level, according to members of a British "productivity" team yesterday. The team arrived Wednesday for a six-weeks' tour of American engine plants.

For the first time in twelve years, the United Corporation's directors declared yesterday a dividend on its common stock. The dividend was 10 cents a share, payable on Nov. 23 to holders of record of Nov 7.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- A Senate-House dispute over 400 airplanes was deadlocked so tight today that the Senate voted to give the Defense Department emergency spending powers until Jan. 16.

PARIS, Friday, Oct. 14 -- Jules Moch, Socialist Minister of the Interior in the Cabinet of Henri Queuille, was approved as Premier this morning by an official count of 311 votes in the National Assembly. He will attempt to form a Cabinet today.

The group of five five-story buildings at the southeast corner of Park Avenue and East Thirty-eighth Street, adjoining the twenty-four-story Town House, an apartment hotel, was sold yesterday by I. Jerome Riker and Henry Morgenthau Jr., to H. C. McClarity. Held for a reported price of $500,000, the property is 120 by 100 feet and is known as 59 to 65 Park Avenue and 102-04 East Thirty-eighth Street.

Seeking to intervene as a friend of the court in a Supreme Court suit brought by a landlord to invalidate the City's Local Rent Law, Paul Ross, chairman of the New York Tenants Council on Rent and Housing, charged yesterday in an affidavit that many of the rent increases granted by the Federal Housing Expediter "ran as high as 40 to 50 per cent."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today a mid-year survey of consumer buying plans showed that demand for automobiles actually rose during the first six months of this year.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Three horses hit the finish line noses apart in today's Chestnut Hill Purse before 10,757 persons at Garden State Park and after the judges had consulted the camera Mrs. S. G. Steckler's Brandy Punch was declared the winner.

The jury in the nine-month-old Communist trial began its deliberations at 3:53 o'clock yesterday afternoon, but was unable to reach a verdict immediately and was locked up for the night at 10:20 P. M.

TOKYO, Oct. 5 -- Little by little the Bank of Japan, for four years important chiefly as a note-issuing agency, is assuming control of Japan's money market. In doing so, it has taken over the place held by the Reconstruction Finance Bank until April.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Government, which holds a $550,000,000 cotton surplus, proposed a rigid control program today designed to cut 1950 production at least 20 per cent below the figure for this year. The program would include acreage planting allotments and marketing quotas.

Congress is right, both in the approval of the military aid measure and in the more recent Senate action on economic assistance, in not allowing itself to be sidetracked from the urgency of the situation in Korea. Our help is required and we are in a position to give it. Time is not on our side in this case and we cannot afford to be dilatory.

Although a series of meetings of the negotiating groups representing the longshoremen and their employers brought no actual agreement yesterday, it was reliably reported that progress had been made on the rigging clause that has stalemated the negotiations for about a week.

MOSCOW, Oct. 13 -- The Soviet foreign affairs journal New Times, in a careful analysis of the United States atomic control plan, today raised two basic objections to the proposals of Bernard M. Baruch.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Air pollution as a major national health problem was made the subject today of a 173-page report by the Public Health Service. The report dealt specifically with the Donora, Pa., smog deaths a year ago.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies declined 3.4 per cent in September compared with the corresponding month in 1948, according to a compilation covering forty companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Representative Frank1in D. Roosevelt Jr., campaigning for the election of Herbert H. Lehman to the United States Senate, last night attacked the record of John Foster Dulles, Mr. Lehman's Republican opponent. In a radio address over Station WJZ, at 9:15 P. M. Mr. Roosevelt said:

WASHINGTON Oct. 13 -- President Truman took another step today to increase Federal efficiency and reduce administrative costs by holding his first meeting with his Advisory Committee on Management Improvement.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Quick action was officially demanded today in dealing with the decline in manpower and the increase in absenteeism in the British mines, factors that are limiting the sales of British coal abroad.

In a radio speech from Station WOR, Abe Stark, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Borough President of Brooklyn, charged last night that Borough President John Cashmore, his Democratic opponent, during the last year had awarded 95 per cent of the paving contracts in Brooklyn to three concerns that were indicted and pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud the city in 1940.

Preparing for a great new industry, which would make the United States self-sufficient in iron and steel for centuries, the Erie Mining Company yesterday asked the state of Minnesota to assure the necessary water supply for proposed multi-million-dollar plants for making low-grade ores commercially usable.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The State Baptist Convention today branded the Feinberg Law barring subversives from school jobs "a system of thought control."

LET'S see now. If Notre Dame gets the pitching and if Tulane's home run power -- whoa! We'll have to start this all over again. A fellow's entire thinking processes have to be reoriented. The runs are proper enough but the hits and the errors have to be eliminated. They say that a football writer is merely a baseball writer with his vest on.
BERLIN, Friday, Oct. 14 -- Premier Stalin made a strong bid today for Russian-German cooperation, which he said could make peace in Europe secure.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- A peace treaty between Eastern Germany's Communist Government and the Soviet Union providing for withdrawal of at least part of the Russian Army of occupation will be signed by Jan. 1, according to reliable sources connected with the satellite nations' missions in Berlin.

BERLIN, Friday, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of a message from Soviet Premier Stalin to the leaders of the Eastern German Republic, as reported today by ADN, official Soviet zone news agency:

John F. O'Donnell, general counsel, Transport Workers Union, in a letter to you printed Oct. 5, objects to a Transit Authority and the use of future annual net income estimated at approximately $20 million to improve subway equipment and services. He urges that it be used instead for a fourth round of wage increases.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, representing merchant marine captains and other deck officers, will intensify its wage contract negotiations today with the whole weight of the American Federation of Labor supporting its demands, officers of the union announced yesterday.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Oct. 13 -- Laurence F. Whittemore, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, called tonight for "plain talk" on New England's freight transportation problems. He said the area's rail carriers already had taken "decisive moves" to improve service.

With the recent signing of a lease by Cherokee Textile Mills., Inc., textile manufacturers, for a portion of the twenty-seventh floor in 100 Park Avenue, which is nearing completion, Cushman Wakefield, Inc., renting agents, reported yesterday that more than 400,000 square feet of space in the thirty-six-story structure had been rented from plans.

A new bold advance ran into resistance yesterday on the stock market after the list had pushed through to the best levels since July, 1948. A strong surge of buying developed during the morning, but as the demand slackened prices backed away from the peak marks and left the composite rate higher by only 0.16 point, although many stocks showed gains of more than a point.

The campaign cabinet of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York yesterday issued a call for full, unprecedented support of the federation's $50,500,000 building fund and maintenance appeal.

David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, expressed a hope last night that Russian advances in atomic development will put an end to the "senseless business of choking ourselves by some of the extremes of secrecy to which we have been driven."
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- The surety company which posted bond for Harold J. Karsten, one of the eight defendants in the Tucker fraud proceedings, served notice today that it wishes to revoke the bond.

The Board of Elections upheld yesterday the validity of the petition of the City Fusion party nominating Newbold Morris for Mayor, Harry Uviller for Controller and Matthew J. Diserio for president of the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican, of Washington, held the Senate floor for almost six hours today as opponents of a House-approved bill liberalizing the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 marshaled their forces for an effort to talk the bill to death.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A decline of 5 to 10 per cent in enrollments in most colleges and universities except teachers colleges was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Truman expressed the opinion today that Senate-House conferees could work out an acceptable farm bill, but he declined to express a preference between conflicting provisions of measures passed by the two branches of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- In a discussion last night of the qualifications of Leland Olds to continue as a federal power commissioner, a debate that filled thirty pages of the Congressional Record, the Senate by a vote of 53 to 15 registered the following conclusions on the issues raised by his reappointment:
A significant change may find Ray Dooney, plunging fullback, as quarterback in the Penn line-up when the Quakers meet Columbia at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, tomorrow.

Business loans by banks in this area registered their seventh consecutive rise during the week ended on Wednesday as the result of borrowings for the marketing of commodities and money needs of public utilities. Figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and covering the twenty-four reporting New York City member banks revealed a rise of $40,000,000 to $4,823,000,000.

A touch of Paris has been brought to New York with the opening this morning of a new shop for imported handmade crystal and linens. The store is Baccarat Porthault, Inc., and the address, 55 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Your excellent editorial of Oct. 7, entitled "Floor Under Poverty," at its close discusses in one paragraph the welfare state. In it the editorial declares that "Welfare legislation must go far enough to make sure that no one suffers for lack of the necessities of life and that no one who does his best within his abilities and opportunities is humiliated when he is sick and old."

Archbishop Paul Yu-Pin of Nan-king, China, first Chinese-born prelate of the Roman Catholic Church to have been installed in an archbishopric, left yesterday afternoon for Washington, en route for a good-will tour of twenty Latin-American countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Truman talked louder than usual at his weekly news conference this afternoon. He was not mad at the reporters, he explained. It was a matter of a big ink-stained rug and the acoustics of his Oval Room.
By way of underlining Manager Casey Stengel's assertion that "they would not stand pat," the Yankees yesterday announced the purchase of two highly-rated prospects from the Pacific Coast League.

New York Airways, Inc., 331 Madison Avenue, announced yesterday that it had filed an application with the Civil Aeronautics Board for a certificate of convenience and necessity to fly mail, property and passengers to thirty-six cities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut by helicopters.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Sharp-shooting Ezzard Charles, brimming with confidence, risks his National Boxing Association heavyweight title tomorrow night in a fifteen-round bout with hard-punching Pat Valentino, local pride.

The thought-provoking special edition of Architectural Forum magazine devoted wholly to schools, with its sharp criticism of the New York school system and the city administration, is published, by coincidence, in the heat of the political campaign. Timed otherwise it might have been received in official quarters with less tendency to self-justification and more willingness to re-shape policy.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 13 -- The Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today adopted a resolution that would refer the question of peace treaty violations on the part of Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria to the International Court of Justice at The Hague.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- Dr. W. George Parks, of Rhode Island State College, reported today that phosphate salts can be responsible for imparting flame-resistant qualities to cotton fabrics.

Still deprived of the major portion of its original grant and handicapped by its inability to expand facilities, New York's Foreign Trade Zone nevertheless produced a gross revenue of nearly $190,000,000 during the calendar year 1948, according to the zone's twelfth annual report.
A campaign for $436,000 for activities of the Y. W. C. A. in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens was started yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Three hundred persons attended yesterday the twenty-second annual fall Rose Day at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, sponsored by the garden and the American Rose Society.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 13 -- Yugoslavia complained today of the activities of United Nations officials who have opposed Belgrade's candidacy for the Security Council.

Officials of five of the twelve railroads that are petitioning jointly for a basic 12 1/2 per cent increase for service within New York State completed testimony yesterday before Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright.
The New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese announced yesterday the excommunication from the church of the former Miss Claire Elizabeth McGinnis, who was married here on Monday to Ivan Obolensky.

George Rabinor and Milton H. Bernstein, builders, have bought a tract on the Lord estate north of Peninsula Boulevard, in Cedar-hurst, Queens, as the site for 100 ranch-style houses with expansion attics. The homes will have radiant heat and will be in the $9,500 price class.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Navy closed its case against strategic area bombing today and "rested" its defense of sea power before the court of public appeal.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 -- Hearing of the Federal Reserve Board's anti - monopoly action against the Transamerica Corporation proceeded here today despite a belief in some quarters that a basis for settlement might be provided by the forthcoming public sale by Transamerica of 1,199,554 shares of its stock in the Bank of America National Trust Association.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., went on rrecord today against Federal deficit spending.
LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Britain is planning to relax controls over trade with certain East European countries in a bid to boost business with the non-dollar world.

Rubber stockpiling activity by the Government had a strong influence on trading in crude rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday. Turnover increased sharply to 2,190 long tons, the highest volume in daily transactions so far this month.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The country's highest daily double payoff of the year -- $3,527.80 for each $2 -- was made today to four lucky bettors.

The General Portland Cement Company reported yesterday that net earnings for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 rose 28 per cent. Earnings after taxes amounted to $3,920,700, equal to $3.81 a common share. This compares with $3,051,200, or $2.97 a share for the same period of last year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Action of soybeans dominated the markets on the Board of Trade today, and with the exception of oats all grains reacted after early firmness. Soybeans led the decline and closed 3 to 4 1/4 cents a bushel lower.

The Foreign Ministers' deputies of the United States, Britain and France, meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to negotiate a state treaty for Austria, submitted a number of "different plans, ideas, proposals and suggestions," for the consideration of Georgi N. Zarubin, Soviet deputy, who is reported to have accepted them without comment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Martin L. Strauss 2d today gave up his long and bitter fight against other management interests in Eversharp, Inc., announcing his resignation as chairman of the board and a director of the writing instrument and safety razor company.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 13 -- John L. Lewis vowed today that his miners could and would win against the coal operators if left alone. If, however, the Government resorted to seizure of the struck mines the profits should go to the people, he declared.
Foote Brothers Gear Machine Corporation declared yesterday an extra of 45 cents and a regular quarterly dividend of 15 cents on the common stock, both payable on Nov. 1.
The text of the charge to the jury delivered yesterday by Judge Harold R. Medina at the trial of eleven Communist leaders in U. S. District Court here follows:

Charles Stern has purchased the twelve-family apartment building at 405 Avenue C in Bayonne, N. J., from the Fischel Friedman estate. J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker in this transaction, also reported the sale of the dwelling at 18 Schuyler Place, Bayonne, after an ownership of more than fifty years, by the Meehan estate to Merrill and Quentin Kovacsy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 -- New York's Forty-seventh Street diamond market will provide the setting for a forthcoming Paramount film, "Jack of Diamonds," for which the studio has bought an original story by Berne Giler. A romantic adventure comedy drama about a detective and jewel thieves, the picture will be shot at least partly against authentic New York backgrounds.

ISLEHAM, England, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Twelve airmen bound from Britain to Helgoland on a practice mission were blasted to death today by the plunge of their United States Air Force B-50 bomber into a wheat field with three tons of live bombs.

The John Scott Award of the City of Philadelphia has been won by Dr. Charles Glen King, scientific director of the Nutrition Foundation, New York, and Professor of Chemistry at Columbia University, for his "outstanding work on the chemistry of vitamin C," it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 574,228 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 83,900 cars, or 12.7 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 317,423 cars, or 35.6 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 382,634 cars, or 40.0 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Eunice Podis, young pianist from Cleveland, gave her third New York recital last night at Town Hall. Unfailing good taste and innate musicality were evinced in her performances, which also could be commended for their technical cleanness and careful attention to phrasing, pedaling and other details.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- Several thousand Bostonians lined vantage points along the waterfront today to bid bon voyage to the French liner Ile de France, which sailed at 4 P. M. for Plymouth and Le Havre after her first courtesy visit to Boston.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Following is the test of a summation presented by Admiral Louis E. Denfeld, Chief of Naval Operations, as part of his statement to the House Armed Services committee:

An agreement on proposed new regulations governing amateur radio operators now appears more likely after a series of conciliatory moves in Washington. The American Radio Relay League, the National Amateur Radio Council and the Society of American Radio Amateurs concurred in their recommendations on the technical aspects of the new regulations proposed by the Federal Communications Commission.

Local taxes do not appear to be a major factor in the location of industry, according to the American Municipal Association and the American Society of Planning Officials, which have just made a suvey of the experience of forty typical cities.

KENT, Conn., Oct. 13 -- A change has taken place in the type of football being played at Kent School this season. The Blue and Gray, which had used the single wing formation and its variations with some success, this year has gone in for the T.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, assured the United States today that his Government would not stay neutral "where freedom is menaced, or justice threatened."

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The economic elations between the United States and Western Europe, which have led to a split in the European Marshall Plan Council between Britain and the Continent, are slated to be discuissed in Paris on Oct. 28 by the Council's steering committee of Cabinet members.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Senate-House conferees failed to agree today on a farm bill, but advocates of rigid, high price supports claimed significant gains.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The "reconstruction" phase of the operations of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is now largely completed, and hereafter the bank's lending activities will be centered upon the "development" of foreign areas, top executives of the bank explained here today.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 14 -- The Women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament over the Montclair Golf Club course, a best-ball event in which each player's full handicap was allowed, was won today by Mrs. A. J. Bryant of Rockland County and Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, one of the low handicap teams, with 35, 35 -- 70.

Between January and August of this year, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad showed a decrease of 12 per cent in passenger revenue as compared to the same period in 1948, Jeremiah J. O'Neill, assistant controller, testified yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing into proposed fare increases.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 14 (AP) -- A small tropical hurricane, with winds up to 85 miles an hour, churned northeastward through the Atlantic tonight some 600 miles least of the mainland.

Perhaps I will appear ungracious if I fail to show some appreciation for the "left-handed" compliment paid me by Peter Kavanagh, when he disposed of his admirer H. T. Edwards by standing him in the dunce corner, and saying that "he is misinformed on Irish politics to a far greater extent than Matthew J. Troy."

The start of the school and college year seems as good a time as any to mention a study of freshman eating that was made recently at the Utah Agricultural College and reported this week by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The bid of Alger Hiss for removal of his second trial on perjury charges from New York to Vermont was lost yesterday when Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe, in a brief opinion, said that evidence submitted did not justify a change of venue.
A chronology of the Communist trial follows:

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- A group of eighty-one residents here, comprising representatives in New York business life and Scarsdale civic affairs, rose today in opposition to the proposal of the self-appointed Scarsdale Committee of Ten, also comprising business and civic leaders, to curb public school books by authors of Communist leanings:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Department of Defense set forth today a code of management-employe relations promising opportunity for the individual development of employes. It called on the civilians to share the department's responsibility for the country's security.

Brooklyn Tech, rebounding from its upset by New Utrecht last week, conquered Manual Training, 19 -- 6, in the second game of the scholastic football double-header before 5,000 fans at Ebbets Field last night. In the opener Erasmus Hall, behind the passing of Bill Connors, routed Midwood, 33 -- 6.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 14 -- The heads of the major organs in the United Nations, joining in special messages marking the fourth anniversary of the world organization on Oct. 24, put it up to the people of the world directly today to determine what they had done for the United Nations instead of asking what the United Nations had done for them.

DETROIT, Oct. 14 -- Leaders of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, warned employes of the Ford Motor Company today that rank-and-file rejection of the pension contract won from the company on Sept. 29 would mean a strike.

The antitrust division of the Department of Justice is studying a request by an association of independent milk dealers that large milk companies be investigated for alleged monopolistic practices, J. Francis Hayden, chief of the New York office said yesterday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14 -- Premier Stalin has placed before the Eastern German Democratic Republic a new and extremely significant analysis of its role in world affairs as the permanent guarantor of European peace through mutual collaboration against war and "world imperialists" alongside the Soviet Union.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed firm, 2 to 9 points net higher.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese New York has quietly lifted a ban prohibiting church marriages between Catholics and non-Catholics, it was learned yesterday. Heretofore, a diocesan ruling had required that all such marriages be contracted either in the parish rectory, or in some place apart from the church proper.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 14 -- Following is the text of the letter sent by John L. Lewis to William Green:

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Globe is "The Black Book," a romantic period adventure with Robert Cummings, Arlene Dahl, Richard Basehart and Richard Hart. The Walter Wanger presentation was directed by Anthony Mann and produced by William Cameron Menzies from a screen play by Philip Yordan and Aeneas MacKenzie.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- House and Senate conferees agreed today on all items in dispute over a minimum wage bill increasing the present 40 cents an hour to 75 cents. Representative John Lesinski, Democrat, of Michigan, chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, said the House would act on the compromise first, but probably not before Tuesday.

The Estate of Eugene Higgins, which is selling off its extensive realty holdings here, yesterday disposed of thirteen buildings occupying the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and West 130th Street to an investing client of Irving I. Rosenberg, broker.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- The Chicago Mercantile Exchange halted trading in October egg futures in mid-session today after a continuing squeeze on shorts had pushed prices up nearly 1 1/2 cents a dozen.

A serious form of heart disease caused by bacteria resistant even to massive amounts of penicillin has been successfully combated when much smaller quantities of penicillin were administered along with ordinary doses of streptomycin, it was reported yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Association of Life Insurance Medical Directors of America at the Statler Hotel.

Seldom has a satellite state been hailed by the Big Chief himself, and never in the terms of the message of congratulation addressed by Premier Stalin to his appointed in the East German state. The note itself is unusual, and the tone is even more so. "Long live and prosper the unified, independent, democratic, peace-loving Germany," he says.

Eleven top leaders of the Communist party of the United States stand today convicted of conspiracy "knowingly and willfully to advocate and teach the duty and necessity of overthrowing and destroying the Government of the United States by force and violence." Their six attorneys, including one prisoner acting as his own attorney, have been sentenced for contempt of court.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 -- Top leaders of the National Congress of Industrial Organizations were accused here today of pursuing a "rule-or-ruin" policy, endangering the CIO as an effective force in the American labor movement. The accusation marked the opening of the annual convention of the California State CIO Council.
The Smith Act, under which the Communist leaders were indicted, was passed by Congress in 1940.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 14 -- A fifty-nine member committee of the United Nations General Assembly overruled strong United States and British protests today and voted to require colonial authorities in areas under the international trusteeship system to submit within one year concrete blueprints showing how millions of African and Pacific natives were to achieve self-government or independence.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Yankees' feat of winning the American League championship on the last day of the regular season and then drubbing the Dodgers in the world series was worth $5,665.54 to the team's full-time members.

Pleas for additional funds for new schools, libraries, health centers and other public projects were heard yesterday by the City Planning Commission at a nine-hour public hearing on its proposed 1950 capital budget of $238,278,804. More than eighty speakers addressed the commission, most of them on behalf of more liberal allocations for new schools in all boroughs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Great satisfaction over the conviction of the eleven Communists in New York was felt and expressed throughout official Washington today.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina, who presided over the Communist trial, was appointed to the bench by President Truman in 1947. He was assigned to the trial by Senior Judge John C. Knox of the Southern District of New York.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The stimulus given to British Government stocks by the announcement that there would be no election this year evaporated on the stock markets today following Prime Minister Attlee's news that post-devaluation measures were being worked out.

Two firemen were trapped early today in a burning loft building at 21 West Seventeenth Street by the collapse of the roof and three floors. Four others were rescued. The missing men were identified by Fire Department official as Fred Lehman and Daniel Shea, both of Fire Patrol Company No. 3.
BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- The Communist-dominated Eastern German Democratic Republic moved fast and far toward full membership in the new Soviet empire today.
Vera Appleton and Michael Field, duo-pianists, were heard in the first of a series of three concerts devoted to a survey of original four-hand keyboard music last night at Town Hall.

At twenty minutes after 11 o'clock yesterday morning a tall broad-shouldered United States marshal in gray mufti came through the door to the left of the bench where Federal Judge Harold R. Medina had presided over the nine-month Communist trial.

TROY, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Prime Minister Louis S. St. Laurent of Canada asserted here tonight that Canada could not make the most effective contribution to the security of this continent without "some arrangement for reciprocal defense purchasing with the United States."

The twelve jurors and three alternates in the Communist trial included eleven women and four men, two Negroes and several persons with Jewish-sounding names. Except for a theatrical producer and the wife of a business proprietor, all were manual or white-collar workers or wives of such employes.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 -- Through the use of special mechanical and electronic devices colors can now be given a numerical rating and "thus take the guesswork out of color matching," Dr. I. H. Godlove of the General Aniline and Film Corporation, New York, said today.
The trial of the eleven Communist leaders has been probably the longest criminal trial in the history of the United States -- and perhaps the longest ever held under the jury system.

President Truman's foreign policy as reflected in his "Point 4" program is indispensable to both peace and prosperity, Dr. Wilson M. Compton, United States alternative representative to the United Nations General Assembly, said yesterday.

With 357,960 New Yorkers registering yesterday it was expected in political circles that when registration week ended tonight that more than 2,600,000 persons will have enrolled 'to vote on election day, Nov. 8.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 14 -- Appointment of a United Nations commissioner to help Libya form a free government was recommended today by a special committee studying the disposition of the former Italian colonies in Africa.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- White House action on pending judgeships, including four for New York, was believed imminent, with the possibility that President Truman might begin nominating for more than a score of vacancies tomorrow.

The Manufacturers Trust Company has arranged to buy the National Bronx Bank and owners of two-thirds of the stock of the latter institution have consented in writing to the transaction, it was made known here yesterday. A meeting of the stockholders of the Bronx County institution will be held on Oct. 27 to vote on the sale.

The United States Maritime Commission announced last night radical changes in its ship charter policy, virtually eliminating itself from the chartering field and with-drawing government-owned ships from competition with privately owned dry cargo shipping.

Despite early whisky sales declines, a general upturn is now being experienced and it appears that estimates of the year's consumption will be exceeded by about 10,000,000 gallons, Tubie Resnick, vice president and general sales manager for Calvert Distillers, declared yesterday.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sailed for Europe at 1:30 P. M. yesterday with 1,186 passengers, among them Albert Devese, Belgian Defense Minister, who praised the mutual defense plans arranged by the Atlantic Pact nations in the recent meetings of Defense Ministers in Washington.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 14 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee adopted unanimously and without any substantial amendment today two programs devised by the Economic and Social Council for technical assistance, through the United Nations to underdeveloped countries.

A Polish painting by the nineteenth-century artist Jan Matejko, said to be the first by him to be shown in the United States, went on exhibition yesterday at the Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 14 -Mindful of the fate that befell Michigan, last week's top-ranking football team of the country, Notre Dame, current holder of the No. 1 spot, will go out tomorrow against a squad that Frank Leahy terms the "strongest and most formidable we've met since my first year in 1941."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Centering its attack on passing, Georgetown University trimmed a surprisingly aggressive New York University eleven, 21 -- 6, last night at Griffith Stadium. Some 5,032 spectators braved an early rain to see the Hoyas gain their third victory of the season.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- In the same persevering manner in which he had built his majority in the National Assembly last night, Jules Moch, France's new Socialist Premier, began today the almost equally difficult task of forming the new Cabinet.

TOKYO, Oct. 14 -- Armed Russian patrol vessels have been raiding across "the MacArthur line" to seize Japanese fishing boats operating in coastal waters, its was charged today by Japanese fishermen returning from northern fishing fields.

Negotiations to avert a strike of 16,000 aluminum workers broke down in Pittsburgh last night after the Aluminum Company of America accused the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, of rejecting the principle that employer contributions to pensions and social insurance programs should be reduced as the Federal social security program was liberalized.

Directors of the North American Rayon Corporation approved yesterday proposals of minority stock-holders, who had been blocking sale of the company's assets to Beaunit Mills, Inc., for reclassification of their stock, retention of North American as a separate corporate entity, and minority representation on the latter company's directorate.

John Creighton Murray has a nine-year background of public appearances as violin soloist in recital and with orchestra both here and abroad. Last night in Carnegie Hall he again displayed the musical style and personality that have won him friends.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 14 -- President Charles Seymour of Yale University declared tonight that for an indefinite period university operations "will result in a red figure" unless decisive measures are undertaken. Addressing a dinner meeting of the Yale Alumni Association convocation, Dr. Seymour added:

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Kid Gavilan, Cuba's aspirant to the world's welterweight championship, tonight administered a decisive defeat to Beau Jack, former lightweight titleholder, in a blistering ten-round battle in the Chicago Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A move to force a vote at midnight on a motion to recommit the bill liberalizing the Displaced Persons Act was blocked in the Senate tonight.

George Meany, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, urged last night the election for former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, as an outstanding American and a devoted friend of the working people.

Miguel Enrique Gonzales, 37 years old, 4 East 108th Street, a co-defendant in Federal court, pleaded guilty yesterday to two counts of violating the Narcotics Act in smuggling cocaine into this country. He will be sentenced Oct. 18.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 14 -- United Nations conciliators have reached the first promising "break" in their efforts to work out a settlement in the Balkans between Greece and her northern neighbors.

GENEVA, Oct. 14 -- A slashing attack on the attitude of governments that propose to leave about 50,000 old, sick, injured, parentless and intellectual refugees to their fate when the International Refugee Organization closes its doors was made today by the French delegate, Robert Rochefort, before the general council of the refugee body.

HONG KONG, Saturday, Oct. 15 -- The big Pearl River bridge in Canton was blown up late yesterday by Nationalist demolition squads just before the last Nationalist troops cleared out of city and left it to the Communists.

New financing of varied kind and in substantial volume will mark the primary market for new securities next week. Most interest surrounds the bidding on Tuesday for $15,000,000 of Duquesne Light Company bonds and on Wednesday or $40,000,000 of obligations of the Indianapolis Power and Light company.

Disclosing that the city's reservoirs were down to about 50 per cent of capacity, Mayor O'Dwyer termed the situation yesterday as "most serious," appealed to the public for a reduction in water consumption and issued a series of orders designed to enforce strict conservation by several city departments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today eliminated all petroleum products but crude oil, fuel oil, diesel oil, furnace oil and gasoline from the petroleum items which Seatrain, Inc., may carry in the side tanks of its vessels without having to file rates with the ICC.
Two rulings favorable to tenants were handed down yesterday in Supreme Court.
The Dallas, Tex., Independent School District announced yesterday that it would receive bids Nov. 8 on an issue of $8,000,000 of bonds.
BRECHIN, Scotland, Oct. 14 -- The fact that both sides are armed with new weapons invented in the last few years will help prevent war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Soviet Union has rejected, in a note received here today, a request by the United States for aid in locating and returning an American merchant vessel on loan to Korea, missing since late last month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A Senate Armed Services Subcommittee recommended today that the Department of Defense investigate whether a plan was afoot to "revive the German nationalistic spirit by discrediting the American Military Government."

A tentative compromise agreement reached last night between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association gave promise of two years of peace on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

Jewelry this season has become an integral part of a woman's costume and, like many of the latest fashions, much of it has been Paris inspired. The deep decolletage offers a perfect frame for wide bib necklaces and the low plunging neckline for pendant necklaces.

The stand of THE NEW YORK TIMES on the Displaced Persons Bill has been well known for some time to many of us, and I think you are to be commended particularly for your editorial "A Lack of Charity," attacking the attitude of the American Legion and Veterans of Foreign Wars.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Republican state chairmen and vice chairmen from fifteen Midwest and Rocky Mountain states, gathered for a two-day meeting here, tonight issued a statement on organizational matters. It focused attention on the importance of the 1950 campaign, and called for stimulating political interest to the utmost.
Biographical details follow on the defendants in the Communist trial:

The five defense lawyers in the Communist conspiracy trial sentenced by Federal Judge Harold Medina to varying jail terms for contempt of court face disciplinary action by the Association of the Bar of City of New York, it was said yesterday.

Major League baseball attendance dipped a slight 3 per cent from its record high of 1948 but unofficial figures show the sixteen clubs drew 20,312,327 paying spectators during 1949, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The Yankees were high with 2,321,302.

For eighty-three years, penniless and homeless women and unmarried mothers, troubled children of all races and creeds found shelter at St. Barnabas House of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society at 304 Mulberry Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Army tonight asked its Chief of Staff, Gen. J. Lawton Collins, to return at once from Japan to state the Army's case in the dispute over this country's fighting strategy.
Following is the text of a statement made by Federal Judge Medina at the Communist trial yesterday in sentencing six members of defense counsel for criminal contempt:

A garden setting of fresh flowers was used for a gala supper dance, "La Fete des Roses," given last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the Boys Club of New York. The party was sponsored by Parfums Caron.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 14 -- Proximity, 7-year-old Protector mare owned by Ralph and Gordon Verhurst of Victor, N. Y., and driven by Floyd Milton, set a new world record for a mile and one-half trot over a half-mile track when she won the second qualifying heat of the David H. McConnell Memorial Stake in 3:07 3/5 before 10,457 tonight. The old record of 3:11.1 was made by Allen Spencer in 1947.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A department store official said today that furniture sales in the last forty-five days have been far ahead of all other types of sales in his store.

Eleven top leaders of the Communist party of the United States were found guilty yesterday of criminal conspiracy. They were convicted of secretly teaching and advocating, on secret orders from Moscow, overthrow of the United States Government and destruction of American democracy by force and violence.
A threatened "showdown" planned by union sea captains and other deck officers to speed settlement of their contract dispute with shipping employers fizzled yesterday at a negotiation session.

Henry Sherek, London producer, told a correspondent for this newspaper yesterday that T. S. Eliot's controversial play, "The Cocktail Party," which had its premiere at the Edinburgh Festival on Aug. 25, will be presented in New York during the second week of January under the co-auspices of Gilbert Miller.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 -- John M.
