Hancock, a partner in the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers of New York and a former member of the United States delegation to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, charged today that the real deterrent to capital expansion by business is industry's reluctance to "go whole hog on its capital programs in the face of an openly hostile or at least unsympathetic Government."
A sweeping realignment of markets by two leading oil and gas companies was disclosed yesterday when the Cities Service Company acquired extensive properties of the Continental Oil Company.

Ground-breaking ceremonies were held yesterday at 103d Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive for a pedestrian bridge to Ward's Island, which will make accessible to upper East Side residents a 125-acre park now being developed. The ceremonies were sponsored jointly by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and the Department of Parks.

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority is trying to finance the building of its $189,000,000 trans-state toll expressway by the private placement of bonds with insurance companies. Its purpose is to save underwriting expense and the cost of borrowing money over the construction period.

BOSTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Boston University, paced by its brilliant sophomore quarterback, Harry Agganis, jumped another notch in its quest for National football recognition by overwhelming West Virginia, 52 -- 20, before 18,034 tonight at Fenway Park.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- The only Goethe program of symphonic music which we have seen given in this year of Goethe celebrations by a leading eastern orchestra was offered for the public this afternoon by Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra, with assisting soloists, and the Goethe Festival men's chorus. in the Academy of Music.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, dismissed today as "premature'' suggestions that the Asiatic nations form a defense alliance similar to the North Atlantic Pact.

WASHINGTON, Oct 14 (AP) - A sharp rise in unemployment, caused by spreading layoffs in industries hampered by the great steel and coal strikes, was reported today by the Bureau of Employment Security.

On Oct. 8 you published a letter by Shiv K. Shastri of the Indian Embassy referring to your editorial, "Kashmir Plebiscite." Besides making certain allegations about Pakistan, he does not say what point or points in your editorial are being taken exception to. Your editorial stressed that by rejecting the arbitration proposal for settling the terms of a truce agreement India had impeded progress toward a solution.

Coffee futures trading was irregular on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Prices were steady early in the day on trade and producer demand. Toward midday scattered long liquidation and profit-taking found support lacking and prices broke sharply.

The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's production of the Benjamin Britten opera, "Peter Grimes," will be relayed by direct wire on Wednesday to the city's frequency modulation station, WNYC-FM, which will carry the full presentation.

Told by Federal Judge Harold R. Medina not to discuss any aspect of the trial of the eleven Communist leaders with anyone, the jury of eight women and four men quit the Federal courthouse for their homes yesterday with a brief "no comment" that varied in tone and delivery with the juror.

Five members of the United States Senate Appropriation Committee sailed from here for Europe yesterday afternoon on the Army transport General Maurice Rose for an inspection of countries receiving Marshall Plan aid. The Senators, all Democrats, are: Burnet R. Maybank of South Carolina, A. Willis Robertson of Virginia, John C. Stennis of Mississippi, John L. McClellan of Arkansas and Dennis Chavez of New Mexico.
An Albanian judge who escaped in dramatic fashion from Communist secret police in his native land called yesterday for the overthrow of the Soviet satellite regime there by the Greek Army.

Jules Moch, the new French Premier, won a victory in the National Assembly that is more disturbing than gratifying. The French Premier is a man of high qualities with a remarkable record as Minister of the Interior in four successive governments since November, 1947.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 14 -- Mrs. George Morris of the Woodlawn Public Foundation, Inc., reported here today that $95,000 of the $100,000 to purchase the 127-acre historic estate at Alexandria, Va., was raised in the first six months of the drive.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that direct subway service to Main Street, Flushing, and Ditmars Boulevard, Astoria, will be available starting with the rush hour period Monday morning. The Queens line of the IRT will operate to Main Street, Flushing, and the Queens lines of the BMT to Ditmars Boulevard, Astoria.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Three directors of Lustron Corporation resigned today in a shakeup at the plant making steel homes.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 14 -- Because of the inadequate standards of many convalescent and rehabilitation institutions for children in New York State, the state should make a survey to find out the present conditions in these childcare institutions, Moir P. Tanner, director of the Buffalo Children's Hospital, suggested today.

Presentation of New York University's first Certificate in General Education was made yesterday to Irving R. Warner, 25 years old, of 4435 Byron Avenue, the Bronx. The certificate represents completion of a two-year program of study at the university's adult branch, the Division of General Education.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Winston Churchill warned tonight that Britain would be kept in a state of damaging uncertainty until the Labor Government set a date for an election to get rid of a Parliament that is "not only dead but decomposing."

BOSTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Favored Mississippi had to roll for three fourth-period touchdowns and then fight off a terrific last-minute aerial barrage to gain a 25-25 tie with Boston College tonight before a 20,103 crowd at Braves Field. Time ended with the Eagles on the Ole Miss 10-yard line.
The conviction of eleven members of the American Communist high command yesterday brought instant and vigorous reactions of praise and condemnation for the jury's verdict.

A testimonial-advertisement campaign for Harwood's Canadian blended whisky will be expanded from trade publications to include daily newspapers in seven states, it was announced yesterday. The ads, featuring testimonials of noted figures in the field of purveying and serving of fine foods and beverages, will be carried by twenty-three newspapers in eighteen major cities.

MANILA, Oct. 14 -- Presidential candidate Jose P. Laurel today accused his rival, President Elpidio Quirino, of having accumulated a 160,000,000 peso [$80,000,000] national deficit through theft, incompetence and extravagance in his Government. He also expressed a fear that the Nov. 8 elections would be ruled by force and fraud, thus failing to express the popular will of the Filipinos.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- Premier Stalin's telegram to the new Eastern German regime caused French observers to remark today that this looked much like a return to the Soviet-German collaboration that had begun with the treaty of August, 1939, as if there had been no war -- and no Soviet annexation of vast German territory -- in the interval.

News that control of Manhattan's famous Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Park Avenue has been acquired by the head of a chain of big hostelries is causing a Manhattanite of many years' standing to indulge in a chain of reminiscences about the great caravanserai of the same name, which, standing proudly where the Empire State Building now stands, was long one of the leading ornaments of the New York of another era.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Dr. Ruth W. Ayres, managing director of the National Consumer-Retailer Council, started today a plan for nationwide consumer-retailer clinics to improve food marketing practices and promote the better across-the-counter understanding.

The political future of Benjamin J. Davis Jr., who is running for a third term in the City Council, was jeopardized yesterday when he was convicted with his fellow Communist leaders of conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 14 -- Harold A. Brand, 61 years old, central figure in the collapse of his million-dollar auction firm on Atlantic City's boardwalk, pleaded not guilty in United States District Court here today to nine criminal charges of fraud and conspiracy.

Paul Robeson, the singer, charged last night Mayor O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for Mayor, with having broken repeatedly promises for improvements in Harlem and asserted that Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for the same office, would be unable to keep similar promises because Governor Dewey, his Republican backers and the big real estate interests wouldn't let him.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., Oct. 14 -George Stuhler, long hitting Cedar Hill pro, scored in both ends of a New Jersey P. G. A. pro-amateur tournament today at the Plainfield Country Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- In the interest of national security, American industry should accelerate decentralization now that Russia has developed "the atomic weapon," Brig. Gen. Donald B. Armstrong, retired Army officer and president of the U. S. Pipe and Foundry Company, declared here tonight.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 14 -- In the presence of 150 applauding pro - Government priests of all denominations, the National Assembly unanimously approved today two laws superseding all other church legislation and making the churches administratively and financially entirely dependent on the state in Czechoslovakia.

Dana R. Staples has been appointed manager of the newly consolidated locomotive engineering department of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, Philadelphia. Ralph Schmidt was named manager of the mechanical section; Ralph A. Miller, manager of the electrical section; John T. Shatagin, manager of the development section and Warren B. Darlington, supervisor of the drawing office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- President and Mrs. Truman attended a reception at the Indian Embassy tonight, but some of the usual formality was missing. The reception was held to mark the visit here of Pandit Nehru.

Edward Homer Mouzon has purchased the two-story one-family dwelling at 115-20 180th Street, St. Albans, Queens, from Josephine C. Peters. The Hamburg Savings Bank made a purchase money mortgage of $10,000 in connection with the transaction, which was negotiated by Florence B. Allen as broker.

Along with the spotlighted clash between Notre Dame and Tulane at South Bend, the meeting of Ohio State and Minnesota at Columbus and the California-Southern California classic at Berkeley command priority national attention on today's college football program.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Dr. Derrick T. Vail of Chicago today was named president-elect of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology, a society of eye, ear, nose and throat specialists.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The House approved today, quickly and without a record vote, a $1,314,010,000 appropriation to finance the Administration's plan to help arm much of the non-Communist world.
WARSAW, Oct. 14 -- Negotiations aimed at a settlement of church-state differences have been broken off, Roman Catholic Church circles reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- The Congressional Atomic Energy Committee met in closed session with the Joint Chiefs of Staff today to discuss the implications of Russia's atom bomb.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 (AP) -An amazing Tulsa University eleven blasted Villanova College from football's undefeated ranks tonight in one of the year's major upsets. Led by 165-pound Dub Graves, Tulsa built up a first-half lead that withstood a stirring rally to win, 21 to 19.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -The House today passed a compromise basing-point bill intended to exempt uniform delivered pricing practices from the anti-trust laws. The revised measure now goes to the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -President Truman today vetoed a bill to direct an examination of claims arising out of the condemnation in 1942 of facilities in the New York Foreign Trade Zone facilities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A petition for a writ of certiorari was filed today in the United States Supreme Court in the Dorsey vs. Stuyvesant Town case, which was brought by three Negro war veterans who had applied for apartments in the New York housing project.
A new electric arc light, small enough to be carried on one hand yet one-eighth as bright as the noonday sun, has been developed in the research laboratories of the Western Union Telegraph Company.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on a compromise bill to give pay increases of $1,000 to $7,500 to 253 top Federal officials.

Home radio sales this year will amount to 8,000,000 units, with a retail value of $320,000,000, Roger Bolin, assistant to J. M. McKibben, vice president in charge of Westinghouse Electric Corporation's radio and appliance divisions predicted yesterday.
In three of the current one-man art exhibitions painters react in different ways to what they see.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Pentagon seethed and rocked today, still shaking under the impact of the Navy's week-long attack upon basic defense policies and unification procedures.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- President Truman today nominated Robert Lebaron, oil company executive, as chairman of the Military Liaison Committee of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

Reports that the Italian Government was dissatisfied with the tenor of discussions going on before the Defense Committee of the North Atlantic Pact in Washington and had threatened to withdraw unless its frontiers got guarantees of sufficient military protection were denied yesterday by Randolfo Pacciardi, Italian Minister of Defense.
BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Former Senator Henry C. Dworshak, a Republican, was appointed today to the United States Senate, succeeding the late Bert H. Miller, a Democrat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The fight for a veto of the $88,000,000 Navajo-Hopi rehabilitation bill is now being supported by six of the eleven members of the Interior Department's Citizens Advisory Committee on Indian Affairs, it was made known tonight.

Gordon Glisson, jockey by trade, and Hirsch Jacobs, trainer by trade, had another of their big, profitable afternoons at the Jamaica race track yesterday. They banged out quadruples. Three of the Glisson winners -- the one in the main event and the two that combined their talents in the $16.20 daily double -- were saddled by Jacobs.

Widespread participation by Protestant laymen in Sunday morning services will take place tomorrow. The day has become recognized by Protestant church councils and ministerial associations as annual Laymen's Sunday, and will be the eighth such observance.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Three unions and Swift and Company entered into new contracts today on behalf of 37,000 meat packinghouse workers. The company said no general wage increases had been granted, but the unions said wage adjustments in the contracts ranged from one-half cent to fifteen cents an hour above former rates.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Walter R. McDonald, 57 years old, a Georgia public service commissioner since 1943 and blind since he was 13, was elected today solicitor general of the National Association of Railroad and Utility Commisisoners.

Mrs. J. Lakin Baldridge, who has charge of the arrangements for the eleventh annual White Elephant cocktail party on Nov. 10, will give a tea tomorrow in her home at 117 East Seventy-second Street, for members of the debutante, postdebutante, junior, ticket and floor committees.
The majority of Manhattan play streets for children are dirty, the Women's City Club charged yesterday, taking issue with Mayor O'Dwyer over the cleanliness of the city's streets.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina came out of the nine-month Communist trial yesterday feeling "pretty good and completely relaxed" -- but admitted that one bad day last summer had almost floored him.

John L. Lewis, in his coal strike talk, sent a cold draft over the stock market yesterday, but pressure never proved intensive and the drift to a lower plane was gradual. A few wide losses appeared in the high-priced issues but the composite rate slumped only 0.59 point on the day.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 14 -- Postal inspectors here arrested today a 29-year-old unemployed welder, who admitted his attempts to earn a living by offering to magazines stories and poems written by others and already published.

For many years the public has been keenly aware of Protestant welfare activities and services in Greater New York. Most of this work stems through the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc., of 122 East Twenty-second Street, New York 10, which coordinates this charitable activity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The deadlock in Congress over the military appropriation bill, which continued today, has put the Department of Defense close to insolvency, but officials there expressed only limited concern over the situation.

A new book by Ernest Newman, author of a number of books on Wagner including a four-volume biography of the famous composer, will be published on Nov. 7 by Knopf. "The Wagner Operas" presents a treatment of the stories, texts and music of eleven operas and musical dramas, interspersed with biographical and historical materials acquired in the process of completing his other books on Wagner.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 14 -- About 200 newspaper men from over the state assembled in this city today for the twenty-eighth annual Better Newspaper Institute of the New Jersey Press Association. Morning and afternoon clinical sessions were held at the Rutgers University gymnasium, and a dinner meeting, with Lester Markel, Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, as guest speaker, took place at the Roger Smith Hotel.
MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The election of Senator John Foster Dulles was of "paramount importance" to keep today's children out of a new war, Governor Dewey asserted tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- A Hungarian delegation will arrive in London next week for negotiations that probably will lead to a fourth British trade agreement with one of the Eastern European Communist countries. Agreements already have been made with Poland and Czechoslovakia and one is being concluded with Yugoslavia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 .Defense attorneys in the Tucker fraud trial appeared before Federal District Judge William J. Campbell today to renew motions for separate trials and two to three-month postponements of the retrial scheduled to start Monday.

Representatives of the Singer Manufacturing Company, whose Elizabeth, N. J., plant has been strikebound since May 1, and Local 401, United Electrical Workers, CIO, reached a tentative agreement yesterday.
Robert B. Gelinson, 29 years old, an ex-GI of 502 Oceanview Avenue, Brooklyn, saw the inside of a Federal jail yesterday because he had promised too many people they would see "South Pacific."
The driver of a Third Avenue bus in the Bronx was injured fatally yesterday and six passengers were hurt as the vehicle plunged into an elevated pillar after colliding with an automobile.
A few minutes after the jury had brought in its verdict in the Communist conspiracy trial yesterday the Voice of America began beaming the news to every corner of the world in all languages.
The driver of a Third Avenue bus in the Bronx was injured fatally yesterday and six passengers were hurt as the vehicle plunged into an elevated pillar after colliding with an automobile.
A few minutes after the jury had brought in its verdict in the Communist conspiracy trial yesterday the Voice of America began beaming the news to every corner of the world in all languages.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Herman Barron, Fenway Club professional and 1948 Goodall champion, and his amateur partner, Norman Gerstenzang of Rye Wood, combined to lead a field of forty-three teams with a 32, 31 -- 63 in the final one-day Metropolitan P.G.A. pro - amateur tournament over the wind-swept Vernon Hills Country Club course today.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -Striving for its third straight victory of the season, Pennsylvania meets Columbia on Franklin Field tomorrow before a crowd expected to reach 40,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Temple University came through with a smashing fourth-period attack for two touchdowns tonight to score a 20-19 victory over Bucknell before 15,000 fans.

Support of voluntary organizations serving community health and education needs was urged yesterday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former military governor of Germany, as the "surest road to continued democracy."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The names of forty Americans who have received teaching and research fellowships abroad for the next academic year under the terms of the Fulbright Act were announced today by the State Department.

CATALOOCHIE, N. C., Oct. 14 -- From the high hills and the low valleys the mountain men converged on Cataloochie this morning carrying the long "hawg" rifle their grandfathers shot, all hoping to take home a quarter of beef from the steer that is the traditional prize at these shoots.

Retail sales declined in the week due to record high temperatures that depressed sales of fall and winter clothing. Department store sales here were estimated to be about 15 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 13 per cent below last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Domestic production of gold declined five per cent in 1948 to reverse an upward trend from a 1945 low, the Bureau of Mines said today. The 1948 output of 2,014,257 fine ounces was only 41 per cent of the high of 4,869,949 ounces set in 1940.

LAKEHURST, N. J., Oct. 14 -- Helicopter Utility Squad No. 2, the only training school of its kind in the East, is buzzing with activity here as its instructors turn out pilots and crewmen to provide helicopter units for the fleet.

A unique school to train Jewish social workers from Europe and North Africa for service in their native communities was opened in a remodeled chateau at Versailles this week by the Joint Distribution Committee. The school will instruct men and women from perhaps a score of countries in American social work techniques, which they will bring back to their homelands for the benefit of the nearly 2,000,000 Jews remaining in Europe and North Africa.

CHITTENANGO, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The fourth week of up-state campaigning by Senator John Foster Dulles ended here today with a prediction by Representative William L. Pfeiffer, state Republican chairman, that the Republican candidate would win the New York Senatorial race by 239,000 votes.

Traveling as C. Holkar, the Maharajah of Indore arrived here yesterday, accompanied by the Maharanee, who is the former Nancy Miller of Seattle, Wash., aboard the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania, which docked at Pier 90, North River, at 7:40 P. M.

THE trouble with books about current affairs is that they are apt to run a hundred days or so behind the news of current affairs in your morning newspaper. Or, to put it another way, most books on recent developments in Europe, say, inevitably sound as if we still depended on sailing ships rather than cable and wireless to bring us information from abroad.

Sergio Osmena Jr., president of the De La Rama Steamship Company, announced yesterday the appointment of Ralph M. Hylton as United States manager for the company, which operates freight lines between United States ports and the Far East.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 14 -- The United States, France, China, Canada, Cuba and Norway presented today a solid front in opposing a Soviet proposal that the Security Council call for information from the fifty-nine members of the United Nations on atomic as well as other armaments.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- William Green had no comment today on the proposal by John L. Lewis to join in a fund to aid the striking steel workers.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 14 -- John L. Lewis made a spectacular appeal today for labor unity. He suggested that nine American Federation of Labor unions and the United Mine Workers pour $2,500,000 a week into a war chest to win the steel strike sponsored by the United Steelworkers of America, a CIO union.

The first national, industry-wide drive to improve sales training of supply and machinery salesmen for manufacturers and distributors is now being planned by more than 700 companies holding memberships in trade associations in those fields, it was reported yesterday.

ATLANTA, Oct. 14 -- A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board today recommended that a leather company in Chattanooga, Tenn., be ordered to open its books for inspection by a union in a labor dispute.

It was made very plain, at yesterday's hearing at City Hall on the proposed Capital Budget for 1950, that the provisions for new public schools are not adequate. The witnesses who gave up their day largely to this cause plead in behalf of children. They do not, in all cases, demand new schools.

LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 14 -- Reluctantly but realistically leaders of the Benelux countries began to plan today for something less than the full economic union originally drafted during the wartime London exile of the Belgian, the Netherlands and the Luxembourg Governments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended Oct. 11, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 152.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.6 per cent below four weeks ago and 7.8 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.
Mayor O'Dwyer defended yesterday the increase in the subway fare from 5 to 10 cents as necessary to provide the money for required pay increases for employes of the subway system.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Winston Churchill defined the role of the British Opposition tonight at the closing session of the Conservative party conference from which the fire had been drawn by Prime Minister Attlee's announcement that there would be no election this year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles knocked out Pat Valentino in the eighth round of their scheduled fifteen-round bout tonight to retain his National Boxing Association world heavyweight title. The bout ended after thirty-five seconds of the round.

The Dow Chemical Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday that net profit amounted to $5,957,148, equal to $1.04 a common share, for the quarter ended Aug. 31. This compares with a profit of $6,393,445, or $1.15 a share, for the corresponding quarter last year.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 14 -- Sun Beau, the Sterling Smith chestnut gelding from Ravenna, Ohio, who won the jumper stake at the National last fall, was in top form today at the opening of the two-day Montclair horse show.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- From 3,200 to 4,200 employes of the tractor works of the International Harvester Company in Chicago prepared today to apply for unemployment compensation when the company did not put them back to work as they ended their month-old strike.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 14 -- A giant new troop and cargo plane, with a wingspread only ten feet shorter than the length of the Wright brothers' first flight, took to the air here this afternoon for its first public demonstration.

Communist party adherents moved quickly yesterday to interpret the verdict against their leaders. Less than ten minutes after court was adjourned they staged a conference in the courthouse basement press room. Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, one of the two national committee members "at liberty," read a 700-word statement.

Branch Rickey continued to clean house yesterday. Latest Dodgers to be swept aside were Marvin Rackley and Dick Whitman who, when employed by Burt Shotton, worked as outfielders or pinch hitters for the National League champions.

The first national, industry-wide drive to improve sales training of supply and machinery salesmen for manufacturers and distributors is now being planned by more than 700 companies holding memberships in trade associations in those fields, it was reported yesterday.

ATLANTA, Oct. 14 -- A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board today recommended that a leather company in Chattanooga, Tenn., be ordered to open its books for inspection by a union in a labor dispute.

It was made very plain, at yesterday's hearing at City Hall on the proposed Capital Budget for 1950, that the provisions for new public schools are not adequate. The witnesses who gave up their day largely to this cause plead in behalf of children. They do not, in all cases, demand new schools.

John Taylor's, Kansas City department store affiliate of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., has been renamed Macy's Kansas City, it was announced yesterday by Richard C. Roth, store president. It has been completely rebuilt and expanded at a cost of about $7,000,000, according, to company officials, and will be formally opened tomorrow.

Evidences that the inventory boomlet is over in heavy goods lines were reported by both buyers and sellers last week. A downward readjustment of markets has appeared, after the short-term rise in demand and prices which appeared in the third quarter.

The New York Giants will open their twenty-fifth home season at the Polo Grounds by facing the Pittsburgh Steelers in the local feature of a seven-game professional football schedule today. The Yankees play the Colts in Baltimore and the Bulldogs oppose the Redskins in Washington in other contests involving New York teams.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Backers of high, rigid price supports claimed a significant victory this morning as a Senate-House conference committee by 11 to 3 reached a tentative compromise on the major point of conflict between farm bills passed by the two branches of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Eighty-first Congress is nearing the end of its first session and President Truman is acting like a quarterback whose team, while it has been stopped cold a few times, has scored most of the touchdowns.

THIS has been a year of great court trials staged against the backdrop of America's running conflict with communism. They have been trials of high political and personal drama. There is the case of the girl from Brooklyn, Judith Coplon, already convicted on charges of spying on behalf of Russia, who is soon to be tried again on another aspect of the same case.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 15 -- Supervisor Harry Tappen, who has been sitting as a watch-dog over the $1,500,000 windfall the Town of Oyster Bay received in taxes more than three years ago from the wartime industrial levy on plants in its area, has announced plans or spending a part of it.

BOSTON, Oct. 15 -- Army's powerful football team that brought Michigan's string of victories to an end last week rolled to a 54-to-14 triumph over Harvard on this bleak afternoon before a gathering of 46,000.

THE air traveler using the regular commercial airlines of this country undoubtedly enjoys the best domestic flying service in the world. From a technological standpoint our lines are even with, if not ahead, of the domestic lines of other nations.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 15 -- Laszlo Rajk, once one of Hungary's top Communists, was hanged today for treason -- the fate he had begged at his trial.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 -- State Commerce Commissioner Harold Keller said today that New York State business men are participating by the hundreds in the 1949-50 business planning forums initiated this week with meetings in five up-state communities.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 15 (UP) -- The United States Coast Guard Academy's football team, buffeted by a stubborn United States Merchant Marine Academy of Kings Point for most of four periods, powered over a last-minute touchdown today for a 21-to-14 victory.
A last-day outpouring of prospective voters served to bring to the registration booths yesterday a record number for a mayoralty election year, a count at 3 o'clock this morning showed.

THE flowering period of most garden chrysanthemums will reach its peak this week. Early varieties are reported to be late in opening this year, and some late kinds are ahead of time. The result is a burst of bloom which is bright and gay, in keeping with the autumn foliage of trees and shrubs.

If the national steel strike, the sixth major work stoppage in the history of the industry, is not ended within the next ten days its adverse effects will be felt strongly in virtually all segments of American industry, industrialists say.

Stuyvesant High School's football team, sparked by the accurate passing of Quarterback Ken Adamec, scored its third straight triumph in Bronx-Manhattan P. S. A. L. competition by defeating Evander, 19 -- 0, at Randall's Island yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Foreign Office announced today that British diplomatic, civil and military officials were to meet in Singapore for talks on the situation in the Orient.

Plans are being formulated by members of an executive committee, headed by Mrs. Thaddeus G. Colwell Jr. and Mrs. George H. Pride as co-chairmen, for a tea dance and fashion show, "Snowflakes and Ermine," to be held on Dec. 2 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Judson Health Center.

RUMOR, poetry, and action are a rare combination in realistic fiction. Miss Lincoln's "February Hill," published in 1934, had all three; but with "Celia Amberley" she gives us more. She gives us that surprise, a story of childhood and adolescence which is accurate and without a note of adult bitterness.
Fred G. La Piana has been appointed director of textile research of Stein, Hall Co., Inc. He was previously head of Stein, Hall's textile laboratory in Providence, R. I.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Missouri slammed 65 yards to a touchdown in the final quarter today, offsetting an Illinois rally inspired by Dick Raklovits' 75-yard scoring dash and snatching a 27-20 intersectional football victory.
WE know a few things about tuna: That it tastes good in cans, and that the monster bluefins -- prize catch for deep-sea anglers these days -- are among the fightingest fish in the world.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Owners of the United States freighter Flying Trader reported that a Chinese Nationalist warship had halted it with gunfire off Shanghai early today.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Shipping officials reported today that forty-eight ore carriers were still to be unloaded at lower lake ports. The upper lake loading docks have been cleaned out, they said.

Why do prematurely born babies breath in gasps or jerks? Because oxygen is not reaching the tissue of the brain center which controls respiration, answer Drs. Bruce D. Graham and Helen S. Reardon of Michigan University's Hospital. They arrived at the answer with the aid of an instrument which resembles a miniature iron lung.

Although most of the coffee produced in the world is raised in the Western Hemisphere, with the United States as the largest consumer, the plant itself is native to Ethiopia and perhaps Arabia. How it came into use as a beverage is a legend cited by Mrs. Kathryn H. Wylie, an agricultural economist of the Department of Agriculture, in an article in the department's Foreign Agriculture bulletin.

Children who are interested in books, magazines, signs and labels before they enter school usually make the greatest progress toward learning to read in the first grade, Dr. Millie C. Almy, University of Cincinnati authority on child development, reports in a monograph just published by the Columbia University Press.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 15 -- The pride of the South was just another football team today against one of the most destructive forces ever turned loose on the gridiron.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Allan Dawson, 46, counselor of the United States Embassy here, fell to his death from the eighth floor of the Embassy tonight.

At least 2,000,000 people in France will be living on $10 to $20 month this winter, Daniel Benedict, chief of the Mission to France for CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe), declared yesterday at its headquarters, 20 Broad Street.

IN "Shadows Lengthen," which continues the story of her life from 1935 to the present time, Clara Longworth de Chambrun throws a sincere and provocative light on the events which lurked in the shadows of occupied and liberated France.
MONTREAL, Oct. 15 -- The Montreal Canadiens made it two victories in as many starts by defeating the New York Rangers, 3 -- 1, tonight and took an undisputed lead in the National Hockey League race.

Because of housing projects mushrooming throughout the city, churches must "rethink their programs," the Rev. Dr. Kenneth D. Miller, president of the New York City Mission Society, declared at its headquarters, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

This memorable new novel -- Miss Chase's first in eight years -- is about three extraordinary old ladies, and Emma Davis, who tries to make them happy. Writing with rare understanding of the pathos and wisdom of old age, Miss Chase shows the heights to which ordinary persons may rise, through compassion.

The need of funds of Irvington House, Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y., where children with rheumatic fever are cared for and research into the cause and cure of the deadly disease which cripples so many is conducted, was stressed yesterday in an announcement that a new wing would open next month.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Graydon of Santa Monica, Calif., were fatally hurt last night when their auto and a bus were in collision at West Field, Ind., twenty miles north of Indianapolis.

In "Germany Today" Thomas Mann declares himself "a non-Communist -- rather than an anti-Communist." He does not even say he is opposed to the totalitarian state. He is only a "stranger" to it. We would be glad to change him from "non" to "anti" and suggest that he might make the change without taking part in what he calls "the rampant hysteria of Communist persecution."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15 --Minnesota's Gophers, whose faculty fathers strongly disapprove of the Rose Bowl football game, made it pretty plain they are going to be in it today when they soundly thrashed Ohio State, 27 to 0, in the biggest Big Ten battle of the season.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 -- California voters are poised for a series of political announcements expected to delineate formally a 1950 electoral contest with ramifications extending right to the White House.

The project of a "welfare state" and its implications for security organizations operating under the private enterprise system is a major concern of savings bankers at present. Although savings bank deposits, in keeping with the rising level of prices, have continued their upward trend in recent years, savings men are convinced that the traditional incentives toward thrift are now diminishing rapidly.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 15 -- Bernie Custis, who is known as "the arm" on the Syracuse campus, proved that the sobriquet is a well-merited one today as he passed the Orange to a 21-to-9 triumph over Rutgers.

THE last of the series of annual surveys of contemporary painting in America -- initiated when the war interrupted the annual international exhibitions -- has opened at Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh. Again there are exactly 300 canvases, some 230 of the artists having participated in last year's event.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 (AP) -In the wake of his knockout victory, Ezzard Charles, the N. B. A. heavyweight champion, asked today "what more must I do to get recognition from the New York Athletic Commission?"

A NEW high-power, high-intensity electric light source, one-eighth as bright as the sun,' was described last week in Hollywood before the Society of Motion Picture Engineers. The invention, Telcoarc, which is based on the same principles as the Concentrated-Arc lamp introduced by Western Union Telegraph Company three years ago, was announced by W. D. Buckingham of Western Union.

HERE in Britain, more than a thousand new chrysanthemum varieties have been raised in the last five years. Most of these varieties are not yet available in America, although other hardy English 'mums have proved sturdy and floriferous along your Atlantic seaboard.

" BUSINESS is business" -- few sayings are more familiar and few are accepted with less thought. Yet what does the saying actually mean? Does it signify that business should concern itself only with ledger balances? It had better not. Amid the compelling events of our time business and business men cannot afford to take a narrow view.

DALLAS, Oct. 15 -- Department store sales in the eleventh Federal Reserve District during the last week again fell below sales for the same period of 1948 and also below sales of the preceding week. Bad weather was a factor in the decline.

YOU keep wondering about every new war novel. What else can it add to what's already bean written? How many facets are there to a regimented training camp, a tough first sergeant, a dead body stinking in the sun? The pattern of plot, already shaped and hardened, has become a high hurdle over which too many future war novelists inevitably must jump and fall.
Saying that he does not favor socialized medicine, Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, proposed yesterday an eight-point expanded Federal health program.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- Sales reported last week by Philadelphia women's apparel stores showed a decline of 25 per cent, compared with a year ago and for the four-week period were off 20 per cent. Continued unseasonable warm weather, plus influence of steel and coal strikes, are blamed for contra-seasonal drop in retail sales here.
WEST CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 15 (AP) -- West Chester High School won a football game by 1 to 0 today after a riot forced officials to forfeit the contest.

PROFESSOR HOGBEN, perhaps best known for his "Mathematics for the Million" and "Science for the Citizen," is one of the most persuasive and provocative popularizers of science for the man in the street.

THE great value of this book is the thoroughness and force with which it hammers home the premise contained in its opening sentence: "The New World cannot survive in freedom if the Old World is swallowed up by any despotism."

For the second time during the week, Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's Royal Governor yesterday was responsible for the posting of a flossy set of prices on Jamaica's tote board. On Wednesday he had won the six-furlong Interborough Handicap at 9 1/2 to 1. This time he took the mile-and-a-sixteenth Grey Lag Handicap at better than 15 to 1.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 15 -A third place in the Frank C. Jones Memorial Stake was just good enough to give Mrs. Don J. Ferraro's 8-year-old black gelding Black Watch the jumper championship of the Montclair horse show today.
LUXEMBOURG, Sunday, Oct. 16 -- Government leaders of Belgium Luxembourg and the Netherlands announced early today an agreement modifying their original plan for a full Benelux union on July 1, 1950.

General delivery of spring and resort lines, which were shown here last week by the Sportswear Guild, has been scheduled for February, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. The new lines featured cotton, sheer, nylon and novelty fabrics.
FREEPORT, L. I., Oct. 15 -- Adelphi College scored in every quarter to beat highly rated Brooklyn College, 33 to 15, at Freeport Stadium before a crowd of 3,500 tonight.

TWO premieres are on this week's schedule of the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House. One of them is Frederick Ashton's "Cinderella," the first full-evening work to be created by a contemporary English choreographer. The music is by Serge Prokofieff, and the scenery and costumes are by Jean-Denis Malcles. Margot Fonteyn and Moira Shearer will alternate in the title role, and the ugly sisters will be played by Mr. Ashton and Robert Helpmann.

The Brooklyn Dodgers continued their housecleaning as Branch Rickey, president and general manager, announced that the National League pennant winners yesterday obtained eight players from affiliated minor league clubs.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 15 -- The Soviet Union tried unsuccessfully today to push debate on its resolution for a Big Five amity pact to the front of the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee.

MRS. BRO'S novel is an interesting example of a trend toward greater maturity in teenage books. Among recent stories for older girls there have been a few which have portrayed young matrons. Nor are we, for that matter, forgetting Meg's domestic problems in "Little Women." In this novel, however, we follow a gifted musician from little girlhood through adolescence, a brief war marriage and widowhood, to the promise of remarriage.

MODERN architects often write books intended, evidently, to obscure the clear language of their buildings. Like people who prefer to talk about the calories rather than the taste of their vichysoisse, modern architects have gone to great lengths to hide the fact that they are more interested in designing beautiful buildings than functional contrivances.

Thomas Alva Edison did not invent the electric light. An Englishman, Sir Humphry Davy, invented it in 1802, forty-three years before the Wizard of Menlo Park was born. It also was Sir Humphry who brought out the arc light in 1809, and five years before the blizzard of Eighty-Eight the folks in Fort Wayne, Ind., squinted at the first night baseball game under a battery of seventeen arc lights.

The bodies of the two missing fire patrolmen were uncovered yesterday in the debris of a five-story loft building at 217 West Seventeenth Street, where they had been buried the night before when the buildings roof and upper stories collapsed.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- A long and tough winter of uncertainty is ahead of the British people. To the burden of the rising cost of living and the lowering of living standards made inevitable by devaluation of the pound now has been added the tension of a long political campaign.

A "win-the-peace" advertising campaign, proposed here last week by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, will be studied by a special committee of the Advertising Council, it was learned yesterday.

Two sales will be held this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 110 East Fifty-eighth Street, one of French provincial furniture and decorations and Continental porcelains and the other of modern precious and semi-precious stone jewelry. The auction of the latter will take place on Wednesday.
The Eighty-first Congress is the third with which Harry S. Truman has had to deal as President, and the first over which he has been able to claim leadership in his own right.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The presence of Freud, the great physician of the subconscious mind, hovered in the House Armed Services Committee room this week as the Navy appealed its case to the public.

The Trusteeship Committee of the General Assembly has adopted a resolution that will, if approved in plenary session of the Assembly, require that administrators of trust territories submit within one year concrete plans for the attainment of self-government or independence in the areas under their administration.

IN flight to such borders as preclude extradition I pause to express my chagrin, not to say horror, at the appalling variety of ways in which I identified the author of "W. C. Fields: His Fortunes and His Follies" in the Book Review, Oct. 2.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 15 -- Soldiers of Palmach battalions, members of the Haganah's striking force, defied an order by Brig. Yaakov Dori, Army Chief of Staff, and participated in a series of rallies and parades of the Palmach veterans last night and today.

HOLLYWOOD -- meaning the motion picture industry -- long has been vulnerable to the type of cheap and undemocratic insult that John Barrymore once paid a producer. "Don't wag your finger at me," the aristocratic Mr. Barrymore stormed, "I remember when it wore a thimble!"

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Demands of the striking United Automobile Workers, CIO, would cost the Bell Aircraft Corporation an increase of 62 1/2 cents an hour for every employe, Julius J. Domonkos, a company vice-president, declared today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Interest in the Central States in the current session of Congress started off at a high pitch because people felt it faced a challenge in carrying out the "mandate" which Democratic leaders said the electorate had given President Truman and the legislators in the 1948 election.

" THE flag of the unit is a symbol of military honor, valor and glory. * * * On the field of battle the flag is up front. * * * If the flag is lost because of pusillanimity on the part of the military unit, the guilty officers are subject to court-martial, and the unit is disbanded and its personnel reassigned."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15 -- Simultaneously with the arrival here today of a Congressional right-man subcommittee investigating United States expenditures overseas, the organ of the Levantine commercial and financial classes appeared with a demand that "Uncle Sam" reach for his pocketbook.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 3 points lower to 12 points higher, with a moderate volume of business.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- Pennsylvania's fleet backs, towering ends and rugged line were far too much for Columbia to handle today. After holding the unbeaten Quakers to a single touchdown in the first half, the young Lions yielded three more scores after the intermission to finish on the short end of a 27-7 count before 34,373 spectators at Franklin Field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee said today the nation's war-built merchant fleet already is becoming obsolete and "a replacement program of new ship construction may be in order."

Large-scale assistance to Brazil in training competent technicians was urged yesterday by Prof. Boris M. Stanfield, Columbia University specialist in international labor and economic problems, as "among the less costly but most effective forms of aid to underdeveloped nations possible underdeveloped nations possible under President Truman's Point 4 program."

EDWIN VALENTINE MITCHELL is Vanguard Press' busiest customs inspector. Four out of six books in the American Customs Series are his, including two published this year. His latest examination of flora, fauna, mores, lares and penates deals with Maine.

THESE are disturbing stories, and the author intended them to be so. Their scenes are from contemporary America and its past, from sixteenth-century France, and from early secondcentury Rome. They are stories of children who are the victims of intolerance.

American students of the Russian economy here received skeptically the Soviet announcement of a record grain harvest and pointed out that proper interpretation of the report required additional facts not stated by the Central Statistical Administration.
MOSCOW, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Government said today that Russia this year had reaped a record grain harvest. [The amount of this year's production was not given.]

WHEN Bellamy Partridge sets out to tell a tale of house-holding in rural New England he almost convinces traffic-jangled urbanites that it's so peaceful in the city. In "The Old Oaken Bucket" Mr. Partridge sketches with gentle humor the vicissitudes of a nice couple, who love their Connecticut home and would like to live in it.

THE world series provided motion-picture theatre operators with their first sustained opportunity to test the drawing power of television as a paid-for "added" attraction. From reports now at hand, it can be said that the results were good, albeit not of solid hit proportions.

ALTHOUGH autumn, with its crisp air and brilliant foliage, is one of the most attractive seasons of the year for motorists, it is also rated as the most dangerous because, as days shorten, an increasing amount of driving is done in the twilight hours or after dark.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Pile-driving Herb Rich pulled Vanderbilt through a narrow squeak 22-17 football victory over Florida tonight.

RESERVATION diagrams for sleeping cars and coaches through Feb. 28 in both directions between New York and Florida are expected to be opened this week. With a considerable backlog of listings and an encouraging number of new cars on hand, railroad officials are optimistic about the coming season.

SALT LAKE CITY -- While residents of seaboard cities mopped their brows during last week's belated heat wave, snow sports enthusiasts in the Mountain States were testing their skis on several of the West's favorite ski slopes.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 15 (AP) -- High Trend, owned by Samuel Greenfield of Baltimore, raced to a two-and-a-half-length victory in the $15,000 added Washington Handicap before 15,815 fans today.

Many business organizations are eliminating or revising outdated or inefficient forms and records as part to the current drive to streamline personnel administration in order to cut costs, Eileen Ahearn, research associate of the American Management Association, disclosed in an interview last week.

George Washington University in Washington is expanding its offerings in American literature to meet increased student interest. Classes in American drama and American fiction, each formerly a one-semester course, will now run two semesters. They will cover the work of nineteenth-century authors during the first semester and the works of twentieth-century authors in the second.

FLOWER show judging courses are being offered in October by garden clubs of three states. All of them begin this week. They may be taken for credit toward a rating by the National Council of State Garden Clubs as an accredited flower show judge, or for general information on horticulture, flower arrangement and flower show practice.
LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 15 -- The pin-point place-kicking of Eddie Semlitz gave C. C. N. Y. a 14-12 victory over Lowell Textile this wet afternoon before a slim crowd of 400 in the Lowell Stadium.

THEODOR REIK has been a well - known psychoanalyst and writer for a great many years, first in Europe and more recently in America. His latest book is an autobiographical account in which he brings to bear his thirty-seven years of psychoanalytic experience for purposes of self-revelation. "To express unafraid and unashamed what one really thinks and feels," he says, "is one of the great consolations of life."

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 15 -- Northwestern's Wildcats, playing the type of game expected of them in pre-season days, rubbed bitter salt into once-mighty Michigan's wounds today with a tingling 21-to-20 victory.

The formation of a committee on "modern food distribution" was announced last week at City College School of Business. It will consist of food authorities and certain faculty members from the evening and extension division of the school.

JESSE L. LASKY, one of the organizers of Paramount Pictures in 1917 and its first vice president through 1932, is again associated with the company, the producer told this corner last week. He is in the process of completing negotiations with Paramount for the release of "Valley of the Mist," an "adventure fantasy with animation which is to be filmed largely in Mexico and Yucatan in Technicolor starting in January."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 -- This region seems to have been more intrigued by Congressional investigations than by legislative matters dealt with by the Eighty-first Congress. Inquiries into communism, the B-36 and armed forces unification caused more conversation and used up relatively more newsprint than the less spectacular legislative program.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- The United Mine Workers charged tonight that "steel interests" had ordered agreement on a new coal contract delayed until after the steel strike is settled.
That American coal mines are becoming safer is pointed out in two articles appearing in Coal Age, McGraw-Hill publication.

OMAHA, Oct. 15 -- Midwest sentiment appears to classify this session of Congress considerably below President Truman's glowing praise of it, but somewhat higher than the view of it reflected in Republican statements.

Dr. Gerard P. Kuiper, who is Professor of Astronomy at the University of Chicago and director of both the Yerkes and McDonald Observatories, came out last week with a theory of the origin of the solar system.

India has no intention of committing herself either to East or West at this time, her Prime Minister, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, declared yesterday on his first visit to New York. Arriving from Washington in a United States Air Force Constellation, the Prime Minister and his party landed at La Guardia Airport at 10:30 A. M. after forty minutes "in the stack" because of traffic congestion.

The Association of Buying Offices has decided to make no comment to the charges of "unfair practices" which were made last week before Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer at the New York regional office of his department, 42 Broadway.

Children suffering from heart disease who are cared for at Irvington House, Irvington-on-Hudson, will be the beneficiaries of a tea dance to be held this afternoon in the St. Regis Roof under the auspices of the Heart League of Irvington House.

IN two earlier books Mr. Felsen has presented the activities of Bertie Poddle, fat boy. In general, Bertie's problems are those of any 15-year-old boy. That he is fat simply accentuates them. He wants to be liked, especially by his girl friend. He wants to win a spectacular place in the backfield, not an obscure one in the line.

IT is ordinarily considered, normal for persons celebrating their birthdays to receive gifts on those solemn occasions. But Alexandre Gretchaninoff, probably the oldest of living Russian composers and now a full-fledged American citizen, has made up his mind to reverse this time-honored custom in connection with his forthcoming eighty-fifth birthday on Oct. 25.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., Oct. 15 -- The man who was fired with the desire to fly before and during the war is now married and busy raising a family and his wife wants him to stay home week-ends instead of spending his spare time at the local airport.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 15 -- The injury-riddled Hofstra eleven dropped a 32-to-7 decision to Moravian today. It was the second straight setback for the Flying Dutchmen, who opened their campaign with a tie.

TOKYO, Oct. 15 -- Monetary stabilization virtually has been achieved in Japan. Joseph M. Dodge, General MacArthur's financial adviser, made the Japanese balance the budget and quit inflationary financing by the Reconstruction Finance Bank. The note issue has been falling steadily.

THE lady was going to a party. There could be no doubt of it. She was dressed in a three - quarter length, billowing blue dress. Hat and gloves matched. Around her shoulders was a fox jacket. The hour was right.

What a silly idea to couple "Sweet Adeline" with Adelina Patti as W. E. Farbstein does in "Matters of Fact." He might just as well have associated "The Bird on Nellie's Hat" with Nellie Melba. * * * As for a "barber shop ballad," what is it?

TOKYO, Oct. 15 -- The Japanese today are discussing with interest the conviction in Federal Court in New York of the eleven top Communist leaders charged with conspiring to teach secretly and to advocate the forcible overthrow of the United States Government. The question is being asked whether the court's action may not have great significance for Japan.

OVERNIGHT fame from one radio appearance is practically unheard of, with the exception of Orson Welles, but it is fast happening to a country doctor in Monroe, Wis. -- population 6,000. In the way of renown, radio is doing for him what the Dionne quintuplets did for Dr. Allen Roy Dafoe.

Among people who greatly admire Sir Stafford Cripps there are many like myself who wish that in his excellent article, "The Spiritual Basis of Democratic Strength," he had used a phrase more likely to create the unity which he wants.

Bearing eighty-nine original documents, New York State's blue and gold Freedom Train will arrive in Grand Central Terminal on Thursday for a ten-day stay in Manhattan, it was announced yesterday. The six-car train will be open free to the public from 9 A. M. to 9:30 P. M. on Track 30.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Bermuda was on the alert tonight for a small tropical hurricane which is expected to pass west of the British-owned colony tomorrow morning.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 15 -- Dick Gabriel, 180-pound back from Valley Stream, L. I., personally escorted Lehigh University to a 33 -- 20 victory over Gettysburg College today with a 95-yard kick-off return and 60-yard punt runback, both for touchdowns.

WASHINGTON -- With Congressional approval last week of a $3,000,000 appropriation for its sesquicentennial, this city is going full speed ahead on plans for its big celebration next year. Beginning on April 15 and continuing until Nov. 22, it will mark with Government exhibits, ceremonies, parades, pageantry, art displays and drama its establishment 150 years ago as the country's permanent capital.

LAKE SUCCESS -- The United Nations will this week welcome its 1,200,000th visitor to the world capital, proving that the international organization is fast becoming one of the most popular tourist attractions in the New York area.

Floor prices on Japanese textiles will either be lowered or eliminated in the "very near future" by the Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers (SCAP), according to New York importers. Cables received from Japanese agents, it was learned yesterday, have advised that prices be withdrawn until new schedules can be quoted.

Those readers who enjoyed Thomas Mann's account in "Germany Today" of the ceremony in Weimar where he received the town's honorary citizenship and the Eastern Zone's Goethe Prize will be interested to learn that in September thirty German scientists of the Eastern and Western Zones traveled to Weimar to receive National Prizes.

Just a few days before reading Bernard Iddings Bell's "The Intangibles Behind the British Crisis," I attended a conference with the seventeen-man British building team at ECA headquarters on the completion of their six-weeks' tour and study of construction procedure in the United States.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Touch And Go," the new musical revue, on the night of Nov. 7 at the Broadhurst Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Sheltering Arms Children's Service.

THE art of gentle foolishness, which has practically disappeared under the deluge of harsh wisecracks from Broadway and radio, has come back to life, it is a pleasure to report this morning. None other than Ed Wynn, the clown with the funny little hats, a million costume changes and the copyrighted giggle, has brought his wares to the television screen (9 Thursdays) on CBS-TV) and they promise to be capital make-believe.

THE other day I was walking down Forty-fourth Street when I came alongside of the Belasco Theatre. The street exit doors were thrown open and inside there was considerable activity. Four or five rows of seats had been taken out of the orchestra and a structure was being erected, based on a frame of cinder blocks.
Dr. William Beebe discovered yesterday that today will mark his fiftieth anniversary with the New York Zoological Society.

A quick rise of $84,000,000 in the dollar reserves of the sterling area appears to have been the most tangible immediate gain to Britain in the four weeks since she revalued the pound sterling. The increase lifted the reserves from $1,320,000,000, where they stood on Sept. 18, the day sterling was revalued, to $1,404,000,000 at the close of September.

John Dewey, America's greatest living philosopher, will be 90 years old on Thursday. In celebration of that birthday, scores of colleges and universities throughout the United States will hold meetings, conferences, roundtable discussions and special convocations this week.

Dr. Hartmut Kallman, Professor of Theoretical Physics at New York University, described yesterday the features of a new device he has created that is said to be ten times more sensitive than the Geiger counter in measuring radioactivity.

No change in price of French perfumes in the United States is anticipated for some time despite the devaluation of the French franc, according to Dr. Benson Storfer, president of Parfums Corday, Inc., 730 Fifth Avenue, who has just returned from a trip to Paris.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 15 (AP) With a thrilling 102-yard touchdown run in the final quarter, California's Bears came from behind to score a 16-to-10 upset victory over the Southern California Trojans today in their crucial Coast Conference football game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Leland Olds said tonight that the "immediate determining issue" in this Senate defeat for confirmation as a Federal Power Commissioner was his past insistence on "really effective" regulation of the power industry.

A SPECIAL attraction for Caribbean cruise passengers this winter will be Haiti's International Exposition, which opens Dec. 9 at Port-au- Prince. Celebrating the 200th anniversary of the capital city, the event is heralded as the biggest affair of its kind ever to be held in the West Indies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- More than half of the manufacturing concerns here will be affected by the steel strike if the shut-down extends more than 30 days, a survey made by the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago indicated yesterday.

Assurance that the United States and Canada were enjoying a close relationship at every military level in preparing for joint defense was given yesterday by Brooke Claxton, Canadian Minister of National Defense.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Builders started construction on 100,000 new homes in September, setting a record for the month that one Government official termed "remarkable."

MARIETTA, Ohio, Oct. 15 (AP) -- "Federal aid to education is desirable and necessary, but it must stop at the point where it involves a threat to freedom," Senator Robert A. Taft said here today. He spoke at ceremonies at which Dr. W. Bay Irvine was inaugurated as Marietta College's twelfth president in 114 years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The United States has been forced by the pressure of events abroad and the limitations on human endurance at home to establish a rough priority system for its foreign policy, worrying first about Russia; second, Europe, and third, Asia.
FORCING bulbs for winter bloom indoors is not as difficult as it may sound. And, of course, the results are invariably so charming that the effort involved is more than compensated.
NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 15 (AP) -- A relentless ground-gaining attack swept the University of Oklahoma to victory over Kansas by 48 -- 26 today. It was the Sooners' fourteenth straight victory.

Remarkable gifts as musician and technician were made known by Lilian Kallir, 17-year-old pianist, who gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Looking even younger than her age, and blessed with a charming stage presence, Miss Kallir acptivated her large audience with a series of performances so poised and controlled, so replete with insight and imagination, that she already proved well on the way toward an important career.

TO list the various observances of the centenary of Chopin's death, which occurred just one hundred years ago tomorrow, Oct. 17, 1849, would be to fill our column with announcements. But some of these cannot be passed over as mere features of an occasion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- While corn remains under selling pressure on the Board of Trade today, soybeans and wheat developed strength in late dealings. A good part of early losses in corn were erased as the market came to life following news that the Senate-House conferees had agreed on new farm legislation.

The phrase "strait and narrow," reference to which was recently made in your letter columns in connection with "straight and narrow," used by Louis Allen in "Great River in the Ocean," did indeed originally mean "narrow and narrow," just as "time and tide" meant "time and time," and "odds and ends" meant "ends and ends."
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 15 (UP) -- Williams College scored in every period today and in every way possible to beat Bowdoin, 33 to 0, before 4,000 fans at Weston Field.

After long negotiations with various owners, Columbia University has assembled property with more than 950 feet of frontage at West 125th Street and Riverside Drive as the site for its new Engineering Center.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 15 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the United Nations General Assembly, said today that there was "every reason to hope" that the Balkan conciliation talks would produce constructive results.
MOSCOW, Oct. 15 -- The Literary Gazette charged today that "mass fascisization" of American youth was being carried out through the medium of such American comic magazines as Superman.

Situated on Peachtree Road, just twelve miles north of Atlanta, Ga., is Oglethorpe University, one of the nation's smallest institutions of higher learning. It has a student body of 220 and twenty-three teachers.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed leather topped tables, women's coats, silverware and watches, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Herve Alphand, director of economic affairs in the French Foreign Ministry, said in an interview today he thought that upon certain conditions Western Germany should be admitted into international organizations.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Communist-led Government cracked down again today in its apparent campaign to wipe out remnants of the middle class.

AS attractive a maneuver as exists in the puzzle type of whodunit, and possibly the most difficult to bring off, is that of the LSP, or Least Suspected Person. Wilson Tucker's first novel, "The Chinese Doll," was distinguished by the most brilliantly conceived LSP since "The Murder of Roger Ackroyd."
THAT modern mass production sprang fully armed out of Henry Ford's head is believed even by engineers and production men.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 15 (UP) -- The Wesleyan University Cardinals pitted their T-formation against Swarthmore's single wing attack today and overwhelmed the Garnets, 41 to 16.

When Herbert H. Lehman and John Foster Dulles were named to contest the Senate vacancy in New York this fall, the contest was widely hailed as a clear-cut test of the "liberal" and "conservative" schools of political thought, the New Deal against the Old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on compromise bills providing an estimated $243,000,000 in pay rises for classified civil service employes and postal workers.
SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 15 -- Fordham unleashed a horde of manpower here this afternoon to wear down Scranton University, 33--13.

THE year was 1895. The setting was Connacht, Ireland, near the "muffled booming of the snarling, white-lipped ocean." Young Jamie McRuin had just dreamed his dream of a visit from Spenser's Queen Una, who had promised him three wishes which, in prosaic language, could be summarized as: travel in foreign lands; a woman as beautiful as the Fairy Queen herself; a wondrous son.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 15 -- Three thousand Boy Scouts and their leaders from the metropolitan area took part this afternoon in the thirtieth annual pilgrimage to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Youngs Memorial Cemetery. The pilgrimage is always held on a Saturday near Oct. 27, birthday of the late President.

A SMALL but ugly posse within the ranks of the New York Drama Critics Circle would like to change the terms of the annual awards. At present the main award (which consists chiefly of a magnanimous handshake) goes to "the best new play written by an American and put on in New York."
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 15 (UP) -- Alabama and Tennessee fought to a 7-to-7 draw before 41,000 today. Alabama fumbled seven times and Tennessee eight times on the wet field.

MR. ARNOLD WHITRIDGE, formerly Professor of History and Master of Calhoun College at Yale, has with this book returned to letters and to scholarship after a long service in Combat Intelligence with the Army Air Forces. He has chosen a subject that must have brought him back, if only vicariously, to the tumults of war days.

THIS biography of General Lee deals chiefly with the idyllic family life of the South's most revered personality. Though the author has a sound respect for facts -- attested by an impressive list of sources -- she has taken sufficient liberty with her material to give the story vitality and sparkle.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 14 -- Reports are circulating here of a major oil deal that would give to hard-pressed Iraq the possibility to go ahead with a national development program similar to the seven-year program planned in Iran under Overseas Consultants, Inc., American engineers.

Women are "smarter" than men: married students do better scholastically than single, persons; and in the spring a young man's thoughts turn to education. These are the conclusions drawn by Harry Chambers, registrar at, Washington State College, from a survey of last year's student body of 6,400.
London, Oct. 15 (Reuters) -- Britain's soccer spotlight shifted today from league play to the international match at Cardiff, where England triumphed over Wales, 4 -- 1.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 15 -- Last Sunday's fire drill at the home of Harold W. Ross, editor of The New Yorker magazine, turned out today to have been a dress rehearsal. This afternoon the Turn of River Volunteer Fire Department staged a real performance there.

SHIRAHAMA, Japan, Oct. 15 -- Four years after the start of the Allied occupation of Japan, even the smallest villages of this nation have begun to put into effect, at least in form, the practices of democracy they have been taught since the war.

ADVERTISING reared its -- well -- pretty head in the BBC television program department a few days ago. In fact there were two heads -- the immaculately groomed coiffures of 23-year-old twins, the Misses Irene and Rita Day, chosen from among thirteen pairs of twins who competed for the parts of "Miss Right" and "Miss Wrong" in a new British Broadcasting Corporation program series to be called "Your Wardrobe."
" WHAT kind of motion pictures do Americans really want?"

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- The conditions under which the National Assembly endorsed Jules Moch as Premier provide but little hope for the permanent stability of the new Government in France. All that may be said until the Cabinet appears in a test vote before Parliament is that it will have an energetic and resourceful chief who may be expected to leave no stone unturned in his effort to achieve success.

As the eleven convicted Communist leaders remained in the Federal House of Detention to await sentence next Friday, congratulatory messages from all parts of the country continued to pour in yesterday on United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey for his successful direction of the prosecution.

Substantial progress in the construction of new recreational facilities throughout the city and the restoration of existing parks, playgrounds and beaches to their prewar condition was reported yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Senate voted tonight, 36 to 30, to recommit a House-approved bill liberalizing the Displaced Persons Act of 1948, thus killing any action on the matter at this session of Congress.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 15 -- Princeton defeated a favored Brown football team today. Capitalizing on the visitors' early misplays, and gaining boundless confidence as the game moved along, the Tigers set down the Providence eleven, 27 to 14.

LESS than half of the men and less than one out of ten of the women of sixty-five years of age or over in the United States are at work. A man of sixty-five years of age may expect to live on the average about twelve years longer; a woman nearly fourteen years. How are people going to support themselves for twelve or fourteen years without working?

SEPTIMUS is a great departure from the Landseer school of thought on St. Bernards and, so far as I am concerned, a great improvement on those mournful giants. Genial, willing, he was undeniably flighty. He simply could not keep his mind on his work and was consequently a great trial to his mother and to the good monks of the Hospice of St. Bernard.

Drs. Leona M. Bayer and Nancy Bayley of the Stanford University School of Medicine say that it is possible to predict accurately how tall a child will grow. In eight case studies they came within one-quarter of an inch in correctly predicting adult height.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- The Government is waging "a carefully calculated campaign of political terrorism" against state and county medical societies, the American Medical Association charges in a letter which has been sent to all members of the United States Senate and House of Representatives.

Lack of balance between investment and plant on one hand and revenue on the other is the crux of the difficulties faced by the Canadian Pacific Railroad, according to a brief filed by the railroad yesterday with the Royal Commission on Transportation in Ottawa.

A SENSITIVE and perceptive Puerto Rican doctor of public health, who justly calls himself an afficianado of art, remarked: "We are a country of divided languages. Perhaps that is why we have developed no native culture, no important artistic movement."

Thomas Coulter, Newtown, and James Silliman, Sewanhaka, were the individual winners while Pishop Loughlin and Sewanhaka took team honors yesterday in the thirteenth annual interscholastic cross-country run sponsored by New York University at Van Cortlandt Park. Because of the large amount of entries, 546 individuals and 78 teams participated, the run was divided into two sections with separate prizes for each.

New York functions smoothly as the country's busiest port -- perhaps the world's -- because a complex of Government agencies keeps ceaseless surveillance over the 700-odd waterfront miles and the waterways where 16,000 deep-sea ves-vels move ocean commerce each year.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Michael Karolyi, former President of the Hungarian Republic and former Hungarian Minister to France today released the text of a telegram he had sent to the Hungarian Government two days ago asking for revision of the verdict in the Rajk trial.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Arthur J. Barth, National Ski Association president, was a surprise visitor today as the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association launched its twenty-eighth convention at the Lake Placid Club.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15 -- Thirty-four years ago, when Herman Hickman and his kinfolk were "jes' plain Tennessee mountaineers," and football was farthest from their thoughts. Yale lost to Harvard, 41 -- 0, in the Bowl. Until the Elis, now coached by Hickman, crossed paths with Cornell today, that 41 stood as the highest total ever achieved against the Elis by a Bowl opponent.
