WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Irrespective of legal semantics, the purpose and effect of the Smith Act, under which eleven members of the Communist party of America were convicted in the United States District Court in New York this week, is to outlaw the Communist party in this country and to make active participation therein a crime punishable by fine, imprisonment or both.

MR. WIERZYNSKI, who is in this country, is a Polish poet. He knows intimately the world out of which Chopin emerged -- the Polish countryside and the Polish cities, the yearnings and struggles of a proud people for freedom, the details of daily living and the broad sweep of Polish history.

The State Congress of Industrial Organizations stepped up its drive yesterday for the election of Herbert H. Lehman to the Senate by sending action letters to 5,000 locals and key officials throughout the state.

Forty men and women savagely pummeled three homeless Bowery habitues yesterday after the men had ripped the hoods from the habits of two nuns who had just registered for the election at P. S. 21 at Elizabeth and Prince Streets.

Can fares charged for metropolitan transit in terms of depreciated post-war money be stabilized at a point where service can be maintained on a pay-as-you-go basis without tax or other subsidy? And if there is an upper practicable limit for the range of such fares, what is it?

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 15 -- The Ministry of Foreign Affairs today countered the Rumanian Government's note of Oct. 1 abrogating the twenty-year treaty of alliance by accusing the Bucharest regime of thereby "confirming its collaboration in the plot against Yugoslavia" engineered by the Soviet Government.
Britain devalued the pound sterling about a month ago, but major trade effects of the wave of currency devaluation still lie in the future.

When most of Europe's displaced persons are resettled, probably by the end of next year, the problem will be to find homes for 125,000 "hard core" cases who, because of physical disabilities, old age and lack of assurance of support here, cannot qualify under the Displaced Persons Act, Representative Francis E. Walter of Pennsylvania said yesterday upon his return from a seven-week tour of European refugee camps.

Dietrich Wortmann, a member of the Board of Managers of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U., was elected president of that organization at its annual meeting at the New York Athletic Club, according to a recent announcement.

Two recorded concerts will be presented on Wednesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The first is the weekly concert from noon to 2 P. M., which will feature selections by Prokokiev, Hindemith and Faure, and the other, at 8:15 P. M., is the first of the season's monthly evening programs.

LAST week, discussing the meaning of the word "literature," this column ended on what might be considered an optimistic note. It hazarded the belief that literature, in the sense of superior writing, would continue to be made as long as men can see with freshness and truth.

Eleven leaders of the Communist party in the United States -- most of its "Politburo" -- last Friday were convicted of criminal conspiracy against the United States Government. The verdict raised large questions and had a widespread reaction in America and abroad.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, honorary chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, asserted yesterday that "Israel deserves the fullest moral and material support from America, because it represents an important ally in our struggle to reinforce the structure of the democratic world."

THE ranks of record-producers who pledge allegiance to the long-playing record and the 33 1/3 revolutions-per-minute speed keep expanding. Now it is Allegro, an independent of modest size, that has joined the group bellwethered by Columbia.

ROME, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, said today the United States is virtually wide open to thousands of dangerous aliens and urged a speedy tightening of immigration controls.

OUR local ballet field is undergoing a two-way European invasion; in the Winter Garden sector is (or are) "Les Ballets de Paris" and in the Metropolitan Opera sector is London's Sadler's Wells Ballet -- both doing marvelously, thank you. They are so totally different in aims, methods, repertoires and dimensions that they can only be dealt with separately, and, to conform to popular usage, in the order of their appearance.
AMONG the many bromides that bubble up around the stage is the old one about the theatre being a place of magic. It is -- and in more ways than the perpetrators of the chestnut usually mean.

ATLANTA, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Georgia Tech manhandled Auburn for three periods today and had enough left to stave off a last-quarter rally by the losers that netted three touchdowns. The Rambling Wrecks won, 35 -- 21.

DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 15 -- Duke edged North Carolina State, 14 -- 13, today in a Southern Conference football game that was settled on a missed placement for conversion ten seconds from the game's end.

BERLIN, Oct. 15 -- Although the inevitability of the step which the Russians took this week when they organized the German Democratic Republic in Berlin has been acknowledged by German politicians ever since the German Federal Republic was established in Bonn, the actual event has had profound psychological effects upon the people of the two republics.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Bill Luther ran and passed an improving Penn State eleven to a 22-to-7 victory over Nebraska today.

SIX out of every eleven Oklahoma voters voted dry recently in the fifth referendum since the State Constitution was adopted in 1907 with a prohibition clause in it. Drinkers in the state continue to consume all the liquor they want, getting it with a modicum of trouble and paying moderate prices for it.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 15 (AP) -Bewitch, carrying the silks of Warren Wright's Calumet Farm, came from off the pace to win the mile and one-sixteenth $20,000 added Vineland Handicap for fillies and mares at Garden State Park today.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- "Stunted minds mean war," declared Mrs. Holbrook Mulford, of Oak Park, Ill. this afternoon before the women delegates to the biennial assembly of the Universalist Church of America, meeting here. She is national president of the association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Guy G. Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today outlined plans to the Republican chairmen of fifteen Midwest and Mountain States for intensive precinct organization work, "the only formula I know for political success."

CONSIDER, if you will, this Sabbath morning, the blissful state of affairs that can confront a management dealing with sensible stars who still have the trouper's blood coursing through their veins. On Nov. 2, at the Shubert Theatre, after fourteen weeks of touring, the Theatre Guild, in association with John C. Wilson, will be bringing in the Lunts in "I Know My Love."
GENEVA, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Building experts from fifteen European nations and the United States reached unanimous agreement here today on a plan for sharing the latest technical information on building.

The impulse given by Dr. Torres-Bodet, the new Director General of Unesco, has resulted in the needed reorganization of some departments of the Secretariat and in greater activity on the part of the officials. However, it is doubtful if Unesco has found itself. This may be due, partly, to inability or unwillingness to face some fundamental issues.

The burden of collecting taxes for the Federal Government has been placed in large measure upon the employer. The employer is required to withhold the basic income tax from wages and salaries and to make monthly deposits thereof in authorized banks for account of the Treasury.

JOHN DEWEY is 90 years old. Such a feat of survival is always impressive, especially when the survivor is eminent. But what is even more impressive is that at the age of 90 John Dewey should be as active intellectually and as influential as when, over half a century ago, he first became famous as a fresh voice and a liberating energy in American philosophy and education.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 15 (UP) -- Rice Institute uncorked a devastating running and passing attack tonight to stun a near sell-out throng of 72,000 with a 41-to-27 upset victory over previously unbeaten Southern Methodist in the Southern Conference opener for both schools.

THE biographers in Chopin's centennial year have taken away a number of illusions, they have divested the life of their hero of many romantic legends, and with the perspicacity of contemporary musicologists have succeeded in making Chopin's personality grayer, more frigid and less romantic than it appeared to the Chopin devotees of the nineteenth century.

The eightieth anniversary of the founding of the New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street, was celebrated at a mass of thanksgiving yesterday morning in the hospital chapel by Cardinal Spellman. The mass ended a week's commemoration that included daily hours for visiting the institution.

An attendance of 1,500 persons representing Federal, state and city governments and all segments of the maritime industry is expected Wednesday morning when the three-day annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States begins at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

FOR the last fortnight there has been among the 300 paraplegic war veterans at the Birmingham Hospital in Van Nuys a malingerer -- a man who, if he wanted, could get up out of his shiny chromium wheel chair and, realizing the dream of every paraplegic, walk.

" Moral anemia" rather than "fervent patriotism" is supporting opposition to the liberalized displaced persons bill now in the Senate, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, charged yesterday in his sermon.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 15 -- Approximately 75 per cent of Missouri's 3,300 industrial companies have begun programs to provide steady, year-around employment for their workers, according to a survey released by the Associated Industries of Missouri.

WITH an engaging smile for all hands Gertrude Lawrence breezed into town last week to play her first role in a Hollywood picture. As Amanda Wingfield, the mother in Tennessee Williams' play "The Glass Menagerie," she will go before the cameras at Warner Brothers studio later this month.

AT this time of the year, visitors in the lower St. Lawrence area have an unusual opportunity to watch one of nature's most beautiful spectacles -- the annual migration of thousands of snow geese as they proceed south to winter homing grounds.

THE painters and the poets and the musicians know that there is an order of reality in which intellectual assurance plays no part and the reason is unimportant. It is not measurable by the machinery of our minds, but it is real. "All great poetry," Keats says, "should produce the instantaneous conviction, this is true."

THE seventy-eight exercises which, for weal or woe, found a platform in New York between May 1, 1948, and April 25, 1949, are variously appraised, cudgeled and condoned in the latest edition of George Jean Nathan's "Theatre Book of the Year."

Starting tomorrow, Newbold Morris. Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, and his running mates -- Harry Uviller, candidate for Controller, and Justice Matthew J. Diserio, candidate for President of the City Council -- will step up the pace of their campaign, it was announced yesterday at their headquarters in the Astor Hotel.

I deeply regret the unwarranted interpretation which Heinz Pol, in his letter of Oct. 9 gave to my statement that President Theodor Heuss was a loyal disciple and intimate collaborator of the late German liberal leader Friedrich Naumann. It seems imperative to disperse Mr. Pol's misconceptions, in order to prevent unjustified reflections on the political faith of the new Western German Chief of State.

RICHMOND, Oct. 15 -- In the Upper South, people seemed generally satisfied with the record of the Eighty-first Congress in its first session -- not so much for what it had done but for what it had not done.

THIS handsome volume is specifically issued as tribute "to a great artist pointing out his place in the literature of music as understood by critics, artists, and composers at the half-turn of the twentieth century."

STANDING by itself on the lawn, the plum tree glowed with something more than the sunlight in its blossoms; like the trees of mythology, it borrowed a magic radiance from the eyes of its beholder -- in this case, an ordinary, middle-aged woman who is the protagonist of Miss Chase's gem-like short novel.

AT about this time of year many gourd growers are ready to harvest their crop. But a few do's and don'ts should be considered if the gourds are to be put to worthwhile use. The first hurdle is judging the proper time for picking.

The key Ministers of the Benelux countries -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- meeting in conference in Luxembourg, have been discussing the final step in their contemplated economic union, scheduled to take effect July 1, 1950. It is now reported that they have substituted a plan for a "restricted" union rather than a full union at that time.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 15 -- The American Association of Port Authorities closed its four-day convention here today with a demand that Congress pass legislation giving the states title to all submerged lands. Delegates from Canada refrained from voting on the question because it was a purely domestic issue in the United States.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Yale University showed an operating deficit of $526,000 for the fiscal year ending June 30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- President Truman nominated nineteen men today to be Federal judges, including the successful prosecutor of the eleven Communist leaders convicted yesterday in New York and the first Negro ever to be named to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

HOW publishers select their Christmas books has always been something of a mystery. A glimpse at the blurbs would indicate that public taste is a factor and that it has to do with what mathematicians call the relative mean -- or perhaps, in this case, the mean relative.

THE gremlins of wartime fame apparently returned last Tuesday evening to play their tricks and raise havoc with WOR-TV's formal debut. After functioning perfectly through weeks of experimental transmissions and rehearsals for the big day, the line carrying the sound portion of the opening night program "cut out" at 6:55 P. M., the exact moment when the station was scheduled to go on the air.

Without warning, Ken Murray's "Blackouts" was quietly withdrawn from the Ziegfeld on Saturday night. Thus ended the phenomenal career of the show, described by Mr. Murray as "the missing link between vaudeville and revue," which established a record-breaking engagement of 3,844 performances (June 24, 1942-Aug. 27, 1949) in Hollywood.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Walter Treichel, assistant treasurer of the First Congregational Church of Oak Park, told police he was kidnaped and robbed of more than $1,000 church collection money today in River Forest. On the basis of his story the police issued the following account:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 -- Asserting that Pacific Coast cargoes, proportionately, were heaviest hit by the Current Panama Canal tolls, the Pacific American Steamship Association predicted today that a study of the tolls system by the Budget Bureau, and which must precede any relief, would be finished by the end of the year.

Foreign travel reservations for the summer season of 1950 already are so heavy that at least one steamship company has closed its books for tourist class, and in some cases cabin class space is reported filled.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 -- Thanks to two second-half interceptions that they converted into touchdowns, the Football Yankees shaded the Baltimore Colts, 24 -- 21, in a see-saw battle at Babe Ruth Stadium before 32,645 spectators today.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- A program of more than 125 events was arranged today for the forthcoming season as the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association ended its twenty-eighth annual convention at the Lake Placid Club.

HONG KONG, Oct. 16 -- The 1,700-ton British steamer Anhui was hit in a crossfire off shelling between Communist and Nationalist artillery at Amoy yesterday afternoon. Three persons were killed and twenty-four were injured, all Chinese.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Chinese Communist leader Mao Tse-tung today "warmly welcomed" the creation of Russia's newest satellite, the Eastern German Democratic Republic, the Soviet-licensed news agency ADN reported.
The fifth anniversary of air freight service on regular scheduled commercial airlines of this country was marked yesterday.

Packaging of fruit, vegetables and meat before they reach the retail shelf or counter is on the way to becoming the most active of new merchandising and packaging fields, according to Egmont Arens, industrial designer.

The task of inducing management not to tie advertising expenditures to sales volume records is one that depends largely on the advertising director's personal stature in his own management's estimate, it was pointed out last week in advertising officials' comments on the extent of cancellations made earlier this year.

LANDSBERG, Germany, Monday, Oct. 17 -- Ilse Koch, who once was the mistress of Buchenwald concentration camp, was turned over to the Western German authorities today to face war crimes charges in a German court.

Hunter College paid its respects to Johann Wolfgang von Goethe the German poet who was born 200 years ago, in a program in the Assembly Hall Saturday night. The Philharmonic-Symphony, conducted by Bruno Walter, played Beethoven's overture to Goethe's "Egmont" and the same composer's "Eroica" Symphony, and Erika von Wagner and Herbert Berghof gave recitations in German from the poet's "Faust."

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- A drastic decline in the price of cash corn featured operations in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week. No. 2 yellow corn, which sold at $1.38 a bushel on Oct. 7, was down to $1.18 yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 16 -- Rare stamps valued at $10,000 were ripped from the $200,000 Webster Knight collection in the John Hay library of Brown University some time last night by thieves with a knowledge of philatelic values.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Trade in lard futures was light last week and prices held within narrow limits.
The Philadelphia Nationals, champions of the American Soccer League, toppled the New York Americans to their first defeat, 5 -- 2, at Sterling Oval in the Bronx, yesterday.
GENOA, Italy, Oct. 3 -- The city of Christopher Columbus is still making ships.

In the five boroughs of the city there are eighty-six voluntary, non-profit hospitals that each year serve one out of every three families in the city. One million of the people who use these hospitals, either as bed or clinic patients, are served at less than cost or free.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 -- The steelmaking rate last week was up one point to 9 per cent of rated capacity. Little chance was seen that it would be much more than 10 per cent in any week until the steel strike is settled.

Irving H. Saypol, chief assistant to John F. X. McGohey, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, is slated to succeed Mr. McGohey as soon as the successful prosecutor of the eleven Communist leaders is confirmed in his new appointment as a Federal judge, it was learned yesterday.

The city registration for the election on Nov. 8, which closed Saturday at 10:30 P. M. reached a new high for a mayoralty election here. With 1,025,190 voters registering on the last day, the total reached 2,783,308, from 100,000 to 150,000 higher than the most optimistic political estimates.

Savings of 30 per cent or more in steel fabricating costs are expected from the new Ugine extrusion process for steel, on which the first blueprints reached this country yesterday by Pan American World Airways Clipper from Europe.
Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, urged last night an end to the atomic bomb race. He suggested that the United States compose differences with Russia.

The massacre at South Bend may mean either that Tulane was much overrated or that the Notre Dame first team is the season's nearest thing to an unreasonable facsimile of Rockne's blocking demons of 1930.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 16 (AP) -- A pass interception gave the Chicago Cardinals a touchdown on the second play from scrimmage today, and they kept right on going to whip Green Bay, 39 to 17, in a National Football League game before 18,464 fans at State Fair Park.

Plans for a two-story business building were announced in connection with the sale of three two and three-story buildings at 340 Eighth Avenue and 269-71 West Twenty-seventh Street, the northeast corner, by the estate of Harry Gertz to Irving Maidman. Louis Lewis was the broker.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 16 -- Technical aid to under-developed countries on a scale fifty to 100 times greater than at present will go forward in a matter of days, it became known here today.

WARSAW, Oct. 16 -- Another link that the Poles have with the West will be dissolved later this month, when the Polish Young Men's Christian Association will adopt a new charter and drop its connection with the international association, The Kurier Codzienny reported today.

Syracuse Interests Buy Big Garden Apartments Valued at $2,500,000 From Builder A few months after its completion, the Park Lane garden apartment development in Hempstead, L. I., has been sold by Sol G. Atlas, the builder, to Jackson M. Potter, Inc., representing investment interests in Syracuse, N. Y. The project houses 240 families and represents an investment of about $2,500,000, including the cost of land and buildings.

Long Island growers expect that thin year's cauliflower crop, now reaching its peak, will be the best in years. They estimate that it will exceed the record 1,600,000 crates that were harvested in 1948. There's concrete evidence of a bumper yield in stores here; last week the price dropped 16 cents to 19 cents a head.

The city's financial position and its over-all credit are at least as good as they were four years ago, according to an informal survey and a study of the available data. Representatives of banks and investment houses expressed that opinion yesterday, although unwilling to be quoted on their analyses of the city's complex financial structure.

Erno Valasek's violin playing at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall was always that of a thoroughly musical artist, whose conception of the works he performed was without exception correct. Yet it was not until he arrived at the second half of his program that he did himself full justice and revealed his accomplishments in a manner that lent them definite distinction.

More than seventy-five bedding manufacturers throughout the country are "trading" steel supplies and components to keep production of metal beds and bedsprings going, J. Paul Fanning, general manager of the National Association of Bedding Manufacturers, said over the week-end. Producers with good inventories of sheet steel, he said, are supplying competitors in exchange for angles, flats or other steel components.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission and Democratic-Liberal candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, yesterday morning declared that "our most prized gift is our individuality, our human dignity." He addressed 1,900 worshipers at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, in observance of Laymen's Sunday.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 16 -- Residents of this city held a parade this afternoon to initiate officially a $20,000 drive for a snow plow to be sent to the people of Capracotta, an Italian hamlet in the mountainous province of Campobasso.
Several times recently I have read or heard the remark:

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, put a wreath of white chrysanthemums on the grave of President Roosevelt today and paid him tribute as "one of the greatest men of our generation."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Representative Arthur G. Klein, Democrat, of New York, today asked Attorney General J. Howard McGrath to halt deportation proceedings against several hundred European. refugees who came here from Communist-dominated countries.

A threatened strike by approximately 2,700 publicists, artists and office workers in the New York motion picture industry has been postponed temporarily at the request of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, it has been announced by the joint strike-strategy committee of the Screen Office and Professional Employees Guild and the Screen Publicists Guild of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO.

As the novelty of its week-end programs at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Sadler's Wells Ballet put Moira Shearer into the title role of "The Sleeping Beauty" at the Saturday matinee, and again yesterday afternoon, and a charming novelty it proved to be.

Mayor O'Dwyer, admitting that "I have my own problems these days," took fifteen minutes yesterday to thank 1,500 foster parents gathered in the ballroom of the Statler Hotel for what they had done for the city of New York.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- French customs figures for the first nine months of this year show a continued drop in this country's deficit in trade. During this period France imported from foreign countries goods valued at 496,160,000,000 francs and exported to the amount of 320,919,000,000 francs.

Faith and good works are essential for good living and for eternal salvation, the Rev. Gustav J. Schultheiss, director of institutional commodity services for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided.

BECAUSE Frank Leahy worries so much, nothing short of perfection ever satisfies him. His mind can conjure up the most hideous hobgoblins and visualize the most cataclysmic disasters. This is no pose with him. It is genuine. He plans for every eventuality with a thoroughness few coaches can match. So exhausting are his preparations that his pre-battle statements frequently look a trifle silly in the cold light of the morning after.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins and the New York Rangers battled to a 2-2 tie as the home forces launched their twenty-sixth National Hockey League home season before 13,700 fans tonight at the Boston Garden.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 16 -- Statistics that were described as coming from the files of the Bureau of Internal Revenue were cited here this afternoon by Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, to document allegations of hypocrisy he made against the managements of the steel industry.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 16 -- The members of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, voted overwhelmingly today to end their 168-day-old strike here at the Singer Sewing Machine Company plant. They will start returning to work tomorrow morning.
Four new films, including an importation from Germany, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved narrowly last week, pending the outcome of farm price-support legislation. Futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes ranging from a decline of 3 points to an advance of 26 points.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- After what seemed like innumerable attempts to get agreement between the party groups, Premier Jules Moch had failed tonight to form a Cabinet. Before he renounced the task, however, it was decided that one more attempt would be made tomorrow morning to get the popular Republicans, Radicals and Socialists in accord.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 16 -- The current wave of arrests of members of the bourgeoisie seems to have let up for the week-end, as it did last week. A report circulated today, however, that a member of the Communist party's Central Committee had been jailed.

SMYRNA, Del., Oct. 16 (UP) -- Closed after a labor dispute at its Woodbury, N. J., plant, the Belber Trunk and Bag Company today prepared to renew operations here, where "people like to do their own bargaining."
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 15 (UP) -- The Arab League will meet here tomorrow to thresh out policy on the controversial issues of a Syria-Iraq union and the status of Jerusalem and Palestine refugees.

MANILA, Monday, Oct. 17 (AP) -- President Elpidio Quirino warned Filipinos today the threat of Communism was nearer than "most of us realize." He made the statement in a political speech at Paniqui, in central Luzon, where the Communist - led Hukbalahap peasant guerrillas have been active.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Thousands of supporters of President Juan D. Peron from all parts of Argentina poured into Buenos Aires tonight to attend the huge mass meeting tomorrow marking the observance of "Loyalty Day." Senor Peron will speak from the balcony of his headquarters.

In a letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 9 A. Philip Randolph presented his views on the Peekskill outrage. Mr. Randolph moves far and wide pleading his case against Paul Robeson, the Communist party and those among the Negro people who are wisely ready to march with any and all forces sincerely committed to an end to "vague generalities" and a militant fight against Jim-Crow, segregation and Klan terror.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Herbert S. Morrison, Lord President of the Council, came right out and said it today: The British Government is about to take decisions that will be unpleasant for everybody.

John Foster Dulles, the Republican candidate for United States Senator, yesterday challenged Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic-Liberal opponent, to debate with him on twelve issues Mr. Dulles had selected.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Oct. 16 -- This city, which was called home by John Jacob Astor and Stephen Foster, and whose past beauties were memorialized in the writings of William Cullen Bryant, Charles Dickens and Edgar Allan Poe, will begin on Tuesday the 100th anniversary of its incorporation as a town.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 16 -- An effort by the Communist Chinese People's Republic to send representatives to the United Nations might create a situation in which the validity of every action taken by the Security Council would be open to challenge, a United Nations legal expert said today.
Miss Ruth J. Niclas, formerly with Kirby, Block Co., Inc., has been appointed fashion coordinator of Gimbels, New York.
DETROIT, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs beat the Detroit Red Wings, 5 -- 1, tonight in a National Hockey League game enlivened by several fist tossing episodes.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 16 -- Although the Israeli Government has signed a contract with the Cooperative for American Remittances for Europe permitting food packages to be received tax free, it has so far withheld official cooperation, with the result that there are 18,000 packages now collecting dust in local warehouses.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 16 -- Having only two theatres in its main plant, the Celevand Play House has opened a third, which was dedicated last evening with a freshly designed performance of "Romeo and Juliet." Located at Euclid Avenue and East Seventy-seventh Street, the new theatre is a renovated church.

ZURICH, Oct. 16 -- Stock exchange operators here all agree that the spectacular rise in prices of many German securities, sharply accelerated since the deutsche-mark was devalued by 2.07 per cent on Sept. 28 and reaching a peak last week is due to pure speculation by persons unable to gauge the value of what they buy.

William Schatzkamer, pianist, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The program contained Bach's "Little" Organ Fugue in G minor, two Scarlatti sonatas, Mendelssohn's "Variations Serieuses," Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 110, two Preludes by Kabalevsky, Jelobinsky's "Scenes of Childhood," Shebalin's Sonatina, Op. 12, No. 1, and Liszt's "Hungarian Rhapsody," No. 6.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The Greek guerrilla army tonight announced it had ceased operations "in order to avoid the total destruction of Greece" -- but had not disbanded.

Senator Hickenlooper's charge of "incredible mismanagement" of the Atomic Energy Commission has been disposed of, for all practical purposes, by last week's nine-to-six vote of the McMahon Committee. The public is not eagerly awaiting the promised minority report.

ATHENS, Oct. 16 -- Greece has been obliged to use Marshall Plan funds to the extent of 500,000,000,000 drachmas for the care of refugees uprooted from their homes in areas attacked by the Communist-led rebels.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today sought revocation of the charter of the American Bowling Congress on the grounds that it discriminates against Negroes.

District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx, in a statement issue yesterday through O'Dwyer campaign headquarters, challenged the charge by Newbold Morris, the Fusion candidate for Mayor, that Frank Costello, underworld figure, was the boss of Democratic politics.

Clothing can make childhood a joy, according to "Clothing for Children," published today by John Wiley Sons, Inc. The authors, Henrietta M. Thompson and Lucille E. Rea, have filled 406 pages of their volume with tips on how that may be achieved.

From 6 o'clock last evening until past midnight, 340 youthful combat veterans, each severely wounded in the last war, held a reunion in Billy Rose's Diamond Horsehoe. The evening actually began at 5:30 P. M. when a khaki-colored Army bus from the Valley Forge General Hospital at Phoenixville, Pa., pulled up in front of the night club and forty young veterans in Army uniform got out.
The interdependence of freedom and religion was stressed yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, in an impromptu Laymen's Sunday statement.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The stock markets here and indeed the whole business world have been acutely election-conscious in the past week, and the decision to postpone the date of a general election until near the end of the Government's term of office next year has removed an uncertainty that Prime Minister Attlee was right in saying was having a detrimental effect on the country's trade and national effort

Kay Kyser and his band have been signed for a weekly full-hour television series over the Columbia Broadcasting System, beginning next month. The program has a tentative starting date of Tuesday, Nov. 15, at 9 P. M.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 16 -- Soviet foreign policy has entered "a blind alley" as the result of its ruthless attitude toward small countries, Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, said today.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 16 -- A decided shift by students from science to the humanities was reported tonight by a Columbia University professor taking part in the opening session of a conference at Wellesley College on the constructive forces in education.

As a result of an attack on two nuns Saturday in a lower East Side street, one man was sent to Bellevue Hospital for observation and two others were discharged by Magistrate William Ringer in Week End Court yesterday for lack of evidence.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine said today that she was one of the Senate's "five least talkative members."

Cash bonuses totaling $2,094,950,000 for veterans of World War II have been approved by seventeen states, according to a study published yesterday by Tax Foundation, Inc., a non-profit research organization.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16 -- Soviet gross production this year is running 20 per cent ahead of last year, employment is up by 2,000,000 and, on the basis of third-quarter production figures, fulfillment of the Five Year Plan by the end of the fourth year, Jan. 1, 1950, seems assured.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 16 -- Leaders in the machine, machine tool, textile and jewelry industries here today were not markedly enthusiastic about the tariff concessions announced last week by the United States and ten foreign nations.

TOKYO, Oct. 16 -- Japan, acting on an idea advanced eighteen months ago by the British-American Tobacco Company, is planning to make tobacco manufacturing a private enterprise instead of a public monopoly.

The self-appointed "Government" of the Greek Communists, which as a creature of the Kremlin and the Cominform and with their aid has been waging war in Greece for the last three and a half years, announces that its guerrilla forces, while refusing to lay down their arms or to disband, have, nevertheless, stopped active military operations "for the time being."

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,821,796,726. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
Citations for meritorious service were awarded to 306 members of the Police Department in general orders issued yesterday by Commissioner William P. O'Brien.

A dynamic second quarter, during which the home side exploded for seventeen points, gave every indication that the Silver Jubilee celebration of the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds would be a rousing success yesterday.

Of outstanding importance among this week's local art events is the Metropolitan Museum's exhibition of paintings and drawings by Van Gogh. Opening to the public on Friday, it will feature works from European and American collections.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 -- An increase of longshore work hours in West Coast ports in September for the second consecutive month was noted today by the Pacific Maritime Association in its bulletin, "Shoreside Report," distributed to waterfront workers.
As a result of the mining stoppage there will be a coal shortage of 1,300,000 tons for the winter needs here, Anthony Masciarelli, City Commissioner of Markets, warned yesterday.
A new "gyp" based on popularity of radio quiz and giveaway programs has been uncovered by the National Better Business Bureau, its officials reported yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The general index for French stocks fell off Friday on the Paris Bourse to 1.116, lowest point in four weeks. This should be associated with the return of anxiety to business circles. Among them there has arisen a renewed fear for French economic stability.
A memorial service for members of the Fire Department who died in the last year was held by the department yesterday at the Firemen's Monument at Riverside Drive and 100th Street.

Construction and reconstruction of four major bridges in the city will be completed or materially advanced next year under allocations of funds tentatively slated for the Department of Public Works in the 1950 capital budget, Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen announced yesterday.
Two thousand sweepers and drivers of the Department of Sanitation voted yesterday not to go to work today, but to report "sick" at the Health Department Clinic at 125 Worth Street.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 9 -- A vastly detailed plan for the industrial and agricultural development of the resources-rich Belgian Congo has been drawn up by Pierre-Wigny, Minister of Colonies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The Chicago Bears played brutally efficient football today under the spurs of Quarterback Johnny Lujack, who played the entire game, to upset the Philadelphia Eagles, 38 to 21, before 50,129 fans in Wrigley Field.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 16 -- Dr. Ordway Tead, Chairman of the Board of Higher Education of New York, said here tonight that college teachers should cease being "neutral, impassive, uncommitted and tentative about the basic tenets of living."

The Christian church today must sound a world-wide "call to penitence" for mankind's inclination to turn to selfish ends the great discoveries of science, the Most Rev. Cyril Forster Garbett, Archbishop of York, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, predicted today that 2,000,000 workers would be unemployed by Nov. 1 if the sixteen-day-old steel strike continued until then. Should the strike last to Dec. 1, he warned, industrial lay-offs would multiply at such a rate that "unemployment directly attributable to the strike will be approximately 5,000,000."

Describing the small neighborhood park or playground as of paramount importance to the health and welfare of the community, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, asserted yesterday that plans for expansion of the city's vast park system would continue to emphasize that type of recreational facility.

The Salvation Army was commended for its spiritual contributions to the cause of international peace and understanding by Benjamin A. Cohen, assistant secretary general of the United Nations, yesterday afternoon at Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street The attendance was 1,800.

It is estimated that every day in New York City about 300,000 persons are confined to their homes because of illness. Many of these persons are seriously ill; many need skilled assistance in applying the treatment that medical science has prescribed; and many cannot afford anything so expensive as private nursing.

GENEVA, Oct. 16 -- Gaston Eyskens, the Belgian Premier, said tonight that he had reached agreement with exiled King Leopold III on holding a plebiscite to determine whether the King would return to the throne.

The Union. of American Hebrew Congregations and the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion have named as one of the four national chairmen of their combined campaign Fred Lazarus Jr. of Cincinnati, president of the Federated Department Stores, it was announced yesterday.

"The Universe of G. B. S.," by William Irvine, will be published on Nov. 9 by Whittlesey House. A biography of Shaw, the volume relates his ideas and his writings to the events of his life. Shaw himself has commented on the book and these comments appear in the text. Mr. Irvine, author of three critical biographies, is Professor of Victorian Literature at Stanford University.

A solution to church problems could be found if men would give them as careful attention as they do their business problems, Clifford W. Petitt, executive director of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, declared yesterday at a Laymen's Sunday observance in the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

In an experience he won't want to repeat, 15-year-old Johnny IVurphy of 500 West 173d Street spent! four miserable hours yeserday in a sewage tunnel twenty feet'below the Harlem River Driveway at 178th Street and a few feet above the river.

Today marks the hundredth anniversary of the death of Frederic Chopin -- and in many parts of the world the multiform celebrations observed in his memory during the past year will reach their peak. Many recent biographies take up again the colorful story of Chopin the nationalist, Chopin the tragic lover, Chopin the romantic poet of the keyboard, who died at the age of 39.

Unseasonably warm weather and the steel and coal strikes were blamed for a considerable decline in activity in the wholesale garment market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

PITTSBURGH, Monday, Oct. 17 -- A strike against the Aluminum Company of America at nine of its plants, employing a total of 16,000 workers, took effect at 12:01 A. M. today, despite the last-minute efforts of a federal mediator to bring the company and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, into agreement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Disputes involving national defense and the welfare of the American farmer commanded the attention tonight of an adjournment-minded Congress planning to end this week a session of nine and one-half months.

The problem of providing "wise and generous" assistance to the "have-not" nations of the world is the greatest challenge this country has faced in the last century and a half, Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, said yesterday in a Laymen's Sunday sermon at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

Switzerland has stopped the issuance of import licenses for women's nylon hosiery in a move to cut down shipments from the United States, it was made known yesterday by New York exporters. The action, which was taken on Oct. 3, has caused much confusion among Swiss importers who as yet do not know what disposition will be made on existing orders.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- Eleven American scientists in varied fields of endeavor together with a Swedish physicist and a British metallurgist will be honored Wednesday at the annual Medal Day ceremonies of The Franklin Institute.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16 -- As one of twelve pictures to be put into production in the first five months of 1950, Paramount has announced that it would make "Union Station," with John Lund starring. Based on a magazine serial by Thomas Walsh titled "Manhattan Madness," which the studio bought in June, it will be produced by Jules Schirmer.

EAST QUOGUE, L. I., Oct. 16 -- Native Shore Pink Lady, fast moving Chesapeake Bay retriever owned and handled by George W. Carmany of Westhampton Beach, captured top honors in the amateur stake today as the fall field trials of the Long Island Retriever Club came to a close.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16 -- From the vantage point of Moscow, it appeared today that the two major questions regarding Germany -- withdrawal of the occupation forces and the signing of a peace treaty -- were rapidly rising to the forefront of the European political scene.

Joan Hammond, British soprano, made her debut with the New York City Opera Company last night at the City Center, singing the title role in Puccini's "Madame Butterfly." Since she is also slated to sing Tosca and Aida, it was her first of three important roles.

Luis Munoz Marin, Governor of Puerto Rico, urged yesterday that his fellow islanders now living in New York dissociate themselves from the mayoralty candidacy of Vito Marcantonio, lest they be falsely accused of favoring Mr. Marcantonio's political ideologies.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. ELDORADO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- An "enemy" submarine was reported sunk today soon after a ninety-six-ship fleet sailed from San Diego for maneuvers -- an invasion to recapture Hawaii from a mythical aggressor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Dignified officials of the Federal Reserve Board don't like to crow "I told you so." But just as they predicted last spring, the days of "a dollar down, and a dollar a week forever" installment buying are fast returning.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 16 -- The South African Government's suggestion that as a token of better relations and to pave the way for the success of the round-table conference in Durban in November both India and Pakistan should remove the ban they have imposed on imports from South Africa is likely to be accepted by the Pakistani Government.

The heavy registration up-state and on Long Island, where Senator Dulles must receive a large vote to offset the plurality in this city if he is to have a chance of election, was generally well distributed. As compared with the 1946 registration, it showed marked increases in Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse, Utica and Binghamton, where there are city elections.
SPARTANBURG, S. C., Oct. 16 -- Former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes said today he was considering running for Governor of South Carolina.

Just about everything that contributed to the comfort and elegance of eighteenth century life was shown yesterday at the opening of the New York Antiques Fair in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Miss Sarah Churchill, daughter of Winston Churchill, Britain's war-time Prime Minister, and Antony Beauchamp, a British society photographer, said today they would be married tomorrow.

FORT DIX, N. J., Oct. 17 -- Unification of the armed forces has been extended to the entertainment section, but the Navy seems to be holding out for better billing. A pioneer project in which soldiers, marines, Air Force personnel and Wacs are studying together to turn out revues has been under way here since the beginning of the week.

Active buying of European pig iron has been started by American foundries here to conserve remaining stocks of domestic metal in their inventories, purchasing agents revealed yesterday. The expanded buying is expected to increase rapidly because larger tonnages are being offered daily by venders, and devaluation of currencies abroad has made present prices attractive.

We have in hand one of those annual reports from the Commissioner of Parks, which carries us back through the years to January, 1934. Here is the record of a public servant, Robert Moses, who, with his building of parks, playgrounds, beaches, parkways, highways, bridges and tunnels, has brought wholesome enjoyment to many thousands of people.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 17 -- The brakes have been slammed down hard in Syria on the movement for unity with Iraq and the chronic conflict in the Arab world between the Hashemite dynasties and the anti-Hashemites has blazed up again over the eventual fate of the Arab part of Palestine.

The postman arrived, bringing offerings. He gave them up, one by one, not exactly opening them for postal inspection, but at the same time not remaining entirely uninterested. There were, of course, those bills which failed to participate in the shower of the first of the month but came as a set of tardy tears.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week dropped 20 per cent below the corresponding period last year -- the largest comparative weekly drop of the year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 13 per cent.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The top price paid for hogs here today was the lowest since Office of Price Administration ceilings were removed on Oct. 15, 1946.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 17 (AP) -- H. W. Leh's Mickey Dazzler whirled to his second consecutive score at Garden State Park in the featured Franklinville Purse today, hitting the tape three and one-half lengths in front of Bold Jo. In third place, just a nose away, was Larkmead Andy.

Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen reserved decision yesterday on a motion for a temporary injunction brought by Henry L. O'Brien, a landlord, to restrain the city from enforcing the new Sharkey Rent Law signed recently by Mayor O'Dwyer.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 17 -- Cavendish Welles Cannon, United States Ambassador to Belgrade, has been called home for reasons of poor health, it was reported tonight.
The text of the address by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru at a convocation held in his honor at Columbia University last night follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- United States imports from South America went up from $103,600,000 in July to $115,400,000 in August, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

Coffee futures continued to advance yesterday in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. All delivery positions, with the exception of December S contract, advanced the daily permissible limit of 150 points.

If Vladimir Horowitz ever has played with more nobility, penetration and self-effacing immersion in the music at hand than he did last night at the Hunter College Assembly Hall, this listener was not in the hall, and those who were, assisted at a memorable occasion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A registration statement covering $2,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due in 1979, and 20,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Missouri Power and Light Company.

Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, called last night for an end to the world armaments race and declared that peace could be achieved only by embracing the philosophy of the brotherhood of man.

More than five months ago the House of Representatives passed by a resounding vote a bill liberalizing the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 to permit a total of 339,000 victims of both wartime Nazi and post-war Communist oppression to seek a new life in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Supreme Court declined today to examine whether a lower tribunal was correct in upsetting the conviction of William Rosen, a witness in the Alger Hiss case, for refusing to answer questions on the ground of self-incrimination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Treasury announced that the tenders for $900,000,000, or thereabouts, of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated Oct. 20 and to mature on Jan. 19, which were offered on Oct. 14, were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today.

Clerical and lay representatives of religious faiths and Negro groups joined yesterday in a denunciation of prejudice as both "immoral" and "undemocratic" at a preview in Town Hall of the motion picture, "Prejudice." The film was produced under auspices of the Protestant Film Commission and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

The minority of sweepers and drivers of the city's Sanitation Department who voted themselves "sick" and did not work yesterday have already voted themselves well again. The strike of some 1,200 workers was short-lived, but illegal just the same. The men lose a day's pay, which, according to their own reckoning, they sadly need.

Sharply increased use of rayon and rayon-and-wool blended fabrics in boys' tailored clothing marked the opening here yesterday of lines for next spring. Participating were the fourteen members of the Tailored Youth Fashion Guild and other manufacturers here. Some lines were incomplete as yet.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Bed O'Roses carried Alfred Vanderbilt's silks to an easy three-length victory in the featured $3,500 Brilliant Blue Purse here today to become a favorite for Saturday's $25,000 added Selima Stakes.

We can all be grateful to the political parties which have offered us this year the choice between Herbert Lehman and John Foster Dulles as candidates to fill the unexpired term of Robert F. Wagner in the Senate. Here, certainly, are two men of unimpeachable integrity, high principles, broad outlook and deep devotion to the public interest, each eminently qualified to represent New York at Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today postponed until next year a list of nineteen new Federal Court nominations and three old ones which have met opposition. The decision was taken on the grounds that there is not time for the Senate to act on confirmation before Congress is due to adjourn this week.

Stimulated, perhaps, by its political success in the rural areas in the 1948 election, the Administration has demanded a new farm bill carrying the Democratic party stamp, and the Senate and House have responded with the two bills now temporarily or permanently blocked in conference.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17-- The State Department today rejected once more the protest of the Soviet Government that establishment of the West German Government violates the Potsdam agreement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today rejected John L. Lewis' proposal that nine AFL unions and the United Mine Workers of America, unaffiliated, together pour $2,500,000 a week into the treasury of the United Steelworkers, CIO, as strike aid.

After marked fluctuations at the end of last week, the money market eased yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 1/8 of 1 per cent compared with 1 per cent on Friday. Under pressure of a heavy outflow of funds to other areas, a Treasury call, and large purchases of a maturing bill issue, excess reserves of the banks here were cut from $110,000,000 on Wednesday night to a deficiency of $90,000,000 on Thursday.

IT was only last February that Arthur Koestler's "Insight and Outlook" was published. That monumental volume of psychological and philosophical theorizing would have left any other author limp and exhausted for years. But Mr. Koestler, as his many admirers know, is not an ordinary author. A powerful novelist, an honest, original and occasionally muddled thinker and an eloquent crusader, he has so much to say that he can never leave his typewriter for long.

VIENNA, Oct. 17 -- The American, British and Russian occupation powers were accused today by the Wiener Tageszeitung, chief organ of the People's party, of intervening in the recent Austrian general elections in the interest of the Austrian Socialists.

Thomas Petrillo has purchased the four-story building at 138 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, containing two stores and six apartments, from Marion D. McKiernan L. L. Yearsley was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin and Secretary of State Dean Acheson were reliably reported today to be in favor of an early review of the program of dismantling German industrial plants for reparations, their idea being to curtail dismantling and conclude it quickly. French agreement has not yet been obtained.
Even Santa Claus is beginning to feel the pinch of the steel strike.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned weak in the late trading yesterday. Prices at the close were 6 to 27 points net lower than on Saturday.

Columbia is due at West Point Saturday to play the Army. Columbia will show up. At least Lou Little, in his talk to the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday, promised that his young Lions will appear at Michie Stadium.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, announced yesterday that it had "gone beyond" the recommendations of President Truman's steel fact-finding board in a tentative agreement covering 12,000 employes of the Radio Corporation of America.

Three television networks yesterday signed a five-year contract with the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers for the blanket use of ASCAP music on their programs. The agreement, retroactive to last Jan. 1, was signed by the American, Columbia and National broadcasting companies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, has submitted his resignation to President Truman, it was learned today, and is packing his office effects in readiness to step out on Nov. 1.

ROME, Oct. 17 -- A change in the Communist attitude of active hostility toward the Marshall Plan was seen today in the friendly welcome received by James D. Zellerbach, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration Mission to Italy, from Communist Mayors in Emilia, during a two-day tour of that region.

GROUNDHOG SPRING, N. C., Oct. 17 -- Neither the historian nor the cartographer will grant recognition to Groundhog Spring, but the name is firmly imprinted in large, black-and-blue bruises scattered over the anatomy of your correspondent.

SHERBURNE PASS, Vt., Oct. 17 -- Snowless skiing was enjoyed on a large scale today at the Long Trail Lodge as State officials joined ski resort owners, lift operators, innkeepers and hotel proprietors in mapping an elaborate program for the 1949-50 season.

Calling a person by telephone in San Francisco from New York, or vice versa, was reduced to a mere matter of dialing, and a few seconds, yesterday afternoon at the formal opening of the Bell System's "toll-dialing" circuits between the two cities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The State Department has received "confirming" reports that Russia is carrying out a mass deportation of Greeks and other non-Russians from the Caucasus area, officials disclosed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 -- Carl F. Wente, retired senior vice president of the Bank of America, testified today that he never had received any instructions or even suggestions from the Transamerica Corporation. He appeared as a defense witness in the Federal Reserve Board's hearing of its complaint against Transamerica, which it charges with tending toward a monopoly in the commercial banking field in five Western states.

More than 15,000 delighted children poured into Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon shouting "Yippee!" "Yahoo!" and "Ride 'em cowboy!" They had come to a free performance of the twenty-fourth annual world's championship rodeo, and they let the world know it.

The underwriting of more than $2,700,000 of new public utility stock of enterprises situated in New England and the Middle West will be undertaken by banking syndicates today. The new issues embrace both common and preferred shares.

The Alcoa Steamship Company announced here yesterday that it would resume scheduled cargo service to the West Indies and South America from Norfolk, Va., on Oct. 29 with the sailing of the Alcoa Pegasus, a C-1 type ship. Subsequent sailings will be at three-week intervals.

Perhaps the outstanding fact of the 100th anniversary of Chopin's death, which was yesterday, is that last night, a century after this master passed away, more than 7,000 people, in three auditoria of the city, listened to three artists who interpreted his music.

The appeal of Mayor O'Dwyer and Commissioner Carney of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity for drastic conservation and economy in the use of water came with something of a shock to a New York public which had assumed that the severe shortages of the summer had been materially eased by early autumn rains.

A State Department's announcement that the sixty-day trial of the recently revised import licenses is designed to "clarify and improve" the situation of American trade with Morocco is being received with skepticism by business men affected, Robert Emmet Rodes, Commander of the Morocco Post of the American Legion, said here yesterday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- Lillian Hellman's play, "Another Part of the Forest," had a distinguished premiere at the Moscow Drama Theatre this week -- the first American drama to be produced this theatrical season.

Although Pennsylvania maintains a slight lead in the Ivy League football race, Cornell has assumed a marked statistical superiority over the rest of the eight-team group, according to figures released yesterday.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged last night that Mayor O'Dwyer was seeking to return to office "on the coat-tails" of Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Senator.

BUFFALO, Oct. 17 -- A special State Board of Inquiry Announced today settlement of the Bell Aircraft Corporation strike that had been shot through with violence since 1,700 production workers walked out on June 13.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 17 -- The United Nations will renew its drive on racial discrimination throughout its African and Pacific trust territories when the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee convenes tomorrow morning to approve a Brazilian resolution denouncing bias in areas under United Nations jurisdiction.

The appearance of Betty Field in Garson Kanin's new play, "The Rat Race," largely a matter of conjecture these past few days, was made definite yesterday with the announcement by Leland Hayward, producer of the project, that she would be starred in it.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (UP) -- A company that holds a franchise for "wired music" today filed a charge of Taft-Hartley Act violations with the National Labor Relations Board against James C. Petrillo, president of the American and the Chicago Federation of Musicians.

The top team in the All-America Football Conference, the San Francisco Forty-Niners, will arrive in town Thursday night and be quartered at Bear Mountain Inn until it is time to move to the Yankee Stadium for Sunday's contest with the Brooklyn-New York combination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A collection of art treasures selected from a Vienna museum, including a large Vermeer canvas depicting "Fame," once fancied and acquired by Adolf Hitler, is on the way to this country for an extended showing.

GENEVA, Oct. 17 -- The shelving by the United States Senate of the revised bill governing the admission of displaced persons to the United States virtually guarantees that Congress will be asked for an additional $25,000,000 next year for refugee care and resettlement. This opinion was expressed by high United States officials here.

Half the nation's youngsters drop out of school before completing their high school education, it was reported yesterday at the opening session of the thirty-fifth annual convention of the National League to Promote School Attendance. Speakers at the convention, which is being held at the New Yorker Hotel, termed the high rate of drop-outs "a waste of human resources" and urged the adoption of a mental hygiene approach to curb truancy and nonattendance.
LINDEN, N. J., Oct. 17 -- The world's largest, fluid catalytic cracking unit was dedicated here today at the Bayway Refinery of the Esso Standard Oil Company as part of Oil Progress Week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that the 1949 Federal Rent Control Act is unconstitutional.

ATHENS, Oct. 17 -- Yesterday's broadcast by the "Free Greece" radio announcing that the rebel forces had stopped fighting was minimized here today as one more Communist stunt, cunningly designed to influence the United Nations representatives in their consideration of the Greek question.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 -- De Declaring that the economic security which is being attempted by various Government controls is overstepping the needs of the situation, the nation's baking industry today voiced its opposition to Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan's plan and other similar farm subsidy schemes.

The worst set-back in a month was sustained yesterday by the stock market as profit taking, induced by fresh complications in the labor picture, reduced prices as much as 3 points. Attempts to steady the list were feeble and only the radio and television issues, as a group, managed to hold their ground.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Uncertainty concerning the outcome of the conference between the House and the Senate over the farm-price-support bill resulted in limited trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade here today. Professional operations produced erratic price movements at times, with the close on wheat about at the bottom, with losses of 7/8 to 1 1/8 cents. Corn lost 1/8 to 3/4 cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- President Truman named Mrs. Burnita Shelton Matthews today to be a Federal district judge for the District of Columbia and soon afterward Mrs. Matthews fractured her left arm in a fall on the steps of St. Matthew's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Marines established a beachhead in the House Armed Services Committee room today, and after an assault landing by Gen. Clifton B. Cates, Marine Corps Commandant, asserted that deliberate attempts were being made to circumvent the unification law and to emasculate the Corps.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 17 -- The disputed princely state of Jammu and Kashmir was specifically exempted by the Constituent Assembly today from articles in the Indian Constitution that put other states on a par with the present provinces.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 17 -- The tenuous cease-fire arrangement in Indonesia was reported by Dutch Government circles today to be wearing "very thin" and considerable concern was expressed over the week-end statements from Republican leaders in Indonesia that an armed clash in East Java appeared inevitable.

Because a "reasonable doubt" existed, a pilot whose passenger parachuted from an airplane over midtown Manhattan last August was freed yesterday in Municipal Term Court of a charge of operating an airplane in a manner endangering life and property.

Christmas is not as far away as you might think. The annual display of new toys sponsored by the American Toy Institute at 200 Fifth Avenue opened yesterday with a wealth of playthings for the 1949 Christmas season.

Bethany Day Nursery at 402 East Sixty-seventh Street will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Browning Version," with Maurice Evans and Edna Best, on the night of Nov. 9 at the Coronet Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The defense high command was accused today by the Marine Commandant, Gen. Clifton B. Cates, of seeking to "destroy" the corps and tending to undermine the power of Congress over national defense.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 17 -- A United Jewish Appeal delegation arrived here today to investigate the immediate needs of immigrants who are not being adequately absorbed. It has come to determine what methods are necessary to relieve the plight of more than 80,000 persons still living in tents and huts.

Add to the list of films arriving on Broadway this week, "Miracle in Harlem," a melodrama with music, which will open at the Gotham on Saturday. Jack Kemp directed and Jack Goldberg produced the Herald Pictures production. Sheila Guyse, Stepin Fetchit, Juanita Hall and Savanah Churchill head the all-Negro cast.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The State Department is considering relieving Ambassador Cannon because of ill health, it was stated today.
Strong opposition to any move legalizing wine sales in groceries was voiced yesterday by members of the Metropolitan Package Goods Stores Association at a meeting in the Park Sheraton Hotel.

The majority of knit underwear manufacturers have opened their spring lines with prices fractionally lower than those of a year ago. Early orders from wholesalers have been good, manufacturers reported yesterday, on such items as athletic shirts, knitted shorts, T-shirts and polo shirts.

The prosecution and conviction of the eleven Communist leaders will be protested before the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, and Attorney General J. Howard McGrath will be asked not to use the case "as a precedent in the arrest or prosecution of other persons until the issues in the case have been finally determined by the highest authority in the land."
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The American Gas Association heard today that 8,500 miles of pipeline were being added to the existing 251,000 miles to carry natural gas.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Premier Jules Moch, Socialist, abandoned tonight his attempts to form a Government. President Vincent Auriol must now choose another candidate for Premier, who must first seek the National Assembly's endorsement and then try to form a Ministry.

ROME, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Senator John Foster Dulles in a state-wide broadcast tonight accused former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic-Liberal rival in the Senatorial race, of trying to give socialized medicine a new label.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, left here tonight for Chicago to continue his personal reports to his membership on the union's fight for noncontributory pension and social insurance funds.

The recovery of 250,000 volumes of Judaica and 10,000 ceremonial objects in Germany, representing part of the Nazi loot from Jewish libraries, synagogues and museums in Europe, and their shipment out of that country last year, was announced by Prof. Salo W. Baron of Columbia University, president of Jewish Cultural Reconstruction, Inc., at its annual meeting last night at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- Emphasizing the improved living standards in the Western sectors of Berlin since the raising of the Soviet blockade last May, in comparison with the high prices at the special Soviet-licensed non-rationed shops in the Eastern sector, the French-licensed newspaper. The Kurier, today published comparative tables for identical items obtainable in both zones.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Seven of the country's largest motion picture producing and distributing companies were sued today for $1,800,000 under Federal anti-trust laws.

Public School 133 at 130th Street and Fifth Avenue, the first school to be completed in Manhattan under the Board of Education's post-war buuilding program, was dedicated yesterday. Four hundred persons, including members of the family of the late Fred R. Moore, for whom the school was named, were present in the school auditorium.
Frank Parker signed a professional tennis contract with promoter Bobby Riggs yesterday, formally abandoning the amateur game in which he has been a standout performer since he was 15 years old.

The United Nations General Assembly will tackle within the coming days or weeks a problem giving it a great opportunity for statesmanship or the chance to make a serious mistake, in connection with the proposal of the Assembly's Palestine Conciliation Commission to internationalize -- to take "full and permanent authority" over -- Jerusalem.

Let all petulant words fly away from this column this morning. For Mr. Chartock's band of Gilbert and Sullivan singers has put on a very enjoyable performance of 'H. M. S. Pinafore," which opened at the Mark Hellinger Theatre last evening. After a week with "The Mikado" and another with "The Pirates of Penzance," they have shaken down into a pleasing troupe of light-opera singers with a particular knack for the music.

The Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry is seeking between 50,000 to 60,000 bales of American cotton under a new procurement program, it was announced here yesterday by the Foreign Trade Office in New York of the Supreme Command for the Allied Powers.

The deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers negotiating a state treaty for Austria reached substantial agreement yesterday on two more articles and sounded a new note of optimism that the talks, which first opened early in 1946, soon may arrive at a satisfactory conclusion.
A new salon on the second floor of Bergdorf Goodman was opened yesterday afternoon to introduce its new line of Delman shoes, called Delmanettes.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- The Rev. Dr. Harold E. Nicely, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church in Rochester since 1938, was elected moderator of the Presbyterian synod of New York tonight at the opening business session of the group's sixty-seventh annual meeting.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) have voted the regular quarterly cash dividend of 50 cents a share plus a share of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for each 100 shares of Indiana Standard held, both payable to common stockholders, on Dec. 12.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 17 -- German authorities, it is understood, have uncovered documents incriminating Ilse Koch, widow of the executed commandant of the Buchenwald concentration camp, in the murders for which she was arrested after her release today from a United States military prison.

ALBANY, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey accused former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman today of "running out" on the proposed debate with John Foster Dulles over issues in the Senatorial campaign in which Mr. Lehman and Mr. Dulles are opponents.

Cosmetic and toiletries ads generally are beginning to show first evidences of "de-glamorization," trade sources reported yesterday. Greater emphasis on selling all varieties of toiletries -- particularly perfumes and fragrances hitherto represented as special occasion luxuries -- is a reversal of long established tradition, it was noted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Final Government mediation conferences to end the soft coal strike are expected by Friday. This second series of mediation sessions is expected to fail. White House intervention is looked for over the week-end or soon after.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A Federal District Judge has upheld the right of the Government to limit the tuition that may be charged to war veterans studying under the so-called "G. I. bill."
LONDON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Communist-led Korean People's Republic [Northern Korea] has threatened to reunite Korea "by its own forces," the Moscow radio reported today.

An audience of 1,500 filled Town Hall last night to hear Frank Sheridan lay his particular laurel at the feet of Chopin. The pianist's tribute took the form of his most wonderful playing in which he gave the fruits of a liftime's devotion to music, to the piano and to the composer who wrote so marvelously for his chosen instrument.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Oct. 18 -- Chinese Communists captured the big southeast port of Amoy on Monday after a month-long fight and clinched their hold on almost the entire 2,000-mile coastline from Korea to Hong Kong.

Herbert H. Lehman, the Democratic-Liberal party nominee for United States Senator, reiterated yesterday in stronger terms than before his charge that Senator John Foster Dulles, his Republican opponent, was conducting a campaign based on bigotry.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- The major elements in a broad propagandistic campaign to subordinate the Western sectors of Berlin and blanket them in under the authority of the new Soviet-sponsored German Democratic Republic were outlined tonight.

With Notre Dame idle, Army a heavy favorite over Columbia at West Point and Oklahoma journeying to twice-beaten Nebraska, Cornell, Minnesota, Kentucky, North Carolina and Texas face the ruggedest opposition this week among the national leaders.

NOROTON, Conn., Oct. 17 -- It is not fair of human beings to refer to "a dog's life" or to use the expression "it shouldn't happen to a dog" to describe the ultimate in unhappiness, Clarence E. Harbison, pioneer dog psychologist, declared today. That is, he added, unless they also will admit that they are responsible for making dogs feel that low.

The Interprovincial Pipe Line Company, a Canadian crude oil transportation concern backed by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, announced yesterday that it had arranged to borrow $35,000,000 from institutional investors on 3 1/2 per cent first-mortgage and collateral-trust bonds to help to finance construction of a 1,150-mile pipeline intended to carry crude oil from Alberta, Canada, to Superior, Wis. The First Boston Corporation was agent for the company.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Britain has assured the United States and other Western powers that she is not proposing at this time to grant even "de facto" recognition to the Chinese Communist regime.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Full-time appointments and group-practice for the clinical faculty of medical schools, similar to the current successful arrangements in private clinics, were described here tonight at the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons as "the most promising way of gradually placing education in clinical medicine on a level that most nearly approximates the education conducted by full-time members of other university departments."

Angela Calomiris, a professional photographer who testified in the New York trial of eleven American Communists, is at work on a book dealing with her seven years as an undercover agent for the "Subversive Squad" of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Pacific Mills, in its report yesterday for the nine months ended on Oct. 1, estimated the net profit at $2,276,000 after all deductions. This is equal to $2.49 a share, and compares with $7,818,000, or $8.53 a share, earned in the nine months to Oct. 2, 1948.
