LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 17 -- The General Assembly's Social Committee today defeated a longstanding effort by Poland to have the United Nations censure "certain" Western countries for alleged exploiting of immigrant labor.

Marabout, running in the colors of George D. Widener, won the Sand Marsh, the $4,500 event that topped the racing bill at the Jamaica track yesterday. Opposing four others in the mile and a sixteenth run, the 3-year-old son of Mahmoud scored by a half length over the favored Rare Mineral, owned by E. A. Stone.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- It is generally recognized in Western Europe and the Eastern Mediterranean that United States foreign policy has registered definite success vis-a-vis Soviet expansionism during the period of post-war readjustment.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 17 -- David S. Fischman of New York City, today demanded an accounting from Royal Little, president of Textron Incorporated, in a stockholders' suit filed here in United States District Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Truman vetoed today a bill providing for a ten-year program for rehabilitating the Navajo and Hopi Indian tribes on the ground that Congress had formulated it in a way that would do far more harm than good.

Pretty enough to turn many a woman's head, and created for the theatre and dining-out, the holiday millinery collection of Lenesta, viewed yesterday at 15 East Fifty-third Street, was given over to small shapes of lace, net and feather-trimmed hatter's plush.

There are 157 hospitals with 31,010 beds serving the people of New York. Of these eighty-six are voluntary, non-profit hospitals that are members of the United Hospital Fund and have a total of 21,186 beds. The cost of operating the eighty-six voluntary hospital in 1948 reached a total of $103,682,111.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 17 -- Unanimously and without abstentions, the United Nations Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee adopted today a resolution pressing the Economic and Social Council for action on the economic development of underdeveloped countries.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17 -- Sol Lesser is retiring as president of Thalia Productions and is being succeeded by his son, Julian, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The United States Supreme Court cleared the way today for the Securities and Exchange Commission to schedule hearings to determine whether the broker-dealer registration of Otis Co., Cleveland, investment banking concern, should be suspended or revoked.

Although the tools and materials for building a better world exist, we have yet "to master the know-how of working together to erect the indestructible edifice of peace, freedom and prosperity," Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States and President of the United Nations General Assembly, said yesterday.

Buyers sought special values at the Shoe Manufacturers Spring Opening yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel. Although retailers in areas affected by the strikes were disposed t be cautious, some good-size orders were placed, according to Eugene A. Richardson director of the show.

Unit sales of Gibson Refrigerator Corporation's appliances this year exceeded 1948 and established a new company record, J. L. Johnson, sales manager, revealed yesterday in an address before the organization's Eastern distributors during introduction of 1950 refrigerator, freezer and electric range lines in the Park Sheraton Hotel. The company's fiscal year ends on Sept. 30.

The last Metropolitan P. G. A. tournament to be played over the famous Pomonok Country Club course in Flushing was a pro-amateur one-day event which brought out a large field of fifty-seven teams yesterday. Twenty-two duos failed to turn in scores.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Truman today assured the new Minister representing Hungary here that the United States would cooperate "in all constructive efforts" to improve relationships between the two countries.

The Pacific Far East Line has applied to the Maritime Commission for an operating differential subsidy covering the transpacific trade route designated as 29-F, according to an announcement by the company. This route covers the California ports of Los Angeles and San Francisco and ports in Japan, China, Hong Kong, the Philippine Islands, French Indo-China and Siam, with the additional privilege of calling at other ports of origin or destination.
Twelve hundred of the city's 10,000 Sanitation Department street sweepers and truck drivers reported "sick" yesterday and skipped the regular refuse collection shift that starts at 7 A. M.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- With Parliament reconvening tomorrow the Cabinet's Economic Committee still struggled today trying to devise economies and measures to meet Britain's dollar crisis and find a formula for avoiding domestic inflation without seriously disturbing Socialist policy.

The results of balloting by 60,000 Atlantic Coast longshoremen on the improved offer made by the employing stevedores probably will be known Friday evening, Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, said yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 17 (AP) -- It took Johnny Mize twenty years to land with a world championship team, but the big Georgia-born slugger will tell you it was worth it.

LEGAL larceny can sometimes be even more distressing than the illegal kind. Stout Steve Owen was wearing the pained look yesterday of a man who just has had his pocket picked. His Giants had had the Pitttsburgh Steelers on the hook and the Steelers -- the preferred spelling now is "Stealers" -- stole the ball from Joe Scott for the touchdown which turned the game topsy-turvy.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- Harry E. Humphreys Jr., president of the United States Rubber Company, today received the "Pennsylvanian of the Year's Award of the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce.

LYNN, Mass., Oct. 17 -- Albert J. Fitzgerald, president of the United Electrical Workers, CIO, and three other members of the Lynn local were found guilty today of "conduct detrimental to the welfare" of the union, it was reliably reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission today disclosed terms of a proposed agreement to complete reconversion of the Mariposa, former queen of the Pacific merchant fleet.

VIENNA, Oct. 17 -- When 500 Russian soldiers swarmed from the stands to the field on which a Hungarian football team had defeated Austria's best eleven yesterday and bore the Hungarians to their dressing room, they foiled a plan by three members of the team to escape into the crowd, according to reports here today.

While many of the provisions for war veterans are "payment for a job well done," the educational and vocational rehabilitation program is a sound investment in the future, Maj. Gen. Carl R. Gray Jr., administrator of Veterans Affairs, said yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 17 -- Herbert G. Holran, executive director of the Republican State Committee, said here today that Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was not quoted correctly concerning his views on bingo in a pamphlet being distributed throughout the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark.

The American Labor party's endorsement of Edmund H. H. Caddy, Republican candidate for District Attorney of Kings County, was invalidated yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Anthony J. Di Giovana in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -The Senate passed today six bills authorizing issuance of additional revenue bonds in Hawaii.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The United States and Colombia, by "mutual consent," will end their fourteen-year-old tariff agreement, the State Department announced today.

Martin T. Lacey, president of the Central Trades and Labor Council, AFL, and Michael J. Quill, president of the New York City CIO Council, delivered radio talks last night in behalf of Mayor O'Dwyer and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman.

A bit of Sweden was stuffed into a single huge wooden carton, as large as a bungalow and weighing 8,000 pounds, and sent from Stockholm to New York a month ago. The contents have now been unpacked and arranged into an exhibit, "The A B C of Sweden," which opened last night in the Art Gallery of the Fort Hamilton High School, Shore Road and Eighty-third Street, Brooklyn.

An experiment is starting in two Ithaca, N. Y., groceries in which many homemakers will wish they might take part. Potatoes are being offered in packages that tell not only the grade (U. S. No. 1), but for what role they are best suited -- baking, boiling, frying.

The reputed leader of a $5,000,000 cocaine smuggling ring was convicted yesterday by a Federal Court jury of narcotic charges. A co-defendant was acquitted by the jury, which deliberated an hour and twenty minutes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The first session of the Eighty-first Congress, with leaders planning for adjournment Thursday evening, broke through some deadlocks with agreements today but remained bogged down in others.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Leopold III, exiled King of the Belgians, declared today that Great Britain's decision in 1940 to abandon the fight against Germany on the Continent and to evacuate the British Army from Dunkerque was taken "without the slightest knowledge of the Belgian command."

Charging that graft was prevalent in some city departments, Oren Root, Republican-Fusion candidate for Manhattan borough president, used a complaining disabled war veteran and his wife, a recording machine and a formal statement yesterday in an attempt to prove his case.
CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- New York Military Academy's big football team today got down to the task of whipping into shape for its all-important battle with Cheshire Academy on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Truman today directed the preparation of legislative measures designed to increase shipbuilding subsidies for American yards which soon will begin to feel the adverse effects of devaluation of Great Britain's pound sterling.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate, began his upstate campaign for United States Senator today with accusations that the Republican "Old Guard" had falsified his stand on social legislation, the Brannan farm price support program and the votes of Communists.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 -- The Union Oil Company of California announced today that it had bought the Los Nietos Company, representing the principal oil interests of the five grandchildren of the late Edward L. Doheny, oil capitalist.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Directors of the New York State Nurses Association asked the membership today to oppose compulsory health insurance.
TEXAS CITY, Tex., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Paul H. Griffith, Assistant Secretary of Defense, declared today that outspoken critics of unification "have done material damage to the cause of national defense."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 17 -- A three-week effort to bring about a settlement of differences between Greece and Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia apparently broke down tonight, and the Balkan question will be resubmitted tomorrow to the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 17 -- Settlement by Saturday of the Missouri Pacific Railroad strike, now in its fortieth day, appeared likely tonight. It was learned that the four striking brotherhoods had ordered inspectors back to work Wednesday as union and railroad negotiators reached the last four or five of 282 claims that caused the walkout on Sept. 9.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 17. -- The Political and Security Subcommittee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today a new United States proposal calling for the independence of Italian Somaliland in 1959, unless the Assembly decided otherwise at that time. The vote was 15 to 3, with the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Poland against, and France, India and Pakistan abstaining.

The dispute between the National Maritime Union, CIO, and American Export Lines regarding a war bonus clause was deadlocked yesterday and the freighter Exchequer, scheduled to sail last Wednesday for India, was still held at her Jersey City, N. J., pier.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Oct. l7 -- A New York mother and her two small sons perished with two other persons today when their four-passenger plane crashed into the sea six miles off Provincetown on a chartered flight from Boston.
The espionage conspiracy trial of Judith Coplon, former Department of Justice employe, and Valentin A. Gubitchev, Soviet engineer, was set yesterday by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell for Nov. 9.

On Oct. 9 I was one of several hundred motorists trapped in the Bronx for about one hour. Cars were lined up bumper to bumper; without, the weather was Indian summer, and within the cars infants raised their voices in vain protest and drivers gave vent to their utter exasperation, by setting up a cacophony of horn-honking.
SHANNON AIRPORT, Ireland, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The stork won and a four-and-a-half-pound American was born today in an airliner 19,000 feet up and 400 miles out over the Atlantic.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 17 -- A member of the President's Commission on Higher Education asserted today that hundreds of small colleges operating "on a shoe string," should close their doors as an essential step in saving "the best of our American colleges and universities."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The system by which at least one-third of the seats in the United States Senate are in contest every two years has given, now to the Democrats and now to the Republicans, an advantage in the struggle for majority control. In 1948 the locations of these seats and the strength of the incumbents -- always wholly fortuitous circumstances -- benefited the Democrats and they overturned the Republican majority.
Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, announced last night that he would support an amended Barden bill that would extend Federal aid to education.
The New York County Lawyers Association began an investigation yesterday to see whether disbarment-proceedings should be started against defense counsel in the recent Communist trial.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Remember the guy who ran the wrong way in the Rose Bowl?

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Uncertainty over what measures the Government will take to supplement its devaluation of the pound had a depressing effect on stock market dealings today and prices fell in most sections, particularly among the industrials.

Mayor O'Dwyer, starting a scheduled three weeks of solid campaigning with a radio speech last night over Station WJZ, challenged Newbold Morris to stop "pretending" to be neutral in the contest for United States Senator.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Bucky Harris and Clark Griffith will meet tomorrow or Wednesday to discuss the managership vacancy of the Washington Senators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced loans today of $2,700,000 to Yugoslavia and $2,300,000 to Finland to finance a timbering equipment project sponsored by the United Nations for those countries and to held revive the East-West trade in Europe.

HONG KONG, Oct. 17 -- The Chinese Navy today applied the blockade to Communist-held Canton. Nationalist warships, firing warning machine-gun bursts, halted a small Chinese steamer bound from Hong Kong to Canton and forced the vessel to return here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The three Communists whom Judge Harold R. Medina sent to jail for contempt of court during the recent trial in New York were refused a review of their appeals by the Supreme Court today. Justice Hugo L. Black favored hearing the appeal.

YOKOSUKA, Japan, Oct. 18 -- Russian sailors hid their faces from American cameramen and a Soviet captain overruled a united States Rear Admiral today as nine destroyer escorts given to the Soviet Union under lend-lease in 1945 were returned to the American flag at the naval base here in an atmosphere of Iron Curtain comedy.

Cassandras, who had been hinting that Mayor O'Dwyer's ten-man theatre committee, of which James E. Sauter, Deputy Commissioner of Commerce, is chairman, would conveniently drop out of existence after its first and only weekly meeting on Sept. 16, are hereby advised to be more circumspect.

Ralph Hollander is one of those unfortunately rare performers who depends solely on his musicianship to put across the message of the composer. Last night at Town Hall he played his violin without any misleading histrionics and still managed to make good music.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-City-Fusion candidate for Mayor, made public yesterday a list of 124 places in Brooklyn, where, he charged, horse bets coudl be placed. He declared they were so open that "the Mayor and the Police Department must know about them."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Henry Frederick White, former New York textile manufacturer, was found dead today in a parkway here, a few hours before he was due to appear in bankruptcy court, according to the police.

Not only are many of this city's school buildings "abominable" but the schools themselves are not equipped in a psychological sense to help adolescents with emotional problems, Dr. Morris Meister, principal of the Bronx High School of Science, said yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Rene Mayer, Radical party Minister of Finance under Robert Schuman, was commissioned today to form a new French Cabinet. He promised to answer whether he would make the attempt after consulting the political groups tomorrow.

KEARNY, N. J., Oct. 18 -- On a pleasant piece of rising ground at South Midland and Passaic Avenues here stands an attractive, Brand new white six-room house. It's "Mr. Kroll's Dream House," but it's also one of a growing number of monuments to an idea.

At least 25 per cent of the sums spent for research by industry in the United States each year comes from the petroleum industry, Frank W. Abrams, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) told more than 1,400 community leaders and oil men yesterday.

There was fire in Steve Owen's eyes when he assembled his New York Football Giants in the Polo Grounds dressing room yesterday morning. The normally mild-mannered mentor was ready to give his charges a severe tongue - lashing for their loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers last Sunday, mindful of its effect on next Sunday's meeting here with the Chicago Bears.

A system to handle the departmental trials of 1,206 Sanitation employes who reported "sick" Monday will be set up, "possibly within ten days," William J. Powell, Sanitation Commissioner, said yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer inherited yesterday the problems associated with the statue of the Argentine hero, Gen. Jose de San Martin, and the Park Department has left the bronze art work in a warehouse for the time being.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the agency would "start from scratch" in hearings to determine whether to suspend or revoke the broker-dealer registration of Otis Co.; Cleveland investment banking concern.

A system of "youth justice" to deal with criminals between 17 and 21 years old, was urged yesterday by Austin H. MacCormick, executive director of the Osborne Association and former New York City Commissioner of Correction.

Gottlieb Hammer, executive director of the American section of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, assailed yesterday Jewish sources, which he refused to name, for giving out statements that resulted in "pessimism and defeatism" in newspaper stories about Israel.

The conviction of the eleven Communist leaders here last week underlines the importance of the vital distinction between advocacy of radical or unpopular ideas and conspiring to use force to put them into effect. It is of the very essence of the American democratic system that there be freedom of thought and discussion, limited only by the overriding necessity of preservation of law and of the orderly processes of government.
Notre Dame, the leader, will be idle this week-end, but other members of college football's "first ten" face rugged foes who should give the rankings another vigorous shuffle.
Mr. and Mrs. Rufus W. Scott of Southscott, Palm Beach, and of Locust Valley, L. I., are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Selection of a grand jury -- six men and six women -- was completed today in the Federal Government's second attempt to convict Preston Tucker, president of the ill-fated automobile company bearing his name, and seven other former Tucker Corporation officials of mail fraud and conspiracy.

Borba, official organ of Marshal Tito and the Yugoslav Communist party, asserts that the offer to compromise on the Greek issue was of particular importance to the Soviet Government because of the growing sympathy with Yugoslavia in the world and the necessity of preventing the Yugoslavs from obtaining a hearing "at the great forum of the United Nations."

Aboard the New York State Freedom Train when it pulls into Grand Central tomorrow morning for a ten-day stay here, will be documents basic in the history of American individual liberty and popular government.

GENEVA, Oct. 18 -- The United States Government announced today it was prepared to ask Congress for funds to support extension of the International Refugee Organization beyond the previously fixed liquidation date of June 30, 1950.

The West Side Association of Commerce, which promotes and protects the interests of the West Side of Manhattan from the Battery to Fifty-ninth Street, is now rounding out its first quarter century. In view of the staggering resources of this area, in business, industry and transport, as well as its large resident population, the association with its more than a thousand members can hardly be compressed into the usual category of neighborhood organizations.

Commissioner of Welfare Raymond M. Hilliard paid tribute last night to the leadership in child care that has been given in the past fifty years by the Catholic Home Bureau of New York Catholic Charities.

Of the 1,700,000 students who entered high school this fall, only half will remain to graduate four years from now, according to an estimate of the National Child Labor Committee. This agency has made a sampling of 1,360 young people in five communities to determine the underlying causes for early school leaving.

Dr. Philipp Auerbach, chairman of an indemnification committee in Western Germany, arrived here yesterday to help expedite claims of damages for 10,000 to 12,000 former inmates of Nazi concentration camps who now live in the United States and Canada.

Richfield Homes, Inc., Benjamin Gallinson, president, purchased sixty acres in Paramus, N. J., for improvement with medium and higher-priced homes there, it was announced yesterday by Harold Nixon, Inc., broker, who assembled the property.

HONG KONG, Oct. 18 -- Relations between Britons and the Chinese Communists were amicable along the Hong Kong frontier today as new Communist troop units arrived to take over border points from local Communist guerrillas.
BUFFALO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The public health section of the New York State Nurses Association recommended today a scale of salaries to be used by public health nurses in collective bargaining.

The electric utility industry, which has increased its sales of power three and one-third times in the last twenty years, is anxious to continue its growth at the same pace in the next two to three decades if the nation's "economic climate" permits, Elmer L. Lindseth, president of the Edison Electric Institute, declared here yesterday.
The angular silhouette characterized many of Laddie Northridge's smart, wearable hats that were shown yesterday at luncheon at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 -- A proposal that the Federal Government sell blanket health insurance policies to the public on a voluntary basis was offered tonight by Senator Lester C. Hunt, Democrat, of Wyoming, at the annual convention of the American Dental Association.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- It is no longer a military secret that Army has a great football team this year.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18 -- The Big Five have agreed to try to cut down use of the veto by getting together in private consultation before important controversies come to a vote in the United Nations Security Council, it was officially announced here today.
Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman declared yesterday that without an adjustment of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation's franchise, and a higher fare the future of the corporation was "not bright."
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Is the magic gone from Michigan's once-bewildering football attack?

SYRACUSE, Oct. 18 -- The Presbyterian Synod of New York called on every congregation in the state today to sponsor at least one family of displaced persons. The Synod in annual convention represents twenty presbyteries covering the entire state.

Associate Justice William O. Douglas has turned over to Harper the manuscript of a book of memoirs to be called "Men and Mountains." The manuscript, which he finished while recovering from several broken ribs suffered when a horse fell on him, deals with his youth and his life hunting and fishing among mountain people while recovering from infantile paralysis.

Ninety years old tomorrow, Dr. John Dewey, world-renowned educator and philosopher, is disturbed at all the "fuss and bother" being made about his birthday. He had hoped for "just another day," in which he could join his wife and two young adopted children for a walk in the park or sit quietly with them at a family dinner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Senator Brien McMahon, chairman of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, announced today that President Truman had authorized the Atomic Energy Commission to dip into its budgetary reserve for funds to begin a "major expansion" of its production program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Disappointed over reports that no progress had been made by coal operators and miners today in their effort to end the soft coal strike, the Government pressed plans for early and final mediation efforts.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18 -- Some less - developed countries voiced fears today in the course of a discussion of commercial policy by the United Nations Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee that steps taken toward multilateral trading might retard their economic development.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Congress today enacted the 75-cents-an-hour minimum wage bill and sent it to President Truman. His early signature is expected, possibly by tomorrow.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 18 -- A nation-wide canine immunization program calling for annual anti-rabies vaccination of all dogs was recommended today at a conference of state health departments and the United States Public Health Service's Communicable Disease Center.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 -- Betty Grable, who has been holding out against appearing in "My Blue Heaven" at Twentieth Century-Fox today agreed to accept her assignment to it, according to a statement by the studio, but not until she had won certain concessions.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18 -- Yugoslavia broke today with the Soviet Union's violent propaganda campaign against "imperialistic" powers responsible for governing dependent colonial peoples in Africa and Asia.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Marshal Tito has invited the world's liberals, progressives -- and even conservatives -- to come and see Yugoslavia's struggle against the Kremlin, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The first session of the Eighty-first Congress had appropriated by tonight some $4,943,000,000 more than the direct money outlays approved by the closing session of the Eightieth.
Robert Lauter has been named merchandise manager of Macy's-Parkchester to assist David E. Duncan, store manager, effective Nov. 1. He is now manager of the small domestic rugs department at Macy's.

A proposed local law granting partial tax exemptions to property owners who rehabilitate old tenements to provide additional housing was adopted unanimously yesterday by the City Council and now goes to the Board of Estimate for final action.

New issues of public utility bonds and preferred stock and railroad equipment trust certificates having an aggregate principal value of $21,950,000 were sold at competitive bidding to banking syndicates yesterday as follows:

The history of the city's hospitals, shown by means of nine dioramas, will be exhibited today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. A cooperative venture of the museum and the United Hospital Fund, which opened its $3,300,000 drive on Oct. 10, the exhibit was shown in a preview yesterday to members and officers of the institution and the fund.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Two improved types of "artificial hearts," used so far in animal experiments to provide circulation of the blood during surgery to repair heart damage, were described here today at the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

The over-all tendency resulting from devaluation is toward lower export prices, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer, the National Association of Purchasing Agents, declared last night. He addressed more than 250 members of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at the monthly meeting at the Builders' Exchange Club.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 -- As of tonight, according to reports by ADN, Soviet news agency, four satellite states have followed the Kremlin's move in officially notifying the Eastern German Government that they would exchange diplomatic representatives.

A series of storms lashed at North Atlantic shipping yesterday from the British Isles to the United States, delaying luxury liners and Army transports up to twenty-four hours and hampering efforts to aid a freighter in distress off the New Jersey coast.

BEAR WALLOW GAP, N. C., Oct. 18 -- You may not be able to locate Bear Wallow Gap on the small-scale map of this state, but do not be discouraged, for without the assistance of one of the local bear hunters and at least two Plott hounds, we could not relocate the place itself.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The stock markets here marked time today waiting for Prime Minister Attlee's statement on the Government's crisis measures. As it was also the day for closing books on the current account, there was no incentive for buyers and prices, with the exception of those of South African gold mining issues, continued to decline.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Yale football team lost two of its regulars, fullback Ferd Nadherny and guard Vic Frank, because of illness and injury today.

Prices of coffee futures declined sharply in one contract in the course of yesterday's trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Contract S closes 10 to 39 points below Monday's levels and the D contract quotations were unchanged to 10 points higher.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the General Assembly, announced today the failure of efforts by a United Nations Conciliation Committee to bring about a settlement of differences between Greece and Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson will reject tomorrow the allegation by Soviet Foreign Minister Vishinsky that the United States violates a "gentleman's agreement" by supporting Yugoslavia for membership in the United Nations Security Council.

PAWLING, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Trinity-Pawling School's smartly drilled football team, undefeated in three starts, must guard against over-confidence if it is to continue its strong showings on the gridiron this season.

The jury's verdict in the case of the Communists is one more triumph of the well-defined and time-honored principle of our Anglo-American law. That is, briefly and in lay language, there is no such thing as absolute freedom of speech, of action, even of worship, in a democratic society.

HARTFORD, Conn, Oct. 18 -- The civil complaint brought by the Federal Government against the Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company was, Attorney General J. Howard McGrath announced tonight, part of a planned anti-trust program to attack restraints of trade that may ultimately lead to monopoly power.

I doubt that many will disagree with the conclusion of your editorial of Oct. 15 which says that the vast majority of the American people will concur in the verdict reached at the trial of the eleven Communist leaders. But the truth of this conclusion seems to me to raise a question which is of greater importance: why this trial ever had to take place.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Grain markets advanced rapidly on the Board of Trade here today following announcement that the House and Senate had reached an agreement on a farm-price-support program. July wheat led the advance, soaring 3 5/8 cents a bushel over the early low and came within 1/4 cent of the high for the year before reacting.
An 83-year-old man was beaten to death in a synagogue yesterday as he prepared for sunrise services. A change purse containing less than $2 was stolen from the victim.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Bolo Mack, flying the silks of Mrs. C. A. Cope, scored a thrilling head triumph in the featured Autumn Purse at Garden State Park today.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Princess Elizabeth emphasized the sanctity of marriage in an age of what she called "falling moral standards" in an address to young mothers today.

ATLANTA, Oct. 18 -- Robert Tyre Jones Jr., the man behind the greatest record ever achieved in the competitive phase of golf, is still the same resourceful sort of fellow he was back in the golden era of sports when his name was bracketed with those of Babe Ruth and Jack Dempsey atop the nation's sports pages.

VIENNA, Oct. 18 -- A production crisis is afflicting the "people's democracies" in Eastern Europe. Their Communist rulers are seeking to find answers to it in "Socialist competitions," "Stakhanovism," "the raising of norms," a reduction of workers' wages through state loans and the creation of slave labor by the liquidation of the middle class.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed unanimously today on a compromise Farm Bill embodying the principle of flexible price supports as a long-range peacetime policy but assuring high props during a transitory period.

Negotiators for the New York Shipping Association, concluding discussions with the last of the allied trades of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached with the clerks and checkers on virtually the same terms that were given to the longshoremen, carpenters, cargo repairmen and maintenance men.

Despite the popular conception that a pretty blond nurse has a definite therapeutic value in the handling of patients in hospitals, studies made by the United Hospital Fund of New York show that male nurses are in great demand in its eighty-six member voluntary hospitals.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., has arranged with fifteen New York banks for a $50,000,000 credit, effective tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by Ralph H. Tapscott, chairman of the board. A $70,000,000 credit with the same group of banks expired on Oct. 14.

Buyers Total Lower Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,377, against 1,766 last week and 1,769 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 687 arrivals yesterday compared with 765 last Tuesday.

Seventeen Negro leaders denounced the "inflammatory statements" of John Foster Dulles, the Republican candidate for United States Senator, and the "smear campaign" of Newbold Morris, the Republican - Liberal - City Fusion nominee for Mayor, it was announced yesterday in a statement from the O'Dwyer headquarters at the Commodore Hotel.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18 -- Russia cast two vetoes tonight to block a United Nations Security Council recommendation for a world census of armed forces and non-atomic weapons.
Judge Harold R. Medina has demonstrated to us again the value of the Bill of Rights and their neutral application in the controversy just completed in the trial of the American Communists.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- President Truman nominated today his old friend, Mon C. Wallgren, as a member of the Federal Power Commission, and in less than three hours, the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee unanimously recommended his confirmation.

Probably the most piteous wail of them all is that lament of childhood, "There's nothing to do." Into this can be crowded more brooding melancholy than any offered by a large chorus of professional mourners, and it sobs and throbs with sincerity.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 18 -- The United States will adhere to its announced policies in Germany and will not try to match Russian moves in Eastern Germany that appeal to fanatic nationalism, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, indicated today.
PRAGUE, Oct. 14 -- A Broadway hit, "Finian's Rainbow," and a Hollywood film, "Boomerang," are providing the most popular stage and screen entertainment of the autumn season in Prague.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- In six predominantly rural counties centered around this city, near the New York-Pennsylvania border, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman is considered certain to make a better run for the United States Senate this year than in 1946, when he lost to Irving M. Ives, a resident of the area.
Mayor O'Dwyer, in his first swing of the campaign, made a strong plea last night for the support of organized labor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- In a table published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday morning recording the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on Congressional roll-calls last week, errors were made in the vote taken last Friday on the Price Practice Pill.

A red-headed Kerryman with a soft brogue will leave for Israel on Nov. 1. He is Edmond FitzGerald, chief probation officer of Kings County Court, and he will spend three months reorganizing the court parole system of the new state with the consent of the board of judges of the Brooklyn court.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Parliament learned today upon reassembling that the Government was not yet ready with an economic program for exploiting devaluation of road and controlling its effects at home. Herbert S. Morrison, Lord President of the Council, informed the House of Commons that Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee probably would be ready to make a statement about it next Monday.

Formation of a state-wide Doctors for Dulles Committee, headed by Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd of New York, was announced yesterday at Republican headquarters at the Roosevelt Hotel. Announcement of the committee confirmed earlier reports that the Dulles supporters were planning to campaign actively on the basis of Mr. Dulles' stand against "socialized medicine."

A stage play intended for Broadway production will have a try-out on television Monday night at 10 o'clock, when the CBS "Studio One" series presents "Battleship Bismarck." The original two-hour play was written by Maurice Valency, adaptor of "Th Madwoman of Chaillot," and Professor of Comparative Literature at Columbia University.

In a brief address last night, Herbert Hoover noted the world's and his country's affairs, contented himself with a terse comment on each, and then told 1,200 diners in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that "for the good of your digestion" he would not speak on any of the subjects he had mentioned.

Horse players soon will be able to study their favorite literature in intellectual surroundings suitable for concentrated thought. The New York Public Library, it was announced yesterday, has begun collecting material on horse racing in the United States.

This year's bountiful crop of apples -- estimated to be almost 130,000,000 bushels -- includes all the important varieties. McIntosh, Delicious and Jonathan are plentiful for eating out of hand. And for cooking there are, among others, the Rhode Island Greening and the Northern Spy.

Naming of a high-powered economic commission, composed of both business men and government representatives, to make a survey of trade conditions and combat communism in the Far East was urged yesterday by Herman Yaras, president of Yaras Co., import-export representatives for major American manufacturers.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (Reuters) -- A British Foreign Office spokesman, although stating no decision on recognition of the Chinese Communist Government had yet been made, denied today a press report from Washington that Britain had given the United States any assurance that this recognition would take the form of de facto recognition.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18 -- The Soviet publication Science and Life charged today that Prof. J. B. Rhine of Duke University and other "reactionary philosophers" were seeking to forestall or postpone the inevitable collapse of capitalism by poisoning the minds of workers.

Chief Judge Learned Hand of the United States Court of Appeals signed yesterday an order convening a three-judge statutory court to decide the constitutionality of a state amendment permitting court-authorized wiretaps.

The Iranian Government soon will spend $1,000,000 annually for advertising and promotion of its exports throughout the world and a "substantial sum" will be set aside for Iranian rug promotion in the United States, Ahmed Mehbod, acting consul general for Iran in this country revealed yesterday.

Religion in American Life, a national interfaith movement, which plans an intensive campaign from Nov. 1 to Thanksgiving Day, announced yesterday that the chairman of its lay committee, Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, had telegraphed to President Truman that in a troubled world the United States might find new reasons at the coming Thanksgiving for gratitude to God.

Plans for converting the five- story private dwelling at 3 East Eightieth Street, near Fifth Avenue, into small apartments were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by S. Platt to the Hervey Realty Corporation. Assessed for $160,000, the house is 39 by 70 feet and contains an elevator.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 -- Lincoln Local 900, United Automobile Workers, CIO, which had rejected every proposed contract with the Ford Motor Company in the past, voted tonight to approve the pension agreement, 1,540 to 909.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Capitol was "invaded" tonight by a District of Columbia National Guard unit.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18 -- Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky declared today at his first formal press conference within the United Nations since 1947 that the Soviet Union never could recognize "as either lawful or just" the election of Yugoslavia to a seat on the Security Council.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- The State Department of Commerce reported today that more than $16,000,000 of Federal and local funds will have been spent in New York State on airport construction under the Federal Airport Act during the three-year period to end in 1949.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- -- Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman declared tonight that additional Federal legislation was a "must" to prevent the fall in farm prices from developing into "a runaway deflation of agricultural values."

The election of Rene d'Harnoncourt as director of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, was announced yesterday by John Hay Whitney, chairman of the institution's board of trustees. Mr. d'Harnoncourt joined the museum in 1944 and since 1947 has held a post analagous to that of director, having been both chairman of the museum's Coordination Committee and director of its Curatorial Departments.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- (AP) -- Independent Government tests for all currently proposed color television systems were ordered today by the Federal Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson is a man who has managed in the past to restrain his enthusiasm for the United Nations, but at least he has now agreed that the United States delegation to that institution should be enlarged and strengthened.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18 -- Railroads had the highest fire losses in their history in 1948, Charles Needham of Washington, chairman of the fire protection and insurance section of the Association of American Railroads, reported today. He said 6,035 fires were recorded last year on American and Canadian railroads, causing damage of $11,033,158.

United States sea safety regulations, which exceed the requirements of the International Safety at Sea Convention, have raised shipbuilding costs but at the same time have given this nation the safest ships afloat, Rear Admiral H. C. Shepheard said yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- In Europe one frequently hears, even from the greatest admirers of the United States, the view that the American Government is overwhelmed by the world problems now facing it and for which it has no previous historical experiences.
Strikes in the domestic steel, coal and aluminum industries and the failures of Brazilian coffee crops will begin to affect the American housewoves' market basket soon.

Mystery surrounded yesterday the disappearance of a 22-year-old Rochester war veteran whose car had been stopped in Holbrook, Ariz., arid its driver held there on a va grancy charge. There is a twenty-six-state police alarm out for the young man and there had been a similar one for the car.

HAZLETON, Pa., Oct. 18 -- The people of this Alleghany mountain city saw today the first concrete results of an unusual plan to insure their preservation with the dedication of a $3,500,000 plant establishing a new industry in the midst of the anthracite coal belt.
With industrial layoffs mounting, top Federal mediators will renew their efforts today to find a key to settlement of the nineteen-day-old strike of 500,000 steel mill workers.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday. Final prices were 9 to 49 points net higher, with the 1950 positions the strongest.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- The French version of Tennessee Williams' Broadway hit, "A Streetcar Named Desire," opened last night before a distinguisshed audience, who gave it an enthusiastic reception. Today the first press reviews to appear gave it a denunciation whose thoroughness has been rarely seen in theatre criticism here.

Tonight's events: Chopin Centennial Festival, symphony orchestra conducted by Franco Autori, Agi Jambor and Jakob Gimpel, pianists; the Mannes Trio, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Mieczyslaw Horzowski, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; "The Tales of Hoffmann," City Opera, City Center, 8:15.

The American Market Association has named fifteen of its top-ranking professional marketing men to the board of judges for the A.M.A.'s national awards program, it was announced yesterday, by William C. Gordon Jr., awards committee chairman.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Dodgers probably will shake up their outfield before next season, Branch Rickey said today. Otherwise, the Brooklyn president indicated, there will be no significant differences between next year's team and the club which lost to the Yankees in the World Series.

George C. D. Odell, whose death at the ripe age of 84 was announced yesterday, has left behind him an enduring monument. His "Annals of the New York Stage," to which the last twenty-five years of his life were devoted, covers "the entire field of public entertainment" in our metropolitan area for just short of two hundred years -- a prodigious achievement.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday urged support for the $50,500,000 building and maintenance fund campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, which he declared "presents to the people of New York City an opportunity to help expand medical and social services on many, many fronts."

The City Council, in what was termed an effort to curb crime by young persons in New York, adopted yesterday a measure under which it would be unlawful to leave a motor vehicle unattended more than three minutes in city streets without locking its ignition and removing the key.

Net earnings of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company for the nine months ended with last September rose to $15,208,999, equal to $5.95 a share, from $9,787,417 or $3.83 a share earned in the corresponding period last year, John D. Biggers, president, reported yesterday.

The stock market reversed its course abruptly yesterday after Monday's slump. A good share of the losses were wiped out as a strong demand for aircrafts, chemicals, televisions and some industrials sparked the upturn. While fractional gains were the rule, some isolated issues advanced as much as 4 points, and the composite rate rose 0.89 point.

The State of New York sold yesterday an issue of $43,365,000 of tax-exempt housing bonds due on Nov. 1, 1951 to 1999, to a banking syndicate headed by the National City Bank at an interest cost of 1.895 per cent. Money raised by the sale will be used by the state to make loans to local government agencies in furtherance of low-rent housing and slum clearance.

Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru hinted yesterday that India might formally recognize the new Communist Government of China. India's Prime Minister, who is here on an official visit, commented on the subject after speaking informally at a luncheon of the Overseas Press Club in the Savoy Plaza Hotel.

The Visiting Nurse Service of New York began its 1949 campaign for funds yesterday with a meeting at its headquarters, 262 Madison Avenue. The service is seeking $412,000 to maintain home-nursing visits, health supervision at day-care centers for preschool-age children, instruction to expectant mothers on how to care for their children, and other work.

The happenings at the Jamaica horse park yesterday included (1) a spill that sent Gordon Glisson to a hospital with a fractured collarbone, and (2) a whingding finish that gave George D. Widener's Lights Up ($17.70 for each $2 on his nose) a neck decision in the $12,500 Remsen Handicap for 2-year-olds.

Early this year Edwin G. Nourse, Chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, sought to retire to private life, only to be dissuaded from his course by the personal plea of Mr. Truman. The past few days have brought reports that the former Brookings Institution economist has again submitted his resignation to the White House, and this time, it is intimated, his decision will stick.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A dispatch in yesterday's NEW YORK TIMEE stated that "shipbuilders" were expected to oppose an Administration move to increase ship building subsidies because it might develop a trend to nationalization of the industry. The story should have referred to ship operators and not builders. The Shipbuilders Council of America pointed out today that it had taken no position in this matter.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18 -- Representatives of the Eastern European bloc were joined today by delegates of African countries in attacking proposals to place Italian Somaliland under Italy's trusteeship before granting independence to the colony.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Each working American will pay an additional $6 weekly in taxes if the Truman Administration's Brannan farm plan and socialized medicine become effective, Governor Dewey said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Air Force plans to operate only 180 B-36 aircraft, of which 120 would be for bomber missions, W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, said today in opening the Air Force rebuttal to the Navy's attacks against the B-36 and the "atomic-blitz" theory of war.

Most newspaper writers seem to find in the conviction of the eleven Communist leaders a source of satisfaction. Now, it would seem, we are safe. Communism in the United States has received a serious, if not a mortal, setback, and the nation may well congratulate itself on the effectiveness of its justice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Winfield V. Riefler, assistant to the chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, is under consideration as successor to Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, who has informed the White House he is determined to quit as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers by Nov. 1.

Several thousand Bronx public school children were released from classes yesterday afternoon to attend ground-breaking exercises for the recreational center in St. Mary's Park, St. Mary's Street and St. Ann's Avenue.

In a quick resale Charles Walzer, operator, has disposed of the one-story store building at 668 Eighth Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of Forty-second Street, which he purchased last month. The new owner is an investor, who made the deal through Thomas A. Kelly, broker.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- British economic officials have been engaged lately on a thorough study of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation with a view to making it a more positive and effective agency. Their general aim is to promote that economic integration demanded of the Marshall Plan countries by the United States.

We do not believe that we are alone in finding the Mayoralty campaign, to this point at least, disappointing. Mr. Morris, on the Fusion side, has been industrious, good-tempered and stouthearted; but we know little, on the basis of the speeches he has made thus far, of the particular measures by which he would hope to solve the formidable problems that loom ahead for the next Mayor of New York City.

Immediate action by the City Council on a resolution by Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat, to oust Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr., Communist, from his Council seat was blocked yesterday afternoon when Eugene P. Connolly, Manhattan Democrat and American Labor party member, arose to say, "I object."

A $100,000 libel suit brought by Max Mencher, former Office of Price Administration official, against Adolph J. Chesley, Bronx real estate man, was settled yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court for an undisclosed financial consideration and a letter of apology.

An investor bought from the Salouber Corporation, Walter Rothschild, president, the seven-story elevator apartment building for forty-seven families at 571 East 170th Street, northeast corner of Fulton Avenue, the Bronx, in a deal negotiated by the Herman A. Acker Corporation, broker.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The prices of cattle hit a new peak for 1949 today at the Chicago Stockyards. The top was $37 a hundred pounds, paid for two loads of choice to prime 1,320 and 1,405-pound steers. The top yesterday was $36.85. Butcher hogs and sows were mostly 25c up. The hog top was $18.40, compared with $18.15 yesterday. Today's report by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Sarah Churchill and Antony Beauchamp were married today in an idyllic setting by the sea. She is the daughter of Winston Churchill. A Georgia country judge, Edwin W. Dart of Glynn County, married them.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 18 -- Latin Patriarchal Vicar Father Terrence Kuehn, top-ranking clergyman for Israeli - Jerusalem and southern Israel, has told Roman Catholic religious institutions in Jerusalem not to cooperate with the Israeli Government in preparations to accommodate Holy Year pilgrims next year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- As Congress rushed toward adjournment the Senate postponed today until next Jan. 20 consideration of a controversial basing point bill that is designed to exempt uniform delivered pricing practices from the anti-trust laws.

Pessimism was absent from Columbia's practice session at Baker Field yesterday as the Lions went through a spirited two-hour workout in preparation for Saturday's game with Army. Both offensive and defensive units engaged in intensive full-scale drills.

An underwriting syndicate of sixty-seven investment houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Drexel Co. and Glore, Forgan Co. will place on the market today a new issue of 250,000 shares of $100 par value stock of Public Service Electric and Gas Company. The stock will bear a cumulative dividend of 4.08 per cent and is priced at $102 a share, to yield 4 per cent.

Mrs. Charles I. Morton gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 111 East Eighty-eighth Street, for members of the debutante and junior committees aiding in the plans for the luncheon in behalf of the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York to be held on Nov. 10 at the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Morton heads the executive committee in charge of the arrangements for the luncheon.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- As the paths of the candidates in New York's Senatorial race crossed at three points today, Senator John Foster Dulles renewed his challenge to Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic-Liberal opponent, to meet him face to face in debate.

The Appellate Division, Second Department, upheld unanimously yesterday a State Supreme Court order invalidating the endorsement by the American Labor party of Edmund H. H. Caddy, Republican candidate for District Attorney of Kings County.
BERWICK, England, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The unfinished aircraft carrier Albion and a coal freighter collided in a gale off the North Sea coast today and twenty British seamen were lost.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York accepted last night the recommendations of its committees on judiciary and the Municipal Court on judicial candidates in the coming election.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 18 (UP) -- Connecticut's efforts to bring a steel mill to the state received added impetus today when Gov. Chester Bowles named a committee to investigate the situation. In a letter to the committee he predicteed that establishment of a mill in the state would provide 40,000 new jobs and increase incomes of farmers and merchants.
Directors of Oppenheim, Collins Co., Inc., at their annual meeting held yesterday in Wilmington, Del., elected Gordon K. Greenfield as president.

Homemakers are often reluctant to wash their fluffy wool blankets because after several launderings the material shrinks and becomes hard and "matted." According to the Springfield Woolen Mills of Tennessee, these problems have been eliminiated in the new "Fortune" blankets which they introduced yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- The Larchmont Temple, a new Jewish congregation that bought for $40,000 last March a twenty-room house at 75 Larchmont Avenue for conversion into a place of worship and only a few days ago was denied village permission to use it as a temple, finally won a partial victory early today.

Rising markets for fixed-income securities often have a way of bailing banking syndicates out of uncomfortably long market positions into which they got by too hard bargaining for underwriting commitments. Less frequently does a changing market vindicate the hard bargaining of issuers of securities, but today's offering of $25,000,000 of Public Service Electric and Gas Company preferred stock is an instance.
Senate and House farm bill conferees agreed yesterday on what they are pleased to refer to as "compromise" legislation.

The civic design committee of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects announced yesterday that it disapproved the proposed adoption by the City Planning Commission, in the form announced for a hearing today, of a revised master plan of areas for slum clearance and low- rent housing in the city.

The civic design committee of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects announced yesterday that it disapproved the proposed adoption by the City Planning Commission, in the form announced for a hearing today, of a revised master plan of areas for slum clearance and low- rent housing in the city.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, charged last night in a radio speech over WMCA that the Sanitation Department was infested with 1,500 "clubhouse loafers" and "political stool pigeons" for Mayor O'Dwyer.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Torrential rains and floods over Guatemala's richest banana, coffee and cocoa lands were reported today to have taken up to 1,000 lives and left 60,000 to 70,000 homeless. The Government said it was a national disaster.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Senate late today passed a new bill providing for a ten-year program for rehabilitating the Navajo and Hopi Indian tribes and sent it to the House.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 -- Blanche Thebom, young mezzo-soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association, appeared tonight for the first time in this country in the role of Dalila in Saint-Saens "Samson et Dalila," and she not only sang, but danced the part. An audience which jammed the War Memorial Opera House acclaimed the performance, given during the annual season of the San Francisco Opera Association.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 18 -- The Netherlands Government has proposed a new meeting of the Western powers to draft a document that would incorporate certain German economic obligations to the Western Allies into the law of the Bonn Republic.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- The gas industry contemplates expenditures of $3,500,000,000 for construction in the five-year period 1948-52, according to a recent economic survey conducted by the American Gas Association, Robert W. Hendee, president of the association, told its convention today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The White Sox, in the midst of settling their managerial problem, today swapped Catcher Joe Tipton for Rookie Second Baseman Nelson Fox of the Athletics.

" I DO not believe in gods. Let the rich have gods. The poor only have the Eighth Route Army." This statement of a new faith by a humble Chinese peasant may be found in "China Shakes the World,"* by Jack Belden. It is a particular instance of the success with which the Chinese Communists wooed the affections of the peasant masses.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Mexico's racing commission has decided jockey Don Meade has been punished enough but it has not licensed him to ride again in Mexico.

Sigi Weissenberg, the 21-year-old Israeli pianist, has won prizes, excited notices, tours here and abroad and scores of friends in the course of the last two years. Now it is expected of him that he live up to all the ecstatic predictions made for his future, which is a heavy burden for a young artist to bear. Nevertheless, he gave a good account of himself at Carnegie Hall last night.

Young women of society will distribute programs at the performance of Les Ballets de Paris tomorrow night at the Winter Garden for the benefit of the American Friends of France. They are Mrs. Hans Frech, the Misses Jo-Jeanne Millon, Cornelia Claiborne, Millicent Satterlee, Mary Jane Lansburgh, Jean Flynn and Lorene Heath.

Schools contribute to truancy because they often fail to provide satisfactory experiences for the child, Dr. J. Andrew Simmons, assistant executive director of the Children's Center, an agency of the Department of Welfare, said yesterday at the thirty-fifth annual conference of the National League to Promote School Attendance.

" Our progress in degeneracy appears to me to be pretty rapid. As a nation we began declaring that 'all men are created equal.' We now practically read it 'all men are created equal, except Negroes.' When the Know-Nothings get control, it will read 'all men are created equal, except Negroes and foreigners and Catholics.'
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (AP) -- On the record you can count on the Washington Redskins to have the best passing attack in the National Football League and the Pittsburgh Steelers the best ground game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Outlines of a $300,000,000 Federal scholarship program that would annually give financial aid to 480,000 college students, or about 20 per cent of the total enrollment, were disclosed here today.

The flair for style characteristic of Castillo's custom-made creations marked his ready-made collection presented yesterday by Elizabeth Arden at a benefit luncheon for the American Women's Voluntary Services at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Marking the closer relationship that will now exist between this establishment and its sister salon in Paris, Revillon Freres celebrated the opening of its new shop at 11 West Fifty-seventh Street yesterday with a showing of furs with a predominantly French flavor.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- Anti-Communist Japanese labor leaders fear that the extraordinary measures now being used to get rid of Communists may eventually be extended so that they will hurt the whole labor movement.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Oct. 18 -- The greatly expanded research and testing laboratory for checking and maintaining quality control of the nation's largest manufacturer of synthetic textiles was shown here today to a group of visiting newspaper men by officials of Burlington Mills Corporation.

" Red, Hot and Blue," which arrives at the Paramount, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Betty Hutton and Victor Mature head the cast of the romantic comedy with music. John Farrow directed and Robert Fellows produced from a screen play by Hagar Wilde and Mr. Farrow and a story by Charles Lederer. William Demarest, June Havoc and Jane Nigh appear in supporting roles.

Mussorgsky's "Khovanchina" in an English version and Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" will be the new productions at the Metropolitan Opera this season, Edward Johnson, general manager, announced yesterday. The major revivals will be Saint-Saens' "Samson et Dalila" and Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra."

This city is rebuilding large areas at a cost that may exceed $3,000,000,000, Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday. He spoke before 1,500 architects, engineers and business and labor leaders at a luncheon of the New York Building Congress at the Astor Hotel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 18 -- Dr. Everett C. Shimp, acting director of Ohio State University's Social Administration School, criticized Protestant churches today for putting their social work under the direction of persons with "little understanding of its professional aspects, whatever their qualifications in the religious field."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Congress approved and sent to the White House today appropriations of $15,585,863,498 for the Department of Defense, while the $1,314,010,000 appropriation for foreign military assistance is expected to be made ready for the President's signature tomorrow.
Mayor O'Dwyer will officiate at ceremonies formally opening Brooklyn's completely renovated city-owned pier at Thirty-third Street on Oct. 27, it was announced yesterday.
TRENTON, N. J., Oct 19 -- New Jersey's loyalty oath law was declared unconstitutional today by the Appellate Division of the State Superior Court, reversing a lower court ruling.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said again today that the United States had no intention of changing the price of gold. He added that the issuance of gold coins in this country, a proposal that had been made in Congress, was forbidden by law.

ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of the five members of the new State Building Code Commission, created by the 1949 Legislature to draft a modern and permissive state building code.

Fifty years ago Andrew Carnegie moved into his newly built mansion on Fifth Avenue and Ninety-first Street, from which he was to give away some $350,000,000 for the education of mankind. At about the same time the Community Service Society welcomed a handful of students to its newly created School of Philanthropy, which then occupied a single room in the Society's offices at 105 East Twenty-second Street.

The merchant marine industry is reviewing its stand on Government shipbuilding subsidies in the light of President Truman's recent directive to the Maritime Commission to prepare legislation that would increase Federal construction subventions.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia's purge reached into the ranks of directors and managers of nationalized industries today. A score of these Communist-approved, Government-appointed executives were dismissed.

TITUSVILLE, N. J, Oct. 19 -- Mechanical and other aids to farm productivity that have been worked out quietly by a banker-economist and half a dozen college professors in the last three years were made public today. The biggest gadget is a "cowfeteria" -- a self-feeding barn consisting of two quonset huts, one inside the other -- which makes possible a 35 per cent saving of labor on dairy and beef farms.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- In an effort to combat juvenile delinquency, an intensive group therapy program will be started in the Children's Court Treatment Clinic of the Court of Domestic Relations, New York, it was reported today by Dr. Harris B. Peck, senior psychiatrist at the clinic.

DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Detroit blasted the New York Rangers, 6 -- 1, tonight as the Red Wings again showed the form that won the National Hockey League championship for them last season. It was the highest team score of the young campaign, but the crowd of 9,507 was the smallest since the war at Olympia.

Notices posted in the windows of trains on the IND division of the subway last night notified passengers that recently announced changes in operating schedules, designed to speed up service, would take effect Sunday.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Although the evident desire of the United States to prevent all Soviet and Communist attempts to establish world hegemony is acknowledged, one is frequently asked in Europe: "What is the United States' long-range foreign policy?"
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Bullish sentiment ran high on the Board of Trade today. May and July wheat sold at new seasonal highs and December oats went into new ground since last January.

The General Electric Company informed the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, yesterday that it was willing to explore "the general pension and insurance benefit field" in present contract talks.

Sharply divergent views on how this country can best meet the threat to democracy inherent in communism were expressed yesterday by six New York City public, private and parochial high school students participating in the Youth Forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- To those economists who hold that their profession is traduced by colleagues that strive to make a set of facts fit a political policy or a preconceived economic theory the only surprise in the resignation of Dr. Edwin G. Nourse is that he lasted so long.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- A new and less painful method of dividing dollar aid, and the achievement of fruitful results in freeing intra-European Trade, are under active discussion by the European Marshall Plan Council and United States officials here.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Chile won tonight in the opening of the international jumping competition at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Lincoln White, State Department press officer, said today that United States Ambassador Cavendish W. Cannon had brought up the question of the release from prison of Archbishop Aloysius Stepinatz in a recent discussion "of the Western conception of basic human rights" with the Yugoslav Foreign Office.

HONG KONG, Oct. 19 -- Although vitally concerned, Hong Kong officials so far have had no contacts with Communist representatives aimed at adjusting British relationships with Chinese Communists on a local basis.

Development of more "triangular-deal" trade channels, plus some conversion of United Kingdom production to export manufacture were seen yesterday as offering a partial solution of Britain's dollar problem. These recommendations were made by Karl Anderson, chief of the British Commonwealth section of the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce, at a meeting of the Government statistics and report group of the New York American Marketing Association chapter in the Shelbourne Hotel.

The real story told in Russeks showing of after-5 and evening fashions at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday was that of many handsome fabrics, the opulent ottomans, stiff brocades, taffetas and luxurious surahs, that lend such beauty to the season's styles.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19 -- The Soviet Union and its Eastern European supporters lost their struggle in the General Assembly's Legal Committee today to prevent or postpone a United Nations debate on the Belgrade-Moscow quarrel.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Most sections of the stock market continued to decline here today as brokers opened the books for the next fortnight's business.

The Douglas Aircraft Company earned $3,202,171 more in the nine months ended on Aug. 31 than it did in the corresponding period of the previous year and yesterday voted an extra dividend of $1.50 a share in addition to the regular quarterly of $1.25 on the common stock, Donald W. Douglas, president, announced.

The tale of a modern "Robinson Crusoe" was unfolded yesterday with the arrival here of a ruddy-faced, white - haired adventurer who, after more than a decade, forsook life on a beautiful tropical island in the Caribbean to return to civilization. James V. McGimsey, the 1949 counterpart of Daniel Defoe's famous character, was one of 110 passengers from Cristobal who debarked from the Panama Line ship Ancon.
Your editorial entitled "Teachers' Pay in Politics" appearing Oct. 13 is not a fair picture of the campaign for teachers' salaries commensurate with living costs.

By adding ten seconds to green lights at twenty intersections along Grand Concourse in the Bronx, engineers gave drivers a chance yesterday to move the entire five miles from 140th Street to Van Cortlandt Avenue without a stop.

The nation's light fuel oil stocks increased last week for the seventh consecutive week and established a new record of 86,952,000 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A year ago stocks were 74,278,000 barrels.

In the well ordered foxhunt -- rare in this vicinity since the Brooklyn Foxhunt Club disbanded in 1861 -- the open appearance of the fox is greeted with a view halloo. At this stirring sound the hunters spur their horses forward in the chase, so that they may be present when the fox is killed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- Before this country can get tax reductions by cutting Federal expenditures, it must let Europe earn the dollars it needs by selling us goods, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, asserted here today.

A large mubscription has been :reported for the performance of George Abbott's new musical revue, "Touch and Go,". on Monday night at the Broadhurst Theatre for the benefit of the Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children. Miss Jessie Mann is chairman of the committee in charge of ticket sales.

Formation of a Canadian Advertising Council similar to the Advertising Council in this country was recommended in Toronto yesterday by Charles G. Mortimer Jr., board chairman of the American organization. Mr. Mortimer, who is vice president in charge of marketing for General Foods Corporation, spoke at the thirty-fourth annual convention of the Association of Canadian Advertisers in the Royal York Hotel.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Manna H., sporting the silks of the Sandy Strand Stable, upset the dope bucket today at Garden State Park when he sped to a length triumph in the featured Medford Purse.

The cornerstone of a housing project that replaces some of Manhattan's lower East Side slums was dedicated yesterday at New Chambers and Batavia Streets. Mayor O'Dwyer, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman, Robert Moses and Bernard M. Baruch paid tribute in brief speeches to the late Gov. Alfred E. Smith, for whom the project is named.

After reading your editorial on the situation in Greece feel it necessary to make an exception to the rule imposed on me by personal disposition and by the responsibilities of my function. I have rarely read an article including in so few lines so many fundamental truths.

American education has failed youth by ignoring moral and spiritual values, Msgr. John S. Middleton, secretary of education for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared last night in an attack on the educational philosophy of Dr. John Dewey and his followers.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 19 -- The Princeton football team today completed the more rugged phases of its preparation for Cornell and tomorrow evening the squad of forty-four players will leave by buses for Ithaca and Saturday's meeting with the favored Ivy League champions at Schoellkopf Crescent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, fired a broadside at the Navy today that all but sank their case before the House Armed Services Committee.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Dr. Howard A Rusk, who is on his way home after a tour of Austria and Poland as a consultant of the United Nations, said today that those two countries had made excellent starts toward the rehabilitation of disabled persons.

A lone thug, using one of his victims as a shield, marched him two and one-half blocks in the crowded garment district at 1 P. M. yesterday and into the West Thirty-fourth Street subway station on the Eighth Avenue line, where he disappeared into a downtown local train with a $4,000 payroll.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 19 -- Presbyterian Church membership in New York State increased from 241,045 in 1925 to 269,776 in 1949, it was reported here today at the annual meeting of the Presbyterian Synod of New York.

Brazil will have its first television transmitter in operation early next year as the result of the sale of a 5-kilowatt transmitter by General Electric Sociedade Anonima, Brazil, an affiliate of the International General Electric Company, it was disclosed here yesterday.

VIENNA, Oct. 19 -- Whether Austria can be induced to make use of United States help to free her domestic trade from the shackles of cartelization, refrain from raising her tariffs and economize in Government spending are three questions to which the Marshall Plan mission here must find an affirmative answer in 1950.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- The first pencil sketch of a proposed Tucker automobile and an "indefinite front and rear end" and bicycle-type fenders on the wheels, a jury in the Federal District Court of Judge Walter J. LaBuy was told today. The description was given by the Government's first witness in the second trial of Preston Tucker and seven Tucker Corporation associates on charge of mail fraud and conspiracy.

With thrusts at both his political opponents for making "bookies" an election issue, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, attacked sharply last night "the big real estate interests" and called for "realistic" property assessments.
In several current group shows contemporary artists, working in a conservative vein, show how ingeniously medium can be exploited without much new ground being broken.

The negotiated underwriting of the new issue of $25,000,000 of preferred stock of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company was marked down yesterday as a success. Substantially all the stock was placed on the first day of offering on a 4 per cent yield basis and the issue price was bid at the end of the day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The House and Senate accepted the compromise farm bill today by top-heavy votes, sending it to the White House for President Truman's expected signature.
Motions to set aside the verdict, arrest judgment or give a new trial to eleven Communist leaders were filed yesterday in the Federal district court.

There are "definite indications" that the Administration will offer in January legislation calling for a 50 per cent tax rate on corporate profits, Alan H.
