Temple, vice president of the National City Bank of New York, declared yesterday. He spoke before the twenty-second annual meeting of the Carpet Institute, Inc., in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Hollywood stars will play leading roles in a new television dramatic series entitled "Romance" which the Columbia Broadcasting System will introduce Nov. 3. The program and "Inside U. S. A. With Chevrolet" will alternate on Thursday evenings at 8:30 o'clock.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 19 -- Dr. Benjamin Fletcher Wright was installed today as the fifth president of Smith College with the stated promise that inevitable changes in the seventy-five-year-old institution must be made without weakening "the quality of scholarship," or impairing "the love of learning."
The start of a campaign to raise $1,000,000 to aid "escapees" from Soviet-dominated countries of Eastern Europe was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, St. Paul, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 75,000 shares of its no par value common stock.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 19 -- E. F. Mitchell of Worthington-Sussex, former president of the National Association of Master Bakers of Great Britain, said here today that if English bread could be made as "white" as that produced here the British people would eat it as cake -- not bread.

Three leaders of two wings of the General Zionist party in Israel, holding a joint press conference yesterday at the Commoodore Hotel, emphasized the need for the Israeli Government to formulate an economic program that would immediately stimulate private investment.

George D. Widener, winner of the Remsen Handicap with an Eight Thirty colt on Tuesday, took the largest chunk of the cash with Rare Perfume, an Eight Thirty filly, in the $12,150 Autumn Day Stakes as the Empire City Racing Association's four-week meeting opened at Jamaica yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct 19 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, said today that the Eighty-first Congress "has displayed more interest in health measures than any Congress in history."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 19 -- Scores of recommendations on health, economic conditions, community, education, family living and institutional and foster care came from the Closing session of the Protestant Conference on Child Welfare here today.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 19 -- The Government announced today that more than 4,000 persons had been killed and property damage of more than $40,000,000 was caused by the worst flood in Guatemala's history.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company, which is having financial troubles, asked Congress today to help it take over all United States telegraph and teletype services here and abroad.

President Branch Rickey of the Dodgers was closeted with Fred Saigh, owner of the Cardinals, for more than an hour yesterday. This may, or may not, indicate that a trade is brewing between the clubs that finished one-two in the National League during the past season.
W. J. Kingsland of New York City sent us this tip recently:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Arrangements for development of a new suburban branch store on five and one-half acres here at Westchester Avenue and Bloomingdale Road were announced today by B. Altman Co. The building will be nearly three times as large as the present Altman branch at Mamaroneck Avenue and Post Road, a half-mile away.
Chemical Bank and Trust Company has been appointed registrar for the common stock of West Kentucky Coal Company.

A comparatively small hospital, such as Beth David on East Ninetieth Street, handles as many as 53,500 telephone calls a month. Since the hosiptal has only 197 beds and thirty bassinets, this telephone traffic is an indication of the interest New Yorkers take in the health and welfare of their relatives and friends.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19 -- In a surprise move, the United States suggested today that the former Italian colony of Eritrea be made an autonomous state, federated with Ethiopia under the crown of Emperor Haile Selassie.
Herman T. Stichman, State Commissioner of Housing, criticized the O'Dwyer administration last night for alleged failure to enforce the tenement house laws.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The American Gas Association today bestowed its highest honor, the Distinguished Service Award, on James A. Brown, president of the Michigan Gas Storage Company, Jackson. The award, made at the association's annual convention here, was for "outstanding engineering achievements" in producing and selling gas and its by-products.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- With a caustic note to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, John L. Lewis today abandoned his plan for raising $2,500,000 a week to aid striking steel workers.

Cross currents ran through the stock market yesterday, but on balance prices improved in irregular and selective dealings. Fractional gains predominated in the pivotal issues, although General Motors scored a major gain and a few other stocks, influenced by corporate developments, moved ahead as much as 3 points.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Congress cleared the way today for a fast start on the Administration's plan to expand atomic bomb making facilities and the supporting Tenessee Valley Authority power system at a cost of more than $300,000,000.

Coffee futures continued steady and moderately active in yesterday's trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Hedge-covering and produce-buying absorbed profit-taking and some new hedge-selling. A cable from Brazil reporting disappointing crop conditions helped to hold prices above previous levels.
Mayor O'Dwyer and his running mates on the Democratic ticket insisted last night that the chief issue in the Mayoralty campaign was the record of his administration.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 19 -- Substantially lower production costs in more than seven branches of metal-working are now definitely assured for 1950, exhibitors stated here today at the thirty-first national metal exposition and congress, centered in the Cleveland Public Auditorium and three large hotels.

IT was rather distressing news on several counts. One day last week Connie Mack made the reluctant announcement that he had fired his two veteran coaches, Al Simmons and Earle Brucker, because the board of directors had so ordered. The gentle octogenarian always has been tremendously fond of Messrs. Simmons and Brucker, two most admirable characters.

Both John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, and Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien denied yesterday the charge of Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, that there was any organized gambling in the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Bucky Harris, twice previously manager of the Senators, today signed to manage the team for the next three years. Clark Griffith, president of the Senators, made the announcement.

Gen. George C. Marshall, on his first visit to Red Cross centers in Manhattan, outlined yesterday a 6,000-mile flying itinerary for next week in his new capacity as president of the American National Red Cross.

A Chopin Centennial Festival concert was given under the auspices of Carlos P. Romulo, President of the General Assembly, Trygve Lie, the Secretary General, and the Polish delegation to the United Nations last night in Carnegie Hall.
BERLIN, Thursday, Oct. 20 (AP). Premier Otto Grotewohl pledged his Eastern German Democratic Republic today to keep the peace with all the nations of the world.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 19 -- A four-man committee including H. Merle Cochran, United States member of the United Nations Conciliation Commission, began work today in an effort to overcome the last major barrier to a successful conclusion of the round table conference on Indonesia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, reported today that the Greek civil war was practically over and a reduction in American aid to Greece was now a logical step.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- James Stewart today was announced by Universal-International as the star of its forthcoming film production of "Harvey," Pulitzer Prize play of 1947.

The New York State Commission Against Discrimination and the Pennsylvania Railroad announced jointly yesterday that, effective immediately, coach seats on through trains from New York to the South operated by the Pennsylvania will be reserved for all passengers alike in any part of the train.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal - Fusion candidate for Mayor, declared in a radio address over WJZ last night that prostitution and the narcotics trade were becoming rife under the O'Dwyer administration. He added these charges to those made the day before to the effect that bookmaking was open in Brooklyn because of corruption in the administration of which Mayor O'Dwyer was cognizant.

A structure recently completed at a cost of $789,980 to replace an eighty-three-year-old building at 304 Mulberry Street for St. Barnabas House was dedicated yesterday afternoon. The house is maintained by the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society as a haven for troubled children and women.

The deadening effects of the steel and coal strikes on American industry were highlighted last night by an announcement that the Ford Motor Company would have to lay off virtually all of its 115,000 production workers by Nov. 15 and halt all production of automobiles and trucks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Congress spent about $34,400,000,000 in the session just over, the House heard today from Representative Clarence Cannon, Democrat, of Missouri, chairman of the Appropriations Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19 -- The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly called upon Britain, France and other administering powers today to overhaul a large part of the economic structure of African and Pacific trust areas under United Nations supervision.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Following are highlights of the testimony today of Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to the House Armed Services Committee:
Coach Red Strader of the Football Yankees views his team's clash with the San Francisco Forty-Niners at the Yankee Stadium on Sunday as a case of "an irresistible force meeting an immovable object."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 12:
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 2 to 21 points net higher than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The first session of the Eighty-first Congress, longest during peacetime for twenty-seven years and at times the most bitterly partisan, adjourned sine die tonight, with President Truman praising its accomplishments and urging vacation rest and recreation to restore energy for the second session coming up Jan. 3.

With recent weather conditions hardly conducive to increased demand for men's clothing, production in the industry compared with a year ago continues to be off sharply. Output figures for the latest period show average weekly output to be running about 25 per cent under a year ago.

Low bids submitted for contracts to construct the Hunts Point Sewage Plant to be built in the southeast part of the Bronx totaled $15,613,468, Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The members of Parliament who follow the Labor party leadership met today and heard Prime Minister Attlee and Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, describe the gravity of the nation's economic crisis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Brushing aside the charge of "government by crony," the Senate today confirmed President Truman's old friend, Mon C. Wallgren of Washing State, as a member of the Federal Power Commission. The vote was 47 to 12.

The City Planning Commission's proposed new master plan for low-rent housing and redevelopment of forty sections of the city came under the fire of civic workers and property owners in a public hearing before the commission yesterday afternoon at City Hall. After more than two hours of debate the hearing was closed and action was deferred indefinitely.

"Why is it," our mathematician friend asked exasperatedly the other day, "that most people consider mathematics dull and difficult? All over the country high schools are making the study of algebra and geometry optional, or dropping these subjects completely, so that we're fast becoming a nation of mathematical ignoramuses.

A seventeen-year high in the short interest in listed stocks on the New York Stock Exchange was reported yesterday by the Exchange. Data compiled from information supplied by members and member firms showed that as of Oct. 14 the short position was 2,230,012 shares, compared with 2,133,700 on Sept. 15.

May I, an Indian reader of your journal, reciprocate Louis Fischer's sensitive and keen interpretation of Prime Minister Nehru's friendly impact on American democracy by expressing an Eastern evaluation of its significance?

"The United States and Russia," a special report on the prospects for peace prepared by a "working party" of the American Friends Service Committee, the Quaker organization that won the Nobel Prize in 1947, is scheduled for publication by the Yale University Press.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Yugoslavia's official press reported today that Russia had moved Soviet Army troops into neighboring Cominform countries as part of a "warmongering" campaign against Premier Marshal Tito's Government.

It is unfortunate that the differences between Soviet Russia and most of the other member states of the United Nations should be further augmented by a conflict over whether Yugoslavia or Czechoslovakia should be elected to the Security Council. It would, indeed, have been better if this particular conflict could have been avoided, especially since the presence of a Soviet dummy in the Council neither adds to nor subtracts from its efficacy.

Members of the chief inspector's office raided an alleged "hot horse wire room" in the financial district with the result that six men were arraigned yesterday in Gamblers Court on charges of violating the gambling laws.

WHITE SULPHUR - SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 19 -- John L. Lewis walked out of the soft-coal negotiations again today and drove off. The mine operators said they, too, had just about reached "the end of the line."

An appeal for cooperation from American importers to help Cuba overcome her economic dependence on sugar was made yesterday by Dr. Oscar Gans, Cuban Ambassador to this country. Speaking at a luncheon in his honor given by the Cuban Chamber of Commerce in the United States in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Dr. Gans said:

Lawrence Winters appeared in four roles at the City Center last night, in the New York City Opera's production of Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann." It was the company's second production of the work this season, and was marked by the return to the organization of Mario Berini, in the title part, after an absence of three years.

WAYNESVILLE, N. C., Oct. 19 -- The gully-washer and trash-mover which was prophesied for last Saturday arrived a few days late, but it sent a dozen cold, water-logged bear hunters back to camp at noon, and the rest of the day was spent trading lies around the big fireplace at Cataloochie Ranch.
The tenth anniversary of the installation of Dr. Harry D. Gideonse as president of Brooklyn College was celebrated last night at a dinner in the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn.

GENEVA, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- In the smaller upstate cities in the Finger Lakes region and along the route of the Erie Railroad near the Pennsylvania border, this year's Senate race between John Foster Dulles, Republican, and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat-Liberal, is overshadowed by contests for local offices.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Chicago and the Midwest will fight Wall Street for their proper share of the securities business. The challenge was issued today by James E. Day, president of the Chicago Stock Exchange.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Oct. 19 -- Completing a stormy voyage that delayed its arrival a day, the Holland America Line flagship, Nieuw Amsterdam, docked this afternoon at the Fifth Street pier here with 1,201 passengers, a piano-playing Rhesus monkey named Herman and three trick dogs.
Pandit Nehru declared last night that his nation rejoiced in not having the atom bomb.
MONTREAL, Oct. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Francis Adams Truslow, president of the New York Curb Exchange, said tonight that the recent devaluation of currencies will mean "more stringent controls."

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 19 -- The Women's Long Island Golf Association held its final one-day tournament and its annual meeting at the Piping Rock Club today and Mrs. J. B. Balding of the Creek Club took low gross in the one and Mrs. E. G. Richmond of Cherry Valley was renamed president at the other.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Federal Power Commission made public today a report outlining a possible plan for a $350,000,000 redevelopment of the United States' side of Niagara Falls for hydroelectric power in the next eleven years.

Firm to higher prices for shoes in 1950 were predicted yesterday by Lawrence B. Sheppard, president of the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, at a luncheon of the National Shoe Institute at the Park Lane Hotel.
ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- Governor Dewey will fly to New York City tomorrow for a series of inspections and political speeches in Queens, Nassau and Westchester Counties.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Oct. 19 -- Burlington Mills Corporation will spend $40,000,000 in the next three years on modernizing and expanding its existing equipment, it was made known here today by J. C. Cowan Jr., president. Marked improvement of business over present levels, he said, would bring a larger capital outlay to round out Burlington's seventy-six plants and replace outmoded machinery.

Congress adjourned last night and some casting up of accounts for the long session that began last January is in order. Amid the welter of major and minor bills passed, postponed and permanently pigeonholed, we find five cheering successes, five dismal failures.

GROTON, Mass., Oct. 19 -- Larry Noble, head football coach at Groton School, finds himself confronted with a unique problem. Often a prep school mentor encounters difficulty in unearthing four good men for his backfield. Groton, this season, is endowed with nine backs, any of whom can be employed as first-stringers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19 -- A tense, anxious mood prevailed among delegation leaders at the United Nations on the eve of tomorrow's critical Security Council election contest between Yugoslavia, openly supported by the United States, and Czechoslovakia, enjoying the full blessing of Moscow.

The success of an experimental program in which mothers care for newborn babies in hospitals instead of lying idly by while the youngsters are isolated in nurseries is gradually spreading its influence among hospitals here, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, has charged that the United States is breaking a "gentleman's agreement" in backing Yugoslavia for a place on the United Nations Security Council, and Secretary of State Dean Acheson, on his word as a gentleman, said today that this was not true.

Masterly pianism, notable for its musicality and charm, was heard from Mieczyslaw Horszowski at his recital last night in Town Hall. Everything he played was a joy to the ear, for his performances were characterized by unflagging beauty of tone, used with a wealth of color and subtlety of nuances, which combined with a highly perfected technique and unusual refinement of approach to give his work true distinction.

It was a mere flake of dirt-encrusted paint, but the young detective was most deliberate and painstaking as he lifted it with a scalpel from the pavement and placed it on a sheet of filter paper. In a court room the paint chip later proved to be the final, conclusive link between a murderer and his deed.
Increased revenues and lower operating costs have caused a substantial improvement in earnings of American Airlines, Inc., according to a report issued yesterday.

S. M. Chartock's Gilbert and Sullivan company will end its engagement at the Mark Hellinger Theatre Saturday night, after a run of three weeks. On Tuesday it was reported that the group would be permitted by Anthony B. Farrell, owner of the theatre, to continue for a fourth week if business improved.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Dr. Otto J. Hermann, surgeon-in-chief of bone and joint service at Boston City Hospital, who delivered the fracture oration before the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons tonight, warned a large gathering of surgeons from many parts of the country and abroad that despite modern advances in techniques a large number of fractures still go unrecognized, resulting in long invalidism.

It was a mere flake of dirt-encrusted paint, but the young detective was most deliberate and painstaking as he lifted it with a scalpel from the pavement and placed it on a sheet of filter paper. In a court room the paint chip later proved to be the final, conclusive link between a murderer and his deed.
Increased revenues and lower operating costs have caused a substantial improvement in earnings of American Airlines, Inc., according to a report issued yesterday.

S. M. Chartock's Gilbert and Sullivan company will end its engagement at the Mark Hellinger Theatre Saturday night, after a run of three weeks. On Tuesday it was reported that the group would be permitted by Anthony B. Farrell, owner of the theatre, to continue for a fourth week if business improved.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Dr. Otto J. Hermann, surgeon-in-chief of bone and joint service at Boston City Hospital, who delivered the fracture oration before the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons tonight, warned a large gathering of surgeons from many parts of the country and abroad that despite modern advances in techniques a large number of fractures still go unrecognized, resulting in long invalidism.

A block of common stock of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, valued at more than $54,000,000, will be placed on the market today by a nation-wide investment banking syndicate made up of 240 investment firms headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

Directors of Aluminum, Ltd., yesterday increased the quarterly dividend rate on its stock from 50 to 60 cents a share and declared a year-end extra of 50 cents, payable on Dec. 5. A special dividend of 75 cents was paid last December.

Though Judge Harold R. Medina did not use the expression, "clear and present danger," in his charge to the Federal jury in the recent Communist trial, analysis of his charge shows he found such danger existed, hidden in the secret, underground activities of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, this country's highest military officer, denounced the Navy's complaining admirals today as men in "open rebellion" against civil authority who had done "infinite harm" to the United States and its world position.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- A Government plan to encourage British exporters to exploit the North American market by guaranteeing a proportion of their preliminary losses will go into effect tomorrow. The plan was outlined tonight by H. Somerville Smith, Controller General of the Export Credits Guarantee Department.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India said today that Marxism and capitalism could not exist together indefinitely in the same world.

Maritime industry leaders attending the opening day of the twenty-third annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States yesterday reflected more optimism than has marked past post-war meetings. The convention will run through tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Navy's acquisition of ships by transfer from the Army for use by the new Military Sea Transportation Service will be a "phased" operation extending at least until April 1, 1950, Rear Admiral William W. M. Callaghan, commander of the MST, said last night.
New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $45,850,000 were sold at competitive bidding to banking syndicates yesterday. The awards were as follows:

Abraham M. Heinowitz, president of Eastern Metals Corporation, announced yesterday the election of Robert B. Marsand as executive vice president and general manager of two affiliated companies, the Structural Iron and Steel Corporation and the Industrial Materials Export Corporation, both of Newark.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- President Truman expressed to the limit today his strong sense of loyalty to his staff. He gave eleven of his advisors the maximum pay rise permitted in the new Executive Pay Law.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- British Foreign Office spokesman said today that Mr. Vishinsky's warning on Yugoslavia had "made a highly unfavorable impression in London," but that Britain nevertheless would vote for Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union's choice.

A substantial softening in drug sundry prices was noted here yesterday by representatives of the Thrifty Drug Stores, Inc., of California, after a three-day, "million-dollar" buying mission in this area.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman authorized yesterday the trustees of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation to assume the company's franchise agreements with the city and to liquidate a $213,792 debt owed the city.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Republican charges of a "welfare state" threatening freedom were derided tonight by former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman as variants on "phony" slogans going back, he said, as far as Herbert Hoover's campaigns.

The National Association of Photo-Lithographers opened a three-day annual convention and equipment show at the Statler Hotel yesterday with a registration of 600, indicating an attendance twice that of any previous year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Congress tonight voted $8,581.68 in back pay for Michael W. Straus, Reclamation Commissioner, and Richard L. Boke, his California regional director.

TROY, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Senator John Foster Dulles declared tonight that former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, in making the charge of bigotry against him, had "let loose forces of evil that can divide our people."

Hartford County, Conn., Metropolitan District sold yesterday $1,000,000 of tax-exempt water transmission and filtration improvement bonds due on Nov. 1, 1950 to 1989, to Wood, Struthers Co. and Bramhall, Barbour Company at a bid of 103.919 for interest of 2 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Special Political Committee voted today to extend indefinitely the life of the Interim Committee, or Little Assembly, in spite of Russia's rigid boycott of it since its creation two years ago on United States initiative.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Charges of "conniving" against the recognized Government of China by United States officials while World War II was still in progress were made on the floor of the House today, just before the adjournment of Congress, by Representative Walter H. Judd, Republican, of Minnesota.
"At least we'll see daylight on Saturday," predicted Coach E. E. (Hook) Mylin of N. Y. U. as he discussed the Violet's game with unbeaten Boston University in the Hub Saturday.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday that the Venezuelan Government had formally requested the city to move the equestrian statue of Gen. Simon Bolivar from its present location in Central Park to a new site at Fifty-ninth Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 20 (AP) -- South Carolina broke into the victory column today for the first time this season with a crushing 27-13 football upset of Clemson, its traditional rivals. A record crowd of 35,000 saw the two Southern Conference teams play their forty-seventh annual state fair classic.

An intensive, nation-wide newspaper campaign promoting the convenient new Measure-Pak for Nucoa margarine will be run for ten weeks with a series of large-space ads, it was announced yesterday by Best Foods, Inc. The new package contains four quarter-pound sections along with instructions and a measuring table telling the consumer that one section equals one-half cup, a half section, two tablespoons, etc.

Charging that many children are drifting into delinquency because the public schools here fail to teach them to read, Justice James V. Mulholland of Children's Court called yesterday for an investigation of Board of Education teaching methods.

The Blackfriars' Guild, the organization that has become a sort of permanent fixture on West Fifty-seventh Street, last evening began its new season with a production of "Shake Hands With the Devil," described as a documentary on "present day affairs."

Decision of the International Refugee Organization to extend its own life nine months beyond the hoped-for liquidation date of June 30, 1950, merely reflects the dismal fact that the civilized world has not yet adequately responded to the plight of the still- homeless victims of Nazi and Communist persecution.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- In its first attempt to limit national industrial expansion in Europe to avoid duplication, the European Marshall Plan Council has approved the construction of oil refineries capable of transforming annually 62,400,000 tons of crude oil by 1952-53.

Representatives of the Association of Buying Offices asked yesterday that manufacturers of ready-to-wear recognize the importance of early deliveries of spring merchandise. They met at the Statler Hotel. All officers of the group were re-elected for the coming year.

The popularity of home sewing received added impetus yesterday with the introduction of a new portable electric sewing machine that sells for $49.95 and weighs only twelve and a half pounds. The Sew-Rite is available now at Ludwig Baumann stores.

Dr. Edvard Kardelj, Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia, marked the triumphant end of his country's hard fight for a seat on the United Nations Security Council yesterday with a ten-minute statement pledging the delegation "to strengthen the spirit of cooperation and peaceful relations among peoples on the basis of equality and mutual respect."

The United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday fixed the percentage of contribution each member will make during the coming year to the proposed United Nations net budget of $27,225,012.
Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru said last night that a flourishing trade between the United States and India would be of as much benefit to this country as it would be to his.

The reports of threats to the peace in East Java come at a most unfortunate time. It is apparent that the Round Table Conference on Indonesia is making headway, however difficult may be the going at some points. Failure of the conference because of this sort of pressure on the meetings at The Hague would be intolerable.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Today was anti-climax in the House Services Committee investigation of the Navy-B-36 row.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 20 -- King Abdullah of Jordan, following a speech today in Amman, was seen moving toward a bilateral settlement with Israel of the Jerusalem question and the annexation of the Arab part of Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The new 75-cent minimum wage law will mean pay increases of 5 to 10 cents an hour for 1,500,000 workers, it was stated today by William R. McComb, administrator of the Wages and Hours and Public Contracts Divisions of Department of Labor.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- For a team that has been playing winning football week after week, Pennsylvania hasn't been getting much attention this year.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, charged yesterday that the Communist party had attempted unsuccessfully to halt the city's subway lines last Monday morning during the rush hour.

PITSBURGH, Oct. 20 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week remained at the same low level of the previous week. Further declines in production and orginating shipments were offset by a small increase in trade, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Truman said today he had no plans to seize the coal or steel industries.

President Truman has vetoed the Navajo-Hopi rehabilitation bill on the ground that certain provisions in it would do the Indians more harm than good. Mr. Truman cited Section 9, which would, as he said, "extend state civil and criminal laws and court jurisdiction to the Navajo-Hopi reservations which are now under federal and tribal laws and courts."
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- At a country mansion in the quiet Yorkshire village of Easingwold British defense experts are learning how to protect the country's 50,000,000 inhabitants from atomic attack.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20--President Truman served notice today that he would ask Congress for higher taxes next year to end deficit financing.

For the first time since the law was enacted in 1948, the Board of Elections was called upon yesterday to pass upon the qualifications of two persons who had been denied the right to register last week. Previously, only a Supreme Court Justice had such power.

The Board of Education authorized the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, Inc., yesterday to conduct a March of Dimes campaign this year in the city's schools. The vote was 5 to 3, with one member absent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower uttered a friendly but plain rebuke today to all officers involved in the controversy with the armed forces, including his old wartime subordinate, Gen. Omar N. Bradley.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- A former Tucker Corporation employe told in Federal District Court today how he averaged about thirteen miles to the gallon of gas on a long trip in a Tucker car, described in early publicity as being capable of thirty-five to sixty-five miles to the gallon.

Unless 135 milk companies in the metropolitan area and unions representing their 15,000 drivers are able to reach agreement today in a contract dispute, the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service will intervene.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Five Republican members of the House of Representatives, in a joint statement, expressed today their opposition to recognition by the United States of any Communist Government in China.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- The Court of Appeals heard arguments today and will decide tomorrow an appeal from a lower court order invalidating the endorsement by the American Labor Party of Edmund H. Caddy, Republican candidate for District Attorney of Kings County.

Trucks loaded with highly explosive materials are rolling through the Holland Tunnel every day in direct defiance of the law, delegates to the fourteenth annual Northeastern Regional Conference on Highway and Motor Vehicle Problems were told yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- The Isbrandtsen Company, New York ship operators, withdrew without explanation today the suit it filed in the Federal court here last April against twenty-three members of the crew of the freighter Flying Arrow.

" Beyond the Forest," a Warner Brothers romantic drama starring Bette Davis, will have its local premiere this morning at the Strand. King Vidor directed and Henry Blanke produced the offering from a screen play by Lenore Coffee and the novel by Stuart Engstrand.

With the objective of educating the public in proper methods of smoke control, a conference sponsored by three engineering societies will be held next Thursday and Friday at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, William H. Byrne, director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, announced yesterday.

Saying that a $500,000,000 housing program had been started during his administration, Mayor O'Dwyer charged yesterday that Newbold Morris, his Republican-Liberal-Fusion opponent, had done little to bring about better housing conditions, of which he now complains, during the eleven years that he held city office.

Speaking at a luncheon in Town Hall, sponsored by the Citizens Union, Controller Lazarus Joseph said yesterday that the financial position of the city is sound because of the prudent fiscal policies carried out by the present city administration.

Two statements by President Truman depressed the stock market yesterday but a subsequent rally left prices no worse than mixed to slightly lower on the day. The observations by the President at his press conference that the next session of Congress would be asked to increase taxes and that he plans no intervention in the coal and steel strikes found the market vulnerable and quotations dropped quickly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 15 were 13 per cent lower than sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:
The current controversy between the Navy and the Air Corps goes much deeper than the question of what type of plane will win the next war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Several resolutions asking equal opportunity for Negroes with other students in military training were adopted at today's final meeting of the presidents of Negro land grant colleges.
The world paid tribute yesterday to a reluctant guest, Dr. John Dewey, world-renowned philosopher and educator, on his ninetieth birthday.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- A formula for obtaining a $300,000 church property for $110,000 despite inflated construction costs was being evolved here today by a small congregation that hopes to grow faster in size and activities than in budget.

CATSKILL, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Former Hudson River Day Line properties at Caskill Point, Newburgh, Albany Kingston, and Hudson were put up for auction here today by Joseph P. Day, Inc., at the Saulpaugh Hotel. Stephen McDonald, vice president of the realty company, conducted the sales.

Newbold Morris, the Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer's word was worthless. The Mayor was so lacking in mental integrity that political intimates of his own party referred to him as a "double-crosser," he asserted.

Crawling along the floor of a smoke-filled bedroom in a crowded tenement at 376 Lexington Avenue, Brooklyn, a Department of Sanitation sweeper saved from death yesterday a 9-month-old girl. The rescuer, unknowingly, left behind to die the infant's brother, 2.

Competitive action resulting from foreign currency devaluation is unlikely to affect this country's paper and pulp industry for the immediate future, an official of the American Paper and Pulp Association declared yesterday in reporting on a closed meeting of the group's board of directors in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 -- Research and safety goals in metal working which have been sought for more than twenty-five years have finally been attained, and now new high-speed standards of production inspection can soon be used commercially in any metal products plant, scientists revealed here today at the thirty-first national Metal Congress and Exposition.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 20 -- The three Western powers and the Western German Federal Republic agreed today to a joint program of commercial and financial aid to rescue Western Berlin from economic doldrums, authoritative sources said tonight.

After consulting the almanac, Maurice Schwartz is performing the annual rite of putting on a new play at the Yiddish Art Theatre in Second Avenue. This year's offering is a folk comedy, "Yosele, the Nightingale," which Mr. Schwartz has made out of Sholem Aleichem's novel and which he formally opened last evening.

WHEN John Ruskin was young he tried to further his ineffectual courtship of a coy maiden by writing a book review for a magazine edited by the young lady's father. As might be expected, no good came from this unusual distortion of the noble art of criticism. And Ruskin's frustration was increased by his conviction, quite a conventional one among writers, that the best parts of his review were cut out.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 -- Establishment of community dental health programs throughout the country, with priority treatment for children, was called for today by the house of delegates of the American Dental Association.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 20 -- Charles Sawyer, United States Secretary of Commerce and Mexico's official guest, said today that "travel between our two countries" is one of the best means of overcoming an unfavorable trade balance and its consequent dollar shortage. He spoke at the annual convention of the American Society of Travel Agents, which was opened this morning by President Miguel Aleman the Fine Arts Palace.
PARIS, Oct. 20 (UP) -- Nine top United States diplomats from both sides of the Iron Curtain will convene here tomorrow to review the United States' position in Europe.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 20 -- Korean army sources said today that North Korean Communist forces had succeeded in wresting from their control a strategic hilltop on Ongjin Peninsula after five days of bitter fighting.
May I comment on your editorial in THE TIMES of Oct. 10, "Loyalty in the Schools"?

The shorter length for evening, or Romantic Look, as it was called, was hailed yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in the Rosette Pennington showing of after-dark fashions for gala nights and entertaining at home. Styles for the cocktail hour played their part too in French adaptations, custom order and ready-made creations.

A two-phase drill, featuring defensive dummy scrimmage, marked Fordham's final contact session yesterday preparatory to tomorrow's encounter with Syracuse at the Polo Grounds. There will be only a light limbering-up session today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Mexico shook off a jittery curtain - raising performance and roared bak to topnotch form in international jumping competition tonight at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 20 -- Last season and the year before football squads at St. Mark's school enjoyed good times. However, the picture during the current campaign is not too rosy at this scenic New England institution, founded in 1865. In fact, Head Coach Ben Howarth is quite ready to admit things look bleak.

Two individuals and two airlines received last night the first safety awards offered by Aviation Week, a trade magazine. The prizes were presented at a dinner given by the Flight Safety Foundation, Inc., a private, non-profit organization to disseminate air safety information. Citations were handed to winners before an audience of representatives of the organizations, airlines, aircraft manufacturers and the Navy in the Administration Building at La Guardia Airport.

Despite a 19 per cent drop in the net income of the General Electric Company in the nine months ended on Sept. 30 the third quarter of 1949 "marked a complete reversal of the unstable but steadily downward trend" which characterized the demand for G-E products in the second quarter of this year, Charles E. Wilson, president, said yesterday.

Formation of an educational committee to combat the "serious growth of loss-leader sales in this area," was disclosed yesterday at a meeting of the Greater New York Retail Grocers Conference at a private uptown meeting place.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Crispin Oglebay's Lock and Key lowered the track record for two and a half miles over brush by two seconds today in the Chevy Chase Steeplechase Handicap.

With current contracts of two American Federation of Labor maritime unions due to expire at the end of this month, two developments taking place today are expected to determine the question of peace along the city's waterfront.

Yugoslavia won election to the United Nations Security Council yesterday, defeating Soviet-backed Czechoslovakia on the second ballot by a vote of 39 to 19. The voting gave Yugoslavia the exact minimum needed to win under the two-thirds rule.
The first hints of a break in the steel strike emerged yesterday from Government-sponsored mediation conferences.

Weather, which has played hob with the plans of coffee growers in Brazil, struck another blow, albeit distant, at coffee consumers here this week when floods destroyed crops of growers in major areas of Guatemala. The losses suffered in the Central American country brought closer the $1-a-pound price that has been predicted for consumers in the United States.
The General Electric Company offered yesterday a broadened program of insurance and pension benefits to its 125,000 workers represented by the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO.

As soon as the city makes its award of work to be done on constructing the new Hunts Point sewage treatment plant in the Bronx, toward which $15,597,129 in low bids have been submitted, more than $50,000,000 worth of new sewage facilities will be under contract, Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, said yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 20 -- The Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, took issue here today with what he described as the "religious uniformity" of the Roman Catholic Church as opposed to the Protestant principle of the "right of private judgment."

The job of directing Columbia's winged-T attack against mighty Army at West Point tomorrow probably will fall upon a sophomore. Bob Russell, regular Light Blue quarterback is suffering from a painful carbuncle on his hip and the plan is to have Kermit Tracy call the signals, it was revealed yesterday by Coach Lou Little.

Estimated net income of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, Inc., in the third quarter of 1949 was slightly less than the net profit in the similar period of last year, but the earnings for the first nine months of the current year were more than $1,200,000 above those of the corresponding period of 1948, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Navy said today the scheduled discharge of several hundred workers in shipyards at New York and Norfolk have been canceled because of "high-priority" work required on ships in those yards.

Most important news yesterday from the City Department of Markets related to the drop, long hoped for by cost-conscious consumers, in egg prices. The medium-sized Grade A's, it developed in the department's weekly check of retail stores, are off 8 cents a dozen from last week-end.

A distinguished violin recital was presented in Town Hall last night by Cecilia Hansen, a handsome Danish artist who has not been heard here for more than twenty years. That the memory of her playing was still alive was testified by the warm greeting given her by a largely professional audience.

Investigation of an alleged shakedown of business concerns in connection with income tax returns has resulted in suspension of five employes of the Third District Internal Revenue office, Assistant United States Attorney Thomas Murphy announced yesterday.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 20--American investment in world stability on an "heroic scale," instead of in "homeopathic doses of fifteen million dollars,' was called for today by Barbara Ward, British economist, as a measure for combatting Communistic infiltration.

Daniel Frisch, president of Zionist Organization of America, called on former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and John Foster Dulles, Democratic and Republican candidates for United States Senator, last night to issue public declaration on Jerusalem and to request the Government to repudiate any plan that would sever the Holy City from Israel.
New York State leads the country in successful small businesses, Harold Keller, Commissioner of the State Department of Commerce, said yesterday at the Astor Hotel.
TORONTO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Football is due for a court case parallel to the much publicized suit this year against organized baseball in the United States by Danny Gardella, Max Lanier and Fred Martin.

HONG KONG, Oct. 20 -- The Communist-dominated Peiping Government announced today a Cabinet of thirty-seven Ministers. The announcement produced an immediate surprise here over its large size. The way in which posts were distributed widely among non-Communist-party members also occasioned prompt comment.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 20 -- Soft-coal operators all but asked outright today for Government intervention in the stalled wage negotiations, but no summons to Washington arrived.

Western Europe has "a long way to go" to acquire a "reasonably healthy" defense, Senator Millard E. Tydings, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, declared yesterday on his return from an arms survey of Great Britain, France and the Benelux countries, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

There will be big games on both banks of the Harlem next Sunday and two of the local professional footbal coaches -- Steve Owen of the National League Giants and Red Strader of the rival All-America Yankees -- are hoping that their teams will be the victors.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- The Court of Appeals unanimously upheld today the action of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, Staten Island, and the New York Foundling Hospital in refusing to release three children to a father who gave up his citizenship in 1947 to return to Soviet Russia.

The first thing that struck one last night at the second subscription program given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall was that the orchestra sounded superbly. This had not been true of the first concert a week earlier.

C. M. Chester, chairman of the New York chapter, American Red Cross, told its forty-third annual meeting yesterday in the Commodore Hotel that the chapter has spent two dollars for every dollar contributed to it by the public since 1946.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Some weeks ago, when appropriation bills passed by the House were clogged in Senate committees and a bipartisan majority was declining to advance major units of what the President calls his "Fair Deal" program, this correspondent pointed out that nevertheless the Eighty-first Congress at its first session in no way merited the current criticism that it was a "do-nothing" body.
SAN MATEO, Calif., Oct. 20 -- Stymie -- a quarter horse, not the all-time money-winning champion -- raced to victory at Bay Meadows today.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 -- Gus Waser, chef de cuisine of the Los Angeles Biltmore Hotel, died today at his home of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 15 were 583,913 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,685 cars or 1.7 per cent more than for the preceding week, 329,044 cars or 36.0 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 370,236 cars or 38.8 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 20 (AP)--An American Red Cross official said today that he believed only 500 were dead instead of the Government's earlier estimate of 4,000 in the Guatemalan floods.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared today that the way to solve a current shortage of venture capital was through changes in the Federal tax structure, not through expansion of Federal lending to business.

Business loans made by banks in this area rose $12,000,000 last week, registering the smallest advance in eight successive weekly rises. Data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, covering the week ended on Wednesday, showed that for the first time in the eight-week period, the majority of the twenty-four reporting New York City member banks experienced reductions in their loan totals.
The State of Louisiana announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on Nov. 29 an issue of $10,000,000 tax-exempt highway bonds dated Nov. 1, 1949, due Nov. 1, 1953 to 1964, and callable in 1954.

Broadway was agog the other day anent a report that Jack Pearl, ousted treasurer of the Majestic, who stood upon his constitutional rights in refusing to answer questions put to him by Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh concerning the distribution of "South Pacific" tickets, would be re-engaged by the Shuberts at the Mansfield, a house they are operating in behalf of the lessee, DuMont Television.

Senator John Foster Dulles declared yesterday that the "violent eruption" in the national defense establishment was a product of the "utter confusion and discord" that comes from a too powerful central government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Leland Olds, recently turned down by the Senate for a third-term membership in the Federal Power Commission, was publicly promised a post by President Truman today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A new firm, the Columbus Transit Company, was organized here yesterday to take over all transportation operations of the Columbus Southern Ohio Electric Company. The CTC, with W. Glover Porter, counsel for Columbus Southern, as president, expects to begin operations by Nov. 1.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and prices at the close were net 6 points higher to 6 points lower than Wednesday's close.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that service on the Queens Boulevard line of the IND subway division would be improved, beginning Monday, by the addition of four ten-car trains during the morning and evening rush hours.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Passage of farm legislation guaranteeing farmers 90 per cent of parity loans on 1950 production of wheat and corn brought in general buying of grains on the Board of Trade today, with May and July wheat and September oats selling at new seasonal highs.

The city administration intends to carry out its incineration program as quickly as possible, including the construction of the $10,000,000 Gansevoort plant, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday afternoon as he laid the cornerstone for the Gansevoort Meat Center at Washington and Little West Twelfth Street.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- Opposed to the evolving philosophy of United States foreign policy as summarized yesterday in the words of one of its sponsors is a more dynamic and, therefore, more precise Soviet creed. This comprises a melange of Stalinist political ideology and Russian national aspirations that have been amalgamated by the Kremlin.

Fred Meyer has sold the four-story building containing two stores and ten apartments at 720 Grand Street and 269 Graham Avenue, Brooklyn, to Anna Berger. A purchase money mortgage of $35,000 was executed at the closing of title to the property, which is assessed at $46,000. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.
The United Nations General Assembly decided yesterday at Flushing Meadow to shelve its half-completed treaty on freedom of information -- at least until the 1950 session.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The election of Yugoslavia to the United Nations Security Council was regarded here today as a significant advance, at a calculated risk, in the United States' effort to bring Belgrade into the Western camp.

New issues of public utility securities valued at more than $47,500,000 will be offered to investors today. One of the offerings represents a refunding of long-term bonds by Indianapolis Power Light Company to get the benefit of current low interest rates.

AS if it isn't difficult enough to make the correct selections, Notre Dame is playing a most shabby trick on all gridiron guessers tomorrow. The Fighting Irish are taking a day off and therefore the only certain victory on the card has vanished. But fools rush in where angels fear to tread and so . . .
A spring exhibition schedule for 1950 of twenty-two games was announced yesterday by Branch Rickey, boss of the Brooks.

Ronald Henry Farah, 5 years old, son of Mrs. Frances Farah of 176 Seeler Street, Brooklyn, and Henry Farah, a lingerie manufacturer, of 50 East Tenth Street, lost his suit yesterday to set aside his mother's Reno divorce. Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter dismissing the complaint "without prejudice."

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Nervousness over the measures to be announced by Government next week to meet the crisis was reflected in continued weakness and increased liquidation throughout the stock markets here today. Even South African gold mining issues, which had resisted the decline of the last two weeks, joined in the retreat.

More than half of the trading floor members of the New York Stock Exchange moved yesterday for greater representation on the board of governors. In a petition which the board will consider at its next meeting on Nov. 3, the 422 signatories declared that the streamlining of the governing body effected in 1938 and in 1941 had "exceeded the limits not only of good management but also of adequate representation of active floor members."
Plans for new construction work filed in the city yesterday included housing for sites in West Fourteenth and Fifteenth Streets to cost $300,000.

Robert F. Wagner called yesterday for the election of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate, to the seat in the United States Senate that Mr. Wagner vacated last June because of ill health.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Truman announced formally today that he would submit to Congress early next year a financial plan for a considerable expansion of atomic-bomb production by the Atomic Energy Commission.

Defining American assistance to other nations as always "marginal assistance," Secretary of State Dean Acheson said last night that the success of that aid depended primarily on the recipients' own "will and effort."

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The Police of eight European countries were closing in today on a big air-sea smuggling ring that might be transporting "pay-off gold" to Wesern Europe from behind the Iron Curtain.

Governor Dewey renewed his criticism yesterday of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for refusing to debate campaign issues with John Foster Dulles, Mr. Lehman's Republican opponent in the United States Senate contest.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- Louis Waldman, counsel for the International Longshoremen's Association, urged at a public hearing today that proposed rules for administration of the state's new disability benefits law be changed to insure benefits for longshoremen and "thousands of others similarly situated."

I. J. Berni, manager of the Cincinnati district office of Procter Gamble Company, yesterday urged office management executives to eliminate correspondence filing wherever possible and to reduce it appreciably where elimination is not possible.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- During the week ended Oct. 19, member bank reserve balances increased $289,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
This is my first year in this country and I was astonished to see the city of New York commemorating Columbus Day as an exclusively American-Italian occasion.

A man who identified himself as a war veteran caused a flurry last night when he leaped onto the speakers' platform at the Brooklyn Labor Lyceum, 949 Willoughby Avenue, as Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, started to speak.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- There is a growing feeling in Whitehall and the City of London that the Government has found its necessity of curtailing expenditure incompatible with a desire to preserve the social services and the defense establishment intact.

Snow swirled into the Great Plains on icy winds yesterday, leaving three persons dead and one missing in the snow-blanketed Rockies, The Associated Press reported. An entire quarter of the country, from the Dakotas, Nebraska and Kansas westward to the Pacific Ocean, had cold weather.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 20 -- Combining global with local character, and with fingers gingerly crossed, officials of the United Nations have selected "The Sidewalks of New York" as a theme song for the cornerstone ceremony next Monday, when the fifty-nine-nation General Assembly meets in a plenary session outdoors on Forty-second Street.

The Columbia Broadcasting System is planning a comedy television program for Robert Q. Lewis, which will start in the latter part of November on a Friday night. The comedian substituted for Arthur Godfrey on both his morning radio programs and his Wednesday night television show during the summer.

A vacant plot 54 by 200 feet on the east side of Franklin Avenue, 225 feet north of Ninth Street, in Garden City, L. I., has been purchased by the R. C. B. Property, Inc., of which Charles Ryan is president, for improvement with a one-story taxpayer.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Experimental evidence was presented here today that the hypothalamus, a part of the forebrain designated as the "seat of the emotions," secretes a vital hormone necessary for the activation of the all-important pituitary and the adrenal glands in response to stress.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- By a comfortable margin, the French National Assembly tonight gave its approval to the designation of Rene Mayer, a Radical and former Minister of Finance, as Premier.

Your older readers will recall the grave concern of the solid citizens when the campaign for the election of Senators by popular vote got under way. It was feared that under the new plan the states would be represented by vote-getting nonentities instead of the ablest men available.

Our John Wm., who rarely fails to bring back at least part of a purse, took the winner's share of $3,275 for Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs in the best of the Empire City-at-Jamaica divertissements yesterday. Once he had shaken off Greentree's Wine List, Our John Wm. had a front-running romp.

Because of dwindling fuel supplies as a result of the coal strike, eighty-nine passenger trains of the New York Central Railroad will be withdrawn from service at midnight tomorrow, the line announced yesterday.
This is a big day for openings, with the waterfowl season getting started at noon and the pheasant and grouse season beginning at 9 A. M. Long Island counties are excepted in the upland game list.

The Sadler's Wells Ballet has given us a number of fine things in its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, but its presentation of "Le Lac des Cygnes" last night stands head and shoulders above them all. It is absurd that New York has never before seek a full four-act version of this famous masterpiece, but to have a first glimpse of it in such a production as this makes the waiting worth while.

With special ceremonies attended by 2,000 persons before the Subtreasury Building downtown, and in visits by 6,645 adults and children, the city yesterday welcomed the New York State Freedom Train for a ten-day stay in mid-Manhattan.

OTTAWA, Oct. 20 -- Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott reintroduced in the House of Commons this evening the budget that he presented last March. It became effective immediately on presentation but it had never been ratified as Parliament was dissolved on April 30 to permit of a general election.

The business news columns have been reporting on developments in men's spring clothing marts and up to a certain point the news has been good. It is possible that next spring men will be able to purchase suits in certain lines at prices $2.50 to $5 less than those prevailing last spring.
Benjamin Feldman's third trial for the murder of his young wife got off to a brisk start yesterday in Kings County Court.

General Eisenhower put his finger yesterday on the primary consideration in the minds of most Americans who are thinking about the inter-service quarrel when he concentrated on unification. However, it was not an accusing finger, but a quietly warning one. Perhaps that is what the situation requires.

Our John Wm., who rarely fails to bring back at least part of a purse, took the winner's share of $3,275 for Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs in the best of the Empire City-at-Jamaica divertissements yesterday. Once he had shaken off Greentree's Wine List, Our John Wm. had a front-running romp.

Because of dwindling fuel supplies as a result of the coal strike, eighty-nine passenger trains of the New York Central Railroad will be withdrawn from service at midnight tomorrow, the line announced yesterday.
Benjamin Feldman's third trial for the murder of his young wife got off to a brisk start yesterday in Kings County Court.

General Eisenhower put his finger yesterday on the primary consideration in the minds of most Americans who are thinking about the inter-service quarrel when he concentrated on unification. However, it was not an accusing finger, but a quietly warning one. Perhaps that is what the situation requires.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The United Corporation, New York, received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to distribute to its common stockholders, as a special capital dividend, 15 per cent of the 9,580,988 shares of common stock of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, Syracuse, N. Y.
HONG KONG, Friday, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Chinese Communist troops today were believed nearing Kweilin, headquarters for Nationalist Gen. Pai Chung-hsi's last-ditch defense in Southwest China.

GENEVA, Oct. 20 -- The governments that are members of the International Refugee Organization advised the United Nations today that plans for permanent international measures to deal with the refugee problem should be ready to go into effect by Jan. 1, 1951.
American Airlines announced yesterday that it had asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to operate "coach type" air service between New York and Los Angeles.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 20 (AP) -- A $1,01.80 daily double provided the chief thrill at Garden State Park today. Speedy Jo, winner of the opener at $54.80, and Cafe Singer, victorious in the second race at $42.40, combined to produce the big return for a $2 bet.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- An attack on the social ills that produce delinquency, as well as the individualized treatment approach, was urged today by Lloyd W. McCorkle, acting assistant director of the Division of Classification and Education of the New Jersey Department of Institutions and Agencies.

About seven months after legislative action creating, at Governor Dewey's request, a new State Building Code Commission the Governor has appointed the five members of that body, to be headed by Col. Edward J. McGrew Jr. This commission will attempt to bring common sense and some uniformity into diverse and antiquated local building regulations.
PURCHASE, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- A 36-hole aggregate of 141 enabled Claude Harmon of Winged Foot to retain the Westchester P. G. A. title today at the Century Country Club.

A five-man ring that allegedly smuggled huge quantities of genuine Irish sweepstakes tickets into the United States on transatlantic planes was smashed yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

TOKYO, Oct. 20 -- Signs of strain are beginning to appear in the occupation's hold-the-line policy on wages and prices. In the year since enforcement began both wholesale and retail prices have risen 20 per cent and labor is beginning to chafe under the virtual strike prohibition by Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Oct. 20 -- Warner Brothers tonight said Ginger Rogers would have the starring role in "Storm Center" replacing Lauren Bacall, whose suspension for refusing to appear in the picture was announced by the studio in an unusual manner late last night.
The United States was re-elected yesterday for a three-year term on the United Nations Economic and Social Council at the plenary meeting of the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow.

The American public has forgotten the seafaring heritage that played a major role in the development of this nation, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A 47 per cent increase in current-year apportionment of Federal funds for construction of airports throughout the country was approved, with little notice, during the closing days of the first session of the Eighty-first Congress which ended last night.

Ira Guilden, chairman of the Trade Bank and Trust Company, and a group of associates have contracted to purchase a large block of the stock of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, it was learned yesterday. The development, according to financial observers, may mark the first step in a program leading to consolidation of the two institutions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The new Midwest Stock Exchange, scheduled to begin operations in Chicago in mid-December and determined to get a larger share of the securities business, will not find itself in conflict with the New York Stock Exchange so long as it moves in the direction of "implanting" and not "diluting" the New York market.

The Men's Fashion Guild of America will issue a seal of approval to men's wear merchandise that passes a rigid test for value, quality and fashion, it was announced yesterday at a spring clinic of the organization in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 20 -- Any United Nations program for technical aid to underdevoloped countries should pay due regard to the pressing need for improved press, radio and film services in these areas, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization concluded today in a new report.
Net earnings of the Hercules Powder Company in the first nine months of this year were $7,373,722, according to the report to be released today.

A row of five two-story apartment houses with ten stores at 152-54 West 103d Street and 873-75 Amsterdam Avenue was sold by the Central Savings Bank to the Sassoon Realty Corporation, which insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company Samuel Cowen was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed for $139,000.

Bankers dollar acceptances outstanding throughout the nation on Sept. 30 totaled $207,169,000, compared with $189,313,000 at the end of August and $214,147,000 on Sept. 30, 1948, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The Trinity Evangelical Church of Brooklyn has sold the two-story dwelling at 215 Ninety - fourth Street in that borough to Soren Karsten Staaby. August Sorenson was the broker. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured the title.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Navy announced today that next month it would conduct the largest peacetime maneuvers ever held in North Atlantic waters.
The Grant Monument Association held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Chamber of Commerce, 65 Liberty Street, and re-elected Lieut Gen. Cornelius W. Wickersham, retired, as president.

Those who were unable to find a pheasant yesterday in the covers of Westchester, Putnam or Dutchess, may exercise their dogs and get some pheasants for the oven at the first of the pheasant shoots of the Southern New York Field Trial Club, to be held at Goldens Bridge tomorrow.

DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 21 -- A liberal education that stresses the humanistic studies and turns to the poets and philosophers for the unifying thread in a bewildered world is "a paramount necessity" for civilization in the atomic age.

The deputies for the Foreign Ministers of the Big Four powers, negotiating the text of a state treaty for Austria in sessions at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, decided yesterday that "sufficient progress has been made" to warrant an extension of their current talks at least until Oct. 28 and perhaps even into November.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 21 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Western German Federal Republic, carried the political struggle for Germany into the Communist camp today when he proclaimed his republic's "responsibility" for the 18,000,000 Germans of the Eastern zone and pledged extensive economic aid for Western Berlin.
BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Secretary Johnson's assertion before the House committee that he asked for Mr. Sullivan's resignation as Secretary of the Navy met with a flat denial tonight.
When applied to certain hams on the market, "ready to eat" is a term that should not always be taken literally. It may mean the meat is safe to eat, and yet not tender enough to enjoy.
New York will be "attacked" this afternoon by American fliers in a mock. bombing raid in which the metropolis will be defended by reserve fighter pilots of the United States and Canada.

Brooklyn College will seek its second victory in four starts today when it faces Northeastern University on its Flatbush gridiron. It is the first daylight game of the season for the Kingsmen, with the kick-off slated for 2:30 P. M.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (UP) -- At least seventy-seven hunters have died over the nation since Sept 1 as the annual fall shooting season approaches full swing, a United Press survey showed today.

Ten of the eleven Communist leaders convicted of criminal conspiracy last week were sentenced yesterday to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine each. The eleventh got three years and a $10,000 fine.

Government revenues -- which, so far as the man in the street is concerned, means federal taxes -- are expected to total between $38 and $39 billions for the present fiscal year. This means that Americans are being taxed at a rate almost ten times the $4 billion annual average of the two decades between the two World Wars.
Chances for settling the paralyzing steel and coal strikes neared the vanishing point last night as Federal officials admitted that the country was "within ten days of an industrial crisis."

HONG KONG, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Independent Chinese press reports indicated tonight that Kweilin would fall in a matter of days, despite a Nationalist announcement that the Red drive against that South China headquarters city had been checked.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 21 -- Czechoslovakia jailed a United States Embassy clerk today and demanded the immediate recall of an Embassy attache on charges that they were running a spy ring "directed against the security" of this Communist-led nation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A new health consultation service to states under the auspices of the Children's Bureau was announced today to State and Territorial health officers.

The Amtorg Trading Corporation, Russia's purchasing agency in this country, and six of its officers were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Washington for failure to register under the Foreign Agents Registration Act.
Both the football Giants and Brooklyn - Yankees announced themselves as ready for their respective battles with the Chicago Bears and the San Francisco Forty-Niners tomorrow afternoon.

Two motions to dismiss the charge of low flying against Capt. George R. Neuhauser were denied yesterday by Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate in the municipal term of Magistrates Court, Long Island City, Queens.
The activities of the Women's Division in the United Hospital Fund campaign for $3,367,000 has produced results exceeding last year's, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Frank E. Adair, chairman.
LONG BRANCH, N. J., Oct. 21 -- Englewood's two professional golfers, Vic Ghezzi and Jerry Volpe, made off with all three prizes in a New Jersey P. G. A. pro-amateur tournament today at Old Orchard.

Challenging Mayor O'Dwyer to a debate on housing, Representative Vito Marcantonio asserted last night that more houses in this city will fall apart in the next four years than will be built in that time.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and prices at the close were 3 to 6 points net lower.

Waterfront peace was assured yesterday for at least two years when a majority of the 50,000 active longshoremen in Atlantic Coast ports voted to accept the terms of a new contract reached by representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the New York Shipping Association.
Governor Dewey sought to advance the Republican cause in state and local elections yesterday by declaring that New York State surpassed all others in the soundness of its credit.
Like the ubiquitous rubber plant or aspidistra, statuary by John Rogers once occupied a conspicuous place in nearly every United States home on marble-topped table or pedestal.

With local transportation at Swatow, China, suspended following seizure of the city this week by the Communists, airplanes are being used to rush merchandise out of the area, it was reported yesterday by David Sutton, partner in A. D. Sutton Sons, 15 West Thirty-seventh Street, importers of Chinese hand-embroidered handkerchiefs.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 21 (AP) -- While Belgrade's press blazed with headlines telling of Yugoslavia's triumph in the United Nations yesterday, the Government sent a bitter note to Poland today, accusing her of "ceaseless hostilities" against this country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Department of Defense, in line with its economy theme, issued figures today to show where savings already had been achieved in the nation's military establishment.

Acting the role of the traditionally coy Broadway producer, Michael Todd yesterday finally conceded over the telephone that he is working on plans for a revue. The project, admitted Mr. Todd somewhat reluctantly, is tentatively entitled "The Tired Business Man's Revue."

Members of the board of directors and superintendents of homes for the aged affiliated with the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies conferred yesterday on the advantages of participating in the federation's Aged Intake Service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered passenger service curtailments on railroads with short supplies of coal. It declared that reserves, in some cases, had reached "a dangerously low level" as a result of the soft coal strike in the East.

Roman Catholics will take part tomorrow in a world-wide appeal for financial support of 80,000 Roman Catholic foreign missionaries in many countries in programs started twenty-five years ago by Pope Pius XI, who established the day as Mission Sunday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The Roman Catholic Church warned its priests today that they would betray and dishonor their faith if they supported the new church-state laws while "hundreds of thousands groan in jails and labor camps."

The desperate economic plight of Berlin is at last being recognized and met by positive action. As the Allied High Commissioners said in their statement yesterday, there was need for immediate action. It is a case of better late than never, for the situation has bordered on the desperate for months.

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- The probability of the fulfillment of Soviet promises of a separate peace treaty with the new Eastern German state have faded materially, the Tag, Western licensed Christian Democratic newspaper, reported today. Second thoughts in the Kremlin after Western diplomats had declared that such action would constitute a breach of the Yalta Agreement, have inspired an abrupt change in attitude among representatives of the Eastern Government, the paper added.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 21 -- The National Council of the Fatherland Front, meeting today, decided to expel from the Council Ivan Maslarov and Petko Kunin, former Finance Minister, for "espionage and treason." Parliament will be asked to deprive them of their mandates as members of Parliament.
