When you suggest in the editorial "Music and the Tax Collector" that the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra would not have incurred a "deficit for its 1948-49 season if it had been able to keep the moneys turned over to the Government," and when you further plead that the wartime emergency taxes should be repealed, there appears to be a confusion of ideas.

William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, assailed yesterday the sentencing and jailing of his Communist colleagues by Judge Harold R. Medina. A co-defendant of the eleven, Foster was not put on trial because of ill-health.

The Traffic Commission recommended yesterday that the city apply immediately to the Federal Works Administration for a grant of $600,000 for an economic survey and funds to design six proposed off-street parking facilities to cost $13,000,000.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer of the United States said today that Mexicans and other Latin Americans might be able to travel north of the Rio Grande in larger numbers soon because prices would probably be lower in the United States before long.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- At a reunion of 10,000 veterans of Britain's desert campaign against Germany and Italy, Winston Churchill announced tonight his opposition to the discontinuance of military conscription suggested as a means of saving money in this country's current financial crisis.

TOKYO, Oct. 21. -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur cracked down today on plans by the conservative Japanese Government to revise the land reform program under which the Allies since 1946 have transferred more than 5,000,000 acres of cultivated land from tenant peasantry to newly created farmer owners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged in the week ended on Oct. 18, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 152.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.2 per cent below four weeks ago and 8.3 per cent below the comparable week of 1948.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 -- The big toe of Dick Haesler, a junior from Montclair, N. J., meant the difference between a tie and victory for Georgetown University's eleven tonight. Attempting a field goal with the score 7-all and two and a half minutes remaining, Haesler made good with a 30-yard boot from placement that beat Boston College, 10 to 7, before a crowd of 22,763 at Braves Field.

Australia and Guatemala proposed yesterday that the United Nations General Assembly, instead of reaching a decision at this session on Eritrea, send out a special committee to the former Italian colony to study the situation and report its recommendations to the 1950 Assembly.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Young People's Concert, Igor Buketoff, conductor; John Corigliano, violin; William Lincer, viola; Leonard Rose, 'cello; Theodore Cella, harp, Town Hall, 11 A. M.; Grace Castagnetta, piano, Carnegie Hall 3; Katherine Bacon, piano, Town Hall, 3.
Rivals with years of tradition behind their games meet in the choice offerings on today's football card in the East and Middle West
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Llangollen Farm's Bullet Proof stuck his head in front in the last strides to win the featured Penn Athletic Club purse at Garden State Park today.

Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate in the New York senatorial race, hinted yesterday that he favored some modification of the United Nations plan for the internationalization of Jerusalem but declared he would advocate no change during the election campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- Elimination of the Marine Corps as an assault force would mean the defeat of this country in another war, Col. Melvin J. Maas, national president of the corps' Reserve Officers Association, warned here today.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Canadian Army jumping team flashed championship form tonight to edge into second place in the Pennsylvania national horse show international competition.
Federal, state and city mediators began efforts yesterday to prevent a three-state milk delivery strike at 4 P. M. Monday by 15,000 drivers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The oil heater industry expects greater sales because of the coal strike, but it hopes the steel strike won't keep it from filling orders. A 20 per cent jump in 1950 sales is expected.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 21 -- Two authorities on the atomic bomb, Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves and Dr. Harold G. Urey, expressed opposite views today on the value of retaining military secrecy in connection with atomic energy development.

The capacity of THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial writers for calmly ignoring what its news columns report is sometimes awe-inspiring. Day after day since Sept. 15 there has been spread upon your pages the record of as unprincipled a campaign as this state has ever seen.
The United Nations Commission on Korea received an indefinite extension of life yesterday and explicit instructions to watch out for outbreaks that could lead to civil war in the country.

In an informal report on operations of the city's Smoke Control Bureau in the three months in which it has been at work as an independent unit, Director William H. Byrne has done well to emphasize to the public the incomplete job he has been able to do with only four inspectors.

As a step toward cutting down juvenile delinquency and a measure of protection for motorists themselves, we welcome the action of the City Council to prohibit leaving a motor vehicle unattended without locking the ignition and removing the key. The proposed law, which must be approved by the Board of Estimate, would subject the driver to a fine or imprisonment if he leaves his vehicle for more than three minutes without removing the key.

A leading public health administrator, a nurse, and six physicians distinguished for medical research were named yesterday as 1949 winners of the annual Lasker Awards of the American Public Health Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 --Employers will begin depositing social security taxes monthly when higher rates go into effect Jan. 1, it was made known today. The employers also will continue to make quarterly returns, according to the Internal Revenue Bureau.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Premier Rene Mayer, in his efforts to form a Cabinet, encountered difficulties today with the Socialist party, which was threatening to refuse participation in the Government. Should there be no change in the present situation, it was thought that M. Mayer would resign, but at a late hour it was agreed that one more consultation would be held tomorrow in an attempt to reach an accord.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Overwhelming favorite to extend its winning streak to sixteen straight games, Army is nevertheless prepared for another close battle with Columbia in Michie Stadium tomorrow before a sell-out crowd of 27,000.

Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch granted to five taxpayers yesterday an order directing the Board of Elections to show cause next Wednesday why it should not be restrained from placing the name of Benjamin J. Davis Jr., convicted Communist, on the ballot for City Councilman.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Men who worked with Thomas Alva Edison when electricity was new made a pilgrimage today to this city, capital of the electrical empire. For five hours they trudged through the General Electric Company's plants and laboratories, gaping at the latest wonders that have grown from the incandescent bulb, invented seventy years ago today.

Ceremonies and speeches incidental to the laying of the cornerstone of the United Nations World Headquarters Building at Forty-second Street and the East River will be carried by all television networks on Monday from 12 noon to 1 P. M.

The American freighter John H. Marion made an emergency call here yesterday to land the body of a crew member killed during a heavy storm on Tuesday and to transfer to a hospital another injured seaman.

Ascribing St. Vincent's Hospital's $193,285 deficit for the first nine months of this year to high operating costs, Sister Loretto Bernard, administrator of the hospital, in her annual report yesterday asked the medical staff for more efficiency to help preserve the voluntary health system.

Manual Training's twice-beaten football team sent Boys High down to its first defeat, 7 -- 6, in the second game of a scholastic double-header at Ebbets Field last night. In the opener Brooklyn Tech outscored Madison, 26-13.

Officials of Calvert Distillers Corporation predicted yesterday that Christmas sales may exceed all previous records. About fifty division managers from all part of the country met at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to discuss holiday plans and prospects.
Donald D. Conners, and Kerrigan Iron Works Inc, in 274 Madison Ave; Glenbrook Woolen Mills Inc, in 221 4th Ave; Bennett F. Silverman and Herbert Drexler, in 100 5th Ave -- Boyd E. Wilson Co, brokers.

Fordham's strongest football team of the post-war era will be subjected to its first serious test today. Primed for the occasion by two impressive victories over lesser opposition, the Rams will tackle Syracuse at the Polo Grounds.

This country is too complacent regarding its interests and responsibilities in the Pacific, Mrs. Hiram C. Houghton of Red Oak, Iowa, vice president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, declared yesterday at its board of directors meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 21 -- Mrs. Yvette Madsen, 22-year-old Brooklyn woman, is being held in near-by Wiesbaden on a charge of the murder of her husband, Lieut. Andrew E. Madsen of the Air Force. She is accused of having shot him to death in their billet near the Rhein-Main airport.

A "disturbing" turn in contract talks between the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and the Atlantic and Gulf Cost ship operators' committee, was reported by shipping lines yesterday as negotiations were resumed after a week's delay.

HONG KONG, Oct. 21 -- The unusual size of the new Communist Central Government structure became still more apparent today with the publication of new details on the regime's organization in the English-language service of the Communist New China News Agency.

Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, who resigned as chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, charged last night that the Army-Navy unification war was typical of the "struggles and distortions" within business and Government that threaten prosperity.

DETROIT, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Lester Felton of Detroit, a comparative newcomer to the ring, turned in an upset ten-round decision over Kid Gavilan of Cuba tonight before 13,187 fans at Olympia. Gavilan is currently the No. 1 contender for Sugar Ray Robinson's welterweight title.
MOSCOW, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Russia has awarded her highest decoration -- the Order of Lenin -- to Peter Ivanovitch Parshin, Minister of the Machinery and Instrument Industry.
Mayor O'Dwyer charged yesterday that Senator John Foster Dulles would be of no help to the people of this city in obtaining social welfare legislation if he were returned to Congress.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- All was sweetness and light today on Capitol Hill as the House Armed Services Committee concluded its public hearings into the Navy-B-36 battle.

Coffee futures again advanced the daily permissible limit of 150 points for all delivery positions in trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Continued demand from producing countries and hedge covering by local trade interests held prices at the high throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The American Bosch Corporation, Springfield, Mass., registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a proposal to sell $4,000,000 worth of twenty-five-year sinking fund debentures.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct 21 -- Repeating their triumph of a year ago, Willie Goggin of Century and Fred Moore of Hudson River won the Metropolitan P. G. A. foursome championship at the Knollwood Country Club today with a 36-hole score of 142.
PARIS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- American small business men will get a chance for more orders under the Marshall Plan through a new buying system inaugurated by the Austrian Government.
Balmy weather, with the temperature fourteen degrees above normal, warmed the city yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The United Electrical Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations qualified today to do business with the National Labor Relations Board when its officers swore that they were not Communists and did not believe in overthrow of the Government by unconstitutional methods.

CAIRO, Oct. 21 -- The Arab League Political Committee, according to a reliable report, has decided, in view of the variety of opinions expressed yesterday, to advise the Arab delegates to the United Nations Conciliation Commission to continue their present stand on the Palestine issues.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Studies on animals indiciating the possibility of increasing or decreasing resistance or sensitivity to radiation were described here today at the closing sessions of the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Hector McNeil, Britain's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs and leader of her delegation to the United Nations, told the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations today that the United States could not escape a position of leadership in international affairs even if the American people wished to avoid it.

Nearly all hospitals have distinctive caps for their nurses no matter where they work the hospital at which they trained can be identified by the nurses' caps. Nurses are proud also of their training uniforms and most hospitals try to make theirs attractive.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 21 -- Dunbar Bostwick's Chris Spencer, 7-year-old bay gelding by Spencer -- Countess Christine by Volomite, driven superbly by Billy Haughton, scored a one-length victory over Proximity in the $10,000 final of the annual David H. McConnell Memorial mile and one-half trot in 3:08 3/5 at Roosevelt Raceway, tonight.

Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable, enjoying its greatest money - winning season, added $3,250 to its $400,000-plus total when Blue Hills won the best of yesterday's Empire City-at-Jamaica races.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Grain markets turned reactionary in the late trading on the Board of Trade today after an early showing of strength that carried May and July oats to a new seasonal high, and the deferred deliveries of wheat only a fraction of a cent under the previous high.

Fourteen prizes and two awards for honorable mention for winning posters and slogans submitted during Fire Prevention Week were awarded to uniformed firemen yesterday by Deputy Fire Commissioner James J. Moran at fire headquarters in the Municipal Building.

ROME, Oct. 21 -- The resignation of Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza was demanded in the Chamber of Deputies today by the leader of the Left-Wing Socialists, Pietro Nenni, during debate on the budget of the Foreign Ministry.

The two-story building at 215 Main Street, Closter, N. J., containing two stores and nine apartments, has been sold by the Bloomfield Hudson Corporation to the 215 Main Street Corporation. The sale was negotiated by the C. B. Snyder Realty Organization as broker.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Raymond R. Rausch, a vice president of General Electric Company, told a jury in Federal District Court today how Preston Tucker had offered him a $50,000-a-year job and then borrowed $500 from him. Mr. Rausch was the Government's forth witness in the reopened trial of Mr. Tucker and seven present and former associates in the Tucker automobile enterprise on charges of fraud and conspiracy.

DETROIT, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Immediate production cutbacks in the auto industry as a result of the steel strike foretell a "bleak Christmas" for the automotive worker, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Reports have been received here that the Soviet Union is making diplomatic preparations for the conclusion of a bilateral treaty of alliance and friendship with the new Chinese People's Republic of Mao Tze-tung.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The State Department today named Stanley Andrews, director of the Agriculture Department's Office of Foreign Agriculture Relations, to be United States delegate to the second session of the International Wheat Council to begin in London on Nov. 1.
A crowd of leftist sympathizers that reached a noontime peak of 800 persons gathered yesterday in Foley Square as Federal Judge Harold R. Medina pronounced sentence on the eleven Communist leaders.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 21 -- India and the Philippines joined today in launching a sharp attack on administering powers who have merged African and Pacific trust areas, legally under the jurisdiction of the United Nations, with their outright colonial possessions.
At midnight two weeks ago a doctor called the Department of Health to report that a woman and her teen-age daughter were critically ill of food poisoning.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Economies in domestic and overseas spending amounting to several hundred million pounds were agreed upon by the Cabinet in a two-and-a-half-hour meeting today. Their effects will be felt by every household in the land, but it is unlikely that they will involve any basic change in Socialist policy.

Reports of neglect of history in the schools of Virginia -- a state sometimes accused of living on its past -- are the more surprising because it is Virginia history in which a special commission set up by the Legislature has found its high school graduates deficient.

VIENNA, Oct. 21 -- Facilities for religious teaching, which the Hungarian Government specifically promised when it nationalized the schools last year, have not been provided, and the news from Budapest indicates they will not be.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The University of Miami Hurricanes struck for two quick touchdowns and then staved off a desperate rally to upset the University of Georgia in the Orange Bowl tonight, 13 to 9.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21 -- Robert Louis Stevenson's romantic novel of 1893, "David Balfour," will be shown next year by a Hollywood company in England and Scotland with Roddy McDowall in the title role.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- In New York's north country, in the St. Lawrence Valley region, Republican canvassers this week have indicated that Senator John Foster Dulles will pile up a bigger margin over former Governor Herbert H. Lehman in the area than Senator Irving M. Ives did in his race for office in 1946.

Retail sales here remained well below last year's figures during the week, according to estimates made yesterday. Department store sales were said to be about 17 per cent below the corresponding week last year, due partially to fairly warm weather and labor unrest. Sales last week were 20 per cent below last year.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 21 -- The Singer Manufacturing Company paid today an estimated $1,000,000 in vacation pay to more than 7,500 of its employes who returned to work this week after a twenty-four-week strike called by Local 401, United Electrical Workers, CIO.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- A state system of probation was called for today by Edgar Bromberger, chief city magistrate of New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the statement of Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson to the House Armed Services Committee today on unification problems and disputes:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Navy has been cruising the gridirons this season with a fleet of "light destroyers" in the backfield and the smallest of them will be, of all things, fullback, against Penn on Franklin Field tomorrow.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, asserted yesterday that Frank Costello, convicted racketeer and reputed friend of Mayor O'Dwyer, had sought to influence him in his campaign for the City Hall post.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Portsmouth, Ohio, Steel Corporation is considering a $10,000,000 expansion program and possible merger with another company, The Cleveland News said today. Officials of the Ohio River city steel company would not comment on either step, pending final decisions expected soon, The News added.
ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the United Nations Department of Trusteeship, warned tonight that civilization's future was in peril because of racial and religious prejudice.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 21 (UP) -- Five scientists reported today that experiments involving the use of aureomycin, a drug isolated from a mold in 1946, have led them to the most promising means yet found for treating atomic bomb radiation sickness and possibly cancer and other related diseases.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- A team of medical men, biochemists and physiologists from the Michael Reese Hospital, Chicago, reported here today that ACTH, the hormone from the pituitary gland producing spectacular results in arthritis and a number of other hitherto intractable diseases, brings gout under control very rapidly.

With rare unanimity the Economic and Financial Committee of the U. N. General Assembly has adopted resolutions calling on all United Nations agencies to speed action on one of the main projects before the present session, namely, the economic development of underdeveloped countries.

An upsurge in cotton goods business has pushed sales into the second quarter of 1950, it was learned yesterday in Worth Street. Market sources estimated that sales in the last three days have reached a 50,000,000-yard figure on cotton fabrics to be delivered mostly after the turn of the year.

"Out of the Crocodile's Mouth," a collection of cartoons from The Crocodile, Moscow's humor magazine, depicting what Russia thinks, or is led to think, about the American way of life, is scheduled for publication late in November by the Public Affairs Press of Washington.

New advertising being scheduled by the Toni Company, home permanent kit manufacturer, will answer two questions. In addition to its own "Which twin has the Toni?" answer, copy will include a credit mention to the effect that both twins' hair-dos were styled by a professional.

Ira Guilden, chairman of the Trade Bank and Trust Company, explained yesterday that his contracted purchase of a large block of shares of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company's stock was solely for "investment purposes." The purchase, originally reported to involve something more than 50,000 shares, may run as high as 75,000 shares, he said.

Leaders of three branches of organized labor, the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Railroad Brotherhoods, predicted yesterday that Madison Square Garden would be completely filled next Thursday evening at the United Labor rally for the election of Herbert H. Lehman for Senator and the re-election of Mayor O'Dwyer and his city-wide running mates.

DETROIT, Oct. 21 -- The American Red Cross, in a prelude to a review of its national policy next month, was participating today with the approval of Gen. George C. Marshall, its new national president, in a city-wide fund campaign with 140 other organizations.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- When directors of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation meet in Paris at the end of the month Britain's representatives will be obliged to say, in the opinion of informed Persons here, that this country is not yet ready to enter into any European financial and economic union.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 21. -- The Administrative and Budgetary Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today an appropriation of $635,900 for a continuation of the United Nations advisory social welfare programs in countries requesting such assistance.

Scorn for the United States' handling of the recent Communist trial in New York was voiced yesterday by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky in a debate on the violation of fundamental liberties and human rights in Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania before the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow.

E. J. Helm, manager, office services, Shell Oil Company, and president, Office-Executives Association of New York, yesterday offered a specific program for discovering hidden skills of rank-and-file office workers by use of human relations techniques in merit rating.

As the shape and purpose of the East German Government become clear, the question that comes to the fore is not what Soviet policy will be in the new republic. That can be seen in any neighboring state. The question is what the Western powers will do with and through the Bonn Government, and what this Government can or will do to influence developments on the other side of the line.
Because the ugly charge of bigotry has been leveled against John Foste Dulles, let us, in Al Smith's tradition look at the record.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 21 - County clerks in New Jersey look to the Appellate Division of the State Superior Court to clear confusion over wording of sample ballots for the next election caused by outlawing the candidates' Loyalty Act.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- A British Foreign Office spokesman said today that British authorities were prepared to discuss with the Netherlands Germany's financial and economic obligations to the Netherlands and other Allied powers.

Building construction work of all types in the metropolitan New York and northern New Jersey area shows an increase in volume of 19 per cent over a year ago, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation, which yesterday reported contract awards in the section for the first nine months of this year at $994,515,000.
The Citizens Union recommended yesterday adoption of three of the first four proposed constitutional amendments, which will appear on the voting machines as Nos. 1, 3 and 4.

A Christ-like world must be built if we expect to avoid trouble with Communists, said Bishop Dana Dawson of the Topeka, Kan., Methodist Area in an address at a Methodist mass meeting at Carnegie Hall last night.
I wish to refer to your editorial in which you already have endorsed a Senatorial candidate for New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- State Department officials expressed "complete surprise" today at the Czechoslovak Government's action. Officials still had the Foreign Ministry's note under advisement this evening, with no definite response yet formulated.

Instruction in traffic safety, at all ages, and formulation of a proper definition for drunken driving were among the recommendations emphasized yesterday at the closing session of the fourteenth annual Northeastern Regional Conference on Highway and Motor Vehicle Problems.

Newspaper editorial writers were urged yesterday by Dr. Lyman Bryson, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College, to give "greater clarity" to their treatment of the issues involved in the daily news. He spoke at a morning session of the second day's meeting of the third annual National Conference of Editorial Writers, held at Columbia.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, told 1,000 students yesterday at a forum in the assembly hall of Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, that he would like to debate the issues of the campaign with Mayor O'Dwyer, his Democratic opponent.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, told Wellesley College students today "that people who take themselves too seriously in managing world affairs won't be managing them long."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 21 -- Without debate, the United Nations Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee approved today an appropriation of $539,000 for the operative part of the enlarged permanent program of technical assistance voted unanimously by the Economic and Financial Committee.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Federal District Court today issued a temporary restraining order against Joel Williams playing pro football with the Washington Redskins.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 21 -- Harry M. Rosenfield, a member of the Displaced Persons Commission, today denounced the Displaced Persons Act in a talk before 3,000 delegates to the national convention of the Jewish War Veterans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Truman took to the official yacht Williamsburg today to polish the major foreign policy speech he will deliver on Monday at the laying of the cornerstone of the United Nations Headquarters in New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The president of the American League today lined up with the National League head in strong opposition to a reported move to place major league umpire control under Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler.

Capt. John N. Johns of the Army yesterday filed in Federal Court a petition for a writ of habeas corpus to free his Polish-born wife, held on Ellis Island by the Department of Immigration and Naturalization since Sept. 20. Captain Johns is an instructor of Military Science and Tactics at Michigan State College, East Lansing, Mich.

"Miracle in Harlem," a melodrama with music performed by an all-Negro cast and produced by Herald Pictures, will begin an engagement today at the Gotham. Sheila Guyse, Stepin Fetchit, Juanita Hall and Savanah Churchill play the lead roles.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Four young men from Manhattan who had led Rockland County law enforcement agents through a bizarre early-morning man hunt were in County Jail here today charged with grand larceny. They were accused of stealing two automobiles and a paper company's thirty-ton truck.

An intent crowd of nearly 2,000, including many teen-agers, visited the Vincent Van Gogh exhibition yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the opening day of the largest Van Gogh show ever held in this country.

The City Department of Welfare aided 319,768 persons in 159,477 cases in September, it was reported yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer by Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard. The report said that the figures represented an increase of 3,463 persons and 1,028 cases over August.

The stock market spent most of yesterday in a neutral corner. Dealings on the Stock Exchange were highly selective and the course throughout the session irregular. The rise of 0.05 point in the composite rate was indicative of the narrow price movements throughout the list.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Confronted with a critical shortage of funds to meet the needs of record numbers of arrivals in Israel, some 1,000 delegates from thirty-eight states will meet here tomorrow for the United Palestine Appeal's "National Conference in a Crisis."

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The selling wave on the stock markets, induced by fears of what measures to counteract the economic crisis may be announced next Monday, was checked here today. There was no material rise in prices and the number of transactions fell, most sections were much brighter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Information about the military assistance program will be withheld from any Communist, even if he should be a Cabinet member of a participating nation, Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, has assured the Senate Appropriations Committee, it was disclosed today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Converging early today on a secluded barn in woods of Harrison township northeast of here, policemen and deputy sheriffs raided a dice game being played by New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Westchester gamblers.

NEWARK, Oct. 21 -- Followers of Father Divine bought and took possession this evening of the Riviera Hotel, one of this city's leading hotels, and said they planned to continue to operate it as a commercial enterprise open to the public.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, rejected today as unfounded all the main complaints of Navy officers against the unified defense command and rebuked them in what he termed "tactful and gentle" words.

This country's merchant fleet, which is the biggest and most modern in the world, is becoming old "in a block" and will be obsolete in fifteen years, or perhaps less, Senator Warren C. Magnuson of Washington asserted last night.

The report of the Timken Roller Bearing Company disclosed yesterday a sharp decline in the net profit for the first nine months this year to $3,286,560 from $11,177,441 earned in the corresponding period a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Agriculture Department's $4,750,000,000 Commodity Credit Corporation found itself today without a board of directors. The C.C.C. is the farm-price support agency of the Government.
Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic and Liberal party nominee for the Senate, declared last night that the principal issue in the campaign was "liberalism versus reaction."

Garden chrysanthemums are featured at the three-day show that opened yesterday afternoon at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park. Long borders of this autumn flower are blooming outdoors, while in the Museum Building, the National Chrysanthemum Society is holding its fifth annual show.

WARSAW, Sept. 30 -- A new Polish sports program developed by the Central Committee of the United Workers (Communist) party will produce "not only the fastest, healthiest and strongest athletes, but also the most courageous fighters for peace," the newspaper Rzoczpospolita predicted today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 22 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist-controlled Government announced tonight it had crushed a large band of "desperate spies and terrorists" who had sought to assassinate certain Government officials.

THE passenger airplane in recent years has made pro-i found changes in the many islands of the Caribbean area and is well on .the way to revolutionizing the economy ofI some of them Travel experts see l tourism becoming the backbone Of many of the lush and lazy islands and the airliner becoming the main form of: transport.

The recent Congressional election in Pennsylvania, dramatically reversing the result in that district in 1948, has been hailed by the Republicans as an indication of a reversal in the tide of national sentiment and belittled by the Democrats as a result of merely local issues. In the forthcoming Senatorial election in New York most of the forecasters seem to think that Lehman will win.

Mayor O'Dwyer appealed personally and in strong terms yesterday to Benjamin Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, for a review of the company's position and an early settlement of the crippling national steel strike.

MIAMI BEACH -- There should be no need for anyone one to sleep this winter on a park bench in this part of the fabulous east coast resort country of Florida. Six new hotels are rising in Miami Beach alone, and at least four of them should be ready for occupancy by Dec. 15, adding 648 more hotel rooms to the city's total.

WHEN one forms opinions about the Sadler's Wells Ballet, one takes one's time. The company is now almost half through its local engagement, but no fair estimate of its accomplishments, its directions, its potentialities can yet be made.

Last Sunday's TIMES published a letter from a correspondent signing himself "Ozymandias," which reported his disappointed efforts to obtain tickets for certain specified performances of "The Browning Version" at the Coronet Theatre.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- The rasping sounds of construction compete now with the gentle pounding of the surf as, off San Juan, more than 800 workmen labor to complete the most modern hotel in the Caribbean in time for an early December opening.

The child welfare program of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund expects to continue its operations abroad until at least the middle of 1951, Maurice Pate, executive director of the fund, announced here yesterday.

HAVING read Mika Waltari's "The Egyptian" in the original Finnish about two years ago, I eagerly awaited its appearance in English translation. I have just finished reading the novel in English and find myself disappointed.
PARIS, Oct. 10 -- Paris is confronted with a serious social and economic problem as the result of a heavy influx of North Africans into this capital.

BOTH to his intimate household and to his public, Alexander Orville is a baffling and impressive phenomenon. A State Senator moving on Washington with the help of a vicious black box and a flair for risky litigation, Alexander bamboozles his political associates with sleight-of-hand moves and borrowed oratory (at a Lincoln Day dinner he delivers verbatim a speech of Stephen Douglas).

HONOLULU, Oct. 22 -- Final agreement on fringe issues holding up the end of Hawaii's long dock strike was expected momentarily tonight as union and management representatives met to formalize an understanding that has delayed the return to work of 2,000 striking stevedores for more than two weeks following settlement of the basic wage issue.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 22 -- State Senator Elmer Wene, Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, charged tonight that "ruthless bossism by the Driscoll party, aided and abetted by the most deceitful tax program in New Jersey's history, will drive New Jersey's local municipalities into bankruptcy."

ARTHUR KOESTLER is sometimes referred to as one of the greatest living English novelists, a slightly imperspicuous appraisal, for Koestler is neither English nor is he a novelist. He is a Hungarian educated in Austria; like Conrad and Santayana, he had to learn a third language in which to write and he learned it well.

Three years ago, or even two years ago, it would have been fantastic to imagine the United States voting for Yugoslavia for membership in the Security Council and Russia voting against Yugoslavia. Down to about sixteen months ago our relations with Marshal Tito's Government were about like those with other satellite nations.
MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Williams held off a late fourth period touchdown drive by a determined Tufts team to earn a 14-14 tie before 4,500 fans at Tufts Oval today.

THE Russian revolution, says Mr. Belden, was the greatest by-product of the first World War, and the Chinese revolution, culminating in the Communist victory, will be the greatest by-product of the second World War. What Mr. Belden is trying to do in this book is to explain how the by-product was made.

Although Norway once again ranks third among the world's maritime nations in volume of tonnage, the future of her merchant marine is threatened seriously by the economic policies of other shipping countries and by heavy taxation at home, in the opinion of T. S. Falck Jr., president of the Norwegian Shipowners Association.

The first coordinated move by governmental and private groups toward agreement on a model bill for uniform, non-compulsory state trade-mark laws is expected to be started in the next few weeks, it was learned yesterday.

The High Plains begin rising west of the Missouri River and flatten off into the great wheatlands of America, turning into ranch land just before they end abruptly at the Rocky Mountains. Early maps labeled them The Great American Desert, and to early travelers they were wasteland to be crossed before they reached a promised land beyond.

MEXICO CITY -- With a devalued peso, with the rainy season sliding into the dry, the great Reforma Boulevard in the capital newly paved and relandscaped, the Pan American highway thrown open from Oaxaca to the Guatemalan border, Mexico offers to fall and winter tourists both her old self and a new look at old-fashioned prices.
WE are not one to berate a publisher for pushing his wares, but the clamor has become a little deafening lately and it is getting harder than ever to pick one's cocktail party.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 22 -- The Indonesian Round Table Conference at The Hague, after eight weeks of meetings, is nearing the end of its job in a mood of confidence. The two groups of negotiators -- Dutch and Indonesians -- have reached general agreement on the future status of what used to be the Netherlands East Indies.

THE book under review, by two members of the Department of Engineering at Columbia University, is an extension of Professor Rautenstrauch's earlier works in industrial economics. The principal emphasis is on the break-even chart.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- Philadelphia women's specialty shops reported last week's sales were 24 per cent under a year ago, and sales in the four-weeks period were off 22 per cent from 1948. Pennsylvania railroad car-loadings last week totaled 74,224.

Workers in the rubber industry discovered long ago that after long handling of tetraethyl-thiruram disulfide a mere whiff of alcohol nauseated them. But it was only last year that Drs. H. Jald, E. Jacobsen and V. Larsen, three Danish physicians, first showed that the compound, now known as antabuse, had its uses in treating alcoholics.

" MY GRANNY VAN" is a salty yet tender memorial to George Sessions Perry's Grandmother Van de Venter. Granny Van was a terror on wheels, whose "magnificent unpredictability," egotism, childishness, bossiness and joy in battle kept the small town of Rockdale, Texas, in pretty thorough subjection.

WHEN Manhattan is as old as Baghdad and story-tellers think their tales to audiences telepathically attuned, one of the favorite yarns will be a farce melodrama in which New York is dominated by a ring of gangsters headed by a strong, silent, cruel man who laughs at decency and sneers at the District Attorney.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- The Pope today indicated that the United States should adopt a more liberal immigration policy to relieve what he called the "pitiful plight of vast populations" uprooted by war in both Europe and Asia.

ST. LOUIS -- Sixty-six honors were awarded by the Photographic Society of America at the annual awards banquet that closed a four-day meeting of the organization here last week. Two honorary fellowships, six honorary memberships, eight fellowships and forty-five associateships were conferred upon photographic workers throughout the country.

Every great man becomes after his death something of a myth. Stories are told about him which fit a certain character yet which may not always be true. Lincoln is such a figure. Did Mr. Lincoln, for example, write a letter to Mrs. Bixby trying to comfort her for the loss of her sons in the war? The assertion is questioned.

UNDOUBTEDLY the principal development in contract bridge this year (disregarding canasta, which might rather be called a development away from contract bridge) is the point-count method of hand valuation.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 (UP) -- Held scoreless through the first half, Villanova's passing attack worked in the second for a 20-to-0 victory over Duquesne before 14,702 at Forbes Field today.

FOR the heroine of his latest story, the veteran British novelist Martin Boyd has chosen an Irish girl, the illegitimate daughter of an Irish peer, whom he poses against the successive backgrounds of a castle in the County of Mayo, a draper's shop in a small provincial English town, and the glitter of London society.

MANILA, Oct. 12 -- Twenty-one employes in the Philippine Government's Department of Finance and the Manila Post Office are involved in the exposure of a systematic purloining and forging of United States Governments checks sent to Filipinos by the United States Veterans Administration and the War Damage Commission.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 22 -- New direct pressure for a revision of the Western Allies' dismantling program, including a flat refusal to work on dismantling projects, is expected in Western Germany in the next two weeks.
Four current one-man shows of painting find artists exercising their immemorial right to paint what they like how they please.

FREEPORT, L. I, Oct. 22 -- Three Freeport school girls who ran away from home last Wednesday for reasons not yet determined returned to their homes here at 6:45 o'clock tonight with indications that their parents would forgive their attack of wanderlust.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 22 (UP) -- One mighty burst through the line for 77 yards by Substitute Fullback Geno Mazzanto enabled Arkansas to upset Vanderbilt, 7 to 6, today before a crowd of 26,500.

PORT-AU-PRINCE -- Haiti is making a major bid for tourist traffic with an International Exposition which will open Dec. 6 to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the founding of this city. The theme of the six-month-long exposition will be "Peace and Progress."

Grace Castagnetta started her recital in Carnegie Hall yesterday with classical compositions, carried it through the romantics an brought it up to date with the first performance of her own Third Piano Sonata. Then she went further and composed while on the stage, using themes suggested by the audience.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 22 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, Republican candidate for re-election, said today the Republican Administration should be returned to office to carry out his plans for development of rapid transit and other transportation facilities, which "would bring a new influx of jobs, business opportunities and economic values to the entire state."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Congress of American Women was accused by the House Committee on un - American Activities today as being "composed primarily of a hard core of Communist party members and a circle of close sympathizers."

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- Set back on its economic heels by sterling evaluation and General MacArthur's unequivocal declaration that the yen will not follow suit -- as it did back in 1931 -- Japan is struggling to regain its balance. It is planning further intensification of its industrial rationalization campaign.

Taxpayers should begin to be aroused over certain tax trends in order to try to forestall the abuse of burdensome imposts before they become realities. ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Fall and winter vacationists en route to Florida's Gulf' Coast resorts by car will start enjoying their holiday far up the peninsula -- as soon as they strike the Gulf Coast Highway. This four-lane highway, Route 19, has been completed from Tallahassee all the way to St. Petersburg.

SAN JUAN -- Puerto Rico, which legalized gambling a year ago, is using the law to increase scarce tourist facilities. Thus, two hotels which will open casinos this season (a third may do so later) have provided more accommodations in order to qualify for gambling licenses.

A crazed mother, sinister brother, thwarted husband, Communist villain and misguided Jesuit all fall into her shadow. Against a background of labor violence, religious symbolism and squalor, Angela follows a program of calculated corruption.

CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix -- In spite of the recent expansion of tourist facilities on this island, there are still accommodations for fewer than two hundred persons, so it will be first come, first served for guests this winter.

Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for that office, will start tomorrow on his fourth up-state trip. His schedule for the week was announced yesterday by Alger B. Chapman, his campaign manager.

A NEW performing organization named Twentieth Century Concerts is launching its first season with three concerts at Times Hall that will be devoted entirely to the music of four composers -- Bartok, Martinu, John Verrall and Ben Weber. At least one work by each of the composers will be on every program. F. L. Ullsberger is the man who rounded up the backing and assembled the artists who will participate.

Retail trade here did not show much improvement last week in comparison with sales figures of the like period a year ago. Temperatures still ruled above last year and did not help to spur the sale of seasonal merchandise. Department store sales were estimated at about 17 per cent under 1948.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 -- General pattern of retail business activity in the Twelfth District during the past week was favorable. The preliminary report of Twelfth District department and apparel stores sales during September showed a minus 8 and 16 per cent respectively as compared with September, 1948.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Fullback Johnny Papit provided the spark for a University of Virginia touchdown explosion today as the Cavaliers routed Virginia Military Institute, 32 -- 13, to protect their position among the nation's unbeaten football teams.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Yale took the cue from its famed football song today, and marched down the field to victory over Holy Cross. The Bulldogs held off by an obstinate Crusader eleven for the first three periods and then came through with a thrilling scoring gesture in the final quarter to register the triumph by 14 to 7.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 22 -- Few delegates believe that the Soviet Union will withdraw from the Security Council -- which of course would also mean a withdrawal from the United Nations -- as a result of the election to the Council of Yugoslavia over Czechoslovakia. Nevertheless, the defeat of Czechoslovakia raises the fundamental question of what the Russians can now hope to attain in the organization.

BOSTON, Oct. 22 -- For the first time in the long history of its gridiron battles, Harvard today found itself with a five-game losing streak.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had recommended to the Westchester Street Transportation Company, which operates several bus lines in Westchester County, and to the Westchester Electric Railroad Company, operating street cars from New Rochelle through the Pelhams and Mount Vernon into the Bronx, that they issue transfers at 3 cents each between bus lines and between buses and street cars.

DALLAS, Oct. 22 -- Southern Methodist hit Kentucky in the middle of its national ranking today, knocking down the seventh-rated national team, 20 -- 7, on the smashing runs of Kyle Rote and the thread-needle passing of Sophomore Fred Benners.

THE latest word from young fans of Frank Sinatra is that they have accepted Dorothy Kirsten. This news undoubtedly will be reassuring to any who might have feared dissension in the ranks last month when Sinatra teamed with the Metropolitan Opera star for the "Light Up Time" radio series on NBC.
Fordham provided a number of surprises for its ardent supporters at the Polo Grounds yesterday with a 47 to 21 triumph over Syracuse.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 22 (UP) Generalissimo Francisco Franco arrived in Portugal today for an official state visit and was greeted by a twenty-one-gun salute and 200,000 cheering citizens who lined his route.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Five Arizona desperadoes smashed out of the midtown, fifth-floor county jail early today, and two fell dead under a blast of gunfire before they could get out of the courthouse containing the jail.

NEGLECTING the annual fall clean-up in the garden not only holds up progress in spring, but is apt to result in increased disease and insect troubles next year. And, actually, with the exception of fall planting, no other operation advances spring work more than this autumn chore.

THE NEW YORK TIMES will begin publication on Sunday, Nov. 6, of daily installments of Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith's "My Three Years in Moscow." They are an accounting of his stewardship as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union during the "cold war" period from March, 1946, until March, 1949.
