Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, urged yesterday the re-election of Mayor O'Dwyer and the election of Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, as two outstanding Americans concerned with the welfare of all the people and followers of the tradition of the late President Roosevelt.

Addition of a limousine and an eight-passenger sedan to the Crown Imperial series was announced yesterday by the Chrysler division, Chrysler Corporation. City-delivered prices of the new models, exclusive of sales tax, but fully equipped, including radio and heater, are listed at $5,518.75 for the limousine and $5,413.75 for the eight-passenger sedan.

AUDACITY and grandeur characterize the task of historical writing which Mr. Gipson, who is Research Professor of History in Lehigh University, has set for himself. Beginning around 1758, he is covering, in all its aspects, the world-wide "British Empire Before the American Revolution."

BUENOS AIRES -- October, November and December north of the equator mean April, May and June below it. Which is another way of saying that the best of the South American season is at hand, particularly for voyagers who yearn for Rio and beyond.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Industrial and commercial employment was continuing "its brisk upward pace" last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The increase between mid-August and mid-September was 464,000.

The report of the Economic Cooperation Administration on the follies and distortions of world trade in general and the United States' share of it in particular is a cold shower that we all doubtless needed. To be told that of our so-called "favorable balance" of trade of $101,000,000,000 since 1914 more than two-thirds took the form of outright grants and unrepayable loans gives a fair measure of the uneconomic methods that we are pursuing.

Phillippe de Croisset, agent general of the French National Tourist Office in North America, predicted last week that more Americans will visit France this year than in any year since the nineteen twenties. He said preliminary figures together with heavy bookings in Paris hotels through next month indicated that the number of American tourists to enter his country during 1949 fould be approximately 250,000.

LAFAYET;FE, Ind., Oct. 22 (UP) --Illinois riddled Purdue's line with fancy trap plays today for spectacular rushing gains and a 19-to0 Big .Ten triumph before 48,000 frbst-bitten fans in the Boflerrnakers' stadium.

PANAMA -- It cannot be said of the five Central American Republics that if you've seen one country you've seen them all. Centuries of comparative isolation, when sailing ships, ox-carts and saddle horses were the chief means of communication, resulted in the development of unique characteristics in each country.

ALL generalizations are false, the French say -- "including this one." And all generalizations about the great and good form of art known with lavish looseness as "the short story" are particularly subject to the fallibilities of human error.

Hal Price Headley's Lithe, full sister to Menow and half-sister to a couple of other stakes-winners, did some top-quality stakes-racing of her own at grayish, dampish Jamaica yesterday. The sixth choice at close to 13 to 1, she ran off with first money of $20,700 in the Comely Handicap, last filly-and-mare stake of the New York campaign.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 22 -- The University of Delaware registered a 7-0 victory over Lafayette today, scoring early in the final period when Bill Shockley's pass to Ed Samocki on the goal line covered 22 yards. It came after Jim Degasperies ran 45 yards after taking a criss-cross from Joe Lank, who caught a punt in Delaware territory.

The Geiger counter, indispensable to nuclear physicists, has been adapted in the research laboratory of the United States Steel Corporation of Delaware to quick and accurate metallurgical analysis. The counter is used in conjunction with special spectrographic equipment to reveal the kind and quantity of alloying elements in steel.

MRS. HEWES has successfully accomplished a difficult task in this story, which is based on recollections of her own childhood. Avoiding incidents of too personal or too dated a nature to be of interest to readers of today, she tells of an 8-or-9-year-old girl who has lived all her life in a small village in the Lebanon Mountains high above Beirut and the Mediterranean Sea.

AMERICA shouldn't starve this year. Even the stoutest pessimist would have to admit that after a look at this country at this time of year. The season has been good, the crops bountiful. The country bulges with plenty.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 22 -- An outmanned Lehigh football team with a porous pass defense was soundly trounced by Brown University's Bruins today, 48 to 0.

Only a day after reading Thomas Mann's report on his Olympian reception in Weimar ("Germany Today"), the New York Postoffice returned to me a book parcel which I had sent to a friend living in the Soviet Zone of Germany. One of the books was Mann's "The Permanent Goethe."

The report of the Lion Oil Company for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, made public yesterday, shows a net income of $6,422,441 or $2.74 each on 2,340,801 shares of common stock. This compares with $8,438,043 or $3.60 a share in the corresponding period of last year.

WHAT the foreign observer needs for an understanding of the "cultural purges" which have punctuated recent Soviet life, is above all the facts themselves. That is precisely what Professor Counts, with the assistance of Mrs. Lodge, now brings to the American reader.

PARIS -- One of the highest cable cars for skiers in the world, rising to approximately 9,200 feet, will shortly go into construction at the winter resort of Val d'Isere in the French Alps. It will be completed in time for the 1950-1951 season and will make trails available for skiing well into late spring.

WASHINGTON, Oct 22 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, called on the country's farmers tonight to use and conserve soil resources "wisely" and thus continue to provide "an adequate diet for the American dinner table."
When a Jewish girl here made a rosary as a wedding present for a Catholic girl in Hong Kong several years ago she never dreamed she would adopt rosary designing as a career.

" THE ETERNAL LIGHT," the series of religious dramatizations prepared by the Jewish Theological Seminary, plans to observe its fifth anniversary on NBC by repeating the programs which proved the most popular over the five-year span.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Dr. John Slawson of New York, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, tonight urged leaders of the thirty-eight major communities throughout the country attending the organization's executive committee meeting to raise funds for a program dedicated to the advancement of civil rights for all Americans.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Retail stores in the strike-bound areas near Chicago have begun to feel the pinch of curtailed buying. Sales last week were down an additional 5 to 10 per cent compared with a year ago, attributed to strike conditions.

Although a plan to protect printed textile designs through a new registration bureau to be Administered by the machine printers union has wide backing in the New York converting trade, large suppliers of low-priced printed rayons are not inclined to go along, it was learned yesterday.

REPRODUCED more times than the Mona Lisa, Gilbert Stuart's portrait of George Washington is certainly the best-known painting in the United States. The painter we have all but forgotten. Ilse Bischoff, a painter herself, undertakes in this biographical novel to separate Stuart from the reflected sanctity of his most famous sitter's halo.

CHARLES E. IVES, who was 75 last Thursday, has lived to see posterity catch up with him. It has taken America a long time to recognize that he is the most audacious pioneer in music this country has produced and that in his vast output of symphonies, choruses, songs and chamber music we have a living portrait of the land worthy to stand beside the literature of New England's flowering.

The evening performance of Nov. 3 of "The Browning Version" at the Coronet Theatre, with Maurice Evans and Edna Best in the title roles, has been taken over as a benefit for the Union Settlement. Mrs. William T. Kennedy is chairman of the committee in charge, and tickets for that evening may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe, 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.

ONE of Mexico's most respected critics, Jose Luis Martinez, recently gave it as his opinion that the present state of Mexican letters is "lethargic" and without "passion." Today, he says, most Mexican authors are dilettantes, unwilling to make sacrifices for their art.
SELINSGROVE, Pa., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Amos Alonzo Stagg celebrated his sixtieth anniversary as a college football coach today with a living-room demonstration of how he played the "T" formation in 1888.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Warren R. Austin, permanent United States delegate to the United Nations, indicated here tonight that the United States would stress in United Nations General Assembly debate the right of the Chinese people to choose their own government.

WHEN Charles Dickens made his celebrated lecture in 1841 he established among English authors the custom of coming to this country and telling, in lectures, how much they like America, and then returning to tell, in books, how much they don't. Mr. Dickens' book was "American Notes," and in it he proved himself a severe critic of almost everything he found there.

AMONG the more curious items to turn up last week was the one about Producer Leland Hayward's embarrassment of riches. For, with everyone around The Street crying about how hard it is these days to get "angels" to part with their funds, Mr. Hayward was being confronted with the paradox of how to turn them down.
NASSAU -- Three new major changes will be noted by former visitors to the Bahamas when they return here for the fall and winter season:

Even if the steel strike should end this week, as is expected in some industrial quarters, the industry will be hard pressed to lift the year's output of raw steel to 80,000,000 net tons. It will be a somewhat disappointing end to a year which at the start gave hope of becoming the first in which the nation's steel output would exceed 90,000,000 tons.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 22 -- The danger of Soviet communism presents a challenge unparalleled in 1,000 years, but it can be met and hurled back without war, Senator John Foster Dulles of New York declared here today.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 22 (UP) -- The battling Buckeyes of Ohio State roared back into the wide-open Big Ten title scramble today by bowling over Wisconsin, 21 to 0, before 45,000 mournful fans.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 22 -- Displaying a powerful running attack that continually picked up yardage through the center of the line, the Amherst College football team defeated their Little Three rivals from Wesleyan, 14 -- 7, today before a homecoming gathering of 7,500.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

BERLIN, Oct. 22 -- The statements yesterday by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Western German Republic, on his Government's powers drew fire today from the Department of Information in the Eastern Government, headed by Gerhardt Eisler.
PARIS, Sunday, Oct. 23 -- Premier Rene Mayer abandoned his efforts to form a new French coalition Cabinet early today after a day-long stalemate yesterday with Socialist leaders.

Disclaimers by high-ranking government officials of any imminent plans for revaluing gold upward in terms of American dollars are being received with skepticism in the financial district. There persists a feeling that current-day official tinkering with the value of money did not end with the wave of September valuations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration made these suggestions to European Governments and business and United States business men today in a report aimed at increasing American imports from abroad.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Oct. 22 -- The election campaign in Suffolk County spotlights ten towns each of which will choose complete town governments for the next two years. Because of that, they will produce a new county board of supervisors, which today is Republican, nine members to one.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Olympic Champion Col. Humberto Mariles shook off a last-hurdle jinx today to take his first trophy at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 22 -- Cuba lost unanimous support today in the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee for a proposal directing the attention of the Economic and Social Council to the influence of international economic and commercial policy on the development of retarded countries.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- After the meeting here today of the United States Ambassadors to the principal Western European capitals, George W. Perkins, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, said this had been the first of a series of such "departmental" sessions and that similar meetings would be held in the future "here and in other parts of the world."
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- A United States-Canadian unit sat in a control room here today and directed the operation of fighter planes that dispersed a simulated bomber attack on New York City.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- ACTH, the hormone from the pituitary gland hailed by medical men as having opened a new era in medicine, has scored new triumphs as the most effective agent found so far for the control of asthma, hay fever, drug sensitivity and other allergic ills, it was reported here today at the closing sessions of the Special Conference on Research Progress With ACTH.

THE fellow in charge of recording theatrical events for posterity had a notable entry to make this month. After a courtship of thirteen years, Ed Wynn and television are as one. Wynn has been pursuing the eighth lively art ever since it was a wide-eyed debutante. Back in 1936 he was saying, "Television will be one of the greatest contributions to the possible contentment of a nation."

LILLIAN HELLMAN was trying to explain the other day, between rehearsals of "Montserrat," why she now stages her scripts. "Directing," she decided, "is no great feat." Not that Miss Hellman considers herself a top-flight director. She just figures she's good enough to get by and that most directors have become expert mainly at camouflaging ignorance with technical jargon.

A rainbow loomed over Brooklyn College field in the closing minutes of the Kingsmen's game with Northeastern yesterday but it was no bright omen for the home forces, who took a 39-7 beating. A crowd of 5,000 watched in a half drizzle as the Huskies spotted Brooklyn a quick touchdown and then came on to roll at will the rest of the way.

RALPH VAUGHAN WILLIAMS was 77 on Oct. 12, and he wrote his Symphony No. 6 in E minor only several years ago. The music is so powerful in its concentration of thought and expression that you marvel at the creative energy of the man, which far exceeds that of composers younger than he.

BOSTON, Oct. 22 -- New York University's eleven put up a courageous but fruitless battle against Boston University at Fenway Park today and the undefeated Terriers, as expected, romped to a 38 to 0 victory. It was the fourth and easiest triumph of the campaign for the home team, which threw forty-four players into the fray.

THE adviser in the back seat was Riley, a vociferous wirehaired terrier who couldn't imagine how the doctor had ever driven a car without him. To be sure, the doctor was a trifle erratic but when Riley got a terrier-sized car of his own he discovered that being at the wheel was not so simple as it looked from the rear.

JUST the other week A. B. Guthrie Jr.'s new novel "The Way West" (a follow-up on "The Biff Sky") came out, and the line in this paper's review that seemed to be the phrase juste was: "This novel is almost entirely free of contrivance." Well, at least that's how Mr. Guthrie himself strikes you -- free of contrivance, and no almost about it.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Emil Zatopek, Cechoslovakia's olympic champion, ran 10,000 meters in 29 minutes, 21.2 seconds today, shattering the world record for the second time this year and clipping six seconds off the best previous mark.

VIRGINIA COWLES interprets modern England, where she lives with her husband, a member of Parliament, for the benefit of America, where she was born. A war correspondent in Britain and other European nations, she has all the connections and equipment to make a completely knowing job of it.

THE 1949 International Horticultural Congress will open next Sunday and continue through Nov. 1. To be held at Essex House, Central Park South, it is sponsored by the American Horticultural Council, Inc.

MUCH has been, and will be, written in explanation of the defeat of France in 1940, but it seems unlikely that the truth of the matter will ever be more accurately and more vividly presented than in this statement of evidence written in 1940 by the late Marc Bloch.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 22 -- Democratic party leaders are showing growing concern over the desertion of new Nassau County residents to the Republican party, it became known today.

IN Mr. Heinlein's cosmos, interplanetary rocket travel is old stuff. Earlier books got his characters to the moon and to stations parked in space. This time he describes colonial life on Mars some years after men from the earth have settled there.

Girls between the ages of 14 and 18 whose conduct gets them into trouble should be treated in smaller voluntary psychiatric institutions rather than in the larger public institutions, Dr. Israel Strauss, president of Hillside Hospital, said yesterday.

The Communist party is carrying on "business as usual" at its old stand near Union Square. Eleven members of the party's national board have been sentenced to Federal prison on charges of conspiracy to advocate forcible overthrow of the Government, but the leaders left in command say the party is going to keep right on doing all the things it has been doing in exactly the same way as before.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Cornell completed its conquest of the Big Three for the first time in its foot-ball history today, but the Big Red and the thousands of homecoming alumni in the crowd of 33,000 had a terrific scare before victory was eked out by the margin of two points after touchdown against Princeton, 14 -- 12.

A survey of 30,000 members of the American Association of University Women on the value of their college education in later life has brought out two major suggestions for improvement: (1) college education should consist of training and experience which are closely related to life after college and (2) college education should be broad and flexible enough to stimulate the maximum development of each individual.

A considerable boom in imported goods in 1950, favored by lower prices or better margins of profits, was predicted yesterday by Harold Mayer, president of Freund-Mayer Co., Inc., agent for European manufacturers of paper products and vice president of Wallner Mayer, Inc., agent for toiletry, leather goods and gift merchandise.

THE morning hours of the nation are the occasion of Charles O'Neill's first novel. Like all morning hours, they are both bright and black; the young air of promise everywhere moves through them, the beckoning gestures of waiting alternatives move in front of them -- all providing a vivid background for this well-researched, swiftly paced story of the adventures of Theron Hawley.

SHADED areas in the garden may offer planting problems during most of the growing season, but through early spring, at least, they can be made bright with color without undue effort. Many of the earliest spring-flowering bulbs, with their vivid blossoms, transform such sites.

TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 22 -- The situation in the Greek civil war is still "rife with danger" and the Greek Army is guarding against any "attempt by the Cominform to send over new guerrilla bands," Constantin Tsaldaris, Foreign Minister of Greece, said here tonight.

Federal Detention Headquarters at 427 West Street reported yesterday afternoon that the five Soviet officials heading the Amtorg Trading Corporation were still in custody in default of $15,000 bail each.
The Wagner College Seahawks defeated the City College football team yesterday, 28-6, before 3,500 fans at Wagner Field, Staten Island.

FIVE years ago a peremptory slogan -- "Wake Up, Kentucky" -- reverberated across a listless state. It was a barrage of blasts from radios, newspapers, banquet speakers and billboards, and the slogan so aroused the sleepy citizens that a few months later it had to be changed to "Kentucky On the March."

Six begoggled workers, equipped with pincers, stood at the head of what resembled an amusement park slideway and whipped a 120-foot-long wriggling rope of red-hot (1725) copper down into a pit. Their job, transforming 230-pound copper bars into quarter-inch rod at the rate of one every twenty seconds, signalled one of the initial steps in a round-the-lock drive to meet world communications needs.

SAN REMO -- The Blue Train, Italian version, rolls again smoothly and rapidly from Nice to Ventimiglia. It crosses the French-Italian border without excitement and speedily proceeds to San Remo, Alassio, Genoa, Rapallo and La Spezia.

A new five-power proposal to combine Eritrea in a federated union with Ethiopia for ten years was handed yesterday to a United Nations General Assembly subcommittee at Flushing Meadow that was trying to reach agreement on the future of the former Italian colonies in Africa.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 22 -- The Arab League's Political Committee. at its meeting tonight, adopted the principle of collective security and it was reported by Egyptian sources that a project would be studied calling for the establishment of a common defense council.

TOURISTS making the quick, pleasant air-trip to the Virgin Islands from Puerto Rico for a one-day visit in the picturesque free-port island of St. Thomas (where cigarettes are ninety cents a carton, Scotch whisky $2.50 a bottle, and cigars, perfumes, French silks and English woolens comparably inexpensive) should be warned that they cannot bring these article back into the United States duty-free.

THIS addition to the lively current discussion of the relationship between religion and American education is in two parts. There is, first, a discussion, from the Protestant point of view, of the numerous aspects of this complex question.

THE Fishermen's Special, which has for years been a popular Long Island Rail Road summertime promotion, is about to become a wintertime attraction -- with aircoach travel to Palm Beach and Miami replacing the railcoach ride to Montauk.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Tennessee rolled over Tennessee Tech, 36 to 6, today before a shirt-sleeved crowd of 15,000.

Three of four loans placed privately by industrial corporations last year were unsecured, and about half of the total were made to repay bank loans or to strengthen working capital, according to a survey by E. V. Hale Co. of Chicago, specialists in private placement financing.

Mayor O'Dwyer issued yesterday a proclamation designating tomorrow as United Nations Day. He urged all citizens to recognize the day as an occasion for celebration in homes, schools, churches, public meeting places and places of work. In this manner, the proclamation declared, the community can demonstrate to the world "that our faith and support stand behind the United Nations for the promotion of world peace and progress in which we all shall share."

WINDOW ROCK, N. M., Oct. 22 -- Indian history of the sort that should impress the white man's "good-government leagues" was made here this week as the Navajo Tribal Council went on record favoring President Truman's veto of a measure that would have assured jobs for thousands of tribesmen and directly benefited every resident of the sprawling Navajo and Hopi reservations.

IN his flight from the florid costumes of Elizabethan drama into the respectable three-piece suit of today, Maurice Evans is catching his breath in Terence Rattigan's "The Browning Version." He is playing the melancholy pedagogue in a short drama about an English private school.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- The Japanese rice crop now being reaped will be the biggest since the war, amounting to more than 325,000,000 bushels, the Ministry of Agriculture announced today following a national survey begun Oct. 10.

NICE -- The French Riviera is busily preparing for what promises to be the most brilliant winter season since the Edwardians sailed off in their yachts. The cote d'Azur was established a century ago as a winter refuge for fashionable Britons.

A chrysanthemum never bloomed that could match the glory of Edward Berlin's hair. Nor could any arrangement of flowers rival the perfection of Richard Einaughler's sartorial splendor. And as for Ronald Satlof's necktie, not all the variegated blossoms in the world could compare.

Frank Costello, reputed racketeer, declared yesterday through his attorney, George Wolf, that after the nomination of Newbold Morris for Mayor two of Mr. Morris' friends had solicited his help for the Fusion candidate, saying they believed he could swing a large part of the Italian vote.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, has been chosen by the Administration to fill the pivotal and crucial post of Ambassador to Yugoslavia, with her outstanding anti-Soviet Gevernment.

In what is hoped will be a step toward development of an Anglo-American Council on Distribution, similar to the Anglo-American Council on Productivity, the National Sales Executives and its British counterpart, the Incorporated Sales Managers Association, will exchange visiting "teams," it was announced yesterday.

AS an old and devoted tub-thumper for wholesome domestic comedy -- the sort of untroubled entertainment which draws amusement from the normal walks of life -- this corner has watched with quiet interest the diligence and consistency with which a couple of studios have succeeded with this type of film since the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- America's total debts -- private and public -- was $429,400,000,000, a record high level, at the start of this year after a twelve-month rise of $14,000,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WINTER sports fans regard as a happy omen for the coming season the fact that there have already been two weeks of skiing in the mountains of Utah and Idaho. Snow came earlier than usual this month, and winter-resort operators are hoping that, with a big program of world championship competitions scheduled for the 1949-50 season, this will be a better winter than last year's.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas -- There was a time when the Virgin Islands were so remote from the United States that it was difficult for tourists to think of coming here for a short vacation and even more difficult for them to realize that the islands are part of the United States.

THE newly opened comprehensive exhibition of paintings and drawings by Van Gogh, at the Metropolitan Museum should prove to be a fairly definitive experience for the visitor. Except that, since the art world is very much alive, a constant process of revaluation necessarily goes on.

THE Los Angeles Art Center and the Fred Archer School of Photography of Los Angeles offer the prospective student a choice, respectively, of the artistic or the direct approach to learning photography. In the first, photography is a department in an art school; in the second, only photography is taught.

IT is fortunate for the new science of parapsychology that Eileen J. Garrett is not only gifted and sensitive, but also an excellent business woman, a more than competent writer, and a woman deeply concerned with ideas as they relate themselves to ideals.

HONOLULU, Oct. 22 -- Fifty thousand American soldiers and sailors, engaged in the biggest amphibious maneuvers since the war, sparred in long-range combat across an expanse of ocean today preliminary to a simulated invasion of the main Hawaiian island of Oahu early next week.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer had undermined the civil service and had disregarded merit and fitness in making appointments to satisfy the needs of Tammany Hall.

SAN JUAN -- Puerto Ricans are fond of saying that Ponce de Leon went to Florida to look for the fountain of youth, but that, having seen Florida and having failed in his quest, he returned to Puerto Rico. He was the first Spanish Governor of the island Today Puerto Rico is inviting the world, and especially fellow-Americans, to follow the old conquistador's trail and come to Puerto Rico.
Otto Behensky of Andrew Jackson High School and Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn shared top honors in the Manhattan College interscholastic cross country trill at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday morning

TORONTO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored with a minute and a half of play remaining tonight to tie the New York Rangers, 2 -- 2, in a National League hockey game. The draw left the Rangers without a victory in four starts with two ties and as many losses.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- What happened to Columbia this dark and damp afternoon might be entitled "Murder at Michie Stadium," where fifty-two golden-helmeted gladiators of the Army football team slaughtered the young Lions, 63 -- 6.

The furnishings and art property of Burwood, the residence of the late Walter Jennings at Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., will be auctioned on the premises by the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Tuesday and Wednesday.

GENEVA, Oct. 22 -- One month after having taken the strong medicine of currency devaluation the European economy still looks dangerously florid, as if it might suffer a new stroke within a few months.
GAMBIER, Ohio, Oct. 22 -- Kenyon College marked its 125th anniversary today with a demonstration of American ability to forget personal political rivalries in the presence of a common cause.

The world's oceans may some day provide civilization with vast new supplies of food and medicine, according to Professor Werner Bergmann of Yale. In his opinion, the solution of the urgent problem of removing salts and minerals from sea water can turn great coastal and near coastal stretches of desert "into productive lands."

The death of Richard Strauss and the encomiums lavished on him by the critics enable me to break a friendly lance with Mr. Downes -- as critic. My complaint is that in the musical field alone the critics are allowed to get away with murder. Worse than that, even, the layman does not even know if the music critic is getting away with murder or not. We, as laymen, have no way of judging you.

A cease-fire was declared last week in the "Battle of the Pentagon." Hearings were concluded Friday in a Congressional inquiry into the extraordinary dispute among America's highest military authorities over what the nation's defense organization and strategy should be.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Oct. 22 -- District Attorney Lindsay R. Henry of Suffolk County has subpoenaed the publisher, managing editor and six reporters of Newsday, a Long Island daily published in Hempstead, in an investigation of the newspaper's report that a bribe had been offered to one of its men not to expose gambling in the county.

THE MARCH OF TIME, noted for its documentary short subjects, is deviating from the norm with "The Golden Twenties," a feature-length compilation highlighting life in that colorful decade, it was learned last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration said today that the United States must buy at least $2,000,000,000 more annually from Europe or see its own exports "dwindle to a mere trickle" and living conditions abroad drop to a point endangering world peace.

The first of ten free health education lectures to acquaint the public with new medical knowledge will be held Wednesday at 8:30 P. M. at the city's Mott Haven-Morrisania Health Center, 349 East 140th Street, the Bronx.
I WOULD like to address the following to Elia Kazan. Dear Mr. Kazan:

The metropolitan area drive in Syracuse University's national campaign to raise $15,000,000 for building and development will be led by Robert W. Morey, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, it was announced yesterday. Clifford P. Goes, utilities tax consultant, has been named executive committee chairman.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 -- The West Coast kept one ear turned this week to the sound effects accompanying the hearings before the House Armed Services Com mittee, but the subject of highway accidents, especially in California, attained a high place in conversation and editorials.

DELHI, Oct. 22 -- With the new republican Constitution about to be passed, India's one-party Government still stands without serious challenge, but opposition is taking tenuous shape for the first general elections to be held about one year from now.

Benjamin Powell's letter and accompanying photograph of a Chinese boy holding a cricket cage (in connection with Donald Culross Peattie's article, "Autumn Full-harmonic Orchestra") interested me greatly, also his reference to oriental cricket cages mentioned by Mr. Peattie.

What is expected to be the largest gathering of public health workers ever assembled will begin here tomorrow morning as the American Public Health Association begins its seventy-seventh annual meeting at the Statler and New Yorker Hotels.

MY friend Governor Curley never "nursed" any "rage" against Roosevelt, as J. V. Healy states in his letter (Book Review, Oct. 2) concerning Louis M. Lyons' review of Joseph Dineen's "The Purple Shamrock: The Hon. James Michael Curley of Boston."
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A historian said today that General Robert E. Lee disposed of a racial situation in his church a few weeks after the end of the Civil War.
Yeggs who specialize in robbing welfare agencies have stolen nearly $8,000 from six such groups since May. The police said yesterday that the loot ranged from $75 in stamps to $3,800 in cash.

Elia Kazan's excellent and thoughtful article denouncing the deplorable state of the theatre and the inevitable need for a city or national project as a solution to the problem also touched, but too briefly, on another apparent ill. True, the lively art of the theatre faces extinction, but the fault is not wholly with the gods, the angels, the backers, the gamblers or the financial titans.

PALERMO -- For all its glorious sunshine, excellent accommodations for winter visitors, and its comparatively modest prices, Sicily's tourist business is facing an unmerited crisis this year. It is the work of one man -- the bandit Giuliano, the much-publicized overlord of Montelepre, Partinico and other obscure villages in which no tourist ever dreams of setting foot.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, warned last night that the nation was nearing a decision between the "freedom to learn" and the restrictions attendant upon a too centralized government.

" THE DARKNESS BELOW" of Mr. Morton's title refers doubly to the subterranean struggle of the book's hero to call his soul his own and to the subterranean workshop which is the prevailing locale. To earn a living for his wife and child while he is studying for his American medical degree, a young refugee doctor takes a night job as the breadbaker's assistant in a West Side New York bakery.

Resolutions calling upon President Truman to intervene in the coal and steel strikes and endorsing steps taken by the General Assembly of the United Nations to outlaw mass genocide were adopted yesterday at the closing business session of the board of directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Author and associate producer of 'Battleground" for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The film will open on Nov. 11, at the Astor.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Three minutes of Ed Salem was too much for Mississippi State today as the Alabama halfback paced his teammates to a 35-6 homecoming victory before 26,000 fans.

In your letters columns Mrs. Anna Y. Fenn wonders if the word "accident" used in Thomas Mann's article, "Germany Today," with reference to Goethe, could have been a mistranslation. May I refer Mrs. Fenn to the famous statement of Nietzsche: "Goethe, not only a good and great man but a whole culture, was in the history of the Germans an accident without consequences."

Although the nation's educators do not know where they are to get the $10 billion needed to build new school buildings for the increased enrollment that is anticipated, they do have some clearly defined ideas about the type of plant and equipment that should be provided.

The dissolution of such corporate structures as the Commonwealth and Southern utilities "empire," now being completed, together with the large number of companies seeking additional equity capital from offerings of stock to their own shareholders, has caused large commercial banks here to establish a whole new body of corporate trust procedures.

Pension history contains some curious chapters. An Encyclopaedia Britannica article recalls that in the year 1676 King Charles II of England granted to his illegitimate son to whom he had given the title Duke of Richmond a perpetual pension consisting of a duty of one shilling a ton on all coal exported from the Tyne for consumption in England.
Independent research opportunities will be available to University of Delaware seniors this fall, as a result of a new program toward more individual instruction.
ODESSA, Tex., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Oil and twenty-three years have caused Odessa to all but forget its once vital cattle industry.
The United Nations General Assembly, meeting in plenary session at Flushing Meadow, decided yesterday to open and close its deliberations with a minute of silence devoted to prayer and meditation.

MR. BELA FABIAN, a member of the Executive Committee of the Hungarian Government-in-Exile, first met Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty in the Thirties, when the prelate was Abbe of Zalaegerszeg, leading the fight against nazism in Western Hungary.
Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, India's Prime Minister, returned to New York from Boston by air yesterday morning, but departed again at 3:17 P. M. for Buffalo, from where he will go to Canada.
A great double rainbow filled the sky yesterday at 5 P. M., and passersby in the Midtown area stood staring at it until the inner ring faded away twelve minutes after making its appearance.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Arnold College of Connecticut stormed back from a two-touchdown deficit to defeat the Merchant Marine Academy by 26 to 14 today.

DeWitt Clinton High School's football team ran roughshod over a lighter Seward Park eleven, 32 -- 7, in a Bronx-Manhattan P. S. A. L. contest at Triborough Stadium, Randall's Island, yesterday. The triumph gave Coach Hank Jacobsohn's Red and Black charges their second victory in four starts and marked the second defeat for Coach Ike Weissberger's forces.

UNDER its somewhat pretentious title, "The Education of a Concert-Goer" proves to be a pleasant, readable and unstartling addition to the rapidly growing list of books written for the lay music public. In the course of nine or ten briskly written chapters, the author covers such varied aspects of professional musical life as concert programming, musical interpretation, symphony orchestra economics, listening habits, music criticism and the problems of the orchestral musician.

THE dainty blossoms of abelia are a contrast to the vivid coloring of the landscape in October. Although this beautiful shrub flowers from July until frost, its bloom is more appreciated at this time of year when colorful foliage and berries are more characteristic of woody plants.
COVENTRY, England, Oct. 22 -- Lady Godiva was undraped again today -- and this time everybody watched.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The resignation this week of Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, meant more than the departure of an officeholder. It was a decisive turning point at the three-year mark of the Council.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Oklahoma turned a big break into a late first-period touchdown today, then buried Nebraska under a football scoring barrage that netted a 48-to-0 victory.
With the eleven Communist leaders facing a week-end in jail after their sentencing on Friday, protests continued to be made yesterday by left-wing organizations against the outcome of the trial.

" LEAP TO FREEDOM" is the fascinating story of Oksana Kasenkina's life from her childhood in Russia under the Czar to her dramatic escape from the Soviet Consulate in New York City. As a personal history it does not differ greatly from many other stories of Russians who watched the creeping terror of communism spreading across their country.

MR. STUART'S domain is that sector of Broadway known to the trade as Tin Pan Alley, and his aim is to lift the curtain on it. The man of his title is Pidgeon Ellis, editor of "Showcase," top trade paper in the entertainment world. Pidgeon is uncrowned king of the Alley.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- With warning that the United Palestine Appeal is faced with an economic crisis that "may spell disaster for the Jewish State," Magistrate Morris Rothenberg of New York, acting national chairman of the Appeal, reported today that the Appeal and its agencies had incurred a deficit of $90,872,000 in the last ten years.

ATLANTA, Oct. 22 -- Gov. Herman Talmadge today bitterly denounced a suit brought in Federal Court by eighteen Negro parents to equalize education facilities in Irwin County. He charged angrily that the aim of northern agitators is to move Negro children "into the nearest, most convenient white schools."

KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- In the Hudson River Valley counties between Albany and Westchester, as in most other sections of the state, the contest for Robert F. Wagner's, vacated Senate seat appears to be playing second fiddle to electoral races for local offices.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Grains showed an easier trend without developing any pronounced weakness on the Board of Trade today. The largest losses were in soybeans, running to more than a cent a bushel at times. Toward the close a mild rally reduced or canceled early declines.

DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 22 -- Dr. Arthur Hollis Edens, whose teaching career began in a small school in the mountains of East Tennessee, was formally installed today as the third president of Duke University.

GENEVA -- Although Switzerland has a big head start over its mountainous neighbors -- Austria, Italy and France -- in attracting American tourists for winter sports, this country is undertaking a serious land continuing campaign to insure the success of the coming winter season.

EDWARD JOHNSON'S final season as director of the Metropolitan Opera Association will assemble more important new singers in the casts than the Metropolitan has present ed its audiences in years. Nor is novelty confined to the casts New productions of operas will be notable.

JOE MORETON is the kind of character preachers and reviewers like to condemn. He has the best of intentions, but everything turns out wrong for him. He is very eager to make the football team in high school, but when he gets his hands on the ball he runs toward the other team's goal.

NOW, when jack o'lanterns begin to leer and the moon looks witch-haunted, this book of tales will be a boon to youngsters who like to scare themselves into fits and yet keep a grasp upon reality. With the exception of the devilish black cat in Mary Walsh's fine, eerie tale of Ireland, these spooks are a friendly lot, bearing a strong resemblance to prankish relatives or the boy next door.
ALBANY, N. Y., Oct. 17 (AP) -- This year's harvests of most major crops in New York State dropped below those of 1948.

UNLIKE Capt. Joshua Slocum, Jack London, Richard Halliburton, and others who have embarked upon sea adventure for the sake of thrills and book material, Texas-born John Caldwell undertook to sail his twenty-nine-foot cutter Pagan westward across the Pacific for one simple reason: he wanted to be on the other side.

THEORY at certain times may be the most practical thing in the world. An important question today is what kind of ideas influence social and political conduct, and under what limiting conditions. In recent times it has been fashionable to assert that positivistic and nominalistic patterns of thought have undermined the moral and social foundations of the West while universalistic and other modes of thought can alone preserve peace and further the common welfare.

MOST of the eight essays in this book, by a group of Harvard physicians and scientists, deal with the fundamentals of disease, research and education, which -- along with social changes that are much less well brought out -- have transformed the old-time "poorhouse for the sick" into the workshop of science and service as we now know it.

IN Mr. Stewart's new novel it is not the atom bomb that destroys civilization but an "unknown disease of unparalleled rapidity of spread and fatality." There are a few survivors left here and there, and one of them is Isherwood Williams, called Ish.

Katherine Bacon, pianist, who has made appearances in this city over the years, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Her program included the Bach-Liszt "Fantasie and Fugue" in G minor; the Gluck-Sgambati "Melody" from "Orfeo"; Beethoven's Sonata in D minor, Op. 31, No. 2; Chopin's Ballade in F minor; Schubert's Impromptu in G flat; the Schubert-Liszt "Hark! Hark! the Lark" and "Erl-King," and Ravel's "Valses nobles et sentimentales," "Jeaux d'eau" and Toccata.

Although no large order cancellations have been received by manufacturers from retail stores in strike areas, the possibility of such a development is not being overlooked, representatives of large buying offices declared here last week.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Spotting Colgate University a 13-7 half-time lead, Rutgers' football machine rallied in the second half to overwhelm the Red Raiders, 35 -- 13, before 7,000 homecoming day fans today.

THE title of this book describes in capsule form what the story is about. The "Will" is one left by an eccentric old bachelor, Roderick Haughton, and consists of one pungent sentence: "I leave my fortune to whoever finds it." The "Way" is the method by which each of Haughton's five personable nephews goes about trying to find this fortune for himself.

CHATTANOOGA, Oct. 22 -- It became evident this week that the Tennessee Valley Authority would raise again the issue of the steam-generating plant. But this time the urgency of national security, instead of "firming up" the power output in the far-flung Federal agency's system, will be the basis upon which funds for the project will be requested.

THERE is no finer gift than laughter and Margaret Scoggin has given generously of it. She has shared it with hundreds upon hundreds of young people in her work at the Nathan Straus branch of the New York Public Library.

ANYONE who imagines that the sort of art that tells a straightforward story realistically died in about 1900 should visit the ACA Gallery, where a group of unregenerate narrative paintings by Anton Refregier is on view.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Ending its seventy-second session here today the council of the International Chamber of Commerce recommended a program of action to the governments of the world so that opportunities afforded by recent currency devaluations would not be lost.

AS John Dickson Carr has become the Master of the Locked Room, Ellery Queen the Master of the Dying Message, and Agatha Christie the Mistress of the Least Suspected Person, so John Rhode has specialized, and with remarkably little competition, in the Rube Goldberg Murder Device.

Large-scale promotions last week helped retailers to overcome lower dollar volume, which has resulted from strikes and unseasonably warm weather, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 22 -- Volume of business activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District for the first nine months of the year was reported at 96 per cent of last year's record high for the same period by the Reserve bank in Minneapolis last week.

The Stalin-Tito fight -- a fight that has become more and more a part of the larger struggle between the Kremlin and the West -- last week headed up at the United Nations. At Flushing Meadow the General Assembly took its most important and dramatic action of the present session.

In his article "At Princeton: 'Drawn From Life,'" describing the Princeton exhibit of portraits by the late S. J. Woolf, H. I. Brock points out that the portrait of Bernard Shaw which launched the artist on his interviewing career is "missing -- regrettably" from the group of drawings lent to the University Library by Mr. Woolf's widow.
ON Leyte, Automatic Rifleman Charles Cosgrove's teeth were knocked out by a Japanese bullet. Back home in San Francisco he couldn't find a denture cleaner he liked, so he made one.
TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- One of Japan's leading wrestlers has been banned from competition for the rest of the year because he is too ardent a baseball fan.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 -- The Soviet press hailed today what it described as a new victory of Michurin science -- the development of the "nest" method of forestation] by Academician Prof. Trofim D. Lysenko for use in the great Soviet shelter-belt system, which celebrated its first anniversary two days ago.

BUENOS AIRES -- This city often gives its visitors the disappointing impression that it is just another big cosmopolitan town, not unlike New York. Bored by the maudlin sophistication of the tango, many a tourist has gone back to the States without discovering the primitive heart of South America that beats beneath the midtown clamor of the Argentine capital.

STATION WOR-TV started its operations with a conspicuous lack of advance fanfare and now that there has been an opportunity to sample its wares it is not difficult to see why. As the seventh outlet in the metropolitan area, the new station is making no pretense to the lavish behavior of its elder contemporaries and plainly is cutting every possible economic corner.

THE name of this new atlas suggests the change that has taken place in the American Weltanschauung since the second World War. It is "cosmopolitan" where it used to be "commercial." Maps of foreign spheres lead off and are followed by maps of the forty-eight states, the reverse of the old order.

NO group of plants gives so much for so little as the deciduous flowering trees and shrubs. Many are dual-purpose, with blooms in spring and fruit in autumn. With few exceptions, there is still time to plant. And some of the choicest shrubs must be set out now, because they start growth so early in the spring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- When President Wilson took office on March 4, 1913, he was confronted, as President Truman is now confronted, with the problem of recognizing or not recognizing a revolutionary new government of China.

Cornell got a bad scare yesterday before squeezing out a two-point victory over Princeton, while Michigan bounded back after two setbacks and toppled Minnesota. Fordham defeated Syracuse, Army routed Columbia, while Penn, Dartmouth and Yale also triumphed in Eastern contests. Scores of leading games:

" THE PRIDE OF THE MALAY RACE" is the biography of the Philippine national hero, Jose Rizal, written by the late Dr. Rafael Palma, a former president of the University of the Philippines, and translated from the Spanish by Roman Ozaeta, an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- Pennsylvania's undefeated, and insuficiently esteemed football team made Navy its fourth straight victim today. In thorough control of the situation from the start, the Red and Blue scored a touchdown in each period to pile up a 28-7 plurality before 66,125 onlookers, largest Eastern crowd of the season, at Franklin Field.

DEVOTEES of Jane Austen tend to divide into two camps. One group is garrulous, noisy, filled with apostolic fervor. Its members proselyte; they proclaim from the housetops and the printing presses that "Our Jane" is not only the greatest of English novelists but likewise a friend and pal.

MR. FOSTER, who conducts a weekly column in Collier's magazine, has put out a handsome collection of what -- for want of a better word -- might be called "peculiarities." The book contains 600 items from his column, and the information they contain is the stuff Sherlock Holmes chided Watson for remembering.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 22 -- Halfback Chuck Ortmann led a rejuvenated Michigan football team to a smashing 14-7 win over powerful Minnesota today.
President Truman has entered actively into the New York Senatorial contest and in effect is making the outcome a national test between the two major parties, it developed yesterday.

HERE is the interesting and profusely documented history of the growth of the oil industry in the Southwest, from the wild days at Cushing, E1 Dorado and Ranger to today's scientific and orderly production, transportation and reCming.

LONDON, Oct. 22 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers, last season's cup winners and this year's English League leaders. suffered their first defeat of the soccer campaign today, bowing by 3 -- 0 to Manchester United before a crowd of 51,457 fans.

SO perceptive and prophetic was Alexis de Tocqueville's "Democracy in America" that this book, first published in France in 1835, may still be regarded as the most penetrating report ever made by a visitor to a foreign country.

During the war years, when American colleges and universities were virtually depleted, many thoughtful educators feared that the loss to this country in trained personnel would create a dangerous shortage that might possibly take a generation to make up.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 22 -- An investigation into charges that liquor has been flowing freely into Georgia's 130 dry counties "under the inducement, protection and promotion of state officials and employes" aroused a heated political controversy this week.
The United Nations General Assembly took the first concrete steps yesterday toward curtailing its lengthy debates and expediting the conduct of business.
A veteran theatre operator and distributor of foreign films, Mr. Mayer recently visited Israel after resigning as Chief of the Film Branch, Office of Military Government for Germany.

Film forums for both adults and young people are presented by the New York Public Library in branches throughout Manhattan, The Bronx and Richmond. This week there will be a forum for each of the groups, the one for adults, "Atomic Power," to be held on Thursday at 8 P. M. at 518 East 125th Street, the other, "Pride and Prejudice," on Wednesday at 7:30 P. M. at 14 Bay Street, S. I.

BERTITA HARDING, whose specialty has been historical themes, turns here to the recounting of her childhood memories. Born to parents of Hungarian, French and German ancestry, she spent her earliest years in Nuremberg and Berlin.

THE material in Margaret Lee Runbeck's book consists of verified facts concerning divine help in the everyday lives of a great number of people. These stories were written or told to the author after her request for such experiences appeared in The Christian Herald.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 22 -- Rhode Island savings banks next month will enter the small-loan field under new legislation which allows them to make loans up to $1,000 for periods not exceeding eighteen months, with or without security.

BARRING intervention by President Truman, it was indicated at the close of the week that an industrial crisis of the first magnitude would be upon the country within ten days as a result of the labor-management deadlock over pensions in the steel industry.

WHAT was inside the box with red wheels standing in the garden? The cow didn't know, the pony didn't know, the rabbit didn't know. The duck knew only that it was sleeping. The kitten purred, the dog kept watch -- and then a little head popped up from the wagon.

MAY I take violent exception to Roger Burlingame's doleful account of the modern book editor's activities (Book Review, Sept. 11). To me he has reduced the noble art of book editing to its least common denominator.

Two of the choicest offerings of the local professional football season conflict today in a patent manifestation of how silly a proposition the "war" between the National League and the All-America Conference, now in its fourth year, has come to be.

Certain large liquor retailers are becoming cautious of overstocking private brand merchandise because of their fear of a possible "open market" during the holiday season, it was reported here yesterday.

TO many people today, the West Indies are almost as much of a mystery as they were to Columbus when he first encountered them 457 years ago this month and gave them their name, unaware that he was still half a world away from his goal in the Far East.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 4 to 7 points lower yesterday, but the market held within a narrow range all day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, instigator of the recent investigation of the Atomic Energy Commission by the Joint Congressional Commitee on Atomic Energy, said today he has found an ally in Dr. Harold C. Urey of the Institute of Nuclear Physics of the University of Chicago.

UP until a few years ago, the lilies listed in catalogues could be counted on one hand. Today, there are some fifty distinct varieties available and, what is more, this number is being constantly increased by the hybridizers.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A new gold discovery has started a small rush to the Yukon.

Competent observers are agreed that the ambitious program of German "re-education," lately more modestly styled "reorientation," will prove a failure equal to that of denazification unless the German youth is made cognizant of the democratic values and accepts them.

President Truman is reviving his demand for increased taxes. Early in the year he asked for an additional $4,000,000,000. During the summer, when employment was falling off and a recession was in prospect, requests for more taxes ceased to be heard. Now that business is deemed to be "looking up," it is proposed that taxes be increased at the next session of Congress.

THE Swiss-born author of this book, who studied in his homeland, in Germany, Italy and France before joining the staff of the University of Toronto in 1931, is enough of a scholar to present his findings only as a preliminary report of rather limited scope.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Indiana's underrated Hoosiers, beaten in their last eleven games, pulled a man-sized upset today when they blasted Pittsburgh's undefeated Panthers, 48 to 14, before a wildly cheering throng of about 20,000.

THE Hoosier State has long had the reputation of being prolific of writers. Now it appears that the Hawkeye State is the mother of pollsters. It was "because Iowa has produced many of the persons now prominent in the field" that the state university arranged a conference on attitude and opinion research.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, announced yesterday that he would lead the AFL delegation to a meeting in London on Nov. 28.

The Madison Square Boys' Club has taken for its annual benefit the evening performance of Nov. 30 of Katharine Cornell's play, "That Lady" at the Martin Beck Theatre. Tickets for it may be obtained at the club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 22 -- Secretary of the Army Gordon Gray urged tonight a "unified -- not unilateral -- approach" to unification.

In "Behind the Split in the Supreme Court," Thomas Reed Powell's observation that the "conservatives" are hardheaded and the "liberals" lamentably "soft-hearted" is an old saw whose edge the years have dulled.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- The speech that Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, will make to the European Marshall Plan Council in Paris Oct. 31 is expected by both United States and European officials to mark a turning point in the European Recovery Program.

AS American concert-goers become increasingly sophisticated, musically speaking, conductors have to search more diligently for program material that is fresh and unhackneyed. No longer can a season be carried by the old war-horses of the repertory.
BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 22 -- Louisiana State's bustling Bengals found an offense tonight and handed North Carolina its first regular season defeat since 1947 by a 13-7 score.

" EASY as it appears to be to fabricate reprints of rare books," once wrote the eminent bibliographer Thomas J. Wise, "it is in actual practice absolutely impossible to do so in such a manner that detection cannot follow the event."

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic-Liberal candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, declared yesterday that New York City's housing program was one of the outstanding achievements of Mayor O'Dwyer's administration.

Creeping paralysis of the national economy, resulting from strikes in basic industries, cast a pall over security markets last week. Attempts by Government mediators to settle differences brought no tangible progress, and the inevitable result of prolonged strikes brought a slump in the industrial indices.

The story of Frank Costello's rise from rags to riches is veiled in obscurity. Even such fundamental details as his true name have been given in various ways by himself as well as by police and friends.

GENEVA -- Despite such commendable endeavors as United Nations Day, which is being observed tomorrow throughout the United States and a great part of the world, many persons are unaware of the great number of international public and private agencies that work day by day in the fields of economics, labor, health, education and welfare to promote the international cooperation and trust essential to world peace.

THIS year's selection of O. Henry Memorial Prize Stories comes to us with the blessings not only of its able editor, Herschel Brickell, but author Eudora Welty, critic John Hutchens and Prof. Roy B. West Jr. of the University of Kansas, who served as judges for the three cash awards.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Indicating perhaps the direction of the wind at headquarters of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in advance of the annual convention, the District of Columbia Industrial Union Council has demanded the expulsion of pro-Communist officers from the CIO "and, if need be, the organizations they represent."

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- This British West Indian island, three air hours from Miami has nearly doubled its number of holiday visitors in the four years since the end of the war. According to official figures released by the Government Tourist Development Board, Jamaica's natural beauty attracted 40,606 visitors in 1946, 61,831 two years later and, for the first half of this year, 38,580 holiday makers, or an annual rate of 77,160.

The voluntary hospitals of the country, of which eighty-six in New York are members of the United Hospital Fund, have long been leaders in research and clinical investigation that has saved millions of dollars in medical expense and untold numbers of lives.

QUOGUE, L. I, Oct. 22 -- Laddie of Roe, liver and white dog belonging to Nelson Smith of Hartford, Conn., won one of the East's foremost stakes for English Springer Spaniels and in the process completed his field trial championship on the dunes hard by Moriches Bay today.

IN this closely reasoned and beautifully written series of essays, Mr. White, Professor of Anthropology at the University of Michigan, makes good use of the Socratic method in attempting to prove that not man but his works is the measure of all things.

MR. JONES, who is Lecturer in History at the University of Bristol, has set himself rigid limits in his book on Manchuria. Within those limits he has done a workmanlike job, obviously painstaking and more than usually valuable to specialists in the field.

William Dubilier, founder and technical director of Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation, is introducing a revolutionary new process of welding without electricity or any applied heat. The process was developed in the laboratories of the General Electric Company, Ltd., London, which is not associated with the General Electric Company of this country.

Foreign traders are watching with interest the suit for a permanent injunction brought against the State Department in the Federal District Court in Washington by Robert E. Rodes, Commander of the Morocco Post of the American Legion and spokesman for a group of American importers and exporters in Morocco.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Lanky Lynn Chandnois showed the way today as Michigan State overpowered Penn State, 24 to 0, to the delight of a homecoming crowd of 34,746 fans.
" THERE are only two kinds of people," said Filemona, my Otomi Indian maid, "the good and the bad. You can always tell good persons. They smile well." She added graciously, "Even Americanos."

ROME, Oct. 22 -- The first tentative step toward socialized medicine has been taken in Italy with a bill introduced in the Senate obligating the Government to produce all the most widely used medicines and to place them at the disposal of the public at the lowest possible prices.

THERE are some playgoers who wait six months for a pair of seats to a smash hit. And others in more of a hurry who pay scalpers' prices. And still others, ordinary citizens with no cousins in producers' offices, who go to every single opening -- for no more than $3 apiece.

WASHINGTON, Oct 22 -- All of the issues in the Army-Navy-Air Force controversy, as revealed in the hearings before the House Armed Services Committee, revolve around sea power. Since Soviet Russia, the enemy that everyone is talking about, has no large surface navy, the question arises: What is the Navy's concept of its role in a war with Russia?

" THE TUNNEL," by Baynard Kendrick, might be called "Self Psychiatry, or What to Do If Your Husband Seems to Be Murdering You." As the book opens we find that Natalie Sherritt, a young attractive girl with a devoted husband, is in bad shape.

THREE ballets will have their first American performances in the Sadler's Wells Ballet season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday evening. Two of them are by Frederick Ashton -- "A Wedding Bouquet" and "Apparitions." The former, created in 1937, has music by Lord Berners and words by Gertrude Stein, which Constant Lambert will speak.

OTTAWA, Oct. 22 -- The proposal of the Dominion Government to seek the right for Canada to amend her own Constitution has produced a lively quarrel between Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent and Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec.

The United Nations General Assembly officially registered yesterday its "increased concern" at the charges that religious and political freedoms were being violated in Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria and asked the International Court of Justice to examine the legal possibilities of an inquiry.

Six prominent City College alumni were honored last evening by 800 of their fellow graduates at the sixty-ninth annual dinner of the college's Associate Alumni in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor Hotel.
OMAHA, Oct. 22 -- An undesirable alien known as the European corn borer edged out Washington farm bill news and the weather in conversational favor throughout the Midwest farm belt this week.

LOS ANGELES -- While most of the nation is just recovering from the vacation season, the Southwest is just starting to think about its annual role of recreational host to tourists from all over the globe.

EARLE BIRNEY'S third book of poetry, "The Strait of Anian," consists in equal parts of new work and of poems reprinted from his two earlier volumes, "David" and "Now Is Time." The poems are grouped under two headings, "One Society" and "One World," which suggest something of the book's principal themes -- Canada and Canadian life, and the war and its aftermath.

There will be a round of entertainment in conjunction with the sixty-first National Horse Show, which opens at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 1 and continues through Nov. 8. As usual the social headquarters of the association will be at the Waldorf-Astoria, where daily there will be luncheons, receptions and dinners.

Two hundred students from Eastern Europe have been brought to this country under the Displaced Persons Act and enrolled, expenses paid, in colleges and universities under a project initiated by the nation's student groups, it became known yesterday.

Six prominent City College alumni were honored last evening by 800 of their fellow graduates at the sixty-ninth annual dinner of the college's Associate Alumni in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor Hotel.

IF there is to be a revival of Milton, corresponding on its level to those of Henry James and John Donne, the book before us may help it along. Professor Hanford, who is among the most distinguished of scholarly critics, is an old Miltonian.
REGINA, Sask. (Canadian Press) -- June McNichol Metcalfe formerly of Saskatchewan and now of New York, follows an unusual calling.

More than 270 speakers from university, laboratory and every phase of industry are scheduled to deliver 200 papers at the seventieth annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Nov. 28 to Dec. 2, in the Statler Hotel, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- State and territorial health officers in conference here today adopted a resolution of opposition to the Administration's proposed compulsory health insurance program.

CIUDAD, Trujillo -- To any traveler who comes to Ciudad Trujillo by air, as did, the city is obviously the newest in the Caribbean. Even before he lands he sees a terrain studded with modernistic factories, hotels and public buildings, strewn like white cardboard cut-outs on the green landscape below him.

THREE ballets will have their first American performances in the Sadler's Wells Ballet season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday evening. Two of them are by Frederick Ashton -- "A Wedding Bouquet" and "Apparitions." The former, created in 1937, has music by Lord Berners and words by Gertrude Stein, which Constant Lambert will speak.

OTTAWA, Oct. 22 -- The proposal of the Dominion Government to seek the right for Canada to amend her own Constitution has produced a lively quarrel between Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent and Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec.

Passage last week by Congress of the new farm-price support bill was reflected in higher prices on distant futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange. The market had been weak early, but closed unchanged to 28 points higher.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- United States Ambassadors and Ministers from behind the Iron Curtain were assembling here today for exchange of views and information on policies and events in the Communist countries of Eastern Europe.
A principal has many fond memories of his favorite school, and Dr. Henry E. Hein of James Monroe High School in the Bronx is no exception. There are two incidents that he clearly recalls.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Joint Atomic Energy Committee in Congress will soon make a thorough study of the country's civil defenses, Senator Brien McMahon, committee chairman, said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles even fumbled well today as they ran, passed and kicked the befuddled Washington Redskins dizzy to win a National Football League game, 49 to 14, before 28,855 at Shibe Park.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy, the nation's senior military statesman, said today he was confident that service unification would "work out all right in the long run," despite current feuding among Army, Navy and Air Force leaders.

Adequate maintenance of existing public health services requires a doubling of the number of doctors, nurses, sanitary engineers and other personnel in that field, according to the top officers of the American Public Health Association, whose seventy-seventh annual meeting will open here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 23 -- Yugoslavia has told the United Nations Balkan Conciliation Committee that she does not "exclude the possibility" of signing a separate agreement with Greece, it was officially disclosed today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23 -- A long-lost statement on Jesus Christ by Maimonides, leading Hebrew sage of the Middle Ages, has been found recently and appears in a volume, just published by the Yale University Press.

QUOGUE, L. I., Oct. 23 -- William Witt, a resident of Fishers Island, N. Y., and an enthusiast in field sports, died while about to shoot over his dog at the annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association today. He was 46 years old.

Harry Uviller, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Controller and impartial chairman of the dress industry, declared yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer's telegram to Benjamin Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, was both futile and insincere.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Trading in October lard on the Board of Trade ceased at the close of business yesterday, and belated short covering sent the price up rapidly in the last few minutes of trading as there were 212 uncompleted contracts when trading started on Thursday.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- The French Administration is now studying a vast scheme for stimulating exports to the dollar zone, particularly to the United States. Experts here are hopeful that within a few years France may be able to sell on an average $120,000,000 of products in the United States each year.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Plans are being completed for the Tuxedo Autumn Ball to be held Saturday night in the Tuxedo Club. There will be the usual dinners and other social functions in connection with the fete.

In the wake of Saturday's havoc, leaving Minnesota, North Carolina and Kentucky strewn among the wreckage, any football prophet daring to come out of the storm cellar and open up shop again will hardly venture to wax dogmatic beyond proclaiming Notre Dame, Army and Oklahoma as the three strongest teams in the country.
President Truman will receive the city's customary elaborate police protection today while he is here to dedicate the United Nations Secretariat Building at Forty-second Street and the East River.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers, displaying their best brand of single-wing power, held on to a first-place Eastern Division tie in the National Football League today by setting back the New York Bulldogs, 24 to 13.

Peter Pears, English tenor, and Benjamin Britten, English composer-pianist, who are on their initial concert tour of this country, gave their first New York recital last night at Town Hall, where they were fervently welcomed by a large audience.

The Yankees moved to the top of the All-America Conference standings by pulverizing the San Francisco Forty-Niners, 24 to 3, before 38,187 onlookers (36,197 paid), at the Stadium yesterday. Cashing in on the breaks forced by its uncompromising defense, Red Strader's aroused team scored all its points in the second half.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- To British military men a bitter public quarrel between, armed services such as the one in the United States is almost inconceivable. It could not happen here they say -- or at least it never has.

Among the leading art events of October's last week in New York are the opening of a new gallery and a number of interesting one-man shows of work by such European and American masters as Braque and Ben Shahn.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The alert Detroit Lions won their first National League victory in five starts this season today with a 24-7 decision over the Chicago Cardinals before 23,215 at Comiskey Park.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 23 -- A three-day conference of social scientists and educators that ended here today has worked out a plan for intergroup relations centers to be established at colleges and universities in this country and abroad.

Sick children are no longer treated as ordinary patients in the eighty-six voluntary hospitals that are members of the United Hospital Fund. Children react more quickly in recovery from sickness if their food is made attractive and if their play interests are considered.

At one of scores of celebrations throughout the world commemorating the fourth anniversary of the United Nations today, President Truman will address the first outdoor session of the fifty-nine-nation General Assembly at a noon-hour cornerstone ceremony on the site of the world capital at Forty-second Street and the East River.

The launching of the Norwegian flag motorship Havnor, to be placed in the North Atlantic service of the Meyer Line, was announced here yesterday by Boyd, Weir Sewell, Inc., 24 State Street, general agents.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 23 -- A full-dress debate on full employment, involving a review of whether members of the United Nations are fulfilling them Charter obligation to take steps toward assuring high levels of employment in their countries, will open here tomorrow in the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- An end of the state of war that exists between Germany and the Western powers is one action that is being suggested in Western Allies circles as a means of strengthening the position of the government of the Western German Federal Republic in its contest with the Communist state for the allegiance of the Germans.

The Congress of American Women, which the House Committee on un-American Activities on Saturday accused of being "composed primarily of a hard core of Communist party members and a circle of close sympathizers," charged here yesterday that the committee had issued its report "with the obvious intent of preventing women from participating in campaigns for peace such as those initiated by the CAW."

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 23 -- South Africans will soon have to pay more for smaller allowances of gasoline and toward the end of the month the price of bread is likely to become higher, either directly or in the form of increased subsidies.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Before sailing on the Ile de France on his first visit to the United States, Jean Desses inaugurated the midseason. Abandoning the interest formerly concentrated on skirts, he turns his attention to bodices, especially to sleeves, dramatic leg-of-mutton sleeves that broaden the shoulder span.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- American shippers want coordinated transportation service but "we won't pay the price of monopolies for it," Representative Andrew Jacobs, Democrat of Indiana, told the convention of American Trucking Associations, Inc., today.

A history of the National Press Club and a description of Washington news coverage will be published by Doubleday on Thursday.
