"Dateline: Washington, The Story of National Affairs Journalism in the Life and Times of the National Press Club" has been edited by Cabell Phillips, Washington correspondent of the Sunday edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, with the assistance of Duncan Aikman, Homer Joseph Dodge, William C. Bourne and William A. Kinney.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 23 -- A three-point national drive to cut costs of Government buying, to eliminate upscrupulous bidding, and to put to work the recommendations of the Hoover report, as aplied to purchasing, was started here today.
HONOLULU, Oct. 23 -- A ninety-ship "invasion" fleet from the West Coast of the United States drew near to Hawaii today, bringing both hypothetical and practical succor for the beleaguered islands.

Weary New York motorists who have had their troubles inching their way through the repaving jobs in Forty-second Street and at Columbus Circle may be expected to look forward with misgivings to the adventures that await them next summer when they drive through parts of the West Side Highway from Leroy Street north to Seventy-second Street.

When selecting the patterns shown this week, we had the bride and her trousseau in mind not that the patterns are exclusively for her -- on the contrary, they will serve all young and smart-minded women. They compose a wardrobe that is excellently adapted to traveling because of the multiple functions for which the styles can serve.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- French and United States officials who have worked together for French recovery before and since the Marshall Plan began are concerned lest a break-up of the moderate coalition regime should undo the progress made toward financial stability.

VIENNA, Oct. 23 -- Moscow has launched an intensive campaign to teach the satellite states Russian and to Sovietize their law, medicine, industrial and agricultural techniques, culture and even sports. The Soviet propaganda, which seems designed to convince the "people's democracies" of the superiority of everything Russian, obviously is intended to counteract the heresy of national communism and to this end is being stepped up from week to week.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -W]am D. mbree, chairman of the Citizens Committee on Veteran Preference, announced today that the committee would award a total of $525 in cash prizes to high school students for the fourteen best essays on the subject 'Vhy Members of 1V[y Family Should Vote 'Yes' on mendment No. 5."

Four years ago today, while the horrors of the last war were still fresh in men's minds, the great majority of the nations of the world put into effect a new and solemn covenant known as the Charter of the United Nations, which dedicated them to the preservation of international peace and security and to the promotion of justice, freedom, social progress and the fundamental human rights.

MOSCOW, Oct. 23 -- The principal Soviet newspapers, Pravda and Izvestia, published declarations today emphasizing Soviet support for the United Nations as an instrument of general peace and security. They declared that Russia would fight for the strengthening of the United Nations against the undermining efforts of the "ruling circles of the United States and England."

CAIRO, Oct. 23 -- Nuri as-Said, Iraqi Premier, told Arab and foreign newspaper men here today that he knew nothing about negotiations for an Iraqi-Syrian union except what the newspapers had been writing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The complete papers of former United States Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York were presented to Georgetown University today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23 -- Specialists from the faculties of Harvard University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology have launched a study of the monopoly problem in American business and government, with a view toward devising standards of acceptable competition.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 23 -- The forty-four-day strike of 5,200 operating employes against the Missouri Pacific Railroad, one of the longest major rail walkouts recorded, ended tonight with an agreement to send unsettled union claims to arbitration.

LILLIAN SMITH, the forthright, idealistic and belligerent Southern lady who wrote one of the great best-sellers of the war years, "Strange Fruit," has been strangely quiet during the five years since the publication of that sensational book. For a woman who felt so strongly and wrote so effectively not to write another book immediately was indeed an example of self-restraint.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Oct. 15 to 19, when Congress adjourned sine die, are given in the appended tabulation:

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Two prominent Prague Communist officials, charged with having accepted bribes to finance high life in night clubs and resorts, have been sentenced to long prison terms, an official announcement said tonight.
HONG KONG, Oct. 23 -- A continued steady increase in exports through Hong Kong to Communist-held ports in North China is shown in trade figures for September released here.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- An almost entirely new Old Vic Company has opened its season at the New Theatre with a production of "Love's Labour's Lost" by Hugh Hunt, who, at the age of 36, has graduated to the directorship of the London company from the cadet troupe at Bristol.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Truman and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman of New York got together this afternoon and decided that Mr. Lehman would be elected to the Senate.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- The State Education Department, in a bulletin showing the effect of the wartime birth rate on the state's educational facilities, called upon every community today to rally its resources for the test of assuring the children a proper education.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- The State Controller, Frank C. Moore, appealed today for public support at the polls for two amendments that would change the present constitutional restrictions on the authority of municipalities to borrow money and to levy taxes on real estate.
A lack of intellectual freedom and "a deep insincerity" make Communists unacceptable as teachers in American schools, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University declared yesterday.

In its week-end programs at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Sadler's Wells Ballet occupied itself almost exclusively with repetitions of "Cinderella," with Margot Fonteyn and Moira Shearer alternating in the title role. At Saturday's matinee, however, it broke through this temporary monopoly with a repetition of "Le Lac des Cygnes," with Beryl Grey in the double role of Odette and Odile and John Field as the prince, both for the first time here.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 23 (UP) -- The Czech Government tonight still withheld permission for United States Embassy officials to see Samuel Meryn, 39-year-old Embassy clerk who has been held incomunicado since his arrest by security police on espionage charges two days ago.

The Chamber Art Society, under Robert Craft, gave a concert of unusual length late Saturday afternoon at Town Hall. Works on the list included Stravinsky's cantata, "Renard," and Suite, No. 1, for small orchestra; Alban Berg's Chamber Concerto, Mozart's Clarinet Concerto; de Falla's Concerto for Harpsichord and Arthur Berger's Duo for violin and piano, which received its first hearing.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A St. Louis surgeon said today that in his study of 400 cases of lung cancer, "it has been very rare" to encounter a man with that form of the disease who had not been an "excessive" cigarette smoker at one time.
J. B. Rutter, vice president of Monsanto Chemical Company and general manager of its Merrimac division, will retire on Nov. 1 to become an industrial consultant, with offices in Boston after Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Delegates to the national conference of the United Palestine Appeal unanimously called today on Jewish communities throughout the country not to expand financing of local services or start projects "which must of necessity deprive the United Jewish Appeal of funds necessary for its life-saving service to Israel."

QUOGUE, L. I., Oct. 23 -- Miss Jurisprudence, an exceptionally small black and white English cocker spaniel owned by the Pen-town Kennels of John J. Jacobsen of New York, won the open all-age stake for her breed, concluding feature of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association competition, today.
An outbreak of vandalism at Public School 28, Tremont and Anthony Avenues, the Bronx, was discovered at 6 o'clock last night when water was found flowing from a second floor window.

Despite the fact that it is by no means true in every case, it is, in the language of the economists, "characteristic" of stock market movements that they precede corresponding movements in the index of business activity.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa -- From the rich black dirt plains of Iowa "ABROAD" is nearly 2,000 miles farther away than it is from the eastern or western seaboard. This goes for the mental as well as the physical distance. It is not very far as the airplane flies or for a population as much on the road as Americans.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Don Newcombe, brilliant Dodger pitcher, and Roy Sievers, the Browns' slugging rookie outfields, were named today "rookie of the year" for their respective leagues by the Sporting News. The double selection by the weekly sports publication was a departure from its past custom of selecting only one outstanding freshman.

The New York Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards, including those of New York, the Bronx, Brooklyn, Staten Island, Long Island and Westchester County, urged yesterday defeat of the three housing propositions at the election on Nov. 8.

In a telegram to Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic-Liberal opponent, Senator John Foster Dules, Republican candidate for election, asked yesterday why, with Attorney General J. Howard McGrath and Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin scheduled to speak for Mr. Lehman, Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan and Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, were not also brought into the state to campaign for him.

Quell yon Fredeholz, a handsome 3-year-old German shepherd recently imported from Germany, indicated yesterday he is apparently headed for a sparkling career when he was named best in show at the twenty-second annual fixture of the Queensboro Kennel Club.

This year's drought, combined with an excessive use of water, has resulted in drying up great areas in the reservoirs that feed New York City with water, an inspection of these reservoirs showed yesterday.

Attorney General J. Howard McGrath, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will urge the election of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, in a radio speech tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A close friend today quoted President Truman as having predicted settlement of the coal and steel strikes in less than ten days -- but later the friend amended his remarks.

Elliott Carter and Donald Fuller were the composers at the season's first Composers' Forum at McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, Saturday night. Mr. Carter submitted his impressive Piano Sonata in a memorable performance by Beveridge Webster, and his Quintet for Winds, both of which have been reviewed.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Rams moved into a commanding lead in the National Football League western division championship race today, smashing the Green Bay Packers, 35 to 7, before 37,546 fans.

On Oct. 4 you published a report of a letter written by Robert W. Dowling, president of the Citizens' Budget Commission, to the three principal Mayoralty candidates. The letter requested Mayor O'Dwyer, Newbold Morris and Vito Marcantonio to express their views on six problems concerning New York City's fiscal affairs.

Now that shadows are long even at 4 o'clock, home is becoming less a stopping-off point and more what the lexicon says it is: a fixed place of abode, a family residence. There were times in recent months when home resembled little more than a large valise, with hot and cold running water, in which members of the family paused to rummage between dashes to hill, lake and seashore.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Czechoslovakia's Foreign Minister, Vladimir Clementis, who is now in New York as chief of his country's United Nations delegation, is scheduled to be interrogated on charges of "deviationism" when he returns to Prague, according to diplomatic advices received here.

Stefan Bardas, pianist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Born in Berlin of Austrian parents, he studied in that city with Edwin Fisher and Paul Hindemith, and also was a pupil of Alfredo Casella in Rome.

Military virtues are not confined to any one branch of the armed forces, but are a common possession of all Americans who follow the flag as a life-long calling or in response to an emergency in time of war, Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, declared yesterday.

The Citizens Union issued yesterday an appeal for the adoption of proposed Amendment 5 to the State Constitution, which would revise the preference of veterans in civil service employment. The amendment proposes to do away with absolute preference for disabled veterans and to give all veterans a point preference, as in the Federal service.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 23 -- Two United States consular officers who spent sixteen months virtually incommunicado in Dairen reached here today from that Manchurian port en route to the United States.

Conchita Gaston, young Philippine mezzo-soprano, sang the name role in "Carmen" for the first time in the New York City Opera production at the City Center last night. She received a warm welcome, including tossed flowers and cheers. Supporting her were Mario Berini, as Jose, and Ann Ayars, as Micaela.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Weakness in the cash corn market last week with new grain of high-moisture content selling about 4 cents a bushel under the December delivery on the Board of Trade was a factor in checking the upturn in corn futures after an early bulge.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Government officials admitted today that there is a big loophole in the 1950 crop-control program which may glut the market with certain surpluses.

Parker Fennelly, who played the role of Titus Moody on the Fred Allen show, will be the star of a new weekly comedy radio series over the Mutual Broadcasting System, beginning next month, under the title "Mr. Feathers." Starting Nov. 9, WOR will broadcast the program by transcription each Wednesday evening from 10 to 10:30 o'clock.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 23 -- Vigorous opposition to Air Force proposals to obtain federalization of the Air National Guard appears in reports of leading National Guard officers filed today for submission tomorrow at the opening session of the seventy-first annual conference of the National Guard Association here.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Handicapped by the failures of two predecessors, Georges Bidault of the Popular Republican party, former Premier and for four years Foreign Minister of France, started tonight a desperate effort to solve his nation's political crisis.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 23 -- Jackson J. Holtz, 42-year-old Boston lawyer and veteran of World War II, was elected national commander of the Jewish War Veterans of America at the closing session of their encampment today.

New York's population, growing at an estimated rate of 30,000 persons a year, which already has taxed the city's housing, sanitation, police, fire and other services, now threatens to run ahead of available water supplies in the next few years, a survey indicated yesterday.
Clergymen throughout the city, in special sermons marking World Order Sunday, hailed the United Nations yesterday as the "last best hope" for international peace.

In an investment deal in the Times Square area, the twelve-story store and office building at 156 West Forty-fourth Street, near Broadway, was sold by Loket, Inc., to a buyer in a deal negotiated by Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers.

In September, 1949, your correspondent Cyrus L. Sulzberger reported new waves of genocide perpetrated by the masters of the Kremlin on the Armenian, Estonian, Greek, Iranian, Jewish, Latvian, Lithuanian, Turkish, Ukrainian and White Ruthenian peoples.

After a brief ownership, Hugh K. McGowan, operator, has resold the one-story taxpayer occupied as a supermarket by the Bohack Company on Main Street, in Southold, L. I. The buyer is an investing client of Poletti, Diamond, Freidin Mackay, attorneys.

THE football season is old enough by now to behave with mature-restraint instead of childish perversity. But it's beginning to look as though the 1949 campaign is modeling itself after Peter Pan and is fully determined never to grow up. In the normal course of events a gridiron year begins with coltish unpredictability.
Policemen in a helicopter yesterday rescued four boys from a rowboat stuck in a Jamaica Bay mud flat.

Receiving a citation for his efforts in behalf of civil rights legislation at the annual luncheon of the Metropolitan Council of B'nai B'rith in the Astor Hotel yesterday, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat, of Minnesota, predicted Congressional enactment in the near future of measures to liberalize the Displaced Persons Act and to establish a fair employment practices commission.

Activity was slow in the wholesale garment market here last week, but business is expected to pick up with the openings of additional lines of spring ready-to-wear, which are scheduled for the first week of November, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

For the bride who wishes to learn her culinary ABC's and for the housewife in search of more advanced instruction, cooking school is in session. Courses and demonstrations now being offered on food preparation cover the field from how to boil potatoes to fancy cake making.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Johnny Clement, a refugee from the National Football League, led the Chicago Hornets in cashing in on Baltimore Colt fumbles today to score a 17-7 All-America Conference victory.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- A more effective part in determining prices of fine wools next year will be played by the ratio between supply and demand rather than the recent devaluation of world currencies in relation to the dollar, it was declared here today by F. Eugene Ackerman, chairman of the executive committee of the Wool Bureau.

DETROIT, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings overcame a two-goal deficit to tie the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game tonight. All three Chicago goals were scored while Detroit was short a man because of penalties.

The phrase "Chinese puzzle" has long been used to characterize an especially baffling situation or problem, but there has never been anything more baffling, from the political viewpoint, than the present French puzzle. The picture an outsider gets is something like the squirrel that runs endlessly in the same wheel of the same cage.

The Christian Church, as exemplified by the Roman Catholic Church, was described yesterday afternoon by the Very Rev. James J. McLarney, prior of the Dominican House of Studies, St. Joseph's Priory, Somerset, Ohio, as "the greatest public school system that ever existed."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 23 -- Argentina favors a declaration by the United Nations General Assembly prohibiting the use of atomic weapons except on the authorization of the Assembly or the Little Assembly, it was learned today.
TOKYO, Oct. 23 -- The Government must get out of business in Japan, Michael Lee, head of the Far East branch of the United States Commerce Department, told a press conference yesterday.

Mischa Elman made his New York debut on Dec. 10, 1908, and his recital last night at Carnegie Hall was billed as his "Fortieth Anniversary Concert." Knowing he was passing a milestone, the audience greeted him with especially long applause when he appeared.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer had deliberately suppressed a report of his Commissioner of Investigation, John M. Murtagh. Mr. Morris asserted this was done because it would show that two Brooklyn Representatives in Congress were paid off in stock of a stevedoring company for their alleged part in pushing through a lease on a city-owned Hudson River pier for an obscure shipping line.

Lionel Corporation, manufacturer of model railroads and equipment, will distribute with its Christmas catalogue 2,400,000, miniature outdoor billboards in 300,000 sets of eight designs, it was announced over the week-end. The toy-size poster panels have been produced by Lionel in cooperation with Standard Outdoor Advertising, Inc., and seven leading national advertisers.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 23 -- Israel has made urgent appeals to the United States and Britain for their immediate intervention against "persecution" of Jews in Iraq, it was announced here tonight. The Government said that anti-Jewish acts in Iraq were "liable to rekindle the flames of conflict in the Middle East."

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills withstood a late rally by the Los Angeles Dons today to take a 17-14 All-America Football Conference victory before 21,310 spectators in Civic Stadium and avenge an earlier defeat.

AARONSBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 -- Twenty thousand Americans of all races and faiths gathered today in this tiny central Pennsylvania, farming community to commemorate a tradition of brotherhood and religious freedom that is deep-rooted in the colonial history of the village.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Luke Sewell, 48, tonight was named manager of the Reds for 1950-51 to succeed Bucky Walters. President Warren Giles said Sewell, who coached the Reds this season and was acting manager for three days after Walters was relieved, signed a two-year contract.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Gloomily and apprehensively, the British looked forward today to the unknown but surely unpleasant new economic policies that Prime Minister Clement Attlee will announce in the House of Commons tomorrow. The newspapers were already calling the day "Black Monday."

An attempt by a 15-year-old boy to demonstrate the "Wild West" technique of "fanning" a single-action revolver, was blamed by the police of the Stagg Street station, Brooklyn, yesterday for the serious wounding of Anthony Santamaura, also 15, of 197 Stagg Walk.

Sales of Philip Morris Co., tobacco manufacturers, in the six months ended with September increased $16,990,621 to $128,457,106 from the $111,466,485 volume transacted in the corresponding period last year, the company's report disclosed yesterday.
BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- Unemployment in the three West sectors of Berlin is growing at the rate of 5,000 weekly.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would appoint an Advisory Committee for the Aged to formulate a "master plan" for the aged of New York, who make up about one-eighth of the city's population.
Eleven new films, including importations from England, France, Italy and Greece, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow: ...

The 300th anniversary of the organizing of the first Lutheran Congregation on Manhattan Island was celebrated yesterday afternoon at a rally attended by 2,000 Lutherans of the New York area at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The emphasis that has been put on research in the launching of the two-month campaign for funds of the United Hospital Fund of New York should serve to fix in the minds of potential contributors the importance of research institutions in scientific medical advance.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Since its organization in 1946 by the Stamford Police Association the Police Boy Scout Troop has cut the proportion of complaints involving juveniles at Southfield Village, a public housing project, from 90 to 10 per cent.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 23. -- The twelve-man "emergency mission" of the United Jewish Appeal, which is to start back to the United States tomorrow after a week's tour of Israel, came out strongly today for unrestricted flow of immigration to Israel.

The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber, pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, stressed the belief in his sermon yesterday morning that afflictions struck at the world generally as well as at individuals.

Eighteen youthful mariners enthusiastically braved the choppy waters and uncertain currents of the East River yesterday afternoon to engage in an unrehearsed lifeboat race. The occasion was the celebration of "Open Ship Day" aboard the schoolship John W. Brown, an annex of Metropolitan Vocational High School.

The obligations of American citizenship and the need for supporting the world-peace objectives of the United Nations were stressed yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer before an audience of 2,500 naturalized citizens.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Corporate profits dropped in the April-May-June period for the third consecutive quarter, the Department of Commerce reported tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- With one of its stars, Lauren Bacall, under suspension for insubordination since Wednesday, Warner Brothers is preparing to take similar action against another, Alexis Smith. A spokesman for the studio said that the necessary formalities probably would be completed early this week.

As negotiations to avert a three-state milk delivery strike set for 4 P. M. today continued into the early hours this morning, hope for a settlement was seen when a a spokesman for the companies announced there was "an outside chance" of an agreement before the sessions ended.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A group of Presidential advisers recommended today that the United States greatly broaden its program of exchanging ideas with other countries.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- A bullish construction placed on the farm bill passed by Congress, guaranteeing farmers 90 per cent parity loans on 1950 production of wheat and corn, resulted in a sharp advance in prices early last week on the Chicago Board of Trade.

The request by major American cities for help from the Department of Justice against nationally organized crime syndicates emphasizes again the difficulty of local prosecution of the modern racketeer. Aloof, silent, highly intelligent, he cultivates all the symbols of respectability. He dresses like a banker.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The period of waiting for the Government's economy program proved last week to be too much for the nerves of the Stock Exchange. As a result security prices fell all round, in some cases precipitately. Industrial shares were more sensitive than were other groups to the host of disturbing rumors, and at the week-end equity values as a whole were down almost to the lowest levels of the year.

HONOLULU, Oct. 23 -- Officials of six Hawaiian stevedoring companies and of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, signed return-to-work agreements today that, to all intents and purposes, finally ended the longest maritime strike in Pacific history.
ZURICH, Oct. 23 -- Rumors of revision of the price of gold continue to retard European recovery.
In a ceremony marked by political overtones, Governor Dewey dedicated the new $1,100,000 Morris Lowenstein Pavilion yesterday at Hillside Hospital, 75-59 263rd Street, Bellrose, Queens.

Shipping men and port industrial interests here indicated yesterday that at the next session of Congress they would press for passage of a bill to legalize the manufacture and exhibition of merchandise in the nation's five foreign trade zones.

Until a bigger one bobs up, the 35-28 defeat of the Chicago Bears by the New York Football Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds will have to be rated the year's biggest upset on the professional gridiron.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Administration officials are "considering further devaluation of the American dollar," Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, reiterated tonight in a statement.

The left-wing United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, called on its 500,000 members yesterday to build a national fund in support of striking steel and mine workers. The move attracted special attention because it came a week before the opening of the national convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, at which Philip Murray, president of the CIO and the United Steelworkers, is expected to attack the electrical union.

TRIKKALA, Greece, Oct. 23 -- Religious, civic and military celebrations marked today the beginning of "affiliation" between this war-battered, barren, provincial town in central Greece and Tucson, Ariz.

Columbia's basketball team will make the first cross-country tour in the school's history this winter, when the Lions engage four opponents in six games during the Christmas recess. The contests will be part of a twenty-eight-game schedule, Ralph Furey, director of athletics, revealed yesterday.

Benjamin F. Feinberg, chairman of the Public Service Commission, announced yesterday that the New York Telephone Company had been authorized to put into effect a plan for the metropolitan area of Buffalo whereby toll charges between that city and eight suburban communities would be eliminated.

A threatened three-state milk strike was held in abeyance early this morning as management and union representatives deferred to a request by a panel of mediators and agreed to go ahead with contract negotiations in a "continuous session."

Convinced that postal rates are due for gradual boosting in future years, publishers of all printed media can be expected to intensify study of other distributions methods, it was learned yesterday. No radically new systems are anticipated, it was said, but cooperation in, or coordination of, present means such as express, parcel service, buses, etc., are held likely.
Negotiations between the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and the Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators' committee continued yesterday with no sign of a settlement in sight.

Notre Dame heads East to play Navy in Baltimore Saturday and the coming of Frank Leahy's scourge of the gridiron is about the most interesting item on a program that does not offer much in the way of games of distinction.

Our attention has just been directed to the special story by Alexander Feinberg from Toronto, published in your issue of Oct. 1, covering testimony the day before at the Federal inquiry on the S. S. Noronic fire.

Emphasizing the new state's potentialities for private investment, Robert R. Nathan, director of the Economic Department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, called attention yesterday to the Israeli Government's establishment of an investment center.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Dr. John R. Steelman, assistant to the President, and Cyrus S. Ching, Federal mediation chief, will review the steel and coal strikes in a White House meeting tomorrow and possibly recommend a course to Mr. Truman, it was learned tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Wheat, corn and oats futures were on the upgrade on the Board of Trade here today, more because of lack of pressure than of any material buying. May and July wheat equaled the previous high prices for the season and all deliveries of oats went to new highs for the year.

When I read the letter of Klalil Totah in your issue of Oct. 11, I was amazed at his sudden devotion to the United Nations and his concern for the "dignity and self-respect" of the world organization. This seems to be an entirely new attitude on the part of the Institute of Arab-American Affairs, for whom Mr. Totah speaks.

Platypuses and penguins stirred publicists at the Bronx zoo into reaching for telephones yesterday. They reported that platypuses had gone indoors and penguins had come out and this meant that the zoo had changed seasons.
The discovery in Afghanistan of a "lost city" thirty square miles in area was reported yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.

President Truman told the United Nations General Assembly yesterday that it would be appropriate for the world organization to hold meetings "from time to time in other countries when that can be done."

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Mark Mourne, Preston Tucker's first cousin and former secretary of the Tucker Corporation, returned to the witness stand in Federal District Court today in the trial of Mr. Tucker and seven present and former associates on charges of fraud and conspiracy.

A report in a Chicago newspaper that the warring All America Conference and the National Football League would merge into one twelve-team circuit in 1950 was firmly denied yesterday by the commissioners of both leagues, according to The United Press.
Secretary General Trygve Lie pointed to the United Nations yesterday as the world's only hope for preventing a new world war.

Member companies of the New York Shipping Association voted yesterday to accept a new contract with the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL. The pact grants the dock workers a pension plan and increased welfare benefits. The agreement was accepted by the longshoremen last Friday.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 24 -- Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight in an address before the Toledo United Nations Association that he believed the time had come "or is rapidly approaching" when there should be issued a call for a convention to revise the Charter of the United Nations.

Aside from the dropping back of his ends, some new loops, slants and overshifting, there was "nothing special" about the defenses that Norman (Red) Strader, coach of the Brookly-New York Yankees, rigged up to upset the San Francisco Forty-Niners Sunday at the Stadium.

With fall volume improving compared with last spring, increasing confidence in the sales outlook for 1950 was reported yesterday by exhibitors at the National Business Show which opened at Grand Central Palace.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Under the auspices of the International Wool Secretariat, a fortnight dedicated to wool incites the imagination of Paris designers. In the shops, in the boutiques of the grand couture appear ingenious novelties.

Defending the policy of industry to retain a larger proportion of earnings rather than pay them out in dividends, G. Rowland Collins, dean, Graduate School of Business Administration, New York University, declared yesterday that such retained earnings are needed for remechanization rather than expansion of capacity.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Dr. Lionel D. Edie, prominent economist and president of Lionel D. Edie Co., New York, has been elected a trustee of Colgate University. This was announced by Norman F. S. Russell, chairman of the board, last night following the fall meeting of the trustees on the campus.

Unconcerned by the presence of more "solid horses" in the competition against him, Selector of the William Helis Stable registered a convincing triumph in the Spur, the six-furlong event that featured the program of the Empire City Racing Association at Jamaica yesterday.

" Everybody Does It," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy starring Paul Douglas and Linda Darnell, which arrives at the Roxy, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Edmund Goulding directed and Nunnally Johnson produced and wrote the screen play from a story by James M. Cain. Celeste Holm, Charles Coburn, Millar Mitchell, Lucile Watson, John Hoyt and George Tobias are among the principals.
WATERFORD, Mich., Oct. 24 (AP) -- A farmer went berserk here tonight and shot and wounded nine persons in two taverns before killing himself.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Georges Bidault, who during the war was chief of the French resistance movement, today ended his first day's efforts to deal with the French political crisis in the midst of difficulties that beset and finally defeated his two predecessors. The chances of the Popular Republican and former Foreign Minister appeared no better than theirs had been.

The paucity of current public offerings of new corporate bonds against a background of money rates likely to remain easy for a while is reviving the old war of nerves between underwriters competing for the award of the new bond supply and the insurance company investors who are the most likely ultimate buyers.

Herbert Hoover, former President of the United States, was elected yesterday a director of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Corporation. Nine other new directors were placed on the board, including Conrad N. Hilton and Col. Henry Crown, who purchased a controlling interest in the hotel two weeks ago.
NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Alfred E. Driscoll, Republican candidate to succeed himself as Governor on Nov. 8, spoke at nine meetings in Essex County today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the United States corn supply in the 1949-50 marketing year might be 515,000,000 bushels greater than the record set last year.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Evidence that six oddly shaped bits of matter that were discovered in the Atlantic coast atmosphere three years ago may be the first fragments of a comet ever to reach the attention of scientific analysts was presented at the autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences here today.

The Municipal Broadcasting System was informed yesterday afternoon that earlier in the day the Federal Communications Commission in Washington had refused to let WNYC, the city's station, operate later than 10 o'clock Nov. 8 to announce final results in the city's election.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Mexico grabbed top honors as the best all-around military jumping team of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Alexander Holtzoff today ordered a physical examination of Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, to determine whether he is able to stand trial on year-old charges of conspiracy to defraud the Government.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower proposed yesterday that leaders in every field of American life gather at Columbia University, of which he is president, to work out a nonpartisan program of social and economic welfare for the nation without jeopardy to individual freedom.

Asserting that shipping was leaving the Port of New York because Mayor O'Dwyer disregarded the welfare of dock workers, Oren Root, Republican-City Fusion candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, told a group of longshoremen yesterday that improvement of conditions on the piers would be of first concern to him, if elected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr., the 48-year-old naval air officer whose activities helped touch off the House Armed Services Committee's inquiry into the unified defense organization, was ordered today to explain his "violation" of military law.

PONCA CITY, Okla., Oct. 24 -- Coincident with the completion of a two-and-one-half-year refinery expansion costing $37,800,000, the Continental Oil Company announced today that it will spend about $20,000,000 this year for drilling new wells and an additional $16,000,000 for exploration.

CAIRO, Oct. 24 -- While the Arab press emphasized today that the collective security pact accepted in principle by all the Arab governments in the Arab League Council meeting had as its prime purpose defense against Israel, rather highly placed sources here expect any such pact to lead to an alliance or alliances with the Western powers.

The International Business Machines Corporation's available sales territory has been increased to cover an additional area with about one-fourth the world's population, it was disclosed here yesterday.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, in a speech last night before 18,000 persons at Madison Square Garden, assailed John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for Senator, as the architect of this country's "insane policy of war."

CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- Industrial suggestion systems are the most important way to gear ideas of workers with those of industrial management, George H. Coppers, president, National Biscuit Company, New York declared yesterday.
The following are the texts of addresses by President Truman and Secretary General Trygve Lie at the United Nations cornerstone-dedication ceremonies yesterday:
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The nation's safety experts were told today that they cannot "claim any real progress" in traffic safety so long as accident tolls were so high.

OTTAWA, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Canada's Liberal Government won half of eight federal by-elections today, but lost three seats formerly held by Liberals to Independents. The Progressive Conservatives, official opposition party, retained the other seat.

IT was Homecoming Day for the local alumni as the football fraternity gathered yesterday for some conversational bag-punching. There were almost enough former Giant stars on the premises to stock a football team -- Steve Owen of the Giants, Mel Hein of the Yankees, Jim Lee Howell of Wagner, Ed Danowski of Fordham, Benny Friedman of Brandeis University and Nello Falaschi, now just a rooter for the Forty-Niners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The American Red Cross today made clear that its policy of separate fund-raising still holds, even in the Detroit United Foundation campaign in which the Detroit Red Cross chapter is joining 140 other groups in a simultaneous canvass of 650 industrial concerns.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 24 -- Members of the New Jersey Synod of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America will be urged tomorrow to reiterate their stand against all forms of gambling, including bingo.

Peter Bregante, a 35-year-old truck driver, took a day off from the job yesterday and used it to move his wife, Rose Marie, and their two children from their cramped, ill-lighted living quarters to a modern five-room apartment in the new Alfred E. Smith Houses on the Lower East Side.
The city and the Madison Square Garden Corporation have reached an understanding permitting resumption of negotiations for a $25,000,000 Columbus Circle Coliseum, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- While the broad scope of Prime Minister Atlee's economy measures was hard for many political economists to understand British housewives and mothers of children were quick to see what that their family budgets would go up again and that the buying power of the pound even in this island would be less than Sir Stafford Cripps' devaluation statement at first indicated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- Rene Williams, former Swiss glove manufacturer of Berlin who in recent years has been living in Beverly Hills, has become an independent motion-picture producer. Operating as Williams Productions, Inc., he will film as his first venture, "Horn of Plenty," in Sicily and Rome.

The authenticity of the much publicized "Study by Candlelight," attributed to Vincent Van Gogh as a self-portrait and owned by William Goetz, executive producer of Universal Pictures Company, is being debated by a board of experts appointed by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Every phase of maritime safety will be covered at the meeting of the marine section of the National Safety Council, held in conjunction with the thirty-seventh National Safety Congress and Exposition, which begins at the Morrison Hotel, Chicago, today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 24 -- Debate on the manner and extent to which the members of the United Nations are fulfilling their treaty obligation to promote full employment by domestic and international policy opened today in the General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee on a highly optimistic note of international cooperation.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 24 -- Winner of three of its four games thus far, Mercersburg Academy's strong football team has "three plenty tough opponents" coming up. Mercersburg's hustling pilot, H. M. (Fido) Kempton has a spirited squad which "has all the earmarks of a good team".
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Yugoslavia's quarrel with the Soviet Union figured prominently in discussions today at the conference of United States diplomats from the Communist countries of Eastern Europe.

The Citizens Union urged yesterday adoption of proposed amendments Nos. 6, 7 and 8 to the State Constitution and all three housing propositions that will appear on the voting machines at the Nov. 8 election.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., will seek to stimulate increased imports by the United States, it was revealed yesterday when the association issued its 1948-49 (fifty-second) annual report.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 24 -- Under harsh Soviet exploitation, the Manchurian port of Dairen has become a shabby, impoverished, isolated, Russian-dominated city, according to two United States consular officers who arrived here yesterday after fifteen months in that once busy port.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 24 -- Yugoslavia formally demanded today that the United Nations legally "bind the hands" of would-be aggressor nations that threaten the independence of less powerful states.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Recognition of Tibet as a free and independent country is a possibility that the State Department is considering in view of current Asiatic developments, it was learned today.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The stock market was quiet here today, awaiting Prime Minister Attlee's announcement of economy measures following devaluation, which came after the official closing. Nevertheless, nearly all leading industrial issues gained and there was a good turnover in British Government securities, with prices generally higher.
Many dinner parties will be given before the performance of "The Browning Version," with Maurice Evans and Edna Best, tonight at the Coronet Theatre for the benefit of the Play Schools Association.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week dropped 20 per cent below the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 14 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- One of the most extensive investigations of "bigness" in American business, as well as an inquiry into the country's anti-trust laws, is scheduled to begin tomorrow before a special seven-man House Judiciary subcommittee on monopoly power.

Good humor was the tone yesterday as delegates from fifty-nine countries convened in an outdoor session of the United Nations General Assembly at Forty-second Street and the East River to mark the cornerstone dedication of their $65,000,000 world capital.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- The first major change in governmental purchasing practices since completion of the Hoover report will be decentralization of Federal purchasing offices to move them closer to places where industrial production is located.

New York gave President Truman a warm greeting yesterday as the Chief Executive rode through eight miles of city streets on his visit here to dedicate the United Nations Secretariat Building at Forty-second Street and the East River.

A continued demand for new houses on Long Island is reported by builders and brokers. The entire development of eight-five dwellings being erected by Videre Homes, Inc., in East Hempstead was sold out in two weeks, according to Butterly Green, sales agents.
ward lust and cruelty and hunting in packs and fighting and destruction.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Passengers lining the rail of the Holland-America Line's flagship, Nieuw Amsterdam, as the luxury liner approached her berth at the Fifth Street pier here several days ago, were surprised to see a black dog jump from the pier-head and swim out toward the ship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The United States, Great Britain and Greece are discussing the withdrawal of the 3,000 British troops now stationed in Greece, and a substantial reduction in the Greek armed forces, it was reported here today.

LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- George Strauss, Minister of Supply, told the House of Commons today that free dealings in tin would be resumed on Nov. 15. The Government thus will abandon its wartime policy of bulk buying and selling.
A union president was drowned last night when the boat in which he was picketing the struck Todd Shipyards in the Erie Basin, Brooklyn, was hit by a passing tugboat.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board was urged today to approve a comprehensive air carrier service for New England, either by lines now in operation or through a new company.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 24 -- Establishment of the Lincoln Filene Professorship of Retailing, the first such endowed chair in the country was announced tonight by Dr James B. Conant, president of Harvard University. The post was made possible by the gift of $300,000 from the Federated Department Stores, Inc., and the Lincoln and Therese Filene Foundation of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

The National Biscuit Company, in its report for the third quarter released yesterday, reported a net profit of $5,101,154, equal to 74 cents a common share. This compares with a net of $4,896,917, or 71 cents a-share earned in the third quarter of 1948. Net sales were put at $72,854,481, against $72,550,265 a year earlier.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Paul-Henri Spaak, former Premier and Socialist, declared tonight in a radio speech that the referendum proposed on the return of King Leopold "might destroy Belgium."

Although the reports from the upland game shooters over the opening week-end seemed to come under the heading "interesting but unproductive," the waterfowl boys apparently did quite well on black ducks and pintails, with a scattering of mallards.

Within the next three years at least one-fourth of all fresh fruits and vegetables sold in this country will be prepackaged, it was forecast yesterday by Egmont Arens, industrial designer, at opening of the first national conference on prepackaging in the Commodore Hotel.

Charles Ruggles will transfer his movie characterization of a perplexed husband and father to television on Nov. 3 when ABC inaugurates a new situation comedy series based on family life. Entitled "The Ruggles," the program will be telecast each Thursday from 9:30 to 10 P. M.

From the time that Sir Stafford Cripps, on Sept. 19, announced a revaluation of the British pound from $4.03 to $2.80 one question more than any other has been the subject of lively and continuous speculation. That was the question, What steps will the British Government take to validate the new rate for sterling -- or, in more conversational language, to "make it stick"?

Residents of New York are among the best served in the world when it comes to ambulance care. Among the eighty-six voluntary, non-profit voluntary hospitals, members of the United Hospital Fund, there are twenty-nine separate ambulance services.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Prime Minister Attlee announced an economy program today that left the Opposition dissatisfied and his Labor supporters worried and anxious about the political future. The nation's spending, he said, would have to be cut by 280,000,000 [$784,000,000] even though that meant tampering with the food subsidies, fixing a nominal charge for prescriptions issued under the National Health Act and some slowing down in the evolution of the welfare state.

Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, charged yesterday that too many physicians disregard the beginnings of disease, or were too busy or unable to detect them. He attributed part of the blame to the nation's medical schools for their asserted failure to teach the value of preventive medicine.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- Raymond C. Firestone, vice president of Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, asserted tonight that the United States was "in the driver's seat" in regard to the world rubber situation because of the superiority of synthetics over natural products as the result of the war-built industry in that field.

We are happy to reassure a recent visitor from the Middle West, as well as some New Yorkers who may have been feeling concern, as to the prospect of early action for repair and repainting of Jumel Mansion, one of the most famous old historic houses in the nation.

The coal strike will cut sharply into passenger service on the nation's railroads at midnight tonight as they comply with an Interstate Commerce Commission order requiring a 25 per cent cut in coal-burning passenger mileage by lines with less than a twenty-five-day supply of fuel.

Mayor O'Dwyer told a cheering audience of 3,000 at Carnegie Hall last night that the election in New York was "strategic" and that its results would have a large bearing on the outcome of Congressional contests in 1950 and the Presidential election in 1952.

Declaring that there were no international problems that men of good-will could not solve or adjust, President Truman said yesterday that the laying of the cornerstone of the permanent United Nations Headquarters constituted "an act of faith -- our unshakable faith that the United Nations will succeed in accomplishing the great tasks for which it was created."
Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, national amateur tennis champion for the past two years, makes his debut as a professional tonight at Madison Square Garden.

DURHAM, England, Oct. 24 -- This is an obscure part of the British Isles. It isn't often in the news. But tonight Prime Minister Attlee singled it out in his radio speech to the nation as an example of what the workers of Britain must do if the welfare state that the Labor Government is building is to survive.
TOKYO, Oct. 24 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Japanese people today that all obstacles to an Allied peace treaty with Japan would be "removed in the near future."

In his inaugural address as president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, Dr. John H. Keating issued a warning last night against governmental compulsory health insurance in this country.

A friend of ours, a former reporter for the old New York Tribune, who at 80 years of age nicely combines a flair for reminiscence with an interest in the future, was recalling the other day his boyhood in the "In Between Land" -- St. Lawrence County, New York -- and how the social and commercial ties of that area in the Eighteen Seventies and Eighties were to Boston and to New England in general.

Two city leaders of the American Federation of Labor charged last night that Newbold Morris was "seeking to ride into office with the same mantle of silence on important national issues affecting labor as was used by Governor Dewey in his unsuccessful bid for the Presidency."

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange again advanced the limit of 150 points in a day yesterday. At the close there were large unfilled demands for all delivery positions, with sellers withholding offers because of firmness in spot coffee and higher f. o. b. Santos prices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation today obtained a $10,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to help finance dealers who market the company's automobiles.

The Port of New York Authority will open sealed bids on Nov. 2 on a new issue of $30,000,000 of long - term tax - exempt revenue bonds for the financing of the development of Newark Airport, Teterboro Airport and La Guardia and New York International Airports, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Authority, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Jane's "All the World's Aircraft," issued today, reported that Soviet Russia was building eight types of jet planes, with two believed capable of carrying an atom bomb.

TRENTON, Oct. 24 -- The New Jersey Superior Court reassured county clerks today they would not have to reprint sample ballots that bear the legend "refused oath of allegiance" after the names of some candidates.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 24 (AP) -- A means of making the blind see, the deaf hear and the paralyzed walk, by sending electrical impulses into the brain of muscles, was seen as a possibility tonight by a scientist in brain research.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review the protest of Miss Rosemary Cross that her trial before Police Court Judge Patrick J. Powers of North Tarrytown, Westchester County, would be unfair because, according to her plea, he has already prejudged the case against her.

New brooms sweep clean. The new owner of the Weylin Hotel brought a new head to the kitchen, a new restaurant to the ground floor. Husky, 36-year-old Geza Kiss, who looks more like the head of a Boy's Club than a temperamental chef, is now in charge of the cuisine.
As President Truman boarded his train in Pennsylvania Station yesterday after his five-hour visit here he gave a succinct tribute to the elaborate arrangements for his safety.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- Eleven Communist-dominated unions are on the way out of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Shades of the Seven Blocks of Granite! Here it is late October and Fordham is unbeaten, victorious over Kings Point, 44 -- 9, Scranton, 33 -- 13, and Syracuse, 47 -- 21. And yet, Ed Danowski, enjoying his greatest success as a coach, refuses to become excited.

HONG KONG, Oct. 24 -- Hong Kong, in the person of its Governor, Sir Alexander Grantham, is expected to advocate early recognition of the Chinese Communist Government at the regional British Empire conference next week in Singapore.
BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet-sponsored German Democratic Republic sought recognition from the West tonight.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The paddling of thirteen pledges at a fraternity initiation here was causing so much displeasure among some parents that the Larchmont Rotary Club today authorized an investigation of the fraternity situation as it affects boys of the Mamaroneck-Larchmont High School.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet Union asked the United Nations to intervene with the Greek Government in demanding that eight death sentences, reported to have been passed by a military court in Athens on Oct. 13, be suspended and then repealed.
GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 24 -- The Long Island P. G. A. officially closed its tournament season with a one-day amateur-pro event at the Fresh Meadow Country Club today, with eighty pairs competing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- "Bolder, speedier and more effective" development of our atomic program to meet "the vital necessity of constantly maintaining and expanding our pre-eminence" in this field is demanded by our national security, a minority of six Republican members of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy reported to Congress today.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 24 -- The success of the roundtable conference appeared to be assured tonight when, after nearly two months of deadlock, the Dutch and the Indonesian reached an agreement on the size of the debt to be assumed by the new Indonesian Republic.

The most brilliant and interesting orchestral concert we have heard thus far in the season was given by the Little Orchestra Society, Thomas K. Scherman conductor, as the first concert of its present series, last night in Town Hall.
DETROIT, Oct. 24 -- Temporary layoffs of 5,000 workers at the Willow Run plant of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation began today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Northern Stakes Power Company, Minneapolis, Minn., had filed a registration statement covering 1,584,238 shares of no-par value common stock to be offered to Northern States' common stockholders.

" Lincoln Collector: The Story of the Oliver R. Barrett Lincoln Collection," by Carl Sandburg, will be issued in a limited edition on Nov. 3 by Harcourt, Brace. It tells how a lawyer amassed the collection "for fun" over sixty years. The volume, which will sell for $15, contains selections from Lincoln letters, documents, relics and source materials.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- The relief measures adopted last week at Bonn have insured at least a 50 per cent solution for West Berlin's economic difficulties, Mayor Ernst Reuter informed a press conference this afternoon.
The cotton futures market yesterday closed steady, unchanged to 14 points higher than on Saturday, with the far months relatively stronger than the near.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24 -- A Missouri Pacific freight train consisting of empty cars was scheduled to leave Texarkana, Ark., tonight, marking the first operations on the 7,200-mile railroad since it was paralyzed by a strike of 5,000 trainmen on Sept. 9.

Mrs. Truman's loss yesterday was Mrs. Tom Connally's gain. For the wife of the chairman of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee "inherited" the dozen red roses intended as a gift for the First Lady when the Presidential train arrived at Pennsylvania Station.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, added yesterday to his demands for a non-political city administration a further demand for the complete revamping of national leadership and policies in the Republican party.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 -- Both major party candidates for the Court of Appeals, Judge Bruce Bromley, Brooklyn Republican, and Justice Charles W. Froessel, Queens Democrat, were deemed qualified for the post today by the Committee on Selection of Candidates for Judicial Office of the State Bar Association.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter yesterday set Nov. 9 for trial of a suit brought by the American Guild of Variety Artists to restrain James C. Petrillo and his American Federation of Musicians from interfering with guild activities.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- To assure the rest of the world of the value of the economic and social principles of democracy, the United States must achieve steady economic progress, M. S. Szymczak, member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve system declared here today.

There is a good chance that the Philip Dunning - George Abbott comedy drama, "Broadway," may be one of the four plays to be done this season at the New York Center of Music and Drama, where the drama phase of activities is scheduled to start on Dec. 28.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 24 -- Lieut. Gen. Gyorgy Palffy, formerly Hungary's highest army officer, was hanged today for treason in an alleged "Titoist" plot.

The proposal to fine a motorist for leaving the ignition key in his car for more than three minutes strikes me as well-intentioned but also as nonsensical. Of course, its principal flaw is that it does not go far enough. Its avowed purpose is to curb crime by removing temptation, and the removal of temptation is said to take place simultaneously with the removal of the ignition key.
Forty-one college football teams remain on the rapidly diminishing list of the unbeaten and untied.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Steers reached the highest price of the year today, but hogs dipped to the lowest top price in more than three years.
It was with greatest interest that I read the comments of some of your readers on the Senatorial campaign. There is one point which seems to me to stand out above all others.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Pledging to continue his fight against Government waste and extravagance, Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate to succeed himself, asserted here tonight that he was against President Truman's proposal to increase taxes.

Afternoon and evening fashions, in many cases complemented with furs from this same shop, composed the showing of custom-made originals offered by Farquharson Wheelock yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. Worn beneath a flowing coat of brown seal, a frock of taupe wool displayed over-size pockets dipping well below the hips, the triangular cuffs folding back to button.

Dick Kazmaier, Princeton's sophomore tailback, retained the Ivy League lead in total individual offense, according to statistics released yesterday. By gaining 83 yards against Cornell last Saturday, Kazmaier raised his output to 580 in five games, 100 yards more than his closest competitor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Facing further losses of the world market for oil and disruption of American overseas oil production, the Government called in today the National Petroleum Council, representing United States producers and refiners here and abroad, to try to work out a solution.
Five officers of the Amtorg Trading Corporation were released yesterday from the Federal detention pen when they put up $15,000 bail each in $5,000 and $10,000 bills.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 24 -- Charges that the Government of Iraq was organizing a "reign of terror" against its 150,000 Jewish subjects were categorically denied today by Dr. Fadhel Jamali, Iraq's delegate to the United Nations, in a statement issued here.
Several members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony have taken to art, and an exhibition of thirty-six of their pictures will be opened next Tuesday in the Carnegie Hall Art Gallery.

Election of Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, to support the Fair Deal program of President Truman was urged last night by Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 24 -- Certain forces are at work in Washington to destroy the National Guard, Maj. Gen. Milton A. Reckord of Maryland, one of the country's most widely known National Guard leaders, told delegates today at the seventy-first general conference here of the National Guard Association.
Two friends met yesterday morning for the second time in thirty-five years. The setting was Carnegie Hall, but it recalled to them the concert hall in Warsaw, Poland, in 1914.

Dr. Nash C. Brennan of Shenandoah, Pa., was named last night to the presidency of the American Society for the Advancement of General Anesthesia in Dentistry at the fall meeting at the Shelburne Hotel. He will take office next spring, succeeding Dr. Harry J. Field of Newark, N. J.

Against a backdrop of increasing economic stagnation, top Federal mediators returned to Washington last night to give the White House a first-hand report on the stalemate in Government efforts to end the steel strike.

BRIDGETON, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Nearly 400 Estonians who were admitted to this country last spring as displaced persons are developing new roots as food-processors and farm workers in this southern New Jersey area. Having experienced totalitarianism of both the Nazi and the Russian types, they are prepared today to compare and contrast these systems with the American way.

The stock market did little more yesterday than hold the line and, while business was fairly active, low-price shares accounted for most of the turnover. Prices moved in a narrow range. A few units in the gold-mining division showed a disposition to gain ground while weakness settled in the tobacco group.

The Belgian Senate is to debate today whether to hold a plebiscite on the return of King Leopold III to his throne. Old and bitter memories will hang like a cloud over the discussions. The King is an exile in Switzerland because his nation is sharply divided over his record in the war and his place in contemporary affairs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Before and since he entered the Senate, John Foster Dulles has been an effective co-commander of President Truman's foreign policy. With Senator Vandenberg and Governor Dewey he has helped more than any other Republican to form and maintain his party's section of the bipartisan edifice -- without which the structure would have no keystone.

A new educational experiment, "Reading in the Family," by the New York Public Library, will be introduced tonight in the High Bridge Branch, 78 West 168th Street, the Bronx, the first of six branches in that borough, Manhattan and Staten Island to carry the course.
Idle Notre Dame still rules the roost as the nation's No. 1 football team, according to 84 per cent of the voters in the fourth weekly Associated Press poll.

TOKYO, Oct. 24 -- Strong recommendations that more Japanese students go to the United States and more Americans come here have been made to Gen. Douglas MacArthur by Education Exchange Survey groups that have just completed a month of examination of this field.

It is encouraging to see recognition given to practical and continuing effort toward still greater safety in various categories of flying. Such recognition comes from the Flight Safety Foundation through awards sponsored by Aviation Week Magazine. One award had special reference to private and military flying.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Opposition to a proposal to recapitalize the Boston Maine Railroad was expressed today in oral arguments on the plan before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

About 250 buyers reviewed resort styles of twenty-four Florida garment manufacturers, it was learned yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel, where the Miami Fashion Council is holding a 4-day show. Order-taking on both men's and women's apparel was described as brisk, with men's wear deliveries scheduled for Dec. 1 complete and women's wear shipments for Dec. 25.
NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 24 (AP) -- A formal proposal by the Italian Government to settle a $26,642,000 debt owed to a New Jersey concern was filed today in Federal court.

Justin R. Whiting, president of the Consumers Power Company, announced yesterday, following a board meeting, the election of three new directors: Edwin Thorne, assistant cashier of the First National Bank of the City of New York; Arthur F. Blakeslee, president of the Kalamazoo Stove and Furnace Company, and Lee W. Hutchins, president of the Hazeltine Perkins Drug Company.

Hospitals that have adopted an experimental program in which newborn infants are placed in the care of their mothers instead of being isolated in nurseries, are finding the procedure beneficial to both mother and child. This was reported last night to the monthly meeting of the Section on Obstetrics and Gynecology of the New York Academy of Medicine, 103d Street and Fifth Avenue.

The $63,000,000 Hershey Chocolate Corporation, largest domestic producer of chocolate and cocoa products, is about to recast its capital structure for the first time in more than twenty years because its non-redeemable but convertible shares "made the capitalization inflexible," company sources said yesterday.
Live steam escaping from a riser pipe caused the death of two children in Brooklyn yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Recommendations on United States policy and diplomatic practice in Eastern Europe were expected to be made to the State Department as a result of the two-day conference of United States Ambassadors and Ministers in Communist countries that ended here today.

The annual meetings of both the Yacht Racing Associations of Long Island Sound, the senior and junior groups, were held yesterday in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. The senior yachtsmen also held a dinner, at which the prizes in the championship regattas last summer were awarded.

From two sources last night came warnings that the city was in danger of losing a golden opportunity for unified development and planning of the Manhattan district surrounding the East River blocks where the United Nations headquarters project is now rising.

A leading proponent of progressive education, Vinal H. Tibbets, has been appointed director of the Walden School, 1 West Eighty-eighth Street, it was announced yesterday by Charles Seligson, president of the board of trustees.

There were expansive smiles and gay remarks at the Football Giants' weekly luncheon at the Polo Grounds press room yesterday. If any member of the organization was unhappy it couldn't be discerned with the naked eye -- all because the underdog Giants beat the Bears last Sunday.

A HORSE race with extraordinary appeal will be run in Baltimore on Friday and it will attract more than one wayfarer who will be on hand for the Notre Dame-Navy football game on the following afternoon. It will be the Pimlico Special, a winner-take-all affair at the hallowed Preakness distance of a mile and three-sixteenths.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 25 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly today sought to allay concern in some quarters of the world over the recent course of the United States economy with a candid statement of the present economic outlook.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 25 -- Delegates to the Synod of New Jersey of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America adopted a resolution today asking their churches to urge members in voting for candidates for the State Legislature to take into consideration the stand of the candidates on the question of bingo and other moral issues.

Mrs. Harold W. J. Brandt, a 25-year-old Austrian for whom her Chicago husband renounced temporarily his American citizenship, was one of the 840 passengers who arrived here yesterday aboard the Polish liner Sobieski.
Two new issues of railroad equipment and public utility securities totaling $25,780,000 were sold yesterday at competitive bidding to banking syndicates. The borrowings were as follows:

A gifted 18-year-old artist-pupil who is taught at home by the Board of Education's bureau for physically handicapped children made one of his rare trips on the subway yesterday to visit his one-man show of paintings and sculpture granted him by the School of Industrial Art, 211 East Seventy-ninth Street.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday that combined net income of the utility and its subsidiaries amounted to $36,546,140 for the twelve months to Sept. 30, equal to $2.35 a share, compared with $36,893,821, or $2.29 a share in the preceding twelve months.

Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net income of $24,303,252, equal to 84 cents a share on the 28,807,314 capital shares outstanding in the third quarter ended Sept. 30, according to the report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Army officials said today that if Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican of New Jersey, must have a new physical checkup to see whether he was able to stand trial next month on fraud charges private doctors would have to do the job.

Metropolitan travelers who recall the chaos caused on the Long Island Rail Road by a swan a few months ago will perhaps not be surprised to learn that a canary achieved a certain amount of delay yesterday on an IRT subway train.

Quantitative imports by this country cannot be expanded to a degree that will appreciably narrow the foreign trade gap on the basis of current "highly inflated" export levels, according to a study of the twenty-four year period from 1925 to 1948, issued yesterday by the American Tariff League.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Joey Maxim of Cleveland, 182 1/2, scored a technical knockout over Joe Kahut, 188, Portland, Ore., tonight when the City Boxing Commission doctor refused to allow the Westerner to answer the bell for the fifth round.

Hitting at what he termed the "Santa Claus" philosophy for financing of employe pensions and social insurance, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, demanded yesterday that Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, "get off his high horse and talk sense" in an effort to end the twenty-five-day-old steel strike.
BUFFALO, Oct. 25 -- A keenly contested fight for control of Buffalo's City Hall overshadows the Lehman-Dulles Senatorial contest in this, the second largest city of the state.

Curandero -- That's a south-of-the-border name meaning witch doctor -- put the hex on the opposition in the best of the Empire City-at-Jamaica races yesterday. He scored a nose tip decision in a mile-and-a-sixteenth run for 3-year-olds and completed a two-for-two afternoon for the King Ranch.
PARIS, Wednesday, Oct. 26 -The chances of Premier-designate Georges Bidault's forming a Cabinet were enhanced early today when the Socialists accepted his offer of ministerial posts for their party.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 -- Major Pelayo Izurieta of the Chilean Army team took the international individual military championship of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight in the most pulse - stirring jumping the event has seen in its week's run to date.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The New York Rangers broke their last-place tie with the Chicago Black Hawks tonight by beating them, 2 -- 1, before 15,618 fans, who saw the opener of the National Hockey League season here.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 25 -- A total of 30,000 army draftees will be permitted soon to go back to civilian life, Gordon Gray, Secretary of the Army, said here today. The discharges will be offered to draftees with at least a year of service.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- The first pre-stresse concrete girder ever fabricated in the United States withstood today the maximum bending force available at a six-hour technical experiment witnessed by more than 300 engineers from seventeen states and five foreign countries.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 25 -- The United States decartelization staff in Germany has been reorganized, John J. McCloy, High Commissioner, declared tonight.

Mrs. Lila Tyng gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home at 480 Park Avenue for members of the committee in charge of plans for the Post-Debutante Ball to be held on Dec. 21 at the Plaza for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Nursery.
Vincent Impellitteri, President of the City Council, denounced Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Mayor, yesterday as a broadcaster of "lies" and a thrower of "mud."
GENEVA, Oct. 25 -- Government policies are leading to excessive investment in motor trucks in many European countries, according to United States transport officials here.

Coach Lou Little sent his Columbia football squad through a heavy contact workout in a mild drizzle at Baker Field, yesterday, laying stress on the Lions' defense for their game with Cornell at Ithaca on Saturday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 25 -- Assured of an affirmative vote, the Catholic Christian Social party introduced in the Senate today a bill formally proposing a plebiscite or "national consultation," as it is officially described, to settle the future of King Leopold III.
EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Oct. 25 -- A parachute jumper snatched a companion literally from the thin air to safety today.

Besides electing local officials, judges, and a United States Senator the people of New York State on Nov. 8 will vote their will on eight Amendments to the State Constitution and three Propositions. We state here the gist of these eleven questions and our recommendations.

The Farrell Lines' African Endeavor, which returns this morning from her maiden voyage to the Union of South Africa, will make a special voyage to Boston, it was announced yesterday. The new American-flag luxury passenger vessel of the Farrell Lines will leave here tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock and is expected to reach the Army Base in Boston Friday at noon.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 25 -- Czechoslovak Roman Catholic Bishops gave ground in the church-state fight today. They said priests might swear loyalty to the Communist Government and accept government salaries -- with reservations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -- Maureen O'Sullivan, who has been absent from the film sets here for the last two years, is organizing her own independent motion-picture producing company, which, she said today, would be incorporated as a California concern within the next few weeks.

The meeting of the CIO executive board this week is the prelude to the eleventh annual convention, which opens Monday.
