Of all the problems facing the organization, there is one which seems now to dominate the minds of officers and delegates, a problem which the Cleveland convention may do much to settle.

Szymon Goldberg, Polish violinist, who appeared last night at Carnegie Hall, distinguished himself in three capacities -- as a master of his chosen instrument, as the leader of an ensemble and as a musician who knows how to arrange an excellent concert.

Three important paintings by Marc Chagall and ninety-four of his prints are featured in the exhibition of recent accessions which open to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art. The other thirteen paintings include work of almost every contemporary style.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The tonnage of steam and motor merchant ships of 100 gross tons or more under construction in Great Britain and Northern Ireland at the end of September was 52,209 tons greater than in the previous quarter, the report of the Lloyd's Register of Shipping for the third quarter showed today.

Underwriting principals were busy again yesterday with bidding on pinpoints and repricing securities to yield an irreducible minimum of compensation spread. About $6,500 was all that separated the best bids submitted for a $15,780,000 equipment-trust borrowing by the Southern Pacific Company.

Manager Frank Boucher yesterday picked the New York Rangers to finish third in the National Hockey League. He made his statement after having watched the Blue Shirts play their first four games on the road, two of which they lost, with the other two ending in ties.

Directors of the International Paper Company approved yesterday a proposal to split the company's common-stock shares two for one. The board directed that the proposal be submitted to stockholders for consideration at a special meeting on Dec. 16.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- The defending titleholder, Clarence Doser of Scarsdale, was eliminated in his opening match of the Metropolitan P. G. A. championship at the Ardsley Country Club course today. Many of the leading contestants drew byes.

Whitney North Seymour, president of the Legal Aid Society, announced yesterday that Mrs. Eli Whitney Debevoise of 925 Park Avenue, had accepted the chairmanship of the Women's division of the society's 1950 appeal.

The Sadlers' Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night turned its back for the time being on the classic repertoire and gave us another evening of works by two of its own choreographers, Frederick Ashton and Robert Helpmann.

Republican party leaders, including five United States Senators, outlined last night the reasons for their preference for state rather than Federal controls over aid given in the fields of education, health and housing.

ATHENS, Oct. 25 -- The Greek Army, which has been fighting Communist guerrillas during the past three years almost entirely dependent upon United States funds, today must face the realities of a situation calling for a substantial reduction in arms expenditures, according to a statement issued tonight by United States Ambassador Henry F. Grady.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 25 -- The United States delegation is preparing a new resolution on the Greek problem that would provide for the resumption of conciliation talks between Greece and her three northern neighbors, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- A suggestion that Britain follow Denmark's example and appoint a Minister for Housewives to advise the Cabinet on domestic matters was made at a conference of the London Association of Women's Clubs today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Former Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes and President Truman, who split in a bitter row in 1946, spent an amiable half-hour together today.

Steps now being taken by Brazil to liquidate her estimated $150,000,000 indebtedness to American exporters should prove successful, Harold V. Roelse, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said last night.

American consumers have not benefited generally by the cheapening of foreign currencies a little more than a month ago, according to the Federal Reserve Board. The reason, it points out, is that producers of many foreign items, such as Scotch whisky, have boosted their prices.

Continuing an unprecedented rise, coffee futures prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange rose the permissible limit of 150 points, or 1 1/2 cents, a pound yesterday for the fourth trading day in a row. Buying orders ran heavy, but offerings were negligible.

The gala showing of holiday fashions offered by Sada Sacks yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel was given over to this shop's "customized ready-to-wear," costumes made on order but without basted fittings.

A full-length portrait of George Washington by Gilbert Stuart was sold at auction yesterday for $17,500 in a sale of the contents of Burwood, the residence at Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., of the late Walter Jennings. The picture the first full-length likeness to come on the auction block in many years, was purchased by George Washington University in Washington.

David E. Lilienthal emerged yesterday from the "radioactive squirrel cage" he occupies as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission to proclaim his faith in "our rough-and-tumble democratic method." To 1,500 persons at the Herald Tribune Book and Author luncheon in the Astor Hotel he said that "democracy among us is stronger, more vital than ever in the history of the Republic."

The fighting in Greece is coming to an end with the defeat of the Communist guerrillas, and that sturdy little nation is beginning to shake off the horrors of war and civil war which have ravaged it for ten long years. It will take time, effort and sacrifice before the wounds are healed.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 25 (AP) -- For the second time in five days, the Communist Czechoslovak Government ordered today the expulsion of a United States Embassy official on charges of spying.

Internal dissension among stockholders of the Madison Square Garden Corporation over the two-year-old plan to negotiate for the proposed $25,000,000 Columbus Circle Coliseum appears to have ended in "unanimous" acceptance of an "understanding" with the city, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- A plea for the maintenance of an effective accident control program in the country's ship repair yards was made here today by Carter Kendall, assistant chief safety engineer of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

HORNELL, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Governor Dewey struck out tonight against the "swindles" of the Truman-sponsored Brannan farm plan and socialized medicine as he resumed campaigning in Steuben County for the election of John Foster Dulles to the United States Senate on Nov. 8.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd and Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith joined yesterday in urging support for the Iron Curtain Refugee Campaign, a $1,000,000 drive to provide emergency assistance and rehabilitation for persons who have fled from the Soviet Union and its satellite states.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct 25 (AP) -- A rainy day dampened more than the Navy practice field today. It brought word that Frankie Hauff, speedy halfback, probably would not be able to play against Notre Dame.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The State Department announced today the selection of an American delegation to help draw up an international tin control agreement.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 25 -- Charley Caldwell and his aides were in their darkened den at Osborne Field House shortly before noon today. They were looking at moving pictures of last Saturday's losing thriller at Ithaca, when, unnoticed, this reporter entered.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- New efforts to strengthen collective security are now under way at both entrances to the Mediterranean Sea. Their connection is probably remote at present, but they definitely can be considered as part of one diplomatic pattern, a pattern with which Britain, as the great power most interested in that inland sea, can be associated.

Your excellent editorial "Purging Czechoslovakia" contains one rather serious misstatement. You speak of Czechoslovakia as "European in the sense that its culture, traditions and history link it to Rome and the West, rather than to Byzantium and the East."

When a representative of the American Labor party apologized yesterday for his party's failure to conform to the rules of the Board of Education, an agreement was reached in Bronx Supreme Court for the party to use the auditorium at De Witt Clinton High School for a political rally on Saturday.

The right of the city, under the Sharkey rent law enacted on Oct. 7, to prevent evictions for refusal to pay rents higher than those that prevailed last March, was upheld yesterday in an opinion handed down by Municipal Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin in the Fifth District Court.

The merits of Federal health insurance were debated last night at a dinner meeting of the Men's Club of Congregation Emanu-el at 1 East Sixty-fifth Street. Several hundred persons attended the symposium.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 25 -- The United Nations Security Council agreed today to postpone indefinitely discussion of the demilitarization of Jerusalem, pending General Assembly consideration of the report of the Palestine Conciliation Commission, currently meeting in New York with representatives of the Arab states and Israel.

Although the coal and steel strikes will temporarily affect the supply of goods, they will have little effect upon the underlying conditions of demand and therefore should not seriously retard the current business recovery, according to Sumner H. Slichter, Lamont University Professor, Harvard University.

The hunter and open jumping competitions, second in public interest only to the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden starting next Tuesday, have drawn banner entries, it was announced yesterday.

There has been no appreciable reduction so far in advertising as a result of the steel and coal strikes, it was learned yesterday in a check of key sources. It was pointed out, however, that much further prolongation of the stoppages is expected to curtail advertising of companies depending on steel for packaging materials, notably in the food field.
For those who can postpone the upland game or waterfowl shooting for a day, the off-shore waters now offer an abundance of mackerel and some really big blackfish.

There will be neither boom nor depression in the woolen goods market during the next twelve months, Dr. Marcus Nadler, professor of banking and finance at New York University, predicted yesterday. He addressed approximately fifty members of the Woolen Wholesalers National Association, Inc., at a luncheon in the Gramercy Park Hotel.

Mrs. Robert De Vecchi will give a tea next Monday afternoon at her home, 270 Park Avenue, for members of the committee in charge of arrangements for the performance of "Regina" on the night of Nov. 3 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre for the benefit of the Riverdale Children's Association. Mrs. De Vecchi, a member of the beneficiary's board of managers, is an aide of Mrs. Stephens Wiman, chairman of the benefit committee.
HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Houston's School Board has banned the civics textbook "American Government" because it found objectionable a paragraph in the 1947 edition.

The eighty-six voluntary hospitals in New York that are members of the United Hospital Fund employ 37,000 persons in their various departments to give medical service to more than 1,400,000 New Yorkers. The largest group is represented by the general professional care departments, in which 16,979 are employed.

The responsibility of the Christian churches to the Jews and means to combat anti-Semitism were discussed yesterday at a conference on "The Church and the Jewish People in America." The two-day meeting is sponsored by the American Committee on the Christian Approach to Jews.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- March, May and July wheat and all deliveries of oats sold at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade here today before profit-taking developed and produced an irregular close. Wheat finished 3/8 cent lower to 1/8 cent higher; corn, 1/2 to 1 cent higher; oats, 1/2 cent lower to 5/8 cent higher; rye, cent lower to 1/4 cent higher and soybeans, 3/8 to 1 1/4 cents lower.

ALBANY, Oct. 25 -- Benjamin F. Feinberg, chairman of the State Public Service Commission, signed an order today for a hearing to determine whether the Brooklyn Union Gas Company faces an emergency as a result of its dwindling coal reserves, and what action the PSC should take to protect the utility's gas consumers.

The newly re-decorated and re-planned fourth floor of Gimbels was officially opened last evening at a reception for the press and manufacturers. Arranged for shopping convenience and offering an inviting vista of fresh pastel colors, the departments grouped on this floor are the millinery salon, shoe, corset, brassiere, negligee, robe, lingerie, daytime dress, uniform, teen and junior apparel sections.

Plans for the creation of a modern one-story waterfront terminal and offices for the United Fruit Company in Weehawken, N. J., were announced jointly yesterday by Mayor John Meister of Weehawken and the New York Central Railroad Company, owner of the site.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 25 -- A bilateral treaty on Marshall Plan aid, prepared for the signature of John J. McCloy, High Commissioner, as representative of the United States Government, and Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the West German Federal Republic, is expected to be concluded within few days.

To maintain its charitable work, the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks is considering underwriting good plays, with professional actors, to be presented in each city where the order is represented. By doing so the Elks would be able to sell tickets to members and friends on a subscription basis and thereby obtain additional funds.

LONDON, Oct, 25 -- The world's first four-jet airliner, the de Haviland Comet, made a round-trip best flight of 2,980 miles today between London and Tripoli, North Africa, in 6 hours 38 minutes flying time. The plane flew at 35,000 feet and averaged 450 miles an hour -- 100 miles an hour faster than any commercial airliner now in operation.
Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer, "if he gets elected" would not serve out his term.

The cause of human welfare and world peace may be served by extension of planned parenthood throughout the world, Dr. Abraham Stone, medical director of the Margaret Sanger Research Bureau and vice president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said yesterday.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange in cotton futures was moderately active yesterday and prices closed near the best levels of the day, 8 to 18 points net higher than Monday's final quotations.

HUDSON STRODE, who teaches smart young Southerners to write novels at the University of Alabama, doesn't write novels himself. He writes popular travel-cum-history books about Bermuda, Mexico, Latin America and Finland. He does so with a brisk journalistic pace, with industrious attention to hundreds of details and with contagious enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, told high-ranking procurement officers of the Army, Navy and Air Force today that Congress wanted to hear fewer "pontifical statements" and see more definite action on the part of the services to provide small business with more government contracts.

Making his weekly campaign swing through Queens County, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, lashed out last night against Mayor O'Dwyer's plan for a Columbus Circle Coliseum.

The stock market threw off some of its concern over the coal and steel strikes yesterday and concentrated on favorable corporate developments, including good earnings reports and higher dividends. Prices marked time through most of the session, but blossomed out in the final hour to produce a net rise of 0.88 point in the composite rate although a few issues advanced a point and more.

ROME, Oct. 25 -- A carefully organized campaign to increase Italian dollar revenue by increasing exports to the dollar area is about to be launched by the Rome Government. Cheese, canned goods, wines, gloves and musical instruments in particular will be brought to the attention of buyers in the United States.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 25 -- A 35-year-old Jewish merchant who said he had fled Baghdad told a Government-sponsored press conference tonight about what he described as a wave of anti-Jewish terror in Iraq.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Molyneux's youthful boxy jackets, with back fullness controlled by a loose strap or half-belt, suggest the early spring, although the colors, black and dark chocolate or tete de negre, are still wintery. Low-set below the natural waistline, the strap forces wide unpressed pleats to adhere to the general boxy silhouette.

Marked by an increase of $3,514,702 over the net profit of the same period of the previous year, the International Business Machines Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $24,700,285 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, last.

Burglars, at least one of them a stamp expert, broke into the General Stamp Company, 100 Nassau Street, some time between 6:15 P. M. Saturday and 8:45 A. M. Monday and escaped with a large quantity of stamps valued in the "tens of thousands of dollars," it was learned yesterday.

May I add a suggestion to the problem of parades brought up by the letter of Leonard Reed? He recommends relegating parades to ball parks. I feel that New York has an ideal parade ground in the driveway in Central Park. It would not interrupt east-west traffic, as four transverse roads cut across the park below the level of the driveway.

A dispute over whether the Republican party or the Democratic party deserved credit for the state housing program developed yesterday when Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, made public correspondence with Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 25 -- Britain told a fifty-nine-member committee of the United Nations General Assembly today that she never would permit the world organization to intervene before hand in projected mergers between British Crown colonies and United Nations trust areas under British administration.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Preston Tucker and Floyd D. Cerf sought to conceal Harold Karsten's connection with the Tucker automobile enterprise by persuading Mr. Karsten, an ex-convict, to change his name and move from Chicago to California, a jury in Federal District Court was told today.

Five new films open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux the attraction is "Passport to Pimlico," a British-made comedy presented by J. Arthur Rank and released here by Eagle-Lion. Stanley Holloway, Hermione Baddeley, Margaret Rutherford, Naunton Wayne and Basil Radford head the cast of the offering, which was produced by Michael Balcon and directed by Henry Cornelius from a script by T. E. B. Clarke.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that operations last month resulted in a deficit of $18,986 on total operating revenues of $56,197,709 because of the coal walk-out. In September, 1948, the road reported net income of $2,325,136 on revenues of $67,058,812.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Central Public Utility Corporation, St. Louis, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for the simplification of its holding company system and corporate structure. The plan also provides for a redistribution of Central Public Utility's voting power among its security holders.

The American Broadcasting Company will curtail many of its local television programs next week, when WJZ-TV deletes eight hours per week from its current operation. Wholesale cuts are being effected in the Monday and Tuesday evening line-ups, while other deletions and revisions are to take place in a general overhauling of the entire schedule.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The first reaction of this Stock Exchange here today to Prime Minister Attlee's economy program was a general advance except in British Government issues. But the improvement was merely a reflection of relief that the drastic increases in taxation that had been feared were not imposed.

Miss. Audrey Emmy Meyer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Willy Meyer of 180 East Seventy-ninth Street, has completed plans for her marriage to Lawton Griswold Sargent Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sargent of New Haven, Conn. The wedding will take place on Nov. 26 in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.
ALBANY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A record off-year number of citizens -- 6,366,322 -- are eligible to vote in New York State elections Nov. 8.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- From left, right and center brickbats were hurled today at Prime Minister Attlee's economy program.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Ninety thousand Jewish immigrants are now jamming reception camps in Israel, Harry Greenstein of Baltimore, retiring adviser on Jewish affairs to the United States High Commissioner in Germany, reported today on his return from an inspection tour of the new state.
Washington still was stirred yesterday by the recriminations and regrets that stemmed from the House Armed Services Committee hearings on Army-Navy-Air Force differences.

There is a gap -- a void -- in American politics between mechanics and ideas. This gap, I believe, is dangerous to the future welfare of our political institutions. A great many people in the United States would like to take part in politics on the basis of the discussion of ideas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The United States and India have agreed to try to work out an $80,000,000 barter agreement under which India would get 1,000,000 tons of United States wheat in return for strategic raw materials.

Paul Martin, Minister of National Health and Welfare of Canada, told the American Public Health Association last night that under Canada's National Health Program, set up last year, more than twice as much per capita had been set aside in grants to provinces "than under the admirable health grants system in the United States."
LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 26 -- The Soviet Union said today it had demanded the recall of the Yugoslav Ambassador to Moscow because he was guilty of "spying and subversive activities" against Russia.

Boeing Airplane Company disclosed yesterday that sales and other income for the third quarter of 1949 amounted to $65,688,373, primarily due to the delivery of 57 airplanes, mostly B-50 Superfortresses and airline Stratocruisers. Sales and other income for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 totaled $176,513,510, which was 147 per cent more than the $71,404,956 volume of the previous year.
The newly elected executive vice president of the Fifth Avenue Association, Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry, USA, retired, was praised as a leader at a luncheon yesterday in his honor in the Pierre Hotel.

The Rev. Bryan Green, British evangelist who drew capacity crowds to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine for seven successive nights last fall, returned to this country yesterday on a British Overseas Airways plane from London to conduct a series of evangelistic missions in New York and vicinity. He is rector of St. Martin's-in-the-Bullring, Birmingham, England.

Despite the fact that the steel strike is "terribly costly," directors of the United States Steel Corporation have declared the regular quarterly dividend of $1.75 a share on the preferred stock and 50 cents a share on the common stock, the same disbursements as were made in the last quarter, Irving S. Olds, chairman, announced yesterday.

Witches and hobgoblins have come to town, ready to appear at the children's Halloween parties. Never since before the war have stores been so well stocked with paper masks, favors and other festive decorations in orange and black.
The Right Rev. Horace William Baden Donegan was elected Coadjutor Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday by the unanimous vote of the 167th diocesan convention.
Mayor O'Dwyer wants the Board of Education to plan for the construction of "at least" fifty new schools in the next four years, Maximilian Moss, president of the board, said yesterday.

Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, called City Controller Lazarus Joseph "an industrious, conscientious and far-sighted public servant" in a letter made public yesterday at the O'Dwyer-Joseph-Impellitteri campaign headquarters.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 -- A complete "model" suggestion system has been set up on a community-wide basis, and its basic plan can now be copied by industries anywhere in the world, Ivar N. Hultman, vice president, Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester. N. Y., declared here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Philco Corporation today asked the Federal Communications Commission not to approve any system of color television that would prove costly to the public.

Harnaby Ardmore, Inc., president Bean Scharfman, has obtained sixty-three mortgage loans aggregating $665,400 on the Ardmore Village development near Foxhurst Road, Harvey and Fortesque Avenues, in Oceanside, L. I. The project will contain ninety-two one-family dwellings, according to J. Halperin Co., who arranged the financing.
Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that the subway unification plan by which the city bought privately owned subway lines in 1940 was "the worst deal that ever happened to the city."

An eight-member committee sponsored by the United Jewis. Appeal, to study immigrant camp conditions in Israel and determine their needs for the coming year, returned here yesterday with a plea to American Jews to help their co-religionists in that new nation.

Forced to transact its business for the nearly four months of its existence in a small room on the eighteenth floor of the Municipal Building, the Bureau of Smoke Control has obtained permanent quarters on the tenth floor at 140 Nassau Street, it was learned yesterday.

Howard K. Smith, author of "The Last Train From Berlin," has a new book on Knopf's list for Nov. 7. "The State of Europe," described by the author as a "whatdunnit," is an analysis of thirty nations, showing the effects of the conflict between American democracy and Russian communism, of the liquidation of colonial empires and of post-war economies.

BORDENTOWN, N. J., Oct. 25 -- Reinvigorated by its defeat of George School last week, Bordentown Military Institute's football team is well on its way toward making amends for the dismal 1948 campaign.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today unanimously pledged itself to raise a multi-million dollar war fund to aid the steel workers who have been on strike since Oct. 1.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Oct. 25--A rich planter and oil man gave a moss-hung military' school a grant worth $50,000,000 today on its promise to teach white supremacy and States' rights.

CAIRO, Oct. 25 -- Eastern Mediterranean and Near East units of the Royal Air Force are preparing for joint Anglo-Egyptian maneuvers in the latter half of this week in simulated defense of the Suez Canal.

An indication of what happens when the principles of contemporary design are applied to an art medium that dates from the twelfth century may be studied in an exhibit of stained glass at America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.

One hair style with many variations was the idea introduced last evening by Guillaume of Lentheric at a special showing given for the press in the Lentheric reception room in the Squibb Building. His inspiration, he said, came from Greek mythology, following the styles of the gods and goddesses of Olympia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A British spokesman said today that he was certain his government would make "every effort" to cut tobacco imports from the, United States as part of its over-all program to reduce dollar outlays.

Mrs. Gretchen Kunigk Fraser of Vancouver, Wash., who surprised the skiing world during the 1948 Winter Olympics in St. Moritz, Switzerland, by winning the women's special slalom -- the first gold medal taken by an American skier in the games' history -- will arrive in this city Monday.

Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate to succeed himself, pleaded for greater government economy yesterday. Addressing 2,000 women at the Astor Hotel, he likened the task of running a government to that of running a household.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 25 -- The creation of a small, efficient and permanent United Nations field force, numbering not more than 300 men plus a cadre of qualified observers for duty in troubled areas throughout the world, was recommended to the Special Political Committee of the General Assembly today.

Mrs. Gretchen Kunigk Fraser of Vancouver, Wash., who surprised the skiing world during the 1948 Winter Olympics in St. Moritz, Switzerland, by winning the women's special slalom -- the first gold medal taken by an American skier in the games' history -- will arrive in this city Monday.

Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate to succeed himself, pleaded for greater government economy yesterday. Addressing 2,000 women at the Astor Hotel, he likened the task of running a government to that of running a household.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 25 -- The creation of a small, efficient and permanent United Nations field force, numbering not more than 300 men plus a cadre of qualified observers for duty in troubled areas throughout the world, was recommended to the Special Political Committee of the General Assembly today.

HONG KONG, Oct. 25 -- A savage battle has developed for Kingman Island, last Nationalist foothold along the Fukien coast dispatches of the Nationalist Central News Agency from Taipei, Formosa, said here tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -- B. P. Schulberg, movie pioneer, once head of Paramount studio, today pleaded with Hollywood to give him a job. His advertisement in the movie trade papers asking for work from the men who used to work for him, said in part:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- The $7,025,425 Westchester County airport in Purchase, war-born for the defense of New York, finally will blossom next week into a commercial transport and cargo center for 1,000,000 residents of Westchester County and southern Connecticut, it was announced today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach in proclaiming Tuesday as Westchester Aviation Day.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Twelve-year-old Bobby Driscoll, American star of the film "Treasure Island," today lost his appeal against a fine of 100 for having obtained employment in Britain without the consent of the Ministry of Labor.

GENEVA, Oct. 25 -- Representatives of musicians and radio and screen performers demanded today establishment of a rigorous international code for protection of their rights in recorded broadcast music.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 25 -- An appropriation of $2,187,000 was recommended today by the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee for information, general services and other administrative activities in the United Nations office in Geneva.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 -- A second major project by the Federal Government to apply recommendations of the Hoover report to improve economy and efficiency in purchasing was revealed here today.

The Soviet Union has rejected two proposals submitted by the United States, Britain and France for a settlement of oil concessions in Austria, thereby prolonging negotiations for a state treaty, it was learned yesterday. However, since a number of alternate solutions still remain in Russian hands, the outlook for a treaty text continues to be hopeful.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Senator Scott Lucas of Illinois, Democratic floor leader, in a broadcast from Chicago last Sunday night warned the nation of the rise of an isolationist group of Senators who work in the name of economy against an adequate national defense system and continued aid to the free nations of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, conferred with President Truman today and later turned back all inquiries about possible changes in the defense high command as a result of the recent Congressional hearings. He confined himself to saying that "we're just working on unification and it's moving along."

DETROIT, Oct. 25 -- The possibility of a strike against the Chrysler Corporation by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was dispelled late today when an agreement was reached on extending indefinitely the Thursday midnight deadline for a strike, according to a joint management and union announcement.

Pointing up the general campus enthusiasm over an unbeaten Fordham eleven, a large turnout of students looked on yesterday as the Rams were put through offensive and defensive scrimmages in rehearsals for Saturday's contest with Georgetown at the Polo Grounds.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Profits have reached an unprecedented peacetime level and the private enterprise system has gained new strength because of Democratic measures that constitute the "welfare state," former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Weekly earnings of the 11,800,000 factory production workers averaged $55.64 in mid-September, the second highest on record, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today in a preliminary estimate.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- Eastern Germany's former Nazis and Hitler career officers in the German Army, boldly made a bid for full equality in the Communist state today. Since their demands were passed for publication by a Russian censor it is probable that they were viewed with favor by the Soviet control commission.

Our special sidewalk superintendent shares with a great many of his fellow New Yorkers a lively interest in the holes in the ground which represent an important stage in the progress of our city toward bigger and better things.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 25 -- A sub-committee of the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee -- established to bring in a proposal for the disposition of the former Italian colonies -- today continued its debate over what to do about Eritrea.

POKAI BAY, Hawaii, Oct. 25 -- In the biggest amphibious operation since the war, a joint Army-Navy-Marine force of 38,000 men transported in 100 ships from San Diego, Calif., made an "invasion" landing here today to "liberate" Hawaii's main island from a mythical enemy.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- The main reason bank stocks are selling at a discount is because current bank earning power is not sufficient to support a market value equal to book value, Morris A. Shapiro, New York authority on bank finances, declared here today.
Ruler of the amateur realm for two years, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales met his master in John Kramer last night as he launched his professional tennis career at Madison Square Garden.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Oct. 25 -- Expansion of atomic facilities announced by Senator Brien McMahon last week will mean a new $185,000,000 plant here.
PORT DEPOSIT, Md., Oct. 25 (AP) -- A private plane exploded in the air tonight, killing Henry L. Straus, millionaire turfman, and three other persons.
ROME, Oct. 25, (UP) -- The Vatican City radio urged Czechoslovak Roman Catholics today to "be strong because great danger will come over you in the next few days."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Eddie Arcaro saved his mount's speed for the stretch and then urged Brookmeade Stable's Blue Hills home first in track-record time today in Pimplico's Governor Bowie Handicap.

The five-story ten-family apartment house at 505 East 140th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Green-Wood Cemetery to Jack Weiss for an indicated consideration of about $15,000. The property, on a plot about 37 by 100 feet; is assessed at $35,000. Lester A. Kent was attorney for the buyer and Heywood Benedict acted for the seller.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 25 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, Republican, who is running for re-election in New Jersey, gained an important ally today when Charles Edison, former Democratic Governor, declared himself for Mr. Driscoll.

When the Polish liner Sobieski docked here from the Mediterranean yesterday, it was learned that Stuart Benson, American sculptor and illustrator, had disappeared from his cabin the night of Oct. 17. Mr. Benson had been ill for some time.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,221, compared with 1,377 last week and 1,764 in the similar week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 570 arrivals yesterday against 687 last Tuesday.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 -- A departure in pension demands by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was reported today to be the subject of heavy, opposition by employers in Toledo.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 25 (AP) -- A world champion and six-time national singles winner was rated today the top-ranking badminton player of the United States.

John Kenna, ailing 77-year-old father of Frank Kenna, Republican leader of Queens County, was rescued yesterday afternoon from the East River near Astoria Boulevard, Queens, after he had climbed a fence and plunged into the water.

A milk strike which would have halted deliveries to 11,000,000 consumers in three states was averted this morning when conferees reached an agreement after almost continuous negotiation since 2 P.M. Sunday

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- American-owned foreign oil production will have to be cut back to the level of 1948, or lower, if Great Britain makes good its 50 per cent expansion program under the Marshall Plan and exploits the universal dollar shortage to its own advantage, according to a report today to the National Petroleum Council.

Deposits in the nation's 531 mutual savings banks rose $57,000,000 in September to a total of $19,082,000,000 on Oct. 1, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday. According to Henry S. Kingman, president of the association and head of the Farmers and Mechanics Savings Bank, Minneapolis, last month's increase compared with a rise of $45,000,000 in September, 1948.

George Edwards, a Horn Hardart restaurant manager, has purchased the six-room house at 113-54 212th Street, Queens Village, Queens, from Dr. Thomas Knox. Twentieth Century Homes, broker in this transaction, also reported the sale of the six-room dwelling at 145-88 222d Street for Louis J. Cannava to John J. Weiss.

A man accused as a principal in a ring of counterfeiters that printed $500,000 worth of bogus American Express Travelers checks and successfully passed $135,000 of them, was held in $100,000 bail yesterday in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- When a group of Washington correspondents called at the White House today with the first copy of "Dateline: Washington," President Truman produced two peculiar writing implements that reporters could do very well without.

A "thinking machine" that performs the functions of an automobile proving ground in detecting car faults was put to work here yesterday as the new service station of the Manhattan Pontiac Corporation opened on Eleventh Avenue between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets.

David Holland, pianist, who has not been heard here since February, 1945, returned to Town Hall last night to give his fifth recital there. Schumann's Papillons, Schu- bert's A minor Sonata, Op. 143, and Mozart's B-flat major Sonata, K. 570, were his major selections.

The Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, maker of heating control devices, reported yesterday a net income of $4,967,430, after taxes for the nine months ended on Sept. 30. This is equivalent, after preference dividends, to $3.71 a share on the 1,267,420 common shares outstanding.

Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson will receive a gold medal from Interfaith in Action for "his outstanding work in fostering better racial and religious understanding among the armed forces," George A. Saltzman, president of the group, announced yesterday. The medal, the fourth annual award of the organization, will be presented at a dinner Dec. 14, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y. Oct. 26 -- Dan Galgano of Woodway, Navy veteran and former Westchester caddie, accounted for the chief upset today when he defeated Jim Turnesa of Briar Hall, 1 up, at the nineteenth hole in the third round of the Metropolitan P. G. A. championship at the Ardsley Country Club course.

What are common stocks? What about risk? What does "listed" mean, with reference to securities traded on the New York Stock Exchange? These and other questions are answered by that institution in a sixteen-page brochure released yesterday.

The nation's light fuel oil stocks increased last week for the eighth consecutive week. They established a new record of 89,030,000 barrels, which represented a gain of 2,078,000 barrels from the previous week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 26 -- The Czechoslovak episcopate's authorization to members of the lower clergy to accept salaries from the Communist-led Prague Government and to swear loyalty to the state with some reservations represents the maximum concessions the Roman Catholic Church can make in Czechoslovakia, Vatican circles said today.

A listener at yesterday's weekly luncheon at the Yankee Stadium Club came away with the fixed idea that if the All-America Football Yankees don't beat the Baltimore Colts next Sunday at the Stadium everything may be blamed on a fellow named Yelberton Abraham Tittle.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Many new contracts will be placed soon, now that more than $500,000,000 in total appropriations for Army ordnance activities have been passed by Congress. In addition to national defense orders, a considerable number of other similar orders for the European military assistance program will be placed.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 26 -- Plans were completed here today by officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to force expulsion of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers and several other unions at the CIO convention next week.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 26 -- Mrs. Horace J. Brogley of New Brunswick, president of the New Jersey Congress of Parents and Teachers, declared here tonight that "freedom of speech is certainly abused when under its cloak are concealed those bent on subversion and perversion of our youth."
The cotton futures market was moderately active on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were unchanged to 11 points higher on the day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- An airline attorney suggested today that Pan American Airways' choice of banks indicated a long-range plan to take over a transatlantic competitor, Trans World Airline.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement today on signing the minimum wage bill:

National Write a Letter Week has given us a good time to reflect on the intricate organization the post office maintains to take all the millions of letters deposited each day in the little green boxes spread over the land and deliver them wherever they are directed.
LONDON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Viscount Craigavon said today he would ask a Government Commission of Inquiry to investigate his charge that Communists "infest" the British Broadcasting Corporation.

ATHENS, Oct. 26 -- Minister of Public Order Constantine Rentis said today the 50,000 men in the 100 National Guard battalions especially formed to combat the rebellion, were now part of the reserve and would be released as soon as guerrilla remnants were liquidated, provided Gen. Alexander Papagos, the commander in chief, and the General Staff agreed.

The Navy's charge that the strategic bombing concept was receiving undue emphasis in present defense policies was the most important issue discussed in the recent Congressional hearings on interservice problems.
LONDON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Torrential rains and eighty-mile-an-hour winds lashed the coasts-of Britain and France for the third straight day today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The State Department rejected today the charges made by Czechoslovakia against three United States Embassy employes recently expelled or arrested as spies.

Brief sit-down strikes on four Norwegian freighters now in port, which were reported settled yesterday, are the latest incidents in a protest campaign by Norwegian seamen over the reduced purchasing power of their devaluated wages, according to Einar Johansen, United States representative of the Norwegian Seamen's Union. The ships involved were the Bowplate, Brott, Byfjord and Fernland.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- Otto Grotewohl, Premier of the Eastern German Democratic Republic, said at a press conference today that his Government was not interested in a separate peace treaty with the Soviet Union but in an "all-German peace treaty."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 26 -- Following are excerpts from the interim report on the consultations of the six permanent members of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission. These excerpts consist of a statement of principles by Britain, which Canada, the
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Premier Marshal Tito said today "we shall fight and we shall fight enduringly" to prevent Yugoslavia's subjugation by Russia.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 26 (AP) -- An official of the licensed beverage industries said today despite increases in the cost of production whisky prices have remained at old Office of Price Administration levels.

The Conference on the Church and the Jewish People called on Protestant churches yesterday to denounce anti-Semitism, and recommended that Jews be included in evangelistic work of Christian missions and parishes.

Hopes of continuing the run of "Twelfth Night" beyond Saturday night faded away yesterday as Roger Stevens, producer, finally decided against such action. Members of the Shakespearean production already had taken a pay cut to keep it going, but business proved unfavorable.
LONDON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The wealthy son of a famous British Naval hero plunged to his death from a sixth-floor window of the Ritz Hotel today after he had learned he was going totally blind.

The Protestants of the country were called on yesterday "to take the lead" in releasing their agencies and institutions to a nonsectarian or public status where the need was too great for private philanthrophy to support.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 26 -- The sudden resignation of President Jose Figueres and his entire Cabinet today threw the Costa Rican political scene into confusion just as all had seemed set for the inauguration of President-elect Otilio Ulate on Nov. 8.
Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union since it was founded in 1920, will resign on Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 26 -- Delegates to committees of the United Nations General Assembly were called to order today for their frequent lateness to morning sessions which, it was estimated, had cost the Assembly forty-four and one-half hours of its deliberations.
General Manager George Weiss of the Yankees yesterday annonced that Joe Kuhel had been signed to manage Kansas City, Yankee farm club in the American Association.
AUBURN, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Senator John Foster Dulles today accused the Truman Administration of keeping the Taft-Hartley Law on the books as "effective campaign material."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 26 -- Israel will permit bonafide religious pilgrims to cross into this state from Arab-held Jerusalem during the Roman Catholic Holy Year in 1950, official sources said today. Hitherto permission to cross the line has been restricted to diplomats and a few special cases.

Indicted last Friday for failure to register under the Foreign Agents Registration Act, the Amtorg Trading Corporation, Russia's purchasing agency here, and five officers have backed down and notified the Department of Justice that they are now willing to register as foreign agents.

John W. Neary, a vice president of the New York Telephone Company and a leader in Bronx civic and fraternal organizations, was honored yesterday at a luncheon at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, the Bronx, as "the outstanding citizen for 1949 of Bronx County."

CINCINNATI, Oct. 26 -- The Disciples of Christ have obtained $11,000,000 dollars of the $14,000,000 being sought in a three-year "Crusade for a Christian World," G. Gerald Sias of Indianapolis, general director of the crusade, told the centennial international convention today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Americans who visit Canada, Bermuda or Mexico for short trips can now bring back $200 worth of goods duty-free instead of the previous $100 limit, the customs bureau announced today.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Sterope, a 25-to-1 outsider, won his second straight Cambridgeshire Stakes today in a driving rain. A final burst of speed on the mile and an eighth uphill course carried him to a head decision over Good Taste, another 25-to-1 shot.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 26 -- The Soviet Union holds that the Baruch Plan was "based on the illusion of a continuing monopoly of the secret of the production of atomic energy," and that since there is no longer any "monopoly" or "secret" the other members of the United Nations have "a right to expect new concrete proposals" from the United States on international control.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- According to responsible sources, the Soviet Union has now concentrated seven to nine divisions, of which probably four are mechanized, along the Yugoslav border, mainly in the Rumanian Banat and in Hungary.

Prepackaged cold cuts are being tested successfully in this market by Swift Co., it was reported here yesterday. Twelve items are being marketed, among which are different types of meat loaves, boiled ham and other meat products. The largest retailer in this area handling the foods is said to be the Grand Union Company.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

Grants and scholarships for graduate study were awarded to 134 students and seven faculty members of Hunter College, the college committee on scholarships and fellowships announced yesterday. Forty-four colleges and twenty-seven social agencies gave grants.

For many years the Young Women's Christian Association, whose city executive headquarters are at 129 East Fifty-second Street, has lived up to its high purpose of building up a fellowship of women and girls devoted to the task of realizing high ideals of personal and social living.
A high Administration official asserted yesterday that President Truman would make a personal effort to end the crippling steel and coal strikes if they were not settled by this week-end.

William H. Colvin Jr., president of the Crucible Steel Company, has come forward with what seems to us one of the most constructive suggestions to make its appearance in the steel dispute in some time. He has proposed that the President's Fact-Finding Board be asked to clarify its report, around which the controversy largely revolves.
I have read the interesting articles in THE TIMES on the "devaluation" of the pound, but have looked in vain for some mention of the historical background of similar situations.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Georges Bidault, Popular Republican, announced tonight that he would go before the National Assembly tomorrow for approval as Premier. He announced his decision after he had obtained agreement that all three chief parties in the "middle-of-the-road" coalition would participate in his Cabinet.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 26 -- The Nassau County Medical Society swung into the political limelight here today by announcing its membership had voted to support the candidacy of Senator John Foster Dulles. The unprecedented action was taken at a meeting held at the Cathedral House last night.

The performance of "Touch and Go," George Abbott's new musical revue, has been taken over on the night of Nov. 29 at the Broadhurst Theatre to raise funds for the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House. Mrs. Henry N. Sachs and Edwin F. Chinlund are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

With another icy blast against dissident Yugoslavia, the Kremlin has now ousted the Yugoslav Ambassador from Moscow on charges of spying and subversive activities against the Soviet Union. The impact of this step is somewhat blunted by the fact that the Yugoslav Ambassador has been absent from his post for months and that Yugoslavia cannot retaliate in kind because there is no Russian Ambassador in Belgrade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- A fuse blew out and a Federal Communications Commissioner blew up today when Dumont Laboratories tried to demonstrate a four-foot spinning wheel for a twenty-inch television set.

New York's three-cornered Mayoralty contest took a new turn yesterday when the leader of a Puerto Rican political party arrived here to campaign for the election of Representative Vito Marcantonio, the American Labor party candidate.

Two detectives became more than ordinarily curious yesterday in a grammar school boy's interest in white mice and, sniffing around like tomcats, pounced on a group of teen-age youngsters who were held in a "cage" for the time being.

There was no lack of drama in the Aronowicz showing of furs yesterday at the Pierre Hotel. Here was a designer who trimmed persian with silk print, made a jacket of broadtail and taffeta, tossed a fabulous leopard stole over a flowing coat of Matara seal.
By use of an automobile and an airplane, Governor Dewey packed 400 miles of up-state and city campaigning for John Foster Dulles into one day's activity yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Senate sponsors of President Truman's compulsory health insurance program have abandoned any hope of a showdown in Congress next year, it appeared today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 26 -- Negotiations for a new British-Belgian trade agreement have broken down, representing a symptom of the economic difficulties lying ahead for Belgium, a "hard" currency island in a sea of "soft" European monies.

Two new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Arcadia, Fifty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, the attraction is, "Just a Big, Simple Girl," a French-made romantic drama starring Madeleine Sologne and Jean Desailly. Jacques Manuel directed
William A. Hadl, a director and former controller of Rolls Razor, Inc., has been elected president and treasurer.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 26 -- This was a great day in the life of this quiet New England town. A notable son returned to the place of his birth.

An increase in the operating and construction differential subsidies paid by the Government to American-flag vessel operators was predicted yesterday in a preliminary report issued by the Special Studies Branch of the Maritime Commission.

Campbell, Wyant Cannon Foundry Company has declared a dividend of 50 cents, payable on Dec. 9, it was announced yesterday. The company has paid $2 this year, against $2.50 in 1948, when $1 was paid in December.

The Zionist movement breeds anti-Semitism by encouraging differentiation between Jews and non-Jews and by contending that Jews are merely "sojourners" in this country, Arthur Garfield Hays, general counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, said yesterday.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, which is affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, announces that its local frequency modulation station WFDR, will put in a special wire to cover the Congress of Industrial Organizations convention in Cleveland next week.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 26 (UP) -- A Ku Klux Klansman testified at the opening of the Alabama flogging trials today that the Klan carried out a hooded raid against a 42-year-old grandmother last June 10.
The proposed $150,000,000 bond issue by the city to finance the rehabilitation and expansion of its municipal hospitals was endorsed yesterday by the Hospital Council of Greater New York.

Increased awareness among European retailers of advertising's effectiveness as a merchandising aid was cited yesterday as improving conditions for expanded importation of American products. The development was reported by H. A. Paniguian, head of the international department of the J. Walter Thompson Company of London, at a meeting of the Export Advertising Association in the Shelton Hotel.

The new ideal of our times -- planned society -- may well begin with planned parenthood, John Haynes Holmes, minister of the Community Church, told 500 persons attending a luncheon of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- United States diplomats from East Europe who attended a two-day conference here at the beginning of the week reported there was little prospect that another Tito would arise in any of the Soviet satellite countries.

VERSAILLES, Ky., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler said today he had directed a full share of world series fourth place money for Manager Billy Southworth instead of the half share voted to him by the Braves.

Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's Royal Governor yesterday won his third stakes race in two weeks at Jamaica. The 5-year-old Pilat gelding, ridden by mud-spattered Eric Guerin, cut between horses up above the eighth pole and moved out to a length decision in the $23,600 Questionnaire Handicap.

Nestle's Quik is rightly named. It converts plain milk into chocolate milk about s fast as it takes to say so. To a tall glass, add two heaping tablespoons of Quik, stir briskly and voila -- something young fry will approve. No beating, shaking or heating of the mixture is necessary.

Oren Root, Republican-City Fusion candidate for Borough President, issued a challenge last night to Robert F. Wagner Jr., his Democratic-Liberal opponent, to say whether or not he intended to keep "the Copacabana cabinet" now in the Borough President's office, if he should be elected.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 26 -- The newspapers of the Wafd party, traditionally the largest in Egypt, warned the Arab nations today that Egypt would be compelled to withdraw from the Arab League if her proposal for a collective security pact of the Arab states was not adopted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Association of Consulting Management Engineers, Inc., New York, and its thirty-three member companies were accused today of trying to monopolize millions of dollars worth of engineering projects financed in foreign countries by Economic Cooperation Administration funds.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat-Liberal, of New York, declared today that Senator John Foster Dulles of New York "ought to continue as Republican adviser to Governor Dewey on foreign policy."

Following the release of the letter of Luis Munoz Marin, Governor of Puerto Rico, in which Governor Munoz stated that "the overwhelming majority of Puerto Ricans are not followers of Mr. Marcantonio," Mr. Marcantonio issued a statement which leveled three general charges against the Governor and his administration.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 26 -- Czechoslovakia conceded today that even in her planned Socialist economy there were persons out of work between jobs, a phenomenon that the capitalist countries call "transitional unemployment." She denied, however, that these persons were "unemployed."

Sascha Gorodnitzki, pianist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. His program contained Mendelssohn's "Song Without Words" in G major from Op. 62, Beethoven's Thirty-two Variations in C minor, Liszt's Sonata in B minor, Harold Triggs' "Regency Suite," which received its first New York presentation, and a Chopin group composed of the Nocturne in B major, Op. 9, No. 3, the "Ecossaises" and the "Andante Spianato and Grande Polonaise Brillante."

Workmen are busy installing special electrical connections and other facilities in ground-floor space at Madison Avenue and 132d Street for a fully equipped dental clinic, the first of its kind in public housing project here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, today protested the refusal of the Chinese Communists to grant an exit visa to Gen. Robert B. Soule, United States Military Attache to China, now in Nanking. He denounced, at the same time, the "negligence" or "deliberate discrimination" of the local authorities

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 19:

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- A break of 1 to 2 cents a bushel in the cash soybean market led to liquidation by holders of futures and closing trades on the Board of Trade were at net losses of 1 5/8 to 3 3/4 cents a bushel. Other grains were unsettled, wheat closing 1/2 cent off to 1/4 cent up, March and May selling early at a new high for the year.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Mayor, devoted a broadcast over station WJZ last night to a demand for the elimination of racial discrimination from housing and all other activities in New York.
In a letter to Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for election, made public yesterday at his campaign headquarters, Bernard M. Baruch exonerated Mr. Dulles of the charge of bigotry.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 26 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of seeking to gain permanent control of the United Nations through force by means of an armed field service designed by its sponsors to protect the lives of the world organization's personnel.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 26 -- Dr. Daniel F. Malan, the Prime Minister, told the congress of his Nationalist party in Blomfontein, Orange Free State, today that when Parliament reconvened in January he would ask it to send a delegation to London to press for incorporation of the three British Protectorates of Swaziland, Basutoland and Bechuanaland into the Union of South Africa.

The potentialities of having a psychologist on the school staff were introduced as a topic yesterday as pupils from public, private and parochial schools discussed the more usual subjects of homework, teachers' pets and classroom crime and punishment.

New York's most consistent political headache, the subway, will be forty-five years old today. Street corner orators will celebrate its birthday by continuing attacks and defenses of the longest intra-urban railway in the country.

Describing Abe Stark, his Republican-Liberal-Fusion opponent, as "a disgruntled and discredited Democrat," Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for re-election, charged last night that Mr. Stark not only had exhibited woeful ignorance of the city government but had demonstrated publicly his "utter unfitness" for the office to which he seeks election.

Several hundred union locals here have promised to have their entire memberships at a United Labor Rally at Madison Square Garden tonight on behalf of the state and city Democratic tickets, officials of the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen said yesterday.

New models of electrical appliances and metal products scheduled for the beginning of 1950 will not make their appearance before the second quarter of the year as a result of the steel strike, it was pointed out yesterday by tool and die manufacturers. The strike, they said, has caused some manufacturers to defer orders of special tools, dies, jigs, fixtures, molds and special machinery owing to the increasing tightness of steel deliveries.

An account of Boake Carter's search for religious truth and of his conversion to the Hebrew faith will be published on Monday by World Union Press, 507 Fifth Avenue, entitled "Thirty-three Candles." David Horowitz, the author, tells of the columnist's travels over three continents that led to his conversion.

The title of this column might very well be: "Is the Scoter a Duck, or, Who Would Eat Seagulls?" and it all goes to prove that there is more to the lowly melanitta perspicillata than will be admitted by a legion of wildfowlers who have never hunted him.

The World Fellowship of Faiths, organized in 1924 by the late Kedarnath Das Gupta of India, a follower of Mohandas K. Gandhi, has announced seven public meetings under its auspices of a "world parliament of religions," starting at 8:15 P. M. today at the head- quarters of the Theosophical Society, 9 East Fortieth Street.

HONG KONG, Oct. 26 -- Nationalist Central News Agency reports from Taipei, Formosa, asserted today that a Communist amphibious force attempting to capture Kingman Island in Amoy harbor from Nationalist defenders had been destroyed.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 26 -- Although opened four months ago, Elizabeth's new $200,000 almshouse with a capacity of 125 persons shelters only forty-eight, while the city continues to pay board to out-of-town institutions for twelve indigents, the local assistance board revealed today.

To strengthen the heart and tuberculosis services available to residents of New York State, a pioneer experiment in uniting the work of two leading voluntary health agencies of the state was announced yesterday by the American Heart Association and the State Charities Aid association.
BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- Reports that reprisals against dissident politicians have been launched on a wide scale in the Soviet zone are reaching here daily.

An early peace treaty with Western Germany and the restoration of its sovereignty was urged last night by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former American military governor of Germany, at the final session of the eighteenth annual New York Herald Tribune Forum.

Keeping New Yorkers healthy and giving them necessary medical care costs the eighty-six non-profit, voluntary hospitals in New York an average of $195.96 every minute of every day, according to Thomas J. Watson Jr., 1949 campaign chairman for the United Hospital Fund.

Argument in a suit to compel the Board of Elections to show cause in Supreme Court why it should not be restrained from including on the ballot the name of Benjamin J. Davis Jr., convicted Communist, as candidate for City Councilman in the coming election, was postponed yesterday until this morning after Justice Benedict D. Dineen had been informed that two of the plaintiffs had withdrawn from the case.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Paul G. Hoffman left Washington for Paris today with every intention of telling the Marshall Plan countries that there might be no third appropriation for European recovery unless they made good their pledges of mutual assistance by removing trade barriers and payments difficulties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The new minimum wage of 75 cents an hour became law in a White House ceremony today, and immediately the textile workers started a campaign for a new national minimum of $1 an hour.
The Damon Runyon Memorial Fund yesterday presented checks totaling $101,000 to eight institutions to support cancer research.
An unusual oxygen piping system installed at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center at a cost of $35,000 was disapproved yesterday by the Fire Department.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 26 -- President Truman's plan to help the free peoples of the world produce more of the goods they need -- more food, clothing, housing and mechanical power -- was defended here today by the Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- The proposals for freer trade that will be set up for discussion in the European Marshall Plan Council Monday, when Mr. Hoffman will address it, are regarded by Continental and United States experts as falling far short of what the Economic Cooperation Administrator considers necessary to induce Congress to renew dollar aid next year.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- The United States District Court here today declared invalid a State Board of Censors' regulation providing for censorship of all films to be shown by television stations in Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Judge Alexander Holtzoff in Federal District Court approved today the sale of The Washington Times-Herald to The Chicago Tribune Company, headed by Col. Robert R. McCormick.

Women who have long taken an active interest in the work of Stony Wold Sanatorium are furthering plans for the annual Tip Top Ball for the benefit of the sanatorium to be held on Nov. 4 at the Ritz- Carlton. The event has been arranged by members of Auxiliary No. 5 of Stony Wold Sanatorium, of which Mrs. Dudley B. Bonsal is chairman.

A quiet but deadly race for supremacy in rocket and jet-propelled aircraft is going on. It is a contest between nations, and the chief participants are the United States and Great Britain on the one hand and the Soviet Union on the other.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- If the number and tone of the United States Government's communications to the Communist world are of any significance, the "cold war" is getting somewhat warmer.

Plans for a campaign for $2,000,000 to provide a ten-story hospital and home as an addition to the present Home and Hospital of the Daughters of Jacob, 167th Street and Findlay Avenue, the Bronx, will be announced at a dinner on Sunday in the Waldorf- Astoria Hotel, marking the fifty- third anniversary of the oldest orthodox home for the aged in the United States.

Formation of a new organization, Produce Prepackaging Association, was announced yesterday during final sessions of the first national conference on prepackaging in the Commodore Hotel. The conference was held in conjunction with the eleventh annual forum of the Packaging Institute.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Opening the House of Commons debate today on the Government's proposed economies, Sir Stafford Cripps dotted the "i's" and crossed the "t's" in Prime Minister Attlee's statement that the Government would cut its spending by 250,

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- Jose Ferrer, Broadway actor who lately has been appearing in motion pictures here, today figured in deals at two major studios. Twentieth Century-Fox reported that it had signed him to a five-year contract,, effective March 15, while Metro announced that before

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 26 -- It was a great night for the Irish as the curtain went down on the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight. The officers of Ireland, previously without victory through seven days of military jumping competition, won the concluding International Military Challenge Trophy event to hearten their adherents for the National that begins in Madison Square Garden next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Two Interstate Commerce Commission examiners today recommended that the commission approve the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's proposed purchase of the Detroit, Toledo Ironton Railroad from the Pennroad Corporation for $25,782,209.50 and also recommended that the Pennsylvania and the Erie Railroads be allowed to buy joint control of the Springfield Suburban Railroad Company from Pennroad.
LONDON, Oct. 26 (Reuters) -- British Government securities slumped today on the London Stock Exchange for the second successive day following the Government's 280,000,000 ($784,000,000) economy cuts.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- Cramp's shipyard, closed since last winter, will be reopened on Friday by the American and Foreign Warehouse Company.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- A committee of trade unionists and employers was instructed today to investigate the redeployment of Britain's labor for more concentrated production and the export drive.

Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board, warned the private insurance industry last night that it must prove equal to the new non-occupational disability insurance in this state or the Government surely would take over the job.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26 -- The mystery man of Yale football finally is ready to step into the role ticketed for him from the day he matriculated as a schoolboy sensation from Hyde Park High in Chicago.
A group of left-wing department store unions that seceded last year from the Congress of Industrial Organizations will form a central unit of their own, it became known yesterday.

POUNDRIDGE, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Wreckage of a F-84 Thunderjet fighter-bomber plane was scattered over a three-mile area here today after it went out of control and crashed from more than 10,000 feet. Jack Bade, 29 years old, of Massapequa, L. I., test pilot, barely escaped with his life.

A $400,000,000 to $500,000,000 loan to and diplomatic recognition of Spain were recommended yesterday by Representative James J. Murphy, Democrat, of Staten Island, who returned on the United States liner America from a seven-week tour of Western Europe.

The stork is keeping a seasoned eye on fashion, judging by the collection of attractive fashions -- all adjustable, of course -- offered yesterday in a showing at Lane Bryant. There a were hip-length boxy jackets in stiff brocades and rich colored velvets to top crepe or velvet skirts and slim faille slacks.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 26 -- Students on the Deerfield Academy campus, who take their football seriously, are wearing grins these days because the Green and White is waging a successful campaign despite severe losses through graduation. Deerfield has dropped only one game while winning three.

Victor McQuistion, former head of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, was incorrectly quoted in an Associated Press story of Oct. 18 as having said that "a fare as high as 10 cents" might have to be obtained for the trustees to operate the system at a profit.

A recent Board of Education decision to move the administrative offices of the Bureau of Supplies from Brooklyn to Queens produced something of a mystery yesterday. School authorities were not sure where the bureau was.

Edward Martin has purchased the two-story two-family dwelling at 951 New York Avenue, Brooklyn, from Alfred Albert. The Lincoln Savings Bank made a purchase money mortgage of $5,000 in connection with the transaction, which was negotiated by Timothy J. Keyes as broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Differences between Local 968 of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and its parent organization must be aired at a trial Nov. 7 in the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, Justice Francis X. Giaccone ruled yesterday.

Prices on the stock market climbed yesterday to the best levels since July, 1948, in the widest and most inclusive rally in a month. It was after midday when the list broke out of a narrow course to develop a major push which raised the composite price average by 1.20 points.

LONDON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Britain turned down today demands for full self-government for the 4,000,000 people of West Africa's Gold Coast. She thereby risked what many colonial administrators fear is a threatened link-up between European Communist agitators and Nationalist leaders in West Africa.

Net income of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for the nine months to Sept. 30 was announced yesterday as $48,964,408, largest in the sixty-three-year history of the pioneer manufacturer of electrical equipment. The share earnings were $3.64.

In reply to Mayor O'Dwyer's assertion that the city's purchase of the transit lines was the "worst deal that ever happened to the city," Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party, said last night that the Mayor was attacking a dead man, the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.

A half billion dollars worth of pre-war dollar bonds of German industrial enterprises, many holding mortgages on Ruhrland riches, are the stake of a unique bondholder protection action announced yesterday by thirteen major New York and Chicago banks.

We hope that the understanding reached between the city and the Madison Square Garden Corporation for the new $25,000,000 Columbus Circle Coliseum will result in realization of the project. The convention hall included in the plans, to accommodate 50,000 persons, is urgently needed if New York is to become the "convention city" to which our principal business and commercial interests aspire.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- In the worst slump in weeks more than 200,000,000 was lopped off the market valuation of British Government stocks on the Stock Exchange here today. The pressure apparently came from industrial companies and individual investors rather than from big banks.

A program of "abundance rather than austerity" in the rebuilding of United States trade with Germany was urged last night by George F. Bauer, international trade consultant, at the annual meeting of the United States-German Chamber of Commerce in Fraunces Tavern.

Fordham, once again the football toast of New York town, is not letting success go to its head. For the second straight day yesterday the offensive and defensive. Ram platoons locked horns in a bristling scrimmage session against the freshmen.
DETROIT, Oct. 26 -- The United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company concluded their agreement containing a $100-a-month pension guarantee tonight.

ELLOREE, S. C., Oct. 26 -- The stores of this predominantly white town of 1,500 population closed yesterday out of respect for a Negro who had died after more than fifty years of service to his community and county. He was Robert Lee Williams, who died on Saturday at the age of 87 in his farm home.

The loyalty and judgment of wartime pilots who swore that there always would be missions for their beloved "Cats" were vindicated yesterday when one of the sturdy amphibious planes passed through New York on the way to the Netherlands Indies. There the "Cat" and four others will serve as island-hopping passenger airliners.

Net income of the Phillips Petroleum Company and subsidiary companies after a tax refund of $1,418,184 was $32,684,666, equal to $5.40 a share, in the nine months ended on last Sept. 30, it was disclosed yesterday. The net represents a decline of $23,018,106 from the net profit of $55,702,772, or $9.21 a share cleared a year earlier.

A three-square-mile area of Brooklyn was without residential and business electric lighting last night as the result of a fire at 9:22 o'clock in a high-tension switch in the basement of the Consolidated Edison Company's substation at Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Owen D. Young was born in the village of Van Hornesville, N. Y., seventy-five years ago today. His home address is still Van Hornesville, and it is safe to say that Van Hornesville never had and probably never will have a more distinguished resident. As a matter of fact, the Empire State, which has produced many famous sons, can boast few who have led more useful lives, few better citizens.

POKAI BAY, Hawaii, Oct. 26 -- Exercise "Miki," the largest amphibious operation since the war, ended today after the invading Second Infantry Division, put ashore only twenty-four hours ago, mounted a hypothetical breakthrough operation from its mountain-rimmed wainane "pocket" beachhead on the western shore of Oahu Island.
For the second time in two years Dr. Edmund Carter Rosenhauch yesterday examined the eyes of a 10-year-old boy blinded from living in a cave near Brody, Poland, to escape the Nazis.
