Abe Stark, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Borough President of Brooklyn, charged yesterday that his Democratic opponent, Borough President John Cashmore, had injected the religious issue into the Brooklyn campaign and was seeking to ride back into office on "the coat tails" of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- In a casual way the British Foreign Office has let the United States Government know that it is not very happy about all the statements that John J. McCloy has been making since became United States High Commissioner in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Air Force announced today that a major air defense exercise employing 200 planes and more than 5,000 personnel from all branches of the service would be held in the Northwest from Nov. 4 to Nov. 14.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 26 -- In the next general war the United States Army will move in fast and the early reserves will probably be National Guard divisions, Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today in an address at the seventy-first general conference of the National Guard Association.
The following political broadcasts are scheduled for today:

BUFFALO, Oct. 26 -- Calling Federal assistance to education a necessity for strengthening democracy in all parts of the country, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman asserted today that Senator John Foster Dulles' opposition to such aid "smacks of economic isolationism."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 26 -- The Socialists formally proposed today that nothing be done to re-establish King Leopold III on the Belgium throne unless two-thirds of the votes of the registered electorate were in his favor in the referendum to be prepared by the Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Restoration of citizenship to three Japanese-American women who renounced that right during internment in wartime West Coast evacuation centers will not be fought by the Department of Justice, Attorney General J. Howard McGrath announced today.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Michigan's Boxing Commission today backed up Kid Gavilan's "never was I robbed so much" claim after losing a split-decision to unknown Lester Felton by firing one judge and the referee.

Mayor O'Dwyer assailed the Federal Government yesterday for what he termed its "stupid and inhumane" action in ordering a layoff of 2,500 employes at the Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn and then appealing to private business in the New York area to provide jobs for them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Controversies centering on the public utilities can always be depended on to emit the heat, light and darkness-due-to-blow-outs which this industry furnishes to the people in the physical sense. The Senate's rejection of Leland Olds to succeed himself as a member of the Federal Power Commission is no exception.

The City of Boston sold yesterday a new issue of $15,550,000 of tax-exempt bonds due on Nov. 1, 1950 to 1979, to a banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers at a bid of 100.004 for interest of 4 per cent, 1 1/4 per cent and 1 1/2 per cent, an interest cost of 1.4918 cent.

A welcome visitor to Grand Central Terminal this week is New York State's own Freedom Train, bearing an exhibition of eighty-nine original documents vividly illustrating the state's contribution to the growth and development of the basic liberties that compose the American heritage.

An appeal for the release of 22-year-old Ephraim Margolin, an active worker in the underground movement in Israel, from Ellis Island, where he has been detained pending investigation since Aug. 20, was sent by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday to Secretary of State Dean C. Acheson.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The earth is now heating up and the day is getting longer, according to a new hypothesis on the origin of the planet presented here today at the autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences. The meeting ended today.

With their defensemen handing out an inordinate number of jarring body checks, and their forwards finding the target with regularity, the New York Rangers made a successful home debut at Madison Square Garden last night.
The five-cent cup of coffee may soon pass into history along with the five-cent subway fare and the five-cent cigar.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Dr. Eslie Asbury's home-bred Brownian closed with a rush to win the Springside Purse at Garden State Park today by three-quarters of a length. Thwarted finished second, a half length before Brown Moat, who set all of the early pace.

WASHINGTON, Del., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Eight convicts escaped from New Castle County Prison tonight. They locked up Guard Captain Harry Harrington, raided the prison arsenal and, using another guard as a shield, walked out the front gate.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 26 -- Followers of former Mayor Frank Hague who attended a Democratic rally today at the Plaza Hotel heard Senator Elmer H. Wene predict that he would poll a plurality of more than 100,000 in Hudson County "despite what is being heard around."

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Prices of cattle soared to a top of $41.50 a hundred pounds today, a new 1949 peak and only 10 cents less than the high record made last year. The high price was $1.50 above yesterday's peak. It was paid for a load of prime steers weighing about 1,200 pounds each.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Rear Admiral H. C. Shepheard, chief of the United States Coast Guard's Office of Merchant Marine Safety, today commended this country's ship operators for operating "the fastest merchant marine in the world," and urged continued vigilance in self-regulation to avoid control by "a gigantic bureaucracy.

About twenty-five sculptures of James Forrestal, either in plaster or as finished works in bronze, are expected to be entered in an open contest for a memorial in Washington to the former Secretary of Defense, it was learned yesterday.

Unbeaten Roland LaStarza, 181 pounds, Bronx, scored his eighteenth knockout and his thirty-sixth consecutive victory when he stopped Walter Hafer, 199, Maysville, Ky., in 2:26 of the ninth of a scheduled ten-rounder before 1,603 fans at St. Nicholas arena last night.

In an interesting and readable report, the State Department's advisory commission on Educational Exchange has told the story of one phase of America's foreign relations that is not generally emphasized and yet is of real importance. That is the program of "trading ideas" and exchanging personnel with other countries in educational, cultural, scientific and technical fields.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 26 -- A plea for closer cooperation of governmental purchasing officials with manufacturing industries and commercial vendors in all classes was put before the closing sessions of the National Institute for Governmental Purchasing, Inc., here today at the Cleveland Hotel.

Rounding out its ownership of an entire tract of 45,000 square feet, the Carter Realty Company, a holding concern for the G. N. Coughlan Company, has bought the industrial property at 12-18 Spring Street in West Orange, N. J., from the Spar-Holl Manufacturing Company, in a deal negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker.

Much is being said and written today on the question of whether retirement income and health security programs won by labor through collective bargaining should be financed entirely by the employer ("non-contributory"), or should be partially employe-financed.

WHEN two book critics meet at an Overseas Press Club luncheon for Nehru, or on board the 6:58 for Niblickdale, or in racing circles at Jamaica, one simply says to the other: "Have you read Cabell Phillips' 'Dateline: Washington,'"* or, "Have you read Dale Kramer's book about Heywood Broun?"

The twelve-story apartment house at 801 West End Avenue, accommodating seventy-one families, has again passed to new ownership. John Kirschner, who bought it last month from the Lona Realty Corporation, of which Frank Slater is president, has sold it to Hardan

Expansion by the United States of stockpiling of metals and minerals from the present narrow concept of military preparedness to the broader goal of long-range national security wasu rged yesterday by Elmer W. Pehrson, acting director of the foreign minerals region of the United States Bureau of Mines.

The American Public Health Association; holding its annual meeting here, yesterday passed a resolution "condemning specific taxes on oleomargarine" and petitioned Congress and the various state legislatures to repeal these taxes in the interest of public health.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 26 -- The United States called today for a United Nations arms embargo against Albania and Bulgaria until both countries were officially cleared of charges of aiding the Greek guerrillas.

TOKYO, Oct. 26 -- If the report submitted to Gen. Douglas MacArthur today by the Advisory Mission for International Trade is adopted, Japan's export trade will be virtually freed from unusual controls, imports will be placed largely in private hands and the Occupation staff now supervising the Japanese will be drastically reduced.

LAS CRUCES, N. M., Oct. 26 (UP) -- Two automobiles crashed head-on twenty-nine miles west of Las Cruces today, killing three persons, including William J. Neal, deputy administrator of the Rural Electrification Administration.

Although the cover is still rather heavy and the woods a bit noisy the initial reports from several Adirondack counties indicate that deer are plentiful and hunting conditions better than had been expected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A suggestion that the board of inquiry in the steel dispute clarify its report and assist the parties in reaching an agreement has a recent and successful precedent in labor management relations, the record shows.

Dick Doheny, Fordham quarterback and passing ace, received a vote of confidence from his coach, Ed Danowski, yesterday, as the Rams ran through a two-hour dummy scrimmage for tomorrow's contest at the Polo Grounds with Georgetown University.

Denials from Washington that the White House contemplated immediate intervention in the steel and coal strikes were ignored yesterday by the stock market as prices pushed ahead to further new highs since mid-1948. Stimulated by new announcements of dividends and earnings reports, quotations on the New York Stock Exchange, as measured by the averages, rose 0.77 point, with gains of a point and much more scattered through a wide variety of issues.

Mayor O'Dwyer charged yesterday that Newbold Morris and his Liberal party supporters were trying to drive a wedge between him and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator.

A collection of original court jewels, predominantly of Czarist Russia but also including pieces from France, Germany, Persia and India, was offered yesterday at Georg Jensen, Inc. Here, glittering with precious stones, were such pieces as a snuff box belonging to Ludwig, the Mad King of Bavaria, his signature worked out in diamonds decorating the lid.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies disclosed today they had asked the State Workmen's Compensation Board to settle a dispute with an insurance company over benefit payments to Eddie Waitkus.

The hunting season for small game has opened. As of this moment, all of the state's small game, including that resident in protected counties and so withdrawing from sympathy, has gone underground. The first shot was the signal, well heeded.

MOST historical novels about brawny heroes and willing wenches finding adventure all across the map of frontier America have no other purpose than to entertain and to earn an honest penny. Most of them are worthless as fiction and suspect as accounts of America's past. On all three of these charges Charles O'Neill's "Morning Time"* must be exonorated.
OSLO, Norway, Oct. 27 -- More than half of Norway's Communist leaders were expelled from the party today and accused of "Titoism."

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Mike Turnesa of Knollwood, who bowed to Ben Hogan in the last round of the National P. G. A. championship in 1948, today reached the final of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association title tournament at the Ardsley Country Club course with Al Brosch of Cherry Valley, three-time winner of the crown.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- The Government abruptly rested its case against Herbert J. Burgman, accused of treason, late today.
Seven basic recommendations for revision of international protection of trade-marks were made public yesterday by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British High Commissioner in Germany, was engaged in talks today at the British Foreign Office. The major topic was believed to be the problem of incorporating Western Berlin into the West German State.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 27 -- The importance of treating as quickly as possible facial mutilation suffered in combat was emphasized at today's session of the Twelfth International Congress of Military Medicine and Pharmacy being held here.

The fur industry's staple market is composed of consumers spending about $200 in savings each, but they are "the women who know least about furs," Morris Hessel, president of the Fur Institute of America, declared yesterday. To help them he listed rules for guidance in purchasing a fur coat.

Commissioner Bernard J. Forman of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, reported "no material progress" yesterday as representatives of Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators resumed contract negotiations with the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Military planning has begun here among Britain, Norway and Denmark. The three powers form the Northern European Regional Planning Group of the twelve-nation North Atlantic pact. The discussions are being attended by United States military experts.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 27 -- The 1949 Nobel Prize for medicine was awarded jointly today to a Swiss and a Portuguese for their discoveries in the function of the brain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Booing Washingtonians jammed a big hearing room today to vent their feelings about an issue that has split the town -- radios in trolleys and buses.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, presented two offerings at its concert last night in Carnegie Hall not performed previously by the organization. These were the Song of the Wood-Dove from Schoenberg's "Gurrelieder" and the symphonic poem, "Uirapuru," by Villa-Lobos.

Oxygen piping systems will be installed in all new construction on city hospitals, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, declared yesterday at department headquarters, 125 Worth Street. In view of the Fire Department's disapproval of a similar system at a private hospital, its possible reaction to the city plan was in doubt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Frank Pace Jr., Budget Director, said after a White House visit today that the budget for the fiscal year 1951 would not be higher than 1950's $41,900,000,000, but that "it certainly won't be below $40,000,000,000.

Doctors from many states and from Canada make regular trips to New York to attend refresher courses at the eighty-six hospitals which are members of the United Hospital Fund. Typical of this practice was a recent meeting of eighty-five out-of-town doctors at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, 210 East Sixty-fourth Street.

HONG KONG, Oct. 27 -- Communists produced victory claims of their own today to rival Nationalist stories of defeat early this week of Communist forces attempting to capture Quemoy Island off the Fukien coast.

Mrs. Fiorello H. La Guardia declared last night that Mayor O'Dwyer would not dare attack her husband if he were still living. Speaking over Station WOR, Mrs. La Guardia pleaded for the election of Newbold Morris, the Republican-Liberal Fusion candidate for Mayor.

It can happen that one part of one show can save an evening's entertainment and turn it into a triumph. This was the case when at group of young Metropolitan singers assembled together through the provisions of the Kathryn Turney Long Trust, and sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, gave a triple bill of buffa operas last night in the Juilliard School on Claremont Avenue.
The Columbia football squad of forty-five players left from Pennsylvania Station last night for Ithaca, where the Lions will play Cornell tomorrow.
Meeting in special session yesterday, the Board of Education awarded contracts totaling $4,027,672 to construct two new schools and modernize two existing ones.

With Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne returning to Broadway, why can't the same be said of another well-known acting couple, namely, Fredric March and Florence Eldridge? This rhetorical question probably will be answered in the affirmative soon, although official confirmation was lacking yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 27 -- The first authentic international gendarmerie has now come very close to realization as a result of a surprisingly favorable vote today in the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly on a motion to create a small field force to protect the personnel and property of the world organization.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 27 -- Several would-be prospectors returned today, convinced that Fishwheel, the booming tent town up on the Yukon flats near the Arctic Circle, is not gold country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Truman said today that a national emergency in coal and steel was a long way off and, by implication, that his personal intervention in those strikes was just as far away.

The paths of two Mayoralty candidates, Newbold Morris and Vito Marcantonio, crossed in Brooklyn last night and, like small boys, they dared each other to say whom they were going to vote for in the Senatorial race.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- The worst October windstorm in years subsided today in England and along most of the Western European coast, after inflicting heavy property damage and causing at least ten deaths.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- A permanent peace will be achieved only when, the enemies of God having been defeated, the entire world will be bound together by the Christian faith, Pope Pius today told a group of United States Senators during a private audience at his Castel Gandolfo summer residence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- It fell to the lot of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld to bear the brunt of unification's first impact on the Navy. He was appointed Chief of Naval Operations largely because his oft speech and gentle manner had given him the reputation of being the greatest compromiser in the Navy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Expressing confidence that within the ranks of American ship builders "there are men who can supply the technical knowledge that is required for a well-rounded and effective safety program," Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, called upon these experts to "give direction and purpose to this phase of "'Operations Safety.'"
LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Prof. Antonio Caetana de Abreu Freire Egas Moniz, informed tonight that he was the co-winner of the 1949 Nobel prize for medicine, said:

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 27 -- Bernard M. Baruch, former United States representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, issued a warning today against acceptance of any temporary substitute for an effective international atomic control plan.

Three - button, single - breasted men's suits are the preferred choice of retailers throughout the the style committee of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, released yesterday. More than forty stores were surveyed on the subject of "University Fashion Trends."
DETROIT, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Detroit police launched a full-fledged investigation today into the bout in which Kid Gavilan of Cuba lost a decision here last week.

The untimely death of Catherine Mackenzie will be felt most keenly by the many friends she had won in the mental health and social work fields. In her constant search for information that would help her readers toward improved parent-child relationships and better family living, Miss Mackenzie always looked to the most authoritative sources and relied only on well documented material.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Governor Dewey attacked former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman here tonight for imputing religious bigotry to John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for the United States Senate.

Though your correspondents have informed you of the profound dissatisfaction of German democrats with the course of events, you may consider the following observations of one of them worth publishing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Truman removed Admiral Louis E. Denfeld today as Chief of Naval Operations. Mr. Truman, Commander in Chief of all the armed forces, made his decision after Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, advised him that he had considered the admiral's "usefulness" at an end.
The wholesale price of the leading brands of coffee rose another 5 to 6 cents a pound here yesterday.

The board of directors of the Child Study Association of America announced yesterday that Mrs. Mildred B. Beck had accepted the post of executive director of the organization. The announcement came after a meeting at the association's headquarters, 132 East Seventy fourth Street.
The Boston Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids on $8,800,000 of temporary tax-exempt loan notes on Nov. 3. Dated Nov. 14, 1949, the notes will come due on Nov. 14, 1950.

ROME, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A United States Senate appropriations subcommittee said here today it would investigate reports Britain was "using American dollars to build up its own private oil industry in the Middle East."

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for election, asserted today that his defeat at the polls on Nov. 8 would mean the further substitution of a "fake humanitarianism" for liberty in the "welfare state" defended by his opponent, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman.

Surrounded by a score of survivors of Nazi concentration ca two recently arrived displaced persons who had lost their families in such camps were married yesterday afternoon in a simple ceremony at the Marseilles Hotel, the national reception center maintained by the United Service for New Americans.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- United States plane manufacturers have asked permission here to build American copies of Britain's new de Havilland Comet, the world's first jet-propelled passenger plane, informed sources said today.

Dictating machine sales have passed the $25,000,000 mark annually and at the present rate of growth will reach $50,000,000 in three years, according to manufacturers exhibiting machines at the Business Show in Grand Central Palace.

Floyd Worthington is a good singer of songs. Such, at least, is the impression the baritone gave at his Town Hall recital last night. His musical intelligence is probably equal to dramatic utterance, but his voice, on this occasion, was not up to it.

Eugene G. Grace, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Company, warned yesterday that the shipbuilding industry in this country was "finished" unless the Government furnished subsidies or other aid to help it meet the pressure of foreign competition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Government had about $2,450,000,000 invested in surplus farm products on July 31. This investment, the Commodity Credit Corporation reported today, covered commodities bought or stored under producer price-support programs.

Apparently this has not been a week to be in the egg business. A decline of 18 cents a dozen on large Grade A's in five days, from a week ago yesterday through Wednesday, has made history in the wholesale market.

In its first change to new quarters in more than forty years, the J. S. Frelinghuysen Corporation, one of the oldest insurance brokerage firms in the city, has moved to 20 Vesey Street, where the concern will have more room to carry on its activity, Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers, reported yesterday.

Criticisms of the handling of the open competition for the James Forrestal memorial grew yesterday as sculptors charged that the project, in addition to unfair or impractical provisions, had been underpublicized.

TOKYO, Oct. 26 -- A special investigation committee of the Diet's lower house today accused the Japanese Communist party of planning forcible revolution in Japan by promoting labor violence and acts of terrorism.
With no visible ray of hope to encourage them, top Federal mediators continued yesterday their fruitless efforts to settle the four-week-old steel strike.

Buddhist priests and Christian missionaries in Japan are working together on social welfare, Chief Abbot Kocho Otani, of the Kyoto Higashi (East) Hongwanji Temple, said yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns announced late today that all of their players over 28 years old -- including Gerry Priddy and Bob Dillinger -- are up for sale or trade.

Sandy Saddler, Harlem boxer who held the featherweight championship of the world for a brief spell in the last indoor boxing season, will appear in the star bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. His opponent will be Paddy De Marco, free-swinging lightweight from the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn, against whom he is listed to travel ten rounds.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- During the week ended Oct. 26, member bank reserve balances decreased $307,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 27 -- Thousands of Jewish settlers from Iraq demonstrated today in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv against what they described as a "plot to disinherit and expel the oldest Jewish community in the world." They demanded government action to save the Jews of Iraq from the fate of the Jews in Germany and Europe.

SIMSBURY, Conn., Oct. 27 -- Last year the football squad at Westminster School got off to a slow start and then improved with rapidity. The result was that the Gold and Black, beaten four times, chalked up victories over South Kent and Pomfret, a traditional rival.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 27 -- Australia will ask the United Nations to set up an internationally protected sanctuary within Greece to receive and rehabilitate guerrillas now in refuge in Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- The Greater New York Safety Council, of which Paul F. Stricker is executive vice president, has been named winner of the National Safety Council's annual award for outstanding accomplishment during 1948 in competition with 250 other councils and chapters throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Truman named George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs and a career diplomat of nearly twenty years' service, today to be Ambassador to Yugoslavia.
John B. Fowler Jr. of Cohu Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, has been elected a director of the American Arch Company of Delaware and the American Arch Company, Inc., of New York.
Plastic window shades that can be wiped clean with a damp cloth, will not ravel and are resistant to fading and shrinking are now available to homemakers at Gimbels and Bloomingdale's.

HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 27 -- There is an increasing disposition on the part of employers in this country to choose workers on the basis of merit and without regard to race or national background, Dr. Channing M. Tobias, director of the Phelps Stokes Fund, declared tonight.

All city expenditures for public improvements authorized between Jan. 1, 1946, and Oct. 13, 1949, have been financed with available money in the city's sinking funds and retirement systems, according to a report submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate by Controller Lazarus Joseph.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- In contrast to the assertions last week by Soviet zone officials that industrial and agricultural quotas had been surpassed, residents of the Eastern zone arriving in Berlin report drastic shortages of the necessities of life.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday a net income of $198,735,386, a new high, for the third quarter of 1949. This raised net profit during the first nine months of the current year to a record $502,414,029, which also was far above any twelve-month earnings in the corporation's history.

Final phases of a five-point program designed to stimulate the sale of plastic housewares has been entered by the Dow Chemical Company, it was learned yesterday, At the second annual display of Styron products, houseware line made from Dow plastics, Donald L. Gibb, plastics sales manager, disclosed that the program has resulted in a sales jump of between 25 and 40 per cent over last year.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27 -- There wasn't a diamond tiara in sight. It was pigtails, short pants and bobby sox at the opera today. The occasion was a children's matinee presented by the San Francisco Opera Company.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Friday, Oct. 28 (AP) -- In a growing attack on Western diplomats, Czechoslovakia expelled two members of the French Embassy yesterday on charges that they had tried to spy out the nation's uranium mining secrets.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Liquidation developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, starting in soybeans and then spreading to wheat, corn and rye. November soybeans were off 4 3/4 cents a bushel at one time, selling at a new low since mid-July, and the July future sold at a new seasonal low.
Mayor O'Dwyer insisted yesterday that the election of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman to the Senate was of paramount importance to the people of this city.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- As was expected, the Government won a vote of confidence from the House of Commons tonight for its program of cuts in spending to meet the country's economic crisis. The Conservative motion condemning the Laborite program as inadequate to meet the nation's needs was defeated by 353 votes to 222 -- a record vote against the Labor Government.

Hundreds of young men and women and boys and girls have been sent to jails and reformatories because New York State does not have enough probation officers, Leonard Probst, State Commissioner of Probation, charged yesterday.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, former president of the Zionist Organization of America, said yesterday in a letter to John Foster Dulles that he was "amazed" at the charges of bigotry that had been lodged against the Republican candidate for the United States Senate.

While paying tribute to President Truman for his recognition of Israel, Edward J. Flynn, New York State Democratic National Committeeman and former Democratic National Chairman, last night denounced the State Department for its failure to intercede with Great Britain for a united Ireland.

PARIS, Friday, Oct. 28 -- Georges Bidault, Popular Republican and former Foreign Minister who had been out of the Cabinet for more than a year, was approved as Premier early today by a vote of 367 to 183. It was the largest vote accorded to a candidate since the current Cabinet crisis developed on Oct. 6.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- The State Bar Association announced today that the thirteen living past presidents of the association had, as individuals, accepted invitations to serve on a committee working for the election of Judge Bruce Bromley, Republican candidate for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals.

The Gotham dances for debutantes, sub-debutantes and young men at home from schools and colleges will be resumed this season after having been discontinued during the recent war. The first in the series will be held on Thanksgiving Eve, Nov. 23, at Sherry's, at which the guests will be limited to young women seniors in secondary schools. debutantes and college freshmen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- President Truman today signed a bill authorizing the Commodity Credit Corporation to take all the loss on any United States wheat shipped abroad at cut-rate prices under the International Wheat Agreement.

The United States must be prepared to fight communism with the "big stick" to repel an attack if one should come, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said last night at a dinner given jointly by the Roosevelt Memorial Association and the Women's Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Association in the restored home of the former President, 28 East Twentieth Street.

Along with a five-game losing streak the New York Bulldogs will display another new player at the Polo Grounds Sunday when they meet the Washington Redskins in the National Football League's counter-attraction to the All-America Conference battle at the Yankee Stadium between the Yankees and the Baltimore Colts.
THE lesson should have been learned last week when the upsets were delivered by the bushel basket. But football selectors have corrugated hides and corrugated heads. They learn nothing. So here goes:

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's net income of $82,898,402 for the first nine months of this year was the record for such a period, E. G. Grace, chairman, reported yesterday. It was equal to $8.14 a common share and compared with $53,183,858, or $5.39 a share, in the same period of last year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- For the first time, an entire American industry has succeeded in a nationwide program which has raised engineering standards by a national educational program, and improved its potential for better customer service through higher quality personnel.

The eleven Communist party leaders who were found guilty of conspiring to organize their party to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government have decided to remain in the Federal Detention House here pending outcome of their petition for bail, which is to be submitted today to the Circuit Court of Appeals.

Suedes, fine men's wear fabrics and wools, in the women's casual coats and suits softened by detail that are characteristic of Sport and Travel, occupied the major part of this shop's showing yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

The CIT Financial Corporation, industrial banking organization, reported yesterday combined un-audited net earnings of $18,577,157, equal to $4.82 a common share, for the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1949.

The first dip in coffee futures quotations in five days brought a slight glimmer of hope yesterday to coffee traders caught in a "short" squeeze on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The development eased slightly a trading situation that was costing shorts roughly $600 daily on each futures contract they were committed to deliver.

Practical results of pin-pointed newspaper market research in boosting grocery manufacturers' sales and advertising budgets were cited yesterday as a low-cost guide to successful selling in a period of rising costs.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 27 -- The Arab League Council adopted a resolution today to be forwarded to all member governments, urging that the rights of citizenship be given to any Arab asking for them and that those not wishing to change their citizenship have the right to indefinite residence.

The Procter Gamble Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $19,737,322, equal to $3.07 a common share, for the quarter ended Sept. 30. This compares with a profit of $13,221,916, or $2.05 a share, for the corresponding quarter last year.

For thirty years the American Civil Liberties Union and Roger N. Baldwin have been almost synonymous terms. Mr. Baldwin and his organization have been in the forefront of virtually every important legal battle for protection of those human rights guaranteed to the American people by the Constitution and by the very spirit of American democracy.

Four nation-wide promotions, to be sponsored and coordinated by the Jewelry Industry Council, New York, have been set for 1950, it was announced yesterday. They are: "Diamond Jubilee" March 23 to April 12; "Silver Parade," April 20 to May 6; "It's Watch Inspection Time," Sept. 7 to 16, and "Watch Parade," Oct. 26 to Nov. 11.
Six of the current exhibitions of contemporary American painting demonstrate that the last fault attributable to it is lack of variety.

Robert Lee Williams of Elloree, S. C., had wanted to be a physician. In 1889, when he was 27 years old, family obligations compelled him to take up farming. An intelligent man, he became a good farmer, one of the first in his section to mechanize his sowing and cropping in this famous old cotton region of the South, and one of the first to see the need for diversifying his crops.

Christopher Morley has a second book listed for publication this year by Doubleday. "The Ironing Board," to be issued Nov. 10, is a collection including burlesque detective stories, letters, fables and "at least one absolute outrage of carnal comedy."

With devaluation of sterling by 30 per cent six weeks old, the discount market in restricted "transferable sterling" trade balances is stirring again. For a brief period after the September devaluations the free market accommodations offered here for the selling of restricted sterling trade balances for dollars was convulsed with extraordinary transactions which reflected the covering of speculators and abnormal capital flight from China.
A post office employe took a postal inspector for a ride in his automobile and wound up yesterday under arrest for stealing mail.

As conditions for continued support of the European Recovery Program, the National Association of Manufacturers made public yesterday thirteen recommendations to help participating countries increase their trade and stabilize economic relationships.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican, of New York, and Herbert H. Lehman, rival candidates for the Senate, agreed today that the United States should take the lead in seeking a political union of the Atlantic security-pact nations.
GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross has been told by the Polish Government to close its operations in Poland and withdraw its staff.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Export-Import Bank authorized today a further $20,000,000 credit to Israel for industrial development in that country. The additional amount brought to $73,350,000 the total credit authorized to Israel under, the $100,000,000 ear-marked by the bank last January.

Arrangements for the city to take over the former settlement house of the Good Neighbor Federation at 115 East 106th Street to be operated as a neighborhood center by the Youth Board were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

While the raw fur market continues firm and new season prices are expected to show advances, retail fur sales have been notably spotty. Volume in many sections of the country is lagging behind expectations, reflecting both poor selling weather and caution engendered by the steel and coal strikes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation, Poughkeepsie, N. Y., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $6,000,000 of ten-year convertible debentures, due on Nov. 1, 1959. It said the interest rate, offering price and underwriting terms and the names of the underwriters are to be filed by amendment.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Martha Lipton, mezzosoprano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Robert Brink, violin, Town Hall, 8:30; "Tosca," City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; Society for Forgotten Music, Carl Fischer Hall, 8:30; Halloween Witch Hunt Hootenanny, Panel Room, 13 Astor Place, 8:30; Goethe Festival, Hunter College Orchestra, conducted by Alexander Bernyk, College Assembly Hall, 8:30; Jazz Concert, Central Plaza, evening.

The British National Health Service "is already part of our national life and everyone recognizes that it has come to stay," Dr. A. Leslie Banks, Professor of Human Ecology at the University of Cambridge, England, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association at the Statler Hotel.

Net sales of Standard Brands, Inc., and subsidiaries operating in the United States were $193,543,776 for the first nine months of 1949, compared with $214,034,858 in the similar period of 1948, Joel S. Mitchell, president, announced yesterday.

The Columbia Broadcasting System will devote a total of seven and a half hours of air time to televising the six-day bicycle races, which start on Sunday at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory. The event, in which thirteen teams of riders will whirl around a steel track one-eighth of a mile in circumference, will be telecast on five different nights.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 9 to 15 points net lower.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 27 -- Dismantling of factories for reparations is the "boiling" subject in Germany and should not be allowed to fester, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner for Germany, declared today.
The United States Trust Company of New York has been appointed co - transfer agent for capital stock of the American Automobile Insurance Company.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Oct. 27 -- Trustees of Jefferson Military College served notice tonight that they would not countenance any charter changes requiring teaching of racial superiority or barring persons of any denominations as students.

The debate in the British Parliament over the economies proposed by the Labor Government to help straighten out the dollar crisis and the effects of devaluation has run the expected course. The Government has too large and too disciplined a majority to be in any danger of upset.

The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that its commuters would now have "the convenience of buying commutation tickets by mail." Henry A. Weiss, traffic manager, described the terms on which this could be done.

The United Hospital Fund started a can-box campaign yesterday to aid eighty-six voluntary hospitals. New Yorkers will be approached for funds on the streets through tomorrow and in shops and theatres through next week.

ATHENS, Oct. 27 -- King Paul conferred a field marshal's baton today upon Gen. Alexander Papagos, Commander in Chief of the Greek armed forces. This is the first time the rank has been held by anyone not of royal blood.
A seven-to-fourteen-year prison sentence was imposed yesterday on a former Navy radar operator who had built his own crime laboratory and used a walkie-talkie radio in a midtown burglary attempt.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct 27 -- The best organized drive in the state by medical men to "prevent socialized medicine" by defeating Herbert H. Lehman for United States Senator and electing John Foster Dulles is under way in the city of Rochester.

For the first time in the political history of New York State, the three branches of organized labor joined last night in a united labor rally, held in Madison Square Garden for the election of Herbert H. Lehman to the United States Senate and the re-election of Mayor O'Dwyer.
With election day eleven days away, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, forecast yesterday his own victory by a plurality of 25,000 to 35,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A Department of Transportation headed by a Secretary with Cabinet status was recommended today by Charles L. Dearing and Wilfred Owen, who recently directed a Hoover Commission task force on transportation.
LONDON, Friday, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A plane crashed in flames as it took off from London airport today and killed six persons, four of them Americans and two Britons.
American Home Products Corporation has declared an extra year-end dividend of 50 cents, in addition to the regular monthly quarterly dividend of 10 cents on the common, both payable on Dec. 1.

Alfred Van Santvoord Olcott, former president of the Hudson River Day Line, has donated the original bell from Robert Fulton's steamboat, the Clermont, to the New York Historical Society, Dr. Fenwick Beekman, president, announced yesterday at a meeting of the organization's board of trustees.

Women headed by Mrs. Robert Clifford Wilson are aiding in the plans for the second annual Christmas sale, luncheon and tea dance for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society to be held on Nov. 15 in the Embassy ballroom and Garden of the Ambassador.

Loans to business in this area rose for the ninth consecutive time in the week ended on Wednesday. Figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed an increase of $23,000,000 in borrowings from member banks in New York City to $4,858,000,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Major cost reductions can be planned on a mass production basis in any industry by using new methods of work simplification, engineers at Servel, Inc., Evansville, Ind., declared here today. They addressed more than 1,000 members of the National Metal Trades Association during the second day of the fiftieth annual convention at the Palmer House.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 27 -- United Nations quarters expressed disbelief today at reports that the Polish Government might oust international agencies employing non-Polish personnel.

Ladies of fashion are going to be all done up in ribbon for the holiday and resort seasons, if the milliners have their way. The prediction was made yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where there was shown a collection of chapeaux, some of them flown over by Air France from Paris for the occasion and many more created by New York's leading designers.

Net income of $29,617,733, equal to $2.17 a share, was reported yesterday by the Standard Oil Company of California for the quarter ended Sept. 30. This compares with an income of $39,461,600, or $3.03 a share, last year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Oct. 22 were 589,088 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Although America has staked its future on education, teacher-training colleges are made "step-children of the alma mater" and the country's 1,250,000 teachers are generally "ill-prepared" for their tasks, Dr. Edwin R. Embree, former president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, declared yesterday.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Prof. Walter Rudolf Hess, informed tonight that he had won a Nobel award; indicated he would use his share of the fund to set up a laboratory for his work in physiology, and medicine.

Fred A. Blaser of Kankakee, Ill., picked a good day to make his first visit of the fall to Jamaica. He was among the 15,982 present for yesterday's Empire City Racing Association proceedings and saw his silks carried by Count-A-Bit to a front-running victory in the Class C Handicap that topped the program.

Preferring a trial before a judge and jury rather than before three justices in Special Sessions, two brothers, who are attorneys, appeared yesterday in General Sessions to plead to an indictment charging rent gouging.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, told Representative Thomas J. Lane, Democrat, of Massachusetts, today that the work load at the Boston Naval Shipyard could not be increased at this time.

Smoke abatement and fuel conservation can be made synonymous with benefit to the community if proper fuel and efficient operation are combined in housing, industry and public service, officials in this field declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 22 were 14 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of 1948, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of last year:

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Renewal of heavy selling of British Government stocks led to further substantial declines in prices on the stock markets here today. At one stage losses ranged up to 1 1/2 points, but a rally reduced the losses about half.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (UP) -- An attorney for a Chicago property-owners' group which has attacked constitutionality of the 1949 Rent Act today asked a three-judge Federal Court for an injunction allowing rents to be increased by 50 per cent.

MONTREAL, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul G. Hoffman predicted today that the Soviet Union would collapse from Within, possibly when Premier Stalin died, if Western Europe were kept strong.

Despite drops of 13 per cent in net sales and of 42 per cent in net income, from last year's levels, directors of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation declared an extra dividend of 25 cents a share in addition to the fourth quarter dividend of 25 cents, it was announced yesterday. The directors also declared a quarterly dividend of $1.75 on the preferred.

On Oct. 18 Admiral Louis E. Denfeld, Chief of Naval Operations, appeared before a committee of Congress and made a sharp attack upon the present military policies of the Government. It was his duty to appear before the Committee when he was asked to do so. Congress, a civilian authority, with power over defense appropriations, has the right to ask questions.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The steering committee of the Marshall Plan Council, made up of eight Foreign or Finance Ministers, will meet tomorrow to discuss what Western Europe can do in reply to United States criticisms that it has been lax about economic cooperation.

PRAGUE, Oct. 27 -- An overflow Prague music theatre audience tonight burst out with a storm of angry protests when a program commentator criticized Bing Crosby as a "greedy American money-seeker who sacrifices his art for gold."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Coach George Sauer pondered several changes today in Navy's starting line-up against Notre Dame at Baltimore on Saturday.

The Wilhelmsen Line, largest Norwegian operator of merchant vessels, will have fully recovered its war losses by the end of 1951, according to Niels Werring, one of four men who own and operate the company.

In an outspoken address at Montreal, Economic Cooperation Administrator Hoffman has called upon the nations of Western Europe to speed up their economic unification as the essential condition for their survival in the face of a Communist menace and the economic facts of life in a modern world.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 27 -- A subcommittee of the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today approved the establishment of a five-man commission to submit recommendations on the future government of Eritrea to the 1950 Assembly.

Commenting on President Truman's recent statement about raising the national income from $200,000,000,O00 a year to $300,000,000,000 a year, the Guaranty Trust Company's monthly publication, Guaranty Survey, warns today that putting income objectives in terms of dollars "is a standing temptation to resort to inflationary measures, because such measures provide a sure and easy way of reaching the goal."

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 27 -- Federal program of educational aid, calling for "some such amount as $300,000,000 annually for scholarships,'' was urged here today by Earl J. McGrath, Federal Commissioner of Education.

MONTREAL, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs stroked in two swift goals just before the end of the game tonight to defeat Montreal, 2 -- 0, and knock the Canadiens into a tie with Detroit for the National Hockey League lead.

The report that former Field Marshal Friedrich von Paulus is coming home from his Russian captivity stirs memories. Seven years ago von Paulus was commanding an army in front of Stalingrad, where he had been ordered by Adolf Hitler to hold his ground. Three hundred and thirty thousand men of his command obeyed the order and fell there, dead or wounded.

One interesting thing about the anniversary of the first ride on our New York City subway system is that it is only the forty-fifth. Plans for the building of a subway date back nearly a hundred years, and an Assembly committee was directed to study such a possibility as early as 1857. The first bill providing the right of construction was introduced in the State Senate in 1864.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- Extremely conscious of the threat that Pittsburgh offers to its undefeated record, Pennsylvania's football squad today piled still more contact work on two days of rugged scrimmaging. Coach George Munger kept the Quakers busy hitting the blocking and tackling dummies and each other until darkness had settled over River Field.

State Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink, national chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, criticized Arthur Garfield Hays yesterday for "an unwarranted attack" against the league in a speech made Wednesday before the New York Chapter of the American Council for Judaism.

All Brooklyn representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, have been "alerted" to the possibility that efforts might be made to "start trouble" on that borough's docks this morning, Joseph P. Ryan, ILA president, asserted yesterday afternoon.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the Grand Jury Association of New York County yesterday made pleas to voters to support Amendment 4 on Election Day. The amendment would prohibit a public official who had been forced to resign or was removed from holding public office again.

With the United States as its "backbone," the United Nations has a far better chance to succeed than its predecessor, the League of Nations, in the opinion of Dr. Carl J. Hambro, veteran Norwegian statesman and president of the Norwegian Storting.

The Farrell Lines pier at Thirty-third Street, Brooklyn, first unit in the city's waterfront rehabilitation program to be completed, was formally dedicated in brief noon-hour ceremonies yesterday. Borough President John Cashmore cut a silk ribbon and opened the dock to traffic.

As spokesman for the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, Inc., a non-profit organization composed of parents and friends of mentally retarded children, I wish to express the gratitude of our entire organization for the very comprehensive article concerning these children by Dr. Howard A. Rusk which appeared in your edition of Sept. 4.
Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Mayor, pitched in yesterday to what he described as the constructive aspects of his campaign.

I would like to point out what I believe to be a gravely misleading implication in your otherwise commendable editorial of Oct. 19. Except for the first sentence, the editorial reflects the usual sound arguments in favor of freedom of opinion and speech; against thought control and censorship. Indeed, the excellence of the editorial, save for the first sentence, compounds the deceptive character of the whole.
State unemployment insurance benefits paid in the first nine months of 1949 showed nearly a 100 per cent rise over payments last year, Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, reported yesterday.
Organizational as well as strategic differences marked the recent Congressional hearings on inter-service problems.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- Robert Lord, vice president in charge of production for Santana Pictures, of which Humphrey Bogart is one of the owners and principal star, said today that dissolution of the corporation following the making of "In a Lonely Place" was being seriously considered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Department of Justice has suspended its investigation into alleged restraints in broadcasting and televising major league baseball games until it can be seen how new rules adopted by the leagues work out.

" Tokyo Joe," the Humphrey Bogart vehicle which opened at the Capitol on Wednesday, broke all opening-day attendance records for the last sixteen months with 13,493 admissions for the day, it vas announced by the management. .. . "The Red Shoes" today enters its fifty-third week at the Bijou.

A total of eighty-nine young riders was announced yesterday as having qualified for the two big events for juniors at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden that begins Tuesday. The events are the National Horse Show Equitation Championship, better known as the Good Hands, scheduled for Saturday afternoon, Nov. 5, and the A. S. P. C. A. Maclay Trophy, to be held during the following day's matinee.

The re-election of Charles E. Scribner, New York lawyer, as president and chairman of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America took place yesterday at the closing session of its annual meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Following is the exchange of letters in which President Truman agreed today to the transfer of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld from his job as Chief of Naval Operations:
BALTIMORE, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Coaltown and Capot hook up tomorrow in the thirteenth Pimlico Special with no holds barred and no love lost between two of the nation's biggest stables.

Net assets of $39,734,274 were held by the Adams Express Company on Sept. 30, according to the company's semi-annual report submitted to stockholders yesterday. On Sept. 30, last year the figure was $40,924,926.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- The Amtorg Trading Corporation of New York registered as an agent of the Soviet Government today, too late to escape prosecution for failing to act sooner.

Excavations for all types of public improvements from major traffic arteries to small "wear and tear" resurfacings have caused Manhattan's streets to be torn up now more than at any previous time in the city's history, a survey showed yesterday.

TOKYO, Oct. 27 -- Before the end of the year, a great new federation of trade unions, representing virtually three-quarters of labor's strength in Japan, is expected to emerge from negotiations now going on. It will be called the Joint Council of Trade Unions and will be conservative and anti-Communist.
The campaign against smuggling of narcotics and their illegal sale must continue through Federal and other law enforcement agencies, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said here yesterday.
Seven movers labored for nearly twelve hours yesterday to haul a six-ton sarcophagus from the loading platform of the Brooklyn Museum to the building's third floor.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 27 -- Harold Sanderson, Canoe Brook pro, scored in both ends of a New Jersey P.G.A. pro-amateur tournament today at the Montclair Golf Club.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 27 -- Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, declared tonight that his union did not intend to withdraw from the Congress of Industrial Organizations but that it stood four-square behind ten other left-wing unions on the question of its right to accept or reject CIO policy by referendum vote.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Jess Larson, director of the General Services Administration, urged today that Government procurement agencies cease to toss a coin to decide who should get a Government contract when two identical low bids were submitted.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dons tonight ended the Chicago Hornets' hopes of reaching an All-America Conference play-off berth by downing the Chicago entry, 24 -- 14, before 11,249 spectators in Soldiers Field.

The stock market's attempt yesterday to move into still higher ground in more than a year was stalled by profit-taking in the afternoon. It marked the first setback of the week, but losses were not of major proportions and the composite rate showed a decline of only 0.21 point.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 28 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll and Mrs. James J. Mason of Ridgewood won the final tournament of the women's New Jersey Golf Association's twenty-sixth season today when they scored a 40, 43 -- 83 in a Scotch foursome event at the Essex County Country Club.

In a speech urging re-election of Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore, Representative Emanuel Celler attacked last night both Abe Stark, Mr. Cashmore's Republican-Liberal-Fusion opponent, and Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for election to that post.
Retail sales improved slightly during the week but still remained below levels established during the corresponding period last year.

The taxpayers suit to deny to Benjamin J. Davis Jr., convicted Communist, a place on the ballot as candidate for City Council in the forthcoming election was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen on technical grounds.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 -- The trainer of the winner of the Pimlico Special gets a silver-framed photo of the finish. Unless the photographers were using wide-angle lenses today, Greentree Stable's John Gaver is going to get a one-horse photo.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 -- Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, defended today his right as a citizen and a war veteran to speak out in favor of the proposed constitutional amendment giving veterans point percentage preference instead of absolute preference in civil service examinations.

I note with distress that the "improved" progressive traffic light system along the Grand Concourse retains the old thirty-second interval for pedestrians, a period which THE NEW YORK TIMES today correctly reports as forcing people to "scurry across."

HAMPTON, Va., Oct, 28 -- This country, in recent years, has made such "tremendous strides" toward a nonsegregated society that Negro youth should transfer their emphasis in racial matters from anti-segregation activities to the development of techniques for assimilation in community life.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent in the week ended Oct. 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday. The index was 152.5 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.1 per cent above four weeks ago and 7.5 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

Assured of the full support of the American Federation of Labor, the Seafarers International Union, an affiliate, plans an intensified campaign to remove control over merchant seamen from the Coast Guard, according to the current issue of the Seafarers Log, official publication of the SIU.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Mrs. Eugenie Anderson, a Minnesota farm wife, took the oath of office as United States Ambassador to Denmark today -- the first American woman to hold this top diplomatic rank.
RENO, Nev., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The United States has too many good markets to be worrying about a depression, the Secretary of the Treasury, John W. Snyder, said today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Speedboat owners, drivers, and committee and racing commission moguls from coast to coast were here today for a three-day week-end of confabs with the high brass of the American Power Boat Association, all of which will culminate Sunday night in the annual meeting and election of the A. P. B. A.

A temporary order restraining the city from enforcing the recently enacted Sharkey rent law was dissolved yesterday and a motion for a temporary injunction to prevent the law's enforcement was denied by Judge Sylvester J. Ryan in the United States District Court.

Federal mediators, led by Cyrus S. Ching, halted mediation efforts with the United States Steel Corporation yesterday and announced plans to talk with officials of three other major producers whose plants are shut down by the national steel strike.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- After thirty-five holes of the final of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship had been played, there was still no champion tonight. When darkness closed in, with the finalists, Mike Turnesa of Knollwood and Al Brosch of Cherry Valley, all even, it was decided to call a halt at the Ardsley Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Truman today appointed six employes of the Department of Agriculture as members of the board of directors of the Commodity Credit Corporation, which has been nominally without a board since Congress adjourned.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The $25,000,000 rural telephone bill became law today at the White House. An element of the Administration's farm program, the law was hailed by President Truman, who said "no group of people needs telephone service as much as do our farmers."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 28 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, proposed today that an international refugee service to succeed the International Refugee Organization be created in 1951, to be carried on by a High Commissioner, aided by an independent staff.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 28 -- Leading American educators were warned here tonight that a new method must be found for financing institutions of higher education in this country.

Today is the date when history was made on the New York Stock Exchange; when 16,410,030 shares were traded, the largest volume ever recorded for the institution. In one hour's trading on that day -- the date, Oct. 29, fell on a Tuesday in 1929 -- approximately 5,000,000 shares were transferred.

Two of France's most famous dishes, cassoulet from the southern provinces and Alsatian chou-croute (sauerkraut) garni, now may be purchased here in tins. Packed for thirty years by Amieux Freres in Nantes, the products are just being exported again after having been off the market for several years.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 28 -- Robert W. Johnson, chairman of the board of Johnson Johnson, announced here today that his home overlooking the Raritan River has been offered as a gift to the religious order of Our Lady of the Cenacle, a cloistered order of nuns with a convent at 628 West 140th Street, New York.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- The football squads of Columbia and Cornell worked out easily on Schoellkopf Field today before the thirty-seventh renewal of their series at 2 P. M. on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Industrial production in the United States will drop to the lowest level in more than three and a half years this month as a result of the creeping paralysis imposed on industry by the steel and coal strikes, it was predicted today by the Federal Reserve Board.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Modern American methods of rearing children might well take a back seat to those of the Okinawans, a people of great emotional stability despite natural hazards and the tragedies caused by the last war.

Charging that the Democratic party of Mayor O'Dwyer has betrayed "the working people," Representative Vito Marcantonio asserted last night that the Mayor and President Truman "play the game of Wall Street."

AUBURN, N. Y., Oct. 28 (AP) -Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat-Liberal, of New York, promised today to make an effort to prevent withdrawal of the International Harvester Company's plant from Auburn. He spoke to 300 persons from the steps of Memorial City Hall in behalf of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman's candidacy for the United States Senate.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The steering committee of the European Marshall Plan Council, composed of eight foreign or finance ministers, discussed today a report indicating that the proposals so far made for freer trade in Europe were insufficient.
Nearly 500 biologists conferred at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday on how to restart the growth of a disease germ that has been inhibited by one of the modern antiseptic drugs.
DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production in the United States this week will total 134,208 cars and trucks, Ward's automotive reports estimated today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Bill Corum, 54-year-old New York sports writer, fell heir today to Col. Matt Winn's Kentucky Derby shoes.

In a prediction based on a personal trip and reports from county chairmen, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, said yesterday that Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, would be fortunate if in the ballot count he came to New York City with a plurality of 4,000,000.

Personality differences, administrative frictions and political influences undoubtedly have affected the operation of the Department of Defense, as the recent Congressional hearings on inter-service differences showed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The battle between rival color television systems will extend far into February, the Federal Communications Commission announced today.

The Greater New York Safety Council, which, over the years, has accomplished so much through the tireless effort of volunteer workers and on a shamefully meager budget, has been named winner of the National Safety Council's annual award for outstanding accomplishment during 1948, in competition with 250 other councils and chapters throughout the nation.

Despite the disturbing influence of strikes, furniture store sales rose in October to within 2 per cent of the dollar volume attained in 1948, Roscoe R. Rau, executive vice president of the National Retail Furniture Association, revealed yesterday in Chicago.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 -- Governor Dewey today ordered a state-wide survey of the effects of the steel and coal strikes in the reported belief that conditions were much worse than President Truman thinks they are.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 28 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, president of the United Nations General Assembly, said today that despite the deadlock on international atomic control "we must reach agreement in order to survive.

Joan Hammond, the Australian soprano who made her debut with the New York City Opera Company as Madama Butterfly this season, last night showed what good training and experience can mean when she sang the title role in "Tosca."

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Premier Georges Bidault and his Cabinet took over the reins in France today from the Ministers of Henri Queuille, who for the past three weeks during the Government crisis had been transacting routine business without the power to make important decisions.
DETROIT, Oct. 28 -- Governor G. Mennen Williams took official notice today of the squabble over the Kid Gavilan-Lester Felton fight decision.

Advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities during September totaled 197,857,675 lines, a gain of 0.3 per cent over the comparable month last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Total lineage for the first nine months of 1949 was 1,671,258,898, a gain of 2.6 per cent over the like period of 1948.

The sixty-third anniversary of that blustery day in 1886 when President Grover Cleveland and other American and French notables dedicated the Statue of Liberty was observed yesterday. A crowd of about 500 attended -- all that could be accommodated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Truman signed without ceremony today the appropriations bill carrying $1,314,010,000 to help arm this country's European associates in the North Atlantic Treaty and other non-Communist lands.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 27 -- Left-wing delegates to the convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations next week will fight for a CIO demand for recognition of the Communist regime in China as the de facto government and for resumption of trade relations with China.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 28 -- The outlook for the commercial air industry is improving, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association said today at the National Transportation Forum here. The meeting was the first of its kind in the United States.
Harris D. Leland has been named special sales representative of the Frankfort Distillers Corporation to the hotel industry. He joined the company in 1946 as assistant export manager.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Federal attorneys in the fraud trial of Preston Tucker an seven Tucker Corporation associates were balked for the third time today in an attempt to introduce testimony on the reported collapse of the first Tucker car at its unveiling.

The new neighborhood youth center at 115 East 106th Street, rented to the city by the Good Neighborhood Federation, will provide space for many additional city, state and Federal welfare services, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday.

Once again France has snatched a Government from the brink of dissolution. The alternative to M. Bidault would have been new elections, accompanied by grave instability and weaknesses at a time when the voice of France was badly needed in European councils.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for election, asserted here tonight that his defeat at the polls on Nov. 8 would constitute American approval of "what the Russians want" and threaten American victory in the cold war.

Lamps that occupy a minimum amount of space yet shed sufficient light for comfortable working are about the only satisfactory solution for the problem of the home-maker who has a small desk that is decorative but not spacious.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled unanimously today that the International Typographical Union, AFL, had violated the closed-shop ban of the Taft-Hartley Law. It said the union's "bargaining strategy" was "a deliberate frustration of the bargaining process."

Advance requests for steamship accommodations to Italy during Holy Year have become so heavy that the Home Lines may transfer two liners from other routes to the New York-Mediterranean run, it was reported yesterday by Giuseppe Cosulich, European general agent of the company.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 28 (AP) -- A 20-year-old murderer and two others of the eight heavily armed convicts who escaped prison on Wednesday were taken into custody without a struggle late today.

The presence of lethal gases in the smoke from industrial plants was cited yesterday by F. M. Van Deventer, consulting engineer for the Walworth Company of this city, as a factor that should be measured and checked to assure the success of the smoke abatement program of any community.

ROME, Oct. 28 -- The spiritual success of Holy Year is now certain as bookings for rooms in Rome and its environs have already been received from more than a million pilgrims, Msgr. Sergio Pinedoli, secretary of the Vatican's Central Committee for Holy Year, said today.

A "run down" of a new contract, incorporating revisions agreed upon to date, was handed yesterday by representatives of Atlantic and Gulf ship operators to the negotiators of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Ezra Van Horn, employer trustee of the United Mine Workers Welfare Fund, told the Federal District Court today that it was true, as charged by a miner, that the fund had been dissipated, but that John L. Lewis and Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, were solely responsible.
Halloween came prematurely to the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park yesterday afternoon, and some 150 youthful members of the Police Athletic League made merry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The cost of living rose at an accelerated pace between mid-August and mid-September, the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor, reported today.

The French liner Ile de France docked at Pier 88, North River, at 5 P. M. yesterday with 1,223 passengers, among them Maurice Martenot, inventor of the "Martenot," a new musical instrument, which he said his sister would play with the Boston Symphony Orchestra on Nov. 4 and Nov. 5 and with the New York Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall Nov. 17 and Nov. 18.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Exempt status put more than $8,000,000,000 of business receipts beyond the reach of tax collectors in 1946, the Internal Revenue Bureau reported today.

One of the perversities of women -- oh, well, it is a pleasant morning, so let it be said it is the only perversity -- is that they insist on keeping the ash trays clean. Phooey, this is, and sheer nonsense. Ash trays are no better than wastebaskets, fulfilling the same purpose to a lesser degree, and yet they are set apart.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Truman signed the classified civil service pay bill today. As a result, about 900,000 Federal employes will get a pay rise averaging $140 yearly.
DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Kaiser- Frazer Corp, expects to have its new low-priced automobile in production early next spring.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "The Doctor and the Girl," a romantic drama, produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, with Glenn Ford, Charles Coburn, Gloria de Haven and Janet Leigh, opens at the Mayfair. Curtis Bernhardt directed and Pandro S. Berman produced from a script by Theodore Reeves and a book by Maxence van der Meersch. . . .

The "Christmas rush" hiring season for behind-the-counter sales help has started in the city leading department stores, from the Fifth Avenue main stem through Herald Square and across the bridges to Brooklyn.

Interest was divided yesterday in a showing of fashions for the woman over 40, presented by B. Altman and Company at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, between American designs created by Fred Greenberg and copies of Paris designs, created for this same house by Molyneux, Balmain, Piquet and Paquin.

American clothing production methods will be surveyed for the next six weeks by the British clothing team of the Anglo-American Productivity Council. The team of sixteen English manufacturers was greeted yesterday morning by officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration at 2 Park Avenue.

Trustees of the New York, Ontario Western Railway, which has been in bankruptcy since 1937, announced yesterday that they would offer the line for sale in the near future. The 544-mile railroad's main line runs from Oswego on Lake Ontario to Cornwall, N. Y., then connects with the West Shore Railroad to Weehawken, N. J.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 28 -- The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company reported today a net profit of $7,514,626 for the third quarter of this year before deduction of a special appropriation of $1,000,000 for increased construction and replacement cost and continuance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, today was ordered to stand trial next month on fraud charges after a Federal Court was advised the long-ailing lawmaker now was well enough to handle "two to three highballs before dinner and three to four cigars daily."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -Warner Brothers today granted a release from her term contract to Alexis Smith, who has been under threat of suspension for refusing a role. At the same time it notified Lauren Bacall, who was taken off the payroll ten days ago for similar disobedience and who also seeks to be a free agent, that it will not let her go.

What undoubtedly constitutes the season's busiest week-end gets under way this evening with the presentation of "Montserrat," Lillian Hellman's adaptation from the French of Emmanuel Robles, at the Fulton Theatre. Tomorrow evening "Lost in the Stars," the new Maxwell Anderson-Kurt Weill musical play, based on Alan Paton's novel, "Cry, the Beloved Country," opens at the Music Box.

Mrs. Basil B. Elmer heads the committee in charge of the sale of tickets for the performance of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" on the night of Dec. 15 at the Ziegfeld Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Homemaker Service of the Children's Aid Society.

The board of directors of Colilectors of American Art, Inc., has arranged a members' open house reception at the gallery (Contemjporary Arts), 106 East Fifty-seventh Street, tomorrow afternoon from 5 to 7 P. M. Most of the paintings, prints and pieces of [sculpture acquired for the Decemi ber distribution to members will be shown.
Public school requirements that all young children learn to read at the same age were assailed yesterday by Dr. Willard E. Goslin, Superintendent of Schools in Pasadena, Calif.
