GENEVA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Polish Government's order to the International Committee of the Red Cross to close its offices in Warsaw was not directed specifically against the Red Cross, but was a general measure against all international organizations, a spokesman for the Red Cross said today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- The Journal of Soviet-pedagogy charged today that the doctrine of original sin lay at the core of the latest "progressive" educational theory in the Unied States and that its purpose was to train "dull but self-satisfied 100 per cent Americans ready on orders of American fascists to conquer the world and subject it to the American way of life."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, by recalling a sometimes forgotten document, the March, 1948, "Key West agreement," has assured the three armed services that there will be no change in their primary roles and functions.
In their nip-and-tuck race with the Rural Electrification Administration to electrify the farms of the nation, the private utilities have created a bonanza for manufacturers of electrical equipment.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Few deaths in recent years have been felt so deeply in France as that of Marcel Cerdan, who was seeking to regain the world middleweight boxing championship when a plane crash tragically ended his life.

The Budd Company, fabricator of railroad passenger cars, disclosed yesterday that new records were established in sales and net earnings for the third consecutive quarter of the current year. The corresponding figures for the nine months of the present year, also were new high records, Edward G. Budd Jr., president, said.

Saying that repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act is the paramount issue between Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican, and Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, last night urged the election of Mr. Lehman.

Feridun Cemal Erkin, Turkish Ambassador to the United States, said last night that his country presented "the most solid political stability in the whole Middle East" and that it had dedicated itself to the democratic way of life.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Millionaire George W. Armstrong announced tonight he had withdrawn his offer of a $50,000,000 endowment to Jefferson Military College.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- An Interior Department survey group said today that natives in the Aleutian Islands and some other parts of Alaska are drinking themselves to death.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 -- In a bruising, slashing contest that was marked by several flare-ups, Villanova's eleven rode to a 28-14 triumph over Boston College before 25,789 persons at Braves Field tonight. It marked the first time a Wildcat squad was able to down the Eagles in four years.

The pilot of the Air France plane which yesterday carried forty-eight persons to their deaths on a peak in the Azores is said to have had 6,700 flying hours to his credit. His co-pilot, navigator, flight engineer and the rest of his crew had been selected by rigorous tests.

PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 28 -- A man known as Vincent Avolino, about 40 years old, of Woodhaven, Queens, was killed by the police and two alleged accomplices were held for questioning at 6 o'clock this evening.

The Federal Government should undertake immediately a program of defense against the spread of airborne disease germs in biological warfare, Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham, director of the division of communicable diseases of the State Health Department, declared yesterday.
The Brooklyn Union Gas Company has on hand a supply of coal sufficient to produce gas for the next thirty days, officials of the company testified yesterday at the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Over the protest of the Port of New York Authority, the Interstate Commerce Commission today approved proposals of the Bull Steamship Line to increase joint ocean-rail class rates between the Eastern Seaboard and the Southwest.

The first for this season of the New York Assemblies took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller, who organized the series of dances thirteen years ago. Many dinner parties were given in conjunction with the fete.
American responsibility for the outcome of the cold war was stressed last night by Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University.

WASHINGTON, Oct 28 -- Congressional cutting of Presidential budget estimates has made it impossible for the Civil Aeronautics Board to make a study of airmail pay and justifications of subsidies, Congress was told today by Joseph J. O'Connell Jr., chairman of the CAB.

A swarthy, chunky bundle of energy, Marcel Cerdan, who was killed in the plane crash in the Azores yesterday, was as amiable out of the ring as he was savage within its confines. The former middleweight champion of the world was by far the most popular post-war sports figure in France, and his magnetism and geniality were such as to enable him also to win the warm regard of the American boxing populace.

The world's rarest postage stamp, the only surviving copy of British Guiana's one-cent, black-on-magenta of 1856, came out of hiding briefly last night under armed police escort and was televised for the first time. It was shown over Station WPIX here in connection with a stamp collector's jamboree at the McAlpin Hotel.

In accepting a token sum of the funds the Boy Scouts of New York and New Jersey are collecting for the rehabilitation of scouting in the Philippines, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the United Nations Assembly, said last night that the youth of the democracies must redeem the failure of the present generation to achieve peace.
Scotland yesterday started a drive with the twin objectives of increasing exports to North America and encouraging American business men to locate factories in that country.

A vast majority of a representative sample of a hundred leading psychiatrists does not believe that the current cancer education campaign, carried on by the American Cancer Society, creates a fear and anxiety among the public that may cause more harm than good, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the society at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $56,660,000 of first refunding-mortgage sinking-fund bonds.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 28 -- Former Gov. Charles Edison tonight called upon a labor audience of about 7,500 persons in Journal Square, here, to defeat Elmer H. Wene, the Democratic candidate for Governor, as a means toward putting Frank Hague out of power permanently.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 -- The Rev. Leonard Feeney, center of a controversy over Catholic doctrine, announced tonight at his St. Benedict's Center in Cambridge that he had been dismissed from the Jesuit Order for "disobedience."
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 28 (AP) -Coleman A. (Brownie) Lollar today admitted for the first time that he was a former Ku Klux Klansman. But he contended he was not a flogger and never had been one.

Eleven Communist leaders convicted of criminal conspiracy two weeks ago petitioned the United States Circuit Court yesterday for freedom on bail pending appeal. Their counsel also served notice of a motion for an order of release, to be argued before that court next Tuesday morning.

A growing shortage of burlap stocks in the United States has compelled bag manufacturers to buy all types of cotton sheetings and osnaburgs well into 1950, it was pointed out yesterday. Sheetings for spot deliveries are very scarce with mills reporting that they are practically sold up for the first quarter of 1950 and are now quoting for April shipments.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Twelve New Jersey college students were announced today as recipients of fellowships under the Fulbright Act for graduate study in France during this academic year.

Samuel Levy and Associates yesterday resold 109-15 Duane Street, northeast corner of Trimble Place, to an investor in a deal negotiated by the Cruikshank Company in connection with the Charles F. Noyes Company, which represented the sellers.

A budget bank account is no bar to high fashion these days. A recent tour of the dress markets confirmed the fact that dresses with high styling are being created to tempt limited budgets. Now the influence of Paris is apparent in sleek hip-molding silhouettes that do not cost three figures.

Gen. Muir S. Fairchild, vice chief of staff of the United States Air Force, told 400 persons last night at the annual dinner of the Wings Club, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, that jet fighters have been greatly improved and that further improvements are on the way.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The National Council for the Prevention of War today called upon Secretary of State Dean Acheson to put in the custody of the new West German Government at Bonn all war-crimes prisoners now held in Germany.

Only a series of shattering upsets today drastically can alter the ranking of the nation's leading college football teams. The final October Saturday of the campaign finds few of the ten top powers matched against opponents who figure to give real battle.

Nationally advertised food products are the backbone of the food industry and yield the best results to retailers who stock them, William H. Albers, credited with being the creator of the super market type of food outlet and currently head of seventeen markets in Cincinnati, told members of the American Marketing Association yesterday in the Commodore Hotel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- The left-wing United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers Union, which faces expulsion from the Congress of Industrial Organizations at the CIO convention next week in Cleveland, has voted to merge with the left-wing United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union (CIO), the UFE International Board said today.

The twenty-seventh annual convention of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference early next month in Columbus, Ohio, will have as a chief aim the promoting of cooperation between urban and rural residents. Addresses will be heard and discussions held on family, educational and youth problems in rural life and the inter-relating of population groups.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Among the fifteen bids opened today for fees on the reconstruction of the White House the lowest was $100,000 plus cost and the highest was $950,000.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 28 -- Farther West Ohio is referred to not as Midwest but as "near East." Actually it is a border state which looks East rather than West and has an outlook heavily weighted by the great concentrations of industry that distinguish it from the prairie country.

Heavy long liquidation by local and producer interests lowered prices another 200 points on most coffee futures contracts on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trading was exceptionally active. Final levels for contract S were 125 to 200 points below Thursday's closing prices, and for contract D they were 169 to 200 points lower, with the nearby months the steadiest.

Sandy Saddler, Harlem's former world featherweight champion, recovered after a faulty start to knock out Paddy De Marco, willing gladiator from the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn, at Madison Square Garden last night. The bout, scheduled as the 10-round main event, ended after the ninth when De Marco's seconds asked Referee Ruby Goldstein to stop matters in order to spare their charge further punishment.

Caught up by the fever that has risen suddenly over two unexpectedly strong teams, a crowd of upward of 25,000 is expected to witness today's twenty-second encounter between Fordham and Georgetown at the Polo Grounds. Kick-off time has been set for 2 P. M.

A new method of "cutting" the needle grooves in phonograph records that reduces the noise of reproduction and simplifies the equipment for playing all types of disks -- both standard and long-playing -- was demonstrated yesterday at the Audio Enginering Society's first annual convention at the New Yorker Hotel.

Red Strader, coach of the All-America Yankees, has been saying all week that he had been stressing offense in preparatory practice for tomorrow's meeting at the Yankee Stadium with the Baltimore Colts.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 8 to 12 points net higher.

The need to increase British production of cotton goods requires an intensification of the weavers' efforts with "moore looms to a weaver" until more capital is available to hasten re-equipment of the Lancashire mills, according to a recent articel in The News Chronicle of London by Andrew Naesmith, general secretary of the Amalgamated Weavers' Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Members of Congress, mainly Republicans, sharply criticized today the removal of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld as Chief of Naval Operations. They asserted that the action was in reprisal for his testimony before the House Armed Services Committee, in which he expressed dissatisfaction with administration of the Department of Defense.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 27 -- Highlighting a series of projected moves to place increased authority in the hands of the West German state and maintain that Government's prestige in Berlin, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has gained approval from the Western High Commissioners to establish several governmental agencies in the former capital.

ROME, Oct. 28 -- Georgi Dimitrov, late Premier of Bulgaria, secretly encouraged Marshal Tito in the latter's stand against the Soviet Union, Josip Vidmar, head of the Yugoslav delegation to the Congress of the Partisans of Peace, stated today in a press conference.

" Actor's Studio," the dramatic series which won a Peabody award last season, will be seen on the CBS television network at 9 P. M. Tuesdays, starting next week. The program was picked up in a matter of hours after it had been dropped by the ABC chain, which this week announced a material reduction in its television schedule.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 28 -- The future status of the Surabaya naval base in East Java was agreed upon today by a delegation of leaders of the roundtable conference on Indonesia. Cheered by this and the drafting of a satisfactory formula on the withdrawal of Dutch troops from the islands, the steering committee announced tonight that the conference would end next Wednesday.

TOKYO, Oct. 28 -- Japan's Communist-led labor federation is collapsing. Public disapproval of violence and sabotage has cost the Communists their leadership and union after union has been abandoning both the National Congress of Industrial Organizations and the National Liaison Congress of Labor Unions, its parent body.

I note from the editorial entitled "Industry Pension Plans" in the Oct. 22 edition that THE NEW YORK TIMES, too, has jumped on the steel industry bandwagon and is loudly declaiming in favor of contributory as opposed to non-contributory pensions as recommended by the President's Steel Industry Board.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, left London for Paris today with the idea of encouraging a still greater liberalization of trade among the members of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation and of promoting a unified liberalization program under direction of that organization.

The Long Island waterfowl shooting is improving despite flashes of bluebird weather, and the recent rain and wind apparently moved some broadbill into Great South and Peconic Bays as well as a number of pintails and some mallards.

Two men, one armed, held up a Brooklyn pawnbroker's clerk yesterday as he was returning from a bank with $1,120 and drove the victim in his own car to the Ridgewood Reservoir at the Brooklyn-Queens line before escaping.

GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- Eight major coal producing countries of Europe, with the unofficial collaboration of the German coal industry, have agreed to adopt a uniform classification system for different kinds of coal, it was announced here today.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 28 -- Greece charged today that the attack of the Communist Information Bureau against Yugoslavia was sharpening the threat to peace in the Balkans.

Net income, including dividends from foreign subsidiaries, of the Chrysler Corporation for the first nine months of 1949 amounted to $97,651,453, equal to $11.22 a common share, K. T. Keller, president, reported yesterday. In the similar period of last year net earnings were $59,887,601, or $6.88 a share.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 28 -- Bud Geoghegan, home club pro, and Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Baltusrol moved toward their third straight New Jersey Professional Golfers Association pro-lady championship for the Frank Cloran Trophy today at Crestmont.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 -- Notre Dame plays Navy here tomorrow in the first of two Eastern appearances for the nation's ranking college football team, and though it appears to be much too strong for the midshipmen, all of the 62,413 tickets in the Babe Ruth Stadium have been disposed of.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The fall of British Government stocks showed signs of flattening out on the stock exchange here today. Closing prices were still mostly below over-night quotations, but the maximum further loss was 1/4 point and the average was nearer 1/8.

The Australian Government has decided to cont;inue to .app0..int: clergymen- as special' dvisers; to the-Australian delegation 'to the United Nations General ssembly.{: The current adviser is the Ve Rev. Rbhert;' .WHson Vfacaufay, former mderator-general of the' Presbyterikn Church of ustraliaj

The vacant blockfront at Avenue N and Flatlands Avenue, between East Thirty-fourth and East Thirty-fifth Streets, in Brooklyn has been sold by Realty Associates, Inc., to Beachport Homes, Inc. Slomka Brothers were the brokers.
A hospital chaplain is no longer regarded as institutional "window dressing" but rather as the newest member of a team composed of doctor, nurse, social worker and minister.

A close balance exists between cattle hide supplies and requirements and this is likely to continue for some months to come, John H. Patterson, economist of the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, declared yesterday in his fourth quarterly survey on raw materials and markets.

An American edition of the Indian classic, "The Life Divine," by Sri Aurobindo has been scheduled for publication on Nov. 14 by the Greystone Press. The 1,000-page opus discusses Eastern and Western thought, the position of the world today in terms of a crisis in mankind's evolution and the idea of unity of all life.
State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein started actions yesterday in Supreme Court against thirty persons on charges of illegal registration for the November election.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 28 -- Dr. J. K. Dunlop, occupation commissioner for the port city of Hamburg, issued a statement today concerning the projected dismantlement of a shipyard in that city that placed in bold relief the firm intention of British officialdom here to carry out the dismantling program.

Asserting that the basic issue in the campaign was a fight between progressive democracy and reaction, Mayor O'Dwyer charged last night that the Republicans were pulling every string and straining every effort "to undermine progressive democracy and to accomplish the defeat of the Democratic forces in this city and state."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 28 -- Israel told the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission today that further indirect negotiations with Egypt, Syria, Jordan and Lebanon "can be of no further value and can even make the situation more difficult."

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) yesterday reported estimated consolidated earnings for the nine months ended Sept. 30 at $195,000,000, equal to $6.46 a share. This compares with estimated consolidated earnings of $290,000,000, or $10.25 a share, for the corresponding period last year.
Following are biographical details on some of the Americans killed yesterday in the plane crash in the Azores:

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 28 -- A Soviet proposal calling for the independence of Eritrea in five years was rejected today by a subcommittee of the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

Net income of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company for the nine months ended Sept. 30 amounted to $2,669,956, equal to $3.58 a share, it was announced yesterday. This is in contrast to $295,045, or 40 cents a share in the comparable 1948 period.
Newbold Morris portrayed Mayor O'Dwyer last night as a frightened man trying to conceal underworld affiliations by seeking shelter with President Truman.

Despite a stumbling start, which brought him out of the gate last, Louis Tufano's Uncle Edgar sped to victory in the feature $5,000 Charentus purse at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday. Seventh in the field of seven at the half-way mark in this mile-and-a-sixteenth contest, the 3-year-old brown colt triumphed in the creditable time of 1:45, a length in front of R. M. Smith's Sagittarius.

Because there "never was a time when the problems before our country were so complex and so great," Americans "should be informed and need to think, and think awfully hard," former President Herbert Hoover said yesterday.

PONTA DELGADA, Sao Miguel, The Azores, Oct. 28 -- An Air France Constellation bound from Paris to New York crashed in flames against an Azores mountain ninety miles north of its normal course early today.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, declared here tonight that he was not the "liar" his Republican opponent, John Foster Dulles, said he was because his character witnesses were the voters who knew his record and had repeatedly elected him as Governor of New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- An industry-wide program for improvement of opportunities for workers in manufacturing industries was advocated here today before more than 1,000 executives attending the golden anniversary convention of the National Metal Trades Association at the Palmer House.

Plans of thirty students to foment a strike among the 5,200 students of James Madison High School, Quentin Road and Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, were balked yesterday by an alert principal backed by the school's football team.

Two years ago today there was published the report of the President's Committee on Civil Rights, a landmark in the never-ending struggle to secure for all the people of the United States the blessings of freedom, liberty and equality now enjoyed by the great majority.

HOUSTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Continuous negotiations were planned today to forestall the threatened walkout early Tuesday of 10,000 American Federation of Labor longshoremen in Texas ports and in Lake Charles, La.

More than a quarter of the nation's farm croplands and pastures has been ruined or severely impoverished because of the lack of conservation, Fairfield Osborn, president of the New York Zoological Society and the Conservation Foundation, declared yesterday.

An investigation into the distribution at a recent political meeting of allegedly anti-Semitic leaflets signed by "The All-American Committee for the Election of Dulles and O'Dwyer" was started yesterday by Nathaniel L. Goldstein, State Attorney General.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Grain markets staged a strong rally today on the Board of Trade here after an early break headed by soybeans. The latter were off over 2 cents a bushel at one time, but finished 1/2 cent higher to 1 1/2 cents lower than yesterday, the latter on the July position, which sold at a new seasonal low.

Mayor O'Dwyer continued yesterday to link his re-election campaign with an appeal to the voters to send former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman to the United States Senate, where his services would benefit the city in its relations with the Federal Government.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29 -- Dartmouth clicked off four rapid-fire touchdowns in the second half today to make a shambles of what had started out to be a close and stirring contest with Yale.

GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- The conference on the rights of radio and screen performers to conpensation for recorded and broadcast performances of their work ended here today without any agreement reached among workers and employers' representatives.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- We are still doing business with the Russians, as the indictment of Amtorg, their sales and purchasing agent, reminded us this week.

EDWARD KIMBROUGH explores a complex field of human relationships in this novel set in Mississippi. Kinsman Todd, smiling, compassionate, and inwardly sure that pain is the price of love, has everything that bitter, fearful Jay Fleming has not. For this Jay hates Kinsman.

CAIRO, Oct. 29 -- Hussein Sirry Pasha, Egyptian Premier, in a statement published here, indicated today that Egypt was not prepared to negotiate directly with Israel if Tel Aviv should seek direct negotiations with the Arab states in place of continuing to deal indirectly through the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission.

The 100,000th displaced person to be admitted to the United States was among the 1,352 refugees who arrived yesterday morning aboard the Army Transport General Howze, which docked at Pier 60 at West Twentieth Street.

THERE are two dozen or more "safety plays" in bridge, each being the preferred technique of playing some suit-holding in declarer's and dummy's hands. The opportunity to use one of these plays seldom arises, and when it does there are usually subsidiary problems that may cause the play to be rejected.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 29 -- The coal and steel strikes have had little effect as yet on business in the Ninth Federal Reserve District, the bank in Minneapolis pointed out in its monthly survey last week. Department store sales, particularly in Minnesota, continue to run close to record 1948 levels.

ALL the elements of a beautiful and moving parable about racial hate and harmony are in the hands of the company that presents "Lost in the Stars" at the Music Box Theatre tonight. The novel from which this play is taken -- "Cry, the Beloved Country" by Alan Paton -- is widely cherished as a portrayal of the peace that replaces racial bitterness in South Africa when whites and blacks recognize their common humanity.

MY thanks to Mr. Cohen (Book Review, Oct. 2) for his correction; and my blushes to you for misderiving "serendipity"; I knew, I knew, that word came from Walpole, though not, I assure you, from where in Walpole.

PROFESSOR WIENER has presented a unique thesis. He sees Darwinian evolution as the stimulus to the various pragmatisms which were begun by the members of the Metaphysical Club of the Eighteen Seventies, a distinguished list which included among others James, Holmes, Peirce, Wright and Abbot.

Aided by cooler weather, which stimulated seasonal apparel sales, retail trade here gave a better account of itself last week. Volume, however, failed to equal last year, with the drop for department stores put at about 6 per cent The decline for preceding weeks had ranged around 15 per cent.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 29 -- Artillery, tanks, planes, trucks and jeeps, supplied under the Truman aid program, appeared prominently in today's parade celebrating the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Turkish Republic. Fifty thousand spectators, including President Ismet Inonu, saw Turkish soldiers handle the United States material smoothly as the armor followed on the heels of the infantry and cavalry.

PRESENTED as a kind of sequel to Mr. McSorley's successful first novel, "Our Own Kind," this episodic, disjointed narrative picks up the career of Willie McDermott at the age of 18, when Willie is working as a combination copy-boy and obit editor on The Providence (R. L) Herald.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 29 -- Tennessee took most of the steam out of famed Charlie (Choo Choo) Justice today, came up with a triple-threat star in Hal Littleford, and defeated North Carolina, 35 to 6, in one of the major upsets of the 1949 football season.
TO THE EDITOR: In Garrett Underhill's "Report on the Red Army" we read, "They still firmly adhere to the traditional Russian belief in victory by counter-offensive, not by the first blow."
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 29 -- The United States and the Soviet Union accused one another today of bearing responsibility for the failure to reach a settlement in the Balkan controversy.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 29 29 (UP) -- The first visit by a United States official to Mr. Meryn since his arrest was permitted shortly after James K. Penfield, United States Charge d'Affaires had called at the Foreign Ministry with a formal note greeting President Klement Gottwald on the thirty-first anniversary of Czechoslovak independence.

Toscanini gave the first of his series of concerts this season with the NBC Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Radio City. With admirable judgment he selected for his audience two of the interpretations for which he has long been famous.

MAX PLANCK advanced in 1900 the hypothesis that radiant energy can be emitted only in definite portions. This theory has become known under the name "quantum theory" and has turned out to be, with Albert Einstein's theory of relativity, the basis of twentieth century physics, which led to the liberation of atomic energy.

DOWN in Greenwich Village this week sculpture is very much in the foreground. At the Clay Club the generous display of Leo Amino's new work is characterized by a restless inventiveness, while, at the New School, the young Colombian sculptor Miguel Sopo is showing realistic wood and stone figures that add a new and warm note of humanity to immemorial themes.

BEFORE man can agree on that great world community where nations have no borders and people no prejudices -- an international peace is no longer a miracle -- there must be some considerable and courageous revisions in his religious thinking.

THIS is an amiable British mystery, with the sleuthing done by two ingratiating amateurs, Jane Hamish, a young ex ecutive in a London solicitor's office, and her fiance, Dagobert Brown, an irrepressible chap who may remind you, in temperament if not in intellect, a little of Lord Peter Wimsey as a younger man.

BOOKMEN being rather gloomy folk, the optimism prevailing along publisher's row these days is creating quite a stir. More luncheons at "Twenty One," it seems, and a kind of Cheshire catty attitude toward competitors -- always a sign that business is good.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion said last night that Israel's deficit was mounting at the rate of 7,000,000 ($19,600,000) a month and that the country was depending on foreign investments.

A STRANGE and sometimes beautiful book which surely can take a place on the front bookshelf of literature about Italy of the late Forties, this story moves in the twilight of fantasy without being fantastic. On the outside -- modern people wandering through the public squares and private villas of a Florence shadowed by its medievalism -- the narrative is fairly simple.

SHIRLEY GRAHAM, noted biographer of Frederick Douglass, George Washington Carver, and others, now brings to her readers the story of Benjamin Banneker, one of the men who made significant contributions to the early history of the American Republic.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 29 -- Reports calling for the elimination of evils in the present system of accrediting colleges and universities and for the creation of a World Universities Association were presented to educators at a conference concluded today on the University of Wisconsin campus.

In the presence of sixteen top-ranking Army officers a "realistic" permanent Organized Reserve Corps training center was opened yesterday at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens, for the New York-New Jersey Military District, with the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division undergoing week-end training.

With a moderate rise to follow during the latter part of next year, further readjustment will characterize the nation's business between now and the middle of 1950, according to an opinion survey by the F. W. Dodge Corporation, released yesterday.
THIS much is known, proven and incontrovertible about Joan of Arc, who is known also as the Maid of France:

Fordham's Rams, definitely on the upswing, overwhelmed Georgetown, 42 -- 0, yesterday at the Polo Grounds, amassing the highest score in the history of the series which started in 1890. There just was no stopping Ed Danowski's spirited charges, who recorded their fourth straight victory and remained among the nation's undefeated elevens.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The State Department learned by telegram from Mukden, Manchuria, today that Angus Ward, United States Consul General there, had been arrested by Chinese Communist authorities on charges of beating a former Chinese employe.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 29 -- A sudden last-minute hitch in the round-table conference on Indonesia developed today over the status of Dutch New Guinea, jeopardizing all the laborious work of the conference during the last two months.

THIS sprightly and suggestive book is more aptly described by its subtitle than by its title. It bears an implicit affinity to the mounting accumulation of studies in Shakespeare's imagery, and shows the same awareness of poetry - as - such that Professor Stauffer has made so explicit in other writings.
MOTORISTS heading south before winter sets in and who prefer their scenery uncluttered by billboards, filling stations or signs of human habitation should make a note of the Blue Ridge Parkway.

IT has been said of Trollope that you can walk about in his books with your hat on. The notion is that his world is more real than that of Dickens. He thought so himself, and so misled a great many innocents, who concluded that a writer's job was to copy life, and got nowhere. For to copy life would be to produce nonsense.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Played off its feet in the opening two periods, Southern Methodist gathered its forces for a mighty last-half 76-yard touchdown surge and then called flu-weakened Doak Walker off the bench to kick the point that meant a 7 to 6 victory over University of Texas today.

THE popular anthologies of stories selected by Phyllis Fenner can well make room for this attractive new volume. It provides a tale or two for most high days of the year: Christmas, Easter, Fourth of July, Halloween, Thanksgiving, and some of the lesser occasions.

Official encouragement of greater imports into the United-States should not be interpreted by foreign countries as "condoning their unfair, restrictive and discriminatory trade policies," the Tanners' Council of America declared yesterday.
Arthur H. Abel and Leander I. Shelley, who were recently elected president and first vice president, respectively, of the American Association of Port Authorities, are veteran port officials.

ST. LOUIS -- An over-all plan for photographic education on a national scale, which may prove to be one of the most important and constructive contributions ever made to American photography, was introduced here at the recent annual convention of the Photographic Society of America.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Communist-ied Czechoslovakia today freed or halted legal proceedings against 127 Roman Catholic priests who had opposed the Government's new church control law.

IF a generalization about drama on television has been warranted this season, it undoubtedly would deal with the limited area in which most plays have been staged. The action of the production might begin here or there but sooner or later the viewer would find himself back in the same old closet as the cast put the final touches to the crisis.

CONVINCED that the consistently poor and sensational publicity involving Hollywood star personalities is beginning to harm the prestige of the whole industry, this production community is seeking ways and means to combat the unfavorable and often distorted impressions that have been created in the public mind.

IN this thoroughly delightful book Mr. Whicher has collected and translated some seventy-five of the so-called Carmina Burana -- the secular song, chiefly anonymous, of those disreputable, frequently Rabelaisian, wandering students of the twelfth century who dedicated themselves, as members of an outrageous parody of an Order, to the cult of one Golias.

LONDON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- The International Committee for the Study of European Questions said today it had evidence that the Soviet Union was trying to produce "atomic clouds" for use against enemy troops and demanded that the democracies form an Atlantic union against communism.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A poor start cost Western Reserve a 28-14 football defeat at the hands of Brown University at League Park today, before 6,000 fans.

The charge that this country is neglecting the education of its teachers was made last week before a gathering of distinguished educators. Not enough money is being spent on preparing young men and women to be competent or well-rounded teachers, a number of speakers insisted.

FOR John Chapman, now editing the Burns Mantle Best Plays series, the making of a list this past season has been an easy assignment. Although there were fewer productions during the 1948-49 campaign than the previous year, it was, he believes, the best of recent crops, qualitatively speaking.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 -- With another demonstration of the explosive speed that wrecked Tulane, Notre Dame today inflicted the most humiliating defeat upon Navy in the 23-year history of their football rivalry, winning by 40 -- 0 before a full house of 62,413 in Babe Ruth Stadium.
A two-day book sale and a two-day sale of French and English furniture and decorations will be held this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 110 East Fifty-eighth Street.

CONRAD NICHOLSON HILTON, who bought the $36,000,000 Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York a few weeks ago, collects such items pretty much as other men collect coins or stamps. It is his business and his hobby, and has paid off rather well. The holdings of the Hilton Hotel Corporation today run to around $100,000,000 and have what the trade calls a "going value" of, roughly, $140,000,000.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- In Cairo this week Mideast statesmen were inspecting the rickety edifice of the Arab League to see whether it was worth rebuilding or should be condemned.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Government mediators apparently are not even trying to find a settle ment of the coal dispute, believing that the industrial crisis will come first in steel. Beside, steel companies account for a substantial influence in coal negotiations and there is no pressure on them to get their coal mines back into production as long as their steel mills are idle.
A WALL garden is simple to construct and will fit in even the smallest backyard. Here, the rock garden plants that intrigue so many people will grow and look at home.

It is with a feeling of foreboding that the nation must view the dark horizons with which we are faced. If we are to believe what we read in our major newspapers, we see lying ahead a growing disruption of the Government, to such an extent that its very leaders are losing faith in the objectives for which we are striving, mainly prosperity and the welfare of the country and the world.

HONOLULU, Oct. 29 -- The United States' dummy enemy, the mythical dictatorship of "Aggressor,'' has been defeated in battle again but it is still fighting and still is in hypothetical possession of key sections of North America from Alaska to the Caribbean.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Truman approved the military supply bill, carrying $15,585,863,498, today, but impounded a sum of $615,000,000 voted by Congress for additional airplanes for the Air Force. He directed Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, to place this amount in reserve, and there was every indication that the money would not be spent.

EXTENDING into the Aegean Sea like the prongs of Poseidon's trident, three peninsulas, Kassandra, Longos and Athos leave the mainland of northeastern Greece. The easternmost of these is Athos, named after the great terminal peak which rises like a giant pyramid out of the sea at its Aegean end.

NEW and interesting translations of Greek plays are coming out in America, England, and France. They began to appear in the Nineteen Thirties, and they are increasing in number and value. They mark a radical departure from the mode of translation which has held in these languages for over a century.

ROMANCES seeking a picturesque historical figure to whom a sprightly narrative might be tethered have long missed a good bet by overlooking William Claiborne of Kent Island, in the upper Chesapeake. Courtier, politician, statesman, trader and indomitable fighter, for more than forty years he waged a generally losing war with the Calverts.

Divertissements for adults and children will be features of the annual Country Fair in behalf of the missionary work of the Protestant Episcopal Church to be held on Wednesday and Thursday in the parish house of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East Ninetieth Street.

Metals can be given a bright, reflective surface by a new process developed by the Battelle Institute, Columbus, Ohio. The metal product is merely dipped into a chemical solution. Withdrawn a few minutes later, it is as bright as a mirror. One luggage manufacturer uses the process to eliminate five buffing operations and thus save $65 for every 1,000 locks and hasps.

I. Milton Colbeth has been elected president of the Baker Castor Oil Company, producer of castor oil and its chemical derivatives for industrial and medicinal use. He has been with the company thirty years.

Max Carr, American pianist who heads the piano department at Trinity University, San Antonio, Tex., gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He proved a young man of marked and individual gifts.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, called upon the United Nations last night to help reopen the road to the Hebrew University and Hadassah Hospital on Mount Scopus, in Jerusalem. The road has been blocked by the Jordan Arab Legion.

Joint establishment of purchasing standards for office equipment by office executives and purchasing agents and an immediate end to the current "feud" among them was urged by Albert Pleydell, head of the management consulting concern bearing his name and former New York City Commissioner of Purchasing.

At the annual meeting of the American Cancer Society last week a new microscope lens, developed at the request of the Navy, was demonstrated. The instrument makes it practicable for the first time to take sharp, highly magnified photographs of living tissues in invisible ultra-violet light.

A WINTER sunw anly illuminates these supposed memoirs of the aging founder of Athens. It is by no accident that Gide, in this recent work, has chosen to impersonate the elderly Theseus and to impute to him a mellow wisdom and a literary sophistication that he certainly does not posses in Plutarch, who represents him in youth as an unsubtle gang-buster and in age as a rapist.

GABRIEL PASCAL is going through the preliminary motions of obtaining screen rights to "Lead, Kindly Light," Vincent Sheean's recent best-selling book on Mahatma Gandhi, it was learned last week. The producer, noted for bringing such G. B. Shaw plays as "Pygmalion" and "Major Barbara" to the screen, confirmed that he "loved the book very much," but added that at the moment he was merely negotiating with the publisher and that "nothing is signed yet."

A PHOTOGRAPH of the promised 6-cent airmail stamp to recall the first flight by the Wright brothers was made available last week by Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson. This commemorative item will have its first-day sale on Dec. 17 at Kitty Hawk, N. C., where, on that date in 1903, Wilbur and Orville Wright flew a heavier-than-air plane of their own contrivance.

A ROMANTIC once described his fireplace as the most charming thing in the world. A skeptic called his an opiate. Thoreau conceded a pleasant fire to be a "most tolerable third party," and even the realistic lexicographer-admits that hearth and "home itself" are synonymous.

AT this time of the year, according to Richard W. Swett, emergency road service manager of the Automobile Club of New York, too many drivers are lulled into a false sense of security by the balmy days of Indian summer and fail to take notice of the signs of approaching cold weather.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Soviet diplomatic strategy must always be viewed in terms of its long-term revolutionary aspirations. This is true of its dual objectives -- whether those of Russia as a nation or those of communism as an ideology.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 29 -- A new sports building and field house for the 140-year-old Lawrenceville School will be built here by the Edward J. Lavino Foundation, Dr. Allan V. Heely, head master, announced today. The foundation was established in 1937 by Edwin M. Lavino in memory of his father.

AMONG books by the commanders of World War II, this one gets a high place -- for fairness, for straightforward admission of inefficiencies when there were inefficiencies, for old-fashioned general readability, for absence of the griping tone in which so many other memoirs are couched.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Senate approval early next year of the bitterly fought displaced persons' bill was forecast today by Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia.

The nation's high school students are ignorant of "the economic facts of life," the Joint Council on Economic Education said last week in a report that suggested a complete revision of the high school social-studies curriculum. Prof. G. Derwood Baker of New York University, director of the council, commented in the report that economic education had too long been considered the "stepchild" of the curriculum.

Sixteen children, ranging in ages from 7 weeks to 9 years, were treated for illuminating gas poisoning yesterday morning because of a defective heating unit at the Marine Park Houses, a city project in the Gerritsen Beach section of Brooklyn. All the victims remained at home after treatment.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 29 -- An undefeated Union team extended its two-year winning streak to 11 games this afternoon, beating Williams, 14 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The long-standing split between the State Department and the Economic Cooperation Administration over policy toward Argentina has been emphasized by a deal in which the purchase of 1,500 tons of meat in Mexico for Greece has been authorized despite the fact that Argentina was acknowledged to have made the lowest bid.

A LITTLE-PUBLICIZED "ether war," which in some cases has resulted in appreciable interference with reception of broadcast stations in this country, gained public attention last week when Southern broadcasters formally accused Cuban and Mexican stations of abandoning their regular wave lengths and jumping on to choice channels assigned to the United States.

Modern intelligence tests are biased against children of the lower social and economic groups in our society, Dr. Ernest A. Haggard, Professor of Psychology at the University of Chicago, declared yesterday.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao -The tourist business is booming in this cosmopolitan island, where an atmosphere reminiscent of the neat orderliness of the Netherlands prevails in a strangely exotic setting. One of the reasons for Curacao's growing popularity is the attractive bargains it offers to globe-trotting shoppers.

THE Wagnerian property, including the Festspielhaus in Bayreuth, was returned to the family early this year and now the composer's two grandsons, Wieland, 32, and Wolfgang, 30, are working to get the famous Bayreuth Wagner Festival reestablished.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad -- People from northern climes who think of West Indies islands as lazy, easy-going places, will be surprised to see them brisk activity and the bustle that is now Trinidad. The island is experiencing a tourist trade boom this year that can scarcely miss breaking all previous records.

To the Screen Editor: THE article in the Sunday TIMES for Oct. 9 [on the filming of "Roseanna McCoy"] entitled "'Kentucky' in California," by George Jenkins, was a feeble alibi at best, but hope that the other "facts" are closer to the mark than his calculation on mileage from Williamson or Logan, W. Va., to a metropolitan center.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Washington political experts, or a good many of them at least, are prepared to accept a switch in the threadbare old saw about Maine infallibility and to make it read: "As New York goes, so goes the nation."

DESPITE the limitations imposed by the medium, these lectures delivered over the BBC are a distinguished contribution to social philosophy. COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 29 (AP) -Missouri came from behind with two touchdowns in the last quarter for a 21-20 Big Seven Conference victory over Nebraska today.

There has been a sharp increase in toy imports into the Philippines, the majority of which come from Japan, according to a report on Philippine foreign trade, prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by C. E. Mauchenheim, special representative of Robot Statistics, 24 Stone Street, New York. "Peddlers," the report says, "may now be seen at every street corner in Manila offering all varieties of Japanese toys.'

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 29 -- With political killings rising to hundreds, according to generally unconfirmed reports in both Liberal and Conservative newspapers, Laughlin Currie, head of the mission of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development that has just completed an economic survey here, warned that "political stability within the law" was a requisite for foreign loans.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 29 (AP) -Bobby Strange booted Sky Miracle, a 6-1 shot, to victory today in the $25,000 added Trenton Handicap at Garden State Park. Favored Vulcan's Forge ran a distant sixth in the field of thirteen.

BISMARCK, N. D., Oct. 29 -- The complicated problem of the distribution of electric power to come from giant dams in the Missouri River Valley appeared today to be headed for Congress and clarification of public power policy that could affect the whole country.

ATLANTA, Oct. 28 -- Negro demands for educational facilities equal to those of white children stirred heated discussions this week following accusations by Gov. Herman Talmadge of Georgia that Northern agitators were attempting "to move Negro children into the nearest, most convenient white schools."

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Premier Georges Bidault tonight officially completed his new Cabinet, adding nine Secretaries of State and six under-secretaries to the list of seventeen Ministers announced on Friday morning. The new Cabinet members met with the Premier in his offices at the Hotel Matignon this evening, when the duties of each Secretary were defined.

Fearful of falling farm prices, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, called yesterday for legislation "which the farmers and farm groups of New York are convinced is fair and in their just interests."

The history of Negro labor in the United States in the last two decades was traced yesterday by Dr. Robert C. Weaver, visiting professor at New York University and the author of several books on Negro life.

Cooler weather last week in many parts of the country spurred the demand for coats and suits, and helped to brighten the season's prospects for many retailers, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

It is true that the findings of some independent researchers have been ignored or attacked, and that valuable medical developments have been adopted too slowly or not at all.
HONOLULU -- Hawaii is offering her Polynesian charms as a travel attraction once again this winter after surviving a five-month waterfront strike with no apparent damage to those charms.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Oct. 29 -- By means of the new radar station established here, weather observers will be able to "see" storms 200 miles away, follow their movements, and thus make accurate forecasts, it was announced yesterday.

In Steel and Coal Strikes Two great strikes in critical areas of American industrial life, last week tightened their grip upon the national economy. CLEVELAND, Oct. 29 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, rejected today all attempts by Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, to formulate a possible compromise on important issues due for discussion when the convention of the CIO opens on Monday.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- The Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts announced today that a $500 prize for ceramic sculpture had been awarded to Mrs. Thelma Frazier Winter of Cleveland for her two circus figures, "Juggler" and Performers."

Home rental of linens has grown into a million dollar industry in New York and may be the basis of a significant change in the distribution of domestics, it was pointed out last week.
