Both parties in the steel dispute were far apart on who would pay pensions although the United States Steel president appeared ready to do some more talking with the union. President Truman declared he would keep hands off because a real emergency was not at hand.

TIME having turned through its familiar rounds, Alfred Lunt and his wife, Lynn Fontanne, are celebrating this month their twenty-fifth anniversary as an acting team. Now they have been acting together longer than the other two illustrious teams of Henry Irving and Ellen Terry, and E. H. Sothern and Julia Marlowe.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- Word that 4,700 New Englanders would be included among the 145,000 civilian employes scheduled to be laid off next month in an economy move by the Department of Defense made less impression on the region this week than it would have earlier.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 29 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister for External Affairs, disclosed tonight that a number of delegates to the United Nations General Assembly were discussing the possibility of a compromise on atomic control under which the ownership and operation functions of the proposed international agency would be diminished in exchange for the right of continuous and rigid inspection against violations.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- Like a battleship brought to action during its shakedown cruise, the United States High Commission in Germany is grappling with some of the most difficult problems it will be called upon to face before its final administrative arrangements have been completed and all its key personnel are at work.

The largest application of scientific management methods in the history of government administration is now well under way, and aims of lower costs, economies in administration and improvement of relations with suppliers are being achieved daily.

EVERY novelist knows that it is more difficult, in our tough-minded age, to write about a good man certain in his purposes than about a man who is evil, or confused, or angry. It would therefore be gratifying to be able to applaud "To Every Man a Penny," Bruce Marshall's chronicle of a Parisian abbe and spotless modern saint.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 -- Harvard accomplished something today it has been unable to do all season. It won a football game. Faced by a Holy Cross eleven which also was victory starved, the Crimson turned in a 22-to-14 decision much to the delight of 19,000 spectators at Harvard Stadium.

OUT of the horror of the concentration camp and the ghetto has come this extraordinary book, an anthology of hope and courage, of sublime heroism in circumstances where anyone might be excused for being a coward.

While the Cleveland Browns and San Francisco Forty-Niners are belaboring each other in Cleveland, the Yankees will seek to solidify their position in the forefront of the All-America Conference race by defeating the Baltimore Colts at the Yankee Stadium today. The kick-off will be at 2:15.

An unusual job placement clinic developed by members of a Yorkville post of the Veterans of Foreign Wars was declared a success yesterday after a sixty-day test in which it had found employment for ten out of twelve ex-servicemen.

OMAHA, Oct. 29 -- High prices of cattle on the hoof were commanding attention in the Midwest this week, but some of the reaction in the cities was out of all proportion to the importance of the situation to the retail buyer.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 29 (UP) -- An obviously power-laden Virginia team beat West Virginia, 19 to 14, today without showing much to the scouts whose teams are laying for the unbeaten Cavaliers in November.

THE history of our own stormy years, still vivid in the memory of most of us, can be suggested effectively on records, as the Columbia album, "I Can Hear It Now," proved some time ago. That album, covering the period between 1932 and the end of the war, had a big sale.

Color television was enlisted yesterday, as a new aid in the fight against cancer with a dramatic New York debut at the annual meeting of the American Cancer Society, at the Biltmore Hotel. The entire day was devoted to television demonstrations of the latest techniques, surgical, chemical and physical, now being employed with a measure of success formerly regarded as impossible, in the treatment of the various forms of the disease.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Army's undefeated and untied record went virtually unchallenged today as the cadets romped to a 40-14 victory over a stout-hearted football squad from Virginia Military Institute before a crowd of 15,555 at Michie Stadium today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- In central Philadelphia women's apparel shops last week sales were 28 per cent under a year ago. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 74,203, or about the same as during the previous week, but 46.6 per cent below the 138,996 reported a year ago.

The three young Americans who reported last week the discovery of a large ghost city in the Afghanistan Desert south of Herat had followed in their jeep the trail of many conquerors. This way came Darius the Great, Persian King of Kings; Alexander the Great, Genghis Khan, his sons and generals; the terrible Timur Lenk, or Tamerlane; Mahmud the Turk and the Moguls who conquered India.

DR. JORDAN has written a detailed account of ante-bellum and reconstruction life on the 5,000-acre Alabama plantation of the Hugh Davis family, an account based on the Davis' day-to-day journals and account books. Dr. Butler, using family records and his own well-stored memory, has told a more discursive story of life at Laurel Hill Plantation, near Natchez, from "sometime earlier than 1775" to the present.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The United States threatened "further steps" against Czechoslovakia today over the arrest of Samuel Meryn, United States Embassy clerk in Prague.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Tulane University's ponderous football team ripped avenues in Mississippi State's outweighed defense today and its fast backs sped to a 54-to-6 victory.

The United States Maritime Commission has scheduled a public hearing for Nov. 16 in Washington to give interested parties an opportunity to express their views on the report issued recently by the Tramp Shipping Committee of the Government agency, it was announced yesterday.

The senior captain of the American Export Lines, W. W. Kuhne, master of the Excambion, will observe his twenty-fifth year of service with the company aboard the bridge of his ship in the Mediterranean next month.

WHEN Mary Kingsbury was 10 years old her Sunday School teacher took her and several other children into near-by Boston one cold Thankgiving morning to bring cheer to an old lady living in a tenement. Young Mary, brought up in a family that never lacked necessities, stood aghast upon seeing this shivering woman in a cold, empty room.

The thirty-sixth running of the East View Stakes at Jamaica yesterday provided a California-bred winner in William Helis' Selector, the favorite in the mile-and-a-sixteenth race for 2-year-old colts and geldings. He paid $4.70, earned $36,850.

WHAT the people don't know, according to Mr. Seldes, is everything important about our relations with Russia and Eastern Europe. For this he blames the newspapers indiscriminately, not exactly a new theme for the editor of the weekly, In Fact.

ITHACA, N. Y. -- Old Lion grads will have to go back in their memories twenty-two years to find a Columbia beating by Cornell comparable to the 54-0 humiliation Lou Little's team suffered today on Schoellkof Field before 25,000 delighted fans.

JIM'S teacher knew why Jim made so much noise. Being the smallest in the class and being called "Tiny" gave him a feeling of unimportance, but when he shouted and yelled and pushed and shoved everyone noticed him and that made him feel big.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 29 -- John L. Lewis, international president of the United Mine Workers of America, was widely acclaimed today in the anthracite region as he led a day-long tribute to the memory of John Mitchell, a leader of the unions in the early Nineteen Hundreds.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 29 -- Widespread desertion by Democrats of Elmer H. Wene, the party's candidate for Governor, was indicated today after City Commissioner James F. Murray called for his defeat to end the political dynasty of former Mayor Frank Hague.

The American Merchant Marine is not getting sufficient consideration in the deliberations of the United Nations, and little attention is being devoted to the part it will play in international economics, Senator Warren G. Magnuson of Washington declared yesterday morning as he prepared to leave aboard the United States liner America for a three-week trip abroad.

MR. WALTER W. HOFFMAN implies in his letter [Book Review, Oct. 9] that I had no knowledge of the existence of Jules Verne's "Mysterious Island." It is evident that he based his letter on Mr. Crane's review without consulting the volume under review.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 29 -- The mariners of Kings Point finally got themselves off a losing football reef with a 27-to-0 triumph over Hofstra today.

THE television industry is trimming its sails and beginning to take a much more realistic approach to its problems -- both monetary and programming, as is indicated by action taken by the ABC video chain.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 27 -- The principle of "great power unanimity" on which the United Nations was founded has been revived and applied with partial but promising success at this fourth session of the General Assembly, it became known today.

JAPANESE readers have developed a sudden appetite for books about the war -- and publishers today are offering a wide range of reporting, from gory battle descriptions to diplomatic maneuvering, including the celebrated attempt by young Army hotheads inside the palace to prevent the Emperor from reading his Imperial Rescript of capitulation.

Notre Dame extended its unbeaten string to thirty-three games by routing Navy at Baltimore yesterday. Pitt upset Penn by one point with a safety in the last thirty-five seconds. Unbeaten Fordham crushed Georgetown, while Columbia lost to Cornell.

TO THE EDITOR: George H. Copeland's "What Makes a Tuna Run?" mentioned some of the larger tuna that have been caught. "You should have seen the one I caught!" cried Frank J. Mather in reversal of the old cry, "You should have seen the one that got away!"

Action will be started tomorrow in what is expected to be the first test of the constitutionality of the new Sharkey rent law in the state's highest court. A notice of appeal will be filed with the Court of Appeals in Albany on the dismissal of eviction proceedings in the Municipal Court on a tenant's refusal to pay a rent increase that had been authorized by the Office of Housing Expediter.

HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 29 -- Dr. Alonzo G. Moron, the first alumnus and the first Negro to be chosen as president of eighty-one-year-old Hampton Institute, was installed today in academic ceremonies attended by 3,000 persons.

Steamship operators using North River piers are rapidly accepting the rental formula adopted by the Board of Estimate on Dec. 16, with the latest to fall into line being the United Fruit Company, it was said yesterday by G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

BROADWAY might well stop crying long enough to examine the workings of the Erie Playhouse. Bringing drama to this city of some 135,000 people on the shores of Lake Erie, the Playhouse, manned by professionals, mounts a show six nights every week during a nine-month season.

MONSIGNOR Knox is a man of composite background. The son of an Anglican Bishop, he has absorbed the music of the King James Version of the Bible and the accompanying Prayer Book. Converted to the Roman Catholic Church, he has devoted a brilliant sense of language to translating the Bible into modern but literary English.

AT the heart of the foreign policy of our great country are the Four Freedoms. The third of these justly celebrated freedoms is Freedom From Want. Most of us have come to realize that the attainment of this freedom throughout the world is essential to our own well-being. As our late President stated so eloquently:

LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Britain wants American public and private investments to help revive its groggy internal economy and spur development of its colonies. But there is more hope than conviction apparent among Government officials that a big scale dollar investment program is just around the corner.

PARENTS usually feel that their child is somebody "special." Most of the time they consider him an individual who is delightfully different from other children. Contrariwise, they so often insist that when Johnny goes to school he must learn to be as nearly like other children as possible, learning the same things as well as, or better than the others.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- Penn was tumbled from the ranks of the unbeaten teams today by Pitt in the last thirty-five seconds of a thrill packed game that had some 42,663 spectators at Franklin Field in an uproar at its conclusion.

Bishop Loughlin made it three in a row yesterday by capturing team honors in the second annual Fordham University interscholastic cross-country run. The Brooklyn harriers earlier had won the team awards in the New York University and Manhattan College meets.

THIS is, as the title indicates, a collection of excerpts from the writings of W. H. Hudson, best known to the general reading public as the author of "Green Mansions," a point that grieves those who know Hudson much better, for it is by no means the best book of this past grand master of modern English literature.

THIS, according to Mr. Bemelmans, whose word one has no reason to doubt, is a favorite proverb among the Vorarlbergers. The Vorarlbergers dwell in the flatlands of Austria, and Mr. Bemelmans prefers the Arlbergers, particularly those who live in Aspen, a mountain village in the Tyrol located just below a triangular rocky summit called the Eye of God.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Wisconsin's Badgers displayed a spirited ground and air attack today to beat Indiana, 30 to 14, gaining their first Big Ten victory and spoiling the Hoosiers' homecoming before 25,000 fans.

GROUNDCOVERS for hardy spring bulbs are most apt to be forgotten during fall planting time. But, after the first mud-bespattering shower in the spring, the gardener will regret his neglect to supply this protection for the blooms.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- Evidence that Titoism was spreading in the Italian Communist party was furnished today by a delegation of Italian Partisans that was present in Belgrade at the celebration several days ago of the fifth anniversary of that city's liberation.

A QUARTER of a century ago, sports stories were exactly what that term implies: stories for boys that included a lot of competitive action, and not much else. Today the majority of sports stories may be termed junior novels.

Taking advantage of an early penalty, the Chicago Black Hawks ran up a pair of goals in less than a minute against the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. Then the Windy City skaters clung to this lead to win, 2 -- 0.

THE stated purpose of this book is "to present a full-length portrait of Robert E. Lee by means of extracts selected from the writings of the many who have taken the Confederate commander as their subject." This is the easy way of compiling a biography; whether it is a wholly satisfactory way is another matter.
Sam A. Lewisohn should not have time for anything else, but he's always taking on new chores. And he enjoys every one of them.

The seventieth International six-day bicycle race will start at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory tonight. Vincent Impellitteri, chairman of the City Council, will fire the starting gun that will send a field of thirteen teams on its long whirl which will come to an end at 11 o'clock Saturday night.
ALFRED, N. Y., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Alfred spotted Brooklyn College a three-touchdown edge tonight, then stormed back to score its fourth football victory in six starts, 20-19.

AUTUMN flower shows are scheduled during the next two weeks in three states. The first to open will be the 120th annual Autumn Flower Show of the Massachusetts Horticultural Society. It will be held in Horticultural Hall, Boston, from Thursday through Sunday.
Big as it is, the $20,000,000,000 power and light industry is helpless to halt the most ambitious Government power program in history.

Sparked by Danny Spensieri, who accounted for 25 points and 350 yards gained, New Utrecht defeated Manual Training, 34 -- 6, in the second game of the football double-header before 5,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday. In the introductory fray, Brooklyn Tech subdued Lafayette, 26 -- 7.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 29 -- Yugoslavia charged tonight that Hungarian troops fired automatic weapons and threw grenades toward Yugoslavia for eight hours Thursday night and early Friday morning in a new outbreak of the "little cold war" between Marshal Tito and the countries of the Communist Information Bureau.

A new rodent killer known provisionally as W.A.R.F.-42 has been developed in the department of biochemistry at the University of Wisconsin in the laboratories of Karl Paul Link. W.A.R.F.-42 is an anti-coagulant which kills rodents by causing them to bleed to death. It is "self-prebaiting," because it is a slow-acting, odorless and tasteless rat poison.

In a letter to Senator John Foster Dulles, made public yesterday at his headquarters, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan declared that the election of Mr. Dulles "will be a very great stimulus to the hopes of America for a dependable peace in a free world of free men."

A highly-regarded Stuyvesant High School football team, victor in three straight Bronx-Manhattan P. S. A. L. contests, was upset by a hard-charging James Monroe eleven, 19 -- 18, in the first game of a scholastic triple-header at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. In the second game, underdog Roosevelt stopped Seward, 12 -- 6, and De Witt Clinton completed the afternoon's play with a 20-0 triumph over Columbus.

OSWEGO, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Governor Dewey told an Oswego Republican rally tonight that John Foster Dulles was the first Senator in history who, in his first three months in Washington, "saved his country a billion dollars."

LONG after his newspaper essays become unfamiliar to modern eyes, the crusading spirit of Heywood Broun will shine among the hallowed ghost's of New York's Park Row. This laureate of the underprivileged people of his time was not content with such early acclaim as he variously had won as a columnist in the departments of sports, drama, book reviews, and as a genial commentator on the metropolitan scene.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and final prices were 1 point higher to 4 points lower.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Michigan State warmed up for a visit by Notre Dame next week by overwhelming an out-classed Temple team by a nine-touchdown 62-14 score before 35,003 fans today.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Penn State came from behind to score its twelfth straight victory over Syracuse, 33 to 21, today before 18,600 fans at Beaver Field.

IN its final week at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Sadler's Wells Ballet will present two more premieres, both by Ninette de Valois. They are "Job" (1931), called "a masque for dancing," with music by Vaughan Williams and scenery and costumes by John Piper; and "Checkmate" (1937), with music by Arthur Bliss and scenery and costumes by E. McKnight Kauffer.

Anyone who thinks this country is all built up and has run out of land to be tamed and inhabited should take a trip through the West. And by the West is meant that vast area beyond the 100th degree of longitude, which runs through central Texas, western Kansas, and central Nebraska and the Dakotas.

DESPITE the romantic antiquity implied in the title, this story is of contemporary England. The complicated plot revolves about a fortune in diamonds belonging to the Grand Duchy of Ehrenburg. The chase for them includes a series of mad dashes in a furniture van that includes a secret compartment containing two pretty girls and a modern Robin Hood.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 29 -- Charley Caldwell's fighting Princeton eleven rebounded from its defeat by Cornell in grand style today. With 37,000 fans looking on, the Tigers completely outplayed their time-honored foe, Rutgers, to win going away, 34 to 14, in Palmer Stadium.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 29 -- Scoring in the first, third and fourth periods, Lehigh University's football team defeated New York University, 21 -- 6, today at Taylor Stadium. A crowd of 8,000 saw Lehigh engineer its first victory over a Hook Mylin-coached eleven.

Failure of the Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers (S.C.A.P.) to guarantee Japanese silk prices beyond the end of 1949 may prove detrimental to the position of the fiber in the American market, it was pointed out last week. The low post-war rate of consumption, it was said, may slip even lower as a result of the price uncertainty.

MAY I address a line or two of friendly jibe to Prof. Perry Miller about his review of "Margaret Fell"? The Quakers in 1949 as well as in 1652 might be classified as nonconformists, but not as "insurgents" according to my Oxford Dictionary definitions.

IT was just fifteen years ago that Sir Cedric Hardwicke journeyed to Hollywood to make his American movie debut in the first feature-length Technicolor picture, "Becky Sharp," at the RKO Studio. Today he is working at the same studio, again in Technicolor.

To the Drama Editor: WITH all due respect to Lillian Hellman's prowess as a playwright, I think she has flopped badly with her comments on directing printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday. Miss Hellman, it seems, believes that directing is no great feat. Maybe it isn't.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 29 -- The last session of the Round Table Conference on Indonesia is now scheduled for Wednesday. When the last document is approved the Indonesian delegates to the two months' meeting will scramble for planes and rush back home to pilot the new Dutch-Indonesian agreement over the final obstacles.

ATLANTA, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The little men of Duke and Georgia Tech, charging like angry heavyweights, stalled each other on the ground, but Billy Cox's brilliant passes could not be stopped and Duke won today, 27 to 14.
ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Alabama shelved its old-fashioned Notre Dame offense in favor of a split T today and the "new look" was good for a 14-to-7 upset victory over Georgia before 35,000 fans.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 29 (UP) -- American Federation of Labor longshoremen paralyzed Port Houston today with an unexpected work stoppage, seventy-two hours before the deadline for a strike that would close down waterfront business on the entire western Gulf of Mexico.

THE high winds and heavy seas that whipped and pounded ocean liners on the Atlantic recently, delaying some of them from six hours to a full day, were early reminders of the coming of another winter. To ocean-liner travelers and steamship companies, winter means relatively rough crossings and a constant struggle to keep schedules on time.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, lashed out at the Department of Welfare in a series of outdoor addresses in Harlem last night. He charged that the department planned to reduce "320,000 public assistance recipients to an absolute starvation level."

FAR HILLS, N. J., Oct. 29 -Mrs. Simon T. Patterson's The Cardinal II from Pittsburgh won the twenty-eighth steeplechase for New Jersey Hunt Cup this gray day, but the question for 5,000 spectators on the rolling E. B. Schley Estate had been, "Could Royal Mission make up the sixty lengths he lost at the beginning?" The answer was "No."

THE review in these pages the other week of Margaret Mead's "Male and Female" characterized the study by parodying a Marxian motto. One can go along that way -- if one has a mind to. For instance, Kinsey is conjured up: The Normal Man's Kinsey.

The evening performance of Nov. 28 at the Shubert Theatre of "I Know My Love," with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in the leading roles, has been taken over as a benefit by the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University. Mrs. J. Cheever Cowdin is chairman of the event, for which tickets may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe, 136 East Shixty-fourth Street.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- More than a hundred debutantes attended the fifty-seventh annual Tuxedo ball held here tonight in the Tuxedo Club. Several hundred visitors are here for the event, the largest since before the war, and nearly every home is the scene of a week-end house party.

To provide American school children and teachers with information and materials concerning French customs and literature, the cultural division of the French Embassy in New York City now prepares a wide variety of teaching aids. Material is distributed to schools, colleges, libraries, museums and educational organizations throughout the United States.

Rabbi Zev Zahavy of Congregation Ohab Zadek, 118 West Ninety-fifth Street, said yesterday that the members of the United Nations should take heed lest the world organization suffer the fate of the Tower of Babel and collapse in "utter failure" through neglect of moral law.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Department store sales in September were one of the two factors to show substantial increases over the July and August low marks registered in the business index of the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry.

FOR THE WEEK: Sow seed of larkspur, poppies and cornflowers where they are to flower next year, and prepare the trench for planting sweet peas next month. . . . Mulch rhubard and grape vines with well-rotted manure. . . . Aphids are even more troublesome on late vegetables than flowers. Frequent applications of non-poisonous rotenone are helpful.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Oct. 29 -- Trustees of Jefferson Military College today severed all relations with George W. Armstrong, who had proposed to donate an estimated $50,000,000 endowment to the school.
BOSTON, Oct, 29 -- The nation's truckmen tactily declared war this week on railroad propaganda.
A seven-hour parade of twelve different sports provided continuous entertainment yesterday for 2,500 City College alumni at the second Homecoming Day.

LOUISVILLE'S orchestra has shortened its name but has not curtailed its year-old commissioning policy. Last season the Louisville Philharmonic Orchestra, whose conductor is Robert Whitney, engaged six composers to write short pieces which were premiered here.

FALL is a good season for planting fruit trees and bushes. Numerous varieties are suited to climatic conditions in this locality, but the space available for them will control their selection to a large extent.
NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 29 (UP) -- University of Oklahoma rolled over Iowa State, 34 to 7, today in a Big Seven Conference football game that was also the Sooners' sixteenth straight without defeat.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- The attention of people in the Central States was drawn dramatically this week to the progressive effects of the coal strike by the abrupt announcement that unless the strike ended in two or three weeks, Chicagoans might not have any running water above the first floor level.

THE past few days have witnessed two minor historic events in the realm of motion pictures which we think we should duly record. One was the loud inauguration of Paul Douglas in his first starring role and the other was the cheerless embalming of Bette Davis in her last Warner film.
BIRMINGHAM, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A self-identified ex-Klansman today was acquitted of masked flogging.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 29 -- On the eve of the annual convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations here next week, the phrase "labor unity" has taken on a new significance.

Steel companies affected by the current strike are considering asking stockholders to ratify or reject any insurance-pension agreement ultimately reached by the management with the United Steelworkers of America, CIO.
AMERICA'S 1,600 colleges and universities reopened this fall under a cloud of economic uncertainty. For higher education in this country is facing the most serious financial crisis in its history.
BOSTON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Harry Agganis fired four touchdown passes and directed two other scores as Boston University swamped Scranton, 46 to 6, at Fenway Park today.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The Communists and the de Gaullists have been staging vociferous demonstrations on the sidelines of the French political crisis but without much visible effect upon the course of events. Their greatest influence derives not from their action but from the fact of their existence.

Under the chairmanship of Miss Alison Pyne, a junior committee is assisting in completing final arrangements for the Bal de Tete, to be given Nov. 15 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton as a benefit for the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Truman vetoed today a bill to permit the use of water from the San Luis Valley (Colo.) reclamation project by farms with acreage exceeding the existing legal eligibility limits.

The scientific and engineering problem facing the United States, Great Britain and the Soviet Union in their race to build the best rocket and jet engines for war-planes are, of course, identical. But the means of coping with the problems vary in the three countries, and engineers believe it will be those variations that will give one country an advantage.

A proposal by several small steel companies that the President's fact-finding board be recalled to clarify some of its recommendations was passed on yesterday to the striking United Steelworkers of America, CIO, by the nation's top mediator.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 29 -- In the opinion of United Nations diplomats from some of the smaller nations, a delegate attending the current session of the General Assembly has to be agile as well as able, and must be willing to forego sleep, regular mealtimes and the luxury of a leisurely Sunday at home.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Paul G. Hoffman, who bears the awkward title of Economic Cooperation Administrator, is slated to make a particularly important speech to the European Marshall Plan Council in Paris on Monday. His purpose may be briefly described as that of saving the Marshall Plan.

MEXICO CITY -- For the ordinary traveler the significant aspect of the nineteenth annual convention of the American Society of Travel Agents which closed here last week is that virtually every geographic area in the world is intensifying its efforts to attract United States tourist dollars.

IN an effort to attract tourists from the hard-currency nations to the Orient, recommendations for easing travel restrictions in that area were adopted by a special subcommittee of the United Nations Commission for Asia and the Far East which met in Singapore recently.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 -- It's later than you think. Seeing Notre Dame in a football game today after having previously seen in the flesh -- a lot more flesh than in the old days, too -- the fabulous Four Horsemen of yesteryear, hammered home with stunning force the point that a quarter of a century has passed since the most famous backfield in gridiron history cavorted on the turf.

The sharpest and most sustained rise seen on any futures market since the post-war featured the coffee futures trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., this month. With only one trading day to go, the market at its close on Friday had advanced 1,146 points since Sept. 30 on the S contract covering December deliveries.

IF I should be asked offhand to identify the author of these lines, I could frantically suggest three or four, but the thought of Marc Blitzstein would probably not occur to me. One always looks for something a bit wry in his lyrics, somewhat offbeat, something that points to a familiar problem from an oblique point of reference.

BOGOTA, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Thirty-five additional persons were reported today to have been killed and 200 wounded in Colombia's political disorders. The unofficial toll for the past thirty-six hours stood at 234 dead.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- A growing resentment smoldering under the surface for several years in the American Power Boat Association, ruling body since 1903 of the sport of speed boating, blazed into open revolt today on the eve of tomorrow's annual meeting and election.

EVIDENTLY Louis Golding wanted to write a novel about an ordinary bloke, so he chose Jim Gunning, a London newspaper deliveryman and a professional boxer on the side. Like so many Englishmen, his life had been scarred by the war, as had his flat in Territon Street, with its garden in the rear, buried under air-raid rubble.
THE smooth-cheeked young man who created Joe and Willie for Stars and Stripes in World War II has done a good book on his own early childhood, different from anything he has turned out previously.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -- Not since the rollicking days of "ham 'n' eggers" and "thirty dollars every Thrusday," a decade or so ago, has California been treated to so lively a pension fight as it is watching in the closing weeks of this fall's election campaign.
CONTRARY to general practice, sweet peas should always be planted in fall. Unfortunately, many gardeners sow the seed in spring with results that are not satisfactory.

LOGGERS live at home with their families today and ride to the Northwest's last stands of virgin Douglas fir in high-speed trucks. They are organized into a strong CIO union, which has agreements with most of the great lumber companies.

Civilized Western man is not so well off emotionally as are the Negritos of the Bataan Mountains in the Philippines, Dr. Kilton Stewart, psychologist and anthropologist, told a Cooper Union audience in New York recently. The Negritos have no written language and seldom even talk to one another.

THE slender young man in brown tweeds whose wry smile makes his eyes crinkle is Benjamin Britten, British composer of recent, wide acclaim. He is here to play piano accompaniments for his friend, the tenor Peter Pears (rhymes with beers).

With official Washington rife with talk about recruiting billions of private American dollars to rehabilitate Post-war Europe No. 2, major banks in New York and Chicago moved last week to prevent certain private American investments in Post-war Europe No. 1 from being wiped out in the Ruhr reorganization plans of the Allied Military Government.

FILMING of Runner Godden's 1946 novel, "The River," by a Hollywood company organized especially for motion picture production in India is scheduled to begin late next month, after three years of preparations which at times seemed to be almost hopelessly entangled in international red tape.

The National Horse Show, New York's distinguished sporting and social event, will begin Tuesday in Madison Square Garden and run for eight days of afternoon and evening performances. By way of introducing the show, a detachment of thirty-two members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police will parade through Central Park and the midtown section this afternoon.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Britain's Labor Government is confronted with an economic and financial crisis. It is also confronted with an election in the next few months. Both facts should be kept in mind in weighing the measures that have and have not been taken by the Government.

SOONER or later Byron will enjoy a decided vogue again. He will never, of course, be so famous as he once was -- he once, after all, intoxicated all England and half of Europe. He carried a sable and self-conscious melancholy to its farthest height; he turned pose into poetry.

ONE could be tempted to call Nobel - prize - winner Hermann Hesse's longest, most profound and most enigmatic work a study of Utopia. What we find in 2500 A. D. is Castalia, an exquisitely landscaped mountain province, where the Castalian Order reigns serenely.

THE Sadler's Wells Ballet still has some important works to show us from among the twelve it has selected to bring to this country, but it has already given us the six ballets in which Margot Fonteyn appears, and has provided accordingly a basis of sorts for an estimate of its bright, particular star.

MR. CHANDOS' performance almost persuades one that the best preparation for writing an intimate and charming book about a foreign country is to keep an inn there. Of course, it needs to be a small inn, so that one is not lost in the mechanics of hotel management, and staffed by the native talent of a remote countryside so that it will be fully flavored with local economy and customs.
Plans for expanded transit service in areas near Brooklyn's new city-built public housing projects were announced yesterday by Borough President John Cashmore.

THIS volume is another addition to the already extensive of memoirs by former prisoners of Soviet slave labor camps. Mr. Petrov's account is of more than ordinary importance, however, because he claims to have spent his years of compulsory labor in the Kolyma gold fields of the Soviet Far East, one of the major sources of the U.S.S.R.'s gold production and one of the regions least known to the outside world.

The Kresge Foundation has given Wayne University, Detroit, a grant of $1,000,000 to erect the Kresge Science Library Building. The new building, the first structure on the campus to be financed by a private contribution, will house the university's Kresge-Hooker Scientific Collection, one of the most complete chemical libraries in the world, and other science books and periodicals.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed Challis print dresses, skid resistant rugs, South Pacific silk squares, cowboy and cowgirl outfits, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- An Atlantic union, binding the United States and the Western European democracies into one political, economic and military framework, is essential to counter the rapidly growing Soviet bloc in Europe and Asia, the committee asserted.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Most grains worked a little higher on the Board of Trade today, but corn lagged behind the rest of the market. Receipts of the yellow grain were fairly large and were expected to expand sharply next week. Cash dealers reported purchases of 175,000 bushels of corn on a toarrive basis.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 -- The United Mine Workers welfare and pension fund has spent in three years more than $137,000,000 of the $151,000,000 it collected, The Post-Gazette will say tomorrow on the basis of information obtained from what it described as authoritative sources.

PRAGUE, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- Dr. Frantisek Onderek, Apostolic Administrator of Ceske Tesin, reported in some newspapers to have approved the Government's new church laws, issued a statement today supporting the Roman Catholic hierarchy.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- Governor Dewey announced today that he had summoned representatives of state agencies to a Monday conference to determine the effect of the coal strike on the state's gas supply, transportation, electricity, food and employment.

Hardest hit during the recent slump of retail sales throughout the nation are women's specialty stores which sell merchandise in the medium to upper bracket price levels. Two weeks ago specialty stores here dropped 26 per cent below figures attained during the corresponding week in 1948, as compared with department store sales that were only 15 per cent lower.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 29 -- Earl Browder, former general secretary of the Communist party, emerged today from political retirement to charge that William Z. Foster, national chairman of the party, is handing over its main task to Henry Wallace's Progressive party.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- All German prisoners of war still held in the Soviet Union will be returned to Germany by the first of next year, Wilhelm Pieck, President of the Eastern German Democratic Republic, announced today.

THIS pleasant, accurate volume is the story of the aristocracy of Quaker merchants who dominated the life of Philadelphia from 1682 to 1763 or thereabouts. The author, an Assistant Professor of History at Swarthmore College and Librarian of the Friends Historical Library, sees the group he is portraying as an aristocracy "not merely of wealth, certainly not of birth, but of virtue and talents."

WHEN I became a young member of the House of Representatives in 1913, and for some time thereafter, I gained the impression that the members of the Washington Press Gallery constituted a rather cynical group of observers and commentators on the processes of legislation and the conduct of legislators.

PRAGUE, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- Dr. Frantisek Onderek, Apostolic Administrator of Ceske Tesin, reported in some newspapers to have approved the Government's new church laws, issued a statement today supporting the Roman Catholic hierarchy.

Hardest hit during the recent slump of retail sales throughout the nation are women's specialty stores which sell merchandise in the medium to upper bracket price levels. Two weeks ago specialty stores here dropped 26 per cent below figures attained during the corresponding week in 1948, as compared with department store sales that were only 15 per cent lower.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 29 -- Earl Browder, former general secretary of the Communist party, emerged today from political retirement to charge that William Z. Foster, national chairman of the party, is handing over its main task to Henry Wallace's Progressive party.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- A feeling of frustration and impatience seems to be growing in high military quarters here over the present state of military cooperation with France.
Aprons can do much for a dress. Down through the centuries women have worn them to add a bright and colorful note, for they are both useful and ornamental.

The people of New York City voted in the 1947 general election to repeal the Proportional Representation system of electing a City Council and to substitute the election of one Councilman from each State Senate District wholly within the city. This means that the new Council, to be elected on Nov. 8, will be composed of twenty-five members instead of twenty-three.

On Oct. 11 THE NEW YORK TIMES published the "judgment" of the New York County Lawyers Association on candidates for judicial office. The article contains one sentence that rouses me from my lethargy and prompts me to write my first letter to the editor.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 -- Eleventh-hour efforts to force a compromise in the civil war rending the Congress of Industrial Organizations failed today.

In addition to electing a Mayor, the voters of New York will choose two other city-wide administrative officials on Nov. 8. One of these will fill the office of President of the City Council. The other will serve as Controller. Each of these officials will have three votes in the Board of Estimate.

Twenty-five hundred Girl Scouts of the Catholic Youth Organization from various counties of the Archdiocese of New York, observed Girl Scout Sunday at services yesterday afternoon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A "foreign force" that had crossed from Canada with this city as its objective was being driven back steadily from Highland, N. Y., yesterday by the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division. The theoretical routing of the enemy brought to a close a week-end of intensive training under a new program for the Organized Reserve Corps at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 30 -- As the rainy season is expected to begin in Israel any day now, about 20,000 immigrants in tent cities began fastening their cots to planks laid over dirt floors as precautions against their being swept away during rainstorms or being sucked into mud.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -Following is the text of the speech by President Truman tonight on the "Religion in American Life" broadcast:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, disclosed today that the Army and Air Force were stepping up the training of crack airborne troops -- the type of soldiers who would play a major role in any future war.

John Haynes Holmes, who will retire Nov. 29 as minister of the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, said in his morning sermon yesterday that in solving the world's problems the important thing was to begin.

The Slotes Realty Corporation bought for investment the five-story apartment house for thirty families on plot 44 by 100 feet at 186-88 Ross Street, Brooklyn, from the 186 Ross Street Corporation and insured title with the City Title Insurance Company.
Sales of cooperative apartments through William A. White Sons were reported in 950 Park Avenue to Dr. Jack J. Squire and in 116 East Sixty-third Street to Florence C. Downs.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 30 -Growing opposition to fair trade practices will result in institution of a fair trade educational program in Rhode Island during the next three months.

Phil Watson's New York Rovers opened their home Eastern Hockey League season in bang-up fashion at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The current Red Shirts, one of the biggest and most spirited outfits to represent New York in the Eastern loop in many a season, took a 3-2 thriller from the Boston Olympics.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- The Government of the Western German Federal Republic is expected to announce this week at Bonn a comprehensive plan for reparations from current production and a system of international trusteeship for German industry.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 -- Light, according to evidence reported by the California Institute of Technology, will not only "kill" organisms but "restore" them to life.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30 -- Mrs. Carleton S. Hadley announced tonight that she and Vice President Alben W. Barkley would be married in St. Louis on Nov. 18. The 38-year-old widow made the announcement as the Vice President, who is 71, stood at her side at a press conference in her apartment here.
Wide publicity was given the other day in many papers in the United States, including THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 24, to the allegation that certain persecution of the Jews is taking place in Iraq.

It was like old times Saturday. Notre Dame and Army were pouring it on, but they have been doing that year after year, and it was nothing to go nostalgic about. It was the old times of the years when Fordham and Pittsburgh were locked in those mighty love's-labor-lost defensive stalemates and the Seven Blocks of Granite and the deep Pittsburgh reverse represented the best in Eastern football.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- An increase both in personnel and in services rendered to the armed forces during 1949 has been reported to the National Jewish Welfare Board by the Rev. Dr. Solomon B. Freehof of Pittsburgh, chairman of the board's Division of Religious Activities.

United Florists Trades, Inc., will begin a campaign this week featuring "take-home specials" of $1.50-$2 bouquets and $1-$1.50 corsages, it was announced over the week-end. According to Isidore A. Fight, president of the organization, this will be the first time that price advertising has been employed in the flower business on a market-wide level.

Leonid Hambro gave a piano recital in Carnegie Hall late yesterday afternoon and proved himself more than ever an artist of extraordinary talent. It was the first in the second series of "Twilight Concerts," inaugurated by Mr. Hambro last season, and was greeted with marked enthusiasm by the large audience.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The home front is unprepared for "modern, push-button war," Bernard M. Baruch, long an adviser to Presidents, declared in a letter released today. The letter supported Representative John F. Kennedy's protest to President Truman on what he called a lack of adequate civil defense planning.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal - Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that the O'Dwyer administration had "relegated to the attic of City Hall" a portrait of the late Mayor Fiorello La Guardia in whose administration he served.
B'nai B'rith's 106th anniversary and the ninetieth anniversary of Rehoboth Lodge, its oldest unit in the Bronx, were celebrated yesterday at ceremonies in the rotunda of the Bronx County Courthouse.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 -- The current easy money policy of the Federal Reserve authorities has been comparatively unimportant in its effect on the loan volume of commercial banks, Evans Woollen Jr., president of the American Bankers Association, declared here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 30 -- The United States delegation is set to deliver two policy speeches tomorrow, the first defending the United Nations' Special Committee on the Balkans from Soviet criticisms and the second explaining the American position on the admission of new members to the world organization.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Lou Groza's 38-yard place-kick provided the victory margin today as the thrice - champion Cleveland Browns defeated the San Francisco Forty-niners, 30 -- 28, in an All-America Conference football game before 72,189 fans.

Contradicting their critics in Government electric power agencies, top utility executives released yesterday for publication today a survey in which they contend there is no power curtailment except in the Pacific Northwest.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -The early-bird Bureau of Agricultural Economics tonight peered far ahead into 1950 and said:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (AP) -The Los Angeles Rams today hammered and passed the Chicago Bears into submission, 27 to 24, in a wild battle witnessed by the largest and-perhaps the loudest crowd ever to watch a National League game.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Unconfirmed dispatches carried by the Liberal party press reported today that more than 100 persons had been killed in an attack by Conservatives in the Department of Santander Norte.

" Crusade for Life," by Kirtley F. Mather, Professor of Geology at Harvard University, will be published on Nov. 12 by the University of North Carolina Press. The book, an outgrowth of his John Calvin McNair Lectures, delivered last year at the University of North Carolina, discusses the mutual bearing of science and theology and the limitations of the scientific method as an approach to a comprehensive understanding of life and the universe.

The goal of all programs for a peaceful post-war world should be increased economic improvement and happiness of the individual, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday afternoon at the fall convention of the Council of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York at Temple Emanu-el, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,822,766,726. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

ZURICH, Oct. 30 -- Profound uneasiness prevails in Switzerland because many events of last week seem to prove that the British Government is unable to check the continuous depreciation of sterling so manifestly indicated by the steady decline in both bank note and security rates which last week reached the lowest levels known in Switzerland since the British pound was devalued on Sept. 18.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Navy is removing seventy-seven vessels, including thirty-five combat ships, from active service for reasons of economy, the Department of Defense announced today.
HONG KONG, Oct. 30 -- A marked falling off in commodities available for export in Communist North China ports has been reported by business men here who are engaged in trade with Communist China.

OTTAWA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Two Federal conciliation boards will be set up to deal with wage-hour disputes between Canadian railways and about 146,000 employes, Labor Minister Humphrey Mitchell said tonight. The unions seek improvements on wages and hours that would run to $74,000,000 a year.

In a letter to Herbert H. Lehman, delivered to his home at 820 Park Avenue, United States Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate, renewed yesterday his challenge to his Democratic-Liberal opponent to debate the charge of bigotry he had raised againt him.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Its operations crippled by the coal strike and operating costs increased by the new five-day week for its employes, the Pennsylvania Railroad's net income went into the red for the first nine months of 1949, the nation's largest railroad reported today.

When Philippine President Quirino was here last August he failed to get a public assurance that our Government would support his plan for "a real union of peoples around the Pacific" to resist Communist imperialism. He hoped such a union might succeed without having to use military force.

The new British Government plan to guarantee its exporters against some of the losses likely to arise from efforts to win a place in the America market has stirred hopeful enthusiasm here among advertising agencies interested in promoting British products, it was learned last week.

Heading a busy week of exhibitions of painting and sculpture in New York are two important museum shows. Opening to the public on Saturday at the Whitney Museum is a memorial exhibition of the work of Alfred Maurer, the American painter who is associated with the early days of Cubism in Paris before 1914.

The resignation of Edwin G. Nourse as chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers a few days ago was a serious loss to the Government and to the country. Its only consoling virtue was that it served to focus public attention on the three - year - old CEA and to bring into the open certain basic policy issues which have hitherto been a matter of muted controversy.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- One of the greatest migrations of mice and rats since the Pied Piper of Hamelin led thousands of them into oblivion is soon to take place here.
DETROIT, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens conquered the Detroit Red Wings, defending National Hockey League champions, 4 -- 1, tonight.

Yelberton Abraham Tittle, with his ever-dangerous aerials, threw a late scare into the Brooklyn-New York Yankees, but the home side, having achieved an early 3-touchdown advantage, hung on grimly and recorded a 21-14 All-America Football Conference victory over the Baltimore Colts yesterday at the Stadium.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 30 (UP) -- President Klement Gottwald said today in an Independence Day address that the dispute between State and Church had been "solved" by the new church law that was scheduled to go into effect Tuesday.

AZUSA, Calif., Oct. 30 (UP) -- A broken rail derailed the Santa Fe Railroad's streamlined El Capitan passenger train near here today, injuring at least twenty persons. Sheriff's officers said they would investigate the possibility that someone had tampered with the rail.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 30 -Rapid expansion of Chile's rayon industry is expected as a result of an investment of United States private capital, announced today. Oscar Kohorn Co. of New York has underwritten a debenture issue amounting to sixty millions of pesos -- close to $1,500,000 -which will be used to finance the purchase of equipment and material.

If psychiatric treatment is given in time to blind persons whose blindness is partly or wholly owing to psychological factors, disability may be cleared up, Dr. H. Robert Blank, one of the few psychiatrists in the nation who works with the blind, declared yesterday.

In its new quarters at the familiar address of 99 Park Avenue, the Children's Welfare Federation will carry on the good work that it has been doing for many years. With a membership of over 200 agencies interested in child health and welfare, it acts as an information clearing house for the agencies themselves and for the general public.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- Balanced against sizable headlines proclaiming immediate price, reductions in various commodities in "free shops," the Soviet-sponsored press announced today to the East zone population increased costs in certain basic items that were to take effect in ten days.

Doris Dunlop, Canadian mezzosoprano, who has a weekly coastto-coast radio program in Canada, entitled "Songs at Eventide," gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Her tastefully chosen program included an aria from Handel's "Semele," lieder by Wolf and Brahms, French art songs and selections in English.

MANILA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- President Elpido Quirino announced today that a preliminary conference to organize a non-Communist Union of Southeast Asia would be held in the Philippines next January or February.

ITALY, like the Confederacy, may yet win in books the war she lost on the battlefields. A whole school of American and English writers (Hersey, Hayes, Burns, Linklater) has written novels about Italy, generally portraying the Italians in defeat more sympathetically than their conquerors. A new crop of highly touted Italian writers seems to have sprung up overnight, or, anyway, since the bombs stopped falling.

Prominent Americans in various fields will discuss and answer questions on domestic and international problems in a new transcribed radio series, "America Speaks Up," which starts tonight at 10:45 as a Monday feature over WINS. On the initial broadcast, Benjamin H. Namm, chairman of the board of Namm's Department Store in Brooklyn, will talk on "Survival of American Industry.'

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 30 -- Indonesian delegates to the round-table conference rejected tonight a United Nations conciliators' proposal to postpone for one year a decision on the future of Dutch New Guinea.

Your appetite is not a sound guide to the choice and quantity of foods for good nutrition and health, Dr. Charles Glen King, scientific director of the Nutrition Foundation, said in his annual report published yesterday.

SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, Oct. 30 -- In four years of little publicized economic and psychological efforts the French have managed to integrate the rich territory of the Saar into France. The 923,000 Saarlanders, or Saarois as they now prefer to be called, generally appear to be delighted by the trend of events.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 30 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, Republican candidate and the first Governor eligible to stand for re-election in New Jersey since 1844, is proclaiming a confidence in victory that is not shared fully by those working with him in the campaign.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 -- Thousands of copies of "a personal appeal" by medical men to their patients, asking the election of John Foster Dulles as United States Senator, have been put in the Bands of doctors for such distribution, it was disclosed today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 30 -- Global press and radio coverage of the United Nations is now more extensive and more favorable than at any time since the world organization was set up in San Francisco four years ago, the United Nations' opinion survey section reports.

A catering service tailored to fill a definite need in this city of small apartments is that offered by George D. Crawford and Mrs. Edith Latimer. For a wedding reception, cocktail party or afternoon tea, one may "borrow," for a nominal fee, the tastefully furnished home of Mr. Crawford at 24 East Seventy-third Street.

Richmond Gale is a pianist of strong fingers, a reliable technique and definite ideas about the music he plays. At his debut recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon he presented a traditional program before a sizable and well-disposed audience.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 30 -- The Ford Motor Company will sponsor fifteen hours a week of United Nations television coverage over the video network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Reorders for coats and suits increased considerably last week as a result of cooler weather, according to a report on the wholesale apparel market here prepared especially for THE NEW YOKK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Retailers said that main-floor departments are doing better business than apparel divisions. This was reflected in the large number of reorders for accessories, it was said.

Establishment of higher standards for finishing spun rayon suitings will enable these goods to maintain their competitive standing in both the men's and women's apparel field, it was pointed out last week by officials of Burlington Mills Corporation, largest producer of synthetic fabrics.

A majority of stores indicate that their Christmas employe staffs will not be built as heavily nor as early as last year, according to a survey just completed by the personnel group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Behind the demand of Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, for removal of trade and exchange controls between Marshall Plan countries is an ambitious plan to transform Western Europe into a single economic unit capable of supporting mass production industries with mass consumption.
The summary relieving last week of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld from his post as Chief of Naval Operations considerably broadens and complicates some of the issues in the inter-service struggle.

" Regina" will pass in review tonight at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. First-nighters are hereby warned to be in their seats at 8 o'clock, as the curtain is advertised to go up promptly at that time. Marc Blitzstein is entirely responsible for the libretto, music and lyrics of what is officially described as a musical drama.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The New York Giants erased a three-touchdown deficit in a second-half drive for a thrilling 41-38 victory over the Chicago Cardinals in a National Football League game witnessed by 21,339 at Comiskey Park today.

The testimonial dinner-dance to be tendered to Representative Schuyler O. Bland on Saturday in the Commodore Hotel is expected to be attended by representatives of all branches of the maritime industry. The celebration is in honor of "the best friend the American Merchant Marine ever had," prominent industry figures declared yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- In his speech tomorrow to the European Marshall Plan Council, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, is expected to urge a program of action of such practical and specific character that, if accepted by the European Governments, it would leave no room for side-stepping.

Late Friday announcement by the Government of a parity price of 29.76 cents a pound for mid-October cotton reversed the upward trend of prices earlier in the week on the New York Cotton Exchange. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts there closed with net advances of 17 to 28 points for the week, compared with no change to an advance of 28 points the week before.
A record for school savings in the United States has been set by New York public school pupils who have $14,675,908 on deposit, it was announced yesterday.

VIENNA, Oct. 30 -- Last week's accusation by the Czechoslovak Government against the American commercial attache, John G. Heyn, of industrial espionage, was only the latest development in a spy panic that now forbids residents of the "people's democracies," under pain of the severest penalties, to communicate the most harmless economic details to the outside world.

The origins of voluntary hospitals in New York are often forgotten as the years pass but none-the less are interesting if known. The Norwegian Hospital in Brooklyn, for example, was founded in 1883 by Norwegian pioneers to care for resident immigrants and sick Norwegian sailors in the Port of New York.

Matthew J. Diserio, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for President of the City Council, charged last night that an associate of Frank O'Dwyer, brother of the Mayor, blocked the modernization of Washington Market.

A three-way land exchange that will permit proper arterial design of the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx, eliminate a huge gas tank that would have been an eyesore to residents of a new housing project and provide additional recreational facilities has been worked out by Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, it was announced yesterday.

MIAMI Fla., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Military and civilian pilots searched today for a private plane believed down in the vast expanse of the Florida Everglades, while a physician told of surviving a separate crash in the same wilderness.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 30 -- Delegates of seven Arab states, composing the Arab League Council, adjourned tonight after having appointed a permanent committee for Palestine affairs and having handed over to a committee of legal and military experts the drafting of a collective security pact.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -- After eight months of secrecy imposed upon it by the United States Navy, Columbia Pictures was able to disclose today that its forthcoming picture, "The Flying Fish," will deal with the possible use of guided missiles launched from submarines in any war involving this country.

Boys and girls who want to blow bugles or beat drums in city parades can arrange for an audition by going to the nearest police station. The same goes for those with ambition to get into dramatic and musical radio programs, Deputy Police Commissioner James B. Nolan announced yesterday.

More than $200,000,000 has been made available for transit improvement in New York during the O'Dwyer administration, according to a report issued yesterday by the Board of Transportation. The report listed the proposed Second Avenue subway as the most needed large-scale item and suggested that the State Constitution must be amended to enable the city to provide the additional capital funds for further transit improvements.
Six new films are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 30 -- German official circles and private industrial leaders regard with the highest hopes the possibilities for advancing German diplomatic and economic causes in the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, once the ceremonies of formal membership by the Western Federal Republic are concluded tomorrow in Paris.

The opening concert of the fourteenth season of the New Friends of Music was given late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Hortense Monath, pianist, appeared as soloist in Mozart's Concerto in E flat major (K. 271), with the Saidenberg Little Symphony, Daniel Saidenberg conducting.
HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 30 (UP) -Nathan J. Klein, prominent business man and civic leader, said to night that he personally would as sume the $5,000 debt of Jefferson Military College in Washington Miss.

Preliminary observations on the effect of ACTH (hormone from the pituitary gland) and cortisone (hormone from the cortex of the adrenal gland) on certain types of malignant tumors were described yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Cancer Society at the Park-Sheraton Hotel.

The public money management authorities will run into trouble "directing" the economy in future year unless the present structure of bank-reserve requirements, based on geographical considerations, is revised, according to a study, "Economic Readjustment and the Money Market," issued today by Dean G. Rowland Collins and Research Director Marcus Nadler of the Institute of International Finance of New York University.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- President Truman expressed the conviction tonight that this country's "profound religious faith" made it strong enough to meet the challenge of leadership for world peace.

Very little stirred in the foreign exchange market last week, business being light and price changes unimportant. The recent wave of currency revaluations aside from producing these results has gone far in eliminating the nervousness which the trading fraternity faced as the week-end approached with its potential and "dreadful possibilities" ahead. Succinctly, the Friday-jitters are no more.

Eugene Istomin played the piano solo in Mozart's remarkable Concerto in E flat (K. 271) with the Philharmonic-Symphony on Saturday night in Carnegie Hall. The work appeared on a program with the first performance of Richard Arnell's Prelude, "Black Mountain," Gliere's Symphony No. 3 and Strauss' "Death and Transfiguration," all directed by Leopold Stokowski.

John B. Royce's Ch. Dah-Lyn Kai Jin of Caversham, a lively gaited 2-year old Pekingese, took best-in-show honors yesterday in the all-toy show sponsored by the Progressive Dog Club at the Livingston in Brooklyn. One hundred ninety-four dogs were entered in the event.

The Liberal party made public Yesterday its national platform advocating support of President Truman's foreign policy, elimina tion of the veto in the United Nations and establishment of a United Nations international police force.

There is no housing problem for Mr. and Mrs. George J. Bernhardt. Mr. Bernhardt is a stake boat attendant for the Reading Company and his employer, in addition to providing him with a floating four-room house, also permits him to do his work right on his own front porch.

Meir Grabowsky, majority lead er of the Israeli Knesset (parliament), who recently arrived here, expressed fear yesterday that the Arab nations might attempt an other attack on Israel. Because of this, he emphasized, Israel "dare not slow up the pace of immigration" to achieve a population of 2,000,000 by 1953.

United States occupation policy in Japan was approved yesterday and characterized as "ethical" by the Right Rev. Kenneth L. A. Viall, Suffragan Bishop of Tokyo, in a sermon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of Saint Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.

The average New Yorker is not too surprised, we feel certain, to learn that New York's streets are now more plowed up than at any time in the cites history. Almost everywhere we go we see either the extensive evidence of a contractor's repaving work or, perhaps, red warning flags and "Men Working" signs here and there in the road.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Marshal Tito's "national Communist" heresy has now assumed such international proportions that Moscow's grip upon orthodox Marxist ideology has been weakened. The effect in the realm of ideology has been at least as great as the effect of the weakening of the Soviet Union's political bloc in Eastern Europe by the establishment of an independent regime dominating the Adriatic Sea and the central Danube Valley.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- Academician Georgi F. Alexandrov, whose book, "A History of Western European Philosophy," was assailed in 1947 by Soviet critics, said in a lecture here that the mistakes in his work were "precisely those concessions to bourgeois philosophy which followed the route of bourgeois objectivism."
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 30 (UP) -A powerful task fleet of almost 100 fighting ships massed here today for the start of a three-week test of the Navy's anti-submarine defenses in the North Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development today reported a net profit of $3,162,980 for the three months ended Sept. 30, the first quarter of the bank's fiscal year.

More than 325,000 employes and union members have been affected by investigations by the State Commission Against Discrimination completed during the first nine months of the year, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- President Truman's delay in acting on the controversal farm price-support bill stirred speculation on Capitol Hill today.

Failure to acknowledge the Kingdom of Christ means a "chaotic and purposeless" life, the Rev. Timothy J. Flynn, member of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared yesterday at solemn mass presided over by Cardinal Spellman.

Vic Dyrgall, one of the country's top long-distance runners, retained the Metropolitan A. A. U. 25-kilometer road race championship yesterday. The 30-year-old accountant was clocked in 1 hour 31 minutes and 35.5 seconds. Approximately fifteen miles, the race was staged through the streets of the Bronx

The giant Dodge, Chrysler and De Soto plants in Detroit will close down Friday for lack of steel, throwing the great bulk of their 35,000 employes out of work, a spokesman for the Chrysler Corporation announced last night.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 -- The third annual assembly of the United World Federalists today called upon the United States Government to make the immediate objective of its foreign policy the transformation of the United Nations into a world federation.

A threat of further job action by sanitation workers, 1,200 of whom participated in a "sick" strike two weeks ago, was issued last night after a closed meeting of Local 333, United Public Workers, CIO, at the Hotel Diplomat.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 30 (UP) -The Green Bay Packers gained a 16-to-14 victory over the Detroit Lions before 10,855 fans today to climb out of the cellar in the National Football League's Western Division.

Net earnings of United States Rubber Company for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were $8,619,600 after all charges, compared with $15,216,798 in the corresponding period of 1948, a decrease of 43.4 per cent, Herbert E. Smith, chairman, said in a report to stockholders released for publication today.

Out of a memorable novel has come a memorable musical drama. The novel is Alan Paton's "Cry, the Beloved Country." The musical drama is "Lost in the Stars," which Maxwell Anderson and Kurt Weill have written. Under Rouben Mamoulian's direction, it opened at the Music Box last evening.

An accident involving seven riders eight minutes after the field of twelve teams had been sent on its way, marked the opening of the seventeenth international six-day bicycle race at the Twenty-Second Engineers Armory last night. A crowd estimated at 10,000 was on hand as Vincent Impellitteri fired the starting gun.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Nov. 8 Congressional elections in New York and California are already stimulating wide-range planning, plotting and speculating for the Senate and House contests of 1950.

J. S. Hewitt will retire as vice president in charge of sales of the Andrew Jergens Company of Cincinnati, effective Dec. 1 and will move to Florida where he will manage the activities of the Jergens company.

A continued survey of East Harlem in search of landlords' violations of the building code was promised yesterday by the Rev. Don Benedict, pastor of the 102d Street Church, a nondenominational storefront church of the East Harlem Protestant Parish at 201 East 102d Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Liquidation was on in lard futures on the Board of Trade last week with January and March selling at a new seasonal low level while the near-by months went into new ground in several months.

The opposition of Cardinal Spellman to the Barden Bill, which would deny Federal funds to parochial schools for any purpose, "is correct and Sound", Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday at ceremonies marking the dedication of the $1,000,000 grade school and auditorium of Our Lady of Mount Carmel on Bathgate Avenue, between 188th and 189th Street, the Bronx.

ROME, Oct. 30 -- The Congress of the Partisans of Peace, which has been meeting in Rome since Friday, closed today with two public meetings and a torchlight display. Except for the inaugural session Friday and today's meetings, all its proceedings were carried on behind closed doors.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks soared into a tie with Boston and New York for fourth place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 10to-4 victory over the Boston Bruins before 14,209.

A two-goal deficit before the game was half over failed to bother the Toronto Maple Leafs at all in their national hockey league clash with the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The Stanley Cup champions turned on the power just when they had to, and in so doing had little trouble humbling the New Yorkers by the score of 4 to 2.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The initial stock market reaction to the economy plan that the Government produced last week was one of relief. For at least a week before, the markets had been tormenting themselves by talking of almost every conceivable form of anti-capitalist taxation that the Government could and might impose.

In view of the harrowing theme it has to unfold, "Montserrat" ought to be completely devastating in the theatre. As put on at the Fulton on Saturday evening, the effects it achieves are mechanical. This is the French drama by Emmanuel Robles that Lillian Hellman has adapted an directed.
The Travelers Aid Society will make a special effort in its annual drive for funds here to put the important port division on the right side of the ledger, it became known yesterday.

WARSAW, Oct. 30 -- A purge of minor officials that may have major repercussions in the political life of Poland is now occurring, reliable sources stated today. Thus far there have been no arrests of major political figures, but enough Vice Ministers have lost their positions to give rise to speculation that there may be a parallel in Poland to the Rajk trial in Hungary.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The power-packed Philadelphia Eagles wrecked the Pittsburgh Steelers football "Cinderella Story" today by roaring to a 38-7 victory before 37,903 fans. The result broke a deadlock between the clubs and gave the Eagles undisputed possession of the top spot in the National Football League's Eastern division.

Declaring that the American people want an end to discrimination, with the enactment now of President Truman's civil rights program, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman appealed last night to Willkie Republicans to assert themselves on the issue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Hedging pressure is increasing in corn due to an enlarged movement from the country as harvesting is making rapid progress and farmers who have no crib room are selling their surplus grain.

The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday replies of the three Mayoralty candidates to a question of how the extensions to the city's transit system proposed by the Board of Transportation at a cost of $900,000,000 were to be financed, with union employes demanding wage increases that would add $72,000,000 to annual cost of operation.

I have known John Foster Dulles for thirty years, as a newspaper man and as a friend. In that period I have never known him to express an opinion even faintly touched with bigotry as to religion or bias as to race.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- A head-on collision between two automobiles this afternoon on Saw Mill River Parkway opposite the Mount Hope Cemetery resulted in the death of two persons and serious injuries to eight others.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Stepped-up efforts are being made by the Associated Paint Manufacturers of Great Britain to increase the sale of British paints in the United States market, following devaluation of the pound sterling, it was announced here today.

Five Stuyvesant Town families in addition to Dr. and Mrs. Lee Lorch are having Negroes as house guests and several more tenants soon will invite Negroes to use apartments for varying periods of time, it was announced yesterday by the Town and Village Tenants Committee to End Discrimination in Stuyvesant Town.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 -- There is no longer any question of a definite shortage of steel for some months after the steel strike ends, according to sales officials of steel companies here.
