Most sales offices continue to accept orders, it was said, but indications are that once the strike ends, these officials will re-appraise their order books to be sure that what they have to sell is fairly distributed.

In his fourth purchase of a Manhattan hotel property in two months, Louis Schleifer, operator, has acquired the Raleigh, a sixteen-story and penthouse building at 119-123 West Seventy-second Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, it was learned yesterday.

Put down this paper, now. This is no time to read over the second cup of morning coffee. On other days, yes, but not today. This is a special day. Put aside the second cup of coffee, put it aside and rise.

The wave of popularity that velveteen as a fashion fabric had in the summer months has continued and even increased in the fall, according to designers' collections in the shops. The fabric now is not only the collar of a dress or the small hat; it is the blouse, the coat, the skirt worn over taffeta or printed cotton.

The eighth annual James J. Hoey awards for interracial justice were presented yesterday to M. C. Clarke, Cleveland insurance executive and Negro Catholic layman, and Dr. John J. O'Connor, assistant professor of history at Georgetown University and secretary of the Catholic Interracial Council of Washington.

UTICA, Oct. 30 -- The Oneida County Democratic organization, centering its strength in the city of Utica, is an up and coming political machine with strong New Deal leanings. The organization has cemented its ties with labor over a period of years, and has made increasingly large inroads into the once strong Republican county organization.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The nation's shoe makers and retailers don't see much chance of cutting shoe prices. Leather continues high priced. They plan a sales promotional program next year.

The one-story taxpayer containing six store, including a unit in the Roulston chain, at 44-61-71 Twenty-first Street, in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Valben Realty Corporation, Y. BenZeev, president, to the M. S. F. Realty Corporation, operators.

All of the $3,447,500 of outstanding French Republic 7 per cent dollar bonds remaining of the $100,000,000 flotation in 1924 will be redeemed on Dec. 1, their maturity date, at 105 of their principal amount., J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., fiscal agents, announced yesterday.

Continuing his attack on the policies of the city's Department of Welfare, Representative Vito Marcantonio, the American Labor party's candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that the "flophouse" relief standards of Mayor O'Dwyer and Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard "menace the health of thousands of the city's needy and shock the conscience of all decent citizens."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- President Truman probably will attend the wedding of Vice President Barkley to Mrs. Carleton S. Hadley if he can spare time from the press of urgent executive business, his friends here said tonight.

They still are looking for their first victory, but the New York Bulldogs at least have ended their five-game string of defeats. With Bobby Layne holding his own in an aerial duel against Sammy Baugh, Ted Collins' team battled to a 14-14 draw with the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
TOKYO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Fifty thousand Japanese youngsters gave Frank O'Doul a thunderous send-off today and the Coast League manager gave them, of all things, a pitching exhibition.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Grain markets reacted on the Board of Trade last week after all deliveries of wheat except December, and all deliveries of oats sold at new seasonal high prices and despite the selling movement which developed later, largely in sympathy with soybeans, closing pric on wheat, corn and oats were still only slightly under the best prices of the season to date.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Guy George Gabrielson, Republican national chairman, told leaders of the party today they must make Republicans of the younger generation of voters if they hoped to be successful in the 1950 Congressional campaign.

Having recently returned from two weeks' active duty on an Atlantic Fleet destroyer, I have observed at first hand the present state of our Navy and would like to pass my conclusions on to your readers as sidelights to the disturbing reports from Washington during the testimony made by leading naval officers before Mr. Vinson's committee.

Maggie Teyte has a very devoted band of admirers, and almost 1,000 of them were on hand Saturday night when she gave a recital at Town Hall. They gave the British soprano an ovation when she first appeared and were loath to let her go when the encores were over.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The pound sterling fell last week on the black market here to the lowest level it has touched since Aug. 2, when rumors of approaching devaluation were at their height. It was quoted on Friday at 935 francs although the official rate is 980

The New York city and state campaigns enter the final week today with results problematical and with all major candidates scheduled to continue their appeals to the electorate until the eve of the election on Nov. 8.

Local government bond issues coming up for sale this week total $109,473,263, including $46,520,000 of temporary loan notes, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with $70,346,417 of offerings last week and a weekly average of $67,643,859 for the year to date.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Elmer H. Wene said tonight that Republican Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll "violated his personal word to the Constitutional convention" by seeking re-election.
Royal Canadian Mounted Police arrived in town yesterday but spent the day working around an improvised stable instead of parading down Fifth Avenue.
JUST a week ago in Philadelphia one New York newspaper man turned to another during Penn's rout of Navy and gasped when word of Fordham's crushing victory over Syracuse was announced.

The 432d anniversary of an October day in 1517 when Martin Luther, an Augustinian friar, nailed his famous "ninety-five theses" to the door of the Castle church in Wittenberg, Germany, and began a movement that eventually divided the Christian world, was observed yesterday as Reformation Sunday in Protestant churches throughout the city.

The Yugoslav Government charges in an official communique and a protest note that the Soviet bloc's second cold war, directed against Marshal Tito, is heating up to the stage of border incidents climaxed by an eight-hour but fortunately bloodless bombardment of Yugoslav territory by Hungarian border guards.

OSWEGO, N. Y., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin said tonight that he was confident former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, "as a United States Senator, will be of immeasurable aid to President Truman in carrying out the humanitarian program of the Fair Deal."

Members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Painters Club hung their first exhibition yesterday morning, and when the thirty-six pictures were up on the brown walls of the Carnegie Hall Art Gallery, it was discovered that only two of them had anything to do with music.

The sudden death of Edward R. Stettinius Jr. a few days after his forty-ninth birthday comes as a deep shock to the host of his friends and admirers in the world of business, of government and of education -- in all three of which he played so active a part.
MADRID, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Spain has offered to the North Atlantic powers a guarantee of active aid in any war with Russia in exchange for United States financial assistance, it was reported today.
PIMLICO, Md., Oct. 31 (AP) -- S. M. Newmeyer's Turbine came off the pace set by the favored Stud Poker and won the $3,000 Ameroid Purse by two and a half lengths in the mud before 8,000 fans today.
Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Mayor, accused Mayor O'Dwyer last night of using "deliberate and complete untruth" in his description of transit unification.

Larger refundings by public utility companies, states and municipalities lifted the total of bonds called before maturity for payment in October to $42,132,000, the highest monthly figure since June and the largest amount for a corresponding month since 1947.

This has been a fine season in our city and state for expressions of gratitude. In times of intense political activity not a day -- perhaps not an hour -- goes by but what somewhere the words thank you roll resonantly forth over a mass of upturned faces as a candidate for office or one of his supporters rises upon a hustings to deliver his message.

Features of the Little Orchestra Society's second series of Youth Concerts were announced yesterday. Thomas K. Scherman will conduct the six concerts starting Nov. 12, in Hunter College Auditorium, with the narrations of Milton Cross.

Marc Blitzstein ought to be well satisfied with the treatment the theatre has given him. In "Regina," which was sung at the Forty-sixth last evening, he has crossed the border-line between popular theatre and modern opera, and the theatre has kept step with him perfectly.

Over-all October dollar volume of independent home furnishings stores throughout the country declined 2 per cent compared with the like month last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the National Retail Furniture Association.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 -- Berlin will become the "capital of united Germany," Dr. Theodor Heuss, President of the Western German Federal Republic, promised today in a speech before 80,000 cheering Berliners.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 31 -- More than 700 production workers who have been on strike for three weeks at the National Union Radio Corporation, 1181 McCarter Highway, have pledged contributions to the Community Chest campaign of Newark, West Hudson and Belleville.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The 1948-49 recession is substantially over and business in the next six months probably will remain at the present level or increase, John M. Hancock, New York financier and a director of twenty-one corporations said today.

ALBANY, N. Y., Oct. 31 (AP) -The still - young Adirondack deer hunting season has claimed its third victim. Philip La Rose, 28, of Hudson Falls was shot and killed yesterday in the woods near Newcomb, Essex County. At least eleven other persons were hurt in hunting accidents over the week-end.
Several changes in this week's National Basketball Association schedule were announced yesterday by Walter Kennedy, publicity director of the pro league.
HONG KONG, Oct. 31 -- A more vigorous British Navy policy of openly protecting British merchantmen off the China coast was revealed today in a news release from Navy headquarters here.

Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, chairman of the Non-Partisan Doctors for Dulles Committee, issued a statement yesterday accusing former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman of vacillating on the issue of socialized medicine.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared last night that the Communist party had a "stranglehold" on the city's Welfare Department. It is using its power there, he said, to exact contributions from the needy and to win political support for Representative Vito Marcantonio, the American Labor candidate for Mayor.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, tonight announced an agreement with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation that provided noncontributory pensions of a minimum of $100 a month for employes reaching age 65 and having twenty-five years of service.

The eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 965 Fifth Avenue and the three-story dwelling at 2 East Seventy-eighth Street have been sold by Blanchen Realty Corporation to 965 Fifth Avenue, Inc., of which Julius Klorfein is president.
A new philosophy of hospital care will be put into practice in the city's municipal hospitals if the voters approve Amendment on election day, authorities said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A combination of soap and synthetic cleaners was described today by oil chemists as a boon to housewives.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- Governor Dewey announced today that a survey by top departmental officials revealed that the effect of the coal and steel strikes in New York State was "serious but will not be critical for another seven days."

BLUE RIDGE, N. Y., Oct. 31 -Had there been half as many deer as there were hunters along the slopes of Ragged and Wolf Pond Mountains over the week-end there would have been at least a few happy hunters in the camps that fringe this glorified tote road.

Total assets of the Ford Motor Company reached a high record of $1,149,240,000 at the close of 1948, according to the annual report filed yesterday with the Massachusetts State Tax Commissioner in Boston. The figure shows a rise of $123,507,000 from the $1,025,733,000 level at the close of 1947.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The Hungarian Government charged today that a platoon of Yugoslav troops had attempted an invasion into Hungary last Thursday night but was driven off by gunfire without casualties.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Liquidation by holders of December wheat and closing of spreads between that delivery and May resulted in the near-by month closing 2 1/8 cents a bushel lower on the Board of Trade today. Deferred months were unchanged to 1 3/8 cents off, the former on July which resisted pressure as the result of buying induced by reports that the President would sign the new farm support bill tomorrow.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 31. -- Some of the mightiest air and surface units of the Atlantic Fleet, scheduled to pit themselves against Arctic weather and submarines, sailed north from this and other East Coast ports today immediately following a Washington announcement that part of the flotilla later would be put out of action by a weapon the Navy cannot counter -- the "mothball."

ROME, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- The Roman Catholic Council of Bishops in Prague has demanded revision of the Communist church control laws to permit the church to administer her own internal affairs, the Vatican City radio said tonight.

The winner of the 1949 Hoover Medal is Dr. Frank B. Jewett of Short Hills, N. J., former president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories and the National Academy of Sciences, Scott Turner, chairman of the board of awards, announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 31 -Strong support for Mr. Hoffman's plea for an economic union in Western Europe was voiced today by the Netherlands in the full-employment debate of the United Nations Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Unemployment in the United States increased 225,000 in the month ended Oct. 8 and total unemployment reached 3,576,000, the Commerce Department reported today. The unemployment figure for October last year was 1,642,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The United States and Britain have decided to reopen the question of a Japanese peace treaty as quickly as possible, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A bill creating a National Trust for Preservation in the United States has been signed by President Truman, it was announced here today by Gen. U. S. Grant 3d. The general, who is president of the National Council for Historic Sites and Buildings, said that the council was taking steps to organize the trust and choose its trustees.

CHUNGKING, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Chinese Nationalist Defense Ministry announced today a counterattack had thrown the Communists back at a point near Tungan, Communist-held rail town ninety miles northeast of Kweilin.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Uniform play-offs in ties for major league basebal pennant championships will be considered by the Major League Council tomorrow. The session will be held at Versailles, Ky., where the Baseball Commissioner, A. B. Chandler, lives.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month expanded to the largest total since June, 1948. The period was also the most active October since 1946. Sales crossed the million-share mark in every full day's session with the exception of one.

WARSAW, Oct. 31 -- Polish officials have congratulated the Soviet Republics of Byelorussia and the Ukraine on the tenth anniversary of their annexation of Poland's former eastern territories, the press reported today.

Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, commanding general of the First Army, will receive the salute of the army teams of Ireland, Mexico, Chile and Canada at 9 o'clock tonight to give the sixty-first National Horse Show its formal start in Madison Square Garden.

A new method of preparing babies' formulas at home is being advocated by many health authorities because it's easier and safer than the usual procedure. This "terminal heating technique" is described in a booklet that the Evaporated Milk Association has just published at the request of the New York City Department of Health.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., former Secretary of State and the first United States delegate to the United Nations, died here today. He was 49 years old on Oct. 22.

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard charged yesterday that Representative Vito Marcantonio, the American Labor party candidate for Mayor, was a "vicious liar." Departing from the text of his prepared speech on the status of the city's relief rolls, Mr. Hilliard said to 500 social workers at a Welfare Council meeting in the Henry Hudson Hotel:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The contest board of the National Aeronautic Association announced a new safety program today in a bid to keep the big air races at Cleveland.

A new edition of the most popular book in the New York Public Library, the Bible, was added to the institution's collection yesterday by its designer, Bruce Rogers, who came down from his home in New Fairfield, Conn., to make the presentation.

A building loan of $1,335,600 has been obtained by the Bayshore Gardens, Inc., from the Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn on its six-story apartment building being constructed on the southwest corner of Brighton Eleventh Street and Cass Place in Brooklyn, according to the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, which issued the title insurance.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Using a technique reminiscent of automobile manufacturers announcing their models for the new year, the Electro-Motive Division of General Motors, last week unveiled three new models of Diesel railroad switching locomotives and displayed a Diesel passenger locomotive and a new type of heavy duty Diesel suitable for combination passenger and freight operation.

A new helicopter capable of carrying thirteen persons or an equal weight of cargo or mail was announced yesterday by the Bell Aircraft Corporation of Buffalo. Although the large rotary-wing craft is not in production its proto-types have been flying for three years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Iowa Power and Light Company, Des Moines, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $7,500,000 of first mortgage bonds due Dec. 1, 1979, that are to be sold at competitive bidding.

The Royal Philharmonic Orchestra of London and its conductor Sir Thomas Beecham, will make a concert tour of the United State and Canada next fall, it was announced yesterday. It will be the second foreign orchestra to visit these shores since the war.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar, Oct. 31 -- While the French insist that the Saar's attachment to France is "only economic," it is apparent here that the territory and its population of close to 1,000,000 have become nearly as much a part of France as Alsace and Lorraine.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 10 per cent last week compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 14 per cent.

Cooperative selling was urged yesterday as an answer to the challenge of a "declining economy." Before more than 125 members of the National Tool and Die Manufacturers Association annual convention at the Statler Hotel, Paul R. Hatch, sales director, Brown Sharpe Manufacturing Company, Providence, R. I., urged increased use of professional sales management services from outside industry sources as a recommended method for solving group-selling problems.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 31 -- Britain assailed the United Nations Trusteeship Council today as "a platform for ignorance, prejudice and polemics" during debate in the General Assembly Trusteeship Committee on a resolution urging administering authorities to place their colonial possessions under United Nations supervision when these have been merged with trust territories under international jurisdiction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A state dinner given by the visiting Mohammad Reza Shah Pahlavi of Iran in honor of President Truman will prevent the latter from attending the wedding of Vice President Barkley and Mrs. Hadley in St. Louis on Nov. 18.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- To some British Socialists Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul G. Hoffman's demand for provision of "direct incentives to private exporters" seemed as heretical as his plea for the immediate "integration" of the European economy was "utopian."

GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- Representatives of the Western German Federal Republic attended as full-fledged delegates a meeting of a conference on social security for workers in Rhine River navigation convened by the International Labor Office here today.

MINERAL WELLS, Tex., Oct. 31 (AP) -- A free press should be inherently antagonistic to the idea of expanding government and the multitude of new controls that accompany such an expansion, a Washington newspaperman said here today.

CHATHAM, N. Y., Oct. 31 -Governor Dewey told a Columbia County Republican rally tonight that the election of Senator John Foster Dulles would be "the best of all possible news to the parents and sons of America."

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 -- Motorists are the "obliterated men" in this country's election campaigns, particularly in the larger cities, such as New York and Chicago, delegates to the annual convention of the American Automobile Association here were told today.

A $1,000 first prize was awarded last night to Herbert Matter, a New York photographer, one of twenty-three artists whose posters on polio are on exhibition in the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, in a cooperative program by the museum and the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Theodore Kiisk, formerly an Estonian farmer, got his name and his picture in the papers Sunday when he and his family of four disembarked from the Army transport General Howze in this city. He and his wife and his three sons looked hale and happy. Mr. Kiisk received special attention because he was the 100,000th refugee admitted under the Displaced Persons Act of 1948.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 31 -- An echo of the effort by officers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to oust leftist groups from membership at their convention in Cleveland sounded here today in an application for a restraining order affecting two locals of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers.

Ten players have been designated by the Junior Davis Cup Committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association for honorable mention based on their playing records for the 1949 season, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. James H. Bishop of Culver, Ind., and Alrick H. Man, United States Davis Cup captain.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -Treasury Secretary John W. Snyder today invited proponents of a smaller national budget to put "their notions in specific terms." Mr. Snyder, scheduled tomorrow to address the annual convention of the American Bankers Association, now in session here, told a press conference that any substantial cut in expenditures could be made only through reducing the foreign aid and defense programs.

Invading the Democratic stronghold of Brooklyn, Senator John Foster Dulles declared last night that leaders of the Washington administration had taken over the campaign of his Democratic opponent, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Truman tonight vetoed a bill that would have provided $1,600 toward the purchase of an automobile for each World War I and World War II veteran who had lost use of one or both hands or feet or who had seriously impaired vision.

After years of laboring in the wilderness, Fordham finds itself back in the full glare of the football spotlight as the opponent of Army in one of the top games of the week and the only one the country over between major unbeaten powers.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday that he believed he could make a greater contribution in Washington to world peace and security than could Senator John Foster Dulles, his Republican opponent in the Senatorial race.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Eighty representatives of business, finance, labor, religion and the professions were taken into confidence today by top defense leaders on some of the country's plans and problems in creating an unbeatable defense team.

In a speech introducing a new degree of candor into relations between the United States and Europe, Economic Cooperation Administrator Hoffman has laid before the European Marshall Plan Council the "considered request" that it prepare both a record of accomplishment and a dynamic and far-reaching program for the economic integration of Western Europe.

The city's school building program is not keeping pace with increased enrollments and present construction needs are "well over" $500,000,000, the Public Education Association said yesterday in its fifty-fourth annual report.

Evelyn Eby and Reginald Bedford, duo-pianists who come from Canada, gave their first New York recital in Town Hall last night. They played a program happily composed mostly of original works for the medium, the best of them by French composers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -The Federal Communications Commission today gave limited license extensions to several big radio stations, pending a check of their national spot advertising activities.

Lutheran church membership in the United States and Canada totaled 5,950,735 persons in 1948, an increase of 114,588 over the previous year, it was reported yesterday by the National Lutheran Council, 231 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Senate race in New York State is by far the most spectacular in the nation, but political observers here, in checking results of the Nov. 8 election for a possible trend in the making for 1950, will be watching contests in five other states as closely.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- The Executive Committee of the National Jewish Welfare Board adopted today a budget of $1,474,485 to finance the organization's services in 1950 to Jewish community centers and Y. M.-Y. W. H. A.'s; to Jewish service men and hospitalized veterans, and to Jewish cultural agencies.

New York's gross funded debt was $2,956,918,919 on June 30, an increase of $64,513,040 over the $2,892,405,879 total on June 30, 1948, according to the report of Controller Lazarus Joseph for the fiscal year 1948-49, made public yesterday.
The second perjury trial of Alger Hiss, former State Department official, will start Nov. 17, Federal Judge William Bondy ruled yesterday. The first trial ended in a jury disagreement.

Much adverse publicity has appeared recently in the press on the harmful effects of salt, used by the Department of Sanitation for ice and snow control, on concrete and steel structures. After reading your editorial of Oct. 24, "More Road Building,"
Three of the five counties which comprise this city will vote on Election Day to fill the important office of District Attorney. Fortunately, there is good material available.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 31 -- Considered to have only an outside chance until a few weeks ago, State Senator Elmer H. Wene, the Democratic candidate for Governor, now looms as a dangerous threat to the continued Republican control of the state government.

The masters of the two Moore-McCormack liners Brazil and Argentina have been commissioned captains in the United States Naval Reserve in recognition of their wartime service, it was announced yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange became moderately active in the late trading yesterday and closed steady 9 to 23 points net higher than on Saturday.

Resumption of manganese ore shipments from Russia on a regular schedule but in quantities much reduced from normal, was reliably reported here yesterday. The Soviet recently delivered 6,000 tons of the ore in one shipment and reports yesterday were that Russia had scheduled similar shipments at two-to-three-week intervals from now until the end of the year.

Unable to reach an agreement after seven weeks of negotiations, the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and the committee representing Atlantic and Gulf Coast operators yesterday approved a second extension of their present contract in order that their talks might continue.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Tommy Wright, veteran professional from Kingsport, Tenn., whipped par by 5 strokes today to post at 33, 34 -- 67, to lead the qualifiers in the North and South Open golf tournament.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 31 -- The Dutch and Indonesians appeared tonight to be moving painfully toward a temporary compromise solution of the impasse on the status of Dutch New Guinea to allow the round-table conference on Indonesia to finish as scheduled on Wednesday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Hotpoint, Inc., today presented to dealers its 1950 line of electrical appliances, including improved electrical ranges, dishwasher-sink units and refrigerators.
The French Government completed negotiations last night for a $75,000,000 loan from a group of New York banks, it was announced here.

HONG KONG, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The Communist radio said today that Angus Ward, United States Consul in Mukden, was being held in jail with four consular employes pending trial before a Communist "Peoples Court" on charges of beating a Chinese employe.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, speaking of the United Hospital Fund, said recently: "I see the United Hospital Fund as an investment in the future of America. It represents a duty that has to be met."

Despite a poor showing in October, cool weather and holiday selling will clear fall and winter stocks of boys' wear, it was predicated yesterday at the merchandise showing of the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association in the Astor Hotel.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 31 -- The provision of the 1948 Displaced Persons Act requiring that 30 per cent of DP's admitted must be farmers probably will make it impossible to bring in the 205,000 authorized in the bill within the eight months left for issuing the necessary visas, Edward M. O'Connor of the Federal Displaced Persons Commission said here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The United States has asked the Czechoslovak Government to withdraw two of its diplomatic representatives to this country, stating their presence here is objectionable.
Financial circles buzzed yesterday with reports of a possible break in the steel strike but the stock market held to a narrow course and closed irregularly lower.

Gustave Ring's Galloping Gus was a galloping winner in the main act of the Empire City-at-Jamaica racing show yesterday. Despite the sloppiness of the track, he was timed in an estimable 1:12 2-5 for six furlongs in showing the way to four other 3-year-olds in a Class C handicap.

Directors of the Chief Consolidated Mining Company ordered the payment of a dividend of 5 cents on the common, payable on Dec. 1. This is the first dividend on the stock since 1938, when 10 cents was paid.

Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan yesterday cut a ribbon at Delancey Street, between Suffolk and Clinton Streets, symbolically opening to traffic the new south inner roadway of the Williamsburg Bridge.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 31 -Joseph F. Battley, Washington, D. C., president of the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, predicted today that the volume of business done by the industry this year will again top the billion-dollar mark, the third successive year that this figure has been reached.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Two reports will be published simultaneously tomorrow urging reforms in British industrial practice.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Action to make the North Atlantic Pact militarily effective was taken by two groups here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Capital Airlines announced today a proposal to recapitalize its present funded debt in a step to obtain money for new planes.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 31 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union and its Eastern European neighbors today of having deliberately incited passions on the Balkan issue and of having encouraged further violence to stir up "now languishing hostilities" in Greece.

The United Nations was luckier than the League of Nations in one important respect: it came into being after the world-wide development of radio and after television had taken its first long steps. Voices go instantly around the earth. Images will some time do the same.

Until industry becomes more sensitive to the needs of the public, "preposterous" attacks on corporations will continue to be widely believed, Frank W. Abrams, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (N. J.), warned 1,200 industrial leaders in the Statler Hotel last night.

The other evening at the County Center in White Plains an event took place which seemed to me to go far to offset the bad taste which the Affaire Peekskill left in many Westchester mouths. This event was, in effect, a rebuke to both sides (each in its own way intent on racial disharmony) in the Peekskill rioting.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 31 (AP) -- If the steel strike continues beyond Dec. 1, "scarcely a rivet will be driven on steel structures," N. R. Patterson of Tulsa, Okla., said today. Mr. Patterson, president of the American Institute of Steel Construction, spoke at the opening session of the twenty-seventh convention of the Institute.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 -- The anti-Communist majority won its first victory at the opening of the annual convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today when the delegates overwhelmingly approved the annual report of President Philip Murray who had bitterly attacked the left-wing leadership of some unions.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 -- Secretary of State Acheson today described the Point Four concept contained in President Truman's inaugural address as a long-range attempt to aid more than a billion and a half people, two out of every three persons on earth.

Local professional football coaches were around town yesterday accepting congratulations for the performances of their charges last Sunday. Norman (Red) Strader of the Yankees, Steve Owen of the Giants and Joe Bach, Charley Ewart's assistant with the Bulldogs, all agreed that things could not be rosier than they are at the moment.

A reduction of about 20 per cent in the maximum rents that the Federal Housing Administration set last August on apartments erected in this area by private builders with FHA mortgage insurance will become effective today on all new insurance applications.

Twelve interstate railroads, which seek permission to raise basic passenger fare rates 12 1/2 per cent in New York state, completed their case yesterday before Ernest A. Bamman, hearing examiner, at the Public Service Commission's offices, 233 Broadway.

ROME, Oct. 31 -- The Sacred Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith today advised pilgrims who intend to visit the Holy Land during Holy Year to avoid the area controlled by the Israeli Government because, it said, the pilgrims might be denied permission to enter the Arab zone.

An unexpected Treasury Department ruling which extends a 20-per-cent excise tax to all fur coats came as a shock yesterday to retailers here preparing for heavy holiday business. The ruling becomes effective immediately.

There can be no effective or permanent solution of the dollar shortage abroad unless North America, and especially the United States, assumes the role of furnishing a much larger and more reliable import market for goods which other nations have for sale, Donald Gordon, deputy governor of the Bank of Canada, said yesterday.

CHESHIRE, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Cheshire Academy's football team "follows directions" in a manner which would make any coach proud. And don't think Head Coach George A. James isn't proud of his unbeaten eleven. And, just as a reward for his spirited outfit, James gave his lads a respite from practice today.

Burglars entered a Gristede store in the Bronx some time over the week-end, placed the safe inside a large refrigerator to muffle the sound as they blasted it open and took $5,000 in Saturday receipts.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- As a consequence of the summer victories of Government forces in the Greek civil war, British troops will be withdrawn from Greece "in the near future," Christopher Mayhew, Parliamentary Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, announced in the House of Commons today.

Doris Day has been named to co-star with Ginger Rogers in Warner Brothers' "Storm Center." Miss Day will be seen as Miss Rogers' sister in the drama, which is to be directed by Stuart Heisler and produced by Jerry Wald. . . . Also from Warners comes news that "The Victim" has acquired Jacqueline DeWitt. . . .

Reacting to reports of possible early settlement of the steel strike, copper and zinc futures were traded actively on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday. Both ended the day up slightly over Friday's close.

Scout House, headquarters of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, was formally dedicated yesterday with the unveiling of a plaque recording the numbers of 706 local troops that had donated $5,625 to the building fund. The building is at 133 East Sixty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Truman plans a friendly wave of the hand but no whistle-stop speeches during his railroad trip to St. Paul, beginning Wednesday afternoon, the White House said today.

Frederic A. Phillips has purchased the one-family dwelling at the northwest corner of Oxford Road and Gardner Walk in New Rochelle, N. Y., from Marion D. Banks, Gertrude L. Fonda was the broker in the transaction, in which a purchase money mortgage of $15,000 was executed at the closing.

ROME, Oct. 31 -- A Cabinet crisis was precipitated this evening when the Right Wing Socialists decided to withdraw from Premier Alcide De Gasperi's Government, in which they had collaborated since December, 1947.

Michael S. Volante of 2135 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, a longshoreman for American Stevedores, Inc., dived off Pier 31, East River, where he was at work, at 2:45 P. M. yesterday, and swam about eighty feet to the rescue of a man who had fallen or jumped off the Manhattan Bridge, 120 feet above.

Mayor O'Dwyer issued a proclamation yesterday designating the period from Nov. 20 to Dec. 20 as "Organized Reserve Corps Month," and called upon the people to "acquaint themselves with the Organized Reserve program, both for the defense of the country and for their own personal security."

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 31 (AP) -Mrs. B. F. Lister's Evening Rose, the only filly in the field of seven competitors, splashed through sloppy going to triumph in the featured Lincroft Purse at Garden State Park today before a crowd of 13,749.
Amateur gardeners joined plant scientists, seedsmen and nurserymen yesterday at the fourth annual American Horticultural Congress at the Essex House, Fifty-ninth Street and Central Park South.

Opening to the general public tomorrow at the Brooklyn Museum is a remarkable exhibition of American folk sculpture, mostly of the nineteenth century. Not since the 1931 exhibition at the Newark Museum has such a group been assembled.

Quick response was won by the fashion collection shown by Ruby Ross of 6 East Fifty-third Street yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. Cocktail, dinner and evening fashions for the social season at hand made up the major part of the showing; however, a few smart afternoon frocks and a handsome coat also were included.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The State Department, still without direct word of the incident, commented today it was hard to "understand'' the charges on which Consul General Ward and four of his staff had been arrested. The consulate was said to have been under Communist guard for the past year.

A forthright attack on truck traffic congestion and wasteful practices in the trucking industry was made yesterday when the Port of New York Authority formally opened its $9,000,000 union motor truck terminal on the lower West Side.

George C. Sherman Jr. has been re-elected president of the Indoor Polo Association of America, it was announced yesterday. Delegates attending the meeting, held at the Union Club, represented clubs in Chicago, Detroit, Milwaukee, New Jersey and the metropolitan sector.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The Tucker "dream car," unveiled with a grand flourish before thousands at the Tucker plant here in June, 1947, had no transmission, no disk brakes, no hydraulic torque converter and no fuel injection system.

Tonight's events: Miklos Gafni, tenor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; "The Love for Three Oranges," City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; Gerda Christensen, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Richard Tucker, tenor, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -Wayne Coy, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today it was up to private business, not the Government, to provide television service in small cities.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The small amount of business transacted on the London stock markets today showed no price trend, and quotations in most sections closed at around Friday's levels.

Urging election of Herbert H. Lehman as Senator, Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, declared last night that Governor Dewey was supporting John Foster Dulles for the Senatorial post so that he, Mr. Dewey, could be the Republican candidate again for President in 1952.

The Union Motor Truck Terminal in downtown Manhattan near the Holland Tunnel which was opened to operation yesterday by the Port of New York Authority is a pilot plant which will be watched with great interest by the trucking industry and by cities plagued with traffic congestion. It is an expensive operation, looked at in one way.

Indian burlap mills, fully cognizant of the harmful effects on their products resulting from suspension of trade between India and Pakistan, have adopted a program to alleviate the situation, according to representatives of the India Jute Mills Association.

Flotations of new bonds here in October were off sharply from those of the preceding month and of a year ago. The total of $312,274,000 for sixty issues was the second smallest monthly figure of the year, next to the $290,561,000 for fifty-three issues in February.
The six-day bicycle race swept into its second session at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night, with ten of the original thirteen teams still pedaling around the eight-lap track.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced last night that it had entered into an arrangement with Al Jolson, securing his exclusive services for the next three years on radio and television. His first appearance will be as a guest performer on the network's leading shows.
By supplementing $600 with sixty man-hours of work, it is possible, even in these days of mounting prices, to acquire all the necessary pieces of furniture to fill a four-and-a-half-room apartment.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, called upon the Europeans today to demonstrate by early next year that they intend to move toward "an integration of the Western European economy."

HONG KONG, Oct. 31 -- Figures reported by the Peiping radio on food production this year in Manchuria and North China support the prediction made here last summer that a food shortage is certain this winter for a large part of Communist China.

The one-story taxpayer building at 2836 West Eighth Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Mollie Kaplan from Harry A. Illions. The property is on an irregular plot about 82 by 200 feet. David W. Kirschen was attorney for the buyer, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The President's order to the Secretary of Defense to "place in reserve" the authorization by Congress of $615 millions more for Air Force contract commitments than Mr. Truman recommended in his 1950 budget has raised another question of Presidential powers.
Representative Vito Marcantonio sought last night to win the support of admirers of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, whose reputation he defended against the "aspersions" of Mayor O'Dwyer.

The probability that the Bethlehem Steel Corporation settlement would lead to prompt termination of the strike against other major steel producers was indicated last night when Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, invited the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, to renew negotiations for a contract covering pensions and social insurance.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 31 (AP) -- A handful of workers, hastily summoned by telephone, entered Bethlehem Steel's Johnstown plant at 11 o'clock tonight to begin re-opening operations.

Foote, Cone Belding International has completed the first phase of expansion in Latin America, it was announced yesterday by Luis G. Dillon, executive vice president in charge of the operations. FCBI now has twelve Latin-American agencies associated with it, in addition to services of its own regional directors and other personnel.

TWO stunning victories over the week-end, each registered in spectacular fashion, provided most of the conversational fodder for the football folk yesterday. One was Fordham's totally unexpected but highly convincing 42-0 rout of Georgetown and the other was the pro-Giants' astonishing rally to topple the Cardinals, 41 to 38.

Suggestions for combining well-designed products of today with fine objects from the past were offered by Edward J. Wormley and Virginia Hamill last evening at the third lecture in a home-decorating course sponsored by the Home Fashions League.
PARIS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Following is the text of the address today of Paul G. Hoffman, Administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration, before the Council of Economic Cooperation:

Wichita Falls, Tex., announced yesterday that it would receive bids next Monday on issues of tax-exempt bonds totaling $5,108,000. The offerings will consist of $2,350,000 of general obligations and $900,000 of water revenue bonds, both dated Dec. 1, 1949, due Dec. 1, 1950 to 1974, and callable after fifteen years; and of $1,858,000 of refunding bonds dated June 1, 1950, due June 1, 1956 to 1969 and callable after fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board revoked today, effective Nov. 8, the operating certificate of Strato Freight, Inc., which operates air passenger service between Newark, N. J., and San Juan, Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Truman Administration has no intention of asking Congress for a third Marshall Plan appropriation unless Western European Governments can agree by January on a plan of economic integration that cuts across present state boundaries, it was said on high authority today.

Trustees of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and its four subsidiaries filed yesterday in Federal Court a profit and loss statement showing a net operating loss of $1,427,334 for the eight months ended Aug. 31. The loss was $464,600 less than the net operating loss for the comparable period in 1948.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- At an early hour this morning, when tellers at the forty-sixth annual meeting and election of the American Power Boat Association ended their counting, the regular admistration slate headed by the incumbent president, C. King Brugman of Los Angeles, was found to have defeated the opposition slate, largely represented by outboard drivers and headed by Albert A. Bauer of Philadelphia.

The general decline in cargo available in the Port of New York and the return of a large number of chartered ships to the Government has had a serious effect the towboat industry, a survey of the major companies showed yesterday.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, yesterday accused Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for re-election, of being "a perilous prophet and apologist for the Soviet military menace" in his campaign speeches.

On Oct. 24 Mrs. Rose Baran, founder of the New York Philanthropic League of the United Order of True Sisters, was 91 years old. Yesterday, a week later, she opened its two-day "tag" drive for the orthopedically handicapped.

A group of veterans' organizations, headed by the American Legion, Department of New York, began a campaign yesterday to defeat the proposed amendment to the state Constitution that would revise the existing system of giving preference to veterans in civil service.
Mayor O'Dwyer's condemnation of the transit unification deal of 1940 as a costly bungle was supported yesterday by Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 31 -- Gov. John W. Bonner has called a public meeting at the State House chambers Nov. 7 to hear recommendations and protests on proposals that 700 elk from the Gallatin area herd in south central Montana and 5,000 from the Yellowstone National Park's northern herd be killed or removed this season.

Chandler Cowles and Efrem Zimbalist Jr. announced yesterday that the New York premiere of Gian-Carlo Menotti's newly completed musical play, "The Consul," will take place early in January. The production-schedule calls for rehearsals to start the latter part of this month.

With the play of private international financial transactions still subject to the limitations of foreign exchange control, what is to be the future status of pledges made by foreign governments in the days of free exchange convertibility that they would service external debt in dollars or other specially designated foreign currency?

Increased horsepower and roominess were emphasized among sixty-four improvements in the 1950 Renault four-door sedan shown yesterday in a preview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The French-built cars will go on display tomorrow at the Renault Selling Branch, Inc., 1920 Brooadway, and dealer showrooms throughout the country, according to Pierre Pery, general manager of the organization.

If sociological studies were made on the span of human memories, particularly political memories, as applied to veterans, we have absolute proof that it is less than five years. Among the various public statements made regarding veterans, John L. Childs, speaking for the Liberal party in September, 1944, stressed the right of returning veterans to jobs and security.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 31 -- The Big Five have agreed on the machinery under which they will consult with each other before taking up important questions in the United Nations Security Council, Warren R. Austin, the United States representative, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Two Democrats and two Republicans on the House Armed Services Committee angrily attacked Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, and Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, today in the wake of the removal of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld as Chief of Naval Operations.

CAIRO, Oct. 31 -- Abul Huda Tewfik, Premier of Jordan, and Nazem el-Kodsi, Syrian Foreign Minister, who was chairman of the Arab League Council session that just adjourned, said at a conference for the Arab press today that none of the Arab states would negotiate directly with Israel.

CAIRO, Oct. 31 -- Abul Huda Tewfik, Premier of Jordan, and Nazem el-Kodsi, Syrian Foreign Minister, who was chairman of the Arab League Council session that just adjourned, said at a conference for the Arab press today that none of the Arab states would negotiate directly with Israel.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 31 -In separate statements, Gen. Sir Brian Robertson and John J. McCloy, British and United States High Commissioners, indicated today the Germans could hope for revision of the dismantling program. Both emphasized, however, that this must be done by decision of the Allied Government on a tripartite basis.

In a small way the New York Senatorial campaign is a sample of the world cleavage in political ideologies. If you care at all to preserve your political freedom, get out on Nov. 8 and place your vote for John Foster Dulles.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 31 -- Senator Robert A. Taft called upon President Truman tonight to make use of the Taft-Hartley Law to end the coal strike, which he said threatened the health of the people of the United States. He made his request in a statement distributed to the press.

The Treasury should be able to obtain sufficient funds from current revenues and sales of savings notes and bonds to meet its money requirements through the first quarter of 1950 without resorting to any new financing, according to the November issue of the Monthly Review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The report of the Distillers Corporation - Seagrams Limited, released yesterday, showed a net profit of $34,766,292, equal to $3.96 a common share for the fiscal year ended July 31. This represents a decline of 37 per cent from the $54,735,660 level of the preceding fiscal year, when the net was equal to $6.24 a share.

A sixty-day workhouse term and a $500 fine were imposed yesterday on a druggist accused of having sold 88,000 sleeping pills in the last twelve months "without a single prescription to show lawful distribution."

The Chase National Bank announced yesterday the etsablishment of a discretionary common trust fund which, with the approval of the New York State Banking Board, will be free to invest trust funds in securities other than those formally designated as legal for trustees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The farm bill providing high price supports of farm commodities through 1950, and a flexible system after that, became law today. President Truman signed the controversial measure without comment.

W. W. Grainger, Inc., of Chicago, Ill., manufacturer and distributor of motors and electrical appliances, has purchased the plot, 100 by 100 feet, at the corner of Mulberry and Chestnut Streets in Newark, N. J., from the Grover Investment Corporation.

ALBANY, Nov. 1 -- The city of Albany is electing a Mayor this year, and it takes no crystal ball or polling device to forecast the re-election of Mayor Erastus Corning 2d, candidate of the O'Connell organization.

Crayon, chalk and water-color pictures by the children of occupied Japan go on view today in the Young People's Gallery of the Museum of Modern Art. Selected by the teachers and sent to America through the Supreme Allied Command at the request of the American Association of University Women, the exhibition will go on an extended tour of branches of the association after the New York showing, which will end on Nov. 27.

An overall review of fashions to come, for spring and resort, was presented yesterday in Fashions of the Times, the eighth edition of this pageant, in Times Hall. The first of the eight performances that will be held during the course of the week afternoon and evening took place at the matinee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Captain Eric Rios Bridaux, pilot of the fighter plane which rammed the airliner here today, is director of civil aviation in Bolivia. He is 28 years old and has a wife and two daughters, 3 and 2 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Mrs. Eugenie Anderson, the Redwing, Minn., housewife recently named by President Truman to be the country's first woman Ambassador, asserted today that United States foreign policy is based on "deeply humanitarian" ideals and a "higher kind" of self-interest that "faces the facts of the modern world."

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Yugoslavia, which has been engaged for several months in negotiations for a five-year trade agreement with Britain, was reliably reported today to be seeking a credit somewhat larger than the 8,000,000 ($22,400,000) originally proposed in the negotiations.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Frenzied natives repulsed an attack by armed policemen tonight at Krugersdorf, twenty miles from Johannesburg, in a pitched fight in the darkness.
Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard regretfully accepted yesterday the resignation of Mrs. Ruth Whitehead Whaley as his executive assistant.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 1 -- While 85 to 90 per cent of displaced persons who have been resettled in the United States are adapting themselves rapidly to their new lives, problems have developed for the remaining 10 or 15 per cent, it was brought out here today at a twelve-state meeting here of state DP resettlement agencies.

British tool and die makers are more advanced than American tool shops in export sales and in making tools for deep stamping work, E. Slater of Slater Crabtree, Ltd., Wakefield, England, declared yesterday. He addressed more than 125 members of the National Tool Die Manufacturers Association during the annual convention in the Statler Hotel.
Lawrence A. Baker of Washington, D. C., was nominated yesterday for his third term as president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
VERSAILLES, Ky., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The major league council suggested today the elimination of baseball's young but storm-ridden bonus rule.
For the second successive week the New York Football Giants' official family was bursting at the seams with cheerfulness at the weekly luncheon in the Polo Grounds press room yesterday.

Sixty essays have been submitted in a contest conducted among disabled veterans in Army and Navy hospitals in this area, William Calhoun Hope, commander of the Crossroads of the World Post, No. 310, Veterans of Foreign Wars, announced yesterday.

A banking syndicate headed by Chase National Bank submitted the best bid yesterday for an issue of $4,000,000 of school bonds of Louisville, Ky., due on each June 1, from 1952 to 1987. The bid was 100.59 for interest rates of 4 per cent, 2 1/2 per cent and 1 3/4 per cent, an interest cost of 1.90776 per cent.

Theodore M. Riehle, 58 years old, president of John M. Riehle Co., Inc., insurance brokers of 234 West Thirty-fourth Street, had served as chairman of the Greater New York Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report since last July.
Thomas M. Belshe has been named vice president of Lear, Inc., manufacturer of aircraft instruments.

YONKERS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- Four armed robbers tied up the head of a shipping company and his family in their home here tonight, took $5,000 from one of two safes and escaped. The police believe the robbers had advance information about the layout of the house.

Settlement of the jurisdictional dispute between the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, and the American Guild of Variety Artists appeared likely last night. The Guild made two conciliatory moves that Mr. Petrillo said opened the way for adjustment of other differences.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- County Attorney Frederick H. Stang today charged at a Public Service Commission hearing that notices of a change in the West Shore Railroad timetable and the removal of two Weehawken-Albany trains, effective Sept. 25, were sent to railroad employes on Aug. 30, with instructions not to display them until Sept. 21.

Thirty-one celebrities from the stage and screen, the literary and sports worlds and other endeavors, all of whom grew up in Brooklyn, received "Youth Oscars" last night for the inspirational leadership they have provided for young Americans.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 -- Plans were approved tonight to expel two affiliates from the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America and the Farm Equipment Workers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee informally agreed today on a method of compensating for a revenue code "joker" that permitted the country's life insurance companies to go without paying taxes in 1947, 1948 and 1949.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- The European Federalist Union, closing its congress here today, voted in favor of the creation of a European supergovernment and of the admission of Western Germany into a federated Europe.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov, 1 -- There is no color television system ready for operation which both the public and the radio industry "can live with" and no accurate forecast is possible as to when color television will be available commercially, H. C. Bonfig, vice president, Zenith Radio Corporation, declared here today.

Combined net assets of the ten Keystone Custodian Funds at market value on Sept. 30, 1949, were $182,758,900, an increase of $9,130,300 compared with Sept. 30 last year, it was disclosed in the annual reports of Keystone Funds B4 and S1 made public yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 1 -- The spread of industrial pension systems, together with rising bank deposits and insurance company reserves, assures a plentiful supply of mortgage money for new building operations in coming months, Earl B. Schwulst, president of the Bowery Savings Bank of New York, declared here today.

I am surprised that your Oct. 20 report of Congressman Judd's attack on John S. Service of the State Department gives only one side of the news story. The United Press report of the same date quotes the department press officer, who pointed out that the White Paper on China had already published the "most forceful" parts of Mr. Service's document.
TULSA, Okla., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Capt. Joe Anderson of American Airlines, who saw it happen, called the crash of an airliner and a fighter plane over Washington today "an awful thing to watch."

Answering Mayor O'Dwyer's assertion that Communists had a "stranglehold" on the city's Welfare Department, Representative Vito Marcantonio termed this yesterday a "red herring" the Mayor was using to cover up his own inadequacies.

Paul H. Jaccard, president of the Swiss Association of Official Tourist Office Directors, will head a group of his country's tourist industry executives on an inspection tour of major resort areas in the United States, it was announced yesterday.

Manufacturers of women's apparel who opened their spring lines yesterday reported capacity showroom attendance and a satisfactory buyer response to styles shown. On the whole, early business for spring compares very favorably with last year, according to Leonard W. Gendler, executive secretary of Fashion Originators Guild of America.

Here for a few weeks' visit, kept short by the recent European currency devaluations, exiled King Peter of Yugoslavia, his Queen, Alexandra, and their 4-year-old son, Prince Alexander, were among 737 passengers who reached New York last night on the Cunard-White Star liner Caronia.

MONTREAL, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Doug Bentley, veteran center of the Chicago Black Hawks, moved into first place in the National Hockey League's individual scoring race with 11 points, official statistics revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The failure of Congress to lift restrictive provisions of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948, it was learned today, will force a 50 per cent reduction in the number of Europe's homeless who can be admitted to the United States this month.
A helicopter took off from Newark Airport yesterday and demonstrated its ability to fly about the metropolitan area without interfering with the commercial airlines at the busy airports in the zone.

Mayor O'Dwyer and John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, joined yesterday in bringing a $1,000,000 suit for libel against The New York World-Telegram for a story about the sale of city tax liens.

Former State Transit Commissioner Reuben L. Haskell, a Brooklyn Republican, told a radio audience last night that he was opposed to the election of Newbold Morris as Mayor because he did not have the ability to cope with the complexities of the city's finances.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- Predictions of pessimists have proved unfounded and American business in 1949 is having "another tremendous year," Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder told bankers here today. The bankers were among 4,000 high executives from all sections of the country now attending the seventy-fifth annual convention of the American Bankers Association.

The four designers, Travis Banton, Norman Norell, Christian Dior and Castillo, invited to contribute to the scene "Fashions of the Ages," accepted the challenge in brilliant manner, creating gowns of extravagant beauty.
G. Fred Rieman has been appointed director of sales of Ball Brothers Company of Muncie, Ind. Philip W. Hatch has been appointed sales manager of the company's commercial products division.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 1 -- Dr. Howard A. Rusk, director of the Institute of Rehabilitation at New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, said today that the United Nations had the opportunity to work out a "true cooperative venture" in the handling of disabled persons between the Eastern European nations and other countries.

The Transamerica Corporation's sale of more than a million shares of stock of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association was described yesterday by Sam H. Husbands, Transamerica's president, as "another step in the voluntary move to reduce Transamerica's holdings in Bank of America, a move started in 1937 when Transamerica distributed 58 per cent of the bank's stock to the corporation stockholders."

Marketing of new issues of public utility bonds and preferred stocks will run to more than $100,000,000 this month, beginning this week with the offering of $15,000,000 of $4 stock of the Union Electric Company of Missouri, which bankers bought yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Soviet diplomacy, having embarked upon a Rapallo policy of collaboration with the East German Democratic Republic, is now engaged in an act of political ventriloquism that is producing some rather odd statements emerging from curious mouths.

Open warfare on the floor of the CIO convention between the anti-Communist leadership of the CIO and the Communist-line leadership of some of the CIO unions is unfortunate in that it represents another bitter split in the ranks of labor that will intensify the raiding and union rivalry and make stable industrial relations more difficult.
Two new teams, Southern Methodist and Michigan State, moved into college football's "first ten" yesterday and one of them, Michigan State, took an immediate bead on the No. 1 spot held by Notre Dame.

The even tenor of Signor de Gasperi's Government in Rome has been jarred suddenly by another of the recurrent disputes among the Italian Socialists. From the governmental viewpoint it is "a trifling crisis," as the Premier put it. The Christian Democrats have a majority and can get along without the aid of Signor Saragat and his associates.

In its second expansion move, the Tobe-Coburn School for Fashion Careers, has rented from the Tishman Realty and Construction Company the entire second floor of the business section of the twelve-story apartment house on the blockfront on the east side of Madison Avenue, from Seventieth to Seventy-first Street, according to William B. May Co, brokers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Fifteen leading German jurists started today a three-day visit to Yale University as part of their tour of the United States to learn about American cultural and legal institutions.

Encouraged by developments in the steel strike, which traders interpreted as meaning an early settlement of the dispute, both copper and zinc gained in price in active trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday.

On the anniversary yesterday of the founding of the first YWCA in this city in 1870, nearly 300 persons gathered in the Central Club for Nurses of the Young Women's Christian Association for its rededication as Morgan Hall.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Donald C. Cook, Washington attorney,
Raymond B. Deane Jr., who lived at Glenwood Gardens, Yonkers, was an assistant executive on the national sales staff of the American Newspapers Publishers Association.
Mid-air collisions between commercial airliners and private or military aircraft are infrequent but by no means unique.

GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- The view is now widely held in Britain and on the Continent that the next major structural change in the world economy consequent upon the prolonged sterling crisis will be the taking over by the United States of part of Britain's role as banker for the sterling area.

Proposed Amendment 5 to the State Constitution, which would revise the system of preferences granted to disabled and non-disabled veterans in civil service, was assailed and defended yesterday by different groups of veterans.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Capt Eddie Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Airlines, said tonight that the crash of one of his planes at Washington was "horrible, just dreadful." Captain Rickenbacker was in Indianapolis when the crash occurred. He took an airline plane to New York to confer with other officials of the company and then was scheduled to go to Washington to conduct his own investigation of the crsh.

A predominate number of representatives of larger manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers believe that the level of business activity in the first quarter of 1950 will be as good or better than in the initial quarter of 1949, according to a survey by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 1 -- An unusual split within the ranks of organized labor has added to the complexity of the hotly contested New Jersey race for Governor and has resulted in both major party candidates' making claims to the support of union members.

Only three of the five Borough Presidents are candidates for re-election next Tuesday. The unlamented Hugo Rogers has been dropped from the Manhattan scene, and James A. Burke, in Queens, is not a candidate for reasons of health. Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx is running as usual.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Japanese bonds rose sharply in the London stock markets today on reports from the United States that Japanese peace treaty talks would be resumed shortly. This movement was the feature of an otherwise quiet, steady day.
Ralph C. Horton, 50, of Dogwood Lane, Rye, N. Y., was president of the Horkins Securities Corporation, 70 East Forty-fifth Street, this city.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 1 -- After ten weeks' arduous bargaining, the actual work of the round-table conference on Indonesia was concluded successfully today. A ceremonial plenary session will be held tomorrow to approve the painfully achieved agreements bringing to an end 300 years of Dutch rule over the rich, strategically situated archipelago.

Four new Federal judges and a new United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York were sworn in yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox in ceremonies in the Federal Court House. All are interim appointments subject to Senate confirmation.

The Government conceded in the United States Circuit Court yesterday that the eleven Communist leaders had an "arguable" point on appeal in their contention that their conviction was unconstitutional under the Free Speech Amendment.

Miklos Gafni's New York debut in February, 1947, was received with such acclaim that when the young Hungarian tenor came back last night for his second local recital, Carnegie Hall was filled and 200 persons occupied seats on the stage.

Use of plastic products as premium offers by advertisers, estimated as nearly half the total volume in the field last year, will increase even further, it was declared yesterday by J. R. Turnbull, sales manager of the Monsanto Chemical Company's plastic division.
The conviction of the top eleven Communists was "viewed realistically" yesterday by Louis Waldman, labor lawyer, as outlawing the Communist party.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 -- Reforms in automotive construction indicating that manufacturers are heeding protests by motorists against extravagant and exaggerated post-war car design were emphasized today at the 47th annual meeting of the American Automobile Association here.
GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- The United Nations Kashmir Commission has agreed on the main outlines of its report to the Security Council, which it expects to complete about Nov. 20, it was learned here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- A two-year agreement between the American Federation of Labor national organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots and the Pacific Maritime Association, bargaining agent for the West Coast shipping industry, was announced here today by Omar Hoskins, Federal mediator.

Hugh Quinn, City Council member from Queens, looked with mock dismay over the group of business and professional men who had come to honor him yesterday at a luncheon of the Commerce and Industry Association at the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street.

Parents who find the punishment-reward system of discipline the only practical way of doing business with their youngsters are in "a pretty bad spot" and had better start digging for the basic cause of their trouble, Mrs. Anna W. M. Wolf of the family counseling service, Child Study Association of America, said yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 8 to 17 points lower.

The sixty-first National Horse Show had its formal opening in Madison Square Garden last night and brought in its sparkling train a touch of pageantry, the amenities of society, the flash of fashion and the fire of competition on horseback.

Campaign appearances on behalf of the candidacy of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman by Administration officials and "erstwhile upper-echelon New Dealers" were criticized yesterday by Representative William L. Pfeiffer, chairman of the New York State Republican Committee.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers nipped the Chicago Stags, 89 -- 87, tonight. Carl Braun led a final-quarter New York rally to tie the score and then starred in overtime action.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 1 -- The United States assured the underdeveloped nations today that technical assistance and other aids to their economic development through its bilateral programs or the United Nations were intended to facilitate the development of their economies along any lines reasonably appropriate to their natural and human resources that corresponded to their wishes.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 1 Usually reliable sources said tonight that troops in the capital had been ordered concentrated in their barracks at dusk and their officers ordered to join their units at once. Official confirmation was not available.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- A frank story of frustration and failure was told today in the first annual report on Britain's biggest and costliest colonial development project, the super-ambitious plan to grow peanuts on millions of acres of previously uncultivated wild bushland in East Africa.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 -- Nick Cullop, former pilot of two American Association teams, today signed a contract to manage the Baltimore Orioles of the International League for the 1950 season.

One hundred years ago this month, fifty employes strong, the Brooklyn Gas Light Company opened its first line and began illuminating the rutted lanes of a dozen separated Brooklyn communities with hand-lit street lamps.

Belin, a 3-year-old colt owned by Clifford (Old Rockport) Mooers and trained by Earl Sande, did a front-running job on the opposition in the Class C handicap that had top billing at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday. At the end of the mile and a sixteenth he was three-quarters of a length to the good after having led by as much as eight lengths in the backstretch.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 1 -- The world situation is no better than in 1946, President Ismet Inonu told the reconvening National Assembly today in his annual speech reviewing Turkey's foreign relations and internal affairs.

John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for election to the Senate seat he holds by appointment, charged last night that the city's fur, cosmetics, luggage and jewelry industries, employing thousands of workers, were "being held back by a punitive 20 per cent Federal tax."

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat, of New Mexico, declared today Spain should receive military and economic aid from the United States to bulwark Western Europe's security.

The annual Army and Navy football classic, plus the colorful pre-game ceremonies, will be brought to the television audience by the National Broadcasting Company network on Saturday, Nov. 26, from Municipal Stadium in Philadelphia.

ALBANY, Nov. 1 -- Secretary of State Thomas J. Gurran, chairman of the state Board of Commissioners of the Land Office, announced today that the board had granted an easement to the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation for construction and operation of a natural gas line on state lands in the bed of the Hudson River from the New Jersey shore to a point opposite West 134th Street, Manhattan.

Several important line-up changes went into effect yesterday as Coach Frank Tubridy continued his revitalization of the City College football team for Saturday night's encounter with Brooklyn College at Ebbets Field. Tubridy has planned an all-out aerial attack and this week's preparation will be devoted to polishing the Beavers' passing and their defense against the Brooklyn single-wing.

We are pleased to note that President Truman has signed the bill creating a National Trust for Historic Preservation in the United States. The law will facilitate public participation in the saving of sites, buildings and objects of national interest. The Trust can receive donations of such shrines and administer gifts of money.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 -- The bank account and safety deposit box of Local 601, United Electrical Workers, CIO, has been raided by right-wing members of the local and about $200,000 in assets sequestered.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- John L. Lewis today called the United Mine Workers policy committee to a meeting in Chicago on Monday in what appeared to be a tactical maneuver in the 43-day-old coal strike.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Leon H. Keyserling became Acting Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers today as the resignation of Chairman Dr. Edwin G. Norse became effective.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The National Labor Relations Board has asked the Supreme Court to mend the ways of the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals, covering six Southern states, declaring that court has thrown out, or modified, "an inordinately large number" of board cases.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, branded today as "ridiculous and untrue" charges made last week by Ezra Van Horn, coal operators' representative for the United Mine Workers' welfare and retirement fund, that the fund had been "dissipated" and that he shared responsibility for it.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 1 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley and Mrs. Carleton S. Hadley, announced today they would be married at 11 A. M. on Nov. 18, in the Chapel of St. John's Methodist Church here. Bishop Ivan Lee Holt will perform the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Albea Godbold, pastor of the church, one of the largest in this area.

A distinguished assemblage was at the first evening session of the sixty-first National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden.
