Persons prominent in society and in diplomatic, military, arts and professional circles were greeted on their arrival in the lobby by the traditional barrage of flashlight bulbs of photographers, and by reporters.

The stock market made a gingerly response yesterday to the Bethlehem steel strike settlement. But, once the reaction became evident, prices were bid up to new highs for the current movement, the averages rising 1.04 points. Although heavily traded, the steels did not share in the upturn and remained passive toward the first break in the industry's tie-up.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Frank M. Mayfield, St. Louis retailer and former president of the National Dry Goods Association, warned today that prices are in the middle of a serious decline that will continue at least six months. He spoke at a luncheon for shoe manufacturers and retailers attending the National Shoe Fair.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The State Department, in a statement of record today, said that investigations conducted by the United States Ambassador to Iraq had not substantiated charges by Israel that 2,000 Jews had been imprisoned in Iraq.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Mayor, laid squarely on Mayor O'Dwyer's Administration last night the responsibility for Communist domination of the city Welfare Department, of which the Mayor had complained the night before.

Capt. George Ray of 77 East Lake Drive, Mount Kimball Lake, N. J., pilot of the transport plane, was born in Vladivostock, Siberia, of Russian parents who fled at the time of the Bolshevik revolution. He had never before been in any airplane mishap.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 1 (AP) -- William A. Julian, late Treasurer of the United States, left an estate of $4,457,988.41. He was killed in an automobile accident near Bethesda, Md., May 29. His wife, Mrs. Gertrude E. Julian, died March 25.

IT'S really the doggondest thing. The Fordham football team, like Topsy, apparently "jes' growed." It was such a harmless-looking toddler a year ago. It wouldn't have hurt a child, much less another football team. And all of a sudden it began devouring giants, swallowing them whole.

Set down among the most thoughtful of expressions that sentence -- more often spoken mentally than aloud -- "It was well worth it." The situation is as follows: All night long there was gay laughter, and dancing to the tune of a piper.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 1 -- Foxzami, 4-year-old bay colt, owned by L. G. Robinson of Lord Howe Island, won the Melbourne Cup at Flemington today by one length and a half from Hoyle. Benvolo was third, a neck farther back.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The Government's loans to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation were brought up to a jury in Federal District Court today in the fraud trial of Preston Tucker and seven associates in the Tucker automobile manufacturing program.

Broadway's leading stage couple, Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt, will observe the twenty-fifth year of a notable acting partnership with their joint appearance tonight at the Shubert in "I Know My Love," directed by Mr. Lunt, First-nighters are requested by the sponsors -- the Theatre Guild and John C. Wilson -- not to dilly dally and to be in their seats promptly at 8, when the curtain will go up.

Keyed to the lively rollicking tempo that paced the entire production, the eighth edition of "Fashions of the Times" unfolded to a spirited start yesterday at Times Hall when the curtains swung back on a fast-moving pantomime of those famous harbingers of spring in New York -- baseball, the circus and a hansom cab ride in Central Park.

The first break in the month-old steel strike has come suddenly and in an unexpected quarter. While the nation was watching United States Steel and wondering how long the stalemate between management and labor on that front could last, Bethlehem (Little Steel) announced that it had reached an agreement with representatives of the union on the moot issue of pensions.
The collision of an Eastern Air Lines transport and a twin-engine fighter plane at Washington yesterday was the worst accident in the history of commercial aviation in the United States.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The Roman Catholic Church in this country became a legal adjunct of the Communist state today as the church control laws went into effect, but high church sources indicated Catholics would continue to protest.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Paramount, the attraction is "Chicago Deadline," a Paramount romantic melodrama, starring Alan Ladd. Lewis Allen directed and Robert Fellows produced from a screen play by Warren Duff and a story by Tiffany Thayer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The press of business in his home district, causing a day's delay in attending a national defense conference here, put Representative George J. Bates, Republican, of Massachusetts, on the airliner that crashed this morning near National Airport, taking his and fifty-four other lives.

Two months ago a union representing 2,400 John Wanamaker workers in New York announced it would spend $6,000 on advertising and promotion to increase the store's business. Yesterday the union raised the ante to $27,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 1 -- Indiana has a Democratic Governor, Henry Schricker, who is being urged to run for the Senate next year to break the long tenure of Senator Capehart, but at first glance it seems more definitely Republican than other states in this traditional GOP stronghold -- and Republican in the Old Guard sense.
What's new for the kitchen? Nothing revolutionary perhaps, but several gadgets are being introduced that lighten culinary careers.

Coach Lou Little began efforts to break in a new pair of right halfbacks during a long and intensive offensive scrimmage for his Columbia eleven at Baker Field, yesterday. The drill consisted mostly of running plays against the regular defensive platoons.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- Dr. Theodor Heuss, president of the Western German Federal Republic, devoted the second day of his state visit to Berlin to the younger generation today, and he was as enthusiastically acclaimed as he was yesterday by the mature population.

STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Jim Lookabaugh, football coach at Oklahoma A. and M. College for the past eleven years, resigned today, effective at the end of the present season. Lookabaugh's resignation was tendered to the athletic cabinet and accepted immediately.

HONG KONG, Nov. 1 -- Reports that Indo-Chinese Communist guerrillas were probing across the frontiers of Tongking into China coincided here today with evidence of further development in the far-ranging Chinese Communist offensive against Kwangsi and Southwest Kwangtung.

In the record of expenses for the Roosevelt Hospital for 1875, one item is for 34 pounds of lobsters for $3.40. The 67,497 pounds of beef used by the hospital that year were bought at about 15 cents a pound. In 1948 the hospital paid an average of slightly more than 66 cents a pound for its beef.

Gardner W. Taylor of 8 Locust Lane, Bronxville, N. Y., was the founder and only president of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York since it was organized in 1934. He was 60 years old.

Small parks may rank high in Robert Moses' announced plans, but to people like us in the East Midtown area plans do not fill a present and pressing need. In the crowded district between East Forty-fifth and East Fifty-fifth Streets there are two "parks" which at trifling expense and little effort can be made available for mothers and infants.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Sutherland Paper Company, Kalamazoo, Mich., had filed with it a registration statement covering 34,400 shares of its $100 par value cumulative preferred stock.

TRENTON, Nov. 1 -- Federal District Judge Phillip Forman ruled yesterday four national manufacturers of variable radio condensers have infringed the anti-monopoly provisions of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.
A proposed capital budget of $223,432,672 for 1950, just $14,488,132 lower than the tentative budget made public on Oct. 7 was adopted yesterday by the City Planning Commission at City Hall.

COLLECTIONS of photographs are in some respects the most alluring of all books. The temptation to lay everything else aside and flip through their pages is almost irresistible. Since the cave men drew bison and boars on the most inaccessible walls of their dark and smoky shelters men have been fascinated by pictures. And modern photographs have much to offer: drama, "human interest," news coverage, portraiture and, sometimes, startling beauty.

The appointment of William E. Berchtold, executive vice president of the Foote, Cone Belding advertising agency, as chairman of the business men's committee for the 1950 finance campaign of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, was announced yesterday by the campaign general chairman, Nathan M. Ohrbach.

The Packard Motor Car Company disclosed yesterday that consolidated net sales reached a new peacetime high of $187,197,673 in the first nine months of the current year. The volume was $164,325,977 in 1948.

Pending determination of test rent cases by courts, landlords must comply with the Sharkey Rent Law freezing rentals at March 1 levels, Charles G. Coster, chairman of the City Rent Commission, warned yesterday. Tenants were requested to report violations to the commission.

HONG KONG, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The Communist New China News Agency reported today that thirty-five Chinese employes of the United States Consulate in Mukden are staging a sit-down strike in the consulate to protest "forced firings."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A thoroughly modernized basis for relations between the United States and Argentina, anticipating a pact to replace the outdated Treaty of Friendship, Commerce and Navigation of July 27, 1853, should be reached by the end of this month, according to experts on both sides of the Joint Trade Commission, established last May.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP) -- What makes a "tired business man" tired? Maybe, says the Benjamin Franklin Clinic of the Pennsylvania Hospital, because he:
GALVESTON, Tex., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Longshoremen at west Gulf Coast ports today accepted a seven-cent hourly contribution to a union benefit fund and wiped out plans to strike.

President Truman's Point 4 program will constitute a test of the ability of the members of the United Nations "to work together in good faith," Carlos P. Romulo, president of the U. N. Assembly, said yesterday.
ALBANY, Nov. 1 -- Governor Dewey, acting to meet a possible state emergency because of the steel and coal strikes, announced today the appointment of an emergency commission and a six-point program.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 1. -- Argentina today attempted to break the three-year deadlock in the United Nations arising out of the procedure for electing new members. Faced with an apparently hopeless blockade of fourteen countries applying for membership, Dr. Jose Arce, former Assembly president, submitted a resolution that recommended an appeal to the International Court of Justice.
BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Nov. 1 -- Mario Cafagno, young Lake Mohawk pro, and Mrs. Herbert Croft captured a New Jersey PGA pro-lady tournament today with a 33, 32 -- 65 at the Forest Hill course.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Truman predicted today that the Federal Government would pile up a deficit of $5,500,000,000 in this fiscal year as the result of record peacetime expenditures and declines in revenues.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 1 -- A subcommittee of the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly completed today three weeks of debate on proposals for the disposal of the former Italian colonies. An Argentine proposal to submit a single resolution, instead of a separate resolution for each of the colonies, was approved 10 to 9 over the opposition of the United States.

POMFRET, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Pomfret School's spirited football team, defeated in its first four contests, has been confronted with a major problem this season and that problem has been lack of seasoned replacements.

Boston is rapidly improving its port facilities and within fifteen years will regain the position it held forty years ago, when it was one of the busiest ports on the Atlantic Coast, Judge James R. Nolen, chairman of the Boston Port Authority, said here yesterday.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- While 1,000 spectators shivered on a runway and military planes maneuvered in bleak skies, ceremonies were held at the Westchester County Airport here this afternoon to mark the beginning of the county's first regular passenger, cargo and mail service by a major airline.

Twenty-two games between local Catholic high school basketball teams have been scheduled as preliminaries to home contests of the professional New York Knickerbockers at Madison Square Garden and the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- General short-covering developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today, and prices advanced rapidly after showing easiness early. Closing trades were about at the top, with corn showing net gains of 1 3/8 to 1 3/4 cents.
Belding-Corticelli, Ltd., has declared the usual quarterly dividend of $1.50, plus a year-end extra of $1 on the common, both payable on Jan. 3. A similar extra was paid last year.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman pictured Senator John Foster Dulles last night as a wrong guesser on international problems time and again during the period leading to this nation's involvement in World War II.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. l -- James G. Plunkett, 46-year-old insurance and real estate operator, shot and killed his wife Esther, 38, at their home on Farms Road today, and hours later attempted to end his own life with the same revolver. He is in Stamford Hospital in serious condition with a bullet wound in his chest.

Unification of command is the law of the land. Contrary to the impression created by much of the current talk, it was not railroaded through Congress without affording an opportunity to the Navy to present its views. The Navy's high-ranking representatives opposed unification before the Congressional Committee on Post-War Military Activities, .and later testified at great length while the act was being debated in Congress.

College girls who feel well-dressed indicate a better social adjustment, according to personality rating devices, than those who are concerned about their appearance, Dr. Dorothy Stepat of Hunter College's Home Economics Department, said yesterday.

Six players from the American loop and four from the National circuit make up the 1949 major league All-Star team selected for The Associated Press by 116 members of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. (AP) -- A mid-day downpour that caught half of the field on the course washed out today's opening round of the North and South open golf tournament. As a result, the 36-hole final of this 72-hole, $7,500 event will be staged Friday instead of Thursday.

Public utility companies continued with the financing of plant expansion programs yesterday by selling to banking syndicates two new issues of preferred and common stock valued at more than $17,400,000. The awards were as follows:

Michael J. Kennedy served as a Representative in Congress for two terms, giving up his seat to become leader of Tammany Hall on April 14, 1942. He assumed his new duties with high hopes, declaring that he had "one primary objective: to conduct the affairs of Tammany Hall at all times in the interest of good government."

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- In reply to the speech of Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, yesterday urging the economic "integration" of Europe, Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that Britain could not integrate her economy with Europe's "in any manner that would prejudice the full discharge" of her responsibilities as leader of the British Commonwealth and the sterling area.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Nov. 1 -- The Saar's industry and coal mines are now producing at nearly the same levels as they did when they supplied Nazi Germany with one-tenth of her iron and steel and one-sixteenth of her coal. The difference is that all products are going into the French economy now.

Almost unnoticed in the multitude of other events, a new nation has appeared in the councils of the Western World in the shape of the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany. It has replaced the Allied Military Governors as representative of the German people in the European Marshall Plan.

With 77,000 workers of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation back on the job, Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, indicated last night that he might have another strike settlement to announce today.

A brilliantly attired audience, numbering among it such well-known personages as Gen. and Mrs. Carlos P. Romulo and Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, made the opening of the sixty-first National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden one of the most gala in many seasons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Vice Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, a 53-year-old naval airman who helped draft the blueprint for unification of the armed services, has been chosen as Chief of Naval Operations, the White House announced late today. He will succeed Adiral Louis E. Denfeld, who was summarily relieved last Thursday by President Truman in the wake of Congressional hearings on the Navy's discontent with defense policies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A P-38 fighter plane today rammed and cut in two a commercial airliner about to land at the National Airport here, killing fifty-five men, women and children in the worst accident in the country's civil aviation history.

Long before even Jack Coffey was at Fordham, the Rams engaged Army in a football game at West Point. That was the year 1891, when the Cadets won, 10 -- 6. Both institutions have been represented on the gridiron since, but never against each other.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, the "radio priest" of the Nineteen Thirties, testified in a tax evasion case today and denied that he once had paid a husband $68,000 after a conversation concerning the man's wife.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Pincher, flying the silks of Henry H. Hecht of Baltimore, defeated Brookfield Farm's Imacomin today in the $10,000 added Benjamin Franklin Handicap as Garden State Park closed the New Jersey racing season.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Butler, owned by J. Herbert Hammond of Baltimore, won his first race in 15 starts this season in Pimlico's featured With Regards Purse by a head over E. Lasker's Natural today before 8,500 chilled racing fans.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1 -- A conference of editors of central newspapers, sponsored by the Agitation and Propaganda Department, to discuss press presentation of propaganda and particularly of questions on Communist party education studies, has reported "serious defects."

Bars will be closed, package stores selling liquor or wine will be shut and all eating places licensed to sell liquor, wine or beer on the premises will not be able to sell them during polling hours, 6 A. M. to 7 P. M., in New York State on Election Day next Tuesday, Chairman John F. O'Connell of the New York State Liquor Authority reminded yesterday.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 12.5 per cent in October, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Robert M. Field, lawyer, author and former United States Assistant Attorney General, had an appointment to confer with John R. Steelman, assistant to the President, this afternoon on his findings during a recent trip to Europe.

The production of Prokofieff's satirical opera after Gozzi, "Love for Three Oranges," produced last night under Laszlo Halasz's direction at the City Center of Music and Drama, is really something to write home about. It is a truly original production of a most original piece.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 1 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky said today that arms had gone to the Greek guerrillas from within three Marshall Plan countries.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 1 -- The United Nations moved today for the first time toward extending its jurisdiction over dependent areas not expressly placed under the United Nations trusteeship system.

MINERAL WELLS, Tex., Nov. 1 -- A goal of $200,000,000,000 in total disposable personal income in 1950 can be achieved throughout the country by applying "an extra 5 per cent of effort now to selling."
BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Three Greek seamen banned from the United States climbed a mast of their freighter today to escape deportation.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- Under a Warsaw dateline, the Western-licensed Abend today published a detailed account of fortifications and defenses erected by the Polish army along the Oder-Neisse line, which, it asserted had been started at the end of September.

Mrs. Edward A. Hill, chairman of the committee for the Grosvenor Debutante Ball to be held on Nov. 26 at the Ritz-Carlton, gave a tea yesterday at her home, 255 East Seventy-first Street, for mothers of the debutantes to be introduced at dinner parties in the Oval Room of the hotel before the ball.

The election of Mark Gardner as president and a director of International Derrick and Equipment Company, Cleveland, Ohio, has been announced. The company is a subsidiary of Dresser Industries, Inc. Mr. Gardner will make his headquarters in Dallas, Tex., where the company's headquarters are being moved.

CRAWFORD, Me., Nov. 1 -- They say the only difference between a deer hunter and a sane person is an abnormal craving for venison, but many of those who took to the woods for the general opening of the Maine season will fail to satisfy the craving.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- A split has developed between Britain and Italy on one hand and France on the other over where to locate their new tri-power defense organization under the North Atlantic pact, according to reliable sources here.

Menus for O. Andreas Garson are more interesting than food. His gastronomic archives, going back more than 100 years, will go on exhibition today at the New York Historical Society and will remain there through Jan. 8.

There was no let-up in the furious pedaling of the ten teams in the seventieth edition of the international six-day bicycle race last night at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory. The 5,000 fans had difficulty trying to keep up with the speedsters as the lead shifted frequently.

The most up-to-date physical check-up that modern medicine can provide, estimated at a cost of $50 a person if given individually in a private doctor's office, will be granted to members of the Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, Local 65, at a cost to the members of fifty cents each.

Fabrics made the news yesterday at the premiere of the eighth edition of "Fashions of the Times." The latest and most lavish textiles from the nation's looms and laboratories were featured in the annual style show presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,285, against ,1,221 last week and 1,254 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 688 arrivals yesterday compared with 570 last Tuesday.

I respectfully ask the opportunity to make an important correction in a statement ascribed to me in your Oct. 27 report on "The Conference on the Church and the Jewish People," sponsored by the American Committee on the Christian Approach to Jews.
Mayor O'Dwyer charged yesterday that Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, was in the race to try to insure the election of Newbold Morris.

A new drive toward further extension of the 20 per cent excise tax on coats with partial fur construction will be started immediately by the Master Furriers Guild of America, Inc., it was learned here yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Connecticut's first vehicular tunnel, the 1,200-foot long, $2,000,000 twin bores beneath West Rock, was officially opened to traffic today with dedicatory ceremonies.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A motion was denied today to dismiss Federal charges of conspiracy to violate neutrality and export control laws against seven men and an airways buying concern in connection with shipment of war materials to Israel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -- The Screen Writers Guild today took official cognizance of a pamphlet recently published here by the so-called Hollywood Ten who were indicted for contempt of Congress following hearings before the Un-American Activities Committee in 1947, and through its three-time past president, Emmet Lavery, denied charges made against it and the film industry in the publication over the signature of Dalton Trumbo.

Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith's account of United States relations with Moscow in three years of the cold war has been scheduled for Jan. 4 publication by Lippincott under the title "My Three Years in Moscow." General Smith, who was United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union from March, 1946, to March, 1949, includes an unpublished interview with Joseph Stalin and a new appraisal of the Soviet Premier and of Russia's future policies.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Henry S. Mitchell of Minneapolis was elected today president of The Duluth, South Shore Atlantic Railroad by the directors. The road was formed to consolidate properties of the Duluth, South Shore Atlantic Railway and the Mineral Range Railroad.
BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Joe McCarthy, who has failed only once in three decades to bring his ball club home in the first division, today agreed to manage Boston's Red Sox for two more seasons.

THE TIMES urges its readers to vote "Yes" on the three housing propositions to appear on the ballot. In asking its readers to commit the public credit to hundreds of millions more for this purpose THE TIMES might at the same time, in fairness to those who foot the bill, also urge that there be a better administration of the regulations governing entrance and continued occupancy of the low-rent apartments.

A 2-year-old moppet using an empty tobacco can instead of the traditional engraved shovel stole the show yesterday from city and school officials at the breaking of ground for a new Public School 32, Hoyt and President Streets, Brooklyn.

Last week a TIMES correspondent in the Middle East cabled your newspaper: "Oppression of Jews in Iraq is widespread. There are no public uprisings; all is done quietly and subtly by Government pressure. * * * Jews are afraid to complain * * *."

The New York Trio, composed of Frances Blaisdell, flute; Lucile Lawrence, harp, and Seymour Barab, 'cello, gave its first concert last night at Town Hall. On the comprehensive program the seventeenth century was represented by works of Buxtehude and Johann Philip Krieger, the eighteenth century by a Trio Sonata of Leclair and the present time by French compositions of Jacques Ibert and Andre Jolivet and American works of Normand Lockwood, Wallingford Riegger and Lou Harrison.

CHUNGKING, Thursday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- All areas controlled by the Chinese Nationalists today were proclaimed war zones and placed under martial law. The sweeping action was proclaimed by the Cabinet as Chinest Communist troops drove deeper into Kwangsi Province.

I commend you for your endorsement of the candidacy of Senator John Foster Dulles for the United States Senate. In breadth of understanding and intellectual capacity to meet the problems of the day Senator Dulles towers over his opponent.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- In response to the plea Monday by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, for the "integration" of Europe's economies, the European Marshall Plan Council decided today that member nations should "adopt the objective" of freeing one-half of their mutual trade from quantitative controls by Dec. 15.

Two New York City members of Congress and several Zionist leaders, speaking last night at a "Save Jerusalem" rally held by the American Zionist Council at Manhattan Center, denounced the plan of the United Nations Conciliation Commission to sever Jerusalem from Israel.

A tract of about nineteen acres fronting 455 feet on Grand Central Parkway in the Glen Oaks section of Little Neck, Queens, has been sold by Julius P. Seymour and Alfred W. Brauman to the Edmil Construction Corporation, which plans to develop the property.

Philip Godfrey, Queens real estate operator, testified for more than an hour yesterday in a grand jury inquiry to determine whether there had been a leak in the advance information on the sale of city tax liens on property later chosen for a housing project.

The gilded frescoes and the enormous chandeliers topped with ruby glass in Saul Birns' Central Plaza Hall at 111 Second Avenue on the lower East Side looked down last night on an extraordinary neighborhood tribute to a Protestant minister and his wife.

The William H. Nichols medal of the New York section of the American Chemical Society has been awarded for 1950 to Dr. Oskar Wintersteiner, head of the organic chemistry division at the Squibb Institute for Medical Research, New Brunswick, N. J., it was announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Michigan Boxing Commission today asked Kid Gavilan to come here on Saturday and answer questions about the Oct. 21 fight he lost by a split decision to Detroit's Lester Felton.

Appointment of Vice Admiral Forrest P. Sherman as Chief of Naval Operations brings to the council table of the Defense Department one of the most brilliant minds in our military establishment. As one of the architects of the unification plan for the services, and because of his personal qualities, Admiral Sherman should help to foster that greater teamwork which is obviously essential.

The commercial building at 1881-1891 Palmer Avenue in Larchmont, N. Y., containing seven stores, has been sold by the estate of Frank S. Bache to Morris D. Heller, Camelia Yavelow and Charlotte Y. Vandroff. Cardozo Nathan were attorneys for the seller and Vandroff Klibanow acted for the buyers.

A new state of 72,000,000 people yesterday joined the free nations of the world. In welcoming the Republic of the United States of Indonesia, democratic peoples in every country can feel a vicarious thrill of pleasure. This contemporary world of ours has borne so much bitter fruit that it is good to see progress in at least one great field of government.

Anti-monopoly injunctions restraining twenty-one corporations and 116 individuals from "stifling competition" among operators of coin-box washing machines in basements of local apartment houses were obtained yesterday by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

Janet Chatfield-Taylor announced yesterday her resignation as promotion director of Saks Fifth Avenue effective Nov. 13. No successor has been appointed, and Mrs. Taylor has not yet announced her future plans. During the past six years, Mrs. Taylor has been in charge of advertising, publicity and other promotional activities for both Saks New York and branch stores, including those in Chicago, Beverly Hills, Calif., Detroit, Miami Beach and Pittsburgh.

Third-quarter earnings of industrial corporations, based on the record of 460 reporting enterprises, reflect recovery from declines in the second quarter but continue below the level of a year ago, according to an analysis made by the National City Bank in the bank's monthly bank letter published today.
Resuming his campaign after only a ten - hour respite, Representative Vito Marcantonio threatened yesterday to divulge "why O'Dwyer is afraid of Tom Dewey."

Negotiations between the Masters, Mates and Pilots Organization, AFL, and East and Gulf Coast steamship operators remained stalemated yesterday, with shipowners maintaining their refusal to accept rotary hiring.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley today urged organized labor support for the North Atlantic pact and the military aid program, which he termed "part of a strategy for lasting peace."

International Cellucotton Products Company has declared a special dividend of $1.25, payable on Dec. 19 and a quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common, payable or Jan. 3. Previously the company paid 37 1/2 cents quarterly. The company also announced that today's action places the common on a $2 annual basis.

John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for election to the Senate seat he holds by appointment, pledged yesterday that if returned to office he would work and vote for anti-lynching, anti-poll tax and fair employment measures as well as a non-discriminatory law for displaced persons.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2 (UP) -A freighter loaded with 9,300 tons of ammonium nitrate, the same chemical that blew up Texas City, Tex., in 1947, was hard aground at the mouth of the Mississippi River tonight, and two tugs could not budge her.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Under a driving ride by Jimmy Lynch, Whiffenpoof, owned by Mrs. P. A. B. Widener, outgamed D. A. Rosenbaum's Friendly Frank in the stretch and survived a foul claim to capture the featured Balladier Purse at Pimlico today.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 2 -- American colleges and universities face the greatest financial crisis that they have experienced in the last fifty years, Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brow University, warned here today.

As the final novelties of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Sadler's Wells Ballet last night presented two works by its director, Ninette de Valois. They are "Checkmate," with music by Arthur Bliss and scenery and costumes by E. McKnight Kauffer, and "Job," the famous "masque for dancing" with music by Vaughn-Williams, which was one of the first serious efforts by a British choreographer and helped enormously in the establishment of British ballet.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Statute of the Netherlands Indonesian Union as approved today by the Dutch and Indonesian delegations at the round-table conference here:
The city's Division of Labor Relations moved back yesterday into the dispute between the Safeway Stores and Local 474, National Food Chain Store Employes Union, CIO.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Most of the activity in the stock markets here today centered in South African gold shares, with most of the Orange Free State group advancing.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The British trade unions struck a severe blow today at the Labor Government's hope of holding wages at the present level in spite of devaluation. The leaders of unions with wage scales tied to the cost-of-living index refused to agree to a temporary suspension of their agreements.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 -- Rival factions of Local 601, United Electrical Workers, in Pittsburgh moved speedily today to take whatever tactical advantages they could from the expulsion of the UE from the Congress of Industrial Organizations in Cleveland.

SALEM, N. H., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Disclosure today that at least four of nine starters in a horse race at Rockingham Park had been "sponged" prompted members of the Horsemen's Benevolent Protective Association tonight to plan a reward for the capture and conviction of the tamperers.

After a conference with the Democratic county leaders of the city, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, predicted yesterday the election of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, by a plurality of 350,000.

MIDDLETOWN, R. I., Nov. 2 -- During the past two seasons, St. George's School has become feared on the prep school gridiron. The holder of a consecutive winning streak that extends through fourteen contests, the Red and White team has been rolling along and now is only two games away from its second straight unbeaten campaign.

The destruction of capitalism in all countries, to be supplanted by a world Socialist Society with a universal language and a common international economy, is forecast by A. Azizyan in the Oct. 26 issue of Pravda, just received in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The United States will oppose, and in effect defeat, the proposal by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization for an "international commodity clearing house" designed to transfer farm surpluses to shortage areas, it became known today.

While there is no question of the importance of the shipping industry to national defense, the point is often overstressed, in the opinion of Joseph H. Ball, vice president of the Association of American Ship Owners and former Senator from Minnesota.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A portrait by Thomas Gainsborough was knocked down for a mere $1,000 today as the art collection of the late Atwater Kent, radio manufacturer and philanthropist, was auctioned off.

Patrolman Robert Stewart has found his full share of drama in six years in the police department. But early yesterday his duties followed him home. Returning with his wife from a movie at 1 A. M., he discovered a fire in the apartment below his own, and helped more than a dozen persons to safety.

The Detroit Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it will acquire the assets and the steel business of the Portsmouth Steel Corporation of Portsmouth, Ohio, on Jan. 1, 1950, and that it will undertake "large-scale" expansion of the latter company's finishing facilities.

Midnight blue provided the color theme for a small but well-executed collection of furs in Hollander-dyed persian lamb and broadtail, created by Pierre Balmain for Saks Fifth Avenue and shown yesterday at that store. Designed in Paris, these models will be incorporated in the designer's forthcoming midseason presentation.

For voters in different parts of this city there are twenty-seven judicial offices to be filled on election day. Following our usual practice, we present as a trustworthy guide to the merits of candidates for these offices a list based on the recommendations made by the city's leading bar associations and the Citizens Union.

James D. Standish Jr. of Detroit, for many years a ranking official in the game, has been nominated as president of the United States Golf Association for 1950, according to the report of the nominating committee. The slate, announced yesterday, will be formally presented at the annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria, Jan. 28.
EAST PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 1 -- Unlike most people, 56-year-old Charles H. Lohsen would not resent having someone say to him, "Go fly a kite!"

After reporting a consolidated net income of $955,308 for the third quarter and a loss of $954,001 for the first nine months of 1949, directors of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the company's common stock, payable on Dec. 19.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 2 -- The perennial conflict over the Federal Government's proper role in the development of irrigation and power in the West was intensified today as the National Reclamation Association opened its eighteenth annual convention here.
Syracuse University's building and development fund drive for $15,000,000 was one-tenth of the way toward its goal last night with announcement of a gift of $1,500;000.

Plaza Mills, Inc, converter of textiles, bought the twelve-story loft building on a plot 37 by 200 feet at 10 East Thirty-ninth Street through to 7 East Thirty-eighth Street in a deal reported yesterday by Williams Co, the broker. Occupied by concerns in the linen, glove and allied lines, the property is assessed for $450,000.

DENVER, Nov. 2 -- Eighty-year-old Henry M. Blackmer, who has paid the United States Government $3,500,000 in delinquent income taxes and fines over a period of twenty-one years, made final settlement here today when he was fined $20,000 for income tax evasion in United States District Court.

Proof that Paris and New York share the leadership of the world of fashion is presented in the eighth edition of "Fashions of the Times." This was pointed out yesterday by industry leaders in the audience at the comprehensive style production sponsored annually by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

In his spacious, sunny office on City's Hall's third floor, far removed from the throngs who frequent the first and second floors, Georg J. Lober, executive secretary of the Art Commission, inspects proposed designs for public buildings, markers and memorials and occasionally thinks back on the days when he defied the Ku Klux Klan in Virginia.

The Wheeling Steel Corporation reported yesterday a net income of $2,139,664, equal to $2.96 a common share, for the third quarter of 1949, compared with $3,886,913, or $5.99 a share in the 1948 period.

The ways of women may be inscrutable, but periodically there takes place in their world an upheaval which gives the thoughtful man cause to wonder. The revolution is universal, seasonal, and insidious in its inception.

Walter B. Devereux, secretary of the National Horse Show, and Mrs. Devereux gave a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria before the evening session of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. John Parsons, Mr. and Mrs. Anson McCook Beard and Linsly Williams.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- The country's business is good, and there appears to be no reason why it should not continue to be good, Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer said today. He spoke at a luncheon sponsored jointly by the Chicago Association of Commerce and the Illinois Manufacturers Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission suspended today rate increases proposed by Hope Natural Gas Company for natural gas sold to wholesalers in Ohio, Pennsylvania and New York. The - increased rates would have yielded about $1,963,412 annually, the commission said.

Proof that American drinking habits are changing is evident in the increased consumption of cordials here, Paul deKuyper, senior partner of the deKuyper Company, Rotterdam, Holland, declared yesterday in an interview.
A run on coffee was reported yesterday in grocery stores in New York and some suburbs as housewives feared a shortage in that popular beverage during the forthcoming holiday season.

It was Mexico once more at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night when Capt. Ruben Uriza rode Hatuey to victory in the Dakota Trophy event before 9,000 spectators. That made the third individual triumph for the Army riders from the republic and the second personally for Captain Uriza, winner of the International Miltary preliminary, also aboard Hatuey, on opening day.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 2 -- In a klieg-lighted ceremony in the ancient Knights' Hall of the Parliament building a Dutch Cabinet Minister today signed the document transferring sovereignty over Indonesia "unconditionally and irrevocably" to the United States of Indonesia.

The Port of New York Authority took its second step in the long-term financing of metropolitan area airport development yesterday by selling $30,000,000 of tax-exempt air-terminal revenue bonds due in 1979 to a syndicate of bankers at an interest cost of 2.651666 per cent.

An order for 8,000 to 10,000 tons of Indonesian rubber, much of it believed to be destined as raw material for factories in Western Germany, has been placed by the Economic Cooperation Administration, it was learned reliably yesterday.

Recent reader inquiries have brought up such culinary problems as how to make bread that has an "old-fashioned" taste and how to tell when a turkey is cooked. Many of these questions are of general interest. We've selected several and offer them, along with the answers:

CRAWFORD, Me., Nov. 2 -- Now that the flush of opening day is past, the Maine deer season can settle down to its normal routine, for the opening always attracts a number of local hunters who hope to get a deer before they have become too wary.

Appointment of Admiral Forrest P. Sherman as Chief of Naval Operations will inevitably -- though probably not immediately -- lead to wide changes in naval commands in Washington and probably in other parts of the world.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Admiral Forrest P. Sherman was sworn in as Chief of Naval Operations today in the office of Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy.

A banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation will offer to investors today a new issue of 150,000 shares of $4 dividend preferred stock of Union Electric Company of Missouri at $102.50 a share to yield about 3.90 per cent. The issue was awarded to the banking group Tuesday on competitive bidding.

The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 12 points higher to 1 point lower, with the near months showing relatively more strength than the distant months.

Industrial advertising budgets are getting an increasing share of dollar sales income it was indicated yesterday in details of a budget survey announced by the National Industrial Advertisers Association at a meeting in its New York headquarters.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 2 -- Albania and Bulgaria got their chance today to testify before the United Nations and promptly accused the United States and Britain of fomenting threats to the peace in the Balkans.

It was off to the land of skiing yesterday at Bloomingdale's. A fashion collection of attractive separates for active participation in this sport and for lounging before the fire later was presented. For active sports, slim tapered downhill pants in black, navy or gray were an important part of every costume topped off with a wide variety of engaging jackets and parkas.

AN important book on Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Rooseveltian era had been completed by Edward R. Stettinius Jr. before his untimely death last Monday. It is called "Roosevelt and the Russians: The Yalta Conference"* and it is published today.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- In a dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 27 it was incorrectly reported that the Monroe County Medical Society had adopted a resolution declaring unsatisfactory the stand of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Senator, on socialized medicine and approving that taken by his Republican opponent, Senator John Foster Dulles.
LONDON, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -Indian Embassy officials in London today denied that the Government of India had made any representations to the British Foreign Office on Indo-China.

PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Sam Snead, the slammer from White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., unloaded a hot 33, 35 -- 68 today to take the first-round lead in the North and South open golf tournament by one stroke.

For the first time in almost a half dozen years, Vinton Freedley will be putting on a Broadway musical offering. His last opus of this type was "Jackpot," presented early in January of 1944. Lest anyone receive the impression that he has been inactive, Mr. Freedley sponsored last season, "The Young and Fair," the N. Richard Nash play, which, while not successful, proved a succes d'estime.

As the New Jersey Governorship race nears its close after intensive campaigns by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and State Senator Elmer H. Wene, his Democratic rival, the consensus of political observers is that Governor Driscoll will be reelected, but by a relatively close margin.

With the action plentiful, the field in the seventieth edition of the six-day bicycle race was sliced to eight teams when Charlie Logan of Montclair, N. J., was badly injured as the grind continued last night at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory.

The nation's gasoline stocks rose 925,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The total was 103,915,000 barrels, compared with 102,990,000 a week earlier and 91,925,000 a year before.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- An unusually comprehensive inquiry into the collision yesterday of an Eastern Airlines DC-4 and a P-38 fighter plane 100 feet above the National Airport here was ordered today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 2 -- The United States High Commission is compiling an analysis of the present state of dismantling in Germany as a preliminary to a further study of the question, an authoritative source said tonight.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 2 -- The name of Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, who lives here, has been mentioned as a possible successor to United States Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, who will assume a place in the State Supreme Court at the end of the year.

Workmen are speeding up operations to have all the permanent exhibits ready for the formal opening tomorrow of the New York Hall of Science at 1506 Broadway. A portion of the premises was opened on Oct. 20 for the Lithuanian art-in-exile display, which will continue with more than 600 items of paintings, sculpture, ceramics and wood carvings.

Hopeful that his compatriots will not meet the same rough conditions during the forthcoming world championships as he had on his flight to the United States, Bjorn Kjellstrom, president of the Swedish Ski Association, yesterday arrived aboard a Scandinavian Airliner at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 2 -- A joint public hearing before an examiner of the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Public Utility Commission of New Jersey on the Lehigh Valley Railroad's application for an average increase of 28 per cent in commuter fares was ended this afternoon after several objecting commuters testified they "could not afford any fare rise."
Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel yesterday was voted baseball's "Manager of the Year" in a poll conducted by The Associated Press.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Lee Treese former vice president in charge of manufacturing for the Tucker Corporation, told in Federal District Court today how he took the company's advertising chief to task for "advertising something we didn't have."

Northwest Airlines has reached a cargo transfer agreement with sixteen other airlines and, pending approval by the Civil Aeronautics Board, will apply the same rates to shipments between 600 American cities and the Orient, it was announced yesterday by R. O. Bullwinkel, Northwest's vice president in charge of traffic.

New sharpness was given yesterday to the contest for United States Senator by former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, the Democratic-Liberal candidate, who compared his wartime activities with those of Senator John Foster Dulles, the Republican nominee.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Despite the difficult political situation of the world and persistent threats both to peace and to the structure of the United Nations, a subsidiary body of that organization, the Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (Unesco), is making slow but definite progress, Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, former Mexican Foreign Minister and now Unesco's head, declared in an interview with the writer today.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Earl Blaik, Army football coach, is more concerned about Saturday's game with Fordham than any since the cadets went to Ann Arbor to end Michigan's three-year winning streak.

TORONTO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and the New York Rangers battled to a 3-3 draw in a National Hockey League game tonight before a crowd of 12,959 fans who had little to cheer about. The deadlock dropped the Leafs into a first-place tie with Detroit.

Another personal report on Russian actions in Europe is scheduled for spring publication by Putnam. The author is Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley, who recently returned after running Berlin's United States sector for four years as Military Governor.

William Z. Foster, chairman of the Communist party, declared last night that statements by Senator John Foster Dulles, implying that the Communist party was supporting Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic-Liberal opponent, constituted a "double barreled lie."

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 2 -- Plans for a large-scale welfare program to assist millions of youngsters in ten Latin-American countries were approved today by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.
The Football Yankees may be without the services of two line mainstays in Sunday's All-America Conference game against the Buffalo Bills at the Yankee Stadium.

Seymour M. Tannenbaum, operator, has purchased the six-story building at 3746 Third Avenue, the Bronx, containing two stores and twenty-seven apartments, from the Han Nat Realty Company. The property, on a plot 40 by 100 feet, is assessed at $41,000.

Heartened by predictions of victory by the five Republican county leaders, Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion candidate for Mayor, renewed his attack yesterday on Mayor O'Dwyer on two fronts.

ALBANY, Nov. 2 -- New York and Vermont membership of the newly created Interstate Commission on the Lake Champlain Basin was announced jointly today by Assemblyman Harold C. Ostertag, chairman of the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation, and Senator W. L. Hammond, chairman of the Vermont Commission on Interstate Cooperation.

Dan O'Brien, king of the hoboes, who was expected to be buried in a pauper's grave in potter's field, will have an impressive funeral tomorrow afternoon. Two well-to-do friends have volunteered to assume all expenses, it was learned yesterday.

While the reduction in value of foreign currencies, weighted according to our imports, averages about 20 per cent, the average decline in prices of imported goods and commodities will not exceed 5 per cent, according to Dr. G. Rowland Collins, dean, Graduate School of Business Administration, New York University.

Columbia Broadcasting System color television is ready now and can be offered to the public within few months after the Federal Communications Commission authorizes its broadcasting, Frank Stanton, president, declared yesterday.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 2 (UP) -- George W. Armstrong, Texas and Mississippi oil man, said today the controversy over his offer of a "white supremacy" endowment to Jefferson Military College was "a tempest in a teapot."

The thirty-eighth running of the six-furlong New Rochelle Handicap at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday resulted in an off-by-himself victory for Woolford Farm's Delegate and a five-horse photo for the minor awards in the $17,150 stake.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee investigating monopoly and bigness in American business was urged today to take action to limit the size of "big labor" as well as "big business."
The exiled King and Queen of Yugoslavia and their son. Prince Alexander, who arrived from Europe on the Caronia, are at the Carlyle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Henry J. Kaiser, head of Kaiser Industries, said today that his companies had returned to the Government $188,086,000 in payments for former war plants and Federal loans.

A bright orange pumpkin filled with fall flowers in tones of yellow, purple and bronze was among the special flower displays shown to the public yesterday by the Metropolitan Retail Florists' Association. Other unusual items were a china pixie seated beneath a "tree" of small white orchids with a scattering of tiny blossoms at his feet and a gray plush teddy bear with a cluster of red and white carnations set rakishly about one ear.

Helen Hayes and David Niven will be starred in a Noel Coward play, "Still Life," over the National Broadcasting Company radio network on Sunday, Nov. 13, at 8:30 P. M. as a feature production of the "Theatre Guild on the Air" series.

One of the most reassuring sights in the various hospital districts of New York is that of an ambulance, with a distinctive color for the hospital it serves, rushing to the aid of someone in an emergency illness or accident.
Mrs. John Foster Dulles went on an East Side, West Side, all-around-the-town tour yesterday to report to her husband on what the women voters wanted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Indiana soft coal operators said "no" today to a proposal to negotiate separately with John L. Lewis for settlement of the miners' strike in that state. Their action slowed down substantially Mr. Lewis' plans for an offensive on the Midwest coal front.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, said today that the armed services must beware of "die hards" who fight against new weapons of war.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 -- The American Bankers Association, at its annual convention here today, was chided for its "negative approach'' to the problems of monetary management. In a "surprise" address which left his audience somewhat annoyed and resentful, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, warned the 4,000 banking executives attending the sessions that "an effective monetary policy" is one of the best defenses of the free enterprise system.

Daniel Frisch, president of the Zionist Organization of America, proposed yesterday the creation of an authoritative body to supervise the activities of all Jewish groups in this country. One of its functions, he said, would be to receive accounts from relief organizations as to their fund-raising activities.

The first step in a reorganization of the United States Maritime Commission, which had been promised by its comparatively new chairman, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, was taken yesterday in the abolition of two bureaus, the creation of two new groups and considerable reshuffling of key personnel.

Rear Admiral Merlin O'Neill, who will assume his duties as Commandant of the Coast Guard with the rank of vice admiral Jan. 1, is a veteran of more than thirty years with the service. During a long and distinguished career he has commanded four destroyers as well as other vessels and for a time acted as commandant of cadets at the Coast Guard Academy, New London, Conn.

ROME, Nov. 2 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi returned to Rome from Assisi this evening and began to go through the motions of solving the Cabinet crisis brought about on Monday by the withdrawal from the Cabinet of the right-wing Socialists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Those who speak officially for the United States Air Force are not likely to lend either open or indirect support to any move in Congress to review, with the objective of challenging, the President's announcement last week that he has impounded $615 millions for this service arm which Congress gave him in excess of his budgetary request.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Asserting the moral supremacy of the United States over Russia, President Truman declared today that his ambition was to show that the ideology backed "by a moral code" could do the most good for the welfare of the world.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 2 -- The Indonesian question will remain on the agenda of the Security Council and the United Nations Commission in the field will continue to function indefinitely to assure political stability and economic growth, it became known here today.

A funeral service for Edward R. Stettinius Jr., former Secretary of State, was held yesterday in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street. Mr. Stettinius, who was the first United States delegate to the United Nations, died Monday at Greenwich, Conn.

Space shortages and emergency conditions which led to commercial rent restrictions are being alleviated steadily, and the "free private enterprise system" again should be permitted to operate in the real estate field here, Edmund F. Wagner, president of the General Realty and Utilities Corporation, declared yesterday.

It is almost a truism to say that the tumult and shouting of political disputes at the U. N. are what capture public attention and tend to obscure the magnificent work in international cooperation that is carried on quietly by many of the U. N.'s far-flung agencies from day to day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 26:

Emil Chaky of Columbia, defensive line-backer, was in uniform for the first time since the Army game yesterday as the Lions ran through a brisk light contact workout at Baker Field in preparation for their game with Dartmouth Saturday.
The season for formal fashions being close at hand, Milgrim's presented a showing of evening clothes yesterday during luncheon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The stock market came yesterday within 1/2 point of the high of last year as inflationary thinking and revived hopes for a resumption of coal and steel production produced a new buying splurge. Prices were advanced 1 to 3 points, sending the composite rate up 1.40, in the strongest market in more than a month stemming from a sharp increase in volume.

Carrying home-made placards on his sturdy chest and back, one of the 20,000 unemployed of Scranton, Pa., marched up and down Wall Street yesterday to plead with the heart of American finance to take industry to his native city.
A cache of illicit narcotics with an underworld retail value close to $1,000,000 was seized yesterday when Federal and police agents raided the Queens home of a truck driver.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -With plans to make two color pictures in the next six months, Irving Allen, Hollywood producer-director, and Sam Dembow Jr., New York producers' representative, today announced the forming of a new independent company. Organized as a New York State corporation, it will be known as Allen Dembow Film Productions, Inc.
A revenue agent was arrested yesterday after he allegedly passed a $2,000 bribe to a Treasury Department attorney to influence the latter's decision in a tax case pending before him.

Negotiations to end the national steel strike started on a broad scale yesterday, with the United Steelworkers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, insisting on acceptance by all other major steel companies of the "pattern" fixed in its settlement with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation on Monday.

Mrs. Samuel W. Halprin, president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, who will leave tomorrow to open the thirty-fifth annual convention of the organization in San Francisco, reported yesterday that 1,500 delegates would be asked to approve a national budget of $6,535,000 to carry on the organization's work in Israel.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 2 -- The State of New Jersey received $11,603,527.90 in revenue from the racing season which closed yesterday, the State Racing Commission announced today. Last year the state received $11,232,246.42 from its three tracks.

Although the Lunts are dazzling actors, it is difficult not to look at what they are playing. It is "I Know My Love," which S. N. Behrman has adapted from Marcel Achard's "Aupres de Ma Blonde" and which the Theatre Guild and John C. Wilson brought into the Sam S. Shubert Theatre last evening.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 2 (UP) -- The federated "Republic of the United States of Indonesia" includes Java, Sumatra and a string of thousands of other tiny islands. The new nation will be linked to the Netherlands through a loose Dutch-Indonesian union headed by Queen Juliana.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it would approve the plan of consolidation filed by the Long Island Lighting Company and two of its subsidiaries, the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company and the Nassau Suffolk Lighting Company, provided certain changes were made.

Several days before the settlement of the pension dispute in Bethlehem Steel, William H. Colvin Jr., president of Crucible Steel, proposed that the President's fact-finding board be asked jointly by labor and management to clarify its position on some of the more controversial points in its report.

Walter Cartier, Greenwich Village boxer, defeated Eugene Hairston of Harlem in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 2,171 fans saw the bout which went to Cartier by unanimous vote.
Twenty-seven teachers are urgently needed in evening trade schools, Dr. C. Frederick Pertsch, associate superintendent in charge of the vocational high school division, announced yesterday.

Vincent R. Impellitteri, Democratic candidate for re-election as President of the City Council, denounced last night the boast of Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, that he (Marcantonio) was a friend of Italy and the Italian people as "a cruel lie."

On Nov. 8 the voters of New York State will be given the opportunity to enact a fair and reasonable law relating to veterans' preference in the civil service by Voting "Yes" on Amendment 5 on the ballot. This amendment would supersede the present absolute-preference law with a point-preference plan and assure non-disabled veterans and non-veterans of more equitable treatment on Civil Service lists.

Charging that Newbold Morris was playing the Republican party's game of fighting progressive democracy, Mayor O'Dwyer urged the voters last night "not to be fooled by a cloak of liberalism worn in the service of Republican reaction."

ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S SPECIAL TRAIN, En Route to St. Paul, Nov. 2 -- On this first anniversary of his unexpected victory at the polls, President Truman was on the way tonight to make a "nonpolitical, bipartisan speech" in St. Paul tomorrow night on Minnesota's Centennial as a Territory.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 2 -- Fifteen Protestant, liberal and labor leaders today proposed to the General Assembly that Jerusalem be divided between Israel and an Arab state, with free access to the Holy Places throughout Palestine to be insured by a United Nations commission.

The proposed Master Plan for low rent housing and development of forty sections of the city was adopted unanimously yesterday by the City Planning Commission, meeting at City Hall. The plan now goes to the Board of Estimate for final approval.

Relying on the food supply of their shop canteen, 100 men and women employes of the National Fastener Corporation of Brooklyn decided early yesterday to continue a sit-down strike in the concern at 32 Thirty-third Street.

Armand Denis and Lewis Cotlow have turned out an interesting and at times exciting pictorial account in color of their last big-game hunting expedition to Africa in "Savage Splendor." This hour-length film, released by RKO Radio Pictures and presented yesterday at the Rialto, is not nearly as sensational as several previous accounts offered by movie-conscious explorers with a decided flair for commercial showmanship.

Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Institution, warned yesterday that if the United States overdid the "welfare state" type of personal security it might so weaken national security as to be unable to avoid being forced into World War III.

Although there is never a day when the entire squad of regulars is able to report for practice because of academic work, Frank Tubridy, City College football coach, remains a rather optimistic person.

There-are about 85 different types of profit-sharing plans in use by members of The Council of Profit Sharing Industries, Akron, Ohio, officials revealed yesterday following a meeting with its regional trustees at the Roosevelt Hotel.

YONKERS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- A 51-year-old Connecticut carpenter, a veteran of two dangerous submarine expeditions, was remanded without bail here today by Judge Martin Fay in City Court on a felonious-assault charge for the alleged shooting of a 46-year-old lawyer last night.
Secretary of State Dean Acheson last night said the United States must find the solution of its foreign trade balance-of-payments problem as an "importer in the world economy."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson has reorganized the Public Affairs section of the Department of State in an effort to improve and increase the flow of foreign policy information to the public at home and overseas.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Miller were returning to their home in Chevy Chase, Md., after a vacation in Europe, according to friends today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 2 (AP) -- In a note just short of an ultimatum, Yugoslavia tonight sternly "cautioned" Albania to live up to her treaty obligations with Premier Marshall Tito's Government.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The admission of Western Germany to the Council of Europe and the relations of the Council with the Organization for European Economic Cooperation will be the two principal topics discussed by the Ministers Committee of twelve nations at their meeting starting at the Foreign Ministry tomorrow morning.

A heroic sculptural group, which besides its concept and workmanship has the distinction of costing $25 a year in rent paid to the city, was unveiled yesterday and the new building to which the group is affixed was dedicated.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Two Montreal players were charged with assault by spectators tonight after one fan had been injured in a melee at the National League Hockey game with Chicago at the Stadium. A third player, picked up on a similar charge, was released before the others were taken to the police station.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The Conservative party leaders happily embraced the opportunity today to attack the Labor Government on charges of waste, inefficiency and miscalculation.
Scene Six in Act One of the Eighth Edition of "Fashions of the Times," now being shown at Times Hall, is devoted to that item reputedly the closest to the hearts of all women, namely, hats.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Evening Bulletin called today for election of Democratic candidates for two city offices, Controller and Treasurer.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 2 -- A life sentence imposed today on Walter Reese, 26 years old, of Bloomfield by County Judge W. Stanley Naughright, after a plea of non vult to an indictment of murder culminated one of the most bizarre cases in New Jersey criminal annals.

In answer to criticisms that inadequate provision had been made for parks and playgrounds along the route of the new Brooklyn-Queens Connecting Highway in Brooklyn, Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn announced yesterday that twenty-six new playgrounds, in addition to already established parks, would be provided in the area.

Five officials of the Amtorg Trading Corporation, Russia's purchasing agency here, agreed yesterday to waive a removal hearing and appear in Washington on Nov. 14 to face charges of failure to register under the Foreign Agents Registration Act. Bail of $15,000 each was continued.

GENEVA, Nov. 2 -- The practice of double pricing, which Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, bluntly told the Council of Ministers of the Marshall Plan countries on Monday could not be squared with their pledges of mutual aid, has become worse in Europe since the currency readjustments earlier this fall.

Albert J. Fitzgerald, president of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, assailed top leaders of the CIO yesterday as "miserably bewildered and perplexed men" and accused them of abandoning "trade unionism in favor of politics."

The Treasury Department agreed yesterday in Washington to advance the effective date on the Nov. 1 ruling which placed all fur coats in the group liable to a 20 per cent excise tax, according to Dane F. Hahn, manager of the retail fur council of the National Retail Dry Goods Association following a meeting with Treasury officials yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- In a series of lightning moves today the convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations expelled the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America and the Farm Equipment Workers and laid the basis for the purge of ten other unions commanded by left-wing, pro-Communist leaders.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Criterion, the attraction is "They Live By Night," an RKO drama with Farley Granger, Cathy O'Donnell and Howard da Silva in the leading roles. Nicholas Ray directed and John Houseman produced from a screen play by Charles Schnee and the novel, "Thieves Like Us," by Edward Anderson.

Mill prices of upper grades of yellow pine may be increased $1 to $2 a thousand board feet soon, James L. Buckley, vice president, Georgia-Pacific Plywood Lumber Company, declared yesterday. The increases, expected to occur across the board on all upper grades, will follow the $1 to $2 a thousand advance on No. 2 common roofers last week, he said.

Unless integrity and a deeper sense of fair play and obligation are cultivated in all divisions of present-day society, "our civilization will cast a pall over tomorrow's," it was declared last night by Prof. Maurice I. Hart of the Department of Banking and Finance, Fordham University.
Though scarcely able to make themselves heard amid the oratorical thunder of the big-time campaign, three earnest candidates of minor parties also are running for Mayor of New York this year.

Edward J. Shaughnessy district director of immigration and naturalization, announced yesterday that the deportation of Hirsch Teper, the London tailor who figured in a bribery investigation in the House of Commons some months ago, had been postponed following a habeas corpus action in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Louisville Gas and Electric Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $41,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, series due on Nov. 1, 1979, that are to be sold at competitive bidding.

The time is fast approaching when those with a mind for winter vacations will be on their way south or north, to those areas that offer a dip in sun-warmed pools or those that promise a slide down snow-covered slopes. For such as these "Fashions of the Times" has many suggestions.

FOOTBALL is such an insatiable devourer of newspaper space that it frequently delays comments that an observer would have liked to have made at an earlier date. Such is the case with the shocking' death of Marcel Cerdan, the one-time middleweight champion of the world, who plummeted from the skies in the crash of a transatlantic airliner.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- Take liquor away from the 'teen-age driver and a material reduction in highway fatalities will result. Lou E. Holland of Kansas City, president of the American Automobile Association, said today at the annual meeting of the organization here.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Winston Churchill added to the roll of his honors today in one of his numerous fields of achievement, that of historian and man of letters. For the first two volumes of his war memoirs he received the award of the Sunday Times made annually for an outstanding contribution to English literature.

The four-story apartment house at 255 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, containing forty suites, has been sold by John Avrutis to the Basmor Realty Corporation. The property, assessed at $135,000, occupies a plot 102 by 150 feet, opposite Prospect Park.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Nov. 2 -- France's successful campaign for the economic absorption of the Saar has been aided to a great degree by the local political picture, which is somewhat akin to the present party alignment in France save that the Saar has very few Communists.

Realizing that Army's hard-hitting attackers may sideline some of Fordham's defensive players Saturday, Coach Ed Danowski yesterday conducted an experimental scrimmage featuring offensive Ram players in a defensive workout against the freshman team.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The British Government is seriously considering turning down a United States offer of seventy long-range B-29 bombers but is worried about the effect this might have on American public opinion.

Brooklyn College held a combination "Beat City" rally and football workout at the Flatbush Field yesterday in an effort to whip up enthusiasm for the big game. While student leaders urged support of the team by the students, the Kingsmen went through a regular daily drill.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Nov. 2 -- The trustees of Jefferson Military College, the 147-year-old preparatory school that rejected a $50,000,000 grant contingent on the teaching of "white supremacy," were hopeful today that a nation-wide endowment campaign would rescue the school from financial difficulties.

In an effort to give new impetus to the various movements for the consolidation of the Western World, Secretary Acheson plans to fly to Paris next week for a conference with the Foreign Ministers of France and Britain. The conference will deal primarily with the problem of Germany, which has entered upon a new stage with the formation of an East-German Government.

The United States has the physical and financial resources for an expanded program of social welfare that would guarantee minimum standards of housing, clothing, food and medical care for the entire population, speakers at a forum meeting of the National Social Welfare Assembly said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 3 -- The urgency of United Nations action, as the need arises, to promote and maintain full employment was stressed today in an Australian draft resolution approved by the General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee after a heated two-week debate.

The three-story business building at 474-82 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, containing eight stores, has been leased by Irving and Herman Brown of the Brown Company from the Bishop estate. Extensive alterations of the property are planned by the lessees.

Last Rose of Summer In their flights of poetic fancy the bards have seized on the last rose of summer or the lengthening shadows of the autumnal season as symbols of the transition of the seasons. These imaginative flights of poesy conjure up images that are allegorical yet definite -- the last rose bespeaks no others, the change in sunlight bespeaks the finality of the dropping of a curtain.

At Columbia University where he is a visiting professor of physics for the current academic year, Dr. Yukawa said yesterday he had not yet decided whether or not he would travel to Stockholm for the formal Dec. 10 awarding of the Nobel Prize.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- After a sharp and extended discussion of the procedure for admitting new members, the twelve foreign ministers on the Ministerial Committee of the Council of Europe decided today to leave consideration of the specific cases of Western Germany and the Saar until tomorrow.

Transportation Realty, Inc., bought the large freight depot at the northwest corner of Tenth Avenue and West Nineteenth Street from Edward J. Kelly in a deal reported yesterday by the James H. Burns Company, broker in the transaction in conjunction with John J. Reynolds, Inc.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Editorial opinion must, of course exercise an ultimate preference. But an appraisal of a candidate should accurately reflect the facts. Your editorial on Nov. 2 avers that Robert F. Wagner Jr. has not "distinguished" himself for "administrative ability," nor demonstrated "marked initiative in the solution of city problems."

The economic education program of the Committee for Economic Development will be greatly expanded and eight new research reports will reach "Main Streets" throughout the country in 1950. The expanded and more sharply focused program was described yesterday by Marion B. Folsom, treasurer, Eastman Kodak Company, and new chairman of CED's Research and Policy Committee, in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Yesterday on this page we reviewed the recommendations of the leading bar associations and the Citizens Union with regard to candidates for state and county judicial offices in next Tuesday's elections.
