Today we summarize the recommendations of these same organizations in the matter of the eighteen places to be filled in the Municipal Courts.

Twenty - six industrial and business groups are aiding the $500,000 drive of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the Manhattan commerce and industry committee of the drive.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The Illinois Central Railroad Company completed a sweeping refinancing program today designed to simplify and improve the railroad's financial structure.
Howard E. Bosman has been named merchandise manager of the New York branch of Wilson Sporting Goods Company, subsidiary of Wilson Co.

James A. Brady, a retired police captain, died yesterday in Fordham Hospital, the Bronx, after having been struck by a taxicab at 224th Street and White Plains Avenue, the Bronx, on Sunday. Mr. Brady, who was 80 years old, lived at 4005 Lowerre Place, the Bronx.

Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, assailed Senator John Foster Dulles last night as an ardent isolationist before World War II. He charged further that the Republican Senatorial candidate favored a policy of appeasement and had shown consistent bad judgment in foreign affairs and in the appraisal of international developments.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In addition to electing officials to public office, the November, 1949, elections in New York State will also require that the people decide whether veterans now living elsewhere may become eligible for the bonus.

ALBANY, Nov. 3 -- Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck challenged as "untrue" today a statement by Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman that Republican leaders had "opposed and obstructed" nearly every piece of social legislation in the state and nation for a quarter of a century.

Prevention in psychiatry is "outstandingly more important than therapy" especially in those countries where psychiatric services are in an early stage of development, Dr. J. R. Rees of London, director of the World Federation for Mental Health, said yesterday.
Special drills were in order at Fordham yesterday as the Rams held their penultimate practice for tomorrow's clash with Army.

Plans for a new store, office and showroom building in the Times Square area were announced yesterday in connection with the leasing by the Ottinger Estate of the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-first Street to Jack D. Weiler of New York and B. H. Swig of San Francisco.

Inspired by the Fete des Roses, which was revived three years ago in Paris, interest has turned to roses as a theme in design for prints. Again and again the flower appears on silks and rayons. So it happened that a scene devoted entirely to the bloom took its place in "Fashions of the Times."
Plans for expanding the Fashion Institute of Technology and Design into a full four-year college that would be part of the new State University system were disclosed yesterday.

A detective's careful study of the trajectory of two rifle bullets, one of which pierced the neck of a 2-year-old boy, resulted yesterday in the appearance in court of an 18-year-old New York State Guardsman who in recent months had been brooding about his poor marksmanship.

After patiently waiting two hours for a Queens real estate operator to appear to testify, a New York County grand jury halted its afternoon session yesterday just a few minutes before the witness, Philip Godfrey, arrived.

HONG KONG, Nov. 3 -- Little Portuguese Macao today faced a critical frontier situation caused by pressure from an anti-Communist military formation that is being squeezed toward Macao by advancing Communist troops.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 3 -- Yugoslavia is firmly opposed to the creation of any new Communist international and believes that socialism cannot be imposed on a country through "foreign intervention," one of the top officials of the Belgrade Government said here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Searchers today had recovered and identified all but one of the bodies of the fifty-five victims of the collision of an airliner and a Bolivian P-38 Tuesday 100 feet above the National Airport.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The first plans for the Tucker car placed the radiator in the front despite the fact that the engine was in the rear. The first Tucker engine, designed to develop 150 horsepower, actually delivered only 20. These were highlights from the testimony today of Paul G. Wellenkamp, former Tucker Corporation engineering manager, before a jury in the Federal District Court trial of Preston Tucker and seven associates for fraud and conspiracy.

Visibly heartened by the overflow crowds that have attended most Democratic rallies lately and by renewed assurances of support from organized labor, Mayor O'Dwyer promised two labor rallies last night that in his next administration he would continue to give the city progressive government in the interest of the people.

It is the general consensus of those who have viewed "Fashions of the Times," which will run for the fourth and final day today at Times Hall, that "Imperial Colors" is the most unusual and outstanding of the fourteen scenes that compose the presentation.
LYNN, Mass., Nov. 3 (AP) -- At what moment does it get too dark to play baseball?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Philip Murray of the CIO and Eugene G. Grace of the Bethlehem Steel Company broke the industry-wide scope of the steelworkers' strike, though the company's pre-strike operation of a non-contributory pension plan makes it clear that the industry-wide pattern on this point never existed and that Mr. Murray's agreement with Bethlehem was merely a timing maneuver.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Nov. 3 (UP) -- Eugene O'Neill, America's greatest playwright, may never write again. "He hasn't worked for three years -- and God only knows if he ever will be able to," his wife, Charlotte, said today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 -- Motor vehicle accidents were likened today to a deadly plague sweeping the country that required scientific treatment to curb its toll.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- James S. Kemper resigned today as treasurer of the Republican National Committee. He assigned, as a chief reason for the action, a drop in party reserves from $832,000 to less than $90,000 in twenty-two months.

Laurania, bidding for at least the vice presidency of the claim-of-the-year club, yesterday scored her sixth victory since Isidor Bieber and Hirsch Jacobs obtained her for $5,000 at Saratoga last August. This latest success was marked up in the $5;000 added handicap for fillies and mares that headed the Empire City-at-Jamaica program.
SALEM, N. H., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Lightly regarded Bar Dal, owned by Will Bartyzel, won the six-furlong Claremont Purse before 5,605 at Rockingham Park today.

Coffee futures eased somewhat in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. It was the most active trading day in the post-war trading era. Prices opened steady to higher, but eased off thereafter as demand slowed up.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- Seven United States Senators visiting Marshall Plan countries to check on the effectiveness of United States aid implied on their arrival here today that their report would recommend decreases in future appropriations for certain countries.

The Port of New York Authority and the New York Central Railroad were joint hosts yesterday at a four-hour tour of the harbor, arranged for visiting delegates to the National Foreign Trade Convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this week.

Mrs. Helen Wortis, head of a committee of downtown Brooklyn residents, registered her dissatisfaction yesterday with Borough President John Cashmore's outline of plans for play spaces in the area. Mr. Cashmore had sent her a map and a letter, in answer to her committee's plea for more play-grounds for school-age children.
Army, Fordham and others use two platoons successfully, but Brooklyn College actually employs "the three" system.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- United States policy toward Yugoslavia has not been changed by the appointment of a new Ambassador. Neither the discussion of policy toward Premier Marshal Tito at the meeting of Eastern European envoys of the United States in London with George W. Perkins, Assistant Secretary of State for European affairs, nor the announced replacement of Cavendish W. Cannon by George V. Allen has occasioned any shift.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A firm that has made a specialty of monumental architecture, the John McShain Company of Philadelphia, today was awarded on a lowest-bid basis the general contract for the renovation, repair and modernization of the White House.

While the sale of women's sportswear has fallen off, the decline has not been as great as in other segments of the apparel trades, it was pointed out yesterday by B. H. Lerner, executive director of the National Skirt and Sportswear Association.

A "garment airlift" that has been operating between the New York metropolitan area and Dallas, Tex., has resulted in a "black" financial statement for Slick Airways, Inc., one of the country's all-cargo airlines that was certified for regular service three months ago, it was announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, Nov. 3 (UP) -- The political weekly New Times attacked George Morgan, First Secretary of the United States Embassy, today as guilty of falsification, slander and warmongering.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 3 -An expansion of high school pupils' knowledge of atomic energy and the United Nations will be among the goals of a contemplated exchange of pupils between the high schools of Bronxville and Oak Ridge, Tenn.

Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr., a former president of the New York Junior League, heads the committee for the Junior League Ball to be given Thanksgiving night, Nov. 24, in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton for the provisional members of the organization, all of whom are debutantes of this season.

The first broadcast in this country by Benjamin Britten, British composer, and Peter Pears, English tenor, will be carried by WQXR Wednesday evening from 10:30 to 11 o'clock. The two artists recently began a six-week concert-recital tour, and this will be the only local broadcast during their trip.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mayor O'Dwyer has great personal charm and for generations there hasn't been a glad-hander in New York City to equal him. But glad-handing and personal charm alone don't fit a man to do a good job in the toughest post in the world, namely, that of Mayor of the city of New York.

" The Wicked Duchess," a French-made romantic drama, described as an adaptation of the Balzac story, "La Duchesse de Langeais," which was to have been "the basis for the recently canceled Walter Wanger production starring Greta Garbo," will open today at the Arcadia, Third Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.
The merger of Stuyvesant Square Hospital, formerly known as the New York Skin and Cancer Hospital, with the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center was announced yesterday.
A battle of sound trucks was joined at 9 o'clock last night on Broadway between Eightieth and Eighty-first Streets.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 -- The ideological conflict within the Congress of Industrial Organizations was accented today by sharp debates at the annual convention over the issues of foreign policy and the CIO's decision to help form a new world Labor Federation opposing the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 29 were 7 per cent below those in the corresponding week of 1948, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The board listed percentage changes from corresponding periods last year as follows:

The three suburban counties of Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk, Republican in their voting tendencies, are again expected to give the party's local tickets and John Foster Dulles, candidate for United States Senator, safe majorities on election day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- An excess of concentrated, private economics power has fostered big government and big unions and is driving this country toward socialism, T. K. Quinn, president of the T. K. Quinn Company, New York, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today.
Spring fashion forecasts for the younger generation are presented in a campus scene in "Fashions of the Times" -- eighth edition -- now showing at Times Hall.

Senator John Foster Dulles warned last night that the election of his Democratic-Liberal opponent, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, would mean the loss to housewives of important household moneys that would go to support "Mr. Truman's and Mr. Lehman's perpetual-motion vote-getting machine.

Eleven hundred persons attended a dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for Irving Geist, manufacturer and philanthropist. It was given by ten veterans' organizations in appreciation for his efforts on behalf of wounded, sick and disabled former service men.

Retail prices on four cuts of pork have dropped 2 to 4 cents in the last week. In the wholesale market tariffs on this meat yesterday were at the lowest level for the year. This downward trend bears out predictions the United States Department of Agriculture has been making that pork soon would be plentiful and reasonably priced.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -- Sultan Hamid of Pontianak, leader of the Federalist delegation to the round-table conference here, said today it would be difficult to "calm" the home governments over the failure to include New Guinea in the new republic.

Well rounded curves and handcraft touches lend an air of opulence and sophistication to a group of contemporary furniture introduced yesterday at the opening of Modern Architecture, Inc., 20 East Sixty-sixth Street. All of the pieces on display including the fabric coverings were designed by Ernst Schwadron and are available from the showroom through architects and decorators.

Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, accused Senator John Foster Dulles, his Republican opponent, last night of waging a "very phony" campaign against the Democratic administration's "welfare state."
The president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday a study had begun on possibilities of a merger of overseas communications companies.

CAIRO, Nov. 3 -- Egypt's coalition Cabinet of all parties, formed in midsummer, fell today. Less than four hours later the same Premier, Hussein Sirry Pasha, formed a new caretaker Cabinet of independents without party support. This new Cabinet, governing by royal decrees, will prepare for elections.

Several thousand persons went on a rampage in Harlem for two hours last night in a tumultuous outburst in celebration of the release, under $20,000 bail, of City Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr., one of the eleven top Communists recently convicted of conspiring to teach and advocate the overthrow of the United States Government.
Payment for legal help to persons unable to afford it is the function of private citizens rather than of the Government, Judge Bruce Bromley of the Court of Appeals, said yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 3 -- The American Institute of Steel Construction, at its annual convention here, announced today the adoption of an educational program under which it will conduct annually a competition on the basis of which it will award ten scholarships of $1,000 each in American colleges and technical schools.

" Out In the Mid-Day Sun," an account of day-to-day life in northern India, by Monica Martin, will be published on Nov. 14 by Little, Brown. The author, who accompanied her husband in 1923 to the Indian mica fields, spent sixteen years in that country, returning to England in 1939 because of ill health.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Shepard Stone, Assistant Sunday Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was named today by the State Department as a special consultant on information and cultural affairs in Germany.

An effort by fifty anti-Communist members of the United Office and Professional Workers to make plans for standing by the Congress of Industrial Organizations was frustrated last night when 100 left-wing members of the union conducted a brief "sit-down strike" in the meeting room the right-wingers had hired at the New Yorker Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Census Bureau released new estimates today on the population of each state as of last July 1.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Business on the London stock markets was again on a subdued scale today. Prices generally were steady, although British Government securities and South African gold-mining issues sagged.

The two management representatives most prominently associated with the development of peaceful labor relations in the city's towering office, loft and apartment buildings have been quietly dropped from their posts by the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, it became known yesterday.

Business loans in this area climbed again last week for the tenth time in a row, although signs of tapering-off were forecast in banking circles. Statistics for the week ended on Wednesday released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank in New York and covering the member New York City banks showed a rise of $15,000,000 in loans for commercial, industrial and agricultural needs to $4,873,000,000.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- The residential apartments of the Chinese Embassy here were forcibly occupied this afternoon by six former members of the Embassy staff and three former members of the Consulate staff, all of whom had declared for the Communist regime of Mao Tze-tung on Oct. 10.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Governor Dewey declared here tonight that the Democratic opposition had been setting up bogus liberalism issues during the present campaign that would be completely forgotten after election day. He said that it had always been the practice of the Democratic opposition to make empty promises during a political campaign solely to win votes.

Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, defended yesterday bigness in business as "good for American industrial society," despite "considerable clamor by Government" as to whether it is good or evil.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 3 -- This year's Nobel Prize for Chemistry was awarded today to Dr. William Francis Giauque, Professor of Physical Chemistry at the University of California. The prize for physics went to a Japanese, Dr. Hideki Yukawa, who is now visiting Professor of Physics at Columbia University.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3 -- There were five main developments here today as right and left wingers fought for control of Westinghouse Local 601, United Electrical Workers, one of the key locals in the 400,000-member US. The local has a membership estimated at about 15,000.

The two-story dwelling and greenhouses at 52-16-18-22 and 53-12 Marathon Parkway in Little Neck, Queens, occupied by Soji and Kuniko Tanaka for their flower business have been purchased by them from Julia Stora. The property occupies an irregular plot about 161 by 703 feet.

CRAWFORD, Me., Nov. 3 -- Those who looked at the lowering clouds at daybreak this morning and hoped it meant a promise of a tracking snow before noon were disappointed as well as wet, for the snow appeared in the form of rain.

If the voters approve Amendment 7 on election day, exempting $150,000,000 from the city's debt limit, this will greatly improve the municipal hospital system, but even that sum is inadequate, authorities said yesterday.

RICHLAND, Wash., Nov. 3 -- The vast Hanford Works of the Atomic Energy Commission is at the threshold of the second phase of a $400,000,000 post-war expansion program. The start of construction awaits only completion of some design details of "important facilities."

CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 -- A strike of stock handlers at the Chicago stockyards has been set for 6 P. M. Monday, it was announced here today by Frank Monaghan, president of the Chicago Stock Handlers Union, Local 44 of the Packinghouse Workers Union, CIO.

WARSAW, Nov. 3 -- The American Joint Distribution Committee has been directed to wind up its relief and rehabilitation activities in Poland, William Bein, director of the organization's work here, disclosed today. The order, issued by Wladyslaw Wolski, the Minister of Public Administration, followed close upon similar action to oust the International Committee of the Red Cross and the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe (CARE).

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 3 (AP) -- A state arbitration board today directed provisional reinstatement of five officials of a local of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, to their jobs at Bell Aircraft Corporation. It decided against the rehiring of six persons described as "poor security risks."

ERIE, Pa., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Walter W. Landseidel, 55 years old, of Elmira, N. Y., chief research engineer for Remington Rand, Inc., was killed in an auto-truck collision last night on Route 5 a few miles east of Erie. Clarence Steen, 57, also of Elmira, another passenger in the car, was injured.

The accessories worn in the "Fashions of the Times" are rich and varied, each field -- jewelry, bags, gloves, shoes, umbrellas and neckwear -- projecting its own story for spring. In bags, the theme was one of simplicity, of evening fashions with casual restraint.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Guy George Gabrielson, Republican National Chairman, called upon the Columbia Broadcasting System to give his party comparable radio time over the same network to reply to President Truman's speech tonight at St. Paul, Minn.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 3 -- University of California students asserted today that officials had turned the institution into a "young ladies' boarding school" by ordering soft drinks and chaperones for all student parties.
MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- A top Russian scientist today said that Soviet scientists in the past year had discovered hitherto unknown characteristics of radiation from atomic nuclei.
The New York City Ballet Company will open its fall season of sixteen performances at the City Center on Nov. 23. Four new ballets and several new artists will be presented.

Charging that the "smear" campaign conducted against Senator John Foster Dulles had been unsuccessful, Representative William L. Pfeiffer, Republican state chairman, predicted yesterday the election of Mr. Dulles by a plurality of 250,000.

With a look back at the early horse-drawn ambulance and the quaint costume of nurses in the '80's, Roosevelt Hospital celebrated yesterday afternoon the eightieth anniversary of the laying of its cornerstone.

The rise in prices of stocks was halted by profit-taking yesterday. There was no real force behind the realizing, but its persistence had the effect of lowering bids by prospective buyers. On balance, losses exceeded gains by only a small margin and the composite rate sagged 0.43 point.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 3 -- An alternative scheme for river-basin development to obviate the highly controversial proposal for a "regional - authority" system was broached today at the annual convention of the National Reclamation Association.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Effective date of a ruling to impose a 20 per cent sales tax on all fur coats, without exception, was postponed today by the Internal Revenue Bureau until March 1, 1950.

The eleven Communist leaders went free on bail last night pending appeal from their conviction for criminal conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 3 -- Measuring off his Fair Deal into ten basic points, President Truman declared tonight that he was steering the nation to a better way of life on a middle course between the revolutionary left and the despairing right.

Players of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra were presented when that body gave its concert under the direction of Leopold Stokowski last night in Carnegie Hall. For on that occasion the concerto grosso for three solo trombones and tuba composed by Arcady Dubensky, violinist, and performed by the three trombonists and tuba player of the orchestra, unnamed on the program, was given its first performance.

The Chester Municipal Authority, Pa., sold yesterday $5,680,000 of serial and term water revenue bonds due from Dec. 1, 1950 to 1988, to a banking syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., at a net interest cost of 2.793 per cent.

VINELAND, N. J., Nov. 3 -- State Senator Elmer H. Wene, Democratic candidate for Governor, asserted today that the "one-man rule" of his Republican opponent, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, "means government by fakery, scandal, slander and deceit."

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 3 -- Without a dissenting vote, the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today adopted a resolution calling for the return to Greece of an estimated 25,000 Greek children now living in Eastern Europe.

Results of the first course in retail men's apparel merchandising given by the evening and extension division of City College Midtown Center under the sponsorship of the Associated Men's Wear Retailers of New York were hailed as "highly satisfactory" yesterday at a luncheon in the Statler Hotel.

The steel strike, which has caused drum container manufacturers to curtail production and put customers on a quota basis, has spurred the call for reconditioned drums, Morris Hershon, president, reported yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of the National Barrel and Drum Association at the Statler Hotel.

Aubrey Pankey, baritone, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. His program contained three arias of Handel, lieder by Schubert and Schumann, songs by Guastavino, Alvarez and Sibelius and a final group of Negro spirituals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- United States imports increased from $490,600,000 in August to $530,500,000 in September, while exports increased from $880,700,000 to $904,300,000, the Department of Commerce announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The coal strike cut sharply into the earnings of Eastern railroads during September, the Association of American Railroads reported today. It said the estimated net income for all railroads was down in that month but the Eastern carriers were hardest hit.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 3 (UP) -- The Government disclosed tonight that Archbishop Josef Beran and his Bishops would have to take an oath of loyalty to the Communist regime in the presence of Premier Antonin Zapotocky.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Dr. Karl T. Compton, noted atomic physicist, resigned today as chairman of the Research and Development Board of the Department of Defense. In a letter to President Truman, Dr. Compton said his decision was dictated by reasons of health.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 3 (UP) -- Dr. William F. Giauque said today he was "pleased" to have the Nobel Prize in Chemistry and described himself as "one of those fortunate people who gets a kick out of my work."
THERE is no sense in stalling. We might just as well take the big plunge. So here goes.
Eight small children were rescued from a burning Queens home at 2 A. M. yesterday by the combined efforts of their father and mother, an uncle who lived next door and a city fireman.

Five members of Congress, returning from official surveys of housing conditions and Marshall Plan progress in Western Europe, were among the 2,198 passengers who arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.

The cotton futures market closed 3 points higher to 10 points lower yesterday as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange continued moderately active. The only advance was registered in the near December option.

The tide of Mexican Army victories continued at full flood yesterday at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden as the riders of the republic swept the team events of the afternoon and evening.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 3 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, announced tonight the receipt of $8,626,506 from the trustees of the Gordon McKay Endowment.
Don Newcombe, big Negro pitcher of the Brooklyn Dodgers, was voted yesterday the National League's rookie of the year in an Associated Press poll.

The 10,800-ton Yaffo, the third unit in a four-ship acquisition program to enter the service of the Israel - America Line between the United States and Israel, will arrive here tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by Raphael Recanati, general manager of the line and also of the American-Israeli Shipping Company, which are its agents in New York.
PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Sam Snead clung to his one-stroke North and South open golf tournament lead with a 2-under par 70 today for a 138 total for 36 holes.
WASHINGTON, Nov 3 -- During the week ended Nov. 2, member bank reserve balances increased $339,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
New York County commanders of five veterans' organizations have joined in condemning the Mitchell-VanDuzer Amendment (No. 5 on the ballot) which will be voted upon Tuesday.

Despite the benefits of an interim increase in rates estimated at $26,000,000 a year when it went into effect on June 9, the New York Telephone Company's net income of $25,301,901 for the twelve months to Sept. 30 was a drop of $7,421,947 from the $32,723,848 reported for the preceding twelve-month period, according to a report issued yesterday.
When it comes to bread, the British public wants something "more solid to bite at" than the "soft" bread baked here, L. F. Cadwallader of London said here yesterday.

HONG KONG, Nov. 3 -- Communist propaganda over recent weeks makes plain that the Chinese Communists have decided the best way to sell Sino-Soviet cooperation to the Chinese people is openly to proclaim and justify the Soviet link-up.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Captain Spero Callimanis of the Greek reighter Aristocratis scrambled up the rigging today to deliver a message from the United States Government to his three mast-sitting crewmen.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 3 -- Moshe Sharett, Israeli Foreign Minister, read messages from President Truman an Sergei I. Vavilov, president of the Academy of Sciences in the Soviet Union, at tonight's banquet winding up the celebrations in connection with the opening of the department of physics and physical chemistry of the Weizmann Institute of Science.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week increased somewhat. Industrial production, originating shipments and trade all showed gains, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3 -- A 24-year-old safecracker told the police today how he became an expert at his business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan announced today a 1950 burley tobacco production program calling upon growers as a whole to plant 10 per cent fewer acres than they did this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Foreign Secretaries of the United States, Britain and France will meet in Paris, probably next Wednesday or Thursday, for another general review of foreign policy questions affecting the three nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Leaders of seven national Jewish organizations appealed to the State Department today to send a "commission of neutral observers" to Iraq to investigate charges that the Iraqi Government is persecuting the Jewish minority there.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States partly lifted its ban on shipments of "war-potential" materials to Eastern Europe today in a move to bolster the civil aviation of Yugoslavia.

Dresser Industries, Inc., of Cleveland, producer of derricks and other equipment for oil and gas drilling, has bought all the capital stock of the Magnet Cove Barium Corporation of Houston, Tex., the nation's second largest manufacturer of drilling "mud," it was announced here yesterday by H. N. Mallon, president of Dresser.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A brisk workout that included both offensive and defensive tactics to be employed against the Navy Saturday afternoon occupied Tulane's Green Wave today.

Following settlement of the strike at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation on Monday, scrap metal prices began to show strength again after having been rather stable during the steel strike. Scrap, one of the principal raw materials of the steel industry, had been rising since the beginning of August.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., Nov. 3 -- Election of Senator John Foster Dulles as "a key builder of our vital bipartisan foreign policy was urged tonight by Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, in a speech at a Republican meeting here attended by 850 persons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, Rochester, N. Y., had filed with it a registration statement covering 132,000 shares of no-par value common stock.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 3 -- Domingo Esguerra, Foreign Minister, objected in a statement to the newspaper Espectador yesterday to a recent comment on the present political situation in Colombia by Alberto Lleras, secretary of the Organization of American States.

ROME, Nov. 3 -- A long step was taken today toward settling the unrest among peasants in the province of Catanzaro when an agreement was signed between representatives of the landlords and the Peasants' Union. The unrest had led to widespread occupation by peasants of privately owned land, and this, in turn, had led to a serious clash with the police last Sunday, in which two were killed and seventeen wounded.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 --Sherman E. Johnson, Assistant Chief of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, told the Annual Outlook Conference today that around 35,000,000 acres of crop land should be shifted away from staple commodities likely to become surplus.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -Alexander Paal, who is producing "A Tale of Five Cities" in London and four continental capitals, will make another film, according to a similar plan, in this country, England, France, Italy and Germany under the title "Goodbye, U. S. A."

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, attacked the O'Dwyer administration yesterday for "rank favoritism" to the Empire City Racing Association on the one hand and a Democratic member of Congress on the other.
Two of New York's professional football coaches yesterday professed deep concern about their respective opponents Sunday, while a third was merely hopeful and more or less relaxed.

A M Karagheusian, Inc., yesterday increased mill prices on its entire Gulistan line of rugs and carpets an average of 5 per cent, effective Nov. 21. Retailers said the action marks the opening gun in an industry-wide increase in rugs and carpets and predicted that Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company will follow the Karagheusian lead almost immediately.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 3 -- The Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament, voted this evening to continue this city as the capital of the West German Federal Republic, defeating an attempt by many of its members to move to Frankfort.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- By a vote of 116 to 29 the House of Lords, which is dominated by the Conservative party, adopted a motion tonight criticizing the Labor Government's economy proposals as inadequate.

Following is the text of the address by President Truman in St. Paul, Minn., last night at the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the creation of Minnesota as a territory of the United States, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Action continued at a brisk pace last night at the 22d Engineers Armory where the six-day bicycle race attracted a crowd of 6,000 enthusiastic fans. The field, reduced to eight teams from the thirteen that started on Sunday night, displayed a ceaseless willingness to hold a speedy pace.

Allen Licht, arrested and later freed in 1948 as the central figure in an international diamond mystery, was re-arrested yesterday on the same charge by Treasury agents upon his arrival here aboard the S.S. De Grasse. United States Commissioner Edward W. McDonald held Licht in $2,500 bail for action of the Federal grand jury on a theft allegation.

INWOOD, L. I., Nov. 3 -- A tall, gaunt former police official -- gentle and reserved -- sat in his trim two-story home here today and looked back over a twenty-five-year career as a member of the Nassau County Police Department, and spoke of his new calling, the ministry. Last Monday night, Lieut. Samuel C. Wood signed the book in Police Headquarters at Mineola for the last time.

Laura Boulton, explorer and lecturer whose specialty is the study of folk music at its source, will leave here Monday on the first leg of an expedition that will carry her to India, Indonesia, Tibet, the Philippines, Borneo, Siam, Burma and possibly Western China.

Raymond Rodriquez of George Washington turned in an impressive time of 14:01.4 yesterday in taking first place in the Manhattan division of the P. S. A. L. borough cross-country runs at Van Cortlandt Park.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- The Foreign Ministers of Norway, Sweden and Denmark called on W. Averell Harriman, Marshall Plan Ambassador, today to say they intended to take prompt action toward forming a customs union of the three countries in conformity with the approval of Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, Monday and the European Marshall Plan Council's approval yesterday of regional blocs to reduce trade barriers.

EASTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 3 -- During the war Lou Gebhard was the football coach at C. C. N. Y. As head of the Lavender's gridiron fortunes he used to have his hands full merely finding enough players to make up two squads for a scrimmage.

Philip Le Boutillier, president of Best Co. and chairman of the Gold Standard League, took exception yesterday to certain references to convertible currency made Wednesday by Allan Sproul, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, in a speech before the American Bankers Association in San Francisco.

Because of good results in the European Travel Commission's campaign to promote off-season travel to Europe, it will be extended into the early part of next year with a probable budget increase, it was learned yesterday. Bookings to Europe, it was said, are running ahead of last year.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 3 -- As a result of the expulsion of the pro-Communist United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union from the Congress of Industrial Organizations at the national convention in Cleveland, a contest for control of thirty-six UE locals in New Jersey opened today between right and left wings.

The price of copper was raised 7/8 cent a pound late yesterday, according to metal traders, but not all large producers followed. Trade circles reported Phelps Dodge Corporation was the first to post the increase. Later officials of Kennecott Copper Corporation said the company was "out of the market."

BATAVIA, Java, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Dutch, extending a friendly hand toward their prospective partner, the United States of Indonesia, today gave amnesty to several thousand Indonesian political prisoners who had committed "misdemeanors clearly emanating from political conflict" between the Netherlands and the Indonesians.

ALBANY, Nov. 3 -- The emergency committee appointed by Governor Dewey to study the effects of the coal and steel strikes on the state's economy, said today that thousands of workers had been made idle and that the adverse results would "snowball" in the next two or three weeks.

Ben Rose has borrowed from such varied design sources as African primitive art and the common rose for the four new fabrics and wallpapers he introduced yesterday at his showroom at 15 East Fifty-third Street. A thread of similarity is apparent, however, in the designer's geometric treatment of all four patterns.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, Jr.'s 7-year-old Trough Hill today easily won the twelfth Battleship Steeplechase, named for the only American-bred horse to win the English Grand National.
OFFENBACH, Germany, Nov. 3 -- The Offenbach City Council elected as a city physician tonight a Jewish doctor whose appointment earlier had been blocked by alleged anti-Semitism.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 3 -- Debate on the question of electing new members to the United Nations seemed for a brief moment late this afternoon to be drawing close to a vote on three resolutions affecting fourteen countries seeking membership.

Although devaluation of the pound sterling was greeted as a panacea for Britain's economic ills and as a stimulus to United States imports, anticipated gains have not materialized, Frederick W. Richmond, president of the United States Foreign Corporation, stated yesterday at the corporation's headquarters at 745 Fifth Avenue.

At least ten years will elapse before the pound sterling becomes freely convertible into dollars, Miss Barbara Ward, British economist, said yesterday. In an interview following her appearance as guest speaker before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, Miss Ward said convertibility would be attained by stages, the first of which would be the convertibility of the various currencies of Western Europe among the Marshall Plan nations.

VIENNA, Nov. 3 -- The conclusion today of a two-day meeting to the Austrian Socialists called to discuss continued cooperation with the People's party in a coalition government opened the way for the constitution of a new Cabinet. It also made certain that the new government's most important immediate task would be the devaluation of the Austrian schilling in terms of other currencies.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Grain prices were on the upgrade in the early trading, on the Board of Trade today but grains other than corn weakened later on profit-taking. The early upturn carried May wheat, all deliveries of corn except the December, and May and July ats sold at new seasonal prices, with December corn at a new high since last February.
NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 3 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll approached the end of his campaign for re-election today with a series of rallies, receptions and parades in Essex County.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Building Officials Conference of America today voted to set up a committee to work out a system of cooperation with the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency in promoting better building codes and the enforcement of building laws.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 3 -- With all the tumult and shouting over the revivification of Fordham and its approaching game with Army, other football attractions listed for Saturday in the East have been pretty well starving from neglect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Admiral Forrest P. Sherman moved briskly into his new duties as Chief of Naval Operations today by abolishing a unit in his office known as the Organizational Research and Policy Division. He said that its functions had been completed.

Science muscled in a little further on a new field -- the traditional lore of Christmas -- yesterday, as the Abraham Straus department store in Brooklyn opened its 1949 Toyland with a preview for underprivileged children.

POMONA, Calif., Nov. 3 -- A three-way race for the Republican nomination for United States Senator in the 1950 election was forecast here tonight as Representative Richard M. Nixon of Whittier announced his candidacy.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, Jr.'s 7-year-old Trough Hill today easily won the twelfth Battleship Steeplechase, named for the only American-bred horse to win the English Grand National.
OFFENBACH, Germany, Nov. 3 -- The Offenbach City Council elected as a city physician tonight a Jewish doctor whose appointment earlier had been blocked by alleged anti-Semitism.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 3 -- Debate on the question of electing new members to the United Nations seemed for a brief moment late this afternoon to be drawing close to a vote on three resolutions affecting fourteen countries seeking membership.

Although devaluation of the pound sterling was greeted as a panacea for Britain's economic ills and as a stimulus to United States imports, anticipated gains have not materialized, Frederick W. Richmond, president of the United States Foreign Corporation, stated yesterday at the corporation's headquarters at 745 Fifth Avenue.

POMONA, Calif., Nov. 3 -- A three-way race for the Republican nomination for United States Senator in the 1950 election was forecast here tonight as Representative Richard M. Nixon of Whittier announced his candidacy.
There is glitter a-plenty adorning the costumes featured in the eighth edition of "Fashions of the Times." From rhinestone tiaras down to rhinestone studded heels each model sparkled in her fashion.
Columbia, beaten in its last four games by teams that were undefeated and untied when they met the Lions, at last will get a chance at an opponent who has experienced adversity.

Acme Steel Company announced the reduction of its common stock dividend to 35 cents a share, compared with 40 cents paid on last Sept. 12. The dividend will be paid on Dec. 12. The September payment was the first made after the stock was split two for one, on June 15.

The New York Chapter of the Society of Industrial Realtors elected new officers at its annual meeting last Tuesday. Bernard L. Hegeman, Brooklyn broker, was named president; Robert E. Forman of Cross Brown Company, vice president, and Harry Schroeder Jr., of William A. White Sons and John S. Turnbull of Joseph P. Day, Inc., were re-elected treasurer and secretary, respectively.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Benjamin Sosner, 42-year-old first violinist of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, collapsed and died last night during a scherzo. It was the orchestra's first concert of the season and Reginald Stewart was conducting Brahms' Symphony No. 1.

OTTAWA, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Dominion Government plans to allow landlords to increase home rentals by 20 to 25 per cent, Finance Minister Douglas Abbott announced tonight in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The State Department opened negotiations with eight adherents of the North Atlantic treaty today for the purpose of reaching agreement on the shipment of arms and supplies to them.
The Celanese Corporation of America, manufacturer of synthetic yarns and fabrics, reported yesterday a net profit of $10,988,870 for the first nine months of the current year.

The Whitney Museum will hold this afternoon a preview of an exhibition of paintings and drawings by Alfred H. Maurer, the American artist who turned his back on a successful academic career, lived in Paris from 1897 until the first World War, became a pioneer of the modern movement in this country with scant recognition and died by his own hand in 1932.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Human relations was described today as the "No. 1 problem of the United States" at the opening session of the third National Conference on Intergroup Relations.

It is good to learn that the State Department has realized the defects of its information system and is trying to remove them. These defects are largely the heritage of the past, when the hush-hush attitude was considered proper and necessary. They are not to be blamed either on Mr. Acheson or on George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary and head of the Public Affairs section.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, declared last night that Mayor O'Dwyer's efforts to rally labor to his support have proved futile and that "labor just isn't for him."

The late Fiorello H. La Guardia was eulogized yesterday by Sava N. Kosanovitch, Yugoslavian Ambassador to the United States, as a "great American and great friend" of the Yugoslavian people. Mr. Kosanovic spoke at a farewell reception for the La Guardia Delegation of the One World Award Committee at the Pierre Hotel, 795 Fifth Avenue.

Mrs. Foeko van der Laan gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 10 East Eighty-first Street, for members of the debutante and junior committees aiding in the plans for the annual Silver Spoon cocktail party and tea dance in behalf of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service to be held on Nov. 25 at the Stork Club.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Branch Rickey and Fred Saigh parted company today but they apparently parted with none of their players.
TORONTO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- City fathers continued to fire verbal broadsides at Maple Leaf Gardens today for moving their complimentary hockey tickets to a cheaper section.

In adopting its new Master Plan for low rent housing and development of designated areas throughout the city, the City Planning Commission has taken a constructive step toward redevelopment and replanning generally, not only for housing purposes, but also for industrial and commercial purposes.

Three major functions of management offer potentials for cutting costs from 10 to as much as 50 per cent or more, three leading industrialists told more than 800 members of the Society for the Advancement of Management at their fifteenth annual conference at the Hotel Statler.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Oct. 29 were 591,317 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Complementing the 140 fashions that appeared in the "Fashions of the Times" was a selection of shoes from the barest evening sandals down to snug, felt after-ski boots. Represented were satins dyed in pastels and jeweled colors to match gowns; variations of the suede pumps and shell pumps; tailored cart pumps, and beach and play shoes.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Tom O'Brien, leader of the film workers trade union, today called for a 20,000,000 ($56,000,000) Government loan to set the British film industry on its feet. Meanwhile, another 130 film workers joined the 1,500 thrown out of work this year by the crisis in the industry, with difficulty in finding financial backers for new British productions said to be the root of the crisis.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The admission of the Western German state as soon as possible as an associate member of the Council of Europe was approved today by the Council's Committee of Ministers. The approval was passed on to the Consultative Assembly for opinion.

HADDONFIELD, N. J., Nov. 4 -The efficient and constructive three-year administration of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll has attracted favorable attention throughout the nation and is worthy of the support of voters of all political parties, Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, said here tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 4 -- France offered today a more detailed plan than that of Secretary General Trygve Lie for the protection of refugees and stateless persons remaining after the International Refugee Organization ends its work in 1951.

A double-header composed of "Zamba" and "Black Shadows" will be the new bill opening this morning at the Gotham. "Zamba" is a jungle adventure story played by Jon Hall, June Vincent and Jane Nigh. "Black Shadows" is a documentary filmed in the Belgian Congo by Andre Cauvin, the director-producer.

Its eleventh annual convention this week in Cleveland may well go down as a landmark in the history of the CIO. For it was here that the decision was firmly and irrevocably taken that there is no place for Communists in a labor organization that believes in the democratic form of government.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- In contrast with conditions two years ago there is now apparently ample supplies of footwear and other leather goods in retail stores in Western Europe, it was declared here today by Julius G. Schnitzer, chief, textile and leather division of the Office of International Trade, Department of Commerce.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 4 -- Egypt demanded today that a United Nations mission of experts be sent to investigate "inhuman exploitation" of native peoples in Tunisia, Morocco and other sections of French North Africa.

FAIRMONT, W. Va., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Charles I. Dawson, a former Louisville judge, today became the coal operators' representative on the board of trustees of the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund.
Ending its four-day run, the eighth edition of "Fashions of the Times" was cited yesterday for performing a unique service for the city's largest single industry.

Advertising in the eight major New York daily newspapers during October totaled 14,756,169 lines, a decrease of 2.36 per cent from that of a year ago, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: automotive, up 2.69 per cent, and financial, .77 per cent.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The stock markets here closed on a dull note today, with losses scattered freely among most of the chief sections. Generally, however, the declines were slight.

The two-story factory building with offices on plot 75 by 100 feet at 236 East 138th Street, near Rider Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Gerosa-Paladino Holding Corporation to the Peller Corporation for investment. Friedman, Marx Handler were the attorneys for the seller and Barry Katzman for the buyer, who paid cash over a purchase money mortgage of $30,000.

Speaking from a sound truck in the garment center at a rally sponsored by unionists in the Liberal party, Newbold Morris, Republican-Fusion-Liberal nominee for Mayor, declared yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer and Frank Costello, reputed slot-machine king, had been seen "talking politics."
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The biggest day for Fordham football in years comes tomorrow in the meeting here between the Ram from Rose Hill and Army. The kick-off is cheduled for 2 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Ampal-American Trading Corporation of New York filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $6,250,000 of its ten-year, 3 per cent, sinking fund debentures, due April 1, 1958, and 200,000 shares of Class A, $10 par value stock.

Though this year's raisin crop hasn't broken records for size, it is large enough to rate a place on the United States Department of Agriculture's list of plentiful foods. About 1,600,000 tons of the dried fruit (made from four times that amount of grapes) are expected to be harvested in California, the state that supplies 95 per cent of the raisins eaten by Americans.

United States Attorney Irving H. Saypol refused yesterday to let five of the bailed Communist leaders visit their homes outside this Federal district without a court order barring them from teaching and advocating violent overthrow of the Government.

NEWCASTLE ON TYNE, Oct. 27 -- In this "heartland" of heavy industry, with its bustling shipyards, chemical plants and engineering works, the average British workingman has just begun to think about the economic crisis.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler announced today that 249 bonus players will be included among the minor leagues eligible for the 1949 major league draft which will be held here on Nov. 17.
John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, denounced Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, last night for his "baseless, vicious, deliberate vilification" of him.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 4 -- Hector McNeil, British Minister of State, proposed today that the people of Libya be left free to decide what kind of government they de sired, instead of being required by the United Nations General Assembly to establish a unified government when Libya becomes independent.
No thematic thread holds together seven widely varied one-man shows of paintings now on exhibition.

Roger Sessions finished his First Symphony in 1927 and it had its first performance that year by the Boston Symphony under Serge Koussevitzky. It was not until last night, however, that the work received a New York hearing, when it was played by the Juilliard Orchestra under the direction of Jean Morel.
MANILA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- An occupation source in Japan says Gen. Douglas MacArthur expects a peace treaty with that country to be signed in Tokyo early next year.

Herbert Charles Co. were the brokers in the recent sale of 68 East Fifty-sixth Street by Esther Dorothy, Inc., to Maxwell L. Low, operator, who resold the property to Greeley Annex, Inc., in a deal negotiated by the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company and Henry C. Lemle, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The United States Government announced today more stringent controls on exports of strategic commodities to most of the world in an effort to forestall reshipment of such goods to the Soviet Union or other countries behind the Iron Curtain.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Prof. J. D. Bernal, who declared in Moscow that scientists in the West were tools of capitalism was dropped today from the Council of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

With the financial district's most favored marketing day for new securities pre-empted by the Election Day holiday, the supply of new marketable investments scheduled for next week is on the scant side. The biggest new-money transaction will be a three-fold requisition by the Central Maine Power Company.

MANILA, Nov. 4 -- Former President Sergio Osmena broke three and a half years of political silence and retirement from public life today with a stern appeal to the Filipino people to observe clean, free balloting on Nov. 8 in the Presidential election.

Pressure group activity through a self-appointed committee seeking a return to the committee system of governing the New York Stock Exchange was assailed in sharp language yesterday by Emil Schram, president.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- The grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade here today, easing after an early upturn which carried December and May oats to new highs for the year to date, while December and May wheat in Kansas City and Minneapolis and oats in the latter market and Winnipeg were also in new ground.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Czechoslovakia's Communist Government tonight rejected the United States' stiff protest against the expulsion of two United States diplomats and the arrest of a United States Embassy clerk, all on espionage charges.

In the Oct. 30 "Review of the Week" THE NEW YORK TIMES refers to the fact that the job of Mayor of New York City has been called the second toughest administrative job in the United States and points out that the Mayor runs a city of eight million people through 109 departments and agencies.
Columbia's battered Lions will return to Baker Field today for the first time in a month to play host to Tuss McLaughry's strong Dartmouth eleven. Kick-off time is scheduled for 1:30 P. M.
Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman pledged himself last night to fight for passage by the Senate of President Truman's civil rights program in its entirety when Congress convenes next January.
Gerald Coleman, graceful second baseman of the New York Yankees, is the top rookie in the American League.

TOKYO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A qualified occupation source said today Japanese newspapers and publishers had been told it would be "unwise" to publish a new American book about the trial of Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita, who was put to death for war crimes in the Philippines.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The British will try to keep the agenda of the Paris meeting of the Big Three Western foreign ministers next week strictly to the subject of Germany.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and final prices were 3 to 8 points net higher.
I would appreciate the opportunity of straightening out the record with respect to some of the things said by Beryl Harold Levey in his letter on behalf of Robert F. Wagner Jr.

The games played by members of the Eastern Hockey League on Sunday afternoons in Madison Square Garden will be added to the sports events available to New York television viewers beginning Nov. 13 at 3 P. M. when WPIX will begin coverage of the sixteen-game schedule of the New York Rovers.

Pledges of a continued fight for Lithuanian independence from the Soviet Union were made here yesterday by delegates to the Lithuanian American Congress. About 500 representatives attended the opening session of a three-day convention at the New Yorker Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission has ruled it has jurisdiction over gas sold by the Colorado Interstate Gas Company to the city of Colorado Springs and the Public Service Company of Colorado for use in their own steam and electric plants. The order reverses a tentative finding of Marvin Farrington, commission examiner.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 4 -- Liberalization of the Federal reclamation laws, under which $387,000,000 is being spent this year for Western water and power projects, will await a national survey of land and water resources by a special commission to be appointed by President Truman, it was authoritatively indicated today.

Of the eleven questions to be acted on by the voters next Tuesday probably none is surrounded by more controversy, misunderstanding and even misrepresentation than Amendment No. 5, which would revise the present system of veterans' preference in civil service employment in New York State.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 4 -- United Nations members were called on today by the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly to join in an arms embargo against Bulgaria and Albania until both countries stop all aid to the Greek guerrillas.

The Sgt. Joyce Kilmer Memorial Association, an affiliate of the Sgt. Joyce Kilmer Post No. 55 of the American Legion, better known in Brooklyn as the "gypsy" post because it has been so long without a "home," has contracted to buy the property at 386-88 East Fifteenth Street in Flatbush.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Four locals, representing 2,600 of some 30,000 electrical workers in the Philadelphia District, voted today to disaffiliate with the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers and join the newly chartered CIO International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers.

The Communist party is concentrating all of its Manhattan apparatus in the Twenty-first Senatorial District, which includes a large share of Harlem, in an effort to re-elect Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr., the only Communist party member holding an elective public office in the country and the only Negro member of the City Council.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 4 (UP) -- The Colombian Embassy in Washington was instructed today to protest against alleged intervention in internal Colombian politics by Alberto Lleras Camargo, Secretary General of the Organization of American States.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 4 -- After a thirty-day trek over the Himalayas against a hostile nature and many man-made obstacles, John Hall Paxton of Galesburg, Ill., United States consul general in Urumchi (Tihwa), capital of Sinkiang Province of Northwest China, reached New Delhi today.

The ghost of Andrei A. Zhdanov, arbiter in his day of Communist culture, can rest quietly in its grave. Soviet philosophy has now been safely tamed. It was Zhdanov who, in June, 1947, led the drive against the heresy contained in Prof. Georgi Alexandrov's book: "A History of Western European Philosophy."

The Boston Housing Authority borrowed $8,800,000 yesterday on tax-exempt one-year temporary loan notes at interest rates ranging from 0.6472 per cent to 0.73 per cent. A banking group headed by J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., bought $2,800,000 of first series notes and $2,100,000 of third series notes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics will start this month a three-year project to tighten up the Consumers' Price Index, formerly known as theh Cost-of-Living Index.

Given the right equipment and an ample supply of raw materials, Great Britain can increase production and sales of fertilizing materials from 40 to 50 per cent, according to members of the British fertilizing industry productivity team. The extra output is needed for domestic use.
New voices for men who never expected to talk again are being provided at the bronchoscopic clinic in Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, 210 East Sixty-fourth Street.

PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Sammy Snead had his putter working today, along with his famed long game, and romped in a six-stroke winner of the North and South Open golf tournament with a rousing 70, 66 finish for 274, fourteen under par.

ABRAHAM LINCOLN told a visitor who asked him how it felt to be President of the United States of America: "Well, I'm like the man they rode out of town on a rail. He said if it wasn't for the honor of the thing he'd just as soon walk."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Power-packed Villanova rocked Georgetown with a furious first-half assault tonight for the points to win the ball game and then fought off a determined last period rally for a 29-to-14 triumph.

"Behind the Bar," by A. E. Bowker, an account of exciting English criminal cases in the last fifty years, will be published on Nov. 21 by Staples Press, 70 East Forty-fifth Street. The author, "a barrister's clerk," served under two of England's colorful lawyers, Sir Edward Marshall Hall and Sir Norman Birkett, and was witness to the cases he describes.

Forecasting victory in a close duel with Mayor O'Dwyer, Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate, read his other rival, Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-City Fusion standard bearer, out of the mayoralty race yesterday.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 4 (AP) -- New Communist advances on the distant approaches to Chungking deepened the gloom of this provisional Chinese Nationalist capital today.

Today's events: "The Old Maid and the Thief" and "The Medium," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Sari Biro, pianist, assisted by an orchestra conducted by Emanuel Vardi, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Ben Jones, pianist, Town Hall, 3; Margareta Von Fielitz, soprano, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30.

At the close of trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, yesterday, coffee futures this week had risen slightly more than 7 cents a pound, the greatest price gains in any week since the war. The March S position advanced 709 points, while the remainder of the active trading months in S rose 530 to 645 points above the final close of the previous week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- The Justice Department announced today that General Electric, Westinghouse Electric and eight other companies have been fined $40,000 as a result of two anti-trust cases filed against them.
Criticism of the Maritime Commission and of its handling of ship construction subsidies is to be studied by the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries.
The issue of bingo in New Jersey politics came to the forefront again yesterday, with the election only four days off. The question was stressed not by politicians, but by religious groups.

Street and park lighting improvements, many of which are designed to curb crime in parks and help cut down the accident rate at heavily traveled road intersections, are planned for next year at a cost of $2,025,000, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, announced yesterday.

First effects of the steel strike on furniture and bedding were reported yesterday by several retailers who said the Simmons Company has substantially reduced shipments of Beautyrest mattresses and Hideabed dual purpose sleepings equipment.

Demand for railroad and public utility issues kept the stock market on an even keel yesterday, but elsewhere prices fluctuated irregularly. Increases in a few stocks ranged to a point and more and, although more issues showed gains than losses, the composite rate slipped off 0.48 point on weakness in a few key components.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. E. H. Augustus' Seven League, the 9-to-10 favorite, rallied in the stretch to beat Brookfield Farms' Itsabet by a length and a half in the featured Cohort Purse at Pimlico today.
More than 900 top executives in American industry were told yesterday to stop "talking to themselves" and to start preparing adequate programs of business information for use in employe education.

The fourteenth annual Tip Top Ball was given in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night for the benefit of Stony Wold Sanatorium at Lake Kushaqua in the Adirondacks. Many prefatory dinner parties were given in conjunction with the fete. The beneficiary provides care and treatment for needy young men and women afflicted with tuberculosis.

A $1,700,000 cargo of Yugoslav metals consigned to two New York metal concerns was brought to this country aboard the Yugoslav Government-owned freighter Hvratska, which arrived here yesterday from Philadelphia. She docked at Twentieth Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- An obscure little by-election for a seat on the London County Council had the leaders of the major parties wondering today what the result foreshadowed. For despite the general belief that Labor was slipping in popular appeal the Socialist candidate won a seat that at the last election had gone Conservative.

Surgeons are important persons in hospital operating rooms, and so are the nurses and attendants. One of the major tasks of the hospital staff, officials of the United Hospital Fund point out, is to assure complete and thorough sanitation of the operating rooms.
A wave of advances which consolidated prices of copper and brass products at a level about 1 cent a pound above recent quotations developed here yesterday.

Exclusive of public service advertising in the interests of dollar volume promotion was termed a "short-sighted mistake" yesterday by Major Benjamin H. Namm, department store head. He spoke at a meeting of business paper editors and publishers held in the Advertising Club to announce the advertising council's new series of public service ads for business publications.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 4 -- The current program of social aid administered by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund in Communist China probably soon will be supplemented by a Communist project for improving the welfare of China's masses, according to a first-hand report submitted here today to the Fund's executive board.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- The "Free Greek" radio announced tonight that the central committee of the Greek Communist party had admitted defeat but had decided to transfer guerrilla forces "to the mountains for a strong movement" against Government forces.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The lower the last three digits of his serial number, the sooner a veteran will get his National Service Life Insurance special refund.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Lee Hills of The Miami Herald was elected president today of The Associated Press Managing Editors Association. He succeeds William P. Stevens of The Minneapolis Tribune.

"We all know this is a changing city," said the dapper elderly visitor who always takes snuff, instead of a cigarette, "but this ninetieth anniversary of Cooper Union has brought me a surprising revelation.

Fashion has taken on a new angle -- perhaps it would be better to say that new angles for daytime and evening dresses are being made with triangular folds and diagonal lines and with drapes that suggest diamond facets and godets in wedge form.

GENEVA, Nov 4 -- One of the first results of the strong stand by the United States against the European practice of squeezing buyers of industrial raw materials has been the withdrawal of a British demand that Denmark pay a higher post-devaluation price for British coal, it was learned here today.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Officials in close touch with the relations of the Western powers predicted tonight that the principal, if not the only, topic that would be discussed by the three Western Foreign Ministers would be problems of Germany, notably the eventual entry of Germany into one of the regional economic blocs that Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, approved in addressing the European Marshall Plan Council.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Given four or five months more training, American ground troops throughout the world will be able "to take on anybody, any time, anywhere," Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, said today to the National Press Club.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 4 -- State Senator Elmer H. Wene, Democratic candidate for Governor, brought his campaign today into the home county of his Republican rival, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of nearby Haddonfield.

Holly Stores, Inc., special shop chain of which Leo Kossove is president, has leased 60,000 square feet of space on two floors in the building at 115 Fifth Avenue and 881 Broadway for the consolidation of its executive, buying and workroom operations now carried on at 498 Seventh Avenue and 20 West Thirty-seventh Street.

The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company declared an extra of 40 cents and a regular quarterly dividend of 40 cents on the common, both payable Dec. 23, it was announced yesterday. This is the first extra since the end of 1945 and brings total payments for 1949 to $2, compared with $1.60 in 1948.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Nov. 4 -- Election campaigning in Suffolk County is practically at an end except for last-minute vote appeals timed for delivery on the last day. An independent movement in two towns, Islip and Huntington, although aiming at the election of local candidates, has been waged against the Republican leadership of Representative W. Kingsland Macy with the result that the spotlight was not centered on men actually contending for office.

ROME, Nov. 4 -- A group of youngsters, including one wearing a blackshirt and another who bore aloft a picture of the late Benito Mussolini, gathered this morning in Milan's Piazza San Sepolcoro, the square where the first Fascist headquarters were founded, and started a dozen fist fights with outraged passersby.

CAIRO, Nov. 4 -- Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat, of Louisiana, chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee investigating overseas expenditures, stated before the committee left Cairo today to visit the oil regions of the Middle East that he had been informed that oil was the means by which Britain expected to cover her trade deficit.
Brig. Gen. Mikulas Ferjencik, former Slovak Minister of the Interior, who fled the Communist regime in his country in 1948, finally won refuge in the Uniteed States yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Informally announcing today that Secretary Acheson would meet with Mr. Bevin and M. Schuman in Paris next week, the State Department said that there would be a two-day discussion of "problems of common interest."

The first direct challenge to the low-cost domestic air transportation by non-scheduled airlines was made a year ago yesterday. On Nov. 4, 1948, Capital Airlines started an air coach service between New York and Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Harry A. McDonald, former Detroit investment banker, was elected chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today. He is the first Republican head of the agency since it was established in 1934.

Democrats are resorting to mud-slinging, distortion of facts and smear tactics out of desperation because they realize they are losing the Senate campaign, Representative William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State chairman, declared in a radio broadcast last night.

Mayor O'Dwyer dismissed yesterday as the talk of a "silly boy" the charge of Newbold Morris that his administration had put through a $2,000,000 subway link between Dyre Avenue and White Plains Avenue subways to accommodate the racing plant of the Empire City Racing Association.

Lumber production for the week ended Oct. 29 was 2.5 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were up 15.1 per cent and orders 23.8 per cent.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri received yesterday at City Hall first class gold medals of the Bolivarian Merit Order of the International League for Bolivarian Action. The presentation, made by Dr. Homero Viteri-Lafronte, Ecuadorean delegate to the United Nations, was "in recognition of their constant, unselfish and effective work in the promotion of inter-American good-will and solidarity."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Public hearings to determine the cause of the collision here last Tuesday between a DC-4 transport of the Eastern Airlines and a P-38 fighter plane piloted by the Director of Civil Aviation of Bolivia will open next Wednesday, the Civil Aeronautics Board announced today.

American emergence from isolationism carries with it a corollary that our friends abroad are just beginning to perceive. While we were in the mind-our-own-business phase of our development we were indifferent to or at best mildly interested in the business of other peoples.

Benjamin Axelrad, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the three-story dwelling at 160 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, containing fourteen rooms and two baths, from Lola J. Jones. The Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, which negotiated this transaction, was co-broker with James Dowdell in the sale of the two-family house at 854 Union Street for Dorothy D. O'Brien to John McElligott.

The "big game" of the campaign for both Brooklyn College and City College will be played tonight at 8:30 when the teams meet on the Ebbets Field gridiron. City has won two games and lost three, while Brooklyn has dropped four straight after an opening victory.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today put a temporary halt to efforts of a stockholders' committee of the Tucker Corporation to send notices about its proposed reorganization plan for the bankrupt company to other shareholders.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Published reports from London that high but unidentified military circles in Britain had expressed dissatisfaction with the French military establishment, which was accused of being a weak link in the Western Union defense organization, were read with dismay in military quarters here.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 4 -- The final session of the convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today took steps to purge from the incoming executive board ten left-wing union leaders. It is charged that they have not supported the CIO policy but have worked for Communist party objectives.

Despite a $9,238,324 rise in net sales, Beaunit Mills, Inc., producer of rayon yarn, reported yesterday that net income after taxes for the six months ended Sept. 30, last, declined to $494,975. For the corresponding six months in 1948, net income amounted to $2,715,602.

The Ford Motor Company called off plans yesterday to stop production of cars and trucks next Friday, sparing the jobs of 115,000 persons, as the United Steelworkers, CIO, carried on peace talks with ten major steel producers with possibilities of wholesale settlements next week.

A detective who jotted down the license number of a station wagon that ran down a pedestrian at Worth and Center Streets yesterday morning brought about the arrest six hours later of George Scher, 34 years old, of 1308 Avenue M. Brooklyn, on a charge of third degree assault.

Imports of Dutch goods by the United States currently are showing a rise of 15 to 20 per cent over 1948, with promise of a still larger increase for 1950, Lolle Smit, Director of Export Trade Promotion of the Netherlands Ministry of Economic Affairs, said yesterday at a luncheon at THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- Under an amnesty measure announced today by Soviet-sponsored newspapers that will be submitted Nov. 9 to a vote by the People's Chamber of the new East zone government, what is termed "second-class citizenship" will be abolished in that area.
