Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic and Liberal candidate for United States Senator, informed an American Federation of Labor Union yesterday that he was opposed to New York's Condon-Wadlin Act that outlaws strikes by public employes.

A Bulgarian-born woman employe of the "Voice of America" and a Chinese clerk at the United Nations were found stabbed to death yesterday morning in a room of the Alamac Hotel, Broadway and Seventy-first Street. Police described the deaths as murder and suicide.

A plea for more volunteer workers in the hospitals and at the local headquarters in behalf of United States Coast Guard personnel was made yesterday by Rear Admiral Edward H. Smith, commander of the Third Coast Guard District, at the annual fall assembly of the New York Unit of the Coast Guard Welfare.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today accused Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, of lying about the qualifications of Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican candidate for the Senate seat he now holds by appointment.

The grip the riders of Mexico had held on the international military jumping competitions of the National Horse Show was loosened in Madison Square Garden last night by a member of the Chilean Carabineros, Federal police of the nation. He was Capt. Oscar Cristi, who rode the 10-year-old bay gelding Scarface perfectly and fast, to boot, for victory in the West Point Challenge Trophy event before a crowd of 12,000.

After an unscheduled sub-Arctic stopover of more than twenty-four hours at Goose Bay, Labrador, fifty-five airplane passengers from London, who had planned to be in New York last Wednesday, were scheduled last night to arrive early today.

Kenneth D. Johnson, former general counsel of the National Security Resources Board, was installed yesterday as Dean of the New York School of Social Work in a ceremony attended by 1,500 persons in the remodeled mansion of the late Andrew Carnegie.

Two Protestant church women have been appointed to prepare a world survey on the "Life and Work of Women in the Church" as a project of a permanent commission on women's work of the World Council of Churches. They are Miss Sarah Chakko, president of Isabella Thoburn College, Lucknow, India, who has been named secretary of the commission, and Dr. Kathleen Bliss, of England, who will write the survey.

The reputed contact man for a ring dealing in counterfeit and stolen securities, a Wall Street securities broker and a Newark attorney were arrested yesterday on charges of conspiracy to possess and sell $245,000 worth of spurious Kingdom of Belgium 1955 7 per cent bonds.
Three young children were burned to death and a fireman seriously injured when flames swept a six-family building at 450 Madison Street, Brooklyn, yesterday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 4 -- The Alfred Stieglitz art collection, consisting of 101 paintings, photographs and photogravures valued at $200,000, was formally presented today to Fisk University by Mr. Stieglitz's widow, Georgia O'Keeffe, noted American painter.

Robert M. Kilgore, 25 years old, son of United States Senator Harley M. Kilgore of West Virginia, received a suspended sentence yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, on his plea of guilty to violation of the Sullivan Law. An assault charge was dismissed.

Retail sales declined less during the week than in previous weeks, according to reports from leading department stores in this area. It was estimated that sales were about 6 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 10 per cent below last year.

WATERVILLE, Me., Nov. 4 -The general Maine deer season will have to improve considerably between now and Nov. 30 if it is to approach the kill totals of last year and the year before, but the majority of the guides and wardens we met during the past week are not too optimistic at the prospects.
The Nassau County Medical Society, at its monthly meeting on Oct. 25, passed a resolution favoring the candidacy of John Foster Dulles for Senator. This was properly reported by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Only twenty-one horses, a segment of the 327 kept by the Army today, remain at historic Fort Myer, a post which once housed more than 1,200 steeds. Activity in the many stables has slowly given way to ghostly silence.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Early construction of a new building for the Scarsdale Congregational Church has been assured by pledges of $148,324 from 272 persons, it was announced today.
New shapes and fabric interest in umbrellas appeared in several scenes in the "Fashions of the Times."

Fordham's acid test against the established might of Army has stirred up the greatest excitement in this vicinity, but the contest at West Point is merely one of many strong attractions in the East and elsewhere today, as the college football campaign heads into the November stretch.
S. K. Bradley has been appointed assistant director of multiwall bag sales of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation, J. J. Patterson will succeed Mr. Bradley as Eastern district sales manager.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Federal Mediation Service moved into the coal strike today as John L. Lewis' "peace" offensive against Midwest groups of operators ran into another failure.

YONKERS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Charges of the Democratic State Committee that he served as attorney for the Nazis and voted against minimum wage increases were labeled "absolute falsehoods" today by Senator John Foster Dulles.
Residential property, particularly small apartment buildings, formed the bulk of realty in Manhattan reported in new ownership yesterday.

A vacant plot about 119 by 100 feet at 33-21 to 33-35 Crescent Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Cress-Broad Corporation to the Friedco Realty Corporation, which will improve it with a one-story taxpayer. Edward A. Dangler was the broker.
There was a large and distinguished gathering for the Horse Show Ball last night at the Waldorf-Astoria, highlight of festivities of the week-long National Horse Show at the Madison Square Garden.

Francis Anthony Ametrano said good-by yesterday to Rear Admiral Walter S. DeLany, commandant of the Third Naval District. In doing so he definitely retired as a chief boatswain, and thus beat a sort of jinx that had dogged him for twenty-eight years.

For the second time within two days a Western Union cable containing 100 wires at Cherry and Catherine Streets on the Lower East Side was damaged early yesterday afternoon, affecting Western Union service in an area about a mile square.

The Broadway presentation of Elaine Ryan's dramatization of Ludwig Bemelmans' novel, "Now I Lay Me Down to Sleep," a matter of conjecture for several years, became definite yesterday with the signing of producing contracts.

Flowers, fruits and vegetables were displayed yesterday at Burrwood, an estate in Cold Spring Harbor in Long Island's largest annual flower show. It is presented by the Nassau County Horticultural Society in cooperation with the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society, the Westbury Horticultural Society and four local garden clubs.

The thousands of motorists who have struggled through the mysterious maze of New Haven's streets en route from New York to Hartford and points north (or vice versa) have no doubt breathed a collective sigh of relief at news that the West Rock Tunnel has at last been opened.

More than 100 masterpieces of Persian art dating from the second millenium B. C. to the nineteenth century, recent arrivals from Iran, were unpacked yesterday at the Metropolian Museum of Art where they will be exhibited Nov. 22.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Truman returned to the capital tonight still avoiding personal intervention or comment in the coal and steel strikes. His special train passed through a vital, halted segment of the industrial empire today.

On Oct. 31 THE TIMES carried a news item which is a slap in the face of democracy. This item reports the "personal" letter which doctors are to send their patients, asking them to vote for Dulles. The actual letter is reported as presumably originating with one of the medical committees backing the Dulles campaign.

The State Charities Aid Association and the City Club of New York announced yesterday this endorsement of proposed constitutional amendment No. 5, which would revise the system of veterans preference in civil service, and urged voters to approve it on election day.
Red Strader and his football Yankees, who clash with the Buffalo Bills in Yankee Stadium tomorrow, received a shot in the arm yesterday as they were about to take the field for practice.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 4 -- Substantial amounts of false gold coins minted in Bulgaria have been discovered among purchases made recently by Swiss banks.

CLAREMORE, Okla., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Admirers of Will Rogers paid him tribute today on what would have been his seventieth birthday. Rogers died with Wiley Post in a plane crash in Alaska on Aug. 15, 1935.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 4 -- Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, new Chief of Naval Operations, said today that aviation was "the core of naval offensive power." He added that he intended to keep the Navy's air arm as large as the defense budget permitted.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 4 -- The Dutch Government has decided to end immediately the dispatch of replacement troops to Indonesia, it became known today. The decision was taken by civilian heads of the Ministry of Defense as a token of determination of the Netherlands to complete the withdrawal of her armed forces from the islands as soon as possible.

Nine New York area locals of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, expelled by the Congress of Industrial Organizations as Communist-dominated, last night voted to join the newly chartered CIO rightist group, the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers.

The Fire Department has reversed its decision on the new oxygen piping sytem recently installed at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and has granted approval to put the system into operation, it was announced yesterday.
Out of the dye pot came the exciting furs that composed a separate segment of "Fashions of the Times." The big news in furs is this transforming of their natural coloring.

Nine special commissions will draw up recommendations for Protestant programs in rural areas at the sixth annual convocation on "The Church in Town and Country" under auspices of three major Protestant groups at St. Paul's Methodist Church, Lincoln, Neb., Tuesday through Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.7 per cent in the week ended Nov. 1, according to the Bureau of Labor statistics. The index was 151.4 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.6 per cent below four weeks ago and 7.7 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

Both physicists and military tacticians must have been mystified by the report from London that the International Committee for the Study of European Questions, which includes Paul Reynaud, Maurice Schumann, Lord Vansittart and Lord Brabazon, takes very seriously the report that the Soviet Union is trying to produce presumably radioactive "atomic clouds" on the battlefield.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 4 -- Bids from the United States for a contract to establish shipyards costing from $20,000,000 to $25,000,000 in the Mexican Gulf port of Tampico are being studied by Petroleos Mexicanos, the Mexican Government oil administration.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4 -- Roman Catholic diocesan directors of rural life, at the opening of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference, today warned that time was running out if visas were to be obtained for the maximum number of additional persons who may enter the country under the Displaced Persons Act of 1948. Visas under the act may not be issued after June, 1950.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- Tyrone Power, for whom several pictures have been under consideration at Twentieth Century-Fox, since his return from Italy, has been announced by the studio for the top role in "The Land Down Under," a story with an Australian background.
Fabrics make fashions. This was pretty conclusively demonstrated in The New York Times fashion show in which several new fabrics and versions of newcomers were presented in interesting ways.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 4 -- The Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted today by an overwhelming majority to refer back to the Security Council the membership applications of nine countries previously rejected by it, some of them several times, on political grounds.
Peter the Great, the Bronx Zoo's 46-year-old hippo, was baffled yesterday. Photographers were making a fuss about him and it was obviously not his birthday because he received no extra rations.
DETROIT, Nov. 4 -- After serving sixteen years in Michigan State Prison for a murder authorities are now convinced he did not commit, Louis Gross, 49 years old, was freed today.

A court injunction was given yesterday ordering the sit-down strikers occupying the premises of the National Fastener Corporation at 32 Thirty-third Street, Brooklyn, to vacate the building. The writ was obtained by counsel for the company from Justice Frank Adel of the Appellate Division, Second Department.

The seventieth international six-day bicycle race moved into its final stages at the Twenty-Second Engineers Armory last night. With 7,000 appreciative onlookers spurring them on, the eight teams of the original thirteen pedaled along at a furious pace.

Today's top number at Jamaica is Empire City's thirteen-furlong Gold Cup race, about which there was much hullabaloo in '47 and '48 because horses were flown here from South America and Europe for it. There's no hullabaloo this time.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The British Government gave prompt and forceful warning to the Chinese Nationalists tonight against the bombing of British vessels in Chinese ports.

BETTENDORF, Iowa, Nov. 4 -- An unidentified West Coast football fan, who unfortunately was not quite up to date on the latest development in either football or electronics, dropped into a Bettendorf tavern last night in the midst of a television broadcast of the Iowa-Oregon game.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 4 -High winds which swept the Essex County Country Club course kept the professionals out of the sub-par class today in a New Jersey PGA pro-amateur tournament.

Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for reelection in Brooklyn, and Abe Stark, his Republican-Liberal-City Fusion adversary, engaged yesterday in a new exchange of statements on office expenses.

It would be a pity if, in the pre-occupation over heated debate between political candidates, one very important proposal on the ballot failed because voters mistakenly took it for granted that it would pass without their active support. A very considerable campaign is being waged, largely through the mail, against the three Propositions which follow the eight Amendments on the ballot.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Sixty thousand former depositors in the Union Trust Company, which was closed in 1933, will be paid more than $13,000,000 about Dec. 15.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 5 -- Tennessee's voters will go to the polls next Tuesday to decide if there should be a limited constitutional convention for the purpose of revising the state's 79-year-old constitution, which has never been amended in its history.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- Portraits of the Politburo used as decorations for the thirty-second anniversary Monday of the Bolshevist Revolution show only eleven members, instead of the dozen displayed in Russia's May Day celebration.

The bodies of twelve of the forty-eight persons killed Oct. 28 when an Air France plane hit a mountain top in the Azores were flown into New York yesterday morning for burial in various parts of this country, Canada, Mexico and Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Restrictive provisions of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948, left unchanged at the first session of the Eighty-first Congress, make it unlikely that the United States will be able to provide the haven promised here for 205,000 of Europe's homeless.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 5 -- Michigan turned back a stubborn Purdue team, 20 to 12, today and moved a step closer to its third Big Ten football title in a row. Purdue, a two-touchdown underdog, made it a scrap all the way. It outclassed Michigan most of the final half and got the only touchdown made in the last two periods. A crowd of 95,207 saw the game.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Having experienced in 1948 its "most trying economic year," Israel can now move ahead to a realization of its "sound economic potential," Harold Glasser of Chicago, director of the Institute on Overseas Studies of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds, said here today.

NEGOTIATIONS are under way to have the New York Philharmonic-Symphony go to Edinburgh in 1951 for the fifth International Festival of Music and Art in the Scottish capital. There were discussions about the orchestra going for the festival this year, but they broke down when the costs were calculated.

DENVER -- The problem facing travel officials and tourism in its dual role as an international industry and as a major factor for understanding and, hence, peace, is simply that of keeping people and dollars moving on a global basis.
LENINGRAD, Nov. 5 -- The casual tourist can visit Leningrad today and -- if he confines himself to the central section of the city -- see hardly a single sign of war damage.

The 1949 Gold Medal for the Holland Society of New York has been awarded to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former United States Military Governor in Germany, for his achievements in military statesmanship, Dr. Harold O. Voorhis, president of the society and vice chancellor of New York University, announced yesterday.
Norman H. Kessler, formerly chief sales engineer, has been named chief engineer of the New Holland Manufacturing Company, Mountville, Pa. James D. Pfahl has been named assistant to the sales manager.

MANY of us were pleased when we learned that the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and the Museum of Modern Art were commissioning twenty-three artists and photographers to produce educational posters on polio.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 5 -- The Amherst College football team fought the Trinity Hilltoppers on even terms for three periods at Pratt Field today, then relinquished three lightning-like tallies to the Blue and Gold in the final stanza and dropped a hard-fought 21-6 decision before 5,000 fans who sat through a cold drizzle.

The British are "going right along" with proposals for trade integration of Western Europe, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, declared yesterday on his arrival at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on a Pan American World Airways plane from London after a ten-day trip to Europe.
DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- With nonpartisanship removed, one of the most bitterly contested Mayoralty campaigns in the history of Detroit will come to a close at the polls on Tuesday.

GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK, Ariz. -- One of the earliest snowfalls on record has brought new beauty to the Grand Canyon country, with some six inches of wintry white powder giving autumn sightseers a view of silvery mesas, peaks and pinnacles usually reserved for a handful of hardy midwinter tourists.

Long range planning, always looking ahead, has been the inspiration behind the building of the Schenley Industries. That inspiration has been and is still being supplied by its chairman, Lewis S. Rosenstiel.

BUZZIE, that round, fat, smoke-colored kitten, will surely endear himself to every 7-to-10-year-old who doesn't positively hate cats. They will like him especially because he was -- like you and me -- not at all perfect.

Helen Colton in "Ed Wynn Conquers His Fourth Medium," wrote that his son Keenan went to a boarding school at Hawthorne, N. J. It was actually the Harvey School, Hawthorne, N. Y. One of the brightest memories of Keen an'sclassmates -- of whom I was one -- is Mr. Wynn's happy custom of taking the whole class to his Broadway shows.

In your readers' debate about Thomas Mann's reference in his article "Germany Today" to Goethe as a "world-conquering accident of German greatness" there becomes apparent again the never-ending misunderstandings created by translations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The meeting in Paris of Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, and the foreign ministers of Britain and France has been formally set for Wednesday and Thursday of next week, the State Department announced here.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5 -- A proposal that could help Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, next year in his campaign for re-election will come up for a decision Tuesday when about 2,000,000 Ohio voters are expected to go to the polls.

WHO will forget the British Eighth Army? As a symbol of the greatness that comes from mixing all kinds of people there was nothing like it even in the United States Army. It comprised South Africans, Indians, Canadians, British, Australians -- and New Zealanders. This is the story of the New Zealanders, told by an infantry officer.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- An acrimonious Philadelphia political campaign, one in which such words as "liar," "thieves" and "Communists" were common amid sensational charges, drew toward a close tonight with both sides predicting victory at the polls Tuesday.

FOR THIS WEEK: Pot bulbs of hyacinths, tulips and daffodils as soon as possible for bloom indoors. Start them in a coldframe or trench and cover with four inches of ashes. . . . Mulch the ground prepared for lily planting. Some varieties may not arrive for another month. . . . Mulch the strawberry patch with salt hay, pine needles or similar light material. . . .
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Pennsylvania fumbled on its first play from scrimmage today at Frankin Field and the Red and Blue never fully recovered from the shock.

Action by Congress at its January session to modernize antiquated customs regulations, dating from the Tariff Act of 1930, will be spurred by the rising pressure for increased imports to solve the dollar shortage abroad and maintain American exports at a high level, it was indicated in foreign trade circles last week.
Eight pastors of Roman Catholic churches in Harlem yesterday blamed "an outside element" for fomenting the outbreak last Thursday night in that area. They spoke for 20,000 members in their parishes.
RICHLAND, Wash., Nov. 5 -- The Pacific Northwest's atomic energy city, which has the Federal Government as its landlord and administrator, is wooing private capital.

THAT summer of 1878, when Greg's Uncle Dick suddenly came back from China with a retinue of a hundred coolies, was something to remember always. And when Uncle Dick produced a bundle of firecrackers said to have been made in the days of Kublai Khan things literally began to pop on the Midwestern farm.

WISE teachers no longer label a child "artistic" or "inartistic" and let it go at that. They feel that children, given the right sort of teaching and a stimulating environment, will all be creative in one way or another.

IT used to be true that a person operating a greenhouse could not leave it even for a day unless arrangements were made with someone to check the heating, ventilation and watering. Modern equipment provides automatic control for all three of these requirements, even in the small greenhouse.

SLIM pickings await those lovers of serious music in the New York area who do not have good FM radio receivers or sets powerful enough to bring in clearly the AM and FM music offerings of WQXR and the New York City municipal station WNYC.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 5 -- Switzerland is ready to join Belgium, Luxembourg, France and Italy now in major moves to knock down barriers to better integration of the Western European economy, high Swiss sources said today.

In a burst of riding that was just too much for any of their opponents, the Australian team of Alfred Strom and Reggie Arnold pedalled their way to victory in the six-day bicycle race that came to an end before 10,000 at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night.

In a whingding, high-decibel-count finish, Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' 3-year-old filly Adile yesterday gained a tip-of-her-nose decision over the King Ranch's Flying Missel in the Empire City Racing Association's thirteen-furlong Gold Cup race at Jamaica.

Stock prices pushed forward into new high territory last week as Bethlehem Steel, second largest steel producer in the nation, broke the labor deadlock and agreed to a pension-insurance program. Higher earnings and dividends, however, continued to overshadow labor disturbances despite the approaching peace in steel and hopes for a solution to the coal problem.

For the first time since the end of the war, the market for bonds of local governments is viewing with unconcern the coming of another Election Day and the possibility that the referendums on bonds holds for another big swelling in the supply of new tax-exempt investments.
RIVERDALE, N. D., Nov. 5 -- Engineers today are adding to their book of knowledge on tunnel construction as they span the broad Missouri River with what will be the world's largest earthen dam.

There is a new cast iron which, unlike ordinary cast iron, can be bent and twisted. It has several times greater strength than ordinary cast iron and greater ductility and resistance to hammer blows. "Ductile cast iron" is the name of the innovation.

Forty-four transatlantic air passengers who were delayed for forty-eight hours at Goose Bay, Labrador, when their New York to London plane developed minor mechanical trouble arrived here at 11 A. M. yesterday.

THIS dozen of stories by Professor Green -- author of the Roanoke Island play, "Lost Colony," and other plays and stories in a Southern setting -- are at once curiously mixed and terribly alike. One character appears in all of them, sometimes acting as a predisposing doom upon the other personalities, sometimes as a fury; sometimes silent and inchoate, sometimes wearyingly articulate; usually tragic, never (unfortunately) comic.

LAURENCE DUGGAN helped guide the Good Neighbor policy. He saw it rise, triumph and then gradually fade as American attention turned to Europe. Out of his profound interest in Latin America and his concern for its future he wrote this book, an able and intelligent guide to the history, developments and still unfulfilled possibilities of the United States' relations with its Latin-American neighbors.

With two physicians aboard, a forty-six-foot motor yacht was rescued in a sinking condition last night by the crews of two police launches, after the craft hit a reef northwest of Execution Light in Long Island Sound.

Alma Booker is to be congratulated for expressing the sentiments contained in her letter in which she differs sharply from the opinions on adoption in the article "Pangs of Adoptive Relations" by Lawrence K. and Mary Frank.

DESPITE its title and its setting in between-wars Italy, "The Woman of Rome" is perhaps the least consciously "Italian" novel among the recent translations brought out in this country. It is completely without local color, and Adriana, the heroine, is more closely related to Moll Flanders than to Alfred Hayes' "The Girl on the Via Flaminia."

The recent election of Yugoslavia to the United Nations Security Council is not a victory for Tito or Tito's communism. It was Tito, primarily, who launched the myth among the Balkan peoples that their only security lay in Communist and Soviet protection. Today, by successfully pressing his suit at the United Nations, he has destroyed his own myth.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- Gold, its price and convertibility, a matter that has aroused widespread and frequently uninformed comment in recent months, received the closest and most competent attention here this week during the annual convention of the American Bankers Association.

THIS new addition to the psychopathic shelf, homosexual division, takes one Michael from early childhood -- his mother had always wanted a little girl and used her son as a daughter substitute -- to alleged manhood as a pianist. Given the almost typically textbook background, the reader can hardly be surprised when Michael makes his eventual choice; nor, indeed, is Michael himself.

THE background of this curiously uneven book is Fire Island in winter and the time is the present. Jerry and Jane Taylor make friends with an orphan called Sam (Steve Silencer) Larrup. These three become involved in an international mystery in which spying, treasure and a final hand-to-hand encounter with two desperadoes in "Steve's" hideout in the sunken forest among the sand dunes all play their part.

MAYBE James Holly Hanford is a typically modern "double" man, or an untypically "single" man -- depending on your viewpoint. As a professor, he is a peripatetic of the first order, having taught at Harvard, North Carolina, Michigan, Antioch, Columbia, California, Chicago, Texas and (current) Western Reserve.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Roman Catholic Bishops disclosed today they had sought without success -- to get revision of government controls that they charged virtually outlawed the church.

TOKYO, Nov. 5 -- The Japanese, as never before since the surrender, today are anticipating the early conclusion of a peace treaty which will readmit this country to the international family of nations and end what may be the longest occupation in history -- now in its fifth year.

THE first "actor" to be seen in the grandfather of modern motion pictures, seventy-seven years ago, was a famous horse named Mahomet. Horses and movies have been in partnership ever since. But only this year, more than three-quarters of a century after Mahomet was photographed by Edward Muybridge, has the motion picture industry, at the behest of California's Gov. Leland Stanford, gotten around to making pictures about famous real horses again.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Argentina announced today that she would permit imports again for the first time since Sept. 17.

THROUGH the battered and ruined cities of Germany, music echoes like a symbol of rebirth. After thirty-five days spent traveling by car throughout the Western zone to give twenty-five recitals under the sponsorship of American Military Government, I cannot help but be amazed at the way these people hang on music as if it were their means of salvation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The matter-of-fact manner in which Admiral Forrest P. Sherman moved into his difficult duties as the new Chief of Naval Operations this week tended to calm the atmosphere of uneasy expectancy that had hung over the Pentagon ever since the explosive hearings before the House Armed Services Committee.

By long-established tradition, the experts, or those posing as such, divide New York State for the purpose of political analysis. They regard New York City as steadfastly Democratic, and up-state New York and near-by suburbs as equally sure Republican.

The A. B. Dick Company's 13-acre plant dedicated yesterday at Niles, Ill., is said to contain more of the Austin Construction Company's pioneering principles than are contained in any single structure it has built since Samuel Austin left England with his carpenter tools seventy-seven years ago to help rebuild Chicago after the Great Fire.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Navy has agreed to let the Air Force have 25 per cent of the Annapolis graduates as they finish their schooling, naval officials said today. The increase goes into effect next year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Manuscripts and paintings dating back to the sixth century A.D., part of the collection of the Greek Orthodox Church Library in Jerusalem, soon will be photographed for the first time.

CHATTANOOGA, Nov. 5 -- Attention of Southerners was divided this week-end between an important referendum on prohibition and the New York Senatorial and Mayoralty elections. The race for the Senate in New York drew much comment because it was felt that it might turn out to be a weathervane for the 1950 off-year national election.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A fighting University of Pittsburgh football team, playing its best home game of the season, today held Ohio State scoreless for the first half while piling up 7 points but the worn out Panthers went down to defeat, 14 -- 10, under the Ohioans' greater power.

IN reference to your review of the German picture, "The Affair Blum," and to your subsequent remarks in the Sunday TIMES (Oct. 23), I should like to clarify a few points. Apparently the actual case on which this film is based never received much publicity in this country.

Darius Milhaud's Second Piano Concerto, which the composer introduced in Chicago eight years ago, was performed here for the first time yesterday afternoon when it was presented by Sari Biro in the second of the three concerts she is giving at Carnegie Hall with an orchestra conducted by Emanuel Vardi.

Master riders of the Mexican Army crammed another piece of silverware into their jammed trophy case at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night when 18-year-old Lieut. Joaquin D'Harcourt took the International Military Special Challenge Trophy before 13,000 spectators.

HOWEVER great the pleasure of most Jews over the establishment of the state of Israel, many of them, as Rabbi Gordon points out in this richly informative book, have neither the desire nor the intent to settle in Israel. Like the Irish in America, like the Poles, the Slavs, the Germans, the Scandinavians, they look upon themselves as Americans.

Ben Jones, pianist from Georgia who received most of his musical training in this city, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. His program contained the Prelude and Fugue in E flat major from Book 2 of Bach's "Well-tempered Clavier," Mozart Sonata in C major (K. 330), a Chopin group, Prokofieff's Sonata, No. 3; Hindemith's Sonata, No. 2, and Liszt's "Gnomenreigen," "Consolation," No. 3, and "Mephisto Waltz."

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 5 -- Recent declines in the sales volume of department stores in the rural areas of Minnesota were reflected this l week in Federal reports on the cash farm income for the state for the first nine months. Figures of the Department of Agriculture showed that the farmers' income l had dropped $154,000,000 during the period to $838,523,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- An Air Force B-25 medium bomber made a practice instrument landing, contrary to regulations, at the National Airport last Tuesday just a few minutes before a P-38 fighter crashed into an incoming Eastern Airlines DC-4 passenger plane killing fifty-five persons, it was disclosed today.
BERLIN, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Communist satellites began lining up today to help the Soviet Union celebrate the anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution on Monday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 5 -- Breaking loose from a 13-13 tie right after the intermission, Princeton exploded for three touchdowns within the space of nine minutes today to launch the defense of its Big Three title with a highly impressive 33-13 victory over Harvard.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 5 -- After piling up thirty-two points during the first half, New York University's football team substituted freely in defeating the United States Merchant Marine Academy eleven, 39 -- 0, today before 4,000 spectators at Tomb Memorial Field.

John Hall Paxton, United States Consul General in Sinkiang, China's most northwesterly province, is now safe in New Delhi, India. Angus Ward, our Consul in Mukden, chief city in Manchuria, China's most northeasterly region, is still held under virtual, if not actual, arrest. Mr. Paxton took a chance on the Himalayas to get out ahead of the Chinese Communists.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 5 -- Ethiopia complained today that the United Nations would be presenting the most "terrible of threats" to her national security if it gave a ten-year trusteeship over the former Italian Somaliland to Italy and left open the fate of Eritrea.

FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 5 -- More than 100,000 itinerant farm workers, now making "big money" in the fertile San Joaquin Valley, face misery and possible starvation this winter, according to welfare agencies. The Agricultural Labor Bureau has started an educational campaign in an attempt to cushion the shock that is expected when cotton-picking ends, in five or six weeks.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Secrets of where Russia's uranium deposits are situated are disclosed in prewar Soviet publications printed before it was known that the ore had any but limited industrial uses.

The Kende Galleries, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, will hold an auction of books from the estate and the personal library of the late Arthur Pforsheimer of New York on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. On Saturday, the galleries will auction furniture, paintings and decorations.

AS winter approaches, New Yorkers will have one consolation, at least. For winter is the season when the horrid sounds of snoring reach their lowest frequency. That is because citizens are at their peak of nervous tension then.

THIS is an able, absorbingly interesting, highly readable book, dealing with three instruments that, since 1896, have "profoundly and directly affected the lives of all Americans." These are the automobile, the movies, the radio.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 5 -- The major surgical operation performed this week by delegates to the convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations will have widespread repercussions in the labor movement and industry generally.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Gold is flowing out of the United States after pouring in from foreign countries for fifteen years without interruption except in wartime.

At the last meeting of the American Dietetic Association, Dr. Stuart Shelton Stevenson objectively considered the relative merits of cow's milk and mother's milk as a food for babies. Though he came out for breast-feeding, he readily conceded the merit of cow's milk, indispensable in some cases.

Although the bill does not amend basic tax law, or change any of the tax rates, it does effect some very important modifications in the estate and gift tax laws and a few in income tax laws.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Peanuts are becoming an important political issue in the pre-election sparring in England. The ambitious plan to raise them in Britain's East African colony of Tanganyika, in an attempt to increase the non-dollar supply of essential oils and fats, has proved considerably less than a success, and Food Minister John Strachey is under heavy fire from the Conservatives in the Commons.

There are thirty-three major ways in which industrial costs can be reduced, according to a survey of twenty-five companies by Walter Mitchell Jr., research director of the Controllership Foundation. The survey was undertaken, it was disclosed here yesterday, after a poll of 3,300 Institute members placed cost reduction high on the list of problems which they believed should be given preference when planning Foundation projects.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 5 (UP) -- Wisconsin's Badgers rode to a 14 to 6 victory over Northwestern on the strong right arm of Quarterback Bob Petruska today and kept in the thick of the Big Ten title race. Petruska, mixing his plays like a veteran, passed for two precision-like touchdowns.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Representative Leslie C. Arends of Illinois, House Republican whip, charged President Truman tonight with developing a "man-on-the-horse" complex.

The season's business prospects for the wholesale garment market here were considerably brightened last week by cooler weather and partial settlement of the steel strike, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Promotions have enabled some retailers to report a fairly good dollarg volume, but figures are still behind last year, it was said.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Fordham's shining moment of story-book glory ended today with the violent eruption of a great Army football team that had been held scoreless almost to the end of the opening half of one of the most savagely fought games of the year.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 5 -- Next Tuesday's referendum on repeal of the Virginia poll tax holds major interest among residents of this area. The fate of this historic levy, inserted in the Constitution of 1902 as an admitted deterrent to Negro voting, outranks the Lehman-Dulles contest and the New York Mayoralty race.

TRENTON. N. J., Nov. 5 -- While election interest in New Jersey has been focused on the Governorship race between Alfred E. Driscoll, the Republican incumbent, and State Senator Elmer H. Wene, the Democratic candidate, many other offices will be at stake in the balloting next Tuesday.

HOLLYWOOD. THE next time you settle yourself comfortably into a seat at the neighborhood picture house don't forget to take off your ear-muffs. Most people don't realize they are wearing any -- at any rate, that is the impression of composers who write for the movies.

DALLAS, Nov. 5 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District last week reflected a moderate gain over the corresponding period of last year, largely as a result of sales volume in one store in San Antonio. That store accounts for 60 per cent of the city's sales volume, and that city's sales volume reflected a 46 per cent gain over the same week of last year.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 5 -- The Hill School's football team registered its seventh straight victory by downing Peddie School, 39 -- 20, today.
UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 5 (AP) -- State police today ruled out a ransom motive as they hunted for an infant said by his mother to have been kidnapped from a bassinette.

In 1815 at a ceremony at The Hague, Wilhelm I of Orange was crowned the first King of the Netherlands and the Netherlands East Indies. For 200 years before, the Indies had been ruled indirectly through the Dutch East India Trading Company.

Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators are determined to resist demands of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, for a hiring hall system of employment, they reiterated yesterday in informal discussions.
The democratic system of free elections was hailed yesterday by Rabbi Louis I. Newman of Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, as the "best answer to totalitarianism."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 9 points lower than on Friday. Fluctuations were within a comparatively narrow range.
One in ten of the city's 2,000,000 children is being aided by the Department of Welfare, according to a report yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer by a committee

ALMOST every flower show has classes for arrangements, including the predominantly 'mum autumn shows. Although the function of a floral composition to decorate home or office is certainly not ignored in those made for competition, there is a subtle difference.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- The United States Army transport Ballou arrived in port today with 1,271 displaced persons, including an Hungarian count who told of witnessing the slaying of a Roman Catholic Bishop by Russian Army officers in 1945.

ROME, Nov. 5 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi was grappling this week with a Cabinet crisis brought about Monday by the withdrawal from the Government of the rightwing Socialists. Public attention, however, was focused not on his labors but on southern Italy and particularly in Calabria, where landless peasants were resorting to violence in an effort to obtain the land they require to save themselves from starvation.

DOROTHY CLARKE WILSON combines fact and fiction to tell the story of Moses as a young man. She recreates the glittering, fabulous time of ancient Egypt in the reign of Pharaoh Seti I. Moses is 15 when the story opens, a prince with access to all the luxury of the royal household due the adopted son of the Princess Sitra.

TO win the Civil War, President Lincoln required the services of a first-class general; the President made several searches, found some leaders who were worse than they have appeared in retrospect to be and others who were not as incompetent as rivals made them out.

Work and worship joined hands yesterday at the Second Presbyterian Church, 6 West Ninety-sixth Street, when the Rev. L. Humphrey Walz, pastor, and seventeen of his parishioners put aside their Sunday clothes in favor of painters' dungarees.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 5 -- One of India's most troublesome minorities, the bearded, militant Sikh sect, was urged today by its leader, Tara Singh to remain loyal to the National Government and to cooperate with the Hindus with whom they have been in conflict on several issues since India became independent.
SPECIAL techniques to heighten the visual impact of election returns will be used by the various television stations in reporting the results of Tuesday's balloting.

Graduate schools of social work should focus their attention on preparing persons for the key positions of leadership for which society "has indicated a willingness to pay," Dr. Ernest V. Hollis, who is conducting a nationwide study on social work education, declared yesterday.

BROADWAY'S biggest inning of the season has come and gone, but the din of controversy lingers on. Bonds of old friendships are being severely stretched, even broken; ancient feuds are being renewed, and as for the critics -- well, the critics are where they usually are, stuck out there in exposed advanced positions on the battle line.

WHATEVER dire conclusions psychiatrists draw from modern man's avidity to read of murder, they should recall that our forebears have been displaying the same avidity as far back as we can trace English literature, though the form may change from the Elizabethan tragedy of blood to the Gothic crime novel of the eighteenth century and thence to the Victorian novel of sensation, or "thriller."

THE best compliment which one can pay Rabbi Wise's autobiography is that the flavor of his life is reproduced with remarkable fidelity in these pages of retrospect, completed shortly before his death. There is no morbid preoccupation with self in the pages, but also no disingenuous effort at modesty.

NOW that we are to see the Sadler's Wells Ballet no more until next season, it is impossible to delay any longer a discussion, however brief, of its repertoire, its personnel, its strengths and weaknesses, as they appear against the background of what we are used to.

As one of the oddest political campaigns in the history of New York City and State draws to a close, supporters of all leading candidates issued yesterday claims of certain victory in Tuesday's election.

In next Tuesday's voting, the key elections from the viewpoint of indicating a possible national trend are the contests for United States Senator in this state, for Governor in New Jersey, and for Mayor in New York and in a dozen cities, scattered through the country.

IN this age of papier-mache memoirs turned out by ghost-writers at so much per yard, it is almost shockingly delightful to read a book which could have been written by absolutely no one else in the world than the great and important figure whose name is signed to it, which is flavorful, characteristic, and moving.

Politically 1949 is about as "off" as a year could be. Only three of next Tuesday's contests -- one for Senator and one for Representative in this state and one for Representative in California -- will affect the make-up of Congress. Only two states, New Jersey and Virginia, are electing Governors.

A GLASSPECKER, to clear that up right away, is Mr. Dodge's term for a woodpecker who looks like Harpo Marx and pecks at windows instead of at trees or telephone poles. Mr. Dodge was an unwilling host to one during a two-year sojourn, with time out for explorations, in Arequipa, Peru.

ONE of the most interesting outgrowths of flower arranging is the hobby of collecting and using unusual containers. Although the basic flat, tall or round vases are indispensable, the arranger is constantly on the lookout for something in which to put flowers that adds a touch of distinction and originality.

TOKYO, Nov. 5 -- Urgent pleas that Japanese austerity be eased have been prepared by the Economic Stabilization Board for presentation to Joseph M. Dodge, Detroit banker, who is General Douglas MacArthur's chief economic adviser.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Great defensive line play and opportunism on the attack gained a 27-to-13 football victory for Kansas over Nebraska today.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 5 -- Charter revision, reorganization of the Public Works Department and improvement in school facilities are some of the major issues in the local political campaign that finds Mayor William C. Celetano, Republican, seeking re-election for a third two-year term.

A LEADING English art critic has recently offered an explanation for the adoption of abstraction by most avant garde American painters today. "It is," Denys Sutton writes, "an art * * * divorced from tradition yet at the same time it provides a refuge from materialism."

PLYMOUTH, MASS. -- The approach of Thanksgiving, which comes early this year, on Nov. 24, is of especial significance to this little city of 14,000 population where the Pilgrims established their permanent home in the New World.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Nov. 5 -- An inspired Middlebury College football team sprang an upset today at Porter Field by holding an undefeated Union College eleven to a 14-14 tie in a thrilling game played in driving snow.

ETONIAN, Cantab, Anglican and among God's most perfected Englishmen, William Ralph Inge, erstwhile Dean of St. Paul's browses amid his books, mystical and modernist, while the Edwardian world in which he lived and moved and had his being is swept over the horizon like the shadow of a total eclipse.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Substitute Quarterback Stan Lavine's passing opened the flood gates today for a 40-14 football victory scored by Maryland over George Washington.

The annual concert of the Bagby Music Lovers' Foundation will be held this year on the afternoon of Nov. 29 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The tentative list of artists who are to appear includes Jennie Tourel, Erna Berger, Enzo Mascherini, Uta Graf, Patricia Travers and Raymond Lowenthal.

For a bit more than twenty minutes at Baker Field yesterday it appeared to some 25,000 spectators that the unexpected was going to happen and that Columbia would break its losing streak at four games.

Disagreement with employes of the Long Island Rail Road concerning the validity of his commutation ticket caused Cecil Ball of 22 Locust Avenue, Port Washington, to be ejected from a train that left the Pennsylvania station early yesterday.

HOUSE plants can be used in any room and in many ways. Distributed throughout the home and properly cared for, they will go far toward filling the void left when the last blooms from the garden have gone.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Grains sank under scattered selling pressure on the Board of Trade today. Losses were confined to less than a cent a bushel, in most cases, although rye fell more than that at times. The market opened with small losses, which were extended late in the session.
Tomorrow morning six persons who, despite their physical disabilities, have achieved distinction in various fields, will meet at the Commodore Hotel to discuss "New Goals for the Handicapped."

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Nov. 5 -- An inspired Middlebury College football team sprang an upset today at Porter Field by holding an undefeated Union College eleven to a 14-14 tie in a thrilling game played in driving snow.

ETONIAN, Cantab, Anglican and among God's most perfected Englishmen, William Ralph Inge, erstwhile Dean of St. Paul's browses amid his books, mystical and modernist, while the Edwardian world in which he lived and moved and had his being is swept over the horizon like the shadow of a total eclipse.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Substitute Quarterback Stan Lavine's passing opened the flood gates today for a 40-14 football victory scored by Maryland over George Washington.

The annual concert of the Bagby Music Lovers' Foundation will be held this year on the afternoon of Nov. 29 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The tentative list of artists who are to appear includes Jennie Tourel, Erna Berger, Enzo Mascherini, Uta Graf, Patricia Travers and Raymond Lowenthal.

It's the Giants against the Bulldogs at the Polo Grounds and the Yankees against the Buffalo Bills at the Stadium in today's local professional football games. However, the day's big battle will be played in Philadelphia. It brings together the Eagles and the Los Angeles Rams, respectively the Eastern and Western Division rulers of the National League.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 5 -- Unbeaten Notre Dame got its stiffest argument of the season, but the versatility of Quarterback Bob Williams gave the Irish a 34-21 triumph over Michigan State here today before 51,277 upset-hopeful fans.

A laboratory for speed reading has been established under the auspices of the Reading Clinic of Temple University, Philadelphia. Designed to help executives, professional people, college students and others whose work requires rapid reading, the clinic will give individualized guidance to small groups of selected students.
CLINTON, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Hamilton College piled up twenty points in the first quarter to defeat Earlham College of Indiana today, 32 -- 13.

Rapidly expanding natural gas transmission lines and large importations of heavy fuel oil are producing a shift in the nation's established fuel markets and causing serious repercussions in both the coal and domestic oil refining industries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Reclamation Bureau will begin at once a repair program on twelve projects affecting 1,650,000 acres of irrigable land in western states, Secretary of Interior J. A. Krug said today.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill. ON a sticky, hot day in August, 1941, the tellers in the House of Representatives in Washington recorded a historic vote. The Selective Service Act, the first peacetime conscription in our history, was extended -- by a margin of one vote.

Despite a continued decline in the use of the Suez Canal by United States-flag vessels, traffic through the waterway returned during August to the record levels set last spring, according to the latest bulletin of the Suez Canal Company (Compagnie Universelle de Canal Maritime de Suez).

The entertaining and lucrative show of pictures by famous amateurs that the Urban League ran last year for its fund campaign will be repeated, beginning tomorrow evening, at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 4 (UP) -- Rambling Robert Smith, a bulldozing sophomore fullback, led Texas A. and M. to a breathless 27-to-27 tie with mighty Southern Methodist University today in the Southwest's greatest upset of the season.
ALBANY, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Charges of "misrepresentation" were hurled today by leaders of two American Legion groups in the controversy over the Mitchell amendment.

NOVEMBER sees us into the season when eating and entertaining are probably taken more seriously than at any other time of the year. Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's are as surely centered around the festive board as the Fourth of July is around firecrackers.

Man has reached the point in his evolution where he has the power to decide whether or not he will follow the dinosaur into extinction. If he should become extinct, it is doubtful whether his like would be again evolved. So says Dr. George Gaylord Simpson, noted paleontologist, who traces man's past, present and future on this two-billion-year-old planet of ours.

TODAY will see the last two performances of the Sadler's Wells Ballet season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The local week, however, will be far from barren. Mariemma, the distinguished Spanish dancer who made so impressive a local debut last season, will give the first of two performances at the Ziegfeld tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Federal officials were resigned today to at least one more week of the soft coal strike but were reported to feel that they could not let the shutdown go beyond another weekend without firmer Government action.

Age should not be the only criterion for determining the qualification of voters, according to high school students who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast from the City Council chamber over WQXR.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein swore in 200 special deputies for election day duty yesterday in a brief ceremony in the State Building, 80 Centre Street. The new volunteer deputies, all lawyers, are part of the record 800 special deputies who will help police during election at the polls and at Police Headquarters.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 5 -- What is interpreted as an accelerating drive by the Department of Agriculture to get a hand in Western reclamation activities aroused marked apprehension this week at one of the region's main conclaves of the year.

IT is a pity that no reliable work on the Dominican Republic has appeared since Sumner Welles published his monumental "Naboth's Vineyard" in 1928. Mr. Welles covered the period from the end of the Haitian occupation in 1844 to the withdrawal of the American Marines in the mid-Twenties.

Walter Gropius, in "Not Gothic but Modern for Our Colleges," says "beauty is a basic requirement for civilized life," and yet, on the opposite page, his design for new quarters for students at Harvard doesn't appear to have had the slightest sense of beauty for its motivation.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Western Allied policy on dismantling seems likely tonight to be the chief point of discussion and dissension at the Paris meeting.

CAMBRIDGE, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- With the opening of the Catskills to deer hunters on the fifteenth many disappointed Adirondack hunters will have their last opportunity to get venison for the locker, and with plenty of deer reported in most areas the chances for success seem good.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 5 (UP) -- The Communist Government today hanged six alleged leaders of a revolt that was supposed to have actually got under way last spring, the official press agency announced.
The national steel strike, now thirty-six days old, was reported yesterday on the verge of a cave-in, with three major producers actually engaged in final negotiations or ready to resume them.

In simple, eloquent phrases that rivaled professional speech-making, thirty-one "grass roots ambassadors of international good-will" -- 4-H Clubs members from twenty-two states -- described yesterday their four-month visits to farms in ten European countries.

SOME twenty years ago R. B. Cunninghame Graham wrote a book to do honor to the horses to whom, "after God," the Spaniards -- by their own account -- owed their conquests "in the New World of the Americas." For his material he went back to the Conquistadors themselves -- to the letters that Cortes wrote Emperor Charles V and to the chronicles of Bernal Diaz, who had his active part also in the conquest.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- White Plains High School downed Hempstead (L. I.) High School by 31 -- 14 today, mixing equal parts of passing and running into the successful recipe for its third victory after a tie and a loss, respectively.

FOR all subsidiary favors within the realm of films, this corner is ever watchful and ever eager to pass the word. And that is why we commend you to the current revival bill at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse -- two grand Preston Sturges films, "The Great McGinty" and "Sullivan's Travels." It is a pleasure that shouldn't be denied.

COMMANDER RONNE'S tale of his expedition to the Antarctic may mark the end of the golden age of exploration. Expeditions now are matters of government enterprise, with many ships, thousands of men, and much equipment.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Tension increased today in the family quarrel of right and left wingers in the United Electrical Workers Union, ousted by the Congress of Industrial Organizations as Communist-led, but a big segment of the electrical industry said it wished to stay out of the fight.

Out-of-town manufacturers of women's apparel are improving their competitive position by combined selling efforts in the New York market, it was pointed out last week. The number of showings are increasing, according to trade observers, and will eat into sales of local producers unless they adopt similar methods both in New York and other leading markets throughout the country.

MR. SMITH gives us a great deal of food for thought and argument, and incidentally a great deal of information about Europe. His descriptions are brilliant, because he is one of the best equipped and most honest reporters working today.

IT is extremely doubtful that James L. Shearer, owner of WHBI across the river in Newark, realizes that his radio station has its twenty-seventh anniversary coming up this very week. The outlet was licensed by the old Federal Radio Commission on Nov. 11, 1922, but Jimmy wouldn't stop to think about that.

St. Barnabas House, owned and operated by the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society, was taken over for its annual benefit, the performance of "La Traviata" with Licia Albanese Feruccio Tagliavini, and Leonard Warren in the leading roles, the night of Jan. 24 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

THIS is a fable of some forty pages, devoted to proving that it pays to be neighborly. Being fabulous, its characters, Mr. Hermit Miser and the three ladies whose gardens touch his, need not live and behave like real-life people.

SEVERAL years ago, when Mars happened to be at an opposition near perihelion, I did research for a man who was writing a piece for the slicks on whether or not there was life on this most intriguing of outer planets.

THE fifteenth volume of "U. S. Camera Annual," in its 1950 International Edition (New York: U. S. Camera Publishing Corp. $6.50), just published, signalizes a change from American to world - wide picture coverage. Henceforth, according to the editor, Tom Maloney, the annual "will attempt to gather not only the best in America but the best in the world."

IT is gratifying that an Olympian was invited to review a Nobel Prize winner's utterances on Chopin. The lofty article is the more valuable as it encourages the apprentice to always use one yardstick only, and let the chips fall.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 5 -- General Romulo called tonight for a "temporary halt" in the atomic armaments race to give the world "a breathing spell during which we could reorganize our thinking and pull ourselves together for what may well prove to be the last supreme effort of mankind to establish an enduring peace."

SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 5 -- Such political matters as California's election next Tuesday, when the voters decide whether to repeal several provisions of the present pension law covering aged and blind persons, interested the West Coast this week.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Sales reported last week by Philadelphia women's apparel shops showed a decrease of 24 per cent from a year ago, and for the four-weeks' period those shops reported 26 per cent less business than last year. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 74,778, as against 141,086 a year ago, a decrease of 47 per cent.

The issue of a possible state income tax dominated the New Jersey campaign for Governor as it drew to a close last night. Charges of mismanagement, incompetence and insincerity were made by two of the candidates in the three-cornered race against their opponents.

The peak of seasonal upturns in hardware buying has passed and wholesale orders will now taper off by gradual reductions in anticipation of end-of-the-year inventory periods, industry executives revealed here yesterday. The rate of buying in October was more than 100 per cent above the rate in August, they said.

Marking the beginning of one of the largest projects of its kind on the city's construction program, Mayor O'Dwyer will break ground tomorrow at 2:30 P. M. for the new $25,350,000 Hunt's Point Sewage Treatment Works, foot of Coster Street, the Bronx, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen announced yesterday.

The maritime industry and the Port of New York paid homage yesterday to Representative Schuyler Otis Bland, Democrat, of Virginia for his more than thirty years of service in behalf of the American Merchant Marine.

Despite some minor declines in dollar volume on food sales in comparison with last year, per capita consumption is remaining far above the 1935-39 average, M. L. Toulme, executive vice president of the National-American Wholesale Grocers Association, declared yesterday.

At 10:16 on the morning of Nov. 3, 1948, President Truman got the news that Thomas E. Dewey had conceded the Presidential election. Last Thursday morning, exactly one year later, Mr. Truman was again on the hunt for votes. He was going to St. Paul, Minn., for a major address in a national election campaign that is already under way.

SINCE reporting on these matters a month ago, five new titles have turned up on the bestseller list and five have dropped quietly out of sight. No earthshaking conclusions here, but it is worth noting that Sholem Asch's "Mary" has been catapulted into third place, and A. B. Guthrie's "The Way West" into fifth within two weeks of publication.

ALTHOUGH it has been known to tolerate erudition, Broadway had its forbearance for intellectuals strained severely before the current revue, "Touch and Go," opened last month at the Broadhurst Theatre.

Members of the community committee for the Brooklyn ]V[useum have arranged a luncheon and fashion show for Nov. ~7 at the Brooklyn Museum in behalf of the institution's department of education, which~provides special services to community groups and schools.

About 500 exhibits, displaying products and services of more than 1,000 manufacturers and organizations, will feature the thirty-fourth national hotel exposition which opens tomorrow at 3 P. M. and continues through Friday in Grand Central Palace. Hours for the balance of the week are: Tuesday and Wednesday, 10 A. M. to 10 P. M., Thursday and Friday, 10 A. M. to 6 P. M.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 5 -- The importance of good college public relations was stressed today by President Roswell Gray Ham of Mount Holyoke College in his annual report to the college's board of trustees. President Ham paid tribute to "the American newspaper, radio, and magazine" which "have shown great good-will toward education and deserve education's continuous gratitude."

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The French look forward with some anxiety to the Foreign Ministers' meeting. The French fear both Washington and London may press for an end of the dismantling of German factories and that Washington may desire some commitment to closer economic relations between France and Germany for which the French are not yet ready.

President John L. Lewis of the United Mine Workers is not the first public character who has been glad to have attention from the press when it was useful to him, but who has resented it at other times. On Friday Mr. Lewis was attempting to have a confidential conference with Government Mediation Chief Cyrus Ching.

DURHAM, N. C., Nov. 5 (UP) Wake Forest's Deacons, a sleeping giant of a football team, awoke with a start today to shatter favored Duke, 27 to 7, and puncture the Blue Devils' Conference title hopes before 35,000.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- German Communists will make an effort to strengthen the already rickety foundations of their Democratic Republic in Eastern Germany by considering legislation next week restoring full political and economic rights to former Nazis and militarists, once their arch enemies.

Groups specializing in child welfare, in addition to undertaking new studies and projects, have a responsibility "to share the wealth of information" that has been accumulated, Mrs. Mildred B. Beck, new executive director of the Child Study Association of America, declared yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Paris was the center this week of a great deal of talk but little accomplishment concerning steps toward European unity. It will be the center of much more talk on this subject when Secretary of State Dean Acheson comes here next week for a brief conference with Foreign Ministers Bevin and Schuman of Britain and France.

To extoll the merits of Tennessee Williams' "A Streetcar Named Desire" at this late date is surely an anticlimax. It is a superb production, for which all of us may be grateful to Elia Kazan and Irene Selznick. For a prodigal recently returned from Hollywood and seeing the play for the first time, it is a profoundly exciting and rewarding experience.

ELECTION returns will be the principal order of business during the evening hours next Tuesday with radio stations providing extensive coverage of New York and New Jersey voting as well as reports on the principal contests across the country.

Otto Behensky, Andrew Jackson harrier, stuck out his chest as he crossed the finish line yesterday to nip Thomas Coulter of Newtown in the Queens P. S. A. L. cross-country championship run at Van Cortlandt Park.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

THE forty-second annual Autumn Exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York opens Wednesday at noon. The four-day show is being staged this year in cooperation with the American Orchid Society in the Colonnades Ball Room, Essex House, 160 Central Park South.
COOPER UNION has just celebrated the completion of its ninetieth year as an instrument of good citizenship and an educational institution unlike any other in our city -- and, indeed, anywhere else.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 5 -- While women's concealment of their age may improve their egos and social standing, it may lose them money when they become 65, Leonard F. Sawvel, manager of the Elizabeth office of the Social Security Administration, warned today in citing the example of a woman who had sacrificed $1,008 in concealing her correct age from her husband.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- As the Boston mayoral campaign surged into its bitter, name-calling final stages today, it appeared that the five-man field had been narrowed down to a choice between Mayor James M. Curley and John B. Hynes, permanent City Clerk.

IN sun-baked Monterey word spread rapidly that Troya was dying of childbirth. This fact meant inconvenience for some and a renewal of life for others. El Capitan Trigo, a former ship's master who had settled in Monterey to drink whisky and to administer justice in his kindly if irregular fashion, had the main problem -- what to do with the child.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 5 -- The United States won unanimous committee approval today for a resolution asking the United Nations to try to cut down the number of its meetings -- now counted in the thousands each year.

RUDOLF KAYSER'S "The Life and Time of Jehudah Halevi" is a sympathetic and penetrating study of the Jewish poet who has been called the sweetest singer in Israel since Biblical times. Halevi's writings were a part of the magnificent efflorescence of Jewish culture which occurred in medieval Spain under the tolerant and learned Moslems.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Boston University remained in the nation's dwindling ranks of unbeaten football teams today by beating tough Temple, 28 to 7, as Sophomore, Harry Agganis squeezed sweet touchdown music from the Terriers' accordion-T formation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Prices of grains were on the upgrade last week on the Board of Trade, with May and July wheat, deferred deliveries of corn and all deliveries of oats selling at new highs for the season, and final sales yesterday were only slightly under the top.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 6 -- When the United Nations' new technical assistance program for backward areas really begins to operate, Afghanistan will be around to make her bid for help, Dr. Abdul Hamid Aziz, permanent delegate at the United Nations, promises.

Despite a record inventory for the liquor industry of approximately 600,000,000 gallons, production will be maintained at maximum normal production levels, large distillers reported here over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration will help small American business participate in Marshall Plan trade by distributing overseas a directory of firms and their products, it was announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 -- Output in the steel industry last week was estimated at about 13 per cent of rated capacity. This was an increase of 3 1/2 points from the week before. The expansion was due entirely to the starting up of plants of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

The ruling hierarchy of Soviet Russia is celebrating the thirty-second anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution by unleashing a new attack against the United States. This was launched by Deputy Premier Malenkov, the tough young machine politician who is now reaching out for the succession of Marshal Stalin by liquidating his opposition, and whose first major policy speech on international affairs deserves special attention for that reason.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Dr Alan Valentine, president of the University of Rochester since 1935, has resigned effective June 30, 1950, the university board of trustees announced tonight.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, continuing his strenuous schedule yesterday, denounced the opinions of political experts on the mayoralty campaign, and expressed confidence that the "common people" would elect him tomorrow.

ZURICH, Nov. 6 -- Beginning on next Sunday, all quantitative restrictions on the import and export of industrial products between Switzerland on one side and Belgium, the Belgian Congo and Luxembourg on the other will disappear.

I want to thank you for your excellent editorial on Roger Baldwin's impending retirement as executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union. You do well to emphasize that "for thirty years the American Civil Liberties Union and Roger N. Baldwin have been almost synonymous terms."

Any of you buckaroos who're getting a mite slow on the draw, might gig on downtown one day and take a lesson from Howard Wade Kimsey. Mr. Kimsey is just about the slickest hammer-fanning hand with a six-gun still left east of the Tonto Rim.

" The Nine Lives of Europe," a report and analysis of Europe by Leo Lania, journalist, novelist, playwright, scenarist and lecturer, is scheduled for spring publication by Funk Wagnalls. Mr. Lania reports on economic and political conditions of Europe and analyzes its political, spiritual and intellectual development since the war.

The youngster was of above average intelligence, alert and eager to learn, and seemed to have a fundamental grasp of reading and writing. Yet he read and wrote backwards. His mother's explanation was: "It must be because he's left-handed."

MOUNT MORRIS, Pa., Nov. 6 -- Residents of this small Mason-Dixon borderline town in Greene County, in the extreme southwest corner of the commonwealth, face the prospect of voting at Tuesday's borough election for candidates who will never hold office.

Sales aptitude tests are being used by 235 manufacturing concerns today for every 100 which used that method of selecting salesmen in 1945. This is the finding of Prof. J. Robert Hilgert, Ph. D., associate professor of economics at Pennsylvania State College, following a survey of 200 concerns which employ salesmen.

President Truman was technically and literally correct when he stated that the outcome of tomorrow's Presidential election in the Philippines would have no bearing upon our friendly relations with our sister republic. What the President manifestly had in mind was the restatement and re-emphasis of our position that the Philippines is truly and fully sovereign and that its domestic affairs are not properly our concern.

WARSAW, Nov. 6 -- Poland and other "people's democracies" must develop a system of guarding their state secrets as closely as the Soviet Union does, the newspaper Trybunu Ludu stated today. State secrets, an article in the newspaper explained, may range from information on how many machines are to be installed in a textile factory to personnel changes in trade unions.

DETROIT, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings routed the New York Rangers, 7 -- 0, tonight. A crowd of 12,254 saw Goalie Harry Lumley get his second shut-out of the season for the National Hockey League leaders.

Title to sixty acres of the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing, Queens, has been taken by the First Housing Company, Inc., as part of the site for a 2,000-apartment nonprofit development under he state's cooperative housing program, it was announced yesterday by State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 6 -- Nobody can get a good bear story started the way President Truman can, according to Representative Frank Boykin, Democrat, of Alabama.

Protestants need "a little definiteness" about their religion and should remember that "activity and attachment" are as important as the spirit, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street, declared yesterday.

The nation must make a positive effort to foster international trade if it is to achieve a sound and successful merchant marine, Archibald E. King, vice president of the Isthmian Steamship Company, declared yesterday.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, using an independent liberal forum for his purpose, delivered a challenging address last night in which he accused the Republicans of making New York State a battleground in their fight for "naked reaction."

Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal's campaign for $250,000,000, announced yesterday that $100,219,000 had been given so far to meet the needs of Jews throughout the world. The money was obtained between Jan. 1 and Nov. 4.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- John L. Lewis came to Chicago today for a meeting with the United Mine Workers policy committee and presumably to try for a strike settlement agreement on the Illinois-Indiana soft-coal front. But representative operators insisted that they would negotiate only in the national wage conference.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal - Fusion candidate for Mayor, asserted yesterday that his election had been assured by the efforts of Republican district workers and the support of their Liberal and Fusion allies.

Forty three trade union leaders including machinists, painters, garment workers, seafarers, actors musicians, pulp and paper mill workers, Pullman porters and clerks, joined yesterday in a statement urging the election of Newbold Morris for Mayor and Herbert H. Lehman for United States Senator.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- After three periods of erratic play, the Chicago Bears, paced by Johnny Lujack's passes, drove to two final-period touchdowns to annex a 24-3 National Football League victory over the Green Bay Packers today.

Deferred from Friday night, "Love Me Long" will have its delayed premiere tonight at the Forty-eighth Street. For Brock Pemberton, its producer, the Doris Frankel comedy will mark his first local offering since the unforgettable "Harvey," although he did have a tussle in the interim with "The Magnificent Heel," which was dropped by the wayside.
