LONDON, Nov. 6 -- There are increasing indications here that "Uniforce," the Western European Union's Command organization at Fontainebleau, France, may be ready for reorganization.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The steady drying up of business on the Stock Exchange last week was due chiefly to lack of confidence in the country's economic outlook. The Government's half-hearted measures to cope with the crisis are still a subject of much criticism culminating in the vote of censure on the Government passed by the House of Lords.

Voting in tomorrow's general election will be done entirely by machine in this city and in all other sections of the state. To record a choice of candidates and a position on the eight proposed amendments to the State Constitution and on three propositions, all that is needed is to pull down the proper lever.

The increasing needs of the aged must be met through private philanthropy in supplementing public funds, Justice Albert Cohn of the Appellate Division said last night at the annual dinner of the Hebrew Home for the Aged, 114-120 East 105th Street.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 6 -- Announcement was made here today that Bowdoin College has received a gift of $225,000 in settlement of a trust fund established by the late Edwin B. Smith of New York, who was graduated from Bowdoin in 1856.
Buddy Young scampered 57 yards for a touchdown on the first play from scrimmage and, almost immediately afterwards, Don Panciera whipped a 28-yard scoring pass to Bruce Alford.

McNARY, Ore., Nov. 6 -- Working around the clock six days a week, Army engineers and their contractors are nearing the halfway mark in cemnt work on McNary Dam, which will generate almost half as much hydroelectric energy as the entire Tennessee Valley Authority system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Southern Conference Educational Fund, Inc., announced today that a poll of 15,000 Southern college teachers had resulted in a 70 per cent vote, out of 3,375 replies, in favor of admission of Negroes to existing professional and graduate schools without segregation.

The three-story commercial building at 1400 Boston Road, the Bronx, which is leased to one tenant, has been sold by Fred Hardy and Isaac J. Pomerantz, operators, to an investing client of Allan S. Feldman Co., brokers, for cash over mortgages amounting to $8,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Outplayed and outscored for three periods, the Washington Redskins came to life to push across three quick touchdowns in the last quarter today and beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 27 -- 14.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Delays in the final settlement of the Government case against the eleven Communists in New York are not relished by the Department of Justice, but nevertheless it is not expected that the case will reach the United States Supreme Court before a year hence.
The diversity of the metropolitan art scene continues in the large number of exhibitions opening this week.

Domestic futures on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net gains of 8 to 18 points last week, although day-to-day price movements were irregular. The nearby deliveries were firmer than the distants, in contrast to the trend in the preceding week, when the distant contracts showed the greater strength.
Suffering is not sufficient to justify the title "saint," the Rev. Canon Edward N. West, sacrist of the Cathedral Of St. John the Divine, said in his sermon there yesterday.

The Census Bureau does not write on walls with moving fingers in letters of fire. Still, it sometimes comes up with news quite as important as the results of a battle or a political campaign. Between 1830 and the middle of the present year Pennsylvania was the second most populous state in the Union.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- Georgi M. Malenkov, member of the Russian Politburo, delivering the principal address at the anniversary celebration of the October revolution at glittering Bolshoi Theatre tonight, charged that United States warmongers sought to turn the entire world into an American colony.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 6 -- While signs and banners displayed outside Dickinson High School here openly urged people to "beat Hague, vote Driscoll," 3,000 persons met in the school this afternoon to cheer former Mayor Frank Hague and State Senator Elmer H. Wene, Democratic candidate for Governor.
A "spiritualized America" to make the world happy was urged yesterday by Msgr. John S. Middleton, secretary of education of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

Respect for God must become part of the life of every American if this country is to endure as "a peaceful, law-abiding Republic and not disintegrate in chaotic strife, bloodshed and genocide," the Rev. Dr. George J. Zentgraf declared at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

The chorus and ballet of the Metropolitan Opera have been rehearsing for several weeks in different rooms of the Metropolitan building, but today rehearsals will move into full swing when the dancers and choristers move to the stage, and the men of the orchestra start their rehearsals too.

The transfer of 29,000 Yemenite Jews to Israel by airplane in less than a year was announced yesterday in a statement by Edward M. Warburg, chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee, which operates with funds furnished by the United Jewish Appeal.
We summarize here the recommendations which this newspaper has made to its readers regarding questions and candidates to be voted upon tomorrow.

Despite the destruction caused by the war, educational facilities in most countries of Europe have been restored to pre-war standards. Although shortages of teachers and buildings still exist, rapid strides have been made to rebuild the schools and colleges.

When Emlen Tunnell returned a punt 68 yards to a touchdown just 55 seconds after hostilities began before 23,222 fans at the Polo Grounds yesterday, practically everybody settled back expecting the Giants to breeze to another triumph.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns moved into first place in the All-America Conference today with a 35-2 victory over the completely outclassed Chicago Hornets as the New York Yankees were dropping a 17-14 game to the Buffalo Bills.

The Ohio Oil Company and subsidiaries disclosed yesterday a net income of $26,734,727 for the nine months to Sept. 30. This compared with an income of $38,035,151 for the corresponding period of 1948. The income this year is equal to $4.07 a common share, against $5.80 a share last year.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- State agencies that campaign to obtain public approval for controversial amendments and propositions were charged with "overstepping proper bounds" in a letter made public here today by the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey.
The proper handling of money is an essential part of religion, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

After twenty years at 11 West Forty-second Street, the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., will move to 100 Park Avenue, the new thirty-six story office building occupying the blockfront from Fortieth to Fortyfirst Streets, where the milk farmers cooperative will occupy the entire fifth floor and part of the third floor.

One of the largest commercial movements of air freight, consisting of enough furnishings to equip a $6,000,000 hotel, has been started by Eastern Airlines and Pan American Airways, is was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Felisa Rincon de Gautier, first woman Mayor of San Juan, capital of Puerto Rico, predicted here yesterday that most Puerto Ricans living in New York would vote for the re-election of Mayor O'Dwyer, despite a general belief that Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate, would attract most of the Puerto Rican vote.

Irving Potash, one of the eleven Communist leaders convicted of conspiracy to teach or advocate the violent overthrow of the Government, is slated for expulsion from the state executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations at a meeting here Nov. 16, it became known last night.

The fifty-seventh, annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers will open here Wednesday at the Walldorf-Astoria Hotel. The three-day business and technical sessions will be attended by members of the shipping and shipbuilding industries and allied trades from all parts of the country.

The Budapest String Quartet, which has never missed a season with the New Friends of Music, played for that organization late yesterday afternoon at its second concert of the season at Town Hall. The program was two parts Brahms to one Mozart.

The role of Monica in Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Medium" calls for a sympathetic and appealing actress with a pretty voice. And the composer was fortunate once more on Saturday night when Ann Ayars took over the part for the first time in the performance of the opera by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center.

" What am I going to do without her?" cried Charles Leiner, 60 years old, of 2846 West Thirtieth Street, Brooklyn, at 1 A. M. yesterday, after his wife, Sophie, 54, had died of a heart attack in front of their home. Thirty minutes later he answered his question by joining her in death, also the victim of a heart attack.

The Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis spent more than $100,000 last month on care and treatment of polio cases, more than double the pre-epidemic monthly average expenditures, it was announced yesterday.

The Irish Army team gained its first blue ribbon here since before the war last night when Bruree, a 7-year-old home-bred gelding, triumphed in the $1,000 international individual military stake at Madison Square Garden. The event provided the highlight for the sixth day of competition at the National Horse Show.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- German political leaders believe that the meeting of the United States, British and French Foreign Ministers in Paris this week will result in strengthening of the position of the West German Federal Republic both in Germany and in Europe.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has turned out another remodeled utility structure. Last Thursday the Federal agency began to close out its five-year file on the $150,000,000 Long Island Lighting Company, with the announcement that the plan of consolidation of the parent and its two subsidiaries was approved, subject to minor amendments that are in preparation.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 6 -- Nassau Democrats concede that the Republicans will carry the county at Tuesday's election, but predict the largest Democratic vote in the county's history.

PAWLING, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- A week-end conference of 200 delegates from social agencies and settlement houses in New York ended here today with a talk by Edmund H. Kellogg, acting officer in charge of United Nations Economic Affairs for the United States State Department.

Delegations representing 300,000 Masons joined church congregations throughout the state yesterday in observance of the seventeenth annual "Go to Church Sunday," designated by Frank M. Totton of Larchmont, State Grand Master of the Masonic Order.

Mariemma, the distinguished Spanish dancer who made her local debut last season returned last night for the first of two recitals at the Ziegfeld Theatre and proved that she is actually as fine an artist as she appeared to be a year ago.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 6 -- Although the results of the round-table conference on Indonesia are interpreted differently in financial and trade quarters owing to the many escape clauses, nevertheless the fact that the conference here ended in some agreement was hailed with a sigh of relief.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 6 -- An anti-trust suit against Oregon doctors and medical groups has reached the halfway mark and has taken a recess in the Federal District Court of Judge Claude McColloch.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 6 -- More than ten thousand persons sat in the State Coliseum of the Ohio State Fair Grounds today in silence as the Twenty-seventh Annual Meeting of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference was opened with the presentation of a pageant, "The Golden Secret of Green Acres," written by the Rev. Urban Nagle.

In tribute to his forty years of service the Norwegian America Line has called Capt. Ole Bull, Iowa-born shipmaster, from retirement to command the new luxury liner Oslofjord on her delivery voyage Nov. 11 from Amsterdam, Holland, to Oslo, Norway.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Paquin this midseason confirms the vogue for street-length evening gowns. Slender, strapless, worn with a medium-size hat and long gloves, they are definitely formal without benefit of any jacket to transform them into afternoon apparel.

During this cold war, when the United States is trying to seek new friends abroad and keep the old ones, the American Government and people might watch with interest the Philippine Presidential election on Nov. 8.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Liquidation was on in November lard on the Board of Trade last week, the price dropping to a new low since 1941, and deferred deliveries went to a new seasonal low. Demand for November was not aggressive as lard made before Oct. 1 and tendered on November contracts cannot be retendered in December under Exchange regulations.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 6 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion warned foreign Zionists today against attempting to bring pressure on the Israeli Government through their control of Zionist funds or organizations. Mr. Ben-Gurion said that if these Zionists wanted to influence Israel's policy they should come to this country and share the responsibilities and privileges of citizenship.

St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church, 147 East Twenty-eighth Street, was rededicated yesterday at a pontifical mass celebrated by Auxiliary Bishop Joseph P. Donahue, vicar general of the Archdiocese of New York.

IT may or may not have been the start of a beautiful friendship, but the Army-Fordham game in retrospect contained a surprising amount of mutually satisfactory elements in spite of the one-sidedness of the 35-0 score. The swift-moving, swift-striking Black Knights proved their greatness and justified more than ever their high rank among the nation's top teams.
Mayor O'Dwyer made Vito Marcantonio the target of a bitter attack yesterday as he neared the end of his campaign for re-election.
TOKYO, Nov. 6 -- Virtually every Japanese business is being embarrassed by rubber checks, according to executives of many concerns. They believe the credit situation is rapidly approaching a crisis.

" Madame Butterfly" and the double-bill of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" were the operas that closed the New York City Opera Company's sixth week at the City Center yesterday. Both drew large audiences.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 6 -- A spokesman for the United States delegation said today that it would give "serious and objective consideration" to the suggestions by Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the United Nations General Assembly, for a temporary atomic truce between the United States and the Soviet Union, including the suspension of production of atomic bombs.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Energetic campaigning by Westchester Democratic candidates in preparation for Tuesday's election was giving to the party today the greatest confidence since Franklin D. Roosevelt carried the county in 1930 and Herbert H. Lehman in 1932, but the Republican organization foresaw no repeat performance for Mr. Lehman and no loss of a fifty-year grip on most county, city and town offices.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 6 -- Soviet diplomats have been bombarding Swiss and other diplomats believed by the Russians to be informed of United States policies with questions as to United States intentions in case of a Russian or satellite invasion of Yugoslavia, it was learned here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The Thanksgiving Day dinner probably will be cheaper this year than it was last year, Agriculture officials said today.

Few New Yorkers realize that the hospitals that serve them are constantly alerted and hold special drills for emergencies that might happen at any time in a city of 8,000,000. Officials of the United Hospital Fund say "disaster drills," common in the last war, are scheduled still in many of the member hospitals of the Fund.

With two more large banks here starting discretionary common trust funds last week, this method of handling trust accounts, which has increased rapidly in recent months, is fast becoming a major factor in trust banking operations.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 6 -- Bids are being sought from contractors for construction of a new-type two-story school structure to be added to the Stockton School in Greenwood Avenue at North Nine-teenth Street here, it was made known today.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Mr. Malenkov, a rising star in Soviet inner circles, said that Russia, though she "possesses the atomic weapon," did not want war and was doing "everything to prevent It."
The Maria Moors Cabot awards, annually awarded by Columbia University "for the advancement of international friendship in the Americas," were announced yesterday.

The essence of Christianity lies not in the Bible but rather in the church, the Rev. Albert A. Chambers, recently appointed rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection, 115 East Seventy-fourth Street, declared in his first sermon yesterday morning.

There are always certain groups that stand to benefit from an increase in the price of gold, which largely explains why the rumor of devaluing the dollar never really dies out, but merely dies down. The idea that there is any logical basis for such a policy at the present time or that it could conceivably serve any useful public purpose is, however, patently absurd.

An investigation of advertising claims for newly marketed antihistamine cold remedies has been started by the National Better Business Bureau, it was learned last week. The bureau is checking questions raised by some ad statements with competent medical and trade authorities.
UTICA, N. Y. Nov. 6 (AP) -- State police announced tonight that Mrs. Stella Komorek admitted that her six-week-old son died of a fall and that she threw the body in a millpond near her home.

CAIRO, Nov. 6 -- The Lebanese Government, it is learned, has again taken into consideration the proposal of its Foreign Ministry for the delineation of Lebanon's frontier with Israel. The proposal was taken up, according to the explanation given in Beirut, because there have been raids on Lebanese villages from the Israel side of the line.

Thomas Hannah Jr. has been appointed manager of the central business contact department of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation of Pittsburgh. He was formerly manager of the Washington sales office.

The time is here for festive children's parties. Making their debut in the whirl of the winter's fun will be children of all ages, from those just out of the toddler's stage up to teen agers on their first date. For the girls, party dresses are an exciting fashion.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- At religious services held throughout the Commonwealth today Britons paid homage to their dead of two world wars.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 6 -- Voters in five southern Fairfield County communities, among them the only two cities in Connecticut with Socialist Mayors, will go to the polls on Tuesday to elect municipal administrations for the next two years.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- The United Lutheran Church in America announced here today that it would hold a six-day collection drive next year to raise $6,000,000 for the improvement and expansion of its twenty-three colleges and theological seminaries.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The attitude of Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, toward the German problems when he meets Dean Acheson, United States Secretary of State, and Ernest Bevin, British Foreign Secretary, in Paris, Wednesday will be affected by the fact that a new and uncertain French Cabinet must face a parliamentary debate on its German policy the following week.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- Billed as the professional football "battle of the year," today's clash between the Philadelphia Eagles and Los Angeles Rams was "no contest." Hitherto unbeaten, the Pacific Coast entrant ran into a near-perfect gridiron machine and was out-run, out-passed, out-smarted and out-scored, 38 -- 14, before the largest football crowd on record at Shibe Park.

Eugene Gash, 29-year-old Negro pianist from Denver, gave his fourth New York recital late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall before an enthusiastic audience. His first two appearances were made at the age of 19, and his third two years later when considerable advances in his abilities were reported.

DEL MAR, Calif., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Rex Mays, 36, of Glendale, Calif., one of the nation's leading race drivers, was killed this afternoon when his car hit a chuck hole on the Del Mar Race Track during an auto race sanctioned by the American Automobile Association.

Our visitor's hat when new may have been a light brown -- or possibly gray -- but as it was placed carefully on the desk the eye perceived that only by scraping away at the surface cautiously, as one might scratch at the paint of an old chair to get to the wood, could the weather-beaten felt's original color be revealed.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 6 -- The fifteenth annual malaria survey of the Tennessee Valley Authority has disclosed that for the first time in the history of the region no positive tests were found in the reservoir areas.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 6 (UP) -- More than 12,000 Communists, shouting "Let the King Stay in Switzerland," stopped downtown traffic for more than three hours tonight in a demonstration against the national referendum on the return of self-exiled King Leopold.

Devotees of Scandinavan design will find a varied assortment of new furniture, fabrics and lamps on the third floor of Bonniers, 605 Madison Avenue. Lighting fixtures, lamps, upholstered chairs, love seats and additional cabinet pieces have been imported to supplement the small stock of furniture formerly confined to the second floor of the shop.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Two issues affecting householders and house-seekers confront the nation this week. One has to do with that household necessity, soap, which still is rationed, and the other with housing. Both are example of how some trade associations and labor unions exploit the consumer in Britain.

Senator John Foster Dulles asserted yesterday that Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic-Liberal opponent in tomorrow's election of a United States Senator, had become so "desperate" that he had given up defending the policies and principles of President Truman's Fair Deal.

Cooler weather has stimulated consumer demand for fall apparel and consequently a large number of reorders for fall ready-to-wear were received by the wholesale garment market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE YORK NEW TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Five hundred members of the Police Department's Shomrim Society, a Jewish group, marched yesterday from the West Sixty-eighth Street station to the Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, to take part in the annual memorial services for the department's dead.

ROME, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi's coalition Cabinet narrowly escaped a full crisis and resignation tonight. The Liberal party directorate voted eleven to nine to remain in the Government.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Excerpts from a speech delivered in Moscow today by Georgi M. Malenkov, a member of the Politburo, as broadcast from Moscow:
Significance in the movement of foreign exchanges was again lacking in last week's markets.

The type of formal support to candidates for political office given by national medical organizations in tomorrow's election was criticized yesterday by speakers at a conference on national health sponsored by the Physicians Forum.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- There is little interest here in the state-wide Senatorial contest as both major parties in Rockland County are in an all-out drive for control of the Board of Supervisors. The Republicans have a three-to-two majority, but close contests are indicated in four out of the five townships.

Russian appetizers with such formidable names as pirojkis and koulibiaks are the feature of Alex Obolensky's newly established catering service. A taste of these savory meat and pastry delicacies, though, and worries about pronunciation are forgotten.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 -- A. Philip Randolph, international president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, today took Paul Robeson, the singer, to task for asserting that he spoke for the Negro people.

Gloomy over the prospects for successful mediation of the coal strike, high Federal officials disclosed last night that they were considering a recommendation that President Truman set up a special fact-finding board outside the Taft-Hartley Act to seek settlement of the mine dispute.

The Mutual Broadcasting System has signed a new seven-year contract for exclusive radio rights to the world series and the All-Star baseball games, which will be sponsored by the Gillette Safety Razor Company, it was announced yesterday.

With regard to an article in the Oct. 26 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES under the heading "Ellender Assures Spain," I should like to know by what sense of ego the Senator from Louisiana sets himself up as the mouthpiece for the whole United States, saying that we "would like to help Spain and Chief of State Francisco Franco," but were "obliged to respect the anti-Franco views of our European allies."
DETROIT, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals shoved the Detroit Lions deeper into the National Football League's cellar with a 42-to-19 rout of the home team before 22,479 fans today.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,823,711,726. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:...

Delivery of the 1950 line of Checker cabs, described as the smallest taxi built to meet New York City specifications, will begin here Jan. 1. It was announced yesterday by the Checker Cab Manufacturing Corporation.
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- France is having increased difficulties in obtaining the deblocking of the Marshall Plan counterpart funds, according to informed sources here.
" What does the Soviet Union want, and how far is Russia going to go?"

That noble but obscure instrument, the viola, made one of its rare appearances in the spotlight on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall with the Philharmonic-Symphony. William Lincer, the orchestra's capable solo violist, played the solo in Jean Rivier's Concertino for viola and chamber orchestra for the first time in New York. Leopold Stokowski conducted.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will make a film of Sir Walter Scott's romantic novel, "Ivanhoe," early next year in Technicolor with an all-star cast. A studio spokesman said the picture would be produced in the British Isles as the first on its London studio schedule for 1950.

After a twelve-year experiment with the proportional representation system of electing City Councilmen, New York returns this year to the district system. Instead of using paper ballots and recording a first, second, third or other preference, voters will cast their ballot for Councilman on the voting machines in the same fashion as they vote for other offices.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- Even as a legislative recess commission studying the Massachusetts textile industry was considering stimulative measures this week, the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston gave indication that the industrial future of the New England area as a whole probably was bound up in durable goods.
Twelve new films, including importations from England, Russia and Italy, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Lili Kraus, pianist, made her American debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Born in Budapest and now a British subject, she began her career before the public at 16 and has appeared throughout the world in recitals and as soloist with major orchestras.

CARLISLE, Pa., Nov. 6 (UP) -- An Army sergeant who vowed he would visit the families of 170 GI buddies driven to their deaths by Nazi storm troopers said today he would "finish the job if it takes me a lifetime."

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 (AP) -- San Francisco bounced back after being behind twice today to repel a battling Baltimore eleven, 28 to 10, in an All-America Conference game before 23,704 in Babe Ruth Stadium.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Although still opposed to the granting of any special concessions to industry as an incentive for increasing the sale of exports in the dollar markets, Britain's Socialist Government is beginning to favor higher rewards to labor for greater productivity.

The annual benefit fair for the Church of the Incarnation will be held in its Parish House at 209 Madison Avenue on Wednesday morning and afternoon and Thursday afternoon and evening, with tea being served on the former day and a buffet supper on the latter.

The march of anti-Communist locals out of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America continued yesterday as more locals voted to leave the UE in the wake of its expulsion by the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

With results of tomorrow's election doubtful, the leading candidates for state, city and local offices will continue their appeals for votes on election eve and will not end their campaigns until a few hours before the opening of the polls at 6 o'clock tomorrow morning.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 6 (AP) -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., in a move to distribute ownership of cellophane production, announced today it has licensed Olin Industries, Inc., to make cellophane on terms involving a $20,000,000 minimum investment.

Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India, who will start for home today after his tour of this country, was the guest yesterday of Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, commander of the First Army, on a sightseeing trip up the Hudson River.
Collision insurance rates for private passenger cars will go up today in all of the city except Richmond, it was announced yesterday by Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance.
LONDON, Monday, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Russia has assigned one of her top Army Marshals to serve in the Polish Army, the Moscow radio announced today.

The collision of a scheduled airliner and a military-type plane at National Airport, Washington, D. C., last Tuesday with the loss of fifty-five lives has spurred the major commercial airports of the nation to re-examine their own safety problems of mixed military, private and airline operations.
Three young men from the Bronx went out from Sheepshead Bay on Friday for a day's mackerel fishing in their thirty-four-foot power boat the Meridian.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- John L. Lewis came to a dead end today in his efforts to arrange separate strike-settling conferences with Illinois coal operators.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 7 -- The admirals and generals of the United Nations Military Staff Committee, a group kept relatively idle by its inability to agree on the structure of an international police force, has rejected firmly a plea by the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee to fuse its employes with the Secretariat here and save money.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Diplomatic officials reported tonight that Britain was planning to give full recognition to the Chinese Communist regime "within weeks." They said that Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin was expected to inform Secretary of State Dean Acheson and French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman of the plan when he meets with them in Paris Wednesday and Thursday.

Temporary and restricted permission for five of the eleven convicted Communist leaders to leave the court's jurisdiction for visits to their homes will be granted, Judge William Bondy ruled in Federal court here yesterday.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Scientists said today they had uncovered a new treatment, involving the use of aureomycin, and a possible vaccine for amoebic dysentery.
Notre Dame so completely dominates the top ten college football ratings that even losing to the Irish moves a club up the ladder.

The Coca-Cola Company announced yesterday an increase in its nine months' earnings over last year's period and declared extra year-end dividends. A special meeting of common stockholders on Dec. 19 has been called to vote on an exchange offering of stock.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- With trading slow in almost all sections, a further decline in British Government issues contributed to the dull tone of the stock markets here today.

Mathe Tibor, a former Hungarian artillery officer, who joined the Budapest police force in 1941 as a traffic policeman rather than fight against the Allies, was among the 1,267 displaced persons who arrived yesterday morning aboard the Army transport Gen. Harry Taylor.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Partial identification of the chemical constitution and structure of vitamin B-12, recently identified as the life-essential factor in liver that controls pernicious anemia, was announced here tonight by Dr. Karl Folkers of the research laboratories of Merck Co., Rahway, N. J.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- J. Arthur Rank, Britain's largest motion-picture producer, disclosed today that unless conditions in the industry improve, his organization may be forced to halt production. Consideration already has been given to the idea, he said, but it was rejected for the present.
The Empire City management guarantees eight winners an afternoon. But there was an extra one yesterday at Jamaica.

Luggage was aboard the Boeing Stratocruiser, the crew were at their posts, and the twenty-eight passengers, bound for London and Frankfort, Germany, were awaiting the boarding signal at New York International Airport, Idlewild, at 3 P. M. yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Supreme Court refused today to consider a plea by three railroad unions that it review a 1948 Federal District Court order enjoining a nation-wide rail strike.

The old adage that if you want peace you must prepare for war has a good American heritage, starting with George Washington. It would be comforting to gaze blandly toward Moscow, where yesterday's customary military display in honor of the October Revolution was held, and consider it as a contribution to peace.

Commissioner Asa S. Bushnell, to whom Eastern gridiron officials are most directly responsible, told the Football Writers Association at its weekly luncheon-meeting at Toots Shor's yesterday that he was wholly satisfied with the arbiters who worked last Saturday's Army-Fordham game at West Point.
TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 7 -- New Jersey voters tomorrow will select a Governor, seven state Senators, all sixty members of the Assembly and a host of county and municipal officials.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Bob Black, Rhode Island State's lanky harrier from Attleboro, Mass., made history today by winning the New England intercollegiate cross-country run for the fourth successive year.
Formation of a committee to further cooperation and understanding between all levels of the apparel industries was asked yesterday at a National Retail Dry Goods luncheon in the Statler Hotel.
BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- No Russian move in Eastern Europe has excited so much speculation here as the installation of Marshal Rokossovsky as Poland's Minister of Defense.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 7 -- Only 2 per cent of the 10,000,000 mentally or physically handicapped children in the United States today are being trained for useful places in society although 50 per cent are capable of satisfactory adjustment, according to speakers at a special conference held here today on problems of the exceptional child.

Foreign doubts about the dollar are becoming manifest in banking transactions and direct dealings between foreign traders here and their foreign suppliers, it was disclosed yesterday. Agitation for an increase in the price of gold, the equivalent of devaluation of the dollar, has made foreign suppliers uneasy and they are now asking assurances from United States customers that payment for goods will be made at the current dollar rate.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Proposed $1,085,050 improvements for Westchester highways, parks and public buildings were endorsed today by the County Planning Commission as "desirable and satisfactory from a planning standpoint."
Benjamin J. Davis Jr., Harlem Councilman, and John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, were barred yesterday from voting in today's election.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 7 -- France and Canada introduced today a resolution under which the United Nations General Assembly would request the six permanent members of the Atomic Energy Commission -- the Big Five plus Canada -- to continue their discussions on the possibility of reaching agreement on international atomic control and the prohibition of atomic weapons.

Although most of the nation's stock exchanges will be closed today for the elections, the cotton and grain exchanges will be open as usual. Because the Department of Agriculture will issue its monthly cotton report the New York and New Orleans Cotton Exchanges will be open.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 7 -- All of Western Germany's hopes -- and they are high -- for a major change in allied policy toward the Federal Republic are based on the role of the United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy in the Paris conference of Foreign Ministers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- A former Tucker Corporation engineer told a jury in Federal District Court here today that Preston Tucker called him a "sissy" for refusing to collaborate in a $30,000 apartment selling scheme. The witness was Enea Bossi, automobile and helicopter expert, nineteenth man to testify for the Government in the fraud and conspiracy trial of Mr. Tucker and seven associates, now in its fourth week before Judge Walter J. LaBuy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Two Interstate Commerce Commission examiners held today that several railroads had been giving General Motors and the Ford Motor Company "unduly preferential" rates on their automoble shipments from assembly plants.

Three new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Victoria, the attraction is "All the King's Men," a Columbia drama written for the screen, produced and directed by Robert Rossen from the novel by Robert Penn Warren.

MANILA, Tuesday, Nov. 8 -- Two reports of violence occurring during early polling hours inaugurated Election Day as an unprecedented large proportion of the 5,000,000 registered Philippine voters began electing a President and a new Congress.
The coffee futures market continued to climb yesterday in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. New high levels were established in all delivery positions.

From the days when the first adventurers from across the Atlantic touched these shores and found the landscape dressed in autumn's coat of many colors -- so that to some of them the forests seemed more like out-size flower gardens -- from those days on, the show put on each year with the turning of the leaves along our Eastern seaboard has been generally, and justly, admired.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justices fired a barrage of questions today as they confronted the issue whether Government employes could be impartial jurors in a trial of a Communist leader.

Maritime questions of wide scope will be discussed at the conference of the International Chamber of Shipping, which opens its meeting in London today. The United States, United Kingdom and most of the Western European maritime nations will be represented at the two-day session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat, of Maryland, today urged the inclusion of Spain in the European Western Union as "most desirable" for the strategic, economic and political interests of the United States.
Judge Harold R. Medina has just about given up all hope of reading the "well over 50,000" letters and telegrams that have deluged him since the end of the trial of the eleven top Communist leaders.

Lili Kraus made her second appearance in this country last night with the National Orchestral Association under Leon Barzin in Carnegie Hall only two days after her recital debut. The Hungarian-born pianist played the solo part in Schumann's Piano Concerto in A minor in a program which included Bizet's Symphony in C and Cherubini's "Anacreon" Overture.

Confident of victory, Mayor O'Dwyer wound up his campaign last night on the theme on which he waged it -- he argued that the record of his first administration entitled him to another four years in City Hall.

Dr. Howard A. Rusk, director of the Institute of Rehabilitation at New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, said yesterday that Austria and Poland were making great progress in rehabilitating their war casualties but that an enormous job remained to be done.

WILLIAM FAULKNER is considered by many Frenchmen and a few Americans as the most important living American writer. That he might have been, since his natural talents are so undeniably great, seems to me a defensible proposition. That he is not seems to me obvious. Undisciplined gifts, intermittent flashes of blazing power, a morbid preoccupation with violence and degeneracy and a monstrously turgid anti obscure style are not convincing qualifications for literary pre-eminence.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Alvin E. Sandroff, 47 years old, pleaded guilty today to two of three Government indictments which charged him and two paper companies which he headed with owing the Government $3,113,609.35 in taxes and penalties over the years 1942-45 inclusive.

The opening of bids for reconstruction of the roadways of the Brooklyn Bridge left the city in a quandary yesterday as to whether to let the contract on a piecemeal basis or whether to put off the entire project until future bidding brings possibly more favorable offers.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 7 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll closed his campaign for re-election tonight with the Contention that former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City would "take over the State House" if Elmer H. Wene, Democratic candidate, were elected.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal -City Fusion candidate for Mayor, ended his campaign by speaking in person and by transcription over twenty-three radio stations and from at least a half dozen sound trucks yesterday. When he finished, close to midnight, he reiterated his predictions of victory and said he would spend today visiting the polls.

An appeal by defense counsel for Alger Hiss that the Government be forced to turn over "important" material for the former State Department official's second perjury trial was taken under advisement yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy.

Ephraim Margolin, 22 years old, who had been held at Ellis Island for investigation since his arrival from Israel on Aug. 22, was released at 3 P. M. yesterday and will be free to remain in New York pending a final determination by Ellis Island authorities.
After having been closed to the public for a year, the House of Italian Handicrafts, 217 East Forty-ninth Street, reopened yesterday and began its first retail operations.

Ending a strenuous campaign, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman last night offered his record of public service against the "misrepresentations of Republican reaction" and said he was confident of the outcome.

In your editorial of Nov. 5, "Don't Forget Housing," you regret that confusion is being spread about the three housing propositions and state further that it has nothing to do with the city program for middle-income families.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Vice Admiral John E. (Billick) Whelchel, one of Navy's greatest football heroes, found the storms of National Football League competition too much for him today and bowed out as head coach of the Washington Redskins.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Navy's active sea force, growing smaller by the month, is now less than half the size of its mothball fleet.

Because of other trade factors, increases in the price of coffee will tend to maintain the present rate of Brazil's import dollar credit payments, rather than speed up their liquidation, it was declared in an interview yesterday by Jose Garrido-Torres, commercial attache of the Brazilian Embassy, following a talk at the Advertising Club.

Mexico's Captain Ruben Uriza and his grand 9-year-old chestnut gelding Hatuey flew over the fences to their third and greatest individual success of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night, this one for the international individual military championship challenge trophy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Both voluntary and Government agencies are indispensable in the fight against major diseases, Miss Mary Switzer of the Federal Security Agency today told the State Advisers on Women's Activities of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

BOSTON, Nov. -- A turnout of 300,000 voters, 10 per cent more than in any previous election, was predicted today in Boston as five candidates for Mayor completed their campaigns for tomorrow's balloting.
State and city law-enforcement agencies announced yesterday their plans to handle voting irregularities at the polls today.

A selection of accessories for the home to suit every taste and budget has been collected for the convenience of far-sighted shoppers in a special Christmas show set up for the holiday season by Georg Jensen at 684 Fifth Avenue, across the street from the regular store. Gift suggestions range from a dainty stainless steel hors d'oevres fork at 80 cents to an elegant seven-piece sterling silver tea and coffee set at $1,400.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for Mayor, loosed final blasts at both his opponents last night as he wound up a strenuous campaign at the "lucky corner," 116th Street and Lexington Avenue.

HONG KONG, Nov. 7 -- A Nationalist warship is detaining the British steamer Tsinan inside the three-mile limit at the mouth of the Yangtze near Shanghai, local shipping agents revealed here today. The Tsinan is one of the three British ships from Hong Kong that ran the Nationalist blockade into Shanghai a week ago accompanied up to the three-mile limit by British naval vessels.

HONOLULU, Nov. 7 -- Honolulu's waterfront, which was struck by Harry Bridges' International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union for 176 days, ending Oct. 23, was closed down again today as ILWU longshoremen walked off their jobs in protest against the hiring of eighteen nonunion stevedores.

A special effort of the Travelers Aid Society, 144 East Forty-fourth Street, through its annual drive for funds this month will be to build up its port division, which each year guides about 40,000 men, women and children from the city's piers to their ultimate destinations. The port division, handicapped by insufficient paid personnel, and forced to rely too largely on volunteers, has been operating "in the red" for three years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, Senate minority leader, accused the Democrats today of "dangerous overspending," while Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, the majority leader, said that the Republican party was "morally bankrupt."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Pro and con campaigns are being organized in Hollywood over Television Authority, a proposed new AFL union. Two mass meetings on the subject have been scheduled for several thousand Hollywood members of the seven union branches of Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent body for all AFL performer unions.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 -- Lester Allen, one-time dancing star of the "Ziegfeld Follies," was struck by an automobile and killed last night while crossing Ventura Boulevard in front of Bud Abbott's Back Stage Club. He was 58 years old.

Charges that "unfair and misleading propaganda" had been circulated by the Commerce and Industry Association, Inc., to defeat he three housing propositions were made yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a suit could not be brought against the Government for alleged negligence at an American-leased military base because it would violate the sovereignty of Great Britain.
The largest cash dividend disbursement in the history of American industry was voted yesterday by directors of the General Motors Corporation.

ROME, Nov. 7 -- The Cabinet crisis brought about last Monday by withdrawal of the right-wing Socialists from the Government was solved on a temporary basis today without the appointment of any new Ministers or Under-Secretaries.

An official of a labor union received a ninety-day prison term yesterday and another a suspended sentence on their pleas of guilty in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to a charge of conspiring to violate the Taft-Hartley Act. A similar accusation against five other union representatives was dismissed.

Jones Laughlin, the country's fourth-largest producer of steel, reached an agreement early this morning with the United Steel workers of America, CIO, on the disputed pension and health insurance benefits.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Notre Dame's football schedule, contrary to a lot of opinions otherwise, is packed full for the next four years, Ed "Moose" Krause, Athletic Director, told quarterback luncheon today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson met briefly with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei Y. Vishinsky, this afternoon and then left by plane for Paris for a conference on Germany and other topics with the British and French Foreign Ministers.

Robert Granville Burke, president of the Guild of Catholic Lawyers in New York, said last night that his organization would await an interpretation of the Pope's remarks on judicial rulings in divorce cases, adding that no layman was qualified to interpret it.

The Tennessee Valley Authority has been able to announce at the end of its fifteenth annual survey of the reservoir areas that no positive tests for malaria were found. Blood tests were made from 4,300 individuals in areas where positive tests and even high incidence had previously been shown. Every one was negative.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Detroit Lions won the bonus draft choice at the National Football League meeting today and promptly picked Leon Hart, star Notre Dame end.

Lower prices and "deals" attracted prompt buying yesterday among more than 18,500 visitors, estimated to have attended the opening day of the thirty-fourth National Hotel Exposition at Grand Central Palace. Most orders were placed for equipment, furnishings and labor-saving devices, exhibitors stated.

Municipal Court Justice Jehial M. Roeder reserved decision yesterday in eviction proceedings brought against twenty tenants on Washington Square South to make room for New York University's proposed $3,000,000 law center.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 7 -- Atomic research in the Soviet Union probably has enabled the Russians to produce a bomb about as good as those made in 1945 by the United States, Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, wartime head of the Manhattan Project, said here tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 7 -- The United States joined thirty-seven other countries in the Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today in calling upon specialized international agencies, such as the Food and Agriculture Organization and the International Labor Organization, to take a leading role in providing technical assistance and training for 200,000,000 native peoples in the world's dependent areas.
More than five million voters will go to the polls in New York State today for the climax of a campaign that attracted and has maintained nation-wide interest.

Arnold Schoenberg and Benjamin Britten were the contemporary composers that the Little Orchestra Society of Thomas K. Scherman paid homage to at Town Hall last night. The homage, of course, took the form of performances of their music, which is the best honor one can pay a composer.

An adult invasion of the city's public schools began yesterday as 100,000 parents marked the start of Open School Week. School officials predicted that 750,000 persons -- 70,000 more than last year -- would visit the schools this week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The National Catholic Welfare Conference said in a statement today that the Pontiff's words did "not represent a newly arrived at position of the Catholic Church."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, asked the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today to hold up final action on $44,400,000 in proposed loans to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The newspaper Liberal said today that political rioting at one point in northern Colombia had approached a "pitched battle," involving more than 1,600 men.

As the result of a "mistake" in embarkation procedure at Bremerhaven, Germany, 910 displaced persons, originally scheduled to go directly to New Orleans on the Army transport Gen. C. H. Muir, will pay an unexpected but brief visit to New York Harbor, it was reported yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 7 -- Norris E. Dodd, director general of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization warned today that collective action by countries was needed of the problems of surpluses and shortages of food were to be averted.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 -- "The Magnificent Yankee," Emmet Lavery's play about the late Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes which Arthur Hopkins produced on Broadway in 1946, has become a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer screen project.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A wartime technique for instantaneous processing of radar photographs may make possible rapid examinations for cancer of the stomach, the Public Health Service stated today in announcing ten new and twelve continuing cancer grants totaling $437,203.

A method for testing supposedly healthy persons in one clinic visit for a number of chronic diseases and defects is being developed by the United States Public Health Service in cooperation with state, local and voluntary agencies, Surgeon General Leonard A. Scheele announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- Soviet political stategists strove today to strengthen their position both in Germany and Eastern Europe on the occasion of the thirty-second anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution of 1917.
Firm prices on women's shoes for spring were reported yesterday at the Fashion Shoe Show, held by the Shoe Manufacturers Board of Trade of New York, Inc., at the Hotel McAlpin.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Premier Antonin Zapotocky said tonight that the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia were using uranium deposits in this country "to block the aggression and bandit greed of the warmongers."

On Election Day we try to influence the future. We might also give a thought to the past. As near as one can tell, this used to be a more generally and jovially celebrated occasion than it is now. Yet we cannot doubt that popular opinion is more accurately reflected today than it was in the good old days.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 5 per [cent last week in comparison with the corresponding week last year. i according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserved Bank of New York. The l drop for the four weeks ended on l last Saturday was 13 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Mrs. Louise Bransten Berman, West Coast heiress, declined to tell the House Committee on Un-American Activities today whether she had made contributions to Communist front organizations. She termed some of the questions asked her "shocking."

CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A motion to appear as "friend of the court" in the Federal Government's anti-trust suit against The Lorain, Ohio, Journal was filed in Federal Court today by the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

VIENNA, Nov. 7 -- A new national coalition Austrian Government was named today four weeks after the general elections on Oct. 9. Its creation had been delayed by the insistence of the Austrian Socialist party, which forms the lesser fraction of the coalition, upon establishment of a new ministry to superintend state and nationalized enterprises.

With right and left-wing factions battling in and out of court for control of workers in the country's electrical manufacturing industry, the group expelled last week from the Congress of Industrial Organizations won a temporary court victory yesterday.
Notre Dame makes its first New York appearance since 1946 this week to head a program in the East that offers the most interesting pairings the country over.

The lack of adequate rainfall in the city's Croton and Catskill watersheds has made the shortage in New York's storage reservoirs increasingly critical, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President and Mrs. Truman attended tonight the opening here of the Sadler's Wells Ballet in Constitution Hall. They were accompanied by Charles G. Ross, the President's press secretary; Mrs. Ross, and G. Walter Gates of Seattle, a cousin of Mrs. Truman, who is their guest at Blair House.

Retailers are showing the same type of caution in their spring buying as they did for the fall season, it was learned yesterday. New York manufacturers of women's apparel reported that the bulk of early buying is being done by specialty and small department stores. Large stores, with few exceptions, are not as yet placing sizable orders for the spring season.
The Central Maine Power Company sold at competitive bidding yesterday issues of mortgage bonds and preferred and common stock valued at more than $11,000,000.

LUXEMBOURG, Nov. 7 -- One conviction seems to dominate the thinking of the United States Senators of the Appropriations subcommittee now touring Europe. It is that a substantial cut must be made in Marshall Plan aid next year.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- One million Moscow men, women and youths paraded through Red Square today behind an hour-long procession of Soviet fighting units honoring the thirty-second anniversary of the Bolshevist Revolution and the Communist movement, which, according to Izvestia this morning, "no force in the world can stop."

A comprehensive program to promote the American merchant marine and bring home to every citizen its important role in the national economy and national defense has been approved by the United States Maritime Commission. The agency has taken steps to obtain funds for the project in its 1950-51 budget, it became known yesterday.

A second book by Robin Maugham, author of the short novel, "The Servant," which was published in February, will be issued by Harcourt, Brace on Thursday. "North African Notebook" is an informal account of a six-month journey by the author through the Arab lands of North Africa and Egypt.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The aircraft industry has proposed a change in regulations to allow freight planes to carry 5 per cent more gross weight than similar planes used for passengers.

Simmons Company will resume production "on a limited scale" next Monday at its Elizabeth, N. J., plant, Norman T. Gilroy, vice president in charge of sales, reported yesterday. The plant, second largest of the company's seven beddin factories, makes all products merchandised by Simmons and has been shut down several days because of exhaustion of steel inventories.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Pleading the Government's case in a bitter state's rights issue, Vice President Alben W. Barkley today sought the oil industry's cooperation in developing national petroleum resources "against the day of possible armed aggression from without or intellectual infiltration from within."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Supreme Court set aside today a lower court decision that the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York City must turn over to the alien property custodian $25,581 deposited by the Deutsche Reichsbank.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 7 -- The Soviet Union charged the United States and Britain today with deliberately building up troop strength and munitions stores in North Africa as part of a wide program for developing "springboards for aggression." This accusation was made before the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee in a debate on the former Italian colonies.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday but the undertone was steady and prices at the finish were 1 to 6 points net higher than on Saturday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The bugaboo of soft red wheat in local elevators got the better of many holders of the December future here today. They decided to get out of the market. The December contract dropped more than 2 cents, while other deliveries also weakened.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 7 -- The Governors of the eleven westernmost states and Alaska concurred today that the defenses of Alaska should be strongly reinforced against a possible attack by the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to rule now on whether Michigan was entitled to detailed reports on $350,000 in unclaimed deposits in the closed First National Bank of Detroit.
Oscar Hammerstein 2d characterized as false yesterday the prevailing impression along theatrical row that the legitimate theatre is on its last legs.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- The Scarsdale Board of Education adopted tonight a report of its Committee on Educational Policies that endorsed the retention in school libraries here of books citizens' group had described as subversive.

The stock market moved yesterday into a neutral corner, with a slight shading of prices near the close which left the list irregularly lower on the day. With the market scheduled to be closed today and again on Friday due to holidays, an indifferent attitude seemed to prevail in brokerage circles.
The report of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., and its subsidiaries showed yesterday a net profit of $28,414,275 after taxes and all charges for the fiscal year ended on July 31.
ROME, Nov. 7 -- Pope Pius XII called on all Roman Catholic jurists throughout the world last night to abstain from passing sentences based on laws that the church considered unjust.
TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 7 (AP) -- A $4,000,000 suit was filed today in Pima County Superior Court against Frederick B. Patterson, former president of the National Cash Register Company, and his wife.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Stubnitz Green Spring Corporation, Adrian, Md., had filed a registration statement covering 183,339 shares of the company's $1 par value common stock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The White House is apparently determined to stave off intervention in the seven-week soft coal strike as long as possible, it was indicated today after Government conferences with Southern operators.
PARIS, Nov. 7 -- This midseason, Schiaparelli achieves an important collection, stimulating to the fashion-wise by exciting detail in cut although without revolution in silhouette.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- Seventy-five used Army tanks, consigned to the Chinese Nationalist Government, and twenty-five stainless steel railroad cars, built by the Budd Company for the Central Railway of Brazil, were being loaded today aboard freighters at Pier G on the Delaware River here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, new Chief of Naval Operations, said tonight he had refused permission for Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr. to make a speech at Montgomery, Ala., because Captain Crommelin would not promise to avoid "controversial" matters.

A fire swept one of the rooms at the Associated American Artists Gallery at 711 Fifth Avenue last night, destroyed and damaged several paintings that had just been hung for a benefit preview for the Urban League and was the cause of the mysterious disappearance of a sizable statue.

IF THE post-mortems were lengthier and more lugubrious than usual at the gathering of the football fraternity yesterday, it was quite understandable. Fordham, Columbia, Giants and Yankees had been beaten over the week-end, the last two quite unexpectedly.

Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India ended his twenty-eight-day visit to this country yesterday with words of gratitude to the American people, who, he said, had made him feel "richer than when I came here."

Pumpkin pie has been a favorite autumn dessert with Americans since the days of the Pilgrims. There have ever been poems written about it such as the one in which John Greenleaf Whittier asks, "What brings back the past like a rich pumpkin pie ?"

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 7 -- Chief interest in Virginia's state - wide election tomorrow centers in a proposed constitutional amendment, up for ratification by the voters, that would abolish the poll tax.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A heavy blow was dealt John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers today when the Suprme Court refused, 5 to 3, to review their appeal of a $1,420,000 fine for contempt of a Federal court by ignoring its order to end a 1948 coal strike.

WARSAW, Nov. 7 -- Soviet Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky became Polish Minister of Defense and Marshal of the Polish Armies today and promised to strengthen Polish defenses. Marshal Rokossovsky issued his first order of the day as chief of "our army." The Polish Government prepared to ask Parliament for an amendment to the Constitution that would allow him to take a place on the State Council.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 7 -- Twenty-five hundred surgeons from this country and abroad arrived here tonight for the opening of the fourteenth annual assembly and convocation of the United States Chapter of the International College of Surgeons tomorrow.

In 1899, as Dr. William T. Hornaday described the situation, the site of what we now call the Bronx Zoo was "an unbroken wilderness, to the eye almost as wild as the heart of the Adirondacks." Some of this wilderness has been deliberately retained. The 2,600 mammals, birds and reptiles that inhabit the Zoo are not tame in the sense that domestic cats and dogs or people who ride in subways are.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Western Europe is in no danger of falling into the Soviet orbit, but "enduring recovery" for the area depends on its integration into a angle economic unit without important restrictions or other trade and payments barriers, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, said today.
Regardless of the outcome of today's election, Senator and Mrs. John Foster Dulles plan to leave here tonight to relax and lead the simple life at their thousand-acre island retreat in Lake Ontario.

Pre-trial testimony to determine the legality of the arrest last March of Judith Coplon, subsequently convicted as a spy, was ordered yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy to be heard in Federal Court tomorrow.

The State Bank of the Soviet Union has adjusted the official exchange rate of the ruble to take account of the recent devaluation of the British pound and the currencies of other countries, while maintaining the former ruble-United States dollar exchange rate stable, the Nov. 1 issue of Izvestia reveals.
Socialist party candidates for municipal offices ended their campaign yesterday at a rally in Brooklyn College's Boylan Hall.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The coming conversations of the Western powers' Big Three Foreign Ministers overshadowed today the other international talks here and, in fact, blocked all decisions and threw other European negotiations into confusion.

Secretary of State Acheson is flying to Paris to confer with the Foreign Ministers of France and Britain on ways and means of speeding the unification of Western Europe. The urgent need for increased effort in that direction is emphasized anew, on the one hand, by fresh Soviet blasts against the Western World and, on the other, by the continued division and bickering among the Western European nations in political, economic and military affairs.

The New York Bulldogs, having upset the Giants on Sunday, emerged from that contest in excellent physical shape and will launch preparations today for next Sunday's Polo Grounds game with the Chicago Cardinals. Assistant Coach Ray Nolting praised the passing of Bobby Layne and spoke about the steadily improving Bulldogs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Slammin' Sammy Snead, who barely missed scoring a grand title slam, was selected the golfer of the year in a nation-wide poll conducted by the Professional Golfers' Association of America.

The Rev. Dr. John H. Johnson, pastor of St. Martin's Protestant Episcopal Church, Lenox Avenue and 122d Street, said yesterday that he expected that a carillon of forty-three bells, purchased from a Dutch concern for $30,000, would be installed in the Harlem church and made ready for use by Christmas.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 7 -- While dining with his wife and a number of guests last night Col. W. F. Stirling, Damascus correspondent of the Times, London, was shot three times by three men dressed as Syrian tribesmen. He was taken to the hospital in a critical condition but was operated on successfully.

R. R. Postel has been appointed Detroit representative of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Postel had been a senior account executive on the bureau's national sales staff for the last five years.

Senator John Foster Dulles declared last night that the preservation of individual liberty was the principal issue between himself and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in the nation's only contest today for a seat in the United States Senate.

We have just returned from a waterfowl check along the Connecticut shore of the Sound, from Branford to Saybrook, and although we have seen ducks on the great Canadian breeding grounds we have never seen as many waterfowl in the air at the same time as we saw off East River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that the Standard Oil Company said bars it from selling gasoline to Detroit jobbers at prices lower than those set for sales to retail service station operators there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Country-wide highway construction by contracts as a protection against political manipulation of motor fuel taxation and other public funds was urged today at the opening session here of the fall conference of the American Road Builders Association.

Now that a sponsor has been acquired, the Columbia Broadcasting System is going ahead with plans for the television premiere of Ken Murray's "Blackouts," which will be presented every other Saturday evening, the starting date still to be determined.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Allegations of racial discrimination played a large part in the deliberations of the Supreme Court as it announced today its first opinions of the new term.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Two chemical weapons against hardening of the arteries were announced at the meeting here today of the American Society for the Study of Arteriosclerosis.

WARSAW, Nov. 8 -- Poland's Sejm (Parliament) today unanimously accepted Soviet Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky as the Polish Government's Minister of Defense. It also passed unanimously a bill amending the Constitution to provide a position on the Council of State for former Marshal Michal Rola-Zymierski, former Defense Minister.

Air freight garment shipments in and out of New York are holding their own despite the drop in manufacturing volume, according to New York shippers. Women's and children's apparel, they said, has become the most important category of air freight deliveries on west-bound trips, constituting 55 per cent of total poundage.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India began a series of informal private talks with British leaders here today. He arrived in London on his way home from a good-will tour of the United States in President Truman's personal plane, the Independence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Five times more parking space is required in New York than is now available, according to data presented today at the closing session of the fall conference of the American Road Builders Association here. Conservative estimates showed that parking allotments should be increased by at least 25,000 to make any appreciable reduction in congestion caused by idle cars in the five boroughs.
MONTREAL, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Sid Abel, captain and center of the Detroit Red Wings, has taken command in the National Hockey League's individual scoring parade, official statistics revealed today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Samuel Meryn, the clerk in the United States Embassy who was imprisoned for nearly three weeks on a charge of heading a spy ring, was released by the Government today. He left Czechoslovakia at once.

After one of the bitterest mayorality campaigns in the history of Paterson, N. J., Michael U. DeVita, Democrat, was re-elected yesterday. Unofficial figures on the voting in all 101 districts gave him 31,495 against 16,882 for his Republican opponent, William A. Marrocco.

John Sloan, the painter whose fame in large part rests on the pictures he produced in Chelsea and Greenwich Village, is having an exhibition at the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House, where, a third of a century ago, the artist had his first one-man show.

HONG KONG, Nov. 8 -- The arrest of Angus Ward, United States Consul-General at Mukden, and his four consulate colleagues is believed to have been inspired by the Russians as a further deterrent to United States and British recognition of the Chinese Communist regime in Peiping.

A Lockheed P2V Neptune, equipped with sixteen-foot aluminum skis fitted over its standard tricycle landing gear, which will be used by the Navy in Arctic rescue operations, has been successfully test flown at the aircraft-manufacturing company's Burbank, Calif., plant, it was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Nov. 8 -- Permanent disarmament under the new constitution is Japan's best guarantee of national security in the atomic age, Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Japanese Diet today. This will be true, the Conservative leader implied, even after the conclusion of a peace treaty ending the United States occupation that for the last four years has assured the protection of Japan.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 8 -- Supporters of a proposal to call a limited constitutional convention to revise this state's 79-year-old constitution took a narrow lead in statewide balloting tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation denied today a request by Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat, of Arkansas that it delay final action on $44,000,000 of proposed loans to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, automobile manufacturer of Willow Run, Mich.
LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -American-born Viscountess Astor declared war today on the "naked glamour girls of Hollywood."
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- Summonses for jury duty in the perjury and conspiracy case against Harry R. Bridges and two co-defendants went out today to 125 residents of this district.

Mayor O'Dwyer has been returned to office in an election that marks a city-wide Democratic victory over the competing forces of Fusion and American Labor. Fusion, represented in this case by a union of Republicans and Liberals under the leadership of Newbold Morris, improved substantially upon its showing of four years ago and did well enough to re-establish itself as a power to be reckoned with in future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A story of how plans for a British battleship were intercepted and copied by Soviet military agents in this country in 1928 was entered into the records of the House Committee on Un-American Activities today as it pursued its investigation of communist espionage.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 8 -An official spokesman for the West German Federal Republic announced today that his Government hoped for an end to the technical state of war still existing between Germany and the Western European countries as a result of the conference of the three Western Foreign Ministers in Paris.

The Democratic sweep spearheaded by the election of Herbert H. Lehman to the United States Senate enabled the party to oust Republican Mayors in at least eight-up-state cities formerly under Republican control.
It appeared yesterday that the end of the forty-day-old national steel strike was not far off as the workers of two major producers returned to their jobs following union-company agreements.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Nov. 8 -- The Benelux countries have formally asked the United States, Britain and France to be included in the conference on Germany opening in Paris tomorrow, at least during the discussion of problems involving the interests of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

Principally due to high labor costs, it is difficult to foresee at this time any decline in prices, but they will not skyrocket because of consumer resistance, it was declared last night by John Block, president of Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. He spoke at the company's ready-to-wear fashion and merchandising clinic in the Barbizon Plaza Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Government's final mediation efforts to end the strike of soft-coal miners will begin at 11 A. M., Thursday. The strike of nearly 400,000 miners started on September 19.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 8 -Costa Ricans are looking forward to four years of peace and progress under the leadership of President Otilio Ulate, who took oath of office here today before an enthusiastic throng in the national stadium.

Only a limited number of minor disorders and misunderstandings were reported at polling places over the city yesterday as New Yorkers recorded a heavy vote. A large force of police in uniform and plain clothes guarded the polls, and 800 assistant attorneys general were on duty to handle charges of fraud and other difficulties connected with voting.
DETROIT, Wednesday, Nov. 9 -- Albert E. Cobo, City Treasurer, was elected Mayor of Detroit in yesterday's election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Officials of the Civil Aeronautics Board took a formal statement today from Capt. Erick Rios Bridoux, the Bolivian pilot whose P-38 fighter plane collided with an Eastern Air Lines DC-4 passenger plane over National Airport here on Nov. 1, with the loss of fifty-five lives. The statement will be introduced into the public hearing on the accident, which will start tomorrow.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 8 -- A city council again consisting of five Charterites and four organization Republicans was expected generally here as the week-long task of counting proportional representation ballots got under way tonight. Board of elections officials estimated that today's votes would total about 150,000.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- The French National Assembly, to which Foreign Minister Robert Schuman has made a promise to submit any new accords on the German question, has assumed a skeptical attitude toward the three-power. Foreign Ministers' conference that will open in Paris tomorrow.

Record inquiries and sales yesterday marked the thirty-fourth National Hotel Exposition at Grand Central Palace, its second day of a five-day stand which ends Friday night. Admissions topped 20,000 for a two-day total of over 35,000.
