WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr., the Naval air officer whose critical remarks and release to reporters of confidential Navy documents helped force into the open the high-level feuding among the armed services, was reprimanded and restored to duty today.
Vito Marcantonio, American Labor Party candidate for Mayor, issued the following statement early today after the complete city election results were in:
DETROIT, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, began discussing pensions today with the General Motors Corporation.

Senator-elect Herbert H. Lehman and Mayor O'Dwyer issued statements shortly before 11 o'clock last night thanking the voters and pledging their continued efforts for the welfare of the people of the city, state and nation.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- An appeal to leaders of all political parties to unite in telling the British people the grim facts of the nation's economic situation that is threatening the island with bankruptcy and ruin was made today by Dr. Cyril Garbett, Archbishop of York and the second highest dignitary in the Church of England.

If you are failing in your job you had better check your personality rather than your ability. This is what the Board of Education believes -- and from now on, the city's junior high schools will try to adjust pupils who lack the charm that conquers.

Robert F. Wagner Jr. has won election as Borough President of Manhattan, a result which was pretty generally foreseen. We congratulate him and have no doubt that he will be a conscientious Borough President and a faithful member of the Board of Estimate.

Manhattan College's cross country team achieved that dream of all politicians, a clean sweep, in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association's twenty-third annual championship run at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday.
Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan appealed yesterday to the nation's farmers for help in solving the increasingly serious food-surplus problem.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 8 (AP) -- George Harkins, Princeton's defensive right end, will not be there when the Tigers meet Yale. The 197-pound senior from Danville, Ky., was injured in the Harvard game last week and will be out of the line-up for a while, Coach Charlie Caldwell said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The twenty-member Educational Policies Commissiion of the National Education Association and the American Association of School Administrators today issued seven recommendations to meet an indicated "basic change in the nation's birthrate" that will mean a continuing "flood of school children."
RICHMOND, Va., Wednesday, Nov. 9 -- Returns early today in the Virginia election recorded a crushing defeat for the proposal to abolish the poll tax.

A man, his wife and their 15-month-old daughter who have been living in subways, railroad terminals and on park benches for more than four weeks were found yesterday morning in Grand Central Terminal and taken to a hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Dr. Philip M. Stimson, Associate Professor of Clinical Pediatrics at Cornell University, advocated today that treatment for poliomyelitis be "centered in a few hospitals where they have the know-how."

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 (UP) -- R. R. McLarnin's New Oxford, a colt who had won his previous race by three and one-half lengths, came right back with another fine performance to account for the King Heather Purse at Pimlico today.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- J. B. Priestley, British author and playwright, said here tonight that the London theatre was bad, was getting worse, and in his opinion should go bankrupt so that it could start again.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 8 -- The Soviet Union introduced today a resolution under which the General Assembly would direct the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission to resume its work and proceed immediately to the drafting of conventions for the prohibition of atomic weapons and the control of atomic energy, both to be concluded and put into effect simultaneously.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8 -- Catholic leaders were urged to seek a better balance between Roman Catholic urban and farm populations by directors of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference here today. In a resolution, the directors said:

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Dr. James E. M. Thomson of Lincoln, Neb., urged his fellow surgeons today to become thoroughly versed in use of the Kuntscher nail in treatments of fractures. He termed the method "perhaps the foremost contribution of German medicine resulting from World War II."

The Mauretania of the Cunard White Star Line arrived at Pier 90, West Fiftieth Street, at 6 P. M. yesterday from Southampton with 1,088 passengers. Among those on board was Sir Leslie Rowan, who has been appointed Economic Minister at the British Embassy in Washington, to carry out the arrangements for the continuing consultations agreed on at the recent monetary talks among Britain, Canada and the United States.
DETROIT, Nov. 8 -- A Federal judge ruled today that a wife might testify against her husband.

GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- The State Department has advised a number of European Governments that it will welcome ratification of the charter of the International Trade Organization by some European signatory states prior to debate on the charter in the United States Congress, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -Richard C. Patterson, United States Ambassador to Guatemala, submitted to President Truman today recommendations for the rehabilitation of that country after the havoc caused by the worst rains in its history.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- On the eve of the conference of the three Western foreign ministers, which will begin in Paris tomorrow, the Bonn Government has proposed a compromise on the dismantling of German factories that has favorably impressed the French Government, it was learned tonight.

Led by President Truman, Democratic spokesmen hailed sweeping party victories yesterday in New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco and a dozen other centers as portents of Fair Deal success in the 1950 Congressional elections.

PARSONS, Kan., Nov. 8 -- Senator Clyde M. Reed, Republican, of Kansas, died tonight in a fall downstairs at his home, He was 78 years old. The Senator had returned from a hospital only last week after an attack of influenza.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- John B. Hynes, a municipal career man who rose from clerk in the Health Department to Permanent City Clerk, ended tonight the dynasty of Mayor James Michael Curley, 74-year-old Boston political boss who was seeking his fifth term.

Had he not, in his teens, bought a six-penny second-hand dictionary John R. Clynes might never have earned the unofficial title of "intellectual lamplighter of British labor," or become a Minister in Britain's first two Labor governments, in the middle and late Nineteen Twenties.

Top representatives of Pye, Ltd., one of the largest British manufacturers of television transmitter equipment, yesterday arrived in New York to solicit orders from American broadcasters. The company's invasion of the American market is the first attempt by television transmitting equipment producers in Britain to export to the United States, according to B. J. Edwards, technical director.

VIENNA, Nov. 8 -- Announcement by the Economic Cooperation Administration in Washington that Austria would be required to return $926,858 overexpended on steel and tallow bought with Marshall Plan funds has been noticeably played down by the Government press here.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- John' L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, probably will leave here tomorrow for conferences on the soft-coal strike with Cyrus S. Ching, Federal mediation chief, in Washington. At the latest he is expected to leave Thursday.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 8 -- The entire Suffolk County Republican ticket was elected, according to election returns just before midnight tonight. Only one election district was missing out of 208.

With a change in rules of the new International Union of Advertising, the way has been cleared for affiliation by the Advertising Federation of America, it was disclosed yesterday by Elon G. Borton, AFA president.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 8 -- The Western Governors Conference went on record today in favor of "broad extension" of Social Security and liberalization of benefits under a contributory plan. It declared such a program to be "much preferable" to the present old age assistance afforded only after persons became destitute.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 -- Emergency measures adopted to cope with the widespread devaluation of national currencies in September were up for review when the ten-day conference of the International Air Transport Association opened here today.

The employment clause in the contract now before Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators would not necessarily mean rotary hiring of deck officers since it contains a seniority clause that would protect men now on the available list of any company, it was said yesterday by Capt. Charles F. May, president of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 8 -- Ohio voters eliminated today straight ticket voting under party emblems by approving the Massachusetts or office-type ballot. An amendment to the constitution was approved.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 8 -- Yugoslavia charged today that the Soviet Union was using 6,000 former "White Guard" Russian refugees in her country to give a "mass base" to the "other, more efficient methods" by which it is seeking to overthrow the Tito regime.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Charlie (Choo Choo) Justice, North Carolina's All-America tail-back, was off his crutches today, but still standing on the sideline as the Tarheels worked long and hard in preparation for Saturday's game in New York's Yankee Stadium with powerful Notre Dame.
BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- Brig. Gen. James McManmon resigned today as Commissioner of State Airports, saying he wanted to devote his time to personal affairs.

Men, who are the chief holiday gift buyers of perfume and fragrance products, will be encouraged by many stores this year to exercise their own personal tastes in selecting purchases, it was disclosed yesterday by the Fragrance Foundation.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 8 (AP) -- A record shattering $208,000 was paid for 163 harness horses today at the opening of the eleventh annual standard-bred sale. The total was some $50,700 better than the first day's sale a year ago when over-all sales soared to an all-time harness horse record of about $1,025,000.
MEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 8 -- Representative John F. Kennedy, Democrat, of Massachusetts, watched a Medford High School football practice yesterday and decided he would work out a little.

With the mushroom season, which lasts through May, now well under way the outlook is for a record crop. Every night truckloads of this palatable fungus are coming into the Washington Street and Newark produce markets as well as direct to retail markets. They are around 49 cents a pound, a decrease of 51 cents over the off-season high.

The Otis Elevator Company announced yesterday that net income for the nine months to Sept. 30 was $8,655,178, equal to $4.18 a common share, compared with $9,326,979, or $4.52 a share, in the 1948 period.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The United States has selected and assigned a team of civilian diplomats to supervise the operation of the Military Arms Program in Europe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- John F. Shelley, a Democrat, was elected to Congress today in California's Fifth District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Representative Richard J. Welch, a Republican, incomplete returns indicated late tonight.

The final performance of the National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden brought out a large and distinguished gathering, many of the hosts entertaining at dinner in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria in advance of the show.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, issued at 9:40 o'clock last night a victory statement in which he hailed the election of Herbert H. Lehman to the Senate as "an unmistakable mandate of the people of New York State for the continuance of President Truman's Fair Deal program."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Truman, jubilant tonight over Democratic victories in New York State and elsewhere, asserted that the elections would increase the already "tremendous responsibilities" thrust on the Democratic party by his own election last year.

With the end of the nation-wide strike in steel now apparently in sight, the strike of John L. Lewis' coal miners takes on a new and increased importance. The seven-week mine shutdown has already produced fuel problems on some of the country's railroads and threats of crises in a number of communities which find themselves faced with prospective shortages of coal for schools, hospitals and homes.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A national survey today showed that more than 108,000 members had bolted the United Electrical Workers in the fight over right-left policies. The union was expelled from the Congress of Industrial Organizations last week as leftists and those deserting intend to go along with the new right-wing union of electrical workers set up by the CIO.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Someone asked Earl Blaik, the Army coach, today if he feared a "letdown" by the Cadets after their 35-0 conquest of Fordham. The question was posed during a discussion of next Saturday's clash With Pennsylvania at Franklin Field, and the mentor, who would like it better if the Fordham fracas was forgotten, replied with a firm "no."

The "outer bankers" from Oregon Inlet to Buxton Light are now feuding with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service over the waterfowl situation on Pea Island, and as usual the service got in the last shot.

Issues of new first-mortgage bonds and common stock of the Central Maine Power Company, valued at more than $7,000,000, will be put on the market today by underwriting syndicates. The securities were bought by the banking groups at competitive sales on Monday. The offerings are as follows:

History of a sort was made yesterday at the Bronx Zoo. Staff members there recorded their voices on a tape to be deposited in the cornerstone of the new Great Apes building. The occasion was the fiftieth anniversary of the zoo.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt made a clean-up in the $56,925 Demoiselle Stakes before 33,168 witnesses at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday. His Bed O' Roses, champion 2-year-old filly, took first money of $38,800 and his Next Move, daughter of the 1939 winner of the stake, waltzed off with the runner-up award of $10,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- General Motors shares, closing with a gain of 3 3/8 points at 72 5/8, dominated trading today on the Chicago Stock Exchange as a result of the corporation's record earnings and increased dividend.

Lest there still be any doubts about the matter, it can now be authoritatively reported that 65-year-old Burton E. (Barney) Shotton will be back at Ebbets Field next spring directing the Dodgers for another season.

The Democrats won an overwhelming victory in the City Council contests yesterday when they captured twenty-four of the twenty-five seats as the city returned to the district system of electing Councilmen after a twelve-year experiment with proportional representation.

MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 9 -President Elpidio Quirino was leading today on the basis of early returns over Jose P. Laurel in the costliest, most violent national election in Philippine annals. Twenty-four persons, some prominent politically, were killed by gunfire and thirty-two others wounded.

ROME, Oct. 8 -- The growth of Titoism has assumed sufficient proportions in Italy to oblige the directorate of the Communist party to take measures against this form of Communist heresy. The meetings of the directorate were secret, but it is understood that "drastic" steps were taken to eradicate the Titoist "contagion."
With tabulations still incomplete early this morning, available totals indicated the adoption of all eight amendments and three propositions in the state-wide referendum.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A near collision this morning between a B-25 medium bomber and an Eastern Air Lines DC-4 a few miles south of National Airport was reported to tower operators and the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

The men put in power in yesterday's local elections, particularly in the State and City of New York, will have a large influence in the development of foreign as well as domestic policy. This influence is of special importance just now because American policy is at one of those turns in the spiral where the next swing may be up or down.
DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Texans today apparently defeated a move to repeal the poll tax as a requirement for voting.
AURORA, Ill., Nov. 8 -- James Powell, 74 years old; a retired real estate and insurance man, distributed $350,000 today to make his friends happy "while I'm still alive."

In the old days food in hospitals was planned and prepared by ordinary cooks who made up menus with little regard for the medical condition of patients. Today, in the eighty-six voluntary, non-profit hospitals that are members of the United Hospital Fund, trained and competent dietitians work in close harmony with the medical staff and with the hospital administration to provide the proper food for patients and personnel.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Representative Gordon Canfield, Republican, of New Jersey, said today that he would ask the Veterans Administration in Washington to investigate the death of William H. Waters Jr., 21 years old, of this city, who died Sunday in the Bay Pines Veterans Hospital, St. Petersburg, Fla.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Government lawyers prosecuting Preston Tucker and seven others on fraud and conspiracy charges probed today into the financial maneuvering of the ill-starred Tucker auto manufacturing enterprise. Ringing in the ears of the prosecutors was a stern admonition from Federal Judge Walter J. Labuy to "get down to the meat of the case" and start proving the conspiracy charge.

SEATTLE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A conduit tunnel cave-in today trapped two workmen sixty feet below the surface of the University of Washington campus. Slipping sand in the vertical shaft from which the tunnel branched blocked rescue efforts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A cotton crop of 15,524,000 bales -- the largest since 1937 and the seventh largest of record -- was forecast by the Department of Agriculture today in its next-to-the-last production report of this year.
A single set of record-keeping requirements for New York liquor stores will be sought by the State Liquor Authority, John F. O'Connell, chairman, disclosed yesterday.

GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- The Egyptian Government is effectively preventing ships under charter to the International Refugee Organization from passing through the Suez Canal if they carry Jewish passengers, it is learned here.

The New York Rangers will oppose the Canadiens of Montreal in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The battle will be the first of a four-game home stand for the Blue Shirts.

Premier Stalin is not one to say, like Louis XV, "After us, the deluge." The discussion of his possible successor by Lieut. Gen. Bedell Smith in today's installment of his memoirs makes grim reading, but it agrees with the verdict of most of the experts. Stalin will go, but totalitarian communism will stay.

Although there are city ordinances against noise, nothing has been done to silence the motors of airplanes. I live in a residential neighborhood where the houses are two or three stories high and apartment houses do not exceed four stories. The planes fly so low even in very clear weather that they sometimes almost touch the rooftops.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Delegates of fifteen maritime countries, including the United States, met here today for the opening of the second conference of the International Chamber of Shipping since the war. Colin Anderson, president of the British Chamber of Shipping, was elected conference chairman.
PARIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The French, British and Italian Defense Ministers today agreed on Paris for headquarters of the Southern Europe-Western Mediterranean regional group under the Atlantic Pact.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Sales and gross receipts taxes provided more than half of all state revenue in fiscal 1949, a survey by the Bureau of the Census showed today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 8 (UP) -- Edward Black, Republican county chairman, said tonight that unofficial returns indicated that Charles Farnsley, Democrat, had been re-elected Mayor of Louisville over Rees H. Dickson, Republican.

HONG KONG, Nov. 8 -- A second British merchant ship was intercepted and held off Shanghai today by a Nationalist warship, it was revealed by British Navy headquarters here. The ship, the Wosang, of Jardine, Matheson Co., Ltd., was attempting to leave Shanghai, after having sailed through the blockade into the port a week ago accompanied to the limits of Chinese territorial waters by a British warship.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 8 -- Republican incumbents on the Nassau County ticket were returned to office tonight by a 2-to-1 margin. The Republican candidate for the post of United States Senator, John Foster Dulles, also marked up a similar victory in the county.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 -- Eight left-wing members of Local 601, United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers, were arrested today in a melee growing out of the leftists' forcible seizure last night of the union meeting hall.
TOKYO, Oct. 8 -- A virtually complete defeat for the right - wing "company union" elements in the General Federation of Labor's election became known today.

Officers of the Mexican Army team won the International Military Challenge Trophy for the fourth straight year in Madison Square Garden last night as the curtain rolled down on the sixty-first National Horse Show. It was the fourth and most important team victory for the riders of the republic who also took six individual events during the eight-day exhibition.

Dissatisfied with the performance of Fordham's offensive platoon against Army, Coach Ed Danowski yesterday demoted three starters to reserve status and announced a practice schedule for Saturday's contest with Boston College that will include contact work for the offensive players only.

Virginia's poll tax of $1.50 a year, assessable against the voter for each of the three years preceding the election year, went before the voters in Tuesday's election. The series of amendments that would have repealed the poll tax written into the state's Constitution nearly a half-century ago were overwhelmingly defeated.

Mayor O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for re-election, was swept back into office in yesterday's New York City election by a landslide. He defeated Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion opponent, by a plurality of 308,430.
Thin crowds in Times Square ast night confirmed the death of a tradition and verified the passing of curious American types who had created it.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A subsurface policy struggle in the American Petroleum Institute neared a settlement deadline today, with the election of a new president scheduled for tomorrow.

William C. Bruton has been appointed district sales manager for American Manganese Steel division of the American Brake Shoe Company. Robert H. Elem has been named Pacific Coast manager of the welding products department.

The retail merchandising and advertising manual issued monthly by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association has been streamlined and redesigned to aid planning of more effective retail newspaper promotion in 1950, it was announced yesterday by John Giesen, director of the bureau's retail division.

Herbert H. Lehman, four-time Governor of New York, was elected to the United States Senate yesterday by an indicated margin of 200,000 votes over John Foster Dulles, the Republican incumbent, serving by appointment of Governor Dewey.

LLOYD MORRIS, a man of formidable intelligence, cosmopolitan culture and much literary charm, has been preoccupied in recent years with an examination of the social transformation which has taken place in these United States during the last fifty years. Anyone over 70 has seen a world changed drastically both materially and culturally.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Request for charters in the new International Union of Electrical Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, have been received from forty locals comprising 100,000 members, according to Albin Hartnett, assistant to James B. Carey, chairman of the IEU-CIO's administrative committee, Mr. Hartnett said that the locals included Local 801, with 12,000 members, at the General Electric plant in Dayton, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt took issue with the American Bar Association today for having denounced the proposed United Nations human rights declaration as "a Communist document."

Unleashing a devastating ground attack in the final period for three touchdowns, Erasmus Hall High School's eleven came from behind to conquer Manual Training, 31 -20, in the annual schoolboy classic at Ebbets Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Railroads serving North Atlantic ports will be permitted to continue to publish tariffs calling for the "actual cost" of bracing freight cars, instead of naming a precise figure, if the Interstate Commerce Commission accepts recommendations made to it by one of its examiners, Harold M. Brown.

OTTAWA, Nov. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's growing manufacturing industries had their biggest year in history in 1948. They turned out products with a gross value of $11,800,887,000 -- nearly $950 for every man, woman and child in the country.

Leading the Democratic sweep in judicial and prosecuting offices on his fifty-seventh birthday, Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel, Democrat and Liberal, had an indicated majority last night for a seat on the Court of Appeals of about 480,000 over his Republican opponent, Judge Bruce Bromley.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Grains rallied on the Board of Trade today and closed with a firm tone after early irregularity. Wheat was weak in near-by deliveries at the start but buying, attributed to mills against sales of flour to eastern bakeries, developed some strength.

In a conventional telegram to former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic opponent in the Senatorial contest, John Foster Dulles, the Republican incumbent, conceded defeat at 10:45 o'clock last night.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The International Labor Organization has completed its investigation of working conditions on ships flying the Panama flag.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Westchester County gave Republican pluralities today to Senator John Foster Dulles and Judge Bruce Brromley in the state-wide election, returned to office a Republican county administration and elected a new Republican-controlled Board of Supervisors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission said today it will fix rules "before the first of the year" for distribution in cold weather of available natural gas supplies among customers of the Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company.

Maurice A. FitzGerald's succession to the Borough Presidency of Queens keeps unbroken the Democratic line re-established when his former colleague in the Assembly, James A. Burke, defeated George U. Harvey in 1941.

Pursers employed by American Export Lines, world-wide shipping operators, have voted for the Brotherhood of Marine Officers, Local 13,212, District 50, United Mine Workers of America, as the bargaining agent with the company.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 8 -- The mushroom growth of the so-called "rural non-farm" population in this country is confronting American Protestantism with one of its major evangelistic problems.
Prices of futures yesterday declined 1 to 6 points, with only a moderate volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- This country appears to be on the threshold of "a decade of opportunity," Harold L. Bache, managing partner of Bache Co., New York, said today at a luncheon celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of the firm's Chicago office.

Continued research in physical medicine and rehabilitation can help make "this precarious age of physics the greatest of all ages" by guiding the physical sciences away from destructive and toward constructive applications, Dr. Frank H. Krusen, head of the Physical Medicine Section of the Mayo Clinic, said yesterday.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Nov. 8 -- Democratic candidates were swept into office tonight in the first party-system election since the proportional representation plan was put into effect here four years ago.

Whatever the over-all results of the repeal of Proportional Representation voted in 1947, and we hope they are also good, the change in method of electing our City Council has put the Communist Benjamin J. Davis Jr. out of office. A coalition of Democrats, Republicans and Liberals defeated Mr. Davis, and its representative was Earl Brown, Negro reporter on Life Magazine.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Selling pressure brought a further relapse in prices of British Government securities in the Stock Markets here today with 4 per cent Consols below par for the first time. They lost 3/4 point and closed at 99 3/4.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey was re-elected yesterday, becoming the first Governor to succeed himself in that state since 1844. He defeated State Senator Elmer H. Wene, wealthy chick raiser of Vineland, who had been picked as the party candidate by former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., Nov. S (UP) -- Two players instigated all of the roughhouse in the Army-Fordham football game Saturday and there was no trouble after they were ejected, Referee George Forbes said tonight.

Fifty-five years ago a wide-eyed boy of 11, filled with the adventure tales of a seagoing father, ran away from his Rockland County home convinced that he could be happy only in the rolling forecastle of an ocean-plying merchantman.
De Witt Clinton's football team kept its P. S. A. L. record intact with a 26-14 triumph over Stuyvesant before 6,000 at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
The football Giants not only lost a game last Sunday but apparently lost Joe Scott, one of their fine backs, in the upset at the hands of the New York Bulldogs at the Polo Grounds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8 -- The film rights to "Night Cry," a 1948 novel by William L. Stewart with a New York background, have been bought by Twentieth Century-Fox and the picture will be produced and directed by Otto Preminger as his next assignment instead of "Transit Hong Kong," previously announced.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey was re-elected yesterday, becoming the first Governor to succeed himself in that state since 1844. He defeated State Senator Elmer H. Wene, wealthy chick raiser of Vineland, who had been picked as the party candidate by former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.
OBERAMMERGAU, Germany, Nov. 8 -- The village elders today rejected 58-year-old Alois Lang for the role of Christ in the 1950 Passion Play. He had played the part in previous performances.
De Witt Clinton's football team kept its P. S. A. L. record intact with a 26-14 triumph over Stuyvesant before 6,000 at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8 -- In the closest municipal election here in modern history, Mayor William C. Celentano, Republican, was elected to his third straight two-year term with an unofficial margin of 702 votes over his Democratic opponent, Richard C. Lee.

In cooperation with the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, WNBC will present for the second successive year a documentary drama series entitled "Everyman's Story" on Tuesdays from 7:30 to 8 P. M., beginning next week.

WARSAW, Nov. 8 -- There are no plans for the establishment in Poland of a national church divorced from the Vatican's spiritual leadership, the Government-controlled Roman Catholic organ Dzis i Jutro Today and Tomorrow said today. The weekly flatly reassured its readers that "it is not necessary to anyone for political reasons, and no one intends to create such a church for such reasons."

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 8 -- Three committees of the United Nations General Assembly approved unanimously today steps designed to curb the topsy-like growth of activities, projects and programs of the United Nations and the specialized agencies and to concentrate personnel and funds on the more urgent undertakings.

" Rigoletto," the Italian-made picturization of the Verdi opera, which opens at the Ambassador, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Tito Gobbi heads the cast in the title role, with Mario Filippeschi and Giulio Neri among the featured players.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- An alert Democratic organization, backed for the first time by the city's two leading newspapers, today smashed the entrenched Republican machine's hold on all major city hall offices.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 8 -- Due to be released Tuesday from the State Prison at Attica, N. Y., where he was sent in 1928 for a twenty-five-year term for assault and robbery, Arthur Barry, who robbed the homes of the late Jesse Livermore and other wealthy persons on Long Island and in Westchester County in the late Twenties, will be rearrested immediately.

Scoring the first two times it gained possession of the ball, Fordham University's freshman football team rolled to a 27-6 triumph over New York University's yearlings yesterday to the delight of a crowd of 3,500 at Fordham Field.

Mrs. Edna F. Kelly, Democrat, became the first woman member of Congress from Brooklyn with a clear-cut victory yesterday in the Tenth Congressional District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Representative Andrew L. Somers.
PORTSMOUTH, England, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The United States Cruiser Columbus ran up the British Royal Standard today and put on a three hour show of Navy pomp and hospitality for King George VI.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The State Department declared today that the appointment of Soviet Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky as the military chief of Poland put that country "openly and more securely" under Russian control.
The week beginning next Sunday will mark the thirty-first annual observance of Book Week under the slogan "Make Friends With Books."

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 8 (UP) -Armed forces throughout Colombia were placed on a "state of alert" today as weeks of political clashes appeared to be nearing their peak. Army units were stationed in the capital's public buildings with orders to put down any "subversive" attempt.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- An insurgent group of members of the New York Stock Exchange fired today a Blast at Emil Schram, the Exchange's $100,000-a-year president, who last week rejected the group's proposals for changing certain Exchange rules.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The United Artist Corporation and World Screen Plays, Ltd., announced today the signing of a contract for the latter to produce seven feature pictures in England during the next two and one half to three years.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- A crusade against dirty food in which housewives have been called upon to play a major role was started in Britain this week following a Government lead intended to combat unhygienic practices that yearly result in many food poisoning casualties.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Representative Lawrence H. Smith, Republican, of Wisconsin, predicted today that the Administration will recognize Communist China before Jan. 1.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Nov. 8 -- The Democrats won five out of six posts in the election contests here today. The one Republican victory was for the office of Commissioner of Finance.

I am a displaced person from the Soviet Union. For three months I have been working on a farm in Pennsylvania as a manual worker. I would like to inform your readers how different the life in the United States is from that in the Soviet Union.

Election Day furniture sales in department and home furnishings stores will run approximately 5 per cent ahead of the like day last year, buyers reported yesterday. They emphasized that the 5 per cent figure is an estimate and some greater gains may be experienced when comparisons undergo final checks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- An increased trend toward automobiles with reduced exterior dimensions without sacrificing interior space was forecast today by Benson Ford, vice president and general manager, Lincoln-Mercury division, Ford Motor Company.

Sweeping changes in both the Republican and Democratic parties in New Jersey are expected as a result of the election Tuesday that returned Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to the State House in Trenton by a plurality of 80,070 over State Senator Elmer H. Wene, the protege of former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -Whether the American people choose to maintain the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will constitute a test case on this country's attitude to the "welfare state," Basil O'Connor, president, tonight told the foundation's State Advisers on Women's Activities.
Your excellent editorial "Greece's Kidnapped Children" was both timely and necessary.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 9 -- The Connecticut Legislature was called back to its third special session today by Gov. Chester Bowles and resumed its argument about how the state should help towns and cities get new schools.

Canada may have to restrict her trade with the United States, Lester Bowles Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Overseas Press Club in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A two - million - volt X - ray machine soon will be available for cancer therapy, Dr. Milton Friedman said today.

Due to lower prices and an expanded educational program, wines are entering a period of expanding consumer acceptance, Marcel Bramerel, head of the wine department of Bellows Co., declared yesterday at the first seasonal offerings of imported French wines in the Plaza Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- Presidents of eight Lutheran seminaries and colleges outlined today the financial needs of their institutions at a conference of 550 pastors and laymen from ten Eastern states.

The New York musical picture was extended last night when Times Hall was opened for its first musical event of the season. It was a program given by Fritz Magg, 'cellist, and his wife, Natasha, a pianist, who made their New York debut as a sonata team.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A Government committee to select' a bust of the late James Forrestal as a memorial tribute to the first Secretary of Defense withdrew from the field of sculpture today and decided to name a subcommittee of experts to do the choosing.

The nation's railroads, fearful that the truce in the coal strike would not give them enough time to replenish their coal reserves, took no immediate steps yesterday to cancel the 25 per cent cut in steam passenger service that went into effect three weeks ago.

Members of a junior committee under the chairmanship of Miss Mary Jane Lansburgh have been meeting frequently in assisting with final plans for the benefit New York premiere presentation of the new David O. Selznick film production, "The Fallen Idol," on Monday evening at the Sutton Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture took initial steps today toward possible imposition of rigid production controls on next year's rice crop. It invited interested persons to submit views by Nov. 26 on the question of marketing quotas for the crop.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 9 (AP) -P. A. Janhonen of Finland, rather than Arthur Cook of Washington, D.C., may be declared the official winner of the individual world championship gold medal in the small-bore rifle shooting competition in three positions.
R. T. Copodanno has been named director of engineering of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation. He formerly was with Philco Corporation.

On his own initiative, twenty-four hours before representatives of the operators and the unions were scheduled to resume discussions in Washington, John L. Lewis has declared an armistice in the fifty-two-day-old coal strike. Mr. Lewis describes this move as "an act of good faith, designed to contribute to public convenience."

The building containing sixty-three apartments and occupying a plot 100 by 150 feet at 286 Fort Washington Avenue, corner of West 172d Street, was sold by the Br. Pollack Realty, Inc., to an investing client of the Globus Realty Corporation, broker in the deal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 2:

Peter Glenville, the British director who staged Maurice Evans' current presentation, "The Browning Version," it is now definitely known, will perform a similar chore for "The Innocents," Willian Archibald's dramatization of the Henry James novel, "The Turn of the Screw."

Advertising in the eight major New York City newspapers during the first ten months of 1949 totaled 125,254,694 lines, a gain of 2.83 per cent over the comparable period last year. Categories recording gains were: Automotive, up 42.47 per cent; general, 4.32 per cent, and retail, 3.31 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- While President Truman and the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, William M. Boyle Jr., at the White House this afternoon were gleefully reviewing the voting choices of Nov. 8, a mysterious stranger might have been seen entering the headquarters of the Republican National Committee in Connecticut Avenue.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 9 -- During the last three months of 1948 and the first six months of 1949, world exports have amounted to $5,000,000,000 a month, according to data released today by the Statistical Office of the United Nations.

NOVELISTS are enormously respectable people. They hold a proper place among the best writers of their day. Anyone who snobbishly doubts that should look into this magnificent plum-pudding of a book, "A Treasury of Great Reporting,"* published in the greatest treasury series ("A Treasury of Art Masterpieces," "A Treasury of the World's Great Poems," "A Treasury of Satire," "A Treasury of Grand Opera") since Alexander Hamilton.

Many civilian exhibitors and all visiting military riders who had taken part in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden were getting ready yesterday to ship their mounts to Toronto for the Royal Winter Fair exhibition that begins next Tuesday.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Vanderbilt is through with night football. Bill Edwards said today that the Commodores will never play another night game as long as he is head coach.

Maurice Richard exploded two shots into the New York Ranger nets at Madison Square Garden last night. And these two shots enabled the Canadiens of Montreal to hold the Blue Shirts to a 2-all tie in their National Hockey League clash, which was witnessed by a crowd of 11,417 fans.

A series of exhibitions to highlight the best of contemporary design in all kinds of home furnishings was announced yesterday by Nelson A. Rockefeller, president of the Museum of Modern Art, and Joseph P. Kennedy, former Ambassador to Great Britain and owner of the Merchandise Mart, Chicago.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 9 -Following is the text of an atomic energy statement by Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the United Nations General Assembly, including his letter to the six permanent members of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission -the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France, China and Canada:

More retailers are specifying parcel post on shipping instructions to cut down costs, it was learned yesterday. For manufacturers of apparel shipping by parcel post has tied up shipping department workers who are required to queue up at branch postoffices.

The American Broadcasting Company's television schedule next week will have its second major curtailment within two weeks when WJZ-TV cancels all programs on Monday and Tuesday with the exception of the Roller Derby at 10 o'clock Monday evening.

With almost 90 per cent of the industry's capacity inoperative as a result of the steel workers' strike, the production of raw steel in October was 916,696 net tons, the lowest volume for any month since July, 1932, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute's monthly statistics, issued yesterday.
BOGOTA, Nov. 9 (UP) -- After President Mariano Ospina Perez had declared a stage of siege in Colombia tonight troops immediately marched into Bogota to maintain order.

During the last week General Mills, Inc., has been telling bakers here about a new method for merchandising rolls. The products are cooked till almost done, then sold to the housewife who browns them about seven minutes in the oven. The advantage?
As a result of Tuesday's election the Democratic party came into even more complete control of government in New York City and its five boroughs than it has had for the last four years.

A slim easy line with detail at the shoulders to minimize the hips is the silhouette story always well told by Dorothy O'Hara. It was stressed effectively yesterday at Arnold Constable in a preview of her spring collection, which will be available in this store around Dec. 1st.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 9 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court stiffened the requirements today for admission to practice law, provided for counsel for impecunious litigants and otherwise revised judicial procedure.

WITH SECOND U. S. TASK FLEET IN NORTH ATLANTIC, Nov. 9 (UP) -- The 1800-ton submarine Tusk, with eighty-eight officers and men aboard, was rammed by a Navy supply ship during a North Atlantic gale 175 miles off the coast of Labrador today but managed to surface and head back for Argentia under destroyer escort.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- Federal agents are investigating an alleged Communist ring that is said to be secretly trying to recruit noncitizen Chinese in this country to rally behind the new Red banner in China, it was revealed today.

The four-story building at 324 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, containing a store and six apartments, has been sold by Louis Schnackenberg to George Kontzamanys. L. L. Yearsley, broker in this transaction, also reported the sale of the three-story dwelling at 619 Third Street for David B. Fleming to David S. Hunter for occupancy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Present inadequate depreciation allowances may cause "the great American industrial machine to shrivel up and die," J. Howard Pew, a director and former president of the Sun Oil Company, declared today at the twenty-ninth annual convention of the American Petroleum Institute.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Currency devaluation abroad and the resumption of Federal deficit financing in the United States have increased the need for a return to the gold standard, James Washington Bell, economist and member of the faculty of Northwestern University, said today.

We regret that the first twenty-five-member City Council elected under the system that replaced Proportional Representation is composed so overwhelmingly of members of one party. Twenty-four Democrats were elected and one Republican-Liberal. The reasons for this are several and not hard to find.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that operations in the first nine months of this year resulted in a deficit of $4,812,598. For the comparable period in 1948 the communications system reported a deficit of $1,406,424, adding that the loss would have been more than $12,000,000 if it were not for a saving of about $7,500,000 from "vigorous expense control measures and mechanization."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The halting of the fifty-two day coal strike came as a complete surprise to the capital today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9 -Herman Hickman was engrossed in a manuscript as the visitor broke in on him at his office in Ray Tompkins House today. With a broad grin, the good-natured Yale coach dropped the papers on his desk.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Business inventories increased in September after having declined steadily for ten consecutive months, the Department of Commerce reported today.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- A resolution calling on all governments to refrain from flag discriminations, such as the requirement that commercial cargoes be carried by vessels of any particular nation, was adopted nearly unanimously here today by the International Chamber of Shipping at its closing meeting.

Plans for a $450,000 drive-in theatre on a site comprising twenty-four acres of land on the new Route S-3 in Rutherford, N. J., were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property by the Mid-West Drive-in Company, of which Philip Smith of Boston is president.

Undoubtedly you have been the recipient of many letters describing the overcrowding in schools. While it may seem annoying to be constantly reminded of the unpleasant situation, it is even more disturbing to us students who are affected by it.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The fundamental difficulty facing the three Western foreign ministers in their Paris discussions remains one of geography. France is a European power, Britain remains an imperial power, and the United States is a transatlantic power.

The suspect in an alleged swindle of $50,000 from Macy's department store over the last two years admitted, it was reported yesterday, that the money had been squandered on an extended splurge devoted to entertainment, women and horse-race betting.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 9 -- Brig. Yaacov Dori, Chief of the General Staff of the Israeli Army and a leader of the Haganah during its most formidable days, retired for reasons of health today. He was succeeded by Col. Yigal Yadin, former chief of operations, who takes the rank of brigadier, Premier David Ben-Gurion announced.

There are 22,000 persons with cerebral palsy in New York State, 92 per cent of whom had symptoms at birth or soon afterward, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, New York State Commissioner of Health.

Paintings, sculpture and prints by war veterans, some of them still hospitalized, went on exhibition yesterday in the Reception Center of the Time-Life Building, 14 West Forty-ninth Street. A special reception, formally opening the exhibit, the American Veterans Society of Artists' eleventh annual, will be held tomorrow.

SOUTHBURY, Conn., Nov. 9--No wild bird purist could call preserve shooting "un-natural" if he hunted the Ballamor Preserve as we did yesterday, following a weimeraner through covers ranging from knee-deep marsh to hill thickets.

VIENNA, Nov. 9 -- The newly elected Austrian Parliament was suspended for twenty minutes today as a result of an interjection by a member of the Nazi-tinged Independent party which brought the People's Party, and Socialist and Communist victims of Nazi persecution, to their feet in an uproar.

Continuing in the third quarter of this year the profitable operations of the preceding three months, Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., overcame a first-quarter deficit of $3,264,535 and showed net income of $2,381,910 for the first nine months of 1949, Warren Lee Pierson, chairman, and Ralph S. Damon, president, received yesterday.

The campaign for $250,000 conducted by the Metropolitan Opera Guild has surpassed its goal, it was announced by Lauder Greenway, the organization's president at its annual membership meeting last night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 -- Herbert S. Duffy, Ohio Attorney General, was called on today by Charles F. Sweeney, Secretary of State, to rule whether the office-type ballot was adopted by the state's voters yesterday.

Industry must plan carefully for emergency mobilization in the event of another war, Roy Cheney, president of the Quartermaster Association, declared yesterday. Atomic warfare, which would start without advance notice, he said, makes it imperative that manufacturers know what to begin producing without waiting for instructions.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 9 -The Conservative Government today declared a nation-wide state of siege in an attempt to restore order and end the daily killings that have reached into the hundreds as a result of the political fights between the Conservatives and Liberals.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 9 -- India proposed today that the United Nations should continue to receive and analyze information on economic, social and educational conditions among 200,000 colonial peoples throughout the world, despite charges by Britain that such a move was in direct violation of the Charter of the organization.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Boston University's undefeated Terriors, whose slim attendance figures indicate they have been taken too lightly by the New England football public, will be risking nationwide fame as well as a post-season bowl bid when they clash with the powerful University of Maryland at Fenway Park on Saturday.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 -- In the heaviest voting in the history of municipal elections here, Albert E. Cobo was elected Mayor over George Edwards yesterday by 105,110 votes in a total of 529,360. The result was the fourth defeat in twelve years of an attempt by the Congress of Industrial Organizations to capture the Mayor's post, which pays $25,000 a year.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Al Sabath's Missab rallied from far back to overhaul the favored Lucky Ned by a half length in the featured $3,500 Mad Hatter Purse today at Pimlico.

The Horticultural Society of New York, in cooperation with the American Orchid Society, opened the forty-second fall flower show in the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House, Fifty-ninth Street and Central Park South, yesterday noon.

Seven "White Russian" families, totaling thirty-six persons, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 12:30 P. M. yesterday on a trip that started in Teheran, Iran, and will end, they hope, in California.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The policy of organized labor regarding wages and hours continues to plague the Labor Government trying to cash in on the advantages of the devaluation of the pound in the dollar markets before the general election.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 9 -- Several hundred Prague citizens read today the text of United States Ambassador Ellis O. Briggs' outspoken speech reminding Czechoslovakia of the role the United States played in her birth and liberation.

Informal talks between representatives of the Board of Transportation and various railroads have explored the possibility of providing new tracks and other facilities to enable commuter trains to carry passengers from the suburbs through the East Side IRT subway to lower Manhattan, William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, reported yesterday.

The refurbished New York Knickbockers will open their 29-game home season tonight, facing the Indianapolis Olympians in a National Basketball Association contest at Madison Square Garden. Joe Lapchick's team has just returned from a successful road trip, on which it won four of six starts against Western opponents.

Wide price fluctuations marked trading in coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. In the early trading prices advanced into new high ground as bids carried quotations up the daily limit of 200 points above the previous close.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 9 -- Chemical analysis of the blood in 581 cases of deafness in individuals ranging from infancy to old age has shown the existence in most cases of a faulty utilization of sugars and fats, it was reported here today at the annual assembly of the United States Chapter of the International College of Surgeons.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., elected Tuesday to the office of Manhattan Borough President, yesterday studied election figures showing his thumping Democratic-Liberal 209,804-vote plurality over Oren Root, his Republican-Fusion opponent, and said it looked as if the people of Manhattan wanted him to be as unfettered and independent as he had promised to be.

If the present civilization ever dies, as someone was saying only the other day that it would, future historians inevitably will do some prodding. They will perhaps glance at television, for example, and what they may gather from that will be the business of no one now alive.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, which is deadlocked in negotiations with the Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, has offered to start immediate contract talks with vessel operators not represented by that committee, Capt. Charles F. May, president of the union, announced yesterday.

The espionage conspiracy case involving Judith Coplon, former Department of Justice employe, and Valentine A. Gubitchev, Soviet engineer who was in the employ of the United Nations, ran into further delay yesterday, the date set for trial in Federal Court here.

Television, textiles and kitchen equipment continued to dominate the interest of hotel men yesterday at the thirty-fourth National Hotel Exposition at Grand Central Palace. Arthur Lee, general manager, revealed that visitors now are 10 per cent ahead of last year in number, indicating that an all-time-high attendance of 135,000 may be reached by Friday night.

Warning that Government subsidies to the nation's technical schools would menace their independence, Dr. James R. Killian Jr., president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, called upon industry last night to aid such institutions.

The Transamerica Corporation, now defending itself before the Federal Reserve Board in West Coast hearings on charges of monopolistic practices in the banking field, is planning to present testimony on its behalf by an extended list of Eastern bankers, including some prominent in New York.
The Reds recently rejected a pair of big money bids by the Dodgers for two of their top-flight pitchers, it was learned yesterday.

A glimpse into mid-season millinery fashions for travel, day and evening wear was afforded by Anita Andra yesterday in a presentation at the Ritz Carlton Hotel. For travel the soft packable hat was shown in such attractive versions as a jaunty red felt cap circled with a roll of twisted blue wool and finished with a flaring bow at the crown.

The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, a salvage and construction company, will complete today the loading of eight 84-ton Diesel locomotives aboard the Argentine State Line freighter Rio Araza for shipment to Buenos Aires.
Voters of New York State did some constructive work yesterday in their approval of the eight amendments and three propositions which were on the ballot.

Mayor William O'Dwyer will undertake the heavy burden of another four years in City Hall with a substantial vote of confidence given him in Tuesday's election. We assume, because of the great reluctance with which he stood for a second time, that this will be his last term.

The National Academy of Design will open its annual autumn exhibition of paintings, sculpture and graphic art with a preview reception for members and guests this evening in the institution's galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue. Beginning tomorrow the exhibition will be open to the public through Dec. 11.

A crowd of 1,105, the smallest in years at the St. Nicholas Arena, saw Chuck Hunter, Cleveland middleweight, outbox Billy Brown, Hartford, Conn., in a ten-round feature bout. Hunter forced whatever battling there was. Hunter weighed 162 3/4 pounds, Brown 162.

Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this city favor the setting up of a permanent joint political committee to carry forward the political unity they built up in the drive for Mayor O'Dwyer and Senator-elect Lehman, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Bolivian pilot of a war surplus P-38 fighter that rammed an Eastern Air Lines DC-4 here Nov. 1, killing all fifty-five persons aboard the airliner, failed to acknowledge and seemingly ignored radioed landing directions issued by the tower operators of the National Airport, according to testimony today.

Herbert Charles Co., renting agents for the 654-family apartment building under construction on the former Schwab mansion site bounded by Seventy-third and Seventy-fourth Streets, Riverside Drive and West End Avenue, reported yesterday that 226 suites had been rented in the past three weeks.

Lower prices received for most products, particularly light and heavy fuel oils, higher costs and expenses and a slight decline in the physical volume of products sold resulted in smaller earnings for the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) in the nine months of this year than those of a year ago, according to yesterday's report, issued jointly by W. T. Holliday, board chairman, and C. T. Foster, president.

Two Columbia line backers, A Nork and Emil Chaky, are doubtful starters against Navy at Annapolis, Md., on Saturday, according to Coach Lou Little, who sent his Lions through a long and spirited workout at Baker Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- John Foster Dulles lost more than his Senate seat in Tuesday's election. The general feeling here was that, in his vigorous campaign against Herbert H. Lehman and the Fair Deal, he lost his status as the detached mediator between the major parties, and with it his role as a Republican spokesman at major international conferences.

Despite the fact that the National Collegiate Athletic Association's tightened restrictions on post-season football games will not go into effect until next season, a number of the New Year's bowl promotions will be affected this winter, a United Press survey showed yesterday.

An entomologist is a man who collects insects. Like the horse and dog-loving crowds, entomologists have their favorite breeds and those who collect tiger beetles are the elite. A good tiger beetle-man is really the entomologist's entomologist.

COBURG, Germany, Nov. 9 -- More than 20,000 East Zone Germans stormed across the frontier into the United States zone today at Neustadt, ten miles from here, after the border had been opened by the Russians to celebrate the anniversary of the Soviet Revolution.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 9 -- The United States and Britain today expressed determined opposition to the Soviet resolution introduced yesterday, calling for simultaneous prohibition of atomic weapons and establishment of an international control plan.
TOKYO, Nov. 9 -- Japanese political leaders expressed growing opposition today to a peace treaty for Japan that failed to include all the Allies -- that is, all Japan's enemies -- in the Pacific war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- The Air Force announced today that Camp Forrest, Tenn., had been selected as the site for its new $1,000,000,000 research center for testing faster-than-sound planes and missiles.
Your editorial "Safety in the Air" in THE TIMES of Nov. 3 presents some good thinking for all of us to review.

Not since the celebrated "fifth down" affair of 1940 has a Cornell-Dartmouth contest excited so much interest as Saturday's game at Hanover, N. H. It's all because of Pete Dorset and Johnny Clayton, the pass masters who operate as T-quarterbacks for the two Ivy League contenders.

Miss Anne M. Herlt, first employe of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, was honored yesterday for fifty years' service as merchandise manager for the Schrafft's retail stores. A party was held in the president's room at 556 Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Prices of all deferred futures of corn on the Board of Trade were advanced to new highs on the crop today on general commission and local buying, and this upturn imparted strength to wheat and oats. An expected sharp reduction in the Government's November corn estimate was the main factor in the market, shorts evening up ahead of the report, which is due tomorrow after the close.

The General Electric Company refused yesterday to withdraw its recognition of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers and recognize in its place the International Union of Electrical Workers, CIO.

A new simplified plan described by its sponsors as a means of accumulating an estate or retirement capital through automatic investment of annual savings was announced yesterday by the Keystone Company of Boston, underwriters for the Keystone Custodian Funds.

With returns incomplete and further contributions expected, more than $5,000,000 was raised this year by the Greater New York Fund, John D. Rockefeller 3d, campaign chairman, reported last night at a dinner that marked the end of the 1949 drive.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Asserting that competitive bidding was the only method business and industry could use to be certain of obtaining the best price for securities issued for cash, H. L. Stuart, Chicago investment banker, urged today that all such securities be registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and held within a narrow range all day, closing 4 to 6 points higher.

LONDON, Nov. 9 (Reuters) -The International Transport Workers Federation with affiliated unions in more than fifty countries has set up a special committee to combat "Communist interference" with work at sea, in the ports and on inland waterways.

John E. Bierwirth was elected president of the National Distillers Products Corporation at a special meeting of directors held yesterday. He succeeds Seton Porter, who was elected chairman of the board after serving as president since the formation of the company. Mr. Porter will continue to be active in the management of its affairs.

It was in the Soviet Union, of all places, where men and women supposedly had equal rights and all class distinctions allegedly had been wiped out by the revolution, that an effort first was made to introduce a caste system into the Smith household.
Mayor O'Dwyer returned early yesterday afternoon to his desk at City Hall to resume full-time performance of the duties of the office to which he was re-elected on Tuesday for another four-year term.

While New Yorkers were, quite naturally, concentrating on their Senatorial and Mayoralty contests, some interesting and important "off-year" elections took place in various parts of the country outside the Empire State.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- Walter Ulbricht, Deputy Premier of the Communist state in Eastern Germany, boasted of the assistance his state was receiving from former Nazis tonight shortly after the People's Chamber of that government had voted full civil and economic rights to former Nazis and militarists.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 9 -- Independence for Libya by the first day in 1952 was recommended today by the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- John L. Lewis today sent his striking coal miners back to work until midnight Nov. 30 without a contract. He waived his "no contract, no work" policy and said the terms of the 1948 contract would apply in the three-week truce period.

From three directions in the metal trades indications appeared yesterday that first effects of the ending of the steel strike may be higher prices for finished metal products. In an active day featured by large orders, zinc advanced 1/4 cent in a "dual" market, pushed up by demand for immediate delivery sought by steel mills.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Senator Kenneth Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, tonight told the American Butter Institute convention that, as a result of tariff reductions, the United States is "virtually on a free trade basis" and that the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act is a "one-way street for foreign countries to flood American markets."
Tuesday's state - wide election, which resulted in the sending of Herbert H. Lehman to the United States Senate by a majority of about 196,000 votes, left far-reaching political consequences.

The rank-and-file among the coal miners received the news of the strike's end with mixed feelings. Many were eager to go back to their jobs on any terms; others viewed the back-to-work order as a costly defeat.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- France's National Assembly will debate the deadlocked status of the European Marshall Plan Council and the slowdown in the Council of Europe coupled with the whole question of Germany, it was agreed today.

Charles Munch appeared for the first time in New York as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. He gave proof immediately of the catholicity of his taste, his sincerity as an interpreter, and his passionate musical nature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Democratic victories and other results of yesterday's elections created widespread conviction at the Capitol today that President Truman would be in much stronger position to press for passage of the rest of his Fair Deal program at the next session of Congress. It was conceded, even by Southerners, that his chances were better now for making progress with some of his long-blocked civil rights proposals.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 9 (AP) -North Carolina continued preparations today for Saturday's game with Notre Dame in New York's Yankee Stadium.

WARSAW, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- By a vote of 8,160 to 4,491, Mrs. Charlotte Smallwood, 26 years old and four years out of law school, has been elected District Attorney. She is believed to be the first woman in the state to have won such a post at the polls.
DETROIT, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Young Lester Felton, Detroit Negro whose victory over Kid Gavilan on Oct. 21 touched off a boxing controversy, battled to a draw with rough Tony Pellone of New York tonight.

The opening of the fifty-seventh annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Enneers,. starting a three-day conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, was devoted to a business session for the organization's council members. The council is the governing body of the society.

POMPTON LAKES, N. J., Nov. 9 -- Youth, in order better to meet the problems of the day, must learn to make itself better informed on current issues through wider reading of newspapers and periodicals and through discussion groups, a panel of six high school students agreed here today.

CHATTANOOGA, Nov. 9 -- It seemed certain today that Tennessee's voters had decided in favor of a limited convention to amend the state's 79-year-old Constitution, the oldest unrevised state Constitution in the country.
Argentina, since devaluation of the peso, has just about cleaned up her heavy accumulation of hides, and to some extent is now selling ahead, it was reported yesterday in the hide and leather trades.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Viscount Templewood and fellow Conservative peers declared in the House of Lords today that Britain was getting far too little for the money she was spending on defense. Lord Templewood, who as Sir Samuel Hoare held the War and Air Ministries in past governments, criticized the system of eighteen-month conscription, the Government's lack of success in attracting volunteers and the alleged combat weakness of the Air Force and Army.

Four new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "That Forsyte Woman," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's adaptation of John Galsworthy's "The Forsyte Saga" featuring Greer Garson, Errol Flynn, Walter Pidgeon, Robert Young and Janet Leigh.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Stanley Kramer, independent producer, today reported that he had bought the screen rights to Edmond Rostand's play, "Cyrano de Bergerac," from Sir Alexander Korda of London and was seeking Jose Ferrer for the title role.

From the modern experimental stage, more often than not, come dramas that are thin and worth- less. It is good to report an exception this morning. "The Edge of the Sword," by George Bellak, presented last night at the Master Institute Theatre by the Abbe Practical Workshop is an engrossing and thought-compelling play about the post-war crisis in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Once more, Louisiana and Texas insisted today that they, instead of the Federal Government, owned the valuable oil lands under the marginal sea adjacent to their coastlines.

MANILA, Thursday, Nov. 10 -- With returns from yesterday's election still far from complete, the mounting provincial totals for President Elpidio Quirino indicated his victory over Jose P. Laurel, Nationalista party candidate, with the third Presidential aspirant, Jose Avelino, former Senate President, trailing far behind.

Your issue of Nov. 4 carries a Moscow dispatch reporting that a writer named N. Leonidov in a Soviet political weekly, The New Times, attacks an article printed in Foreign Affairs for January, 1949, entitled "Stalin on Revolution," signed with the pen name Historicus.

Prospects for peace in the steel and coal industries were brushed aside yesterday by the stock market and, after a firm start, prices eased. General Motors and du Pont were exceptions to the trend as a result of the large year-end dividend declared by the former.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The turn of one of the most significant off-year elections in recent political history toward the Democrats was acclaimed widely today as a strong affirmation of the Truman Fair Deal program.

A check for $4.14, all that remained from the $5,200,000 gift that the late Andrew Carnegie made to build branch libraries in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond, was handed over yesterday to the Reference Department of the New York Public Library as the first gift in its new drive for funds.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- The Democrats gained a seat in the California Congressional delegation and the state's present old-age pension law was drastically overhauled by the voters, for an annual $65,000,000 saving, at yesterday's special election.

PARSONS, Kan., Nov. 9 (P)--i President Truman joined political and business leaders today in extending sympathy td the f. mily ofI Senator Clyde M. Reed, who diedI last night at his home here. The PresidenL said he wa shocked and saddened by the death of the 78J! year-old Republican Senator.

Right on the heels of having been beaten by the Buffalo Bills, Red Strader, who might well qualify as his own press agent, yesterday told the writers at the Football Yankees' luncheon at the Stadium that "we still rate the Chicago Hornets ahead of Buffalo."

The King Ranch's Cita third at 2 to 5 on Monday, again was a beaten favorite at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday. But this time she at least made it close, losing only in the last stride to Hal Price Headley's Valuta.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Hard-driving Roy Conacher paced the Chicago Black Hawks to a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins tonight before 10,074 fans at the Boston Garden. Conacher broke a 1-1 tie in the second period and more than settled matters early in the final session by setting up a goal for Doug Bentley.
The Permanent Committee for the Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency is planning to found a Girls Town patterned after the late Father Edward J. Flanagan's Boys Town, it was announced yesterday.

So far as Fordham is concerned, the game with Army is a closed book. Coach Ed Danowski and his Ram squad are much too absorbed in preparations for Saturday's test with Boston College to take time out for further post-mortems on the battle at West Point.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Louis Ware quit the board of the United States Gypsum Company today as directors accepted the resignation of William L. Keady as president and named Oliver M. Knode as his successor.

State licensing of real estate appraisers was advocated by Robert M. Armstrong of Armstrong Associates in a speech last night at a meeting of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board in Sakele's Restaurant at 174 Montague Street, Brooklyn. Urging rigid standards and examinations, Mr. Armstrong said that the appraisers cannot attain professional status until the educational and experience requirements are raised above the present levels.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The foreign ministers of Britain, France and the United States agreed here today that Western Germany should be admitted to the Council of Europe along with the Saar, which the French desire to admit at the same time. The decision was subject to approval by the French Parliament, which Robert Schuman, Foreign Minister, had promised to consult.

Not all glamour for after dark is worn beneath a coat this season. It shines and glitters in many a wrap. Nor is it only a story of luxurious fabrics richly fashioned. A delightful sense of imagination is seen in the styling and variety of the coats.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 9 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, and John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, will confer Sunday with Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Western German Republic, and members of his Cabinet in Bonn, the Chancellor's office announced tonight.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Drenching rain and a mishap in which dozen or more bystanders were slightly injured did little today to mar the most colorful City of London Lord Mayor's show since the war.

ALBANY, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Alcoholic beverages now are legal in Richford, Tioga County, provided they are consumed at year-around hotels or taken home. The town, formerly dry, was one of twelve communities that held local option elections yesterday.

AMONG the Election Day results was one which caused the least amount of surprise, the retention of Barney Shotton in office for another year. It was foreordained, of course. Branch Rickey was the only voter and the Mahatma considers Shotton as his alter ego. So his bullet ballot did the trick and his beloved Barney manage the Brooklyn Dodgers for another season.

HONG KONG, Nov. 9 -- A wholesale switch by Chinese airlines from the Nationalist to the Communist banner was heralded here today by the departure of twelve Chinese commercial transport aircraft from Hong Kong's Kaitak airport for Communist China.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov, 9 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, United States delegate, firmly and heatedly denied here today that the United States was preparing for war against the Soviet Union or "war with anyone."

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov 9 -- Members of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations are abandoning acrimonious propagandist exchanges and are cooperating sensibly in tackling purely economic and social problems, James Thorn of New Zealand, president of the Council, said today.

The Board of Justices of the State Supreme Court, Second Judicial District, made public yesterday its own suggestions for a "workable plan" to ease calendar congestion in tort jury cases in the courts.

BOSTON, Nov 9 -- James Michael Curley, Boston 74-year-old political boss, was one of six Massachusetts Mayors who were turned out of office in yesterday's thirty-one municipal lections, a review of the results disclosed today.

A new type of aircraft servicing that will reduce delays caused by instrument failures will be put into effect soon at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, it was announced yesterday at the Durham Aircraft Service, Inc., of Woodside, Queens.
Gimbels, New York, played host last night to 500 manufacturers, buyers and merchandise managers at the official opening of the remodeled second floor of the department store.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 9 -- A final decision that would officially end the sending of reparations to the Soviet Union from the western zones of Germany is expected here to emerge from current Western Big Three conference in Paris.
