For nine weeks Manhattan detectives trailed two ex-convicts, then took them into custody Tuesday night after setting up a roadblock near the New York end of the Holland Tunnel to stop their automobile.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Efforts of railroads bringing Florida citrus fruits into New York City to meet steamship rate competition were blocked today for at least seven months.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 9 -- The rural community was singled out here today by Dr. Benson Y. Landis of New York as a logical starting point for improving Protestant Roman-Catholic relationships.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries had a net profit in the first nine months of this year of $26,077,125 after taxes and all charges, equal to $1.68 a share on 14,584,025 common shares, Robert C. Stanley, chairman of the board, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administra tion has not actually taken over control of good weather flights by Air Force and Navy planes, a CAA spokesman said tonight.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- George Eastman House here was officially opened today as a photographic museum. It was dedicated as a center for study of the history and practice of photography.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 9 -Menachem Begin, former Irgun Zvai Leumi commander and now leader of the Herut opposition in the Knesset [Parliament], presented today a motion that would proclaim Jerusalem the capital of Israel.
The Pennroad Corporation declared yesterday two dividends of 50 cents each, the first payable on Dec. 12, and the second payable on June 12, 1950.
The Brooklyn College basketball squad will play 26 games, second highest total in the school's history, during the 1949-50 season, it was announced yesterday.

The market for the tax-exempt bonds of local governments was unruffled yesterday by the outcome of referendums on proposed bond issues, likely to swell the backlog of new investment supply even more than in the election day voting last year.

EPHRATA, Wash., Nov. 9 -Farm boundaries are being redrawn in a way believed unprecedented in American history as the Federal Bureau of Reclamation sets about changing the lives of thousands of persons in the 1,000,000-acre Columbia Basin irrigation area of Washington.

Department stores and large home furnishings chains are placing large pre-market bedroom furniture orders for January and February delivery, manufacturers' representatives reported yesterday. Buyers agreed that order volume is heavier than at this time last year but added that it is not huge.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Heavy selling on the stock markets here today again depressed British Government issues. With the decline gathering momentum most of the day, the losses were as much as 1 1/8. Colonial and dominions issues also were weak.

With more than 40 per cent of the country's steel mills back in operation, the giant United States Steel Corporation cleared the road yesterday for prompt termination of the steel strike. The walkout will complete its sixth week tomorrow.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Sparkling embroidery concentrated on long, separate glove-like sleeves worn with somber evening gowns, the return to favor of mat crepes are the highlights of Lanvin's Christmas party gowns.

Reports that 488 New Orleans-bound displaced persons were embarked erroneously on the Army transport Gen. M. B. Stewart, which arrived here yesterday morning with 1,272 passengers from Bremerhaven, Germany, were denied by spokesmen for the International Refugee Organization.

The State of Delaware announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Nov. 22 on tax-exempt bond issues amounting to $28,369,000. Dated Oct. 1 and Dec. 1, 1949, the bonds will be due from 1950 to 1969.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Advocates of liberalizing the Displaced Persons Act expressed confidence today that Congress would respond to the Displaced Persons Commission's renewed pleas for the "earliest possible" revision of the law.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 10 -- The fifty-nine member countries of the United Nations will soon get the good news that their contributions to the regular costs of running the world peace organization next year may be $5,000,000 to $5,500,000 less than they paid out this year.

The biennial convention here of the American Jewish Congress ended several hours of sharp and often acrimonious debate at 12:45 A. M. today, approving by more than 2 to 1 the report of its executive director, Dr. David Petegorsky.

Leaders of the Protestant Episcopal Church urged yesterday greater interest by its communicants in the work of the Youth Consultation Service of the Diocese of New York, Inc., a non-sectarian agency that has ministered since 1911 to girls with serious personal problems.

The cooler weather being here, it will not be long before the world is sneezing with the common cold. Nor will it be long before reddened eyes turn accusingly on the medical profession and again demand the cure.
MANILA, Nov. 10 (AP) -- President Elpidio Quirino slowly increased his lead in Tuesday's Presidential election to more than 258,000 votes late tonight, but refrained from claiming victory.

Mayor O'Dwyer signed yesterday a local law making it illegal to leave a motor vehicle unattended for more than three minutes on city streets without shutting off motor and removing the ignition key. The law, previously approved by the City Council and the Board of Estimate, becomes effective in thirty days for private cars and on Jan. 1 for commercial vehicles.

The statement yesterday by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, before a United Nations committee repeats practically verbatim a report that appeared Nov. 5 in the Russian-licensed newspaper Nacht Express, published in Berlin, to the effect that the Russians had used atomic energy to blow up mountains in order to reverse the direction of two Siberian rivers.

With one exception, the home opener of the New York Knickerbockers was a rousing success last night at Madison Square Garden. A record crowd was on hand, the action was fast and furious, the contest with the Indianapolis Olympians a thriller and the brand of basketball top-flight all the way. But the Knicks lost.

Summarizing their impressions of the basic difference between American and British methods of cotton goods production, members of a British textile productivity team asserted yesterday that poor yarn quality was one of the greatest obstacles to higher British output.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- Governor Dewey announced after a conference with Republican fiscal leaders of the Legislature today that his 1950-51 state budget might be lower than the current record $936,000,000 budget and that there would be no new taxes.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 10 -- If Harry Kutik, 25-year-old paraplegic veteran, makes a success of the bookstore business he opened here today, the concern that is backing him in the enterprise will do the same for other paraplegics.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 10 -- Naval Academy midshipmen put on a dress parade in honor of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today and cannon thundered a seventeen-gun salute.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 10 -- The "rechurching" of Rural America can be achieved only through the cooperative efforts of all major Protestant bodies working together as a single force unhampered by denominational limitations.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Astor, the attraction is "Battleground," Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's drama about the Battle of the Bulge, which was directed by William A. Wellman and produced by Dore Schary from a story and screen play by Robert Pirosh, Van Johnson, George Murphy, Ricardo Montalban, John Hodiak, James Whitmore, Douglas Fowley, Marshall Thompson, Jerome Courtland and Denise Darcel head the cast.
Gifts galore were showered yes-i terday on Mrs. Amelia 1V. Propper in celebration of her 101st birthday. But the One she wanted most --the sight she lost last year--was not among them.

Our greatest complaint against the Soviet Government's treatment of the American Embassy's personnel stemmed not from our physical discomfort but from the restrictions placed upon our freedom as individual human beings.

Despite cables reporting Brazilian price advances, coffee futures lost ground in trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. For the first time this week the market closed with quotations on both S and D contracts below the previous day's levels.

The New Jersey upland game season will open at 9 A. M. today and the prospects for hunting are as good or better than last year, with some counties reporting conditions to be better than they have been since before the war.

YONKERS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Splendid team-work coupled with familiarity with the course earned a record-shattering best-ball victory today for Andrew Macko, Dunwoodie pro, and Ed Mallery Jr., as thirty-two pro-amateur teams competed in the final post-season one-day tournament staged by the Metropolitan P. G. A. at the Dunwoodie Golf Club.

The eleventh annual White Elephant Cocktail Party and Tea Da_ce, for the benefit of the Chfid Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, took place yesterday afternoon in the main ballroom and adjoining small ballroom of the Plaza.

Charley Fusari will meet Terry Young of the East Side in the star bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Irvington (N. J.) welterweight, who will be making his first start since his surprising stand against Rocky Graziano two months ago, is scheduled to go ten rounds against the aggressive East Side warrior.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- An implied offer to leave the Republican party marked the opening today of the second national Republican Round-up, which was formed here last July with the objective of "revitalizing" the GOP.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States called today for Congressional reconsideration of long-range financial commitments that are not subject to reduction by cuts in appropriations.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- Opposition to the removal of quantitative trade restrictions in Europe is becoming more and more a reflection of protectionist fear of competition and less and less a reflection of balance-of-payments difficulties.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Conservative President Mariano Ospina Perez strengthened his rule under a state of siege today by decreeing that any Supreme Court ruling on constitutional questions must be passed by a three-fourths majority.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Building trades unions have won a significant Taft-Hartley case in the courts.

Earnings of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for the nine months ended on Oct, 1 are estimated at $19,299,000, compared with $20,015,000 for the nine months to Oct, 2, 1948, according to a statement issued for publication today.

Movements of stocks were erratic yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, with the gold issues under heavy pressure after President Truman announced that there would be no change in the price of gold while he was in the White House.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 10 -- Overriding bitter protests by Britain, France and other colonial powers, forty-one countries in the Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, including the United States, voted today to continue for three years a special United Nations organ responsible for analyzing information on economic, social and educational conditions among the 200,000,000 inhabitans of the world's dependent areas.
Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien and Yeheskel Sahar, Inspector General of the Israeli Police, found yesterday they had one problem in common -- traffic.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 -- Western Pennsylvania miners were back in the pits today at a strength of about 70 per cent, according to Harry A. Sutter, vice president of the Western Pennsylvania Coal Operators Association.

The nation's gasoline stocks were increased by 342,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies at the week-end were 104,257,000 barrels, compared with 103,915,000 a week earlier and 91,377,000 a year before.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The Air Force announced today completion of the first C-124 "Globemaster II" -- a troop and cargo plane designed to carry 200 fully equipped soldiers and field equipment.

Two armed men held up the box office of the Broadway Theatre, Broadway at Fifty-third Street, at 7:35 o'clock last night, just as a few early theatre-goers were entering the obby to pick up tickets to see Bobby Clark in "As the Girls Go." The thieves escaped with $15,200.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 -- Agreement tomorrow between the striking United Steelworkers of America, CIO, and the United States Steel Corporation appeared certain here today. The com pany, giant of the industry with more than 177,000 employes, has made a definite offer to the union. Today lawyers for both sides spent long hours haggling over technical details and ironing out legal language.

The $200,000.000 Ohio Edison Company, which recently became independent electric operating sstem following the break-up of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, has made plans to purchase the adjoining Ohio Public Service Compa from the Cities Service Company.

A banking group headed by Shields Co. submitted the best bid yesterday for $2,480,000 of municipal improvement and refunding bonds of Birmingham, Ala., due from Dec. 1, 1952 to 1977. The bid was 100 for 2 1/4s and 2s, an interest cost of 2.1991 per cent.

ROME, Nov. 10 -- The "Titoist contagion" has spread to the Italian Left-Wing Socialist party, whose directorate announced measures against ten of its members who recently went to Belgrade at the invitation of the Central Committee of Yugoslav labor unions.
For 25 cents a day the majority of the 1,000,000 epileptics in this country can live normal lives, Dr. Frederic Gibbs, one of the nation's leading authorities on epilepsy, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- During the week ended Nov. 9, member bank reserve balances decreased $292,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Hugh Hickey, 58-year-old "sales sponsor" in Macy's department store, was paroled yesterday in Felony Court after it was revealed that he had turned over to the District Attorney an envelope containing securities valued at $50,327.

Public utility equity financing continues to figure prominently in the issues of securities right ahead of the market. Underwriting syndicates will bid next Wednesday on the underwriting of two large offerings of new utility stock to company stockholders -- 1,584,238 shares of the Northern States Power Company and 669,508 shares of the New England Electric System.

" I wish -- for several reasons -- that Andrew Carnegie were here today!" These wistful words were uttered by Morris Hadley, president of the New York Public Library, as he opened the library's new appeal for gifts from the public to support its operations at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The State Bonus Bureau is prepared to receive about 150,000 additional applications for bonuses as a result of approval by the voters on Tuesday of a constitutional amendment making New York State veterans who now reside in other states eligible for payments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- An official of the American Association of University Women said today that many of its members thought colleges should concentrate on teaching co-eds how to cook, sew, and take care of babies.

PARIS, Friday, Nov. 11 -- The Foreign Ministers of Britain, France and the United States closed a two-day conference here at 2 o'clock this morning by instructing their High Commissioners in Germany to negotiate with the Bonn Government for the liquidation of the dismantling program and acceptance by the Western German regime of Western Allied controls.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 10 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles indicated today that he was willing to serve again on the American delegation to the United Nations. But added that "would be up to President Truman."

ROME, Nov. 10 -- Pope Pins XII urged all Roman Catholics in the world today to undertake a "crusade of prayers" in the hope that the United Nations would arrive at what he considered a just settlement of the issue of the Holy Places in Palestine.

LIVERPOOL, England, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Monaveen, owned by Princess Elizabeth and her mother, the Queen, finished second in the Grand Sefton Steeplechase at Ain-tree today. The race of about three miles was won easily by Mrs. L. Brotherton's Freebooter, who paid 3 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Truman issued a proclamation today designating Nov. 24 as Thanksgiving Day this year. He said that "we are thankful that our resources enable us to aid the peoples of other countries in the furtherance of economic well-being and security."

In spite of the excellent cooperation which the public has been giving in cutting down as much as possible on the use of water, Commissioner Carney of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity calls attention again to the increasingly critical condition of New York's Catskill and Croton storage reservoirs.

United States trade with Brazil is larger than trade between the United States and any other country except Canada, Jose Bettencourt Machado, assistant director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau, told New York University's Foreign Trade Club last night. Trade with Brazil, he said, averaged more than $1,000,000,000 a year in 1947 and 1948 and was nearing that mark this year.
Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky laid aside last night a prepared talk bitterly critical of United States "warmongers" and devoted himself to a strong plea for peace.
LONDON, Nov 10 -- The recent steady drop in British Government securities was halted today and the close was about on a level with yesterday's final prices.

When the second Bal de Tete is given on Tuesday in the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton, several world famous jewels, property of Harry Winston, sponsor of the ball, will be displayed by a group of women prominent in society.

Dr. Ervin Munk, former Czechoslovak Consul General in New York, and one of two Czechoslovak officials ousted by the United States in retaliation for a similar action by the Prague Government involving two American Embassy officials, expressed resentment yesterday over the attitude of the State Department.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 10 -- Blame for the persistence of noxious "smogs" in many American cities was placed by a leading air-pollution expert today on official mismanagement, misguided public enthusiasm and selfish industrialists.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 10 -- All drugs now used in the treatment of Tuberculosis merly stop the growth and multiplication of tuberculosis bacilli and do not destroy them, specialists emphasized today at a National Tuberculosis Conference sponsored by the Veterans Administration.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Western powers said today the West German Federal Government was soon to have a bigger say in conducting its international trade -- but only under watchful Western Allied eyes.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 10 -- A ten-year Italian trusteeship over Somaliland was approved today by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 10 -- This important steel district's "back-to-work" movement was in full swing today as five of its eight big steel plants were being rushed back into production.

Cecil Wood, one of the unseen but indispensable men in the movies, came down from his projection booth in the Paris Theatre yesterday morning and graciously accepted felicitations on his fiftieth anniversary as a motion picture projector operator.
Among this week's exhibitions of paintings are several group shows that cover the ground between Paris, New York and Haiti.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The State Department said today that it had received no reply to its Nov. 3 request to the Chinese Communist authorities for the release of Angus Ward, United States Consul General in Mukden, and four members of his staff who were arrested Oct. 24.

There is nothing in the export situation today to justify undue tightening of credit terms to well-rated foreign buyers in many active markets which continue to offer good business opportunities, Stanley E. Hollis, president of the American Foreign Credit Underwriters Corporation, said yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 10 -- A new campaign for home and job assurance for additional displaced persons was promised at a meeting of directors of the Catholic Resettlement Program and representatives of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference today.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Representatives of two and one-half million engineering workers decided today to press their claim for a 1 [$2.80] weekly pay increase.

All members of the New York Ticket Brokers Association have signed the new ticket code, jointly revised by the League of New York Theatres and Actors Equity, which expires next Aug. 31, it was reported yesterday by Ben Kaiden, president of the brokers' organization.

BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- The prospect that the United States program for the economic integration of Western Europe will lead to a sharp curtailment of trade between Western and Eastern Germany apparently has aroused deep concern among both the Communists and non-Communists in the East German state.

General Electric Company yesterday resumed limited production of refrigerator units at its Erie, Pa., plant, which has been shut down for two weeks because of lack of steel. Production of units will reach the level prevailing before the shutdown, the latter part of next week, according to H. L. Andrews, vice president in charge of the company's appliance and merchandising division.

Two women and a 9-year-old boy, who arrived among 1,272 displaced persons on the Army transport Gen. C. H. Muir yesterday were sent to Ellis Island by Immigration officers for a hearing by a board of special inquiry when both women claimed to be the mother of the boy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Corn and oats futures again registered new highs today for the season, with the exception of December corn, with active buying of the feed grains on expectation of a big slash in the corn estimate by the Government.

The Long Island Lighting Company reported yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington amendments which the Federal agency said last week were necessary to effect consolidation of the utility with its two subsidiaries, the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company and the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company.

Largely because of the election day holiday, bank clearings for the five-day week ended on Wednesday fell sharply from the volume of the previous week and also from that of the corresponding period last year, each of which included six days.

BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- The population of the eastern sector today reported that all food shops in that area had been closed throughout the day, and that the owners had advised customers they would reopen tomorrow with a schedule of considerably higher prices.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Laborites demanded today that the Government drastically revamp Britain's film industry to save it from collapse and protect local cinemas from an avalanche of Hollywood pictures.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- Legal experts at the Capitol asserted today that Mr. Dulles was still the state's junior Senator, despite his defeat in Tuesday's election.
Lehn Fink Products Corporation declared a dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 14.

Demonstration commercials on television are relatively ineffective, according to tentative conclusions drawn by an analysis of the first two months of the Starch Reports on television commercials, it was announced yesterday by the Daniel Starch Staff research organization.
The air soon will be filled with movie - struck, California - bound young stowaways if others can duplicate the feat of Arthur Biggs. This, however, is unlikely. Arthur has alerted the airlines.

Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, yesterday stepped into the deadlocked negotiations between East and Gulf Coast steamship operators and the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, with the result that the contract talks will shift to Washington for eleventh-hour meetings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- In a new flare-up in the investigation into the controversy over policies of the unified armed forces command, Representative W. Sterling Cole of New York today accused Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, of "destroying" the ability of Congress to provide for the common defense.

SUMMIT, N. J., Nov. 10 -- Emery Thomas of Forest Hill and George Stuhler of Cedar Hill tied in the pro individual with 74, one over par, in a New Jersey P. G. A. pro-amateur tourney at Canoe Brook today.
The left-wing United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers and its new Congress of Industrial Organizations rival each claimed two victories yesterday in their fight to win the support of UE members.

Two five-member Congressional subcommittees sailed yesterday afternoon on the S. S. Puerto Rico for a two-week investigation into Puerto Rico's minimum wage and social security problems. They left at 4 P. M. from Pier 23 in Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- Negotiations that have been proceeding here this week between committees of actors seeking to compose differences between the Screen Actors Guild and the various other groups of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America over a proposed "Television Authority" were reliably reported today to have made little or no progress.

MONTREAL, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Maurice (The Rocket) Richard slammed home two goals tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-2 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs. The victory enabled the Canadiens to tie the Maple Leafs for second place in the National Hockey League race.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- Details of a plan offered to the Western Allies by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancelor of the Bonn Republic, for French financial participation in the Ruhr steel and coal industries became known today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (Religious News Service) -- Communist assaults on freedom of religion and worship in Iron Curtain countries call for common action Protestants, Catholics and Jews, speakers declared here today at the annual meeting of the board of directors of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland financier, denounced Wall Street investment bankers today as the "money monopoly." He urged Congress to take immediate action to "smash" the "unholy alliance" between the "New York money ring" and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The YoungWomen christian Association, of New York has ended its '1948-1949 year with an excess of $16,823-over expenditures and,has served ' 783,557:'.persons. in ten 'categories, it was announced last night.

The promotion - minded New York Yankees have come up with a new ticket-selling plan designed, according to the baseball club's announcement yesterday, "to get a sizeable portion of world series reserved seats into the hands of everyday general admission customers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- United States atomic officials are in South Africa to survey prospects for mining uranium from the rich gold fields there, it was revealed today.

The Iraq Minister and Charge d'Afraises in a letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 31, dealing with the persecution of Jews in Iraq, makes a blanket denial of the accusations against the Government of Iraq and through this denial hopes to dispel the fears and apprehensions of thousands of well-meaning people over the fate of the 150,000 Jews of Iraq.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- The complex court career of Preston Tucker plodded forward on three fronts today, forcing the would-be automobile maker at one point to hustle away from his trial in Federal District Court on charges of fraud, to post bond in another case in Municipal Court.

More than 2,500 members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, voted unanimously last night to defy efforts by the parent union to oust the local's business manager, Harry Van Arsdale Jr.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather quiet yesterday and closed barely steady, 1 to 8 points net lower.
Columbia's football team will leave today for Annapolis, with little hope of scuttling the Navy tomorrow.

There is cause for anxiety on the part of all Americans, North and South, over developments in Colombia, where a state of siege has now been imposed. As the date approaches for the Presidential elections of Nov. 27 the heat and turmoil are increasing. An internal political struggle is assuming international proportions and there are possibilities of disturbances throughout the Inter-American world.

The fifth Limited Editions Club gold medal award, given to the American author of that book published during the last five years that the judges believe "most likely to attain the stature of a classic," will be presented next Wednesday at a breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The Port of New York Authority authorized yesterday the final land purchase necessary to complete its plans to make Newark Airport second only to Idlewild in size and importance.

A new musical organization, the Stradivarius Society, will make its first appearance at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Jan. 10, it was announced yesterday. In a series of six concerts, the society will make use, where possible of the famous string instruments owned by the performers or borrowed from private collections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index was 151.5 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.4 per cent below four weeks ago, and 7.8 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

The Repertory Theatre of the Dramatic Workshop opened its eleventh season last night with Ted Pollack's play, "Wedding in Japan," at the President Theatre. The play deals with two American soldiers, a Negro sergeant and a white Southern lieutenant, who vie for the love of a Japanese girl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The United States, in a move believed here to further its own as well as the world's economy, will take part in another effort next year to lower tariffs and puncture trade barriers between nations, the State Department announced tonight.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 10 (AP) -- North Carolina's All-America tailback Charlie Justice said today "it doesn't look, like I'll play" Saturday against Notre Dame in New York.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 10 -- John D. Hickerson, Assistant Secretary of State for United Nations Affairs, said here this afternoon that Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky's speech on atomic control earlier in the day had convinced him that, "if this matter is to be settled, the best possible forum is discussion by the six permanent members of the (United Nations) Atomic Energy Commission."

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman, in his first opinion since appointment to the bench last month, dismissed yesterday a damage suit by William T. Bohannon, ruling that a ship's agent was not liable for injuries to a crewman.

A Supreme Court order has been handed down restoring control of the Bethlehem Silk Company, a million-dollar manufacturing company, to Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Bowen of 1160 Park Avenue, it became known yesterday. The decision was made by Justice Felix C. Benvenga in an equity action.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 10 -- Almost 100 bills were dropped into the legislative hopper of the Lower House today as the Connecticut Legislature went into its third special session.

Retail fur sales this year are off sharply, running at the rate of $250,000,000, against an average of $446,000,000 for 1943-48, David R. Hochberg, president of the American Fur Merchants Association, said last night at the annual meeting of the organization at the Hotel Statler.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- The American Federation of Labor has been selected as bargaining agent by Pennsylvania Railroad shop employes in three of eight job classifications.
The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals failed yesterday to qualify for a certificate of exemption from city laws in connection with a housing problem.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 10 (UP) -- A game warden snatched a 300-pound dressed bear from Representative Frank Boykin's deep-freeze in the deep woods today and the Democratic party lost the piece de resistance for a harmony dinner.
DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Ford Motor Company paid two dividends amounting to $4.50 a share for the year ended on July 1, last, a report filed in Probate Court here today showed.

" Peace On Earth," a collection of essays about the United Nations and its work to achieve peace, will be published Tuesday by Hermitage House. The volume, which has an introduction by Robert E. Sherwood, contains articles by Trygve Lie, Herbert Evatt, Charles Malik, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Jaime Torres Bodet, Brock Chisholm, John Boyd-Orr, Ludwik Rajchman, Ralph Bunche, Benjamin Cohen and Carlos Romulo.

Although participation in the lunch program in New York's elementary and high schools has increased more than 100 per cent in the last four years only 39 per cent of the 880,000 students take advantage of the program, it was disclosed yesterday.

Thirty-one years ago this morning many thousands of men climbed out of the long trench lines that ran almost without interruption from Switzerland to the sea. Some of these men belonged to advancing divisions which had broken a four-year deadlock, crossed the blasted and funereal areas of No Man's Land and come at last into the clear.
Armistice Day of 1918 will be observed here and throughout the nation in ceremonies today.

The outlook for the future of shipbuilding in this country cannot be said to be promising unless new projects are developed and new contracts placed in the near future, John B. Woodward Jr., president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- President Truman today shrugged off a report that he might ask Congress to enlarge the nine-member Supreme Court to provide two more seats -- for a Republican and a Democrat.

The Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of Fordham University, told faculty members in an informal progress report released yesterday that the primary concern of college educators today should be to develop in their students an "informed and active sense of social responsibility."

Until two weeks ago Foy D. Kohler had never done anything more ambitious with a radio than listen to it. Then he took over as chief of the International Broadcasting Division of the State Department, the director of the complex, far-reaching Voice of America.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y.,'Nov. 10 --After hearing testimony since Oct. 24 in a suit for removal of executors of the $14,499,000 estate of the late Hiram Edward Manville of Pleasantville, head of the Johns-Manville Corporation, and for a $500,000 surcharge against them, Supreme Court Referee Frederick P. Close reserved deci, sion this afternoon and called for briefs by mid-January.

A new setting for an old auction house that has been the country's leading medium for the exchange of works of art and furnishings was shown last night in the opening of the Parke-Bernet Galleries' just-completed quarters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 5 were 578,981 cars, the Association of American Railroads anounced today.

Your issue of Nov. 6 has a long news article by Tania Long from London which seeks to establish secret uranium deposits in Soviet Turkestan of high grade and great extent, such data "lying for years unheeded in the files of the British Museum."
DETROIT, Nov. 10 -- Henry J. Kaiser has agreed to an out-of-court settlement of $1,379,503 in a suit brought by Kaiser-Frazer Corporation stockholders. Mr. Kaiser is chairman of the board.

Decline of 6 cents on pork loin roasts and chops are among the few price changes favorable to consumers this week-end. Large Grade A eggs advanced 2 cents for the second successive week and several vegetables are from 4 to 6 cents higher than they were last Friday.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Tech. Sgt. Huelett Benner of the United States Army established a world record winning the Olympic silhouette pistol competition at the international shooting championships today with a score of 577.

A series of dramatizations designed to emphasize the need of blood and its many uses by local hospitals will be inaugurated by WMCA Tuesday from 9:30 to 10 P. M. The series, entitled "New Blood," is part of an over-all campaign to obtain 250,000 pints of whole blood to meet the minimum requirements next year of hospitals and community blood banks in the city's five boroughs.

Judge William Bondy rebuked Valentin A. Gubitchev yesterday for his criticism of the court proceedings after the Federal jurist had ordered the Soviet engineer to be ready for trial Monday with Judith Coplon, former Department of Justice employe on spy charges.
TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Trenton State Teachers ended a 45-game winless streak born in 1938 with a 7-6 victory over Montclair Teachers today in their final game of the season.

Most Americans will be relieved and pleased that the Philippines has rejected the Presidential bid of the former Japanese puppet chief, Jose Laurel, and has returned to office a man of the proved friendliness of President Elpidio Quirino. Americans may observe with some satisfaction, also, that President Quirino's actual margin of victory is larger than the official returns because of the quirks of the three-cornered contest.

Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, predicted last night that the nations of Western Europe would take action within the next few weeks toward easing barriers to intra-European trade and commerce.
LIKE autumn leaves, the unbeaten teams flutter to earth from the topmost branches. More of them will fall tomorrow. But let's look them over.

A vacant plot of land about 100 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of Covert and Main Streets in Port Washington, L. I., has been purchased by George A. Burdick and Charles Hyde Walker from Ralph. V. and Eleanor S. Carlson. The Charles E. Hyde Agency was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
LENINGRAD, Nov. 5 -- Just beyond the sprawling Kirov steel works on the Moscow highway leading out of Leningrad there has been erected for the Nov. 7 revolution celebration a large display poster.

The plight of a 3-year-old leukemia victim, son of a Veterans Administration employe, struck home yesterday. Two hundred workers of the VA's Brooklyn regional office contributed a pint of blood each to a mobile unit in Brooklyn from the Greater New York Red Cross blood program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Roman Catholic school superintendents today accused public-school teacher organizations of blocking Federal aid-to-education legislation by a dog-in-the-manger attitude toward help for private and church schools.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10 -- A decision made by the Supreme Court this week may prove another milestone in the conservation of the country's natural resources and strengthen the concept that man is the trustee of the land for the general welfare.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Asked at his press conference today if he saw any reason growing out of Tuesday's elections why there should be any "modification of the bipartisan attitude on foreign policy," the President replied certainly not; that only Col. Robert R. McCormick and William Randolph Hearst thought so, and they are isolationists.

I read with some amazement the letter from Arthur S. Hodgkiss, executive officer of the Department of Parks, in THE TIMES of NOV. 9. He describes the outdoor recreation spaces available in the Kips Bay area and adds, quite gratuitously, that these playgrounds "exist today only because of Commissioner Moses' interest and were built over most strenuous objections by former Borough President Isaacs."

ALBANY, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Two-tenths of 1 per cent of a worker's wages, contributed jointly by employer and employe, will be made for a six-month period to build a reserve fund for new state disability benefits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Dr. Lee De Forest, pioneer radio inventor, told the Federal Communication Commission today that neither of the two major color television systems was ready for commercial use.
Senator Irving M. Ives expressed fear yesterday that the election of Herbert H. Lehman to the United States Senate would "mark the end of our bipartisan foreign policy."
Herbert M. Woolf's Woolford Farm lost a race it should have won at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday, then took the main event with a 9-to-2 third choice that scored in a romp.

Najeeb Halaby, director of the Office of Foreign Military Affairs of the United States Department of Defense, reported yesterday that the first peacetime munitions production board is functioning now with a permanent staff in London.

An entirely new branch of administrative management in industry was proposed yesterday by a leading management executive. Leroy E. Roark, executive vice president, the National Foundry Association, proposed during the fifty-first annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that this $5,000,000,000 industry install "departments of encouragement" to bulwark general economic development.

HONG KONG, Nov. 10 -- Spokesmen for the thirty-seven Americans employed by the China National Aviation Corporation made it plain at a press conference here tonight that they were prepared to work for the corporation in the Communist areas of China.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 10 -- Solomon R. Guggenheim, philanthropist and mining executive, who died Nov. 3 at his Sands Point, L. I., estate at the age of 88, left $8,000,000 to the foundation bearing his name, according to his will filed for probate here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, petitioned the United States District Court here today to review and audit his stewardship as the neutral trustee of the United Mine Workers' Welfare and Retirement Fund. He also requested that when the review was completed he be released from his $35,000-a-year post.

Describing his election as a victory for those who believe that it is the duty of government to look after the general welfare of the people and not that of a privileged few, Senator-elect Herbert H. Lehman declared yesterday that it would have an influence on the Congressional elections next year, the Presidential election of 1952 and "way beyond that."
New ready-made bedspreads by Craig introduced yesterday at Lord Taylor disprove the idea that special decorator-type fabrics and fine details of workmanship can be found only in custom-order spreads.

Describing his election as a victory for those who believe that it is the duty of government to look after the general welfare of the people and not that of a privileged few, Senator-elect Herbert H. Lehman declared yesterday that it would have an influence on the Congressional elections next year, the Presidential election of 1952 and "way beyond that."
New ready-made bedspreads by Craig introduced yesterday at Lord Taylor disprove the idea that special decorator-type fabrics and fine details of workmanship can be found only in custom-order spreads.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Another request for the release of two United States officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration and a United States merchant ship sailing under a Korean flag that disappeared in waters off Communist-held North Korea has been made to the Soviet Union by the United States, the State Department announced today.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 10 -- Hudson County officials, most of whom were supporters of former Mayor Frank Hague's Democratic leadership until Tuesday's crushing defeat of Mr. Hague's hand-picked candidate for Governor, State Senator Elmer W. Wene, today hailed Mayor John V. Kenny of this city as the new Hudson County Democratic leader.

The play of Bill White at safety on Fordham's defensive platoon won the commendation of Coach Ed Danowski yesterday as the Rams ended work for Boston College with a dummy scrimmage. The squad of thirty-six will leave Grand Central Station at 1 P. M. today for the contest at Braves' Field tomorrow.

Retail prices on department store goods will decline as much as 4 per cent below present levels during the first six months of next year, Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, predicted yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Commerce Department announced today that it had established a "voluntary" program to control the export of technical, but non-secret, data significant to the national security.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- J. A. Krug announced today that he intended to resign as Secretary of the Interior, effective about Dec. 1. Reports that he had contemplated this step have been current here for several days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Government canceled mediation efforts in the soft-coal dispute today when John L. Lewis shunned them, but Cyrus S. Ching, Federal mediation chief, dropped a hint that firmer action would be taken if the miners renewed their strike Dec. 1.

The Federal Government is moving to attach all of the assets of the eleven Communist leaders convicted before Federal Judge Harold R. Medina for conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government, it was disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The British protectorate of Basutoland, in Southeast Africa, today told King George VI that it wants him to keep on protecting it.
PARIS, Friday, Nov. 11 -- A communique issued after the night session of the Foreign Ministers' meeting read:

All the signs indicate that the stage is being set in Poland for a major development in Soviet policy. Following closely on the appointment of a Russian Marshal to the commanding position in the Polish Army and Government comes a report that Premier Stalin himself has intervened to order a drastic speed-up in the collectivization in Polish agriculture.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The first trade negotiations at Cabinet level between France and Western Germany opened today when Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Economics Minister in the Bonn Government, conferred with Maurice Petsche, French Minister of Finance.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Dusky black, dramatic against a snowy scene, is Jacques Heim's choice for ski togs that nevertheless achieve youth and gaiety. With slim black corduroy trousers, various boxy jackets are shown, one of black corduroy with two wide box pleats flowing from under pocket flaps on the chest.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Union is now using atomic energy for peaceful purposes, not to stockpile bombs, but "if, unfortunately, and to our great regret, this were necessary, we should have as many of these as we should need -- no more and no less," Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky told the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today.

Business loans made by banks in this area rose $22,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday but the total outstanding on that day was about $800,000,000 below the peak level of $5,671,00,000 reached on Nov. 10, 1948, it was disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- Since the start of their modern series, Penn has a habit of playing one of its best games of the year against Army, even though it took some bad beatings from the cadet invincibles of the Blanchard-Davis period.
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Madeleine de Rauch devotes her midseason to practical ski togs as well as the picturesque for after-ski life in chalet or hotel.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 10 -- As an old French cannon sounded retreat, the red clay parade ground of Camp Kilmer echoed for the last time today to the measured tread of marching men, the last of 4,000,000 who passed through the station in its seven years of service.

The concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Leopold Stokowski last night in Carnegie Hall had unusual features. The most novel of these was an example of some of the earliest instrumental music of which we knew: one was a "Canzon" of Giovanni Gabrieli, played by three different groups of brass players, echoing or supplementing each other in the antiphonal manner across the spaces of the stage.
